column2: JERUSALEM, May 36 -- There has been no split in the Executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, as indicated by a recent statement of David Ben-Gurion, the chairman, it was said today. Gershon Hirsh, an Agency spokesman, declared that Mr. Ben-Gurion had expressed his own views and not official policy.

It took the Japanese General Staff only two and a half hours to decide to surrender after being assured by their scientists that there was no defense against the atomic bomb, according to testimony by a prominent Japanese physicist before the Atomic Bomb Casualty Commission, appointed by the National Research Council, which recently returned from Japan.

New silver serving accessories, representing the first postwar collection in a New York store to be imported from the noted Swedish firm of Guldsmeds A. B. i Stockholm, known briefly as Gabis, have just been received by Altaian's.
The recently formed JapaneseAmerican Artists, Group has opened its first exhibition in the Riverside Museum at Riverside Drive and 103d Street. It will continue through June 8.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Republican sponsor of the Taft-EllenderWagner long-range housing bill, has undertaken an active campaign to bring about Senat. enactment of the measure before the closing of this Congressiona session.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 26 -- Albania charged today in a complaint to the United Nations that forty-three Greek airplanes attached an Albanian shepherds' camp last week, killing two persons and wounding eight.

CHICAGO, May 26 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 8,000 head; total. 8,500; market fairly active, with most sales 50 to 75 cents higher, but cloning slow with part of advance lost on weights over 260 pounds.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., May 26 -- William K. Evans, 36, a former lieutenant colonel who served in the military government in Japan, was arrested by Federal agents at his home here today on charges of embezzling $100,000 in gold seized by the Army from the Japanese on Formosa.
LONDON, May 26 (Reuters) -- Crowds estimated at 100,000 saw ten first class cricket matches an Britain observed the Whitsun holi day today.

The tanker Mobilube, which was so badly damaged by a Japanese torpedo in February, 1943, that the Navy merely made her hull sea worthy and used her for floating storage space during the war, left Subic Bay in the Philippines yes terday for the West Coast under low by another tanker.

MELBOURNE, May 26 -- Months of painstaking research by a team of Australian scientists had promising results recently when two of them boarded a Liberator plane, flew over a cumulus cloud about 100 miles northwest of Sydney and caused rain to fall from the cloud.

BOSTON. May 26 -- That advertising, in which the United States excels, should be used to the fullest to sell free enterprise and democracy to the American people and the world was urged by speakers today at the annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America here.

Plans for a campaign to raise $2,000,000 next fall were discussed yesterday at the organizational meeting; of the National Campaign Committee of the Hodgkin's Disease Research Foundation at the Metropolitan Club, Fifth Avenue at Sixtieth Street.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 26 -- An almost complete victory for the present regime was recorded today in the Lebanese Parliamentary election results. The Opposition candidates continued to make vehement protests against the manner in which the Government conducted the election, held yesterday.

Criticizing President Truman's recent call upon Congress to enact a national compulsory health insurance plan, Dr. William Crawford White, retiring president of the Medical Society of the County of New York, declared last night the problem must be solved on a voluntary basis.

From the viewpoint of the construction industry, the forces with which the national economy is coping resemble those of the 19201929 period, with a good possibility that the decade ahead will bring expansion similar to that of the Twenties, without a recession at the start like that of 1921, or a "bust" at the finish.
The last pieces of paper worts attending the official death of the Office of Price Administration in New York were being seen to yesterday in the Empire State Building.

BOSTON, May 26 (AP) -- Leading from wire to wire, Mrs. T, Haskos' Windmill defeated Cherry Oca Stable's White Wine by a half length in today's feature at Suffolk Downs. A crowd of 15,962 saw the winner cover the six furlongs in the fast time of 1:11.2. Mort Stuart's Halbarail finished third, three-quarters of a length Dehind White Wine and an equal iistance ahead of Weston Adams' 3ay Moonbeam.

NEW BRAUNFELS, Tex., Ma 26 (UP) -- Stock losses sustained t Dr. Lloyd I. Ross were believe tonight to have been the moti in the slaying' yesterday of an in vestment dealer and three members of his family. Dr. Ross is held as the slayer.

Unless manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers can work together, there will be a depression in this country "the likes of which lisa never been seen," Isidore Immerman, executive secretary of the Associated Men's Wear Retailers of New York, warned last night.

MAXWELL, FIELED, Ala., May 26 -- The Air University -- A unique educational institution, which has a heavy responsibility for American security -- is virtually concluding this week its first academic year. The university, which is commanded by Maj. Gen. Muir S. Fairchild, is charged with the education of Army Air Force officers and it has fulfilled that obligation with distinction in the course given in its component schools the last year.

ASPEN, Col., May 26 -- Opening day, whether it happens to be on the Roaring Fork or the Amawalk Outlet, is different only in the scenic backdrop and the Colorado anglers are no different from their eastern cousins. They are going to fish whether the conditions are good or bad.
Mayor O'Dwyer dramatically ordered yesterday that two relief families with children should be returned to their former homes in hotels, if no other decent living quarters could be found for them.
Shreveport, La., announced yesterday it would receive bids on June 24 on bond issues aggregating $9,600,000. The bonds will be dated July 1, 1947, and will come due July 1 from 1948 to 1967.

Representatives of forty-three storage warehouses and 1,500 union employes met yesterday at the State Mediation Board, 270 Broadway, In an effort to forestall a threatened strike that would cut the city's supply of food.
Fire Insurance Unless steps are taken immediately to awaken the public to the results of carelessness, waste by fire this year will exceed $575,000,000, according to the current Weekly Underwriter.

As three witnesses testified before the New York County Gram Jury yesterday in the pier-lease investigation, Mayor O'Dwyer was named by an official of a sightseeing-boat company as the person who knew most about the events leading up to the inquiry.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The War Department outlined today a plan to organize 2,500 specialized reserve units which in time of emergency would be ready to assume Army missions as experienced teams. The units would comprise 300,000 specialists.

One of the strongest trade barrages laid down in recent years will be directed against the current 20 per cent Federal excise taxes when the House Ways and Means Committee holds hearings on these levies, it was indicated here yesterday.

DETROIT, May 26 -- Blaming the Ford Motor Company for lack of progress in negotiating a new contract, the United Automobile Workers, CIO, today called for a secret strike vote among its 130,000 members at the Ford plants. The call was issued in a letter by Richard T. Leonard, director of the UAW-CIO Ford department to local union presidents and recording secretaries.

Some companies advanced copper and brass prices here yesterday and others, after considering cancellations and price trends, decided to "hold-the-line" on prices, spokesmen revealed. These decisions created a dual price level within the industry, with some copper and brass products reflecting high cost levels of copper based on world prices, and others reflecting lower price levels of domestic copper.

"Up in Central Park" will terminate its run at the New York City Center after Saturday night's performance, thereby gaining for itself the dubious distinction of being the first stage offering in the history of the civic playhouse to cut short an engagement.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Aides of Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. said today that to their knowledge no communication had been received from the grand jury that investigated the election day murder of Joseph R. Scottoriggio, Republican party worker.

To the Congress of the United States: I submit herewith for the consideration of the Congress a bill to be entitled "the Inter-American Military Cooperation Act" authorizing a program of military collaboration with other American states including the training, organization and equipment of the armed forces of those countries.
NANKING, May 26 -- Chinese military leaders here are plainly concerned over recent developments in the campaign against the Communists. Red gains in Manchuria are a particular source of worry.

The Pulitzer Traveling Scholarships, given annually by Columbia University and carrying stipends of $1,500 for a year's study abroad, have been awarded to three students of the university's Graduate School of Journalism, Carl W. Ackerman, dean of the school, announced yesterday.

Secretary of the Navy James Forrestal, speaking last night at a 5100-a-plate dinner of the Democratic State Committee in honor of Mayor O'Dwyer, delivered a strong defense of America's twoparty political system and its system of "democratic capitalism."

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- With party lines drawn the tightest of this session, the Senate rejected by a vote of 48 to 44 today a Democratic motion to postpone further consideration of tax reduction until June 10.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, today asked Congress to put new teeth, into the laws regulating bank holding companies. He recommended full regulation of the concerns to make them conform to laws governing banks and to block expansion programs.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 26 -- The Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America was defended tonight by its president, Charles P. Taft of Cincinnati, as not being Communist merely because it was critical of "the bad working" of some parts of the capitalistic system.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 26 (AP) -- Polynesian returned today to the track where last year he equaled the six-furlong world record of 1:09 1/5 and soundly whipped a hand of sprinters in the 510,000 -- added Atlantic City Inaugural Handicap.
Price movements in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday again were marked by absence of a trend. Closing prices were 11 points off to 2 points higher than Saturday's final levels.

The clinking of coins on the sidewalk at the Sub-Treasury Building steps blended with the blare of the 321st Army Service Force Band yesterday as the New York City Cancer Committee put on a Cancer Tag Day rally in its drive for $1,300,000.

The war veteran's employment status has shown recent improvement, but there are still "certain indertones of warning," the Interlational Association of Public Employment Services was told yesterday by perry Faulkner, chief of the United States Veterans Employment Service.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: At this writing the passage of the bill appropriating $400,000,000 for "aid" to Greece and Turkey is past history. It is not, however, too late to discuss the merits of the broad statement of foreign policy outlined in President Truman's message of March 12.

Light-heavyweight champion Gus Lesnevich suffered two chipped bones in his right hand when he knocked out Melio Bettina in 59 seconds of the first round at Madison Square Garden last Friday night, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

A period of business adjustment or correction is at hand and the turn in trade will be downward, Dr. G. Rowland Collins, dean of the" Graduate School of Business Administration at New York University, said in a talk last night at the annual meeting of the New York Employing Printers Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 26 Describing the food situation in war-devastated Europe as critical, Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, called on the fifty-five member nations today to take constructive steps within less than two months to recommend solutions.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 26 -- In a strongly-worded rebuke to the "war-mongering" press in some countries, J.M. Lomakin, the Russian representative, presented a five-point program today pledging the world press to work for peace and security.
WASHINGTON, May 26-Business expansion halted in April, although activity remained at a high level, the Department of Commerce reported today.

MARGATE, England, May 26 -- The Labor Government won its first test at the forty-sixth annual Labor party conference here today when its peacetime conscription policy was endorsed overwhelmingly. This largest and most important of Labor party conferences opened a five-day meeting this morning.

Since Congreve's "Love for Love" is a notorious classic, one must naturally speak of it with respect. But Mr. Gielgud and his company, who revived it at the Royale last evening, make it seem inferior to Wilde's "The Importance of Being Earnest," which no one is required to treat with respect.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 26 (AP) -- The garages at Indianapolis motor speedway bulged with race cars today, but only three more qualifiers were squeezed out, filling fifteen positions of the 33-car starting line-up for the" 500-mile Memorial Day race.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- William C. Foster, Under-Secretary of Commerce, testified today that while the United States had made available to the world all German industrial secrets it had uncovered, Russia had declined to reciprocate.

Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, wall appear in a tenround non-title bout as a feature of a boxing show in Ebbets Field on July 30, in the interests of the Damon Runyon Memorial Cancer Fund, if plans outlined yesterday are successful.

LONDON, May 26 -- The Soviet Union has abolished the death penalty in peacetime in view of the "exceptional" devotion to the state displayed by the people during the war and because peace can now be regarded as certain for a long time, the Moscow radio announced tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Plans for the formation of an industrial union of telephone workers were made known here today by Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
ST. LOUIS, May 26 (AP) -- Harry (The Cat) Brecheen stopped the Cubs with five hits tonight as the Cardinals took a 3-1 decision from their southpaw nemesis, Johnny Schmitz.

As a first step toward working out "Continental plans" for Europe and Asia, at least in respect to food, the United States proposes calling a world grain conference by mid-July to chart the most effective distribution of world supplies and to improve food management in deficit countries.

MADRID, May 26 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco's trip through the eastern part of Spain has been such a success that he is seriously considering agreeing to a popular referendum, according to a particularly well-informed source.

LONDON, May 27 (U.P.) -- President Truman's program of hemisphere military cooperation was hailed in most British quarters today as extending and making stronger military ties binding the Americas, Britain and Western Europe.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 27 -- The Presbyterian Church in the United States of America has again rejected a proposal to ordain women ministers, it was announced today at the 159th general assembly of the church.

Housing Authority Bonds Of two issues of housing authority bonds offered yesterday, $1,190,000 of refunding bonds of the Austin, Tex., Authority, maturing from 1948 to 1984, were awarded to Shields Co. and associates at an interest cost of 2.137 per cent.

Asserting that New York City will need 1,250,000 dwelling units in the next twenty years, Charles Abrams, former counsel to the New York Housing Authority, called last night for the creation of a master plan for the reclamation of blighted areas.

Mayor O'Dwyer proposes to set up a permanent office of analysis and control, staffed with experts in finance and management -- "top men for the job" -- which would check on and, supervise personnel, clean up finances, separate drones from workers, clear away cobwebs, study possibilities of greater mechanization, seek out places for economy through constant inspection, and make recommendations for reform which the Mayor himself would carry out.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- A squadron of nine Superfortresses will leave the United States next Tuesday on a flight to Germany and England, the Strategic Air Command announced today.
MAXWELL FIELD, Ala., May 26 (Delayed) -- The air university, with headquarters at this great field near Montgomery, is completing the first year of a great educational effort.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 27 -- The Yonkers-Alpine ferryboat John J. Walsh, with forty passengers aboard as spectators, filled the emergency role of a fireboat tonight when the 27-foot cabin cruiser Pal went ablaze almost in midstream in the Hudson River off the Ludlow Marine Basin docks here.
DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., May 27 -- A gallery of comic art was installed at the Children's Village here today by newspaper cartoonists of the nation while the 400 unadjusted boys of the school cheered.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 27 Atomic units providing direct heat for larger buildings and hot steam for houses were a "real and early possibility" in cities, Dr. Arthur H. Compton said tonight in the twentieth Steinmetz Memorial Lecture.
The Federal Public Housing Authority is winding up this week its $101,395,000 temporary housing program for this five-state region.

The only person in the world who wants an American depression is "Joe Stalin, master of the Kremlin and chief medicine man of those who hanker after total power," Earl Bunting, president of the National Association of Manufacturers and head of the O'Sullivan Rubber Corporation, said last night.

CRANFORD, N.J., May 27 -- Samuel Houston Baker of 230 Denman Road, this place, supervising architect for James Gamble Rogers, New York architect, who designed the Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital in New York and the Sterling Library and other buildings at Yale University, died today in his home, after a long illness, at the age of 72.

BERLIN, May 27 -- An official report of the Russian military administration asserted today that "rations in the Soviet zone are steady and the population receives all the food it is entitled to according to ration cards."

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Herbert Hoover, who, though out of office, is functioning smoothly these days as an architect of major international policy, expressed a viewpoint in his letter to Representative John Taber of New York that is becoming at least semiofficial in Washington.

Mrs. Tessie Earle, mother of Willie Earle, the young Negro who was lynched in Greenville, S.C., will bring civil suit for $250,000 damages against the twenty-eight defendants acquitted of the murder, her counsel said last night.

DETROIT, May 27 (AP) -- Combining the hitting of George Kell with the hurling of Al Benton and Hal Newhouser, the Tigers beat the Indians, 4 to 2, in the rain today, handing Bob Feller his fourth defeat against five victories.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Benjamin Lacayo Sacasa has been designated Provisional President of Nicaragua by the Congress, pending the calling of new elections, the State Department was informed in a telephone conversation today by Maurice M. Bernbaum, the American Charge d'Affaires in Managua.

Contrasting the lag in domestic ship construction to the boom in foreign shipyards, Eugene G. Grace, chairman of the board of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation predicted yesterday that only repair business will remain for our yards unless the Government finds it possible to provide some form of adequate protection for American shipbuilding.
MADRID, May 27 -- A plenary session of the Cortes may be called in the first few days of June to approve the Law of Succession, Esteban Bilbao, President of the Cortes, informed the press today.
BOSTON, May 27 (AP) -- On his fourth try, Johnny Sain gained his fourth victory of the season for the Boston Braves with a 7-3 decision over the Phillies tonight before 21,676.

GRANDVIEW, Mo., May 27 -- For the first time since he reached here May 17, President Truman seemed to be genuinely heartened over his mother's condition tonight. He looked confident and relieved after another day spent at his mother's home.

Employe training is "good business," I. Dent Jenkins, general personnel manager, Harrison radiator division, General Motors Corporation, declared yesterday in describing the peacetime General Motors training program. He spoke during the conference on training and education in industry at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, jointly sponsored by the Society for the Advancement of Management, New York chapter, and the City College of New York, School of Business.

A turbulent business session yesterday ended the three-day convention of the New York State Optometric Association when resolutions were introduced to "clean up" the profession in the state by outlawing the use of large illuminated advertising signs and the use of merchandise displays.

The Veterans Guidance in Advertising and Selling organization, which has found jobs for 2,526 veterans, will close June 1, it was annuonced yesterday by Allan T. Preyer, found Two groups, however, will continue to aid veterans. They are the Job Finding Forum of the Advertising Club of New York and the Man Marketing Clinic of the Sales Executives Club of New York.
LONDON, May 27 -- The stock markets here today made a cheerful start after the Whitsun holiday although the turnover was well below the average.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., May 27 -- The last was first when the shooting ended over the West and Center nines of the Ridgewood Country Club course today. Mrs. Philip Cudone of The Knoll, the last starter of 104 players, won first prize, in the second one-day Women's Metropolitan Golf Association tourney.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 -- A stop order revoking a registration statement filed by the Globe Aircraft Corporation of Fort Worth, Tex., was recommended today by a hearing officer of the Securities and Exchange Commission on the ground that the registration included "untrue statements of material facts and omitted required material facts."

William H. Davis, who recently resigned from the Board of Transportation following rejection of his plan for employe representation, predicted yesterday that the board would never have "good relations" with its thousands of workers until it decided to deal with them "in the positive sense."

MARGATE, England, May 27 -- Prime Minister Attlee denied this morning that Great Britain was subservient to the United States. He made that statement as he moved the parliamentary report at the Labor party's forty-sixth annual conference here.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 (AP) -- Glen Russell's first home run of the season with two mates aboard enabled the Boston Red Sox to snap a four-game losing streak and stop the Philadelphia Athletics' run of floodlight victories at seven tonight with a 4-2 triumph before 23,843.
The American Institute of Graphic Arts presented last night its Institute Medal to Elmer Adler for his distinguished service to graphic arts in this country.

The Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, yesterday opened negotiations with the Committee for the Steamship Companies and Agents on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, for a new agreement to become effective June 15. The MEBA is the second of three CIO maritime unions scheduled to hold wage talks here.

What Youth Did Class day is at hand in the colleges and the commencement speakers may already be thinking about their seasonal message to youth. If the orators go back to the oldest styles in such matters, they will venture to offer youth a bit of counsel, though humbly and with emphasis on the fact that it is for youth to shape the future world.

In a strong plea for work pledged "to render a dollar's worth of service for a dollar fairly paid," Cardinal Spellman told the New York Building Congress yesterday that he would expend $25,000,000 for construction within the Archdiocese of New York.

CINCINNATI, May 27 -- Dr. Coleman L. Maze, Professor of Management at New York University, tonight was awarded the 1947 Leffingwell Medal for outstanding contributions to the field of management at the twentyeighth annual conference of the National Office Management Association here.

MEXICO CITY, May 27 -- The Nicaragua issue is virtually certain to come up at the Rio de Janeiro conference, and the United States will associate itself with any joint action censuring former President Anastasio Somoza, according to the best diplomatic sources today.
Great masses of the American people are still illiterate, particularly in the political field, Dr. Harry J. Carman, president of the New York Adult Education Council, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- By a vote of fifty-one to twentynine the Senate rejected today a proposal to permit husbands and wives in all states to halve their combined income for Federal tax purposes and thus take advantage of Tower rates.

Stadium Concerts, Inc., announced seven additional soloists yesterday and the first four programs to be played by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium, where it will open its thirtieth season on June 16.
IMLAY CITY, Mich., May 27 (AP) -- A farm boy of 16, described by his father as a "problem child," was accused today of slaying four young playmates because "I just wanted to see someone die."

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- House conferees on the labor bills have informally agreed to drop their prohibition against industry-wide collective bargaining, Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., chief of the House group, said today.
The $100-a-plate dinner at the Hotel Commodore Monday night yielded more than $100,000 for the Democratic State Committee, but it left some ruffled feelings in its wake, it was learned yesterday.

Two New York steeel brokers who were cited in testimony last week before the Senate Committee investigating the "gray market" in sheet steel, notified THE NEW YORK TIMES by telephone yesterday that they would appear today before the committee in Washington, D.C., to reply to statements made by other witnesses last week.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Looking nearly a year ahead, Wisconsin supporters of Harold E. Stassen for the Presidency will meet in their state next month to make formal plans to enter a full slate pledged to him in the state's Republican delegate primary.
NANKING, May 27 -- Starvation is creeping again into the famine corridor of southern Hunan and northern Kwangsi, where last year tens of thousands died of hunger.

JERUSALEM, May 27 -- Terrorists, probably members of the Stern group, made three attacks on railway lines in the Lydda and Haifa areas today. The station at Ramleh was wrecked and the line damaged at two other points. [According to The Associated Press, a freight train was derailed.]

LANDSBERG, Germany, May 27 (AP) -- Twenty-two guards and foremen at the Germans' Mauthausen concentration camp died on blackcurtained gallows here today in the yard of the prison where Adolf Hitler wrote "Mein Kampf." Twenty -seven more, including an Austrian Gauleiter, are to be hanged by American soldiers tomorrow.

BERLIN, May 27 (AP) -- An American official said today that Russia and the United States could not agree on a definition of an occupation force and thus could not yet deal with the problem of reduction, as ordered by the Council of Foreign Ministers.

The stock market suffered another sinking spell yesterday with limited offerings of issues of key industrials, but a substantial recovery was made in the late trading. Losses of up to 3 points in pivotal shares were reduced to fractions and in some cases turned into gains, while the composite rate showed a fall of 0.10 on the day.

With Memorial Day this year on Friday, railroads, bus and air lines are preparing to handle exceptionally heavy holiday traffic over the week-end. Thousands will be leaving the city for vacation resorts and additional thousands are expected to come into New York City.

CALCUTTA, India, May 27 (Reuters) -- A peace appeal "leaflet raid" on Calcutta and a broadcast by Sir Frederick Burrows, Governor of Bengal, were part of a general effort by responsible leaders today to end civil strife in India.

A resolution supporting Mayor O'Dwyer and Welfare Commissioner Edward E. Rhatigan in their stand against current "luxury living" relief charges was adopted unanimously yesterday at the first annual conference of the Brooklyn Jewish Child Care Council at the Hotel Bossert.

The installation, of two compact clothes closets on the third floor of Hammacher Schlemmer Co., Inc., 145 East Fifty-seventh Street, marks the opening of the store's new closet planning service. Suggestions and blueprints, as well as the actual execution of designs, will be provided by Kim Hoffmann and Stephen Heidrich, the interior designers who planned the models.

MONTREAL, May 27 -- The International Civil Aviation Organization's first assembly swiftly completed action on its long agenda today and adjourned in a burst of goodwill. Arthur S. Drakeford, the Australian president of the assembly, and American and other delegates joined in praising its achievements.

HOBOKEN, N.J., May 27 -- Sweeping changes in the Hoboken Police Department are directed in a special departmental order issued this afternoon by newly elected City Commissioner George J. Fitzpatrick, Director of Public Safety, who for two years spearheaded the fight of the so-called rebel policemen who were at odds with the administration of former Mayor Bernard McFeely.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Early speed carried the Yankees to a 4-0 lead over the Senators tonight at Griffith Stadium, but the New Yorkers were slowed to a walk after the third inning and came to grief in the end. Counting two runs, the second unearned, in the eighth inning, Washington subjected the Yankees to a 5-4 setback that shattered a five-game winning streak.

Pricing the New Bonds The pricing of new bond issues is no longer one of the lesser headaches of post-war financial markets. Competitive bidding, after having been shown up in the last fortnight as an inadequate means for bringing about the sale of a series of blocks of public-utility company stock, has been unable since to pilot certain bond issues through the present market.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 27 -- State Senator Robert E. Johnson, Staten Island Republican, announced today that he had asked Governor ewey to call a special session of e Legislature to authorize a cad legislative investigation of e New York City administration.
Governor Dewey urged yesterday that the United States do everything in its power to bring a "just" solution of the Palestine problem in the United Nations.
SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., May 27 -- The housing crisis was brought sharply to the attention of the National Savings and Loan League here today at its fourth annual convention.
BUDAPEST, May 2 -- The process of shifting Hungary from her former status as a dependency of German economic imperialism to Soviet domination of her foreign trade is about completed.

CINCINNATI, May 27 (AP) -- Lanky Ewell Blackwell gave only four hits today as Cincinnati romped to a 6-1 triumph, but the Pirates got three blows with two out in the ninth to spoil the big righthander's bid for his second shut-out of the season.

With an international campaign to raise $15,000,000 for American schools in the Near East barely under way, Albert W. Staub, director of the Near East College Association, announced yesterday that $2,000,000 in special gifts had been received.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Benjamin Fine, education editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, urged at a hearing before a House education subcommittee today that Federal aid for public schools be immediately doubled to $5,000,000,- a jump to 3 per cent of the national income.

PASSAIC, N.J., May 27 -- Seven hundred and fifty persons gathered in the recreation hall of Botany Mills, Inc., tonight to attend the first graduation exercises of the joint labor management school, which presented diplomas to 381 foremen and shop stewards.

Early examples of panorama scenic wallpapers went on exhibition yesterday at the studio of Nano McClelland, Inc., 15 East Fiftyseventh Street, to mark that twenty-fifth anniversary of the decorating firm. Included in the display is "Savages of the Pacific," a picture paper depicting the discoveries of Captain Cook.
C. Bedell Monro. president of the Pennsylvania-Central Airlines Corporation, reported yesterday that his line had moved "into the

Declaring that "sin and cynicism" were the reasons for the absence of peace in the world today, Cardinal Spellman yesterday afternoon spoke at the commencement exercises of the Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart, 133d Street and Convent Avenue, at which he conferred bachelor degrees on 108 members of the graduating class.

ASPEN, Col., May 27 -- Colorado lived up to its fishing reputation today, as far as we were concerned, but as we write this, our aching muscles loudly proclaim that the horse is an outmoded form of transportation.

An agreement providing a $9 across-the-board increase for 1,500 employes of forty-three cold and dry storage warehouses was reached yesterday, averting a strike that had threatened to tie up part of the city's food supply.

LEVIDI, Greece, May 26 (Delayed) -- This typical Arcadian village, terraced on a mountain slope and made up of gray stone hovels clustered around a church and a square, was attacked Saturday evening by a guerrilla band. The fighting lasted three hours.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Continuing its study of the bill to unify the armed forces, the Senate Armed Services Committee rephrased today the section dealing with the Navy to define Navy and Marine Corps scope and functions in greater detail.
Cotton prices moved over a comparatively narrow range on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and closed 5 points lower to 5 points higher.
Players of odds-on favorites didn't have even a soupcon of fun at Belmont Park yesterday.

CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, May 27 (AP) -- America's powerful challenge for the British amateur golf championship gained impetus today as five of Uncle Sam's Walker Cup stars swept through secondround matches. Only one, Smiley Quick, fell by the wayside, beaten by a teammate.

GARMISCH - PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, May 27 -- The testimony of Jewish witnesses counted heavily today in averting the conviction of the two principals in the cast of the world famous Passion Play of Oberammergau as active Nazis.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 27 (AP) -- Almost half the starting positions for the 500-mile Memorial Day race at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway were still vacant tonight after a morning rainstorm and mechanical bugs had permitted only two more cars to qualify today.

BOSTON, May 27 -- The establishment of a Harvard branch of American Youth for Democracy, which has been accused of being a Communist "front" organization, has been approved, Harvard College announced today.

A New York landmark for yearin and year-out presentation of spectacular ice shows at low prices, the Center Theatre reopens its doors tonight with "Icetime of 1948," the eighth offering since Sonja Henie and Arthur M. Wirtz introduced the series there back in 1940.

Over the strenuous protests of counsel for Elmer R. Haslett, suspended City Airports Director, Mayor O'Dwyer upheld yesterday the postponement of a hearing on departmental charges against Mr. Haslett until June 10.

THE big hose race for the Belmont Stakes on Saturday bears a remarkable resemblance to the National League pennant chase in one respect. For weeks on end the fans have been waiting for both Phalanx and the St. Louis Cardinals to come charging up to victory. But neither favorite has been able to do very much to date and each has proved a grievous disappointment.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- Reported extremely high prices for grain in other countries, with Canadian flour export quotations, stimulated late buying of all grains today, resulting in a recovery from a sharp early drop, with all futures strong at the close.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 27 -- A grievance committee of United Nations employes has taken under advisement Secretary General Trygve Lie's veto of the selection of Saleh Mahmoud and William Epstein as members of the secretariat that will accompany the Committee of Inquiry to Palestine, it was learned today.

One of the most significant features of the current wage-price controversy is the "strangely fearful and distrustful attitude toward business profits that seems to underlie and pervade much of the discussion," the Guaranty Trust Company of New York says in its monthly review of business and financial conditions, issued yesterday.

Last autumn Vincent J. Schaefer, a General Electric engineer, went up in an airplane and sowed pellets of dry ice (solid carbon dioxide) in a cloud. Nobel prize winner Dr. Irving Langmuir, stationed on the ground, saw snow fall -- not much, but enough to verify a theory that without nuclei of some kind droplets will not freeze into snow or precipitate themselves as rain.

BALTIMORE, May 27 (U.P.) -- Prospective purchasers of new automobiles could find cheer today in a court ruling that new cars must be dealt out according to dealers' waiting lists -- no more juggling and playing favorites.

Forty-three youngsters, many of them professional entertainers and others the children of theatrical people, were graduated yesterday from the Professional Children's School. The exercises, at the New York City Center Theatre, 131 West Fifty-fifth Street, were attended by 300 persons.
PHILADELPHIA, May 27 -- The fifty-first Devon horse show and country fair opened today with horses owned by Mr. and Mrs. Ralph T. King of Gates Mills, Ohio, winning two of the first four events.

Welfare Commissioner Edward E. Rhatigan made public yesterday a letter from the State Department of Social Welfare which he contended showed its approval of his policy of housing relief cases in hotels because of the acute housing emergency.

The National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters announced yesterday a general revision of the rates for miscellaneous bodily injury and property damage liability insurance and extensive changes in underwriting rules and classifications, effective on next Monday, and applicable in all states except Texas.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The House leadership was moving cautiously today in acceptance of responsibility for further investigation into the fatal beating of Joseph Scottoriggio, Republican election worker in the Eighteeth New York Congressional District last November.

Liebmann Breweries, Inc., brewers of Rheingold Extra Dry Beer, announced yesterday the purchase of the John Eichler Brewing Company of New York. Acquisition of the new company brings total capacity of Liebmann Breweries up to an estimated 2,500,000 barrels a year, about equal to the production of Ruppert's Breweries, but still below Schaefer F. M. Breweries, largest company in the metropolitan area.

Dr. Ernst P. Boas, chairman of the Physicians Forum, and Michael M. Davis of the Committee for the Nation's Health endorsed yesterday the Wagner-Murray-Dingell bill for a national compulsory health insurance plan.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 21: Decreases of $121,000,000 in loans and $344,000,000 in demand deposits credited to domestic banks, and an increase of $320,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted.
Boxing returns to Ebbets Field and the outdoor season gets under way in earnest tonight with the heavyweight show featuring the meeting between Tami Mauriello and Jimmy Carollo of Corona.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- President Truman asked Congress in a special message today to create a new housing and home finance agency to coordinate and supervise present Government housing activities. These now are temporarily consolidated under the National Housing Agency, which expires with the First War Powers Act.

LONDON, May 27 -- Reports that non-Jewish mercenaries are being recruited among Europe's displaced persons to swell the terrorist forces in Palestine are under investigation in British official quarters, it was learned authoritatively today.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Howard C. Petersen, Assistant Secretary of War, left for Germany by plane today to inquire into the food shortage situation and the conditions of unrest that have developed from it.

Picnics which are as much a part of Memorial Day as the parades, will be like old times this year. There'll be plenty for everybody; hamburgers, frankfurters, olives and the rest of the fare that's customary for such occasions.
VIENNA, May 27 -- Today's meeting of the four-power Austrian treaty commission found that body still getting nowhere.

THERE is enough energy, curiosity, judgment, fair-mindedness and literary skill in John Gunther to equip a dozen reporters of more than ordinary ability. With inexhaustible industry, astounding ambition, patience and enthusiasm he has added volume after volume to his 'Inside" series, until his collected works are little less than a political guide to the mid-twentieth century.

In December, 1942, in a small clearing on Guadalcanal, the Solomons, several hundred United States Marines were gathered informally around a tall, gaunt-faced, cropped-haired man of 46, listening to him speak. The speaker was Lieut. Col. (later Brig. Gen.) Evans F. Carlson.

Culminating six months of discussions, the New York Cotton Exchange made yesterday several important revisions in its margin and other trading rules in an effort to tighten speculative dealings in cotton futures. The new regulations will become effective on Monday.

MARGATE, England, May 27 -- Capital from all sources, not excluding the United States, will be required in the development of the great territories under British control, Colonial Secretary Arthur Creech Jones told this correspondent today.

Inquiries for rayon fabrics in the last ten days indicate a strengthening of the market which was believed due for a price break, according to piece goods distributors yesterday. Woven filament goods is in strong demand, it was learned, and in plied yarn fabrics it was predicted there will be a further tightening of the present squeeze.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- The text of President Truman's message to Congress proposing the creation of a new housing agency follows: To the Congress of the United States: I am transmitting herewith Reorganization Plan No. 3 of 1947, prepared in accordance with the Reorganization Act of 1945.

The busy ABC network, which locally means WJZ, will introduce several new shows in the next few weeks. Beginning June 26, Edward Arnold, the film star, will play in "Mr. President," a series dramatizing little-known incidents in the lives of American Presidents.

A bronze plaque commemorating the courage and devotion to duty of 5,000 officers and men who served in vessels of the United States Lines during World War II has been placed by the company at its Chelsea Piers and will be dedicated today at 11 A.M.

Nearly 500,000 young people who will leave school next month in search of jobs constitute a special challenge to placement agencies, Robert C. Goodwin, director of the United States Employment Service, declared yesterday at the thirty-fourth annual convention of the International Association of Public Employment Services.

The contributions made to democracy by scouting through its training of future citizens was acknowledged officially yesterday by President Truman, Governor Dewey and Mayor O'Dwyer in messages read at the opening session of the thirty-seventh annual meeting of the National Council, Boy Scouts of America.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Charges of coercion and discrimination alleged by Georgia against twelve Northern and eight Southern railroads were denied today by the Northern group in arguments before a special master hearing evidence in Georgia's fight for lower freight rates.

Buyers' Total Lower Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,489, against 1,624 last week and 1,232 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower called on the citizenry of the United States last night to take leadership in reinforcing development of international cooperation and arbitration as a barrier against war.
Senator Harley M. Kilgore of West Virginia urged the United States last night to provide leadership in bringing "beacons of hope" to a distraught world.

DAMASCUS, Syria, May 27 -- Syrian and Lebanese Ministers will meet Saturday at Shtaura, the half-way house of the twin states of the Levant, and it is "most probable" that they will reach final agreement on a division of the revenues from great United States oil pipeline that may run through these countries from Saudi Arabia, Syrian Premier Jamil Mardam Bey stated today.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Congress will at last have film screening rooms, under the Reorganization Act, if it first authorizes and then appropriates for the $84,000remodeling of House and Senate caucus rooms recommended by David Lynn, architect of the Capitol.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- Production of candy last year declined to the lowest level since 1940 while the manufacturers' sales value soared to the highest mark attained by the industry, George F. Dudik, of the foodstuffs division of the Department of Commerce, revealed today in an address before the opening session of the National Confectioners Association annual meeting.

Fall openings of medium price dresses in the New York market brought an excellent response, according to a survey yesterday. Volume houses which have begun booking orders predicted business equal to or greater than that of a year ago.

The Russian Government announces that it has abolished the death penalty in times of peace. By decree of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet, crimes hitherto punished by death will henceforth be punished by a term of twenty-five years in the "corrective labor camps."

So many young American singers have applied to sing at the Vienna Opera that Erich Leinsdorf, conductor, announced yesterday he would hold at least three more preliminary auditions in order to hear them all. Twenty-five will be heard at 3 o'clock this afternoon at the New York City Center and forty will be heard there tomorrow morning.

JERUSALEM, May 27 -- Reliable Zionist quarters scouted tonight suggestions that non-Jewish Poles or Yugoslavs had infiltrated the refugee ships. These quarters insisted that the Jewish refugees would quietly recognize any "aliens" among them and would not tolerate their presence.

A new first mortgage loan of $1,500,000 at 3 1/2 per cent interest for fifteen years has been placed with the Prudential Insurance Company through Samuel Kronsky, Inc., on the thirty-one-story office building at 21-23 West Street.
PARIS, May 27 -- Russia launched two bitter attacks on the French Government today and the Foreign Ministry spent a good part of the day replying.

A few hours after Councilman Michael Quill, head of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, warned yesterday afternoon of a possible tieup of the city's transit lines through strict interpretation of a sixty-year-old book of 400 archaic working rules, an almost imperceptible slowdown began during the rush hour on the IND division.

JACKSON, N.C., May 27 -- A white man has confessed to the Federal Bureau of Investigation that he attempted to lynch Godwin Bush, 24, Negro, and named seven accomplices, Solicitor Ernest R. Tyler announced tonight after J. Edgar Hoover, head of the FBI, made the same announcement in Washington.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Representatives of auto dealers, retailers and labor unions asked Congress today to end restrictions on installment-plan buying.

PRETORIA, South Africa, May 27 -- Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, South Africa's Premier, said today in the Senate that a revival of Britain as a leading power would be "a safer guarantee of peace in the world than the United Nations."

Former Prince Carl Johann Bernadotte, nephew of King Gustav of Sweden, brought suit in Supreme Court yesterday to have his two-year lease on an $8,000-ayear duplex apartment at 36 West Fifty-third Street, declared void because his landlord had not "equipped it in a manner consistent with his tastes or social standing."

CHICAGO, May 27 -- Federal District Judge Michael L. Igoe, accused in his own court last Friday of seeking control of the reorganized Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad, was ordered today to explain in person to the Circuit Court of Appeals why he has insisted on appointing a majority of the board of reorganization managers for the road.

The Cunard White Star liner Mauretania with a capacity list of 1,163 passengers docked at Pier 90, North River, yesterday after a fiveand-one-half-day crossing from Liverpool. The 35,677-ton vessel brought a cosmopolitan group of business men, Government officials, musicians and authors.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 27 -- "Head Over Heels," previously labaled "A Cool Million," will go before the cameras at Warner Brothers on Monday, with Robert Hutton and Joyce Reynolds in the leading role, the studio announced today.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 27 (AP) -- Tzaritsa made a walkaway of the fifth and featured race, the $3,500 Oceanic Purse for 3-yearolds, at the Atlantic City race track today.

"The arts, in the broadest interpretation, constitute the social hope for all mankind," Irwin Edman, Professor of Philosophy at Columbia University, said yesterday at the first session of the thirtyseventh annual convention of the American Federation of Arts.

PARIS, Wednesday, May 28 -- The leaders of France's 85,000 gas and electrical workers called off early today the strike demonstration scheduled for today and the Government rescinded its decree mobilizing the workers.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Herbert Hoover's proposal to counter Russian obstruction tactics with separate negotiations for peace with Japan and Germany struck a stridently responsive chord in Congress today.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- Disclosure that the General Motors Corporation had developed changes which would improve the gasoline engine's efficiency "possibly 33 1/3 per cent" was made here today by Charles F. Kettering, GM vice president, inventor and research expert.

Stainless steel powder has arrived at a commercial position along with copper-lead, and brass metal powders, and welding with stainless steel powder is about twice as fast as older methods, John D. Dale, president, Charles Hardy, Inc., metal powder makers, declared yesterday.

Mario Denaro, 69-year-old book-keeper for James V. Auditore, Brooklyn stevedore boss, was released in $2,500 bail last night after being detained as a material witness for the New York County grand jury in its pier-lease investigation.

In a letter published on this page today William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, returns to the attack on the pending labor relations bills, repeating his earlier assertion that they represent "slave legislation." The head of the AFL sees them as a threat to the freedom of labor, and he likens the situation to a legislative attack on the freedom of the press.

NANKING, May 27 An invitation from the People's Political Council, meeting here, to the Communists, went off by radio broadcast today. The Communist members of the Council were asked to attend the Council sessions and discuss terminating the civil war.

Full-scale production and the influence of competition will correct whatever distortions exist in the price levels of manufactured goods now, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the General Motors Corporation, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Wilmington, Del.

Home from their triumphant tour of the west, the Giants came an inelegant cropper at the Polo Grounds last night and it scarcely should take anyone more than half a second to name the culprit who stuck his foot out.

Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., had a net loss of $5,723,523 in the first quarter of this year, according to the report issued yesterday to stockholders. The net loss for the first three months of 1946 was $1,341,805 after income tax credits.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 21 -- J.M. Lomakin, Soviet representative, lost a stubborn all-day parliamentary battle today to include the "struggle against fascism" as a specific obligation of the world press.

A program for national maritime improvement, specifically excluding Federal financial aid for port improvement as unnecessary and undesirable, was proposed here yesterday by Walter P. Hedden, director of port development of the Port of New York Authority.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In an editorial which you published in the issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 18, you expressed the opinion that I was suffering from a nightmare, only dreaming, when I classified the Hartley and Taft anti-labor bills as slave legislation destructive of individual freedom.

ST. LOUIS, May 27 (AP) -- The Cubs moved into the National League lead tonight when they banged fourteen hits against five hurlers to hand the Cardinals their first night defeat of the season, 10 to 3. Bib Chipman gave eleven scattered hits to St. Louis.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The United States has completed payment into the capital fund of the world bank of its cash share of $635,000,000, it was shown today in the Treasury Department's daily statement. The last "call" completing this subscription required that $158,750,000 be paid to the bank no later than yesterday.

Fifty-seven physically incapacitated persons who have demonstrated proficiency in overcoming their handicaps were graduated yesterday from the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled at 400 First Avenue.

BERLIN, May 21 -- The United States is blocking German currency reform in a complex situation born solely of distrust of the Russians. Out of a welter of rumor, accusation and counter-charge that emerges as an actuality. It serves to postpone to the indefinite future any fundamental change in the chaotic German currency situation.

BOSTON, May 27 -- Constructive "hard-hitting" advertising is necessary to prevent a depression, Dr. Charles M. Edwards Jr., dean of the School of Retailing of New York University, warned the fortythird annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America here today.

The leading article in The London Economist of May 24 cites as an example of our "relative concern for the external and internal aspects of America's anti-Communist crusade" the action of Congress in giving the FBI all the funds requested for tracking down Communists at home and on the same day throwing out the appropriation for the "Voice of America" broadcasts abroad.

The leading article in The London Economist of May 24 cites as an example of our "relative concern for the external and internal aspects of America's anti-Communist crusade" the action of Congress in giving the FBI all the funds requested for tracking down Communists at home and on the same day throwing out the appropriation for the "Voice of America" broadcasts abroad.

ROME, May 27 -- A crisis witnin the Italian Cabinet crisis was precipitated today by unfavorable reports reaching Rome concerning the progress of the economic mission at present in the United States headed by Deputy Ivan Matteo Lombardo.

CLEVELAND, May 27 (AP) -- An Episcopal minister from Massachusetts and his two brothers today ignored union pickets in strikebound Lake View Cemetery and dug a grave for burial of their mother despite an alleged threat from one of the pickets that "the grave will be dug up again."

CHICAGO, May 28 (U.P.) -- A team of Chicago Golden Glovers tonight scored a 7-to-1 victory over a European team in the international amateur boxing competition before a capacity crowd of 21,000 at Chicago Stadium.

PARIS, May 28 -- The Foreign Office issued a formal statement today to deny that when in Paris recently, United States Secretary of State Marshall "intervened with the President of the Republic in favor of [Marshal HenriPhilippe] Henri Philippe Petain."

The State Liquor Authority's proposal to implement its power of making fair trade practices mandatory will tend to "freeze" prices rather than regulate them, liquor men said yesterday. The tentative proposals which were presented to a liquor industry council composed of all the major liquor associations provide that contracts will be mandatory on all products with the exception of private brands.
MADRID, May 28 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco, addressing a mass meeting of workers on the outskirts of Barcelona today, presented his case for what he termed the "social justice" of his regime.

The Commissioner of Welfare is suing a nurse for return of public assistance funds given over a twelve-year period to a woman who, the city declares, is the defenddant's mother, it was learned yesterday. Publicity when the nurse was named a legatee under a retired stock-broker's will started the action.
BOSTON, May 28 (AP) -- Scoring two runs in the first inning after two were out, the Phillies tonight went on to defeat the Boston Braves, 4 -- 2, before 20,377 fans.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Senator James P. Kem, Republican, of Missouri, told the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee that Attorney General Clark's order last year for an FBI investigation of the alleged election irregularities in Kansas City was "restrictive."
TRENTON, N.J., May 28 -- New Jersey restrictions on summer employment of children under 18 years old are being emphasized this week in bulletins to schools from the State Labor Department.

STANTON, Del., May 28 (AP) -- Something new in the way of jumping races will be offered tomorrow when Delaware Park opens a thirty-day meeting with the $10,000 Tom Roby Steeplechase Stakes as the feature attraction.
TOKYO, May 28 -- Tempers blazed high today at the meeting of the Allied Council for Japan when the Soviet member challenged the occupation's figures on the state of Japanese public health.

TRENTON, N.J., May 28 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll expressed hope today that the proposed convention to rewrite the New Jersey constitution would confine itself to basic principles. Operating detail, he said, could be left for later Legislative action.
CHICAGO, May 28 (U.P.) -- A snowstorm swept into the Middle West from Canada today, and temperatures tumbled to record seasonal lows.

For the third successive week the nation's production of crude oil has exceeded 5,000,000 barrels daily. Average daily output last week was at a new record of 5,024,850 barrels, an increase of 16,800 over the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

PARIS, May 28 -- The Ramadier Cabinet gained a political victory by the cancellation of the gas and electric strike that was to have taken place today, but that victory was won at the cost of probable concessions that raised doubts as to the effectiveness of the wage freezing policy.

CLIFTON, N.J., May 28 -- The indefinite lay-off of 6,000 workers at its Clifton and East Newark plants was announced today by the Federal Telephone and Radio Corporation, which attributed its move to union-inspired slowdowns and general interference with production.

After two months of hearings and two weeks of closed meetings, the Armed Services Committee of the Senate now seems reasonably sure of reporting this week the Unification Bill that would set up a National Security Establishment in place of the present two independent military departments.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Former Representative Andrew J. May's son Robert said today that he held a war contract for 60,000 shell boxes with a Garsson munitions firm.

Small Banks Get Call Supplementing its heavy call on the B banks earlier this week, the United States Treasury announced yesterday that the A banks would be required to provide 50 per cent of the War Loan Deposit Accounts, as of the close of business on April 30, payable on June 4.
The Cities Service Company announced yesterday that the remaining $40,578,100 of its outstanding 5 per cent debentures due in 1950 will be redeemed at 102 per cent, plus interest, on July 28.

Stockholders of the Wheeling Lake Brie Railway Company, at their meeting held in Cleveland yesterday, elected John W. Davin, James M. Nicely, Rupert T. Zickl and William H. Wenneman as directors to serve three-year terms. Mr. Davin, who is president of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad, was elected chairman of the Wheeling Lake Erie, filling the office for the first time since the death of
For the consolation of New Yorkers who have thrown their arms out of joint trying to flag occupied taxicabs, the Police Hack License Bureau announced a new regulation yesterday.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 28 -- The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America ended its 159th meeting today with the adoption of resolutions condemning compulsory military training in peacetime and asserting the United Nations to be the rightful instrument for reconciliation of differences between this country and the Soviet Union.

Gen. Brehon Somervell warned last night that a "final" world war is a "probability" because of the atomic bomb and the "probable" combination of aggressors against us, unless we adopt an adequate advance plan of industrial mobilization immediately.
PHILADELPHIA, May 28 (AP) -- The Red Sox, flashing again the power that carried them to the American League championship last year, blasted the Athletics, 9 -- 2, today before 3,433 spectators.

In the tug-of-war that has been going on among Mayor O'Dwyer, the Board of Transportation and the Transport Workers Union, with occasional outbreaks of internecine dispute within the Board itself, none of the parties seems to us to be entirely without fault.

MUNICH, May 28 -- The most uproarious session of the Bavarian Landtag [state assembly] to date was held here today. It grew out of the order issued a week ago by Brig. Gen. Walter J. Muller, United States Military Governor of Bavaria, for dissolution of the "control service" set up by Denazification Minister Alfred Loritz in civilian internment camps.

LANDSBBRG, Germany, May 28 (AP) -- Twenty-six more guards and torturers of the Nazis' Mauthausen concentration camp -- some making sardonic speeches about American justice -- died on twin gallows here today as United States Army hangmen completed the biggest Allied mass execution of convicted war criminals.

JERUSALEM, May 28 -- The British Colonial Office has asked the Jewish Agency for Palestine what steps are being taken to reconstitute the Jewish Agency Executive in accordance with its constitution. A final reply to the inquiry is now being awaited.

BUFFALO, May 28 -- The belief that more women should hold policy-making posts in Government and business will be translated into action when the annual convention of the Business and Professional Women's Clubs of New York State, Inc., officially opens here tomorrow.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- Japan was kept in the dark about the fate of its fantastic balloon bombs because Americans proved during the war they could keep their mouths shut. To their silence is credited the failure of the enemy's campaign.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Even among the loyal members of the President's inner circle there is agreement that his action on the bill to curb the excesses of organized labor involves the most important political decision he will be required to make in his current term.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The basic economic problem that confronted the major Allies in Europe at the end of the war and is now preoccupying Secretary of State Marshall and his policy planning committee, can be defined as follows:

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 28 -- After twenty-four hours of a Cabinet crisis, the Lebanese Government today announced the final results of Sunday's Parliamentary elections, which still are being roundly denounced as fraudulent by a number of substantial citizens.

Tami Mauriello did the expected in his scheduled ten-round fight with Jimmy Carollo of Corona at Ebbets Field last night. The veteran heavyweight from the Bronx scored a knockout in 2:58 of the fifth round, when Referee Ruby Goldstein stopped matters to protect a reeling Carollo.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- The Monsanto Chemical Company, which has operated the atomic energy project at Oak Ridge, Tenn., for the last two years, will terminate its contract with the Atomic Energy Commission.

The United Fruit Company is planning to use the Chiriqui and Talamanca, presently in the final stages of reconversion, on a twelve-day cruise service out of New Orleans to Cristobal, C.Z., and Puerto Barrios, Guatemala, it was announced yesterday.

ASPEN, Col., May 28 -- The famous Frying Pan was still rather high today and not even a local enthusiast would call it "gin clear," but opening day having come and gone, it was almost barren of anglers and was productive of some nice trout.

PARIS, May 28 -- In a preliminary committee report distributed to the Assembly yesterday, Charles Barange, rapporteur, declared that delays in voting the 1947 budget, which now goes to the Parliament for its final discussion, would imply considerable delays for the budget for 1948.

Leading men's clothing concerns have sold up their production through November or December, it was learned here yesterday. The market position of worsteds for fall continues strong and has not been affected to any appreciable extent by weakness in woolen suits.

The Tudor City Fifth Unit, Inc., has obtained a first mortgage loan of $525,000 at 4 per cent interest for ten years on the ten-story apartment building at 321 East Forty-third Street. The loan was made by the Union Square Savings Bank through Louis M. Rogovin, broker.

Contributions totaling $3,402,616 have been received in the first four weeks of the Greater New York Fund's, tenth annual drive, it was announced yesterday by Frederick M. Warburg, chairman of the campaign.

Congress was asked yesterday by the Municipal Finance Officers to disapprove contemplated budgetary cuts which the association said, would require the Civil Aeronautics Authority to discontinue operating control towers at municipal airports.

JACKSON, N.C., May 28 (U.P.) -- Hostility to "outside interference" grew in Northampton County today as seven white men charged with kidnapping a Negro from jail went free under $2,500 bond. In Rich Square, where the men live, residents made no secret of resentment at the arrests.

BALTIMORE, May 28 (AP) -- Labor troubles were blamed today by Sosthemes Behn, chairman and president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, for loss of $10,865,155 in 1946 by a subsidiary, the Federal Telephone and Radio Corporation.
The tendency of committing courts to regard institutions for juvenile delinquents as "dumping grounds" was deplored yesterday ay Robert Cooper, executive director of the Wiltwyck School for Boys.

The first post-war shipment of toys, records and playground equipment for the Moore Memorial Church Nursery School and Kindergarten at 316 Tibet Road, Shanghai, China, was inspected yesterday at headquarters of the China Aid Council, 1790 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Reporting to the Interstate Commerce Commission that the Federal District Court in St. Louis had agreed on May 20 to a dismissal of bankruptcy reorganization proceedings of the St. Louis Southwestern (Cotton Belt), that rail road today asked the ICC for authority to refund secured notes, paying a part of them, at a sharply reduced rate of interest.

Three men, one of them seriously wounded, were taken into custody late last night after a chase up Fifth Avenue to Central Park that followed the hold-up of five bars on the East Side, in which $400 was stolen within fifty minutes.

PITTSBURGH, May 28 (AP) -- The Pirates put on another thrill-aminute finish tonight as they staged a three-run rally in the ninth to beat the Cubs, 7 to 6, and topple the Chicagoans from the league lead.
Four graduates of New York University received medallion awards last night for distinguished service to the university. The awards were presented at a dinner at the Faculty Club.

Some means must be found to eliminate irresponsible merchants in the textile export business, William C. Planz, vice president of the Textile Export Association of the United States, asserted yesterday. It would be unfortunate for reputable exporters if the Government was compelled to take remedial steps to satisfy complaints of foreign importers which appear to be increasing, Mr. Planz pointed out.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The International Emergency Food Council today voted, 10 to 1, that the crisis in bread rations was such as to necessitate calling a special cereals conference in Europe before the third week in July.

CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, May 28 (AP) -- For a "non-playing" captain, 54-year-old Francis Ouimet of Boston did all right today as he led six of his American Walker Cup stalwarts into the fourth round of the British amateur championship over the sun-baked Carnoustie links.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 28 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie has asked members of the United Nations for statements of the relief supplies they are prepared to give to the war-devastated countries.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 28 -- Karl Rex Hammers of Syria Temple, Pittsburgh, was elected today Imperial Potentate of the Shrines of North America, the highest office on this continent of the Ancient Arabic Order, Nobles of the Mystic Shrine.

A vigorous denial that any relief families had been supported in luxury by this city was made last night by Welfare Commissioner Edward E. Rhatigan. He said only the "cheapest side-street hostelries" had been used to shelter persons who otherwise would have had to sleep in the streets.

The first store in New York to devote an entire floor to the wardrobe needs of the junior girl is Lord Taylor, where the sixth floor is now completely given over to the young New Yorker aged 7 to 15. In the smart, newly decorated setting she can outfit herself from head to toe.

CHICAGO, May 28 (AP) -- Today's report or the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 5,000 head, total 7.500; market slow early, later moderately active, 25 to 50 cents higher; most advance on weights over 250 pounds, with some big weights fully 50

AMSTERDAM, May 28 (Aneta) -- The Stock Exchange Association today announced modification of its trading hours effective June 2. The modification advances the trading period ten minutes, the market being open from 1:20 to 2:30 P.M. (8:20 to 9:30 A.M. E.D.T.), instead of from 1:30 to 2:40.
PHILADELPHIA, May 28 -- Two companies filed registration statements today with the Securities and Exchange Commission, while two others applied for permission to withdraw statements.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 -- Control of electric, gas and transportation properties under a single management serves the best interests of residents of New Jersey, the Board of Public Utility Commissioners of New Jersey advised the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., May. 28 -- The achievement record of pupils in the Scarsdale public schools has been "very satisfactory," Dr. Vernon G. Smith, superintendent of schools, said this afternoon in disagreeing with some findings and recommendations of the education and school budget committee of the Town Club.

NEW DELHI, India, May 28 (Reuters) -- Countrywide fears that June 2 -- when Indian leaders hear the British Government's plan for transferring power to them -- may herald unprecedented bloodshed were referred to today by Mohandas K. Gandhi and other leaders.

Rapid recovery of the apparel and textile industries in Holland makes it possible for her to build the largest European export business in these fields, it was pointed out yesterday by Henri Kattenburg, spokesman for the group of Netherlands fabric and apparel exhibitors in the forthcoming International Exposition of Textiles.

TOKYO, May 28 -- Former Premier Shigeru Yoshida again today denounced the Japanese Socialist party as a group "accepting communism" and thus apparently definitely ended the attempts to form a four-party coalition Government under Socialist Premier Tetsu Katayama.

NANKING, May 28 -- The proGovernment majority in the Peoples Political Council virtually took charge of an incipient "peace movement" in the Council session today. All opposed concessions to the Communists and many demanded a Government suppression order against the Reds and a war to the finish.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts announced yesterday that it will receive bids on June 10 on issues of bonds totaling $26,000,000 and consisting of $25,000,000 veterans' services fund bonds due May 15 from 1950 to 1956, and $1,000,000 of metropolitan sewerage bonds due from 1947 to 1966.
Rytina, at close to 23 to 1, was the surprise package in the $20,000 added Top Flight Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. And Ted Atkinson once again was the young man who delivered the goods.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 28 (U.P.)--Former President Gen. Anastasio Somoza was appointed today as Minister of War, Navy and Aviation and Commander in Chief of the National Guard by Provisional President Benjamin Lacayo Sacasa.

Housewives doing the marketing that usually must precede a holiday, especially when it comes so near a week-end as tomorrow's fortunately does, will find supplies and prices of perishable foods today not too different from those of last week.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Benedetto Miccoli and a fellow IRT employe, John Portone, had an unwelcome automobile ride through isolated sections near Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. When the ride was over, two armed thugs had taken $700 but Miccoli had occasion to rejoice.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Government is undertaking a broadscale study of so-called fair trade laws throughout the country in its latest effort to bring about a general lowering of prices to consumers, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- A House Un-American Activities Subcommittee asserted today, in a report on its recent inquiry in Hollywood, that "some of the most flagrant Communist propaganda films were produced as a result of White House pressure."
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Builders of year-round houses will not need a Federal construction permit after May 31, the Government ruled today.

Shadowy cool black in fashions for restaurant dining provided the theme for Russeks Fifth Avenue's showing yesterday at Chatham Walk. Combining the work of American and French designers, this store included originals from the houses of Piquet, Christian Dior, Gres and Balenciaga in the collection.

Whether the Aluminum Company of America still has a monopoly of the aluminum ingot market will be argued at hearings to be conducted before Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey, which probably will start some time next month.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 28 -- The Rhode Island Senate, controlled by Republicans, passed by a voice vote this evening a compromise omnibus tax bill, including a 1 per cent sales tax, which the House, controlled by Democrats, had passed earlier.

HOUSTON, Texas, May 28 -- A Federal court decision setting a possible precedent in litigation involving an estimated $35,000,000 to $50,000,000 worth of foreign vessels seized by the United States before the outbreak of the last war was handed down here today.

A nonprofit gallery is being opened by the Artists League of America for its members at the organization's headquarters, 77 Fifth Avenue. An exhibition of paintings, drawings and prints by war veterans will open this evening at 8 o'clock with a preview and a forum led by Joe Solman.

In the last two days forty-eight condemned Nazis under American guard have mounted the gallows in Landsberg prison yard and plunged to eternity. No men in history ever did more to earn the noose. Under their administration of the Mauthausen concentration camp 700,000 victims were foully murdered.

Hot weather having come round they are naturally putting on another ice show at the Center Theatre, where "Icetime of 1948" opened last evening. This routine has been going on since 1940 with practically no interruptions and many of the same skaters gliding swiftly around the stage.

A dinner in honor of Miss Lila Van Der Smissen, retiring curator of Columbia's School of Architecture, was given last night at the annual meeting of the Arehitectural Alumni Association of Columbia University held at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 28 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, acknowledge today that he had excluded a Moslem and a Jew from the staff that will be attached to the Palestine Inquiry Committee, but he said that this policy applied only to the key positions.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- A Congressional investigation of Government publicity and alleged "propaganda" activities began today with accusations from Congress members, and denials from Federal officials that public funds are being spent to promote socialized medicine.

GROTON, Conn., May 28 (U.P) -- The Rev. Nicholas Shepler, his wife and their 16-year-old daughter, Evelyn, were attacked at their home here early today and are in a hospital at New London with only an even chance to live. They were beaten over the head with a fifteen-pound furnace shaker.

ROME, May 28 -- The charge by Sumner Welles, former United States Under-Secretary of State, that the Italian Communist party was financed by Moscow received some measure of confirmation today from an open letter addressed to the leader of the left-wing Socialists, former Foreign Minister Pietro Nenni, by the president of the Italo-American Labor Council, Luigi Antonini of New York.

DETROIT, May 28 -- The Ford Motor Company offered its 108,000 production workers today an increase equivalent to 15 cents an hour, and the offer was promptly rejected by the United Automobile Workers-CIO.
The Bendix Aviation Corporation had net earnings of $2,888,433 in the six months ended with last March, Malcolm P. Ferguson, president, reported to stockholders yesterday.

Export advertisers should give more careful attention to the South African market, where ample dollar exchange is available and there is great demand for sound American merchandise, Paul R.
