Kruming, president, National Export Advertising Service, told members of the Export Advertising Association, Inc., at a luncheon meeting at the Belmont Plaza Hotel yesterday.

BOSTON, May 28 -- Radio advertising was criticized and the need for truly constructive, better coordinated advertising not only to increase sales thus preventing depression, but to better the prestige of the profession, were emphasized by speakers as the forty-third annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America came to a close here today.

The near-record field of 1,318 golfers seeking places in the fortyseventh National Open championship at St. Louis next month will compete in sectional qualifying rounds at twenty-six locations next Monday, the United States Golf Association announced yesterday through The Associated Press.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- All grains advanced rapidly today on the Board of Trade with buying stimulated by continued unfavorable weather, strong cash markets and reports of big foreign requirements, short-covering followed active commission absorption.

Breakfast in New York at a normal hour lunch in Miami shortly after noon, then dinner at the usual time back in New York became a reality yesterday for commercial airline passengers when Eastern Air lines set a going-andcoming speed record for flight between the two cities.
A marked improvement in sentiment in the cotton market lifted cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday to net gains of 25 to 37 points.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 28 (AP) -- Twenty-eight cars, five fewer than a full field, had qualified by tonight for the thirty-first annual 500-mile Memorial Day race at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway Friday and eleven of the starters earned their positions in a last-day rush that had seven cars on the track at once just before the qualifications ended at 7 P.M. (Eastern Standard Time).

The best upturn of the year in stocks took place yesterday, with prices bid up as much as 3 points. Given the advantage of only meager offering's, which were absorbed quickly and the covering of short commitments as a prelude to the long week-end, a wide variety of issues responded readily to the slightest demand.
LONDON, May 28 -- With buyers holding off during the last stages of the three-week account, the stock markets here today generally were dull.
KANSAS CITY, May 28 -- Evidence on which a state grand jury returned eighty-one vote fraud indictments was stolen today.

A number of persons active in social causes, among them, individuals whose good opinion we value, have been critical of the newspapers of New York City for their news stories and editorials about the housing of relief families in hotel suites. We print one such letter of comment on this page today.

OTTAWA, May 28 -- No firm contract has yet been agreed upon between Canada and Argentina for the purchase by the former of the second installment of 9,000 tons of edible oil under a special arrangement by which Canada would make an equivalent tonnage of newsprint available to Argentina.
ROME, May 28 -- The first attempt since the liberation to govern Italy without the Left Wing parties is about to be made by Premier Alcide de Gasperi.

Adherence to the principles of he Scout Oath and law -- to love God and country and respect the Rights of the individual -- was advocated yesterday by civic and religious leaders at the closing ceremonies of the thirty-seventh annual meeting of the National Council of Boy Scouts of America.

MARGATE, England, May 28 -- The National Executive of the Labor party announced with obvious embarrassment today that it endorsed with certain reservations its recent statement on foreign policy, entitled "Cards on the Table."

License Commissioner Benjamin Fielding announced yesterday that he had ordered an investigation into the practice of some used car dealers and unlicensed "curbstone operators" of buying new cars through "unscrupulous high priority methods" and reselling them at advanced prices as used cars.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 -- The Cumberland Allegheny Gas Company and the Binghamton Gas Works, each supported by their joint parent, the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, today asked the Securities and Exchange Commission, in separate applications, for permission to undertake transactions designed to provide funds for construction.

LONDON, May 28 -- Viscount Mountbatten, the Viceroy of India, will leave London tomorrow morning charged with making a last ditch effort to persuade Indian leaders in New Delhi on Monday to accept Britain's suggestion of last year for a united independent India.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee, delving into complex and frequently contradictory accounts of a $50,000,000 "gray market" steel transaction, heard testimony today that a key letter involved in it was forged.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 28 -- Twenty thousand more displaced persons are expected in Belgium from the United States zones in Germany and Austria within the next two months, it was officially stated here today. They will take up work in the coal mines.

JERUSALEM, May 28 -- Terrorists struck at the Haifa oil dock area today, causing damage to the water main, the outer wall and a metal shed. Apparently they mistook two water ballast tanks for oil reservoirs and tried to blow them up, as they did the Shell Oil tank farm near this spot more than a month ago.

Large scale cancellations of unfilled orders for builder's hardware by jobbers and distributors, reported here by manufacturers yesterday, have created a healthier condition of remaining orders, members of the industry disclosed. Jobbers had inflated orders as much as 500 per cent, manufacturers said, to obtain shipments from as many sources as possible because some allotments had been held to as little as 10 per cent of quantities ordered, due to scarcities of materials.

With their mightiest offensive of the campaign, a bristling nineteenhit attack that had the Flatbush contingent in a crowd of 28,260 howling with glee, the Dodgers all but blasted the Giants clear out of their Polo Grounds yesterday as they bagged their second triumph of the current three-game series, 14 to 2.

Howard Lindsay and Dorothy Stickney, who will appear in "Life With Father" for the evening of June 14 to commemorate the show's passing the 3,182-performance record established for plays by "Tobacco Road," have agreed to remain for an addition two weeks, Oscar Serlin's office announced yesterday.

SECURITY COUNCIL Working Committee of Committee 1 of Atomic Energy Commission -- Representatives of United States, Britain and Canada told Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet delegate, that they could not ever agree to use of veto on atomic affairs.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Referring to the thirty-seven unfortunate families who were temporarily housed in hotels by the Welfare Department, THE NEW YORK TIMES in its editorial of May 27 reports that "this backlog of accumulated cases was rehoused in less than a week."
VIENNA, May 28 -- The Vienna Treaty Commission again drew a blank at today's meeting, its ninth.

Stores Here Open Saturday Most department stores and many specialty shops will be open on Saturday, following Memorial Day, it was learned here yesterday. Lord Taylor and B. Altman Co. will be closed, as they begin their summer Saturday closings on that day.

AN event of considerable significance in turf circles will take place today when Delaware Park, one of the prettiest and one of the most progressive tracks in the country, will formally open. Delaware is a non-profit organization that tries -- and usually succeeds -- in staying at least one step ahead of the rest of the parade.

SINGAPORE, May 28 -- The Singapore Government announced today a crackdown on the illegal importation of American goods into this colony. Singapore so strictly regulates United States dollar exchange that American products are scarcer here than in perhaps any other great port of the Far East.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Wage contracts for 400,000 bituminous coal miners are unlikely before mid-June or even later, according to opinions expressed here today. This view is based on the strong desire of coal operators to see the outcome of current action by Congress on proposed labor legislation.

PARIS, May 28 -- Dr. Gustave Roussy, rector of the University of Paris, former dean of the Paris Medical School and a scientist of international fame who founded the French Cancer Institute, was suspended without pay today and ordered tried for administrative disciplinary action.

For the better part of a week an interesting discussion has been taking place at Lake Success in the U.N. Subcommission on Freedom of Information and the Press. The very heart of the question of "freedom of information" is obviously the elimination of the censorships which now destroy such freedom.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, asserted today that a questionnaire being circulated on behalf of the Congressional joint committee on the economic report had been "carefully designed to produce a preconceived result."
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall today approved the $500,000,000 St. Lawrence Seaway project as an essential step toward tightening the continent's defenses.

ALBANY, May 28 (AP) -- The claim of Robert R. Young, chairman of the board of directors of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, to a seat on the New York Central Railroad's board of directors was upheld today by Gustav Metzman, president of the latter, in the face of a stockholders' challenge.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- T.E. Braniff, president of Braniff Airways, Inc., told Senators today that consolidation of American international airlines into a single company would not be successful and would eventually end "in Government ownership."

ANTWERP, Belgium, May 28 -- A new destiny is being worked out for this great port to meet the changed face of Europe. If any ray of light is to be found in the future, it lies far west in the United States and far east in Europe, according to experts.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- The General Motors train of tomorrow, four cars, Diesel-drawn, was unveiled here today. C.E. Wilson, president of General Motors Corporation, described it as a research project designed to enhance the service of railroads to the public.

Under-Secretary of Labor Keen Johnson, sounding a note of "economic urgency," told 700 Federal and state job placement officials and unemployment compensation workers yesterday that their contribution toward economic stability "must be even greater in the months ahead."

The American sponsors of a SovietAmerican chess match that was to have been held in New York next September announced yesterday that they were calling the whole thing off because they were tired, of the Russians "stalling."

DEVON, Pa., May 28 -- The Dodge Stables of Rochester, Mich., Won the Sunnywood Farm Challenge Trophy for ladies' harness ponies at the Devon Horse Show land Country Fair tonight when Glenavon Filmstar swept to victory over a highly competitive field.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 28 -- A record group of fifty-nine players teed off over the windswept Cherry Valley course in the second one-day tournament of the Long Island Women's Golf Association here today.

The Fordham baseball team came through with some timely hitting yesterday to hand Manhattan a 5-2 defeat at Fordham Field. The victory, which gave Fordham undisputed possession of fourth place in the Metropolitan Conference, was the fourth straight for the Maroon.

A new musical program featuring Peggy Lee, Johnny Johnston and Buddy Clark is announced for 9 P.M. Wednesdays on CBS, beginning June 11. This is the time now being filled by Frank Sinatra, who is being dropped by the sponsor after next week.

ST. LOUIS, May 28 (AP) -- Enos Slaughter's home run with two men on in the seventh gave the St. Louis Cardinals a 4-to-2 victory over the seventh-place Cincinnati Reds tonight, putting St. Louis just a half game below the Reds. A double by Terry Moore in the third brought in Red Schoendienst for the other Redbird run.

KENNETH ROBERTS discovered Moreau de St. Mery's "American Journey: 17931798"* when he was writing "Lydia Bailey." He got his wife to help him by translating this curiosity struck Frenchman's account of his adventures and discoveries in the very young America of one and a half centuries ago. Others lent their hands to the enterprise.

Underwriters headed by The First Boston Corporation will offer to investors today an aggregate of $75,000,000 of debentures of the New England Electric System, a Massachusetts merger of the six intermediate companies of the New England Power Association's system.

Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, announced yesterday that he would turn over to Mayor O'Dwyer at 2:15 P.M. today releases from all airline and oil companies with whom the city signed contracts in 1945 for space and other privileges at Idlewild Airport in Queens.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Senate passed the Tax Reduction Bill today, 52 to 34.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Spokesmen for both Houses of Congress approved today a compromise labor bill sharply reducing the power of unions accumulated through the New Deal years and everywhere following the basic approach of the measure, which the Senate passed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 28 -- John Ford announced today that he will go to Ireland in the summer of 1948 to produce and direct a film there based on "The Quiet Man," a short story by Maurice Walsh, with Maureen O'Hara, Victor McLaglen and John Wayne in the leading roles.

A 12-year-old Greek-American boy, red-headed George Pappas of 403 West Thirty-eighth Street, received yesterday the nineteenth annual George Lane Nichols Award for good sportsmanship. The award was made by the Children's Aid Society at the West Side Boys Club, 419 West Thirty-eighth Street, by J. Edward Obey, director.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Early House action on the Mundt Bill authorizing the State Department to continue its Voice of America broadcasts as part of a foreign information and education program was assured today by a split vote of the Rules Committee.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Batted out in his last two starts, Don Johnson, with a splendid relief chore, helped the Yankees gain a 9-5 victory over the Senators tonight. Blanking Washington in his 5-inning emergency role, Johnson, the third New York hurler, did not receive credit for the victory -- that went to Randy Gumpert -- but the 20-year-old right-hander regained starting status.

BERLIN, May 28 -- High officials of the United States Military Government were unanimous today in the conclusion that Herbert Hoover's suggestion of a separate peace with Germany had not been seriously intended. They were equally unanimous in the belief that the consequences of such a step would be disastrous.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- The Coast Guard reported today that an investigation of the Texas City disaster on April 16 showed ignorance and violations of safety regulations governing the handling of "dangerous" cargoes.

The Rev. Dr. Oscar Fisher Blackwelder, pastor of the Lutheran Church of the Reformation, Washington, is to replace the Rev. Dr. Paul Scherer as preacher on this year's Sunday Vespers programs of the American Broadcasting Company, it was reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 28 (AP) -- Federal Judge John P. Barnes today signed a final order approving merger of the Gulf, Mobile Ohio Railroad with the Alton Route into a 3,000mile North-South trunk line between Chicago and the Gulf of Mexico.

Glancing Through the Paper For the reason probably that the misprint comes pretty close home we find ourselves thinking what a wonderful typographical error that was which spoke of Henry A. Wallace as "the stormy petrol" of the Democratic party.

From London, Lord Mountbatten is taking back to India a new plan for restoring order and, if possible, unity in that divided land before the British begin withdrawing their forces a year from now. It may prove a forlorn hope, for storm signals are flying over the whole subcontinent.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The United States and the Netherlands, made a final settlement of war accounts today through agreements signed by the Secretary of State, George C. Marshall, and Dr. Alexander Loudon, Ambassador of the Netherlands.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 28 -- The United States, Britain and Canada gave the Soviet Union new notice today that they could never agree to place international control of atomic energy under the veto of the United Nations Security Council.

The port of New York dispatched more than 1,400 convoys during the war and handled more than half of the men and supplies sent abroad during the conflict, Frederick G. Reinicke, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, declared yesterday.
John E. Wade, who will retire as New York Superintendent of Schools in August, may be retained in the city's public school system in an advisory capacity, it became Known yesterday.

An extensive exhibit of students' work, ranging from sculpture to package designs, opened yesterday at the Cooper Union Art School, Cooper Square. Each gallery on the sixth floor is filled with different types of work to indicate the courses that future architects, designers and artists are required to take.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- A bill to establish a civil government for Guam and to grant United States citizenship to its people was submitted today to a subcommittee of the House Public Lands Committee with the endorsement of the Secretaries of State, War, Navy and Interior.
MARGATE, England, May 28 -- Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer, put the Labor Government solemnly on record today as opposed to another loan from the United States.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, Thursday, May 29 (AP) -- An Army courtmartial today sentenced Col. Edward J. Murray to ten years in prison at hard labor and dismissed him from the Army for misappropriating diamonds while he was custodian of the Bank of Japan vaults.

Officially registering its protest against the State Department's cancellation of the exhibition of modern American paintings abroad, the American Federation of Arts adopted yesterday a resolution endorsing the Government's objectives in initiating a program to further understanding of American art in foreign countries.
GENEVA, May 28 (U.P.) -- The United States introduced a proposal aimed at guarding capital investment in under-developed countries at the World Trade Conference today.

BERLIN, May 28 -- Most German boys and girls in the United States zone have not taken part in the American-sponsored youth activities program. More than half of them have never even heard about it. Most of those who do participate do so to get candy and food.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Sherwood Dodge Shankland of this city, who retired last September as executive secretary of the American Association of School Administrators, died in George Washington Hospital last night. He was born in Willoughby, Ohio, seventy-three years ago.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- Confectionery manufacturers were informed today that a buyer's market was developing in some essential candy ingredients and that sugar allocations probably would be increased soon. At the same time, the industry was warned that it must prepare for reduced profit margins and be alert to rapidly changing market conditions.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The House, after two turbulent days of partisan contest, passed by a vote of 315 to 38 tonight an appropriation bill carrying $848,101,976 to run the Department of Agriculture through the coming fiscal year. It was still $340,469,342 short of Administration estimates, as the Budget Bureau had asked for $1,188,571,318.

The Christian Church is about to enter upon an important epoch with "a new and more realistic approach" to the problems of life, declared the Right Rev. John William Charles Wand, Lord Bishop of London, in an address at commencement exercises yesterday morning at the General Theological Seminary, 175 Ninth Avenue.

William Hunt Diederich, Tappan sculptor who sent anti-Semitic literature through the mails in the name of the National Institute of Arts and Letters, Was formally expelled from that 49-year-old organization at a membership meeting yesterday afternoon.

As members of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, continued yesterday their slowdown of service on the IND division of the city subway system, Mayor O'Dwyer put further pressure on the Board of Transportation to force that body to make its labor relations policies conform to his own.

DAMASCUS, Syria May 28 -- In a peaceful, cool room in one of the newer houses in the oldest inhabited city in the world, Fawzi elKawukji talked of war today -- the renewal of the Arab fight for Palestine in which he was a field commander in 1936.
Thirty-one thousand persons will march in Manhattan's Memorial Day parade tomorrow. The last G.A.R. marcher died in 1944, so 200 Spanish-American War veterans will be up in the van.

The New York County grand jury that has been investigating pier leasing irregularities is sheduled to complete the first phase of its inquiry today. District Attorney Frank S. Hogan is expected to ask it to return at least two indictments.

NEWTON CENTER, Mass., May 28 -- With sixteen of the country's best professionals on hand, including America's top trio, Ben Hogan, P.G.A. champion; Jimmy Demaret, winner of the Masters and leading money-winner to date, and Lloyd Mangrum, open champion, the stage is all set for tomorrow's start of the $10,000 Goodall round-robin tournament, now one of the outstanding fixtures of the golf year.

GRANDVIEW, Mo., May 28 -- With his mother considered definitely out of danger, President Truman decided late today to fly back to Washington tomorrow. He made the announcement after spending the day at Mrs. Martha E. Truman's home here, as he had passed every day since he flew to her side on May 17.

MUNICH, Germany, May 28 -- Fulfilling his promise to protest to the Military Government of the merged British and American zones against what he termed the Allies' plundering of German forest reserves, Dr. Josef Baumgartrier, Bavarian Food and Agriculture Minister, brought the topic before the Legislature today and obtained its endorsement for an appeal to the Council of States.
PARIS, May 29 -- The labor struggle seemed to move into a new phase today and major strikes grew less likely.

LOS ANGELES, May 29 -- A mysterious warming of the climate is slowly manifesting itself in the Arctic, engendering a "serious international problem," Dr. Hans Ahlmann, noted Swedish geophysicist, said today.

After pleading not guilty to a seventeen-count information accusing him of charging dock workers usurious rates for loans ranging from $5 to $50, Christopher O'Connor, 35 years old, of 300 West Seventeenth Street, was held yesterday in $2,500 bail by Special Sessions Justice Matthew J. Troy.

DEVON, Pa., May 29 -- Chamorro, faultlessly ridden by his owner, Morton W. Smith of Middleburg, Va., tonight won the final and feature event on the third day's program of the fifty-first annual Devon horse show and county fair.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The United States and Denmark soon will undertake negotiations on the future status of Greenland.

The first building in each of the three new housing developments or the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company is ready for occupancy, and successful applicants for the 414 apartments thus available are being notified that they may sign leases and move in soon.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 890,605 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 2,397 cars, or 0.3 per cent more than for the preceding week, 319,132 cars, or 55.8 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 7,852 cars, or 0.9 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

The reported move by Government agencies to make a broad scale study of fair trade laws throughout the country was held unjustified and based on "hysteria" by Nicholas Gesoalde, executive secretary of the New York State Pharmaceutical Association.

Howard S. Cullman, chairman or the Port of New York Authority, proposed yesterday that the name of Idlewild Airport in Queens be changed to New York City Airport, as a move to give the city added prestige as a center of airborne traffic.

MADRID, Spain, May 29 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco, nearing the end of his East Coast speaking tour, heard words today from a Catholic Bishop, which although diplomatically put, needed very little study to appear as criticism rather than the adulation the Chief of State has been getting.

WASHINGTON, May 29--The Senate voted, 48-26, today to approve rent increases of 15 per cent where tenants and landlords entered contracts voluntarily and in good faith. A similar authorization was adopted by the House on May 1.

For a life-term inmate at Dannemora Prison this Memorial Day marks the end of a six-year search on his behalf by a New York City policeman and a former Brooklyn assistant district attorney. They believe he is innocent of the murder for which he was convicted.

Business in the nation's security and commodity exchanges will come to a halt today in observance of Memorial Day. The suspension of trading, for most of the markets, marks the start of a threeday holiday. Normal activities will be resumed on Monday.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- Attorneys for senior bondholders of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad today carried into the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals their fight to prevent District Judge Michael L. Igoe from appointing a majority of the road's reorganization managers.

Mel Ott sent his Hondo Hotshot, Clint Hartung, to the Polo Ground mound yesterday. The fabulous young man more than justified the confidence reposed in him by pitching and batting the Giants bad into first place.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Although outward developments in the simultaneous coal wage conferences today gave no clue as to a possible early agreement the policy committee of the United Mine Workers was asked to remain "on call" for possible developments.

MOSCOW, May 29 (AP) -- Pravda published today a vitriolic attack on Gen. Mark W. Clark, containing one of the sharpest references yet made to American advocates of a "firm policy" toward Russia. Pravda said the task of such policy -seekers was to "hamstring peace and provoke war."

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 29 (AP) -- George (Barney) Poole, one of the best forward pass receivers in college football for three years, today was dismissed from the United States Military Academy for failing in his studies.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The following is an analysis of the composite Labor Control Bill agreed upon, 7 to 3, today by the Senate and House conferees: Declaration of policy -- Prescribes "the legitimate rights of both employes and employers;" finds that the practices of "some labor organizations," as well as of some employers, have led to unrest.
Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., in its report for the first three months of this year issued to stockholders yesterday by J.J. Russell, president, showed a net income of $2,507,776 after taxes and

A list of the crew and passengers of the United Airlines DC-4 that crashed last night follows: CREW Captain Benton Baldwin, pilot, 31-32 Eighty-third Street, Jackson Heights, Queens. R. B. Sands, co-pilot, 30-01 213th Street, Bayside, Queens.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29 -- With New York University an overwhelming favorite to end on three-year reign of Navy as team champion, a record field of more than 700 athletes from forty-four colleges will open competition tomorrow in the sevent-first annual outdoor track and field championships of the Intercollegiate A.A. A.A.

WASHINGTON, May 29--President Truman returned today to the White House and a desk piled high with work. On arrival, he directed that no appointments be made for Friday and Saturday so that he could have a chance to catch up.

Trade Here Good in Week Retail trade here has been active this week, with warmer weather spurring seasonal and Memorial Day purchasing. Department store sales, it was estimated, are running at a rate approximately 15 per cent over the like week of last year when coal and transportation labor troubles had some adverse effect on trade.

TRIPOLITZA, Greece, May 29 -- The Athens Government has been urged by leaders in this area to resort to more severe methods in dealing with the Leftist guerrilla bands. At several public meetings citizens of this Arcadian provincial center, representing various unions, civic groups and societies of merchants and professional men, have made known that in their view any implementation of the amnesty law might cause security conditions to deteriorate further.
MARGATE, England, May 29 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin drove his steamroller over rebel opposition to his foreign policies today with ease and complete success.

BERLIN, May 29 -- The Allied Control Council has had only partial success in carrying out edicts of the Big Four Foreign Ministers on agreements reached at the Moscow conference, it was learned today.
LONDON, May 29 -- Russia is reported seeking a credit here of u55,000,000 (about $220,000,000) for the purchase of British powergenerating and transportation equipment and other capital goods.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Lower prices for foods were largely responsible for a decline of 0.1 per cent in average primary market prices during the week ended May 24, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, Department of Labor.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was very much interested in Judge Leach's letter about the proposed revision of the Army's archaic courtmartial system.

DETROIT, May 29 (AP) --Charles (Red) Embree, determined little Cleveland right-hander, turned the tables on the Detroit Tigers today with a four-hit pitching performance that was worth a 4-to-1 triumph. Twice this season the Tigers had beaten him by shutout scores.

TOKYO, May 29 -- Japan's three leading dailies, Asahi, Mainichi and Yomiuri, have started a campaign for reform of the bureaucracy. All three, which have a combined circulation almost half the national total, declare that Japan cannot have a democracy without getting rid of entrenched bureaucrats.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 29 -- In a surprise decision, the Motor Speedway management today reopened the entry list for the 500-mile race tomorrow to allow additional qualifying tests early this evening. The list officially had been declared closed last night with twenty-eight contestants, but a field of thirty now is possible.

No matter how busy the Theatre Guild may be, it's always on the alert for good scripts. And when one does come along, the organization springs into action. Newly acquired is "Member of the Wedding," converted into a play by Carson McCullers and Greer Johnson from the former's novel of the same name published last year.

Tattered Civil War battle flags brought back from Appomatox eighty-two years ago will be the only reminder in Memorial Day parades here today of the hundreds of thousands who went out from New York City to fight in the Union Army.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 29 -- Well-informed Greek sources reported today that preparations were under way here for the creation of a Turco-Greek organization to foster relations between the two countries.

STANTON, Del., May 29 (AP) -- American Way, recovering from a poor jump at the thirteenth fence where he almost unseated Jockey William Bland Jr., closed fast today easily to win the first running of the $10,000-added Tom Roby Steeplechase Stakes at Delaware Park.
A substantial increase in community interest in recreation in 1946 is indicated in a survey released here yesterday by the National Recreation Association, 315 Fourth Avenue.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 29 --Karl Rex Hammers, Pittsburgh, new Imperial Potentate of the Shrine of North America, declared today that the order must dismiss petty differences and small discontent, "for the big job of keeping democracy alive and strong and incorruptable in a world with scores of conflicting ideologies, not one of which has even proven itself even a poor substitute.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The Department of Agriculture today made public its civilian sugar increase figures to back up the announced thirty-five-pound 1947 ration, and added, "if recent improvements continue, a moderate increase above the thirty-fivepound figure is in prospect."

Admiral Thomas C. Kinkaid, commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier, told 5,000 persons in Madison Square yesterday that "isolation is no longer possible." The country is not yet free to devote all its energies "to the reestablishment of the peaceful mode of life," he said.
WASHINGTON, May 29--The Senate-House conferees brought out today a composite bill offering the first peacetime hardening of Government policy toward the labor unions since the Wagner Act of 1935.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 29 -- Making her first appearance in golf competition this season, Mrs. Walter J. Reynolds of the Knollwood Country Club, Westchester open champion, captured the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association one-day event over the difficult west course of the Winged Foot Club with 43, 44 -- 87.

THE footracers and the hardware heavers will be toiling manfully at Philadelphia's Franklin Field today and tomorrow in the intercollegiate track and field championships. It's positively a pleasure to report that business is definitely on the upswing. The thin-clads -- as the Midwesterners persist in calling them -- apparently are becoming very conscious of the approach of the Olympic Games and performances have steadily improved.

House and Senate conferees reached agreement yesterday on a compromise tax reduction measure to become effective July 1 next. It calls for a total saving of about $4 billions for the forty-eight million taxpayers of the nation. The bill now goes back to the two Houses of Congress for a final vote.

Despite the high volume of import and export freight moving through the Port of New York, local trucking companies are experiencing a sharp decline in business that has immobilized an estimated 20 to 30 per cent of their rolling stock, it was learned yesterday.

Charles P. Gross, chairman of the Board of Transportation, charged yesterday that the board's efforts to operate the city's unified transit system safely and efficiently had been handicapped by Mayor O'Dwyer's repeated interference in its affairs, especially in the matter of labor relations with its 29,300 operating employes.

TOKYO, Friday, May 30 -- Lieut. Gen. Robert L. Eichelberger, commander of Allied ground forces in Japan, warned in a Memorial Day address today that the United States "almost certainly would be the first target of aggressors" if a new world war came.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 29 -- The Rhode Island General Assembly adjourned its 1947 session at 6:10 A.M. today after passing a controversial merit rating bill, actually an omnibus bill, which reduces employers' unemployment compensation taxes about $5,000,000 yearly and cuts employes' cash sickness contributions from 1 1/2 to 1 per cent.

The plot of the Communist minority in Hungary to nullify the will of the people and oust the elected Government has now reached a climax. Nowhere is there a more flagrant example of Communist tactics in flouting the democratic process and seizing power by terror and trickery than in this unhappy country.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today denied Andrew J. May's statement that the general was "screaming" for more shells in 1945.

FORT BLISS, El Paso, Tex., May 29--A wild German V-2 rocket, launched from the Army's White Sands proving ground in New Mexico, fell tonight near the Mexican town of Juarez, just across the border from El Paso, alarming residents of this area. No casualties were reported.

A representative selection of literary material acquired by the reference department of the New York Public Library during 1944, 1945 and 1946 has been placed on exhibition in the main exhibition room of the central building, it was announced yesterday.

Brooklyn College concluded its baseball season yesterday by dropping a 14-10 decision to Manhattan College on the Flatbush diamond. The Kingsmen closed their metropolitan Collegiate Conference campaign with one victory and eleven defeats.

NANKING, May 29 (U.P.) -- Chinese Communist troops lashing out at Nationalist supply lines to Changchun, Manchurian capital, entered the suburbs of Szepingkai on the Mukden-Changchun railroad. The Communists again severed the vital Peiping-Mukden line northeast of Tientsin, Government military dispatches reported.

SALT LAKE CITY, May 29 -- Orson Welles gave an enthusiastic Salt Lake City audience last night a drastically but skillfully cut version of Shakespeare's "Macbeth," a part of Utah's centennial drama festival.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29 -- The Commonwealth of Australia filed a registration statement today with the Securities and Exchange Commission, its second this year. It registered new securities to obtain funds with which to redeem outstanding bonds.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 9 points lower to 9 points higher than the day before on a moderate volume of business. It started with gains of 5 to 12 points and held them during the early trading, due chiefly to some price-fixing, and some commission house buying on reports that Commodity Credit Corporation plans to purchase cotton to ship to Japan and may start buying soon.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Senators seeking the origin of a forged letter figuring in an investigation of "gray markets" steel deals ran up against a blank wall today when Herbert M. Karp, Brooklyn attorney, testified it was handed to him by a mysterious stranger.

Former tenants of a six-story tenement near the Amsterdam Avenue ice-house that was destroyed last December by fire demanded yesterday that they be readmitted to the homes from which they fled at the time.
Today May 30, is the thirtysecond day of the Greater New York Fund's Tenth Annual Campaign in behalf of 423 local hospitals, health and welfare agencies.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 29 -- The way was cleared today for another important battle on the veto when the working committee of the United Nations' Atomic Energy Commission unanimously adopted a Russian resolution placing international atomic control "within the framework of the Security Council."

ALBANY, May 29 -- The Adjutant General released the following State Guard orders today: Cox. Col. J.H., 42d Division, artillery, to Headquarters as executive officer. Briggs, Lt. Col. J.A., 114th Bomb Squad, to Headquarters as squad commander. Jenks, Maj. H.P., 114th Bomb Squad, to Headquarters as operations officer.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 29 -- Princeton's baseball team in the Eastern Intercollegiate League today avenged an early season defeat by downing Penn, 6 -- 5, behind Righthander Bob Wolcott.

Fourteen men were charged by a Federal grand jury in three indictments yesterday with having conspired during 1944 and 1945 to sell and use forged War Production Board priorities. The racket caused the diversion of 845,000 yards of scarce textiles worth $500,000 into the black market, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Thousands of New York's music lovers are looking forward to the beginning of the open-air concerts at Lewisohn Stadium.

Tax news dominated the stock market yesterday and enabled prices to forge further ahead although the gains in the pivotal issues generally were limited. The rally was selective and confined to the early afternoon, with some of the best gains reduced near the close.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 29 -- Two sailing yacht fleets started through Long Island Sound tonight in holiday distance races. One was the Storm Trysail Club's event out to Block Island, and the other the schooner contest of the Corinthians.
PHILADELPHIA, May 29 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Chamber of Commerce today called on its 3,041 members for a voluntary program of forcing back prices "whenever and wherever possible."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Henry J. Morgenthau, chairman of the $170,000,000 United Jewish Appeal, has announced that in some 200 communities committees of leading Christians have been formed whose sole purpose it is to participate in this great humanitarian effort.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Senate and House conferees agreed quickly today on a tax-reduction bill identical to the measure passed by the Senate yesterday except for one change in the graduated scale of percentage cuts.

WASHINGTON, May 29 - The House Appropriations Committee today reduced the War Department's 1948 military budget by $475,809,077. It asserted that its recommended appropriation of $5,240,982,423 was sufficient to maintain the Army at its prescribed strength of 1,070,000 men.

A denunciation of the Senate's action in reducing funds for employment services was made by Senator Robert F. Wagner in a message read yesterday at the convention here of the International Association of Public Employment Services.

SEOUL, Korea, May 29 -- Disagreement among the members of the vital subcommission on consultation with Koreans led today to an unscheduled three-hour meeting of the full United States-Russian Joint Commission for the establishment of a provisional Government in Korea.
NEW DELHI, India, May 29 -- India awaits the return of Viscount Mountbatten, Viceroy of India, and next Monday's conference in a mood amounting almost to apprehension.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., May 29 -- Women who have become members of labor unions were urged today to attend union meetings and check on any activities that "might discriminate against or curtail the female members of the union."

PHILADELPHIA, May 29 (AP) -- Relief Pitcher Russ Christopher smacked a single to left that scored the deciding run in the ninth today as the Philadelphia Athletics snapped a four-game losing streak by nosing out the Boston Red Sox, 3 -- 2.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 29 (AP) -- The Brazilian War Ministry announced today that Army sergeants involved in an alleged armed plot against the Government had implicated former President Getulio Vargas. The War Ministry prepared to ask permission of Congress to question Vargas personally.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations and nineteen affiliated unions and the National Lawyers Guild petitioned the Supreme Court today to reconsider a decision that upheld a police search of a home without a search warrant.

The State Department's cultural program abroad, now under fire in Congress, is more than radio programs. It is also books, peripdicals, pictures, educational films and people. This point is well made in a letter signed by fifteen of America's leading librarians, published today in another column on this page.

Import licenses on textiles from America have been temporarily suspended in Australia, it was learned yesterday from New York exporters. Cables received from agents in Australia stated that the order was effective as of May 25, and that it had been instituted as a retaliatory measure for the tariff increase anticipated for Australian wool as the result of pending legislation in Congress.
KINGS POINT, L.I., May 29 -- Two hundred and eleven cadetmidshipmen of the United States Merchant Marine Academy here were sworn in as ensigns in the Naval Reserve today at graduation exercises.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 29 -- Claude Jarman Jr., the 12-year-old actor from Tennessee who made his screen debut in Metro-GoldwynMayer's "The Yearling," has been borrowed from Metro by RKO for a leading role in "Roughshod," the latter studio announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Exploding all their runs in a sixthinning uprising highlighted by consecutive homers by Bill Johnson and Yogi Berra, the second-place Yankees bagged the odd game of the set, beating the Senators, 5-2, today at Griffith Stadium.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The Departments of State and of Labor announced today the personnel of the delegation who would represent the United States Government, labor and industry at the International Labor Conference in Geneva from June 19 to July 11.

I. James Brody, ousted deputy commissioner of Marine and Aviation; James V. Auditore, "millionaire stevedore," and Albert Gross, a former bootlegger who is a business associate of Auditore, were arrested yesterday on a seventeencount indictment charging them with conspiracy and taking unlawful fees for rent of city piers.

JERUSALEM, May 29 -- Just before the arrival of the United Nations' fact-finding commission there is a strange state of confusion here. Arabs are becoming annoyed with Arabs and Jews are angry at other Jews over the question of policy.

WILLOW RUN, Mich., May 29 -- Dedicatory services in which the University of Michigan assumed a share of responsibility for Willow Run Airport through the establishment of an aeronautical research center were held today as aircraft of many types roared a salute in the skies overhead.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 29 -- Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha, secretary general of the Arab League, said today that his "personal inclination" was for cooperation with the United Nations committee of inquiry into Palestine but that a decision on the League's position would not be made until the seven member countries' Foreign Ministers met in Cairo early next month.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It will be tragic if Congress sacrifices our excellent international cultural relations program because it disapproves of the Stale Department's news handouts and radio programs. Yet this is exactly what appears to be happening.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- J. Monroe Johnson, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, today laid a lag in the delivery of freight cars in the laps of the carbuilding companies.

NEWARK, N.J., May 29 -- When four-year-old Cornelia Byron tried to catch a kitten in a backyard at 732 Mt. Prospect Avenue today but it ran into a narrow space between two brick walls with Cornelia after it.

LONDON, May 30 (Reuters) -- Estimates of how the proceeds of the sale of British owned railways in Argentina will be shared among the various classes of stockholders were published here today. Ordinary stocks are estimated to receive the following percentages of their nominal values:

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- In his first message to the new Republican Congress on Jan. 26 President Truman proposed a limited approach to labor legislation, centered upon prevention of jurisdictional strikes and some secondary boycotts.
BUDAPEST, May 29 -- A high Hungarian source said that Premier Ferenc Nagy of the antiCommunist Small Landholders party had telephoned his resignation from his vacation resort in Switzerland today.

NANKING, May 29 -- A civil war armistice and a resumption of Government peace negotiations with the Communists appear impossible because of developments in the last two days. These are: (1) Yesterday's outburst of antiCommunist sentiment in the People's Political Council.

Eight good horses and true, among them the King Ranch's Assault and Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' Stymie, are to provide the action today in the sixty-first running of the Suburban Handicap. As a result Belmont Park will be bulging with racegoers.
Ben Hecht declared yesterday that he had been grossly misquoted in an article concerning his views on Palestine that appeared on Tuesday in The London Evening Standard, written by Evelyn Webber.

Because coke producers are shutting down ovens in some locations for repairs, coke supplies for foundries and blast furnaces are growing critically tighter and shortages now threaten to force further cutbacks in gray iron and malleable foundry operations, industry spokesmen revealed here yesterday.

Marking the worst disaster in the history of this country's commercial aviation, a huge four-engined United Airlines plane, with forty-four passengers and crew of our crashed and burst into flames it 8:10 o'clock last night just after it had taken off from La Guardia Field on a scheduled non-stop flight to Cleveland.

The thirty-first annual report of the Todd Shipyards Corporation and its consolidated subsidiaries informed stockholders yesterday that the net profit for the fiscal year ended on March 31 amounted to $944,740, or $6.76 a share on the 139,451 no par capital shares outstanding.

BATAVIA, Java, May 29 (U.P.) -- Dutch authorities, in what amounted to an ultimatum, demanded tonight that Indonesian Republican leaders act at once toward carrying out the agreed formation of a United States of Indonesia within the Netherland Empire.

The 143-foot seagoing tug Leon, formerly the ATA 170, is now en route to Piraeus, Greece, by way of the Canal Zone, officials of the Moran Towing Transportation Company reported yesterday. At the Canal Zone, they explained, the tug will take in tow two sixtyton floating derricks brought down from Seattle, Wash.
LONDON, May 29 -- Outside of South American railway issues, business was at a low ebb in the stock markets here today.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission's first decision setting 6 per cent as a fair rate of return for a natural gas company has been upheld by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. A decision was handed down late yesterday on an appeal by the Mississippi River Fuel Corporation from an order issued by the commission directing it to reduce its rates by $945,000 annually.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Spokesmen of organized motion picture theatre owners urged Congress today to eliminate or drastically reduce the tax of 20 per cent on admissions.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Proponents of the controversial $500,000,000 St. Lawrence Seaway ended their case today before a Senate Foreign Relations Subcommittee with testimony of Undersecretary of War Kenneth C. Royall that the project would be "helpful, but not vital, to national defense."

Gross operating revenues of the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation reached a new high record of $35,589,089 in 1946, according to the annual report, released yesterday. In 1945 the revenues were $33,344,576, or 7 per cent below last year's total.

Local CIO authorities estimate the unemployed in New York City at 450,000. Inasmuch as this city has one-fifteenth of all the nations workers, the CIO figures would be already confronting us with a very serious national unemployment problem.

June Financing In shutting shop for the holiday, bond men yesterday trimmed calendars down to June, thereby exposing a heavy schedule of marketings with many a challenge to pricers and salesmen. According to trade estimates, more than a score of bond issues running up to about $700,000,000 may reach the market before the new month is out.

MOSCOW, May 29 (U.P.) -- The newspaper Pravda published today a letter to its editor from Prince Mozaffar Firouz, the Iranian Ambassador to the Soviet Union, stating that the Iranian news agency Pars had canceled an agreement with The United Press.
The Welfare Department was authorized yesterday to add 250 worKers to its staff, which Welfare Commissioner Edward E. Rhatigan has said was seriously below strength.

VIENNA, May 29 -- Both the Austrian and Hungarian Communist parties are getting a reputation as motorized parties. Attention has been strongly drawn to the great amount of motor transport available to Communists at the time of the May Day parade in Vienna.

CARNOUSTIE, May 28 (AP) -- Three former American champions, Marvin (Bud) Ward, Willie Turnesa and Dick Chapman, slashed through today to the quarter-finals of the British amateur golf championship, but a fourth Yankee aspirant, Skee Riegel, fell victim of the tournament's biggest upset when he was dumped out by a 45year-old Scot.

For the third straight year major crime in New York City increased sharply in 1946, the annual report of the Police Department disclosed yesterday. Although the patrol force was strengthened by 1,927 men, the first manpower gain in four years, felony complaints in 1946 rose to 31,842, against 28,555 in the previous year, or an increase of 11.5 per cent.

A freakish cold wave moving eastward from the Middle West is expected to lower temperatures in New York and its suburbs today, but the drop should not be too severe and may come as a welcome change from the 80-degree high at 2:30 P.M. yesterday.

An extensive campaign will be launched shortly by the Millers National Federation in an effort to return wheat flour products to "their proper place in the American diet," it was learned yesterday. Consumption of such flour, it was said, dropped from 176 pounds per person in 1920 to 160 pounds in 1946.

The Goldman Band concerts will be carried as usual this summer from the Central Park Mall and Prospect Park, Brooklyn, by the city stations, WNYC and its frequencymodulation affiliate, WNYC-FM. The opening program will be heard on Friday, June 13, from the Mall and will run from 8:30 to 10:30 P.M.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 29 -- Three youths who escaped from the Ohio State Reformatory at Mansfield Monday were captured here this afternoon as they sat in a motion picture theatre viewing a picture titled: "Wild Bill Hickok Rides Again."

BERLIN, May 29 -- The creation of an economic government for Western Germany on a political pattern was announced jointly today by the United States and British Military Governments. The French and the Russians were publicly invited to participate.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The text of the labor bill as drafted by the Senate and House conferees is as follows: SHORT TITLE AND DECLARATION OF POLICY Section 1. (a) This Act may be cited as the "Labor Management Relations Act, 1947."

CHICAGO, May 29 -- Lowell B. Mason, a member of the Federal Trade Commission, today called for greater reliance, in the relations between Government and business, on fair trade practices voluntarily adopted and cooperatively observed by business itself -- a return to the tradition of the "law merchant."

St. John's strengthened its hold on second place in the Metropolitan Conference yesterday by handing Fordham an 11-4 defeat at Fordham Field. The Rams' victory streak thus was ended at four games. Earlier in the season the Maroon had beaten the Redmen, 4 -- 3.

ASPEN, Col., May 29 -- The stream-stocking problems out here are no different from those encountered by conservation groups in the Eastern States, and with a minor blizzard sweeping down from the Rockies this morning there has been an opportunity to discuss the situation at some length.

Acting to offset drains on their reserves, the New York City reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System sold $130,000,000 of their holdings of Government securities during the week ended on Wednesday, it was disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- During the week ended May 28, member bank reserve balances decreased $237,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

MUNICH, May 29 (AP) -- German authorities placed Frau Hermann Goering in a women's internment camp on the outskirts of Augsburg today prior to her forthcoming trial on charges that she was a member of the Nazi party.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 29 -- Gov. James L. McConaughy today signed a bill imposing a 3 per cent sales tax after the Republican majority in the State Senate broke up a Democratic filibuster and forced its passage.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Political animations in both major parties have guided the course through Congress of the bills to correct union labor practices and to reduce income taxes. But the President will be able to give a more persuasive argument for a tax bill veto, if that should be his decision, than for a veto of the labor legislation.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 29 (AP) -- Complaints of disabled veterans that their rights were violated in connection with nineteen appointments to the Lackawanna Fire Department resulted today in county grand jury indictments of the Mayor and three Civil Service Commissioners of that city.
ANKARA, Turkey, May 29 (Reuters) -- Turkish Prime Minister Recep Peker, addressing the Turkish Parliament today, said that "a certain foreign power had sent a note requesting bases in Turkey."

CHICAGO, May 29 -- Grain markets on the Board of Trade reversed their trend today after having displayed great strength yesterday. Weather news was still generally unfavorable, but buying failed to follow the upturn of yesterday. There was heavy profittaking by longs which put a weight on the market.

The DC-4, the type of plane that crashed at La Guardia Field, has two emergency doors, one on each side of the cabin, placed four or five seats forward of the main passenger door at the rear. They are plainly marked and easily opened by breaking a clear plastic sheet and turning a single handle below the window.

VIENNA, May 29 -- Austrian trade union leaders asked the Allied Council for Austria directly today to abolish zonal restrictions and censorship and to increase food rations. They urged especially more food for heavy workers to provide Austria's industries with more coal, and that the Allies cease requisitioning Austrian production, reduce the occupation costs and release Austrian prisoners of war.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 -- A prodigious decline in shipping along the Pacific Coast was described to a panel of the Interstate Commerce Commission here yesterday as it continued hearings on an application for increased rail and water rates.

FORT BLISS, Tex., May 28 (Delayed) -- The greatest bomber in the world, the XB-36, first of a line of 100 sky giants on order by Army Air Forces from the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation's plant here, will take to the air again next week on its eighteenth flight.

LONDON, May 29 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan, Toledo, Ohio, golfer, wan unfavorable headlines in London newspapers today although he denied yesterday that he had tried to claim a hole on a technicality in the British amateur tournament at Carnoustie, Scotland.

Like all our three big summer holidays, Memorial Day has been twisted from its original purpose. For most of the people of this country this is not a day of solemn commemoration, any more than the Fourth of July is a day devoted to thinking about independence or Labor Day a day devoted to labor.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 29 (AP) -- Gen. Anastasia Somoza, former President, said today he had complete confidence that the twenty other American republics would recognize the change in the Nicaraguan Government.

Working in the glare of huge searchlights set up by the Police and Fire Departments, rescuers trudged through thick mud and pelting rain last night to reach passengers inside the DC-4 plane that crashed and burned near La Guardia Field.

NEWTON CENTER, Mass., May 29 -- A "dark horse," Ellsworth Vines of California, former national tennis champion, now in his sophomore year as a professional golfer, took the lead in today's opening round of the seventh anlual $15,000 Goodall round-robin tournament on the narrow treelined fairways of the Charles River Country Club.

Bonds called before maturity for payment in May amounted to $143,934,000, compared with $194,122,000 in the preceding month and $425,080,000 in May, 1946. Although the second largest total for the year to date, the month's total was the smallest for a May since 1944, when $130,152,000 was redeemed.

More Than India Mahatma Gandhi has said that, chaos or no chaos, the British must be prepared to leave India on the promised day next year. If a stable order is to come to an independent India, said Gandhi, it must be the work of its own people.

For a number of reasons New York has become the Mecca of good music. In range, variety, quantity and skill the New York concert season is unranked by that of any other city in the world. Yet it is an odd fact that in this city, whose population compares with that of a medium-sized nation of Europe, there is only one major symphony orchestra and one becoming so.

NANKING, China, Saturday, May 31 (AP) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek flew secretly to Mukden yesterday to confer with his commanders over the increasing Communist offensive in Manchuria, Chinese Government sources said today.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Now that conference agreements have been reached, the Republican-dominated Eightieth Congress has practically if not actually presented President Truman with two major questions of the session.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 30 -- An old country store, for 150 years a landmark at the four corners of North New Salem and recently moved to the courtyard of the Northampton Hotel and Old Wiggins Tavern, was officially opened today at a one-day fair held in the tavern grounds.

A new iron that raises on the hinged front of its sole plate to iron ruffles and hard-to-reach frills will be introduced in New York stores Monday. Called the Tip-Toe automatic electric iron, it is the first home appliance to be produced by the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company, known for its locks and electric industrial trucks.
CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., May 30 -- Reginald J. Stranger, wartime Mayor of Southampton, England, made an engagement more than two years ago with an American soldier from McConnellsburg, Pa.

A special pontifical vesper service will be held at 4 P.M. tomorrow. Trinity Sunday, in St. Patrick's Cathedral signalizing the start of the third year of the campaign of Cardinal Spellman for foster homes to care for dependent and neglected children in the confines of the Archdiocese of New York.

Thomas J. Connors will shortly relinquish his duties as vice president in charge of sales and distribution for the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, it became known yesterday. Mr. Connors, who joined the company in 1941 as personal assistant to the late Sidney R. Kent, then president, will, however, remain with Fox in an as yet undefined advisory capacity.

WHITE SANDS PROVING GROUND, N.M., May 30 -- Technicians and engineers began today to study the erratic behavior of a German V-2 rocket -- the twenty-eighth fired here in the past year -- which fell last night near the Mexican town of Juarez.

The Port of New York Authority's interest in the present investigation by the Maritime Commission of freight forwarders' practices here, and in all other ports, is threefold, Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the organization, declared yesterday.

Determined to hold their lead in the National League pennant jumble at all costs, the Giants huffed and puffed magnificently at the Polo Grounds yesterday. They wound up blowing down Ben Chapman's Phillies in both ends of the holiday double-header, to the thunderous cheers of 46,848 paying spectators.

NEWTON CENTER, Mass., May 30 -- Shattering the course record and equalling the tournament record, Bobby Locke, sensational 29-year-old South African who bears a marked resemblance to MacDonald Smith both in looks, mannerisms and shot-making, today took a firm hold on first place in the seventh annual Goodall round-robin tournament at the Charles River Country Club.

The nation's domestic fleet is in a desperate situation, and it is the responsibility of the Interstate Commerce Commission to reach an early decision in its investigation of rail and water rate practices, according to the Association of American Ship Owners.

Low-end and popular-price dress production, which was sharply curtailed in March and April, has hit full-scale operation in the last few days, a survey of the market indicated yesterday. Buyers for chain stores, specialty shops and basement departments have been making substantial purchases of summer dresses, it was learned, as warmer weather has boosted sales of lighter garments.
MADRID, May 30 -- Certain Spanish business men have been informed privately that if they wish to trade with the Soviet Union, the Spanish Government will not put obstacles in their way.
BERLIN, May 30 -- Figures on the denazification trials fail to support the charge of Germans and United States businessmen that the trials of "little Nazis" are impeding German economic recovery.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 30 -- Problems precipitated by the autonomous organization of high school youth in fraternities and sororities were discussed in a seminar on teen-age and young-adult councils held today by the National Conference of Jewish Social Welfare.

DETROIT, May 30 (AP) -- Detroit's largest crowd of the baseball season -- 56,367 fans -- saw the Tigers lift their American League lead to three full games today with an even break in a holiday double-header with the St. Louis Browns. The visitors took the nightcap, 8 to 3, after Detroit had won the opener, 2 to 1.

MONTREAT, N.C., May 30 (AP) -- Southern Presbyterians, having elected Dr. John Reed Cunningham of Davidson, N.C., moderator of their eighty-seventh general assembly, opened their business meetings today with a report showing 63,248 new members of their church during the yast year.

Taps, rifle salutes and marching feet marked the day in Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and suburban areas yesterday as hundreds of thousands of persons gathered to witness the parades and wreath-laying ceremonies of Memorial Day.

In the shadow of the Third Avenue "El" at Chatham Square, a Memorial Day ceremony honoring Jewish patriots of the American Revolution was held yesterday in the Spanish-Portuguese Congregation Shearith Israel's New Bowery Cemetery.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., May 30 (AP) -- Friends and neighbors of the late President Roosevelt gathered today at his grave for a memorial service at which Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson asserted "men in every land will take heart," if the United States does its utmost to "achieve, prove and promote democracy."

NEW DELHI, India, May 30 (Reuters) -- Grim reports of internal strife in India faced Viscount Mountbatten, the Viecroy, as he arrived here today from London with Great Britain's momentous plan for transferring power from British to Indian hands.
PITTSBURGH, May 30 (AP) -- After Billy Cox's home run in the tenth had carried Pittsburgh to a 2-1 triumph, Hank Borowy pitched and batted the Cubs to a 5-2 victory before a sellout crowd of 37,451.

The decision of the city authorities to add 250 workers to the staff of the Department of Welfare was looked upon yesterday in social work circles as a start toward correcting the personnel shortage that Welfare Commissioner Edward E. Rhatigan has blamed, along with a mounting caseload, for inadequate control over relief disbursements.

With the purchase of the four-story eight-family apartment house at 39 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, from 100 Montague Street. Inc., the 229 Twenty-third Street Corporation announced plans to alter the building into seventeen suites of three and four rooms.

Despite larger offerings of public utility and railroad securities, new bond financing in May was the smallest in three months and the lowest amount for a May since 1945. The total of $357,023,000 for thirty-nine issues compared with $459,459,000 for thirty flotations in the preceding month and with $636,286,000 for fifty issues in May last year.

Friends and kin of the victims of the United Airlines DC-4 crash at La Guardia Field on Thursday night identified their dead yesterday with extraordinary emotional control. Their task made easier by an efficient police plan, they moved quickly through the morgue at Queens General Hospital in Jamaica.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- What the years of World War II did for the scientific advancement of farms and farming is summarized in the 1943-47 Yearbook of Agriculture, a 944-page volume published today under the title "Science in Farming."

PHILADELPHIA, May 30 -- The Yankees dropped a double-header to the Athletics before an overflow crowd of 30,261 in Shibe Park today. And, adding insult to injury, the Mackmen turned the Bombers back without a single run in either game.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., May 30 -- Representatives of sixteen colleges and hundreds of alumnae and parents assembled at Skidmore College today to pay tribute to the institution's achievements in its first quarter of a century as a senior college.

Fibber McGee and Molly and Bob Hope swapped standings in the popularity ratings compiled according to C.E. Hooper's formula and released yesterday, with Wistful Vista's leading citizens taking first place. Following in order, are Radio Theatre, Red Skelton, Jack Benny, Fred Allen, Amos 'n' Andy, Screen Guild Players, Mr. District Attorney and Charlie McCarthy.

AMSTERDAM. May 30 (Aneta) -- Prices remained steady in light trading today on the Amsterdam Stock Exchange. Quotations were virtually unchanged from yesterday's close. The official Stock Exchange index showed a net gain of 0.1 point.

RYE, N.Y., May 30 -- For the third championship regatta of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, which was held today by the American Yacht Club, wind and sea were in a kindly mood, and 84 craft had smooth sailing around their various courses

Some radio specialty stores, faced with heavy inventories of well-known standard brand table radios retailing at more than $25 and table radio-phonograph combinations selling for more than $100, have begun to reduce prices on such items despite their being fair traded or under a list price suggested by the manufacturer, a representative of a leading retailer said yesterday.

Current stocks of finished leathers are far under those which led to the inventory-bust of 1921 and in fact constitute one of the remarkable exceptions to the tide of mounting inventories reported by the Department of Commerce according to a survey issued yesterday by the Tanners Council of America.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (U.P.) -- A $150,000 Federal project that produced a successful cross-wind landing gear may force drastic revision of the Government's $500,000,000 country-wide airport building program.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- Washington swept both games of a double-header from Boston here today, 13 -- 6 and 5 -- 3, before a crowd of 26,693. The Red Sox made four errors in the first game and two in the second. All figured in the scoring.

CARNOUSTIE, May 30 (AP) -- For the first time a pair of Americans, Willie Turnesa and Dick Chapman, will meet tomorrow in the thirty-six-hole final for the British amateur golf championship over windswept Carnoustie.
NANKING, May 30 -- Violent methods of Government agencies in dealing with students was denounced today in the Legislative Yuan.
PARIS, May 30 -- What appear to be a Communist coup in Hungary, openly backed by the Soviet Union, was virtually completed today.

JERUSALEM, May 30 -- Appreciation for British Foreign Secretary Bevin's declaration on Palestine yesterday at the Labor party conference was expressed today by Arab leaders and newspapers. The Hebrew newspaper Hatzofeh declared, however, that the speech meant that the most extreme Arab attitude had "become the authorized view of the British Government."

BOSTON, May 30 -- Hitting lightly and playing raggedly at times, the Dodgers did a double nose dive here today, losing twice to the Braves, 6 -- 3 and 3 -- 0. A highly delighted crowd of 30,535 Hub fans saw the games.

Tests on human beings catapulted out of a plane at an acceleration twenty times that of gravity, to determine the safety limits for emergency escape from high-speed aircraft, are described in the current issue of Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

John B. Kelly Jr. of the Vesper Boat Club, Philadelphia, national single sculls champion, won the senior single shell race on the Harlem yesterday as the New York Rowing Association put on one of its most successful Memorial Day regattas.

Fall production of a play, "Eden Rose," by Robert Anderson, was announced yesterday by the new firm of Penelope Sack and Robert Woods. Both Miss Sack and Mr. Woods are members of Theatre Incorporated's board of directors, but the production will be an independent venture to be put on during the interim between TI's presentations of "The Big People" and "The Changeling."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 30 -- Dodie Smith, British author of the plays "Autumn Crocus" and "Dear Octopus," has been engaged by Paramount to adapt Henry James' novel, "Portrait of a Lady," to the screen. Published in 1882, the novel deals with an American girl who marries a dilettante European only to find the union loveless.

In his proposal for changes in our present policies toward Germany and Japan, former President Hoover made a clear distinction between Germany and Japan. Germany, he pointed out, is paralyzed and in need of American relief mainly because it is split into four zones under four Powers pursuing different policies, with indefinite boundaries and with little interchange of economic life or food supplies.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 (AP) -- The first ten drivers in the 500-mile automobile race at the Speedway today follow:
HAMM, Luxembourg, May 30 (AP) -- The vow to fight forever against aggression was given anew today here over the graves of Gen. Georgo S.Patton and 8,000 American soldiers by Gen. Lucius D.Clay.
TOKYO, Saturday, May 31 (AP) -- The Army said today that forty persons were killed in the crash of a courier plane southwest of Tokyo and that the bodies were "burned beyond recognition."
Eight-oared crews of Navy and Cornell meet in dual competition today over the two-mile course on Cayuga Lake at Ithaca.

ATHENS, May 30 (U.P.) -- Government members announced in Parliament tonight heavy guerrilla attacks on two towns in northern Greece. The Ministers asserted their conviction that the guerrillas were receiving substantial support from abroad.

Preparing for possible use television as an advertising medium for decorative fabrics, Carlton C. Brose, vice president in charge of Waverly Fabrics Divsion, F. Schumacher Co., has started experimental work with a television set installed in his tenth-floor headquarters office at 60 West Fortieth Street, where out of-town buyers see the current collection of Waverly patterns.

LONDON, May 30 -- A price-finding system based on cost estimates and a rate of profit approved by the Ministry of Supply should be established by Textile Machinery Makers, Ltd., a privately owned concern, a Government committee of investigation of textile machinery industry recommended tonight.
MUNICH, May 30 -- Warrants were issued today for the wives of three major Nazi war criminals executed at Nuremberg.

New panel wallpapers, small in scale and simply colored to blend with contemporary room schemes, have just been introduced in several New York stores. Designed by American concerns, they are especially suitable for small houses, wallpaper authorities asserted yesterday, since they offer the same feeling of distance but not the heaviness found in many traditional imported patterns.

LONDON, May 30 -- The feature in quiet but otherwise cheerful stock markets here today was the big adjustment in Argentine railway issues following the official notice of "take-over" values issued late yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Many devices in radio ranging and instrument navigation of aircraft are present among the 369 inventions winning patents this week from the United States Patent Office.
PARIS, May 30 -- Americans and Frenchmen joined today to honor the United States military dead of the two World Wars and to recall the bonds of friendship between the two nations.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 30 -- Speaking here today at the nineteenth annual commencement of Sarah Lawrence College, Dr. Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard Observatory and president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, told an audience of 300 that somnambulism was worse than communism, fascism, and all other "isms."

One of President Truman's first appointments when he returned to Washington was with Dr. Karl T. Compton, chairman of the Commission which he had appointed to study the question of universal military training. After extensive hearings the Commission has been preparing its report, which Dr. Compton called to discuss with the President.

Furniture buyers will purchase a great deal more merchandise at the forthcoming July markets than they did during the January events, retailers' and manufacturers' representatives agreed yesterday. A good port on of the increased volume will be chalked up by department store buyers no longer subject to the "not open to buy" status arising out of heavy over-all store inventory, primarily in soft goods, buying office spokesmen pointed out.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (Science Service) -- Among the inventions patented this week are:
ROME, May 30 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi today virtually completed formation of the first Italian Cabinet since the liberation from which the Socialists and Communists were excluded.

PORT DEPOSIT, Md., May 30 -- Eye-witnesses to the crash of the Eastern Air Lines DC4 plane near here tonight said the huge craft plummeted almost vertically from an altitude of about 1,500 feet. The explosion that followed shook doors and windows of homes and buildings within a five-mile radius.

BUFFALO, May 30 -- After an hour's debate, the Business and Professional Women's Clubs of New York State, Inc., today voted to support 'by name' qualified women for policy-making posts in Government and business. The resolution was passed in spite of charges that the organization would "become involved in partisan politics."

Mayor O'Dwyer was asked yesterday by the Registered Nurses Guild, Local 312, AFL, to intervene in its dispute with Mt. Sinai Hospital over the hospital's threat to suspend its registry of nurses on July 1.

A diagnostic test for cancer, promising to make it possible to detect cancer of the internal organs in its early stages, when it is still curable by radiation or surgery, is reported in Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

CHICAGO, May 30 (AP) -- The Western Conference, prodded by a membership bid from Michigan State College, today asserted it had "no disposition to enlarge at this time." The sentiment was expressed in an informal poll of Big Nine athletic directors after President John Hannah of Michigan State personally had backed his college's long standing bid for membership.

CAMBRIDGE, England, May 3 -- A United States Flying Fortress swooped low today over the American military cemetery at Madingley, on the outskirts of Cambridge. From its bomb bay dropped a wreath that settled to earth in almost the center of the ordered rows of white crosses above the graves of 5,889 American war dead.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The clanging bells, piercing sirens and other mechanical wails of our fire engines, ambulances and similar vehicles of disaster are logically enough designed to be heard in heavy traffic.

MARGATE, England, May 30 -- Aneurin Bevan, Minister of Health, won an overwhelming victory for the Government's housing program today as the Labor party wound up its forty-sixth annual conference here.

RALEIGH, N.C., May 30 (AP) -- Godwin (Buddy) Bush, the almost illiterate 22-year-old Negro, talked freely early today of his break-away from an armed and masked mob at Jackson a week ago, and his escape from the threat of a lynching.

STANTON, Del., May 30 (AP) -- A crowd of 26,000 at Delaware Park today saw Polynesian, owned by Mrs. Peter A.B. Widener of Philadelphia, add the $10,000 added Wilmington handicap to his list of victories.
