Among the passengers on the wrecked Miami-bound Eastern Air Lines plane were Mrs. Esther Stuart and her 1-year-old son, Michael. They were returning to Miami Beach after a week's visit to the home of Mrs. Stuart's mother in Jersey City, according to a brother, Michael Rosenberg of Newark.

The one-story taxpayer property at the northeast corner of Thirty - seventh Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, has been sold by Ben Davidson and Rubin Block to the New Kleb Realty Corporation, of which M. Newman is president.

Assault again proved his greatness -- this time before a crowd of 59,745, largest of the New York racing season -- when he scored a smashing triumph in the sixty-first running of the $50,000 added Suburban Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.
The passenger list of the plane which crashed in Maryland was given by Eastern Air Lines here last night as follows:
PHILADELPHIA, May 30 -- Before a Memorial Day crowd of 10,000 persons this city today opened a three-day "world air show" that was dominated completely by Army, Navy and Marine Corps aircraft.

William E. Coney, pilot of the wrecked Eastern Air Lines plane, was a top-notch Navy flier during the war and piloted the Mars and the Hawaii Mars, the latter taking the title of the largest flying boat in operation from the former after, its launching in the summer of 1945.

PORT DEPOSIT, Md., May 30 -- Forty-nine passengers, including a 1-year-old infant, and all four members of the crew of an Eastern Air Lines plane making a nonstop flight from the Newark, N.J., Airport to Miami, Fla., were killed near here at 6:45 o'clock tonight when the plane crashed and exploded in a wooded swamp area in Cecil County.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Having read in your issue of May 23 the dispatch from your Warsaw correspondent covering his interview with Vice Premier Gomulka, I am constrained to reply, fearing that if the one-sided dispatch of Mr. Gruson were permitted to stand by itself a completely erroneous impression would be obtained by your readers as to the party at fault for the deterioration in Polish-American relations.

A marked increase of crime in this city is revealed in the annual report of the Police Department. This is deeply disturbing not only because it continues a steady rise since 1941 but because it reveals a shocking percentage of increase despite a heavily reinforced police force.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 -- Death rode into the cheers and sunshine at the Speedway today when William (Shorty) Cantlon of Indianapolis, driving an Automobile Shippers Special, was killed during the thirty-first 500-mile automobile race.

CHICAGO, May 30 (AP) -- The Indians advanced from fourth to second place in the American League standings by sweeping a double-header from the White Sox before 25,932 fans here today, 8 -- 4 and 9 -- 1.
Late reports from the Catskill streams indicate excellent fly-fish-fishing conditions, with streams in splendid shape and the water temperatures ranging in the neighborhood of 55 degrees.

JERUSALEM, May 30 -- Breaking the underground's rule of ignoring court proceedings, one of the five young Jews being tried on charges resulting from the blasting open of the Acre prison stood up in the Jerusalem Military Court today to question a British soldier.

NEWARK, N.J., May 30 (AP) -- Unleashing a fifteen-hit attack against four Jersey City pitchers for a 15-3 nightcap triumph, the Newark Bears snapped a four-game losing streak as they split the holiday twin bill with the league-leading Giants before 15,121 fans.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 30 -- Conceding that the United Nations "has not a long list of accomplishments to its credit," Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz told 204 members of the graduating class of Seton Hall College here this afternoon that the United Nations "is still the best thing we know of to bring us lasting peace."

The Senate has voted against income tax reform at this time designed to eliminate the advantage enjoyed by residents of the so-called "community property states. Ten states have this system, which permits each spouse to report half the family income for tax purposes, even though all or most of it may have been earned by one of them.

With two grim tragedies in air transport already marring the Memorial Day week-end, the mystery has been taken out of at least one. Yesterday, when it was still news, government and airline officials produced a reasonable explanation of the shocking United Air Lines crash that cost thirty-nine lives at the edge of La Guardia Field in Thursday evening's sudden storm.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The political crisis in Hungary is being studied in the State Department, it was learned today. Indications were that several days might elapse before a decision on policy was reached.

BASEBALL The Giants swept a double bill with the Phils, 7 -- 1 and 5 -- 3, at the Polo Grounds yesterday to stay in first place, while the Dodgers lost twice to the Braves, 6 -- 3, 3 -- 0, dropping to fourth. The Yankees were blanked by the Athletics, 1 -- 0 and 4 -- 0.

EVANSTON, Ill., May 30 (AP) -- Superbly balanced Illinois began its team title defense with sixteen qualifiers, and Charles Fonville of Michigan made two record-breakng shot-put tosses in the trials of the Big Nine outdoor track and field meet today.

Eighty representatives from the press, magazines and radio played truant from their desks one day this week and "bussed" down through Jersey, as far as the Delaware to see how eggs are produced. That, readers, is not the simple process you may think it.
New Yorkers observed Memorial Day yesterday in brisk weather, but fair skies and a bright sun lured thousands to parks, playgrounds and near-by beaches.

The United Air Lines DC-4 that crashed and burned at La Guardia Field Thursday night never got into the air and the pilot after using up about two-thirds of the 3,500-foot runway was trying to halt his giant craft by braking and ground looping.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in May was approximately at the same pace as the month before, but the dullest for a corresponding month since 1944. Sales exceeded the million-share mark in five sessions, the largest of which was 1,859,130 shares on May 19.

The new American President liner President Cleveland now is receiving her finishing touches at the Bethlehem-Alameda shipyard, Alameda, Calif., and is scheduled to make her maiden voyage from San Francisco and Los Angeles on or about Aug. 15, according to latest word from the steamship company.

Youngs Textile Mills, Inc., of 594 Broadway will move to the Bronx, where a temporary factory will be occupied pending the erection of a new building on the southwest side of Morris Park Avenue, 100 feet west of Eastchester Road.

The Board of Transportation announced yesterday that it would begin on Monday a series of at least nine hearings at which unions and other associations of employes of the city's unified transit system may discuss their requests for changes in wages, hours and working conditions.

HANKINSON, N.D., May 30 (AP) -- Frank H. Pietz celebrated his seventy-third birthday and fifty years in business here today by giving a party for every man over 70 years of age in these parts. Fifty-two put in an appearance at the event.

All round the world Taps echoed softly yesterday in global Memorial Day tribute to America's soldier dead. It mingled with reverent prayer in far-flung cemeteries -- at Anzio Beach, on the white African shore, on a green hillside in Britain, in tiny Luxembourg, at tropic Guam and Pearl Harbor, at Lisnabreeny in North Ireland, in Southern Holland, in Paris, at Sydney in Australia and at the Cenotaph in Auckland, New Zealand.

Matyas Rakosi, Communist leader in an anti-Communist country, is today the acting Premier of Hungary. He is an unprepossessing little man with small, shrewd eyes and the rude, authoritative manner of the stage Commissar. He came to this country last year with Ferenc Nagy, the Premier he has now displaced, to negotiate for the return of the Hungarian gold the American Army recaptured from the Germans.

Continuing their investigation into pier operations, members of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's staff dug deeper yesterday into the background of Christopher O'Connor, the 35-year-old former longshoreman facing usury charges.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, May 30 (AP) -- A Presidential military aide said today that Communists were threatening to extend their bloodless Hungarian coup by forcing the resignation of President Zoltan Tildy, former chief of the Small Landholders party, unless he fell into line with their plans.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 30 -- The Slovak populace is stirred up anew by the arrest of men suspected of circulating treasonable pamphlets entitled "Legacy of Tiso." Similar leaflets also have been distributed among the soldiers.

Surveys of cost-cutting methods in metalworking operations have been greatly stimulated by the current recession in business, machine tool distributors here revealed yesterday. Reports from factory managers, tabulated by field engineers of the distributors, show that more than one-half of the larger metalworking plants in the New York industrial area are now studying cost reduction opportunities through using new plant equipment and tools. Present interest in lower

ST. LOUIS, May 30 (AP) -- The Cardinals, behind Al Brazle, won the second half of a double-header, 7 to 3, after the Reds had out-slugged them, 12 to 8, before a crowd of 29,443, largest of the season here, today.

DEVON, Pa., May 30 -- Brandywine, 10-year-old chestnut gelding owned and ridden by Betty Jane Baldwin of West Chester. Pa., won a leg on the Newbold Ely's Hounds Challenge Trophy at the Devon horse show and county fair today.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- A wreath was put before the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier at 11 A.M. today, as a tribute by President Truman to the fallen warriors for American freedom and democracy.

JIMMY WELLS and Janie Chase, the two leading characters in this merry tale of murder, speak the same language -- one that you may have some difficulty in understanding unless you are hep to the jive. In other words, if you don't dig it, it doesn't send you.

IN attempting to study the relation between the modern novel and modern society. Mr. Burgum has undertaken a formidable task indeed. From Proust to Richard Wright, through Joyce, Kafka, Mann, Malraux, Stein, Steinbeck, Huxley, Hemingway, is quite a literary row to hoe.

A flight instructor and his student were killed yesterday afternoon when their Piper Cub plane plummeted from a 2,000-foot altitude into woodland near Red Bank, N.J., after a collision with a Navy transport plane bound from Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn, to Patuxent River, Md.

THE steamboat whistle used to blow down at the wharf, and a voice hollered " 'Board!" The Dixieland band played its come-on for the straggling cash customers, and the side-wheeler churned up the Mississippi. On board, a happy musical combo blew trumpets into tin hats and slapped a new American rhythm into existence.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 31 -- Jim Arbucho, Fordham righthander, weathered stormy first and ninth innings today to down Princeton's nine, 7 -- 5. A four-run uprising in the sixth overcame a two-run Tiger lead and gave Fordham, an advantage, which it kept.

NANTUCKET, Mass. -- Extensive air, and sea facilities to this former American whaling island thirty miles off the Massachusetts coast have been added for this summer's visitors. Off-islanders, as anyone front the mainland is chauvinistically called, already have arrived to take in the antiques and antiquity that are preserved here.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 31 -- The fabulous salmon runs of the Pacific Northwest and Alaska are sharply declining, and commercial fishermen and advocates of power projects engaged in a bitter controversy this week as to who is responsible.

CEDARHURST, L.I., May 31 -- Those in charge of seeding the teams in the annual Rockaway Hunt Club invitation doubles tennis tournament, which got under way today, were faultless in their figuring. As the field moved into the semi-finals, the four top-seeded combinations had made their way into the semi-finals.

PARIS, May 31 -- The decision of Abd el Krim to stop at Port Said and his declaration that he would later choose the country to which he would go was received with marked surprise by the Foreign Office here today. It was pointed out that Krim was allowed to travel from the Island of Reunion on condition that he would take up residence in France.

HONOLULU, May 31 (AP) -- His claim of a foul in the thirteenth round rejected amid boos, bantamweight boxing champion Manuel Ortiz came back strong last night to take an undisputed fifteen -round decision over challenger David Kuikong Young.

NEWTON CENTER, Mass., May 31 -- After basking in the limelight for the first two rounds of the Goodall round-robin golf tournament by slashing the course record to 65 yesterday and taking the measure of Ben Hogan the day before, Bobby Locke, the South African invader, was whittled down by Jimmy Demaret, current Masters champion, in today's third round at the Charles River Country Club.

The Columbia Broadcasting System started last night a new series of weekly broadcasts, with a WCBS program at 6:15, entitled "CBS Views the Press," involving critical appraisals of news magazines, press associations and New York newspapers.

THE Literature Division of the Progressive Citizens of America held a book and manuscript auction the other day, and we are sorry to report that the bidding was marked by apathy and low scores. A letter of Sherwood Anderson's, for example, went for $3.50; a ten-page original manuscript of W.H. Auden's for $25: Hubert Davis drawings for "An American Tragedy," signed by Theodore Dreiser, for $50.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The House Labor Committee reported today that a seventy-six day strike at the Allis-Chalmers plant at Milwaukee early in 1941 was called by direction of the Communist party because of the important work being done there for the Navy.

FIELD MARSHAL THE VISCOUNT MONTGOMERY of Alamein was one of the war's most controversial figures. Legends grew around him. His tongue was a whip-lash. His studied arrogance and ego were rivaled only by his complete concentration upon the task in hand.

The American Institute of Architects and the National Association of Home Builders have decided to collaborate in a joint program aimed at improvement in the quality of low-cost houses and reduction in building costs.

WHEN tulips are at the height of their bloom nothing can steal the show from them. Like narcissus, tulips have individual personalities and characteristics. Outstanding developments have been made in this spring flower.

Fourteen recommendations for policy in the operation of the nation's thrift and home-financing organizations under present uncertain conditions are contained in a statement sent out by the United States Savings and Loan League last week to its 3,600 member associations.

SEOUL, Korea, May 31 -- A vital sub-commission of the Joint United States-Soviet Commission for the establishment of a provisional Government in Korea has been instructed to resume its broken-off discussions and to report to the full commission on Monday, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, May 31 -- Speaking in the name of Christian representative leaders from seventy-six communities in twenty-seven states, the American Christian Palestine Committee ended a three-day national seminar in near-by Highland Park tonight with a plea to President Truman to implement the established American policy with regard to Palestine.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (U.P.) -- The Navy is going to devote its time to long range research in radically new arms rather than to minor refinements of existing weapons, it disclosed tonight.
Thirteen of those killed in the crash of the Eastern Airlines plane in Maryland on Friday lived in New York, seven in New Jersey and four in Connecticut.

CHICAGO, May 31 --The fate of proposed legislation aimed at reapportionment of Illinois' congressional districts was a subject of grave concern to sponsors of the measure as the Legislature adjourned over the Memorial Day week-end.
James M. Breen of 170 East Hartsdale Road, Hartsdale, N.Y., general freight agent of the New York Central System, with ,headquarters here, died in New Rochelle Hospital Friday at the age of 62.

MR. GIELGUD'S "Love for Love" does not match in brilliance his incompaable "The Importance of Being Earnest." Since Congreve and Wilde inhabit the same bailiwick of artificial comedy, Mr. Gielgud's triumph in the one seeme to promise triumph in the other.
GREENFORT, L.I. -- "Lark calling Yankee Clipper, Lark calling Yankee Clipper. Where're you fishing, Bob, and how're you doing? Over."

TWO superlative beauties -- and we have Miss King-Hall's insistently repetitious word for it -- were the Lynch sisters. They first bloomed in Ireland in the second half of the eighteenth century, moving from wild, seaswept and decaying Cabra House to Dublin -- to London, Paris, Versailles.

Mayor William O'Dwyer has disclaimed all future responsibility for the safe and efficient operation of New York City's far-flung unified transit system. He says that henceforth all responsibility must rest with the Board of Transportation, whose members he intends to hold accountable for "any results which adversely affect the safety and welfare of the people of the city."

As we have previously conceded, in this column, the world would be a pretty empty place if it weren't for the women in it, and man would be miserable, indeed, if he didn't have the help and encouragement of the members of the opposite sex.

LAST night the theatrical season of 1946-47 went into limbo (the expiration date is fixed by the termination of Equity run-of-the-play contracts). At this juncture it is customary to examine the events just passed and to interpret them -- if possible -- for the edification or amusement of the drama student.

HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., May 31 (AP) -- The Western Conference today fixed a procedure to select its Rose Bowl representative for the next two years, tightened eligibility requirements and set sites and dates for six Big Nine meets.

Activity last week in new fall ready-to-wear lines was heavy as the influx of buyers approached the peak expected during the next two weeks, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc., resident buyers.

During a century stamp collecting has developed from a curiosity into a matter of substantial nation-wide interest with considerable investment appeal. Auctioneers are still selling the vast Charles Lathrop Pack collection, and Gordon Harmer of Harmer, Rooke Co., international stamp auctioneers, estimates the complete collection will yield "over $400,000 based on sales thus far."

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- In formally requesting Congress to authorize the United States to make surplus modern armaments available to Latin America and Canada and to assist in the training of their military forces, President Truman has moved to implement a plan long favored by the Inter-American Defense Board as a means of strengthening the military and political security of the Western Hemisphere.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- The twenty-seven national parks are preparing for a tidal wave of visitors this summer, the national park service said today. The flood of tourists normally starts in midJune.

DAISIES capture the spirit of June as no other flower does except, perhaps, the rose. It is in June that the common daisy chooses to beautify the fields and roadsides, and then also its more sophisticated relatives adorn cultivated gardens.

IN these days of clinical novels when old lace is not generally identified with lavender, it is news to come upon a novel in which no character is remotely neurotic, no adolescent is delinquent, and an old woman is pictured as doing a good deed or two -- just because she feels like it.

The recent heavy calls by the United States Treasury on its War Loan accounts with the banks, which largely exhausted such holdings, will minimize the adjustments which those institutions will be required to make at the end of this month, when the special wartime exemptions which they have enjoyed are scheduled to expire, financial observers noted last week.

American food processors are now playing an international waiting game with foreign suppliers of basic commodities such as coffee and cocoa, purchasing executives of a major food producer stated last week. As a result, they said, current imports of these commodities are greatly reduced.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 31 -- Abd el Krim, whom the French have kept in exile for twenty-one years because he led the Riff war in Africa against both them and the Spanish, "jumped ship" at Port Said today upon the personal invitation of King Farouk.

Delegates to the first constitutional convention of the United Negro and Allied Veterans of America have protested to Postmaster General Robert E. Hannegan that postmasters in Southern states failed to deliver application forms for terminal leave pay to Negro veterans, Howard Johnson of New York, vice commander, reported at yesterday's session of the organization.

SCHENECTADY, May 31 (AP) -- Three track and field meet records were broken today in the seventh Schenectady interscholastic sports carnival. Russell Schuh of Bronxville, N.Y., High School repeated his last year's performance by winning two events.

HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, N.J., May 31 -- Forty-six local high school students declared today in an open letter that "we are not a spiritual or moral problem to our clergy, nor a delinquent problem to our parents, but a recreational challenge to our community."

IT is no fun to care for unhealthy chickens and it certainly is easier to keep them well than to cure them once they are sick. In a small flock, good care will help to eliminate disease and other troubles.

TOKYO, May 31 -- Formal investiture last week of Tetsu Katayama, first Socialist Premier of Japan, and attempts of the Socialists to form a coalition Cabinet under Socialist auspices, again have brought into the limelight one of the fundamental questions of the occupation.

KINGSTON, Jamaica -- With the impetus of a tourist boom and the Government's recent grant of money to the Tourist Trade Development Board, Jamaica, the largest island of the British West Indies, is considering a tourist expansion program that should when effected place her in the forefront of Caribbean vacation lands.

PERHAPS the idea of making a wedding cake at home for the June bride seems like taxing the ability of even the best cook in the family. Not so however. The cake itself is probably no more difficult to turn out successfully than an ordinary fruit cake.

DEVON, Pa., May 31 -- Thoroughbreds owned by Dr. Alvin I. Kay of Washington, D.C., and faultlessly ridden by Miss Betty Bosley of Monkton, Md., captured legs on two coveted trophies at tonight's final session of the fiftyfirst annual Devon Horse Show and County Fair.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- A robot is a leading character in a new Weather Bureau service. It gives business men a map showing the scientific gambling odds on the weather.
BERLIN, May 31 (AP) -- The state Parliaments of Thuringia and Sachsen-Anhalt in the Soviet zone have nationalized all the natural resources in their provinces.

STATEMENTS on the cost of war have done little to banish that scourge from the face of the earth. Similarly, it is doubtful whether prejudice will be eliminated by an exposition of its high cost to us all. Racial hate is only in small degree, if at all, the product of reason and appears to be not easily subject to cure by reason.

JUNE 10 win be the fifth anniversary of the destruction of Lidics and its population by the Nazis, and an official notice received from Prague last week says memorial stamps are being issued by Czechoslovakia: 1.20 and 1.60 koruna, each black, with design symbolizing a victim of the tragedy; and 2.40k dark red, a kneeling feminine figure.

AFTER V-J Day, the American Theatre Wing assumed that its famous war baby. Victory Players, would receive deserved governmental accolades and then vanish as quietly as a one-week flop. The tributes arrived on cue, but Victory Players, its name changed to Community Plays, is still very much alive and one of the most interesting phenomena in the theatre.

Authoritative works on history, philosophy, science, art and other subjects, first edition standard sets and other literary material comprising the second and final part of the library of the late Cloyd H. Marvin, president of George Washington University, will be auctioned tomorrow at 2 P.M. and Tuesday at 10 A.M. and 2 P.M. at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31 -- The ambitious task of organizing the country's 450,000 telephone workers into a single industrial union was undertaken here this afternoon by the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Now come some of the pleasantest nights of our year, nights when you can almost hear the grass growing and the rosebuds straining at their seams. There's a moon almost at the full to gleam on the sumac and the youngleafed sycamores which stand in whitewashed ghostliness.
Most public libraries in the United States are inadequate, understafred, housed in outmoded buildings, lack sufficient books and in general do not meet the needs of their communities.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- There is probably more lobbying going on at the near-by country clubs than in the corridors of the Capitol. To that extent lobbyists have been driven out in the open by the compulsory registration provision in last year's Congressional reorganization act.

SANTIAGO, Chile -- Now that Santiago is only a day and a half by air from Miami, the southern Chilean and Argentine area known as "The American Switzerland" is opening up as an attractive vacation choice for United States travelers, especially winter sports fans.
PHILADELPHIA, May 31 -- The Rev. Dr. Paul Zeller Strodach, Lutheran clergyman, author and editor, died last night in Eastern, Pa., at the age of 71.
OAKLAND, Calif., May 31 (AP) -- California's Bears swept to a double victory over Wisconsin's Badgers in their rowing regatta today on the Oakland Estuary.

Savings bankers and other mortgage lenders, blocked in their efforts to complete lending arrangements on certain new housing as a result of inability to obtain gas heating as specified under contract, have joined with the Veterans Administration in pressing for administrative relief, it was learned yesterday.

THIS novel is the moving account of Father Garces who, in the Seventeen Seventies, carried the word of God to the Indian tribes living in the wild and little-traveled lands belonging to Spain in the New World. The father's great dream is to have a church built on the majestic hill overlooking the mighty rivers in the land of the Yumas.

No modern writer has surpassed Kipling in technical skill. He had at his command all the resources of the language. His feeling for words was keenly sensitive and he could extract from them all that they had to give.

Dormant all through the war period, the issue of "fair trade" pricing came into prominence last week with the announcement that the Government is undertaking a broad-scale study of the fair trade laws now on the statute books of all but three of the forty-eight states and the District of Columbia.

A proposal to combine trucking and shipping interests of the port in a drive to speed up cargo and minimize costly trucking delays on the waterfront will be considered this week by shipping representatives, it was reported yesterday.

BOSTON, May 31 -- Here, in what for some years has been the world's biggest wool market, the Senate-approved measure permitting the Government to increase the import tax on wool is under bitter attack. Brokers assert that they will be driven out of business, and manufacturers insist that their industry will be threatened, if the measure becomes law.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 31 -- The largest cyclotron in the world, together with an atomic pile of undisclosed dimensions and characteristics, will be installed in the Brookhaven National Laboratory, which is now being established by the United States Atomic Energy Commission at Camp Upton, Long Island.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Official circles today gave it as their opinion that it woud be difficult to take effective counter-measures against the extension of the iron curtain to Hungary through Russia's apparent plan to dominate the Hungarian Government and control its army.

New York City's 240 miles of subways and Els operate under control of the Board of Transportation -- an autonomous body. The board's three members are appointed by the Mayor, but may be removed only after a hearing on charges of inefficiency or misconduct.

IN the nineteenth century it was Europeans who described the United States; though no other nation was ever subjected to so overwhelming a literary barrage, the description was rarely comprehensive and only occasionally understanding.

THE old problem of the window box becomes pressing as the pansies set out optimistically in full bloom last April begin to fade. A new group of plants is needed for summer color and since these are expected to look well until frost strikes, thought should be given to their selection and environment.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Wage negotiations covering the bulk of the soft coal industry collapsed today with the United Mine Workers and the operators far apart on money issues.

AN experiment unique in the operation and management of commercial airports finally got under way in the metropolitan area at midnight last night when the Port of New York Authority took over New York City's three major airfields.

NOVA -- A "new" star, or nova, has been spotted in the constellation Sagittarius, the archer, by two Mount Wilson Observatory astronomers, Cora Burwell and William Miller. "Nova Sagittaril," as astronomers term the discovery, has increased sharply in brightness, but it is still too faint to be seen with the naked eye.

ROBERT J. KUHN, a radio writer before he turned to fiction, has written first novel in a technique borrowed from the air waves. Flashbacks alternate with the interior monologues of his two principal characters, and for background music there is "Kerry Dance," which swells and fades according to the intensity of the emotions described.

BRIG. GEN. EVANS F. CARLSON: On May 28, at Portland, Ore., age 51. An Army officer in World War I and a Marine officer in World War II. Led the famed "Carlson's Raiders," who made military history in the war against Japan. After the war he became national vice chairman of the Progressive Citizens of America, cochairman with Paul Robeson of the Committee to Win the Peace and a member of the American Veterans Committee.

BOSTON, May 31 -- A masterful pitching performance by young Ralph Branca salvaged the final battle of the three-game series here today as the Dodgers beat the Braves, 5 -- 0, before 23,275 paying fans. This success sent the Brooks back home in a much better frame of mind to meet the Cardinals tomorrow.

AKRON, Ohio, May 31 (AP) -- A general reduction in the retail list of prices for passenger car tires and tubes manfactured by the B.F. Goodrich Company was announced tonight by James J. Newman, vice president, who acknowledged the cooperation of retailers of Goodrich tires in sharing with the company "a substantial reduction in profit."

PATHOLOGY is never easy reading. The scientific account of disease is too dispassionately grim for many but the specialists. This small book, written in a clear and cool if somewhat academic style, is an account of the pathology of society.

ROME, May 31 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi this evening announced the names of fifteen of the seventeen members of the first Italian post-war Cabinet from which Socialists and Communists have been excluded.
The Westminster Kennel Club yesterday announced modification if its regulations to permit Canadian -owned dogs to enter the Westminster show without first qualifying in the United States.

The continued leadership of New York City as a commercial center is enhanced by the coordination of the city's existing and projected major air and motor transportation facilities under the administration, of the Port of New York Authority, in the opinion of S. Earl Honig, real estate man.
LONDON, May 31 (AP) -- France and Czechoslovakia won their way to a semi-finals conflict in the European Zone Davis Cup competition today with victories over Monaco and New Zealand.

MODERN houses do not as a rule look expensive. But the fact is that most of the modern houses you have seen, either in the flesh or on paper, cost a good deal to build. One reason is that the majority of them were custom designed for people who could afford to be adventurous and didn't have to worry too much about their budgets.

CINCINNATI, May 31 -- Representatives of the Protestant and Catholic faiths joined more than 500 Reform Jewish leaders from a score of States at a testimonial dinner at the Netherlands Plaza Hotel here in honor or Dr. Julian Morgenstern, who is retiring as president of Hebrew Union College.

Short-selling, long a controversial method of operating in the stock market, so far as the public is concerned, was under fire again last week after publication of the highest short position on the New York Stock Exchange since December, 1945.

HARLEM is in a confident, even optimistic, mood these days. Removal of the "For Whites Only" sign from many jobs has opened new horizons to the Negro and choked off his loudest complaints. The man in the street hopes "the good times will roll forever," yet, as he counts his wartime gains, his optimism is tinged with anxiety.

STARTING as an amateur diversion during the height of the miniature camera's popularity in the Thirties and now offered as a professional service by portrait studios, candid wedding photography remains in spirit a characteristic amateur field.

HANGING in one corner of J. Arthur Rank's suite in a New York hotel is a map of the world with tiny cards pinned on every continent but Asia. At first glance it brings to mind the maps in an army headquarters during a war. Like them, it shows the progress of a campaign, each card marking where Rank motion picture forces have captured a foothold.

We are still besieged by "quaint," "hilarious," and "delightfully mad" literary tintypes of Grandpa, Grandma, their sisters, cousins and aunts who seem inevitably non compos mentis, amusingly or otherwise.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 31 -- In a neck-and-neck race throughout the length of the two-mile course on Lake Cayuga, Navy's varsity eight shot home the winner over Cornell by a scant few feet today in the final big sprint regatta of the Eastern college rowing season.

Stirred by hazardous conditions at congested "spoke-wheel" crossings in Greenwich Village, civic, religious and patriotic organizations will meet Tuesday to plan a comprehensive drive to increase pedestrian safety.
BERLIN, May 31 -- Reports from German sources reveal a surprisingly prompt reaction in the Berlin black market to the ban on shipment of cigarettes to individuals here.

Just how solid was the recovery of last week in the stock market still remains in the realm of speculation and dependent to a great extent on the length of time necessary for business and industry to pass through their period of readjustment. Although the run-up in prices of securities on Wednesday was the sharpest of the year to date, trading remained predominately professional, with a further lack of public participation.
STANTON, Del., May 31 (AP) -- Harry LaMontagne's Larky Day, an invader from New York, was an easy winner today of the tenth Brandywine Handicap at Delaware Park.

Brady, was a feeling of optimism. Can it be, I pondered, that those in charge of our most exciting dramatic medium are at long last concentrating on quality rather than quantity production?

This is the big week of the season in lacrosse. Fans will assemble in Baltimore for the national open championship and the annual North-South, game, which will be played Wednesday and Friday nights, respectively, at Homewood Field on the campus of Johns Hopkins University.

WHILE: there is hardly a garden in America that does not contain some tall bearded iris, very few indeed have these flowers growing to the best advantage. Retail trade here was active last week as customers bought seasonal and Decoration Day needs. Department store volume was estimated as approximating 15 per cent over the like week of last year.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- Tracy S. Voorhees, who administers food distribution for the War Department in occupied countries, said tonight that communism would "take over" if the United States quit feeding the Germans.
Columbia University's annual baccalaureate service in St. Paul's Chapel at 4 P.M. today will open a three-day program of the university's 193rd commencement.

IN each generation parents repeat the questions heard, over and over, by doctors, nurses, teachers and other specialists in child care. "What is normal height, weight, for my child?" "When do babies walk?" "Everything is 'No.' What can I do about it?"
PARIS, May 31 -- Charles de Gaulle who established the system of rigidly planned economy in France, a system that now is under fire, urged today a return to a regime of economic liberty.
The American Merchant Marine will mark the 100th anniversary of scheduled transatlantic service by American steamships today, the Steamship Historical Society of America announced yesterday.

Cotton dress departments last week did very well, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Sportswear sales were spurred by week-end holiday buying with tots' and girls' sportswear moving briskly.

Industrial leaders in every branch of industry are seriously studying recommendations for "industrial war games," which were suggested as a practical method for testing the success of industrial mobilization, in a keynote address by Gen. The first postwar International Exposition of Textiles will open to the trade tomorrow at 2 P.M. for a week's showing in the Grand Central Palace. Displayed will be the latest advancements in fabrics, accessories, equipment and techniques from this country and abroad.

PERFORCE, and-owing to circumstances over which it had not entire control, the Philharmonic-Symphony Society returns next season, temporarily, to a system of "guest" or "virtuoso" conductors. This is not the best system for a symphonic organization, which develops in the most systematic and artistic manner when there is one musician and orchestra builder of high competency at its head.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 31 -- A world festival of films and fine arts in which motion-picture producing firms of nineteen nations will take part, will open here tomorrow. It is expected to last through June.

Unfinished dwelling units and dormitory accommodations for 1,350 prospective student veterans at educational institutions in the New York area may not be ready for the fall classes unless the Federal Public Housing Authority gets additional funds soon to complete its program.

IT is understood that the New York City Opera Company will add Mozart's "Don Giovanni" to its repertoire this fall. If it does, Enzo Mascherini will sing the Don. Another work the company may revive is Massenet's "Werther," which was last done at the Metropolitan in the 1909-10 season, and certainly hasn't been given here many times since.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica -- This wee republic differs from other middle-American lands in four ways: Orchids, ox carts, climate and freedom. Outside the Union Club in San Jose, Pablo Vega peddles orchids -- thirty-two lavender beauties for 35 cents.

EARLY summer group shows make up a large part of the gallery attractions at this time of year. Several of them are reviewed elsewhere on this page. Another has just opened at the Kraushaar Gallery, including work by both well-known artists and, relatively, newcomers.

FOR once in his life the Hoosier farmer can put up with his seasonal aggravations without fretting too much about the mortgage. This has been one of the latest springs that ever sent a shiver up a farmer's back; and on top of that, the city people tried to put him on "Daylight Wasting Time," as he calls it.

THERE has been a grave shaking of heads both by English and American motion-picture executives in recent days over the latest manifestation of anti-American sentiment expressed by the British Film Producers Association.

BAD TOELZ, Germany, May 31 (AP) -- The wives of former Hitler Youth Leader Baldur von Schirach and Minister of Economics Walther Funk, both convicted war criminals, were jailed here tonight for trial as alleged major Nazi offenders.

SHANKS VILLAGE, N.Y., May 31 -- The same ingenuity that produced wartime overseas theatrical productions under seemingly impossible conditions enabled the veterans of this Federal Public Housing Authority installation to put on a successful presentation of "You Can't Take It With You" last night.

A DAY of genuine anticipation for most gardeners is when young lettuce plants may be thinned out to use as the basis of the salad bowl. Yet, no matter how many varieties of lettuce are grown, other greens can be planted to add zest and flavor to the daily diet.

Editor New York Times Book Review: I HAVE just read Harvey Breits article on the financial aspects of book publishing in the May 18 TIMES. The little table of coats it contains is startling -- and illuminating. Exactly half of the gross price of the book goes to the dealer for commissions and for shipping.
THIS is one of the best times of the year to visit near-by parks and public display gardens. Lilacs, iris and peonies are the featured flowers this week, with many other blooms worth seeing.

Probably never before in American yachting has the spirit of mutual understanding between pleasure boat skippers and the efficient but stern arm of the Federal Government known as the United States Coast Guard been so pleasant and amicable.

DETROIT, May 31 (AP) -- Frank (Stubby) Overmire, Detroit's stocky little lefthander, fooled everybody but Stan Spence today as the Tigers beat the Washington Senators, 5 to 4, despite Spence's pair of two-run homers.
LOS ANGELES, May 31 -- California is adopting for the fiscal year starting in July the largest budget in its history, nearly double its previous one.

With rain washing out the inaugural card last Sunday, outdoor polo in this sector will make another attempt to get off the mark today. Feature of the program will be a high-goal match opening the tenth season at Bostwick Field, Old Westbury, L.I., where Bostwick Field rides against Westbury.

THIS is an odd story with the makings of a parable. Ria, whose cosmopolitan American parents brought her up in Japan and in Germany, lost her husband in the war. Living alone in a seaside hotel, she has developed an unaccountable numbness and pain in her right hand -- not organic, says the doctor, nor a psychosis that can be traced to her husband's death.

A revised list of the passengers and crew members killed in the crash of the Eastern Air Lines DC-4 in Maryland on Friday follows, with street addresses given for the New York metropolitan area: PASSENGERS ARONS, ALEXANDER, 1133 Broadway.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 31 (AP) -- Mrs. Willie Turnesa walked into the White Plains ReporterDispatch Building today on another mission -- just as The Associated Press teletype machines carried the news of her husband's victory in the British amateur golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (U.P.) -- Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., chairman, said today that the House Education and Labor Committee would investigate about 250 cases of alleged union racketeering this summer.

The Communist coup d'etat in Hungary is now apparently complete except for the rigged elections in September called to confirm it. From now on Hungary takes her place with Poland, Rumania, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia as a police state and a Russian satellite.
Three Washington officials of the Civil Aeronautics Board were in New York last Friday morning to investigate an aircraft accident.

MADRID, May 31 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franoo today is riding the crest of a wave of unprecedented confusion among his opponents. He is stronger than at any time in the last year, at least.

MONTREAT, N.C., May 31 (AP) -- An official group of the Presbyterian Church in the United States (Southern) called on the church's general assembly today to take a positive stand on the civil rights of minority groups throughout the country.

YOUNG Jack Paar has decided to give radio another chance. Setting aside his declaration of only last January, that "if this is radio, it never should have been invented," he will endeavor to keep Jack Benny's fans laughing while that gentleman vacations, beginning tonight in the familiar 7 o'clock spot on WNBC's hook-up.

CLEVELAND, May 31 -- That painful experience which must come to all sports heroes if they remain active long enough, came to Bob Feller today. A ladies' day crowd of 41,507 saw the Yankees batter him in the worst beating he has suffered this season as they trounced the Indians, 8 to 4.

A panel of forty architects, retail executives, engineers and other experts will participate in the conference on store modernization to take place concurrently with the store modernization show at Grand Central Palace July 7 to 12, according to John W.H. Evans, managing director.
LONDON, May 31 (AP) -- Unhappy London sports writers mourned for British golf today as they reported how two Americans fought it out for the British amateur championship.

DETROIT, May 31 (U.P.) -- Prospective passenger car and truck buyers have been handed another double-barreled piece of bad news. Alfred P. Sloan, chairman of General Motors Corporation, world's biggest producer, says auto production will remain below capacity for another year and there is no price relief in sight.

The citizenry of New Jersey will go to the polls on Tuesday to pass on a constitutional convention, to set in motion the machinery for drafting a new State constitution. Final approval or rejection of the new proposals for constitutional revision will be for the voter to decide at the general election in November.

Commodore F.A. Rudolph of the New Rochelle Y.C. and his board of governors presided at the official club opening yesterday afternoon on Harrison Island, with a dinner party following the cocktail assembly. Pending the completion of the club's new shore station at the City Boat House, launch service is being maintained to Harrison Island from the old station adjoining the New Rochelle Rowing Club.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- As Henry Wallace stumps the country in advocacy of his program for altering the course of American foreign policy, he is leaving in his wake a recrudescence of that familiar form of political rebellion that seeks its ends through the formation of a third party.

The Pirates, with Hank Greenberg on first base and Sing Crosby in a box seat as their major attractions, yesterday made their first appearance of the season at the Polo Grounds. Though their stay called for only a single encounter there was enough action crowded into it to shatter the nerves of the hardiest in a gathering of 32,905 that also included Governor Thomas E. Dewey.

To the Drama Editor: MANY of us in the theatre have for a long time been worried because it is economically impossible substantially to increase the number of cheaper seats for dramatic productions. It is all the more regrettable that most of the 200,000 high school students in the world's greatest theatrical center cannot afford to attend a play.

CHICAGO, May 31 (AP) -- Clear weather over the Southwestern winter wheat belt, where some harvesting is starting in early fields, caused fairly heavy selling pressure today in the bread-cereal market on the Board of Trade. Wheat dropped as much as 4 cents a bushel at times and other grains weakened.

THE month of May has passed into business history without duplicating the spectacular price break of May, 1920. The pressures on prices from the White House down have been heavier than they were twentyseven years ago so it is fair to assume that the underlying structure of the market has been stronger than it was after World War I.

Editor New York Times Book Review: HAVE you space for a word from Devil's Island? Mr. Russell Maloney's recent confession in your columns that his review of "Aurora Dawn" lacked Olympian calm and hacked away too much at the jacket blurb was a most generous gesture.

BETWEEN the United States and Soviet Russia political relations are obviously serious and possibly grave. But despite the bitterness apparent on every level, they are not dangerous now. Although the pure logic of our relations has pointed toward war for at least two years, war is impossible now and by no means inevitable eventually.

HANOVER, N.H., May 31 -- Teller (Red) Tellefsen checked Dartmouth with four hits While his Columbia team-mates pounded bespectacled Bill Gray for twelve earning a 6-2 Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League victory today.

WHEN a poor player makes a play that seems stupid there perhaps some reason to assume that the play is just as stupid as it seems. When a good player makes the same stupid-looking play it is well to pause and consider the chance that it was prompted by some insidious plot.

Administrators answerable for the finances of American cities were warned here last week of the financial implications of urban decentralization -- the "shrinking sickness" which, according to census studies, is visibly afflicting major centers of population.

Pittsburgh, Youngstown and Middle Western steel mills are being scared out of shipping flat cold-rolled products to their Eastern consumers by fear of future freight absorption costs which may run as high as $4 a ton or more if a new basing point is established at Sparrows Point, Md., steel warehouse executives here revealed yesterday in statements to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

TOKYO, May 31 -- Japan's first Christian Prime Minister, Tetsu Katayama, today all but succeeded in forming his cabinet. Late tonight fourteen chief posts had been filled and negotiations regarding three more were nearing conclusion.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 31 (AP) -- Bill Holland, 39-year-old runnerup in the Memorial Day 500-mile race at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, said today "it's the lousiest deal I ever got" as participants in the event, won by Mauri Rose of Chicago, prepared to cut a $132,000 prize melon.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 31 -- Puerto Ricans like other people yield to the lure of the United States as the Promised Land. But what distinguishes these islanders from other migrant groups is that the overwhelming majority -- at least 75 per cent -- over a period of years have been unable to adjust themselves to the new environment.

BECAUSE of the shortages of steel and copper, automobile manufacturers are turning to aluminum to solve some of the vital problems in the production of new cars. Surveys in dicate that this metal will be adopted more generally than ever before in the 1948 models and will "key up" outstanding improvements which have been forecast for next year.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The forces of righteousness scored a minor victory over their old enemy, John Barleycorn, when hearings were recently held before the Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee on the Capper Bill to outlaw the interstate transportation of liquor advertising.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 31 -- An unobliging wind dragged out the regatta of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club today in which another record of summer sailing was broken, although this season is only four sessions old. There were ninety-nine starting craft, which topped the all-time May mark.

TSINGTAO, China, May 31 -- Tsingtao is a paradox in United States-Chinese relations. Here, in China's finest anchorage and on Chinese shores, Admiral Charles M. Cooke's powerful United States Seventh Fleet guards the western extension of American Pacific power.

Four talented young Negro musicians were presented late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall by the National Negro Congress. The event was called an ''Open Hearing" and it was the first of a series of such joint recitals that is to be sponsored by the music chapter of the congress's newly formed cultural division.

A SERIES of demonstrations in portrait lighting will be a feature of the Westchester Hobby Show, to be held at the County Center, White Plains, June 5-9. Speakers will be Mrs. Helene Sanders of the School of Modern Photography; John Muller of Engel-Muller Studio; Don Bennett, technical adviser of ShappeWilkes, and leut. Col. James H. Glenn.

The three-day advertising clinic held last week at the Hotel New Yorker by Allied Stores Corporation is the first in a permanent series of such activities to be integrated into the organization's intensive training program for advertising personnel, Russell A. Brown, vice president in charge of sales promotion disclosed in an interview.

WASHINGTON. TODAY in the United States Senate, where Republican Presidential dark horses approximate a herd, everyone is intently watching the vigorously competitive stride of two leaders. Robert Alphonso Taft of Ohio, son of a President, and Arthur Hendrick Vandenberg of Michigan, only child of a harnessmaker, are manifestly out in front.

Planning to function along the same lines it operated under last year with four-team Eastern and Western divisions, the American Football League will play a fortygame schedule this year, according to the 1947 program released yesterday by Joe Rosentover, president of the circuit.

AN outstanding development of the week was the thirtyseventh annual convention of the American Federation of Arts, held here in New York on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. Many important, often pressing, issues were aired in panel discussions and open forums.

ESSEN, Germany, May 31 -- The separations program in the British zone is being sabotaged by the Germans to such an extent that the British intelligence has been put on the job of finding out where the equipment scheduled for delivery to the Allies is disappearing.

-- A SHY BIRD We buttonholed the Common Man last Friday while he was trying to slip around a corner and out of sight. He confessed, under pressure, that he was feeling pretty much like a suspicious character these days.

THE region of this book lies near the geographical center of the nation; its subject is, perhaps, as close to the national life. "Corn laid-by at Fourth of July, farmer, fly high" -- school children used to sing in a happy count-out song sixty years ago.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31 -- Franklin Field's venerable cinders were churned into powdery dust in a series of breath-taking performances today as New York University rode off all challengers to capture the team title in the seventy-first outdoor track and field championships of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A.

Completions of new homes this spring may exceed that of last year, according to figures compiled by the United States Savings and Loan League. Although complete figures to date are not yet available, the league says the data on hand warrants caution on writing off the current year as a loss in solving the housing shortage.

BOSTON, May 31 (AP) -- In the most thrilling finish of the meeting with noses separating the first three horses, H.T. Darling's West Fleet, 6 to 1, won the $10,000 added Plymouth Rock Handicap today before a closing-day crowd of 32,102 at Suffolk Downs.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee made public today a revised and final draft of a bill to provide for the "coordination for national security" of the armed forces and their related agencies.

EVANSTON, Ill., May 31 (AP) -- Illinois won its third straight Big Nine outdoor track title with an overwhelming total of 69 1/2 point today as Herb McKenley, the fleet Illinois flyer from the British West Indies, easily retained his 220 and 440 crowns.
ROME, May 31 -- Pope Pius today praised the work of the American Red Coss, which he said had won a deserved reputation for "its prompt and effective relief" in national calamities.

DURING the past season the most unusual program on the air undoubtedly has been "The Greatest Story Ever Told," which is offered at 6:30 Sundays on ABC and WJZ. Telling with dramatic and reverent simplicity the parables of the New Testament, it has been presented under commercial sponsorship yet has not had the slightest taint of commercialism.

WASHINGTON. IN the drafty, metallic war room that had been improvised on the after deck of the cruiser Augusta, the caged lights shivered under the concussion of our naval guns. It was cold that morning, -- June 6, 1944 -- and the blackout tarp over the thin steel door to the deck closeted the oily smell of our impregnated GI clothes.

NEW DELHI, India, May 31 -- The Viceroy, Viscount Mountbatten, conferred today with his political advisers prior to Monday's round-table meeting with Congress party and Moslem League and Sikh representatives. At that conference he will present to these Indian political leaders the British plan for India's partition should be fail to obtain their agreement on a compromise plan preserving the country's unity.

PITTSBURGH, May 31 -- Mrs. Harry G. Samson, chairman of the women's division of the Pittsburgh Council of Churches and for many years a civic leader here, died in her Mount Lebanon home last night. A private funeral was held at her home today.

JOSEF STALIN doodled all through the interview he gave Harold Stassen. David E. Lilienthal covered sheets of paper with penciled crosshatchings while the long debate over his confirmation as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission went on in Senate committed. Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg is an inveterate doodler. George Washington and Thomas Jefferson doodled.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 31 (AP) -- Harry Bridges, head of the Longshoremen's union of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, told an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing today that shipping companies were not justified in demanding higher rates on the grounds of high labor costs and waterfront work stoppages.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The social and economic needs of the middle class family in New York City in the period 1940 to 1947 is the subject of a study for which Marion R. Farren, consultant in the New York State Department of Social Welfare, received a fellowship today from the American Association of University Women.

CHICAGO, May 31 (AP) -- Fifth Army headquarters announced today that advanced students of the Reserve Officer Training Corps in the Fifth Army area would attend six weeks' summer training courses starting June 21.

VIENNA, May 31 -- Expectation of a break in the deadlock between the attitude of the western and the Soviet members of the Vienna Treaty Commission over the commission's functions, which was engendered at Thursday's meetings, was realized to some extent today.

MRS. FRIEDRICH and her friend Andrik, of this report, belonged to a small resistance group, called "Uncle Emil." Holding no political ambitions, the group started simply as a rescue squad and its members began their work in the fall of 1938 when the Nazis' drive against the Jews reached its feverishly insane climax.

WARREN, Ohio, May 31 (AP) -- Wally Harper of Detroit, United States champion in his class, maintained his reputation today following his clean sweep in two sections of the Warren Boat Club regatta, first major American Powerboat Association event of the season.

IN chatty style, Mr. Rolston describes many of the pitfalls, costly "extras," unethical practices on the part of some contractors and other headaches which may be encountered by the enthusiastic, inexperienced couple starting out to build a home for themselves.

FOR the last three years Dr. Dewhurst, economist for the Twentieth-Century Fund, has -- with the help of some twenty economists, statisticians, political scientists and sociologists -- been making an estimate of how much the United States can produce and whether it will be enough to satisfy the needs and reasonable desires of the American people.

Yesterday's announcement that negotiations between the United Mine Workers and the soft-coal operators of the North and South had been indefinitely suspended cast a familiar and ominous shadow over an industrial situation which is otherwise free from the threat of mass strikes.

THE pleasures and attitudes of so-called high society command a disproportionately large amount of attention in comparison to the numbers of its members. Movie stars emulate these worthies; tabloids chronicle them in detail; novelists (for one reason or other) employ them as adornments for their pages.

ARTHUR MAHONEY and Thalia Mara have announced more detailed plans for the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival (near Lee, Mass.) and its associated school, which they are to direct this summer for the first time.

Two more occupants of the United Air Lines DC-4 that crashed and burned at La Guardia Field Thursday night died in hospitals yesterday. This brought the disaster toll to forty-one dead. Of the seven injured survivors, two were still in critical condition last night while the others were reported showing improvement.

Estimates have recently appeared which indicated that corporate profits for 1947 would exceed by a significant margin the record volume attained in the last quarter of 1946. The demands for large wage increases were in part based upon this anticipated development. The inaccuracy of these forecasts is now indicated by the quarterly compilation of profits prepared by the National City Bank.

AUTHORS, as far as Hollywood is concerned, come in two categories, with one notable exception. There are those who want no part of Hollywood and those who want Hollywood's eye teeth. The notable exception is Rita Weiman.

WHEN a British general, speaking recently of Jewish extremists in Palestine, said his forces would have to "winkle them out," he was drawing upon a great fund of British slang developed during the war and now traveling across the Atlantic as a sort of reverse lend-lease.

The Cunard liner Mauretania, reopening for the first time since the war the company's service to Cherbourg, sailed yesterday with 1,152 passengers and a cargo that included British stamp collections and displays brought here for public exhibition.

At the Manhattan General Hospital, New York, Dr. Paluel J. Flagg has arranged an exhibit which includes a remarkable apparatus that ought to save many a patient from death by asphyxiation when oxygen cannot be administered directly by way of the lungs. The apparatus is the invention of Dr. John R. Guarino, Brooklyn, who developed it with the engineering aid of his brothers Frank, Vincent and Louis.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 31 -- A fresco said by experts to be unique because it portrays the Holy Family in reversed order has been unearthed here by a young Turkish archaeologist.

SEA GIRT, N.J., May 31 -- Seven competitors in the Dewar match, shot at 50 and 100 yards, scored possible totals of 400 in the smallbore rifle tournament. Ransford D. Triggs, Madison, N.J., who had 33 of his 40 shots in the inner circle of the bullseye, won the match from Arthur E. Cook, Washington, who made 32 inner circle shots.

Britain's Labor party is made up of many political elements. These include the Fabian Socialists; left-wing intellectuals of more radical leanings than the Fabians; independents, middle -class shopkeepers and clerical workers; and the 7,800,000 members of the British trades unions, from whose ranks came Foreign Minister Ernest Bevin.

PORTLAND, Me., Construction of a scientifically conceived express highway has begun in Maine. If it is completed as planned in November, it will be the first superhighway finished since the war, and people of the State say that it will probably serve as a model for roadbuilders in other States.

PARIS, May 31 -- Labor troubles in France, which are only beginning place workers and the Government before this dilemma: The French may improve the lot of the admittedly badly paid wage-earners by increasing their pay.

As revised by the Senate Finance Committee and passed by the Senate on May 28, the 1947 Tax Reduction Bill (H.R.1), if enacted into law, will result in a reduction for 1947 of approximately one-half of the reduction provided for in the House bill.

Ever so often the fear of an oil shortage developing in the United States gains prominent mention. At present, such a campaign is in full swing. It stems from the unprecedented demand for oil products, particularly light fuel oil for heating homes and oil for operating the Diesel locomotives that are replacing steadily the steam engines on the railroads.

CHICAGO, May 31 -- The Air Line Pilots Association, AFL, is assigning investigators from its engineering and air safety departments to study the airliner accidents in New York and Maryland, and the findings will be made public "regardless of whose toes are stepped on," David L. Behncke, president of the association, said today.

SINGAPORE, May 31 -- The United Planting Association of Malaya has recommended to its member firms a 20 per cent reduction in wages paid to contract rubber tappers as a means of countering the last month's 30 per cent drop in rubber prices here.

Leonard D'Attolico, a 26-year-old former Army paratrooper equipped with a 16-mm, motion-picture camera, dropped out of the blue in a parachute yesterday afternoon from a two-seater plane over the Times Square area. He landed in the backyard of a tenement at 447 West Forty-fourth Street.

PHOENIX, Ariz., May 31 -- Several months ago E.G. Harwood, operator of extensive mining properties in northern Arizona, was inspecting his property at Hack's Canyon, a tributary to the famed Grand Canyon, when he picked up a rock containing a canary-yellow mineral he did not recognize.

Adhering to the plan it put into effect in its inaugural season last year, the All-America Football Conference will play a fifty-sixgame schedule in 1947, with the eight member clubs of the circuit meeting each other twice on a home-and-home basis.

BERLIN, May 31 -- The most publicized potential heir to Adolf Hitler's bloody mantle appears to be on his way out of the Bavarian State Government in view of developments of the past week. He is Alfred Loritz, chief of the Special [denazification] Ministry, whose conduct in office has lost him the confidence and gained him the profound distrust of everyone but the members of his own fractional party.

THERE is a whole generation to whom Blandings Castle is as real as Times Square, so many of P.G. Wodehouse's tales having unfolded against that familiar background of turret, terrace and pigsty (you will recall that the apple of Lord Emsworth's somewhat myopic eye is Empress of Blandings, his prize sow).
KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 31 -- Kansas City's election fraud inquiry awakened the Midwest this week to realization that the ghost of Tom J. Pendergast may stalk through the 1948 Presidential election.
HOLLYWOOD. CEDRIC GIBBONS and his colleagues in the MetroGoldwyn-Mayer art department have been regarded as specialists in earthquakes ever since the production of "San Francisco" in 1936.

BUFFALO, May 31 -- The United Nations was charged today with discriminating against women in refusing them "a voice in the making of peace." Miss Sally Butler, president of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, Inc. was the accuser.
SHANGHAI, May 31 (AP) -- A riot in Canton, in which five students were reported killed and scores were injured or missing, featured China's deepening crisis today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 31 -- A state of police alarm has been declared in the Swedish south coast city of Malmoe following disturbances tantamount to race riots between white and Negro crews of two American freighters, it was disclosed here today.
Adrienne Ames, radio commentator and former screen star, died yesterday in her home at 25 Sutton Place South. She was 39 years old.

WHAT with teachers everywhere striking about wages, the plot of this would-be psycho-thriller reads a little more credibly than it ordinarily might. It tells the sad plight of Sam and Catharine Forester, a badly paid couple in a Midwestern university town.

At 2:06 P.M. on last Thursday President Truman returned to Washington after an eleven-day emergency stay at the bedside of his critically ill mother in Missouri. He told a Cabinet member who greeted him, "I never spent such a week in my life."

A LONG AWAITED day turns up this week for show business. Come Tuesday, interested parties will tell Congressional representatives why the 20 per cent tax on theatre tickets should be eliminated or at least reduced.

LOS ANGELES. ONE of the several enigmas of the Atomic Age, the near-absence of legitimate theatre in this metropolis of 4,000,000 -- including the largest concentration of actors in, presumably, the universe -- is about to undergo an exploratory operation.

THE current mass of literature about Alaska is principally by men who are poking and prodding at the Territory's colonial economy, at its makeshift government, at its exploitation by absentee canning and mining interests.

BERLIN, May 31 -- The Allied Control Council for Germany has failed to carry out the solemn agreement of the Big Four that they would fix the new reduced strengths of occupation troops by June 1 -- tomorrow. The decision had been regarded as a signal victory for United States policy at the final session of the Moscow Conference of the Council of Foreign Ministers.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that it had authorized purchase of $744,000 of airport equipment in preparation for its assumption of responsibility for the operation and development of three city airports beginning at 12:01 o'clock this morning.

Because New York is a city of specialists, Jerrry, a 8-month-old tiger-striped mele kitten, found himself in a tight spot for eight hours yesterday at 107 East Seventeenth Street. The scene was the Kitchen of the sixth-floor apartment Occupied by Jerry's owner.

BAINBRIDGE, Md., May 31 -- Government investigators tonight sifted evidence indicating that a damaged or defective tail structure sent a four-motored Eastern Air Lines plane into a dive that carried fifty-three persons to death in a Maryland swamp.

LET me say it right off: Mrs. Brooks Atkinson's account of Soviet Russia, based on a tenmonth stay there, is unique. The author, it becomes instantly apparent, is neither Russophile nor Russophobe, and approaches her awesome materials much in the way that an efficient and rather urbane housewife approaches naughty children -- she will tolerate no nonsense.

AFTER nearly one year of postwar television service the British Broadcasting Corporation has decided that television has reached the point where it is worthy of its own critic and, accordingly, has added Mr. Harold Hobson to its staff of independent critics to give his impressions of television programs available to British viewers.

"WHEN the Japanese landed on Attu, at the extreme tip of Alaska, they accomplished one good purpose. They turned the spotlight of publicity on Alaska." So writes J.B. Caldwell in a foreword to "Introducing Alaska," and the observation is so true that, in the wake of so many more successful volumes on the subject, his book focuses little more than a two-cell beam on the Territory of Alaska.
CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, May 31 -- Wee Willie Turnesa won the British amateur golf championship today with his mother-in-law's putter and an educated wedge.
THE STATUE of Liberty has a thirty-five-foot waist and weighs a half million pounds, but its "skin" is only 3/32 of an inch thick.

PARIS, May 31 (U.P.) -- The French Government said today that it has refused to allow an Egyptian relief ship to enter the port of Tunis because of "the manifestly political character" of the relief mission.

TRENTON, N.J., May 31 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll approved today twenty-seven measures passed by the legislature in its closing hours, including the Mathis measure forbidding the placing of children under 16 year old in prisons, jails, lock-ups or police stations for juvenile delinquency offenses.

BROOKHAVEN, L.I., May 31 -- A family of four was burned to death at 4:30 A.M. today when fire believed to have been caused by a kerosene hot-water heater destroyed a two-story, eight-room frame dwelling on Beaver Dam Road here.

TOBACCO, which does so little to enrich our radio art, is, curiously, one of the most literary of crops. Through the years we have had excellent novels of the Georgia and Connecticut tobacco country. Now upper New York State adds its bit in the form of an honest and richly endowed first novel by Jane Cuddeback, who grew op on a tobacco farm near Syracuse.

LEON BLOY died during the first World War, an extraordinary and powerfully influential French writer, and an anguished prophet who saw in that inaugural cataclysm a confirmation of the violent cries he had constantly sent forth from the wilderness of poverty and disregard -- a wilderness in which he had suffered during a harassed creative period of forty years.

EXETER, N.H., May 31 -- Making the first progress report on the campaign to raise $5,000,000 for Phillips Exeter Academy, Joseph T. Walker Jr., '14, national chairman, reported at the annual Alumni Day exercises here today that the fund had reached $972,389.27.

The spotlight of the news, swinging restlessly about the earth in these confused days, reveals trouble wherever in two continents it comes to a focus. Disorder in Palestine and Greece, an antidemocratic conspiracy in Hungary, ominous struggles for power in Italy and France, paralysis in divided Germany, hunger cutting production and lack of production creating hunger -- such is the picture in the West.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- President Truman will deliver a 20-minute address in Kansas City on Saturday, June 7, return to Washington on Sunday, and then depart for a good-will visit to Canada on Monday, the White House announced today.

To further a program for promoting American concepts of democracy, the Near East College Association is seeking to raise $15,000,000 to maintain and expand facilities of eight American colleges in six countries of the Near East.

JERUSALEM, May 31 -- For the first time since the start or organized large-scale unauthorized Jewish immigration to Palestine a shipload of Sephardic Jews from Arab territories reached Palestine today. They came from French North Africa.

NANKING, May 31 (AP) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek conferred with his generals at Mukden, Manchuria, today. Government sources said he was discussing the intensified Red offensive in Manchuria. His visit may herald new Government military action.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 31 (AP) -- Wheatley Stable's Keynote was a driving winner of the Mermaid Handicap at six furlongs for fillies and mares today.

Reporting twenty-five transactions by his office in the last few months, Harold D. Nixon, president of Harold Nixon, Inc., Hackensack realty firm, finds a good demand for industrial property in Bergen County, N.J. The sales include sites for improvement with factories.

SWEDEN -- American Students The Universities of Stockholm and Gothenburg, Sweden, will sponsor a series of special courses for American students from September, 1947, to June, 1948. Although the courses have been designed particularly for veterans under the GI Bill of Rights, they also are open to other qualified applicants.

THIS is a collection of quotations in the style of "The Practical Cogitator," but conceived in a different spirit. Messrs, Greenslet and Curtis presented the most diverse opinions on the most diverse subjects, the only common factor being intelligence; Mr. Zuckerman, aiming not at intellectual pleasure but at moral conviction, sticks to one subject and presents only two points of view, pro and con.

Editor New York Times Book Review: IN his concluding chapter, Professor Corwin said that "the Constitution of peacetime and the Constitution of wartime have become, thanks to the New Deal, very much the same"; he then tried to justify that comment.

LONDON, May 31 -- Annual political party conferences in Britain are like a battlefield where policies are fought out and antagonists face each other in hard fights. Then they close ranks against other parties and the world in general.

PART of Paul Mommer's recent paintings, at the Ferargil, constitute a vivid first-hand report on his recent revisiting of his childhood home and adjacent areas -- Lorraine, the Saar, Luxembourg, with a further excursion to Slovakia.

AUSTRIA, once second only to Switzerland in the European touring picture, can again welcome American visitors beginning July 1. Recognizing the essential part played by travel business in the country's economic regeneration, the Government has authorized the reopening at two resorts, according to the local Austrian State Tourist Department office.

GOSHEN, N.Y. May 31 -- By way of carrying on a noteworthy string of successes, Mrs. Edward P. Alker of Great Neck today placed a new winner of beat-inshow honors in the ring at the twenty-ninth fixture of the Tuxedo Kennel Club.
READING through Frost's new book one stops for a long tune at "Directive." Back out of all this now too much for us, Back in a time made simple by the loss Of detail, burned, dissolved,

In a statement made public last week the Greater New York CIO Council reported that unemployment in New York had increased 50 per cent in sixty days. The city's jobless total 450,000 compared with 300,000 only two months ago.

LONDON, May 31 (Reuters) -- Liverpool jumped to the top of the English Football League's first division today with a 2-1 victory over the Wolverhampton Wanderers, and postponed settlement of the close championship struggle until June 14.

THIS is Mr. Bromfield's first fiction to stray between book covers in three years -- and the fact is no cause for rejoicing. Consisting of two mag-minded one-shots and a short story from the same mill, it will seem an empty exercise to the reader who remembers this author as he was (much more than three years ago).

A remarkable example of what appears to be practical and effective labor-management cooperation attracted attention last week in the first graduating exercises of the Labor-Management School conducted jointly by Botany Mills, Inc., and the Textile Workers' Union of America, CIO, at Passaic, N.J.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, May 31 -- A new Hungarian Cabinet, beaded by Lajos Dinnyes of the Small Landholders party as Premier, was installed tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- President Truman signed into law today the bill making $350,000,000 available for the relief of war-torn countries in Europe and Asia.
BERLIN, May 31 -- The United States Military Government announced today a tenfold increase, starting tomorrow, in the power of its radio station in Berlin.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., May 31 -- In their second quarter century of political enfranchisement, women must become proficient in politics or the consequences will be dire Mary Donton, chairman of the New York State Workmen's Compensation Board, said here today.
