OTTAWA, May 31 -- Last Tuesday's vote on the budget, which gave the Government a dear majority of nineteen over all opposition parties combined has put an end to any hopes that may have been entertained of a general election before the normal time, three years hence.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., May 31 -- The success of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development will find reflection in the lives of all of us for many years to come, for without a dynamic world economy the United States cannot hope to maintain its present high standard of living, E. Fleetwood Dunstan, the bank's director of marketing, declared today at the annual convention of the Virginia Bankers Association.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Having read the recent letters of Dr. Otto Nathan and of Dean Albert B. Newman regarding the merits and demerits of Mr. Hoover's report on Germany, we should like to express our point of view.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Transmission of the State Department's "Voice of America" broadcasts by way of Algiers ended today. The final program included statements by Henri Bonnet, French Ambassador to the United States, and William Benton, Assistant Secretary of State.

Behind the effective five-hit pitching of Jerry Brown, the St. John's University baseball team closed its season yesterday by halting Manhattan College, 5 -- 2, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Conference battle at Dexter Park, Woodhaven.

In an attempt to show his employer that he was a super-salesman, William Weingard, 43-yearold manager of a flower shop on Lexington Avenue, marked as sales, but threw away $7,969 worth of orchids, long-stemmed roses and other expensive blooms, according to testimony yesterday in the Felony Court.

Behind the effective five-hit pitching of Jerry Brown, the St. John's University baseball team closed its season yesterday by halting Manhattan College, 5 -- 2, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Conference battle at Dexter Park, Woodhaven.

In an attempt to show his employer that he was a super-salesman, William Weingard, 43-yearold manager of a flower shop on Lexington Avenue, marked as sales, but threw away $7,969 worth of orchids, long-stemmed roses and other expensive blooms, according to testimony yesterday in the Felony Court.

THOUSANDS of young Americans once lived in mortal terror of the school report card. For them Report Card Day was pretty much a preview of Judgment Day at both ends of the route between school and home. Nobody knows how many child runaways dated from that day, and still sadder, how many failures in life.
BERLIN, May 31 -- Military Government officials handling the democratic reconstruction of the trade unions in the American and British zones are faced with a new and important problem.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 1 -- The American Jewish Committee called on the United Nations Committee of Inquiry on Palestine today to recommend a United Nations trusteeship for the Holy Land.

More than $729,000 worth of surplus ball bearings, about $400,000 worth of unused spyglasses and telescopes and $1,300,000 worth of construction, farm and mining machinery are included in current regional programs of 156 scheduled sales valued at $140,323,000 in acquisition cost, Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director of the War Assets Administration, revealed in an announcement over the week-end.

JERUSALEM, June 1 -- Dr. Hussein Khalidi, secretary of the Palestine Arab Higher Committee, said today that the "tendency" of the organization was to boycott the hearings of the United Nations Committee of Inquiry on Palestine.

LOS ANGELES, June 1 (U.P.) -- The famed Palestine Hapoels, on a good-will tour of America, today forfeited a soccer game to the Los Angeles All-Stars, 2 to 1, by walking off the field in protest on a referee's decision.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Legal opinion in Government and labor circles was divided tonight on whether unions were no longer required to file 30-day strike notices before participating in walk-outs.

The summer theatres, where disciples of Thespis and Thalia perfect their art and vacationists seek entertainment, soon will be operating in earnest. Tonight the Music Hall Theatre in Clinton, N.J., will open its doors under the management of Eddie Rich with "The Glass Menagerie" as the initial bill.

BAINBRIDGE, Md., June 1 -- Investigators for the Civil Aeronautics Board established beyond reasonable doubt today that the Eastern Air Lines plane that crashed near here Friday evening, killing all fifty-three passengers and crew members, was on its back and out of control at the time it hit the ground.

BUDAPEST, Hungary June 1 -- The first notes of the new regime in Hungary sounded faintly today. The Sunday newspaper of the Small Landholders party, once the supporter of equally good relations with the West and the East, interpreted the disappearance of foreign Minister Janos Gyongyosy from the Cabinet as the end of the "balancing policy" of looking both to the West and the East.

E. Allan Williford, vice president in charge of the Ansco film and camera diviison of the General Aniline Film Corporation, announced over the week-end that Ansco's district managers from all sales districts, including San Francisco, Los Angeles, Chicago, Toronto, Boston, Washington, Dallas and Cincinnati, will meet in New York for a week's convention at the Hotel Chatham starting today.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 1 -- A royal spokesman said tonight that some reports from here had indicated that Abd el Krim, former Riff leader, had landed in Egypt yesterday by pre-arrangement. He denied that this was so, asserting that neither King Farouk nor Premier Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha had had any inkling of el Krim's intention until his arrival.

During the first four month of this year transatlantic otvian passenger traffic on Maritime Commission vessels showed a considerable increase over the same period in 1946, according to a report released here yesterday by the commission's Atlantic Coast regional office.

Death yesterday morning claimed the forty-second victim of the United Air Lines DC-4 take-off crash at La Guardia Field Thursday night. Miss Margaret Leddin, 30 years old, of 90 St. Marks Place, St. George, Staten Island, died in Flushing Hospital, Queens, at 9:25 A.M.

A rush repair job reminiscent of wartime days enabled the Norwegian America liner Stavangerfjord to sail from New York last Thursday with three of her main boiler furnaces renewed, it was learned yesterday. A group from the Bethlehem Steel Company's yard at Fifty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, completed the work in five days.
The Long Island Rail Road reported "an unusual error" yesterday. One of its trains skipped a scheduled transfer stop to the consternation of most of the 200 passengers.

Condemning the policy of the Veterans Administration in the South as one "based on racial prejudice" that "prevents the Negro veteran from securing full benefits under the GI bill," 200 delegates to the convention of the United Negro and Allied Veterans of America voted yesterday to send a committee to Washington today to ask for a Government investigation.

DETROIT, June 1 -- A "moment's notice" strike against the Briggs Manufacturing Company, one of the largest makers of automobile bodies in the country, was authorized almost nine to one today by the rank and file of two locals of the United Automobile Workers of America of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

SEA CLIFF, L. I., June 1 -- Plunging into and over waves in an unusually confused sea for Long Island sound, and a wind that piped up close to 25 miles an hour in gusts, forty-seven craft raced today in the championship regatta held by the Sea Cliff Yacht Club.

BALTIMORE, June 1 -- The American Jewish community has entered the most crucial stage of its history, Dr. Salo W. Baron, professor of Jewish history, literature and institutions, Columbia University, told the National Conference of Jewish Social Welfare tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Veterans Administration estimated today that war veterans and their families would, make up 43 per cent of the country's population by 1952.

A gathering of 45,795 slightly delirious baseball addicts spent some agonizing moments at the Polo Grounds yesterday as Mel Ott's unpredictable Giants threatened to blow all of their hardearned lead in the National League flag race in a single afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- A Presidential commission drew back the curtain today on atomic warfare of the future to hint at "the indescribable horror" of a single day's attack in which twelve of America's largest cities could be crippled or destroyed and our utilities, railroads and communications eliminated.

PINE BLUFF, Ark., Monday, June 2 -- At least thirty-seven persons were killed, fifteen were missing, hundreds were injured and other hundreds were made homeless late yesterday when a tornado swept through a heavily populated plantation region near here.

After all our major wars the exsoldier has been important in American life and politics, but until the second World War he and his immediate family were always a small minority. Now the picture has changed. We have, as the Veterans Administration has just announced, 14,267,000 new veterans.

Week Ended May 29, 1947 Interest in the foreign exchange market last week centered for the most part in the irregularity of the free currencies of Canada and Switzerland. Elsewhere spot sterling was steady but forwards continued weak at widening discounts. Other Europeans were lightly traded at no important change in rate.

LONDON, June 1 -- There is a somewhat significant lassitude and lack of initiative about the London financial markets generally and particularly on the Stock Exchange, which is as much a business barometer to Britain as Wall Street is to the United States.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I correct an error which crept into your editorial "Finland and the Russians" on May 20, and offer a few additional facts regarding Finland's reparations payments to Russia.

"White Ribboners" from twentysix foreign countries, together with, delegates from all parts of the United States, will attend the seventeenth convention of the World's Woman's Christian Temperance Union, to be held in Asbury Park, N.J., from Thursday through June 10.

AMSTERDAM, June 1 -- Annual reports of corporations for 1946 all reflect marked Dutch recovery. With the exception of Dutch East Indies concerns, nearly all companies wiped out occupation losses and recorded very good profits. Satisfactory dividends have been paid.

The Central Trades and Labor Council, AFL, made public yesterday a proclamation signed by Mayor O'Dwyer last Thursday, designating Wednesday as a day of "protest to our national authorities at Washington, D. C." against enactment of the Taft-Hartley bill imposing substantial curbs upon labor unions.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period May 24 to 30 are given in the appended tabulation: The Senate On the George motion to postpone until June 10 consideration of the tax reduction bill, rejected 44 to 48: YEAS

There was no gloom over Brooklyn yesterday. The sun was shining, the air was balmy and 34,109 cash-dispensing Flatbush fans -- the season's high at Ebbets Field -- found no flies in their ointment of pleasure.

According to a survey undertaken by the Social Science Research Center of the University of Puerto Rico and released here over the week-end, the Territory of Puerto Rico's net income increased to $483,000,000 in 1944, an increase of 112 per cent in four years, and a real increase of 34 per cent, allowing for a higher price level.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $49,997,287,447. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

CHICAGO, June 1 -- Planting of corn has been irregular. In Iowa a large percentage of the crop is in, but wet weather in Illinois, Missouri, Indiana and the Ohio Valley has delayed operations, and much of the crop will now have to be planted in June, which means that the season will have to be fairly late to permit maturing safely.

The American Export freighter Express, built to replace a vessel of the same name that was torpedoed in the Indian Ocean in 1942, has been delivered to the line at Mobile, Ala., by the United States Maritime Commission.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- Population increases in many Southern cities and on the West Coast have resulted in the rapid expansion of food distribution systems since the war, E.J. Martin, secretary-manager of the National Food Distributors Association, said over the week-end in revealing a sharp increase in the number of storedoor-service distributors in those areas.

The Communists in France will lose offices when tested in the October municipal elections, Mme. Jacqueline Thome-Patenotre, member of the French Council of the Republic, predicted yesterday. She said this would be caused not by a decrease in their number but by the union of other parties against communism.

Retailers and wholesalers last week were considerably more optimistic than they were a month ago because of the encouraging reports from different parts of the country, according to the reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 1 (A.P) -- Jersey City and Buffalo divided a doubleheader before 13,552 today, the little Giants coming back to take the nightcap, 6 -- 2, after the Bisons had annexed the opener, 9 -- 3.

The Pennsylvania-Central Airlines Corporation, which suffered serious financial losses last year and during the first quarter of 1947, has filed a refinancing program with the Securities and Exchange Commission, it was announced yesterday by C. Bedell Monro, president of the company.

GENEVA, Switzerland, June 1 -- More than 500 delegates from thirty countries, representing business, industry, banking and insurance will attend the eleventh congress of the International Chamber of Commerce in Montreux tomorrow, which is scheduled to continue until Saturday.

Among the numerous factors which have contributed to dividing opinion on the tax reduction bill which goes to the President this week, none, perhaps, has been a more potent influence than the wide divergence among the answers to one basic question.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 1 -- Princeton University will confer baccalaureate degrees on 560 seniors and advanced degrees on seventy-five graduate students at commencement exercises on Monday, June 9. This will be the climax of a four-day series of festivities starting next Friday.

The Christian, religion is China's greatest need today, the Right Rev. Keh Tsung Mao, Assistant Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Shanghai, declared yesterday at the Trinity Sunday service in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Services marking the golden anniversary of the ordination of the Rev. Herbert J. Glover, vicar of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, were held yesterday morning in the church, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street.

Cotton prices in the domestic market last week moved to slightly higher levels. For the four-day weekly period ended on Thursday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed a net advance of 11 to 41 points.
The Memorial Day week-end closed last night with the traditional influx of thousands of New Yorkers who had spent the threeday holiday at rest and at play far from their familiar haunts.

TOKYO, June 1 -- Hopes that democratic government in Japan may be "permeated by a spirit of Christian love and humanism" and "guided by a Christian spirit of morality" marked the first statement to the press by Japan's new Prime Minister, Tetsu Katayama.

The Port of New York Authority, on its first day of operations at three New York airports, announced yesterday that it would make a new, concrete offer tomorrow to the city of Newark for inclusion of Newark Airport in the authority's chain of metropolitan air fields.

The National City Bank's June letter, published today, declares that Federal Trade Commission reports on studies of the trend toward corporate mergers say a great deal about the reasons why big concerns might want to acquire little ones, but nothing about the reasons why little concerns might want to be sold to big ones.

LEEDEY, Okla., June 1 (UP) -- Six persons were dead, twentythree injured, half this little town's population of 855 was homeless and the business district was a shambles today in the wake of one of three tornadoes which ripped across western Oklahoma and the Texas Panhandle last night.

The placement of dependent and neglected children with foster families is hampered today by social service methods that "seem to be bordering on the excessive," Cardinal Spellman declared yesterday at vesper in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

With the first quarter of the New York racing season written into the records after four-week sessions at Jamaica and Belmont Park, the horses -- and the horse players -- move to Aqueduct today. There will be eighteen days of competition during the spring meeting at the Queens County Jockey Club's course.

SYCAMORE, Ill., June 1 -- An extensive advertising campaign for "wire-nuts" utilizing both magazines and direct mail, intended to reach all electrical equipment manufacturers, electrical contractors and plant electricians, was announced today by Ward R. Schafer, general sales manager of Ideal Industries, Inc.

SEOUL, Korea, June 1 (AP) -- The United States and Russia have settled the chief difference that disrupted last year's negotiations on a provisional Government for Korea, a joint communique said today.

Rayon yarns from other than primary sources represent only a small fraction of the total amount required, it was learned from yarn producers over the week-end. Under current market conditions, they said, second-hand dealers cannot offer much relief to manufacturers who are hard pressed for rayon fabrics.
CEDARHURST, L.I., June 1 -- Sidney B. Wood Jr. of New York and Early Cochell of Los Angeles won the annual invitation tennis doubles tournament of the Rockaway Hunting Club today.

THE man in the black beret who awoke one morning after the battle of El Alamein to find himself world famous is one of the great heroes and one of the most controversial figures of the Second World War. Field Marshal the Viscount Montgomery of Alamein is certain to occupy a conspicuous niche in the military histories, but just what the historians will say about him is far from certain.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (U.P.) -- Labor Department sources said tonight that probably no formal ruling would be issued on the lapsing of the thirty-day strike notice. But they said that the department would maintain its strike notice filing unit through June 30, when the War Disputes Act expires.
ROME, June 1 -- Thirteen of the fifteen Ministers in Premier Alcide de Gasperi's fourth Cabinet were sworn in today as political thunderclouds seemed to be gathering.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Daily it is my unfortunate lot to have to walk two or three blocks down Broadway from my hotel to my office, and in the process I am required to cross the four booby traps masquerading as the uptown and downtown highways, respectively, of Broadway and Seventh Avenue, between Forty-sixth and Forty-third Streets.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., June 1 -- Tom Mather's goal twenty-six seconds after the sudden-death overtime period began enabled Cecil Smith's 21-goal Westbury four to top Pete Bostwick's Bostwick Field team, 10 to 9, today. The game inaugurated Bostwick Field's tenth season of high goal polo.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 1 -- David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, will appear at 2:30 P.M. tomorrow before the Control Committee of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission. He is expected to confine his statement to the technical question of how an effective international system of enforcement can be established.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The effect of buyer resistance, attributed to the rise in prices, is being felt by manufacturers of clothing and textile products, the Department of Commerce reported today.
PARIS, June 1 -- Haying failed to obtain satisfaction of the demands presented to Premier Paul Ramadier, bakery workers called a forty-eight-hour "warning strike" tonight.

Old Sporting Days Our city scout has a way of looking backward when he should be looking around him. While everybody that wasn't away somewhere else was out at Belmont Park this past weekend to see what the top horses of two seasons were doing in the two famous races that come at the end of May, he was reminding us of something that happened in this town in 1668.
The liner Alcoa Corsair, scheduled to depart from New Orleans Friday on her maiden voyage, will be the third new ship of the Alcoa fleet to enter cruise service since the beginning of the year.

Every crisis abroad these days raises a critical question for America. It is impossible to write about political developments anywhere except in terms of United States policy. The line between foreign and domestic is so blurred that even the proverbial ostrich cannot be sure whether he is burying his head in the home sands or in the drift from some other shore.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., June 1 -- Far reaching beneficial effects on the construction and performance of motor vehicles were forecast today in the program for the annual summer meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers which opens here tomorrow.

RHINEBECK, N.Y., June 1 -- A veteran of the show rings, Champion Deephaven Warspite, Scottish terrier from the Marlu Farm Kennels of West Long Branch, N.J., took best in show today at the fifth all-breed event of the MidHudson Kennel Club.

LOS ANGELES, June 1 -- The Ford Motor Company's project of procuring $50,000,000 more worth of parts annually on the Pacific Coast to save freight to its western plants has encountered surprising apathy and lack of "know how" among manufacturers of the region, it was learned today.

Grants totaling $532,000, chiefly for research in medical colleges, universities and hospitals in the United States and Canada, were made during 1946 by the John and Mary R. Markle Foundation, it was announced yesterday by John M. Russell, executive director.
AMSTERDAM, June 1 -- The United States-Netherlands lendlease settlement last week and the result of the Dutch $20,000,000 loan floated in New York have been sources of great satisfaction here.
MEXICO CITY, June 1 -- The long-awaited report to the Government on the Mexican oil industry will be made public tomorrow. It is expected to have far-reaching effects on the oil industry.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- Wide price swings characterized the wheat market last week on the Board of Trade. There was a rapid upturn early when buying was stimulated by unfavorable weather in all sections and by the strength in the cash wheat markets after the expiration of May trading.
The recreative and therapeutic value of silence was extolled yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Robert James McCracken in his sermon at the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

The season of 1946-47 having just been interred amidst a flurry of statistics, the new term of 194748 will be ushered in at 8:30 tonight at the Century with the premiere of "Louisiana Lady," a musical comedy. After this evening the top will range downward from $3.60, an unusually low scale for a new song-and-dance offering.

An increase in liability rates for private passenger automobiles becomes effective today throughout New York State, with the average rises 16.5 per cent for policies covering bodily injury claims and 27.5 per cent for those covering property damage.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (U.P.) -- Senator Owen Brewster, said today that Argentina might well become a bulwark against Communism and urged the United States to join her and other LatinAmerican nations in a hemisphere defense pact.

James G. McDonald, former member of the Anglo-American Committee of Inquiry for Palestine who returned last week from a visit to that country, said last night that its arid southern area the Negeve could be restored to cultivation by irrigation and take care of tens of thousands of Jewish families now in camps in Europe.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your "European Food Picture -- Two Years After the War," in THE TIMES of May 18, which gave comparative estimates of the daily caloric consumption in various European countries, I noticed that the figure for "town dwellers" in Greece showed a daily consumption of 2,250 calories per individual.

The war of nerves between the Transport Workers Union, CIO, and the Board of Transportation took a new turn yesterday as union leaders prepared for mass meetings tonight and tomorrow morning to discuss the alleged unfairness of the Board of Transportation in assigning runs to the 2,000 motormen and conductors on the IND division of the city subway system.

Confronted with an opposition tickets, Actors Equity will hold its annual election of councilors to the union's governing board at the Hotel Astor this afternoon, starting at 2:30 o'clock. Adherents of the independent slate aroused the membership because they felt that Ilka Chase and Aline MacMahon deserved re-nomination as councilors on the basis of their records.

BOSTON, June 1 (AP) -- Winning both games of a doubleheader from the Pirates, the first a 2-0 shutout for Johnny Sain and the second an 8-7 ten-inning affair, the Braves today moved into the National League's third slot, a halfgame ahead of the Dodgers.

PITTSBURGH, June 1 -- The scrap market turned stronger here last week when the average price of No. 1 heavy melting steel advanced $2.50 a gross ton. Quotations on this grade were $32 to $32.50 a gross ton, representing the first advance since the scrap market started its downward trend in March.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., June 1 -- Twelve members of the International Society for Malaria Control, public health specialists from South America, Mexico, China and this country, completed inspection today of pest-control methods developed here by Dr. C.H. Curran, curator of entomology at the American Museum of Natural History.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., June 1 -- A motor freight strike here scheduled for 7 A.M. tomorrow seemed inevitable tonight as two last-minute negotiating sessions called today by Mayor David L. Lawrence failed to bridge the wage differences between the Western Pennsylvania Motor Carriers Association and Local 249 of the AFL Teamsters Union.

NANKING, June 1 -- Arrests of liberal and alleged Communist students, newspaper men, intellectuals, workers and professional men continued in China yesterday and today. The Government moved on a broad front to smash opposition criticism within its own territories.

A dispatch to this newspaper from Sweden reports the activities of some of our fellow-citizens in the port of Malmoe. Two American vessels are at Malmoe. One, the William K. Kamake, is manned by a white crew from Texas. The other, the Booker T. Washington, carries a Negro crew.
MOSCOW, June 1, (U.P.) -- The Moscow radio began broadcasting commercial announcements this week-end. A check disclosed that the audience listened happily to the advertisements and demanded more.

One thousand persons attended the thirty-fifth anniversary dinner of the Mizrachi Organization of America in the Hotel Astor last night and pledged themselves to raise $500,000 for its education and expansion fund. Morris H. Lifschitz, who presided, called upon American Jews to share in the group's constructive activities.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- While anxiously wondering how President Truman will act on its two major achievements, the tax reduction and labor bills, Congress will start tomorrow on a number of important and controversial measures, to be disposed of by June 30.

NEWTON CENTER, Mass., June 1 -- Sammy Snead conferred no favors on himself or any of his brother professionals when he brought Bobby Locke back to America from South Africa, for ever since his arrival here a day in advance of the Masters Tourney at Augusta the dapper little man from Johannesburg has been a thorn in the flesh of the United States stars.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 2 -- A program of vocational, educational and avocational guidance, developed in the last year by the Department of Psychology at the Westchester Division of the New York Hospital, is proving to be of therapeutic value in the treatment of many psychiatric patients, according to the annual report for 1946, issued today.
WEST POINT, N.Y., June 1 -- Twelve cadets of the graduating class at the United States Military Academy were honored today for outstanding academic work.

THERE is nothing tabloid about Dan Parker except the paper for which he works. He's a massive man, 260 pounds in displacement and 6-feet-4 in height. And he throws massive punches. That fearsome bludgeoneer, Westbrook Pegler, once confided to me that Large Daniel was the only writer he'd hate to tangle with in a battle of words.

The importance today of the words "duty, passion and holiness" for the knowledge acquired through a college education was stressed yesterday by the Rev. Stephen F. Bayne Jr., Columbia University chaplain, at the university baccalaureate service in St. Paul's Chapel on the Columbia campus.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- Completion of successful tests on direct-action hydraulic shock absorbers for railroad freight cars, similar to those on automobiles, was announced today by Brouwer D. McIntyre, president of the Monroe Auto Equipment Company, Monroe, Mich.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 1 (AP) -- Dr. Kurt Schumacher, leader of Germany's Social Democratic party, denounced "reckless world politicians" today for "misusing" the German people in a post-war struggle for power between the East and West.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- A letter of transmittal and the summary of findings and recommendations by President Truman's Advisory Commission on Universal Military Training were as follows: The Letter May 29, 1947.

As a first step toward giving practical effect to the economic merger of their zones, the American and British Military Governments in Germany have now agreed on the creation of a German economic government with authority over both zones. This government remains, of course, subject to Allied supervision and control, and its authority is strictly limited to economic affairs and does not even extend to all of these.

When a group of American citizens of the caliber of the President's Advisory Commission on Universal Military Training can study for six months an important problem confronting the United States and can agree unanimously on a program in favor of such training, then that report surely merits the most serious consideration of the American people, and of Congress.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Compulsory military training of all American males on reaching the age of 18 or on completion of high school was recommended in a report to President Truman today by his Advisory Commission on Universal Training as indispensable to the national security in an atomic age.

To provide a centrally located unit to serve families throughout east and west Harlem, the Community Service Society will redistrict its Harlem, Jefferson, Mount Morris and Yorkville units. Each year the four combined serve close to 5,000 families, composed of 16,000 individuals.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, threw his weight today behind a drive by Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican of Michigan, for early Senate ratification of peace treaties with Italy, Bulgaria, Rumania and Hungary.

TROY, N.Y., June 1 (AP) -- Judge Florence E. Allen of Cleveland, United States Circuit Court magistrate, told the Russell Sage College graduating class today that "never again should men, however great, be allowed to meet in an oriental capital as they did at Teheran and Yalta and give away with a nod the rights of individual nations."
District Attorney Frank S.Hogan will resume the questioning of witnesses this morning in his dual investigations of pier leases and airport contracts, it was learned yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 -- A decision on the part of the new telephone workers' organizing committee, CIO, to boycott the June 9 convention in Miami of the Communications Workers Association, rather than move in and attempt to take it over, was disclosed today by Allan S. Haywood.
CHICAGO, June 1 -- Poor housing conditions and discrimination in employment are the major problems of the Negro in this city, their leaders report.

BOMBAY, India, June 1 (U.P.) -- Monandas K. Gandhi, the spiritual leader of India's Hindus, said today in a telegraphic interview that he regarded war between the United States and Russia as "highly improbable." Six questions were sent to him.

The "escape" into Egypt of Abd El Krim, aged leader of the bloody Riff war in Spanish and French North Africa, after his twenty-one-year imprisonment on lonely Reunion Island, may not develop into a return from Elba. But is it bound to be highly embarrassing to France.

NEW DELHI, India, June 1 (London Times Dispatch) -- On the eve of tomorrow's fateful conference with the Viceroy, Viscount Mountbatten, Indian eyes are turned tonight toward New Delhi, where the nation's leaders are gathered.
JERUSALEM, June 1 -- Another influential voice was raised in Palestine today to advocate a Zionist decision for the partition of Palestine.

The reaction to infra-red radiation of the dyestuffs used in clothing is an important factor in their warmth or coolness, according to new studies and experiments made at the Philadelphia Textile Institute as part of a research project sponsored by the Philadelphia Section, American Association of Textile Chemists and Colorists.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 (AP) -- Clyde McCullough's triple after Bob Sturgeon had reached first on Jim Tabor's error in the eighth inning broke a 3-3 tie and gave Chicago a 4-3 victory over the Phillies today before 14,841.

TROY, N.Y., June 1 -- The first chapter of Humanity International, an organization founded to promote world friendship and understanding, which was established here May 1, has begun a survey to discover what an average American community is doing for world neighborliness and what participation it may desire.

"I am haunted by numberless islands," sang the poet Yeats. This must be true also for many veterans of the Pacific War who often find their thoughts turning back in a variety of moods to scenes once vivid. It will be interesting to see, as time goes on, how much of a movement there is among these veterans to revisit islands where they once "sweated it out."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 1 -- "The Senator Was Indiscreet," George S. Kaufman's first motion picture directorial effort, will go before the cameras on location in New York on Thursday, Universal-International has announced. Kaufman is on the way to New York.
CALCUTTA, India, June 1 -- The atmosphere in Calcutta is charged with grave apprehension tonight.

MARGATE, England, June 1 -- The smoke of battle that lay over Margate during this week of the annual Labor Party Conference has drifted away under the sizzling hot sun. Many of the worries of the Government leaders have also drifted away, for they had expected a much harder fight.

The hostess who gives party guests no choice except to drink liquor or to go thirsty was denounced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, as lacking in courtesy and as "the greatest offender in the use of social pressure."

Andrew W. Smith Jr., former Eastern division sales manager at Twentieth Century-Fox, has been appointed general sales manager succeeding Thomas J. Connors, Spyroa Skouras, president, has announced. Mr. Connors, it was reported on Saturday, announced his intention to retire on the expiration of his contract, which takes place, it is understood, in August.

Columbia College seniors will gather today at 10:45 A.M. in Columbia's Van Ambringe Quadrangle for the first Class Day exercises since 1942. Tomorrow, at the university's 193d commencement, they will receive bachelors' degrees.

Revenues from sales of gas by utility companies for the first quarter of 1947 were about 429,800,000 an increase of 15.5 per cent over the same quarter a year ago, according to the American Gas Association.
If you're something of a detective, you can discover a surprisingly large number of restaurants in Manhattan where a really good dinner may be had for a moderate price.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (U.P.) -- The Government is trying to sell to American women the idea of wearing silk again.

Five record-breaking performances highlighted the twenty-first annual Catholic High Schools Athletic Association outdoor track and field championships as Mount St. Michael ended the thirteen-year monopoly of Bishop Loughlin at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.

Undeterred by lateness of the season, local galleries have scheduled nearly a score of group and one-man shows for the first week of June. Today's openings include the first of a series of exhibitions by members of the Artists League of America at that organization's headquarters, 77 Fifth Avenue, the work shown in this event being confined to paintings, sculpture and drawings by war veteran members.

Fred Allen and Henry Morgan, radio's two most facile dispensers of saucy and acerbic wit, have walked off with the principal honors in The Billboard's annual poll of radio editors, out today. Mr. Allen's divertissement was picked by the critics as their "favorite program" and their "favorite comedy show," Mr. Morgan being runnerup in both cases.

ST. LOUIS, June 1 (AP) -- Home runs by Jeff Heath and Vern Stephens, combined with the sixhit pitching of Jack Kramer, gave the Browns a 7-to-2 victory over the Athletics in the opener of a listed doubleheader today. Elmer Valo hit a home run for the Mackmen.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 1 -- Commonwealth officials emphatically deny suspension of certain licenses for importation of textiles from the United States is retailiation for projected increased American duty on wool, as alleged in New York.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Frank R. Creedon, Housing Expediter, estimated today that over 1,000,000 new dwelling units of all types would be completed this year if Federal controls were continued for "a few more months."

CLEVELAND, June 1 -- Joe Di Maggio hit the jackpot today and propelled the Yankees to victory over the Indians at Municipal Stadium before a crowd of 47,132 and when the struggle that was played in rain, mud and fog was over, the score was 11 to 9.
PARIS, June 1 -- After extensive nutritional studies conducted throughout France the bulletin of the National Hygiene Institute reported today that France had made important progress during 1946.

CINCINNATI, June 1 -- Declaring that religion cannot thrive when it remains "in suspended animation" for three months, Dr. Leon Saks of Cincinnati told the first conference of presidents called by the Union of American Hebrew Congregations that steps must be taken to correct the tendency for "religion to vacation during the summer."

Training of city, county and state police officers from northeastern states in "modern methods of accident and congestion control" will be undertaken in a two-week course in traffic police methods opening today at the New York University School of Law, Washington Square.

TSINGTAO, China, June 1 -- The United States Navy's training program for China's future navy here at Tsingtao is one of the few examples of close working cooperation between Chinese and Americans in this land today.

RABAT, Morocco, May 29 (Delayed) -- The French are holding their North African sphere of influence with a strong hand. They are determined that the conflicts in Indo-China and Madagascar Shall not spread to Morocco, Algeria and Tunisia.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Allow me to make the following remarks with reference to the editorial concerning the ratification of the so-called "satellite" treaties in your issue of May 10.

Sixty passengers aboard a double-decker bus of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company, bound from Manhattan to Jackson Heights, Queens, were jolted from their seats at 7:15 o'clock last night by a freak accident as the bus was leaving the Long Island City end of the Queens-borough Bridge.
PURCHASE, N.Y., June 2 -- The Westchester women emerged victorious in the Metropolitan intersectional team matches for the Golf Illustrated Trophy over the Century Country Club course today.

BOSTON, June 2 -- The election of Mrs. Helen Chaffee Elwell of East Hebron, N.H., and Boston, as president of the Mother Church, the First Church of Christ, Scientist, was announced today at the annual meeting of members. Mrs. Elwell, who succeeds Luther Phillips Cudworth, is a daughter of the late Lieut. Gen. Adna R. Chaffee, Chief of Staff of the United States Army.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Supreme Court decided unanimously today that a Pennsylvania district judge improperly ordered a new trial for a defendant to whom one had previously been denied by an Appellate Court.

Some electrical appliance distributors which had taken on nonelectrical housewares lines as an emergency measure to maintain dollar volume during the wartime period, will expand such items shortly, retailers reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture announced today that it has resumed large-scale buying of wheat for shipment to shortage areas abroad.

John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, will recommend at tomorrow's meeting of the Board of Education that New York public school teachers who write textbooks in use in the city school system be permitted to collect royalties on them.

If plans made yesterday are carried out, the world will learn this morning the latest British proposals for the independence of India. The world will have a right to be interested, for the Indians number nearly one-fifth of the human race. When the Viceroy, Viscount Mountbatten, goes on the air he will throw light, hopeful or otherwise, on the future not only of India but of the whole Orient.

ROME, June 2 -- All Italian LeftWing parties joined forces in attacking Premier Alcide de Gasperi's fourth Cabinet, from which they are excluded, in a mass meeting here today. The gathering marked the first anniversary of the plebiscite by which Italy changed from a monarchy to a republic.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- While the two armed services committees of Congress planned hearings on universal military training, the consensus among Congressional leaders today was that final action on the issue would not be reached at this session.

NEW DELHI, June 2 (Reuters) -- It was learned here tonight that the British Government was proposing to introduce legislation in the current session of Parliament in London providing for the transfer of power to Indians this year.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The death penalty has been abolished in the Soviet Union by a decree of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet published on May 26. A few days earlier it was announced in London that Soviet citizens in the displaced persons camps would be forcibly deported to Russia, while groups of Ukrainians and other nationals would be permitted to remain in the west.

The Chicago Park District, announced yesterday that it would offer on June 10 an issue of $1,092,000 of funding bonds dated July 1, 1947 and due on July 1, 1957, or, optionally, on each July 1 from 1949 to 1966.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 2 -- The Communist Deputy Premier, Matyas Rakosi, now the real ruler of Hungary, has affirmed in a public address that he called former Premier Ferenc Nagy on the telephone in Switzerland before he resigned. Mr. Rakosi said he had told the Premier he would be dragged before the People's Tribunal in Budapest as soon as he returned to Hungary.

STUTTGART, Germany, June 2 -- The latest warrants for wives of major German war criminals include Frau Alfred Jodl and Frau Julius Streicher, whose husbands were executed last year and who were to be arrested today.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Comparatively few of the "portal-to-portal" wage recovery suits, amounting to several billions of dollars, that were pending when the President signed the bill that seeks to outlaw them have since been withdrawn. He signed May 14, and thus a sufficient period has elapsed for an organized withdrawal to have become manifest.

MONTREAL, June 2 (Canadian Press) -- Discussion of major league hockey's relations with minor professional and amateur groups and some minor rule revisions featured the National Hockey League's annual meeting here today.

Federal Housing Administrator Creedon's prediction that a million dwelling units will be completed this year if federal controls are continued for "a few more months" might make careless readers believe our housing crisis is subsiding. It really is not. Of the million, 610,000 are permanent dwellings now under construction.

Maintenance of a privately owned and privately operated. American merchant marine was recommended yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council as an "absolutely necessary instrument of national foreign commerce."

The American flag will be first around the world in commercial air transportation. Juan T. Trippe, president of Pan American Airways, announced here yesterday that on June 17 a Constellation of his line would leave New York for Europe with a party of publishers, to return after leisurely stops at important news centers a day short of two weeks later.

LOS ANGELES, June 2 -- A great new test center and proving ground for long-range missiles probably will be established at El Centro, Calif., it was learned today, if the unanimous recommendation of a service committee is approved in Washington.

LONDON, June 2 (Reuters) -- South Africa's cricketers were in a good position at close of play against Middlesex today, their opponents declaring their innings closed for the loss of eight wickets when still 108 runs behind.

Dorothy Lamour will be the regular mistress of ceremonies and singer on a new variety show making its bow on July 6 over NBC. Occupying the period from 8:30 to 9 on Sunday evenings, which Fred Allen will be vacating for the summer, the program will be sponsored by the United States Army as part of its campaign to stimulate enlistments in the Regular Army.

The Council for Racial Understanding did two things at Town Hall last night to promote the purposes for which it was founded. It sponsored a musical program by an excellent mixed white and Negro chorus, and it presented an award to Dr. Charlotte Hawkins Brown, founder of the Palmer Memorial Institute in Sedalia, N.C.

The Real Estate Board of New York protested yesterday to Mayor O'Dwyer against his sponsorship of an American Federation of Labor rally in Madison Square Garden Wednesday night to protest enactment of the Taft-Hartley labor bill now before Congress.

The first patterns of Varlar, the stainproof wall covering similar to wallpaper in texture but not in make-up, are now available at Gimbels. Formed of paper, plastic resins and ink, Varlar is impervious to a variety of household stains.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., June 2 -- The "pent-up consumer demand" on which many business men are counting may actually be a mirage representing only lack of purchasing power, Neil Petree, a leading Los Angeles retailer, warned the twelfth annual convention of the National Federation of Sales Executives today.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The first public indication that the Republican-controlled Congress might question the motives under which the "Freedom Train" will tour the country for a year came today as Attorney General Tom C. Clark was asked to appear before a House committee to give an accounting.

NANKING, June 2 -- The efforts of the Peoples Political Council to promote an end of China's civil war produced a final resolution today. It was an invitation to the Communists to send representatives to Nanking to engage unconditionally in new peace negotiations with the Government.

Philip Morris Co. Ltd., Inc. closed its fiscal year on March 31 in the strongest financial condition in its history, achieved an improvement in operating earnings and added substantially to its productive facilities, according to the annual report issued yesterday by A. E. Lyon, president.
PEIPING, China, June 2 -- Two recent incidents have brought to light the Chinese Government's concern over the rapidly deteriorating situation in Manchuria.
LONDON, June 2 -- Business in the stock markets today was small and price movements were irregular.

Single-payment loans amounted to five-eighths of all consumer loans carried by member banks of the Federal Reserve System in this district at the end of 1946, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The figure was in an analysis of the participation of the banks in this field of credit, contained in the bank's Monthly Review.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 2 -- Holy Cross chalked up its eleventh triumph in thirteen starts this season by defeating the Columbia nine, 7 to 3, in a twilight game today. The Lions outhit the Crusaders but played sloppy ball afield, committing four costly errors.

The major partners in the Iraq Petroleum Company have reached the basis for a new agreement through which they would obtain crude oil from the Iraq Concession in accordance with their needs rather than in fixed proportion to the total production, as has been the case previously, the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- With the nation's $12,000,000,000 livestock industry in jeopardy until the fight is won, the Administration will ask Congress this week for $65,000,000 more for continuing the battle against the dread foot-and-mouth disease that is ravaging livestock in southern Mexico.

First Congressional reaction to the report of the Compton Commission on universal training is that this is a fine report but that Congress hasn't time to do anything about it now. Besides, said Senator Hill, Democrat, of Alabama, and Senator Taft, Republican of Ohio, the Eightieth Congress has held no hearings on the matter.

More than 3,500 buyers and manufacturers attended the opening of the International Exposition of Textiles, which got under way yesterday afternoon at Grand Central Palace. Visitors who viewed the show, the first of its kind to be held in the United States, arrived at the rate of 700 per hour, according to Arthur Tarshis, president of Exhibitions of Fashion, Inc., sponsor of the show.

The prevailing opinion in both judicial and political quarters yesterday was that Governor Dewey probably would promote Associate Justice David W. Peck of the Appellate Division to succeed Presiding Justice Francis Martin, who died on Sunday.

Net earnings of the National Pressure Cooker Company and subsidiaries for the March quarter of this year amounted to $1,871,525, equal to $3.74 a share of common stock, according to the report isued yesterday. This compares with $692,482 or $1.38 a common share for the quarter ended on March 31, 1946.

IF Jimmy Wilson ever rued the making of one play, it undoubtedly was the steal he made of second base in the 1940 world series. That play lifted him from comfortable obscurity into the full glare of the spotlight. And it so impressed the Chicago Cubs that they hired him forthwith as their manager, the first time that larceny on the basepaths brought so rich a return.

ATHENS, June 2 (U.P.) -- Reliable reports said today that the first elements of a Leftist international brigade formed in France and Italy to fight beside Greek guerrillas have arrived at the Adriatic port of Spalato, Yugoslavia, and may soon enter Greece.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 2 -- By playing the wind-swept Garden City Country Club course in 68 strokes, diminutive Clarence Doser, pro at the Scarsdale club, showed the way today to ninety-five golfers who struggled to squeeze their way into the Unite States Open championship, to be played at St. Louis June 12-14.
Events in Hungary and Italy again call forceful attention to the fact that Europe is being divided into rival camps, both as between nations and as between parties within nations.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Bituminous coal operators from the North and West do not expect John L. Lewis seriously to negotiate terms of a new agreement until he knows the fate of the Hartley-Taft labor bill.
The American merchant marine will lose its best customer in the next few weeks as the unprecedented peacetime program of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration grinds to a close.

NEW DELHI, India, June 2 -- The Viceroy, Viscount Mountbatten, informed Indian political leaders today of the British Government's plan to partition India into Hindu and Moslem states upon Britain's departure by June, 1948.

Bernard M. Baruch, former United States member of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, said yesterday that it would be "sheer suicide and sheer madness if we didn't adopt the compulsory military training plan just reommended by the Advisory Commission on Universal Training."
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The House gave its approval by 220 to 99 today to the bill reducing personal income taxes by 10.5 to 30 per cent, starting July 1.
Mrs. Ethel T. Gibson of 20 Continental Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens, wife of Frederick M. Gibson, mechanical engineer, died yesterday morning in St. Luke's Hospital. Her age was 67.

LONDON, June 2 (AP) -- The Weather and the scratching of three outsiders served today to make John (Lucky) Dewar's Tudor Minstrel an even-money favorite for the English Derby Saturday, although many British Sportsmen continued to pull hopefully for the King's entry, Blue Train.

Dr. Harry J. Carman, dean of Columbia College, expressed the hope yesterday that the members of its graduating class had discovered how best to use their talents in the service of others. He spoke at the college's Class Day exercises held out of doors on Columbia's Van Ambringe Quadrangle for the first time since 1942.
MASHIPACONG LAKE, N.J., June 2 -- Sixty-five New York school children arrived here today to begin the city's first public school experiment in camp education.

International amity, Coney Island, Henry Wallace and baseball were among the subjects discussed yesterday by a few of the more communicative passengers arriving here from Odessa on the Soviet liner Rossia.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- The mental hospital of the future will be a part of the community where all agencies can cooperate to help patients go on with normal lives, both before entering and after leaving the hospital, Dr. George S. Stevenson, medical director of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene, said at a meeting of the Illinois State Society for Mental Hygiene here today.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review the Illinois Supreme Court's decision that religious education classes may lawfully be held in the public schools of Champaign, Ill.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The first official and unqualified prediction that the joint labor bill will become law, Presidential veto or no veto, was made today by its principal, authors.

Upsetting earlier calculations that the month would show a decline under a year ago, sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores in May showed an increase of 11 per cent over the like month of 1946, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
MONTREUX, June 2 -- Mr. Aldrich came out strongly against economic controls at the opening session of the International Chamber's eleventh congress -- its first since before the war.

Although they call it "Louisiana Lady," it is put on at the Century Theatre which, as every geographer knows, is well up towards Central Park. This musical serenade to New Orleans of the last century accordingly overfulfills its norm of stock theatre, including a magnolia number, which could not be squeezed into Central Park even by the stage's most ingenious horticulturist.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- As Congress heard calls today for a "gloves off" investigation of last week's airliner crashes, James M. Landis, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, reported that a structural failure of the tail assembly caused, in all probability, the accident to a DC-4 near Port Deposit, Md., which took fifty-three lives.
Unemployment insurance rolls in this city, which have been rising steadily since mid-March, are expected to take a sharp upward swing this week.

BATAVIA, Java, June 2 (AP) -- The Indonesian Republic's Cabinet met in Jogjakarta today to consider the "final offer" of the Dutch that a joint interim Dutch-Indonesian Government be set up to establish a federal government for the projected United States of Indonesia.

CHICAGO, June 2 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs. 7,500 head: total, 12,500. Some early sales around a quarter higher, but later trade and general market active and 25 to 50 cents higher on weights under 250 pounds:

BERLIN, June 2 -- Sweeping authority to promulgate laws covering the entire economic field was handed to the new German bi-zonal Economic Council by the recently announced United States-British agreement, it became known today. This is completely contrary to previous statements by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, and several of his principal subordinates that such powers were narrowly limited.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 2 -- Marshal Tito told visiting Bulgarian journalists over the weekend, it was reported today, that unification of "free Balkan peoples into a strong monolithic entity is indispensable."

SECURITY COUNCIL Committee 2 of Atomic Energy Commission -- Heard David E. Lilienthal, chairman of United States Atomic Energy Commission, declare United States intends to maintain and strengthen its pre-eminence in atomic weapons and general field of atomic energy.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The conviction of Mayor James M. Curley of Boston on mail fraud charges was upheld by the Supreme Court today. The tribunal refused to review the findings of the Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

WEST POINT, N. Y., June 2 -- Nine hundred graduates, the greatest number ever to return for June Week, participated with the corps of cadets in the alumni day exercises at the United States Military Academy today.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Senate passed by a voice vote today its bill to continue Federal rent controls, but on a much modified scale, from June 30 through Feb. 29, 1948. The measure was sent to conference with the House after the Senate, by a vote of 58 to 16, rejected a proposal for a one-year extension without any relaxations, as was urged by President Truman.

CLEVELAND. June 2--Ted Sepkowski, 24-year-old left-handed hitting outfielder, today became the property of the Yankees when the New York club claimed him for the waiver price of $10,000 from the Indians.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Suspension of a credit of $15,000,000 to the Hungarian Government was announced today by the State Department. Officials said the step was taken "pending clarification of developments" in Budapest.

Random notes: Reports on the striped bass fishing on Cape Cod are flowing in, and those who fished over the past week-end found conditions excellent, both at Buzzards Bay and in the Canal. Although most of the fish seem to have been taken on bait, the plug fishermen did all right, too, and the average bass ran about twelve pounds.

A ninety-sixth birthday celebration was held a bit ahead of time yesterday at the Lighthouse of the New York Association for the Blind at 111 East Fifty-ninth Street for James Hughes, who has been sightless since he was 81 years old.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- The plan for peacetime universal military training of American youth, recommended to President Truman by his advisory commission, was attacked today by Maj. Gen. Ellard A. Walsh, adjutant general of Minnesota and president of the National Guard Association.

World Bank Although making "satisfactory progress" in their preparations for the offering of debentures this summer, officials of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development have yet to make final decisions on a number of highly important matters, it was disclosed yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 2 -- Emil Sandstroem, Sweden's representative on the Permanent Court of Arbitration at The Hague, was elected chairman of the United Nations Committee of Inquiry on Palestine today. The ballot, a secret one, was the first of three important votes by the committee.

Almost 1,000 members of Actors Equity Association, attending the annual meeting held yesterday afternoon in the Hotel Astor heard speeches from supporters of the regular and independent tickets before casting their votes for councilors to serve on the union's governing board.
Amateurs and professionals competed at twenty-five sites throughout the country yesterday for 118 qualifiers' places in the forty-seventh United States Open Golf championship at St. Louis next week.

LONDON, June 2 -- There was great activity at the Indian Office and at the Prime Minister's office today as the British Government prepared to issue its fateful statement on the partition of India. Prime Minister Attlee is expected to make an announcement in the House of Commons and Lord Listowel, Secretary of State for India, in the House of Lords some time tomorrow afternoon.
BOSTON, June 2 (AP) -- Mayor James M. Curley indicated today he had no intention of resigning -- even though he might have to run this city of 800,000 from jail.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 2 -- Pending the establishment of a "foolproof" system of international atomic control, the United States is determined to maintain and strengthen its pre-eminence in atomic weapons and atomic energy generally, David E. Lilienthal told the control committee of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission today.

VIENNA, June 2 -- The possibility that the Russians may now regret Foreign Minister Molotoy's consent in Moscow to set up an Austrian treaty commission as a body to "establish the concrete facts" underlying the disputed articles of the Austrian treaty and are trying to retreat from it, has emerged from three weeks of futile sessions.

CHICAGO, June 2 (AP) -- The White Sox after losing the opener, 6 -- 2, scored two runs on a force play today to win the second game of a double-header from Boston, 6 -- 5, to end a five-game losing streak.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Wheat developed an extremely weak tone on the Board of Trade today, as buyers backed away from light hedge sales, the market running into stop-loss selling, after a higher opening had reflected unfavorable weather conditions.
ST. LOUIS, June 2 (AP) -- The Athletics mixed timely hitting with Cliff Fannin's wildness to take a 6-to-3 decision from the last place Browns tonight, getting an even break in the two-game series.

The Port of New York Authority filed yesterday with the Interstate Commerce Commission a protest against increased motor carrier rates to and from New York, which were published by the Middle Atlantic States Motor Carrier Conference and are in effect subject to investigation.
The flags of the United Nations were raised high in Brooklyn yesterday as 10,000 school children opened a week of tribute to the United Nations with a mile-long parade in the East New York section.
CHICAGO. June 2 -- Crop prospects in the Middle West, the nation's bread basket, were darkened today as the result of the unusually late, cola spring, capped by heavy rainfall over the week-end.

One thing that makes it harder to understand international news at a cursory reading is the new value of foreign moneys. It is a case where the hasty reader may fail to see that 40,000 is the same as 20,000,000, if the first number is British pounds and the second number is French francs.

TORONTO, June 2 (Canadian Press) -- Seventy per cent of Ontario's 3,230,000 acres of feed crops may be lost this year because of incessant rainfall and an abnormally cold spring, Minister of Agriculture T.L. Kennedy said today.

Months of negotiation between the Presbyterian Hospital and the city's Department of Public Works over means of supplying heat to the Florence Nightingale Hospital have delayed completion of the institution for cancer treatment and research, it was learned yesterday.

A United States-German Chamber of Commerce, Inc., with offices at 71 Broadway, has been organized for the purpose of stimulating private trade between the two countries by investigating markets, by assisting members in making contracts for transactions in the two countries, and by compiling data on trade conditions and availability of goods, it was announced yesterday.

JERUSALEM, June 2 -- Twelve shots were fired yesterday from the Syrian side of the border at a group of Jews who were plowing, the police reported today. The attack stemmed from a border dispute. There were no casualties.

The cotton market was slightly irregular, although quiet, during most of the session yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Final prices were 8 points higher on July and 4 to 7 points lower on other months.

An indefinite delay was forecast yesterday in the opening of public hearings by a three-man committee of the State Board of Social Welfare into relief expenditures by the city Welfare Department The inquiry was ordered as a result of the disclosures that thirty-seven relief families were being sheltered in hotels by the Welfare Department.

Glint Hartung, whose mound exploits for a time threatened to surpass even his most enthusiastic advance notices, yesterday finally met his match. But when defeat, his first after four victories in a row eventually cooled off the Hondo Hotshot, he at least had the satisfaction of knowing he had bowed to no one short of a grandmaster's rank.

The state's highest birthrate in thirty years and a flood of inquiries from young parents are among the reasons for a new bulletin, "Living With Baby," just off the press. It is the first of its kind to come from the New York State College of Home Economics, Cornell University, Ithaca, N.Y.

There's nothing like a brisk early morning tour through the Fulton Fish Market to shake that apathy that always goes with blue Monday. That's an observation, though, and not a prescription. It would gum up the wholesale fish business if all the New Yorkers who start that day in low gear rushed down to South Street to remedy their mood.

An increase in railroad rates that would have added an estimated $3,000,000 a year to fresh fruit and vegetable costs in the New York market has been suspended by the Interstate Commerce Commission, it was learned yesterday, the day the higher rates were to have become effective.

BOSTON, June 2 (AP) -- Throttling a ninth-inning rally, during which Rip Sewell, starting pitcher, had to leave the mound because of freezing in three fingers of his pitching hand, the Pirates today defeated the Braves, 4 -- 3. It was the second Pirate triumph over Boston in seven meetings this season.

PARIS, June 2 -- Foreign Minister Bidault protested today to the Egyptian Government on the arrival in Cairo as King Farouk's guest of Abd el Krim, conquered Moroccan Emir, El Krim had given his word to the French to settle with his wives and retinue on the Riviera, where the Government had arranged sumptuous quarters for him.
JERUSALEM, June 2 -- Officials of the Jewish Agency for Palestine conferred today on the presentation of Zionist evidence before the United Nations Committee of Inquiry on Palestine.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 2 (AP) -- Col. A. W. Herrington, contest board chairman of the American Automobile Association, said today last Friday's 500-mile race over the Indianapolis Motor Speedway was run fairly and was won fairly and that there is no basis for an investigation of the finish.

As a result of property owners' protests, the municipal Tax Commission has pared $107,509,075 from the $1,137,468,329 rise in assessed valuations it announced tentatively on March 1, Harry B. Chambers, commission president, announced yesterday in making public the final tax rolls for the fiscal year 1947-48.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 2 -- Unprecedented demands for electricity, resulting largely from industrial expansion and the growing use of electrical appliances, will pose no problem for the power and light industry this year, Grover C. Neff, president of the Edison Electric Institute, and head of the Wisconsin Power and Light Company, said yesterday at the first session of the institute's four-day annual meeting here.

A Hungarian food mission, headed by Dr. Josef P. Ersek, councilor of the Ministry of Agriculture of Hungary, arrived here on the Swedish American liner Gripsholm yesterday to study American and Canadian agriculture and tinned and frozen food processing.

Post-holiday apathy engulfed the stock market yesterday and, despite only moderate offerings, prices fell 1 to 2 points, especially in the air transports, while the composite rate fell 0.70 point. Extreme losses were shaded during the afternoon but demand failed to increase to such an extent as to change the downward course.

SANKILOS ISLAND lies somewhere in the eastern Mediterranean Sea of P.H. Newby's imagination. Rather like Rhodes, something like Cyprus, and much like Crete, with a strong Balkan flavor and numerous Levantine characteristics, it is no particular island and at the same time many islands. On Sankilos the barren mountains run like a spine down the interior and the banana plantations are nearly washed by the tideless sea.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., June 2 (AP) -- T.C. Melrose's Mel Eppley scored his second consecutive triumph in the $5,000 Inaugural Purse today, marketing the opener of Narragansett Park's 30-day summer meeting.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 2 -- Robert E. Dineen of New York, Superintendent of Insurance for New York State, said today that the new responsibility for the regulation of insurance rates accepted by the individual states under Public Law 15 must result in the fair and competent administration of rate regulatory laws now in effect.

Dolls dressed as June brides held the spotlight yesterday at the opening of the American Doll Show. The display will be on view till June 14 in the fifth-floor auditorium of Hearns, Fifth Avenue and Fourteenth Street.

Salvage work on the wreck of the United Air Lines DC-4 that crashed and burned at La Guardia Field Thursday night with the loss of forty-two lives was resumed yesterday. Every part of the giant airliner was examined carefully as it was cut from the ship.
ATLANTA, June 2 -- A broad community movement aimed chiefly at combating juvenile delinquency was begun in Atlanta today.

DETROIT, June 2 -- Members of the American Institute of Banking, assembling here today for their forty-fifth annual convention, were advised to make certain that their subordinates should know not only what they were doing but how to do it.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 2 (AP) -- Mrs. C.O. Ferguson's On The River raced to a front running victory in the Hotel Association Purse today at the Atlantic City track.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The news and rumors of contemplated slashes in the budget of the Veterans Administration, especially in so far as its Department of Medicine and Surgery is concerned, should have a disquieting effect upon every far-sighted citizen.

BALTIMORE, June 2 -- A challenge to "management" in the social welfare field to provide living-cost increases in the salaries of social workers was issued today in a forum discussion sponsored by the Social Service Employes Union as part of the program of the National Conference of Jewish Social Welfare.

Reports that a slowdown on the IRT Division of the city's rapid transit system would get under way soon gained circulation last night as 2,700 members of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, met behind closed doors to consider further action in the union's dispute with Charles P. Gross, chairman of the Board of Transportation.

PARIS, June 2 -- Bread-hungry Frenchmen in Paris and the surrounding area formed long lines before bakeries today to receive their slender ration of bread, reduced from 250 to 150 grams for the next two days as a result of the forty-eight-hour bakery-workers' strike.

In a setting of academic pageantry, Columbia University will award 6,876 degrees for undergraduate and advanced study at 4 P.M. today in South Court at the university's 193d commencement. Nearly half the graduates are war veterans whose effect upon enrollment is shown by the fact that the number of recipients of degrees exceeds last year's total by 2,455.

ROME, June 2 -- In his strongest anti-Communist speech since his elevation. Pope Pius condemned Russia's foreign policy and her oppression of neighbor nations today. By implication he praised the Truman Doctrine.

A long-range promotional program for furs, estimated as costing $100,000 for its first year, has been started by the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers. It was made known yesterday. The first issue of a house organ, entitled "Fur News," made its appearance yesterday.
LONDON, June 2 -- Herman Darewski, Russian-born composer of light song hits, band leader and former music publisher, died here today. His age was 64.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 2 -- Twentieth Century-Fox's projected remake of "Escape," the 1926 John Galsworthy play, will go before the cameras in England in August, with Rex Harrison in the leading role, the studio announced today.

The Marine Flasher docked at 7 o'clock at Pier 62, North River, last night. An hour later a pretty French girl stepped down the gangplank, rushed up to her future husband, threw her arms around him and cried "Leon, Leon!"

Rushing three runs across in the seventh and four more in the ninth, Fordham's baseball team handed the Halloran General Hospital nine a 7-to-2 setback on the later's diamond at Willowbrook, S. I., yesterday.

SINGAPORE, June 2 -- A qualified neutral observer recently in the fighting areas of northern French Indo-China predicted today a major famine in that troubled land if the French and Viet Namese continued hostilities beyond midJuly.

ZURICH, Switzerland, June 2 (Reuters)--Bullion believed to be worth about 300,000,000 Swiss francs (approximately $68,400,000) has been flown from Rumania to Switzerland in the last two months. It is estimated that about fifty tons of gold have been brought to Switzerland in this manner.

ROME, June 2 (AP)--The official English - language text of the Pope's speech follows: The Year 1947 Once again the recurrence of the feast of our holy predecessor and heavenly patron provides us with the occasion, venerable brethren, of dwelling for a while with you on the great questions of the tremendous happenings of the day, and on the dangers that threaten the whole world.

At the age of 61 years, Roderick Stephens has decided it is about time to give up ocean racing and confine his navigating to weekend races and cruises on Long Island Sound. He has also decided to go after his B.A. degree.

Harry Young's new comedy, "Open House," opening this evening at the Cort Theatre, brings back to the Broadway stage Mary Boland after an absence of five years. The comedienne was last seen hereabouts in the Theatre Guild revival of "The Rivals," which also starred Bobby Clark and Walter Hampden.

The present business readjustment period is temporary and will eventually lead to continued high production and sales levels for American industry, price and commodity experts in major industrial fields agreed yesterday. The conclusions were reached at panel sessions on commodity trends at the opening session of the thirtysecond annual convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

License Commissioner Benjamin Fielding announced yesterday that he had summoned seventeen used-car dealers to appear in his office later this week for allegedly buying new cars and selling them at exorbitant prices when some of the speedometers had readings as low as thirteen miles.

Gallorette, W. L. Brann's strong-running 5-year-old mare had it out with Stymie in the stretch at Aqueduct yesterday -- and won. Second choice to the second biggrest money winner of all time, Gallorette held off the Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' colorbearer in a grueling stretch duel and crossed the finish line a head in front of the 6-year-old son of Equestrian.

A sharp warning that the food industry in now facing declining price, record production and a shortage of sales was issued yesterday to retail grocery operators attending the first post-war Grocery Buyers Show at Madison Square Garden.

PITTSBURGH, June 2 -- a crippling strike by 2,500 freight-hauling truck drivers began here at 7 A.M. today as negotiators for an American Federation of Labor teamster local and the Western Pennsylvania Motor Carriers Association failed to agree on a wage increase.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Members of the music and musical instrument industry have proposed strong measures to counteract What Louis G. LaMair, president of the National Association of Music Merchants, declared was the backward movement of the industry.

BERLIN, June 2 -- The United States Military Government issued today a statement of economic policy strongly asserting that the reconstruction of German industry was indispensable to the reconstruction of Continental Europe.
TOKYO, June 2 -- American bankers have offered to Gen. Douglas MacArthur a $50,000,000 oneyear loan for Japan, it is understood on reliable authority.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor in the Franklin D. Roosevelt Cabinet, today called on the National Congress of Parents and Teachers to attack the problem of juvenile delinquency.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 2 --Conversion of twenty acres of the Westchester County Airport at Purchase into a home for the new Fifty-second Fighting Wing of the New York National Guard was proposed to the Westchester Board of Supervisors today by Col. Hampton Anderson, deputy state chief of staff of the guard.

Howie Pollet, St. Louis southpaw, who has been finding the going rough this season, won his own game with a tenth-inning single that brought the Cardinals a 5-4 victory over the Dodgers at Ebbets Field yesterday. The hit, Pollett's second of the long afternoon, drove home Enos Slaughter from second and gave the left-hander his third triumph of the campaign. He has lost six.

WASHINGTON, June 2--Herbert Hoover, in whose Administration the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was created, suggested today that if the agency was to be continued by Congress its lending power should be limited within its "original purpose."

Sales Here Up 15% in Week Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week snowed an increase of 15 per cent over the like week of last year, according to the "Hash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, June 2 (AP) -- Winthrop W. Aldrich, retiring president of the International Chamber of Commerce, told that group today that a recession in the United States would not "degenerate into a depression."
