Scrupulously holding to the standards of the week, Harry Young's ''Open House" kept open house at the Cort last evening. Since Mary Boland plays the leading part in it, you will not believe that it is a disastrous theatre frolic, nor will she.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 3 -- The Gould Paper Company's dam at McKeever went out tonight, threatening new floods along the Moose and Black Rivers as rainswollen streams receded elsewhere in flooded upstate areas.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- President Truman was directly informed today by an old Democratic Senatorial colleague of a prevailing Capitol opinion that a veto of the Republican labor bill would be overridden, if by a rather thin edge.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Representatives of the legitimate theatre told Congress today that the 20 per cent tax on theatre admissions is threatening to push the stage into a new depression. They asked a return to the prewar 10 per cent rate.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The vote by which the Senate approved today the $4,000,000,000 tax reduction bill was as follows: FOE THE BILL -- 48 Republicans -- 42 Alken Flanders Robertson Baldwin Gurney (Wyo.)

BALTIMORE, June 3 -- Jewish youth in Europe, particularly in the displaced persons camps, constitute a new pschological species of shock cases, as a result of "an utterly abnormal life," Ernest Papanek, executive director of American Youth for World Youth, today told the national conference of Jewish Social Welfare.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 3 -- Two United States Army prisoners who escaped from the Army transport General Ballou at Pier 13 on Staten Island late Monday night were recaptured by two military policemen in Raritan Township near here at noon today.

NEWARK, N.J., June 3 -- A committee of the Port of New York Authority offered to a committee of the City Council today a $70,000,000 proposal to take over and develop Newark Airport and Marine Terminal.

LONDON, June 3 -- Continued strength, of front rank industrials, a rise in oils, together with gains in Indian shares on the political news from New Delhi, were the features in an otherwise quiet stock market here today.

With commendable promptness, Representative Andrews and Senator Gurney have moved to present the matter of universal military training to the House and Senate Armed Services Committees. Mr. Andrews already has obtained the agreement of his committee to begin hearings within a week or ten days.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Henry Garsson said today he never saw a 2,100-acre Kentucky lumber business he owned during the war and that Andrew J. May, then chairman of the House Military Committee, ran it for him for nothing.

In an action that caught more than 300 residential and business tenants by surprise, the Office of Housing Expediter last night gave its sanction to initial construction work on a thirty-nine-story office and store building to replace the Marguery Hotel and apartments.

DETROIT, June 3 -- The Briggs Manufacturing Company broke off negotiations today with the United Automobile' Workers, CIO, charging that a "wildcat" strike had taken place during efforts to reach a new agreement.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3 (AP) -- The Phillies broke a four-game losing streak tonight as Schoolboy Rowe subdued the Cincinnati Reds, 4-1, before 15,551 for his seventh victory of the season. Eddie Miller of the Reds hit his twelfth home run of the season in the seventh.

Animals -- and we are one specie, don't forget -- need about half a hundred chemical compounds, none of which can pinch-hit for the other. There is one single remarkable food that contains every one of these necessaries -- milk. It's the first thing to sustain us in infancy; its consumption should continue for the rest of our lives.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Southern Coal Producers' Association made public today an offer of 85 cents a day wage increase to the United Mine Workers of America. They made the proposal, however, on condition that the miners abandon the basic sevenhour day, return to the basic eight-hour day at straight time pay and give up demands for portal -to-portal pay.

Many parents and teachers are "fumbling the ball" in their responsibility toward children, Dr. Charles Noble, dean of Hendricks Chapel, Syracuse University, charged yesterday. He spoke at the spring conference of the Metropolitan District New York State Congress of Parents and Teachers at the Pennsylvania Hotel.
Three hundred persons attended commencement exercises yesterday at the Horace Mann School for Boys in Fieldston, the Bronx.

The moderate epidemic of chicken pox that appeared among New York children early last December has passed its peak and should disappear within a month or two, Health Commissioner Israel Weinstein said yesterday.

Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson announced yesterday his intention to retire as rabbi of Congregation Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at Sixty-fifth Street, which he has served as spiritual leader for the last twelve years.

Operation at the Young-Demo amendment to the New York State Unemployment Insurance Law will reduce tax credits of employers in seasonal industries within the State on a long-term rather than an immediate basis, Milton O. Loysen, executive director, division of placement and unemployment insurance, State Department of Labor, declared yesterday.

STUTTGART, Germany, June 3 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, conceded today that establishment of the new bi-zonal German Economic Council would decrease to some extent the influence and prestige of the Laenderrat (council of states), which has functioned as the premier German legislative group in the United States zone.
RABAT, French Morocco, June 2 (Delayed) -- Equal trade rights here for all nations will be discussed this week by the Sultan and Gen. Alphonse-Pierre Juin, Resident General.
Accounts The Pilgrim Press, Boston, book publishers, to Alley Richards, Inc., same city.

Prizes have been awarded in the fifty-first annual exhibition of work by Artists of Chicago and Vicinity, which opens with a preview this, afternoon and to the public tomorrow at the Chicago Art Institute. Thirteen of the fifteen prizes were awarded by a jury of four artist-teachers of the Middle West, the other two awards being made by committees of the Municipal Art League and the Art Institute.

NEW DELHI, India, June 3 (Reuters) -- Following are excerpts from the radio addresses tonight of the Viceroy, Viscount Mountbatten, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, representing the Congress party, Mohammed Ali Jinnah, representing the Moslem League, and Sardar Baldev Singh, representing the Sikh community, concerning the British proposals in respect to India.

The return of the "Good Neighbor Fleet" to peacetime passenger service between New York and the east coast of South America was announced yesterday by Moore-McCormack Lines. The first sailing will be made on July 25 by the reconverted liner Argentina.

Staving off a spirited bid by the losers in the fourth and last period, the New York Polo Club handed Pete Bostwick's Bostwick Field trio a 10-to-7 defeat last night. It was the feature game of the double-header that inaugurated polo under lights in New York City at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island.

Commencement exercises for 133 students were held yesterday at the Riverdale campus of the College of Mount Saint Vincent, a Catholic institution for young women. Cardinal Spellman presided at the granting of degrees and Clare Gerald Fenerty, justice of the Court of Common Pleas, Philadelphia, was the speaker.
Plans have been completed for the Maine Tuna Tournament, which will be held July 26 to 29, inclusive, on Casco Bay, and entry forms may be obtained from the Bailey Island Tuna Club.
Two young Brooklyn boys, taking advantage of a mild June day to "play hookey" from school were instrumental yesterday in preventing a suicide leap from Williamsburg Bridge.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development made its first progress report to the world by short wave radio yesterday, offering the hope of immediate loans to ease the stringencies of life in many devasted countries throughout the world.
STUTTGART, Germany, June 3 -- At the Crossroads Red Cross Club in Stuttgart soldiers may have German girls as guests but WACS or Red Cross girls may not have the same privilege for German men.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- James M. Landis, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, said today that Russian airline services "are infinitely inferior" to American and that neither the Russians nor the British threaten this country's supremacy in commercial flying.

Rival banking syndicates comprising most of the nation's dealers in securities competed closely yesterday for an issue of $200,000,000 of new-money forty-year debentures of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. This is the utility company's second financing of this aggregate this year.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., June 3 (AP) -- Gradual elimination of all manual gear shifting on passenger automobiles in favor of automatic controls and transmissions was predicted at tonight's session of the Society of Automotive Engineers.

CAHBRIDGE, England, June 3 -- Twelve trumpeters sounded a fanfare from the top of a medieval tower when King George VI and Queen Elizabeth drove today through the great gate to open the fourth centenary celebrations at Trinity College.

The Police Department was commended to employes of other city departments as an example by Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday because of the great sacrifices made by members of the force while giving service to the city. He presented thirty-seven medals, including six posthumous awards, for extraordinary heroism during 1946 in a ceremony at City Hall.

MONTREAT, N.C., June 3 (AP)-- The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States (South) today reconsidered its stand on the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, tempering previous action by eliminating passages of a report which was critical of the council.
SECURITY COUNCIL Meets today at 3 P.M. to discuss report of Military Staff Committee (open).

The fey humor of Robert Q. Lewis, the disk jockey who graduated into the ranks of the comedians, is to receive more extensive exploitation by the CBS network. Beginning June 13, his "Little Show" is to be expanded into a twenty-five minute venture and will be heard at 8:30 P.M. Fridays.

In a letter to stockholders James Wilson, president of the Shawinigan Water and Power Company of Montreal, Quebec, stated yesterday that a special meeting of shareholders has been called for June 18 to vote on a proposal for the creation of a $30,000,000 issue of preferred stock.

LONDON, June 3 (AP) -- Lloyd Marshall, Negro light heavyweight from Cleveland, Ohio, tonight knocked out 175-pound British champion Freddie Mills and cast the deepest of gloom over British boxing prospects.

Money Market The New York money market experienced a heavy movement of funds yesterday, with a substantial part of the $1,000,000,000 in certificates redeemed by the United States Treasury in this area. According to informed observers, the outcome of the operation was that the banks got considerably more money than they lost through the Treasury's recent call.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 3 -- One of the major accomplishments of the United Nations so far is that it has helped clarify the nature of the conflicts that divide the various national states.
Led by the strength in July, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 14 to 37 points net higher.
LOS ANGELES, June 3 -- Interservice rivalry for developmental and operational control of guided missiles is still influencing the national missile program.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 3 -- In the last forty years the press of France, Britain and the United States have failed to play their proper roles in the interests of peace, Andre Geraud, French representative, charged here today.

For the second afternoon in succession one of the W.L. Brann racing string won the main event at Aqueduct yesterday. Monday, it was Gallorette in the Queens County Handicap; this time it was the 4-year-old gelding Daralet, also by Challenger II, in the $5,000 Class C Rockaway Purse.

American weather has become a critical factor in world recovery. This is the only nation that can produce the needed excess of food which less fortunate nations must have. If our crops this summer are poor, or much below normal, western Europe and large areas of the Far East must tighten their belts still more, with political consequences which none can foresee.
P.H. Glatfelter Company In connection with negotiation of private placement of $3,000,000

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Secretary of State Marshall urged Congress today to grant discretionary authority to the President to send military missions, consonant with American interests, to any country that asked for them.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 3 -- Howard Hughes today borrowed Melchor Ferrer from David O. Selznick to direct the closing sequences of "Vendetta," the problem production about which Hughes has disagreed with two previous directors.

New Jersey voters approved overwhelmingly yesterday the holding of a constitutional convention to revise the 103-year-old state charter. Voting throughout the state was exceedingly light as no high public positions were at stake.

Dictatorships can move quickly, quietly, without statements preparing public opinion for what they are about to do. They can always start war, military or political, without declaring war. Democracies can do none of these things. They cannot proceed by bold coups and all-out programs.

LONDON, June 3 (U.P.)--Lord Gretton, first baron of Stapleford, was known throughout Great Britain as a symbol of diehard conservatism for two generations. He spent many years trying with other ultra-conservatives to wreck the Liberal party.

VIENNA, June 3 -- Under heavy fire or criticism from his British and American co-members of the Austrian treaty commission the Russian representative, M.V. Novikov, at last explained today why he had refused to permit the Commission's committee of experts to examine "concrete facts" on German properties in eastern Austria claimed by Russia.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 3 -- Foreign trade handled, in the seaports of the world during the first three months of this year was only a fraction of what it had been in 1937, according to enlarged tables of official figures contained in the latest issue of the United Nations monthly statistical bulletin.

BOSTON, June 3 (UP) -- Pushing across three runs after two were out in the fifth inning, two of them on Stan Musial's fifth homer of the season, the Cardinals tonight shut out the Braves, 3 -- 0. In doing so they ended Lefty Warren Spahn's winning streak at eight games.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The United States is satisfied with Argentina's compliance with the anti-Nazi provisions of the Act of Chapultepee and is now willing to resume discussions of a Western Hemisphere defense pact with the LatinAmerican republics, President Truman disclosed today.

Writing history on a grand scale and in a manner which will win praise throughout the free world, the British Government has proposed, and the Indian leaders have accepted, a settlement for India which offers that great sub-continent and its nearly 400,000,000 people their best and perhaps only chance of achieving peacefully their long-sought goal of complete self-government.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, denouncing the "apparent treacherous conquest" of Hungary by the Communists, told the Senate today that it might become the duty of the United States to bring Hungary's case "to trial" before the United Nations.

There isn't much time left for those who haven't attended "The Telephone" and "The Medium" to witness Gian-Carlo Menotti's twin bill of musical dramas or miniature operas at the Barrymore. At the end of the week the final curtain will ring down on the forty-fourth performance.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: An Associated Press story printed in the times on May 20 contains the following paragraph: "Monsanto is the third organization to run the Clinton laboratories. Scientists and a staff from the University of Chicago first operated the plant.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 3 -- For the first time since he won the Houston open, Bobby Locke, the 29-year-old invader from South Africa, had to play second fiddle to America's golf pros today. Two of them finished ahead of him in the pro-amateur medal play tourney at the Meadow Brook Club an three others matched his score.

With all the color, dignity and pageantry of traditional academic ceremony, Columbia University conferred yesterday a record total of 6,876 degrees for undergraduate and advanced study at the university's 193d annual commencement exercises in South Court.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 3 -- Hungarian Minister of Justice Istvan Ries announced today that he would meet tomorrow or Thursday with the Communist Minister of the Interior and head of the police, Laszlo Rajk, to work on a new election law.

LONDON, June 3 -- The Philippine Government is pressing a claim for possession of the Turtle Islands, a small group off the Borneo coast now administered by Great Britain, it was disclosed here today.

The stock market resumed the advance yesterday after Monday's interlude and, paced by selected industrial issues, rallied fractions to 2 points. Losses sustained in the previous session were more than offset and final quotations remained at the day's peaks, with the composite rate up 1.01 points.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., June 3 -- Earnings of the Standard Oil Company (N.J.) in the first half of this year will approximate $140,000,000, Frank W. Abrams, chairman, told stockholders at a meeting today. This would be equal to $5.12 a share on the outstanding capital stock of the company and would compare with $88,000,000, or $3.22 a share, in the first half of 1946.

Plans for an Institute of Industrial and Social Medicine as a unit of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, to meet the increasing interest in industrial health as a factor in world production, were announced yesterday by Dr. Currier McEwen, dean of New York University College of Medicine.

New York University's Metropolitan Conference baseball champions will represent District II in the National Collegiate A. A. playoffs in the Eastern division. The tournament will establish an official college champion for the first time.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., June 3 -- President Truman's new private transport plane was unveiled at the Douglas aircraft plant today. Its nose is adorned with a painted eagle and its interior decor displays mahogany, elkhide and transparent plastic.

If all the weird things that bobbed up in the double-header between the Dodgers and Pirates at Ebbets Field yesterday were laid end to end there would be a Congressional investigation. There might still be one when the eerie facts surrounding the 11-6 and 8-7 sweep of the twin bill by the Dodgers become known, if possible.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, today urged the 3,000 delegates attending the golden jubilee convention of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers here to enlist the aid of their state health departments and local medical societies as a first step in helping their communities obtain more adequate local health departments.

ALBANY, June 3 -- Paxton Blair, chairman of the three-member committee of the State Social Welfare Board that is investigating the administration of relief in New York City, said today that test cases already taken from the files "tend to show grants of special relief without thorough investigation of the basis for the requests."

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Warning that enactment of the incometax reduction bill would only deepen and prolong an inevitable business recession was sounded today by Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The condition statement of weekly reoprting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 28, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:

CHICAGO, June 3 (AP) -- Lefty Frank Papish stopped the Athletics on three scattered singles tonight as the White Sox won the series opener, 3 -- 0. The White Sox bunched four of their seven hits off Joe Coleman for all their runs in the fourth inning.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 3 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie, in a talk to secretariat employes assigned to the United Nations Committee of Inquiry on Palestine, outlawed today off-duty discussion of the Holy Land problem. He warned the special staff that hard days were ahead, with overtime work but no extra pay.

Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., filed suit in Federal Court yesterday for $750,000 against the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation of Burbank, Calif., for the loss last July 11 of a four-engine Constellation plane that crashed near Reading, Pa., with a loss of five lives.

The predicament of the builders and prospective purchasers of 1,850 houses on Long Island, designed for gas heat but unable to obtain the necessary fuel, was studied yesterday at a hearing before the State Public Service Commission.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 3 -- The professional soldier justifies his place in American life through his self-dedication to the preservation of the free system established by our Constitution, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, Chief of Staff, told members of the United States Military Academy graduating class here today.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday the formation of the Mayor's Executive Committee on Administration and creation of a Division of Analysis in the Bureau of the Budget to improve the efficiency of the city government and supervise policies and procedures in city departments under his control.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- James M. Landis, chairman of the civil aeronautics board, said today that it was possible a piece of cowling or propellor may have struck the tail of the Eastern Air Lilies plane, leading to the crash in which fifty-three persons died at Port Deposit, Md.

The wide experience of David E. Lilienthal as a manager of publicly owned enterprises and his present responsibility as head of the agency which has sole control of atomic activities in this country clearly made him a well-qualified witness to appear before the Atomic Energy Commission of the United Nations.

DALLAS, Tex., June 3 -- Theatre '47, which will change its numerals with each year, began its life here tonight under the direction of Margo Jones, known to Broadway for participation in the productions of "Joan of Lorraine," "On Whitman Avenue" and "The Glass Menagerie."

The Lay Society of the New York Diabetes Association, composed entirely of laymen, both diabetics and non-diabetics, interested in the promotion of knowledge about the proper care and prevention of this disease, held its first meeting last night at the New York Academy of Medicine.

The automobile and the highway must be perfected to the highest degree of safety and the public educated to use them properly if the problem of traffic accidents is to be solved, Sidney J. Williams, assistant to the president of the National Safety Council, warned yesterday.

CADETS Glenn W. Davis and Felix A. Blanchard traded in their cadet gray uniforms for Army brown with shiny gold bars on the shoulders yesterday at West Point. They are brand-new second lieutenants and the intercollegiate sports world undoubtedly breathed a collective sigh of relief. Superman and his twin have departed.

LONDON, June 3 (AP) -- The text of Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee's statement on the British plan for Indian self-rule: I desire to make an important statement on India policy. A similar statement is being made at the same time in the House of Lords and by the Viceroy in New Delhi.
The famous tourist center of Deauville is back to normal and ready to welcome thousands of American travelers, Robert Fossurier, Mayor of the Normandy resort, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Administration's spokesman on foreign policy at the Capitol today once again was Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, a Republican. This phenomenon in United States politics has gone on view so frequently in the last two years that it is being accepted as a commonplace.

LOS ANGELES, June 3 -- The public "rightly or wrongly," believes lower prices are in order, and "that can be accomplished only by greater output per manhour," Don Francisco, New York advertising executive, told the twelfth annual convention of the Federation of Sales Executives today.

Combining a few strokes of good fortune with some hefty blows of their own, which included three jarring home runs, the Giants last night served notice that their bid to lead the National League flag race is nothing to be brushed aside in a hurry.

Sharply rising competition at higher rather than lower costs will mark business developments for many months to come, it was predicted yesterday by Paul H. Nystrom, Professor of Marketing at Columbia University and president of the Limited Price Variety Stores Association.

Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson took issue with critics of the "military mind" yesterday, asserting that it is not a mind hostile to freedom and that under its leadership this nation came safely through the greatest war ever fought.

City regulation of residential rents in the event Federal controls are eased or removed from New York City while they are retained for other sections of the country was proposed yesterday in a bill introduced in the City Council by Joseph T. Sharkey, Brooklyn Democrat and majority leader of the Council.
A "town meeting" of the neighbors in Greenwich Village on solution of the section's serious traffic problems was held last night at Greenwich House. 27 Barrow Street.

Prince Abdorreza Pahlevi, younger brother of the Shah of Iran, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, told yesterday at the Hotel Pierre in his first interview here, how he has been studying "incognito" at Harvard University for three years.

Opposition to legislation which would permit an increase of 50 per cent in the duties of wool and woolen products was expressed in a telegram sent by the National Foreign Trade Council to the members of Congress concerned, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- Definite announcement that the Government was starting its buying of new crop wheat and asking the trade for offers for export shipment from Gulf ports, stimulated buying of wheat futures today, on the Board of Trade, while shorts in corn were on the defensive as buying of that grain became general due to prospective unfavorable weather and the pronounced strength in the cash market.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The freight car shortage which has plagued commerce for months became an anti-trust issue today when Attorney General Tom C. Clark announced that he has authorized a grand jury investigation into alleged restraints of trade by certain corporations and individuals in the railway freight car building industry.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (U.P.) -- Three Texans appeared before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today and criticized the AngloAmerican oil treaty as "the entering wedge" toward Government control of the domestic petroleum industry.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The writer of this letter visited Hungary twice in the last two years and, through old friends and acquaintances, was able to find out the true feelings of thoughtful Hungarians of all shades of political opinion.

Glancing Through the Paper Mrs. Roosevelt, speaking to no less than eleven reunion classes at Vassar over the Memorial Day holiday, was moderately cheerful about an international charter of human rights.

The Mugg was behind bars in the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals shelter at 233 Butler Street in Brooklyn yesterday after fourteen months of freedom. He was captured on Monday afternoon in a BMT garage on Thirty-ninth Street between Second and Third Avenues.

ST. LOUIS, June 3 (AP) -- Bob Dillinger singled home the tying and winning runs with no one out in the ninth inning to give the St. Louis Browns a 4-to-3 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight. The visitors had taken a one-run lead in the first half of the inning on a double by Rudy York.

An issue of $2,500,000 of bonds of School District No. 150, Peoria, Ill., due June 1, 1948 to 1967, was awarded yesterday at bidding to a banking group headed by the Harris Trust Savings Bank. The bid was 100.003, with $1,550,000 designated as 1 1/4s and $95.0,000 as 1 1/2s, an interest cost of 1.407 per cent.
DOVER, Del., June 3 (AP) -- Robert E. Ringling won back the presidency today of the Ringling Brothers-Barnum Bailey Combined Shows, Inc.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 3 -- Unless the destructive policy of unnecessary regulation and high taxation of free enterprise is stopped, Grover C. Neff, president of the Edison Electric Institute, said here today, the whole tempo of free enterprise would be slowed, with disastrous results.

CLEVELAND, June 3 (AP) -- Gerry Priddy slammed a home run in the ninth inning tonight to give the Washington Senators a 6-5 victory over the Cleveland Indians in the opener of a three-game series before 20,968 fans. It was Priddy's first four-bagger of the season.

JERUSALEM, June 3 -- Within three and a half hours after the first attache of the United Nations Committee of Inquiry on Palestine had arrived here, antiterrorist sirens sounded a general alarm tonight. The cause of the alert was so insignificant an explosion that it could not be located at first.

Two former employes of the Office of Price Administration, one an enforcement attorney, were indicted yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, on the charge of demanding and accepting a $10,000 bribe to influence the prosecution of an alleged violation of OPA regulations on sugar.

PARIS, June 3 -- As negotiators failed today to settle the bakers' strike and other strikes began or were threatened, the Socialists joined the moderates and conservatives in accusing the Communists of stirring up labor troubles for political purposes.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- With an independent survey already in hand, indicating a drop in production and sales for the last half of 1947, the Senate-House Committee on the Economic Report announced today that it will begin hearings June 23 on the general business outlook.

BAYSIDE, L.I., June 3 -- Conquering a course which has always been one of her jinxes, Mrs. R.M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley, New York State champion, posted a record score of 36, 40 -- 76 over the Oakland Golf Club course today.

LONDON, June 3 -- The procedure for dividing India, an offer of dominion status and the transfer of British power this summer, and the fact that the Indian leaders had accepted these proposals were all announced today in New Delhi and London.

Fourteen table settings arranged by members of the garden clubs of Brooklyn were exhibited yesterday at Abraham Straus. They will remain on view today on the store's eighth floor and will be moved tomorrow morning to the china department, where they may be seen until Saturday.

LUDWIGSBURG, Germany, June 3 (AP) -- Thirty-six German-born undesirables deported from the United States, including convicted criminals, Nazi sympathizers, former Bundists and draft-dodgers, will be turned loose in Germany soon.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Despite the optimistic statements in the press, and in speeches by business leaders and Government officials, that we are not in for a depression, all the visible signs point to the contrary. Coming events cast their shadows before, and the present recession is the shadow.

Formal hearings before the Civil Aeronautics Board's safety division in the crash of the United Air Line's DC-4 at La Guardia Field last Thursday will begin next Wednesday, probably at the Hotel New Yorker. The inquiry into the crash of an Eastern Air Lines' plane at Port Deposit, Md., will open a week later.
LONDON, June 3 (AP) -- Eighteen horses still were entered tonight for Saturday's running of the Derby at Epsom, but it was predicted that at least three of them would be scratched.

The trim 216-foot former Coast Guard cutter Northland, whose history since she was built in 1927 has been an open book, marked by valiant service including the destruction of German weather expeditions in Greenland during the war, suddenly became a mystery ship yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 3 -- The Palestine Arab delegation to the United Nations has recommended a complete boycott of the United Nations fact-finding committee on the Holy Land. The recommendation, which was unanimous, was announced tonight by Emile Ghory, a member of the Palestine Arab Higher Committee.
NANKING, June 3 -- The scope and violence of the Government's repressive measures against students and other critics are characteristic of the worst periods of the Kuomintang dictatorship.

ROME, June 3 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi, in an interview granted to the writer today, expressed gratification over the statement made about Italy by United States Secretary of State Marshall yesterday and pleaded for American help to Italy in this very difficult phase of her history.

A controversy in which city officials and counsel for Elmer R. Haslett, suspended City Airports Director, would be opponents, was foreshadowed last night as Mr. Haslett prepared to demand a public hearing when he appears before John M. Murtagh, Investigation Commissioner, at 10 o'clock this morning.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Senate completed Congressional action on the tax reduction bill today amid persistent reports that President Truman would veto it.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve Board, told the House Banking and Currency Committee today that the RFC and all other Federal credit agencies operating on Government capital should promptly get out of business and liquidate their holdings.

DETROIT, June 3 -- The American League has a new batting leader tonight. His name is Joe DiMaggio and, because of the resurgence of this same DiMaggio, the Yankees now are one game closer to the league leadership, two games back of the Tigers.

Two Federal inter-agency programs aimed at reducing costs and improving efficiency in governmental purchasing of more than 3,000,000 items of supplied and materials were disclosed yesterday by Clifton E. Mack, director of purchases, Treasury Department, during the convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents at the Waldorf-Astoria.

CHICAGO, June 3 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 9,500 head, total 17,000; general market active at 50 to 75 cents lower on weights under 250 pounds; weights over 250 pounds 35 to 50 cents off; some big weights

TOKYO, June 3 -- A life of almost tedious simplicity, apparently with few amenities not shared by most of their subjects, was revealed today in the first joint interview ever given by the Emperor and Empress. Their food is the same makeshift mixture distributed under the rationing system.

NEW DELHI, India, June 3 -- Spokesmen for India's quarreling political elements in broadcasts to their countrymen tonight indicated that they were prepared to accept, however reluctantly, the British proposal for the partition of India.

Trade indicators reveal that the boom in United States exports is about over, despite current totals equivalent to $1,000,000 a day for every state in the union, D.W. Michener, associate director of research, the Chase National Bank, said yesterday.

PARIS, June 3 -- Although the Russian veto has held up the union of the Saar with France, the Government is proceeding in the district on the theory that economic union will soon be an accomplished fact, Pierre Denoyer says in an article from Saarbruecken to be published in the Figaro tomorrow.

Thousands of garment workers, bakers, truck drivers, longshoremen and members of other American Federation of Labor unions will parade to Madison Square Garden late this afternoon to demand that President Truman veto the Taft-Hartley labor bill.
The graduate of a school of Columbia University will not have to worry about getting a job, according to Miss Mary A. Wegener, Associate Director of Placement at Columbia.

CHICAGO, June 3 (U.P.) -- Ten youngsters who had never taken a piano lesson faced a veteran in teacher-instruction today, Dr. Raymond Burrows, professor at Teachers College, Columbia University, and in only 40 minutes all were playing with both hands.

LAKE SUCCESS. N.Y., June 3 -- Andrei A. Gromyko sharpened Russia's demand today for a highpriority treaty to outlaw the atomic bomb and announced that he would again carry the fight through to the United Nations Security Council.
Nation-wide protest demonstrations against recent legislation restricting the employment of aliens on American ships have been scheduled for today by the National Maritime Union, CIO.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The House Armed Services Committee decided today to begin hearings on universal military training next week. This action was accompanied by a mutual acknowledgment of urgency by Chairman Walter G. Andrews, Republican, of New York, and Dr. Karl T. Compton, chairman of the President's Advisory Commission on Universal Military Training.

Mayor O'Dwyer, speaking last night on a national radio network under the auspices of the American Federation of Labor, vigorously opposed the Taft-Hartley revision of the Wagner Labor Relations Act as class legislation, sponsored by Republicans and others who "fear the working man."

Twenty-seven physicians and two pharmacists in New York have come under the disciplinary scrutiny of the State Board of Regents for illegal dealing in narcotics during the war, it was disclosed yesterday.

Twenty-seven physicians and two pharmacists in New York have come under the disciplinary scrutiny of the State Board of Regents for illegal dealing in narcotics during the war, it was disclosed yesterday.
An 1,800-acre wildfowl sanctuary in Suffolk County will be presented to the Federal Government next Saturday by Maurice Wertheim, banker and sportsman, it was announced yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 4 -- Rental agreements between the United Nations and the Metropolitan and New York Life Insurance Companies, involving 912 apartments and more than $1,000,000 annual rentals in two great housing projects now under construction, were canceled today.
AKRON, Ohio, June 4 -- (AP) -- Although he failed to participate in the United States open qualifying rounds, Herman Keiser "teed off" anyway today -- against the United States Golf Association.

FORT WILLIAM, Ont., June 4 (AP) -- Twelve crew members, including three women, perished before dawn today when the Canadian freighter Emperor rammed into Lake Superior rocks in the fog and sank in the worst Great Lakes shipping disaster in five years.

JERUSALEM, June 4 -- "If the Palestine troops were permitted to use the full power of their weapons against the whole Jewish community," Lieut Gen. Sir Alan Cunningham, High Commissioner, declared in a dispatch published tonight, "terrorists' activities would be brought to an end in a matter of hours."

Late selling yesterday canceled out a new rise on the stock market as early gains up to 2 points were transformed into fractional losses. The list thus followed a pattern which had been anticipated in Wall Street at the week's start, with each successive move of strength followed by a period of backing down.

The conditions laid down by the other Pan-American nations in 1945 for Argentina's readmittance to good standing were that she rid herself of the Nazi influences and personalities which had made Buenos Aires a center of Axis espionage during the war. This, says the Peron Government, it now has done.

Delivery of New RCA Set Due Radio Corporation of America will make initial deliveries of its new ten-tube console radio-phonograph combination to New York dealers within a week, Irving Sarnoff, vice president and general manager, Bruno, Bruno-New York, RCA metropolitan area distributor, announced yesterday.

The stepping down from office of Frank Hague in the principality he has ruled for thirty years marks the end of an era. It was the era of the urban boss who brooked no opposition and ruthlessly crushed any signs of it. Hague was the most durable of them all.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- American Federation of Labor and Railroad Brotherhood spokesmen told Senators today that they feel a merger of this country's overseas airline operators is inevitable in the face of foreign competition.

Charles T. Lawson, chairman of the excise tax committee of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association, told the House Ways and Means Committee yesterday that the present excise tax is discriminatory because it taxes some products and not others of almost identical classifications.

A collision between a city-owned bus and a gasoline truck, after which the bus struck a memorial tree in front of the Vanderveer Park Methodist Church, killed a young woman passenger at Glenwood Road and East Thirty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, at 4:45 P.M. yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 4 (AP) -- The Athletics pushed over seven runs during a wild eleventh inning today to hand the White Sox a 10-3 setback. It was the third time that Philadelphia bounced back during the game after overcoming 1-0 and 3-1 Chicago leads before breaking a 3-3 deadlock established in the eighth inning.

JERSEY CITY, June 4 -- Frank Hague Eggers Sr., who will become this city's Mayor on June 17, succeeding his uncle, Frank Hague, little resembles the man whose place he will take in public office. Mr. Eggers is considerably shorter than the Mayor, with reddish brown hair thinning at the forehead but with the Mayor's forceful jaw.

LONDON, June 4 -- Responsible Palestine Jewish elements are determined to stamp out terrorism there and ready to use force, if necessary, to do so, Mrs. Golda Myerson, head of the political department of the Jewish Agency for Palestine said today.

The Port of New York Authority, in its first action as manager of New York's air fields, last night closed to four-engined aircraft the No. 18-36 runway at La Guardia Field from which a United Air Lines DC-4 lurched to disaster last Thursday night.

BOSTON, June 4 -- George C. Marshall, Secretary of State, will receive the degree of Doctor of Laws from Harvard University at the commencement exercises tomorrow. He is expected to deliver a speech which perhaps will include an important pronouncement on foreign affairs.

KILKIS, Greece, June 4 -- Members of the subcommittee of the United Nations Balkan Commission of Inquiry, engaged in investigating frontier incidents, said today that a Bulgarian frontier guard at the Spanovitsa post had refused them entry yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 4 -- When Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg condemned the "apparent treacherous conquest" of Hungary by the Communists and said that the United States might have to bring Hungary's case "to trial" before the United Nations, he raised the most difficult and in some ways the most serious political question in the whole field of international relations.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (U.P.) -- Dr. Alf S. Alving of the University of Chicago told an Army Medical Center Conference today that scientists have discovered a cure for tertiary or recurrent malaria, the greatest single Army medical problem in the second World War.

One of the last of the powerful city bosses, whose influence extended to state and national politics, Mayo Prank Hague of Jersey City ruled his home town with an iron hand, quelled rebellions against his rule ruthlessly and sought to prevent criticism of his administration even to the point of trying to suppress "free speech."

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Republican tax reduction bill was delivered to the White House today amid indications that President Truman would take his time in letting Congress and the country know what he planned to do with it.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- The texts of Messrs. Braden's and Truman's letters follow: Mr. Braden's Letter My Dear Mr. President: It is with regret that I tender my resignation as Assistant Secretary of State, which I should like to take effect on July 1.

A half million enthusiastic New Yorkers lined Broadway from the Battery to City Hall yesterday as the Fire Department gave a preview of twenty-four pieces of its newest apparatus that cost the city $330,000.

PITTSBURGH, June 4 -- Construction of the first of a series of new large-scale smokeless solid-fuel manufacturing plants to be built in coal consuming centers throughout the country is being started here immediately by the Disco Company, subsidiary of Pittsburgh Consolidation Coal Company, officials revealed today.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 4 -- Soviet Lieut. Gen. V.P. Sviridov has refused permission for a United States Army officer to inspect military installations of Hungary, technically still an enemy country, United States spokesmen disclosed today. The Soviet action raised speculation that the Russians might already be taking a hand in training the Hungarian army.

AMSTERDAM, June 4 (Aneta) -- The market rallied strongly in increased trading on the Stock Exchange. The firmer tone was attributed to favorable reports of Netherlands industrial developments. Industrials led the advance, followed by Indies plantations issues and banking shares. Shipping stocks and state bonds were steady.
LONDON, June 4 -- Featuring the start of the new account in the stock markets here today were the Indian shares, as a result of the new Government plan for India.

ST. LOUIS, June 4 (AP) -- Home runs by Ted Williams and Sabath Mele, the latter with a man on base, gave the Boston Red Sox the margin of victory over St. Louis in a twilight game tonight, beating the Browns, 5 to 2, to split a two-game series.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Former Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana resigned today as special counsel for the Senate War Investigating Committee. He was named several weeks ago to handle an investigation of Government purchases of oil from the Arabian Gulf area.

Plans for an eighteen-story building containing ninety-seven apartments to be erected at 248-358 East Seventy-ninth Street were filed yesterday by the 350 East Seventyninth Street Corporation of 9 Rockefeller Plaza. Carroll W. Harding, the architect, estimated the cost at $1,000,000.

The "finger man" in The Brooklyn Daily Eagle hold-up last January, embittered by the indifference of his accomplices to his confinement in Brooklyn City Prison, has identified those who took part in the crime.

BOSTON, June 4 (AP) -- On the strength of successive sixth-inning home runs by Nanny Fernandez and Danny Litwhiler, the Boston Braves tonight defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 3-1, behind Charlie (Red) Barrett, who was making his first start against his former teammates.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- The text of the statement by the Hungarian Minister to the United States and three diplomatic associates declaring their unwillingness to recognize the new regime in Hungary: After the free and unfettered elections in November, 1945, diplomatic relations between the United States and Hungary were resumed.

Although wholesalers' inventories have risen considerably in the past year, all available evidence indicates that in relation to sales volume they are below most prewar years, it was pointed out yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., June 4 -- (AP) -- Charles F. Kettering reported tonight progress in development of a new high compression automobile engine which, with improved fuel, may increase gasoline mileage by 33 1/3 per cent, and eventually save American motorists a billion dollars annually.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 4 (AP) -- Midshipman James W. Hawthorne of Greenwich, Conn., honor man of the Naval Academy's graduating class, received nine of the sixty prizes handed out today at a brigade parade.
TRENTON, June 4 -- By popular mandate, New Jersey's Constitution will receive a complete overhauling this summer at a convention of civic and political leaders.

ROME, June 4 -- Premier de Gasperi's fourth Cabinet held its first meeting this morning and approved the reorganization of the financial Ministries. The new Ministry of the Budget was created, with powers of supervision over the Ministries of the Treasury and Finance, and was entrusted to the distinguished liberal economist, Luigi Einaudi, who also has the post of Vice Premier.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, informed the Senate Banking Subcommittee on Sugar today that the country is "very close to the point" where household rationing of the product can be ended but said it was "much safer" to continue controls for the present.

Leland Hayward is said to be planning an active role in the theatre this season. The producer has taken an option on "Mr. Roberts" and is looking to a fall presentation, according to reliable reports.

CANTON, Ohio, June 4 (AP) -- Walter McClain, amateur star from the Sleepy Hollow Club of Cleveland, and John Malutic. 34-yearold pro from the Squawk Creek Club of Youngstown. Ohio, today led the 36-hole Northern Ohio qualifier for the National Open Golf Championship next week at St. Louis.

PARIS, June 4 -- French officials acknowledged today for the first time that a special Russian mission and Russian police had charge of Camp Beauregard at Vaucresson, near here, for Russian citizens being repatriated from France.

VIENNA, June 4 -- The Austrian treaty commission adjourned indefinitely today to permit the Russian members to ask Moscow for authority to accept a French Compromise proposal designed to extricate the commission from the three-week impass over procedure.

RUTLAND, Vt., June 4 (AP) -- A flash flood roaring out of a broken power dam paralyzed this second largest Vermont city today, causing damage estimated at $2,000,000, but the only feared casualty, a 13-year-old boy, was safe.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The House refused today to go further than its Appropriations Committee had recommended in reducing the War Department's military budget of $5,716,791,500 for 1947-48.

Fifty representatives of almost every branch of civil and military aviation met with Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallahder yesterday to study a set of proposed regulations for flying over this city. Details of the new regulations were not disclosed.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- For the moment the government of the United States has been compelled by the Hungarian crisis to violate a basic dictum of diplomacy. This is that a nation must never "first shake a fist and then a finger," an admonition which The Washington Evening Star called to the attention of the government editorially today.

A banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. was awarded yesterday a new issue of $1,000,000 sewer improvement bonds of Reno, Nevada, at a bid of 100.6658 for interest of 1 3/4 per cent. The bonds, maturing from 1949 to 1967, were reoffered at prices to yield from 0.80 per cent to 1.80 per cent.

PARIS, June 4 -- Beset by the increasing number of delegations demanding wage adjustments, the Cabinet staved off the railway engineers' and firemen's strike by a day and dealt today, with only limited success, with claims from a half-dozen other trades.

WASHINGTON, June 4--President Truman asked Congress to-day for "early consideration" of legislation to require all physically able young men to undergo mili-tary training. His first recom-mendation on the subject was sent to Congress on Oct. 23, 1945.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The United Mine Workers of America ended today wage conferences with the Southern Coal Producers Association by rejecting the latter's wage offer as one which would mean "betraying the membership and liquidating the union."

In an intrepretation of contracts between the International Longshoremen's Association and stevedoring companies, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that the contract "overtime" rate for night and holiday work did not constitute overtime compensation within the meaning of the Fair Labor Standards Act when an employe works over forty hours in a week.

Deputy Commissioner Charles E. Martin of the Board of Transportation announced yesterday he would order Benjamin Cordts, superintendent of the IRT repair shop at 147th Street and Lenox Avenue, to begin an investigation immediately of charges made by the Civil Service Forum Transit Committee involving activities of men described as members of the Transport Workers Union, CIO.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 4 -- A five-man parking authority, said by officials here to be the first of its kind in the nation, was appointed today by Mayor Silas S. Clark to try to solve the city's tantalizing problem of keeping automobile parking spaces abreast of needs.

LONDON, June 4 (Canadian Press) -- The Government, in a statement next week, will accept the principle of equal pay for women in industry, but will refuse to put the policy into effect immediately, it was learned today. An overwhelming majority voted for prompt action on this issue at the recent Labor party conference at Margate.
With two members in opposition, the Board of Education approved yesterday a six-year school building program estimated to cost $260,000,000.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Predicted opposition to the Stratton Displaced Persons Immigration Bill began materializing this morning when hearings opened before a House Judiciary subcommittee. Representative William G. Stratton, Republican, of Illinois, spent two hours in defense of his measure before a series of sharp attacks led by Representative Ed Gossett, Democrat, of Texas.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 4 --A plan for "balanced economic development" in all countries must be evolved so that the building up of underdeveloped regions may proceed without feelings of national economic conflicts, Dr. Lewis Larwin, the United States representative, told the United Nations Economic and Employment Commission today.

DETROIT, June 4 -- The Yankees soared to new hitting heights before a gathering of 35,948 today at Briggs Stadium in their twin bill against the Tigers, but concentrated too much fire power in one demonstration. The result was a stand-off that left second-place New York still two games back of Detroit.

A $25,000,000 program calling for the establishment of thirtythree municipal parking lots and the construction of nine parking garages in "traffic problem areas" in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx, was submitted to Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday by his Special Traffic Committee.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: However optimistic one might be by temperament, it is hard from time to time not to despair of the future of our world and of our civilization. I found myself in one of those gloomy moods about the future of the world when I had the good fortune to read the article by Anne O'Hare McCormick in NEW YORK TIMES of May 24.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 4 -- A five-year defense program, in which emphasis will be put on naval building, was outlined in the House of Representatives at Canberra today by Defense Minister John J. Dedman.

Bawl Street Journal Out Advance sale of the Bond Club's 1947 edition of the Bawl Street Journal will begin this afternoon, with $1-a-copy first editions obtainable at the Wall Street newsstand outside the Stock Exchange Building and at the offices of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane, whose Norman Smith is circulation manager.

Welfare Commissioner Edward E. Rhatigan yesterday accused Paxton Blair, chairman of the committee of the State Board of Social Welfare that is investigating relief expenditures in this city, of "jumping to conclusions" before the Welfare Department had had an opportunity to be heard.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 -- A "compromise" amendment to the reorganization plan of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey, making it acceptable to all parties if promptly consummated, will be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission within a few days, it was announced today.
TOKYO, June 4 -- A rule prohibiting any official connected with the occupation from engaging in commerce in Japan within six months or a year after his discharge has now become almost a certainty.

CHICAGO, June 4 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 9,000 head, total 14,000: market now active and mostly steady on all weights and sows: some early sales around 25 cents lower on weights under 240 pounds: top $24: bulk of good and choice 170 to 260 pounds.

ALBANY, June 4 (AP) -- Governor Dewey commuted today the death sentence of Floyd E. Martin, 21 years old, less than forty hours before he was to die in the electric chair for a murder which he said he had confessed to shield his mother.
BUDAPEST, June 4 -- Political Budapest is rapidly coming around to the Leftist bloc's declared position that nothing the United States can now do is of any immediate political importance for Hungary.

With this nation how assuming greater international responsibilities, it is more important than ever for historical groups to continue "to try to spread the creed of the fundamentals of this American democracy," former Governor Walter E. Edge of New Jersey declared yesterday.
Greentree Stable's problem colt, Blue Border, won first money of $15,000 in the Shevlin Stakes before 25,330 at Aqueduct yesterday -- but only after almost tossing it away in the stretch.

Indications that Robert Murphy's efforts as counsel for the American Baseball Guild, an independent labor union, to involve the State Labor Relations Board in his dispute with the three major league ball clubs here would soon fade were seen yesterday.

Five hundred members of the National Maritime Union, CIO participated in a parade and demonstration here yesterday in protest against recent legislation restricting the employment of aliens on American merchant ships.

CLEVELAND, June 4 (AP) -- Bob Feller won his first game since May 18 tonight as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Washington Senators, 6 to 2, and snapped a three-game losing streak. Pat Seerey homered for the Tribe in the fourth.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- During April retail stores in the United States had sales totaling $8,810,000,000, a gain of about 15 per cent over April of last year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There were two stories in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 27 which should be of considerable interest to all of us. One story told of War Department plans to organize 2,500 specialized reserve units, while the other reported an urgent appeal to Congress by Robert P. Patterson, the Secretary of War, for universal military training.

BASEBALL'S midsummer classic, the AllStar game, is back in the hands of the fans this year and they will start balloting tomorrow to name the diamond heroes who will comprise the National and American League squads. There is something irresistible about picking an All-Star team, and the saddest part of it is that no one is completely satisfied with the selections that anyone else makes.

Increased efficiencies in production methods have made it possible to pare slightly the base price of the semi-assembled Johnson Quality Homes. Edwin Johnson, vice president of the company said yesterday at the preview of new models in the "Village of Vision" on Wanamaker's eighth floor.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The House approved today, by 320 to 79, a bipartisan majority far above the two-thirds needed to override a Presidential veto, the final composite Taft-Hartley Labor Bill worked out by its spokesmen in conferences with the Senate.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Senator Kenneth Wherry, Republican, of Nebraska, the majority whip, charged in the Senate today that its Foreign Relations Committee had withheld for nearly three months an official Italian communication that he interpreted as pleading for rejection of the pending peace treaty with Italy.

President Truman was urged yesterday by the human relations commission of the Protestant Council of the City of New York to incorporate safeguards of civic rights and liberties in his executive order to investigate the loyalty of government employes.
Thirty-five thousand members of American Federation of Labor unions gathered in and around Madison Square Garden last night to demand that President Truman veto the Taft-Hartley labor bill.

Five large machine-tool builders have announced 10 per cent price increases effective immediately, machine-tool distributors disclosed here yesterday. Types of equipment represented include milling machines, grinders, broaches and lathes, they said, and the advances have resulted in sharp stimulation of demand for new tools.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The seventy-nine members of the House who voted against the labor control bill today were as follows:

Little progress toward a new contract wag reported last night following a three-hour meeting between representatives of the National Maritime Union, CIO, and the Committee for the Companies and Agents, Atlantic, and Gulf Coasts, which represents over thirty-nine steamship operators.

Bread made by an old family recipe that includes goats' milk and honey is being introduced today at Macy's. Though this formula has been passed from generation to generation in the family of Dr. L.W. Bagg of Basking Ridge, N.J., this is the first time that the product has been baked commercially.

Two individual gifts totaling $100,000 to the National Christian Committee of the United Jewish Appeal were announced yesterday on the opening of the committee's drive by Henry Morgenthau Jr., general chairman of the appeal campaign to raise $170,000,000.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange lost most of yesterday's early gains and closed irregularly with July 7 points up, and new-crop months off 21 to 33 points.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Henry Garsson, arms manufacturer, testified today that he began getting former Representative Andrew J. May to help him at the War Department after the Army balked at accepting Garsson ideas for speedier wartime shell production.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (U.P.) -- Chairman J. Parnell Thomas of the House Unamerican Activities Committee testified today that Gerhart Eisler, German-born Communist, was "very arrogant" and repeatedly said "no" when asked to take the oath as a committee witness.
BALTIMORE, June 4 -- A plan for rehabilitation of European Jewry "not pitched on philanthropy" was discussed at the closing session of the national conference of Jewish social welfare today.

100 Years Ago It is not the first time in the history of Hungary that a small landowners' party, though not known exactly by that name, has found itself under heavy Russian pressure backed by a Russian army of occupation.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 4 (AP) -- Shamrock Stable's Westminster pulled away from the pack to win the featured Insurance Commissioners Purse at Atlantic City today.

DETROIT, June 4 -- The Automobile Manufacturers Association admitted today that a widespread black market in new cars was in operation and declared that greater production was the only means of eradicating it.

To make it all "legal" and "democratic," the new head of the Hungarian Government is a member of the majority party -- and the first thing he does is to arrest more deputies of that party and to take all the measures necessary to disrupt and discredit it. He is installed as the "election premier," and his first step in preparation for new elections is to announce that 500,000 voters will be disfranchised.

Purchasing agents were warned yesterday against "being on the short side of anything next fall." The warning was issued by members of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, who summarized results of nine intensive panel inquiries into all basic commodity price and supply trends presented during their three-day thirty-second annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LONDON, June 4 -- The Ministry of Food opened a campaign today that could well revolutionize British life -- if anybody paid attention to it. It was an effort to teach British cooks how to make cod, herring and haddock appetizing.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 4 -- Ground was broken here today for the Archbishop Stepinac High School, a Roman Catholic school that will have facilities for 1,360 boys of Westchester County. Last winter the building was expected to cost $2,000,000, but the contracts today amounted to $3,964,000.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The resignation of Spruille Braden, Assistant Secretary of State for American Republic Affairs, was announced by the White House today. President Truman "reluctantly" accepted it, effective on July 1.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 4 -- Argosy Pictures, the John FordMerian Cooper producing company, announced today that Shirley Temple and her husband, John Agar, have been borrowed from David O. Selznick for the chief romantic roles in "War Party," with John Wayne, Henry Fonda and Pedro Armendariz.

Fordham University expects to begin test transmissions with its new frequency modulation station next week, thus becoming the first college noncommercial outlet to take to the air locally. The Rev. R.F. Grady, program director of the station, said that all the equipment had been installed with, the exception of a frequency monitor on which delivery is expected momentarily.

A further decrease last week of 1,952,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the close of the week total stocks amounted to 95,876,000 barrels, compared with 97,827,000 a week earlier and 93,960,000 on June 1, 1946.

LIMA, Peru, June 4 (UP) -- Dr. Julio Cesar Tello, noted Peruvian archaeologist and anthropologist, died today at the age of 67. He was director of the Peruvian Archaeological Museum, and had won world-wide renown for his research and discoveries of pre-historic Andean civilization.

The United Palestine Appeal and its units expended $52,621,000 during 1946 for the rehabilitation and resettlement of immigrants in Palestine and for the development of the country, Dr. Israel Goldstein, national chairman of the organization, announced yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Kindly permit the courtesy of a look at the record in refuting the allegations of sinister motives ascribed to me in your issue of May 24 by Luigi Antonini, president of the Italian-American Labor Council. Mr. Antonini's rejoinder stems from my letter to Senator Vandenberg urging the ratification of the Italian peace treaty, excerpts of which letter you published on May 8.

Repeal of the Feld-Crawford Act would inevitably result in a "substantial number of appliance retailer bankruptcies" because of the return of such factors as indiscriminate price cutting, "fictitious" list prices and unwarranted dealer discounts, Benjamin Gross, president, Gross Distributors, Inc., said yesterday.

Advertising in New York newspapers during May totaled 12,413,236 lines, a gain of 13.25 per cent over the corresponding month last year, according to a compilation of Media Records figures. Financial showed a loss of 34.08 per cent.

Trade movement of luggage and personal leather goods has improved considerably in comparison with recent months, reflecting the start of the vacation period and buying for Father's Day, it was reported here yesterday. Liquidation continues of certain grades of merchandise at concessions, but consumer demand was described as stressing better grade goods.

Despite a slightly fulminous title, "The Great Betrayal," the feature-length documentary on Palestine, which simultaneously arrived yesterday at the Irving Place, the Ascot in the Bronx and the Hopkinson Theatre in Brooklyn, studiously skirts for the most part the heated issues arising from today's strife-ridden Holy Land.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, June 4 -- German union leaders representing approximately 80,000 metal workers have notified the British Military Government that they are willing to back any workers who refuse to take part in dismantling operations at plants scheduled for reparations, it was learned today.
STANTON, Del., June 4 (AP) -- Greentree Stable's What's New, under a strong ride by Jockey Charlie Givens, scored a hardearned victory in the Polly Drummond Stakes today at Delaware Park.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt of Sagamore Farm, Glyndon, Md., have come to the Waldorf-Astoria.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 4 -- Fernand van Langenhove, Belgian representative on the United Nations Security Council, today criticized the decision of the Military Staff Committee not to make any provision for the use of the proposed international police force agains acts of aggression by the five great powers.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A spokesman for the American Bankers Association today accused Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, of attempting indirectly to bring about a central banking system in the United States to the detriment of banks outside the Federal Reserve System.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Majority and minority Congressional leaders discussed with President Truman today the extension of certain war powers, which will expire by termination on June 30.

License Commissioner Benjamin Fielding, who announced Monday that he was starting an investigation into the alleged rackets relating to the sale of used automobiles, said yesterday that thousands of potential buyers of new cars finally are purchasing "second-hand" machines.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- Wheat sold off sharply today on the Board of Trade following an early upturn, while corn and oats maintained a strong tone. The selling of wheat was partly due to the BennettCalvin June crop report estimating the winter wheat crop at 1,066,000,000 bushels, or 41,000,000 more than the Government forecast last month.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., June 4 (AP) -- Mort Stuart's Ogham, 6-yearold Wise Counsellor gelding, led throughout at Narragansett Park today to win the Warren Purse by two lengths from Mrs. Constance Flack's Nell A. Favorite of the crowd of 12,000, Ogham covered six furlongs in 1:12 and paid $5.40 for $2.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 4 -- Yale's title-bound Bulldogs spoiled Class Day for 5,500 Harvard celebrants by humbling the Crimson, 9--3, today at Soldiers Field in the opening game of the seventy-fifth baseball series between the rivals.

Emergency measures, including the shortening of some trains, extra runs and orders to motormen to skip scheduled stops, were used by the Board of Transportation yesterday in an effort to counteract the spreading slowdown on the city's subway service.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

It took the Cubs quite some time to snap the shackles which the Giants so mystically had woven around them this spring, but when they finally got around to it there was no denying they did a thorough job.

LONDON, June 4 -- The British, elated by the prospect of India's remaining within the Commonwealth, directed all their powers of persuasion today toward inducing Burma to follow India's lead. There is every expectation and hope that this effort will succeed.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 4--The United States labeled Russian atomic policy today as a "fraud on the people of the world" and warned that it would increase the dangers of atomic warfare.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 4 -- Regaining her putting touch, Mrs. Harry McNaughton of Seawane Harbor topped a field of forty-nine players to win low gross honors with 39, 39 -- 78 in the Long Island Women's Golf Association weekly one-day tournament over the Meadow Brook course here today.

Seventeen hundred deaf-blind persons have been found in fourteen states during the last year by a representative of the American Foundation for the Blind, Inc., Dr. Robert B. Irwin, sightless executive director of the foundation, announced yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 4 -- The "majority party" in Congress was accused today by Virgil Jordan, president of the National Industrial Conference Board, of being unwilling or unable substantially to reduce the budget or the tax burden.

Eviction, of the tenants of 270 Park Avenue is not so imminent as it might appear from the fact that the Housing Expediter has given permission for the erection of an office building on the site, it became known yesterday. Representatives of permanent residents of the Hotel Marguery and the apartment buildings on the site announced that they would fight eviction before the Office of Rent Control and in the courts.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 4--The Jewish Agency for Palestine appealed today to the United Nations committee of inquiry into Palestine to recommend the establishment of a Zionist state. As an interim measure, it renewed its previous appeal to the General Assembly that British restrictions on Jewish immigration and land settlement be removed immediately.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Ralph K. Davies told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that it would be "tragic and disheartening" if the Senate failed to ratify the Anglo-American oil treaty.

JERUSALEM, June 4 -- Jamal el Husseini, vice chairman of the Palestine Arab Higher Committee, conferred with Lieut. Gen. Sir Alan Cunningham, British High Commissioner, today before leaving for Cairo, where the committee and the Arab states' representatives are meeting this week to decide whether to cooperate with the United Nations' inquiry committee.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The State Department stressed today that Ivan Matteo Lombardo, head of the Italian financial mission that is conducting negotiations here looking to a commercial treaty, the release of blocked Italian property in this country and the adjustment of other financial problems, is in constant touch with ranking American officials.
The Peconic Bay weakfishing is continuing to improve, according to the latest reports, and the larger fish are now being taken off Cow Neck by anglers chumming with grass shrimp.

NEW DELHI, India, June 4 -- Viscount Mountbatten, the Viceroy, said at a press conference today, in response to a question whether one part of India could remain in the British Commonwealth and another part withdraw, that either the Hindu or the Moslem nation had "complete and absolute freedom" to do exactly as it liked.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 4-- Frank Hague, state Democratic boss and vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, announced today his intention to retire June 17 as this city's Mayor. He has held the post for thirty years and is now half-way through his eighth term.

A petition signed by 652 Protestant, Catholic and Jewish clergymen and religious leaders urging President Truman and Congress to renounce any proposal for universal military training was made public yesterday.
LONDON, June 4 -- At least eight leading Britons, including important members of the Government, have received letters containing powdered gelignite explosive in the past twenty-four hours.

LONDON, June 4 (AP) -- American girls and their mothers will be presented at the Court of St. James on Tuesday for the first time since pre-war days, but the ceremony will bear little resemblance to the pomp and ceremony of old.
LONDON, June 4 (Reuters) -- In comments today on the British plan for India, the Dominions generally welcomed the prospect of India's remaining in the British Commonwealth.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Enactment of the so-called anti-monopoly bill to amend the Clayton act would have serious effects upon small unit industries such as cotton textiles, according to a brief filed here today by Dr. C. T. Murchison, president of the Cotton -Textile Institute, with the Senate Judiciary Committee.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The bill authorizing the unification of the armed forces was sent to the Senate today. It had the vote of thirteen members present at the final session of the Armed Services Committee and Senate leaders have pledged final action before the end of July.

WASHINGTON, June 4--Aladar de Szegedy-Maszak, the Hungarian Minister to the United States, and seven members of his staff refused today to recognize the legality of the new Communist-controlled Gov-ernment in Budapest and remained at their posts. Among them was Ferenc Nagy Jr. 24-year-old son of the ousted Premier, who is an attache or the legation.

Surrogates James A. Delehanty and William T. Collins in concurring decisions yesterday established a precedent in accepting "a certificate of presumptive death duly issued by a foreign state of domicile" as proof of death of civilians who apparently died at the hands of the Nazis.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 4 -- The Bank of Brazil issued today new instructions regulating foreign exchange and affecting all international currencies.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 -- The National Supply Company of Pittsburgh, and the Florida Power Corporation of St. Petersburg, Fla., filed registration statements today with the Securities and Exchange Commission, while Swern Co. of

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations accused proponents of the Taft-Hartley bill today of using "deceptive tactics" to create an impression that the bill was a "mild" or "compromise" measure.

LONDON, June 4 (Reuters) -- In India, opinion on the British proposal ranged from the approval of the independent Times of India describing the plan as "the only method by which India's constitutional problem can be settled justly and peacefully," to the condemnation of the ultra-nationalist Free Press Journal carrying the headline "The Greatest Betrayal."
LONDON, June 4 -- The coming six weeks represent a crucial period in Britain's battle for production, Herbert Morrison, Lord President of the Council, said today.

The shortage of freight cars cannot be blamed on excessive exports, but is rather due to failure of railroads to place volume orders at the end of the war before the shortage of steel became acute, L.L. Horch,, regional director, Department of Commerce, stated yesterday.

The American Jewish Committee and the Jewish Labor Committee issued a statement yesterday deploring the recent publication of advertisements in behalf of the Palestine resistance movement by a group sponsored by Ben Hecht, the writer.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 (AP)-- Ken Heintzelman made the first start of his career against the Cincinnati Reds today and aided by a twelve-hit attack on three Red pitchers, hurled the Phillies to a 9-2 triumph before 3,810. It was the Phils' sixth victory in seven starts against the Ohioans.

With Peewee Reese belting a grand slam home run in the second inning and Ralph Branca holding Ralph Kiner and Hank Greenberg to singleton homers, the Dodgers last night made it three straight over the Pirates, 9 -- 4, before 32,287 cash clients at Ebbets Field.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 -- Nearly 20,000 construction workers were reported to be idle here today as a result of a wage contract dispute between contractors and building trade unions that has halted work on 400 construction projects.
