JERUSALEM, June 5 -- Twentysix Arab leaders have demanded the abolition of the Jewish settlement police or the formation of a similar force to defend Arab villages, the Government announced today.
Drawings for landmarks of the future, such as the United Nations Center and the new Bellevue Hospital, are included in the exhibition that opened yesterday at the Architectural League.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today a plan of reorganization for the Wisconsin Central Railway Company, whereby the road's capitalization would be reduced from $71,151,200 to approximately $46,840,600.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 5 -- According to Information made public here today, a subcommission of the Balkan Investigating Commission, which was refused permission to enter Bulgarian territory last Tuesday, had been notified in advance that it would not be admitted until June 11.
A small crowd gathered in the Bronx yesterday afternoon for what might have been any high school track meet, except that all the participants, as well as their cheering section, were blind.

Asher Rossetter sat In his swivel chair in the large office at the Pinkerton's National Detective Agency, Inc., 154 Nassau Street, yesterday, for the last time. After sixty years of uninterrupted service, the last twenty-four as first vice president and general manager, he has retired.

Re-Introduce Packaged Cottons Counter packaging of cotton piece goods, a pre-war merchandising development which was largely abandoned in the sellers' market, is making its appearance again, according to trade sources yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, June 5 (Aneta) -- An average annual dividend of 5.3 per cent for the seven years from 1940 to 1946 and raising of the company's capitalization by 20,000,000 guilders [about $7,540,000] was proposed today by the management of the Nederland Steam Navigation Company in its annual report to the stockholders.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 5 -- One of the best ways people can help prevent the development of gastroduodenal ulcers is to keep food in the stomach and not so more than four or five hours without eating, the twelfth annual convention of the National Gastroenterological Association was told today.

The possibility of four gasless days during the coming winter for Long Island consumers was mentioned yesterday at the last of two hearings on the refusal of three Long Island utility companies to supply gas for household heating to 1,858 applicants.
Joseph B. Hare, retired treasurer of the Dollar Savings Bank, died yesterday at his home in the Hudson View Gardens, Pinehurst Avenue and l83d .Street, after a long illness. His age was 80.

Uniformed policemen climbed through basement windows at 2314-2318 Crotona. Avenue in the Bronx yesterday to arrest Charles Wray, house superintendent there, and sixteen fellow-members of his union, who had barricaded Wray's apartment in an attempt to prevent his eviction.

RALEIGH, N.C., June 5 (AP) -- Henry A. Wallace, asked at a press conference here today if he would support President Truman for reelection, said "that depends," and, after a moment's hesitation, added, "I would say, 'No.' "
Kent Miller's Elkridge, who keeps rolling along year after year showing them the way to go home in over-the-jumps races, did it again at chilly Aqueduct yesterday.

MUNICH, Germany, Friday, June 6 (U.P.) -- The Minister Presidents of the five German states in the Russian occupation zone withdrew early today from the German economic conference and announced that they would leave for their homes later this morning.

Imported Indian saris, scarves and bags and traditional jewelry and exquisite children's frocks from Georg Jensen, Inc., of 667 Fifth Avenue, were shown yesterday at a press luncheon in the gardens of Northcourt, the Roslyn, L.I., home of Frederik Lunning, president of the store.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- An official of the Jones and Laughlin Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh told a Senate subcommittee today that "the purported large quantities of black market steel are a myth."

A bill calling for the identification of furs in a manner similar to that of the Wool Labeling Act was introduced in the Senate yesterday under the co-sponsorship of Senators Edwin C. Johnson of Colorado and Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the issue of May 18 THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review contained a review of my recently published volume of sermons entitled "Be Strong in the Lord." The review was a very able and generous one, but it included one statement which seems to me to convey a wrong impression and one which is important in its implications.

The big handicap match of the local boxing season will take place at Madison Square Garden tonight, when Jake La Motta, the sturdy middleweight from the Bronx, opposes Tony Janiro, Youngstown, Ohio, welterweight. Interest in the clash has been at a high point for the past two weeks, and it is likely to attract a crowd of 15,000 fans and a gate of more than $75,000.

One of World War II's "expendables," the Porto Rico Line's passenger vessel Borinquen, completed yesterday a rigorous trial run, and was found ready for peacetime passenger service on the company's route from New York to Puerto Rico and the Dominican republic.

Fifteen hundred persons In the garden of Presbyterian Hospital at 622 West 168th Street witnessed the commencement exercises yesterday of its School of Nursing. The occasion marked the school's fiftythird graduation and the tenth anniversary of its affiliation with Columbia University.
Vigorous opposition to any use of park or playground space as a site for temporary housing was expressed yesterday by the Park Association of New York City.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The State Department announced today that "pending further developments the Government of the United States would not be disposed to enter into official relations with the regime now in power in Nicaragua."

Robert Payne, whose forthcoming book, "The Revolt of Asia," will be published by John Day on Sept. 25, will have another work published by the same concern. It is an anthology of Chinese poetry, entitled "The White Pony," which covers from the earliest times to the present.
MUROC ARMY FIELD, Calif., June 5 -- Many of the country's newest planes were put through their paces here today in a preview of the shape of things to come.

Humbled with three hits by Paul Erickson in dropping the opener, 5 -- 1, the dynamic Giants exploded eight runs in the third inning of the nightcap to crush the Cubs, 9 -- 3, behind Montia Kennedy at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 5 -- George Tatarescu, Vice Premier, Minister of Foreign Affairs and president of the dissident National Liberal party, has urged members of "the other parties in the Government" to study a fifteen-point proposal he has just made for "changing of the internal and external policy" of Rumania.

The finals in the first Helen Hayes Declamation Contest of the Vocational High Schools Division, sponsored by the Board of Education of New York and THE NEW YORK TIMES, were held yesterday afternoon in Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.
CHICAGO, June 5 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics gained their third victory in five games on their second Western invasion by beating the Chicago White Sox, 5 -- 2, today.

NEWARK, N. J., June 5 -- Opposition to the offer by the Port of New York Authority to lease Newark Airport and Marine Terminal is headed by Commissioner Meyer C. Ellenstein in the City Council, it was reported here tonight. It is doubted that a majority of the Council favors acceptance of the offer as it stands.

CHICAGO. June 5 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department at Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 6.000 head, total 8.500: market active; 50 cents to 51 higher: most advance on weights over 250 pounds: sows around 25 to SO cents higher: top of $24.75 paid sparingly: bulk of good and choice 170 to 260 pounds.

An experimental program to combat prejudices in young children will be put into effect next year in five public schools in Philadelphia, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Max Ascoli, a member of the executive committee of the Bureau for Interciiltural Education.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Communications Workers of America, recently formed, and the Congress of Industrial Organizations exchanged accusations today in what appeared to be a foretaste of union jurisdictional warfare involving the telephone workers.

PARIS, June 5 -- United States Secretary of State Marshall's speech at Harvard today suggesting that Europeans frame a Continental recovery program to justify further United States aid was read with intense interest here.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- There began to be a few indications on Capitol Hill today that the plight of the public schools might bowl over even the economy - minded Congress and result in enactment of the Federal Aid to Education Bill.

The first four peace treaties to follow the Second World War have now been ratified by the Senate with much more than, the necessary two-thirds majorities. They will become effective as soon as the documents are deposited by the United States, Britain, Russia and -in the case of Italy-France.

The marriage of Mrs. Harriet Drisdale Hemsted, widow of Capt. Edwin D. F. Hemsted, RCAF, of Montreal, and daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar D. Drisdale of San Antonio and Del Rio, Tex., to David Dows Jr. of Glen Head, L. I., and Aiken, S. C., took place yesterday afternoon in the chancel of St. James Episcopal Church.

More than 33,500 visitors have registered at the International Textile Exposition which is being held this week at the Grand Central Palace, according to Arthur Tarshis, director. Attendance yesterday, he said, was approximately 11,000.
ST. JOSEPH, Mo., June 5 (AP) -- The News-Press said today Marion Allen McElreath, ex-outfielder for Muskogee, had termed "a lie" charges banning him from the game for life.

The Waterman Steamship Corporation and the National Bulk Carriers have submitted high bids for seven of nine former escort aircraft carriers which they plan to convert for cargo purposes if the Navy Department approves the sales, it was learned yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In war-ridden China, reeling under political and economic blows, there stands one great non-political figure-- Mme. Sun Yat-sen. She now appeals to the American people for medical supplies and equipment which will save many of her countrymen's lives.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 5 (U.P.) -- United States and Soviet delegates to the International Organization of Journalists agreed today there should be world freedom of the press, but could not agree what exactly constituted "freedom."
CHICAGO, June 5 -- Maintenance of strong forces of the country's regular defense arms was urged today by the board of managers of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers.

The possibility of a shut-down of the subway system, today or Monday, on the ground that operation is unsafe under present conditions, was raised yesterday by City Councilman Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO.

The Knickerbocker Village Tenants Association has protested to Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander that during the last six months "a wave of crime" in the housing development has resulted in a woman being assaulted and robbed on an average of once a week in the corridors, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The city of Jersey City and the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company were permitted today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to intervene in reorganization proceedings before that body of the Central Railroad of New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, June 5--President Truman was put under powerful pressure today, direct and oblique, to veto the Hartley-Taft labor bill as the Senate opened its last grand detailed debate on that measure.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- President Truman. Indicated today the possibility, of early action on the tax reduction bill.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 5 (AP) -- The president of the minors' National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues placed a permanent ban on a Western Association outfielder of the Muskogee, Okla., club today for "conduct detrimental to baseball."

Reasonable cooperation from the weather man should find the Catskill, New Jersey, eastern Pennsylvania and upper Connecticut streams in excellent condition for fly fishing, and should make the dry fly purist very happy.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 5 (AP) -- Wendell Wathen, wealthy potato grower of Fort Fairfield, Me., was injured seriously tonight when his horse, Volo City, whom Wathen was driving in the fourth race at Roosevelt Raceway, stumbled and fell.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's statement today on Senator Taft and prices: Senator Taft la reported to have said that "apparently the President and the Administration are abandoning talk of keeping prices down in favor of spending abroad that will keep them up."
LONDON, June 5--More, explosive letters from Italy were handed over to Scotland Yard today, including one addressed to Foreign Secretary Bevin.

From several angles Poet's the news of the day Gorgeous leads, more or less directly, EAST to thoughts of John Milton. There is India, for instance. Many of us remember the great protest and organizational mass meeting described in an early book of "Paradise Lost."

PITTSBURGH, June 5 -- 4 seaplane crashed into a north side house here this afternoon, and the three occupants of the plane were killed. None of the occupants of the house was injured but a resulting fire routed a half dozen families from their homes.

A council of experts representing medical schools and the city's Health and Education Departments is drafting recommendations to the State Legislature for a publicly financed program of education and medical aid to the 12,000 New Yorkers who are afflicted with cerebral palsy, Health Commissioner Israel Weinstein announced yesterday.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 5 -- Princeton University's $200,000 grant from the Carnegie Corporation to finance a five-year investigation of university education will be. directed by Prof. Frederick F. Stephan, it was announced today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university.
PHILADELPHIA, June 5--William M. Elkins, founder of the investment banking firm of Elkins, Morris Co., died today at bis country home, Briar Hill, in suburban Chestnut Hill. His age was 63.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Government officials today expressed the belief that when the TaftHartley labor bill is out of the way conferences between coal operators and the United Mine Workers will be resumed.

The use of some form of "authority" to finance, construct and operate the thirty-three municipal parking lots and nine parking garages recommended on Wednesday by Mayor O'Dwyer's Special Traffic Committee will be considered by the Board of Estimate in executive session next week, it was indicated last night.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Senate ratified the long-disputed peace treaty with Italy today by a nearly 8-to-1 vote of 79--10. A two-thirds majority was all that was required for formal approval.

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 5 -- The Piping Rock club team of five won the women's metropolitan interclub championship today by defeating Winged Foot, 3 to 2, in a play-off at the Century Country Club here today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 5 -- During the last year material progress has been made In this country In the several phases of tuberculosis control, Dr. Frank J. Weber of the United States Public Health Service, Washington, reported to the thirteenth annual meeting here today of the American College of Chest Physicians.

ALBANY, June 5 -- Six investigating committees, created by the 1947 Legislature, met at the Capitol today to organize and elect officers. Eight other committees, continued from last year, also organized, seven of them re-electing their former chairmen.

Government Bond Prices Markdowns in Government bond quotations at the close of the market yesterday ranged from one thirty-second of a point to five thirty-seconds, net changes of the greatest extent in weeks. A quiet day, with little offset to Federal Reserve offerings, caused the tap issues to sell off, the markdown communicating itself elsewhere in the list.

As a wartime enterprise the St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project had little to commend it. We could not have wisely risked the diversion from industry of at least 20,000 men and an immense amount of essential raw material for at least five years. Now that we have returned to our normal pursuits it is fitting that the Project be re-examined in the light of national needs.

Because of the large number of new cars being sold in the New York area as second-hand machines, License Commissioner Benjamin Fielding announced yesterday that he would seek local remedial legislation, to define exactly what constituted a used car.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Predictions of an early merger between the American Federation of Labor, the Congress of Industrial Organizations and other labor groups and the subsequent setting up of a solid labor bloc for the 1948 elections are hardly consonant with the public interest.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 -- American business will never return to the "good old freedom" known from 1920 to 1933, but if it is able to shape the nature of future Government regulation and control the next ten years "will see the finest business we have ever known," Roy A. Cheney, president of the Underwear Institute, said today.

While the Giants and Cubs were beating each other's brains out yesterday, the Dodgers were completing the cleanest of sweeps over the Pirates at Ebbets Field, making it four in a row with a gaudy 3-0 victory that gave the Brooks the league lead.

LONDON, June 5 (AP) -- The International Amateur Athletic Federation is scheduled to reach a showdown on Monday on whether athletes should run for both gold and glory -- or be content with cheers alone.

New decorative prints, upholstery fabrics, wallpapers and new ideas for using them were presented yesterday at the opening of the new second-floor showroom at F. Schumacher Co., 60 West Fortieth Street.

BUDAPEST, June 5 (AP) -- The Communists and Socialists, who lave been bedfellows since just before the 1945 elections, are beginning to kick each other under the covers. Mr. Rakosi declared in a speech yesterday that "within the Social Democratic party is a crowd fighting against the workers' unity."

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 5 (AP) -- The United Lutheran Synod of New York expressed opposition today to inclusion of parochial schools, "both Catholic and Protestant," in bills proposing Federal aid for education.

IF Branch Rickey still has hopes that his Dodgers will win the pennant, the Mahatma should order an future Brooklyn games played on the Parade Grounds. It's the only guaranteed method of keeping Pete Reiser sound of limb. As soon as a wall encloses a field, it's a certainty that Pistol Pete will some day crash into it and the Brooks can't win any championship without the services of their spirited and talented young outfielder.

PARIS, June 5 -- Premier Paul Ramadier told his Cabinet and a meeting of his party group in the Assembly today that he would resist excessive labor demands and hold to the anti-inflation program endorsed by his party and Parliament.
WASHINGTON, June 5 --The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill to appropriate $5,280,982,423 for the War Department's military activities in the 1948 fiscal year, which begins July 1.

STANTON, Del., June 5 (AP) -- Cornelius V. Whitney's Jeep, who finished second to Larky Day in the Brandywine Handicap last Saturday, did better today when he won the featured mile-and-sixteenth Bellevue Purse at Delaware Park.

NEW DELHI, June 5 (Reuters) -- India made two moves today toward communal peace. Mohammed Ali Jinnah, president of the Moslem League, called off the threemonth-old Moslem civil disobedience campaign against the Congress party Ministry of the NorthWest Frontier Province, and the Congress party Ministry of Bihar impounded all arms and ammunition on sale throughout the province.

In the first backward move from recently advanced levels copper product prices have been reduced about 1 cent by two leading fabricators, Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., and the American Brass Company, industry spokesmen disclosed yesterday.

A new series of meetings has been started by the Copy Research Council under the direction of Gerald H. Carson, president. Under the plan members will hear from outstanding men in advertising posts in manufacturing and distributing concerns.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 5 -- The text of Secretary of State Marshall's address at Harvard University today follows, I need not tell you, gentlemen, that the world situation is very serious.

Mayor O'Dwyer defended his criticism of the Taft-Hartley labor bill yesterday on the basis of its Interference with the Wagner Act and not "as a partisan of labor" In welcoming 500 postmasters from various parts of the state at their annual convention in the Hotel New Yorker.

DETROIT, June 5 -- In a game interrupted in the third inning for seven minutes by a modified cloudburst, halted briefly in the fourth while open warfare between the teams flared and punctuated thereafter by two gorgeous home runs by Tommy Henrich, the Yankees shut out the league-leading Tigers, 7 to 0, today to advance within a game of first place.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Cash-ins of Series E bonds, the former War Bond issue, exceeded purchases in May for the second straight month. Treasury officials said today, redemptions outstripped buying by $23;953,000, or $329,015,000 against $305,062,000.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The estrangement between the United States and Argentina, which has lasted since 1942, was declared ended by President Truman today. The United States is now on friendly terms with Argentina, he said.
LONDON, June 5 -- Gold shares were the leaders in an otherwise quiet stock market here today.

PARIS, June 5 -- The Russian colony in Paris was surprised today by a decree from the Moscow Patriarch, sent to Archbishop Vladimir of the Orthodox Church here, stating that the Holy Synod in Moscow had taken the rank of Bishops from Arhcbishop Vladimir and his two deputies, Bishop John and Bishop Nikon.

CLEVELAND, June 5 (AP) -- Six-hit pitching by Early Wynn and home runs by Sherry Robertson and A1 Evans gave the Washington Senators a 3-to-0 victory over the Cleveland Indians in the final of a three-game series today.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- Par was just something nobody paid any attention to today in the $10,000 National Capital open golf tournament.

LOS ANGELES, June 5 -- Two nationally prominent Democratic |party members "begged off" at the last minute from attending the party's Jackson Day dinner here tonight presided over by James Roosevelt, state party chairman.
PHILADELPHIA, June 5 -- (AP) -- Sweeping both ends of a twin bill from the Phillies, 5-0 and 6-3, the Cincinnati Reds jumped into fifth place today before 13,198 fans.

LONDON, June 5 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin called on Great Britain today to "dig for dollars" as she dug for victory during the war. His plea was the latest in a long succession coming from all top Government leaders who stated frankly that Britain must export to get more dollars or cut down on her standard of living.

The Music Critics Circle of New York has voted Aaron Copland's Third symphony and Ernest Bloch's Second quartet the outstanding American orchestral and chamber music works heard for the first time in New York during the last season.

New York's housing shortage has reached the point where it is as difficult to find a vacant cold-water flat as a modern apartment. The Real Estate Board of New York made public yesterday the result of its latest occupancy survey, showing an unprecedented situation in the tenement districts, with scarcely any of these less desirable quarters empty.
BOSTON, June 5 (AP) -- Marty Marion's fourth home run of the season with two mates aboard and one out in the ninth inning today gave the St. Louis Cardinals a 5-3 victory over the Boston Braves.

The importance of religious faith in the struggle to abolish racial antagonisms and preserve democracy was stressed yesterday by Governor Dewey, Mayor O'Dwyer and other speakers as part of the celebration in Brooklyn and Queens of the 118th anniversary of the Brooklyn Sunday School Union.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The appointment of Dwight P. Gris-wold of Nebraska to head the Greek aid program was announce by President Truman today. The President also made public the ap-pointment of Richard F. Allen, former director of European relief for the Red Cross, to be field administrator of the $350,000,000 foreign relief fund recently voted by Congress.

Three years ago this dawn, in the words of the official communique, "Allied naval forces, supported by strong air forces, began landing Allies armies * * * on the northern coast of France." Of those who landed many thousands were to die in the Normandy fighting, in the Bulge, in the Rhine crossings.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 31, 1947, totaled 830,383 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 60,222, or 6.8 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 203,498, or 32.5 per cent, more than for the corresponding week of last year and 7,503, or 0.9 per cent, fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 5 -- Harvard needs $90,000,000 in new endowments, in addition to the $165,000,000 it already possesses, Dr. James B. Conant, its president, declared during the commencement ceremonies today in Harvard Yard. Degrees were awarded to 2,185 students and twelve honorary awards were made to distinguished Americans.

BUENOS AIRES, June 5 (UP) -- The establishment of a Government monopoly of newsprint, proposed by Miguel Miranda, economic czar, would deal a severe blow to the freedom of the press in this country, the Prensa said today.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- President Truman, in a highly unusual step, denounced today as "fallacious and dangerous" certain economic views he attributed to Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, one of the leaders of the majority party in Congress.
MUKDEN, Manchuria, June 5 -- Mukden is in the grip of fear as 80,000 Communist troops stand poised across the main railway only sixty miles to the north.

EPSOM DOWNS, England, June 5 (AP) -- Imprudence, 3-year-old French filly born while shells screamed over the Palaise Gap in the Battle of Normandy, today won the 165th Oaks Stakes -- secondary feature of the racing week to be climaxed by Saturday's running of the Derby.

AMSTERDAM, June 5 (Aneta) -- The market eased off in light trading on the Stock Exchange. The generally depressed tone of the market was attributed to misinterpretation by traders of reports from Indonesia. Indies plantations issues, industrials and oils showed the greatest losses.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- The trend of grain prices on the Board of Trade was irregular today. In wheat there was an uneven close, with July relatively heavy, while the far - off deliveries were firm Weather was showery throughout most of the grain territory, but reports indicate winter wheat it nearing maturity, with no serious backset yet, and about the only remaining hazard is that of heavy rains prior to harvesting.

The revised $70,000,000 development program for Newark Airport and Seaport offered by the Port Authority follows the general lines of the proposal accepted by New York City for its airports. While the capital expenditure promised is more modest, in keeping with the lesser need, the financial returns to Newark seem persuasive.

The Citizens Housing Council of New York, Inc., hailed yesterday the action taken toy the United Nations in canceling rental agreements between the United Nations and the Metropolitan and New York Life Insurance Companies because of the insistence by the companies on the right to restrict accommodations in two housing projects.

Agreement on a means of speeding construction of public housing by the use of vacant land is now anticipated by state and city. officials, it was reported yesterday by Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner. He spoke at cornerstone ceremonies for two Harlem developments of the New York City Housing Authority.

Two men nominated by the President yesterday will be responsible, if confirmed by the Senate, for the expenditure of 650,000,000 American dollars abroad. One of them, former Gov. Dwight P. Griswold of Nebraska, will have as delicate and critical a task as ever came the way of an American diplomat.
LOS ANGELES, June 5 (AP) -- James M. Carter, Federal District Attorney, announced tonight the arrest on treason charges of Tomoya Kawakita, American citizen of Japanese ancestry.

John R. Hargrave, 35 years old, a jewelry salesman of 493 Halsey Street, Brooklyn, was held yesterday in $50,000 bail by United States Commissioner Jacob A. Visel in Federal Court, Brooklyn, on a charge of forging a Government check.

Heavy sales of short term Treasury certificates despite a sizable increase in loans to brokers, produced a decrease of $32,000,000 in the earning assets of the reporting member banks in New York City of the Federal Reserve System during the week ended on last Wednesday.

ANTWERP, June 5 -- First tremors of panic are to be felt on Pelikaanstraat, heart of the diamond trade, where it is feared the powerful Diamond Trading Company, Ltd., of London is attempting to crush the Belgian industry.

The likes and dislikes of radio listeners are to be reviewed for a second time by the National Association of Broadcasters in a survey scheduled for the fall. The trade organization, has made an appropriation for research Into such matters as program preferences, attitudes toward advertising and an analysis of radio's role in community life.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Dwight Palmer Griswold, the 53-year old former Nebraska Republican Governor, chosen by President Truman to head the $300,000,000 Greek aid program, has been in political lit for a quarter century and nationally known in recent years.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- A Senate committee which investigated the mine explosion killing 111 at Centralia, Ill., on March 25, today blamed, in some degree, all the principals involved -- management, miners, and state and Federal governments.

The stock market lapsed yesterday into a state of inertia, prices moving irregularly and closing slightly easier in the dullest and narrowest session in about a year. In only a few instances were price alterations more than fractional, and the composite rate ended 0.15 point off on the day. Business was the smallest since July 5, last, with transfers on the Stock Exchange 520,000 shares, against 820,000 on Wednesday.
ROME, June 5 (Reuters) -- The forthcoming visit of Archbishop Gregorio, Metropolitan of Leningrad and Novorod, to the United States evokes considerable interest in Vatican circles.

KILKIS, Greece, June 5 -- In clashes between guerrilla bands and regular army units In Macedonia the former Invariably comes out second best, it was indicated today. None the less the impression gained from commanders in the field is that there can be no decisive end of this wasting warfare unless outside assistance to subversive elements ceases.

OTTAWA, June 5 -- Out of a short bill aimed at facilitating the internal administration of United States troops stationed in Canada there has arisen during the past two days what has amounted to a full dress debate on CanadianUnited States relations, with some pretty sharp criticism by members on all sides of the House of Commons.
John H. Sienold, formerly banquet manager of the Hotel New Yorker, has been appointed sales manager of the Hotel Plaza.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Weekly sales of department stores for the week ended May 31 were up 12 per cent compared to the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Percentage changes from like periods of a year ago follow:

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- By proclamation today, President Truman called on citizens and residents of the United States to refrain from undermining law and order in Palestine and from promoting violence there. The proclamation was blanket in form and named no organizations or individuals as having engaged in such activities.

MADRID, June 5 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco, during his visit to Barcelona that has just ended, conferred secretly with an obscure Carlist Prince whom he intends to spring as a surprise candidate for the throne, a Monarchist source said last night.

Many have sought to combine the functions of Hollywood and Broadway to the mutual advantage of each -- and for themselves, too. Among the pioneers in that highly specialized field are Lee Strasberg and Anderson Lawlor, who have formed a combine to test their theories.

LONDON, Friday, June 6 -- Acted by an English cast, "Life With Father" was presented at the Savoy Theatre last night. In its transition from New York it seemed that the play lost something of its warmth and pace.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark strongly denied today a charge that he had sought to "whitewash" alleged vote frauds in Kansas City.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 5 -- Ilona Massey and John Carroll were named today by Republic to appear with William Elliott and Joseph Schildkraut in "Monterey," which Joseph Kane will product and direct starting late in August Bradbury Foote has written the scenario from a screen story by John K. Butler dealing with California before the gold rush.

As a result of a decision Wednesday by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in favor of longshoremen seeking back overtime pay, a new judgment against stevedoring companies will be entered by an attorney for the waterfront workers, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- During the week ended June 4 member bank reserve balances increased $216,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- Republicans in Congress welcomed Mr. Wallace's remarks today as a sign of division in Democratic ranks and of a Republican victory in 1948, but Democrats disagreed.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Assistant Secretary of State to be appointed, to the vacancy caused by the resignation of Spruille Braden is expected to receive authority over all the geographical offices under plans now being developed in the State Department, it was learned today.

PITTSBURGH, June 5 -- Walter S. Hallanan, chairman of the National Petroleum Council, said tonight in an address at the annual convention of the Pennsylvania Grade Crude Oil Association that the oil industry in the United States has no reserve capacity to meet emergency demands of another war.

A banking syndicate headed by Drexel Co. and Lobdell Co. received yesterday the award of an issue of $1,300,000 of water revenue bonds of Tacoma, Wash., due on each July 1 from 1955 to 1964 and callable in 1958, at an Interest cost of 1.674 per cent.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, June 5 -- Dr. Michael A. Heilperin, economic adviser to the Bristol-Myers Company of New York, made a plea today for the return of private investments for financing foreign industrial development in an address to the International Chamber of Commerce, which is meeting here.

Laszlo L. Medgyesy, formerly Hungarian acting consul general here, announced yesterday that he had joined the Hungarian Minister in Washington and members of his staff in rejecting the new regime's orders.

Cotton futures gathered strength as the session progressed on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, closing 11 to 25 points net higher. The market opened 1 point down to 10 points up and during the morning a spot firm was a smaller seller of October, while there was further price-fixing in near months.

President Truman has taken Senator Taft to task for some rather caustic remarks attributed to the latter in connection with the Administration's campaign for lower prices. In a prepared statement issued at his White House conference yesterday Mr. Truman declared:

ATLANTIC CITY, June 5 -- The greatest immediate danger to the country's economy is the "politically developed hope for artificially low prices," Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, declared today at the final session of the four-day convention of the Edison Electric Institute here.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- President Truman denounced the Communist coup in Hungary today as an outrage and approved the dispatch of a sharp note of protest to the Soviet commander in Budapest.
ROME, June 5 -- The forced repatriation of Russian refugees in Italy was debated in the British House of Commons on May 21. Subsequently the Italian press published particulars.

Dr. Millicent Carey McIntosh, dean-elect of Barnard College, retired yesterday as headmistress of the Brearley School, 610 East Eighty-third Street, after seventeen years of service. In an informal ceremony she handed over to Miss Jean Fair Mitchell, newly appointed headmistress, "the only external "symbol of office" she could find -- the black hand-stamp machine used to impress the school seal on documents.

Alfred E. Vondermuhll, for many years a banker in this city, died yesterday in Martha's Vineyard Hospital, Vineyard Haven, Mass., after a, long illness, according to word received here. His age was 67.

The Port of New York Authority expressed yesterday its opposition to Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander's proposed new air regulations for this city and raised a question as to the constitutionality of such measures.

Louis F. Budenz, former Communist editor, appeared yesterday as a voluntary witness before the June grand jury to tell what he knew about local Communist activities. Prior to going before the inquiry body, where he was questioned for an hour by Jacob Grumet, assistant district attorney, Mr. Budenz told reporters that he planned to amplify on statements in his autobiography, "This Is My Story," concerning the murder of Leon Trotsky in 1940.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., co-sponsor of the Taft - Hartley Labor bill, denounced Mayor O'Dwyer of New York tonight for taking the leadership in last night's Madison Square Garden demonstration against the measure.

COLUMBIA, Mo., June 5 -- The University of Missouri awarded today the degree of Doctor of Science to Dr. Howard A. Rusk, chairman of the Department of Rehabilitation and Physical Medicine of New York University and associate editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Louis F. Budenz, former Communist editor, appeared yesterday as a voluntary witness before the June grand jury to tell what he knew about local Communist activities. Prior to going before the inquiry body, where he was questioned for an hour by Jacob Grumet, assistant district attorney, Mr. Budenz told reporters that he planned to amplify on statements in his autobiography, "This Is My Story," concerning the murder of Leon Trotsky in 1940.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 5 The countries of Europe were called upon today by the Secretary of State, George C. Marshall, to get together and decide upon their needs for economic rehabilitation so that further United States aid could be provided upon an integrated instead of a "piecemeal" basis.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- Carson Pine Scott Co. announced today opening of a new major household appliance section which has been laid out in the shape of a fan with each division devoted to a certain type of merchandise. A spokesman for the large Loop department store pointed out that the floor lay-out had been designed to provide the most convenient arrangement of equipment for display and demonstration.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- Federal Judge Michael L. Igoe today appealed to the executive committee of the United States District Court to assign the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad reorganization proceedings to another judge, but his request was refused, it was learned authoritatively.

BUDAPEST, June 5--Hundreds of speakers daily at hundreds of meetings throughout Hungary are engaged in agitating against West-ern nations and in particular against the United States. Com-munists and Socialists are speak-ing in the propaganda campaign, which began last Monday and is to last until a week from Sunday.

BERLIN, June 5 (AP) -- Dwight P. Griswold, appointed by President Truman to head the United States mission to Greece, said tonight that he was "in favor of using our economic strength to stop wars before they get started, rather than using our youth after they get started."

Distributors and dealers of Premier vacuum cleaners in Manhattan, Brooklyn and New Jersey have revived trade-in allowances on consumers' used machines to achieve greater volume, it was learned yesterday. The allowances, held in abeyance since May, 1942, have been reinstituted because both segments of the trade now are "not only selling against orders but actually are digging for orders," a representative of a Manhattan distributor reported.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 5 (AP) -- Picket lines established today by Sinking grain shovelers halted activities at all twenty waterfront elevators and threatened a full shutdown of operations in this country's largest flour milling center.

NEW DELHI, India, June 5 (London Times dispatch) -- Maintaining the initiative gained by his bold handling of the Indian situation, the Viceroy, Viscount Mountbatten, in consultation with seven Indian leaders today, took the first step to implement the British Government's procedural plan, for the transfer of power.

VALPARAISO, Chile, June 5 (U.P.) -- The 8,000-ton steamer Socrates of the Royal Dutch Line Struck a reef last night off the Island of Quiriquina, but although drawing water in three holds was not in immediate danger it was reported today.
RABAT, Morocco, June 2 (Delayed) -- King Farouk's action granting asylum to Abd el Krim is regarded here as greatly strengthening the ties between Morocco and Egypt, the home of the Arab League.
TOKYO, June 5 -- Japan is not yet sure that she has lost Okinawa permanently, Hitoshi Ashida. the new Foreign Minister, said at a press conference today.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Led by agricultural commodities, primary market prices rose 0.3 per cent during the week ended last Saturday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor reported today. At 147.4 per cent of the 1826 Average, the highest level since mid-April, the bureau's index of commodity prices in primary markets was 1.3 per cent lower than its peak at the end of March.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 5 -- For the second week in a row, Mrs. Walter Reynolds of Knollwood captured low gross honors in the women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association one-day competition by scoring 43. 41 -- 84 at the Siwanoy Country Club today.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 5 -- It has been pretty well established that Egypt had no hand in the plot to free from French bondage Abd el Krim, exiled Riff leader, who is now enjoying the hospitality of this country.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- John D. Goodloe, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, told the Senate Banking Committee today he believes the $14,000,000,000 Government lending agency can performa useful service in the post-war period and should not be immediately liquidated.

The reported doubling of Scotch imports Into the United States over the next twelve months will not materially reduce the price of Scotch to consumers, importers and retailers stated yesterday. The demand for Scotch, they said, if it continues at normal levels, would still be well above the increased supply.
The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed registrar for the 4 per cent cumulative preferred stock, series A, of the Nopco Chemical Company.

JERUSALEM, June 6 -- Hosni Barazi, former Syrian Premier, who is an advocate of what he calls "Syrian unity," has recently conversed twice with King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan, he disclosed today in an interview. He saw the King yesterday on the latter's ceremonial visit to Jerusalem.

Random notes. Just a sample of what the experienced striper fisherman can do if he hits the right place at the right time; three Long Island bass fishermen, Fred Ackerman, George Cedar and George Ditorick went up to Cape Cod and took a total of 32 fish.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- While lawyers were in apparent agreement today in holding that the Taft-Hartley Labor Bill, if it becomes law, would allow the Government to ask the court to restrain the United Mine Workers from carrying on a strike after July 1, there was disagreement on several features in connection with such a possible injunction.

LEXINGTON, Va., June 6 -- Washington and Lee University today conferred a surprise honorary degree upon Mrs. Alfred I. du Pont of Wilmington, Del., thus making her the first woman ever to receive a degree of any kind from the all-male university.

Although the United Nations has aided considerably in bringing about the "rebirth" of the Middle East, it still remains one of the most likely starting places for a new world conflict, Edgar Ansel Mowrer, journalist and author, warned yesterday at the New York University School of Education.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 6 -- Thanks to present advances in surgical techniques anesthesia and the use of antibiotic drugs, cancer of the lungs which a few years ago was an incurable disease, is now being treated with remarkable success.

The outline of a program, designed to transform the Manhattanville area of New York's Upper West side into a model urban community, was given last night in a report delivered at a meeting of the Manhattanville Housing Committee by John G. Vaughan Jr., chairman of the committee.

Something About Mayors Mr. Hague's thirty years as Mayor of Jersey City may be an Mayors All-American record for that municipal office, though one recalls a Mayor Dahlman of Omaha who was a permanent fixture for nearly a generation, and there are perhaps other cases among our smaller towns.

MOSCOW, June 6 (AP) -- Pravda attacked right trend leaders of Europe's Socialists today for attempting to create what it said was a schism with the Communists and called upon the working classes throughout the Continent to unite in smashing Right Wing and "bourgeois" political parties.

LONDON, June 6 -- The British Government will take "urgent steps" to follow up with the United States Government Secretary of State Marshall's proposals for European reconstruction, a Foreign Office spokesman said today.
It just doesn't seem in the Cards for the cellar-bound world champions to beat the Giants this season.
A first accounting of administration of the estate of Franklin D. Roosevelt was filed yesterday morning in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., by its executors and was released here at the same time.
BERLIN, June 6 -- The Russians chose the third anniversary of D-Day to deliver a smashing editorial assault on the United States and British Armies' participation in the war against Germany.

PARIS, June 6 -- The Ramadier Government faced its severest test so far when the railway workers' leaders tonight refused the Premier's request to call off the strike that since this morning had paralyzed large parts of the transport system within a radius of some 140 miles of Paris.
CLEVELAND, June 6 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians defeated the Philadelphia Athletics, 7 to 4, in the opener of a five-game series before 19,983 fans tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- A Senate Small Business subcommittee today wound up the first phase of its inquiry into the tight steel market and staff aides said they are planning a broader investigation.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 6 -- Herbert C. Clish, head of the School Department at New Rochelle, N.Y., has been appointed Superintendent of Schools for San Francisco, the Board of Education announced last night.

NEW ORLEANS, June 6 -- Mechanized farm operation does not necessarily mean a great loss of farm people to the South because of the tremendous natural resources and potential markets that can utilize population sources in the area, the National Planning Association's Committee of the South was told here today.

Trade Gain Here Smaller Retail trade here continued active this week, but the margin of gain over last year was less than in preceding weeks. Estimates indicated department store volume will show a rise of about 7 per cent over the 1946 period.

Indictments charging bribery were returned yesterday against I. James Brody, former Deputy Commissioner of Marine and Aviation; James V. Auditore, boss stevedore, and Albert Gross, Auditore's former business partner.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Fiftytwo nations have been invited to a special cereals conference to open in Paris on July 9, it was announced today by the Directors General of the Food and Agriculture Organization and the International Emergency Food Council.

Hundreds of buyers returned to New York this week to place orders for coats, suits and dresses which were displayed in fall showings during the last three weeks, a survey of the market indicated yesterday. Order-taking got under way in earnest, according to resident buyers and manufacturers, and initial purchasing on higher and medium priced lines should be complete in the next ten days.

A vacant lot on Fifty-second Street between Ninth and Tenth Avenues belonging to St. Clare's Hospital directly opposite was turned over to the Police Athletic League yesterday for a summer playground that will open on July 1.

Monday evening, July 14, has been designated as the time when James Stewart, top-flight movie actor, will give his first performance in the role of Elwood P. Dowd in "Harvey," the Mary Chase Pulitzar Prize play which is fast approaching its third year at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre.

Few would deny that the public library serves a useful and unique function in a democracy. Not only does it provide free books and other reading material to young and old but it serves as a highly important adult education center for the entire community. Because libraries are so essential today, it is all the more disheartening to read the report of the American Library Association.

SECURITY COUNCIL Continued study of Military Staff Committee's report and heard Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet representative, make veiled attack on other great powers for alleged attempts to obtain "preponderant" influence on smaller ones.

The stock market returned yesterday to the recovery side as offerings were meager and sufficient demand appeared in the afternoon to give the list a definitely higher range. Several of the key industrial stocks, notably the steels and motors, were raised slightly more than a point, although the composite rate showed an increase of only 0.31 point.

Expansion steps now under way, in response to more than 1,500 requests for membership information from qualified industrial executives; will soon triple the size of the Systems and Procedures Association of America, H. Kenneth Marks, newly elected president, disclosed here yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- A warning that if democracy were to be strengthened, Americans must cultivate the family, "the smallest democracy," was voiced here today by Bayard Foster Pope, president of the Community Service Society of New York.
The older people of this country have a duty to educate their children in such a way that they will be worthy of their great heritage of freedom, Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The State Department has virtually decided that the United States should continue to recognize the Hungarian Government and not inject the recognition issue as a factor in pressing its case against the Communist coup, it was learned today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I congratulate Dr. Wulf Sachs for having so realistically stated the facts about racial discrimination in South Africa and W.A. Hunton for his supplementary information. Possibly this contribution of mine may further help to enlighten H.M. Moolman, the Director of the Union of South Africa Government Information Office, and to drive home to him the need of an objective treatment of a vitally important problem.

NEW DELHI, India, June 6 (AP) -- The Indian Chamber of Princes tonight was prepared for extinction but its end was no surprise. So far as British officialdom was concerned, the significant factor was that the notoriously jealous princes of 500-odd states failed to make any provision for continuing the organization to resist hostile nationalistic forces opposed to them.
VIENNA, June 6 -- United States imports will assure Austria of her present rations until this summer's harvest, according to a statement made today by Assistant Secretary of War Howard C. Petersen.
BUFFALO, June 6 (AP) -- A fourth mill closed down today as a five-day-old grain shovelers' strike gradually paralyzed operations in this nation's flour milling center.

Houston, Texas, was brought within five hours of New York by air yesterday. Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker, president of Eastern Air Lines, with a "blue ribbon" crew, flew one of the line's new-type Constellations from La Guardia Fiel dto Houston for a buffet luncheon and returned his guests to New York shortly after 6:30, in time for an early dinner.

This column cheerily changes its tune today. For once our theme is not the high or higher price of an important item on the market list, but rather the story of a product that cost 77 cents a pound seven months ago and is available for about 43 cents today in large independent and chain stores in the city.

Of the need for more parking space for automobiles in New York City there can be no argument. Mayor O'Dwyer's special traffic committee appointed six months ago has now added one more report to the many studies of this problem. A little bit of everything for housing a car is offered in this report, at a cost of $25,000,000, plus a further annual outlay for rent on leased land.
The second annual phase of the city's three-year campaign to end hay fever in New York by destroying ragweed, the plant that causes the sneezing misery, will start early next week.

Reacting vigorously against a seventy-five-minute work stoppage yesterday morning by 800 Board of Transportation repairmen in the 147th Street shops, the board served last night departmental charges and suspensions without pay on two members of the Transport Workers Union.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 6 (AP) -- Pompeian, owned by J.R. Steinman, proved best in a field of eight 3-year-olds by streaking six furlongs in 1:12 1-5 to win the Senator Purse today.

Two wreaths dropped from the deck of the Corps of Engineers Dredge Goethals landed gently and flowed far out to sea yesterday to honor, on the third anniversary of D-Day, 10,000 members of the Army Amphibian Engineers killed during the recent war.

BAD SALZUFLEN, Germany, June 6 -- The British Control Commission for Germany is expected to place greater emphasis on the resettlement of the zone's displaced persons than on their repatriation to eastern European countries when it assumes control of the refugee camps, it was learned today.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 6 -- On the eve of her departure for Brae Burn at West Newton, Mass., to defend her Eastern medal play championship, Miss Laddie Irwin of Glen Ridge proved today that she will be hard to beat by posting a 2-over-women's par 41, 36 -- 77; at the Upper Montclair Country Club to win low gross honors in the New Jersey Women's weekly one-day tournament.

TOKYO, June 6 -- Occupation officials now have in their possession orders allegedly sent to party members by the Tokyo headquarters of the Japan Communist party immediately after the April election. In effect, they instruct the members to go underground.

"THE GALLERY,"* by John Home Burns, is a rather unusual farewell to aims. It is a rancorously vivid portfolio of portraits of many Allied soldiers and Italian civilians who swarmed through steaming Naples in August, 1944, with preliminary scenes in Casablanca, Fedala, Algiers and other stops in that palmsand-atabrine-haunted theatre of operations.

BOSTON, June 6 (AP) -- Phil Masi's three-run homer gave the Boston Braves a 5-2 triumph over the Cincinnati Reds for Johnny Beazley tonight before a crowd of 23,854. Beazley, whose arm was treated by a New York specialist this week, kept eleven hits well scattered until the ninth.

SEOUL, Korea, June 6 -- Final decision of the joint United StatesSoviet commission on the difficult question of consultation with the Koreans may be announced tomorrow, Maj. Gen. Albert E. Brown, chief United States delegate, said today.
ROME, June 6 -- A difference between Washington and London over alleged Yugoslav war criminals is said to have developed.

New Capital Market A heavy concentration of new security marketings will face underwriters next week. Two preferred stock standbys are slated for Tuesday. One comprises 100,000 shares of Class A cumulative stock of the Dayton Power and Light Company, to be offered to stockholders as an exchange concurrently with a public offering of 75,000 shares of Class B stock by a Morgan Stanley Co.-William E. Hutton Co. syndicate.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 6 -- The three-under-par 70 that Joe Brascher and his partner, Johnny Mikrut of Shore View produced on Wednesday stood up today to give them the qualifying medal in the annual member-guest tournament of the Hempstead Golf Club.

Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday defended, as "an obligation to the city's best interests," his use of an official proclamation to designate last Wednesday as a day of protest against the Taft-Hartley bill to regulate labor unions. The Mayor's forum was a City Hall reception to a group of editors and publishers of foreign-language newspapers published in the city.

With each day bringing new incidents, a situation is developing on our city transportation system that is fraught with grave dangers. What form these dangers may take is not yet apparent, but they are inevitable when many of the men operating our subways are in an angry and provocative mood.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, chairman of the Senate's Majority Policy Committee, fired back today at President Truman, who yesterday attributed to Mr. Taft economic views concerning prices which the President said were "fallacious and dangerous," smacking of "boom and bust" tactics.
LONDON, June 6 -- Despite a falling off of business because of the week-end, the stock markets here today had some bright features.
TOKYO, June 6 -- In line with the announced policy of the Katayama Cabinet, Hiroo Wada, new Director of the Economic Stabilization Board, plans a determined drive to end black markets.

Speaking here yesterday on the question of utilizing Negro manpower in the post-war Army, Brig. Gen. Benjamin O. Davis declared flatly that the work of the Army can be "seriously impaired if any racial group is withheld from full participation in its over-all mission."
It's a good thing Aqueduct doesn't have a lake. If it had, players of "money horses" would have been heading for it yesterday.

General Sessions Judge James G. Wallace sentenced yesterday Mariano Abello, convicted of fatally strangling a woman last July 4, to twenty years to life in prison. A few minutes after he imposed the minimum mandatory term for seconddegree murder, Judge Wallace cited the prisoner's counsel, Edward V. Broderick, for contempt of court.

On the page opposite the text of the address of the Secretary of State at Harvard there appeared in this paper yesterday a picture of children playing in what's left of an invasion barge on Omaha Beach. This three-years-after view of the landing place of the American troops in Normandy was not intended to be an illustration of General Marshall's speech.

ST. LOUIS, June 6 -- With an inviting chance beckoning them to draw within half a game of the league-leading Tigers, the Yankees bogged down at Sportsman's Park tonight and, before 13,832 fans, bowed to the last-place Browns. The score was 4 to 3.

Several million New Yorkers may be surprised to learn that, on the authority of Representative Ed Gossett of Texas, their city "isn't an English-speaking place." Representative Gossett expressed his opinion yesterday at a hearing of a House judiciary subcommittee.

OTTAWA, June 6 -- The House of Commons this afternoon rejected a motion to refer back and voted second reading of the bill to permit the administration and discipline of United States troops visiting Canada according to United States Army regulations.

KILKIS, Greece, June 6 -- Orders signed by political commissars of the guerrilla army that have been seized by the Government forces indicate the strength of their control, amounting to the exercise of life-and-death powers, it was disclosed today.

An imperfect fire warning indicator on a four-engined DC-4 plane carrying a United Nations inquiry group to Palestine caused the return twice yesterday of that craft to La Guardia Field. A Trans World Airlines spokesman said last night that the trip had been postponed tentatively until 5 o'clock this morning.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 6 -- Threats of a tie-up of Pacific Coast shipping on June 15 were eased today with a conditional agreement between the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union and the waterfront employers.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Congress completed approval of the Taft-Hartley labor bill tonight, when the Senate accepted it fiftyfour to seventeen, and thus joined the House in raising the clearest prospect that any Presidential veto would be overridden.

The Marinduque Gift Company of 26 Platt Street has notified the Department of Markets that it will cease advertising in European newspapers offering "free" overseas packages in return for the names of American friends or relatives.

MUNICH, Germany, June 6 -- The internal political frictions that led to the walkout of representatives of the Soviet zone early this morning apparently have effectively scuttled the Minister-Presidents' conference, which opened here today.

More than $716,000 has been raised in New York and vicinity in the campaign for the World Youth Fund of the Y.M.C.A., it was announced yesterday at the final spring report luncheon of the campaign, at the Commodore Hotel. This represents two-thirds of the $1,075,000 goal in this area in the campaign that began on May 1.

In their first general assembly of the outdoor season, the metropolitan district's top track and field athletes, plus a few talented outsiders, will convene at Travers Island today for the 151st games of the New York Athletic Club. Handicap competition will dominate the fifteen-event program.
LONDON, June 6 -- Nine more letter bombs addressed to prominent members of the Government and Cabinet Ministers have arrived in Britain and been intercepted without mishap, it was disclosed today.

Songstress Joan Edwards yesterday filed a $75,000 damage suit in Supreme Court charging the American Tobacco Company with failure to comply with an agreement calling for her continuance as star vocalist on "Your Hit Parade."

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- The National Council of State Garden Clubs protested today against a Senate-approved amendment to the 1912 Plant Quarantine Act that would permit limitations on the imports of flowering bulbs.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Between January and July of any year the public prints burgeon with budgetary barbs directed at the number of people's servants who toil in the bureaus of the United States Government. The federal employe then becomes "it" in the rough-and-tumble game of "Trim the Budget."

Gov. Earl Warren of California arrived yesterday afternoon at La Guardia Field on his way up-state. The California Governor was asked if he would accept the Vice Presidential nomination on a ticket headed by Governor Dewey.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Maj. Gen. Robert Webster, commanding general of the Air Transport Command, announced today that a routine check of Douglas C-54 air transports was being made, but categorically denied that they were being grounded.

In his speech at the conference of the Labor party at Margate, Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin said that if peace could be established in Indonesia, the fat ration of the world could be met in twelve months. The same thing could be said of other places and other foods.

Bedding manufacturers have terminated all allocations on dual purpose sleeping equipment and are now selling against orders, Irving Weisglass, president of Eclipse Sleep Products, Inc., and member of the executive committee of the National Association of Bedding Manufacturers, reported yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, June 6 -- The Toledo Edison Company's refinancing plan, backed by its parent, the Cities Service Company, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Slammin' Sammy Snead shot a 65 for a new course record today and his 131 gave him a three-stroke lead at the halfway mark of the $10,000 National Capital open golf tournament.

Mayor O'Dwyer urged yesterday that "full cooperation" be given to the current campaign for $6,000,000 by the Greater New York Fund, for the continuance of the services of 423 hospitals, health and welfare agencies throughout the city.

PARIS, June 6 -- Overriding Communist opposition, the national assembly voted today 324 to 195 to withdraw the parliamentary immunity that hitherto had prevented the arrest of Joseph Raseta, Madagascan deputy accused of having plotted and directed the revolt in Madagascar March 27.

Reluctant to share anything, let alone first place, with the Giants, the Dodgers regained their undisputed half-game hold on the National League lead by beating the Cubs, 6 -- 2, last night at Ebbets Field, a few hours after the New Yorkers had moved up to deadlock the Brooks.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Senate and House conferees on the rent control continuation measure agreed tentatively today that, as long as Federal powers prevailed, states, counties and local communities should not take such matters into their own hands.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., June 6 -- Governor Dewey told 500 guests at the annual dinner of the Orange County Republican organization in Bear Mountain Inn here tonight that the Republican party offers women more opportunities for political leadership than any of its rivals.

MILWAUKEE, June 6 -- An attack on the Truman administration's domestic and foreign policies and a confident prediction that a Republican President would elected next year were made today by party spokesmen addressing the convention of the Young Republican National Federation, which opened here today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 6 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of the Navy, praised the United Nations today as a "beginning" toward a secure and peaceful world in which the United States was "the principal core of stability."

STANTON, Del., June 6 (AP) -- Herbert C. Boorse's Our Sensation triumphed at Delaware Park today in the second of the Montchanin Handicap series of distance races. Under a good ride by Johnny Breen, the 5-to-1 shot beat Mason Dixon by a half-length.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- A statue of William Edgar Borah, one of the most colorful and famous men who ever sat in the United States Senate, was unveiled in the rotunda of the Capitol today. Bryant Baker, New York sculptor, executed the statue upon the order of the Borah Statue Commission, created by legislative act in 1945.

VIENNA, June 6 (U.P.) -- The Rev. Bela Varga, former President of the Hungarian National Assembly, has escaped to the British-United States occupation zones in Austria, reliable informants said tonight.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 6 -- Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet representative, told the United Nations Security Council today that, as a result of the Allied victory, there was no reason for "inflated" military forces, whether they belonged exclusively to individual countries or were ear-marked for the proposed international police force.

Annual Children's Day will be observed tomorrow in many of the Protestant churches of the city. Tomorrow is Children's Day in the Presbyterian parishes of New York State and th general theme is "I Am the Way".

Governor Dewey and Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota, both of whom have been mentioned as Republican Presidential possibilities, conferred for an hour and twenty minutes yesterday morning on the foreign situation and its implications.

As had been expected in the trade, the evening-up in the July futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was the central attraction of trading yesterday. The futures market closed 40 points higher to 15 points lower than on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Opposition to legislation authorizing the long-debated St. Lawrence Seaway will be heard next week by a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee with twenty-five witnesses scheduled to testify.

Two 22-year-old Brooklyn veterans who are paralyzed from the waist down due to war injuries received in 1944 in France will move late this summer into specially designed homes to be built for them through funds raised in their neighborhood.

MINDEN, Germany, June 6 -- Military Government officials and representatives of the Export-Import Bank are negotiating a cottonimport plan that would give American and German private business interests greater latitude in the redevelopment of the German textile inudstry, it was learned today.

One of the most complete ensembles for furnishing bedrooms, dining and living rooms with modern furniture and accessories of matching designs and harmonizing colors will be introduced Monday in room settings at McCreery's. The group, known as "California Manor," was designed by Robert Dorr Jr.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 6 -- The Aero Medical Association, at the closing session of its eighteenth annual meeting today, condemned "dangerous policies" initiated by the Civil Aeronautics Administration in the last three years regarding standards for private and student pilots in the country.

John F.X. Finn, trustee of the Childs Company, operator of a restaurant chain, reported yesterday to Federal Judge Edward A. Conger in the District Court here that an understanding has been reached among all parties interested in the reorganization of the company, which petitioned voluntarily for reorganization in August, 1943.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- A bipartisan majority of the Senate Finance Committee is studying the possibility of issuing a critical blast at the proposed International Trade Organization. Such a move might shake the Geneva conference to its foundations.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- Pit operations in corn and oats overshadowed the wheat trade today on the Board of Trade. Big advances in the feed grains were induced by unfavorable weather and tight market conditions. July corn rose to $1.89 3/4 a bushel, highest since 1920 for any July delivery of that grain.

Pre-war visitors to the Palace and Kulm Hotels at St. Moritz, Switzerland, have returned, Hans Badrutt, proprietor, said yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria. On his first visit to this country to study American hotel methods, he described the changes that have taken place in Switzerland as a result of the war.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 6 -- Negotiations have begun here for the formation of a totalitarian-like coalition regime for Hungary copied from the Yugoslav and Rumanian pattern.
CHICAGO, June 6 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox came from behind tonight to beat Washington, 5 -- 4, for their sixth straight triumph of the season over the Senators.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan said tonight that he would recommend a full Senatorial investigation of reported frauds and irregularities in a Kansas City Democratic primary last August.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Following are the texts of Senator Taft's reply to President Truman on economic issues and of the Senator's statement on April 28 to which he refers in the reply: Reply to the President President Truman issued a statement yesterday attributing to me a lot of economic views on wages and prices which I have never expressed.

VIENNA, June 6 -- Austria has become a refuge for Hungarians who fear it will be unsafe to remain in their country under its Communist semi-dictatorship. Not all the movement is one way, however. Russian occupation authorities are reported to be returning to Hungary all whom they detect passing through their zone westward.

Failure of several subsidiaries of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to maintain dividend rates in the face of increasing operating costs was brought into sharp focus yesterday when the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company reduced its quarterly dividend rate for the third time since 1946.

LOS ANGELES, June 6 -- A pronounced schism in Democratic ranks widened today after Gael Sullivan, Democratic national publicity director, was openly criticized at the party's Jackson Day Dinner last night as having "insulted" Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt by his eleventh-hour failure to appear on the speaking program with her.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Mundt bill to give statutory authority for a State Department information and cultural exchange program survived its initial test in the House today, but a highly vocal group of opponents forced postponement of final action until next week.

BUDAPEST, June 6 (AP) -- Hungary's ranking Communist, Deputy Premier Matyas Rakosi, boasted that the Communists "perfectly put over" the seizure of the Government in this Soviet-occupied country "before the United States could rub its eyes."

Two thoughts govern consideration of the air tragedies at La Guardia Field and Port Deposit. Could they have been prevented? Can recurrence be averted? A full answer to both questions cannot be given until expert and honest men have had more time to weigh the evidence.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6 (AP) -- Howie Schultz's home run into the left-field stands with one out in the ninth broke a 3-3 tie and gave the Philadelphia Philies a 4-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates here tonight before 12,421 fans.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The roll-call vote by which the Senate approved today, 54 to 17, the Taft-Hartley labor bill was as follows: FOR THE BILL -- 54 Republicans -- 37 Aiken (Vt.) Knowland (Calif.)

The Hungarian coup is part of a campaign of organized aggression by Communist political minorities that can be expected to spread to other countries in Europe, it was charged here yesterday by Alexis Kyrou, acting head of the Greek mission to the United Nations.

Methods employed by the United States Postal Service to move mail for European distribution last fall during the maritime strike were revealed at yesterday's session of the State Postmaster's convention by John Hardy, Deputy Second Assistant Postmaster General.

EPSOM, England, June 6 (AP) -- Gordon Richards, England's champion race rider, will change his boots tomorrow and try to change his luck in the 168th running of the English Derby at Epsom Downs, and he'll be trying it, too, with the colt many Britishers are calling "the horse of the century."
Jake La Motta steam-rollered his way to victory over Tony Janiro, Youngstown (Ohio) hopeful, in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

Stanton Griffis, new United States Ambassador to Poland, declared yesterday that when he takes over his official duties in Warsaw around July 1, one of his chief aims will be to see that all private relief contributed by Americans reach is Poland's needy "without any leakage or graft."

PHILADELPHIA, June 6 -- William H. Collins, assistant advertising manager of Scott Paper Company, Chester, Pa., was reelected president of the Eastern Industrial Advertisers at the annual outing of that organization here today.

Three more members of the alleged Westo hijacking gang pleaded guilty yesterday as one of their number, Carmine Marrone, 21 years old, took the stand in Federal Court, Brooklyn, as a Government witness.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Plans for speedy servicing airplanes on landing fields have been developed and patented (No. 2,421,512) by Walter C. Leitch of Springfield and Joseph A. Logan of Hadley, Mass. This invention, one of 370 to win patents this week, is held to facilitate refueling and other operations in which safety and speed are of high importance.

A Senate investigating committee blames the 111 deaths in the Centralia coal mine disaster of last March on "almost everyone concerned * * * management, the miners, the mine workers union, State Bureau and Federal Bureau."

EASTON, Pa., June 6 -- Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, today received the degree of doctor of laws at the 112th annual commencement exercises at Lafayette College at which 10 graduate degrees were conferred.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 6 -- The first important upswing in motion picture production this year will become apparent next week with forty-five pictures shooting in Hollywood or at near-by locations, three working in New York, three others on distant locations and a Paramount production before the cameras in England.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 6 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, has forwarded a British Government appeal to all member states requesting them to guard their frontiers against the departure of "illegal" emigrants to Palestine, it was announced today.

CLEVELAND, June 6 (AP) -- The Fere Marquette Railway was merged today into the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company, creating what officials described as the seventh largest railroad in the nation in point of operating revenues.
LONDON, June 6 -- The British draft proposals for the United Nations Bill of Human Rights were published as a White Paper by the Foreign Office tonight.

CLIFTON, N.J., June 6 -- A labor dispute that has thrown 4,000 workers out of their jobs at the Clifton and East Newark plants of the Federal Telephone and Radio Corporation entered its ninth day here today with no signs of a settlement.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 6 -- The United Nations Housing Bureau has obtained more than 800 furnished rooms and 500 apartments for members of the secretariat, R.D. Potter, administrative assistant of the bureau, disclosed today.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- The judicial executive committee of Federal District Court today ordered the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad reorganization case reassigned to Judge Michael L. Igoe, refusing to heed his request that it be transferred to another member of the district bench.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 6 -- Delegates from twenty-six nations attending the seventeenth world convention of the Women's Christian Temperance Union were urged today by Mrs. Ella A. Boole, president of the group, to "increase the immunity of the world to alcoholism."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 6 -- A spectacular 29 on the back nine gave the Ardsley team of Ben Roman and J.R. Lenahan, the latter a former Rhode Island State amateur champion, victory in the pro-amateur tournament sponsored by the Westchester County Golf Association at the Fenway club today.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- James M. Landis, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, told a Senate hearing today that Federal aviation officials lacked direct authority to require "adequate" fire fighting equipment at airports.
