LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 6 -- Until disarmament lightens the tax burdens of the peoples of the world there can be no free economic development, Alexander P. Morozov of the Soviet Union, acting chairman, told the United Nations Economic and Employment Commission today.

More than 1,400 patrolmen, detectives and precinct commanders have been on special voluntary crime patrol here in the dark-todawn hours the last two nights, it was learned yesterday. They have focused on districts where burglaries have increased since early May.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, June 6 -- Nikola Petkov, leader of the Opposition to Bulgaria's Communistdominated Government, was jailed today and told reporters as he was led to his cell that his arrest was "nothing but a prolongation of what already has happened in Hungary."

Nine junior high school students debated the question "What Is the Responsibility of Youth Toward World Peace?" in Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, yesterday. The discussion was broadcast over Station WQXR.

BUENOS AIRES, June 6 (AP) -- Argentina's pro-Government press today interpreted the withdrawal of United States Ambassador George S. Messersmith as an unfriendly act, one newspaper calling his case a "dismissal."

LOS ANGELES, June 6 -- Somewhat more than 1,000 men comprise the bulk of the Army's antiaircraft artillery defenses in the continental United States, a survey of available anti-aircraft units has disclosed.

PRAGUE, June 6 (AP) -- The International Organization of Journalists, nearing the end of its world congress, today unanimously approved a broadened resolution on freedom of the press and specific proposals for enforcing it.

KANSAS CITY, June 6 -- An audience which included President Truman was told tonight by General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, Chief of Staff, that the first responsibility of United States citizens "is to depend upon ourselves for the preservation of America's free system."

BOSTON, June 6 -- Seventeen Germans who are pitiful remnants of Goebbels' propaganda machine were assembled today in Federal District Court to testify for the prosecution in the trial of Douglas Chandler, one-time American newsman, for treason.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., June 6 -- T. Jerrold Bryce of Clark, Dodge Co. was installed as president of the Bond Club of New York today at the conclusion of the club's field day at the Sleepy Hollow Country Cub here. He succeeds James Coggeshall Jr. of the First Boston Corporation.

Rinehart reports that Leo Schwarz is translating and editing more than 100 manuscripts written by survivors of camps and ghettos in German-occupied countries. Mr. Schwarz, editor of "Memoirs of My People," "The Jewish Caravan" and "A Golden Treasury of Jewish Literature," has just returned here after three years in the Army and thirteen months as director of operations in the United States zone of Germany for the American Joint Distribution Committee.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Under-Secretaries of the Departments of State, Commerce and Agriculture told Congress today that some Presidential war-time powers must be continued to avoid a "scramble" for scarce materials.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The United States must take the lead in finding a solution for the problem of displaced persons if it is to be solved, John H. Hilldring, assistant secretary of state, told a House Judiciary subcommittee today at the second session of hearings on the Stratton immigration bill.
LONDON, June 6 -- Five thousand housewives from all Britain demanded tonight the removal of Food Minister John Strachey and Fuel Minister Emanuel Shinwell in a stormy meeting that ended in fighting.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 6 (AP) -- Matyas Rakosi, virtual dictator of Hungary and leader of that country's Communist party, is a Russian citizen and a brigadier general in the Soviet Army.

The new labor bill which the Senate has now sent to the President by the overwhelming vote of 54 to 17 extends to labor unions precisely the same prohibition against political contributions which already prevails in the case of banks and corporations. In the opinion of one Democratic critic of the bill, "this in itself is sufficient ground for a veto.

ALBANY, June 6 -- Increased minimum wage rates affecting about 249,000 employes (158,000 restaurant and 91,000 hotel workers) ranging up to 22 cents an hour, have been recommended by the respective wage boards to Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner.

GARY, Ind., June 6 -- The school board of this city has decided to assign all its students to their "proper" school district next fall without regard to race, creed or color, Charles D. Lutz, board superintendent, said today. The first steps will be "limited" and will apply to only about 100 Negro children in the primary grades.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Dr. Bradford Murphy, chairman of the trustees of the Colorado State Medical Society, today endorsed the Taft health bill to provide $200,000,000 a year for five years to aid state medical aid programs.

TWILIGHT on the South African veld is a heart-easing experience. The hills turn a dark purple, the stars peep through the bluegum trees, night settles down like a cloak. If you can sense the earth breathing its deep contentment, you have veld fever.

THESE poems by Weldon Kees form a chapter in the history of the disintegration of our world, written by an intelligent, witty and detached mind. Mr. Kees has obviously felt it necessary -- like many a contemporary and ancestor -- to take refuge from chaos in irony.

The 115th commencement season of New York University will open today at 4 P.M. with baccalaureate exercises in the chapel of the Gould Memorial Library on the University Heights campus. University Avenue and 181st Street, the Bronx.

OTTAWA, June 7 -- Canadian nervousness over the dollar situation and the increasingly strained relations between the United States and the Soviet Union broke to the surface this week on the eve of President Truman's visit in a manner that was entirely unexpected and regretted by many.

BOB FELLER seems to be a rather nice person. In his personal narrative of how he became the fastest throwing pitcher in American baseball at the present time, there is no note of egotism. Whether he is as fast as Walter Johnson, and some people believe he is even faster, he does not say; that is just one of those things he doesn't think he is qualified to talk about.

NEW DELHI, June 7 -- Observers here find that the most encouraging aspect of this week's momentous developments in Indian politics is the realistic attitude political leaders showed in commending the British plan for India's partition to their followers.

LONDON, June 7 (Reuters) -- A record-breaking third-wicket partnership of 319 runs scored in four hours by Capt. Alan Melville and Dudley Nourse enabled South Africa to collect 376 for three wickets on the first day of the cricket test match against England at Nottingham today.

INYOKERN, Calif. -- The tourist ordinarily thinks of the desert as an utterly barren expanse of earth to be traversed as quickly as possible. But anyone familiar with the desert will tell you this is "city slicker" ignorance. And as far as the Mojave is concerned -- even though it includes that supposed epitome of desolation, Death Valley -- it must be acknowledged that the facts bear out the desert boosters.

THERE are sixteen teams in the two major leagues. Fifteen of them fall into recognizable patterns of remorseless logic and sanity. The sixteenth is Brooklyn, which defies all the laws of reason. In first place or last, under this manager or that the Dodgers are the darlings of the Flatbush Faithful.

NEWARK, N.J., June 7 (AP) -- The Newark Bears' International League Baseball Club announced tonight Manager George Selkirk would become supervisor of Yankee farm teams, succeeding Bill Skiff, who is to manage Newark.

Interest in twenty parcels to be offered at auction in the Hotel Commodore at 1 P.M. tomorrow by the city is heightened by the increased subway traffic around these properties, according to Bernard P. Day, president of Joseph P. Day, Inc., who will conduct the sale.

JUST before the new, proCommunist Cabinet was formed in Hungary, stamps honoring Franklin D. Roosevelt and the Four Freedoms were printed by the Budapest Government. Stocks reached Gimbels stamp department last Tuesday, the day after the series was scheduled to receive first-day sale in Hungary.

The New York season's first outboard hydroplane regatta of the familiar racing pancakes will be held this afternoon on the Hackensack River at Carlstadt, N.J., where the retired Freddy Jacoby Jr. was wont in pre-war years and before he became a Signal Corp major to lower records and raise speeds.

THE reappearance in New York of this classic of Jewish literature is significant of the geographical trends in Jewish scholarship in our generation. The author, Dr. Scholem, a native of Berlin, has found his academic home not in his native Germany, which for a century was in the forefront of Jewish learning, but in the Hebrew University in Jerusalem.

BERLIN, June 7 -- Twelve thousand Chetniks have been brought from Italy to Germany by the British army to prevent their being sent back to Yugoslavia by the Italian Government. They include officers and men of former Royal Army units and their dependents and are registered by rank and unit as if they were members of a recognized army.

ACCUSTOMED to hearing so much about the Catskills and the Bear Mountain region, vacationers are apt to overlook many other pleasurable haunts along the Hudson River. Less well known, perhaps, they offer, none the less, grand opportunities for delightful holidays at a cost suited to the average purse.

THE Ballet Society, having completed a very full first season, including not only four programs of ballets, but also a flock of small events, a series of publications and a double bill of Gian-Carlo Menotti's music oramas, is already taking a deep breath and getting ready for next season's program.

DISARMINGLY, George Middleton subtitles this record of his sixty-six years "the autobiography of a journeyman playwright." It is an honest statement. Even his more successful Broadway compositions, while they stir a nostalgic memory or two among the oldsters, are not of the theatre's artistic elect.

EPSOM, England, June 7 (AP) -- Pearl Diver, winner of today's Derby, was foaled during the war in occupied France and given an alias to hide his identity from the Germans. He is a son of Vatellor, who finished second in the French Derby of 1936, and Pearl Cap, who won the French Oaks in 1931.

GEORGIA -- Personality Test Schoolma'ams have a greater tendency to dominate than do male teachers, according to the results of a personality test given to education majors at the University of Georgia's College of Education. The results showed that 50 per cent of the men tested were below average in their tendency toward domination, while only 44 per cent of the women were below average.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 7 -- The Truman Doctrine was attacked here today by educators as being an ineffectual pre-atomic bomb measure and a move away from world peace at the Institute on International Relations being held at the University of Kansas City.

One of the problems that preparatory schoolmasters have to face every year is the insistence of parents that their children enter "acceptable" colleges or universities, according to Dr. Allan V. Heely, headmaster of the Lawrenceville (N.J.) School.

THE local galleries, stall pretty active despite the fact that the season has about reached the mopping-up phase, offered last week a little of this and a little of something else. Not much seemed to be of more than routine interest, though here and there a show or perhaps an isolaed picture tended to lift itself above the conglomerate level.

Cotton dress sales continued high last week, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Other departments which reported good activity were sportswear, sporting goods, men's furnishings, neckwear, blouses, handbags, infants' wear and housewares.

ON the verge of closing last night at the Barrymore, Gian-Carlo Menotti's double bill of musical dramas, "The Medium" and "The Telephone," received a last-minute reprieve. Whatever its fate this week, it has stirred more than a pebble's ripple in the Broadway pond.

THE vacationist who prefers the calm, unhurried ocean voyage to distant places is normally one of the least insular of persons. Yet, in many instances this summer, he is turning his thoughts inland. The ocean trip to former European haunts is still not devoid of difficulties.

AMERICAN lovelists have lately bagged some of their biggest game in the preserves around Rockefeller Center, where radio shares a hunted existence with the advertising agencies. Mr. Freeman, in an effort to nail an even bigger hide to the door, has chosen to poach in the sacred groves of Hollywood.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The number of young men and women studying in countries other than their own is increasing again, and farreaching proposals are being made to inaugurate new systems of international exchange of students and scholars, or to expand established systems.

Disciplinary action was taken yesterday by the Board of Transportation against two additional members of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, when it suspended Thomas Carew, a motorman, on charges and delivered misconduct charges to the home of James F. Kelly, another motorman.

LONDON, June 7 (U.P.) -- Britain's new Commonwealth Atomic Energy Committee today appealed to Prime Minister Attlee to take the initiative in arranging an early meeting of the Big Three to settle the problem of atomic control.

Results of the market absorption survey conducted by the Silex Company in a test area surrounding Peoria, Ill., since May, 1946, will be projected on a national scale in six weeks to chart steady demand for the company's products following the period of "surge" or scarcity buying, a company spokesman announced last week.

TO bring forth laughter by digging below the surface absurdities in human behavior is an exacting art. Good humor will bear the test of time and is a recurring delight. Gag humor is another thing. The point hits home, the loud guffaw follows, and then it's all over.

UNLIKE the other Post-Impressionists, Georges Seurat was a man of shadows. Cezanne, like a gigantic mason, constructed his mountains, his immense plains, even his platters of apples, in some blue-shining, midday light.

CHICAGO, June 7 (AP) -- Rains and floods in midwestern agricultural areas, creating apprehension over the crop outlook, were responsible for price advances in corn and oats on the Board of Trade today. Wheat weakened under hedging pressure.

WERNERSVILLE, Pa., June 7 -- Henry Morgenthau Jr., former Secretary of the Treasury and general chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, reported today that $115,000,000 has been raised toward the $170,000,000 quota.
Held up for four hours by rain, John Kramer, Montebello, Calif., national tennis champion, left by Pan American plane from La Guardia Field last night for London.

PARIS, June 7 -- British, American and other tourists in Paris and crossing France today experienced many troubles because of the railway strike. Some were stranded because of money troubles. Others were dropped in places where no accommodations were available.

LONG ISLAND points a tapering finger eastward from Manhattan to a varied vacation land. The direction is significant, for the farther east one goes the greater are the opportunities for a diversified and restful holiday.

MUNICH, Germany, June 7 -- Disappointment over the end results of the Minister-Presidents' conference, which ended here today, was only partly tempered by indications that attempts might be made to convoke further such gatherings to promote economic improvements.

To the Drama Editor: UNLIKE most plans for bringing the theatre within the reach of those with limited means, that of Alfred de Liagre Jr. at least has the virtue of actually being in operation. While I admire his initiative, I cannot quite believe that reduced ticket prices would solve the problem for all, or even most, established productions that are no longer "selling out."

WASHINGTON, June 7 (U.P.) -- A United Press poll of twenty-one key Democratic Senators showed today that President Truman has almost no chance of getting the necessary votes to sustain a veto of the labor bill.
THE BRIDE Weeping bride, laughing wife; laughing bride, weeping wife." -- German proverb.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander announced yesterday that special voluntary policemen, who have been doing extra patrol duty in an effort to combat crime, made ten arrests for various crimes in Brooklyn and Queens in the last twenty-four hours.

THIS is a family chronicle, a word sampler put together from the colorful events in the life of the Lancasters, who moved into the staid atmosphere of West Philadelphia in the early Nineteen Hundreds and became the talk of the neighborhood.

IN "The Red Sox, the Bean and the Cod," Al Hirshberg, prominent sports writer for The Boston Post, has told the story of the Boston team from its purchase in 1933 by Tom Yawkey, a baseball bemused young millionaire, to that recent autumn day when a stunned Johnny Pesky saw too late the wild dash of Enos Slaughter toward home plate.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Summer hotel managers and the proprietors of tourist homes and cabins are winding up their spring cleaning in preparation for the coming vacation season. Some of the summer places were ready for business Memorial Day, put most are now welcoming their first guests.

The recurrence of terrible airplane accidents has made people wonder if the old Air Safety Board should not be revived. Under the Civil Aeronautics Authority and the Air Safety Board, which were established in August, 1938, the airlines had for more than a year an enviable record.

The developers of the Continental Village home recreation center near Peekskill, N.Y., report that plans are being made to convert a large barn on the property into a "straw hat" theatre. The building will have a seating capacity of 600 and will be suitable for stock companies and previews of New York plays.

LINCOLN, Neb. -- American motor tourists tend to be the long-distance kind. We have the great open spaces, we haye the smooth, broad highways, arid we have -- or hope soon to have -- the cars. Those of us who hail from New York think little of driving to the Mississippi, and not much more than a little of keeping on to the Pacific Coast.

IT might be interesting to collar a member of a theatre audience some time and get him to tell you just how he imagines a particular tune was prepared for his entertainment. If he has a clear idea of the long, and usually painful, hours of struggle with the details of composing, lyricizing, staging, arranging, copying, and rehearsing involved, the number probably didn't entertain him much.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 7 (AP) -- William G. Hells' Jobstown closed with a rush today to win the $10,000 added Absecon Handicap for 3-year-olds before 12,955 spectators.

Moving closer to the pre-war ratio of outstanding orders and stocks-on-hand to sales, retailers have achieved marked progress in meeting their inventory problem, which at one time threatened to present serious difficulties if not culminate in debacle.
FOR more than 20,000,000 anglers invading the lakes, streams, bays and offshore waters a good season is in prospect, to judge by the early signs.

TUCSON, Ariz. -- This state, wintertime host to thousands of visitors, also invites summer guests to look around the cooler portions of the fifth largest of the forty-eight states. Most summer visitors will probably head for the northern part of Arizona, seeking out cool weather and the leading attraction, the Grand Canyon.

After eight years of research the delicate inner workings of the thyroid gland, key regulator of the living body, have been bared through the use of byproducts of atomic energy by Dr. I.L. Chaikoff and his associates at the University of California. Every step in thyroid metabolism from the time inorganic iodine is taken into the body until it is poured into and used by the body cells is now known.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 7 -- All seven defendants in the trial of Ustashi leaders and members of the regime under AntePavelitch were sentenced to death this morning by the Croat Supreme Court in Zagreb. Six of the condemned will be shot, while the seventh, Siegfried Hasha, Hitler's Minister to Croatia, was sentenced to be hanged.

LOS ANGELES -- The chambers of commerce don't talk about it, but there is a malady which sometimes strikes visitors to the Golden State. It is California-fright and it is analogous to stage-fright or the mikefright that hits neophyte radio performers when they suddenly realize the vastness of the medium confronting them.
A marked decline in building permits throughout the nation for the first quarter of 1947 is shown in the latest tabulation of construction projects made by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

BRUNSWICK, Me., June 7 -- Nine honorary and 127 baccalaureate degrees were conferred today at Bowdoin College's 142d commencement, which was marked by the opening of a campaign for $3,000,000 for immediate needs.

Although a great gap still exists between supply and demand, the automotive industry's production for the first half of 1947 is expected to be only slightly below schedule. The six-month production record will be impressive and should make the planned output of 4,700,000 new vehicles for the year easy of attainment despite shortages of materials, according to industry officials.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 7 -- A specific blueprint for an international atomic development agency, with six or more super laboratories and a world pool of physicists, chemists and engineers producing atomic power for nations at peace, has been proposed to the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission by Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, American physicist who headed the New Mexico atomic bomb laboratory.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- The tourist industry of this mid-Atlantic resort is still marking time. Though the first phase of reconversion is at an end, the second cannot be completed until Bermuda again has adequate shipping service.

For the first time since 1921 when it was the scene of the national amateur championship, St. Louis will be the golf capital of the world this week when it will be the scene of the forty-seventh open championship of the United States Golf Association.

GULLANE, Scotland, June 7 -- Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zaharias, American woman golf champion who lashes the ball as far off the tee as a man, fired a red-hot 71 over the windswept Gullane course today and announced, "I'm really hitting the ball."

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, June 7 (AP) -- Four United States golfers, including two - time runner - up Johnny Bulla, have entered the British open championship starting June 30, officials of the Professional Golf Association announced today.

CEDAR CITY, Utah -- Straddling the Los Angeles Highway just 264 miles south of Salt Lake City, this pleasant town is the entrance to no fewer than five major scenic attraction of the inter-mountain region. Grouped in a roughly rectangular area some 150 miles from north to south, and approximately 200 miles east to west, all can be visited in a week of comfortable touring.

Government surplus disposal has resolved itself into a tough merchandising problem, with sales volume leveling off and selling costs going up, according to a survey of the New York region of the War Assets Administration last week.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. has presented to Memorial Hospital the entire block bounded by Second and Third Avenues and Sixtyeighth and Sixty-ninth Streets, it was announced yesterday. The announcement, made by Reginald G. Coombe, president of the hospital, put no value on the property, but Edward C. Delafield, treasurer, estimated that the assessed valuation ran between $2,000,000 and $3,000,000.

Roy Rogers, the guitar-strumming singing cowboy of the motion pictures, will invade the Polo Grounds next Sunday afternoon for an eight-day stay with the "largest, most spectacular outdoor show in the world."

OLD FORGE -- The year-round residents of the Adirondacks are a hardy lot. They spend their winters plowing about through great snowdrifts and watching their breath turn to frost in 10, 20 and 30 degrees below zero temperatures.

LONDON, June 7 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin took the unusual step today of personally authorizing a Foreign Office statement reiterating the British Government's satisfaction at the Harvard speech of United States Secretary of State Marshall on aid for Europe but denouncing "certain misleading interpretations" of Britain position.

BOSTON, June 7 -- Despite the refusal of the United States Supreme Court to hear James Michael Curley's plea for a hearing, some quarters in Boston feel that their Mayor, convicted for defrauding the Federal mails, will not serve a day in jail.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 7 -- Lajos Dinnyes, new Premier of Hungary, said today that his Government intended to "develop the closest collaboration with Soviet Russia" and that "nobody can withdraw" that right from his country.

At the last meeting of the American Mathematical Society two papers were presented about the coloring of maps. Every schoolboy knows that two adjacent regions on a map are never of the same color. Thus, in a map of the United States, New York and Pennsylvania would be colored differently because they touch each other.

As New York City's riding season gets into full swing, the city's seventy or more miles of bridle paths are crowded with equestrians ranging from the Bronx cowboy in his Stetson hat to the Central Park dandy sporting a black derby.

OTTUMWA, Iowa, June 7 (AP) -- The swift floodwaters of the Des Moines River drove 10,000 Ottumwa residents from their homes, swept at least seven persons to their death, stranded hundreds and left this southeastern Iowa industrial city of 32,000 without power or drinking water today.

IN his last years David Livingstone became obsessed with the idea that somewhere in the spongy swamp south and west of Lake Bangweolo lay the "fountains" of Herodotus and the ultimate source of the Nile. The thought fired his stubborn imagination.
CHICAGO, June 7 -- Labor leaders today attributed many difficult on-the-job problems faced by Negroes to the lack of training.
PARIS, June 7 -- The railway strike is expected to cut heavily into the industrial production of France by late next week, it was said tonight.

Abroad and at Home For President Truman's 108th press conference last Thursday, 136 Washington correspondents crowded around the executive desk in the Oval Room of the White House. On the President's left sat Clark Clifford, the Presidential counsel; on his right, John R. Steelman, his chief adviser on labor matters.

CHICAGO, June 7 -- The outlook for relief of financial difficulties confronting Chicago's administration darkened this week. As a result, a predicted year-end deficit of $9,000,000 in the government's corporate (operating) fund, mostly in unpaid bills, and possible payless paydays for municipal employes in 1948 still plague Democratic Mayor Martin H. Kennelly after nearly two months in office.

A budget of $24,760 has been authorized for the Commission on Ministry to Veterans and Service Personnel of the Protestant Council of the City of New York, the Protestant Fund of Greater New York announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- President Truman was roughly in the position this week of the country editor who wanted to keep peace in the community but somehow could never stay out of trouble.

VERY often the novel with a tricky pattern is no better than a stunt, calling attention to itself, accomplishing little. It is to the great credit of the author of "The Gallery" that he makes the unusual design of his story functional and strongly effective.

HOLLYWOOD. THE screen version of "I Remember Mama," which has been in prospect at RKO for four years, has gone before the cameras with George Stevens directing and Irene Dunne playing mama, the role done on Broadway by Mady Christians.

PRINCIPLES of teaching photography that proved successful in training soldiers during the war have been recorded on movie film for general use. Three veterans who taught and practiced photography have produced a training film called "Basic Motion Picture Technique" which, with supplementary printed texts, offers the beginner a practical course in moviemaking.

RUNNING airports is a big job. Making them pay is an even bigger one. But the Port of New York Authority has undertaken the task of making the airports in the Port of New York self-supporting, so that they will not be a drag on the taxpayer or the airlines.

IN the spring of 1934, after going through "a long period of great strain," Anne Fowler felt dispirited when she arrived with her husband and three children at their summer home on the New England coast. She progressed from a state of semi-apathy to one of nervous overactivity and, finally, to one of confusion and depression.
DETROIT, June 7 (AP) -- The Briggs Manufacturing Company received today from the United Automobile Workers, CIO, the threat of a strike Wednesday.
Although rain washed out the second game of the Giant-Cardinal series at the Polo Grounds yesterday, it was scarcely an idle afternoon for Manager Melvin Ott.

Browning Ross, the little gamester from Villanova who took runner -up honors in the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. mile last Saturday, outlasted Bill Hulse, long striding holder of the American outdoor mile record, in a thrilling stretch duel to win the special three-quarter mile run at the 151st track and field meet of the New York Athletic Club yesterday.
Trouble Underground The conflict between the men who run New York City's subways and Els and the men who manage them last week reached a critical stage.

EPSOM, England, June 7 -- A 40-to-1 outsider won the greatest of all horse-racing prizes today when the French colt Pearl Diver beat the pick of Britain's horses by four lengths in the Derby. The Aga Khan's Migoli was second, three-quarters of a length ahead of the second favorite, Sayajirao, owned by the Gaekwar of Baroda.

MAX MANUS, a young, footloose adventurer, sometime smuggler, seaman and construction worker in South American jungles, was preordained for the reckless, ticklish job of sabotage within his native Norway during the occupation.

The American aircraft manufacturing industry, which performed miracles of design, production and modification during the war and at its peak turned out three times as many planes as the British and twice as many as the Germans, is now in a sinking condition.
MADRID, June 7 -- The Spanish Government's bluff of great shipbuilding activity has been called loudly by a local economic paper, whose charges are backed up by figures from the companies' reports.

Roy Harris, American composer, conducted the American Broadcasting Symphony yesterday afternoon in the first New York performance of one of his latest works, a concerto for the seldomattempted combination of accordion and orchestra.

THE advent of "CBS Views the Press," the new program on which the Columbia Broadcasting System appraises the performance of the New York newspapers, would seem a healthy and provocative development for the press and radio alike.

LONDON, June 7 -- The restriction of British imports from all parts of the world and a further belt-tightening are in store for the British people, it was authoritatively learned today. This action, which officials concede will bring a storm of protests from the British public, is considered inevitable in the light of the nation's badly balanced foreign trade.

FRENCH LICK, Ind. -- Car prices will remain at about the same level through this year at least, unless there are serious economic disturbances to force them upward, C. Ray Buckendale of Detroit, former president of the Society of Automotive Engineers, declared in an analysis offered at the S.A.E. summer meeting here last week.

BEAR MOUNTAIN -- A foretaste of what to expect in the way of summertime business at Bear MountainPalisades Interstate Park came on a warm Sunday in late May when a crowd of 10,000 thronged to this vacationland.

The Two AEC's David E. Lilienthal is a tall man of 47 whose profession is the law (he studied under Felix Frankfurter at Harvard Law School) and whose hobby is boxing (he studied it under a professional boxer named the "Tacoma Tiger").

LATE last week, too late to be reviewed on this page today, an exhibition called "Tomorrow's Buildings" opened at the Architectural League. It is described in advance as a "flexible review of architectural progress in 1947" -- flexible in that from time to time new projects included will be replaced by still newer ones.

MONTREAL -- Good roads across the international boundary, an increased number of air routes, and frequent trains bring eastern Canadian cities within easy reach of New York. The foreign atmosphere, romantic scenery and historic buildings are attracting many visitors from the States.

The Communist coup in Hungary stirs intense uneasiness throughout Europe because it reveals so baldly the pattern Russia seeks to apply to every nation where her followers have been allowed to entrench themselves. All the countries within or adjoining the Russian sphere of influence are exposed to Hungary's fate.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (U.P.) -- Chairman Fred A. Hartley Jr. revealed tonight that the House Labor Committee would investigate charges that trades unions had staged "a deliberate slowdown" against the housing program."

PORTLAND, Ore. -- That fellow in fuzzy wool chaps and ten-gallon hat, leaning nonchalantiy against the veranda pillar of a cow-town hotel, turns out as often as not to be a summer wayfarer from Shaker Heights in Cleveland or perhaps an apartment house on Manhattan Island.

BEFORE he left on his last journey to the Pacific. Ernie Pyle said to his publishers: "I hope some day you people will publish the book of mine that I like best myself. That's the book with all the stuff I wrote before the war, the book about my own country.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 7 -- Importance is attached here to the conference with Marshal Tito in Belgrade for which Rumanian Government leaders left today.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 7 -- Joe Brescher and Johnny Mikrut of Shore View, medalists in the Hempstead Golf Club's annual member-guest tournament, proved themselves good duck hunters today by advancing through two rounds to reach the semi-finals.

SUMMER, officially, is nearly here. Summer vacations, which are guided but not wholly controlled by the calendar, have already started. By all accounts, earlier prophesies that this will be the greatest vacation season since the war are now well on the way to fulfillment.

VERNAL, Utah -- Modern motorists may venture into the land of the dinosaurs simply by turning off U.S. 40 a mile or so east of Vernal and driving into the Dinosaur National Monument just six miles from the Denver-Salt Lake City Highway.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Leaders in India think that partition will result in ultimate unification of the country. But historically, India has never been united. Rather than serving as a force for unity, partition will prove to be as disastrous in the long run as was partition of Poland, or as might have been the partition of the United States if the Civil War had ended differently.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia -- This province by the sea was rapidly becoming one of the most popular vacationlanda in eastern North America when World War II intervened. This year, from all appearances, Nova Scotia will regain its hold on the affections of travelers.

The 1947 Tax Reduction Bill, passed by both Houses of the Congress with a liberal margin, awaits the signature of President Truman. The choice of three courses of action is open to the President: He can sign the bill, veto it, or permit it to become law without his signature.
DESCRIBED as "a research project for the improvement of American transportation," General Motors "Train of Tomorrow" is now on a six-month exhibition tour of the nation.
WASHINGTON. IN his neat, gray, affably punctilious person, Carl A. Loeffler illustrates some of the changes that have come over Congress since the "old days" -- a year ago -- of Democratic control.

LONDON. NOT long ago London's theatreland was full of prosperous managers complaining of the high rate of income tax. Now it is full of worried managers complaining of the crushing burden of entertainment tax.

THERE are novels by the ream which sing the neuroses of novelists: the present example belongs to that subsection. How it differs from the run of the grist is moderately curious. In most such books, the novelist suffers for his true art.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- The White House inner circle of advisers was reported about evenly split today between those urging President Truman to sign the union-curbing labor bill and those favoring a veto.

Complaints by exporters that they are having difficulty getting payment on credit shipments to Latin-American countries have shown a sharp increase over the last few months, foreign credit men stated last week. This is the first time since the war, they said, that the problem has appeared.

Adequate housing should be provided for residents of this city, with suitable playground space and recreation areas, through the aid of the Federal and local governments, according to pupils who participated yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over WQXR.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Sam Snead putted himself right out of the lead in the $10,000 National Capital Open tournament today, and three golfers gratefully moved into a tie for first place at the end of fifty-four holes.

APE-MAN A whole family of ape-men and apewomen have been dug out of the stony floor of the cave at Sterkfontein, South Africa, Dr. Robert Broom of the Transvaal Museum reports in Nature. The most precious discovery is the skull of a toothless, elderly female, lacking only the lower jawbone.

STRAWBERRY vines are heavy, the warm sun deepens the hue of the fruit from blush to crimson, the fragrance that goes with ripening rises to perfume the air. On Main Streets everywhere baskets of big berries are set out in grocery windows, the best inducement a dealer has to get people into his store.
LONDON, June 7 -- Britain turned to her women this week to save her production program from impending failure.

TO THE EDITOR: You have given one side of the story in your article. "Any Resemblance Is Purely Coincidental," by C.A. Lejeune. How about the American movie-goer's impressions of England from British films? It would run something like this: England consists of an enormous foggy mass called London, where burly bobbies, smart young Cambridge men with bowlers and walking sticks and slim, cool, cameofeatured blondes dine on tea and crumpets and read The Times.
SUMMIT, N.J., June 7 -- The Watchung Riding and Driving Club opened its two-day horse show today, carrying out the program despite rain.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti -- The biggest piece of publicity that Haiti has received in many a year was its selection by Kenneth Roberts for much of the locale of his bestseller, "Lydia Bailey". Settings for historical novels, however inviting, are usually inaccessible bits of fantasy about as tangible as gossamer.

SACRIFICE bidding is one off the few department of bridge strategy that is demonstrably profitable. Mathematically, at least, it is. Suppose both aides are vulnerable and one side can bid and make four hearts. By this it will score 120 for tricks and 500 for rubber, a total of 620 points.

RAPID CITY, S.D. -- The welcome sign is out, the tourists are arriving and the Black Hills of South Dakota anticipate a $30,000,000 season before Labor Day and fall weather send the sightseers homeward once more.

PARIS, June 7 -- Capture of the leading military chieftain of the Malgache rebels of Madagascar and a lull in violence of marauding bands have offered the French hope that the island revolt is getting under control.

WASHINGTON -- As Congress rushes to end its work here and begin vacations elsewhere, the city is preparing for its heaviest months of tourist traffic. Summer along the Potomac isn't like that along Baffin Bay, or even Penobscot, but it's the favorite time for Americans to see the town they own.
AL JOLSON will serve as narrator and also will sing the traditior Jewish lament "Eli, Eli during the United Jewish Appeal program scheduled to be broadcast tomorrow night at 7:30 over CBS.

Virgil Jordan, president of the National Industrial Conference Board, sought to determine last week what keeps the American free-enterprise system ticking so strongly. He seemed to think that the answer would be helpful not only to this country but also to the rest of the world, at a time when private enterprise appears to have broken down almost everywhere else, and when Socialist and Communist planned economies continue to run down in poverty and confusion.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- A threat of a wide-open break in the bipartisan alignment on foreign policy developed today when it was learned that Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, was considering opposing President Truman's program for providing Latin-American countries with military equipment, aircraft and naval vessels for the training and development of their armed establishments.

The breath-taking pace of events of the last week served to divert, at least for the time being, a more critical appraisal of President Truman's declarations ending, so far as this Government was concerned, the estrangement between the United States and Argentina.

ONE-MAN shows in considerable abundance pepper the week's panorama. These range in size from the group of forty flower paintings by Andrey Avinoff at Knoedler's to an incidentally displayed little handful of brightly decorative water-colors (exuberantly and not slavishly Dufyesque) by Robert O. Bach at a.i. friedman, inc.

NEW ORLEANS, June 7 -- Increasing industrial expansion in the South since the end of the war stems from a recognition of the raw material and fuel resources of the region and its rising importance as a market.

A TONIC for flower borders lies in entirely new combinations possible when brilliant blossoms of corms, tubers and bulbs classed as summer-flowering are used with favorite annuals and perennials. Quick-growing kinds add unusual touches to borders this month and next, while others will combine with August and September flowers.

MARC BLITZSTEIN has no hesitation in tackling big, dramatic themes; he seems to be drawn to them. His symphony, The Airborne, written on assignment from officers of the Eighth Air Force, in which he served, touches on the theory, history and mythology of flight, and recalls its use in the late war.
THE New York Botanical Garden will hold its fifth annual Rose Growers' Day on Wednesday. This is given in cooperation with the American Rose Society.

Percy Roberts, known to just about everybody in the dog world as a handler and importer of purebred dogs, is back from a twomonth buying trip in England. Since what he had to report on conditions there looked as though it might be interesting, a call was made to his Stamford kennels.

THE summer visitor need not have been an "Ivy Leaguer" to enjoy the well-worn charm of the college and university towns that dot New England. In such towns the mall, the steeple, the village square and the campus each year attract thousands of vacationists, a few seeking to recapture the undergraduate mood, but most looking for calm relaxation after a year of urban hustle.

NORTHERN readers who may have expected a generally violent reaction by Southern reviewers to Sinclair Lewis' "Kingsblood Royal" are in for a mild surprise -- or so it would seem from a glance at the newspapers reaching this desk from below the Mason-Dixon Line.

Although public attention was focused last week on the possibility of a general business recession later in the year, the center of interest shifted from prophecies to the labor and tax bills now awaiting action by President Truman.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (U.P.) -- The soft-coal industry, facing a possible work stoppage July 7, said tonight that miners were the country's highest paid industrial workers "if they will just work full time."

TURNING from the front page, parents may feel that singlehanded they can't do very much about the state of the world. This isn't the way Dr. Howard Wilson feels about it. Parents can do a good deal, he told us the other day.
Dominions of India In the House of Commons in London last Tuesday at 3:30 P.M., Prime Minister Clement Attlee arose at his desk and said: "I desire to make an important statement on Indian policy."

NEW YORK has not lacked out-of-town visitors of late -- or for a long time. But, perhaps, with a great many New Yorkers away, visiting other places, this summer will not be a bad time for more out-oftown visitors.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 7 -- Eric A. Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Producers Association, proposed tonight an executive-legislative joint council on foreign policy to make an inventory of the world's needs and a survey of American resources.

In view of the latest statements by Secretary of State George C. Marshall it is evident that the urgency of the world's economic needs and the approaching "dollar crisis" have relegated the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development already to a subordinate position in foreign financing, informed observers asserted yesterday.

Sweeping reorganizations of key divisions of the Army Ordnance Association have been made to improve liaison with the War Department on industrial mobilization plans, L.A. Codd, executive vice president, disclosed yesterday in a statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

CANANDAIGUA -- The Indians used to believe that the Great Spirit placed his hand in benediction on his favorite hunting ground and created the Finger Lakes. This is indeed a "happy hunting ground" for the tourist, the casual traveler, and the vacationist seeking a peaceful spot for rest and relaxation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We all have a graphic idea of the horror which will accompany the next war -- the Atomic War. We have, in fact, heard about it so often and imagined it so minutely that the entire population lives under a tension and apprehension that was alien even during the war years.

NANKING, June 7 -- China's student front is unsettled but much nearer normal than it was a week ago. Classes have been resumed at most of the universities where the undergraduates went on strike at the height of the recent "peace and bread" agitation.

FRANK NORRIS died fortyfive years ago, at the age of 32, in the same year as the author who most influenced him -- Emile Zola. He died almost accidentally, one may say, after an operation for appendicitis. If medical science had been as far advanced in 1902 as it is today, Norris might still be alive, with a long record of finished work in which "The Octopus," now republished, would have a certain place.

THOUSAND ISLANDS -- This vacation, sightseeing and fishing area stretching along the St. Lawrence River from Cape Vincent to Alexandria Bay, is marshaling its facilities and manpower for the busy summer months ahead.

The supply of petroleum products is so near in balance with demand that any decline in tanker transportation over the next few months might result in acute shortages developing in the Northeastern States and in several foreign countries where water-borne methods are used almost exclusively to furnish oil supplies.

There was never any doubt in the minds of novelists that if you hypnotized a man and ordered him to commit murder he would oblige. Psychologists were not so cocksure about this. Dr. John G. Watkins (Welch Convalescent Hospital, Daytona, Beach, Fla.) seems to have settled the matter in favor of the novelists.

CONTRARY to an impression that is taking hold among our young, there actually was once a time when "Life With Father" was not being played on a stage. Indeed, hardly a soul had heard of the play at all before it came out of the Maine woods one dark August night in preatomic time.

Two hundred steel stamping plants throughout the country have opened a campaign to restore the Pittsburgh Plus Pricing System in steel sales. Tom J. Smith Jr., president, Pressed Metal Institute, Cleveland, disclosed to THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday.

James Keane of the Donnybrook Club, a Saxon Woods affiliate, led the first contingent of qualifiers in the tenth annual public links championship of the Metropolitan Golf Association by carding 37, 38 -- 75, four above par, in the rain at Split Rock yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 7 -- The price for black market babies has increased in Brooklyn during the past four months from $1,500 for a baby girl and $1,700 for a boy to a flat $2,500, it was charged here today at the annual conference of the American Society for the Study of Sterility by Dr. Abner I. Weisman of New York City.

BUDAPEST, June 7 -- Brig. Gen. George H. Weems, United States representative on the Allied Control Commission for Hungary, has posted on the agenda for the next meeting the United States request to Lieut. Gen. V.P. Sviridov, Soviet chairman of the commission, for the documents allegedly implicating former Premier Nagy in the purported plot against the Government.

Development of a sandwich-type wall panel three and one-half inches thick designed to be used in place of a conventional solidmasonry wall thirteen inches thick has heen announced by the New York Housing Trust.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- A probability that further consideration of legislation increasing second, third and fourth class postal rates will be postponed until next year was reported in official circles today.

PROVIDENCE, R.I. -- With two more attractions added to its summer program and two more airlines serving the State from New York and points south and west, Rhode Island expects a banner vacation season.

JOPLIN, Mo. -- Just before the last war an estimated 2,500,000 persons were visiting the Ozarks region annually. Then came Pearl Harbor and an end of travel. Resort owners, however, did not fold their hands and resign themselves to fate.
A variation of the "man-bitesdog" fable was recorded in the minutes of the annual meeting of stockholders of the United States Lanes in Hoboken last week.

ASBURY PARK -- New Jersey may be just the State on the wrong side of the river to some insular New Yorkers, but to most other Americans it is a top-ranking resort State. And for all their joking about the "sticks," New Yorkers give it their approval, too.

The Modern Man I MUST say that the man we call modern, the man who is aware of the immediate present, is by no means the average man. He is rather the man who stands upon a peak, or at the very edge of the world, the abyss of the future before him above him, the heavens, and below him the whole of mankind with a history that disappears in primeval mists.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- This week-end the vanguard of 15,000 physicians expected from all parts of the United States began to pour into Atlantic City for a meeting, which, it is said "will represent a high point in the assemblage of physicians anywhere in the world."

KANSAS CITY, June 7 -- President Truman took his daily walk today, but a little later than usual. This time he marched at the head of the 35th Division's reunion parade. He covered a mile and a half, nearly all uphill.

DURING a recent sojourn in Boston, we made a flying visit to the Addison Gallery at Phillips Academy, Andover, Mass., to have a look at the current textile exhibit. We were hardly prepared to find a fine arts museum relaying orders for contemporary decorating and dress fabrics, but that is exactly what we did find.
FOR the current six weeks iris will dominate the perennial display and it is pleasant to see plants of the Siberian type to contrast with the more familiar bearded varieties.

The "jeep tow patrol" to eliminate traffic bottlenecks on the West Side Highway will be demonstrated at 10:30 A.M. tomorrow and immediately thereafter it will be put into service, it was announced yesterday by Hugo E. Rogers, Borough President of Manhattan.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga. -- The six - room, Dutch - style Little White House on Pine Mountain, near Warm Springs, Ga., will one day become one of the most visited spots in the United States if plans of the Georgia Franklin D. Roosevelt Memorial Commission materialize.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The program for completing a peace treaty with Austria this year might be delayed indefinitely as a result of a Soviet coup in that country, according to views expressed in official circles here today.

An improved method of selecting the trustees of American colleges and universities to provide broader representation of all segments of the population is proposed in a recent study by Dr. Hubert Park Beck entitled "Men Who Control Our Universities."

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 7 -- Armed with many requisition orders, some brick and mortar and Military Government approval, Frankfort city officials are now preparing their city for its new role as the economic capital of the United States and British zones.

The Hapoel soccer team of Palestine will make its second local appearance of its nation-wide goodwill tour this afternoon when it meets the American Soccer League All-Stars at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, starting at 3:15 o'clock.

GENEVA, Switzerland, June 7 (AP) -- Ferenc Nagy today told his story of the events leading up to his ouster as Premier of Hungary by the Communists. He declared that the accusations against him were ridiculous and said "there was no constitutional ground for my resignation."

THE Alsatian poet, Yvan Goll, is known for his song-cycles about modern uprooted man, Jean Sans Terre, a few of which have been translated into English. In the present book Yvan and his wife, Claire Goll, collect love poems they have written each other.

Declaring that the Truman Doctrine of aid for Greece and Turkey was in line with the late President Roosevelt's "quarantine the aggressors" speech in 1937, Paul Porter, former head of the American Economic Mission to Greece, said yesterday that he hoped to see American financial aid extended to other European countries to help in reconstruction of their economies.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 7 -- Bohumil Lauschman, Minister of Industry, acknowledged today before the Industrial Committee of Parliament that 1,000,000 yards of textiles had been sold in the black market across the border through Slovak channels.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 7 -- Historic Jekyll Island, fabulous winter colony playground, owned and occupied exclusively for sixty-one years by Eastern millionaires, will soon become a magnificent public seashore park under a proposal announced this week by the State of Georgia.

The primary cause of human misery today is not poverty of resources. Nor is it destruction caused by war. The primary cause is a breakdown, throughout large areas, of the machinery of production and distribution. Among the countries that have escaped this blight the United States is the greatest and richest.

Despite the fact that Nostradamus himself, at the height of his powers, would have been stumped by an effort to prophesy the waterfowl populations of the coming fall, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service is planning to dust off its crystal ball tomorrow and begin working out waterfowl shooting regulations for the coming season.

"ROSES INDOORS AND OUT," the two-day program presented at Times Hall on Tuesday and Wednesday, will have twelve exhibitors from Connecticut, New Jersey and New York garden clubs to demonstrate flower arranging on the two afternoons.

LONDON, June 7 (Reuters) -- With settlement of the first division championship in the English League set for next Saturday when Stoke City plays Sheffield United, chief interest today centered in the 4-2 defeat of Sheffield Wednesday by Chesterfield.

The States Marine Corporation, using chartered ships for its Pacific Coast-European services, will replace them with C-2 type vessels recently bought from the Maritime Commission, according to Henry D. Mercer, president.

Last week's dramatically timed announcement by Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City that he would relinquish his city post -- but not his Democratic leadership -- is believed to result largely from the gradual process of attrition which for several years has been operating against his political prestige and power in New Jersey.

FOR city dwellers cross-country bicycling offers a novel, enjoyable and inexpensive way to get out into the countryside during the summer months. One recent week-end we undertook such an excursion through the wooded hills of Massachusetts and Connecticut.
NEW ORLEANS, June 7 -- It may come to a case of fish or oil from the Gulf of Mexico.

TRENTON, N.J., June 7 -- Some of the legislative atmosphere of Trenton will be transplanted to New Brunswick this summer during the New Jersey constitutional revision convention, which opens next Thursday.

Reminding realty owners that they may be without the protective features of the New York State mortgage mortatorium after July 1, Nathan Goldman of the Sonnenblick - Goldman Company, mortgage brokers, pointed out yesterday that funds for new loans are ample and that current market conditions generally are best suited to refinancing.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Former Gov. Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota, an avowed candidate for the Republican nomination for president, favors the enactment of the Taft-Hartley labor bill which received final Congressional approval yesterday.

CHARLESTON, S.C., June 7 -- The cotton textile industry, by virtue of its gains in public and labor relations, research and technology, has reached the position where it does not need to apologize for any aspects of its operations or philosophy, Dr. C.T. Murchison, president of the Cotton-Textile Institute, declared here today.
WASHINGTON. ON April 22, 1946, Harlan Fiske Stone, twelfth Chief Justice of the United States, was stricken at his place on the nation's highest bench. Within a few hours he was dead.
Three active apartment and home-building organizations have joined hands in an unusual housing project on Long Island, which will provide rental accommodations for 1,632 families.

The formation of an East Coast Joint Policy Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations maritime unions was announced last night by Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, who has been elected chairman of the new group.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Congress, which gave prompt and pressing attention to surplus war material and the dismantling of the mechanism of conflict, finally got around this week to another kind of war surplus, the thousands of homeless, suffering displaced persons in Europe.

A MYSTERY story in reverse is the original and piquant idea at the root of the new novel by Olive Higgins Prouty, author of "Stella Dallas." A young man with a weak heart drowns in a Maine lake. His death plays hob with the life of Murray Vale, who had made valiant attempts at rescue in a storm.

THE awards of the Music Critics Circle for the best new compositions of the New York season of 1946-47 have now been made. They are of interest for various reasons. In the first place, they are an index, not unreliable, to the quality of the new compositions that have been heard in the period mentioned.

STANTON, Del., June 7 -- Elpis, one of William Helis' extensive string of thoroughbreds, chalked up her most important victory today when she roared through the stretch to take the $25,000 added New Castle Handicap at Delaware Park.

LAST Tuesday a group of representative theatre people argued before the House Ways and Means Committee that the 20 per cent tax on theatre tickets ought to be removed. To their way of thinking the theatre should not be taxed as a luxury; or, more precisely, theatregoer should not have to pay a 20 per cent tax for the privilege of buying an expensive ticket to the theatre.

NEW DELHI, June 7 (Reuters) -- Viceroy Lord Mountbatten is making "very satisfactory" progress in his conferences with Indian leaders to settle ways and means of carrying out the British evacuation plan, it was authoritatively learned tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Groundwork was laid today for a Congressional investigation of currency and black market transactions in Germany that may ultimately cost American taxpayers several hundred millions of dollars.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., June 7 (AP) -- The Stamrock Stable's Air Patrol, skillfully guided along the rail rounding the fair turn by Jockey R.J. Martin, scored by a neck over H. Ted Darling's West Fleet in the $10,000 Spring Handicap today before an estimated 20,000 crowd at Narragansett Park.

SOME people travel the hard way -- a Seattle couple have arrived home after pedaling all the way from Winter Haven, Fla. The trip took six months, partly because their impedimenta included their three children, aged 1, 2 and 8, who rode in a canvas compartment slung between the couple's connected bicycles.

VIENNA, June 7 -- A high Government official declared today that a leading Austrian Communist had demanded a new Communist -controlled regime in this country, with the threat that the Soviet Union would never sign a peace treaty with the present moderate Cabinet.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 7 -- Slapping around in a nasty Easterly rain and sea, thirty-seven of the racing craft on Long Island Sound went out today in the Stamford Yacht Club regatta, the sixth of the championship summer

NORTH and South, East and West, across the North American Continent stretch waterways offering vacation paths to the canoeist and the foldboater. These "voyageurs," as they are known because of the sport's popularity for centuries in the French Canadian country, have almost no serious limitation but the calendar (and their equipment and skill in its use) in making a choice of trips.

MADRID, June 7 -- The Spanish Cortes (Parliament) tonight approved unanimously a bill for a "law of succession" which makes Generalissimo Francisco Franco practically King of Spain during his lifetime and gives him the right to choose his successor.

USE of the rail credit card, a new charge-it service for travelers started April 1 by forty-five railroads, is growing steadily, according to H.W. Siddall, chairman of the Rail Travel Credit Agency. Eight hundred to a thousand cards are being issued daily and it is estimated that more than 50,000 already have been issued.
BALTIMORE, June 7 (AP) -- Northern lacrosse players today held a 3-2 edge over their southern rivals in the annually renewed allstar series.
LOS ANGELES. THE project of a lavish civic opera house as a western "home" for the Metropolitan company is making substantial progress both materially and esthetically.

Patrolman John E. Carton, who campaigned on a platform advocating a forty-hour, five-day work week at a permanent annual salary of $4,000 for policemen, has been elected president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association of New York City, the PBA's election committee announced yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, June 7 -- Addressing himself to themes apparently popular with his midwestern audience, President Truman tonignt reproached the House of Representatives for what he considers false economies in cutting budget estimates for Federal agricultural and land reclamation programs.

BERLIN, June 7 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay expressed annoyance and regret today that the Russians had chosen through their official newspaper for the Germans to deprecate the United States role in the victory over Germany. Assistant Secretary of War Howard C. Petersen also rejected Soviet assertions that the Russian army alone had won the war.

SHARON, Pa., June 7 (AP) -- A tornado followed in places by hail "as big as ice cubes" swept for 75 miles through northeastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania today, leaving five dead, scores injured and property damage running into hundreds of thousands of dollars.

Just what is happening in the theatre, financially speaking, may be gleaned from the statement for "Alice in Wonderland" for the week ended May 24 at the International Theatre. Nine performances were given, one being a special benefit matinee showing. The gross income was $21,250.40, the net profit $1.22.

ATLANTIC CITY -- This place is always having anniversaries as well as conventions. Two years ago the Boardwalk was seventy-five years old, and this year the Steel Pier is fifty years old. It doesn't much matter; both are always full in the summer time.

MR. FREUND'S newest novel is located on Easter Island, that isolated, legend-encrusted Pacific island of extinct volcanoes, blistered rock, ancient burial platforms crumbling above the sea and the mysterious towering monoliths (some of them over thirty-five feet high) of the Easter Island gods, inscribed with ciphers that still defy decipherers.
OMAHA, June 7 -- Cuts planned by Congress in the appropriation of the Department of Agriculture will force a curtailment in the 1947-48 soil conservation programs that are planned for Midwest farms.

Former President Herbert Hoover's recommendations on the future of Germany, submitted last week to Representative John Taber, chairman of the House appropriations committee, "would make Germany the greatest industrial power in Europe," it was charged yesterday by the Society for the Prevention of World War II, 515 Madison Avenue.

GRANT was President and John A. J. Creswell, a Marylander, was Postmaster General when Congress, seventy-five years ago today, authorized a startling innovation called the postal card. The idea, which had been tested briefly in Europe, was, in a sense, revolutionary. It officially accepted an amazing concept that a letter need not be so long nor in the same elegant style as an article in a literary quarterly.

Every month substantial checks for "carry-back" payments are being sent to New York companies by the Treasury Department. Nevertheless, more than half of the New York business executives, asked about "carry-backs" in a survey here yesterday, did not know that the money you lose in business in 1947 or 1948 can get you a refund of 1943 to 1946 taxes from the Treasury Department.

Lewis Merrill, international president of the United Office and Professional Workers of America, CIO, has resigned "for reasons of health," it was announced yesterday by the union's national, administrative committee.

CONCORD, N.H. -- Vacations in New Hampshire this summer promise to be more comfortable than for several years. More help is available and so is more food; repairs are once more possible. The monotonous fare and inconveniences of the war years should be things of the past.

PORTLAND, Me. -- Lakes, mountains, rolling hills and sweeping coast line, which constitute the physical attraction of the State of Maine, do not change from season to season, but the conditions under which the tourist reaches and enjoys them are not so constant.

STACKS, or funnels, have always been major identification characteristics of the ocean liners. They have been subject to style changes through decades of travel, just as other ship features have been altered by time and custom.

PARIS, June 7 -- The railway network throughout France was practically at a standstill tonight. The sporadic strikes that began in the Paris region spread rapidly during the day to nearly every corner of the country.

TORONTO -- You can still hear the slap-slap of a beaver's tail as he works on plastering his home at night. You can paddle silently around the turn of a Canadian lake to see a deer drinking at the water's edge. You can paddle up some small backwater stream and unexpectedly watch the epic struggle of a duck as a turtle pulls it by one leg to shore.

MESA, ARIZ. SITUATED in an irrigated valley, this town, sixteen miles from Phoenix, is blessed with sunny skies, a climate that's well-nigh perfect, and something quite new in the way of radio -- KTYL, "the drive-in station."

ECONOMICS were argued last week by President Truman and Senator Taft. They were discussed in other quarters and the International Chamber of Commerce in session at Montreux, Switzerland, decided that another great depression was not probable but merely "a temporary adjustment like that in 1920" and passed a resolution to that effect.

When the New York Athletic club's yachting department disclosed yesterday that the dates of July 11 and July 12 had been chosen for the Block Island races it really meant something more. James A. Amatulli of Pelham Manor, committee chairman, hopes to fill the 105 nautical miles of Long Island Sound between Execution Light and the western harbor of Block Island with one of the largest collection of competitors in the history of long-distance racing.
VIENNA, June 7 -- Of the downfall of the old Austro-Hungarian Empire, Count Ottokar Czernir said: "We were doomed to die. We could only choose the manner of our death and we chose the most terrible."

LONDON, June 7 -- The financial and distribution problems that have proved insurmountable so far seem likely to prevent hungry European nations from receiving an extra 600,000 tons of fish this year, it was disclosed today at the offices of the Emergency Economic Committee for Europe.

GENEVA, June 7 -- It is two months today since delegates of seventeen countries met here for talks of deep import for the world's economic future. There have been two parallel sets of discussions. One is for the drafting of a charter for an International Trade Organization as an organ of the United Nations.

CONSIDERED as a novelist, Gerald Kersh is a very odd fish indeed. He writes romantically of perversion and decay. He sees in present-day city life the final degradation of human beings, and is a good enough writer to be able to put this feeling into a description of an empty room in an abandoned tenement.

As recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES the text of the speech by President Truman at Kansas City last night was as follows: General Bodie, Mister President of the Thirty-fifth Division, Admiral Leahy and General Eisenhower, distinguished guests, members of the Thirty-fifth Division and their guests.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 7 -- Chief Justice Clarence E. Case, of the New Jersey Supreme Court, denied today, because of a technicality, a writ of review regarding legality of this city's ordinance banning dancing and orchestras in restaurants.

THE horse opera is generally presumed to be not only the oldest but also the least changing category of motionpicture entertainment. Actually, however, styles in Westerns have undergone five distinct variations and are currently, to the accompaniment of considerable hoopla, entering a sixth.

ROME, June 7 -- The Partisans are among the most colorful and picturesque groups of men in Italy. They are also among the most turbulent. Every time that events take a turn that does not please them they "take to the hills," and the Government has to mobilize the police to chase them back into the plains again.

THERE will be more and more books about conquered Germany, but "The Hidden Damage" will remain one of the best. It has the double value of being good writing and of being honest testimony from an unpretentious but skilled observer. For historians a hundred years from now it can serve as a dependable record of how Germans talked and acted during the first months after their unconditional surrender.

THERE are few holiday trips in this hemisphere that provide more variety and interest than island-hopping in the Caribbean. For a short vacation it is well to concentrate on the islands that lie close to each other.

TRENTON, N.J. -- Motorists traveling the easterly portion of U.S. Route 22 in New Jersey are witnessing the beginning of a war memorial idea in landscaping and beautification that may ultimately stretch across the entire nation from the Atlantic to the Pacific.

PROFESSOR LUNDBERG, sociologist of the University of Washington, has elaborated two articles which he wrote for Harper's Magazine and in which he championed the social sciences as the only disciplines that are likely to be of any use if the world is to achieve peace, security and happiness.

During the war years our spirits were encouraged by many entrancing promises of comforts and conveniences which were to emanate from the knowhow acquired under the duress of the great conflict. Some of them, such as faster, bigger airplanes and better radios and television, have become realities, but we are still waiting for many of the marvels that were to come out of the laboratory and the workshop.

OFFICIAL hearings by the Civil Aeronautics Board into the crashes of two commercial airliners over the Memorial Day week-end will not start until the middle of this week, but already it appears that the causes of the two worst air disasters in American aviation have been determined.
JUNE is the month of bold and handsome flowers. Shrubs and perennials with lavish bloom make this a time of unstinted profusion in the garden.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 7 -- The Istanbul press, which two days ago was ordered by the military authorities not to publish the movements of the United States planning group within the martial law zones, was completely muzzled today on what the American Army and Navy officers are doing in this country.

PARIS, June 7 -- Physically and politically tortured, Europe is now preoccupied with an ideological struggle between various shades of Right and Left -- a struggle upon the final outcome of which may depend the whole complex of Great Power and therefore global relationships.

The ceaseless war of nerves between institutional investors and underwriting syndicates over the "going price" for new bond issues has taken an arresting turn in recent weeks. The change suggests that the large insurance companies, after having been on the defensive against falling interest rates for more than a decade, are marshaling power to take the offensive themselves.

'Good Neighbor' For more than a year a battle has been waged in Washington over United States policy toward the regime of Argentina's "strong man" President, Col. Juan D. Peron. The conflict was personified by two men in the State Department -- Spruille Braden, former Ambassador to Argentina and for the past nineteen months Assistant Secretary of State in charge of American Republics Affairs, and Ambassador George Messersmith, Mr. Braden's successor at Buenos Aires.
HOLLYWOOD. IF you should ask Hollywood people. "Parlez-vous francais?", nine out of ten who can answer you at all are apt to say. "Mais oui, grace a Mrs. Salemson."

THIS being the time of year when a couple of million Americans are venturing out onto golf courses to try out theories they've had a whole winter to think about, it's only natural that most of them again will fall heir to the pains and ills that beset linksmen the world over.
SHAKESPEARE'S Hamlet, who once remarked that in spite of everything dogs would have their day, failed to foresee the time when they would have horoscopes, too. That situation has arrived.

WHEN I first read this provocative manuscript, I suggested that it was the best piece of writing to date to bring the United States Supreme Court out of its high ether of mystery down to the level where nonlawyers might share the excitement.
BERLIN, June 7 -- In Charlottenburg castle, built by Frederick the Great for his sister, German book publishers opened today the Festival of the New Book with a display of their post-war wares.

ST. LOUIS, June 7 -- The amazing Frank Shea carved his seventh straight victory at Sportsman's Park this afternoon before a gathering of 5,388 sweltering fans as he turned back the Browns, 3 to 1, and brought the Yankees again within a game of the American League lead.

MONTICELLO -- Residents of the vacation region of the Catskills land Shewangunk (pronounced Shongum) Mountains, taking in Ulster, Greene, Sullivan and Delaware Counties, say that no similar area in the United States plays host to as many summer tourists as does that playland less than ninety miles from New York City.

THIS book is composed of ten essays in the reading of as many poems by Donne, Shakespeare, Milton, Herrick, Pope, Gray, Wordsworth, Keats, Tennyson and Yeats. There is a concluding essay, "The Heresy of Paraphrase," which argues the point that good reading returns to the poem and that no substitutes should be accepted.

BERLIN, June 7 -- The way was opened today for foreign private interests to do business in the economically-merged United States and British zones on a vast scale. A delegation of American financial and textile experts, including representatives of the American Cotton Shippers Association of Memphis, Tenn., won what they described as a satisfactory agreement with the United States and British Military Governments.

MEXICO CITY -- President Miguel Aleman's unprecedented tour of the Unied States is reported to have awakened additional interest in this country on the part of Norteamericanos. The result is likely to be more tourists than ever from north of the border this summer.

THE wartime "share-the-ride" plan is extending to vacation trips this year, and many car owners are planning parties with friends whose vehicles are too old for long journeys into the wide open spaces. Reports from motoring organizations and other travel groups indicate that there will be no empty seats in the average family automobile when it speeds away on a recreation run to country, mountains or seashore.

Jim Carrington, Navy lineman, will join Doc Blanchard, Glenn Davis and seven other Army players on the Eastern College AllStars in the game against the New York Giants of the National Football League at the Polo Grounds on the night of Sept. 3.

USING the same pictorial method as in her popular "The Little History of the United States" and "The Little Geography of the United States," Mable Pyne here bravely tackles the history of the world -- the rise and occasional slipping back of civilization from the very beginning of life to the United Nations.

"American architects should lead a drive to free our communities from the 'strait-jackets' imposed by faulty street patterns and by unintelligent restrictions in deeds, zoning ordinances and building codes," Kenneth C. Black, a director of the American Institute of Architects, said yesterday.

To the Drama Editor: IF the theatres are so much interested in reducing costs, why do they not eliminate the socalled broker? If a person wants to buy a suit, shoes, a railroad ticket or a dinner, he goes to the place which sells these.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 7 -- While everyone is trying to figure out how he did it, Abd el Krito, exiled Riff desert leader who escaped from French bondage, is treading the paths of King Farouk's beautiful estate at Inchass glorying in his new found freedom.

Yarrow begins to open its graywhite heads of miniature bloom in the meadows, and if one walks through a patch of it there is the pungent odor of its crushed foliage, faint but unmistakable.
