The foliage itself is amazingly delicate, finer cut than that of the daintiest fern, and of a silvery green color quite unlike anything around it.

ALTHOUGH Defender's Varigam Paper, the photographic enlarging and contact paper which is printed by filtered white light to provide any desired tonal contrast, has been available for some years, the use of the Varigam filters for "dodging" purposes has been neglected.

TO present some baseball highlights of the last seventyeight years, Bill Brandt, a sports commentator, formerly a sports writer and publicity director for the National League, uses the question-and-answer method. The wide range of topics he selects could hardly have been welded into a continuous story.

THE Society of American Etchers has broadened its policy and in consequence has adopted a new name. This active and influential organization will henceforth be known as the Society of American Etchers, Gravers, Lithographers and Woodcutters, Inc. John Taylor Arms, the president, thus explains the move:

THE passage from Mary Webb's "The Spring of Joy" quoted in today's Treasure Chest provides one more instance of the deeply suggestive quality one usually finds in analogies drawn from the observation of nature. She has been writing about motion in nature and she compares the swaying of trees in the wind with the action of a poised mind in its response to new ideas.

TRAVELERS who appreciate good food should savor some al fresco feasts as they explore the country this summer. America boasts a picnic tradition that goes back, a long way. The Indians staged the first clambake, and maybe it was they who also originated the fish fry, the Southern counterpart of that delectable shore dinner.

BAD SALZUFLEN, Germany, June 7 -- More than 80 per cent of the British zone's 24,000,000 nationals feel that no German representatives should sign any peace treaty without discussing its provisions with the Germans, according to a report made public today by the Military Government.
CHICAGO, June 7 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox won their seventh straight victory from Washington today as relief pitcher Joe Haynea scattered four Senator hits over eight innings for a 4-0 decision.

Hailed as a success from the standpoint of a convention that justified attendance of more than 3,000 utility executives from almost every section of the country, the recently convened four-day meeting of the Edison Electric Institute in Atlantic City failed to produce any evidence of amity in the breach that has existed between public and private power advocates for more than a decade.

IN March, 1933, Josephus Daniels was appointed United States Ambassador to Mexico. His appointment was one which on the surface, at least, violated all the canons of political tact and diplomatic practice. For, nineteen years before, it had been Josephus Daniels who, as Secretary of the Navy, had ordered the American landing at Veracruz, an operation carried out at a cost of 126 Mexican dead and 195 Mexican wounded.

While most investors act promptly to notices advising them that their securities are to be redeemed, many others lose millions of dollars yearly by neglecting to do so, officials of corporations and banks pointed out last week.

PENDLETON, Ore., June 7 -- The spring wheat crop of Oregon's eastern uplands, already seared by abnormally dry weather, is threatened with destruction by the worst cricket plague in many decades. A host of crickets is advancing across the rolling plateau of Umatilla County and thus far efforts to halt them have proved futile.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 7 -- Proposed nationalization of the liquor industry in Great Britain and Canada was called "illogical and anti-social" by Mrs. Dorothy Staunton, English delegate to the 16th convention of the world's W.C.T.U. here today.

MIAMI BEACH -- This is the time of year when "South for the Winter" becomes "Summer Vacation in Florida." A big season already is under way, attributable to a latewinter and early-summer influx of visitors.

WITH 34,000,000 workers in the United States now receiving paid vacations, plus the thousands of people who do not have to rely on such considerations when going on holiday, indications are that 1947 travel figures in the Western Hemisphere will top last year's by 25 to 30 per cent.

WASHINGTON. IF a group of economists and other observers of current affairs gathered to appraise America's economic future, opinions would be about as follows: some of the group would regard a recession as inevitable in less than a year; others would believe that it still might be averted by prompt action.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa., -- Called the driest region east of the Rockies and the coolest south of Maine, this Pennsylvania mountains vacationland is preparing for a boom summer. Reservations for July and August indicate a new high in popularity, and for September and October, when the foliage is the chief attraction, bookings are unusually high.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 7 -- Rumanian Premier Petru Groza and four members of his Cabinet arrived on schedule this morning by special train from Bucharest. The Rumanian officials were met by Marshal Tito, his Cabinet and the diplomatic corps at the Central Station.

The Rev. Dr. Lewis Weatherbee Pitt, the rector, and the wardens and vestrymen of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, will open on Sept. 18 an elementary school there for girls and boys. It will have a nursery and kindergarten departments and all the grades through the eighth grade.

AMERICAN Youth Hostel headquarters report a 60 per cent membership increase over last year, indicating that the nation's highways and byways will be dotted this summer with some 23,000 sun-tanned hostelers pedaling their way around the country at a cost of little more than a dollar a day.

AT the opposite pole from the luxury vacation on board a "floating hotel" is the windjammer cruise, especially designed for those who like to feel (and be) close to the water. Unaffected by post-war shipping problems, reconditioned schooners will sail on this summer as merrily as in the past fifteen or so years, plying the waters off Long Island, Massachusetts and Maine and in Chesapeake Bay.

Supreme Court Justice James B. McNally dismissed yesterday a suit for an injunction and $500,000 damages brought by Lee and Jacob J. Shubert and their Trebuhs Realty Company, Inc., against Columbia Pictures Corporation, producers of "The Jolson Story." Justice McNally held that the plaintiffs had failed to establish a cause of action since "there is no property right in an idea as such but only in the expression of the idea."

Two million tenant families in New York, and occupants of more than 16,000,000 rented houses, apartments and hotel rooms throughout the country are awaiting with interest the outcome of Congressional committee conferences over the future of residential rent control.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, boasting a sizable capital reserve, will oppose the creation of a single, unified budget for the United Nations and other specialized world agencies as proposed by members of the United Nations secretariat.

-- THE U.S.A. Our Professor Ensykle, who has been out West in his little old car for three weeks, discovering America, comes home bursting with enthusiasm, also with notes for a book, which he allows us to see.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- As the leader of the Senate majority on domestic affairs -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg is its spokesman on foreign policy -- Robert A. Taft of Ohio is a natural as well as titular adversary of the Democratic Administration. For this reason controversy with the White House, on the floor as well as in non-official public forums, is inevitable.

Surprises were the order of the day in the double-feature presentation at rain-drenched Aqueduct yesterday, William Helis' colt Rippey winning the $25,000 added Carter Handicap at a shade under 6 to 1 after C.V. Vhitney's filly Mackinaw had taken the $20,000 added Astoria Stakes at better than 11 to 1.

While a crowd of several thousand persons looked on, a 45-yearold woman, a commercial artist, attempted to jump from the roof of the four-story Strand Theatre Building, between Forty-seventh and Forty-eighth Streets on Broadway, yesterday noon, but was restrained by the police.

SCHENECTADY, June 7 -- Governor Dewey extolled Gov. Earl Warren of California at an alumni luncheon today at Union College as a "scientist in the art of government" and in the art of politics, with which, he said, government is so closely allied.
Hundreds of buyers returned to the wholesale markets here last week to make final selections on initial buying orders for fall and to make last-minute purchases of summer dresses.

HAL ROACH, one of the few remaining pioneers in film comedy, is convinced that there is a dearth of "good visual comedy writers" in Hollywood and that the feature length picture has done much to "kill off" ranking comics.

THERE have been several Stevenses in literature and biography as there were probably several Stevenses in life. Not even Lincoln has been so fulsomely praised as a sainted friend of the Negroes and of liberty; Beast Butler was not so excoriated as a malevolent and partisan enemy of the South.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn. -- The TVA country is a thousandmile horseshoe swinging down from the VirginiaTennessee border, dipping into North Carolina, Georgia, Alabama and Mississippi and curving up through Tennessee again and across the westernmost tip of Kentucky.

Buyers last week were surprised by a tightening and an actual increase in wholesale ready-to-wear prices while stores were fearful of increased resistance from a public expecting lowered prices, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buyers.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, June 7 (U.P.) -- Nikola Petkov, Agrarian party leader, who was arrested Thursday night, was charged by the public prosecutor today with participating in a twenty-three-month conspiracy to overthrow the Government by organizing Bulgarian Army officers into an illegal military organization.

JUST eighteen years ago this week in this Review: Page one contains a treatise on "Chicago: A More Intimate View of Urban Politics," by Charles Edward Merriam, and the reviewer disagrees with the author (who claims a special patriotism for Chicago by the Chicagoan).

BERLIN, June 7 -- Monday, June 2, was a day to be remembered in the history of United States policy toward Germany. It marked the virtual abandonment of the doctrine of decentralization enunciated by former Secretary of State Byrnes at Stuttgart nine months ago and the creation of a central regime for western Germany chosen by, but not responsible to, the Governments of the individual states.

Autograph letters, color plate books, first editions and other literary material, in part the property of Mrs. Dwight Davis of Washington, will be auctioned on Tuesday and Wednesday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Within the 959 square miles comprising the Berkshire Hills of western Massachusetts, the two cities of Pittsfield and North Adams, and some thirty small towns, offer a wide variety of recreation and entertainment.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- President Truman was urged today in a three-volume report by Attorney General Tom Clark to order nationalization of public financed research and development by requiring government ownership of resulting invention under a system of non-exclusive free licensing.

HYDE PARK -- The home and the grave of Franklin D. Roosevelt, high on the Hudson River bluffs here, draw thousands of travelers. They come from near-by cities, but they come, too, from the farthest corners of the world.

TROPHIES and awards for outstanding prints and color slides will be presented at the annual dinner of the Metropolitan Camera Club Council Thursday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The new Lootens Trophy, in memory of J. Ghislain Lootens, popular teacher of photography, will be awarded for the first time.

Serge Koussevitzky, conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, announced yesterday that there would be fourteen instead of twelve concerts at the 1947 Berkshire Festival and that all nine of Beethoven's symphonies would be played in the four-concert Beethoven cycle.

MASSILLON, Ohio, June 7 (AP) -- A killer stole into the third-floor nursery of City Hospital, battered to death the two baby girls he found there and escaped without leaving a clue to his identity or motive, police said today.

THE announcement last week of the engagement of former Secretary of State James F. Byrnes as special counsel for the motion picture industry to fight "encroachments upon the freedom of the screen" is highly auspicious and reassuring, if it means that Mr. Byrnes is going to put starch into the industry to counter recent damaging attacks.

WOODS HOLE, Mass. -- If you consider a noiseless Fourth-of-July a summer attraction, the town of Falmouth should be on your vacation map. Prospective visitors are informed by the police and fire departments that importation of and shooting off of firecrackers will be strictly illegal.

AN orchestral season has to be worked out months in advance, and many of the leading symphonies of the country have announced dates, prices, soloists and the more ambitious works they will perform. There will be a wide reshuffling of conductors and several of the orchestras are lengthening their seasons, but the basic picture will not be altered radically.

BOSTON, June 7 (AP) -- Lefty Warren Spahn pitched his 1947 masterpiece, a three-hitter against the Reds, while chalking up his ninth victory for the Braves, 9-0, tonight before a chilled crowd of 19,536. Lead-off man Tommy Holmes sparked a 12-hit attack for Boston by belting a two-bagger and four singles in five tries agrainst a pair of Cincinnati moundsmen.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Jane 7 -- An engineer's or a scientist's success depends on the accuracy of his appraisal of ideas, data, statistics, experimental results and men, Dr. Donald Keyes, vice president in charge of research and development of the Heyden Chemical Corporation, New York, told the graduating class of Stevens Institute of Technology today.

HYDE PARK -- Men, women, children of all nationalities, of virtually all races, creeds and political faiths, have visited the Franklin D. Roosevelt, Memorial since it was dedicated on April 12, 1946, first anniversary of the President's death.

CHICAGO, June 7 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 500 head (estimated): total, 4,500. Compared with week ago: weights under 240 pounds steady, heavier weights and sows 20 to 50 cents higher.

Two hundred hardy welcomers stood on the rainswept Navy pier just north of Franklin Street yesterday afternoon to greet the Argentine naval training cruiser La Argentina. Including many Argentinians in white naval uniform and a number of women, the spectators cheered as the training vessel was brought alongside the open dock and the ship's band set up the strains of the Argentine national anthem.

SCHENECTADY, June 8 -- More energy must be devoted to keeping pace with the mounting human and social problems incident to progress, particularly those arising out of world relationships, Governor Earl Warren of California told the 104 members of Union College's 152d graduating class today.

MILWAUKEE, June 8 -- The three-day convention of the Young Republican National Federation ended today with an executive committee meeting. Presiding was Ralph E. Becker of Port Chester, N.Y., who was re-elected national chairman yesterday for a two-year term.

MUROC ARMY AIR FIELD, MUROC, Calif., June 6 (Delayed) -- The Douglas "Skystreak," the Navy's stub-winged experimental sub-sonic plane, today completed successfully its third test flight -- its first with the landing gear reiracted.

Readers call us to say they rebel at paying 89 cents a pound for loin lamb chops and 95 cents for veal cutlets and $1.10 for calves' liver. We don't blame them -- in fact, what sensible consumer would? But we haven't, alas, any suggestions as to how you can procure the same cuts at appreciably lower prices.

PATERSON, N.J., June 8 -- Climaxing a campaign to use state housing funds for permanent veterans' homes, instead of for the barracks type of temporary dwellings, Paterson's Board of Finance and Mayor William P. Furrey will receive bids on June 19, for the construction of seven seven-story modern apartments designed to accommodate 392 families.

Dr. George Gaylord SimpSon, curator and chairman of the Department of Geology and Paleontology at the American Museum of Natural History, announced yesterday that a search for 200,000,000year-old fossil remains of early reptiles, possibly including ancestors of the dinosaurs, would highlight the latest paleontological expedition by the museum.

ZURICH, Switzerland, June 8, (London Times dispatch) -- The international conference of Socialist parties, meeting here, rejected today a plea of the German Social Democratic party headed by Dr. Kurt Schumacher for admission to the conference.

CANBERRA, Australia, June 8 -- Important talks on Pacific strategy surrounding the use of Manus Island as a base for the Australian Navy will be held here tomorrow. United States Ambassador Robert Butler, accompanied by the Commander of the United States Pacific Fleet Admiral Louis E. Denfield, will call on Prime Minister Joseph B. Chifley and External Affairs Minister Herbert V. Evatt to discuss the future status of Manus.

CHICAGO, June 8 -- About 4,000 Chicagoans from every walk of life visited flag-bedecked Tribune Tower this evening in a remarkable outpouring of friendship for The Chicago Tribune, which is celebrating its one-hundredth birthday on Tuesday.

With a leading company announcing reductions in quotations in a move to clear its yards for new supplies, lumber prices are down sharply, according to Myron L. Matthews of the Dow Service, who reports, however, that building material supply dealers are not expecting general reductions to contractors on prices for brick, cement, plaster, lime, stone, lath and other mason's items.

ZURICH, Switzerland, June 8 -- Recommendations for concerted international action to solve economic problems resulting from the war and to prevent a recurrence of trade depressions are embodied in fifty-four resolutions passed yesterday at Montreux at the closing session of the eleventh congress of the International Chamber of Commerce.

SUMMIT, N.J., June 8 -- Notwithstanding continuous rain, the Watchung Riding and Driving Club carried out its two-day horse show program here today. When the last event had been decided, the sky began clearing.

GULLANE, Scotland, June 8 (AP) -- Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zaharias, topmost of three American bidders for the British women's golf championship, slept until noon today and "rested" all afternoon in confident preparation for tomorrow's start of a four-day grind to the title.

ST. LOUIS, June 8 -- George McQuinn crashed a double against the club to which the Yankees exiled him ten years ago to save the Yanks the humiliation of a twinedge setback today at the hands of the Browns. The blow fell in the seventh inning of the finale, to propel home two runs that pointed the Yanks to victory, 5 to 4.

CHICAGO, June 8 -- The coarse grains futures markets took the limelight last week on the Board of Trade, while the wheat market worked lower as traders switched their activities to corn and oats. The corn market was the leader, influenced by a combination of exceptionally bad weather that has delayed planting to what is considered a dangerous extent, and of an abrupt tightening of the cash market.

MILWAUKEE, June 8 (AP) -- A pair of relay teams which produced 20 points between them gave Michigan State College its first Central Collegiate Conference track title in two decades last night. The meet was one of the closest in the twenty-two-year history of the Midwestern carnival.

CLEVELAND, June 8 (AP) -- Bob Feller, pride of the Indians, blanked the Athletics, 2 -- 0, on three hits today for his fourth shut-out of the year after the Athletics took the first game 4 to 0. It was Feller's seventh triumph of the season.

Edward C. Maguire, top labor adviser to Mayor O'Dwyer, has submitted his resignation, to become effective Aug. 31, it was learned yesterday. Mr. Maguire, who has served since Oct. 1, 1946, as director of the city's Division of Labor Relations, will resume the private practice of law, specializing in management-labor relations.

CHICAGO, June 8 -- Demand for mahogany, veneers used in the manufacture of furniture has been easing slightly during the last month indicating a return to more normal pre-war season buying characteristics, a large manufacturer revealed today.

The person with a telephone in his automobile now will have to answer for his tastes in radio programs. The Hooper survey organization on Friday completed its first interview with a telephone subscriber traveling about the city in his car.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- Representative Leonard W. Hall of New York, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, said today that the Republican House victory in Washington State showed that the Democratic party "can win neither with nor without its Henry Wallace wing."

The cavernous railway stations in Paris were empty yesterday. The usual Sunday crowds that scurry about in the perpetual twilight of the grands gares, bound for the country in the morning and coming back in the evening with parcels of food, were obliged to stay at home.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 8 -- Representatives of eight nations will meet here tomorrow to begin the actual drafting of an International Bill of Rights, aimed at guaranteeing basic freedoms and protections to all peoples.

Mrs. Benjamin Prager, 85 years old, put the knife to the huge cake. Her 86-year-old husband placed his hand over hers and pressed the knife downward on the rose icing that read: "Congratulations on Your Golden Anniversary." A violin sighed away in the soft strains of "I Love You Truly" and photographers' bulbs flashed.

A suggestion that graduates of Jewish and Christian theological seminaries spend a year in Palestine before becoming full-fledged ministers was made here yesterday by James G. McDonald, who was a member of the Anglo-American Committee of Inquiry on Palestine.

Buyers visited the New York wholesale markets last week in Considerable volume, shopping fall lines selectively but expressing approval for new flare-back styles, according to reports prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

ALBANY, N.Y. June 8 -- (AP) -- The index of prices paid New York farmers for their products dropped three points last month from the April level and was seven points lower than in May, 1946, the State Agriculture Department said today.

Boys and girls across the country have learned about Greek history and art while helping the homeless children of Greece under classroom project described yesterday by the Greek War Relief Association, Inc., 221 West Fiftyseventh Street.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 8 -- With the new elections less than three months away, auguries of a possible split between the Communists and the Socialists over the spoils of their victory over the Smallholders are increasing. An editorial in the Socialist organ Nepszava, referring today to the cooperation between working class parties, emphasized that "cooperation does not mean either party should impose its will on the other.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 8 -- The Brigantine Madalan, once a millionaire's plaything, set sail for the Cape Verde Islands today with 21 passengers. She will make the twenty-to-thirty day trip entirely under sail.

George McIlroy, formerly assistant department manager of kitchen furniture and major appliances at Macy's, New York, "has been appointed to succeed Elmer Fraass as department manager of hardware, paints, garden goods and fireplace accessories.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 8 -- Dr. Petru Groza, the Rumanian Premier, disclosed the reason for the visit of the Rumanian Cabinet delegation here at an official luncheon given for Marshal Tito yesterday. He said: "We desire to create full political, cultural and economic cooperation in order to contribute to the maintenance of peace and to assure for ourselves and for future generations peaceful conditions."

Officers and firemen of the Fire Department who performed acts of heroism during 1946 will receive medals from Mayor O'Dwyer at City Hall ceremonies at 12:30 P. M. tomorrow, it was announced yesterday by Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle.

At the end of last week the President took occasion to rebuke Senator Robert A. Taft for what the latter had said about the Government's foreign lending policy. The Ohio Senator had expressed the opinion that this policy, by increasing the inflation potential in the United States, ran counter to the President's drive for lower prices.

PITTSBURGH, June 8 -- A new post-war peak was reached in steel production last week when the industry was able to raise its rate 1 point to 97.5 per cent of capacity. According to reports in the trade it may not be possible to go much higher because of the scrap and pig iron situation.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I would like to add to the opinions already expressed in the press regarding the published designs for the United Nations project.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- President Truman declined today to give any indication of what action he would take in respect to the tax-reduction bill, or when he would take it. He has until June 16 to make his decision.

BATAVIA, Java, June 8 (Reuters) -- The Indonesian Republican Government's counter-memorandum to the Dutch note suggesting an interim federal government for Indonesia was handed today to the Dutch authorities.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- A renewed bipartisan effort in Congress to increase the statutory minimum, wage from 40 cents to 75 cents an hour in two years was announced today.

Passenger ship plans of Agwilines are snarled in the red tape of Maritime Commission ship sales procedure and it will be at least another year before the company can get its proposed passenger operations under way, it was reported yesterday.

On the basis of current ordertaking, production of women's coats and suits for the fall season will approximate 75 per cent of the dollar volume of last year, according to estimates from trade observers last week.

The public schools must become an increasingly positive force in education for peace and for the preservation of democratic society, John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday in his final annual report.

Only by "a personal, spiritual revolution" will the world be spared from atomic war, the Rev. Thomas J. Malone, assistant to the superior general of the Catholic Foreign Mission Society at Maryknoll, N.Y., declared yesterday morning.

The local art season promises comparatively little activity in the galleries this week, so far as openings are concerned. Of signal importance, however, is the double Stieglitz exhibition, which opens to the public on Wednesday at the Museum' of Modern Art.

LONDON, June 8 -- Presumptive acceptance by India of the British plan for independence of that country was an excellent tonic last week for the stock markets here. Almost all classes of securities benefited in greater or less degree, although the threatened "dollar crisis" continues to overshadow certain important groups.

LANDOVER, Md., June 8 (U.P.) -- Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago, playing the same scintillating golf in the stretch that won the National Open for him last year, scored his first major victory since then today by taking first prize in the $10,000 National Capital open with a 72-hole card of 269.

Degrees Honoris Causa Conferring honorary degrees is a prized -- and sometimes profitable -- privilege of our institutions of higher learning. The Commencement lists are witness that in the exercise of this privilege the honors often are even.

Nine graduating students of the rabbinical school of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America were ordained yesterday afternoon is "rabbis, teachers and preachers in Israel" at commencement exercises. Scheduled to take place in the quadrangle, the ceremony because of bad weather was held in the Unterberg Auditorium of the building, at Broadway and 122d Street.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 8 -- The American Council for Judaism, Inc., submitted a memorandum to the United Nations today asserting that establishment of a Jewish state in Palestine would be harmful to Jews throughout the world and would endanger peace and security in the Holy Land.

DETROIT, June 8 (AP) -- Producing his best performance of the season to the intense satisfaction of a throng of 55,941 fans, Hal Newhouser pitched four-hit shutout ball and drove in Detroit's first two runs as the Tigers blanked the Red Sox today 5 to 0.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- Several million taxpayers facing a quarterly deadline on income-tax payments have an immediate stake in speedy action by President Truman on the tax reduction bill.

WERNERSVILLE, Pa., June 8 -- Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, former commander of the American Occupation Forces in Europe, warned today in a prepared address read at the final session of the United Jewish Appeal Emergency Conference against a possible uprising of the displaced persons overseas unless they receive immediate and proper help.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 8 -- John R. (Jack) Lyons, Garden City Golf Club star who has ambitions to become a top-notch tournament player, added another feather -- albeit a droopy one -- to his cap today. He and his host, George Jenkins, came out on top in the Hempstead Golf Club annual member-guest invitation tournament.

Ferdinand C. Smith, national secretary of the National Maritime Union, CIO, charged yesterday that some shipowners were violating the law by barring aliens from service in unlicensed posts on United States merchant vessels.

After her husband, Horace S. Marshall, 36-year-old lawyer, had plunged to his death from the terrace of their penthouse apartment at 302 West Twelfth Street, at 6:03 o'clock last night, Mrs. Amelie Marshall, 32 and also a lawyer, took an elevator down eighteen floors and saw the body lying in a rear courtyard.

BERLIN, June 8 (AP) -- The two Soviet-controlled newspapers that are the main Communist voices in Germany lashed out today at the German officials heading the Western zones for having refused to discuss political unity of Germany at last week's Munich conference.

For the second time rain caused the postponement of the soccer match between the touring Hapoel team of Palestine and the American Soccer League All-Stars, which was to have been played at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday.

ROME, June 8 -- In a long and strongly worded manifesto published this morning the Italian Communist party declared war on Premier Alcide de Gasperi's fourth Government. The Communists called upon all left-wing parties to unite in an effort to overthrow the new Cabinet, which goes before the Constituent Assembly tomorrow for the first time, without delay.
Children sat on the altar rail and sang youthful songs yesterday at the morning service in the Village Presbyterian Church, 143 West Thirteenth Street.

There was a degree of stability last week in the two foreign exchanges which recently had an erratic price movement -- the Canadian free dollar and the Swiss free franc showed improvement, although not by any substantial margin. What appeared significant about the alteration was that there was a cut-back in the offerings, resulting in a firm undertone.

MILWAUKEE, June 8 -- Mayor John L. Bohn joined other community leaders today in defining the main problem brought about by Negro migration here as housing. They agreed that employment was still at a high peak.

Asserting that the aim of the Taft-Hartley labor bill was to put American workers in "an economic concentration camp," Louis Hollander, state president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, declared last night that organized labor was "amazed and shocked" at the support given the measure by Senator Irving M. Ives.

GENOA, Italy, June 8 (AP) -- A man who described himself as a member of the Stern band, Palestine underground organization, said today that he had mailed twenty-four "letter bombs" to prominent Britons. He added that he had posted the letters, designed to explode when opened, at the central postoffice in Turin.

Shortages of all kinds of fuel can be expected next winter, coal and oil industry spokesmen said yesterday. They urged householders to assure their own comfort and aid the over-all supply by laying in stocks now.

LONDON, June 8 (U.P.) -- The International Amateur Athletic Federation will consider one of the most controversial problems that has come up in the post-war period when it meets tomorrow to make a decision, on "broken time" payments for athletes involved in international competition.

It's now official for John Gielgud and his "Love for Love" company of British actors to say good-bye June 28 at the Royale, where William Congreve's classic will have been seen for five weeks. On June 30 the "troupe will begin a three-week Canadian tour in "Love" before returning to England in August.
PARIS, June 8 -- The French railway strike has become practically complete and nation-wide tonight at the end of its third day.

A national $13,000,000 blanketdisposal program in which the New York office is participating is included among the surplus sales activities of the War Assets Administration starting this week, it was announced over the weekend by Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director.

CHICAGO, June 8 (U.P.) -- The White Sox and the Senators battled through seventeen scoreless innings today and finally reached a decision in the eighteenth, the Senators winning, 1-0. This matched the all-time record for 1-0 endurance contests.

A study of Lincoln's adherence to his political principles in the face of powerful reaction has been written by James G. Randall, entitled "Lincoln, The Liberal Statesman." This is a separate study from Dr. Randall's four-volume series.

OLYMPIA, Wash., June 8 -- A Republican who upheld the Truman foreign policy defeated a "progres-sive Democrat" backed by Henry A. Wallace for the House seat in Washington State's third district yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- With the number of military prisoners cut by more than 68 per cent since October, 1945, the War Department Advisory Board on Clemency ending a task that took almost two years, expressed approval today that no general amnesty was granted when the war ended.

THE average baseball fan seems to grow up with the impression that umpires are loathsome creatures who should be sprayed regularly with DDT, and the expression "Kill the umpire!" has become accepted as a genteel household term. But most of the arbiters in the major leagues are high-class gentlemen of irreproachable probity and talent who handle a tough assignment well.

PITTSBURGH, June 8 -- Strikes have started in the southwestern Pennsylvania soft coal fields in protest against the Taft-Hartley labor bill, which is to reach President Truman's desk tomorrow. More than 6,600 miners have participated thus far.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 8-- "Charity credits" to countries with "feeble money" will henceforth be ruled out as part of a general campaign to protect the Swedish crown and preserve Sweden's rapidly dwindling foreign exchange assets, it was stated in financial circles here today.
PARIS, June 8 -- The first efforts to rescue American and British travelers stranded in France by the railway strike were put in operation today.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., June 8--Dedicated to better employer-employe relations, the twelfth In-stitute on Industrial Relations of the National Association of Manu-facturers will open a five-day ses-sion tomorrow at Saranac Inn.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 8 -- Legislation to create a national heart disease institute within the United States Public Health Service was approved unanimously here today by the board of directors of the American Heart Association, at the close of the association's annual meeting. A bill to establish such an institute will be introduced n Congress by Representative facob K. Javits of New York.

CHICAGO, June 8 (AP) -- Ray "Cracker" Schalk, who led American League catchers in fielding eight times during his 1,721 games with the Chicago White Sox from 1913 through 1926, today nominated Aaron Robinson of the Yankees and Walker Cooper of the Giants as his choice of starting Catchers for the fourteenth AllStar baseball game at Wrigley Field, July 8.

"The Baby Corner," designed to offer a new advertising approach to the baby market, estimated at $27,OQO,000 as the cost of bringing up American children to the age of five years, will be launched shortly in sixty-four Sunday newspapers in fifty-eight cities, it was announced over the week-end.
A growing concern throughout the country over the increasingly complicated transportation problem is reported by the National Foreign Trade Council.

The events now taking place in Europe follow such uniform and familiar patterns that their inspiration, direction and purpose become unmistakable. As happened so often during the recent past, from the Russian-German pact which sparked the second World War, to the Russian annexation or domination of eastern Europe, Russia is again engaged in trying to create a series of accomplished facts behind her supposed allies' backs.
LONDON, June 8 (U.P.) -- The American housewife, despite the recent upswing in prices, still gets more for her dollar than her British counterpart.

The House of Representatives has cut 28.7 per cent out of the Agriculture Department's budget and has slashed Interior Department requests for reclamation, irrigation and waterand-power projects by about 60 per cent. In his Kansas City speech Saturday evening President Truman made an effective plea for the restoration of some of these cuts.

Pajama-clad and armed only with a golf club, the Rev. Dr. Alvin E. Magary, pastor of the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church of Brooklyn, early yesterday morning captured a burglar who had invaded his home at 122 Cambridge Place, Brooklyn.
As rain washed out the final pair of games with the Cardinals at the Polo Grounds yesterday the Giants renewed their efforts to swing another deal that would further strengthen their pitching staff.

The Chemical Bank Trust Company has been appointed agent for the exchange of 3 per cent refunding fifty-year gold bonds, due in 1949, of the Chicago and Alton Railroad and also for the 6 per cent guaranteed preferred and common stock of the Kansas City, St. Louis and Chicago Railroad Company under the plan of reorganization.

Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver, president of the Zionist Organization of America and head of the American Department of the Jewish Agency, criticized the United States Government yesterday for failure to take a stronger stand on the Palestine problem.

A first mortgage loan of $82,000 for ten years at 4 1/2 per cent was obtained by the Naillil Realty Corp. on the apartment houses at 308-10 Lexington Ave through Hardy, Braunels Naumann, Inc. brokers.

JERUSALEM, June 8 -- President Truman was asked tonight by Irgun Zvai Leumi, undeground organization, to raise his voice against Britain's "bloody regime" in Palestine "instead of encouraging it by one-sided appeals and by identification with its policy."

LARCHMONT, N,Y., June 8 -- Seldom has a championship event of the Yacht Racing Association on Long Island Sound been called off because of rough going, but that scheduled today at the Larchmont Club was.
PHILADELPHIA, June 8 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates and the Philadelphia Phillies divided a double-header here today before 18,551 fans.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Walter Morrow, president of the American Retail Federation, representing more than 500,000 retail establishments throughout the nation, addressed a letter to President Truman on behalf of the Federation today urging him to sign H.R. 1, the tax reduction bill.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., June 8 (U.P.) -- Miss Pauline Betz defeated Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Cooke today, 6 -- 2, 9 -- 7, and won a $1,000 purse.

If we are to establish a National Science Foundation which is to pay for research under a contract, some patent policy must be laid down. This Attorney General Clark has done in his report to the President, made public Saturday. No one will take issue with the broad principle there enunciated that if patents flow out of research paid for by the Government they should belong to the nation.

First prize in the national retail newspaper advertising contest conducted from April 23 to May 29 by the Men's Fashion Guild of New York has been awarded to J.L. Kinney, advertising manager of the B.R. Baker Company, Cleveland.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 8 (AP) -- The Iranian Government said today that two Iranian officers of its gendarmerie would leave soon for the United States to purchase $5,000,000 worth of "army equipment, clothes and boots" for the gendarmerie.

PITTSBURGH, June 8 -- The A. W. Mellon educational and charitable trust has distributed more than $78,000,000 during the first sixteen years of its existence, a report of the trustees disclosed today.
The annual report of Northeast Airlines, Inc., mailed to stockholders yesterday, disclosed an income of $190,707 for 1946 after taxes and all charges, equal to 38 cents a share.

New legislation to end the "black market" in babies, in which lawyer - doctor combinations are said to get from $1,500 to $2,500 for an infant, will be introduced in the Legislature this winter, Assemblyman Samuel Rabin of Queens said yesterday.

A third World War can be avoided if the people of the world are willing to devote their inherent resources toward keeping the peace rather than using them to foment physical conflict, The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, minister of Christ Church, Methodist, said at New York University Baccalaureate services yesterday in the Gould Memorial Chapel, University Heights.

HICKSVILLE, L.I., June 8 -- Walter Tomsen of Flushing, L.I., with a score of 1,992 -- 120x's won the Metropolitan district smallbore rifle-shooting tournament today. The event was sponsored by the Long Island Rifle and Pistol Association and was concluded today at the Gunners' Club.

DETROIT, June 8 (UP) -- A mass meeting of the 65,000 production workers at the Ford Motor Company's River Rouge plant voted today to take a strike ballot to support wage and contract demands presented by the CIO United Automobile Workers.

Except for the July contract, which moved steadily higher, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated irregularly last week. The near-by July option registered a net advance of, 107 points during the week, while other months ended mixed, 4 points lower to 25 points higher than the preceding week.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, said today that Government agencies were using "the most violent pressure campaign have seen in fourteen years" to prevent cuts in Federal spending.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to 549,996,403,447. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 8 -- E.W. Hare and Sumner Waters, Garden City Golf Club, were one under par with 35 -- 36, 71, despite the continual rain to lead the way on opening day of qualifying for the Cherry Valley invitation memberguest tournament here today.
LONDON, June 8 -- Britain's outspoken Attorney General Sir Hartley Shawcross denounced today the women who yesterday and Friday staged protest here about the hardships of life.

Five plays and two musical revues have been added to the roster of shows that will receive try-outs at summer theatres during the forthcoming season. One playhouse, the Red Barn, Westboro, Mass., will offer two of them, "My Fair Lady," by Otis Bigelow, and "An Expensive Wench," by Zoe Schiller, with Vega Keane taking the leading role in both.

KANSAS CITY, June 8 -- An immediate exchange of 50,000 students and teachers between this country and the rest of the world, to be sponsored by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, was proposed here today by Prof. Robert Beck of the University of Kansas City.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 8 -- Warner Brothers has paid $250,000 for the screen rights to "The Patriots," Sidney Kingsley's play which won the New York Critics Circle award for the 1942-43 season, the studio has announced. Bretagne Windust, who recently joined Warners under a term contract, will make his debut as a film director on the screen version of the play, and Jerry Wald will produce the picture.

LONDON, June 8 -- Hundreds of Britons who had planned continental holidays wandered unhappily around Victoria Station here today, wondering what to do next. The strike on the French railways has had the effect of ruining longplanned trips for many British families.

If Henry Wallace hadn't campaigned for one of the candidates an off-year Congressional election in Washington might have attracted little national attention. Because he did, however, appraising eyes are turned on Washington's Third District where Russell V. Mack, a Republican publisher, has just nosed out Charles R. Savage.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with interest the letter on your editorial page of May 18 by Max J. Rubin, with reference to compulsory arbitration. As an attorney, I saw the possibilities of and the need for arbitration in commercial disputes, more than twenty-five years ago, following which I spent considerable time in advocating the cause, organizing arbitration tribunals, serving as arbitrator, etc.

TOKYO, June 8 -- Changes in the purge system intended to remove at least some of its most obvious unfairnesses have been announced, by the Katayama Cabinet. In the future, if the plans are approved by Brig.Gen. Courtney Whitney's Government Section at Headquarters, those accused, when appealing, will be permitted to know the charges against them and may appear before a re-examining committee with attorneys to plead their cases.

The problem of Displaced Persons in Europe has marked time for many months. The opportunities for solving it were never greater in a world which will surely quicken to courageous example. That example can -- indeed, should -- be set by the United States in two fields.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Consumers are so disturbed about present high prices for some foods, and have been so hopeful of materially lower prices after this summer's harvests, that some inaccuracies in your editorial of June 4 should be corrected.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 8 -- Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company; Carroll L. Wilson, general manager of the Atomic Energy Commission, and Admiral Raymond A. Spruance, president of the Naval War College, were recipients of honorary degrees at the 157th commencement ceremonies of Williams College today.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- With the labor and tax-reduction bills at the White House for President Truman's consideration, Congress will turn to other fields of legislation this week, including a proposed exemption of railroads from anti-trust laws, the State Department's foreign broadcasts, and appropriations.

An appeal for financial aid for the "very poor" diocese of El Paso was made yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral, where it was announced that collections at all masses would be turned over to the support of Roman Catholic churches in the Texas city.

Normal operations were reported yesterday by the Board of Transportation on all branches the city transit system as members of the Transport Workers Union prepared to submit wage demands amounting to $25,000,000 to the board this morning.

GENEVA, N.Y., June 8 -- The Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Bishop of New York, told the graduating classes of Hobart and William Smith Colleges in a baccalaureate sermon in the historic Trinity Church here tonight that bitter experience must make it clear that we cannot rely upon treaties or covenants or compacts or leagues, however nobly conceived, to build a new and better world.

PEIPING, China, June 8 (AP) -- Chinese Government officials were reported to be quitting Mukden today in fear of an imminent Communist assault, and an unconfirmed dispatch said that Government troops had pulled out of Antung, important railway city on the Korean frontier.

THE DALLES, Ore., June 8 (AP) -- One hundred dazed farm workers searched today for missing relatives and personal belongings in the wake of flash floods that took one life, injured four persons, left at least two others unaccounted for and devastated fruit crops in Oregon and Washington.

KANSAS CITY, June 8 (AP) -- Frank Parker of Los Angeles, third ranking United States Amateur, turned back Gardnar Mulloy, Coral Gables, Fla., in straight sets to win the men's singles title in the Heart of America tennis tournament today.

GLASGOW, June 8 (AP) -- Promoter Charles Black tonight announced the postponement of the scheduled 15-round title fight Wednesday between the world flyweight champion, Jackie Paterson of Glasgow, and challenger Dado Marino of Honolulu.

HANNIBAL, Mo., June 8 -- The swollen Mississippi River and its Iowa tributary, the Des Moines River, presented a major picture of death and destruction today as one town was completely inundated and communities from Ottumwa, Iowa, to Louisiana, Mo., were partially submerged.

Susie, one of the most photographed and best-adjusted boarders at the Bear Mountain Trailside Museums, is now an outcast. The way John Orth, director of the museums, told the story yesterday it looked as though Susie was the victim of a housing problem.

SEATTLE, June 8 (U.P.) -- Coach Al Ulbrickson today said the University of Washington varsity and junior varsity crews would entrain tomorrow for Madison, Wis., and the races with the Wisconsin Badgers on Lake Mendota next Saturday.

Home seekers who have beer looking with longing at the nearly completed buildings at Stuyvesant Town will have their first chance this morning to see what the interior of one of the apartments will look like. An exact copy of a four-room suite has been built on the fourth floor of Hearn's from plans furnished by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, which is erecting the development.
MOSCOW, June 8 (AP) -- Pravda declared today that Right-Wing Socialists, hostile to Russia and communism, had gained control of the Governments of Britain, France, Belgium, Norway and Austria.

PARIS, June 8 -- In anticipation of the economic annexation of the Saar, which the United States and Britain have approved, the French have decided to reduce its area by redrawing the new frontiers they established in December, which the Western powers did not approve.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, June 8--The arrest of Nikola Petkov, the Opposition Agrarian leader, is a domestic matter, Premier Georgi Dimitrov told United States and British political representatives who sought information yesterday about the arrest.

LONDON, June 8 -- From the political viewpoint, the expected acceptance of the Government' plan for the partition of India is regarded as a distinct triumph for the Government, but how it will work out in terms of economics and finance has most persons here guessing.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (U.P.) -- Government figures showed tonight that anti-union sentiment of Southern workers was twice as great as among wage-earners in the North and West.

The congregation of St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church welcomed yesterday the congregation of the Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator, who will occupy the St. Peter's parish house, 336 West Twentieth Street, on July 1.
MADRID, June 8 -- Senora Eva Peron arrived at Barajas airport here tonight in a special plane, which was escorted over the field by forty - one Spanish fighter planes.

MANILA, June 8 -- The joint Philippine-American Finance Commission's report to President Truman and to President Manuer A. Roxas, after a six months' thorough investigation of Philippine economic prospects and budgetary methods, recommends a set of financial and tax reforms that will be bitter medicine for the Filipinos to swallow.

Eliminating the clement of skill and placing the emphasis on agility, strength and endurance, physical examinations for Police Department candidates began yesterday with 100 competing in newly devised tests.

Public offering of a new issue of $7,500,000 of Class B cumulative preferred stock of the Dayton Power and Light Company will be undertaken here today by a syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co. and W.E. Hutton Co.

GULLANE, Scotland, June 9 (AP) -- All three American seekers of the British women's amateur golf title -- Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zahaias of Denver, Miss Helen Sigel of Philadelphia and Miss Ruth Woodward of Fall River, Mass. -- moved into the third round today with golf that almost any man would envy.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- So firmly implanted in the policies of both major parties are nearly all of the objectives stated by the President at Kansas City Saturday that very little dissension remains. The New Deal doctrine of a powerful central government that would tax and spend heavily for certain social-economic projects is now strongly opposed by only a few politicians and political philosophers in both parties.

Wallace K. Harrison, director of planning for the United Nations, gave a glimpse of the United Nations home of the future last night in addressing the American Society of Landscape Architects at a dinner at the Hotel Biltmore.

DETROIT, June 9 (AP) -- Rattling thirteen hits off four pitchers -- half the Tiger mound staff -- the Athletics clubbed Detroit's American League leaders, 11 to 3, today to move into a three-way tie with Boston and Cleveland for third place.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- Increased hedge pressure against Southeast wheat purchases was mainly responsible for a weak market in wheat today, with considerable long liquidation being evident as prices declined on the Board of Trade here.

LOS ANGELES, June 9 -- William M. Jeffers, veteran official of the Union Pacific Railroad, today linked Henry Wallace and Robert R. Young, Chesapeake Ohio head, as "disturbing influences in this country, planting distrust and undermining confidence among the uninformed."

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UP) -- Spruille Braden, former Assistant Secretary of State, believes that Communists in Latin America are a "greater peril" than were the Nazi fifth columnists, the House Appropriations Committee reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- President Truman nominated Norman Armour to be Assistant Secretary of State today. If confirmed by the Senate Mr. Armour will fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Spruille Braden.
BUDAPEST, June 9 (AP) -- A reliable American informant said today that Hungarian Communists had threatened to banish American executives of the HungarianAmerican oil company, Maort.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The United States Education Mission to Germany, in its official report, has called attention to "the significance of the educational program in Germany, not only for the Germans but for all the world." The mission emphasizes in particular "that political democracy can be developed to the full only by those who have the basic necessities of life."

JERUSALEM, June 9 -- Clad only in bathing suits, two British policemen were kidnapped from a swimming pool near Tel Aviv this afternoon by a terrorist band. At midnight their fate was still not known to the British. The abductions came only a week before the United Nations Committee of Inquiry on Palestine was scheduled to open its hearings here.

NEW DELHI, India, June 9 -- Under the urging of its president, Mohammed Ali Jinnah, the Moslem League Council in a closed meeting tonight accepted the British Government's proposal for a truncated Pakistan Dominion, which would operate alongside the Dominion of Hindustan for an interim period.

The twice-postponed battle between the Hapoel eleven of Palestine and the American Soccer League All-Stars will be staged tonight at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island. The match is set to begin at 8:30 o'clock.
Mayor O'Dwyer offered yesterday a new formula for solution of his transit troubles, but after hearing it and endorsing it even a group of his warmest supporters doubted that he ever would use it.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today that Federal District Judge Michael L. Igoe had no right to give himself power to appoint three of five reorganization managers for the Chicago. Rock Island Pacific Railroad.

GENEVA, N. Y., June 9 -- Edward P. Curtis, former chief of staff of the United State Strategic Air Forces in Europe and now vice president of the Eastman Kodak Company, declared here today that American relations with the Soviet Union had been emphasized more than they deserve, because "Russia isn't that strong and not that good."

The debris of shattered Dodger winning streaks was strewn all over Ebbets Field last night after 32,864 alternately hopeful and despairing fans finally had seen the Cincinnati Reds beat the Brooks, 9 -- 6. It was a slam-bang contest under the lights which dropped the Dodgers into second place, half a game behind the Giants.

ST. LOUIS, June 9 (UP) -- Ellis Kinder, 32-year-old Browns' sophomore pitcher, shaded the venerable Bobo Newsom in a brilliant hurling duel tonight and the Browns beat the Washington Senators, 1 to 0.

Managers of the radio stations in the metropolitan area expressed opposition yesterday to a "Radio Council of Greater New York" if they had to participate formally in its administration or financing. Meeting informally at the Hotel Roosevelt, the officials were of the opinion that a council for listeners preferably should be entirely free of any connection with the broadcasting industry as such.

Preparations by Great Britain to dominate transatlantic air travel with luxury planes were disclosed here yesterday while at the same time Belgium's national airline, Sabena, opening a New York-toBrussels service, described its operations as the most profitable on the European continent.

DETROIT, June 9 -- Accused of committing sabotage and conducting a slow-down on six assembly lines, 1,100 employes were sent home today by the Ford Motor Company as the threat of major strikes grew in the automotive industry.

More than 800 locker and frozen food plant operators and members of the National Frozen Food Locker Association were warned yesterday against over - expansion The warning was sounded by Ray Farquhar, executive secretary of the Frozen Food Locker Institute, Inc., at opening sessions of a three-day regional convention and exposition at the Hotel New Yorker.

Cleverly handled by Teddy Atkinson, Clover Lea stepped down to a convincing victory in the Mignonette, the Class C race that served as the feature attraction on the card at the Aqueduct course yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: What the so-called capitalists and financial wizards overlooked in bygone days was that there was a public in existence who suffered and paid the price for their selfishness and greed. The public ultimately made its voice heard and the Government stepped in and established laws and legislation to curb and control monopolies, cut wildcat stock exchange gambling and the selling of worthless securities, etc.

TRENTON, N.J., June 9 -- The eighty-one delegates to the New Jersey Constitutional Convention, the first since 1844, received by mail today complete advice on registration and accommodations at the Rutgers University gymnasium, New Brunswick, for their summer deliberations.

PARIS, June 9 -- Both sides began efforts today to settle the railway strike. The executive committee of the General Confederation of Labor persuaded the Railway Federation's leaders to ask Premier Paul Ramadier to receive them and he agreed to do so tomorrow, although he had said he would resume negotiations only when the strike had been called off.

Additional information on the total short position in all listed stocks this month to cover the clearance date, June 17, has been requested of member firms, the New York Stock Exchange revealed yesterday. In addition to the regular short data regularly requested, the special report must include the following:

VIENNA, June 9 (U.P.) -- Hungarian Deputy Premier Arpad Szakasits, who passed through Vienna today on his way to Zurich, Switzerland, for a Socialist conference, defended the course of his Government in ousting Premier Nagy.

Austrian industries will be able to make a rapid recovery as soon as political conditions and the serious shortage of food for industrial workers are rectified, Dr. John Heller, president, Heller Candy Company, reported yesterday, following his return from a visit to the company's branch plant in Austria.

LONDON, June 9 -- Mechanism for the transfer of power in India has now been worked out in broad outline, it was announced here today. No time is being lost, as the Moslem League Council lready today accepted the British plan and the Congress party's All-India Committee is certain to follow suit when it meets on Saturday.

Demands by the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, for a new agreement providing increased wages and overtime and various lesser concessions were rejected yesterday by a committee for the steamship companies and agents on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts.

WASHINGTON -- June 9 -- Eleven parties and interveners before the Interstate Commerce Commission today asked the entire commission to rehear the case in which, by a five to four vote, the ICC approved acquisition of control of the reorganized Florida East Coast Railway Company by the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company, through an exchange of $4,125,000 in cash and $36,375,000 of ACL securities.

BASEBALL often has been accused of being a hard-hearted business which is completely lacking in sentiment. Perhaps there is more truth to the charge than the magnates like to admit. Occasionally, though, there is such a wide streak of unabashed sentiment put on display that it leaves a warm glow in its wake.

WASHINGTON, June 9 --The House was told today by Chairman Harold Knutson of the Ways and Means Committee that Republicans of that committee supported the $6,000,000,000 corporate tax reduction legislation in 1945 "with the understanding" that relief to individual taxpayers would be given in 1946. He inferred that "the understanding" stemmed from President Truman.

Amid strong TWU arguments yesterday before the Board of Transportation for higher wages and other changes that would push our present transit deficit past the $100,000,000 mark a question was suddenly asked by one of the Board officials sitting in on the hearing.
Reversing their tactics suddenly, leaders of the Transport Workers Union moved yesterday to call off the slowdown that has plagued the city transit system intermittently for the last two weeks.

UNITED STATES ORDNANCE TEST STATION, INYOKERN, Calif., June 7 (Delayed) -- "Big Dick," "Tiny Tim" and a whole family of new rockets and guided missiles are being developed and tested at this $100,000,000 naval establishment in the heart of the California desert.
NOTTINGHAM, June 9 (Reuters) -- South Africa beat its previous highest test innings by three runs today in the second day's play of cricket against England.

CLEVELAND, June 9 - The American Red Cross, which collected more than 13,000,000 pints of blood for the Army and Navy during the war, highlighted the opening of its twenty-second national convention today by announcing a program to supply blood and its derivatives to the country without charge.

Approximately 300 buyers attended the corset and brassiere show which opened yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker under the auspices of the Corset and Brassiere Exhibitors Guild. Indications were clear that price lines, quality and merchandising efforts have been adjusted to overcome consumer resistance in a line of apparel which was among the first to experience the change-over to the buyers' market.

NEWARK, N.J., June 9 -- Henry A. Wallace declared here tonight that the United States had become the center of world reaction and was so recognized by the rank and file of the people in nearly every country of the world.

TOKYO, June 9 -- The new Japanese Government headed by the Socialist Premier, Tetsu Katayama, today approved a program of sweeping state controls designed to rebuild Japan's tottering national economy.

STONINGTON ISLAND, Palmer Land, Antarctica, June 9 -- This expedition's geophysical research program, headed by Andrew Thompson, is making headway at the base here. The program involves long-term observations of tidal movements, terrestrial magnetism, seismology and seawater salinity.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- A lot of farmers who incurred income tax liability but paid no taxes during the war years will wish they had if a recent Treasury Department sampling of several Midwestern counties proves correctly to reflect widespread evasion by farmers.

PARIS, June 9 -- The economic union of the Saar with France moved further toward completion today with two announcements by the Foreign Office. Both measures look to American and British approval of the economic union plan.
CHICAGO, June 9 -- Giving a new twist to a familiar routine, the Yankees bowed to the White Sox today.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (U.P.) -- William C. Bullitt, former ambassador to Russia and France, said tonight that only American air superiority and possession of the atomic bomb prevented Joseph Stalin, Soviet Premier, "from ordering the Red Army to occupy all Europe."

BOSTON, June 9 (AP) -- Behind the one-hit pitching of Charlie (Red) Barrett the Braves tonight blanked the Cubs, 1 -- 0, to move into third place in the National League, a full game ahead of the Chicagoans.

PITTSBURGH, June 9 -- A mushrooming strike by more than 11,000 western Pennsylvania soft-coal miners in protest over the TaftHartley labor bill cut off today thousands of tons of coal destined for four steel companies.

John D. Corrigan, former Navy commander, his business associate, Robert H. Wells, and their industrial engineering firm of Corrigan, Osburne Wells, Inc., were found guilty yesterday afternoon by a Federal court jury of a conspiracy to deprive the Government of Corrigan's honest services as a Navy inspector.

WASHINGTON. June 9 (AP) -- The Government's program to speed the construction of houses was branded a failure today by the House Appropriations Committee, which called for the Office of the Housing Expediter, under Frank R. Creedon, to cease functioning.
The American Federation of Labor put forward yesterday a program for world labor action to bring about economic recovery and lasting peace.

An international conference of Socialist parties meeting in Zurich has voted unanimously to appoint a commission headed by the French party to study the possibility and presumably advisability of reviving the Socialist International. This is the second of the so-called Internationals.

BERLIN, June 9 -- Under instructions from the American and British Military Governments, German officials are working out details for the revival of a customs organization for the combined area. The implementation of the program is expected to begin by the end of next week.

The Presbytery of New York voted yesterday to support the recent action of the general assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America at Grand Rapids, Mich., in calling for a doubling of gifts, to missions and benevolences.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 9 -- Plans for the rapid mobilization of our medical forces, both civilian and military, for defense against possible attacks with atomic bombs and bacteriological agents were discussed here today at the opening of the annual meeting of the house of delegates of the American Medical Association.

LOUISIANA, Mo., June 9 -- The Mississippi River rolled on in flood stage today, inundating more thousands of rich farmlands and small towns in Missouri and Illinois, while river men predicted nearrecord crests that may cause damages to run into the millions of dollars.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 9 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, United States representative, called upon members of the drafting committee of the United Nations Commission of Human Rights today to draft an international bill of rights that would set out the privileges and freedoms that must be recognized by all nations.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The late Mgsr. John A. Ryan, for many years Professor of Moral Theology at the Catholic University in Washington, was and remains recognized as one of the great pioneer sociologists and social scientists that this country has produced.

During the war, while "boys" were in the armed forces, State and Federal agencies crowded each other to get publicity on what they were going to do to insure the returned veteran of good hunting and fishing.

VIENNA, June 9 -- The Austrian Communist leader, Ernst Fischer, announced tonight that Chancellor Leopold Figl had stated to him at an especially arranged conference that he was ready to resign as Chancellor.

The fate of the project to send Arthur Miller's prize-winning play, "All My Sons," to compete at Prague's World Youth Festival this summer will be determined today. Representatives of the American troupe, already organized, will make an appeal for funds at a special meeting to be held this afternoon at the Hotel Astor to which prominent theatrical business men have been invited.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 9 -- Four hundred residents of communities in southern Nassau County jammed the Board of Supervisors room here today to oppose establishment of a sewage disposal plant in Bay Park, on Hewlett Bay.

Without the intervention of the United Nations Greece would be under Communist control, Mark F. Ethridge, United States representative on the United Nations Balkan Investigating Commission, declared yesterday after returning from a four-month mission to the Balkans.

LONDON, June 9 -- With accumulated orders on the small side, stock markets here today were quiet. British Government stocks showed losses of one-sixteenth to one-quarter and other sections turned dull.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Fifty leaders in the farm loan field adopted in closed conferences today a general resolution designed to discourage further inflation in farm real estate.

President Truman could not have found a man better tailored to the job of Assistant Secretary of State than Norman Armour, long-time career diplomat, former Minister to Canada, former Ambassador to Argentina and Spain, former State Department Director, Office of Latin-American Affairs, courteous gentleman, stanch American.

LONDON, June 9 (AP) -- Two decrees promulgated today by the Supreme Soviet provide punishments for the disclosure by any Russian of Soviet state secrets -- military, scientific, economic or political, the Moscow radio reported tonight.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 9 -- The United States representative on the Allied Control Commission for Hungary received today a negative reply to his request that the Russian occupation authority furnish a copy of the document implicating former Premier Ferenc Nagy in an alleged conspiracy against the Hungarian republic.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia opened a fight against the Bulwinkle railroad bill on the Senate floor today, declaring that it "clearly and plainly eliminates the anti-trust laws so far as the railroads are concerned."

A resolution urging the curbing of the Government's power to export meat items in short supply was passed yesterday by the New York State Association of Retail Meat Dealers at their fifty-fourth annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- President Truman left by special train tonight to pay a state visit to the Governor General of Canada, Viscount Alexander of Tunis. He was accompanied by Mrs. Truman and their daughter Margaret.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 9 -- The Jewish Agency for Palestine today criticized Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, for circulating a British appeal requesting that all member countries discourage "illegal immigration" into the Holy Land.

Little Willie Turnesa, young Westchester golf star, came home to a tumultuous welcome yesterday. He carried with him the highly prized British amateur championship trophy which he won at Carnoustie, Scotland, last month.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- A spokesman for Secretary of War Patterson and Secretary of the Navy Forrestal told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today they believe the Anglo-American petroleum agreement is "essential to our national defense."

Traveling under an assumed name, Stephen Hero, former sonin-law of Jose Iturbi, the pianist, arrived here yesterday by plane from California with his two daughters. He said he had taken them from the Iturbi home in Beverly Hills, Calif., because they were "not happy" there.

AMSTERDAM, June 9 (Aneta) -- Prices were irregular in quiet trading on the Stock Exchange. Phillips moved sharply higher on rumors of a forthcoming capital increase, while Netherlands Indies Handlebank advanced on reports of a possible merger with another institution specializing in Indies banking.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9 (AP) -- A single by Del Ennis drove in Emil Verban in the fifteenth inning to give the Phillies a 2-to-1 victory over the Cardinals in the second game of a twin bill that saw the Cards take the opener, 4 to 2.

Glancing Through the Paper Six and a half million theatregoers over a period of seven and a half years have paid their money to see "Life With Father." Has it been nostalgia, which is the explanation commonly advanced ?

MADRID, June 9 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco's lifetime tenure as dictator and right to pick the King of Spain will be submitted Sunday, July 6, to a referendum. Many thousands of his opponents will be disqualified from voting.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 9 -- A special meeting of the Cabinet will be called soon after the return from Belgrade of Premier Petru Grozu and his delegation of Government leaders to consider a memorandum submitted to the Government by George Tatarescu, Vice Premier and Foreign Minister, it was learned today.

PRETORIA, South Africa, June 9 -- The prices of meat, jams, jellies and cereals grouped in nine categories were increased today throughout South Africa by governmental order. Since Jan. 1 the prices of eggs, bacon, lard, cooking fats, soap, sugar, butter and fish also have risen, in some cases more than once.

FORCE, Pa., June 9 -- The folk of Bennetts Valley are bidding sad gpod-bys to Dr. Elizabeth Hayes, the slim, blonde mining company doctor who led the miners of this northwestern Pennsylvania area on a strike two years ago to win better living conditions for them.

Major floods in the Mississippi Valley generally come earlier in the year than this and do their greatest damage in the lower river. In its wilder moments the Ohio alone has been known to put 1,500,000 cubic feet a second -- or twice the normal flow of the Mississippi at its mouth -- into the main river at Cairo.

Cardinal Spellman will preside at the ninety-sixth commencement exercises of Manhattan College in the college quadrangle in Riverdale today at 3:30 P.M. Degrees will be conferred by Brother B. Thomas, president of the college.

Filled with many interesting new ideas, the showing of Maximilian furs yesterday at the Plaza Hotal was marked by hemlines that dipped to the new longer length An opulent sweep and fullness is the manipulation of fur and a rounded, curved or spiral line rar throughout the collection.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Fourstar generals and admirals will hold the top rankings in all of the armed services after July 1, 1948, the House was advised today by a twelve-member subcommittee that has been studying the question for many weeks.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- Establishment of a Great Book Foundation to develop a mass education program which may reach possibly 15,000,000 adults in the next five years was announced today by Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, chancellor of the University of Chicago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 9 -- Screenplays, Inc., Stanley Kramer's new film producing company, has leased space from the Enterprise Studios for the production of at least two pictures, the first of which will be a screen version of Ring Lardner's 1921 novel, "The Big Town."

PRINCETON, N.J., June 9 -- Before 3,000 persons assembled in front of Nassau Hall, 646 students received degrees from Princeton University this afternoon at the largest graduation ceremony in the history of the university.

SEOUL, Korea, June 9 -- Consultations between Korean political leaders and organizations and the Joint United States Soviet Commission will begin here on July 5, it was announced today. Maj. Gen. Albert E. Brown, Chief of the American delegation, revealed that major differences between the American and Soviet representatives had been reconciled on the vital question of which Korean groups and leaders would be invited to voice opinions in the formation of an interim Government.
There was a fairly heavy volume of trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Final prices were 39 points higher to 10 points lower than Saturday's final levels.

BATAVIA, Java, June 9 (Aneta) -- The Indonesian Republic Government's reply to the "final" proposal for implementation of the Cheribon agreement, submitted to the Republic May 27 by the Netherlands Commission General for the Indies, was made public here today.
Thomas B. Kalfbus has been appointed market development manager of the Westinghouse Electric Supply Company. Ira G. Deitrick has been appointed syndicate manager for the New England district.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- In his letter to Chairman John Taber of the House Appropriations Committee several days ago, former President Herbert Hoover made a proposal that has disturbed some of the leading European emissaries in Washington, but now appears to have been misconstrued.

Pierre Cardinal Gerlier of France, wearing on his cassock ribbons representing awards for val as an infantryman in World War I arrived here yesterday and told of an effort by the Gestapo to kill him in 1943 in Lyon.

Store Sales 3% Over Year Ago Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week rose 3 per cent over the corresponding week of last year, according to the "flash report" yesterday of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

OAKLAND, Calif., June 9 -- A strike of 3,000 employes of the Key System, which operates trains and buses over the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge and throughout the Oakland Metropolitan area, was ordered for 12:01 A.M. Wednesday by a vote of more than 1,000 members of the Carmen's Union of the American Federation of Labor early today.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- Easing of material supplies has brightened prospects in the packaged fuel field, Harry Turner, secretary of the National Association of Packaged Fuel Manufacturers, said today at the conclusion of the first session of the organization's annual convention.
