BOSTON, June 9 (AP) -- A former American Army captain testified at the treason trial of Douglas Chandler today that the former Baltimore writer told him in 1945 that he felt Russia was more of a menace than Germany.

SKYTOP LODGE, Pa., June 9 -- Business in this country operates on a profit and loss system not a profit system alone, it was emphasized here today by Paul S. Wills, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America. He decried the practice of some business men of preaching free enterprise while at the same time advocating extension of government control in an address before the annual midyear meeting of his organization.

Indecision ruled yesterday in the stock market and prices drifted easier more from lack of demand than pressure. Final quotations were irregularly lower, however, with only a few wide changes and the combined averages 0.18 point lower on the day.

The Public Administrator held a public preview yesterday at 226 William Street of 150 items taken from the house of the Collyer brothers in Harlem. The items will be auctioned today. Five hundred persons -- most of them women and almost all curiosity seekers -- visited the seventh-floor loft.

CHICAGO, June 9 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 8,000 head; total, 10,500; market fairly active and fully 25 cents higher on most hogs under 250 pounds: some earlier sales of heavier weight hogs also selling a quarter

Thirty steamship lines, after several weeks of discussion and negotiation, have organised to cooperate with trucking carriers in the Port of New York in reducing congestion and confusion on the waterfront, it was announced yesterday.

CLEVELAND, June 9 (AP) -- Sam Mele's home run into the left field stands with Ted Williams on base in the eighth inning provided the winning margin today as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Cleveland Indians, 7 to 5, in the opener of a three-game series.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- National headquarters for Harold E. Stassen, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, took ains today to deny that the meeting between Mr. Stassen and Gov. Thomas E. Dewey presaged a olitical deal between them.

The new forty-year 2 7/8 per cent debentures of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company dropped in price yesterday from 102 7/8 to 101 5/8 following dissolution of the syndicate of l06 underwriters that bought the bonds at competitive sale last Tuesday at 102.219.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- The Executive Board of the CIO United Auto Workers unanimously authorized today a strike of 20,000 Briggs Manufacturing Company workers to start on Wednesday if the company failed to agree to the union's wage and other demands by that time.
The importance of learning in childhood that group differences are only "skin deep" was stressed yesterday at a luncheon given by the Bureau of Intercultural Education at the Hotel Pierre.
Vehicular traffic in lower Manhattan was snarled for two hours yesterday by a demonstration on the West Side Highway of the city's new "jeep patrol" service to eliminate bottlenecks.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 9 -- More than $6,000,000,000 was given or lent by the United States to needy countries in 1946, Dr. Isador Lubin, United States representative on the United Nations Economic and Employment Commission, told his colleagues today.

LONDON, June 9 -- The most comprehensive and far-reaching agriculture bill ever presented in Britain passed the final stage in the House of Commons tonight without a division. In principle, the measure was largely agreed on before it started its journey, and its acceptance by the House of Lords is virtually assured.
ROME, June 9 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi began the battle for his fourth Cabinet's life today when he presented his program to the Constituent Assembly.

Columbia University's president emeritus, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, received yesterday the first Alexander Hamilton Award at a ceremony at his home, 60 Morningside Drive. The award will be presented annually by the Alumni Association of Columbia College to an alumnus for "distinguished service and accomplishment in any field of human endeavor."

OTTAWA, June 9 -- It would seem that the Canadian capital is relying on its natural beauties to impress President Truman and his party, for no preparations have yet been made for any great display of flags and bunting.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Supreme Court upheld the conviction, om Major Walter V. Radovich, former Army Ace, and two New York civilians for using bribery to keep two soldiers at Mitchel Field from being assigned to combat duty overseas.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- An application of the "full faith and credit" clause of the Constitution laid down by the Supreme Court in a 5-to-4 ruling today, led to criticism that the majority conclusion was "revolutionary." Under the Constitution "full faith and credit shall be given in each state" to the laws, records and judicial proceedings of all the others.

LONDON, June 9 (U.P.) -- A very Brundage, president of the U.S. Olympic Committee, today won his battle to postpone a decision on "broken time" payments to amateur athletes, probably until after the 1948 Olympics.

Photographs of a Mexican scene and still-life subjects have inspired a new group of decorative fabrics by Wesley Simpson just introduced at Macy's. Based on photographs by Horst, the designs feature a cross-like arrangement of motifs, as well as unusual color combinations.

MUNICH, Germany, June 9 -- Fewer than a thousand persons, including some women, attended a mass meeting tonight where Fritz Ebert, son of the late President of Germany after the first World War, and Walter Ulbricht, deputy chairman of the Socialist Unity party, announced a campaign for a plebiscite on unification.

This afternoon at 2 o'clock the International Exposition of Textiles being held in the Grand Central Palace, will open its door to the general public. Already the exposition has been visited by large crowds of buyers and manufacturers, who attended during the past week when it was open to the trade.
NORTHFIELD, Vt., June 9 -- Secretary of the Navy Forrestal declared here today that, even though the United States won the war against nazism and fascism, it was still in danger.

Critics of the Labor-Management Bill, which is now awaiting action by the President, have called it an "extreme" measure. Is this charge justified? Is this legislation "punitive" in the sense that the President used the term in his message of last January on the state of the Union ?
The postponed departmental hearing of Elmer R. Haslett, suspended director of the city's airports, will begin at 10 A.M. today in the City Court Building, 52 Chambers Street.
GULLANE, Scotland, June 9 (AP) -- Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zaharias is going native.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., June 9 (AP) -- Joseph A. Beirne, officiating at the birth of the Communications Workers of America here today, predicted a merger of the CIO and the AFL and urged the new telephone union to affiliate with such a merger.

NANKING, June 9 (U.P.) -- ProGovernment press reports listed major Nationalist victories in the Mukden and Changchun areas of Manchuria today. The reports indicated that the Government held little hope of retaining Antung, railway center on the north Korean border.
Two hundred and ten boys and girls received cash prizes yesterday for their essays on, "What Can I And My Community Do to Prevent Accidents in the Streets And on the Highways?"

LONDON, June 9 -- The British Government, has instructed its Ambassador in Moscow, Sir Maurice Peterson, to take up the question of Hungary directly with the Soviet Government, Hector McNeil, Minister of State, told the House Commons today.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The possibility of an imminent economic recession was scouted today by Jesse H. Jones, formerly Federal Loan Administrator and Secretary of Commerce and one of the country's leading financial figures.

OSSINING, N.Y., June 9 -- At 4 o'clock this morning, as Hudson River craft called dismally through fog, Jacob (Gurrah Jake) Shapiro died in the Sing Sing prison hospital of coronary thrombosis. He was 50 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Democratic New Deal wing in Congress, with some irregular Republican support, began an effort today to force the Republican majority to take a decision at this session on a proposal to raise the minimum wage standard.

The rent-free tenancy of 150 guests of the Hotel Imperial will end June 25, under a ruling yesterday by Municipal Court uJstice James S. Watson. The court directed a jury that had been hearing evidence for a week to return a verdict in favor of the hotel's owners, who asked eviction of the residential tenants.

An expert rider can show off his horsemanship on a sluggish, stubborn horse, and an expert golfer can play well without the finest set of clubs in the world. Similarly, an expert cook can turn out a memorable meal on a one-burner gas plate.

A break in the ranks of the Teachers Salary Conference, which represents virtually all of the city's 30,000 public school teachers, appeared possible yesterday after the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations and the Teachers Union, CIO, exchanged accusations of "traitorous action" and "character assassination."

JERUSALEM, June 9 -- Despite the Arab states' boycott of Zionistmade goods. The Palestine Economist, a Jerusalem monthly, asserted today that Palestine's exports had increased by u1,000,000 in 1946, more than compensating for the loss of Arab markets.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9 -- Edward Hopkinson Jr., financial adviser to the Electric Bond and Share Company in its recapitalization proceedings, said today that any further payment to the $5 and $6 preferred stockholders of the company would be a "windfall."

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Capt. N.H. Collisson, U.S.N.R., Coal Mines Administrator, ordered today an investigation into the "wild-cat" strikes of soft-coal miners in Pennsylvania, presumably in protest against the TaftHartley labor relations bill.

Margins For Low Price Stocks In view of the many stock splitups which have placed the shares of many long-established companies at prices at $10 or less, Wall Street hailed with approval yesterday the request of the Association of Customers Brokers to the New York Stock Exchange the margin trading be restored in the low-price category.

DETROIT, June 9 -- Representative Carroll D. Kearns, Republican, of Pennsylvania, was threatened today with expulsion from the American Federation of Musicians if he carried out his plan to take part in an Independence Day musical program at Interlochen, Mich.
PHILADELPHIA, June 9 -- Registration statements covering $75,000,000 of debentures and 460,000 shares of capital stock were filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today by two companies.

Purchasing power in India will double in the next fifteen or twenty years, according to Edward J. Fielden, managing director of J. Walter Thompson Company's office in India, now visiting this country. Mr. Fielden stated yesterday that the demand for all types of consumer goods is definitely on the increase in India.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- A bill authorizing the Federal Government to grant the state $300,000,000 a year to help equaliz educational opportunities was approved today by a Senate Public Welfare subcommittee.

Mel Ott allowed himself the luxury of a second-guess and because the little pilot thought twice, his Giants won a story-book thriller from the Pirates yesterday at the Polo Grounds. Ordinarily, a manager must rise or fall with his first guess, but there was nothing ordinary about this thrill-packed struggle in which the Giants, seven runs behind at one stage, finished on top, 13 -- 10.
TOKYO, June 9 -- On Aug. 15 private international trade with Japan will be resumed and on Sept. 1 the initial deals may be consummated. Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

A new order department for sending food parcels abroad will open today under auspices of the American Women's Voluntary Services, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Ann C. Cunningham, who heads the project, at Greater New York AWVS headquarters, 99 Park Avenue.
PHILADELPHIA, June 10 (AP) -- Harry (The Cat) Brecheen failed to finish against the Phillies tonight but scored his seventh victory of the season as the Cardinals came through with an 8-3 triumph.

NEW DELHI, India, June 10 (AP) -- Informed observers said tonight that Lahore probably would become the capital of the new Moslem nation of Pakistan, and that Mohammed Ali Jinnah would almost certainly head the country as its "George Washington" who achieved independence from the British and the majority Hindu community.

TRENTON, N.J., June 10 -- There is an election in New Jersey this fall for legislative and municipal offices, but thoughts of the State Republican and Democratic leadership were elsewhere today at their party conventions. Attendance was light at both meetings.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Labor-management relations appear to have taken a turn for the worse in recent weeks, despite the peaceful settlement in such basic lines as steel and automobiles earlier this year and the absence of spectacular walkouts like those of 1946.

A rise of 35 per cent in the number of adult American drinkers during the war years was estimated in a report on recent trends in alcoholism in the current Quarterly Journal of Studies on Alcohol, issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- A strong effort to get the earliest possible Senate hearing on the Fulbright-Thomas-Boggs concurrent resolution through which Congress would favor the creation of a United States of Europe will be made within the next few days, Representative Hale Boggs, Democrat, of Louisiana, said today.

Ready-to-wear retailers were urged last night to take a mark-up one the net instead of gross price by Morris W. Haft, president of the coat and suit manufacturing concern bearing his name. He said that manufacturers already have reduced prices by improving quality at the same price.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Truman Administration has evidently accepted the lesson of the Greek-Turkish debate: that it is not good policy or good politics to give basis for the charge that it has ignored the United Nations.

NEWTON, Mass., June 10 (AP) -- A tournament-tested trio, which included two former winners, posted four-over-par 79s to pace a field of 84 through the first round of the women's Eastern golf championship tournament today at Brae Burn.

DEFENDING champions in all sports are always regarded with profound respect when they put their titles on the line again. But not in golf. The divot-diggers are a breed apart, leaving both fame and reputation in the locker-room as they start their mad scramble after that aggravating, perverse and ill-behaved little white pill.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 10 -- "The Corsair," Lord Byron's poem of sea adventure, will be adapted to the screen and filmed next fall by Sam Katzman for Columbia release, the Katzman producing unit announced today.

When Congress has approved an important piece of legislation not only by an enormous vote but actually with the majority support of both parties in both Houses, only the soundest and most persuasive reasons justify a Presidential veto. Mr. Truman's mail, we are told, is running strongly in favor of a veto of the new labor bill which now awaits his action.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 10 -- Only honest debate on the question of what are the essential rights of modern man and a frankly written international bill of rights can do the United Nations any "good" in this field, where the temptation to mince words is strong, Dr. Charles Malik of Lebanon, raporteur of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, said today in an interview.

Buyers' Total Higher Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 2,578 against 1,678 last week and 3,651 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Contributions of $1,432,486 for war relief and to charitable and labor organizations in 1946 were reported by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, in its thirteenth annual fiscal report published yesterday.
BUDAPEST, June 10 -- While the United States still is apparently weighing the advisability of sending a note to Moscow in protest against the Communist coup in

TOKYO, June 10 -- Almost two years after her surrender, Japan has reached a precarious economic, political and social balance. It is one that has been maintained and can be maintained for a long period only through constant material assistance from the United States and constant Allied supervision on the scene.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The State Department expressed the hope today that the settlement projected in the British plan for India would work out well for all concerned. It reiterated our friendship for Indians "of all communities and creeds."
SECURITY COUNCIL Sir Alexander Cadogan, British Representative, warned that despite veto, the United Nations could take military action against any member of Big Five found guilty of aggression.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 10 -- Sharp criticism of the American program of aid to Turkey was expressed today by Alexander P. Morozov of the Soviet Union, acting chairman of the United Nations Economic and Employment Commission.

LONDON, June 10 (AP) -- The London golfing writers worked themselves into a mild -- and strictly un-British -- frenzy today over Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zaharias' golfing prowess. They had never seen anything like it in a woman, they wrote almost unanimously of the Babe's heavy hitting in the British women's championship at Gullane, Scotland.

Austria has now become the immediate focal point of Russo-Communist activity. Having overthrown the legitimate Government in Hungary with charges which the new Communistdominated Premier admits cannot be proved, the same Communist elements have launched a campaign to overthrow the Austrian Government in order to replace it with a more compliant regime which could be expected to surrender Austria to Russian domination.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (U.P.) -- House Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr., confirmed today that Congress plans to quit late next month, with a definite understanding that a special "foreign policy" session will be called if strained United States-Russian relations reached a crisis stage.

PARIS, Wednesday, June 11 -- Premier Paul Ramadier failed to settle the railway strike after an all-day effort that ended just before last midnight. It included renewed appeals to both railwayunion leaders and the executive committee of the General Confederation of Labor.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- German-born Gerhart Eisler, 51 years old, alleged link between the Kremlin and American Communists, was convicted of contempt of Congress today for refusing to be sworn for testimony before the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

An "agreement in principle" covering exchange of technical workers between the English and American motion-picture industries was announced yesterday by Tom O'Brien, general secretary of the National Association of Theatrical and Kine Employes, and Richard Walsh, president of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 10 -- Great Britain declared today that, despite use of the veto, the United Nations could take military action against any member of the Big Five found guilty of aggression.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 10 -- Premier Lajos Dinnyes announced today that "anti-democratic" elements would be purged from the Hungarian Army. He added that 80 per cent of the officers had "fled to the West."

A conference of thirty boy delegates, representing sixteen South Bronx neighborhood "gangs," was held last night at the James K. Paulding Junior High School, Trinity Avenue and 158th Street, to arrive at a working agreement in the interest of neighborhood peace and community betterment Those present represented 500 to 700 members who were pledged to secrecy.
LONDON, June 10 -- Britain's Labor Government was defeated three times in the House of Lords tonight during debate in the committee stage on the bill to nationalize all inland transport.
A shortage of skilled seamen has reached such proportions that for the first time since the end of the war American-flag merchant ships are being delayed by manning problems.
BUFFALO, June 10 (AP) -- The Western New York Episcopal diocese failed a second time today to elect a Bishop coadjutor to succeed the Right Rev. Cameron J. Davis as Bishop.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Big Johnny Lindell, who is a substitute for a substitute in the Yankee scheme of things, tonight blasted Bucky Harris' troupe to within half a game of the American League lead at Comiskey Park.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 4: Decreases of $638,000,000 in holdings of United States Government obligations and $720,000,000 in United States Government deposits and an increase of $237,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted.

After winning two out of three demands it made on the Board of Transportation yesterday, the Transport Workers Union voted last night to go back to normal operations on the New York City Transit System.

WASHINGTON, June 10--Political conditions affecting the economic status of prospective borrowing nations are well within the scope of inquiry of fact-finding missions sent abroad by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development for on-the-spot investigation, according to an interpretation today by John J. McCloy, the bank's president.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Dr. Martha Eliot, assistant chief of the Children's Bureau, today told reporters on her return from a six-weeks trip into seven European countries for the International Children's Emergency Fund that need for the operation of this still-pending fund is immediate and very urgent.

A far-reaching investigation into alleged graft and other irregularities in the Brooklyn office of the Department of Housing and Buildings was indicated yesterday with the arraignment in Felony Court, Brooklyn, of a department clerk.

John McKenzie, former Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, testified yesterday that Elmer Haslett, suspended city Director of Airports, was the first to broach to him a proposal of the Gulf Oil Company to bid for an exclusive fuel concession at Idlewild Airport.

Buying of meat in wholesale cuts for storage in frozen food lockers saves customers about 20 per cent over regular retail prices, C. Stuart Wishart, general manager, Country Life Frozen Foods, Inc., Westbury, L.I., declared yesterday. This service brings operators "purchasing fees" of 5 or 10 per cent, Mr. Wishart said in addressing the eastern regional meeting of the National Frozen Food Locker Association.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store organizations showed a rise of 25.8 per cent in May, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. In April the increase was 18.1 er cent.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Kate Smith declared today that the transfer of her daily radio commentary from the Columbia Broadcasting System was to escape "restrictions and censorship" imposed by the Columbia program department. It was announced in mid-May that her news and comment broadcasts would move to the Mutual Broadcasting System June 23.

Ernest Murphy, president of Pressed Steel Car Company, Inc., classed as the nation's third largest builder of railroad freight cars, announced yesterday that "a continued shortage of steel plates" has forced the company to plan a closing of its McKees Rocks plant, near Pittsburgh, during July.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., June 10 -- A dispute between, a department executive of the New York Stock Exchange and employes here of the president of the American Tobacco Company, involving alleged maimings of sheep and shootings of dogs resulted today in three men being accused of penal law violations.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP)--Following is the text of Mr. Nagy's letter from Budapest: Mr. Secretary: My son Ferenc Nagy Jr., a junior member of the foreign service, has been assigned to the Hungarian legation in Washington and is now departing to take up his duties and at the same time to study at a university if that is practicable.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Modern plants that were used for war purposes by the large industrial and banking companies of Japan were placed first on the priority list for removal as reparations under a decision of the Far Eastern Commission, announced today.

JERUSALEM, June 10 -- Within nineteen hours after their disappearance, two British policemen who had been abducted yesterday and held as hostages by a terrorist band, were returned unhurt today while secret security forces of the Zionist comuiunity were still mobilized in a search for them.
MADRID, June 10-Barcelona's fifteenth international fair opened today.

A rule making it mandatory for specialty clubs to set a closing date for entries in their shows was adopted yesterday by the delegates of the American Kennel Club at a meeting at the Hotel Commodore. Previously there was no rule requiring the printing of a closing date on premium lists and post entries often were accepted.
BERLIN, June 10 -- Six men claiming to be active anti-Nazis have been held without a hearing in Dachau by the United States for periods ranging from four to twenty-six months.
Hapoel, the soccer team from Palestine, and an All-Star eleven of players from the American League played a scoreless tie at Randalls Island last night.

PARIS, June 10 -- France's Treasury stringency may force appeals to the United States for loans that may be subject to conditions affecting French independence, Charles Barange, reporter of the budget, today told the Popular Republican group in the Assembly. The Cabinet tomorrow will discuss solutions of the Treasury problem.

The City Council deferred voting yesterday on a resolution calling upon President Truman to veto the Taft-Hartley Bill. It also sent to committee a proposed local law and a resolution bearing on the transit situation. Considerable parliamentary by-play preceded both these actions.

CHICAGO, June 10 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs. 10,000 head; total. 13.500. Market uneven; 25 to 75 cents, mostly 25 to 50 cents, lower; sows 50 to 75 cents lower; top. $24.35: bulk of good and choice 170-240

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 10 -- Congress held a secret session today to discuss the issue of Brazilian neutrality in the face of the Paraguayan war, during which Paraguayan troops, both Government and insurgent, have allegedly crossed and recrossed the border.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that remaining controls on installment buying may be scrapped this summer unless Congress specifically authorizes peacetime credit regulation.

SKYTOP LODGE, Pa., June 10 -- Unsettled conditions in the grocery industry are due to a high degree of consumer selectivity and not to a decrease in consumer purchases, it was emphasized here today at the second day's sessions of the mid-year meeting of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc.

CANBERRA, Australia, June 10 -- Prime Minister Joseph B. Chifley stated today that Australia would seek a fair share of Japanese trade when normal trading was resumed. His statement followed the announcement that a resumption of private trade with Japan would be permitted from Aug. 15 and Gen. Douglas MacArthur's comment in Tokyo that "Japan must trade or starve."

A nice way to show Dad we feel he deserves lots of attention on Father's Day would be to serve one of the "straw-hat" cakes designed especially for the occasion by the A. P.'s Jane Parker bakery department. Keep it on a dark shelf in the kitchen, bring it forth as a surprise greeting for Sunday dinner.

The economic blackout which has enveloped Japan for almost two years appears to be lifting partially. An American trade commission announces the decision to give 400 Allied trade representatives entry to Japan, and the Far Eastern Commission, in its first statement on the matter in some time, has begun to spell out the bill of reparations that is to be handed the Japanese Government.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Publication of the text of the "Summary of the Findings and Recommendations" of the President's advisory commission on universal training on June 1 was an event of moment. I am a veteran who found the regimen and ennui of Army life as distasteful as any GI, but I am constrained at this time to endorse the report with utmost vigor.

WINS will begin operation next Sunday with its new transmitter of 50,000 watts power. To mark the event it plans a special program from 1 to 2 P.M., the participants including Tallulah Bankhead, Jerry Colonna, Tommy Handley, the English comedian, who will broadcast from London; Monica Lewis and Dorothy Day.

VIENNA, June 10 -- Austria's majority party, the People's party, the equivalent of the Small Holders party in Hungary, announced officially today that there would be no change in Government under Communist pressure.
Twenty-two pupils of the city school system have changed their classroom for a week. Instead of reporting each morning to Junior Sigh School 65, where they belong, they go to Macy's.

The daily reversal in price trends was repeated yesterday on the stock market and the list recovered from early softness under a later demand which was led by the industrial group. The rally was the strongest in a week and returned the composite rate about to the level of last Tuesday.
PARIS, June 10 -- In a maneuver to strengthen their grip on rich, strategic Morocco, the French have moved to strip the Sultan of most of his authority, it was learned today.

Inactive on Broadway since he staged and produced "Jeb" in February of last year, Herman Shumlin is enthusiastic about a new play called "The Scenic Route" and is seriously thinking of putting it on as his first offering of the new season.

NOTTINGHAM, England, June 10 (Reuters) -- England, with a score of 209 for four, still needs 47 runs with six wickets standing to avoid an inning's defeat by South Africa in the first cricket test match of the season.
The fight scheduled for June 27 between Ezzard Charles of Cincinnati and Elmer (Violent) Ray of Minneapolis at Madison Square Garden has been postponed to the tentative date of July 11.

NEW DELHI, June 10 (Reuters) -- It was announced here today that Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, Chief of the British Imperial General Staff, would arrive in New Delhi on June 23 for a two-day visit.

BERLIN, June 10 -- Negotiations are quietly proceeding between France, Britain and the United States to implement the proposal made by French Foreign Minister Bidault in Moscow last March for the emigration to France of large numbers of Germans, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The prospect was raised today, before the House Committee on Expenditures, in the executive departments, of uncovering opposition to the unification of the armed forces which is said to be widespread in the ranks of the Navy.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department informed Congress today it is willing to sell potatoes at 1 cent a bushel for industrial use to prevent dumping of surplus crops.

More than one fan in the crowd of 39,690 at the Polo Grounds last night left the park convinced that he or she had witnessed one of the greatest baseball games ever played under Coogan's Bluff -- or anywhere, for that matter. It was a thrill-packed struggle between the Giants and Pirates that lasted three hours and thirty-three minutes and wound up in a 3-2 twelveinning victory for the league-leadins New Yorkers.

NANKING, Wednesday, June 11 -- Cavalrymen of Soviet-dominated Outer Mongolia, supported by planes described as bearing Russian markings, penetrated fifty miles inside China's Sinkiang Province on Friday in a punitive raid and fighting still was reported under way four days later, authoritative sources said today.

Money Market Easier The money market was somewhat easier yesterday with Federal funds quoted at five-eighths of 1 per cent. According to financial observers, it appears that there was some inflow of funds from out-of-town banks, with the Federal Reserve member banks here, after starting the day from an even position, registering a moderate gain of funds.

BOSTON, June 10 -- The port of Boston may be taking business away from the port of New York, both as a result of congestion in the latter and the fact that permits from the Association of American Railroads are necessary to ship through New York, whereas they are not required to ship through Boston.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- By making public an exchange of letters between Under-Secretary of State Dean Acheson and Ferenc Nagy, former Hungarian Premier, the State Department disputed today a Hungarian Communist's charge that there had been commitments, which were said to be secret, between Messrs. Acheson and Nagy.
Two hundred and nine Fordham College seniors received degrees last night in the university gymnasium on the Bronx campus at the first of two commencement exercises this week.

The daily "float" among the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and the participating member and non-member clearing banks has been reduced nearly $80,000,000 on outgoing items as a result of the system of consolidated air cargo shipments now in use here, it was disclosed yesterday.

Many war-born electric iron producers are winding up operations because of competition from the easy supply of well-known brands, distributors and dealers reported yesterday. A traffic appliance representative of a large distributor stated that off-brand automatic 100-watt irons, formerly retailing for between $10 and $12 are selling in many Chicago stores for $3.95.

The millinery division of the Fashion Group met at luncheon in the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday to View a group of hats designed by leading milliners to complement the new fall fashions. Throughout the showing there was emphasis on the width of brims and crowns and in many cases there was a definite feeling of the early Nineteen Hundreds.

The question that bedevils Washington is what to do to stop the successive moves of the Soviet Government to organize and control central and southeastern Europe before the satellite treaties go into effect. The Russian moves and their objective are clear enough; the counter-moves are extremely difficult.
LONDON, June 10 -- With buyers holding off the stock markets here today generally were quiet.

AMSTERDAM, June 10 (Aneta) -- Lack of public interest was responsible for the small turnover of shares on the Stock Exchange, and prices were generally lower. Industrials, shipping stocks and Indies plantations issues registered declines, while State bonds and banking shares as a group were steady.

Meat prices in this city, particularly for the better cuts, are "higher than they were in the black market during the days of the OPA," Jack Kranis, president of the National Meat Industry Council, which claims 25,000 members in eight eastern States and the District of Columbia, asserted yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Both corn and oats futures showed pronounced strength today on the Board of Trade. Wheat was still under considerable hedge pressure and was affected also by the expectation of the bearish Government report that was issued after the close of the market.

The annual commencement exercises of the Teachers College, Graduate School and School of Nursing of St. John's University, Brooklyn, were held there yesterday before 700 spectators. The Rev. James M. Gillis, editor of The Catholic World, made the graduation address and warned the 143 students receiving degrees of communism's "religion of irreligion."

May shipments of rayon yarn and staple totaled 78,300,000 pounds, an increase of 8 per cent over the corresponding month last year, according to the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc., yesterday. Shipments for the first five months of the year amounted to 381,800,000 pounds, 8 per cent more than was shipped in the same period in 1946.

YONKERS. N.Y., June 10 -- Miss Peggy Mackie of Inwood pieced together a fine 39, 41-80 to win the fourth one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association season at the Dunwoodie Golf Club today. She defeated Mrs. Jerome Herbert of Old Oaks, who posted 42, 41-83.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York advanced yesterday its $290,000,000 bond refunding program by selling $60,000,000 of first mortgage twentyfive year bonds at an interest cost of about 2.66 per cent to a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.
OTTAWA, June 10 -- Some 40,0000 citizens of the Canadian capital turned out today to welcome the first President of the United States ever to pay a state visit to their country.

Award of an issue of $25,000,000 of veterans' services funding bonds of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to a banking group headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co. was one of several substantial bond sales in the municipal market yesterday. The Massachusetts veterans' benefit issue, which will come due on May 15, 1950 to 1956, was awarded at a bid of 101.2902 for l 1/4 s.

The advance fall collection of Robert Dudley, seen yesterday at 54 East Fifty-sixth Street, was called "The Continental Look" for it stressed hats for the woman of matured taste. Worked out in velvet, satins and metallic jerseys, the hats were rich in color and trims of ostrich, feathered wings and glistening coq.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 10 -- The first draft convention calling on United Nations members to punish individuals governments who seek to destroy entire racial, religious, national or political groups was completed here today.

With a private view last evening the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, opened its exhibition honoring Alfred Stieglitz, distinguished American photographer and indefatigable friend and proponent of the modern movement in art, who died last July.

CLEVELAND, June 10 (AP) -- Bobby Doerr's line single to left in the eighth scored Johnny Pesky from third tonight to give the Boston Red Sox their second' straight victory, 3 -- 2, over the Cleveland Indians before 49,787 fans. Joe Dobson gained his sixth victory, while Al Gettel suffered his second loss.

The International Exposition of Textiles in Grand Central Palace was opened officially to the public yesterday afternoon. Grover Whalen, assisted by four models costumed as queens of cotton, rayon, silk and wool, officiated. The exposition will be open through Saturday from 11 A.M. to 11 P.M.

Invasion and seizure of the west room of the Governor's Suite in City Hall by Mayor O'Dwyer's new Executive Committee on Administration, efficiently executed under cover of darkness Thursday night with the sanction of the Mayor, has brought grief to the Municipal Art Commission, it developed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The State Department's foreign information and educational exchange program, with its broadcast "Voice of America," encountered more snags and delays in the House today.

Twelve more cadet midshipmen from the graduating class at the Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L.I, will join the United States Lines as junior third officers this week, it was announced yesterday. Fifteen members of the same class reported for company duty last week.

The largest graduating class in the history of New York University will take part in its 115th commencement exercises at 10:30 A.M. today at Ohio Field of the University Heights campus. Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, Chancellor of the university, will confer certificates and degrees on 5,643 graduating seniors and present awards to four alumni leaders for meritorious service.

Starting 4 points lower to 2 points higher than the preceding close, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange gained strength yesterday as the session progressed. Final prices were 28 points net higher to 1 point net lower.

All types of garden roses, from miniatures whose blossoms fit in a thimble to stately tree varieties, were put on display yesterday at the opening of THE NEW YORK TIMES rose show in Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

Much at Random Brooklyn announces the existence of a large black market in babies for adoption. Apparently there are childless couples who are willing to pay more for a black-market baby than they would have to pay for a new-used or a used-new automobile.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10--The Rochester Telephone Corporation of Rochester, N.Y., the Arden Farms Company of Los Angeles and the Santa Maria Mines, Ltd., of Toronto, Canada, have filed registration statements, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Inspiration and emotion have little influence on the work of budding musicians, it was concluded yesterday at the annual concert of original compositions by students at the High School of Music and Art. Even a bathtub will serve to start the music flowing, according to one of the young composers, 16-year-old Leonard Marcus.

CHANGCHUN, June 10 -- Changchun, the capital of Manchuria, is still cut off from other Nationalist areas by strong Communist forces to the south. After four days of little activity around Changchun, two powerful Red units were reported commencing a westerly movement toward the Chinese Changchun Railway.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 10 -- Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson said today that President Truman's program for providing Latin-American countries with military equipment for training their armed forces is carrying out the plan for a unified defense of the American hemisphere and follows an agreement set up at the Chapuetepec Conference in Mexico City during the recent war.

Comprehensive planning of suburban areas was advocated yesterday by Prof. Philip H. Elwood of Iowa State College as a means of assuring the economic and aesthetic development of expanding centers of population and a wider control of the use of land for the public good.

After going down before Ewell (Whitey) Blackwell, 3-1, in the opener for their fourth successive defeat at the hands of the Reds, the Dodgers turned the tables on their troublesome rivals from Cincinnati with an eight-inning rally that won the second game of a double-header, 6-5, at Ebbets Field yesterday.

Staged like a musical comedy, with a cast of 100 headed by Jinx Falkenburg. the Fashion Fair will open tomorrow in Madison Square Garden. Daily through Saturday, June 21, it will be open from 11 A.M. to 11 P.M., presenting the latest styles "from lingerie to mink."

DETROIT, June 10 (AP) -- Outlasting the American League leaders in a see-saw slugfest, the Athletics put together 14 hits, including three home runs, two doubles and a triple, today to down the Tigers for the second time in two days, 9 to 8.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Influential Congressional Republicans are prepared to try new labor legislation, wholly apart from the Taft-Hartley omnibus bill, if a "paralysis" strike comes in soft coal and cannot otherwise be put down, it was learned today.

GUAM, June 10 (AP) -- A nervous little Japanese fleet surgeon charged with using American prisoners for inhuman medical experiments went on trial before a military commission today with eighteen subordinates accused of spearing, strangling and beheading ten of their captives.
WASHINGTON, June 10--Two of three plans submitted by President Truman this year for reorganization of executive agencies met with adverse action in Congress today.

Wheel-chair patients who have developed the facilities will demonstrate this afternoon the features of three house units especially designed for paraplegic veterans at Halloran Veterans Administration Hospital in Staten Island.

By only a head at the end of six furlongs, after considerable of a tussle through the stretch, Louis Rabinowitz' Speeding Home won the Class B handicap that was the top presentation at the Aqueduct horse park yesterday.

GULLANE, Scotland, June 10 (AP) -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias, as hot today with her golf sticks as the blazing sun over her native Texas, blasted her way into the quarter-finals of the women's British championship with a pair of lopsided victories as her two United States compatriots faltered.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- (AP) -- Federal Works Administrator Philip B. Fleming told officials of Southern states today that nationwide attention to building codes is imperative to keep fire regulations up to date.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Representative Carroll D. Kearns, Republican, of Pennsylvania, showed no concern today over the threat of James C. Petrillo to expel him from the American Federation of Musicians.

Prompt acceptance by the Moslem League of the British plan for partitioning India apparently assures the birth of a new nation. Pakistan, which only a few years ago seemed an illogical and impossible dream, is now on the very threshold of reality.

Sixty thousand members of Congress of Industrial Organizations unions paraded up Eighth Avenue and gathered in and around Madison Square Garden last night to demand that President Truman veto the Taft-Hartley labor bill and that Congress sustain the veto.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- In assigning to Norman Armour a scope of authority far exceeding that usually given to an Assistant Secretary of State, Secretary George C. Marshall met one criticism that has been made of his organization of the department in so far as he was able to do so after his selection of Robert A. Lovett to succeed Dean Acheson as Under-Secretary.

CLEVELAND, June 10 -- Dr. F. D. Patterson, president of Tuskegee Institute and Negro member of the Central Committee of the American Red Cross, today lauded the committee as author of "a forthright and sound" statement on the question or segregation of the blood of persons of different races in connection with a proposed national blood program.

ALBANY, June 10 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey will leave the state July 4, for an extended Western tour which his supporters believe will increase his chances for another Presidential nomination in 1948.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 10 -- Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson told the house of delegates of the American Medical Association today that the Army faces a serious shortage of physicians in its Medical Corps. He urged the delegates to support a bill to make Army service more attractive to physicians from an economic and professional point of view.

Another round in the battle between the conservative and the "modern" champions of art was fought over the air yesterday when three artists and an art critic gave their views on the controversial subject: "Why the Conflict Over Modern Art?"
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Coast artillery is almost as obsolete as horse cavalry, War Department spokesmen acknowledged today, and may be abandoned as soon as scientists perfect the guided missile.

Ideal weather provided the setting yesterday afternoon for the ninety-sixth commencement exercises of Manhattan College in the quadrangle of the Riverdale campus. Cardinal Spellman presided at the exercises, attended by 2,400 relatives and friends of the graduating class and the faculty.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 10 -- Mark F. Ethridge, American member of the United Nations Balkan Investigation Commission, said today that there was "every prospect" that the Truman program would promote economic security in Greece, and that this in turn would make possible the development of political security.

Philip J. Cruise, long an official in the City Department of Parks, is one of a group of men picked to take over key positions on the staff of the New York City Housing Authority, it was learned yesterday.

DETROIT, June 10 -- A strike against the Briggs Manufacturing Company by 20,500 workers was averted at the eleventh hour tonight by negotiators for the company and the United Automobile Workers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

HURTSBORO, Ala., June 10 -- Jimmy Harris, 18, a Negro, who at noon today was standing with a rope around his neck under a tree in front of a home where he had been found with a screaming white woman, was alive and unharmed tonight in the State prison at Montgomery.

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., June 10 -- A flat sea, an agreeable group of fellow fishermen, an able captain and plenty of mackerel mean a memorable day of off shore fishing where ever you may go, and today qualified in each of these requirements.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., June 10 -- Mayor O'Dwyer, speaking tonight at a Jefferson dinner of the Sullivan County Democratic organization at Kiamesha Lake, assailed the Republican party record in the fields of price controls, housing, labor relations and veteran affairs, and made a plea for the Democratic party to remain "the party of the people."

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture forecast today a surprisingly large wheat crop, nearly double the prewar average, but painted less favorable prospects for some other crops, particularly livestock feed grains.

During its first year of operation, completed this week, the Motion Picture Export Association, Inc., has reopened markets to American films in ten of thirteen countries in Europe and Asia, where normal commercial relations had been discontinued due to the war and post-war political developments.

A store manikin completely attired in the latest 1947 fashions was sealed in a specially constructed copper rocket and lowered into the cornerstone of the new Westchester store of Lord Taylor at White Plains Road and Wilmot Road, in Eastchester, N.Y., yesterday.

LONDON, June 10 (AP) -- Five thousand guests, including more than 100 Americans, were entertained today by King George VI and Queen Elizabeth at a Buckingham Palace garden party -- the post-war equivalent of formal presentation in court.
ST. LOUIS, June 10 (AP) -- A fourth-inning single by Bob Dillinger with the bases loaded gave the Browns a 2-to-1 victory over the Senators tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- John L. Lewis returned unexpectedly to Washington today and found reports awaiting him from officers of the United Mine Workers of America explaining their efforts to end the unauthorized strikes of union members in various parts of Pennsylvania.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: William Green's letter in your issue of May 28 repeats the standard trade union misrepresentation of the injunction in labor disputes. He says: "Here is compulsion, a form of involuntary servitude, because when free working men, owning their labor, are compelled by court injunction to work against their will they are slaves to that extent."

Some of the Collyer brothers' worldly goods went under the hammer yesterday. The auctioneer and cynical aides offered what most of them described as "junk I wouldn't pay a (Sine for," but 200 persons, including the owner of a flea circus, antique and secondhand dealers and private buyers paid, a total of $1,800 for 150 items taken from the Collyer "mansion" in Harlem.

Drawings for lanes in the Poughkeepsie rowing regatta, to be held on the Hudson June 21, were made yesterday in the Hotel Biltmore offices of Asa S. Bushnell, secretary of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association. Representatives were present from the eleven colleges that will send the record number of twenty-nine shells to the starting mark in the three races.

BOSTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Braves made it four victories in a row today by defeating the Cubs, 2-1, behind Johnny Sain, who squeezed home what proved to be the winning run and then pitched himself out of a tight jam to gain his sixth triumph of the season.

A conspiracy by fur manufacturers and unionized fur workers to put out of business "outside" fur lining contractors was charged in a suit seeking $3,000,000 damages that was filed in Federal Court yesterday by the American Fur Liners Contractors Association, Inc., an organization of fifteen fur-lining contractors.

LONDON, June 10 --The British Government is temporarily holding up its drastic program to cut imports, it was learned today. British leaders have been roused to hope by the address of United States Secretary of State Marshall at Harvard last Thursday and they want to find out what his new proposal means before they take the sad and hard road of reduced importations.

There has been a slight recession of business activity in Mexico since the beginning of 1947 but a great backlog of demand for almost every type of merchandise will still be evident for some time to come, William A. Conkright, senior economic analyst, American Embassy, Mexico City, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The House Banking and Currency Committee approved today a bill to end immediately the rationing of sugar for home consumption.

ST. LOUIS, June 10--The Mississippi River receded slightly today after reaching record crests at several communities in eastern Missouri and north central Illinois but downstream communities prepared to fight the flood waters which has engulfed several thousands of acres of rich farm lands.

Condemnation of a report recommending revision of statutory minimum wages in the beauty service industry on the allegation that one of the employe representatives on the wage revision board consistently acted with the employers was expressed yesterday by Congress of Industrial Organizations leaders at a state public hearing on the subject.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 10 -- Arabs here are not pleased about the Palestine Arab Higher Committee's decision to boycott the United Nations' inquiry commission and declare a general strike on June 16, when the inquiry opens. This merely emphasizes the rift among Arabs, they think, and cannot help their cause.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Philip Murray, head of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, urged President Truman today not only to veto the Taft-Hartley labor bill but to take the strongest measures to insure that a veto would be upheld in Congress.

BERLIN, June 10 -- A conspiracy for the prevention of repatriation of Yugoslav displaced persons and for the maintenance of former royalist troops as a sort of anti-Communist foreign legion was charged to the British, French and United States Military Governments today by the chief of the Yugoslav military mission.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is hard for me to understand your continued advocacy of universal military training. President Truman's commission stressed the terrible swiftness and utter destructiveness of any future atomic war. Yet they look to a mass army of teen-aged youth "for home defense, for effective counter -attack and for complete victory."

A special study of window display readership and circulation was recommended for adoption in future research plans of the Advertising Research Foundation, after discussion at a luncheon at the Biltmore yesterday. Executive members of a joint committee of the Advertising Research Foundation and the Point of Purchase Advertising Institute attended.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 10 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie has refused to transmit to all fiftyfive nations a protest letter from the Jewish Agency for Palestine that criticizes his action in circulating to all the United Nations Governments an earlier British request asking all nations to discourage "illegal immigration" to Palestine.

If there is any danger of such a thing as ineffective control of atomic energy between nations, we ought "to get out and fight" about it, John M. Hancock, former member of the United Nations Atomic Commission, told 500 members of the American Management Association last night at the Waldorf -Astoria Hotel.

"STAR-SPANGLED MIKADO,"* by Frank Kelley and Cornelius Ryan, is a brisk, free-swinging account of Japan under the rule of Gen. Douglas MacArthur during the first year or so of the American occupation. It is not exactly a suave book, but it tosses out quite a lot of information and ideas. Mr. Kelley covered Supreme Headquarters in Tokyo for The New York Herald Tribune and Mr. Ryan was out there for The London Daily Telegraph.

Despite the fact that two of the three members of the Board of Transportation had just been subjected to unwarranted and abusive denunciation from spokesmen for the Transport Workers Union, the Board at the close of hearings on union demands handed down a generous and fair decision on three TWU requests.
MADRID, June 11 -- The program laid out for Senora Eva Peron, wife of President Juan D. Peron of Argentina, was so strenuous today that part of it had to be canceled.

A tent in Grand Central Palace provided a temporary solution to the housing problem of a former paratrooper, his wife and daughter on Tuesday night, as the operators of the International Textile Exposition were startled to learn yesterday. Reports of the incident also brought the family an attractive offer of a home in Union City, N.J.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 11 -- The Soviet Union renewed its demand today that the United Nations work simultaneously for the prohibition of the atomic bomb and the general reduction of all other arms.
ST. LOUIS, June 11 -- The flood crests of the Mississippi and Missouri Rivers raced toward St. Louis today, leaving behind more than 1,000,000 acres of farm land and many communities under water.

Scheduled to have its local premiere at the Empire Theatre during the week of June 23, "Dark Memory," the Edith Gordon production, will not be coming along until the fall, it was learned yesterday. Second-act trouble is said to be the reason for the decision to suspend.

The seventh annual national sewing contest fashion show, sponsored by the National Needlecraft Bureau, was held yesterday in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Awards of $100 each were given to nine national winners chosen from more than 15,000 nonprofessional, home-sewing contestants in forty-one cities and twenty-six States.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of the Navy, declared today that the Navy should not be weakened by budget cuts in a time of world instability, as indicated by the recent change of government in Hungary.
OTTAWA, June 11 -- The Truman Doctrine, expounded by its author, received a resounding ovation from the Canadian Parliament today.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The House cut $5,000,000 out of the $7,200,000 budget for the Federal Public Housing Authority today, and with another swing of the axe ordered Housing Expediter Frank Creedon to start closing up his agency July 1.

American Machine and Metals Directors of American Machine and Metals, Inc., yesterday resumed the payment of dividends on the common stock with the declaration of 25 cents a share for distribution June 30. No action was taken at the February meeting on the dividend due at that time, "owing to increased volume of business and working capital required."

SALONIKA, Greece, June 11 -- The United Nations Balkan subcommission of investigation was turned back at the Bulgarian frontier today when it attempted to cross to inquire into alleged incidents and to visit a town that Greece charged was a hospital and training center similar to Yugoslavia's Bulkis.

The Taft-Hartley Labor Bill aims "to restore equality in collective bargaining and to strengthening such bargaining by making both parties responsible for their acts," Senator Robert A. Taft declared last night in a radio address over WQXR.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, repeated with new emphasis today his opposition to a reduction in taxes this year, and in so doing he strengthened the view that President Truman will veto the bill which would lower taxes by $4,000,000,000.

Present business conditions are normal and are only considered to be receding because they follow a pattern which has been uniquely abnormal, Arthur D. Whiteside, president of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., said yesterday. Addressing more than 400 members of the New York Board of Trade, Inc., at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, he said in similar past circumstances a seller's attitude is usually pessimistic when the buyer "gets in the saddle."

The seventy-seventh annual commencement exercises of St. John's College, St. John's University, BrooKlyn, were held there yesterday in DeGray Hall. Seven hundred friends and relatives of the graduates attended. Seventy-eight graduates received their diplomas from the Rev. Dr. Thomas F. Flynn, acting president of the university.
MUNICH, Germany, June 11 -- The United States Military Government told Bavarian farmers today that they must slaughter 398,000 of their 3,000,000 cattle this year and a proportionate number of pigs.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- Senior Federal Circuit Judge Evan A. Evans today expressed "gravest doubt" that he has power to assign a circuit judge to replace District Judge Michael L. Igoe for the balance of the proceedings in the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad reorganization case.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Senate -House conferees agreed today on a bill to continue rent control until March 1, 1948, under considerably modified regulations.

Negotiations between the National Maritime Union, CIO, and the Committee for the Companies and Agents, Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, were resumed yesterday afternoon, with no progress reported after more than three hours of discussion.

Brookmeade Stable's Inseperable -- and whoever named the colt will never be an odds-on choice in a spelling bee -- did a brisk bit of running at Aqueduct yesterday, so brisk that he was only a fifth of a second off the track record it winning the $20,000 added Tremont Stakes.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The text of the United States note to the Russian authorities in Budapest on the Communist coup in Hungary: The United States representative on the Allied Control Commission for Hungary, Brig. Gen. George H. Weems, has been instructed to deliver the following note to the Soviet acting chairman of the ACC.

QUINCY, Mass., June 11 -- The Quincy Chamber of Commerce's campaign to "save the shipbuilding industry" is gathering speed and force and will be ready for turning into a country-wide program within a few weeks.

It will be the policy of Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the British Exchequer, according to a dispatch from London, to encourage the retention of earnings by British companies, rather than their distribution as dividends. The purpose behind this is twofold. It is designed, on the one hand, to combat inflation; on the other hand, to stimulate capital formation, with the longterm objective of expanding and modernizing Britain's productive plant.

LONDON, June 11 -- In a day of exceptionally important foreign affairs developments inside Parliament and out, the British Government finally lined itself up with Washington today in rebuking the Soviet Union for the Hungarian developments.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 11 (AP) -- Gerrish H. Milliken, president of Deering, Milliken Co., Inc., New York textile-manufacturing concern, died today while playing golf with a group of business associates and friends on the course of the National Golf Links of America, near here.

NEWTON, Mass., June 11 (AP) -- While the four-time winner, Miss Maureen Orcutt of Haworth, N.J., was stroking steadily into the lead at the two-thirds stage of the women's Eastern golf championship, 21-year-old Miss Mae Murray of Rutland, Vt., captured the individual honors today at the Brae Burn Country Club.

DAY-DREAMING is a pleasant enough diversion, if you have the time for it, and perhaps it's no more than an idle flight of the imagination to think that the Giant-Yankee game at the Polo Grounds tonight might be a world series preview. The two New York teams collide under lights in an attractive charity exhibition game, with both sandlot baseball and the Runyon Cancer Fund benefiting thereby.

The joys of June are many, not the least of them the sweet cherry cart that waits for you at the office door as you leave in the evening, that greets you at the entrance to the park, that even loiters at a busy corner of Fifth Avenue. It is almost impossible not to buy a bag, and sneak a couple of surreptitious samples on the way home.

It is with pleasure and profound gratitude that the peoples of North America turn away for a moment from troubled scenes elsewhere to rejoice in the harmony prevailing on this continent. President Truman's journey to Canada is a visit of the chosen head of one free people to another free people, for the purpose of giving visible expression to their mutual friendship and cementing their solidarity in the defense of the things they stand for.

Eitingon Plan to Be Approved Referee Irwin Kurtz yesterday stated that he will sign an order of approval for the reorganization plan of Motty Eitingon, Inc., following a hearing in the United States Court House. Referee Kurtz was advised during the hearing that sufficient consents to the plan by all classes of creditors had been filed and ruled that it is "fair and equitable" to all creditors.

Yesterday afternoon, on the eve of his departure for Paris, Charles James presented a collection of twenty models to the fashion press. He is taking the collection to Paris where he will exhibit it in the palace of Count Etienne de Beaumont.

CLEVELAND, June 11 (AP) -- Manager Joe Cronin used two of his front-line hurlers and his ace relief pitcher today and the trio came up with a six-hit shut-out over the Indians as the Red Sox triumphed, 3 to 0, for a sweep of the three-game series.
Yesterday was the hottest day of the year, with a temperature of 86 degrees recorded in the city at 4 P.M. It would have been hotter, the Weather Bureau said, but for sea breezes.

James Butler, president of the Empire City Racing Association, announced yesterday receipt of the entry of Marcel Boussac's 3-yearold French colt Djelal for the $100,000 added Empire Gold Cup race at Jamaica on July 19. Boussac is one of the best-known French horsemen.
LONDON, June 11 -- Laurence Olivier has been made a knight for his services to the stage and to the films, in the King's birthday honors' list published tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Dr. Karl T. Compton told the House Armed Services Committee that the President's Advisory Commission on Universal Training believed that a program based on only four months instead of six months of training would not be worth the effort or the cost.

Mandatory fair trade contracts in the sale of liquor and wine will be required in the State of New York as of Sept. 1, according to the new rules and regulations promulgated by the State Liquor Authority and announced yesterday by John F. O'Connell, chairman.

The largest audience at a New York University commencement was present yesterday on Ohio Field, University Heights, when 15,245 persons witnessed the bestowal of 5,643 degrees and certificates. The graduating class was the biggest in the history of the university.
LONDON, June 11 -- British Fascists attempting a post-war comeback are encountering surprising opposition to the brand of antiSemitism they have started preaching.

Following is the text of President Truman's address before a joint session of the Canadian Parliament yesterday in Ottawa, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES: Mr. Prime Minister, Honorable Members of the Senate, and Members of the House of Commons of Canada:

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Justice Alexander Holtzoff of United States District Court here was barred today from presiding at the conspiracy trial of sixteen board members of the Joint AntiFascist Refugee Committee.

CLEVELAND, June 11 -- Courtney Hodges, commanding general of the First Army, recommended tonight that the Compton Commission's report be read and studied by every American citizen who hoped to avert another world war.
Seward H. French Jr., Pittsburgh attorney, has been appointed assistant to the president of Crucible Steel Company of America, in charge of industrial relations.

GULLANE, Scotland, June 11 (AP) -- Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zaharias, the feminine golfing machine from Denver, Colo., drove and putted her way into the final of the British women's amateur golf championship today. She is a prime favorite to win the title for the United States for the first time tomorrow.

In its first change of ownership in thirty years, the property at 227-33 and 235-37 West Fortyeighth Street, west of Times Square, has been sold by the New York Society of the Methodist Church to Maxwell L. Low, operator, in a cash deal.

Increases in the basic monthly rent of apartments in the Stuyvesant Town and Riverton Houses developments of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company were approved tentatively yesterday at an executive meeting of the Board of Estimate.
Senator Robert F. Wagner forecast last night a veto of the TaftHartley Labor Bill and listed the reasons why President Truman would disapprove the legislation.

Total advertising outlay will equal or exceed the record $3,000,000,000 advertising investment for 1946, Printers' Ink predicts in today's issue. Based on national advertising indexes in the magazine, nothing short of a major economic disaster during the remainder of the year can depress the 1947 total of advertising below the level of 1946.

LOS ANGELES, June 11 -- The merchandising price problem is not a simple matter of price cutting, but calls for extensive "experimentation" by retailers to establish levels most acceptable to the public, Lew Hahn, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said today.

NORWALK, Conn., June 11 -- Henry A. Wallace predicted here tonight that the next extension of the Truman Doctrine would be to China. He said he understood that the extension of a loan of $500,000,000 to "the Kuomintang Government of China" was already under consideration.

LONDON, June 11 -- Scotland Yard, which has a post-war crime wave on its hands, had the added complication of an irritated Soviet Embassy to worry about tonight. The embassy has filed two formal protests with the British Foreign Office over burglaries on four occasions in London premises enjoying Russian diplomatic status.

WOOD-RIDGE, N.J., June 11 -- The Wright Aeronautical Corporation put into full operation here today a laboratory for the testing of the largest turbine-type aircraft engines known to be under practical development anywhere in the world.

The long-expected break-through was negotiated successfully yesterday by the stock market in the strongest surge of the year. The sharp rally encompassed every section of the list. High price issues advanced as much as 8 points, others showed increases up to 4, and the composite rate pushed ahead 2.33 points.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 11 -- More than a handout of dollars is needed to sell democracy to the world, Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll declared today at the 181st Rutgers University commencement. He called for a high level of industrial activity to avert economic depression and to make the free enterprise system work at home.

One-year-old Owen Kelly Jr. miraculously escaped serious injury yesterday afternoon as his carriage, in which he was strapped, turned over several times as it rolled 100 feet down a ravine with a fifty-degree grade in upper Manhattan. The baby suffered only a slight scratch of his forehead.

Diplomas were conferred yesterday upon 111 graduates at the eighty-eighth commencement of the New York Medical College, Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals, at the New York Academy of Medicine, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.

PARIS, Thursday, June 12 -- As a result of an agreement signed at 5 o'clock this morning the nation -wide strike that has tied up the whole French railway passenger network for the past five days was ordered ended, effective at 9 o'clock this morning.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Following is the text of the State Department's statement on the Bulgarian Government's arrest of Nikola Petkov, anti-Communist leader: The Yalta Declaration on liberated Europe clearly defined the responsibilities of the U.S.S.R., the United Kingdom and the United States to aid the peoples of the former Axis satellite states to solve by democratic means their pressing political and economic problems.
DETROIT, June 11 -- Two new strikes, one of them an alleged sitdown, occurred today to bring to more than 20,000 the number of idle automobile workers in the Detroit area.

Even in his days as Chief of Staff, Secretary Marshall probably never made a more earnest or imperative plea for a program than he did before the Senate Appropriations Committee in asking that at least $55,000,000 be restored of the $60,000,000 which the House has deleted from his budget.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- The law of averages caught up with Frank Shea at Comiskey Park today and the Naugatuck chucker crashed to defeat, his seven-game winning streak shattered as the Yankees bowed, 3 to 2, and fell one full game behind the league-leading Tigers.
Active trading continued yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and the futures market gained 5 to 42 points.
TOKYO, June 11 -- Out in the little farm villages of Japan, to borfow a phrase from the GI, "They never had it so good." They are "on the crest of the wave."

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 -- The anti-trust action filed against Pullman, Inc., in 1940 apparently entered its final phase today when a proposed agreement for the sale of its subsidiary, the Pullman Company, to fifty-three railroads for $40,202,482 was filed here in the Federal district court.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Representatives of shippers, water carriers and railroads appeared today before Commissioner J. Haden Alldredge of the Interstate Commerce Commission in the final stage of a hearing on competitive railroad and water carrier rates between the East and West Coasts.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Representative Herbert A. Meyer, Republican, of Kansas, called Henry A. Wallace today ''the evil tool of those who would destroy America," then he asked the House: "When will the Attorney General of the United States do his duty and indict this renegade ?"

LOS ANGELES, June 11 -- The Los Angeles Democratic Committee was in virtual revolt against the National Party organization today. It voted censure of President Truman last night, demanded the ouster of National Committeeman Edwin W. Pauley Jr. and impounded the profits of the local Jackson Day dinner because of alleged insults to Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt and her son, James, state party chairman.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Representative William Stratton of Illinois is to be congratulated for sponsoring a bill titled "Emergency Temporary Displaced Persons Admission Act," which is about to have a hearing before the House subcommittee on immigration.

Top management men can solve problems of recession by using new methods now available, more than 500 industrial executives concluded yesterday, following all day sessions of the annual conference on general management problems sponsored by the American Management Association; at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The extension of social security benefits to persons in all parts of the United States who are not included under the Federal Social Security Act was advocated yesterday by Gerard Swope, chairman of the National Health and Welfare Retirement Association, Inc.

The heavyweight elimination battle between Ezzard Charles of Cincinnati and Elmer (Violent) Ray, Hastings, Fla., originally slated for June 27, has been rescheduled for July 25 at Madison Square Garden, it was announced yesterday by the Twentieth Century Sporting Club.

The national banks of the United States retained during 1946 $323,000,000, or 66 per cent, of their total net profits, to add strength to their capital structures, according to the annual report of Carl K. Withers, president of the National Bank Division of the American Bankers Association, issued yesterday.

BERLIN, June 11 -- German business men in the economically merged United States and British zones will be permitted to correspond freely with foreign firms and to conclude deals by mail, starting June 15, it was disclosed today.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 11 -- The Soviet Union today called upon all United Nations members who still appy capital punishment to abolish this practice in peacetime.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The War Assets Administration tonight scaled down from $1,000,000 to $500,000 the amount it said it will charge Preston Tucker, automobile maker, for the first year's rental on the huge Chrysler-Dodge plant at Chicago.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Something new was added to the St. Lawrence Seaway debate today as opponents, once again mustering the old familiar arguments against the proposal, attacked it as setting up a prime target, impossible of defense in modern atomic warfare.
The State of Maryland announced yesterday that it would receive bids on June 23 on bond issues aggregating $9,625,000.

Cardinal Spellman accused Protestant groups yesterday of waging a crusade of bigotry against the Catholic Church in which the patriotism of Catholics is being impugned. It has resulted already, he reported, in increased tension between religious groups in rural communities.

Degrees in course were awarded yesterday to 501 seniors in graduate schools at Fordham University at the university's annual commencement exercises on the terrace in front of Keating Hall on the campus in Fordham. Four thousand persons attended the ceremonies.

Cash prizes totaling $650 have been awarded to professional and amateur designers in the fabric design competition sponsored by La France Industries, manufacturers of upholstery textiles, the company announced yesterday. The awards were given for modern upholstery and drapery fabric designs adaptable to power loom weaving.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 11 -- Universal-International has closed a preproduction deal for "The Survivors," a new play by Irwin Shaw and Peter Viertel, which covers post-Civil War events in Texas, drawing an allegorical parallel between that period and the present.

LONDON, June 11 -- Fending off a demand by women's organizations for equal pay for women, Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer, asserted in the House of Commons today that such a move now would have an inflationary effect on Great Britain's delicately balanced economy.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Congress was warned today that the emergency power of the Maritime Commission to operate ships must be extended forthwith if a world-wide crisis in shipping and petroleum distribution was to be averted.
Can This Be True? Now and then the pictures of the June weddings and the June college commencements in the paper suddenly lose their familiar, accepted character and become almost startling.

NOTTINGHAM, England, June 11 (Reuters) -- Dogged batting on a perfect wicket today saved England from defeat by South Africa in the first test cricket match of the season. The four-day game ended in a draw with the visitors 60 runs short of England's twoinnings total and with nine South African wickets to fall.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In implementing the resolution of the General Assembly of Dec. 11, 1946, the Secretary-General of the United Nations has submitted to the Committee on Codification of International Law a draft convention on the crime of genocide, which he prepared with the assistance of invited experts in international and criminal law.
