BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 11 -- The Ford Motor Company of Egypt has obtained a contract here for approximately $500,000 for the sale of cars, trucks, tractors and spare parts in 1947, Derek Walker, its representative, announced today.

BERLIN, June 11 -- The Russians have gained a significant and apparently final triumph in the Allied Control Council on the question whether any single occupying power has the right to veto a German election choice in Berlin, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The United States has sent to the Russian authorities in Budapest a stern and vigorous protest against the Communist coup in Hungary.

Real price reductions for most manufactured goods cannot be realized under existing conditions of high commodity and labor costs, Ernest R. Breech, vice-president of the Ford Motor Company, asserted yesterday. Increased efficiency of production, he said, by itself, might eventually bring the price of Ford cars to their 1941 price level, but it would take twenty years to do it.

KASTORIA, Western Macedonia, June 1 (Delayed) -- This Grecian town is within easy striking distance of North Albania and Yugoslavia. In the event of a formal invasion, it would be among the very first to fall.

Straying from the script, which had been accomplishing miracles recently, the Giants failed to stage their characteristically strong finish yesterday at the Polo Grounds and the series finale went to the Pirates, 8 -- 7. Three home runs, one by Johnny Mize and two by Willard Marshall, were wasted by the New Yorkers, whose four-game winning streak fell by the wayside before 13,272 fans.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 11 -- The statement of Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet representative, before the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission this morning: Almost a year and a half has passed since the adoption by the General Assembly of the resolution on the establishment of the Atomic Energy Commission.
At the annual commencement of the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn last night 341 degrees were conferred on graduating and graduate students.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 11 -- By continued experience in "working together" the United States and the Soviet Union can achieve the kind of understanding that eventually will make a thoroughly specific international bill of rights possible, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said here in an interview today.

DETROIT, June 11 (AP) -- The Athletics threw a 20 - year - old rookie surprise at the Tigers today to gain an even break in a doubleheader when Carl Scheib pitched a seven-hit 4-to-0 victory over the Bengals in the nightcap after Detroit had taken the first game, 7 to 1.

CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 6,000 head, total 8,000: market uneven but generally 25 to 50 cents higher: most advance on weights under 240 pounds: heavier weights and sows closing slow: top

SALT LAKE CITY, June 11 (AP) -- West Coast shipbuilders and labor representatives agreed yesterday on 13-cents-per-hour wage increases for mechanics and higher grades and what participants called the "equivalent" of a 10cents-per-hour increase for all lesser classifications.
BOSTON, June 11 (AP) -- The Cubs moved ahead of the Braves into third place in the National League today by twice defeating the Tribe, 4 -- 0 and 5 -- 2, before a paid crowd of 26,992.

Random notes. The New Jersey striped bass fishing seems rather spotty, with one beach producing good fishing one day and not a single fish on the next, although the surfcasters turn out in good numbers at most of the popular spots.
The dramatic possibilties of roses as a focal point in flower arrangements was demonstrated yesterday at the final session of THE NEW YORK TIMES rose show at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson denied today that rising meat prices were caused by meat exports. He charged the higher prices to "other factors," but did not specify what they were.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- A limited form of state option in a proposed Federal law to combat discrimination in employment was suggested today by Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican, of New Jersey.

Twelve persons, including several clerks in the Brooklyn office of the Department of Housing and Buildings, were questioned yesterday as the District Attorney of Kings County continued his investigation into charges of corruption in that department.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: President Truman is now being urged by many people to veto the tax reduction bill on the ground that it is necessary to reduce the national debt "in order to prevent inflation."

JERUSALEM June 11 -- Moshe Shertok, a member of the executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine who returned from New York two days ago, reported today that he had found in the United States a 'wave of shallow sympathy" for terrorism here.
LONDON, June 11 -- The best section in a generally dull stock market here today was the industrials, where some good dividend announcements stimulated business in selected issues.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, China, June 8 (Delayed) -- Experienced observers of the Manchurian scene foresee the day when China may well lose all of Manchuria unless early and sweeping changes in policy up here are made by Nanking.

Norman Brokenshire, one of the pioneer announcers, is the latest radio personage to be planning a local disk jockey program. Negotiations are on the verge of completion for his show to be carried from 12:30 to 12:55 P.M., Monday through Friday, over WNBC.
His words punctuated by sobs, a rape case defendant in Kings County Court confessed yesterday to his attack on the French bride of an Army lieutenant colonel.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial on the St. Lawrence Waterway developed an objective analysis of this important project. To the writer, one of America's landlocked millions, it furnishes a logical thesis for further study and action.

WILMINGTON, Ohio, June 11 -- A four-engined Army transport plane operating without a pilot at the controls landed at the Clinton County Airfield, Army Air Forces flying center here, at 3:50 P.M., Eastern standard time, today after a 2,000-mile non-stop flight from Long Beach, Calif.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 (AP) -- Brilliant relief pitching by Tommy Hughes and Schoolboy Rowe, coupled with a five-run attack off Howie Pollet in the first inning, gave the Phillies a 5-4 decision over the St. Louis Cardinals today.

A first mortgage loan of $150,000 at 4 per cent for ten years was made by the Dollar Savings Bank on the 5-story business building at 107-09 W 43d St. owned by Jonan Equities Inc. Eugene O Hussey was the broker. The same bank also made a first mortgage loan of $29,250 at 4 per cent on the 2-story garage structure at 502 River Ave, the Bronx, owned by F D M Inc.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The United States Forest Service disclosed today that it has taken the first concrete step toward promoting an Alaskan pulpwood and newsprint industry.

The Board of Transportation was accused yesterday by an American Federation of Labor spokesman of showing favoritism to the Transport Workers Union, CIO, with which the board had effected a truce on Tuesday, ending two weeks of subway slowdowns.

Security and disarmament are attainable within the present machinery of the United Nations, the Commission to Study the Organization of the Peace declared in a report made public yesterday. It offered a series of specific recommendations for coping with these twin problems without revising the United Nations Charter.

Serious doubt was cast yesterday on two hitherto held theories regarding the cause of the airplane crash at La Guardia Field on May 29 last that cost forty-two lives. The new uncertainties developed during the Civil Aeronautics Board's formal investigation at the Hotel Lexington into the tragedy.
ST. LOUIS, June 11 -- The stage is set once again for golf's premier event -- the national open championship over the billowy fairways of the St. Louis Country Club.

Mrs. Madge Tucker Miller, 42year-old radio producer of the American Broadcasting Company, was critically injured yesterday in her apartment at 41 West Fiftythird Street when she was struck on the head with a metal doorstop by a man who had got in on the pretense of washing her windows.

The Communist seizure of power in Hungary is hailed in certain quarters in this country as the Soviet answer to the Truman Doctrine. It is obviously intended by the Moscow Government as an answer, and especially that it should be interpreted as such by the opponents of the Truman policy in the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- A new setback to the American Government's efforts at Geneva for worldwide removal of national trade barriers developed today as Senate and House conferees broke a two-week deadlock over proposals for an increased tariff on wool.

PARIS, June 11 -- In a move to check unrest such as flared into open conflict in Indo-China and Madagascar, a report recommending greater participation by natives in the French colonial governments was adopted today by the National Assembly's Commission on Overseas Territories.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 11 -- The Soviet Union's acceptance of international atomic inspection last autumn was reaffirmed and elaborated today by Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, at a special meeting of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission.

Restitution of $124,100 in cash, furs and jewels, was made yesterday to the Mergenthaler Linotype Company of Brooklyn at Police Headquarters, 400 Broome Street. Part of the loot was recovered from the Freeport, L.I., home and safety deposit boxes of W. Arthur Nickel, confessed embezzler awaiting sentence for taking $775,516 from the Mergenthaler company, where he had been a bookkeeper.

VIENNA, June 11 -- The Austrian Treaty Commission may be able this week finally to get to work on its assigned task of investigating on-the-spot property problems connected with the Austrian treaty, the American member, Joseph M. Dodge, indicated today.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 11 -- The borrowed putter that could not miss while he was winning the British amateur championship played Willie Turnesa false today. As a result, he tied for fifth place in attempting to repeat his 1946 victory in the William Rice Hochster Memorial Tournament at Quaker Ridge.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

William H. Davis, former member of the Board of Transportation, suggested last night that the subway system be taken "out of the red" by transferring subway construction costs and debt service to the city and raising the subway fare just enough to cover operating and maintenance expenses.

Jackie Robinson yesterday had his greatest day at bat since he joined the Dodgers, with a triple, a double and a pair of singles at Ebbets Field, but his team-mates cooperation was something short of perfect. So the Dodgers lost, 5 -- 4, to the Reds, who took the series, three games to one.

World Bank Politics The disclosure by the World Bank's president, John J. McCloy, that political conditions, affecting the economic status of prospective borrowing nations, are within the scope of inquiry by the bank's fact-finding missions abroad, was received here yesterday as a forthright recognition of the realities of the situation.

DETROIT, Mich., June 11 -- The international executive board of the American Federation of Musicians, of which James C. Petrillo is president, received full authority today to halt the manufacture of recordings and transcriptions after Dec. 31.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Warning that a business slump would send many new small enterprises "to the wall," the Committee for Economic Development urged in a report today the establishment of a new system of capital banks chartered under the Federal Reserve to supply the financing requirements of small businesses.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- Hedge pressure and local selling on the bearish June crop estimate caused further weakness in wheat futures at all markets today. The market on the Board of Trade showed a rallying tendency at times on the strength in coarse grains, but the upturns failed to hold.
JERUSALEM, June 11 -- The Palestine Government appeared tonight to be restoring a degree of the wartime recognition that it gave Haganah as that Jewish community's official defense force.

A proposal by Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, to construct a general-purpose roadway through Van Cortlandt Park as a one-mile link in the $30,000,000 Major Deegan Expressway project in the Bronx, ran into vigorous opposition yesterday at a meeting of the City Planning Commission.

OTTAWA, June 11 -- In an unscheduled, unprepared speech at a luncheon given by the Canadian Government and attended by all members of both Houses of Parliament, President Truman put his seal on this first state visit of a United States President to the Canadian capital as far greater in human portent than an official act.

While in the city employ, Elmer Haslett, suspended director of airports, helped subordinates of Milton N. Weir, Gulf Oil Company executive, in preparing late in 1944 a private proposal for a concession at Westchester County Airport. William A. Washburne Jr., former Gulf-representative, testified yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson in a sudden move late today ended household and institutinal sugar rationing effective at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow. Rationing to industrial users of sugar continues and price controls on sugar and related products are not affected by the order.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 -- Clamping down oh the registration statement filed last month by the Tucker Corporation of Chicago, the Securities and Exchange Commission declared today that the document omits essential information and appears to include "untrue statements of material facts."

VIENNA, June 11 -- Chancellor Leopold Figl was publicly charged by an Austrian Socialist party spokesman in Parliament today with negotiations with the Communists that could have brought Hungary's fate to Austria.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 11 -- Alexander K. Helm, British Minister -designate to Hungary, called today on the new Hungarian Premier, Lajos Dinnyes, and presented a statement in connection with the recent change of government.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 11 (AP) -- An American veteran of D-Day, listed as killed in action in Normandy almost three years ago, has been found working as a blacksmith in a little Normandy village, the Army announced today.

MINDEN, Germany, June 11 -- Some bizarre aspects of the law covering the Control Commission's personnel and their families were bared today as the Military Government opened the first case in which high-ranking British control officials are charged side by side with Germans for alleged illegal dealings in silver and cutlery sets.

Effective progress is being made in school-community projects for relieving racial and group tensions, the Superintendent of Schools' Advisory Committee on Human Relations reported yesterday. It warned, however, that a lack of responsible leadership in local communities would limit the effectiveness of the public schools' contribution to such projects.

Five station wagons, loaded with forty-five vacationists, left the Lighthouse for the Blind, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street, at 9:30 A.M. yesterday bound for River Lighthouse at Cornwall-on-theHudson. Women from 42 to 81 years of age composed this first contingent of the 500 blind persons for whom the Lighthouse will furnish free fresh air vacations this summer.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 11 -- Radioactive sodium atoms produced in the atomic energy pile at Oak Ridge, Tenn., have led to the elucidation of a fundamental mechanism in congestive heart failure which promises to save more lives in the next few years than were killed by the atomic bomb in Japan.

The nation's crude oil production last week reached a new peak of 5,064,200 barrels daily, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This represented an increase of 39,850 barrels daily over the previous week. It was the fifth successive week when production has exceeded the 5,000,000-barrel daily mark.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- For years no people in history have been more steadily "warned" than the Americans. In the late Twenties this became a habit among public men and publicists, the particular warning being that we were headed for the crash and depression that followed.

PARIS, June 11 (NANA) -- Details have just come to light of a secret arrangement that permits Mme. Darlan, widow of assassinated Admiral Jean Francois Darlan, head of the French state in North Africa following the Allied invasion, to live in the United States with a considerable fortune.

LONDON, June 11 -- Some plan for bringing United States imports into balance with its export trade must be found or the world will face conditions more chaotic than in interwar years, Sir Stafford Cripps, President of Britain's Board of Trade, said today.

NANKING, June 11 (AP) -- The Chinese Government instructed its Ambassador in Moscow today to protest to both the Soviet Government and the Outer Mongolian Minister there over alleged violation of the border in remote Sinkiang Province of China.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- An estimate that gross national production will reach $172,000,000,000 in 1950 was made today by H.B. McCoy of the Department of Commerce.

NANKING, June 12 (AP) -- Chinese defenders of Sinkiang, beating back invading Outer Mongolian troops, have been bombed and strafed for three days by planes with Soviet emblems, the Central News Agency said today.

NEWTON, Mass., June 12 (AP) -- Miss Maureen Orcutt of Haworth, N.J., gained her sixth women's eastern golf championship since 1925 by shooting a two-over-par 77 for a 54-hole total of 234 today at the Brae Burn Country Club.

The sharp rise on the stock market on Wednesday invited moderate profit-taking yesterday. Despite a slight decline in the price index due to realizing in certain key industrials, the list managed to end on the higher side, with 449 of the 989 issues dealt in closed with gains, while 326 showed losses.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The State Department's International information and educational exchange program appeared to move toward safe ground in the House today, despite continued determined opposition and threats of further delaying tactics.

Calico From Golconda It is not quite clear from the available pictures of the late Maharajah Sir Umaid Singh of Jodhpur whether his full dress uniform includes the European military garb or the riding clothes to which his country has given its name.

Somebody should have warned the British about Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias, the Texas tomboy whose Amazonian feats have been amazing Americans for the past fifteen years and yesterday brought her the British women's amateur golf championship.

A field of forty-five, headed by Robert L. Riggs of California, was drawn, for play yesterday in the national professional tennis championships, which start Monday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

ST. LOUIS, June 12 -- Predictions that a new low scoring record would be set in the forty-seventh National Open golf championship appeared to be justified today when three players were tied with 67s at the end of the opening 18-hole round of the 72-hole tourney at the St. Louis Country Club.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 12 -- The Georgia Supreme Court today ordered dismissal of involuntary manslaughter indictments against operators of the Winecoff Hotel, where 119 persons lost their lives last December, in the worst hotel fire disaster in the nation's history.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Senator Claude Pepper, Democrat, of Florida, asserted today that there were indications of a "widespread" design by employers to "lock out hundreds of thousands of workers in an effort to make it appear that there is a general strike against Congress."
LONDON, June 12 -- Fresh uneasiness over the international situation restricted business in the stock markets here today and as a result most sections were dull. Price changes, however, were small.

YONKERS, N. Y., June 12 -- Miss Marie Martin of Apawamis won low gross honors in the one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association at the Hudson River Country Club today after matching cards following a four-player deadlock at 85.

Exactly twenty-five hours after Mrs. Madge Tucker Miller, radio producer, had been critically injured and robbed in her one and one-half room, apartment at 41 West Fifty-third Street, the police arrested yesterday a 46-year-old Harlem, handyman who admitted the crime.

OTTAWA, June 12 -- President Truman extended and clarified his foreign policy today to say that the United States wanted only peace in the world and friendship with every nation in it. He told reporters to underline the word "every" in recording what he had to say.
MUNICH, June 12 -- Bavarian teachers may again whip naughty elementary-school boys.
The 10,000-ton liner Ancon, famous as a command and communication ship in the war, arrived in New York last night after a complete rebuilding and reconversion for peacetime trade.

MADRID, June 12 -- The world's most powerful commercial radio station, already under construction on the Spanish African island of Fernando Po, will be used largely for advertising and one beam will be directed to the United States, it was revealed today.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall said today he was fearful that the Senate-House conference compromise on tariff phases of the wool price support bill might seriously disrupt the international trade program being advanced at Geneva.
The temperature mounted to 87.1 degrees at 4:40 P.M. yesterday, making June 12 the hottest day of the year.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., June 12 -- Mike Cestone, four times runner-up in the tourney, fired an even par 72 to take the medal in the qualifying round of the New Jersey State Golf Association amateur championship at the Ridgewood Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- An on-the-spot Senatorial investigation of the current Mississippi and Missouri River floods, intended to produce a national plan to keep them down in the future, was proposed today by Senator James E, Murray, Democrat, of Montana.

As autobiography, which it just lolls short of being, Herbert Read's "The Innocent Eye"* is austere fare, spare, formal and abstract. But as an introduction to a brilliant writer and an extraordinarily provocative mind it is exceedingly stimulating. Mr. Read has the rare faculty of being able to write with the sensitive felicity of a poet, which he is, and with the contagious enthusiasm for ideas of an original thinker, which he is, too.

Steps which are succeeding in preventing interruptions in mass production in the United States Steel Corporation and in the General Motors Corporation were described to more than 600 members of the American Management Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

The latest statement of Mr. Gromyko regarding Russia's position on control of the atomic bomb has been welcomed by Mr. Austin, the American representative, as a "step forward." But it is a step forward only in so far as it replaces a hitherto purely negative position with a clearer exposition of the Russian point of view.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- A special tax study committee of private citizens, created to advise the House Ways and Means Committee in the preparation of a general tax revision bill for 1948, held its organization meeting here today to the accompaniment of vehement protests by three Democratic Representatives.

LINDEN, N. J., June 12 -- A Huge, expansion program for the Bayway Refinery of the Standard Oil Company here, designed to meet increased production demands and to effect further quality improvements, was announced today by Donald L. Ferguson, New Jersey works manager of the company.

Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said yesterday that the inflationary pressure of increased money supplies is being met through the increasing curb of expansion of credit.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 12 -- New Jersey's first constitutional convention in 103 years, assembled today in the gymnasium of Rutgers University, heard Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll make a plea for a modern document that would be free from all legislative detail but still tuned to, modern governmental demands.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Congress received word today that President Truman wants it to approve a bill permitting the Government to continue controls on retail installment buying to guard against "economic instability, reduced production and unemployment."

Russian children have received "friendship boxes" sent by American children and have read with interest the letters that accompanied them, Mme. Andrei Gromyko, wife of the representative of the U.S.S.R. to the United Nations, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 12 --The United States Atomic Energy Commission, it was learned today, has rejected requests for isotopes from twenty nations until the day when its production more nearly satisfies American demands and until knotty legal problems are worked out.
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 12 -- in another Russian attack on the Truman Doctrine, White Russia proposed today that all requests for assistance be made through the United Nations.

The Board of Estimate granted yesterday the application of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for increases in the monthly rents to be charged for apartments in its Stuyvesant Town and Riverton Houses developments in Manhattan.

NEW DELHI, India, June 12 -- The status of the Princely States in independent India has engaged considerable attention throughout this country since the British Government anonunced its plan for Hindustan and Pakistan.
DETROIT, June 12 -- The American Federation of Musicians of the American Federation of Labor adopted today a resolution banning all members who are convicted of carrying or using narcotic drugs.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 12 -- Robinson Murray of Westchester Hills, who lost a play-off for the Westchester Seniors' Golf Association championship to John Taylor of Siwanoy last fall, was the only player in a field of 102 in the association's annual spring tournament at Knollwood Country Club today to better 80, and won top honors with a steady 41, 38 -- 79.

Mayor O'Dwyer's announcement on the subject of a possible referendum on a higher transit fare, tentative and qualified though, it is, suggests that he may be facing this city's financial problems with more realism than he was last winter. He is apparently beginning to see the relation between the heavy burden of transit deficit and the maintenance of other essential city services.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The automobile industry asked Congress today to repeal automotive excise taxes, declaring they are "a cruel burden of taxation" on more than 30,000,000 motor vehicle operators.
LONDON, June 12 -- It was the King's birthday celebration but it was Princess Elizabeth who stole the show today at the first Trooping the Color ceremony since 1939.

The New York Telephone Company's application to the Public Service Commission for permission to issue $125,000,000 of thirty-fiveyear debentures was refused yesterday on the ground that it "does not conform to the standards set up in numerous other cases."

NEW ORLEANS, La., June 12 -- With six Gubernatorial candidacies already announced, the electorate of this state are now witnessing campaign skirmishes that indicate a primary battle next January involving every shade of political turbulence that has marked recent Louisiana history.

One of the appeals for contributions currently before the public is that of the Protestant Fund of Greater New York, Inc., of 57 William Street, New York 5, which at the moment is seeking $1,095,000 to meet the demands for increased religious, educational and welfare services in the city.

DETROIT, June 12 (AP) -- The Packard Motor Car Company announced tonight a flat general wage increase of 15 cents an hour for its production workers linked with an agreement for dismissal of 545,000,000 in back pay claims.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Continued advances in prices of agricultural commodities raised average primary market prices 0.3 percent during the week ended on June 7, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Non-agricultural prices declined slightly.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 12 -- The Soviet Union strongly attacked today an Australian proposal to set up an international court of human relations to hear complaints of violations of individual liberties.
PASADENA, Calif., June 12 -- New rocket fuels or propellants much more powerful than any now in use are being developed by the California Institute of Technology here.

TOKYO, June 12 -- In an interview at headquarters of the American Military Government in Hokkaido, at Which this correspondent was present, Toshifumi Tanaka told Lieut. Gen. Robert L. Eichelberger that he knew of no Japanese repatriates from the Russianoccupied zone who owed allegiance to any country other than their own.

Once more the week-end fishing possibilities rest in the lap of the weather man, who, in the light of recent bad guesses on the holiday weather, is inclined to make a somewhat Delphic forecast. In other words, he insists it will be clear provided there is no rain.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on June 7 were 900,747 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 12 -- In the boldest speech heard in the Budapest Parliament since the city was liberated more than two years ago, Becso Sulyok, leader of the Right-Wing Liberty party, said Hungary had become a police state in which the wildest terror raged and a net of spies made public or private freedom impossible.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today announced new allocations of natural gas supplies provided fry the Texas Eastern Transmission Company, to the Appalachian area from the "Big" and "Little Big Inch" pipelines for the period from June 17 to Nov. 1.

Despite the easing of the tight money market situation this week, the relief is expected to be temporary, according to the statement of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System, issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The Senate Commerce Committee today ordered a subcomitte to re-draft a measure by Senstor Capper, Republican, of Kansas, which would prohibit liquor advertising from, crossing state, lines in any form Chairman White, Republican, of Maine, told reporters that Constitutional questions, including possible infringement on freedom of the press, had been cited in committee discussion of the Capper measure.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Lifting of sugar rationing was quickly followed today by indications that a new permanent quota system might be quickly enacted at this session of Congress.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- Unlimited opportunities for expansion of the radio industry exist in the fields of television and FM broadcasting, industrial electronics and foreign trade, Brigadier General David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, declared tpnight.

ALBANY, June 12 -- In the belief that New York may face next winter an "even more serious" shortage of gas than that experienced last winter, the Public Service Commission has urged the Federal Power Commission to deny requests for additional natural gas from "Big Inch" and "Little Big Inch" pipe-lines where it may be used for industrial purposes.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The International Emergency Children's Fund of the United Nations will receive $1,229,240.61 earned during the war by conscientious objectors in the United States, if a bill considered by the House Armed Services committee today becomes law.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, asserted today that a slash of 28 per cent in funds for his department, which the House has approved, would be false economy in many instances.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- A bill to provide for the daily establishment of official exchange rates on fluctuating foreign currencies for purposes of customs assessments was introduced in the House today by Representative Robert W. Kean, Republican, of New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- A Port of New York Authority spokesman warned a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee today that the port would lose one-sixth of its foreign commerce, with resultant large-scale unemployment, if the St. Lawrence Seaway were built.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 12 -- Yale virtually clinched its second successive Eastern Intercollegiate League championship by conquering Princeton, 7 -- 3, in the 201st contest of collegiate baseball's oldest rivalry at Yale Field today.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, June 11 (Delayed) -- The isolation of the eleven Americans in Changchun, so far as overland communications are concerned, can be appreciated only after flying over the 160-mile stretch of demolished railway that formerly linked the major cities of central Manchuria.

LONG BEACH, Calif., June 12 (AP) -- Benjamin V. Cohen, State Department counselor, said today that Europe might need from $15,000,000,000 to $24,000,000,000 in outside assistance during the next three or four years to halt starvation and check the "danger of dictatorships."
LIKE the weather, the pennant races are getting hotter and hotter. There will be another fortnight of East-West series starting today, but with a change in scenery.

The expiration tomorrow at midnight of the contract of the Marine Cooks and Stewards, CIO, with the Pacific American Shipowners Association will affect all maritime unions affiliated with the CIO Maritime Committee and will "inevitably result in a nation-wide shipping tie-up," it was disclosed last night.

Commercial Paper Reflecting a seasonal decline, the volume of open-market commercial paper outstanding on May 29 was slightly below the level at the close of the previous month but nearly double the volume of a year ago, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Three hundred and ninety graduates, the largest group in this week's commencement exercises at St. John's University, Brooklyn, received their diplomas yesterday from the Rev. Dr. Thomas F. Flynn, acting president of the university. Graduates of the College of Pharmacy and the Schools of Commerce and Law participated.

The number of Roman Catholics in the United States, Alaska and Hawaii has reached 25,268,173, according to the official Catholic directory for 1947, just published by P.J. Kenedy Sons. It is the 125th printing, the first having been brought out in 1822 by another publisher.

These prices result from a spot check of independent and chain stores in leading shopping centers of this city, and are reported by the Department of Markets. Asterisks indicate particularly good purchases in fresh produce.

The Music Education League presented the older and more advanced winners of its auditions this season in a concert last night at Town Hall. A feature of the program was a competition by four adult vocalists for the award of an appearance next April with an orchestra at Town Hall.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned slightly easier yesterday and closed 24 points lower to 15 points net higher.

Two members of the Police Department and two women who attained summa cum laude were among 109 men and women who had degrees conferred on them by the Brooklyn Law School at the annual commencement exercises held last night in the school's auditorium, 375 Pearl Street.

Despite China's terrible ordeal of eight years of war, internal dissension and confusions indescribable, the Institute for Research in Chinese Architecture has managed to continue its work. Not only has it continued its work, it has made remarkable discoveries in many of the very provinces where fighting is reported almost daily in the headlines.

The reorganization of National Guard units throughout the nation should be conducted "in a realistic way" to insure national defense against modern weapons of war, Maj. Gen. Cornelius W. Wickersham, commanding general of National Guard forces "in the metro politan area, declared yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, June 12 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs tonight spoiled Pittsburgh's hopes for a winning streak on its home grounds after a disastrous road trip, administering a 7-3 defeat in which a succession of Pirate pitchers failed to hold the visitors in line to the disappointment of 32,132 fans.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Argument before the Interstate Commerce Commission today on the matter of competitive rail and water rates between the East, West and Gulf coasts disclosed that eight of ten ship lines in the intercoastal business have applied to the Maritime Commission for charters to operate in that trade until Dec. 31.

The Columbia Broadcasting System is modifying its ban on the use of transcriptions on the network, a move which could have far-reaching effects in broadcasting. Sponsors and advertising agencies are scheduled to be notified today that hereafter CBS will permit use of transcriptions in repeating for West Coast listeners a program heard "live" in the East earlier in the evening.

AUCKLAND, N. Z., Friday, June 13 (Canadian Press) -- A secret weapon that may play a vital part in world affairs because it is so powerful that it is said to have capabilities approaching the atomic bomb in effectiveness, is reported to have been developed in New Zealand.

If it develops that there is a nickel world series next October, the Giants will have good reason to respect the Yankees. In the opener of the two-of-three-game intracity exhibition series for the Mayor William O'Dwyer Trophy at the Polo Grounds last night, the second-place American Leaguers handed the National League leaders a 7-0 pasting.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 -- The United Corporation applied today to the Securities and Exchange Commission for authority to redeem its outstanding 1,136,199 1/6 shares of $3 cumulative preference stock by payment to holders of such stock of a package of securities of the corporation's statutory subsidiaries.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 12 -- A trend toward "keeping the ships rolling" was reported this evening by Vincent J. Malone, president of the Independent Marine Firemen, Oilers and Watertenders. A vote is being taken by his union on the question of extending the present contract with shipowners from June 15 to Sept. 20, 1948.

Charley Fusari, the undefeated welterweight from Irvington, N. J., will fight Tony Pellone of Greenwich Village in the main event at Madison Square Garden tonight The bout has caught on with the local fans, and the promoters are confident that a crowd of close to 15,000 will be ond hand to see the rivals travel over the ten-round route.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Weekly sales of department stores were up 7 per cent for the week ended June 7 compared to the corresponding period last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Percentage changes from like periods of a year ago are indicated in the following tabulation:
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- During the week ended June 11, member bank reserve balances increased $107,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 12 -- United Nations investigators are preparing to bring Bulgaria before the Security Council to answer charges that she refused to cooperate fully with a subsidiary group left behind in the Balkans to keep an eye on border trouble, it was reported today.

It wasn't a walkover, but it amounted to that as Kent Miller's pair of War Battle and Copper Beech hedge-hopped their way to both the first and second shares of the $10,000 added purse in the Hitchcock Steeplechase Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.
SUCHOW, China, June 11 (Delayed) -- Government and Communist troops have battled each other into a stalemate in central Shantung.

Forty music boxes are tinkling at the Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center. One that will delight young people is a monkey that strums a guitar and wobbles its head to the strains of a lively tune. The instruments date back to 1762.

Detectives Samuel Bress and James Costello of the West Fortyseventh Street Station, doing voluntary extra patrol early yesterday morning, chalked up four arrests. They booked two men on violation of the Sullivan Law and implicated two youths in a burglary and twenty hold-ups in the Chalsea section.

JERUSALEM, June 12 -- The United States Government is making informal inquiries at the Jewish Agency for Palestine to determine the exact Zionist attitude on Palestine's future, it was learned reliably today.

Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday that he is now disposed to favor a fare rise on the city's unified transit lines. but only to the extent required to meet operating deficits, leaving the annual burden of $57,000,000 in debt service deficit to be borne entirely by real estate.

Woolen Goods Output Sold Production of the American Woolen Company's Assabet and Brown mills, which make woolen goods, has been completely sold through September, it was announced yesterday. Assabet is the world's largest woolen mill.

A first mortgage loan of $575,000 has been placed on the nineteenstory apartment house at 315 Riverside Drive, southeast corner of 104th Street, for the A. C. H. M. Hall Realty Company, owners of the property since 1929. The building occupies a plot 86 by 100 feet.

LINCOLNDALE, N.Y., June 12 -- Dr. Emily Hickman, noted historian and worker for world peace, was killed this morning when her automobile plunged into Amawalk Reservoir between here and Somers, N.Y. She was 66 years old.

The foreign market which has been booming for the American business man and farmer is one supported mainly by the United States Government, it was pointed out last night by Willard L. Thorp, Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs.

The Brooklyn Round Table of the National Conference of Christians and Jews paid tribute yesterday to Bernard M. Baruch because of his contribution to the solution of "problems consistent with the great moral principles and spiritual values" of Judaism and Christianity.

A delegation representing retail butchers and meat cutters throughout the metropolitan area visited City Hall yesterday to demand immediate action by Mayor O'Dwyer on the problem of spiraling meat prices.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- All grain futures finished sharply lower today on the Board of Trade, after sharp advances which had lifted new crop corn of all deliveries to new high marks. The declines in the coarse grains appeared to be of a technical character, as there was no change in the news.

VIENNA, June 12 -- Joseph M. Dodge, United States delegate to the Austrian Treaty Commission, charged at today's meeting that the Soviet representative was demanding a veto over the German property cases to be considerd by the commission, the concrete facts to be admitted for consideration and the order of discussion.

Closing down at the Biltmore on June 21 will be "The Whole World Over." The final performance will mark the 100th showing. Purporting to be a commentary on the post-war housing situation in Moscow, the comedy was freely adapted by Thelma Schnee from the Russian of Konstantine Simonov.

A kinkajou -- a honey bear originating in Central and South America -- bit through a cookie holding the two ends of a white ribbon drawn across the entrance to the new Monkeys and Small Mammals house in the Bronx Zoo and formally opened the exhibit yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Italian Government, through Ivan Matteo Lombardo, chief of its financial mission in this country, has notified the State Department of its intention to resume payment on and ultimately, to honor the face amount of $105,000,000 of Fascist Government bonds floated in this country before the war.

MINEOLA, L. I., June 12 -- J. Russel Sprague, Republican National Committeeman from New York, in effect tossed Governor Dewey's hat into the Presidential ring this afternoon, introducing him at a Nassau County Republican luncheon at Jones Beach as "the next President of the United States."

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 12 -- Measures for reducing the death rate from cancer of the stomach, which kills annually more people than cancer of any other organ and is responsible for one-fifth of all cancer deaths, were outlined here today at the scientific sessions of the centennial meeting of the American Medical Association.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, June 12 (AP) -- The Communists have extended their purge in Bulgaria with the ousting from the National Assembly last night of twenty-three Opposition Agrarians on charges that the legislators were "tools" of the jailed Nikola Petkov, general secretary of the Agrarian party.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Maj. Gen. Lowell W. Rooks, director general of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, today answered charges made against UNRRA personnel in a letter from David Martin, secretary of the Refugee Defense Committee.

STOCKHOLM, June 12 -- Helsinki has a strong claim as venue for the 1952 Olympic Games as the city that made all preparations for the cancelled 1940 games, said Avery Brundage of Chicago, chairman of the International Olympic Committee, on his arrival today.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Democratic National Committee, officially silent on the serious split within the party in California which flared into the open in the last few days, is hoping to heal the breach when state leaders come here for a conference June 26.
The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it would offer at competitive sale June 20 an issue of $1,475,000 of notes dated June 1 and due Sept. 1.

James A. Farley, ending his long silence on the reasons for his break with the late Franklin D. Roosevelt, in the first of a series of articles in the current issue of Collier's, lists five events which took place in 1936 and during Mr.Roosevelt's second term as President which led to a gradual estrangement.

It was a foregone conclusion when Mrs. George Zaharias entered the British Women's Golf Championship that she would win it, thereby doing what no other American woman golfer had been able to accomplish. The American sports writers were unanimous in that opinion when she announced her intention to compete.

PARIS, June 12 -- Trains that had stood still for five days began to move again today as a result of the agreement signed at dawn, and by noon, the great Parisian stations had reacquired an air of normality.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Senator's contention that the South has "taken care" of Negroes better than other parts of the country drew the comment today from Dr. Stephen S. Wise that "people don't want to be taken care of in a democracy. They want a right to shape their own lives."

KOZANI, Western Macedonia, June 2 (Delayed) -- It was just after the evening ceremony of lowering the colors in front of divisional headquarters here that this writer asked the brigadier for permission to interview some of the guerrilla fighters who recently had surrendered.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Out of the West, this time from California, has come another of those factual analyses of political action which are at once a guide for experts and a diversion for laymen. It is a book titled "They Voted for. Roosevelt" (Stanford University Press, $3), by Dr. Edgar Eugene Robinson, a Professor of American History at Stanford, and in comment and statistical matter the study is illuminating.

A great many persons must nave been surprised yesterday to read the testimony of Secretary of State Marshall and Under-Secretary Clayton that a shipping crisis was in sight. During the war we spent more than $22,500,000,000 to assemble, mainly by new construction, a merchant fleet of 4,221 vessels with a deadweight tonnage of 44,940,000.

An unusually diversified collection of upholstered furniture, plus an assortment on occasional tables to accompany them, was presented yesterday by the Valley Upholstery Corporation in its showroom for decorators at 428 West Fourteenth Street.

Spokesmen for an American Federation of Labor local and an unaffiliated union, who were heard yesterday by the Board of Transportation, expressed conflicting views on the Davis labor plan but were in agreement that the board's present relations with the city's transit workers were unsatisfactory.

A revision of the regulations of the State Banking Board mostly terminating war emergency powers, has been completed and a new printing of the requirements will be distributed soon to all banking institutions concerned Elliott V. Bell, Superintendent of Banks, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The Treasury, moving to trim the $5,000,000,000-a-year interest on the national debt, took steps today to retire the bonds that pay the highest interest rate.Secretary Snyder called for cash redemption on Oct. 15 the whole of a $758,945,800 issue of 441/4/ per cent Treasury bonds of 1947-52 which were issued in October, 1922.

CINCINNATI, June 12 (AP) -- Kent Peterson, rookie southpaw, held the St. Louis Cardinals to five scattered hits as the Cincinnati Reds defeated the staggering world champions, 1 -- 0, before 27,075 fans tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Chairman J. Parnell Thomas, Republican, of New Jersey, of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, reported today that an amateur poet had marked him for sudden death.
To the editor of the new york times: The "Topics of The Times" of May 30 challenges the accuracy of the CIO's report on unemployment, which places the current figure for New York City at 450,000.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The institution of an additional tariff on raw wool may have serious consequences far surpassing the limits of the domestic raw wool industry itself. It will simply imply that negotiations for concessions entered into by our delegates at Geneva will not be supported by Congress.

GULLANE, Scotland, June 12 -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias hitched up her faded blue corduroy slacks after lunch today and slapped out a 5-and-4 victory over London's Miss Jacqueline Gordon. This feat made the Texas tomboy the first American-born golfer ever to win the woman's British crown.

The Duke of Edinburgh Stradivarius violin, so called because it once belonged to Queen Victoria's son, was found yesterday in the shop of the Century Pawn Brokers, 725 Eighth Avenue. It had been pawned there June 5 for $30.

A small, neat apartment was ready yesterday in one of the small, neat old tenements of East Eightieth Street -- ready for the return of a mother and daughter whose home was saved for them through the spontaneous kindness of their neighbors.

The story of the United Air Lines wreck that cost forty-two lives near La Guardia Field on May 29 was told yesterday by the surviving pilot, Capt. Benton (Lucky) Baldwin, before an inquiry by the Civil Aeronautics Board in the Lexington Hotel.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a London dispatch published in the May 27 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES there was an account of the new Soviet decree abolishing the death penalty in peacetime. Unfortunately, this dispatch conveyed an incorrect impression of the legislation affecting minors prior to this new decree.

Adaptations of the operas "La Boheme" and "Faust" will be filmed in English in Rome by the independent producer, Gregor Rabinovitch, in association with Columbia International, it became known yesterday. Mr. Rabinovitch will leave for Italy on Wednesday with the singing-acting husband and wife team of Jan Kiepura and Marta Eggerth, who will star in "La Boheme."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 12 -- Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, insisted today there was a possibility that an international atomic agreement could be reached on the basis of the divirgent Soviet and United States proposals.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 12 -- Samuel Goldwyn today completed casting the major roles for "That's Life," his new Danny Kaye comedy, which Howard Hawks will direct starting next week. Appearing with Kaye as college professors in the film will be Felix Bressart, Benny Goodman, J. Edward Bromberg, Hugh Herbert and Ludwig Stossel.

A fashion fair of a new type was opened to the public yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden, entrance on West Forty-ninth Street. It combines static and animated shows, with costumes and accessories exhibited in smart settings on display models and on living manikins.

The Gulf Oil Company was under no obligation to buy back the stock of North American Airport Corporation with a $49,000 profit to Elmer Haslett, suspended city airports director, until Mr. Haslett fulfilled the condition of leaving the city employ, Edward C. Rowe, a lawyer retained by Gulf to organize the company, testified yesterday.

BERLIN, June 11 (Delayed) -- The American and British Military Governments, which long ago publicly announced their intention of raising the level of industry for their two zones in the absence of a four-power agreement for economic unification, have failed to agree on a formula for carrying out this action, Gen. Lucius D. Clay disclosed today.

TOKYO, June 12 -- The dissolution of Japan's Zaibatsu, or family holding companies, is now virtually complete, and occupation officials are moving into the next phase of their battle against cartelization. This will entail breaking up and reorganizing the Zaibatsu -like corporations of smaller size.
LONDON, June 12 -- The British Government returned today to its charges against Moscow for refusing to furnish information about the political crisis in Hungary.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- President Truman and Secretary of State Marshall have authorized Under-Secretary of State William L. Clayton to explore in Europe the possibilities of developing a program of unified self-aid among the European states.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 -- In briefs filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Globe Aircraft Corporation of Fort Worth. Tex., and the underwriting concern of Newburger Hano, through their counsel, denied a charge made by an SEC trial examiner that the company made untrue statements in a stock registration filed in March, 1946.
Three preventive measures to curb juvenile delinquency were proposed yesterday by the directors of the Youth Counsel Bureau of the District Attorney's office at their annual meeting.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- Jay N. Emerson, president of Kiwanis International and prominent West Coast business executive, died today of a heart attack while driving from his home at Pullman, Wash, to his office at Spokane, the organization's headquarters announced here.
LONDON, June 12 -- The British Government returned today to its charges against Moscow for refusing to furnish information about the political crisis in Hungary.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- President Truman and Secretary of State Marshall have authorized Under-Secretary of State William L. Clayton to explore in Europe the possibilities of developing a program of unified self-aid among the European states.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 13 -- My Bill, 5-year-old chestnut gelding owned and ridden by Mrs. Hank Greenberg, did well in the first program of the three-day Greenwich Horse Show today.

Permanent consumer credit control has many supporters among manufacturers, retailers and banks, Dr. Theodore H. Smith, dean, School of Business Administration, Montana State University, declared yesterday.

The Teachers Salary Conference, which represented virtually all the city's 30,000 public school teachers in the recent campaign for pay increases, will be disbanded after it issues a final report, it was learned last night.

In his first such punitive action since he became Police Commissioner twenty-one months ago Arthur W. Wallander demoted a ranking officer yesterday. He dropped Deputy Inspector Martin Sheehy to a captaincy and continued him on night duty at headquarters, one of the department's least desirable posts.

AMSTERDAM, June 13 (Aneta) --The market moved higher in light trading on the Stock Exchange. Indies plantations issues led the advance followed by industrials, while shipping stocks were easier. Banking shares and State bonds were steady.

BOSTON, June 13 -- That he had seen Douglas Chandler, American writer on trial in Federal Court here on charges of treason, speaking into the microphone of the German Broadcasting Corporation was testified today by Edward Veith Sittler, American-born, German naturalized Nazi.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee voted $215,530,353 for the Interior Department today, or $54,116,840 more than the House approved. Much of the money is to go to reclamation projects in the West.

The, Broadway long-run title, held these many years by "Tobacco Road," which clicked off 3,182 performances locally before calling it quits, will be captured this evening by "Life With Father." The momentous event will come to pass at the Bijou Theatre, where the comedy, an a'daptation by Russel Grouse and Howard Lindsay of the late Clarence Day's stories about bis parents, achieves its 3,183d showing.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, June 14 -- Maj. Gen. Albert E. Brown, chief United States delegate to the joint United States-Soviet Commission, gave a stern warning last night that Korean political leaders who refused to consult with the Commission "will surrender democratic rights and influence."
Eight colts and a filly are in the $50,000 added Dwyer Stakes at Aqueduct today, and the "big horse" of the group is Phalanx, who finally hit the jackpot in the Belmont Stakes.

A duel of pickets Began yesterday in front of the Yardstick, fabric shop, at 11 West Fortysecond Street, with one side representing the management and employes of the shop and the other Local 1102, Retail Dry Goods Employes Union, CIO.

Burton Y. Berry, en route to Washington after a three-year assignment as United States Minister to Rumania, said here yesterday that the Rumanian people have "faith in the United States and that is all they have to hang on to."

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- An improvement in building and placing marine towers, eliminating many of the hazards and much of the expense of marine tower construction for sucn offshore operations as installing beacons, gun emplacements, observation posts, well-drilling rigs and the like, was one of the 434 inventions for which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.
An interdenominational group of churchmen telegraphed President Truman yesterday asking for an audience to set forth their reasons for urging a veto of the TaftHartley bill.
Construction of a building at 191 Livingston Street as an addition to the Abraham Straus department store in Brooklyn will be completed on June 25, it was announced yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 13 -- The usual practices of relegating new-born babies to the nursery and treating the father as "a germ-carrier from whom the baby must be shielded" are giving way to new approaches in which the infant is placed in a crib in the same room with the mother and the father is allowed to think of himself as an acceptable member of the family.

LONDON, June 13 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin hailed United States Secretary of State Marshall's Harvard University address offering economic aid to Europe in such glowing terms at a foreign correspondents' luncheon today as to make it clear that the British Government saw a new international era opening.

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey denied yesterday the motion of Leon Josephson, Communist party member, to dismiss the indictment charging him with contempt for his refusal last March 5 to testify under oath here before a subcommittee of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

VIENNA, June 13 -- The Soviet commander in Austria refused today to participate in an Allied Council discussion of the distribution of the Zistersdorf oil field supplies and said that unless a Soviet representtaive participated in the talks the council was powerless to consider the matter.
MUNICH, Germany, June 13 -- Ten minor members of the staff of Bavarian Minister of Denazification Alfred Loritz were arrested by the German police today on black-marketing charges.

ST. LOUIS, June 13 -- With the crucial round of the National Open championship coming up -- it's an old golfing axiom that the third is the round that forecasts the winner in one of these medal play events -- two Midwestern pros, Melvin (Chick) Harbert of Northville, Mich., and Dick Metz of Arkansas City, Kan., are showing the way to the star-packed field.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 -- Engine-room officers agreed today to a one year's extension of their contract with West Coast shipowners, thus following the lead of the longshoremen. However, a shipping tie-up beginning at midnight Sunday was forecast in an advertisement prepared by maritime unions for publication in Coast newspapers tomorrow.

Plucking the strings of a rare Stradivarius violin that was created by the Italian master in 1723, Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger told a crowded courtroom, "I wouldn't dare try to play it, but I love to hear the tone.

NEWARK, N. J., June 13 -- The Port of New York Authority served notice today on a committee of the Newark City Commission that there would be "no further financial concessions" in its offer to take over and develop the Newark Airport and Marine Terminal.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 -- The Mississippi Power Company asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authorization to sell $2,500,000 of new first mortgage bonds at competitive bidding. The proceeds from the sale would be used to help finance a construction program.

An analysis of air power, entitled "The Right to Fly," has been written by John C. Cooper, former vice president of PanAmerican Airways and a member of the United States National Commission of the Permanent American Aeronautical Commission.

NEW DELHI, India, June 13 -- The All-India Congress Party Committee meets here tomorrow to consider the British Government's proposals of June 3, and it is confidently expected that the partition scheme will be accepted.

Random notes. The Montauk pollock fishing is now at its peak, and should be excellent for the next week, after which it will taper off quite rapidly. However, as the striped bass should be present in fair numbers by that time, the Montauk boatmen are not worried about customers.
A strike of 350 production employes of the Hanscom Baking Corporation forced the company to close its chain of retail outlets in the metropolitan area yesterday for an indefinite period.

FLORINA, Greece, June 13 -- A total of 82,200 persons had fled their homes in Macedonia and Thrace by May 1, according to Constantin Rodopoulos, Governor of Northern Greece. The Governor said that by today the figure might be 112,000.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Mundt bill to give statutory authority for continuation of the State Department's international information and exchange program survived tests in the House today without major damage, but a determined opposition again delayed final action.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 13 -- Deszo Sulyok, leader of the Right-Wing Liberty party, who electrified Parliament here yesterday with his open denunciation of terroristic conditions in...

The fifty-sixth annual national fencing championships started at the New York Athletic Club last night with the Salle Santelli carrying away the first title with a victory in the saber team event. Members of the winning contingent were Dr. Tibor Nyilas, present national individual saber titleholder; Dean Cetrulo, George Worth and Miguel de Capriles.
If the Yankees persist in their distressing habit of playing seconddivision baseball against seconddivision clubs, they are not likely to continue permanently among the American League's elite group.

Home furnishings stores are prepared to offer more liberal credit terms for consumer purchases of furniture and electrical appliances once Regulation W is terminated or eased, Manfred I. Behrens Jr., vice president and general manager of Ludwig Baumann, disclosed yesterday.
MUKDEN, Manchuria, June 13 -- The Manchurian civil war appears to be moving into a critical stage.

Total tie-in newspaper advertising thus far reported to Eversharp, Inc., by dealers has equaled the company's own $150,000 special campaign announcing a new repricing plan, Thomas Emerson, vice president and general sales manager, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 13 (AP) -- The Federal Housing Administration today announced approval of $27,500,000 in mortgage insurance financing for construction of 3,010 rental homes thirty miles south of Chicago's Loop.

ST. LOUIS, June 13 -- Before a crowd of 25,606 fans, who were chilled by the unseasonable weather, George (Red) Hunger put the Dodgers in a deep freeze at Sportsman's Park tonight, allowing them only three hits as the Cards won, 3 -- 0.

ONE of this week's new novels was written nearly a century ago. This is "The SemiAttached Couple,"* by Emily Eden. It was first published in England toward the end of the author's lifetime in 1860, and is now brought out here with an introduction by Anthony Eden, no less, who is a relative of Miss Eden, and some rather generous comparisons, on the publishers' part, between her and Jane Austen.

The present unsettled conditions throughout the world, which are compelling "everyone to look to this country for leadership," were emphasized yesterday by James A. Farley in an appeal for support of the Greater New York Fund campaign for $6,000,000.

We found during five years of sugar rationing that we could make many products without sugar and many more with less sugar than we had been accustomed to use. One thing defied all our attempts to adopt it to the sugar shortage, however, and that was jelly.

The $45,000,000 loan to the Philippines announced by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation is the second this year that has been made by the RFC under the $75,000,000 authorization voted by Congress last August. A loan of $25,000,000 was made in March. No loan made by the RFC will be more widely approved than that to the Philippines for use in reconstructing their battered country.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- The fiveday convention of the Special Libraries Association adjourned today after electing Mrs. Irene Strieby, librarian of the Eli Lilly Company, Indianapolis, Ind., its new president and announcing an award of $2,000 to a foreign student.

POINT MUGU, Calif., June 13 -- American-made copies of the German V-1 buzz bombs launched from shore catapults, launching ramps and surfaced submarines have been guided successfully by radio to area targets at this naval air missile test center.

HAWTHORNE, N.Y., June 13 -- Arrested by state troopers here on a charge of flying so close to a Coast Guard picket boat that he hit its aerial, Edward Maelia, 22 years old, of 194 Nassau Avenue, Brooklyn, pleaded guilty this afternoon before Justice of the Peace Edward Caterson at Valhalla and was fined $25.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We have two divergent economic movements which are now endangering our country more immediately than any threat from abroad.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe decided, yesterday that the twenty seven families forced to leave their apartments at 2517 Amsterdam Avenue because of a fire and the collapse of an adjoining ice house last Dec. 13 may return to their former homes.

The State Department will provide the material for thirteen weekly dramatizations of international issues, beginning Wednesday at 11:30 P. M. over WNBC's network. The series, entitled "Your United Nations," will continue through Sept. 10.

Custom of the Country The cheerful news comes from France that railway traffic is nearly normal. In as much as the French railways have seldom been exposed to the same criticism as the French telephone system, we assume that normal train traffic is really normal.

In answer to the Public Service Commission's refusal to approve the application of the New York Telephone Company for an issue of $125,000,000 of thirty-five-year debentures, the company said yesterday that it would issue an equivalent amount of thirty-fiveyear first mortgage bonds under its refunding mortgage.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- While Mayor James M. Curley of Boston lay ill in a hospital at Cohasset, Mass., his attorneys asked the Supreme Court today to reconsider its refusal to review his mailfraud conviction.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 13 -- The New Jersey State Bar Association, at the opening session of its forty-ninth annual meeting, recommitted today a report of its law reform committee relative to the judiciary article of the new State Constitution of New Jersey.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., June 13 -- Peonies, roses, irises, delphiniums and a host of lesser flowers were brought in from Long Island gardens to the Agricultural and Technical Institute here as the second district of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State opened its annual two-day flower show today.

New York women "are afraid to open their doors or go out in the streets for fear of savage assault," Assistant District Attorney Paul F. Reilly declared yesterday as two men were held without bail in Felony Court on charges of burglary and robbery.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The American anti-Communist Association asked the Federal District Court today to bar former Vice President Henry Wallace from using the Watergate Amphitheater for an address on Monday night.

An airline pilot whose automobile was hit by the United Air Lines plane that crashed at La Guardia Field on May 29, killing forty-two persons, testified yesterday before the Civil Aeronautics Board at the Lexington Hotel that the four engines of the plane were cut off when it ricocheted over Grand Central Parkway.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Urgent pleas for United States participation in the World Health Organization were placed before a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee today by Representative Walter H. Judd, Republican, of Minnesota, author of the joint resolution for United States membership in WHO, and by Surgeon General Thomas Parran, of the Public Health Service, United States member of the WHO Interim Commission.
PITTSBURGH, June 13 (AP) -- Behind the pitching of Charles (Red) Barrett, the Braves throttled the Pirates, 6 -- 2, before 6,341 fans today.

With the work of redecorating 85 per cent complete, the new home of the Lotos Club at 5 East Sixty-sixth Street is open for the use of members, H. Paul Letsch, the manager, said yesterday. The club has a membership of 778 in the business, educational, art and professional fields.

Orders for large quantities of standard types of steel office equipment, desks, filing cases, transfer files, lockers and shelving are "going begging" in the hands of purchasing agents for the largest companies in New York, purchasing executives revealed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Department of Justice disclosed plans today to seek perjury indictments against two union officials, Harold Christoffel and Robert Buse, who denied to the House Labor Committee that they were Communists.

WASHINGTON, Saturday, June 14 -- The following is the passenger list of the DC-4 plane reported to have crashed near Leesburg, Va., as released by a spokesman for the Capital Airlines at the company's headquarters here.

New York public school teachers of social sciences were warned yesterday not to allow personal prejudices to creep into their classroom presentation of controversial subjects. The warning was contained in a new curriculum bulletin on American history and economics being distributed to city high schools.
PARIS, June 13 -- France's National Assembly approved today ratification of the peace treaty with Italy by 510 votes with none in opposition.

Temporary possession of St. Nicholas Russian Orthodox Cathedral, 15 East Ninety-seventh Street, will be taken at 1:30 P.M., today by representatives of the Russian Orthodox Church in North America, it was learned yesterday. The move is intended to result in a peaceful settlement of differences existing since 1917 with the Patriarchal Russian Orthodox Church in Moscow.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Budget cuts ranging from 30 per cent for the Atomic Energy Commission to 1.8 per cent for the Veterans Administration were ordered today by the House Appropriations Committee.

Nothing could illustrate more poignantly the depths to which Britain's -- and Europe's -- hopes had sunk than the almost pathetic enthusiasm with which Foreign Secretary Bevin, addressing the Foreign Press Association in London, yesterday described Secretary Marshall's recent speech at Harvard as "one of the greatest in the world's history."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 13 -- Sam Coslow, United Artists producer, today signed Laraine Day to play the leading role, that of Brooklyn manicurist, in "Champagne for Everybody," which will go before the cameras in August. Miss Day will receive $125,000 plus 10 per cent of the profits from the film, it was learned from her representative.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 13 -- The Arab Higher Committee sent official notice today to Secretary General Trygve Lie that it would boycott the meetings of the United Nations Committee of Inquiry on Palestine.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The United States has a moral duty to take the lead in giving haven to European refugees, Owen J. Roberts, retired Supreme Court Justice, told a House Judiciary subcommittee today. The subcommittee is continuing hearings on the Stratton bill through which 400,000 displaced persons would be admitted to this country over a period of four years at 100,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, spoke out today, as the Republican leader on foreign policy, for the establishment of a special bipartisan high council to advise the President and Congress alike on the vast job of helping Europe's reconstruction.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The United States has made strong representations to the Bucharest Government reserving all rights on behalf of American interests in Rumania in enterprises that might be affected adversely by measures pointing to nationalization of property without compensation, the State Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Returning from a survey in Germany, Howard C. Petersen, Assistant Secretary of War, warned at a press conference today that this country must give priority to food shipments for that shattered nation or communism might gain a foothold in the United States zone.

LONG BEACH Calif., June 13 (AP) -- More than a million tons of steel pipe will start leaving Long Beach Harbor and other ports this summer for Saudi Arabia in what maritime authorities describe as the greatest single commercial shipment in history.

The city picked up the tab yesterday for a couple's dinner, thereby saving a magistrate the job of figuring out what to do about a man who dined out with his wife and could not pay the check. The money for the bill came out of a relief payment brought into court by the defendant's wife.

BOSTON, June 13 (AP) -- While being outhit by a 13-8 margin, the Red Sox dedicated their new lighting plant by defeating the White Sox, 5 -- 3, tonight before a capacity crowd of 34,510. The American League champions collected all of their runs in the fifth against Frank Papish on three singles, two walks and an error.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- Senator Edward Martin of Pennsylvania said today that the shortage of scrap metal "will probably force many open-hearth furnaces in Pennsylvania and elsewhere to shut down this fall and winter."
LONDON, June 13 -- With business still checked by European political uncertainties, the stock markets here today finished the week on a quiet note.

JERUSALEM, June 13 -- Extreme embarrassment on the part of the Palestine Government was apparent tonight as a result of the sinister-sounding mystery surrounding the arrest in Syria of three British officers of the Palestine police.

CLEVELAND, June 13 -- victory for the management of the Cliffs Corporation, a holding company interested chiefly in the steel industry, was gained today as shareholders gave the management a substantial majority of votes in approving a merger of the corporation with the Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Company.

TRENTON, N.J., June 13 -- Drafters of a 1947 platform submitted today to the New Jersey Republican leadership a statement of principles notable for brevity. Action will be taken next Tuesday on the 400-word one-page tentative draft.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The text of a statement by Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, proposing the creation of a bipartisan advisory council to assess United States resources for foreign aid follows:

CLINTON, N.Y., June 13 -- Appointment of Dr. Thomas B. Rudd of Clinton, now acting president of Hamilton College, to the presidency, came today as the college's trustees accepted with regret the resignation of Dr. David Worcester, tendered as the result of continued ill health.

William J. McDermott, a city employe for sixteen years, was dismissed yesterday by Robert F. Wagner Jr., Commissioner of Housing and Buildings. McDermott, who is free on $7,500 bail, was charged with irregularities in connection with his work in the department's Brooklyn office.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- Army, engineers today increased the estimated cost of the St. Lawrence Seaway project from $455,086,000 to $674,707,000 but Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman indicated the waterway's traffic potential was high enough to pay for itself through tolls.

The stock market tested yesterday the high levels of May and then eclipsed them in a final-hour buying surge which carried prices into the early April range. Demand for the gold issues, which paralleled a similar move in the Toronto market, supplied the necessary momentum to raise the composite rate 1.61 points, 'while wider gains were scored by several individual stocks.
Mayor O'Dwyer urged Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson yesterday to use his good offices to relieve the "shocking" rise in meat prices.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Ben Herzberg, representing the American Jewish Committee, told a Senate Labor subcommittee today that concern about frictions which, might be generated by a Federal law against, discrimination in employment was not supported by the record of similar legislation in New York State.

Retail Trade Here Normal Retail trade here continued active this week with normally good response to offerings heading up to Father's Day. Estimates indicated department store volume will show a gain a little better than 5 per cent over the like period a year ago, when pre-Father's Day sales were good.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, June 13 -- The Bulgarian Government in a reply published today to the British note of June 3 protesting against suspension of two Opposition newspapers here, rejected the protest as unfounded. The two newspapers had carried criticism to the point where they threatened to undermine the national economy, said the Bulgarian reply.
