PHILADELPHIA, June 13 (AP) -- Two home runs by Joe Gordon and one by Ken Keltner carried Bob Feller to his eighth victory tonight as the Indians defeated the Athletics, 5 -- 4, before 28,628. Feller, who fanned 12 to bring his season's strikeout total to 87, was relieved in the eighth by Ed Klienman.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 13 -- Wilder Foote, information chief of the United States delegation to the United Nations since 1946, has been appointed director of the United Nations Bureau of the Press and Publications, a new branch, Secretary General Trygve Lie announced today.

Five small groups of civil service employes in the New York City Transit System asked for pay increases and improved working conditions yesterday as wage hearings continued before the Board of Transportation at 250 Hudson Street.

CLEVELAND, June 13 -- A group of fifty industrialists, representing thirty-nine concerns in the eastern half of the United States, who have profit-sharing plans of one kind or another, took initial steps at a meeting today toward forming an association.

One of the great commanders of the Second World War, Lieut. Gen. Ira C. Eaker, will doff his three stars tomorrow and go back to mufti after thirty years in the Army. As Deputy Commander of the Army Air Forces he will be sorely missed in the high councils of security.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 13 -- The Soviet Union warned today that refusal to link control of the atomic bomb with world-wide disarmament might mean the failure of the whole arms-reduction effort.

SOUTH ORANGE. N.J., June 13 -- The Eastern Lawn Tennis Association's defending champions and the New England team qualified for the final round of the Sears Cup intersectional matches today on the turf of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

The annual series of Daniel and Florence Guggenheim "Memorial Concerts by the Goldman Band, under Dr. Edwin Franko Goldman, opened last night on the Mall in Central Park. This 1,697th concert of the series, now in its thirtieth year, attracted an audience of good size, considering the doubtful state, of the weather.

PARIS, June 13 -- A dual FrenchAlgerian form of Government to replace the present French-controlled administration of Algeria is now under discussion in the French Cabinet, it was learned today. The proposal is sponsored by Fehrat Abbas, leader of Algeria's strongest Moslem political group.

LONDON, June 13 -- Britain's preoccupation with her foreign trade balance and everything that menaces her stability in export trade was evidenced today in expressions of concern from various quarters.
Tony Pellone, the Greenwich Village dynamo, snapped another long winning streak by beating Charley Fusari of Irvington, N.J., in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, June 13 (AP) -- Babe Didrikson Zaharias, still flushed with the success that won her the British women's amateur golf championship, ran smack into the Friday the thirteenth jinx today and played the poorest game of her visit to Britain.

The departmental hearing of Elmer Haslett, suspended director of city airports, which has been on since last Tuesday, was adjourned abruptly yesterday until 10 o'clock Monday morning, after a letter of further particulars had been served on Mr. Haslett.

The famous battery of Cooper and Cooper was reborn yesterday with the acquisition by the New York Giants of Mort Cooper, righthanded pitcher, from the Boston Braves. The deal sent Bill Voiselle, also a pitcher, to the Boston club, which also received an undisclosed amount of cash.

ROME, June 13 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi's fourth Government won its first clean-cut Parliamentary victory today when the Constituent Assembly by 248 votes to 175 defeated the Communist move to appoint a special committee to investigate the Minister of the Interior.

PARIS, June 13 -- The oneday warning strike of municipal employes took place throughout France today, but in spotty and incomplete fashion. Just as the railway strikers had made an exception for food trains, so did today's strikers leave the Paris subways and buses in operation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The report of Benjamin Fine on the state of the public libraries, based on a nation-wide survey undertaken by the American Library Association during the course of two years, and published in your issue of June 1, will certainly be of greatest interest to all working in the important field of adult education.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 13 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, said today that recent statements by President Truman and Secretary of State Marshall on the possibility of a broad program of help for European countries had been "very helpful."
Bids will be received July 1 by Kingsport, Tenn., on an issue of $563,000 school and improvement bonds dated July 1, 1947, and due July 1 from 1948 to 1967.

BERLIN, June 13 -- The Germans in this four-power occupation capital were confronted today with a spectacle of conflicting policies within the United States Military Government that threatens to perpetuate the snarl in the city government.

Mayor O'Dwyer, it became known yesterday, is prepared to take the lead in a campaign for a November referendum on a higher subway fare, earmarked exclusively to meet operating deficits on the city transit system, if such an increase is recommended by his executive committee on administration.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 13 -- Grants amounting to $1,343,000 for cancer research, covering the last ten years and commitments for the next three years as well, have been appropriated by the Jane Coffin Childs Memorial Fund for Medical Research, it was announced tonight.

The steel industry, which has peacetime at a record pace for peace time since the beginning of the year, fears a sharp recession in mill activity within a few weeks unless the threatened coal strike is averted.

Rear Admiral E. H. Smith, commanding the Coast Guard's third district and the eastern area, announced yesterday that the service's fourth district, with headquarters in Philadelphia, would be abolished and absorbed by the New York headquarters.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Speaking at the unveiling of a bust of himself at the National War College, Bernard M. Baruch declared today that this country was determined to preserve the heart of democracy, which he defined as "the maintenance of rights, not privileges; the dignity of each man and each woman."

NANKING, June 13 -- There is no evidence in the reports of the Outer Mongolia-Sinkiang border clash to show that the incident has major international complications. It appears to have been a frontier skirmish of the kind that has been occurring periodically for a long time.
ST. LOUIS, June 13 -- A strike of 3,500 union, street car and bus operators tied up the public transportation system in the St. Louis metropolitan area today.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission formally struck from the record today allegations of antiJewish and anti-Negro bias made against The New York Daily News by the American Jewish Congress.
ATLANTA, Ga., June 13 -- The National Order of the Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, Inc., voluntarily surrendered its Georgia charter in the Fulton County Superior Court here today.

Two new flags will be placed in the pew of George Washington in St. Paul's Episcopal Chapel, Trinity Parish, Broadway, between Fulton and Vesey Streets, this morning at 10:30 o'clock by the Sons of the Revolution at a special Flag Day service.

ROME. June 13 -- L'Osservatore Romano, Vatican newspaper, today urged Russia and the United States to set aside their ideological differences and seek a political understanding as a means to achieve peace.

CHICAGO, June 13 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs beat their Philadelphia "cousins" again today, 4 to 3, for the eighth straight time this season and the seventh time by one run, and the Cubs moved within a half game of the league-leading New York Giants, who were idle.

NEW ORLEANS, June 13 -- International House, this city's unique effort to integrate commercial and cultural relations between the vast Mississippi Valley, Latin America and the world, celebrates its second anniversary Saturday.

Two new furniture pieces planned especially for young children have just been introduced in several New York stores. Designed by the Modern Child Company, they are a small bathroom shelf and a portable closet rack, both made of wood.

Fragmentary reports of settlements, threatened strikes and scheduled walkouts added to the confusion here yesterday regarding the possibility of a nation-wide tieup of shipping, but the marine industry's "elder statesmen" continued to take an optimistic view of the situation.

PRAGUE, June 13 (U.P.) -- Jaroslav Drobny and Vladimir Cernik, Czechoslovakia's irrepressible iron men, gave their nation a surprise 2-to-0 lead over favored France today by turning back Bernard Destremau and Marcel Bernard, respectively, in the opening singles matches of their Davis Cup European zone semi-final play.

Urged to give honest opinions in a recent study, and assured that they would not be "marked" on it, New York City public school pupils have thrown new light on children's reasons for liking or disliking school.

Federal Judge Harold M. Kennedy in the District Court, Brooklyn, ruled yesterday that $2,133 found on the person of a man who drowned while on a "maritime venture on navigable waters" could be properly classified as salvage under the Admiralty Law.

After fifty years of denial to the people of Guam of those basic human rights which the founders of the United States held to be self-evident, it now appears that something is to be done for these islanders by Congress. The war stirred interest in this forgotten bit of land that we acquired from Spain by the Treaty of Paris in 1898.

John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, presented Christopher Columbus Scholarships worth $2ob each to eleven June graduates of city high schools yesterday at a ceremony held in the Board of Education, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- With a gratifyingly successful state visit to Canada behind him, and a busy week ahead, President Truman returned to the capital by special train from Ottawa tonight. Mrs. Truman, Miss Margaret Truman and members, of the White House staff came back with him.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- A Presidential veto next week of the Republican tax reduction bill was accepted at the Capitol today as foregone, and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, the Republican leader on domestic affairs, declined to predict that it could be overridden.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 12, you gave a prominent position on page one to the charge of Cardinal Spellman to the effect that Protestant Church groups in the United States are impugning Catholics' patriotism by a crusade of bigotry.

ST. LOUIS, June 13 -- While one major flood continued to spread destruction along the Mississippi and Missouri Rivers, torrential rains produced new floods in central Iowa and northwestern Missouri today that threatened to top crests already at records.

A 14-year-old freshman at the Bronx High School of Art received last night first prize of $200 in the semi-annual illustration contest for high school students, for which the Society of Illustrators and the Board of Education are joint sponsors.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The House Appropriations Committee proposed today a $43,449,000 fund for research in aerial weapons after hearing that potential foes might "jump at us" if they ever get air superiority.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Federal Public Housing Authority tonight flatly contradicted a House appropriations subcommittee report charging that FPHA had "failed miserably" to meet its aims.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Free hedgeselling with long liquidation caused another setback today in wheat prices on the Board of Trade, and in the coarse grains there was a weak tone, with buying support not sufficient to offset the selling.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., June 13 -- Mike Cestone of Crestmont, yesterday's medalist, defeated Anthony Pacifico in this morning's round of the New Jersey State Golf Association's amateur championship at the Ridgewood Country Club. Cestone had a difficult time gaining the lead after finishing the first nine all even.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today accused Charlie Chaplin, Mary Pickford and their associates in United Artists, Inc., of showing to the public a cut version of "The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp" as the whole film.

LEESBURG, Va., Saturday, June 14 -- Search parties were scouring a three-state area early this morning for a Capital Airlines DC-4 plane which has been missing since 6:13 o'clock, Eastern standard time, last night on a flight from Chicago to Washington.

JERUSALEM, June 13 -- Official Zionist witnesses before the United Nations Committee of Inquiry on Palestine will continue to insist that the Jews are entitled to a state in the whole of Palestine, it was reliably forecast here today, but they will drop hints that the Jewish Agency for Palestine would be willing to consider an offer of less territory if made by someone else.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- A woman has a right to look and feel beautiful -- and that right should not be taxed, the Toilet Goods Association told Congress today.

LOS ANGELES, June 13 -- The record sales and earnings of department stores last year were to some extent deceptive, and in some respects business declined sharply, Malcolm P. McNair of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration said today.

VIENNA, June 13 -- The Soviet chief of the welfare division, in the Russian zone of occupation warned all foreign relief agencies yesterday that they would not be permitted to enter the Soviet zone without special permits and that they must present monthly reports on deliveries and other activities.

BERLIN, June 14 -- A United States Military Government investigation of the two largest banks in Germany -- the Dresdner Bank and the Deutsche Bank -- disclosed that these institutions lad been active partners of the Nazis in the political and economic domination of Europe.

OTTUMWA, Iowa, June 14 (AP) -- The Des Moines River swept through sections of a mile-long barricade on Church Street in the business section of South Ottumwa early tonight, inundating this area for the second time in a week. It was expected that 8,000 or 9,000 persons in this city of 32,000 would be driven from their homes.

PARENTS have raised some new questions since this book first appeared in 1936. A decade of research and experience affects answers to some of the old questions. This edition bears on war marriages, and on life with small children in trailers; on self-demand feeding and hospital roomingin arrangements for mothers and new-born infants and on father's new share in bringing up baby.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad has decided to use exclusively 4,500-horsepower Diesel-electric locomotives in through freight service on its 125mile line from New Haven, Conn., to Maybrook, N.Y. Last week, the first such locomotive was placed in steady service.
Ferenc Nagy, who was forced out of the Premiership of Hungary in a Communist coup, arrived at La Guardia Field last night in a Trans World Airliner from Geneva, Switzerland.
The foremost professionals of the country and several from overseas will start play tomorrow in the national professional tennis championships at Forest Hills.

Hundreds of Long Island commuters missed train and bus connections and were late to work in the city yesterday morning when twelve westbound Long Island Railroad trains were tied up ten to sixty-two minutes just east of Woodside, Queens.

NEW ORLEANS, La., June 14 -- The greatest single step in public improvements in this city since the turn of the century when a sewerage and water system saved the population from malarial scourges is now under way at the proposed cost of $41,000,000.

Key decisions made by major equipment makers last week started an unorganized but real national drive to reach new peaks in output next year. Many durable goods manufacturers started planning for expanded production and sales operations after concluding a series of studies of current economic trends, spokesmen revealed here yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 14 -- William E. Howland of Khakum Woods, Greenwich, won the A.S.P. C.A. horsemanship event at the Greenwich Horse Show today to qualify for the championship A.S. P.C.A. horsemanship class in the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden in November.

VANCE RANDOLPH is our authority on the folkways of the Ozark mountain people of southern Missouri and northern Arkansas, who, he says, "were, until very recently, the most deliberately unprogressive people in the United States."

PARIS, June 14--British Foreign Secretary Bevin will come to Paris Tuesday to discuss with Foreign Minister Bidault and French experts the possibility of drafting rapidly a common European reconstruction as suggested by Secretary of State Marshall, the French and British Foreign Offices announced today.

LONDON, June 14 -- The contrast between the omnipotence of Communists in eastern Europe today and their almost complete absence from the surface of political life between World Wars has led many western observers to conclude that communism is a mere import from the U.S.S.R., lacking any real roots in the east European countries themselves.

In a Flag Day sermon yesterday Rabbi William F. Rosenblum in Temple Israel, 210 West Ninetyfirst Street, declared that "the flag of the United States, though oft carried in war, has on it only the symbols of hope and peace."

DESIGNER T.H. ROBSJOHN-GIBBINGS now presents his own alternatives to the "decaying antique" and the "machine-for-living" modern which he blasted with impartial scorn in his book, "Good-Bye, Mr. Chippendale." Herewith are a few designs from the first complete line of manufactured furniture to come from Mr. Robsjohn-Gibbings' drawing board.

NO SUNDAY article today. Confound it! At this season of the year the weekly service in the left-hand column of this page frequently collapses, and through no fault of mine. A conscientious workman, I wrote an article in ample time to reach the printers, who have a lot of petty rules, like the one according to which they refuse to receive copy after the Sunday section has gone to press.

QUEBEC, June 14 -- The possible effect of the State Department's current survey of the world's rehabilitation needs upon the United States' domestic economy, the World Bank, and the relationship of that bank with their own individual operations are expected to be major topics of discussion among the 700 members of the New York State Bankers Association now gathering here for their fifty-first annual convention.

IN 1856, Samuel Mordecai, a long-time citizen of Richmondon-the-James, wrote an informal, entertaining volume about his city. This book, part history, part tradition and anecdote, discussed personages, places and events from the granting of the site to William Byrd in the seventeenth century, to the eve of the War Between the States.
LONDON. GETTING a personality piece about David Lean, the director of "Great Expectations," from David Lean, is like drawing teeth, and the knowing investigator doesn't attempt it.

Two young men did not profit front experience early yesterday morning. At 2 A.M., with two companions, they were taken to the Fifth Avenue Station in Brooklyn When suspicious policemen noticed them sitting in an automobile.

DESPITE eight years of war and manifold other problems, the Institute for Research in Chinese Architecture carried on. At the Metropolitan Museum photographs and drawings have been placed oil view to illustrate its "finds" in recent years of examples of early architecture.

Eighty representatives of thirty-one member states in the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization will attend a six-week seminar near Paris this summer to study means of education for international understanding.

NEW DELHI, June 14 (Reuters) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi, hitherto a strong opponent of the partition of India, tonight swung over and added his plea for acceptance of the British plan to establish two Dominions, Hindustan and Pakistan.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Five of the scheduled seven months of the first session of the new Republicancontrolled Eightieth Congress have passed. A glance at the budget of finished and unfinished business might make one wonder why Republicans voted (while Democrats were in control) for the Reorganization Act that shuts down Congress not later than July 31 each year.

NANKING, June 14 (AP) -- The Government's Central News Agency charged today that "a certain nation" -- a Chinese press term for Russia -- had directed the Communist offensive in Manchuria, backing it with 30,000 Japanese war prisoners and ninety tanks.

FOR THIS WEEK: Spray gladiolus planted a month ago with DDT and plant more corms for late bloom.... Watch sweet peas for aphids and spray with nicotine sulfate and soap. Many other plants will also need to be sprayed weekly at this time for these insects.... Plunge tuberous-rooted begonias, pot and all, in flower borders or window boxes.
WASHINGTON, June 14--A high Administration official said tonight that the Government is "considering" grounding all former Army C-54 planes that have been converted to commercial airlines uses.

The Civil Aeronautics Board ended yesterday its fact-finding hearing on the United Air Lines crash at La Guardia Field on the night of May 29. Meanwhile the forty-third victim of the accident, Mack Gordon of Cleveland, died of his injuries at New York Hospital.
ST. LOUIS, June 14 -- The national open championship of the United States Golf Association ended in a tie today for the fourth time in the last five tournaments played for the title.

New York stores gained fractionally on Father's Day business and it was estimated that sales were 5 per cent ahead of last year. Buying activity in the wholesale markets was brisk on coats, suits and other women's apparel. Primary markets were reported as stronger than in some weeks past, with sizable orders of cotttons sold for fourth-quarter delivery.

DETROIT, June 14 (AP) -- In a quick-change shift from the scene of the national open at St. Louis, golf's top professional stars will turn their attention next week to Detroit, where methodical little Ben Hogan of Hershey, Pa., opens defense of his national P.G.A. crown on Wednesday on a long, rolling Plum Hollow Golf Club layout made to order for his game.

FOR the past ten years the name of Ronald Knox has accumulated well-deserved honor to Roman Catholic circles, both lay and clerical, in both England and America. In 1936 appeared his first important work, "The Holy Bible:

THE contract has not yet been signed, but insiders say Pia Tassinari, soprano, wife of Ferruccio Tagliavini, will sing next season at the Metropolitan Opera. The two met in Palermo in 1941, when both were engaged to sing in "L'Amico Fritz."

The Maritime Commission denied charges yesterday that "government red tape" had been the cause of delay in negotiations with Agwilines, Inc., for the purchase of war-built tonnage for the company's services between the United States and Cuba, Puerto Rico, the Dominican Republic and Mexico.

A SHORT time ago delegates in the lounge at Lake Success witnessed an astonishing scene. Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Andreyevich Gromyko, Russia's notoriously aloof delegate to the United Nations, had risen from his chair and was having an amiable and lively conversation with a group of incredulous correspondents.

Cancellations of orders for builders' hardware by wholesalers engaged in cooperating with their sources of supply opened a new chapter in scientific merchandising, John R. Schoemer, managing director of the National Contract Hardware Association, revealed here yesterday following his return from round-table sessions with large wholesaling houses on the West Coast.

KATONAH, N.Y., June 14 -- A red Doberman that doesn't appear often but makes good when she does took best-in-show at the fifteenth annual event of the Greenwich Kennel Club, held on Wind Mill Farm today. She was Champion Duvetyn of Stone Croft, owned by F.F.H. Fleitmann of Far Hills, N.J.

A veteran Salle Santelli team, made up of Norman Lewis, Jose de Capriles and Ralph Goldstein, captured the epee team title as the second day of competition in the week-long national fencing championships was completed on the strips of the Fencers Club last night.

VLADIMIR Nabokov, born a Russian and now an American citizen, has written a moving and powerful novel about the plight of a civilized man caught in a tyrant state. There is a terrible inevitability about its movement and a warm humanity about its main character which are not often found in what is essentially a thesis novel.

The news of the past few days ought to convince Americans that there exists in Britain and on the Continent a will toward recovery. Secretary Marshall's proposal that the nations of Europe draw up a joint plan for their own economic salvation and that this country's future aid to Europe be based upon that joint plan has met with a gratifyingly swift and eager response.

PRAGUE, June 14 -- Czechoslovakia's two-man tennis team reached the final round of Davis Cup play in the European Zone today by adding a triumph in the doubles to its two singles victories over France yesterday.

PARIS, June 14 -- During the spring and early summer of this year an active United States foreign policy has been developing. Its most positive aspects can be detected on peripheries of the Eurasian Soviet Empire.

OTTAWA, June 14 -- President Truman's restatement of United States foreign policy before the Canadian Parliament on Wednesday cleared up many misconceptions and suspicions that had begun to gather even in this country, which knows the United States better than most.
The following is a revised list of the passengers and crew killed in the crash of a Capital Airlines DC-4 plane near Leesburg, Va.:

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 14 -- The final round of the intersectional matches for the Sears Cup was interrupted by rain today at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club after the New England Association and the Eastern Association teams had finished two singles contests.

The return to passenger ship operation of the American South African Line, although still some six months away, was viewed yesterday as closer to realization with the disclosure that two wartime transports it sought are being surveyed by Maritime Commission officials preparatory to their reconversion for peacetime service.

Big Powers Seek One Ten days ago at Cambridge, Mass., Secretary of State George Catlett Marshall spoke before the alumni of America's oldest university. His speech was expected to be perfunctory, an acknowledgment of the honorary degree Harvard was conferring upon him.

HARRIET LANE LEVY, at 80, has played a neat trick on the critics. She has written a "Life with" chronicle that can't be described by the order-made tags of "charming" or "wacky." Looking backward without the heady enthusiasms of the memoirwriter, she demonstrates that childhood reminiscences need not follow the accepted pattern.

LONDON, June 14 -- The British are anxious to get a plan for European economic recovery drafted before Presidential election campaign in the United States adds new complications to Secretary Marshall's task of winning Congressional assent to large-scale assistance.

Arnold Gray, defending titleholder, led the field into the quarterfinal round as play in the Metropolitan Golf Association's public links championship started yesterday at the Split Rock course in the Bronx.
Several organizations celebrated Flag Day here yesterday in formal ceremonies.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 14 -- A thirty-six-foot cabin cruiser blew up this evening in Long Island Sound near here and the nine occupants, including four young married couples, were hurled into the water.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 14 (AP) -- Harry LaMontagne's Larky Day turned on the heat at the head of the stretch, wore down the pacemaking Westminster, a Shamrock Stable star, and romped to the wire to register a three-and-a-halflength victory in the Boardwalk, a $10,000 added mile and a furlong handicap.

A SWASHBUCKLING romance of Maine in the Eighteen Seventies, this vast, sprawling novel spans the world and admits within its boundaries multitudinous sub-plots that range from the selfless love of a mother to the violence and violations of passion.

French furniture, porcelains Oriental rugs, decorations and a small group of paintings, in part the property of Arthur F. Williams of New York, are on exhibition at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, and will be auctioned on Thursday.

ERNEST WALKER wears the facial trade mark of those who make a living from humor -- he looks as though someone had interrupted his pet gag to say: "Yeah, I heard that one ten years ago." Yet Walker, though intensely and professionally interested in radio wit, has never been on a program in his twelve years in radio.

PARIS, June 14 -- As the first step in revising the tottering priceand-wage situation, the French Cabinet today considered returning to a form of collective bargaining. If carried into effect, the plan would be a wide departure from the Government's policy of fixing wages.

THE Department of Parks announces the third summer of free square dance sessions through the courtesy of the Pepsi-Cola Company. There will be three separate series: one at Riverside Drive and 103d Street (lower level) on Monday evenings from tomorrow through Sept. 15; another in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, on Tuesday evenings from June 16 through Sept. 16, and the third on the Mall in Central Park on Saturday afternoons from June 21 through Sept. 20.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Labor-Management Relations Act of 1947, now on President Truman's desk, is one of the most important pieces of social legislation of the last fifteen years.

ONE of the few men in this city who get the jitters every time there is talk of razing an elevated is Charles S. Horowitz. It means that hundreds of thousands of people will no longer be able to stare at his contribution to roof-top art, and, incidentally, the most famous wall and chimney advertisement in town.

With Johnny (Trade Bait) Lindell continuing his spectacular clubbing, the Yankees overwhelmed Browns, 12 -- 4, before 17,094 at the Stadium yesterday. Ben rain drops -- there was a 16 te delay in the fifth inning -- New Yorkers drubbed Nelson er and Clarence lott for thirresounding hits and gained a -length on the idle Tigers, se first-place lead over the Yankees was cut to one game.

WICHITA, Kan., June 14 -- A strange phenomenon in the American scene, the "for rent" sign, has appeared in this former war-boom city. In many of Wichita's sprawling residential sections there are rooms and apartments to be had. Tenant-seeking advertisements in the newspapers are still none too plentiful.

The Department of Markets will resume tomorrow a policy carried out when Office of Price Administration control was in effect by sending inspectors throughout the city to make zone surveys of meat price fluctuations.

Despite a surface apathy to President Truman's admonishment to the House of Representatives for slashing the Department of the Interior's budget by nearly 50 per cent, the electric light and power industry is fearful that the Senate will act to restore a substantial part of the funds requested for advancement of public power.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (U.P.) -- Following is the text of President Truman's statement on the Italian peace treaty: With the ratification of the treaty of peace with Italy we bring to a close an unhappy chapter in Italian-American relations.

Arthur J. Hayslip of Flushing, who last week succeeded William C. Wolfmuller, also of Flushing, as commander of the Bayside Power Squadron, one of the largest in the entire U.S.P.S., is appointing aides and committees right and left for the season's big squadron event.

THIS book reflects the growing maturity of the Naval Academy curriculum. "American Sea Power" is written by instructors and professors at Annapolis, and edited by Allan Westcott, senior professor, well known to many generations of midshipmen.
SEVERAL authorities will discuss the problems of "Photography as a Creative Art" in a symposium Wednesday evening at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

BERLIN, June 14 -- Investigation of the fitness of German nominees for bizonal jobs was abandoned by the British and United States Military Government the week before the new bizonal government was announced. Under the new policy delegates to the new bizonal Economic Council will be responsible for seeing that appointees are not Nazis or militarists.

In a final effort to bring the disputants together before the taking of a vote on a work stoppage in the shipping industry, the United States Conciliation Service announced last night it had scheduled two joint conferences for today.

William Benton, Assistant Secretary of State, replied yesterday to an attack on the State Department's information program made by Kent Cooper, executive director of The Associated Press. Mr. Cooper's criticism was made in an address at North-western University in Chicago on May 26.

MADRID, June 14 -- At a cost of a few million dollars to the Spanish people Senora Eva Duarte Peron, wife of President Juan D. Peron of Argentina, is carrying out the most original diplomatic mission devised in recent times. So far as can be judged up to the present moment, it should be a huge success.
MADRID, June 14 -- Enrique Cardinal Play Deniel, Archbishop of Toledo, has drafted an appeal to all Spaniards to support the Franco Law of Succession in the forthcoming referendum.

FOR the benefit of air-minded guests, a number of resort hotels here and in the West have added flying lessons to their list of vacation activities this summer. The lessons will be given under the supervision of the Civil Aeronautics Authority, and the enterprising vacationer who completes the course successfully will carry away a bona fide CAA solo license.

NEW ORLEANS, June 14 (AP) -- Frankie Parker, 30-year-old No. 3 player in the nation, won the Southern amateur tennis title here today, but not before an uproariously partisan crowd had seen a New Orleans boy, Jack Tuero, extend the veteran to the limit.

As youngsters at play scurried for safety in crowded tenementlined West Forty-seventh Street between Tenth and Eleventh Avenues a man wearing dark glasses and gripping a submachine gun leaped from a black sedan and shot to death 31-year-old Vincent Wice, a milk-wagon driver and former soldier, shortly before noon yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Joseph E. Davies, former United States Ambassador to Moscow, denied today that pressure from the White House during the war induced Warner Brothers to produce the motion picture film based on his book "Mission to Moscow."

NEW DELHI, India, June 14 (U.P.) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi warned the ruling Princes of India at his prayer meeting tonight that they must change their ways or be swept from power on the wave of nationalism flooding India in anticipation of the British withdrawal.

All Dressed Up President Truman's visit to Canada was obviously a tremendous all-round success, in big things as in small. He made a wonderfully effective speech to the members of the Canadian Parliament.

LEESBURG, Va., June 14 -- A search party located the wreckage today of a four-motored DC-4 transport which crashed and turned on a West Virginia mountain top last night, killing all of the fifty persons aboard. The DC-4 was operated by the Pennsylvania Central Airlines, Inc., which is known by its unofficial name of Capital Airlines.

ROME, June 14 -- By 279 votes to 155 the Constituent Assembly decided today to prolong its own life by more than six months to Dec. 31. As a necessary consequence, the general election originally scheduled for October will not be held until next year, probably in March.
ST. LOUIS, June 14 -- Sam Breadon, Cardinal owner, who likes to see his players on the field night and day, must have been very happy about his latest Cole Porter production at Sportsman's Park.

Canada Entertains It is a tradition in the Canadian House of Commons that no one may occupy the Speaker's chair -- which is behind and slightly above the rostrum -- when a chief of state addresses the members. The reason is that no one can take precedence over the visitor.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., June 14 -- The season's eighth Y.R.A. championship regatta, held under the auspices of the Riverside Yacht Club in a haze and snappy southsouthwest breeze which lifted to 20-knot swirls at times, attracted only forty-nine starting craft today.

LONDON, June 14 (AP) --- The report of the International Committee for the study of European Questions said: "There are today in Argentina 90,000 Germans who took part in Nazi activities during the war. Sixty thousand of them were members of the German Workers' Front, and 20,000 belonged to Nazi sporting and cultural associations.

The State Youth Commission refused to allow one of its members, who had already accepted the invitation, to speak at a conference held by the Child Care Centers Parents' Association of New York, it was learned yesterday during a session of the conference.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., June 14 -- Gene Krautter of Baltusrol realized his ambition today when he defeated Alex Antonio, last year's state titleholder, in the quarterfinal round of the 1947 New Jersey State Golf Association's amateur

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Labor Department officials were hopeful today but uncertain that a maritime strike tomorrow at midnight could be averted and believed the key was the negotiations with the marine cooks and stewards on the West Coast.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 14 (AP) -- With the Thames River and its submarine base reconverted to peacetime activities, the YaleHarvard regatta, one of the biggest, returns here next Wednesday after a five-year war-necessitated absence.

SOLID beds of gray orange, gold and mahogany red nasturtiunms seen in a public Shakespearean garden last summer proved how effective mass plantings of this annual can be when weather and location suit them.

The third fatal airplane crash in fifteen days on a domestic airline, raising the death list to 146 persons, would seem to call for an immediate revaluation of safety procedures by the airlines themselves and by the Civil Aeronautics Authority. Every other consideration must be subordinated.
The annual invitation men's tennis tournament of the Hispano Club of Whitestone was revived yesterday on the club's courts, with seeded players coming through their matches with little trouble.

APPRECIATORS of the work of Franz Kafka owe an incalculable debt to Max Brod, his friend, literary executor and biographer. Convinced that Kafka was a genius, Brod exerted himself on Kafka's behalf during the latter's lifetime.

The community should see that children of school age have suitable recreational facilities during the summer and also give some guidance in cultural pursuits, according to views expressed yesterday at the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over WQXR.

LOS ANGELES, June 14 (AP) -- Ten thousand track fans, the smallest crowd of the year here, got the biggest surprise of the season last night when Mel Patton of the University of Southern California met defeat, but explanations were in order today.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- A group of leading American clergymen will leave June 23 on a thirtyfive-day mission in Europe during which they will conduct for the War Department a study of the problems facing the United States Army in Germany and Austria, Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson announced today.
THE AVERAGE American housewife puts in sixty-three hours of work a week. In Belgium the average is 114 hours.
LONDON, June 14 (Reuters) -- Sheffield United upset Stoke City by 2 -- 1 today and handed Liverpool the championship of the first division of the English Football League on a silver platter.

"ARKANSAS" is a panoramic, highly detailed story of Arkansas, past and present, by John Gould Fletcher, one of the foremost Imagist poets in the era of Amy Lowell, and still a poet whose work commands respect.

To dispel any notion that employerfinanced health and welfare funds in the women's clothing industry might be used as a union "war chest," the general executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, made public yesterday a recommendation that the union constitution be amended to outlaw the spending of sickness, vacation and other welfare funds for strikes or any purpose pertaining to the general operation of the union.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 14 -- Billy Edwards and Jim Nammack of Hempstead, the medal winners, led the way through the opening round of the Cherry Valley invitation member-guest golf tournament with a 4-and-3 victory over Dr. M.D. Webb and Dr. Robert Millen of Piping Rock, today.

LIKE its companion volumes in the "Rivers of America" series, "The Connecticut," by Walter Hard, is not so much the study of a body of water as it is of the people who dwell along its banks. It covers the past 300 years of the river's history in some detail, beginning with the day when Adrian Block first sailed past Saybrook Point in his Onrust in 1614, and ending with the great hurricane of 1938.

PASADENA ALTHOUGH the Pasadena Playhouse has become a national theatrical byword, a visitor still hardly expects to encounter in this sedate suburb much more than a nice little microcosm of dramatic culture.

MADISON, Wis., June 14 (AP) -- Washington's Huskies, warming up for next week's Poughkeepsie regatta, swept to a four-length victory over the University of Wisconsin crew on the choppy, wind-swept waters of Lake Monona today.

Intelligence I THINK that one has to distinguish between two forms of intelligence, that of the brain and that of the heart, and I have come to regard the second as by far the more important. I guard myself against saying that intelligence does not matter; the fool is ever as noxious as he is wearisome.

Prime Prices From the ranch to the dinner table, the nation's meat supply passes through four stages: feed-lots, stockyards, wholesale warehouses, retail butcher shops. Last week there was a sharp rise in meat prices that affected meat costs at each of these stages.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 14 -- Five thousand Princeton alumni took joyous part today in opening the final four-day celebration of their alma mater's bicentennial. They paraded through the campus to University Field, where they roared with uproarious glee as the Tiger baseball team unexpectedly defeated Yale.

The All-Star college squad which will meet the football Giants in the anual Tribune Fresh Air Fund game at the Polo Grounds on Sept. 3, received added strength yesterday, when it was announced that Eddie Allen and Bernie Gallagher, two stars of the University of Pennsylvania's 1946 team, had accepted invitations to play.

On Labor and Taxes Of the past twenty-nine days, President Truman has spent nineteen away from the White House -- twelve in Grandview, Mo., with his ailing mother; three at a Thirty-fifth Division reunion in Kansas City, four (including travel time) on his Canadian visit.
BEFORE roses are cut to be used in flower arrangements, they ought to be studied as they grow. The qualities they so richly possess outdoors are worth repeating in the house.

LONDON, June 14 -- Declaring that a future war would be a matter of life and death for civilization, Prime Minister Attlee asserted today that peace depended upon the actions of people as much as upon those of statesmen and governments.
ITHACA, N.Y., June 14 -- The Cornell baseball team completed its season today by defeating Colgate, 3 -- 1, in a game shortened to five innings by rain.

New York's subways have had a five-cent fare since the first of the subway lines was opened in 1903. Through the years the question of subway fare increases has frequently been broached, but the nickel fare has remained, largely because millions of subway riders whose opinions are important politically do not want a change.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., June 14 (AP) -- Weathercock, 4-year-old son of Challenger 2d, owned by Dan Harrington of Worcester, Mass., won the $10,000 added Governor's Handicap in a photo finish today at Narragansett Park.
The most lucrative family quarrel in theatrical history bickered its way into Broadway's hall of fame last night when "Life With Father" set a new endurance record with its 3,183d performance.

Many of the major food processing companies are currently pushing production of packaged products in their foreign subsidiaries, officials reported last week. Warexpanded facilities abroad, they said, are now producing at top capacity to meet the demands of a food-short world.

With collections holding up exceptionally well and business failures relatively few, the wholesale credit structure gives every indication of being in a healthy state, it was pointed out yesterday by New York credit men and bankers. The condition augurs well for the nation's business, they said, as it indicates ample liquid assets and a good net worth position for the majority of retail and wholesale merchants and manufacturers.

LONDON, June 14 -- Detailed charges that nazism and fascism, "supported by considerable means and by steadily growing influences," are "openly starting to rise again," not only in Germany and Italy, but in many countries, are made in a report published today by the International Committee for the Study of European Questions.

While sufficient is transpiring hereabouts to keep metropolitan dog fanciers busy, notably in the Longshore Kennel Club all-breed show at Westport, Conn., today, and that of the Kennel Club of Northern New Jersey in Hackensack next Sunday, a glance to the other side of the country may nevertheless be in order.

ON BOARD U.S.S. SNYDER, Off Huntingdon Bay, L.I., June 14 -- Split into two divisions, the fleet of sailing craft on the Indian Harbor Yacht Club cruise made the initial run today from Greenwich, Conn., to Price's Bend in Huntington Harbor.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- President Truman took steps today to protect for the United States foreign patent rights for inventions developed during the war through research conducted or financed by the Federal Government.

THE potboiler market is somewhat heavily stocked these days with handy little fact books on the United Nations, but frequently this kind of capsule almanac is simply an easy way to accumulate misinformation. The cautious reader approaching the "new field" of the United Nations will therefore be delighted by Dr. Harley's latest -- and very impressive -- contribution to the international library.

DYED-IN-THE-WOOL New Yorkers are frequently and righteously disturbed at the spurious way in which their city is generally imaged on the screen. For one tough and credible reflection in a locally-shot "Lost Weekend" there are six to a dozen pictures which show the big town is a painted set, they say.

California's population by 1960 may be twice what it was in 1940, according to estimates prepared by the California Reconstruction and Redevelopment Commission and cited by the Association of State Planning and Development Agencies as a warning that extensive long-range planning must be carried out to accommodate this growth.

CUMBERLAND, Md., June 14 -- An all-plastic fiberglass plane which existing radar equipment could not detect will be constructed here if the plans of A. Derr Golladay, who helped design some of the leading wartime aircraft, materialize.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- Chicagoans are anticipating improved educational opportunities for their children this fall. Their optimism arises from the complete victory scored in the generation-long battle to remove what was described as "spoils politics" from the city's public school system.
HONOLULU, June 14 (AP) -- A strong mainland A.A.U. all-star boxing team held ten victories in fourteen bouts with Hawaii's amateurs today and pointed for the final cards Monday and Wednesday nights.

Nine Cardinals will attend the International Marian Congress opening in Ottawa Wednesday and continuing through next Sunday. The ceremonies will be dedicated "as a prayer for world peace through the intercession of the Blessed Virgin Mary."
ZAGREB, June 14 (AP) -- Yugoslavia's tennis team gave South Africa a jolt in the European zone Davis Cup semi-finals today, winning both of the opening singles matches.

GOLDEN-VOICED preacher, slick-tongued promoter -- mud-slinging editor, crusading politician, defendant in a famous adultery trial -- the Rev. Mr. Kalloch began life in Maine and ended it in Washington Territory, with wayside halts to impress his questionable but always startling personality upon Massachusetts, New York, Kansas and California.

MONACO, one of Europe's smallest principalities, will open its summer season on June 25 with the silver jubilee of its ruler, Prince Louis II. For five days pageants and other carnival features will mark the present ruler's twenty-five-year reign.

Prototype plants for war production are the first new projects on the schedules of industry today, leading executives revealed, as a consequence of disclosure by Government officials that new plant capacity will be needed to meet industrial mobilization requirements.

A flood of complaints is now being received by the Department of Commerce over unethical practices of American exporters to India, it was reported yesterday. American exporters are dumping shoddy goods at prices from 10 to 15 per cent over domestic levels for quality merchandise, Commerce officials said.
BERLIN, June 14 -- Russian officials disclosed tonight the creation of a permanent German Economic Commission to formulate and carry out "measures for the revival of economy" in the Soviet zone.

Northern Indiana should be green with corn today, corn reaching for a hot June sun. Northern Indiana is green, but it is the green of oaks and maples and sassafras, and sumac along the fence rows. The cornfields are black with mud and brown with last year's stalks.
Strong support has been offered by savings and loan associations and other interests in behalf of the plan to permit these home-financing agencies to build housing "on their own."

BECAUSE it is the kind of book that must make its way quietly and slowly, the sort for which intensive promotion is quite impossible. I should like to say a little today about "Lark Rise to Candleford." Under that title the Oxford University Press published two years ago in one volume three books which had previously appeared as "Lark Rise," "Over to Candleford," and "Candleford Green."
"I hereby warn mankind to beware of women with large eyes, and crescent eyebrows, and a smile, and a love of miracles and moonsheen." -- -- G.B. Shaw.

BOSTON, June 14 (AP) -- With one seeking speed and the other power, Managers Joe Cronin of the Boston Red Sox and Ted Lyons of the Chicago White Sox today made an even swap of their first basemen, 33-year-old Rudy York for the seven-years younger Murrell Jones.

IT became more evident last week that domestic business is traveling on an evener keel although the flare-up in meat prices again drew attention to the disproportionate share of the family budget which still must be laid out for food.

DANIEL CHESTER FRENCH was a sculptor who has set for generations of Americans their familiar image of three almost legendary historical figures. His Lincoln, monumental and contemplative, sits under a massive neo-Grecian canopy at Washington.

Back in 1930 it struck Drs. Louis I. Dublin and Alfred J. Lotka, two statisticians of international reputation, that every man who insures his life wants to leave a sum of money which will enable his family, so far as that lies in his financial power, to maintain the standard of living that he has set.

More than 700 building managers, owners and agents of the commercial building throughout the country are expected to attend the fortieth annual meeting of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers at the Hotel Statler, in Boston, opening on Monday, June 23.

Significant changes in the curriculum, designed to give students more freedom in the selection of courses and to place emphasis on general education rather than on a specialized program, have been adopted by Vassar College.

RED CROSS CAMP, Va., June 14 -- The Capital airliner that crashed on a Blue Ridge mountainside last night hit with such force and burned so fiercely that the bodies of many of the fifty victims may never be fully identified. The big plane slashed a swath through trees and then smashed itself and its human cargo to bits on a granite outcropping.

LONDON, Sunday, June 15 (AP) -- The Moscow radio said today that Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov had denied a charge attributed to the British Ambassador, Sir Maurice Drummond Peterson, that Russia had engineered the coup d'etat in Hungary.

BOSTON, June 14 -- Governor Robert F. Bradford is taking part in discussions to decide what shall be done about governing Boston in the event that Mayor James M. Curley is unable to continue to serve.

JERUSALEM, June 14 -- What the Jews and Arabs of Palestine respectively feel about the United Nations special committee is plainly shown by their preparations to receive the committee when it convenes here on Monday.

Italy's Choice? In Rome last week Premier Alcide de Gasperi stood before Italy's yearold provisional Parliament to plead for the life of his relatively conservative Christian Democratic Government. His chief opponent was the Communist party.

Motor truck production and registration in the nation have reached new highs, while passenger car production -- as all who seek to trade in the faithful old "jalopy" know -- still lags far behind the demand. The Automobile Manufacturers Association has just issued the 1947 edition of Motor Truck Facts, which was suspended during the war years.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- President Truman formally signed today the peace treaties with Italy, Hungary, Rumania and Bulgaria, but sharply rebuked the governments of the last three countries for their "measures of oppression."

A bridge hand frequently comes to a point at which it is clear to everyone at the table, to the defenders as well as to the declarer, that the declarer must choose between two possible plays; if he guesses right he will make his contract; if he guesses wrong he will go down.

LILACS now deserve care after the annual bloom they have recently given. A few simple attentions will make a big difference in the amount and quality of bloom next year. Of course weather influences their performance, but the gardener also can control it to a large extent.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- The Commerce Department announced today it is now accepting applications from businessmen for permits to visit Japan, beginning Aug. 15.

EASTERNERS not wanting to go far from home this year may vacation in any of five national parks east of the Mississippi. Nearest New York is Acadia National Park, on Mount Desert Island. M Shenandoah National Park, in Virginia.

Phalanx did what was expected of him at Aqueduct yesterday -- he won the $50,000 added Dwyer stakes -- but he had to go all out to make it by a head. Those who had backed him down to 17-to-20 didn't start cooling out till the photo had been printed and the numbers went up.
LONDON, June 14 -- Uncle Sam is going to have to help out his indigent European relatives. If he does not it is going to be almost as bad for him in the long run as for them.
SUCCESSION sowing is the best way to secure continuous returns from the vegetable garden. In spite of delays earlier in the season, the plot is probably ready for second plantings now.
ST. LOUIS, June 14 -- Two proposals for the settlement of the 2-day-old St. Louis transit strike were advanced today at a conference of union and company representatives with Mayor Aloys P. Kaufmann.

MOSCOW, June 14 (AP) -- Youthful Russian geographers, puzzled by reports of Arctic rivers that flooded villages by day and receded by night, traveled to the coldest inhabited place in the world and discovered a huge glacier and mountain range, Soviet scientists said today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 (AP) -- Market value of security holdings of 144 management investment companies declined $56,189,000 during the first quarter of this year as compared to the $2,331,614,000 value at the end of 1946, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today in a quarterly survey of sixty-three open-end and eighty-one closed-end companies registered under the Investment Company Act of 1940.

A SUMMER group show at the Downtown Gallery includes work by early nineteenth century American artists side by side with contemporary work still wet from the studio and cleverly arranges some contrasts and comparisons.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 14 -- A cautious hope that the remaining Soviet-American differences over international atomic control can be settled, was expressed today by members of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission on its first birthday.

THE impetus for writing this book came, as Dr. Lips says in his preface, from a private poll he had taken on public interest in the origin of things. The result, in fifteen chapters, is a handbook of the history of human ingenuity from paleolithic cosmetics to political democracy.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In an interesting article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sunday, May 4, Hanson W. Baldwin sets forth eight reasons why, in his judgment, there is doubt regarding the worth of Universal Military Training. Each of these reasons when read casually appears to have weight.

What happens in France is of interest to everyone everywhere. The Continent of Europe cannot go Communist unless France goes Communist. On the other hand, if France goes Communist it might well mean that the Continent goes Communist. Therefore, what goes on in Paris is watched closely by the capitals of the world -- in Washington as well as in Moscow and in all the other capitals.

IN this collapsible, foldable, pack-itaway, put-it-in-your-pocket age, our industrial designers have not, alas, devised a car that you can hang on your arm or sling over your shoulder when it is not in use.

Dissatisfied with the progress made by the railroad freight carbuilding industry in a recently mapped accelerated program for the production of critically needed boxcars, a subcommittee of the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee is preparing to initiate a sweeping investigation into the situation, it was learned yesterday.

THE headline appeared to a Pittsburgh paper. It read: "Geary, Weary, AWOL Again!" That sentence might be as unintelligible as Sanscrit to most folks but to Pittsburghers and close followers of baseball it's crystal clear. It merely means that Huck Geary, a potentially great shortstop, became homesick once more and shuffled off to Buffalo -- and home.

JACQUES ROUMAIN was a young Haitian poet and ethnologist who died at Port au Prince in 1944 shortly after finishing "Masters of the Dew." Although his family was wealthy and distinguished -- his grandfather, Tancrede Auguste, had been President of the Republic -- Roumain took the side of the exploited Haitian peasants.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 14 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey warned Colgate University alumni tonight that to maintain the American system we must add emphasis to the teaching of reverence and love for country and respect for the free economic processes which have raised the United States to the highest economic level ever seen.

With the conservation agencies of every State straining their limited resources to the limit in order to provide more fish for the stocking of lakes and streams, it would seem to be the duty of the sportsmen to cooperate in the effort now being made to eliminate the pollution of our waters.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 14 -- The suggestion made yesterday by the Liberty party's leader, Deszo Sulyok, that the Hungarian elections should be held under foreign supervision to insure, as he said, their integrity, brought an angry reaction today from the Marxist parties.

STANTON, Del., June 14 -- Mrs. John D. Hertz's Owners Choice kept the record clear for New York horses winning Delaware Park stakes today when he scored a front-running victory in the $25,000 Kent Stakes. Seven stakes have now been run and every one has been won by an invader from the Empire State.

New York devotees of chess will give their attention to the activities of Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, former world champion, during his brief visit here which will end with his appearance at the Marshall Chess Club Tuesday night.

PLANS for vacations, and plans for hearty in-and-outdoor eating, go hand in hand. To be well prepared, then, this is the season to treat yourself to a new cook book. Two books which offer plenty of ideas are "How Mama Could Cook," by Dorothy Malone and "More Than Cooking," by Stella Standard.

THIS biography, by Judge Wilkin, of fascinating, manysided Cicero has three aspects. It supplies an excellently written, compact narrative of Cicero's career; the author discloses his own eminent fitness to be on the bench (he is United States district judge, Northern District of Ohio) in his compassionate understanding that no man, however great, comes all of one piece.
More than a dozen contests for Tammany Assembly district leaderships in the primary election on July 29 are in prospect, according to information obtained at Tammany headquarters, 331 Madison Avenue.

MISS ALBRAND'S legendary kingdom sounds quite a lot like northern Westchester -- or, at any rate, Hollywood's idea of it. Here, surrounded by swimming pools, private tennis courts and rafts of faithful servants, her characters float serenely above mundane problems, concentrating exclusively on love in its various forms.

MOSCOW, June 14 (U.P.) -- Soviet sports authorities reserved opinion today on whether Russia will participate in the 1948 Olympic Games, choosing to wait until Russian athletes are invited officially.

ITHACA, N.Y. THE senior classes that are trooping up to platforms this month all across the land to get their diplomas are classes like no others that have ever graduated. For one thing, as a line in the senior class history here at Cornell says, they "are not exactly the class of '47."

VIENNA. THIS year's Salzburg Festival will mark an important break with Salzburg tradition -- and a break with tradition is not something to be entered upon lightly in Austria, least of all in Salzburg.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read with great interest the letter of Dr. Taraknath Das which appeared in your columns on June 8. This letter is dated June 5. It must have been written after the details of the new British "procedural plan" were published' in this country on June 4.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- Business activity is continuing to decline while the trend to a competitive economy is accelerating, E.S. Page, chairman of the business survey committee of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago, revealed today, in comparison of business conditions during May with those prevailing at the end of last year.

LAYMEN who try to take an intelligent interest in science sometimes get the feeling that never a day goes by but somebody trundles another epochmaking discovery out of his laboratory. We tire of these oneday epochs.

UNITED NATIONS officials are now equipped with the latest in travel documents, a "laissez passer," designed to facilitate crossing national frontiers on U.N. business. Literally meaning "let pass," the term belongs in that special category of official "foreign affairs" language which every diplomat must know.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- By whatever calm and irrefutable logic it reached its decision, few actions by the Republican-controlled House of Representatives have caused it more acute embarrassment than the 54 per cent "Taberizing" it meted out to the Reclamation Service of the Interior Department.

VIENNA, June 14 -- Austrian Foreign Minister Dr. Hans Gruber said tonight in a broadcast to the Austrian people that the Soviet Union would not attempt to put the Communists in power here and would sign the Austrian treaty because it was interested primarily in limiting the spread of foreign political dangers.
CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) -- Feed grains developed strength on the Board of Trade today, bouncing back from yesterday's break, but once again wheat slipped into lower territory.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 14 -- Princeton's baseball team defeated a favored Yale nine today for the first time in their last twelve meetings. On University Field, before 10,000 Princeton alumni and guests, Bob Wolcott shut out the Elis, 1 to 0.

LONDON. WINSTON CHURCHILL, recently described the last war as "unnecessary." It is true that all wars have been "unnecessary," but that does not mean that given the total circumstances of the times they could have been prevented.

THE relationship between the broadcasters and the Federal Government, which has been a source of controversy practically since radio's birth a quarter of a century ago, will come to the fore again this week. Beginning Tuesday, hearings are Scheduled to be held in Washington on the bill of Senator Wallace H. White, Republican, of Maine, to overhaul the basic law under which radio operates from day to day.

Buyers in great numbers continued to shop the wholesale markets last week, concentrating on ready-to-wear, but showing great interest in piece goods and cotton wash goods, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

CINCINNATI, June 14 -- The second time around, they say, is always a bit tougher. The Giants learned that today as they embarked on their second swing around the western loop of the National League and tripped right over the Reds at the very start.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Through the years Atlantic City's mammoth Convention Hall, one of the world's largest auditoriums, has been the scene of innumerable events. From the huge hall have come important decisions on political, social and economic problems that have affected the daily lives of millions of persons.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 14 (AP)-- California-bred On Trust captured the $25,000 added Will Rodgers Handicap at Hollywood Park today against twelve rival 3-year-olds. Handlebars was a surprise second, with Sullivan third in a hotly contested seven-furlong race before 39,435 fans.

OAKLAND, Calif., June 14--A new conciliation meeting, aimed at ending the Key System strike which has paralyzed public transportation in the Oakland metropolitan district for four days, failed to produce an agreement today.

ALMOST any paragraph, almost any sentence from the writings of a wise man will convey the special tone and signature of his wisdom. Alfred North Whitehead is one of the true and rare sages of our time. He describes himself in one essay of this volume as the typical Victorian, and his reflections seem to have the stamp of a serene world, ordered and remote.

SUCHOW, China, June 12 (Delayed) -- Hundreds are dying every week from starvation and disease in the war-torn northeastern corner of Kiangsu. This information was brought here today by the Rev. Wilfred McLaughlin, American mission worker from the port of Haichow.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 14 -- The Clemence-Irons House on George Waterman Road in adjacent Johnston, one of the most authentic examples of the type of home inhabitated by seventeenthcentury Rhode Islanders, has been presented to the Society for the Preservation of New England Antiquities by three prominent residents of this city.

ADAH ISAACS MENKEN managed during the last ten of her thirty-three years of life to become the most notorious, reckless and attractive woman in the public eye in New York, San Francisco, London and Paris as well as some other less populous communities.
