IT TAKES good recipes to insure good eating, and it takes time and thought and experimenting to find the best way of preparing foods. Margaret Yardley Potter, in her book, "At Home on the Range," and Anna Olsson Coombs, in her book, "Modem Swedish Cookbook," pass on to the reader the benefit of their years of experiences.

Action of the House Appropriations Committee in reducing the proposed Federal Housing subsidy fund for the coming fiscal year from $7,200,000 to $2,200,000 threatens to disrupt the whole public low-rent housing set-up and future program throughout the country.
BUDAPEST, Sunday, June 15 (AP) -- The Russian commander in Budapest today refused, for the third time, an American proposal for a tripartite investigation of Hungarian internal affairs.

Bolstered by expressions of confidence and a realization that foreign conditions, despite their gravity, must somehow be settled before the nations of the world can achieve tranquillity, the stock market last week registered the widest gain in share prices this year.

A PROJECT to the liking of the departmental trend spotter turned up last week with the announcement that Lee Strasberg and Anderson Lawlor were forming a firm to develop writers for the stage and screen. Roughly, what the gentlemen propose is to work with writers on material they like, advise them on what makes merchandisable properties in either medium and produce worthy items on Broadway.

LISBON FALLS, ME. A FELLOW who ought to know better sent me a newspaper clipping that says city people have better mental health than us country folks. A professor out at Ohio State University made a survey and said so, but being a professor he said it in a nice way, and I don't know as I have ever been called a fool in more learned language.
OMAHA, June 14 -- Is the inflated balloon of farm land values and farm commodity prices likely to explode with crippling results for the farmer?

CURRENT styles in commercial transport plancs run to four engines, high-speed, long-range performance and seating capacity for fifty or more passengers. The Lockheed Constellation and the Douglas DC-6 are two planes combining those features, and the Boeing Stratocruiser -- when it goes into service -- will be the same, only more so.

Queens College will confer baccalaureate degrees Tuesday on 255 seniors, the largest graduating class in the ten years of the college, at outdoor commencement exercises on the campus Quadrangle in Flushing.

WITH the June splendor of hybrid tea roses reaching its peak in gardens and display grounds, we have perhaps the best opportunity of the year to make a general survey of their varieties. The particular kinds, old or new, which promise to give the most enjoyment can be selected.

The refusal of the New York Public Service Commission to order into effect intrastate passenger fares in conformity with a recent decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission granting higher fares to railroads in the East is causing a considerable loss of revenue to the railroads operating in New York State and is creating an unsatisfactory operating condition.

ABYSSINIA has issued five miniature sheets each containing twelve stamps "in memory of the second anniversary of the death of Franklin D. Roosevelt." Postal paper associated with the late President has appeared also in Argentina, Brazil, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Ecuador, Greece, Guatemala, Haiti, Honduras, Hungary, Liberia, Monaco, Nicaragua, Salvador, San Marino, Turkey and the United States.

PARIS (By Wireless) SCRAWLED in whitewash on the window of a neat little bakery in the Rue Pergolese is a sign reading: "Bread at 11 o'clock." This means that there is no bread until that hour when, exactly on schedule, it will emerge from the ovens and be quickly sold out.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 14 -- Signing of an agreement with the Independent Marine Firemen, Oilers, Watertenders and Wipers, extending their present contract without change to June 15, 1948, was announced today by J.B. Bryan, president of the Pacific American Shipowners Association, as efforts continued to avert a threatened shipping tie-up on this coast at midnight tomorrow.

Father's Day stimulated business in men's furnishings last week according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Cotton dress departments were very active and beachwear departments were crowded.

IF someone read aloud to you when you were 5 years old, chances are that you remember it now. Maybe you heard tales by Andrew Lang, or Hans Christian Andersen, or "The Three Bears" or the "Just So Stories."

STOCKHOLM, June 14 -- The traditional Olympic salute may be discontinued at the 1948 games in London because of its resemblance to the salute once used by the Nazis, it was disclosed tonight as members of the International Olympic Committee prepared to open a week-long meeting here Monday.

ALTHOUGH the automobile industry is pretty much a man's world, at least 80 per cent of the important improvements in cars and motors which make for driving ease and riding comfort can be attributed to the influence of women as drivers and passengers.

LOS ANGELES, June 14 -- The Rev. Will H. Houghton, president of the Moody Bible Institute of Chicago, and a former pastor of the Calvary Baptist Church in New York City, died early today at the Hollywood Receiving Hospital after collapsing in his suite at the Ambassador Hotel.

WHEN the summer concerts of the New York Philharmonic Society were instituted at the Lewisohn Stadium in June of 1918 the kind of program that Pierre Monteux will present for the opening of the 1947 season tomorrow night would have been viewed with alarm by the sponsors of the project, if not by its prospective public.

AN economist by profession (recently at Hamilton College, formerly at The Hague), and, judging from this book, a confirmed internationalist by faith, Mr. Heilperin sees economic nationalism as the arch-villain of the era that witnessed two great wars and a great depression.

ATLANTA, June 14 -- Many small towns in the Southeastern States appear today to be threatened with large-scale out-migrations, because of heavy proportions of unemployment and serious imbalances between employment of men and of women workers.

BOSTON, June 14 -- The Massachusetts Institute of Technology, whose scientists have played a large part in developing the atom bomb, controlled missiles and other weapons, in addition to making peacetime technical advances, needs an additional $28,000,000.

HERE is an author who has been shabbily treated by the swift passage of time, during which there have occurred developments inevitable in a competition for labor leadership between Communists and honest trade unionists.

MAHAN'S inconspicuous naval service during the Civil was perhaps less important to his later career than the threeyear cruise which he made shortly after the war. It was on this cruise to the Asiatic station via the Cape of Good Hope, with subsequent detachment and return via Suez, that he first realized what he spoke of many years later as "the continual outcropping of the British soldier" along the maritime routes.

ST. LOUIS, June 14 (AP) -- A veteran and a dangerous newcomer will battle it out for the title tomorrow in another play-off finish of the United States open golf tournament and it looks as if the veteran -- Slammin' Sammy Snead -- will win this one.

WHAT sort of research organization or lack of organization leads to the greatest production of scientific knowledge? With a new drive on to establish a national science foundation, this question is of national importance.

JERUSALEM, June 14 -- Arriving here today Chief Justice Emil Sandstroem of Sweden, chairman of the United Nations Committee of Inquiry on Palestine, disclosed that the committee would tour the country "to get the background" of the Palestine problem before starting its hearings.

Eighty-two members of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association will compete in the annual championship which will be held at the Westchester Hills Golf Club, White Plains, starting tomorrow and continuing through Friday.

CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) -- Joe DiMaggio of the New York Yankees today took the lead as fans balloted for teams to compete in the All-Star baseball game July 8. DiMaggio displaced Ted Williams of the Boston Red Sox.

IF someone read aloud to you when you were 5 years old, chances are that you remember it now. Maybe you heard tales by Andrew Lang, or Hans Christian Andersen, or "The Three Bears" or the "Just So Stories."

STOCKHOLM, June 14 -- The traditional Olympic salute may be discontinued at the 1948 games in London because of its resemblance to the salute once used by the Nazis, it was disclosed tonight as members of the International Olympic Committee prepared to open a week-long meeting here Monday.

ALTHOUGH the automobile industry is pretty much a man's world, at least 80 per cent of the important improvements in cars and motors which make for driving ease and riding comfort can be attributed to the influence of women as drivers and passengers.

LOS ANGELES, June 14 -- The Rev. Will H. Houghton, president of the Moody Bible Institute of Chicago, and a former pastor of the Calvary Baptist Church in New York City, died early today at the Hollywood Receiving Hospital after collapsing in his suite at the Ambassador Hotel.

During May private builders started work on 1,150 new dwelling units in New York, as compared with 790 during the previous month, according to figures released yesterday by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

IT was inevitable that there should be a new book about Thomas Erskine -- the eloquent defense counsel in the long series of attempts to stifle free speech and liberal opinion in England in the Seventeen Nineties. Frightened almost out of their wits by the revolutionary theories coming across the Channel, Pitt and his conservative backers instituted a witch hunt for radicals and Jacobin fellow-travelers.

THE constantly growing list of public rose gardens will be increased by one more when a fifteen-acre planting of this popular flower in Newark, N.Y., is opened formally to the public at 9 A.M. on June 21. Thus the Jackson Perkins Company will mark its seventy-fifth anniversary as a grower of roses and perennials and will give new meaning to its annual Rose Festival.

BIG museums, numerous galleries and resident wealthy collectors have made Manhattan the mecca of the American art world for so long that New York has, perhaps, become a little smug and somewhat patronizing in its attitude toward the rest of the country. So far as contemporary American art is concerned.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 14 -- A large slaughter-house company that has abattoirs on the site of the projected world capital in midtown Manhattan has asked the United Nations for permission to remain there until next October, and preferably later, it was learned today.

If a physician who practiced his science and art in 1847 could have attended the centennial meeting of the American Medical Association at Atlantic City last week he would probably have regarded nearly everything that he saw and heard as a colossal joke.

LONDON. A BBC comic the other day said that our slogan in 1940 was "Britain Can Take It." In 1946 it was "Britain Can Make It." Today it is "Britain Can't Have It." This latest slogan applies to some extent to television.

PARIS, June 14 -- Marius Moutet, French Overseas Minister, has asked the War Minister to screen Foreign Legion regiments in IndoChina for German war criminals suspected of hiding out under the French flag, it was learned today. It has been acknowledged that the two regiments of the Foreign Legion serving in Indo-China contain many Germans but the Army has reported that most of these were enrolled before the war.

THE third volume of the Navy's "Battle Report" series continues with marked success the hard task of telling in "simple ...well-rounded" form, what "happened to Navy men and Navy ships" in the maelstrom of World War II

IT is doubtful if factual books about foreign countries ever ensnare the imagination of the young so tightly as do really good stories about them. Remember the first time you met Lucy Fitch Perkins' "Dutch Twins," or Thomas Handforth's naughty "Mei Li"?

MEDFORD, Mass., June 14 -- President Leonard Carmichael of Tufts College revealed today that the college received a total of $1,173,569 in gifts and bequests during the past year. This, he indicated, was one of the largest sums received by the institution in many years.

SANDY HOOK, N.J. -- After more than five years of Army restriction, a two-mile stretch of beach on the Fort Hancock military reservation here has been opened for surf casting. This strip of shore is one of the finest spots for striped bass fishing along the Atlantic coast.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 14 -- Frank Hague will take his departure from public office next Tuesday evening and make a show of it.

Plans are being completed by the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards for its annual meeting, to open on June 25 at Saranac Inn, N.Y. More than 300 registrations have been made, including nearly forty from the New York board.

LOS ANGELES, June 14 -- Militarytype "road-blocks" and screenings executed periodically by surprise at key intersections throughout the city were credited this week by Los Angeles police with having effected a considerable reduction in crime.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Southern Conference for Human Welfare, which is sponsor of a mass meeting for former Vice President Henry Wallace here on Monday night, was characterized by the House Un-American Activities Committee today as "perhaps the most deviously camouflaged Communist-front organization."

DAYTON, Ohio, June 14 -- Naval officers and men who served at the Bikini atom bomb tests last summer have been ordered to submit to blood tests, as a check against possible exposure to radioactivity, it was learned today.

IOWA -- U.S. Civilization A new major in "American civilization" will be offered at the University of Iowa for the first time next fall. It will be a two-year program covering the fields of history, literature, social science, economics, art and philosophy. In explaining its purpose, the courseplanning committee declared:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 14 (AP) -- Twenty-nine eight-oared crews from eleven colleges will converge on Poughkeepsie today and tomorrow for a final week of training before the twilight races next Saturday that will revive the famed regatta after a six-year lapse.

History is repeating itself in the sport of speed boating. Just as after World War I the daredevils had to turn to automobile motors and, somewhat timidly, to the noisy old Liberty aircraft engines, so after World War II the speed demons who want to break records on the regatta ovals are utilizing conversions of auto power plants and now and then some airplane Allisons.

GOVERNMENT CAMP, Ore. WHILE America's young men were away at war, the Forest Service discovered that women could hold down the loneliest jobs in the United States. Indeed, they held them down so competently that this month many females of assorted backgrounds and ages are returning to the task of guarding the vast forests of the Pacific Northwest from the summertime menace of fire.

WITH a light touch and gently ironic attack, Ralph Arnold dissects an imaginary spot of English countryside along with its inhabitants much in the same way Angela Thirkell has done in her Barsetshire series. Yet there is this difference:
President Truman will address the opening session of the American Legion's national convention in Madison Square Garden on the morning of Aug. 28, it was announced here yesterday.

JUST seven years ago this week in this Review: A short look back, since time is swift these days: Page one has a new novel by Upton Sinclair, "World's End," and critic R.L. Duffus commends Mr. Sinclair for writing "a novel of the edges of war" but not of "drums and trumpets."

The Eightieth Congress has been outstandingly conspicuous for the number of pieces of major legislation passed by decisive majorities which have been accompanied by talk of a Presidential veto. The portal-to-portal bill, for example, passed the House 345 to 56 and the Senate 64 to 24, yet right up to the moment that Mr. Truman attached his signature it was being confidently predicted by many that the measure would be vetoed.

-- PROGRESS The long-run mood of the United States, John Gunther finds, is progressive. To a hasty observer that's hard to believe at times -- and this may be one of the times. Yet look at the gains of the last fifty years.

THOMAS MANN is the last of a long line of European world-figures. In his panoramic and generalizing qualities, he is a true son of the nineteenth century, the age of the grandiose and the monumental in art, memorializing the triumph of the enlightenment and of the humanist and liberal tradition.

GOVERNMENT CAMP, Ore. WHILE America's young men were away at war, the Forest Service discovered that women could hold down the loneliest jobs in the United States. Indeed, they held them down so competently that this month many females of assorted backgrounds and ages are returning to the task of guarding the vast forests of the Pacific Northwest from the summertime menace of fire.

President Truman will address the opening session of the American Legion's national convention in Madison Square Garden on the morning of Aug. 28, it was announced here yesterday.

JUST seven years ago this week in this Review: A short look back, since time is swift these days: Page one has a new novel by Upton Sinclair, "World's End," and critic R.L. Duffus commends Mr. Sinclair for writing "a novel of the edges of war" but not of "drums and trumpets."

The Eightieth Congress has been outstandingly conspicuous for the number of pieces of major legislation passed by decisive majorities which have been accompanied by talk of a Presidential veto. The portal-to-portal bill, for example, passed the House 345 to 56 and the Senate 64 to 24, yet right up to the moment that Mr. Truman attached his signature it was being confidently predicted by many that the measure would be vetoed.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (U.P.) -- The housewife, already beset by high food prices, faces another problem -- this one involving the family health.

SPRINGFIELD, Vt., June 15 -- An Army B-29, battling a blinding storm, carried twelve men to death shortly after midnight today as it crashed at 250 miles an hour into a granite ledge on Hawkes Mountain. Shocked villagers, aroused from sleep by its low, roaring flight to disaster, saw the plane's lights blink a final, frantic plea for help before it crashed and exploded.
MANHASSET, L.I., June 15 -- The town fathers of North Hempstead have hauled out a legislative shotgun and trained the sights on pigeons and all fur-bearing animals, except cats and dogs.

A plan to begin a nation-wide drive aimed at making candy as popular a gift for Father's Day as it is for Mother's Day was announced over the week-end by the Association of Manufacturers of Confectionery and Chocolate of New York.

A complete clothing factory in Baltimore has been bought by the Jewish Joint Distribution Committee for dismantling and shipment overseas to enable survivors of concentration camps to make their own clothing, it was announced yesterday.

Out-of-town buyers were in the New York wholesale markets last week in large numbers placing orders for fall in good quantity and with much less conservatism than earlier display, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

MANTOLOKING, N.J., June 15 -- Harold E. Stassen, declared candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1948, made his first move today to get delegate support in New Jersey. He was the guest of honor at a reception held at the estate of Amos J. Peaslee, a close friend, as well as a New Jersey political figure.

When the Taft-Fulbright bill to create a new Federal Department of Health, Education and Security came out of committee eleven days ago Senator Aiken of Vermont remarked that "what it really does is to raise the human being to the level of dignity already enjoyed by the Holstein cow through the Department of Agriculture."

MEXICO CITY, June 15 -- A national children's foundation dedicated to the protection and welfare of this country's thousands of underprivileged youngsters is projected in a new law backed by President Miguel Aleman, it was learned today.
Brooklyn College graduated 1,583 young men and women yesterday at its twenty-second commencement.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market moved into higher ground last week, with the best gains in the nearer positions. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange at Friday's close were up 15 to 67 points in the week.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of May 30 you printed a statement by America's leading librarians supporting the State Department's maintenance of seventy American libraries in foreign countries. The department's "Voice of America" programs have likewise received a great deal of public support.

LONDON, June 15 -- The embattled housewives of Britain, of whom those enrolled in the Housewives League have been harshly criticized by Government Ministers, received unexpected moral support today from the National Union of General and Municipal Workers, one of the most powerful British unions.

ST. LOUIS, June 15 -- There's a reason for the nick name his fellow -professionals nave bestowed on Lew Worsham, the new open golf champion. They call him "the chin" on account of the prominence of his jaw. Protruding jaws are supposed to indicate great perseverance and tenacity.

Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr, chairman of the American Association for a Democratic Germany, declared yesterday that the United States was "in imminent danger of defeat" in the struggle for democracy in Germany.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- President Truman, "deeply concerned" over the recent series of aviation accidents, appointed today a special five-man board to examine and promote the safety of air transport operations.

PITTSBURGH, June 15 (AP) -- The Boston Braves used the hapless Pittsburgh Pirates as a springboard into first place today as they flattened the cellar-dwelling Pirates, 13 to 4 in the opener and 12 to 3 in the nightcap of their Sunday doubleheader.

HANOVER, Germany, June 15 -- All German, newspapers circulated in the Stats of Niedersachsen [Lower Saxony] will be ordered to carry in every issue a column explaining the official British Military Government point of view on current crises and events in this Land, it was learnned today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 15 -- President Truman today assured the 800 delegates to the sixtieth annual convention of the Independent Order Brith Abraham of his determination to do everything in his power to reach a "just solution" in Palestine.

ST. LOUIS, June 15 -- Stirred by the upward surge of the Cards against the docile Dodgers, 29,686 St. Louis fans, the largest home attendance of the year, came to Sportsman's Park today -- and they didn't go home disappointed.

ROME, June 15 -- The Socialists and Communists made no effort today to hide their anger over the Constituent Assembly's decision yesterday to prolong its own life until Dec. 31, which makes it certain that a general election will not be held until next year.

Three suburban pastors celebrated yesterday the golden jubilees of their ordination. Two of the services were in Yonkers for the Rev. Dr. Oliver Shaw Newell and the Rev. Dr. Alexander Von Schlichten, and the third in Jersey City for Msgr. Thomas F. Monaghan.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 15 -- Universal-International has purchased screen rights to "Gus the Great," a forthcoming novel by Thomas Duncan for a price reportedly more than $200,000. A 1,500page work, the novel deals with a man's circus career beginning in the Eighteen Eighties and ending in the Nineteen Twenties.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 15 -- A fleet of 114 yachts the best of the season, was favored with splendid sailing conditions today in the Yacht Racing Association's ninth championship regatta, sponsored by the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.
LIDICE, Czechoslovakia, June 15 (U.P.) -- Czechoslovakia laid a foundation stone for the new home of the widows of Lidice today while a thunderstorm lashed their husbands' mass grave.

LEWISTON, Me., June 15 (AP) -- Warren R. Austin declared today that the United Nations had made "amazing progress" which he said "gives promise of as rapid development of collective security and peace as we ought to expect."
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 15 (AP) -- Knocking on wood just for good luck, Coach Hube Glendon said today his Columbia Lions are "as ready now as they'll ever be."

Shy $5,400 of a $20,000 goal, The Company of Twelve has deferred the launching of its bargainprice stock season at the City Center from June 30 to July 14. Asked to confirm a rumor that a Wednesday deadline had been set to get the required sum, an official of the group expressed confidents yesterday that no trouble would be encountered in raising the balance.
Robert L. Riggs will begin the defense of his national professional championship today as the tournament starts in the stadium of the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Former President Herbert Hoover today issued a gloomy report on the economic and political state of the world and concluded that the United States would have to produce more or consume less if it was to be able to deal with it effectively.

The one group of persons in the world about whom no political, economic or ideological question can be raised, but who themselves pose a challenging question, is the children. In the war-devastated areas of Central and Eastern Europe twenty to thirty million children are suffering from malnutrition and disease.

PITTSBURGH, June 15 -- Outlaw coal strikes that hit steel company coal mines in this area last week are expected to affect the steel operating rate to some extent this week. Steel companies that had been attempting to build up supplies as a hedge against a nationwide mine shutdown on July 7, were forced to dip into their supply in order to offset the loss.

JERUSALEM, June 15 -- After having received preliminary factual information on Palestine from the British administration and the Jewish Agency for Palestine, it was announced today, the United Nations' committee will begin, its inspection on Wednesday with visits to Jewish, Christian and Moslem religious shrines in and around Jerusalem.
AMHERST, Mass., June 15 -- Secretary Marshall called upon war veterans today to support him in the attempt to obtain "lasting peace" in the world.

When Foreign Secretary Bevin meets with Foreign Minister Bidault in Paris tomorrow to explore the possibility of drafting a continental plan for European recovery with American aid, they will initiate an undertaking of momentous potentialities for Europe and the world.

Archbishop Leonty of the Russian Orthodox Holy Trinity Cathedral in Chicago officiated yesterday at the first mass to be celebrated since 1926 in the St. Nicholas Russian Orthodox Cathedral, 15 East Ninety-seventh Street, by representatives of the Russian Orthodox Church in North America.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Convention registration and other preliminaries today marked the eve of the annual International Cost Conference of the National Association of Cost Accountants. The association, with headquarters in New York, has 23,000 members throughout the world, about one-tenth of whom are expected at the threeday meeting beginning tomorrow.
Beating his nearest rival by a mile and a quarter, Mikko Hietanen, Finland's European marathon champion, created a new American record for the 15-mile run at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 15 -- Princeton's Third Century Fund has made a flying start, Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, president of the university, reported today. He told a meeting of the National Alumni Association that the fund, which was started last October, would approximate $1,000,000 by the end of this month.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The relationship of the Missouri and Mississippi flood damage to American foreign policy may not at once be evident, but anyone who reflects about it will readily see that we cannot long permit the continuance of this soil wastage without seriously weakening our country's ability to hold its own in the family of nations.
LONDON, June 15 -- The Moscow radio broadcast tonight an official denial of the Outer Mongolian Government that its troops had invaded the Chinese Province of Sinkiang.

The United States Bureau of Public Roads has set up a comprehensive longterm program to bring about an "era of national relief from the growing blight of automobile congestion." For the first time an over-all plan is envisioned to cope with the problems of city traffic, suburban traffic and through travel between major population centers.

Winning all six of its matches, a star-studded Salle Santelli trio, made up of Dean Cetrulo, Jose de Capriles and Dr. Tibor Nyilas -- all present or former champions -- took the three-weapon crown on the strips of the New York Athletic Club as the week-long national fencing championships were continued yesterday.

NANKING, June 15 -- Fighting between Chinese and Outer Mongolian forces during their recent clash at Peitashan on the northern frontier of Sinkiang Province lasted for three days, according to a dispatch released here today by the Central News Agency from Urumchi.

CLEVELAND, June 15 -- Increased emphasis on united political action by American labor to halt the legislative onslaughts of "union-baiters and reactionary politicians" was recommended today in a report by the general executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL.

LOS ANGELES, June 15 -- Three thousand members of five CIO maritime unions prepared late today to paralyze Los Angeles harbor at one minute after midnight unless last minute orders calling off the nation-wide strike were received from New York and San Francisco negotiators.

Representatives of Scottish, Welsh and Breton cultural groups in the New York area joined with the Irish yesterday afternoon to participate for the first time in the fifteenth annual Feis, sponsored by the United Irish Counties Association, on the Fordham University campus in the Bronx.

CLINTON, N.Y., June 15 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey urged the Hamilton College graduating class today to seek careers in government, declaring that "we must face the fact that government has become our biggest industry and will continue to be big."
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Henry A. Wallace said today that Great Britain and the United States would fight if Russia should attempt to expand to central Turkey and thus threaten Saudi Arabian oil.

MAYWOOD, N.J., June 15 -- Mrs. Marguerite Gardner, 57 years old, of 586 Lucy Avenue, Teaneck, was shot dead and her sister, Mrs. Jeanette Sylvestri, 60, of 34 East Pleasant Avenue here, was wounded critically this afternoon by a third woman as the result of a quarrel in which the victims had no part.

BOSTON, June 15 (AP) -- Only twenty-four hours after becoming a Red Socker, Murrell Jones hit a homer in each game as the American League champions gained ground by sweeping a doubleheader from his recent White Sox teammates by 7 -- 3 and 8 -- 4 margins today before a packed 34,024 crowd.

A crowd of 14,000 cheered more than 400 competitors in a fivehour track and field meet for members of the New York City Police Department held yesterday afternoon at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, under the auspices of the newly formed Police Department Athletic Club.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 15 -- My Bill, chestnut gelding owned and ridden throughout the threeday Greenwich Horse show by Mrs. Hank Greenberg, the former Miss Caral Gimbel, of New York City, garnered the young hunter championship and conformation hunter reserve championship today.

ZURICH, Switzerland, June 15 -- Discreet soundings in behalf of the French Government about the possibility of floating in Switzerland a loan issued in American dollars and bearing interest at not more than 4 per cent produced a very sharp reaction among Swiss commercial banks.

FROM the indictment of the twenty-one Nazi chieftains until the final climax of their monstrous story, which found Goering a suicide, ten others dead by the hangman's rope, seven sentenced to prison terms and Schacht, von Papen and Fritzsche acquitted, Capt. G.M. Gilbert served as prison psychologist in the Nuremberg jail.

Excavations and building operations have their sidewalk superintendents, true, but the gadget counters in housewares departments have just as loyal a following -- and it's not entirely a feminine one, either. Last week we joined the latter group to see what was new and what had returned, after a wartime absence, in the way of kitchen utensils designed to lighten the housewife's work.

PARIS, June 15 -- French employers and labor organizations, invited by the Government to get together on a scale of production bonuses in lieu of pay increases, tonight expressed doubt that the plan would work. Their statements indicated the prospect of most difficult discussions.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., June 15 -- On the second run of the cruise of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club of Greenwich, Conn., which was from Huntington Harbor to the bell buoy off here, Mrs. Samuel Peck's white-hulled and whitesparred yawl Good News and Arthur Davis' sloop Patricia were the winning craft in the two outstanding classes.

OTTUMWA, Iowa, June 15 (AP) -- Flood workers in their ten-day battle with the debris-filled Des Moines River strove today to save the city waterworks and prevent a power failure as the muddy waters receded very slowly after cresting at 6 A.M. (Central Standard Time).

STOCKHOLM, June 15 (AP) -- This Swedish capital loomed as a darkhorse candidate tonight for the honor of being the host city for the 1952 Olympics as delegates from several cities sought acceptance of their offers by the International Olympic Committee Which opens its sessions tomorrow.

Alexander A. Falk, former State Senator, announced yesterday his withdrawal from all partisan political activity because of representations to him that his candidacy for the Tammany leadership of the Fifteenth Assembly District would interfere with his duties as a member of the State Civil Service Commission, to which he was appointed recently by Governor Dewey.

A 42-year-old longshoreman was booked as a material witness yesterday afternoon at the West Forty-seventh Street Station in the machine-gun killing of Vincent Wice, 31, on crowded West Fortyseventh Street, between Tenth and Eleventh Avenues, shortly before noon last Saturday.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 15 -- Former Premier Ferenc Nagy and the Rev. Bela Varga, former President of the Parliament, will be tried in their absence on a charge of conspiracy against the Hungarian Republic, is was reported today.

Aeronautical charts of the region in which the Pennsylvania Central Airlines' DC-4 crashed Friday night indicate how close to safety the plane was. Within a mile of the crash scene a CAA course beacon marked the next to last ridge of the Alleghanies.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Dr. Charles Clayton Morrison, editor of the Christian Century, one of the leading non-denominational Protestant weeklies, today announced his retirement after forty years with the publication.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 15 -- Britain will inform the United Nations' Security Council this week that the Big Four have been unable to agree on a governor for Trieste and that consequently the seven-month search for the right man must begin all over again, it was disclosed today.

One hundred members of the American Academy of Dental Medicine attended the first annual meeting yesterday in the George Washington Hotel, Lexington Avenue at Twenty-third Street, and in Alpha Omega Fraternity House, 41 East Nineteenth Street.

J.K. Lasser, chairman of New York University's Institute on Federal Taxation, has become affiliated with the University of Miami, Coral Gables, Fla., as director of the annual Conference on Federal Taxation and consultant on business research.
A work stoppage by maritime unions beginning at midnight last night threatened the nation's seaborne commerce with complete paralysis less than eight months after settlement of a similar walkout.

LEESBURG, Va., June 15 (AP) -- Recovery of the instrument panel of the Pennsylvania Central (Capital) Airlines plane which crashed with a death toll of fifty was reported today, but investigators said they have not determined the cause of the disaster and launched a far-reaching inquiry.

The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, CIO, spent $2,882,840 last year, according to the union's annual financial report, made public yesterday by its president, Jacob S. Potofsky, and its secretary-treasurer, Frank Rosenblum.

Most of the members of the Board of Estimate do not yet share Mayor O'Dwyer's disposition to favor a fare rise on the municipal transit lines sufficient to meet operating deficits, an informal survey revealed yesterday. The survey also disclosed that in general organized labor and the political parties in the city are definitely against such a fare rise.

A grant of $250,000 for an experimental five-year program to develop in this country four permanent university study centers on Latin America was announced yesterday by the Carnegie Corporation of New York.

CARENTAN, France, June 15 (AP) -- Ten thousand persons swarmed from the Normandy countryside into this arch-spanned, flag-bedecked town today and joined in a solemn High Mass celebrating the liberation of Carentan by United States troops on July 14, 1944.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, advocating the restoration of price control in order to avoid a depression, Henry Waldman states "the OPA, with all its shortcomings, did keep prices down and curb inflation."

Three Cardinals participated in services at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. The 8 o'clock mass was celebrated by Eugene Cardinal Tisserant of Rome, French-born Papal Secretary of the Sacred Congregation for the Oriental Church.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Senate and House will meet at noon tomorrow alerted for President Truman's word on the $4,000,000,000 tax-reduction bill, which the Chief Executive has said he will sign or veto by tomorrow night.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 15 -- Although a jurisdictional dispute between carpenters and laborers, both American Federation of Labor affiliates, which has snarled an estimated $30,000,000 of large industrial construction projects for the last few months in Union County still is unsettled in many cases, the tieup is easing on a number of jobs, a survey revealed yesterday.

It was Junior's turn instead of Dad's to do the spending for presents yesterday. Since 1910 the third Sunday in June has been observed as Father's Day, and as a result of the younger generation's "digging down" all over the country many fathers were wearing new ties, showing off new sport shirts, or smoking fresh cigars.

Italy looks forward to eventual revision at the "very harsh" terms of its treaty and needs $2,000,000,000 in credits for the next four years to re-establish its economy, Giuseppe Saragat, leader of the Socialist Party of Italian Workers, said on his arrival yesterday at La Guardia Field.

PARIS, June 15 -- When they meet in Paris Tuesday, British Foreign Secretary Bevin and French Foreign Minister Bidault will seek to insure action this summer on the Marshall suggestion for a European agreement on a joint program for the use of United States reconstruction credits.

Direct obligations of the United Estates Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $49,993,271,447. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

JERUSALEM, June 15 -- No danger threatens the United Nations' special committee on Palestine "from the Hebrew underground Army," the Irgun Zvai Leumi broadcast tonight. Simultaneously, Haganah's high command was reported to have announced that it would countenance no disturbances during the committee's investigations here.
MADRID, June 15 -- Denials by the Russians that they have traded with Franco Spain have brought out here further details of the specific transactions.

Outstanding among the art events this week will be an exhibition opening Friday at the Metropolitan Museum -- the showing of American contemporary sculpture from the collections of the Metropolitan and Whitney Museums, for an indefinite period.

New demands to halt the runaway prices of meat were made on Mayor O'Dwyer and Governor Dewey yesterday as the city's Department of Markets made ready for today's survey to determine how far prices have advanced in all neighborhoods.

MADRID, June 15 -- Senora Eva Duarte de Peron, wife of Argentina's President, arrived at Granada by plane tonight, after a week's stay in Madrid, on the next stage of an air trip around Spain. She will proceed to Seville, Corunna, Saragossa and Barcelona before leaving for Italy.

Higher pier rentals and charges for various other waterfront facilities were recommended yesterday to Mayor O'Dwyer by Controller Lazarus Joseph, who said the city's policy should be to set its charges just high enough to break even on its waterfront investments.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 15 -- Back after a four-month inspection of guerrilla warfare in Greece, members of the United Nations Balkans Investigating Commission will convene here tomorrow morning.

CINCINNATI, June 15 -- Coming up with one of their characteristic big innings, the Giants flattened the Reds today in the second half of a double header that for a time threatened a complete rout for the Polo Grounders.
The value of fluorine in preventive dentistry and cautions concerning its use are outlined for parents in the summer issue of Dental Health, issued yesterday.

New examples of Italian craftsmanship that indicate foreign artists are aware of decorating trends in this country will go on exhibit today at The House of Italian Handicrafts, 217 East Forty-Ninth Street. The collection includes hand-fashioned mahogany coffee tables, black ceramic vases, modern brass and other home accessories by craftsmen from villages and cities throughout Italy.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 15 (AP) -- The text of the note from Lieut. Gen. V.P. Sviridov, Russian commander in Hungary, to Brig. Gen. George 3. Weems, chief of the United States military mission here, refusing a proposal for a Big Three investigation of Hungarian political affairs:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It was no lack of patience with Soviet chessmasters which caused the American sponsors of the proposed United States-U.S.S.R. chess match to call off the 1947 games, but an inability to keep our players' time open, as well as to retain the hall and hotel reservations which we had made until a suitable date could be agreed on between our committee and the Russians.

Following is the text of a letter, dated yesterday and under the caption "The Limits of American Aid to Foreign Countries," from Herbert Hoover to Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire and chairman of the Senate Committee on Appropriations:

M.G. Klosty, vice president of T. J. Stevenson Co., ship operators, announced yesterday that the line had purchased the war-built Liberty ship Raymond Clapper from the Maritime Commission for use in its Mediterranean cargo service.

If taking the stand that public school education should be safeguarded against the encroachment of sectarian leadership and control is "bigotry," then the Protestant groups in America "are guilty," the Rev. George A. Crapullo, pastor of the Irving Square Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn, said yesterday in reply to recent charges by Cardinal Spellman.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- During the major part of last week prices of wheat on the Chicago Board of Trade were on the down grade, while corn and oats were strong, both reaching new high marks for all deliveries. On Friday and yesterday, however, advances in feed grains were less energetic.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 15 -- More than 900 bankers from all parts of the country began arriving here today for the thirteenth annual resident session of the Graduate School of Banking conducted by the American Bankers Association which will open tomorrow on the Rutgers University campus.

HANOVER, N.H., June 15 -- Supreme Court Justice Robert H. Jackson declared today at the 178th commencement of Dartmouth College that Soviet leaders wanted "at all hazards to avoid actual war with the United States, at least in the near future."

KHOI, Iran. June 15 (AP) -- The Iranian Army was waging fullscale warfare today against 1,000 encircled Barzani tribesmen in the mountainous northwest corner of Iran in sight of the Turkish and Soviet frontiers.

College and university tuition fees now are at the highest point ever and some will increase by fall, according to a survey of 120 institutions made public yesterday. The study was conducted by the John Price Jones Corporation.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A proposal for a full-dress Congressional investigation into the responsibility for the housing shortage was put forth today, coincident with a report of an upsurge in the number of houses and apartments being put under construction.

CHICAGO, June 15 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies won their first game of the season from the Chicago Cubs today, defeating the home-towners, 6 to 1. Schoolboy Rowe, yielding only 5 hits, snapped a five-game Cubs winning streak for his eighth victory before a crowd of 32,712.

Business in the foreign exchange market last week was limited and done over a narrow arc of price changes none of which were important in size. This was due to the restriction of interest to current requirements beyond which there appeared to be little incentive to commitments because of the picture of uncertain international finances.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 15 -- Dr. Charles Seymour, president of Yale University, declared here today there are certain moral principles with which a nation cannot compromise. In such light, he called on the United States to "develop our national strength -- scientific, industrial, naval and military," to make certain "we do not enter any compromise of fear" in international politics.

An all-star variety program to call attention to the need for traffic safety measures to protect the lives of children will be offered at 9:30 P.M., Thursday, over the ABC network (WJZ). Eddie Cantor, Jane Wyman, Ralph Edwards, Judy Canova, Jack Carson, John Beal and Hoagy Carmichael will appear in special sketches and songs collectively entitled "We Are Parents, Too," to underscore the work of the National Safety Council.

A joyous family reunion took place at La Guardia Field last night when Jacobo Reingold of Buenos Aires, Argentina, arrived here to meet for the first time Since 1905 his brothers and sisters, one of whom he had never seen. More than, 50 persons, including nephews and nieces, swarmed around Mr. Reingold and his wife when he cleared the customs and immigration officials at the field.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 15 -- The Soviet Union's "pursuit of policies diametrically opposed to the very premises of international accord and recovery" was blamed tonight by Under Secretary of State Dean Acheson for retarding thus far "the whole course of recovery and the international pursuit of happiness."

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- The Senators swept both games of a double-header from the fading Tigers today, capturing the first contest, 1 -- 0, behind the eight-hit pitching of Walter Masterson and the nightcap, 5 -- 1, on the seven-hit hurling of Mickey Haefner.

As this is written the fate of the Republican tax reduction bill is still, in theory at least, a matter of conjecture. But much of that conjecture, perhaps a preponderance of it, leans to the view that the measure will be vetoed. Such an eventuality, it should be noted, would be of considerable historic significance.

BILL BRANDT is a persistent fellow. For all of his adult life he's been an ardent and loyal Phillie fan, the very pinnacle of persistency. He's been suffering with the Phils for decades on end and that is suffering on a grand scale. Except for the mental quirk which drove him to pick the Phils as his diamond love, Bill is a sound and knowing baseball man.

Warner Bros. Pictures. Inc., and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $14,013,683 after all charges, including $8,400,000 provision for taxes, according to the semi-annual report covering the six months ended on March 1, to be issued today to stockholders.

The Brooklyn Hispanos defeated the New York Americans, 5 to 1, in an extra session game in the quarter-final round of the National Challenge Cup competition at Hawthorne Field, yesterday. As the Americans were 4-1 victors in the first encounter, the Hispanos captured the home-and-home series by a total score of 6 to 5.

VIENNA, June 15 -- Top economic and financial advisers of the Austrian Government have informed the Cabinet that unless the United States is prepared to make or finance sizable grants of coal, raw materials and machinery Austria will break down economically during the coming winter.

NEW DELHI, June 15 (AP) -- The All-India Committee of the Congress party served notice today that the security of this great subcontinent would not permit the Princely States to declare their independence of the two new Dominions.
NEW DELHI, India, June 15 -- The All-India Committee of the Congress party accepted today the British plan for the partition of India between Moslem and Hindu states.

LONG BEACH, Calif., June 15 (U.P.) -- Unhampered world trade and a strong international trade organization were favored by the United States Junior Chamber of Commerce, which closed its fiveday national convention here yesterday.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 15 (AP) -- Eight feminine tennis stars from New Jersey and New York today won the Sears Cup for the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association, its sixth straight triumph and twelfth in the twenty-one years the cup has been in competition.

Expressing concern over the civil-liberties aspects of the TaftHartley Bill rather than labormanagement considerations, the American Civil Liberties Union joined labor groups yesterday in urging President Truman to veto the measure as "a direct violation of labor's civil rights."

Walks by the Wall Passing along under the double row of elms that spread a leafy canopy over the broad walk skirting Fifth Avenue beside the Park wall, our city scout was reminded of what used to be another reach of the Avenue with a tree-shaded walk beside another wall in the vicinity of our own Times Square.

To the Polo Grounds yesterday came Roy Rogers, the guitarstrumming and singing cowboy, with his Thrill Circus for an eightday run. For three hours Mr. Rogers and his aerialists, tigers, lions and clowns had the audience of 40,000 -- a majority of them youngsters -- whistling and cheering.

When Mohandas K. Gandhi swung his support to the Mountbatten Plan for partition of India it was assured that partition would receive an overwhelming vote in the Congress party's All-India Committee. The vote of 153 for, 29 against and 32 abstaining was not as large as might have been expected.

Public housing subsidies are required to relieve the housing shortage in metropolitan New York, according to a survey made public yesterday by the Joint Legislative Committee on Housing and Multiple Dwellings.

LONDON, June 15 -- The conference of the United Nations Association in York added its authority today to the chorus of praise for Secretary Marshall's proposed economic aid for Europe. Its resolution followed Government and private pronouncements that saw in the United States proposals a new hope for Europe.

More than 1,140,000 bottles of insect repellent are listed, along with men's rain apparel, electronics, paints and varnishes, plant handling equipment, drafting supplies and hardware, in current surplus sales aggregating about $157,000,000 in cost value, announced over the week-end by Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director of the War Assets Administration.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 15 -- Champion Twin Ponds Belle, the Welsh terrier with the great record, got back into best-in-show stride today. It happened in the event of the Longshore Kennel Club at the Longshore Club, hard by Long Island Sound, and the top prize came as Belle's eleventh.

TRIVANDRUM, Travancore, India, June 15 (Reuters) -- Sir C.P. Ramaswami Aiyer, Dewan (Premier) of Travancore State, tonight called on the people to rally around the 34-year-old Maharajah and his declaration of independence for the State when the British leave India.

Revision of the Federal tax system "as desirable objective to be attained as rapidly as the budget situation permits" was recommended in messages sent over the weekend by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., to members of the Senate Finance Committee and the House Ways and Means Committee.
Cardinal Spellman announced yesterday his support of efforts to admit to the United States displaced persons from Europe.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 16 -- The Children's Emergency Fund has started procuring milk and food and plans to begin its foreign relief worK by Sept. 1, it was learned today.

BUENOS AIRES, June 16 (AP) -- The Sub-Secretariat of Information, the Argentine Government's press office, in a nation-wide radio broadcast tonight termed The Associated Press "an instrument of certain interests engaged in disturbing good relations between Argentina and friendly countries."
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Corporation profits after taxes set a record last year, jumping $2,000,000,000 above the previous peak set in mid-war 1943, the Department of Commerce reported today.

PENN YAN, N.Y., June 16 (AP) -- Representative Ralph W. Gwinn, Republican, of New York, said today that "the Taft-Hartley Bill marks the beginning of a struggle to restore freedom in our country, whether the bill is vetoed or not."

Charles P. Gross, chairman of the Board of Transportation, said yesterday that some of the wage demands made by 33,000 transit workers should receive favorable consideration, as the board ended headings on the requests of eighteen transit unions.

Ima Fastone, 4-year-old owned by W.S. Jacobs, proved the best of the lot in the Murray Hill purse, the main attraction at the Aqueduct Race Track yesterday. With Abelardo DeLara handling the reins skillfully, the Tiger filly won the six-furlong race for 4-yearolds and upward in convincing style to the satisfaction of the greater part of the crowd of 22,383 on hand.

There is beauty in the rhythmic waves of water that ruffle across the ocean's breast and find their fulfillment against land and rock, salt meadow and beach. As the earth wheels its circle around the sun the colors in the waves change to meet the moods of the seasons.

AMSTERDAM, June 16 (Aneta) -- Prices, for the most part, were unchanged in light trading on the Stock Exchange, reflecting an almost total absence of public interest. Brokers had virtually no orders on hand and most market leaders were practically neglected.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 16 -- The urgency of the situation demands that the new bizonal economic council be functioning by midsummer, Dr. Edwin Litchfield of the American Military Government told the Minister-Presidents of the American and British zones today.

A new issue of $32,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds of the Toledo Edison Company was awarded at competitive bidding yesterday to an investment banking group headed by The First Boston Corporation. A new issue of 160,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock of the same company was sold to an underwriting group headed by Blyth Co., Inc.
CHICAGO, June 16 -- Earl Bunting, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said here today that costs must be brought down and the saving "passed straight to the consumer."

The Hapoel soccer team from Palestine will conclude its goodwill tour of this country tonight at Ebbets Field, playing a combination of all-stars from the American Soccer League. The final international match will start at 8:30 following musical entertainment by the New York City Fire Department Band.

SEOUL, Korea, June 16 -- Dr. Syngman Rhee, former chief of the Korean Provisional Governmentin-Exile, charged today that the Joint United States-Soviet Commission we attempting to set up a "chop suey Government."

One of two men who were fleeing from a stolen taxicab was shot and killed early today in a pistol battle with a Board of Transportation patrolman on the northbound elevated platform of the Dyckman Street station of the IRT subway's Broadway-Seventh Avenue division.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Having spent a month in this country, both in New York and Washington as the only British delegate to the B'nai B'rith convention there, I have had many opportunities of ascertaining the views of my co-religionists on this side in relation to the Palestine problem.

Religious education as part of living rather than formal teaching is stressed in the workshop program opened yesterday at New York University. This year, for the first time, a demonstration school and practice teaching in church vacation schools in the metropolitan area will be features of the summer course, to run through Aug. 8.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The President's veto of the tax reduction bill was received in Congress today with little surprise but with a great surge of reaction, economic and political. The accent appeared to be upon the latter.

The Army established a beachhead at the Yankee Stadium last night, consolidated its position in the infield and then evacuated with colors flying half an hour later, having attained its objective of honoring Army Ground Forces Day.

The position of women in the business and professional fields is stronger today than ever before because they have learned "that the corollary of privilege is responsibility," Miss Caroline E. Slocum, recently re-elected president of the Business and Professional Women of New York State, Inc., declared yesterday.

QUEBEC, June 16 -- Under current conditions, the "pegging" of interest rates on short-term securities is a monetary device, "altogether too strong," according to Stephen M. Foster, economic advisor, New York Life Insurance Company.

City inspectors found several instances yesterday of meat selling at more than $1 a pound, with record prices including veal cutlets at $1.25, loin lamb chops at $1.20, and porterhouse steak at $1.10.

Three thousand paraplegic war veterans who can move about only in wheelchairs or on crutches are living an otherwise fairly normal life today because of significant advances in the field of physical medicine.
SECURITY COUNCIL Voted, 9 to 0, Russia and Poland abstaining, to take up Military Staff Committee's report point by point.

LONDON, June 16 -- Great Britain is joining France in seeking to induce the Soviet Union to help make United States Secretary of State Marshall's program of economic aid for Europe work, it was announced Here today. However, the news of a Pravda attack on the Marshall plan threw a pall over the Foreign Office this afternoon and there was little hope that the Russians could be won over.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 16 -- The best approach to world peace is to attack the causes of war itself and not the weapons or the concept of armies and navies and air forces, Secretary of the Navy James Forrestal said today at Wellesley College's first outdoor commencement.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Unless the maritime strike interferes, American shipments of relief materials under the $350,000,000 authorization voted by Congress for foreign aid may go forward this month, Richard F. Allen said today.

OTTAWA, June 16 -- The names of President Roosevelt and former Prime Minister Churchill have been erased from the great bell of the carillon that is being installed at Niagara Falls, Transport Minister Lional Chevrier told the House of Commons today.
Involved in the current Ship stoppage are six unions, all members of the CIO except the independent firemen. The unions and their position in the action as of last night are as follows:

STOCKHOLM, June 16 (AP) -- A committee that had struggled for almost a year to define the word "amateur" made its report and immediately was sent back to work tonight by the delegates of twenty-three countries attending the meetings of the International Olympic Committee.

MOSCOW, June 16 (AP) -- Foreign observers said there appeared to be little chance that Russia would come in on United States Secretary of State Marshall's plan for aid to Europe, following a blunt attack on the proposal in the Communist newspaper Pravda today.

The sharp upturn in promotional activity in several important durable goods lines, which has developed on a wide front here during the past week, was brought into major prominence by Henry Ford II, president of Ford Motor Company, yesterday.

Veto of the tax bill has stirred machine tool and process equipment manufacturers to obtain reconsideration of Treasury Department policies on depreciation of capital assets, manufacturers disclosed here yesterday.

Newspaper delivery by helicopter to suburban circulation areas was predicted by Charles C. Frost, circulation manager for The Niagara Falls Gazette, at the semi-annual meeting yesterday of the New York Circulation Managers' Association in the Hotel Commodore.

The seventh annual members' exhibition presented by the New York Art Directors Club opened with a preview yesterday afternoon at the American British Art Center, 44 West Fifty-sixth Street. It opens to the public today and will be on through June 28.

An Army Air Forces captain, convicted by a court martial for black market conspiracy in France and sentenced to dismissal from the service, received the Legion of Honor from the French Government on Saturday, it became known yesterday.

President Truman's veto of the tax reduction bill was no surprise to the stock market. Prices, in fact, staged a vigorous rally after the release of the White House message, but gains which ranged as high as 3 points were whittled substantially in the final hour and the list closed about at Friday's level.

After the first World War, when sugar again became more plentiful, people went back to its free consumption with such enthusiasm that per capita intake broke all records. Let's hope the same thing doesn't happen again. Sweets are the last consideration in planning a diet, because they furnish calories and little else in the way of vitamins and minerals.

The Kon-Tiki raft expedition, drifting from Peru to the Marquesas Islands in the wake of the presumed migration of a mysterious "leader" race 1,500 years ago, has passed the halfway mark ahead of schedule despite storms and marine monsters.

LONDON, June 16 -- Repudiating hostile articles in London newspapers, a Foreign Office spokesman said today that Senora Eva Duarte Peron, wife of the President of Argentina, would be "a most welcome visitor to Britain."

Fifty - eight Salvation Army "Warriors" cadets were commissioned last night on the stage of Carnegie Hall. They were told by their eastern territorial commander, Commissioner Donald McMillan, to "go into a new battle against the pessimism that has settled on the world, knowing that religion is older and more durable than wars and hatreds of men."

Store Sales 6% Over Year Ago Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week rose 6 per cent over the corresponding week of last year, according to the "flash report" of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday.

Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard sentenced John D. Corrigan, former Navy commander, to eighteen months in prison and a fine of $5,000 yesterday for conspiring with his business associate, Robert H. Wells, to deprive the Government of his impartial services as a Navy inspector.

SZEGED, Hungary, June 16 -- A meeting of Deszo Sulyok's Liberty party held tonight to test freedom of speech in Hungary demonstrated forcefully that there was none, at least for the Sulyok followers at this particular gathering.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 16 -- Alliance Productions, the RKO-J. Arthur Rank company, will film Sir Walter Scott's "Ivanhoe" in England this year as the second of two pictures called for by the agreement between Rank and RKO, the first having been "So Well Remembered," which was made in England last year.

The trouble with bees hanging around a drug store is that they do not buy anything and will not let anyone else buy. And that is why a Brooklyn druggist buzzed the Police, Fire and Park Departments and finally had to solve the problem himself.

Referring to Governor Dewey's administration, Glen R. Bedenkapp, Republican State Chairman, declared last night that the American people were entitled to the same leadership in Washington as New York State residents were getting in Albany.

New stationery items and a number of lines that have been revived for the first time since the war attracted an estimated 450 buyers to the first New York Stationery Show which opened at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday. The show, which occupies four floors of the hotel and features more than 200 lines of stationery items for home or personal use, will run through Friday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 16 -- A Jewish state in Palestine before the end of 1947 was predicted today by Dr. Stephen S. Wise of New York, president of the American and World Jewish Congress and founder of the Zionist Organization of America.
Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger cracked down yesterday on a garage operator who parked four cars on the street although he was charging the owners $35 to $50 a month each for storage.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The bodies of twelve of the victims of the Blue Ridge plane crash of Friday were buried today in a 20-by-20-foot common grave in Fairfax Cemetery at Leesburg, Va.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Administration supporters who want the Taft-Hartley Labor Bill to be Rilled are dismayed by the turn of events in the maritime dispute.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Once again in American history the principal threat to the continuance in office of the party in power has come from within its own ranks. The strongest force operating against President Truman, his administration and the Democrats in Congress who have supported his policies is centrifugal.
HANOVER Germany, June 16 -- The first joint export fair of the combined American and British zones is doomed to failure, according to Germans and Britons who are concerned with the venture.

Robert S. Darbee, president of the Bay Ridge Savings Bank, Fifth Avenue and fifty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, died Sunday night in his home at 237 Eightyfirst Street, Brooklyn after an illness of three months. He was 66 years old.

ATHENS, June 16 (U.P.) -- The Greek Cabinet approved today a draft agreement between the United States and Greece providing that Americans be assigned to Greek Ministries to see where "every dollar" of the $300,000,000 American grant goes, Greek Government sources said.

Julius Lobel, alias Jimmy Collins, received yesterday the alternative of spending the rest of his life in prison or revealing the whereabouts of approximately $350,000 he allegedly received in the Mergenthaler Linotype Company swindle.
PARIS, June 16 -- The United States has urged the French to take steps to terminate their conflict with the Viet Nam in IndoChina, it was learned today from authoritative French sources.

The thirtieth season of the Lewisohn Stadium concerts opened auspiciously last night. The weather was cool, comfortable and advantageous for the spirit of the audience and the sonorities of the orchestra. Not even a four-motor plane which appeared to hedgehop straight over the orchestra stand had the power to dampen the enthusiasm or distract the attention of the people to the performance.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that if the present crime emergency continues a substantial number of patrolmen would be appointed to the Police Department, perhaps even raising the department above its present authorized quota of 18,827.
The American liberty Steamship Corporation announced yesterday temporary suspension of its coastwise common carrier service from New York and Baltimore to Galveston and Houston.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., June 16 -- Harold E. Stassen, avowed Republican Presidential candidate, urged today that the United States act with speed to save the "entire deteriorating economic system in Europe."

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The pilot of the DC-4 which crashed in West Virginia with a toll of fifty lives on Friday was flying on an optional route visually and in soupy weather, James M. Landis, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, said today.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- Holding the Cubs to six hits and shutting them out in every inning but the first, Harry Taylor today hurled the Dodgers to 2-to-1 triumph to snap their losing streak at five games, and move them within two and a half games of the league lead.

Modern hand - fashioned silver by several famous Danish silversmiths will be introduced in New York today with the opening of the H. Nils shop at 1 East Fiftyeighth Street. Flatware and hollowware characterized by fluid curves, plain gleaming surfaces and careful workmanship bear such names as A. Michelsen and Rasmussen, plus the signature of the designer who supervised the making of the particular pattern.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 16 (U.P.) -- Col. Istvan Zemes, wartime resistance leader and chief of the Hungarian military delegation at the Paris peace conference, has been arrested as a conspirator, political circles said today. It was reported that four others were seized with him.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The House expunged from the record by 146 to 7 today a denunciation of its Committee on Un-American Activities sent forward by the Southern Conference for Human Welfare.

DETROIT, June 16 -- The Chrysler Corporation disclosed today that it had shut down entirely its De Soto-Wyoming plant as the result of a walkout following the imposition of a three-day disciplinary lay-off upon an unnamed worker for allegedly handling carelessly and damaging radiators.

BUDAPEST, June 16 (Reuters) -- Mr. Rakosi, the Communist leader, replied today to references to him in the recent United States note of protest addressed to the Russian Commander in Chief in Hungary, alleging that Mr. Rakosi had boasted that his party, "a party of the iron fist," had seized power during the recent crisis.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 16 -- Following is the text of the broadcast today by Mr. Sandstroem made public here by the United Nations Press Division: The members of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine are now here and the committee, which I note from the press is referred to locally as "UNSCOP," will get down to work immediately.

BURLINGTON, Vt., June 16 -- Warren R. Austin, this country's representative to the United Nations today told the graduating class at the University of Vermont that "the foundations for peace and progress have been laid with great dispatch."

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- President Truman rejected today the $4,000,000,000 tax reduction bill and told Congress in a veto message that the measure was "likely to induce the very recession we seek to avoid." He called for a thorough revision of the tax structure to meet the nation's economic and financial needs.

The twin bill of "The Medium" and "The Telephone," to be seen at the Barrymore Theatre has once again benefited by an upturn in business. Yesterday the producers announced that prosperity continues unabated and that, instead of closing the production on Saturday, its run will be extended for another two weeks, through July 5.

The responsibility always rests, or should rest, upon the President, in employing his veto power, to justify such action by reasoning which is so logical and so convincing as to be, to all intents and, purposes, unanswerable. There are two reasons, moreover, why this generalization may be said to have applied with more than ordinary force in the case of "H.R. 1", which President Truman refused to validate with his signature yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- President Truman's veto message on the tax reduction bill follows: To the House of Representatives: I return herewith, without my approval, HR 1, entitled: "An act to reduce individual income tax payments."

PHILADELPHIA, June 16 (AP) -- The budget director of the 11month-old Tucker Corporation of Chicago testified today the auto manufacturing company expect to make its first sale of its "Tucker 48" in September and to sell 129 cars at $1,800 each retail by the end of that month.
PARIS, June 16 -- Despite continual difficulties with material and labor, French decorative artists are in a gayer mood this year.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Henry A. Wallace warned the Truman Administration in effect tonight that, in the interest of world peace, it must take the initiative in reaching agreement with Russia on "all points at issue" or meet defeat in the 1948 election.

The move to repeal proportional representation in the election of members of the City Council was started formally yesterday. George F. Mand, president of the Bronx Chamber of Commerce, announced that nineteen civic associations had formed a committee that would ask that a repeal referendum be submittted to the electorate on election day.
If commutation fares on the New York Central Railroad are raised, no drop in traffic will occur, Everett E. Pierce, general passenger agent for the company, maintained yesterday.
LONDON, June 16 (Reuters) -- The United States shipping shortage will Le a tragedy for the world's food supply if it lasts for a substantial time, observers said today.
Popular Simonov Play Long after the First World War, and in fact up to a few years ago, it was a conclusive argument, turning up in all connections, that forty million Frenchmen cannot be wrong.

TOLEDO, June 16 (AP) -- Rocky Graziano, middleweight contender, of New York, won a technical knockout over Jerry Fiorello of Brooklyn in the fifth round of a scheduled 10-rounder before 6,000 fans at Swayne Field tonight. Graziano weighed 159 1/2, Fiorello 158 1/2.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 16 -- The United Nations Economic and Employment Commission rejected today a Russian resolution, aimed at the Truman Doctrine, that would have outlawed loans given for military purposes or to obtain political advantages.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There has been considerable comment in the press recently concerning the architecture of the proposed United Nations buildings. This has gone the gamut from castigating them as so many upturned sandwiches to proposing that they be draped with a Venetian decor of universal architectural synthesis.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to rule on a manufacturer's challenge of Constitutionality of the War Profits Renegotiation Act.

Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wede meyer, wartime commander of United States forces in the China Theatre, was among 1,166 passengers who arrived here yesterday from Southampton and Cherbourg on the Cunard White Star liner Mauretania.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 16 -- Despite Russian objections, the United Nations Security Council decided today to take up the report of its military staff committee paragraph by paragraph on the principles governing the establishment of an international police force.

"There is little use in feeding people indefinitely just to keep them barely alive," he said. "The improvement of the conditions of the laboring man and the farmer will, in the long run, be far more effective as a block to the advance of militant communism than arms and munitions.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 16 (AP) -- With the arrival of the Wisconsin contingent late today, all eleven colleges which will compete in Saturday's renewal of the Poughkeepsie Regatta were on the scene and ready to buckle down to hard work.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange continued steady yesterday and closed 4 to 40 points net higher than Saturday's final levels.
GENEVA, June 16 -- An analysis of Europe's economic ills and suggestions for overcoming them are outlined in a report of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe published today.

EDGEWATER, N.J., June 16 -- Miss Eleanor Van Gelder, former teacher and principal here for many years, during which most of the present adult population came under her influence, died yesterday at the age of 84.

CLEVELAND, June 16 -- A tenpoint program designed to increase purchasing power and to avoid a depression was put before the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, today by David Dubinsky, its president.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- Liquidation and hedging pressure caused a sharp break in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today, corn declining more than 6 cents a bushel and wheat around 3 cents before the selling movement spent its force.

The old Harper estate property it the northwest corner of Ninetieth Street and Roosevelt Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens, on which a one-story taxpayer is now being erected, has been sold by Leo Fischer to Leeann Associates, of which Sam Berger is president.

ALBANY, June 16 -- Dr. M.P. Catherwood, State Commissioner of Commerce, is preparing to resign from Governor Deway's Cabinet following his appointment today by Cornell University as dean of the State School of Industrial and Labor Relations at Cornell.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 16 -- The United Nations' Balkans investigation commission, which has just completed a four-month inspection of Greek border warfare, met here today to put the fininshing touches on its report to the Security Council.

In exploring the possibilities of European reconstruction with American assistance, as suggested by Secretary Marshall, the British and French Foreign Ministers, who meet today in Paris, will have to face squarely two problems that are mainly responsible for the growing economic crisis in Europe.

WASHINGTON, June 16 --The House approved today, while Administration Democrats vainly cried accusations of "economic isolationism," a bill making possible the exclusion from this country of up to 50 per cent of the normal wool shipments from abroad.

TRENTON, N.J. June 16 -- Dr. Dean P. Smiley, consultant to the American Medical Association on health and physical fitness, called today for much wider application in public health fields of the great advances made in recent years in medical science.

Despite Secretary Marshall's earnest appeal, the State Department's cultural and informational program is still in danger of being largely suppressed. Its troubles began when the House eliminated the entire $34,000,000 appropriation for this purpose on the ground that the activities had not been authorized.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial on wool you permit yourself to use the term "economic isolationism." This has been coined by the State Department and repeated parrotwise throughout the country. It is an implied accusation which cannot be substantiated, and its use is absolutely unjustified.

New York policemen, in the air and on the ground, may soon be in a position to arrest airmen who imperil the safety of the city.
