Substantial agreement to this effect was reached at a conference at Police Headquarters yesterday between Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander and a committee of fourteen, representing all phases of aviation, who have been studying the subject.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 16 -- Unanimous approval for the work of the United Nations Press Division was expressed today at a special meeting of the Standing Committee of United Nations Correspondents.

A Brooklyn architect in private practice was accused yesterday of participating in acts of corruption in connection with the activities of the borough office of the Department of Housing and Building. His arrest was ordered by District Attorney Miles F. McDonald of Kings County.

Plans calling for Al Jolson to make a series of ten guest appearances next fall on Bing Crosby's transcribed show have been abandoned, reportedly as the result of differences between the two singers. When Mr. Crosby was host this past season to Mr. Jolson, the resultant highjinks on the American network proved one of the successes of the season.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved a recapitalization program of Kentucky Utilities Company, Lexington, proposed by the firm to reduce annual charges for interest and dividends.
The New York Athletic Club thwarted the attempt of Salle Santelli to sweep the national fencing team championships when it captured the foil crown last night at its home strips.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today refused for the second time to review the mail fraud conviction of Mayor James M. Curley of Boston.

LONDON, June 16 -- Activity in stock markets here today was confined mainly to new issues in the industrial section, several of which opened at substantial premiums. Little business was seen in other industrials, which closed irregular.

BERLIN, June 16 -- The United States is ready to take firm action to induce Russia to initiate reciprocal deliveries for her share of reparations from the Western zones, as provided in the Potsdam Agreement, it was learned today.
The nation's strangest maritime strike gathered momentum last night in ports along the three coasts.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- The nation's forestry outlook is more favorable now than at any time since the beginning of commercial lumbering, the American Lumber Congress was informed today. The lumber industry was further assured that the forests are abundant enough to more than supply all the lumber needed for a record-breaking construction period and for years to come.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 16 -- Herbert Hoover, speaking with unwonted irony, said here tonight that it was possible that another ideology could do better in the next 200 years than the one that has served the American people for the last 200.

DURHAM, N.H., June 16 -- The annual health examinations of public school children throughout the country were characterized as "folly and wasted effort" by Dr. C.E.A. Winslow of Yale University, editor of the American Journal of Public Health.

ON BOARD USS SNYDER, Naval Reserve Training Ship, Duck Island Roads, Conn., June 16 -- A fair wind and a fair tide brought the fleet on the cruise of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club of Greenwich, Conn., here today from Port Jefferson, L.I.

CHICAGO, June 16 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 7,500 head; total 11,000. Weights under 240 pounds fairly active and 25 to 50 cents higher early, but these weights closed with part of advance lost.

ATLANTA, June 16 (AP) -- The State of Georgia charged the Columbia Broadcasting System with conspiracy in restraint of trade today, and obtained a temporary injunction in Federal Court to prevent transfer of CBS affiliation from the state-owned radio station WGST to chain-owned WAGA.

OTTAWA, June 16 (Canadian Press) -- Reconstruction Minister C. D. Howe, offering a resolution for the establishment of a Maritime Commission, told the House of Commons tonight that the Dominion's ocean-going tonnage was more than four times the 1939 figure.

ST. LOUIS, June 16 (AP) -- Those rejuvenated St. Louis Redbirds continued their winning ways tonight as they took a 4-to-3 teninning decision from the Phillies for their fifth straight victory since returning home.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The text of the speech by Henry A. Wallace, delivered here tonight at a meeting sponsored by the Southern Conference for Human Welfare, follows: During the past sixty days I have traveled in five foreign countries and in the East, West, North and South of the United States.

Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, announced yesterday at a luncheon in Queens the appointment of Hervey F. Law, a veteran in the field of airport development, as Director of Airports for the Authority.
Although no reports have come in yet, the opening of the black bass season in the Thousand Islands -St. Lawrence River area yesterday had better prospects than any opening for several years.

PARIS, June 16 -- The French Government announced tonight that it had proposed to Washington the creation of special committees representing the producing countries of Europe, plus the United States, to devise a program for the United States' financial assistance to Europe as a whole.

JERUSALEM, June 16 -- While one of the biggest Arab strikes in Palestine's history was in progress and three Jewish youths were being condemned to be hanged on charges of terrorism, the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine held its first two Jerusalem sessions today.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the United States District Court in New York may try a suit for $39,000,000 damages against former officials of the Central States Electric Corporation, a Virginia concern.

LONDON, June 16 -- Pleading that British theatre managers would tend more and more to bring to London established American successes like "Oklahoma!" unless they were given some tax relief, Sir Alan P. Herbert, British playwright and member of Parliament, made a futile effort today to get the entertainments tax on "the living" theatre reduced to pre-war levels.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., June 16 -- Harvey D. Symonds, construction manager of the New York office of the George A. Fuller Company, building contractors, and once a vice president of that concern, died today in Orange Memorial Hospital, East Orange, N.J., after a week's illness.

Elmer Haslett, suspended Director of Airports, interrupted his departmental hearing on misconduct charges yesterday to protest what he interpreted as a broadening of the proceeding to include a lesser charge of improper conduct.

CHICAGO, June 16 (AP) -- Baseball officials met today to outline rules for the annual All-Star baseball game to be played in Wrigley Field July 8, and came up with nearly the same set of rules that has covered previous contests.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 16 -- Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, surprised the United Nations Security Council today with the assertion that it could not begin to consider choosing a Governor of Trieste until after the peace treaty with Italy came into force.

ATLANTA, June 16 (AP) -- Miss Grace Lenczyk, a smooth-stroking youngster from Newington, Conn., showed the way here today for medalist honors in the women's Western open golf tournament with one-over-par 77.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 16 -- Mrs. Edwin C. Longcope of Siwanoy, champion at her own club, won the medal in the qualifying round of the twenty-second annual championship of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Counties Golf Association today.

JERUSALEM, June 16 -- Security measures never before surpassed here were in operation today as a British military court sentenced three terrorists to hanging and committed two others to prison for a minimum of fifteen years.

With an appropriate flourish of hits when they counted, amid an ear-splitting din from 52,633 fans, the Yankees celebrated Army Ground Forces Night at the Stadium last night by "squeezing" the White Sox out of victory. The score was 4 to 3.

LILIAN VAN NESS, whose sensitive awareness of the nuances of human relationships and whose joy in the music of the English language were first made manifest in "Again in October," has written another deft and disturbing novel, "The Indifferent Blade."* It isn't a major work of fiction by any means; but it is a subtle investigation of some rather specialized moral and psychological problems of human living.

JERUSALEM, June 16 -- A belief that the United States Administration must reach conclusions on its Palestine policy between now and September, especially on whether it is prepared to accept a share of the responsibility for a solution of that problem, was expressed today by Moshe Shertok, political chief of the Executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 16 -- Saying that pictorial journalism and motion pictures have shown the way, Raymond Rubicam, New York City advertising executive, called today for simpler and less dull techniques for conveying economic information to the average person.

LONDON, June 16 (AP) -- John Bromwich, Australia's No. 1 net star, withdrew without explanation from the singles of the London grass courts tennis championships late today, three hours after beating India's Ghaus Mohammed, 6-1, 6-3, in the first round.

LONDON, June 16 -- The elimination of private commercial ownership of newspapers was recommended as a step toward the freedom of the press in a resolution adopted today by an international conference on human rights.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Congress sent to President Truman for signature today a bill to raise the pay of cadets and midshipmen at West Point and Annapolis from $65 to $78 a month. The Coast Guard Academy would get the same increase.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16 (AP) -- Curt Simmons, sensational schoolboy pitcher from Egypt, Pa., and Esquire's "All-American boy" in 1945, today signed a contract with the Phillies. He will be sent to the club's Interstate farm team at Wilmington, Del.

Reduction of tariffs on men's and women's gloves, now being debated at the international trade conferences at Geneva, threatens the existence of the $65,000,000 American glove industry, James H. Casey, secretary of the National Association of Leather Glove Manufacturers, said in an interview here yesterday at Club 21.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- Free enterprise represents the world's newest and most liberal thought while communism and socialism are reactionary throwbacks to the era of serfdom, Charles E. Wilson, president of General Motors Corporation, said today.
Robert L. Riggs began the defense of his title yesterday with a routine conquest as the twentieth national professional championship started at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.
Women speakers only will address the fifty-sixth annual convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs at the Hotel Commodore, beginning next Monday and continuing until June 28.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Many formidable engineering problems must be overcome before atomic energy can be used for practical power production, Alfred O. Nier, physics professor at the University of Minnesota, declared here tonight.

ST. LOUIS, June 17 (AP) -- Stan Musial's ninth inning triple with the bases loaded gave the Cardinals their sixth consecutive victory -- the second over the Phillies -- 7 to 6, tonight. The Phils used three pitchers in the last frame in an attempt to keep their two-run lead.

Ebbets Field will be the site of a major middleweight bout tonight, when Herbie Kronowitz, Coney Island gladiator, engages Harold Green of Brownsville in a tenround encounter that headlines the program. Admission prices are scaled from $6 down to $1.50.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Development of an automatic water heater which derives its heat from surrounding air was announced today by Hotpoint, Inc. The device employs a motor-driven heat pump similar to the mechanism used in an electric refrigerator.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Wheat and corn futures were up 5 cents a bushel at one time on the Board of Trade today as the result of buying induced by announcement of a tentative Government loan rate on the 1947 wheat crop, removal of hedges against sales of cash wheat to the Government and heavy rains in parts of the main Corn Belt, especially Iowa.

The pamphlet report for 1946 of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company, issued for publication today, shows a net profit of 72,607,501 guilders, compared with 38,099,490 guilders in 1945. The guilder is worth about 38 cents in United States currency.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The following is the vote by which the House today sustained President Truman's veto of the tax reduction bill: FOR OVERRIDING -- 268

CLEVELAND, June 17 -- Asserting that another world war was imminent, Adolf A. Berle Jr., former Assistant Secretary of State and now state chairman of the Liberal party in New York, urged today that Henry A. Wallace sever his ties with the Progressive Citizens of America and support the Truman Doctrine.

SINCE an easy dollar is almost irresistible, human nature being as it is, gambling's hold on mankind is virtually unshakeable. But there also is a certain breed of individual who never is satisfied with a normal gamble. He's the fellow who loads the dice, cold-decks the cards or rigs the horse races. His bets go down only on the sure thing.
Business on the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderate yesterday and prices at the close were 19 to 85 points net higher than Monday's final levels.

The American Society for the Musical Interpretation of the Bible presented a program of "Music Inspired by the Bible" last night at Town Hall, the first in a prospective series. The unusually diversified program included the premiere of Mordecai Sandberg's "Three Songs of Ascent" for soprano, baritone, clarinet and piano, which were well received by a scattered but enthusiastic audience.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Senate, after much old-fashioned political in-fighting, authorized today a $35,000 investigation of "political activities" in the appointment of postmasters through the Democratic years.

Councilman Michael J. Quill declared yesterday that the Transport Workers Union, CIO, which he heads, would oppose any moves to raise the five-cent transit fare, including Mayor O'Dwyer's proposal for a November referendum on a higher fare.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 (AP) -- Carl Scheib, 20-year-old right-hander, pitched the second complete game of his career in organized baseball tonight and for the second time within a week he defeated the Tigers, 5 -- 2, before a crowd of 24,261.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 (AP) -- Preston Tucker, 44-year-old president of the nation's newest automobile manufacturing concern, said his plan to produce a "better and safer car" than has ever been built will provide jobs for 455,000 throughout the nation.

Elmer Haslett, suspended city airports director, told the Gulf Oil Corporation that he had left the city employ when he went to Westchester in April, 1943, to manage the county airport for North American Airport Corporation, Milton N. Weir, assistant to the vice president in charge of sales of Gulf, testified yesterday.

The threat of a severe curtailment of electric power consumption in the heavy industrial production areas of the Middle West and a strongly-enforced power rationing program elsewhere throughout the nation loomed large yesterday as coal and utility company spokesmen pointed to the dwindling supply of bituminous fuel.

A recommendation of mercy made by a jury in Kings County Court was disregarded yesterday by Judge Louis Goldstein as he sentenced John Valletutti, 20 years old, to die in the electric chair during the week of July 27. He was convicted June 7 of taking part in the hold-up of a bar and grill in which a disabled paratrooper, home on leave, was shot fatally.

An all-day effort to bring about a meeting of steamship operators and striking seamen failed early today, the third day of the mari-time walkout, but Federal conciliators announced in a statement early this morning that "considerable progress" had been made.

Two Red Cross centers here began yesterday to enroll volunteer blood donors for a new civilian service. Brief ceremonies at 4 East Thirty-seventh Street and 57 Willoughby Street, Brooklyn, preceded the start of registration. The first objective of the program is to provide free blood for patients in one city hospital in each borough, it was explained.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- With a persistent rain forcing postponement today of the second of a scheduled four-game series between the Dodgers and Cubs, Branch Rickey filled in the news lack by lopping two players from the Brooklyn roster.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Ferenc Nagy, ousted Premier of Hungary, protested today against Soviet "aggression" in his country.

Several prize-winning posters submitted by high school students in a nation-wide contest conducted by the American Automobile Association will be used throughout the country to promote traffic safety and to aid in the prevention of accidents.

CINCINNATI, June 17 (AP) -- The pace-setting Braves pounded five Cincinnati pitchers for 16 hits today to win, 11 to 1. The Reds' only run was a homer by Third Baseman Grady Hatton in the sixth inning, although Red Barrett was tagged for a dozen blows.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, June 17 -- Dispatches from the front indicate that the Communists are still concentrating on the siege of Szepingkai. Two days ago the Nationalists announced that the Reds had captured the Szepingkai airfield.
Fourteen Suffolk County and sixteen Nassau County villages held elections yesterday on Long Island, but in only four were there any contests.

LONDON, June 17 (UP) -- The Moscow radio broadcast today the following: Pravda carries a dispatch from its Shanghai correspondent which states that local journalistic circles are greatly interested in the declaration of a State Department representative on the subject of the provocational statement of the Chinese press agency, Central News, on the violation by a Chinese armed detachment of the Mongolian frontier.

DETROIT, June 17 -- It's out of the frying pan into the fire for golf's topnotchers these days. No sooner are they finished with the national open, world's premiere scoring test, than they're headed for the National Professional Golfers Association championship, tops among the match play events.

Buyers' Total Lower Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 2,379 compared with 2,578 last week and 2,605 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The appointment of David W. Peck as presiding justice of the Appellate Division of the First Department to succeed the late Francis Martin will be made by Governor Dewey soon it was learned yesterday. Justice Peck, now serving as a member of the Appellate Division by designation of the Governor, was elected to the Supreme Court in 1943.

With August cloth coat events planned on a larger scale than possibly at any time in the last five years, retailers want the problem of coat lengths to match longer dresses for fall solved so that consumer lay-away purchases will not be affected.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- A House Foreign Affairs subcommittee finished hearings on United States participation in the World Health Organization today with the rueful prediction by one member, Representative Donald L. Jackson, Republican, of California, that it "has the usual floor battle ahead of it."

Theatre experts of all nations will gather in Paris on July 28 to plan the organization of an International Theatre Institute. The meeting, to last three days, is designed to set up an inter-professional world association of theatre artists and craftsmen who will evolve a concrete and constructive program for the advancement of international understanding through the theatre.

The time has not come, as the Walrus didn't say, to speak of ships and wool and American aid to world recovery. At least not in the same breath; at least not while Mr. Bevin and M. Bidault are meeting in Paris to discuss what Europe can do to carry out the proposal of Secretary Marshall.
SECURITY COUNCIL. Meets today at 10:30 A.M. -- Begins point-by-point discussion of Military Staff Committee's report, (Open).

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 17 -- On the final of the four cruise runs of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club of Greenwich, Conn., today from Duck Island Roads to here, John B. Shethar's New York Yacht Club thirty-two-foot sloop Sylvia showed the way.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- A State Department project directed toward bilateral treaties on the exchange of information has reached the stage in which data from at least four countries will be studied soon.
Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander announced yesterday that he had called for the retirement of thirty detectives at least 64 years old.

HARRIMAN, N.Y., June 17 -- Local 338 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, filed charges of unfair labor practices today against the Arden Farm and Dairy Company, which is owned by W. Averell Harriman, Secretary of Commerce, and his brother, E. Roland Harriman.

Prompt and intelligent action on the part of business leaders can forestall an economic recession, Leon H. Keyserling, vice chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, declared yesterday in answer to the question "Is a depression inevitable?"

A novice, James Strauch of Salle Montague, scored an amazing upset last night on the strips of the Fencer's Club when he took the national epee fencing championship over a field studded with former titleholders.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We who are patients in the Veterans Hospitals can already feel the effects of the threatened cut in appropriations to the Veterans Administration. Positions have been frozen; no personnel is being hired. Attendants and technicians who leave are not replaced.

Thomas Wolfe said of Maxwell Evarts Perkins that he was "a great editor and a brave, honest man." That will be the verdict of many other authors who have been nursed into fame by the man with the clear blue eyes and the "tight-lipped, bashful New England smile" -- as another has put it -- whose career of thirty-six years at Scribners has just been terminated by his untimely death.

There is one misunderstanding which should be cleared away even in these first stages of the discussion of Secretary Marshall's plan for European reconstruction. This misunderstanding is typified by much of the comment, perhaps particularly in Paris, which assumes that in the Marshall plan the United States is thinking of an immediate short-term interest, which is commercial, rather than of larger and more fundamental objectives.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Cleveland's Bob Feller notched his ninth victory of the season, 5 -- 3, tonight at the expense of the Washington Senators before a crowd of 30.701, largest of the season at Griffith Stadium. Feller struck out nine, walked none and permitted eight hits, one of them a home run by Stan Spence.

TRENTON, N.J., June 17 -- The Republican and Democratic state leadership at final sessions of their J party conventions today adopted campaign platforms pledging support for constitutional revision and opposing new general state taxes.

ROME, June 17 -- L'Osservatore Romano, in what is desribed as one of the most pessimistic editorials published since the end of the war, said today that a new conflict was inevitable if the United States and Russia continued to distrust each other.

Sale of the large apartment house at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street for Simon Brothers to a cooperative group was announced yesterday by Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Under fire for failing to order a full investigation into alleged Kansas City vote frauds, Tom C. Clark, the Attorney General, announced today appointment of Richard K. Phelps as a special assistant to prosecute any violations of Federal law that might be uncovered there.

Already embroiled in shipping difficulties, the Atlantic Coast may be forced to take on additional trouble as the possibility of a breakdown in negotiations between shipyard management and the Industrial Union of Marine and Ship Building Workers of America, CIO, was advanced yesterday.

The Manhattan General Hospital has purchased from the Society of the Lying-in Hospital the nine-story and basement hospital building known as 307 Second Avenue, occupying the blockfront between Seventeenth and Eighteenth Streets.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today, the following proceedings were had: CUSTOMS 4358 -- Garrad Sales Corp., v. United States. Opinion by Associate Judge O'Connell. Judgment reversed. Judge Bland specially concurred. PATENTS

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 17 -- Geoffrey M. Wilson, British member of the United Nations committee drafting an international bill of rights, today proposed that every citizen should have the right to own property "to maintain the average, standard of life" in his own country.

Puget Case Decision A long-awaited decision was issued by the Washington State Supreme Court yesterday, ruling against the sale of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company to local public utility districts for $135,000,000.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 17 -- The United States and Russia should collaborate in the economic reconstruction of Europe without permitting the division of the Continent, Alexander W. Rudzinski of Poland told his colleagues on the United Nations Economic and Employment Commission today.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 17 -- With the exception of two extra hole matches, all topnotchers got safely past the first round of the seventeenth annual Women's Long Island Golf Association championship tournament at the Nassau Country Club here today.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The Army is having printed for distribution to troops a pamphlet which says the American Communist party is an agent of Russia and Communism is a danger to democracy. The War Department confirmed this today but said the pamphlet was not due for publication for several weeks.

Two firemen were killed and six other firemen, two policemen and the owner of a private motor boat were seriously burned about 9 o'clock last night when a speed-boat exploded in Long Island Sound after a blaze on it had seemingly been extinguished.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 17 -- Yale's Frank Quinn and Brendan Reilly of Harvard hooked up in a brilliant pitching duel today before a commencement gathering of almost 10,000 at Yale Field, where an unearned tally in the fourth inning carried the Elis to a 1-0 decision.

The first break in steel fabricating price quotations has appeared, with firm prices being quoted for the first time since the end of the war on inquiries for new projects in some regions. District engineers of the American Institute of Steel Construction, Inc., disclosed the development yesterday, during reports following a luncheon meeting, at the Commodore Hotel.

NEW DELHI, India, June 17 -- Mohammed All Jinnah, president of the Moslem League, issued a formal statement tonight defending the right of the Indian Princely States to declare themselves independent sovereign nations. He offered to negotiate alliances between such Princely States and the Moslem Dominion of Pakistan.
An angry group of Brooklyn residents turned out yesterday to protest an eviction that had been brought about by a landlord in need of a home.

LARISSA, Greece, June 17 -- The Greek Second Army Corps claims that it has accounted for more than 5,000 guerrillas since full-scale operations began April 9. The larger number have given themselves up within recent weeks, corps officers said today, and most of them are said to be free.

BERLIN, June 17 -- The first step toward the re-establishment of Berlin as an aviation center has been taken by the Allies, it was disclosed today after long-awaited Russian approval. A four-power committee has set an important precedent by approving the Royal Dutch Airline's right of entry to the huge Tempelhof airport.

Glancing Through the Paper Hollwood will obviously be giving us more and more pictures about New York streets, and if the films to come are as good as their predecessors, in the opinion of public and critics, it is a cheerful prospect.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Authoritative Presidential advisers believe that President Truman will veto the Taft-Hartley labor bill on Friday, it was reported today.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Holders of convertible bonds of the Chicago Rock Island Pacific Railroad will ask Federal District Judge Michael L. Igoe on Thursday to ratify the appointment of Roy D. Keehn, Chicago attorney, as one of the road's reorganization managers, Michael Gesas, the group's attorney, said today.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 17 -- President Truman appealed here today for a program of universal training, which he said was "vital to the national welfare." He linked the need for it directly wiith the troubled international situation.

JERUSALEM, June 17 -- At its first public hearing the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine today heard Moshe Shertok, political chief of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, declare that political cooperation between Jews and Arabs would be impossible in an independent unitary state of Palestine.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 17 -- Harvard University announced today Dr. Robert B. Woodward, Associate Professor of Chemistry, has succeeded in synthesizing protein-like materials that have the chemical aand physical characteristics of silk and hair.
"Operation Ragweed, 1947," the second annual phase of the city's three-year campaign to reduce hay fever by eliminating ragweed from New York, was started in each borough simultaneously yesterday.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 17 -- An old custom, started well nigh a century ago, will be renewed on the Thames River tomorrow when the Yale and Harvard varsity crews meet for the eighty-second time.

STOCKHOLM, June 17 (AP) -- Russia has received memberships in four world sports controlling federations and now needs only to organize committees in the Soviet to be eligible for an invitation to the 1948 Olympics in London, the International Olympic Committee president, J. Sigfrid Edstrom, announced tonight.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 17 -- Mrs. Edwin C. Longcope, of Siwanoy, the medalist, marched through the first round of the twenty-second annual Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association championship with a 5 and 4 triumph over Mrs. Russell Holman, of Innis Arden, at Westchester Hills Golf Club today.

Seven years ago Frederick Morton of 630 West 151st Street, a Viennese refugee, was working as a baker's apprentice in London and struggling to learn the English language. Yesterday Mr. Morton, who is only 22 years old, was announced by Dodd Mead Co., publishers, as the winner of the annual Intercollegiate Literary Fellowship for hia novel "The Hound."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 17 -- The working committee of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission today reached a compromise informal agreement on the procedure it would follow in discussing the new Soviet atomic proposals.

LONDON, June 17 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin took the assent of the British Cabinet and the hopes of the British people with him when he flew over to Paris this afternoon for consultations with the French on Secretary of State Marshall's offer of United States economic aid to Europe.

President Truman dealt with one of the oldest problems of government in his address yesterday. Ancient as that problem is, it is of pressing concern today to all of us and is, because of its nature, most difficult to cope with. This is the task of improving personnel in government service.

PARIS, June 17 -- Foreign Minister Bidault came out today for the return to Italy of her pre-Fascist colonies as France's Council of the Republic, the upper house of Parliament, unanimously approved ratification of the Italian peace treaty.

A long-awaited flight, the first around the earth by a commercial airline plane, began at 2:10 P.M. yesterday when the Clipper America, a Lockheed Constellation carrying twenty-one passengers, left La Guardia Field on a 22,170-mile trip.

To circumvent high finished goods prices, New York manufacturers of low-end dresses are giving serious consideration to purchasing rayon gray goods, it was learned yesterday. Savings effected on fabrics ranging from 70 cents to $1 per yard, they said, would be at least 15 per cent.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The House ended today all prospects of tax relief in 1947 by sustaining President Truman's veto of the Republican bill to reduce personal income levies 10.5 to 30 per cent.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 17 -- The first annual Virginia Music Festival came to a close tonight with the final movement of the Brahms First Symphony. Audiences totaling more than fifteen thousand heard the three programs at the University of Virginia's Scott Stadium, which had been transformed from a football field to an open-air concert hall for the occasion.

The United Nations Special Committee on Palestine has begun its inquiry in Jerusalem under circumstances that are not encouraging. The Palestine Arab Higher Committee has staged a successful one-day strike, joined by Lebanon and Syria, to demonstrate Arab solidarity.

A chance bar-room meeting early yesterday morning led later to the severe beating and robbing of a hospitable stranger by a British merchant seaman and an accomplice in the host's apartment at 173 Riverside Drive, at Eighty-ninth Street.

LONDON, June 17 -- Higher pensions for former members of Parliament are expected to be hastened by the case of J.R. Clynes, three times a Cabinet Minister and thirty-five years an M.P., who, it was revealed today, is on the verge of destitution at the age of 77.
J.G. Schaefer has been appointed merchandising manager of U.S. Royal tires by the U.S. Rubber Company. R.W. Ceilings has been named head of a newly created marketing department.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 17 -- The right to a free life in a free society "is again being challenged by aggressive foes," Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, president of Princeton University, declared here today. He added that realism forbade the belief that the issue would easily be resolved in favor of free dom.

ASCOT, England, June 17 -- Horses of France met their Waterloo today as Royal Ascot opened its most brilliant race meeting since before the war. Faced with what had been heralded as the greatest French challenge the English turf ever had known, British thoroughbreds swept the field clear on the first day.

QUEBEC, June 17 -- New York State bankers have developed a comprehensive program for the establishment of service charges or a uniform basis, it was disclosed here today. The schedule, it was explained at the closing session of the New York State Bankers Association's fifty-first annual convention, will not provide uniform state-wide rates but will establish a single method for determining such rates.
ROME, June 17 -- The Leftist newspaper Repubblica d'Italia announced today that Provisional President Enrico de Nicola intended to tender his resignation to the Constituent Assembly tomorrow.

PARIS, June 17 -- After a long after-dinner talk tonight between British Foreign Secretary Bevin and French Premier Ramadier and Foreign Minister Bidault, Paris officials said the British had accepted the French suggestion for a series of committees to assess European assets and needs.

The Johns-Manville Corporation manufacturer of building materials, has entered into an agreement with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York for long-term borrowing under which loans up to $25,000,000 may be received, Lewis H. Brown, chairman of Johns-Manville, announced yesterday.

LONDON, June 17 (AP) -- Officially announced seedings for the All-England tennis championships beginning at Wimbledon next week confirmed today the choice of experts and fans pieking Jack Kramer, the United States' No. 1 star, to win the men's title.

ALBANY, June 17 -- Governor Dewey approved today the allocation of $2,000,000 of state funds for the reconversion of existing New York City tenements into 500 emergency housing units for veterans and their families. The first contract, involving sixteen units, was let today.
NANKING, June 17 -- Authoritative commentators here believe that only a Government policy of defending Manchuria at all costs can save the Nationalist position there.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 17 -- RKO today named Melvyn Douglas to appear with Barbara Bel Geddes in "The Pittsburgh Escapade," a screen story by Christopher Isherwood and Lesser Samuels, which was purchased by the studio last March under the title "Sweet Genevieve."
ATLANTA, June 17 (AP) -- Three upsets marked first-round play today in the eighteenth annual Women's Western open golf tournament.

DURHAM, N.H., June 17 -- Voicing strong opposition to the arbitrary retiring of employes at the age of 60 or 65, and expressing himself as "opposed to handouts and pensions," Dr. Roger L. Lee of Boston, past president of the American Medical Association, pleaded today for the employment of these older persons as a means of sustaining their lives.
Pacific sunsets bored him out the young Navy veteran was fascinated by the dark figure against the light blue sky of a small water color picture at his friend's home.

Brooklyn will not have to say, "wait till next year" in the barber shop quartet league because the "Brooklyn Dodgers Knothole Four" won the city-wide barber shop quartet competition held on the Mall in Central Park last night.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Former Senator James M. Mead, Democrat, of New York, said today that ex-Representative Andrew J. May and Henry Garsson tried to get him to break a War Department "freeze order" on Garsson company funds.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with interest the editorial of June 12 on the subject of "Distribution of Corporate Profits." You might be interested in the following extract from a paper read by Sir Henry Clay, a former economic adviser to the Bank of England, on "The Conditions of Industrial Progress" at the Wharton School of Finance in Philadelphia in January, 1947:

Dr. Harold Taylor, president of Sarah Lawrence College, warned a record Queens College graduating class of 255 and their 1,500 guests yesterday against the control of education by "those who wish to prevent the free interchange of social ideas" in colleges.
Barney Balaban, president of Paramount Pictures, Inc., at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday expressed confidence concerning the future of the company's business in this country.

The Sheffield Farms Company has purchased the one-story taxpayer building on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 1033-39 Webster Avenue, the Bronx, from Mary Elizabeth McConnell in an all-cash transaction. The new owner plans to use the building upon the expiration of present leases.
New York's public elementary and junior high schools will have 887 new teaching jobs for the first half of the academic year begining next fall, it was reported yesterday at the Board of Education.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 17 -- Thirty-five men and one woman received honorary degrees from Princeton University at the final academic convocation of the university's bicentennial celebration today.

The stock market was unable yesterday to set a definite course either to higher ground, or to lower. Prices drifted aimlessly with only a few alterations of major proportions, while the composite rate showed a reduction of 0.15 point on the day.

Small sailors worn on the back of the head and hats that stressed arched brims and bulkier cushiony crowns were featured by Florence Reichman in a showing of advance fall millinery yesterday at the Park Avenue Theatre. Inspired by the forthcoming motion picture, "Ivy," set about the year 1911, the collection was followed by a preview of the motion picture itself.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- A 163-73 vote of the House approved today the conference agreement for extension of Federal rent control through Feb. 29. Earlier a motion to recommit the legislation for further study was defeated, 114-87.

OTTAWA, June 17 -- Labor Minister Humphrey Mitchell introduced a bill today to revise former labor legislation and regulations according to the experience gained in their administration and in the light of representations received from provincial authorities and labor and employers' organizations.

PARIS, June 17 -- Cabinet members and, later, Socialist Ministers conferring with Premier Paul Ramadier and former Premier Leon Blum split today on a plan for revising or replacing M. Blum's foundering policy based on his proposed price and wage freezing.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 17 -- Over the objections of Russia and Poland, the United Nations subcommission investigating the Balkans has officially condemned Bulgaria's refusal to cooperate and has called for a Security Council study of the obligations of every country toward the world organization.

BOSTON, June 17 -- (AP) -- The defending American League champion Red Sox registered their seventh victory in a row today by defeating the Browns, 6-5. The victory streak is the longest the Sox have achieved this season.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Amendment of the Communications Act to impose the economic factor as a limitation on the number of radio stations to be authorized in a given area, or to bring the multiple of ownership of stations within a 25 per cent population rule, was opposed today by Charles R. Denny, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.

In his plea at Princeton for support of the proposed Universal Military Training program, on which Congress is marking time, the President restated one principle governing international relations that cannot be too often restated: moral leadership unsupported by strength is not sufficient in today's world.

The new and different Frank Kovacs was a complete success yesterday. By the simple expedient of sticking closely to business, the erstwhile clown of the courts turned in the most impressive exhibition of the second-round singles play in the twentieth national professional tennis championship.

The sugar supply picture is still not sufficiently clear to warrant immediate increase of allotments to industrial users or removal of industrial ration controls, Albert S. Nemir, chief of program analysis, sugar branch, Department of Agriculture, told a meeting of The Sugar Club at the Downtown Athletic Club yesterday.
Dr. John Robert Gregg, creator of the Gregg shorthand system, has never stopped being glad that he went to church in his native village of Rockcorry in northern Ireland some sixty-five years ago.

PATERSON, N.J., June 17 -- Webb Knapp, New York realty company with varied interests, made the high bid when the two surplus plants of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation here were put up at auction today.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 11: A decrease of $221,000,000 in loans and increases of $328,000,000 in holdings of United States Government obligations and $163,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted.

Closing their good-will tour of the United States, the Hapoel players from Palestine lost the ninth game of their trip to a picked team of the American Soccer League, 2 to 0, before 20,000 fans at Ebbets Field last night.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial of June 14, "Fares in Other Cities," you indicate that even with a ten-cent fare New Yorkers would be getting a bargain in transportation due to the superior speed of our subways and to the distance underground. In support of this, you cite the fares in the next nine largest cities of the country, which range from 9 to 15 cents.

Immediate action is being taken by leading industrial purchasing agents to reduce "costs of buying" and to help lower "costs of invoicing," for suppliers, purchasing spokesmen revealed yesterday at the annual meeting of the Purchasing Agents Association of New York, held at the Builders' Exchange Club.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 17 -- Dr. Ivan Kerno, Czechoslovak assistant secretary general in charge of the United Nations' legal department, expressed satisfaction today with the "success" of the Committee on the Progressive Development of International Law and Its Codification.

Something new was added to New York's musical life last night -- summer opera at Carnegie Hall. The innovation was launched by a performance of "Aida" presented by the Internationale Opera Company, the first of two companies that will play there in the next month or two.

Patriotic British themes always have fascinated Noel Coward. His latest play, "Peace in Our Time," is described as a serious work about war-time England, showing the general effect on the people. Divided into two acts, it will employ a cast of thirty-four relatively unknown actors, with all the action confined to one set.
The New York Chapter of the Military Order of the World Wars held its annual dinner at the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street, last night.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 17 -- Mayor Frank Hague bade a rose-scented farewell tonight to the office that he had held for thirty years. He was succeeded by his sister's son, Frank Hague Eggers, hand-raised for the post.

The House, while reiterating in decisive manner yesterday its stand in favor of the Tax Reduction Bill, was unable to muster enough votes to pass the measure over President Truman's veto of the day before. The motion to override received a 268-137 majority, but fell short by two votes or the two-thirds needed to send the measure to the Senate for a similar test of strength.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 17 (U.P.) -- The text of president Truman's address at the Princeton University bicentennial celebration today follows: President Dodds, Distinguished Guests, Ladies and Gentlemen: The president of Princeton University spoke of crises a short while ago.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Spokesmen for several states opposed today the continued separation of unemployment compensation and job-finding functions in two Federal agencies.

Last month the Police Department revealed that major crime in this city has been steadily rising for the past three years. Because the increase over last year was almost 12 per cent, Commissioner Wallander hit on the expedient of night patrols by volunteer members of his force.

Bootlegging of babies that begins even before the child is born was disclosed by a study of nine voluntary and five municipal hospitals made by Rose Helen Steltzer under the auspices of the United Hospital Fund of New York.

EMMET JOHN HUGHES, a young American historical scholar, saw some pretty nasty contemporary history from 1942 until 1946, the years he spent as press attache to the American Embassy at Madrid. For the last two of those years Mr. Hughes added to his diplomatic duties those of military intelligence and investigation of the opposition to the Spanish dictator ship.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (U.P.) -- The Secretary of the Interior, J.A. Krug, said today that gasoline shortages are threatened this fall in some regions, especially the Midwest, and that a scarcity of fuel oil and natural gas may follow next winter.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Army redeemed $380,000,000 of Allied military currency in excess of appropriated funds, and most of it was printed by Russia from American plates, an extraordinary Senate inquiry disclosed today.

THE Canadian Broadcasting Corporation's repertory company in Toronto, whose vigorous and mature productions have won many prizes over American network competition, is to be heard regularly over WNEW under a special arrangement between the independent station and the CBC.

Twenty-two officers and firemen who performed heroic acts in 1946 received medals from Mayor O'Dwyer at a ceremony yesterday in City Hall Plaza. Five post-humous awards were made to the widows and next of kin of four firemen who died in the performance of their duties.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement issued by former Premier Ferenc Nagy of Hungary today: A year ago, when I first came to Washington, I was the leader of the freely elected majority in the Hungarian National Assembly and the head of a coalition government.

All is excitement at Montauk right now, and with good reason, for an out-of-breath angler appeared at Frank Tuma's Tackle Shop with a bluefish he had just taken from the surf. When the needle stopped vibrating it rested squarely on the thirteen-pound mark.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Department of Agriculture today announced that the Government would offer to wheat growers a chance to sell their crops outright this year to the Commodity Credit Corporation at 90 per cent of parity.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Senate and House Republican leaders today set Saturday, July 26, as an "outside" date for adjournment of the first session of the Eightieth Congress. Under the new reorganization act, the adjournment deadline was established at July 31, unless there was an emergency.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 17 -- Reporting a "startling drop" in the tuberculosis rate so far this year among industrial insurance policy-holders Dr. William P. Shepard of San Francisco, president of the National Tuberculosis Association, asserted tonight that discoveries in the tuberculosis field never had "looked more promising."
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Spokesmen for several states opposed today the continued separation of unemployment compensation and job-finding functions in two Federal agencies.

Last month the Police Department revealed that major crime in this city has been steadily rising for the past three years. Because the increase over last year was almost 12 per cent, Commissioner Wallander hit on the expedient of night patrols by volunteer members of his force.

Bootlegging of babies that begins even before the child is born was disclosed by a study of nine voluntary and five municipal hospitals made by Rose Helen Steltzer under the auspices of the United Hospital Fund of New York.

EMMET JOHN HUGHES, a young American historical scholar, saw some pretty nasty contemporary history from 1942 until 1946, the years he spent as press attache to the American Embassy at Madrid. For the last two of those years Mr. Hughes added to his diplomatic duties those of military intelligence and investigation of the opposition to the Spanish dictator ship.

PITTSBURGH, June 17 -- The Giants and Pirates made a noble effort to play their scheduled nocturnal contest tonight but an unrelenting rain that started falling shortly before game time washed the contest onto the postponed calendar.

A first mortgage loan of $115,000 at 4 per cent Interest and 2 per cent amortization was made by the Seamen's Bank for Savings on the 5-story office and loft building at 227-229 E 44th St. owned and occupied by Jacobson Co. Howard Geoghegan Associates were the brokers and title was insured by the Home Title Guaranty Co.

HANOVER, Germany, June 17 -- Approximately 200,000 workers brought industrial production in Lower Saxony to a virtually complete standstill today in a one-hour sit-down strike. Called by unions in protest on the food situation the strike affected factories in Brunswick and Hildesheim as well as here.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt decried last night what she called "the unfortunate and irresponsible pessimism" of older people who think of the United Nations as another League of Nations. Such people, she said, were doing the cause of international cooperation much harm by predicting that the United Nations would eventually "go the way of the League of Nations."

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Alberto Tarchiani, the Italian Ambassador, said today that his Government was ready to collaborate -- but on a basis of equality with other nations -- in the formulation of a plan for implementing the suggestions of Secretary of State Marshall for European economic rehabilitation.

The best six-furlong clocking of the Aqueduct meeting, a most estimable 1:11, was marked up by Windfields yesterday in stepping to an easy triumph in the $5,500added Audacious Handicap, a Class B sprint.

For hot weather Macy'a has a plan that should be especially appealing to working housewives who must rush home from the office to prepare dinner for the family. Stop in at the store's delicatessen department and a clerk will help you select the complete menu for a cold dinner-complete, except for bread and beverage.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 17 (AP) -- State Comptroller Frank C. Moore sold $28,175,000 worth of 50-year state housing bonds today to a syndicate headed by the Bank of Manhattan Company at a net interest cost of 1.5723 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (U.P.) -- Senator Wayne Morse, Republican, of Oregon, said today that Henry A. Wallace was "mistaken" when he stated yesterday that he thought the Senator "would go along with us" in a third party, if one developed.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- If the industries supplying the housing industry fail to meet home builders' needs, both the supplying and building industries will be "slapped in the face, with Government controls more stringent than any so far experienced," the American Lumber Congress was told today.

Dissatisfaction among silk traders and weavers on the slow progress in starting a silk promotion campaign with the cooperation of the United States Commercial Company may lead to an independent advertising drive it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Presidential veto of a bill passed by Congress-in this instance the income tax reduction "measure -- demonstrated the following values in legislative terms of the Executive's share in the process of enacting bills into laws:

A book of fifteen short stories by Christine Weston, author of "Indigo" and "The Dark Wood," will be published by Scribner on July 7. Entitled "There and The," it contains stories created from episodes and tales she recalls from her childhood in India.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 17 -- The political committee of the Small Landholders refused today to approve a proposal that the party should repudiate the recent United States note to the Russian chairman of the Allied Control Commission as interference with Hungary's internal-affairs.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Chairman Ross Rizley, Republican of Oklamhoma, of the House Surplus Property Investigating Subcommittee asserted today that the armed forces are "hoarding" vast amounts of real estate. Representative Rizley said that the committee now is having its investigators survey the amount of surplus real estate in control of the Army, Navy and the War Assets Administration to determine how much the armed forces might be "hoarding."

The City Council adopted yesterday a resolution asking Congress to investigate soaring meat prices throughout the nation. At the same time, Markets Commissioner Eugene G. Schulz reported, on the basis-of a citywide sampling in butcher shops, that meat prices, within a period of eighteen days, had made an "unusual" advance that ranged from 5 to 29 per cent.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 17 -- France in an announcement today became the second member of the United Nations to provide a financial contribution for the international Children's Emergency Fund.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia. June 17 -- The British commission that has been here for several weeks for discussions on British compensation claims for nationalized property returned to London this morning with proposals from the Yugoslav Government, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Truman expressed surprise and gratification today over the action of the House of Representatives in sustaining his veto of the bill to reduce income taxes. He got the news at Princeton University where he received an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws and delivered an address.

The National Maritime Union's demands for a 20 per cent wage increase would, if granted, raise the base pay of the chief steward of the liner America, on which top wages are paid, from $527.88 to $633.46 a month, a spokesman for ship operators said here yesterday.

BOSTON, June 18 (AP) -- Johnny Pesky's two-out single drove in pinch runner Eddie Pellagrini with the tally that gave the Red Sox a fifteen-inning 6-5 victory over the Browns in a 4-hour 20-minute struggle tonight before a thrill-exhausted crowd of 34,462.

A plea to former President Herbert Hoover to head a nation-wide campaign to eliminate food waste so that more food can be sent for relief in Europe was made yesterday by Alvin Johnson, president emeritus of the New School for Social Research.

MANILA, June 18 -- A new wave of nuisance strikes reached a climax today with a demonstration by 2,000 striking workers in front of the Court of Industrial Relations protesting what they charged was the court's "anti-labor" attitude.
LONDON, June 18 -- Great Britain has again asked the Soviet Government for full information on developments in Hungary, Hector McNeil, Minister of State, told the House of Commons today.

BUDAPEST, June 18 -- Lieut. Gen. V.P. Sviridov, Soviet chairman of the Allied Control Commission, denied to the United States and British members of that body today that he had influenced the recent changes in the Government of Hungary.

LONDON, Thursday, June 19 -- The first reaction in London early today was that the invitation to Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov, as announced in Paris, to join the British and the French next week in discussions of the Marshall plan for European rehabilitation was the land of procedure most likely to win Soviet acceptance.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- If the Interstate Commerce Commission accepts the recommendations made today by two of its examiners, Myron Witters and Paul C. Smith, it will impose a penalty charge of $5 a day in periods of car shortages on box cars held by other than the owning railroad except for certain specified causes.

LONDON, June 18 -- Britain has a special stake in the success of the Marshall proposal for the economic recovery of Europe because she is more deeply involved in the world's economic problems than any other nation, Herbert Morrison, Lord President of the Council, said today.

NANKING, June 18 -- A Government spokesman, Hollington K. Tong, director of the Information Office here, declared today that the Government was "continuously" dispatching reinforcements to Manchuria in an effort to save the situation for the Government there.

The suspension of Elmer Haslett, city airports director, expires today. Tomorrow Mr. Haslett will return to the payroll of the Department of Marine and Aviation, pending disposition of administrative charges being heard before Herbert Wechsler, temporary deputy commissioner.

A reading of a brief story from Sydney, Australia, reporting the marriage of two of the Princes of Tonga may have created a mental image of savages celebrating pagan rites in palmthatched huts and drinking toasts out of coconut shells. If such an image was created it is false, as thousands of sailors who were in the beautiful harbor of Nukualofa on Tongatabu Island during the war can testify.

Cash sales of light machine tools, electric motors and controls, to export buyers of South American countries indicate that plant managers in Brazil, Argentina and Venezuela are gearing up for future metal-working production, machinery dealers here revealed yesterday.

The stock market held yesterday within the trading range established this week, although some easiness developed in the final hour to reduce early gains. Pressure against American Telephone and Packard in the afternoon produced a sympathetic decline in several key divisions, although the composite rate showed a rise of 0.22 point on the day.

A warning that enactment of legislation now before Congress for unification of the armed forces and universal military training was essential to this country's defense was advanced last night by Maj. Gen. James A. Van Fleet, deputy Army Commander of the First Army.

With speed unusual in International affairs, France and Great Britain have agreed to convoke a European Economic Commission to map out and carry out the program of European recovery with American aid suggested by Secretary Marshall in his now famous Harvard speech.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 18 -- The two best scorers in the qualifying round, Mrs. Edwin Longcope of Siwanoy Club and Mrs. John Bartol of Greenwich Country Club, reached the semi-finals of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Counties Golf Association's twenty-second annual championship in the rain at Westchester Hills Golf Club today.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Army and Navy face an acute shortage of aviation gasoline as a result of the petroleum industry's failure to bid to fill the services' needs, it was disclosed today.
DETROIT, June 18 -- Golf's Gliaths met their David in today's opening qualifying round of the twenty-ninth national Professional Golfers Association championship at Plum Hollow.
ASCOT, England, June 18 -- Master Vote, 4-year-old owned and trained by H.G. Blagrave in Britain, won the Royal Hunt Cup today -- the main event of the second day's program at Royal Ascot.
Activity on the New York Cotton Exchange increased yesterday, and the market closed firm, 30 to 44 points net higher.

Leaders in commerce, finance and education received official awards of the Netherlands Government yesterday for services rendered during the war and in the period of reconstruction, at a brief ceremony held at Holland House, 10 Rockefeller Plaza.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The National Labor Relations Board unanimously reversed today a trial examiner's recommendations on a "free speech" issue. The board refused to set aside a collective bargaining election which two unions lost and rejected the argument that an employer's letter was coercive per se.

Nature reached the pinnacle of creation with protein, the basis of all life. Because life is varied, protein assumes hundreds, even thousands, of forms, from flesh to hair, from tendons to feathers. There are also possible forms for which Nature had no use, just as she had no use for synthetic explosives or most of the perfumes, flavors and dyes that the coal-tar chemist has synthesized.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A sharp rise in the number of families with both husband and wife working was noted today by the Women's Bureau in an analysis of 1946 census population estimates.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Francis Cardinal Spellman of New York voiced an appeal for an intelligent understanding of differences instead of bigoted action in a commencement address tonight to 490 graduates at Loyola University.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The State Department was criticized before a House committee today for neglect in promoting peace. The criticisms were voiced before the Committee on Expenditures hearings on the Snyder Bill to create a Department of Peace in the President's Cabinet.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 18 -- The rehabilitation of Germany "would fit into Secretary of State Marshall's plan for European recovery to great advantage," Gen. Lucius D. Clay said today.

New designs in printed luncheon cloths, some with matching napkins scaled and styled to do double duty as place mats, were introduced yesterday by Simtex Mills at a showing held in the Sherry-Netherland Hotel. Woven red and white checks in bold sizes were also featured.

The report of Controller Joseph shows that general fund receipts, including those from the sales tax, have been running beyond expectations in the current fiscal year. This may -- and may not -- mean that the tax on automobiles can be avoided or deferred.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Senate Appropriations, Armed Services and Banking and Currency Committees decided, in combined sessions today, to request the Secretaries of State, War and the Treasury to submit recommendations for currency reform in Germany.

General Svirdlov, head of the Russian Military Government in Hungary, has replied to the American note asking an explanation of the Communist coup with the bland statement that the Soviet Government had nothing to do with it. No doubt this is true; Russia does not have to act directly in countries where Moscow-trained local leaders of the Communist party know what to do.
VIENNA, June 18 -- The Western delegations and Russia agreed today on a method of procedure to guide the Austrian treaty commission's discussions of German assets.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- If President Truman rejects the Taft-Hartley labor relations bill, the House will override the veto within an hour and send the measure to the Senate, it was reported today.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 18 (AP) -- Mayor William Hart Hussey of Mount Vernon described today as "unsound" the state's mandate of large increases in education expenditures to be provided through permissive local taxing powers.

Net income of the Common-wealth and Southern Corporation in the first five months of this year increased to $15,503,533 from $14,882,231 for the corresponding period a year ago, Justin R. Whiting, president, reported yesterday at the annual meeting held in Wilmington.

Production of crude oil last week in the United States averaged 5,113,300 barrels daily, an increase of 49,000 over the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The output represented a new peak in production and made the sixth successive week that production had exceeded 5,000,000 barrels daily.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Treasury submitted to the House Ways and Means Committee today an analysis of four methods of correcting inequities in the taxation of family incomes.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- President Truman's suggestion at Princeton University yesterday that the colleges train young men to assure to the Federal Government a continuing supply of compotent administrative career officers met an approving respons here today from Administration officials who have been, wrestling with the problem.

An agreement was reached at 2:40 o'clock this morning between union and operators' representatives in the "no contract, no work" dispute that has kept much of the shipping in the nation's seaports strike-bound since Monday.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- The Very Rev. Edmund A. Walsh, a member of President Truman's commission on universal training, said today that Russia would not start "a shooting war" until she got the atomic bomb.
ST. LOUIS, June 18 (AP) -- Taking a first-inning lead on two hits and two errors, the Cardinals pulled on to top the Phillies, 5 to 2, tonight for victory No. 7 in a row.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 18 -- On the request of Prof. Vladimir M. Koretsky of the Soviet Union, the United Nations committee writing an international bill of rights agreed today to broaden the right of asylum to include other than political refugees.

The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, will call a nationwide strike of 150,000 workers in more than fifty shipyards throughout the country unless a satisfactory agreement is reached before July 1, the union's policy committee decided yesterday.
ROME, June 18 -- Provisional President Enrico de Nicola announced officially today that his health made it necessary for him to resign.
LONDON, June 18 -- A form of dominion status will be conferred upon Ceylon soon after a government is elected there, Arthur Creech Jones, Colonial Secretary, announced in the House of Commons today.

The memory of 6,000,000 European Jews, including those who fell in the Battle of the Warsaw Ghetto and those who died by Nazi gas and guns in concentration camps, will be kept alive by a monument being designed by Jo Davidson, the sculptor, for Riverside Park at Eighty-fourth Street, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Following are the texts of notes exchanged between the United States and Greek Governments on the United States program for aid to Greece:

A banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will offer to investors today a new issue of $40,000,000 of thirty-year 2 7/8 per cent first mortgage bonds of Public Service Company of Colorado at a price of 103 1/4 to yield 2.72 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today that the Brown Williamson Tobacco Corporation of Louisville, Ky., has agreed to quit advertising that Raleigh cigarettes are "right for the throat."

PRESSMEN'S HOME, Tenn., June 18 -- Hundreds of letters and telegrams and visitors by the score poured into Pressmen's Home today in celebration of the fortieth anniversary of Maj. George L. Berry as president of the International Printing Pressmen and Assistants Union of North America.

Mayor O'Dwyer drew a word picture of the city yesterday for 600 women at the opening luncheon of the sixth annual convention of the National Association of Insurance Women in the Hotel Commodore. He portrayed it as a city of small wage-earners who nave "squeezed out of their pennies" enough money to support the museums and cultural centers New York "holds in trust for the nation."

SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 -- Six months of experimentation with Streptomycin as a therapeutic agent in coping with pneumonic plague in laboratory mice led Dr. Karl F. Meyer, chief of the University of California's Hooper Foundation, to recommend today its use on human beings infected with this historically fatal disease.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The article in your May 30 issue quoting Dr. Josef Baumgartner, Bavarian Food and Agriculture Minister, on the subject of what he called "plundering of German forest reserves" was particularly interesting, not only for what it said but also for its omission of a much more important problem which has its source in this reduction of German reserves.
PARIS, June 18 (U.P.) -- The text of a joint communique issued by British Foreign Secretary Bevin and French Foreign Minister Bidault:
The summary of waterfowl conditions on the Canadian breeding grounds is an optimistic one compared to last year, according to the latest report from Ducks Unlimited.

Certificates of eligibility for a $200 salary differential under the Feinberg State Education Law have been sent to 3,300 teachers in New York's public elementary and junior high schools, it was announced yesterday at the Board of Education.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial urging United States citizenship and constitutional rights and protections for the natives of Guam is an important and long-over-due step in arousing public sentiment in support of these "second class citizens."
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The National Planning Association set out today to find "the causes of industrial peace under collective bargaining."

Local home-furnishings retailers attending the summer furniture market opening Monday at the New York Furniture Exchange are expected to exercise extreme caution in placing orders because of the feeling that newer and more desirable merchandise will be shown at the Chicago market, which begins July 7, it was learned yesterday.
CHICAGO, June 18 -- Grain markets were active and sharply higher today on the Board of Trade.

Divided opinion on reported improvement in wholesale food buying during the past week was evidenced in food circles yesterday. Metropolitan wholesalers tended to regard a report of improved conditions by the National Food Brokers Association as premature.

CINCINNATI, June 18 (AP) -- Lanky Ewell Blackwell of the Reds scored a double first tonight, pitching the first no-hitter of the major league season against the Braves in his first night game of 1947.
Two of the oldest child-caring institutions in New York City announed yesterday their merger and at the same time released a letter from Mayor O'Dwyer congratulating them on the step.

Governor Dewey was asked yesterday by the Dental Laboratory Association of New York to investigate the operation of four private trade schools licensed by the State Education Department to teach "mechanical dentistry" or ''dental technology."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 18 -- New Jersey's constitutional convention, which completed organization in a brief second session today at the Rutgers University gymnasium, set up its working schedule under which it must complete a revision of the 103-year-old Jersey constitution by Sept. 12.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Legislation continuing the life of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation but intended to remove it from competition with private lending institutions was introduced today by Representative Jesse P. Wolcott of Michigan.

LOS ANGELES, June 18 -- Howard Greer is favoring fringe for fall. He concentrates on late afternoon and dinner fashions, formal and informal, in the collection of ready-to-wear which he is presenting in his Beverly Hills salon.

JERUSALEM, June 18 -- Attired in native costume, Sir Abdur Rahman, Indian Moslem member of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine, turned toward Mecca and prayed at the grave of an old friend today when the committee toured Moslem, Jewish and Christian shrines in Jerusalem's redolent and raucous Old City.

MIAMI, Fla, June 18 -- Secretary Robert P. Patterson, in a statement released here today, denied a printed allegation that the War Department had maintained an unsympathetic attitude toward the Organized Reserve Corps. He termed the charge "shocking" and praised the role of the Reserve officer in national security.

Another Kind of Recessional The cheering and the singing dies, the B.A.'s and LL. D.'s depart, silence descends on the campus until the summer sessions begin, but the college prexies and their fund-raising assistants have taken precautions, lest we forget, lest we forget.

Raymond G. Ingersoll, a member of the American Labor party, filed yesterday with the Board of Elections a petition designating him for the Democratic nomination for State Senator in the Twenty-third district, thus furnishing additional opportunity for a test of the Wilson-Pakula law.
A 30-year-old mother was killed and her 8-year-old son and a friend were injured late last night after an explosion in the galley of a commercial fishing boat in Old Horse Creek, Flatbush, Brooklyn.

The only certain defense against dictatorship is militant democracy, former Governor Herbert H. Lehman declared yesterday. He spoke at a luncheon of the National Conference of Christians and Jews in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

Two armed thugs held up ten men yesterday in a wholesale car dealer's garage at 1540 Jerome Avenue, the Bronx, and escaped with $5,420 and a star sapphire ring valued at $250 after locking the victims in a washroom only three feet wide and four feet long.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Robert R. Wason, chairman of the board of the National Association of Manufacturers, tonight accused the Government of hamstringing American production with "Communist economic controls," while at the same time demanding more money and greater production to prop up "authoritarian states of Europe."

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Appointment of a bipartisan council to examine the resources of the United States and its capacity to extend economic assistance abroad was considered virtually assured today when William L. Clayton, Under-Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, endorsed the proposal.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18 -- Four companies filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission registration statements covering $29,000,000 of bonds, 125,000 shares of preferred stock and 109,921 shares of common stock.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 18 -- One great upset and two unexpectedly close matches marked the quarter-final round of the Women's Long Island Golf Association's seventeenth annual championship at the Nassau Country Club here today.

Representatives of Western Union and the American Communications Association, CIO, signed yesterday a new one-year contract providing a general increase of 5 cents an hour for 7,000 employes in the New York area.

It develops that boys not only like to eat but enjoy cooking, too. Twenty of them, ranging from 10 to 14, appeared in the kitchens of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel yesterday after school to receive certificates for the completion of a six-session nutrition and cooking course in Woodhaven given by the Central Queens Red Cross Chapter.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 25 there was a brief column containing news of the third annual model congress sponsored by Hunter College. This article outlined some of the bills passed.

Meat prices hovered yesterday around their record high points, with some going even higher despite lessened buying by house-wives. The growth of consumer resistance was reflected in a falling off in business at local whole-sale markets, both for livestock and dressed meat.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 18 -- Harvard's rowing supremacy over Yale continued uninterrupted today. The heavily favored Crimson varsity, however, as put to a stern test as the oldest of intercollegiate rivals in this country slugged it out over the four-mile course on the Thames for the first time since 1941.

NEWARK, N.J., June 18 -- A bitter attack by Commissioner Meyer C. Ellenstein on what he called "Port of New York Authority propaganda" brought about a unanimous vote of the City Commission today to postpone consideration of the authority's offer to take over and develop the airport and marine terminal.

BERLIN, June 18 -- The Russian-American fight over the city government moved rapidly to a showdown tonight when a Russian officer warned city officials that any discussion of the Allied Control Council's recent order requiring the confirmation of elected officials would be considered illegal criticism of an occupation power.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Senate agreed today to vote tomorrow on the wool tariff bill as the Administration marshaled all its power in an effort to break what its spokesmen termed a movement toward "economic isolationism."
The nation-wide maritime tie-up, which continued yesterday for the third day, involves the following union demands for increased wages and improved working conditions:
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 18 -- Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, warned the United Nations Commission for Conventional Armaments today that the rejection of...

Real estate interests, informed of the indicated increase of 19 points in the basic tax rate for the city for the coming fiscal year, expressed keen disappointment yesterday at the "continued heavy burden" of levies borne by real property in New York.

WRIGHT FIELD, Ohio, June 18 -- Pilot ejection seats, swept-back propellers, power plants of ever-increasing thrust and planes powered by six or more jet engines are some of the technical marvels now under study or test in this aviation center.

THE trouble with, light novels is that they generally don't stay light. They start out on the light fantastic and then they trip. This is lamentable. The world has need of souffles in its fiction as well as meat and potatoes, large or small.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., June 18 -- To finance its business pending consummation of its reorganization program, the Interstate Power Company of Dubuque, Iowa, applied today to the Securities and Exchange Commission for authority tomorrow $1,600,000 from the Chase National Bank and the Manufacturers Trust Company of New York City in equal amounts.
