BOSTON, June 18 -- Gerhardt Wagner, a German witness who became an American in 1936 and then returned to the Reich, testified today in Federal Court that Douglas Chandler, on trial for treason, had turned him in to the Gestapo because he expressed differences of opinion with Nazi doctrines.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 18 -- The long tradition of friendly relations between the United States and Canada provides a blueprint for the success of the United Nations, Viscount Alexander, Governor General of Canada told Tale alumni today at a luncheon following commencement exercises.
The Bowery Savings Bank extended for ten years the $165,000 mortgage on the 6-story apartment house at 73 St Paul's Pl. Brooklyn, through the Sonnenblick-Goldman Co. broker.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Senate passed today by 60 to 27 the so-called Reed-Bulwinkle bill, a measure to permit the railroads to act together in making rates, free from Anti-Trust Law prosecution, as long as the agreements so made have the approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

An issue of $2,125,000 of bonds of School District No. 111 of Kankakee, Ill., due from 1948 to 1966, was awarded yesterday to First National Bank of Chicago and associates at an interest cost of 1.477 per cent. The bid was 100.06, with $475,000 designated as 1 1/4%s, and $1,650,000 as 1 1/2s.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 18 -- The five Great Powers joined today in, resisting an attack in the United Nations Security Council by Col. W.R. Hodgson of Australia on those parts of the Military Staff Committee's report on an international police force on which the Big Five are agreed.

EVANSTON, Ill., June 18 -- The clash of free versus police states will demand either peaceful or military solution, in coming days, John Foster Dulles, Republican adviser to the State Department, asserted today at commencement exercises at Northwestern University.

The Dramatists' Guild recent decision rejecting the James Merrill Herd plan to subsidize talented playwrights in return for a percentage of their royalties has produced the first protest from a member of the organization.

RARIS, June 18 -- Against the background of strikes and renewed labor agitation for a general wage and economic settlement, the Cabinet will take the rest of this week to frame a new policy replacing former Premier Leon Blum's program to defend the franc and revive industry.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 18 -- The United Nations Balkan Investigation Commission decided today to ask the Security Council to give separate consideration to the problem created by the refusal of Bulgarian authorities to allow the commission's subsidiary group to carry on its investigations within Bulgaria.
LONDON, June 18 -- Although the stock markets here today started the new account cheerfully there was no perceptible increase in business

Price advances on men's better shoes were reported in the making here yesterday as a result of the recent stiff rises in top-grade leathers and lighter weight hides. Increases of 50 cents per pair at wholesale were mentioned, with volume shoes, however, not included.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- In recent testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee with respect to the inquiry made by the Federal Bureau of Investigation into the Kansas City primary election frauds last fall, J. Edgar Hoover, director of the FBI, left an implication concerning his chief, Attorney General Clark, which with every mark of sincerity He is now seeking to correct.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 18 -- It just wasn't the same old town and it wasn't the same appropriately named river, the Thames.

ISTANBUL, Turkey (London Times dispatch), June 18 -- An agreement has been signed between the Turkish Government and Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the J.G. White Corporation, United States Corporations, for the construction of new airfields in Turkey or extending and moderninzing the existing ones to accommodate the biggest aircraft.

To Flatbush last night came word that on June 30 the Brooklyn community will lose the services of the New fork Water Service Corporation and tie into the general city water system. The 350,000 residents of the area had been anticipating this new-fangled water for a long time, but with varied feelings.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- President Truman warned today on the perils in driver licensing laws whose administration is "a travesty on public safety." He told the President's Highway Conference here "that we are dealing with what amounts to a national disaster." Revision of these statutes in some states has not kept pace with other efforts to reduce the accident tolls on highways, he added.
CHICAGO, June 18 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Production and employment have reached high levels and there is no down-turn in sight, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
Abandonment of the city's proposed automobile use tax appeared likely yesterday as Controller Lazarus Joseph estimated at $344,342,905 the general fund revenue for 1947-48, ...

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 18 (AP) -- Monmouth Park race track opens its 36-day meeting tomorrow with the $10,000 added Colleen Stakes featuring an eight-race program. Favored entries include Greentree Stable's Attic, with Ted Atkinson the jockey; and Brookmeade Stable's Elastic, with Job Dean Jessop up.

ALBANY, June 18 (AP) -- Picket lines set up at six up-state. Remington Rand Company plants today by about 6,000 striking CIO-United Electrical Workers blocked a company effort to get office workers into three plants, a management spokesman said.

JERUSALEM, June 18 -- Any United Nations decision denying the Arabs an independent state in Palestine would have instantaneous repercussions throughout the Arab world, according to Jamal el Husseini, acting chairman of the Palestine Arab Higher Committee.

DURHAM, N.H., June 18 -- A suggestion that medical researchers working on infantile paralysis problems take a leaf out of the atomic energy scientists' notebook as a means of "getting on the right track in the attack on the disease," was made here today by Dr. William Lloyd Aycock, associate professor of preventive medicine at the Harvard Medical School, an authority on infantile paralysis.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The House passed today a bill to continue Social Security payroll taxes at the present level until 1950.
PHILADELPHIA, June 18 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Army Chief of Staff, received the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws today at the 191st commencement of the University of Pennsylvania.

WAKEFIELD, R.I., June 18 -- Albert Ellsworth Thomas, playwright, author and former newspaper man, died here in South County Hospital today after a long illness. His age was 74. Of his many plays, probably the most successful was "Come Out of the Kitchen."

CHICAGO, June 18 -- The time has come to step up large-scale building of homes in factories on assembly lines, Ira Mosher of the National Association of Manufacturers today told the American Lumber Congress. If the housing and associated industries cannot provide housing at costs within the means of the public, the Government will be invited to do it by popular demand, he warned.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Greek Government has pledged itself to carry out a far-flung program of rehabilitation in that country and to make widespread reforms in government to achieve efficient administration. A note giving these assurances was acknowledged at satisfactory by the State Department today.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your recent editorial dealing with Secretary Marshall's speech at Harvard you neglected to consider the problems involved from, a practical point of view.

The American Federation of Radio Artists indicated yesterday that it would act against guest appearances by entertainment stars on disk jockey programs. The move primarily would affect the forthcoming Paul Whiteman show, which had planned extensive use of guests, but might also have a bearing on the format of the Tommy Dorsey and Martin Block presentations, as well as many local record shows.

Unaffected by the maritime tieup, which has forced postponement of the scheduled sailings of the passenger snips America and Panama, the Eastern Steamship liner Evangeline departed at 4:10 P.M. yesterday on a ten-day cruise to Bermuda and Nassau.

SEOUL, Korea, June 18 -- The joint United States-Soviet Commission today completed final arrangements for its first meeting with representatives of the Korean democratic parties and social organizations.

Cold water flats on the south-west corner of Second Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street will be modernized by the United Nations at a cost of $300,000 to provide new quarters for fifty families now living on the East River site of the future world capital, it was announced yesterday.

Lack of timber and pulp-making machinery prevent, the paper industry from meeting present inflated demands for newsprint, it was said yesterday at the annual convention of the International Circulation Managers Association.

PARIS, June 18 -- British Foreign Secretary Bevin and French Foreign Minister Bidault decided today to ask Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov to meet with them some time next week to agree on a method of framing the European reconstruction program suggested by Secretary of State Marshall.

THE global thinkers, who frown on Russian tactics in the United Nations, are going to watch with intense interest the emergence of the Soviet into the realm of international sports. The International Olympic Committee has paved the way for the participation of Russia in the 1948 Olympic Games at London, and, surprisingly enough, the Soviet has been neither demanding nor dictatorial in seeking recognition from the various governing bodies.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Senior creditors of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad filed today a brief in support of their motion to remove District Judge Michael L. Igoe from the case. They charged Judge Igoe has caused an unnecessary delay of two years in the road's reorganization.

There was booing at Aqueduct yesterday when only four 2-year-olds, three of them carrying Brookmeade Stable silks, went out on the sloppy track for the Great American Stakes. Either the customers didn't expect much of a race or they were booing themselves for being at the horse park on such a rainy, dismal afternoon.

NANKING, June 18 -- Outer Mongolia's broadcast claim that Chinese Sinkiang forces attacked Outer Mongolian defense posts and penetrated Outer Mongolian territory early this month was branded as "absolutely false" by the Government spokesman, Hollington K. Tong, here today.

ALBANY, June 18 -- Alger B. Chapman, president of the State Tax Commission, moved today to insure prompt payment of bonuses to New York veterans of World War H if the proposed $400,000,000 bonus bond issue is approved by the voters in November.

The Commission on the Status of Jewish War Orphans in Europe will appeal to the United Nations Committee on Human Rights for legislation to return to the Jewish faith 40,000 Jewish war orphans estimated to be in Christian foster homes, it was learned last night.

Prices on carbonated beverages will definitely be forced down within the next few months, according to representatives of the industry attending a two-day management conference which opened at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday. Chain distributors are refusing to pay present prices, the bottlers said, because consumers are now showing reluctance to pay more than 10 cents for soft drinks.

Two young women are patrolling the city's subways as the first policewomen of the transit system, it was announced yesterday. It is their duty to protect women from too romantic men, to watch for women pickpockets and wayward children.

Metal Products Prices Up Manufacturers of metal products are studying costs and selling prices in lines which have not already been adjusted upward, spokesmen revealed here yesterday. They said that continuing shortages of metals and parts purchased from contract manufacturing sources indicate increases may be introduced individually within the next two weeks.

Bank-Holding Bill Although noting the action yesterday of the Senate Banking Committee, unanimously approving the so-called Tobey bill to regulate bank-holding companies, banking executives here generally believe the measure will not advance through the Congress.

Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen, who already had two books on the way to publication, has signed with a third concern for a third book. He will do a book "against Communism" for Bobbs-Merrill, and has turned over to Appleton-Century the manuscript of "The Philosophy of Religion."

Net profit of the Singer Manufacturing Company for 1946 was $15,227,817, equal to $16.92 a share, compared with $14,300,776, or $15.89 a share earned in 1945, Sir Douglas Alexander, president, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 18 -- Universal-International today announced the purchase of screen rights to Arthur Miller's Broadway play, "All My Sons," which won the New York Critics Award this season. Although the studio did not disclose the price paid for the property, outside sources set the figure at $150,000.

CLEVELAND, June 18 -- The general funds of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, American Federation of Labor, and its affiliated locals and joint board, have passed the $20,000,000 mark, it was disclosed today in a three-year financial report distributed at the union's convention.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A bill to deny all veteran benefits to Communists, sympathizers with their aims and those owing allegiance to Russia or her satellites, regardless of service, was approved overwhelmingly today by the House Committee on Veterans Affairs.

Nearly all of the 982 ships, ranging from battleships to water barges, assigned to the Atlantic Reserve Fleet, have been inactivated or decommissioned and put into "moth balls," fleet officers announced yesterday at 90 Church Street.

JERUSALEM, June 18 -- A carefully planned plot by Irgun Zvai Leumi terrorists to blow up Citrus House, the British military headquarters in Tel Aviv, has been frustrated by Haganah, the latter underground organization announced today.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Business management can no longer ignore the demands of stockholders, workers and the public at large for understandable and reliable accounting information, Carman G. Blough, director of research, American Institute of Accountants, warned today.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 18 -- Family heirlooms and other remnants of the past will go on the block here tomorrow and Saturday when Christ and Holy Trinity Church holds an auction sale to raise $150,000 for a youth center and church house.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Cleveland battered Sid Hudson and Mickey Haefner for fourteen hits here tonight to defeat Washington, 9--3.

In an open letter to Henry A. Wallace, Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, yesterday asked Mr. Wallace if he rejected the theory that Communist totalitarianism, using the Russian Army and its other army, the international Communist movement, was "relentlessly, patiently and boldly seeking world power," and added:
CHICAGO, June 18 -- Gil Hodges, 23-year-old rookie catcher, hit his first major league home run today to give the Dodgers two straight over the Cubs. The score was 5 to 3.

The alarming upward curve of traffic accidents caused President Truman to call his first Highway Safety Conference last year. At this year's conference, gathering in Washington, he was able to report a dip in the curve.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 18 -- Miss Laddie Irwin of Glen Ridge paced the field of sixty women today in the first round of the Women's New Jersey Association 54-hole medal play championship at the Essex Country Club. Miss Irwin turned in a brilliant three-over-women's-par 78 to lead by three shots.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Tom Clark, United States Attorney General, told a House Expenditures Committee today that the projected tour of the so-called "Freedom Train" about the country is privately financed and free of any political implications.

PITTSBURGH, June 18 -- Perseverance prevailed today as the Pirates, their nocturnal encounter with the Giants washed out last night, went all out to launch their series with the Polo Grounders despite a drizzling rain that fell right up to game time.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 19 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, expressed the belief today that Secretary of State Marshall, French Foreign Minister Bidault and British Foreign Secretary Bevin would "do their utmost" to use United Nations machinery in carrying out United States proposals to finance the reconstruction of Europe.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The State Department announced today that the United States bas decided to withhold recognition from the regime in Nicaragua of which Benjamin Lacayo Sacasa is President and which came into power by revolution late in May.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- J. Edgar Hoover said today Attorney General Clark had done nothing "to prevent any investigation" of alleged Kansas City vote frauds.

TIENTSIN, China, June 19 -- After a two-weeks visit to Manchuria, I believe that the Communists have not shown sufficient strength to capture Mukden or Changchun. The Reds do not appear able even to dislodge Nationalist armies from their present hold on other major fortified positions in southern Manchuria.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial in THE TIMES of June 17 is indeed a clear-cut statement regarding Mr. Truman's veto of the Income Tax Bill. At the last election the electorate clearly expressed their resentment at the continued high war taxes which were being collected, with no effort being made to cut government expenses down to a level in keeping with peacetime.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Charles E. Saltzman, vice president of the New York Stock Exchange, was nominated by President Truman today to be an Assistant Secretary of State.

DARIEN, Conn., June 19 -- Douglas Ford of Bonnie Briar, former New York State junior titleholder, carried off medal honors with a one-over-par 73 as the twentyeighth annual Westchester Golf Association's amateur championship started today at the Wee Burn Country Club.

WARSAW, June 19 (London Times Dispatch) -- The Polish Socialist party is to hold a conference of its Supreme Council, probably next Tuesday, and among other matters on the agenda will be the clearance of party ranks of "undesirable" elements.

PINECLIFFE, Col., June 19 (AP) -- Emily Griffith, 68 years old, a pioneer in adult education, and her sister, Florence Griffith, 67 years old, were found shot to death in their mountain home today and a neighbor and friend was sought for questioning.

An attempt was made yesterday afternoon on the life of Carmine Marrone, 21 years old a member of the Westo hijacking gang and the Government's principal witness against Salvutore Imperiale, alleged leader of the mob, and his associates.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The revival of full-scale output of coal in the Ruhr through introduction of United States mining and business methods, and financial aid through the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, is being advanced as the key to European reconstruction by John J. McCloy, president of that institution.

CLEVELAND, June 19 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, predicted today that President Truman would veto the Taft-Hartley labor bill and that his veto would be sustained by the Senate.

Plans for a six-week seminar of a hundred international educational leaders, to be held at the Educational Center at Sevres, near Paris, from July 20 to Aug. 30, were announced yesterday by Dr. Howard E. Wilson, director. The meeting will be sponsored by the United Nations Education, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Senate, by a vote of 48 to 38, completed Congressional action today on a compromise bill making it possible for the President to impose 50 per cent wool import fees atop the existing tariff and to exclude as much as half of the normal foreign wool shipments.

MOBILE, Ala., June 19 -- A $20,000,000 dock construction program and a novel scheme for a floating exhibit ship to visit Latin America are two principal projects in this city's plans to develop post-war world shipping.

The opening days of the early bass season at Cape Vincent and Alexandria Bay were about as forecast, "fair to middling," and despite a gathering of visiting experts the catches were far from exciting.

The acquisition of the additional land necessary to protect, develop and beautify Conference House Park on Staten Island was urged yesterday at a luncheon of the Park Association of New York City, in the Golf Clubhouse of LaTourette Park, Staten Island, at which 100 members and guests of the association attended.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 (AP) -- The Warren Petroleum Corporation, Tulsa, Okla., registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission 100,000 shares of $100 par cumulative convertible preferred stock for a public offering at prices and underwriting discounts to be disclosed in an amendment.

The nation's merchant marine stirred into normal activity last night as the four-day-old maritime strike came to an end. A sufficient number of locals of the striking National Maritime Union had ratified the new contract terms to call the strike officially over, and locals of the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association and the radio men of the American Communications Association also accepted.

The initial issue of "Newspaper Research Memo," designed to acquaint adverting and marketing researchers with information about the newspaper industry's national research program, published by the Bureau of Advertising, ANPA, reveals that six grocery audit operations are in full swing, with ten others well into the sample -testing stage.

London Understands Broadway A plea for lower theatre taxes failed the other day in the House of Commons in the face of an ingenious argument by Sir Alan P. Herbert. He said that British managers, confronted by heavy costs, will refuse to take chances on new British plays and will import more and more established American successes like "Oklahoma."

THE last of the wartime casualties, the Poughkeepsie regatta, will be gently disinterred tomorrow and life breathed into it again. With the staging of the rowing classic the world of athletics will have shaken off the final effects of Pearl Harbor in a complete return to normalcy on all fronts. The aquatic affair on the Hudson is one of the great spectacles that sports has to offer.

DETROIT, June 19 -- Jimmy Demaret, the year's leading moneywinner on the tournament circuit, added another honor to his lengthy list today when he won the medal in the twenty-ninth annual National Professional Golfers' Association championship.

Mrs. Mary Quayle, 82-year-old mother of Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle, was carried to safety yesterday when a fire started in the basement of her home, 421 Seventy-fourth Street, Brooklyn. The blaze caught in a wooden storage bin in the basement among old clothes and was confined to the cellar but smoke filled both floors of the two-story brick house.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- With lower prices for agricultural and industrial commodities, average primary market prices decreased 0.2 per cent during the week ended June 14, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

The Board of Education is studying a proposal to buy large sections of land in the undeveloped areas of northeastern Queens that would be used as school sites within the next twenty years, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Radio representatives protested to a Senate Commerce subcommittee today that a proposed new broadcasting law would create "confusion and chaos" in the industry.

The maritime tie-up was limited to four days, which is an occasion for rejoicing both here and abroad, where the needy are waiting for stores from America. But the pity is that a strike had to occur at all.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- A voice vote in the Senate completed Congressional approval today of the measure to continue Federal rent controls on a sharply modified basis through Feb. 29. It now goes to the White House for Presidential action.

NEW DELHI, India, June 19 -- Whether to hold a referendum in the strategic North-West Frontier Province of India at the risk of clashes between Pakistan and Congress party Moslems is the principal question before Indian leaders and the British-Raj in New Delhi today.

There were other contributory factors, but principally because Floyd Bevens served Rudy York a fat pitch at a time when he had two strikes against the slugger, the Yankees dropped out of first place in the American League yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- President Truman today urged Congress to provide, in this session, for civil government, citizenship and a bill of rights for the island of Guam.

ROME, June 19 -- In keeping with its traditional role of peacemaker, the Vatican will do everything in its power to avert war, Vatican circles acquainted with the views of Pope Pius told the writer today.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 19 (AP) -- Elastic, 15-1 shot, won the $10,000 added Colleen Stakes for 2year-old fillies today as a 36-day summer meeting opened at Monmouth Park, with a crowd of 16,596 on hand. The handle was $1,107,686, contrasted with $702,000 on last year's first day.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- A top Administration source declared tonight that President Truman had decided definitely to veto the TaftHartley Labor Bill.

HAIFA, Palestine, June 19 -- Members of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine had a hasty glimpse today of the vast oil interests that operate behind the scenes of British and United States policy in the Near East and of the destruction wrought by terrorists in harassing Actions against oil installations.

Pooling their American sculptural resources, the Metropolitan and the Whitney Museum have arranged a joint exhibition of work by native sculptors, all of the pieces, with one exception, belonging to the respective permanent collections.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I be permitted to correct several inaccuracies and to take issue with some statements in Delbert Clark's article on the Chetnik refugees in Germany, which appeared in THE TIMES of June 8.

Wearing fashions of their own creation, students of design school throughout the country competed yesterday at the Fashion Fair at Madison Square Garden for a trip to Paris. The contest was sponsored by the International Wool Secretariat.

AMSTERDAM, June 19 (Aneta) -- Trading on the Stock Exchange was quiet and prices were generally lower. Indies plantations issues, shipping shares and oil stocks showed slight losses, while banking stocks were irregular. State bonds and industrials were firm.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The presidency of Columbia University has been offered to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, and it was reported today that he would step out as Chief of Staff of the Army to take the post on Jan. 1.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 19 -- The power of determining what countries will be permitted to establish nuclear power plants is so great that such decisions should be made by the countries taking part in the control plan, rather than by the proposed international agency, a working group of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission reported today.

Elwood Cooke of New York, fresh from the amateur ranks, accounted for the only departure from routine yesterday as the twentieth national professional tennis championship reached the quarter-final stage at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The next time an important person in office or out admonishes the American people -- the usual word is "warn"-- that they must accept "a lower standard of living" if an effective program of world rehabilitation is to be carried out, it would be useful if he would specify what he means by the phrase.

The 500 tenants of the Hotel Marguery, 270 Park Avenue, who face eviction because the huge apartment house is scheduled for demolition to make way for a commercial structure to be erected by Time and Life, Inc., took their case yesterday to the City Council.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 18 -- Long Island University, now located in Brooklyn, has signed a contract to purchase Hillwood, the estate of Mrs. Joseph E. Davies, wife of the former Ambassador to Russia, in the old Brookville section of the North Shore.

The Mediterranean area, as it gets back to "a standing position," will assume a role of ever-increasing importance to the business of this nation, John F. Gehan, vice president of the American Export Lines, declared yesterday.

New York suppliers of hat bodies, ribbons, braids, feathers and other materials used in the millinery industry will contribute a minimum of $25,000 to the national millinery promotion campaign, according to Sam Finkelstein, executive administrator of Millinery Promotions, Inc., yesterday.

BUDAPEST, June 19 -- A Government White Book, containing the alleged confession of Bela Kovacs, former Secretary General of the Small Landholders party, to his Russian captors and other recent and past evidence about the alleged conspiracy against the Hungarian republic, will add President Zoltan Tildy's son-in-law and his former Minister of Cabinet to the list of those accused of connection with the conspiracy.

A banking group headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of an issue of $1,600,000 of storm and sewer bonds of Midland, Mich., due on Oct. 1, 1948 to 1976, at a bid designating an average interest cost of 1.8707 per cent.

The veteran battleship Washington, her powerful 16-inch guns silenced in thick coatings of grease and plastic and her fighting compartments hermetically sealed, perhaps forever, joined her famous sisters at the Bayonne Naval Annex yesterday for the "long sleep" as a member of the Atlantic Reserve Fleet.
Four employes of the city subway system went on trial yesterday at the Board of Transportation offices, 250 Hudson Street, on charges arising from the recent "book of rules" slowdown.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 -- A new type of occupational disease, traceable to compounds of beryllium, one of the metals used by the Manhattan atomic bomb project, was reported to the National Tuberculosis Association's meeting today by Dr. Harriet L. Hardy of the Massachusetts Department of Labor and Industries.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 19 -- Atomic research at the University of California was declared today to have penetrated further into the mystery of photosynthesis, laying a possible basis for improving on nature by making plants more efficient and therefore greater food producers for mankind.

The ate President Franklin D. Roosevelt as early as April 12, 1938, barred Henry A. Wallace, then Secretary of Agriculture, as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for President and indicated a preference-for Harold L. Ickes, then Secretary of the Interior.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- There was nothing jolly about Cholly Grimm today as he watched the Dodgers gleefully outscore his Cubs, 5 -- 1, to sweep a three-game series and move into third place ahead of the Bruins.
NEW DELHI, June 19 (Reuters) -- Mr. Gandhi told his prayer gathering tonight that a "movement for a free frontier state called Pathanistan has come to stay, for it is a solid movement."

MIAMI, Fla., June 19 -- Two ranking officers of the United States Army vigorously championed the cause of university military training as a means of salvation for this country. They spoke at meetings of the national convention of the Reserve Officers' Association.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 19 -- In the name of the World Jewish Congress, Dr. Maurice L. Perlzweig appealed to the United Nations today for action in enforcing respect for human rights. He said that only the presence of "United Nations troops" in Germany has prevented "massacres" now against the Jewish resident there.

ST. LOUIS, June 19 -- Striking street car and bus operators unanimously rejected today a proposal that the Missouri Public Service Commission arbitrate the dispute that has tied up this area's public transportation system for six days.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 19 -- Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of Piping Rock and Miss Evelyn Odom of Wheatley Hills blasted their way to the final of the seventeenth Long Island Women's Golf Association championship over the Nassau Country Club course here today.
The crash of the Pan American Airways Constellation plane Eclipse in Syria early yesterday carried the death toll in the series of air disasters since the Memorial Day holiday to 161.

Herbie Kronowitz, Coney Island middleweight, gained the decision over Harold (Red) Green of Brownsville in the star bout of ten rounds at Ebbets Field last night. The battle was bitterly waged and satisfied a crowd of 15,000.

Becoming "confused with traffic" half-way across the avenue against the lights, a 67-year-old partly blind World War I veteran was injured fatally yesterday morning by an Eighth Avenue bus at Ninety-eighth Street and Central Park West.

Miss Julia Clemons, second oldest living graduate of Hunter College and a member of the class of 1872, paid her first official visit yesterday to the "new" Hunter campus at Park Avenue and Sixtyeighth Street.

By a Senate vote of 48 to 38 yesterday afternoon Congress completed action on a measure which might truthfully be called "An Act to Hinder World Trade." This was, of course, the wool bill, a hybrid produced by grafting on an Administration price-support plan a provision for quotas or import fees to keep foreign wool from competing with domestic wool.

A prince from the Near East had a look at an American public school yesterday. It was difficult to judge who was more delighted with the royal safari into the borough of Queens -- His Royal Highness Prince Nawaf al Saud of Saudi Arabia or the students Of Bayside High.

Consolidated Textile The Consolidated Textile Company declared yesterday a dividend of 40 cents payable on July 10 to holders of record of June 27. Container Corporation Container Corporation of America declared an extra dividend of 50 cents and the regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents on the common stock, payable on Aug. 20 to holders of record of Aug. 5.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The House passed by voice vote today a measure designed to give impoverished railroads a detour around the bankruptcy courts.

A resolution urging the passage of the proposed Federal anti-lynching bill, providing criminal penalties against local officials failing to prosecute lynchings was forwarded to Congressional leaders yesterday by the Human Relations Commission of the Protestant Council of the City of New York.

GUAM, June 19 (U.P.) -- Six former Japanese Army and Navy officers and men, who murdered United States prisoners of war and Guamanians during the occupation, were hanged last night in the first such executions on this United States-occupied Pacific bastion.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., June 19 -- Pleading for sound principles in the expansion of foreign trade and calling upon other nations to follow the example of the United States in removing artificial restrictions and controls, Harold Connett, president of the Tanners Council, suggested here today that where such barriers are maintained Congress aid importers by "a Webb-Pomerene Act applied in reverse for importation of raw material."

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The late President Roosevelt promised post-war assistance to the Sultan of Morocco in his efforts for Moroccan independence from France, Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha, secretary general of the Arab League, said at a news conference today.

Accusing the shipbuilding and ship repair industry of "ganging up on the union," Charles Leone regional director here of the Industrial Union of Marine and Ship Building Workers of America, CIO, held out no hope last night of avoiding a paralyzing shipyard tieup on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The Washington Senators scored a 3-2 victory over the Cleveland Indians today as Early Wynn held the visitors to seven hits and scored his eighth triumph of the season.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended June 14 totaled 895,292 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 5,455 cars, or 0.6 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 27,374 cars, or 3.2 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 21,970 cars, or 2.5 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 19 -- The Children's Emergency Fund will supply milk and supplementary food this year to 3,250,000 undernourished children in Europe and China, it was decided here today by the fund's executive board.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 19 -- New York City's milk supply next winter -- as well as that of other cities in the metropolitan milk shed -- is threatened by the expected oat and corn shortage due to the wettest, coldest and most backward planting season in Weather Bureau history.

Central Park, in the heart of the city's skyscrapers, offers a wealth of outdoor fun. For toddlers there are special playgrounds where little ones may play on slides, dig in sand boxes and on hot days cool off in showers. There also are model yacht ponds, pony cart rides, ducks to feed, and the carousel.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- During the week ended June 18 member bank reserve balances increased $213,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Seek Discount on Seconds Rayon converters are seeking to obtain once again the 5 per cent discount on Substandard goods and seconds, it was learned yesterday. The percentage of seconds being received on gray goods contracts from weavers has been increasing, according to the converters, and they believe therefore that the former practice of billing substandard goods at a discount should be reinstituted to ease the losses susstained in making adjustments with fabric purchasers.
Cosmic Missile, who never fails to get at least a share of the purse, earned the winner's portion of $20,600 in the fifty-second running of the $25,000 added gazelle stakes at Aqueduct yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, June 19 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district last week fell to the lowest level since the middle of April, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Declines marked all major lines of activity, particularly industrial production and originating shipments.
MEXICO CITY, June 19 (ONA) -- The reported development of substitutes for chicle in the manu-
NANKING, June 19 -- National elections will be held this fall, as scheduled by last December's National Assembly, Interior Minister Chang Li-sheng announced today.

Two hundred engineers and members of their families were guests of the Army yesterday at a luncheon and demonstration of river dredging conducted in the Narrows during an inspection tour aboard the War Department Corps of Engineers dredge Goethals.

The stock market at one time yesterday made the best gains of the month, but some slackening of demand in the afternoon reduced peak additions. Trading was active until the easing set in and sent transfers on the Stock Exchange to 1,010,000 shares, against 910,000 shares on Wednesday.

CHICAGO, June 19 (U.P.) -- Soviet Ambassador Nikolai V. Novikov deplored today "poisonous rumors" of another war and said it was "possible and desirable" that the Soviet Union and the United States embark on a policy of cooperation in world affairs.

A general increase of $2.50 on a sixty-trip monthly commutation ticket was cited by Walter S. Franklin, vice president of the Long Island Rail Road in charge of traffic, as "the most equitable, way to pass the increase to the public," in testimony presented yesterday at a hearing before the Public Service Commission, at 233 Broadway.

Tippy Larkin, veteran campaigner from Garfield, N.J., will oppose Ike Williams, Trenton, N.J., lightweight, in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. The clash is expected to draw a crowd of 12,000 fans.

PARIS, June 19 -- French and British authorities said today that their Governments would go on with the program for assessing the aid Europe needs from the United States even if the Soviet Union should not participate.

Although details are yet to be ironed out, there's a likelihood of Max Gordon becoming interested in the destiny of "Music in My Heart." If he does, he will coproduce the Tchaikovsky musical with Henry Duffy, who made a valiant attempt to do it on his own.

In an editorial in its current issue, The Christian Century, a non-denominational Protestant publication, denies a charge made by Cardinal Spellman in his Fordham University commencement address on June 11 that the magazine was leading an attack on the Roman Catholic Church over the Supreme Court parochial school bus decision.
LONDON, June 19 -- Outside of business in new issues, the stock markets here today were quiet, although a confident tone generally was seen.

TAMIMENT, Pa., June 19 -- Louis Waldman, chairman of the Taminent Social And Economic Institute, urged the United Nations tonight to accept the Truman Doctrine as its own and halt "the aggressive and expanding policies of the Soviet Union."
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 19 -- Forty-eight hours before the revival on Saturday of the Poughkeepsie rowing regatta, the consensus today inclined toward an eastern victory.

The special feature of the program presented by the Philharmonic -Symphony Orchestra, under Pierre Monteux, last night at the Lewisohn Stadium, was the superlative performance of the Liszt Concerto in E flat, with Simon Barere, the Russian pianist, as soloist.

Stockpiling of machinery and plant equipment and preservation of key war-production plants are equally as important as the stockpiling of strategic materials to create adequate industrial preparedness, Vice Admiral Edward L. Cochrane, chief of the materials division of the Office of the Assistant Secretary of the Navy, told more than 400 members of the Machinery and Allied Products Institute at the opening of their annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Rear Admiral Ellis Mark Zacharias who as a captain conducted the Navy's psychological war against Japan, declared today that the proposed measure to unify the armed forces "presents a danger to us far greater than any possible enemy in the world today."

PARIS, June 19 -- Premier Paul Ramadier, whose constant efforts to mediate strikes and governmental differences have left him scarcely a night's sleep for the past few weeks, continued receiving delegates all day today in an attempt to hold his majority together on proposed financial reforms.

PITTSBURGH, June 19 -- A lot of pent-up wrath exploded in all directions today as the Pirates, to the delirious cheers of a ladies' day crowd of 12,560, decided it was time to lay violent hands on their arch tormentors.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today a one-year extension of the Government's authority to control exports, imports and domestic use of certain scarce materials.

DAMASCUS, Syria, June 19 (AP) -- A Pan American World Airways Constellation plane, bound from Karachi, India, to Istanbul, crashed early today near the bank of the Euphrates River in eastern Syria, killing eight of its twentysix passengers and seven of its crew of ten.

Activation ceremonies for thirtysix units under control of the 305th Anti-aircraft Artillery Brigade, Organized Reserve Corps of the First Army, were held last night at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

A sharp rise in the short-term Government securities held by the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System, reflecting the increase in deposits and other funds arising from the June 16 Treasury interest payments, is disclosed in the banks' statements released yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 19 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 8,000 head: total, 12,000. Market slow, closed very dull with about 2,000 hogs unsold: hogs under 350 pounds around 25

In the House of Commons debate on foreign policy, Ernest Bevin and Anthony Eden spoke yesterday of the Marshall proposal in almost identical terms. As spokesmen for the Government and the Opposition, both the present Foreign Secretary and his predecessor characterized the offer to back a program of economic recovery as an act of great generosity on the part of the United States and a "not-to-bemissed" opportunity for Europe.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 19 (AP) -- State Controller Frank C. Moore asserted tonight that "if our municipalities want financial home rule they must demonstrate a willingness to accept financial responsibility for their acts."

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The steady reduction of highway accidents in New York State despite the sudden post-war upswing of traffic volume, thousands of miles of deteriorated roads and extensive use of over-age cars was described today by Clifford J. Fletcher, New York's Motor Vehicle Commissioner, at the President's Highway Safety Conference.

ASCOT, England, June 19 -- The French horse, Souverain, owned by F.R. Schmitt, won the valuable Ascot Gold Cup today by four lengths from a former compatriot, Chanteur II. The Aga Khan's Field Day was in third place, another three lengths away.

A collection of original wallpapers, some done by a new blueprint method, others decorated with an arrangement of superimposed motifs, was presented yesterday at Katzenbach Warren, 49 East Fifty-third Street. This special-order group, designed by Ilonka Karasz, will be on view through July 15.

The new 50,000-watt transmitter of WINS was cut off the air yesterday at 1:56 P.M., fourteen seconds after the start of the broadcast of the Yankee-Chicago game. The transformer linking the station with a power line at Lyndhurst, N.J., first short-circuited and then burned out.
Members of the New York City Housing Authority met yesterday in their nearly completed office building, which is expected to become the first unit of the United Nations headquarters.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Wilfred Sykes, president of the Inland Steel Company of Chicago, predicted today that "by the end of this year ample steel will be available to satisfy the needs of the country."

MILWAUKEE, June 19 -- World War II veterans by the hundreds converged on Milwaukee today from all parts of the country for the convention of the American Veterans Committee. A call from their national chairman, Charles G. Bolte, warned the delegates to prepare "a positive program to halt the drift toward depression and war."

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 19 -- The Belgian commission appointed by King Leopold to investigate his acts during his reign has cleared him of charges that he surrendered the Belgian forces to the Germans in 1940 without warning his allies.

MATAWAN, N.J., June 19 -- Police authorities here, nursing badly bruised feelings, notified the State Motor Vehicle Commissioner today that a routine traffic summons proffered to Dr. Rudolfo Munoz, Argentine representative to the United Nations, had been thrown on the roadway by the diplomat as he claimed diplomatic immunity.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Here is the vote by which the Senate today adopted the conference compromise on the Wool Bill, sending the measure to the White House:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 18 (AP) -- Conversion of the mansion of the late George Eastman, founder of Eastman Kodak Company, into a historical and cultural center of photography, was announced today jointly by the University of Rochester, to whom Mr. Eastman willed the estate, and Kodak.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 -- Interim agreements permitting resumption of shipping from West Coast ports were reached today by ship operators and two unions, the Marine Cooks and the Radio Operators, upon recommendation of Dr. Nathan P. Feinsinger, special representative of the Secretary of Labor.
The city administration has abandoned, for the time being, its plan for an automobile use tax, Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday.

LONDON, June 19 -- Cheered by the whole House of Commons except a few Left-Wing extremists, Foreign Secretary Bevin bluntly warned the Soviet Union tonight that the period of appeasement in Anglo-Russian relations was over.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 19 -- Miss Laddie Irwin of Glen Ridge increased her lead to five strokes over the nearest contestant on the second eighteen holes of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association fifty-four-hole medal play championship today at the Essex County Country Club.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Federal Reserve Board suggested today that prices of housing and real estate are too high to support the present boom market but added that a collapse of values that marked the late Nineteen Twenties is not in prospect.

The Fifth Avenue Coach Company had a consolidated net income of $273,940 for 1946, compared with $368,459 in 1945, according to the company's annual report to be made public today. Operating revenues were $6,572,681, against $6,410,562 for 1945, but net earnings from operations were only $144,939, compared with $308,202.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Federal Aid to Education bill, which was favorably reported by a 6-to-1 vote of the Senate Education Committee on June 10, was readied today for floor action by the full Labor and Public Welfare Committee in executive session.

House organs can make use of emotional devices to arouse interest, even though they deal with facts, Harry Shaw, Harper Brothers editor, said yesterday at the eighteenth annual spring meeting and exhibition of the House Magazine Institute at the Roosevelt Hotel.

Although the dress manufactureing business in the last few weeks has taken a definite turn for the better, the industry is operating in a buyers' market, Isadore A. Agree, general manager of the National Dress Manufacturers' Association, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Failure by the Administration and the new Republican majorities in Congress to curb climbing prices was denounced in the Senate today by a new Republican member, Raymond E. Baldwin of Connecticut. The denunciation and his proposal, which followed, did not appear to set well with the GOP leadership.

This week-end shoppers must choose one of two courses in buying food supplies. They may purchase meat at the same high prices that were attained last Friday, thus using a disproportionate share of the budget on this one item, or they may look for a more economical substitute.

Opening a school canteen to the neighborhood, raising funds for a recreation center, cutting down on vandalism, helping in health and sanitation campaigns are among outcomes of children's action programs in three cities, the annual report of Youthbuilders, Inc., 120 East Sixteenth Street, showed yesterday.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 19 (AP) -- Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, said today that the sole motive of the proposed purchase of the fabricating facilities of the Consolidated Steel Corporation of Los Angeles by the Columbia Steel Corporation of Calfornia is to provide an adequate backlog for the successful operation of the Geneva steel plant at Provo, Utah.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange continued active yesterday. Prices were steady on the close, 6 to 20 points higher.

Back in New York this week after five months in the wilderness of the Belgian Congo, Mrs. Mary L. Jobe Akeley said yesterday that she saw a tremendous value to the world in the wild-life sanctuaries established there by the late King Albert.

Confined by illness to a wheelchair, preventing his appearance in court, Justin W. McCarthy, 26year-old former airplane ferry pilot, pleaded guilty yesterday to first-degree robbery after General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente held a hearing in a twelfth-floor steel-barred detention room in the Criminal Courts Building.

World Bank Promotion Efforts of investment firms to help publicize the coming debenture financing of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development has come to a full-stop following realization that the Securities and Exchange Commission cannot give sanc on to the retail dissemination of information about the bank as an investment in advance of effectitveness of registration of the bank's obligations.

ALBANY, June 19 -- Governor Dewey announced today the designation of Justice David W. Peck, of New York City, as Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division, First Department, and of Justice Bernard L. Shientag as a member of the same court.

MOSCOW, June 19 (AP) -- Pravda accused Dean Acheson today of having made a "gross and rude slander against the Soviet Union" and said the retiring American Under-Secretary of State and his "masters" apparently believed they could dictate to Russia.

The Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood who has held pastorates successively in Australia, London, Vancouver and Montreal, has just accepted the office of general missioner for Protestant denominations in the United States and Canada.
Alfred R. Marks, assistant controller, Saks Fifth Avenue, has resigned effective Aug. 31. He will join Ferro Berdon Company, certified public accountants, as a partner.
SEOUL, Korea, June 19 -- Maj. Gen. Archer L. Lereh, Military Governor of Korea since January, 1946, will leave for Washington in a few days.

MUROC, Calif., June 19 -- An American Army plane, a jet-propelled P-80R, hurtled through the desert air today to establish a world speed record of 623.8 miles an hour. The former record of 616 miles an hour was established by a British Gloster-Meteor on Sept. 7, 1946.
Wholesale meat dealers here have begun to sell some of the stock from their bulging refrigerators at less than cost, the United States Department of Agriculture reported yesterday.
LONDON, June 19 -- Negotiations aimed at solidifying Britain's foreign trade position progressed here today.

The cleanliness of New York police station lockups in comparison to those in Chicago was praised yesterday by three Chicagoans who have been inspecting local police and court systems during a three-day tour of inspection.

MUNICH, Germany, June 19 -- Dr. Rudolf Zorn, Minister of Economics in Bavaria, unleashed here today the sharpest utterances yet voiced by a German executive against the displaced persons of various nationalities still harbored in camps in this country.

Col. John Henry Patterson, commander of the Jewish Legion in the first World War and a supporter of the Zionist cause, has died at the age of 80, according to word received here from Los Angeles by the United Zionists-Revisionists of America.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Weekly sales of department stores were up 6 per cent for the week ended June 14 compared with the corresponding period last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Percentage changes from like periods of a year ago are indicated in the following table:

Memories of heroism and victory across the fields of France, Belgium and Germany grew bright again yesterday as the Fourth Armored Division began its first reunion and convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

JERUSALEM, June 19 -- Zeev Werber, the Haganah platoon leader who died "in action" yesterday, preventing the carrying out of one of the largest terrorist operations ever attempted in Palestine, received a hero's funeral today in Tel Aviv.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio compared President Truman's veto message on the Taft-Hartley Labor Bill today to a memorandum prepared by Lee Pressman, counsel of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 20 (AP) -- Canada's adverse trade balance With the United States is creeping higher, but financial circles while concerned do not consider the situation serious enough to warrant drastic action.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee unanimously demanded today a "full and complete" $50,000 investigation of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Here briefly are some main provisions of the Taft-Hartley Labor Bill and what President Truman said about them: 1. The bill would allow the Government to get court orders to block national strikes affecting: public health or safety during eighty days of mediation.

New orders for commercial radar equipment, for marine and aircraf use, are taking up the slack in cancellations of stock orders for electrical and industrial supplies made by plants in the metropolitan New York area, spokesmen said here yesterday.

Long Island University, which has run into a zoning snag in its contemplated purchase of Hillwood, the estate of Mrs. Joseph E. Davies on the north shore of Long Island, may be forced to consider the possibility of utilizing the site for separate schools and maintaining them either as individual units or as branches of the Brooklyn institution, it was learned yesterday.

NANKING, June 20 -- Dr. Sun Fo, vice president of China and Chairman of the Legislative Yuan, today issued a warning that the loss of Manchuria to the Chinese Communists by the Central Government might be the prelude to another world war.

Twenty-one hundred employes of the New York City Omnibus Corporation, which operates twenty 5-cent bus routes in Manhattan, won a general hourly wage increase of 6 cents in an arbitration award announced yesterday by David E. Cole.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 20 -- The United Nations is conducting a world-wide survey of crime and punishment, it was learned today, to provide member nations with a broad international program for establishing minimum standards in the control of crime.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Labor and industry sharply disagreed today on President Truman's message disapproving the Taft-Hartley Labor Relations Bill.

In bringing several transit employes up on departmental charges for the recent subway slowdown and work stoppage the Board of Transportation is "really placing the Transport Workers Union on trial." Anything the Board does to these men by way of punishment will be construed "as action against the TWU."

GENEVA, Switzerland, June 20 -- Tariff negotiations at the Geneva trade conference, complicated by United States Congressional action in passing the wool tariff Trill, have, nevertheless, advanced to the stage where Aug. 15 has been set for the end of the tariff discussions.

An Irish novelist, who during his life was the subject of considerable literary, controversy, has managed even in death to create a problem. For the late Matthew Phipps Shiel left his English home to the 13-year-old son of a Brooklyn woman, though he had never seen her or the boy.

CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows. HOGS Salable hogs, 4,500 head; total 6,500. Market moderately active and generally steady on all weights of hogs and sows; top $25, paid freely for choice 190-220 pound hogs; most good and

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Tom J. Smith Jr., president of the Pressed Metal Institute, told a Senate subcommittee today that small steel users are "afraid' to complain about discrimination which, he said, they are suffering at the hands of large steel companies.

The Rev. Charles W. Newman, for the last fifteen months a member of the staff of Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street, has been appointed as the vicar of historic St. Paul's Chapel, Trinity Parish, Broadway between Fulton and Vesey Streets.

CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) -- The Cubs, who had blown early leads in dropping four straight games, finally snapped their losing streak today when they climaxed an uphill fight with a ninth-inning run that defeated the Braves, 6 to 5, before a ladies' day crowd of 20,683.

Governor Dewey has demonstrated again that as a lawyer he is fully conscious of the importance of judicial appointments and of his responsibility as Governor for selecting men with outstanding records.

OTTAWA, June 20 (AP) -- Francif Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York, arrived here today to join the thousands of Catholics attending the Marian Congress. He is a guest at the United States Embassy. He will deliver a sermor Sunday morning.

BOSTON, June 20 -- Attorneys for Douglas Chandler, American writer, charged with treason in broadcasting for the Nazis from Germany during the war, entered a plea of insanity today and presented the testimony of two Boston psychiatrists who diagnosed Chandler as a paranoiac.

A 200-pound stevedore accused of attacking and robbing at least five frail women, all past 70, in mid-town railroad terminals was under arrest yesterday. Detectives described him as a "Helpful Harry.'"

Concerned at the city's apparent lack of interest in restoring service on the Thirty-ninth Street Brooklyn -Staten Island Ferry since the fire at the St. George Terminal a year ago, merchants at the Bush Terminal, Brooklyn, are leading a campaign for resumption of the service, it was reported yesterday.

Charles Balogh, 55 - year - old landlord and superintendent of a four-story tenement house at 806 East 156th Street, the Bronx, was found murdered in the cellar of the building yesterday morning. His skull had been fractured by blows from an iron bar.

PEIPING, June 20 (AP) -- Chinese Communists smashed into Szepingkai today, increasing the gravity of the situation of Nationalist forces in Manchuria, which some observers fear may be completely lost by the Government.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 20 -- After Yale defeated Clemson, 7 -- 3, in the first game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Eastern play-offs at Yale Field today, rain washed out the second encounter between N.Y.U. and Illinois, with the Big Nine champions at bat in the last half of the fifth inning of a scoreless contest.

Representatives of the Democratic, Republican and Liberal parties appeared yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Samuel Null to oppose a motion by Hyman N. Glickstein, counsel for the American Labor party, which will result ultimately in a test of the constitutionality of the WilsonPakula law before the Court of Appeals.

Following is the text of President Truman's radio address last night on the Taft-Bartley Labor Bill, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES: My Fellow Countrymen: At noon today I sent to Congress a message vetoing the TaftHartley Labor Bill.

The turn for the better in the women's apparel manufacturing business and continuation of the strike at the Maryland plant of the Celanese Corporation has resulted in a shortage of linings, it was learned in the trade yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Public apathy was designated today the most formidable hazard to further reduction of highway accidents by "Paul G. Hoffman, chairman of the Automotive Safety Foundation. At the closing session of the President's Highway Safety Conference he emphasized that thousands of towns and cities had failed to push protective programs.

Sixty to 75 per cent of the blindness in the United States is preventable, Ernest R. Fryxell, chairman of the blind-aid and eyeconservation committee of the New York Chapter of the Lions Club, declared yesterday. Mr. Fryxell made his statement at a press conference at which he announced a drive to obtain $25,000 to aid the blind in the city.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel Null reserved decision yesterday in a suit brought by the Tool Owners Union, Inc., a Delaware corporation, to compel the Board of Standards and Appeals of the State Department of Labor to issue to it a certificate of incorporation authorizing it to do business in New York State.

Long-range planning by Bucky Harris paid dividends yesterday at Yankee Stadium. At least a week ago, the Yankees' manager made up his mind to pitch Frank Shea against the Tigers the day that Lefty Hal Newhouser would go for Detroit.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- One hundred and six Democrats joined 225 Republicans today in the drive by the House to re-pass the TaftHartley labor bill over President Truman's veto. Seventy-one Democrats, only 40 per cent of those of that party participating in the test, went to the support of the Chief Executive.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have the greatest respect for Joseph Clark Baldwin. I have voted for him whenever he has been up for office. His eloquent words in THE TIMES of May 31 will hold up the "Palestinian Terrorists" in a more kindly light.

LONDON, June 20 (AP) -- British observers noted today that the Scandinavian and central European countries had not given the Marshall proposal the same enthusiastic reception it had received in Paris and London. Switzerland, clinging to traditional neutrality, has not yet held any official discussions of the plan.

DARIEN, Conn., June 20 -- Douglas Ford of Bonnie Briar, medalist in the twenty-eighth annual WestChester amateur golf tournament, being played on the Wee Burn course, here, today advanced to the semi-final round. The former New York State junior champion defeated William Rickenbacker of Sleepy Hollow in the first round, 4 and 3, then downed William Kuntz, a clubmate, by the same score.

MADRID, June 20 -- The approach of the national referendum on July 6 on the future of the Franco regime has produced enormous activity in governmental circles. All efforts are being concentrated on piling up the biggest possible vote in favor of the Franco Law of Succession.

Wesl Ellison Megaw, son of the Rev. Dr. Wesley Mega, will be ordained by the Presbytery of New York at 8 P.M. tomorrow in the Fort Washington Presbyterian Church, Wadsworth Avenue and West 174th Street. Dr. Megaw, pastor of the church, will offer the ordination prayer for his son.

WASHINGTON, Saturday, June 21 -- President Truman sharply rejected the Taft-Hartley labor bill yesterday, calling it a menace to a successful democratic society, and the House with triumphant shouts at once overrode his veto, 331 to 83.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 20 -- An end to "by-passing" the United Nations and to falling in with any trend toward accepting "so many convincing reasons" that apparently "we are drifting into an inevitable war" was called for today in a statement of the board of trustees of the Church Peace Union.
Aqueduct's race meeting ends today. If the script is followed, Whirlaway's five-year reign as the money-winning champion also will end with the fifty-ninth running of the Brooklyn Handicap.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Saturday, June 21 (Aneta) -- The Commission General for the Netherlands Indies has formally broken off relations with the Indonesian Republic despite a lastminute effort by the Republican Government to salvage the negotiations.

ST. LOUIS, June 20 -- Exploding a fourteen-hit barrage that included homers by Joe Medwick and Del Rice and four straight blows by Stan Musial, one a triple, the onrushing Cardinals rode roughshod over the Giants tonight to win the opener of a three-game series, 7 to 3, amid the cheers of 26,250 onlookers.

"It's up to Europe," said Secretary Marshall in effect, and the echoes and reverberations of his words that are coming back from Europe are as instructive to Americans as an intensive course in foreign relations. Or in human relations, for the buried, fact under the mountainous and oppressive problems of our time is that nations and governments often act and react like human beings.

DUBLIN, June 20 -- The part that Ireland may play in any future war between Russia and the United States was visualized by Deputy James Dillon in a debate on the vote for the External Affairs Department, of which Premier Eamon de Valera is Minister, in the Dail Eireann here today.

JERUSALEM, June 20 -- A member of the North African Arab Office said last night that there was a distinct possibility that the case might be taken to the United Nations General Assembly in September but that no final decision had yet been made.
HACKENSACK, N.J., June 20 -- The driver of an automobile, alleged to have been stolen, was captured here this afternoon by a motor-cycle policeman in a threemile chase.

GENEVA, June 20 (AP) -- The International Labor Conference received from its governing body today a proposed resolution declaring the right of "employers and workers, public and private," to organize.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Following isa the text of the agreement on aid to Greece signed today in Athens on behalf of the United States Government by Ambassador MacVeagh and on behalf of the Government of Greece by foreign Minister Tsaldaris:
The United States Liner America, caught in the aftermath of the four-day strike that ended Thursday, sailed late yesterday without a complete crew In her stewards department.

Sixteen travel editors from newspapers and magazines all over the country started a tour of New York State yesterday. The tour is being conducted by the State Department of Commerce to show scenic spots in the state and outline vacation possibilities.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., June 20 -- Legal safeguards built up by a free society to protect human rights have not kept pace with techniques developed by totalitarian states to enslave the individual, Allen Welsh Dulles, wartime head of the Office of Strategic Services in Switzerland, declared today.

The way was opened yesterday for a test of the degree to which diplomatic immunity will affect relations between American landlords and tenants who represent foreign Governments. In dismissing an action for the eviction of a Soviet Russian school at 6 East Eighty-seventh Street, Municipal Court Justice John M. Lewis wrote:

A 13-year-old girl stabbed Mrs. Sarah Friedman, 52, in the back of the neck in her husband's paint store at 458 West Forty-second Street yesterday and was caught as she stood screaming hysterically in the store doorway. The girl's mother told detectives later:

LONDON, June 20 -- Intermittent heavy rain marred the last day of the Royal Ascot meeting today when the longest race run over British tracks, the two-and-threequarter mile and seventy-five yards Queen Alexandra Stakes, featured the program.

CLEVELAND, June 20 -- A tumultuous demonstration of approval greeted announcement of President Truman's veto of the TaftHartley labor bill at the convention of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, here today.

TAMIMENT, Pa., June 20 -- Norman Thomas, five times a Socialist candidate for President, said tonight that an American appeal for controlled universal disarmament was the world's only hope of avoiding the suicide of another world conflict.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Washington's Walter Masterson, ran a string of consecutive scoreless inning's to thirty-four here tonight when he stopped the St. Louis Browns on two hits to win, 3 -- 0.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 20 (AP) -- Robert Ringling, opera -- singing circus man, lost control of the "biggest show on earth" today when James A. Haley and John Ringling North were named top executives of Ringling BrothersBarnum and Bailey Combined Shows, Inc.

The Federal rent bill now before President Truman was vigorously protested last night at a wellattended meeting at 2131 Broadway of permanent residents in hotels who were advised by counsel not to pay increased rents in the event the measure becomes a law.

New Capital Market Another heavy week will face the underwriting community on Monday following the marketing this week of $142,805,000 in bond issues and $21,266,965 in stocks. On Monday, syndicates will bid on $24,000,000 of thirty-year bonds and $13,000,000 of preferred stock of the Kentucky Utilities Company; on $12,000,000 of thirty-year bonds of the Southern California Gas Company, and on $4,500,000 of thirty-year bonds of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire.

Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange on June 17 was 1,540,493 shares, an increase of 226,102 shares over 1,314,391 shares reported for May 15 and the largest number since Nov. 15, 1945, when 1,566,015 were reported, it was announced yesterday by the Exchange.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The recommendations in the report of the Committee for Economic Development, for improving the plight of small business enterprises are encouraging because they have long been needed. It is hoped that means will be found to put them into effect with reasonable dispatch.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 20 -- Russia's top-ranking Army and Navy officers at the United Nations walked out of the highechelon Military Staff Committee today in an argument over procedure, but made it clear later that they would be walking back in time for the next meeting.
Despite decreases recently announced in women's full-fashioned hosiery, the majority of brand manufacturers will hold to their current prices, it was determined yesterday in a survey of the market.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- President Truman was represented as having under serious consideration an official visit to Brazil when Carlos Martins, the Brazilian Ambassador, gave him today a formal invitation from President Eurico Caspar Dutra to visit that country.

City children often outstrip country children as gardeners, Miss Helen Barrett Smith, executive secretary of the New York Plant and Flower Guild at 598 Madison Avenue, declared yesterday. She made this comment at the guild's Children's Garden at York Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street where 350 youngsters raise flowers and vegetables in five, by ten-foot plots and which closed a three-day flower show yesterday with the announcement of awards.
DETROIT, June 20 -- Reputations weren't worth a hoot in national Professional Golfers Association championship at Plum Hollow today.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Several mayors and leaders of more than thirty civic, veterans, labor and church organizations will participate in a "Fight-for-Housing Day" rally here next Wednesday in an effort to win support for the Taft-Ellender-Wagner Housing Bill, the Rev. Thomas Keehn, committee chairman, said today.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The defense suggested a "personal revenge" motive in the MayGarsson war-fraud trial today by raising a question about an alleged seizure of liquor on the Canadian border during the prohibition era.

The Lemonade Opera Company, so named because it sells lemonade between the acts, presented its production of "Don Giovanni," conducted by Kenneth Hieber, last night at the Greenwich Mews Playhouse. The opara was sung in English before a full house of sympathetic and resppnsive listeners.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- A warning by the Treasury Department against "inflation" failed today to slow down a Congressional drive to cash an estimated $2,000,000,000 in terminal leave pay bonds held by former service men and women.

The Aetna Insurance Company announced yesterday that it has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission an issue of 250,000 shares of $10 par value capital stock which it proposes to offer to its stockholders. The issue would increase outstanding capital stock to 1,000,000 shares.

After the collapse of the Western Front in May, 1940, there were scandalous rumors that King Leopold of Belgium had surrendered to the Germans without warning to his allies. The inference was that he had done this to save his throne and perhaps his life.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Evan A. Evans, senior judge of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, denied today a petition of senior bondholders of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad to remove District Judge Michael L. Igoe from, jurisdiction, over the fourteen-year-old case.

Ike Williams heavy artillery proved too much for Tippy Larkin's ring artistry in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The heavy hitter from Trenton, N.J., clearly outboxed in the first two rounds, dominated the veteran Larkin in the third before going on to put his Garfield (N.J.) opponent down for the full count in 1:44 of the fourth.

John B. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, has nominated Francis A. Turner, a Negro with the rank of first assistant in the school system, to the new $8,400-a-year position of assistant director of community education.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- July corn advanced today 1 3/4 cents a bushel over yesterday's finish to $2.00 3/4, a new high record for futures on the Board of Trade, showing 1 5/8 cents above the previous record established in July, 1919, and 17 7/8 cents above the low of last Monday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 20 -- The United Nations Security Council voted, 9 to 1, against Russia today to put discussion of the Trieste Governorship on its agenda. The Council then closed its doors and drew the blinds for a secret meeting on the candidates for the job.
President Truman and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio came to grips last night in country-wide broadcasts from Washington discussing the Taft-Hartley labor bill.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The War Department announced today that N.W. Ayer and Son, Inc., has been awarded the contract for recruiting advertising for 1948, which will involve a sum between $4,000,000 and $4,500,000. In approving the contract, Under-Secretary of War Kenneth C. Royall said Ayer was the successful bidder out of a group of five firms which had elected to make competitive presentations.

BOSTON, June 20 (AP) -- Jimmy Hegan, for whom fans of his home city of Lynn, Mass., put on a "night," drove in all the Cleveland runs tonight as the Indians defeated the Red Sox, 3 -- 2, snapping a Boston winning streak at eight games.

ROME, June 20 -- Palmiro Togliatti, the Communist leader, today accused the United States of interfering directly with Italian internal affairs and of having suggested, if not actually demanded, the exclusion of the Communists and Socialists from the Government here.

Deputy Chief Harold J. Burke, in charge of the city's firefighting forces in the Bronx, has been transferred to the department's Limited Service Squad in the same borough, according to an announcement last night from Fire Headquarters in the Municipal Building.

After a Cuban vacation of three months, Joshua Logan is in town again ready for a busy session on the Main Stem. Although the staging of the road company of "Annie Get Your Gun," starring Mary Martin, occupies first place on his agenda, Mr. Logan also is contemplating one or two productions on his own this year.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- A Senate Appropriations subcommittee today approved a $177,000,000 increase in new funds for the Navy Department over what the House has voted.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 20 -- Miss Polly Andrews of Innis Arden captured the women's Westchester and Fairfield Counties Golf Association championship for the fourth time today at the Westchester Hills Golf Club.

In the Congressional elections of last November the American voters revolutionized the political complexion of the House of Representatives through the recall of fifty-one Democratic members and the election of fifty-seven additional Republicans. Even in the Senate, where change is normally a more or less gradual process, the results were almost as emphatic.
