LONDON, June 20 -- The best section in generally cheerful stock markets here today was that devoted to oil shares. Heavy buying based on prospects of world-wide shortage of petroleum products, due to expanding demands coupled with inadequate refining and storage facilities, plus difficulties of transportation, was the cause.

The city sacrificed gross revenues of between $11,500,000 and $24,500,000 from oil sales at Idlewild Airport in the negotiation of Idlewild airline leases, Milton N. Weir, assistant to the vice president of the Gulf Oil Corporation, testified yesterday.
Those who have not been able to buy a new 1947 automobile may be able to derive some consolation in seeing what the latest model off the assembly lines in 1967 will look like.

PARIS, June 20 -- Premier Paul Ramadier today obtained the Cabinet's support for an emergency deflationary program to meet the overwhelming Treasury and import deficits and to save the franc. In submitting the proposals to the Assembly's Finance Committee, he gave notice that he would push them for an urgent vote on Monday -- on the basis of a vote of confidence if necessary.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Five railroad unions, representing 350,000 operating employes, today renewed requests for forty-four changes in working rules. Notice of the action came as the carriers and heads of seventeen unions were negotiating over a 20-cent-an-hour pay increase asked by 1,000,000 non-operating workers.

Having lately retraced the American invasion routes in Europe and the Pacific, Bill Downs and James Hurlbut are back in town conferring with the CBS Documentary Unit for the preparation of "We Went Back," a onehour broadcast scheduled for Aug. 14, second anniversary of V-J Day, at 10 P.M.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall appealed again today for passage of a bill to authorize continuation of the State Department's international information and cultural exchange program.

After Bobby Riggs, Don Budge and Frank Kovacs had marched with certain strides to their predestined places in the semi-finals, Welby Van Horn and a heavy downpour of rain disrupted the charted course of the twentieth national professional tennis championships at Forest Hills.

Prospects for a general lowering of retail meat prices next week improved yesterday. Wholesale markets declined further and one packing house with 108 retail outlets announced cuts ranging to 10 cents a pound.

The legendary three-story Collyer home at 2078 Fifth Avenue was opened yesterday morning long enough for an auctioneer to dispose of one tuneless piano for $45 and a miscellaneous lot of goods for $100.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 20 -- The Eastern college rowing season comes to its grand finale tomorrow in the revival of the Poughkeepsie regatta, last held in 1941.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (U.P.) -- The Maritime Commission said tonight that it would have to close its doors until June 30 because of the lack of funds and failure to convince Chairman John Taber of the House Appropriations Committee that it must shift its money around to meet the payroll.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 -- International effort to combat an alarming rise in Europe's tuberculosis incidence, one of war's legacies, was called for today by Dr. Johannes Holm, chief of the tuberculosis division of the State Serum Institute in Copenhagen.

The Episcopal Church of the Incarnation was the setting here yesterday for the marriage of Miss Margaret Morton Keeney, daughter of Mrs. John Milton Quaintance of 112 East Thirty-seventh Street and Woodstock, Vt., and the late Morton Keeney of Grand Rapids, Mich., to Edward Well Rosenheim Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rosenheim of Chicago.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 20 -- Mrs. Barbara Riggs Clement, 24-yearold mother and a relative of former Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson, has been missing since Wednesday evening, it was disclosed here today.

Since 1935 when Edith Kalman came to the United States from Hungary with other members of her family, she had watched enviously as her father, four brothers and three sisters became citizens. Then only 10 years old, she waited anxiously for her turn.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Radio "soap operas" and singing commercials were defended today by Edgar Kobak, president of the Mutual Broadcasting System.

PARIS, June 20 -- Predicting that the next few weeks would prove decisive for the future of world unity, Foreign Minister Bidault made in the Assembly today his first public comment on the Marshall plan for European recovery.

The 265-foot acid-disposal barge Sayreville, said to be the largest of her type ever built, was launched yesterday at the Bethlehem Steel Company's Staten Island yard. The launching marked the first step of a $2,000,000 program of the National Lead Company for disposal at sea of liquid waste.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- (AP) -- Entry into the United States of about 30,000 Poles, former combat troops, now in Great Britain and Italy and refusing to go home, was proposed today by Representative George MacKinnon, Republican, of Minnesota. These Polish soldiers, he said, are anti-Communists and do not want to return to Russiandominated Poland.

GLYNDEBOURNE, England June 20-"Albert Herring," the new opera by Benjamin Britten received its first performance tonight, when it was presented by a newly formed company 'in John Christies Theatre here on Sussex Downs.

Trade Gain Wider in Week With consumer demand for seasonal merchandise broadening, the percentage of gain in retail trade here this week increased compared with the preceding week. Estimates indicated department store volume rose about 12 per cent over the 1946 period, against a rise of 7 per cent last week.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 20 --With a final check and inspection tonight, thirty-six yachts were passed for the New York Yacht Club ocean race to Annapolis. The start will be 2 P.M. tomorrow off Brenton lightship, outside the harbor here.

PITTSBURGH, June 20 (AP) -- Ernie Bonham, former Yankee hurler starting his first game for the Pirates, pitched five-hit ball to shut out the Phils, 6 to 0, at Forbes Field tonight. Wally Westlake hit his eighth homer of the year With no one abroad in the seventh.
F.R. Archer has been appointed merchandising supervisor of the fluorescent lighting fixture division of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 20 (U.P.) -- Czechoslovakia and other countries of eastern Europe showed considerable skepticism today about the Marshall plan.

Representative Hoffman's attempt to find some political or subversive influence at work in the project to send on a country-wide tour some historic Americany documents, such as the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution, has been adequately frustrated, we hope, by the hearing before the House Expenditures Committee.
Six liners carrying 4,000 passengers sailed from North River piers for European and Caribbean ports yesterday, marking the traditional opening of the summer travel season.

The Age Classes Navajo children, it was stated the other day at a national conference on child development in Iowa City, have such an easy time of it perhaps it is best that knowledge of the fact does not circulate too far.

The City of New York has borrowed $13,000,000 from twenty-six local banks on 0.875 per cent taxanticipation notes and $18,000,000 on 1.125 per cent budget notes for transit operation, Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday Both series of notes are dated June 20.

The executive committee of the American Association for the United Nations yesterday urged this government to carry out its promise to use United Nations machinery in efforts to bring" about economic reconstruction in Europe.

CLEVELAND, June 20 -- A resolution urging admission to this country of 100,000 displaced persons a year for four years from Europe was passed today by delegates to the Catholic War Veterans' convention here.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y. June 20 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, will visit Secretary of State Marshall in Washington next week to sign the special convention on immunities and privileges offered by the United States to the United Nations, it was learned today.

LONDON, June 20 -- The Soviet Union is "considering" the Marshall plan for aid to Europe at the urgent request of Great Britain and France for action by Europe's three chief powers, the Moscow radio said tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- An improved system of vehicle air-conditioning whereby fresh clean air is always available in the passenger space while the system is in operation was one of the 475 inventions on which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.

BERLIN, June 20 -- Pointed criticism of the new Economic Coordinating Committee in the Soviet zone was issued today by the British Military Government in a formal press release. The statement said the chief difference between this and the new bizonal Economic Council in ths United States and British zones was that the latter "represents popular opinion" and had been set up ''on a democratic basis."

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- A formal agreement signed today in Athens assured to the United States complete control of the expenditure in Greece of the $300,000,000 assigned to that country under the Truman Doctrine. The funds were assigned by Congress in the $400,000,000 bill to assist Greece and Turkey.

Even if the sun does shine it's still nice weather for ducks. The peak of the season is upon us, the production and marketing' administration of the Department of Agriculture notes. As reported here yesterday, the city-wide average is only 33 cents a pound, which is low in relation to other poultry and many meats.

MAYADINE, Syria, June 20 -- A tangled mass of scorched and twisted metal that on Wednesday night was the Pan American World Airways clipper plane Eclipse, flying from Karachi, India, to New York, is strewn on the flat desert above the Euphrates River near this village.

James G. Fuller, convicted with Mayor James M. Curley of Boston for mail fraud, was termed yesterday "a confidence man of no mean ability," as General Sessions Judge Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. sentenced him to five to six years in state prison on his guilty plea to passing a worthless $130 check.

AMSTERDAM, June 20 (ANETA) --The market was strong in moderately active trading on the Stock Exchange, as a result of reports -- denied after the market closed -- that the Indonesian Republic had accepted Netherlands proposals for settlement of the Indonesian problem.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- President Truman's message vetoino the labor management relations bill today follows: To the House of Representatives: I return herewith, without my approval, H.H. 3020, the "Labor Management Relations Act, 1947."

Small, war-born Northeastern lumber mills with a maximum monthly output of 200,000 board feet have suffered a 30 per cent mortality within the last sixty days because of a 25 per cent price drop in low grade stock and other factors, R.E. Broderick, executive secretary, Northeastern Lumber Manufacturers Association, reported yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 20 -- Acting on behalf of British Foreign Secretary Bevin, Sir Alexander Cadogan assured Secretary General Trygve Lie today that the role of the United Nations in the efforts to rebuild Europe was being kept in mind, and that Mr. Lie would be kept informed of the developments.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 20 -- The Communist newspaper Szabadsag announced today that the police had begun to unravel the threads of a plot leading to Rumania and involving Deszo Sulyok's Liberty party and the secretaries of former Premier Ferenc Nagy and of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, who is attending a Catholic conference in Canada.

ALBANY, June 20 -- The State Board of Regents today elected John P. Myers of Plattsburg, a member, vice chancellor of the University of the State of New York, effective Aug. 1. He will succeed William L. Thompson of Troy, who will continue as a regent.

Hyman Blumberg and Adoif A. Berle, Jr., state chairmen of the American Labor party and the Liberal party, respectively, congratulated President Truman yesterday on his veto of the Taft-Hartley labor bill and called on the Senate to sustain him.
LONDON, June 20 -- The Royal Commission on the Press in Britain announced today that it had decided to hear oral evidence entirely in private.

THIS is still a free country. That is proved by the fact that John Cournos and Sybil Norton have gathered nineteen short tales from various parts of the planet and with magnificent blitheness called the collection "Best World Short Stories, 1947."* How do they know that the two-billion-odd inhabitants of the earth didn't write better ones in the course of the last year? Well, as a matter of fact, they don't, of course.

JERUSALEM, June 20 -- After a two-hour private meeting tonight, the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine announced that it would continue touring Palestine until July 3, visiting Arab and Jewish districts. Presumably, the committee will not begin hearing political testimony until then or later.

PARIS, June 20 -- Commercial and financial operations in France were considerably slowed today as the strike of the banking employees kept the domestic banks closed for the second straight day throughout the nation and in Algeria.

LONDON, June 20 -- A program for European economic cooperation, under which the most efficient producing areas regardless of national boundaries would receive priority assistance from the United States under the Marshall plan, was under study today by British economic experts.

JERUSALEM, June 20 -- Palestine and British authorities searched the country today and flashed descriptions to neighboring territories in the hunt for Major Roy Alexander Farran, who last night "walked out" of the army barracks here where he was being held in custody.

An agreement settling family differences on the estate of Max J. Kramer, builder and hotel chain operator, was approved yesterday by Surrogate James A. Delehanty. Papers on file showed Mr. Kramer left a gross estate of $3,500,000 and a net of $1,800,000.

Shortly after the sun went under a bank of dark clouds directly over Times Square a wire arrived from Roscoe, N.Y., stating that the Beaverkill and Willowemoc were in excellent condition, water temperature just right, and fish rising to excellent hatches of flies.

LONDON, June 20 (AP) -- American tennis -- particularly of the California variety -- again proved its power today when stars from the Sunshine State filled three of the four final berths in the London championships at the Queens Club.
Fluctuating over a fairly wide range, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed barely steady, 10 to 45 points net lower.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 20 -- Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of Piping Rock became the new Long Island match play champion today. She overwhelmed her young Wheatley Hills rival, Miss Evelyn Odom, 9 and 8 in the 36-hole final at the Nassau Country Club.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 20 -- It is time that the United States assumed the initiative, through mobilization of its vast material resources and development of enlightened leadership, in the reconstruction of a war-torn world for peace and freedom, the American Veterans Committee convention was told here today by three speakers.

A strong recommendation that shoe manufacturers, if their minimum working inventory requirements are now reasonably met, adopt the LIFO (last-in, first-out) method of inventory valuation at this time was made yesterday by the National Shoe Manufacturers Association.

CALCUTTA, India, June 20 (AP) -- Hindu and Moslem area representatives, meeting in one joint and two separate sessions, cast a series of ballots today that had the effect of partitioning Bengal, a province twice the size of Indiana and with a population of 60,000,000.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Following is the text of a radio address tonight by Senator Taft, answering President Truman's veto and radio messages on the Labor Bill: The President's message vetoing the Labor Bill was a complete misrepresentation of both the general character of the bill and of most of its detailed provisions.

WITH an abundance of ballyhoo not usually accorded a summer venture, Jack Paar, erstwhile GI comedian, has taken over the choice Jack Benny time on NBC (7 P.M. Sundays). After three performances he seems reasonably well settled in the niche and should provide diverting enough fare for the next few weeks.

The semi-annual office occupancy survey by the National Association of Building Owners and Managers shows that for the first time in thirteen years there has been an increase in the amount of vacant space.

All shipbuilding and repair work by CIO members in this port will be halted tomorrow at noon, to enable nearly 20,000 members from six locals of the Industrial Uniion of Marine and Ship Building Workers of America, CIO, to attend a port-wide mass meeting at the Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., Republican, of New Jersey, accused President Truman tonight of sponsoring "misrepresentations, half truths and distortions" in his veto message on the Taft-Hartley labor bill and contended the President did not write it himself.
Albert Einstein has withdrawn his support from Brandeis University, the proposed non-sectarian school in Waltham, Mass., organized under Jewish sponsorship, it was announced yesterday.

BRIDGETON, N.J., June 21 -- Kenneth Sweeney, a Philadelphia heating contractor, drove up to Ivy Manor, a nearby sanatorium for alcoholics late last night with a woman in the back seat who local physicians said had been dead for about four hours.

PRESIDENTIAL vetoes of the tax and labor bills were banner line news last week. What they failed to obscure was the first Truman veto which fell to the lot of the Republican OPA bill. This anniversary draws close and prices still are well up in the news.

AT the age of 11, Luis Perez was a full-fledged soldier in a Mexican rebel army. The boy's rifle was bigger than he was, but looking back today, Mr. Perez gets down more of the meaninglessness, the waste and the melancholy charm of life in such an internecine war than half a dozen historians.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The United States, wealthiest nation in the world, is challenged today by the problem of pursuing a foreign trade policy that will not bankrupt its best customers.

Italy now stands formally beside France as the second of the western democracies of Europe to exclude Communists from her Government. By a narrow vote of 274 to 231 her Constituent Assembly has endorsed Premier de Gasperi's fourth Cabinet, the first since the liberation to contain no Communist Ministers.

MEMBERS of the New York Art Directors Club are giving us glimpses of the art they themselves like to create off duty. Although most of their pictures are doubtless painted on Sundays and holidays, it would of course be a mistake to speak of them as "Sunday painters" in any sense having "primitive" connotations.

Community X-ray surveys conducted the first time in Queens by the Queensboro Tuberculosis and Health Association revealed thirteen active tubercular cases, it was said yesterday in the organization's annual report.

BREMEN, Germany, June 21 -- The Constitution for Bremen, the youngest State in the American zone of occupation, will embody provisions for the socialization of certain industries when it is put before the population for approval, it was learned today.

JERUSALEM, June 21 -- With rumors rampant of high-level resignations and a general shake-up pending in the Palestine police force, a court of inquiry met today to investigate the escape from custody of Major Roy Alexander Farran, much-decorated Royal Marines Commando officer.

WHEN Chancellor Robert M. Hutchins of the University of Chicago announced the other day the organization of the Great Books Foundation, together with his hope that some millions of copies of "The 432 Great Books" would vie with the latest titles on the best-seller lists, all right thinking people hastened to share that hope.

A State-wide program for qualifying veterans of World War II for a high school diploma and for college admission has shown an unusual degree of success in North Carolina, according to William B. Harrill, senior institutional training officer for veterans' education in that State.

More intensive pilot training in all-weather flying, better instrumentation and navigational aids and more thorough maintenance can reduce but never eliminate airplane accidents in both commercial and military operations.
BOSTON, June 21 -- Boston now being governed by its City Clerk, John B. Hynes.

THE season of club activity having been closed formally by the recent annual dinner of the Metropolitan Camera Club Council, it is time again to look back over the pictures and progress recorded in the past year. Unfortunately, this backward look affords little metropolitan satisfaction.

ON a day in April, seven years ago, an America still at peace was shocked by the news that Hitler had invaded Norway and Denmark. On the same day, bankers and business men throughout the world were shocked by the publication of an executive order, signed by President Roosevelt, freezing all Danish and Norwegian assets in the United States -- ail item of some seven billions of dollars.

MOST motorists who drive on New York City's parkways are unaware of a regulation laid down recently, but without much publicity, by the Department of Parks which forbids use of low-beam headlights on the municipal parkways.

A HAPPY-GO-LUCKY novel of present-day New Orleans, written with engaging freshness and gusto, Robert Tallant's "Mrs. Candy" is a pleasant hammockspecial from cover to cover. Here, praise heaven, you will find not one magnolia, no star-crossed creoles, and nary a rustle of family trees.

LONDON, June 21 -- The Observer, an influential Sunday newspaper, will say tomorrow that seven to ten years and a minimum of $25,000,000,000 will be needed to rehabilitate Europe along the terms of the Marshall proposal.

ENTRIES for the 1947 $5,000 Graflex Photo Contest, which closes Oct. 1, may be submitted beginning July 1. The rules permit any subject so long as the picture was taken between Oct. 1, 1946, and Oct. 1, 1947, with a Graphic, Graflex, Crown or Century camera.

As evidence of a restoration of confidence in the retail picture for fall, buyers in the market last week placed fairly substantial orders, according to a market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc.

A total of 35,500,000 pounds of relief materials have been shipped to Germany in the last fifteen months through the Council of Relief Agencies Licensed for Operation in Germany (CRALOG), according to Edward M. O'Connor, chairman of the council, in a statement issued here yesterday.

SALT HARBOR. THE seasons in this part of New England are, to employ understatement, somewhat variable. The calendar is as false a guide as division of the year into four socalled seasons. Salt Harbor to New England resort towns between Long Island Sound and Bay of Fundy is deliberate, the result of considerable familiarity with those areas -- as well as of some mental effort.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 21 -- Declaring that "for many years ahead we must place major reliance upon those techniques, weapons and items of equipment with which we successfully fought the last war," Admiral Dewitt C. Ramsey, deputy chief of naval operations, said today that "until the day comes when present-day warfare is completely outmoded our Navy is built around our aircraft carriers as spearheads of attack."

To Americans with the June sun in their eyes and vacations around the corner, hunger is a remote and abstract thing. To Europe, hunger is close up, personal and terrifyingly in the present. The farm lands just emerging from floods and frosts look into the sun, too -- unequal to the demand or completely devastated.

THERE is a commonly believed myth that there are "no playwrights" in America any more. I would agree that there are very few who write seriously, well, and regularly for the Broadway theatre, but the myth implies that the lack is the fault of those people who are trying to become playwrights and those who have made the grade more or less creditably.

IN 1904 the daughter of Abram S. Hewitt, gathering material for a life of her father, asked the advice of Henry Adams. "Consult old John Bigelow," Adams wrote her, but also he cautioned her that no biography of any figure in the "last generation" was yet satisfactory:

WELL, what do you know? A film company has actually been called on the mat by the Federal Trade Commission for allegedly advertising a film in such a way, and under such circumstances as to "mislead" the general public and exhibitors alike.

SEVENTY miles from New York, near Patchogue, L.I., is a lonely sign -- "Brookhaven National Laboratory" -- half hidden by undergrowth. About a mile beyond the sign you come upon a guard. He asks you to identify yourself, to tell whom you want to see. If everything is in order you are admitted to the reservation -- in war days Camp Upton.

IN less than a year, Frank Hague of Jersey City and Ed Kelly of Chicago, both of whom doubled in brass as Mayors and political bosses, have quit one or both at their jobs. In Kansas City, Jim Pendergast, son of the late Tom Pendergast, has pulled out by request and in Hoboken the McFeely brothers' edition of the Hague machine has crumbled like the only slightly older one-hoss shay.

Cooperative housing, if capably managed, offers one of the few opportunities for the moderate-income family to obtain new housing at this time, Abraham E. Kazan declared yesterday. Mr. Kazan is head of Amalgamated Housing Corporation and of East River Cooperative Apartments, both of which will begin construction of large developments in August.

CINCINNATI, June 21 -- In a see-saw game that was not distinguished by perfect play, the Dodgers today ran their winning streak to four games and moved into second place ahead of the Giants as they outscored the Reds, 6 -- 5.

TRENTON, N.J., June 21 -- A city-wide recreational program to defeat trends to juvenile delinquency through use of school facilities at night has been presented to the City Commission by the Council of Social Agencies.

Many ardent surfcasters who follow their sport as far as the wind-swept beaches of the North Carolina outer banks will be surprised (and some of them disappointed) to hear that law and a highway are making their debut on Hatteras.

BRIDGETON, N.J., June 21 -- A 52-year-old Bridgeton man was arraigned as a matricide in police court here late today. Formally charged with the murder of his aged mother three years ago, Herbert Bowers, an itinerent junk dealer, entered a plea of not guilty and was taken to the Cumberland county jail, where he has been held since his arrest May 15.

To the Drama Editor: AS a member in good standing of the Dramatists' Guild of the Authors League of America I am writing to protest the decision of the Guild's council meeting on June 10th in regard to the proposed contract between the Herd Theatrical Corporation and myself.

BOSTON, June 21 (AP) -- With Bobby Doerr belting a grandslammer and Sam Mele a three-run homer, the Boston Red Sox chased Bob Feller after the fifth inning today while romping to a 9-1 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

Wheat stands tall on the high plains, oceans of wheat rippling green in the sunlight, and the wheat ranchers have only two fears -- hail and rust. Spare them hail and spare them rust and they will again fill the nation's granaries to overflowing. All across the plains, Kansas, Nebraska, eastern Colorado, the wheat is lush with a wet spring's growth.

AUSTRALIA is in no very acute need of a good fivecent cigar, but it does desperately need a good literary critic. When you say this in Australia the invariable reply is, "But we had one -- A.G. Stephens." To be sure Australia once bad one, but the point is that Mr. Stephens died in 1933.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Two Senators and a Representative from wool-growing states called on President Truman today to urge him to sign the Wool Import Tariff Bill.

BERLIN, June 21 (AP) -- A highly placed American source proposed today that all industrial holdings in the British and American zones of Germany should be "frozen" for the next five years in a "political truce'' between capitalism and socialism.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 21 -- Yugoslav authorities announced today an amnesty for persons convicted of having hoarded grain in the recent food crisis. No one has died and no one's health has suffered" in Yugoslavia because of hunger, they said.

In Soviet-occupied Hungary last week the coup which had brought the ousting of the conservative Government clique in favor of a proRussian regime was over. The Communists were in control of the country and of the Smallholders party -- formerly the mainstay of Hungary's conservatives.

THE idea itself, that of presenting a large assembled selection of sculpture from the collections of the Whitney Museum and the Metropolitan, was excellent. But how good material may, so to speak, be thrown away is, in the upshot, pretty conclusively proved.

Australia, the first foreign government to sell its post-war bonds here, probably will be the last overseas government to undertake such borrowing in this private-capital market, at least for the time being. This is an opinion widely held in investment circles following the offering last week of the two final issues of the Commonwealth's refunding bonds -- $38,000,000 of 3 1/4 s and 3 1/2 s, to run for ten and twenty years, respectively.

FAT FROM MOLD -- Straw, oat hulls and whey were used in a German laboratory to produce fats by a microbiological process described in a report by A.K. Balls of the United States Department of Agriculture and two British experts for the British Intelligence Objectives Subcommittee.

HOLLYWOOD. THE first information on the two-month-old negotiation of a new contract between the Screen Actors Guild and the film producers was released last week by the guild in an "intelligence report" to its membership which said:

LONDON, June 21 -- The western European response to United States Secretary of State Marshall's speech at Harvard is a pretty good measure of Europe's need. The speech was seen as a recognition by the New World of the necessity of tackling the Old World's problem as a whole rather than as a patchwork enterprise of meeting emergencies in piecemeal fashion.

ROME, June 21 -- An article in l'Osservatore Romano said today that the gravest threat to world peace was the Soviet Union's determination to impose communism beyond its borders. This, it implied, is a most serious obstacle to the maintenance of peace because it has caused strong anti-Communist reaction on the part of nations that are equally determined to oppose this Soviet policy.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Senator Wayne L. Morse, Republican, of Oregon, gained the title of talkathon king of the Eightieth Congress today by holding the floor for ten hours and two minutes. But neither he nor the Senate set any new records for length of speeches or continuous meetings.

BIENNIAL flowers at their peak now are among the most beautiful sights of the garden year. They are seen all too seldom. In spite of their great beauty, they discourage the gardener because they need a whole year of care before blooming, and then the plants must be discarded.

TO most Americans, the religion of Islam is an almost total unknown. Yet one seventh of the world's population are Moslems, and they live in areas extending from Atlantic Africa through the Arab heartland to the isles of the Pacific.

GRANDCAMP-LES-BAINS. THIS fishing village of 1,652 persons on the Channel close to the corner of the L formed by the Cherbourg Peninsula and the northern coast of France was liberated in June, 1944, and I lived here for about two months afterward as a member of an Army Air Forces headquarters.
MUNICH, Germany, June 21 -- Munich members of the Economic Reconstruction party rallied today to the support of Chairman Dr. Alfred Loritz, ousted yesterday by party leaders.

BROOKLINE, Mass., June 21 (AP) -- The Middle Atlantic States Tennis Association team competing for the first time since the Church Cup matches were inaugurated in 1917, gained that trophy, one of the most valuable in sports' competition, with a 5 1/2 to 3 1/2 match margin over the New England forces today at Longwood.

BURIED in vaults and film libraries for the past quarter century, Robert J. Flaherty's famous film on life among the Eskimos, "Nanook of the North," will return to the nation's screens if current negotiations jell, it was learned following the announcement last week that United Artists had acquired the documentary feature for distribution abroad.

HERE is a romantic drama, in the manner of "Dragonwyck," of a machinating heroine who is ultimately destroyed by her own uncanny, deliberate evil. A sustained portrayal, with strong story value and unobtrusive regional and period contours, this is holding, chilling fare.

Forty-six Dutch sixteenth and seventeenth century paintings which were stolen from the Netherlands by the Nazis will arrive on Tuesday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for a month's exhibition beginning July 1.

Colleges and universities throughout the United States expect a greater number of students on their campuses next fall than ever before in their history. Advance reports indicate that the current record-breaking student body of 2,000,000 will be substantially increased when classes reopen in September.

Department store sales by reserve districts, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board, are listed in the following table which gives percentage comparisons with a year ago: 4 Weeks Year Federal Reserve Week Ended Ended to
OTTAWA, June 21 (AP) -- A throng of pilgrams watched a parade of 20,000 persons honoring the Virgin Mary today and joined in prayer services for world peace as a climax to the Marian Congress.

THE series of crashes that have beset the airlines since May 29 have quite definitely cost the lines patronage. It is a slight reduction in actual figures, but it comes at a time when, in other years, the patronage of the airlines would show an increase.
LOS ANGELES, June 21 -- California is scheduled to launch the first organized Henry Wallace-forPresident movement in a few weeks with or without the subject's formal blessing.

BRUNSWICK, Ga. -- When a citizen of Brunswick is feeling opulent, exhilarated and altogether happy with his lot, he doesn't say he's "sitting on top of the world." He says instead, "I'm settin' on Jekyll."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 21 -- The longest day of the year became the saddest for N.Y.U. this sunshiny afternoon at Yale Field. Like the fellow who had heard a rumor that he had inherited a fortune and already was making plans how to spend it, the Violets thought they had the Eastern Regional N.C.A.A. baseball championship wrapped in cellophane as they held a 4-1 lead over Yale in the seventh inning.

THE airplane is the covered wagon of Alaska. Long after the Wright Brothers flew at Kittyhawk, Alaska was still an empty wilderness. Its frontier era continues, but gradually daring men in the air have tied together its far-flung settlements.

IF you have never experienced the secret urge to sweep the Kiwanis Club off its collective feet by a brilliant and witty extemporaneous speech, you need not read Josh Lee's handy manual for orators. If you have felt such a yearning for the unattainable you will enjoy his book.

The charges that women's clubs of the nation are primarily interested in social affairs and that the clubwomen take themselves too seriously and the world not seriously enough were denied yesterday by Mrs. LaFell Dickinson, national president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs.

DECORATIVE plants play a great part in making the outdoor porch or terrace a more enjoyable place during the summer months. A wise selection of material properly placed and cared for adds to the attractiveness of any room, whether it be indoors in winter or the outdoor living room at this time of year.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Restoration of controls on oil exports was predicted today by Rep. Paul W. Shafer, Republican, of Michigan, after an inquiry into petroleum shipments to Russia.

Dr. Robert B. Woodward, Harvard's thirty-year-old associate professor of chemistry, already a historic figure because of his Synthesis of quinine in collaboration with Dr. William E. Doering of Columbia in 1944, electrified both biologists and chemists last week with the announcement that he had synthesized materials which come closer to natural protein than any hitherto made.

ALTHOUGH Sun Yat-sen declared at his death that the Chinese Revolution was unfinished, and though at the end of the long agony of the war of survival against Japan it is still unfinished, at least the world now regards Chinese politics with a new respect.

VIENNA, June 21 -- The Austrian Treaty Commission will plunge Monday into the most important single problem connected with the establishment of an independent Austria -- the ownership of the Zistersdorf oil fields.

BERLIN (By Wireless) TO millions of Europeans the New World seems like a paradise. The countries of North and South America offer them opportunity and security which they despair of finding in their lifetime at home. Two wars within a generation, and the paralysis and chaos which inevitably follow destruction on such an enormous scale, have left a whole continent with little hope either for future peace or prosperity.

CORINTH, Miss. AS trains approached this town around the turn of the century the conductor used to call out, "Corinth! Twenty minutes for breakfast and prayers!" At least that's the way the story went. And whether or not it was true it was in the spirit of truth.
The fortunes of war dealt lightly with 20-year-old Staff Sergeant Michael Lonardo of New Haven, Conn., but the fortunes of love -- that was a different matter yesterday.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., June 21 -- An extensive program for the revision of Navy justice based on global operations in the recent war was described here today by Rear Admiral Oswald S. Colclough, Judge Advocate General of the United States Navy.

MUNICH. THE first feature-length German film produced in the United States zone since the war, "Between Yesterday and Today,'' was completed last week. Lieut. Col. W.C. Rogers, theatre officer at the Bavaria film studios, said the picture would be ready for distribution in Germany in the autumn but that no plans have been made to export this or any other film from the United States zone.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- A newly incorporated company has asked the Federal Power Commission for permission to become the successor to the Tennessee Gas and Transmission Company and operator of its natural gas system, which is to consist chiefly of the "Big Inch" and "Little Big Inch" pipelines.

The National Association of Manufacturers urged yesterday that this country maintain enough merchant marine tonnage to support Army and Navy movements in time of war as well as our peacetime international trade. It made its views known in a letter to the President's Advisory Committee on Merchant Marine.

When the police arrested Cornelius Dougherty late Friday night they thought he was just another automobile thief. But after hearing his story they took up a collection for their 39-year-old prisoner and even tried to help quash the charge against him in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday.

Why all these airplane accidents? President Truman has appointed an impressive board to give him an answer. And the question is being echoed by Americans who are becoming increasingly air-conscious as flying becomes more and more commonplace.

Brooklyn's small fry athletes on the Police Athletic League 79th Precinct track team won't have to offer any alibis about their efficiency in sports as some of their older colleagues in the borough's baseball field are inclined to do.

IN "The Double Darkness," by Edward Fenton, we are given several days in the life of an English lance corporal attached to the British forces in their effort to halt the civil war that prostrated Athens following the German withdrawal.

TOKYO, June 20 -- The new Socialistdominated Japanese Government apparently is hesitating to implement its pledge for "democratic" control of the annual grain collections. None of the seventy government bills prepared for the Diet, which meets Monday, proposes any change in the system used by former conservative administrations.
The Juilliard School of Music issued its annual report yesterday on its concert-giving activities for the year. It lists fifty concerts and a larger number of radio broadcasts than ever before.

PARIS. ONE of the significant events in French literature during the period between the two wars was the discovery of American literature. I remember with what fervor the initiated, those who could read English, passed along the first books of Dos Passos, Hemingway and Faulkner.

Although earnings of banks for the second quarter of this year, to be reported at the end of this month, are likely to compare unfavorably with those at the close of the similar period a year ago, it is probable that improvement over the first quarter of this year will be registered, acccording to banking observers.

THE Diamond Jubilee Festival of Roses in Newark, N.Y., which started yesterday, has a variety of events scheduled for this week. Sponsored by the Jackson Perkins Company, the festival marks the seventyfifth anniversary of the nursery and the opening of its new public display garden.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Hearings on the Stratton bill -- introduced by a Republican Representative, William G. Stratton of Illinois, for the admission into this country of 400,000 of Europe's displaced persons -- are now going on in Congress before the SubCommittee on Immigration of the Committee on Judiciary.

When the House of Representatives voted to override the President's veto of the Taft-Hartley Labor-Management Bill there seemed to be no obstacle to similar action in the Senate, which had approved this compromise measure by a more than three-to-one vote. Thus far, and on this issue, Mr. Truman had been trying to beat back an irresistible tide.

PARIS, June 21 -- Rejection by the Assembly Finance Committee of the Government's "distress program" to carry France over her critical financial emergency today presaged a strenuous battle when Premier Paul Ramadier puts the measures before the Assembly on Monday.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 21 -- Winging away with their sails full in a light southerly breeze, the thirty-six yachts in the longest ocean race of the year, that of the New York Yacht Club down to Annapolis, Md., started off the red-hulled Brenton lightship at 2 o'clock this afternoon.

ROME, June 21 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi's fourth Cabinet obtained its first vote of confidence from the Constituent Assembly today by 274 votes to 231. The majority of forty-three, which is larger than anyone would have believed possible yesterday, marks the failure of the Communists and Left-Wing Socialists' efforts to overthrow the Government, installed on the 9th of this month.

OMAHA, June 21 -- Rain makes the Midwest go. Lack of it is the beginning of tragedy. But many residents of the region, farmers particularly, felt this week as though they were about to dive over a mythical waterfall in a soggy barrel.

THE psychiatrists must be used to slinking disguised through the streets, so probably Norman Anthony's new book will be a breeze that will not ruffle their hair. The above scientists have been so studied and dissected, their terminology so extended into rolling periods or parody commas, that they must almost feel they themselves are hallucinations -- even if the books about them are not.
VIENNA, June 21 -- Headquarters of United States Forces in Austria announced tonight that beginning July 1 all occupation costs will be paid to the Austrian Government in American dollars.

LITTLE ROCK, June 21 -- An industrial revolution is under way in Arkansas through the "Arkansas Plan," the essence of which is to focus all energies within the state on a campaign for creation of more industries financed and managed by Arkansans and producing goods from Arkansas materials.

PARIS, June 21 -- With new strikes breaking out on the one hand and the financial consequences of earlier strike settlements piling up on the other hand, the Ramadier Government struggled this week to get Cabinet and Parliamentary agreement on drastic measures to safeguard the solvency of the state and of the railways and other nationalized industries.

DETROIT, June 21 (AP) -- The socalled "Reuther faction" in the CIO-United Automobile Workers blasted a proposed merger with the CIO-Farm Equipment Workers today as a "flagrant violation" of the UAW constitution which "seriously undermines the basic industrial union structure of our organization."

THE author has a better right than most of us to call Franco and his regime all sorts of evil names. He is a Roman Catholic; he was in Spain as the American Embassy's press attache for four crucial years from 1942 to 1946, and he has given us an honest, earnest, well-documented study.

WITHOUT any embellishments Brooke Conway has given a true-to-life picture of one family's struggle to make both ends meet. Mrs. Kraemer had seven children to care for after her husband's death -- three of her own and four of her husband's by a former marriage.

THIS volume, by our foremost Lincoln scholar (author of the two-volume "Lincoln: The President"), contains eight essays, two of them never before printed, the others revised from various learned magazines. Unlike many volumes of essays, this volume has unity -- a unity imposed not only by the subject, but by the point of view.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- The War Department announced today that it would build "the greatest medical research center in the world," costing $40,000,000, at Forest Glen, Md., near Washington.

The large percentage of claims arising from the sale of surplus goods, and delays encountered in adjustment of such claims, have discouraged merchants and veterans from dealing in the commodities and consumer goods which the Government puts up for sale, it was pointed out last week.

HAVING learned the most common signal used in defensive play -- a high card as a "come-on" -- the bridge player must start learning the corollary rule, which is that one should not signal when one does not need to.

LONDON, June 21 -- Prime Minister Attlee delivered today an implicit but sharply pointed attack on the Soviet Union and its satellites in Eastern Europe in a speech to Yorkshire miners stressing the vital importance of freedom of speech and personal liberty.

ESCANABA, in Michigan's Upper Peninsula, will begin its first annual Hiawathaland Festival on July 3. Pageants, tournaments and speedboat races will highlight the fourday celebration. The main pageant, tracing development of the area from the days of the Indians (immortalized in Longfellow's poem "Hiawatha") through the lumbering and mining eras to the region's present popularity as a resort center, will be given nightly on the high school athletic field.

The black market in babies can be eliminated if the public will support the accredited adoption agencies, Miss Roberta G. Andrews, field secretary of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service, declared yesterday.

A recent war, with its global travel, has given wanderlust and itchy feet to untold thousands of yachtsmen. This season of 1947 will be the cruisingest in the history of American pleasure boat skippers.

DEVOLITE-PEERLESS "Frame-Finished" contact printing paper, which produces a white border without using a mask, was demonstrated here recently. Ordinarily in contact printing a frame or border is obtained by using a cut-out mask or masking bands between negative and paper.

NEWARK, N.J., June 21 -- In an action filed in Chancery Court here, three complainants are seeking to enjoin Newark and the major airlines from operating Newark Airport, contending that it is a "nuisance."

Edward M.M. Warburg, chairman of the Joint Distribution Committee, major American agency aiding Jews abroad, announced yesterday formation of a new committee that will advise the JDC on activities designed "to help Europe's Jewish survivors leave the relief rolls and achieve self-support."

MILWAUKEE, June 21 -- Three slates of candidates for the two top national offices of the American Veterans Committee were nominated by the organization's national convention here this evening. They reflected the views of three blocs of delegates whose differences revolve about the basic issue of Communist influence in the AVC.

Plans for a medical center building on Northern Boulevard, about 500 feet east of the Lord Taylor branch store in Manhasset, L.I., were announced yesterday. Construction is to be started about Sept. 1 and the project is scheduled for completion next March.

Nation Awaits Verdict At 12:05 P.M. on last Friday the Reading Clerk of the United States House of Representatives read to a packed chamber a historic Presidential message. It began with the words, "I return herewith, without my approval, H.R. 3020, the 'LaborManagement Relations Act, 1947.' "

The reaction of the business community has been favorable on the whole to last week's evidence that the Government and the country are putting more emphasis on the positive, constructive aspects and the basic economic features of the Truman-Marshall proposals for world reconstruction.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 21 (AP) -- A high-ranking Government official said today that Premier Ahmad Ghavam had presented for the Shah's approval a new Cabinet with several members "very friendly toward the western Governments."

Mrs. Barbara Riggs Clement, 24- year-old mother of a 15-months-old son, and daughter of a cousin of former Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson, was found last night as she approached the Park Plaza Hotel, 50 West Seventy-seventh Street, between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue.

Out of New York Harbor, gateway for 40 per cent of American foreign trade, scores of ships move seaward every day. In their holds are products of farm and factory -- wheat from the Midwest, autos from Detroit, machine tools from Toledo, clothing from Manhattan. The current value of all United States exports is rated at $19,600,000,000 a year.

ALTHOUGH the British do not share the American's gnawing anxiety to know what makes him tick, this fat and restless volume -- a companion piece to the same publisher's "American Thought, 1947," published last spring -- is proof enough that the British spirit is ticking on all cylinders.

WORD from Mary Wigman tells of her production late in March in Leipzig of Gluck's "Orpheus" as a dance drama. It was prepared through the hardships of a difficult winter and often looked as if it would never be completed, but, in her own words, "there it is now, living and conquering all doubts."

Consolidated net income of 228 industrial manufacturers in the first quarter of this year rose 305 per cent to $597,553,217 from the $147,665,103 return of the same companies in the initial three months of last year, according to our survey of official earnings statements.

EVERY Sunday thousands of New Yorkers enjoy walking tours within a hundred-mile radius of Times Square. Many of these hikers spend their week or two-week summer vacations afoot. A vacation tour afoot is real adventure, healthful, inexpensive and exhilarating.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 21 -- Stewart B. Iglehart played in midseason form today as he led the Westbury poloists to a 10-7 victory over Cecil Smith's Texas four on Whitney Field of the Meadow Brook club. In a second game at Waterbury Field Old Westbury turned back Roslyn, 10-4.

By the mere margin of a halfpoint the New York A.C., captured the team trophy in the fifty-sixth annual junior track and field championships of the Metropolitan Association of the A.A.U. at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. The Winged Foot athletes amassed a total of 68% points, and just managed to beat the New York Pioneer Club, with 68 points, for the top honors.

DR. KEEZER, president of Reed College from 1934 to 1942, opens his book with the melancholy observation that "it is almost the duty of a college president to become a stuffed shirt." Obviously, Dr. Keezer escaped this fate or he could not have written so unpretentious a book on liberal education as "The Light That Flickers."

GENEVA, June 21 -- A formula by which nations with industries wholly or partly under state control may trade more freely with countries where private industry predominates was engaging the attention of the Geneva trade conference today.

Bobby Riggs, the tireless retriever of the courts, muffled the thunder of Frank Kovacs yesterday to reach the final of the twentieth national professional tennis championship. Opposing Riggs in today's title match for the second straight year will be towering Don Budge, who eliminated Welby Van Horn in the other semi-final.

SEOUL, Korea, June 20 (Delayed) -- The extreme Rightist and Leftist parties in South Korea have presented challenges to the Joint United States-Soviet Commission that may soon test its ability to set up a provisional government for all Korea.
OCEANPORT, N.J., June 21 (AP) -- Polynesian, Elmendorf Farm favorite, romped to victory in the Oceanport Handicap at Monmouth Park today.

BY the time Thales in the Greece of 650 B.C. declared that "all things are one," and that being is but becoming, the thought of the Near Eastern world was already old. It had come a long way from the myths of Shumer and Babylon and the Valley of the Nile.

MEXICO CITY, June 21 -- Mexico, facing the serious problem of dwindling foreign exchange, has informed the United States of her plight in the hope a possible crisis may be avoided, it was learned today.

To the Drama Editor: THE Play Committee [an authors' representative] deprecates the proposed activities of the three gentlemen reported last week: namely, to subsidize authors and to take more of their royalties than The Authors' League has fought for years to assure them.

A concert in memory of Grace Moore, the celebrated soprano, who died in an airplane accident on Jan. 26 in Denmark, was presented before an audience of 13,000 last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. Alexander Smallens, who conducted when Miss Moore made her only appearance at the Stadium Concerts on Aug. 10, 1944, was on the podium for the first time this season, and Dorothy Kirsten, soprano, and Eugene Conley, tenor, were the soloists.

NEW DELHI, India, June 21 (Reuters) -- Communal tension was high tonight as more than forty fires darkened the sky over Lahore, Punjab Provincial capital, at the close of the city's worst day of arson since the beginning of recent disturbances.

HICKSVILLE, L.I., June 21 -- A preview of the Army Air Forces fighting power was given here today in a demonstration of Republic's P-84 Thunderjet that zoomed over the turf-covered airfield of the Aviation Country Club, founded in the summer of 1929.

Fourth-seeded Ladislav Hecht paced a record field of 141 entries as play began in the New York State clay court tennis championships at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills, yesterday. Hecht and Irvin Dorfman, eighth ranked, were the only seeded players to see action.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 21 -- An attempt to involve the United States Government in the "conspiracy against the Hungarian Republic" was the chief feature of the Government's White Book, which was available to Hungarian newspapers tonight. It is to be issued to the foreign press tomorrow.

-- COMMUNISTS The Department of Agriculture, knowing of our interest in gardens, favors us with its literature from time to time, and we hear from the Bureau of Internal Revenue right along. But our first recognition from Capitol Hill came last week.

To THE EDIOTR: William D. Ogden's informative "All for a Cent," shed much light on the ancestry of one of our most taken-forgranted conveniences -- the ubiquitous penny postal. I would like to postscript a couple of pertinent facts:

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The reality of a Treasury surplus for the first time in seventeen years and the prospects for whopping uncommitted revenues in fiscal 1948 has produced a pleasant dizziness among Federal financial experts that comes from trying to look backward and forward at the same time.

A substantial rise in construction activity and increased employment for building trades workers are foreseen by Tyler S. Rogers, president of the Producers Council, in the prospective removal of limitations on repair and maintenance of homes, stores and most other structures as provided in the bill passed by both houses of Congress and sent to President Truman on Thursday.

ANNUAL or China asters are among the best cut flowers. So desirable are the freshlooking, cool, crisp blossoms for indoor decoration that gardeners are willing to give them the extra care they demand. Raising these annuals well is not as simple as growing a zinnia or a marigold.

STOCKHOLM, June 21 -- Helsinki won the right today to stage the 1952 Olympic Games. The decision was reached in two ballots taken by delegates to the International Olympic Committee here. Five other competing cities mustered a maximum eleven out of a total of twenty-eight.

QUOTHA -- A bulletin of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington declares that the raven has at least three distinct calls: a hollow, "sepulchral" laugh, haw-haw-haw-haw; a series of "crawks" sounded while on the wing and interspersed with a musical note, ge-lick-ge-lee; and a sound strongly resembling the twang of a tuning fork, thung-thung-thung.

With the completion of plans in the Middle East, there will be available to the European market ample supplies of the cheapest crude oil in the world. In addition, this development will result in the greatest shift in the distribution of petroleum supplies in the history of the industry.

PEIPING, China, June 21 -- It was stated here today that high Chinese National Relief and Rehabilitation Administration officials in Manchuria had been advised by Chinese Government authorities to prepare for the possible evacuation of their entire staff.

LONDON, June 21 -- Coal, the key to Europe's economic recovery, dominated discussions of the Marshall plan for the rehabilitation of the Continent this week. Dollar loans would provide the means by which foodstuffs and manufactured goods could be purchased but only coal can turn the factory wheels in Britain and on the Continent for the production here of needed essentials.

Despite railroad car shortages, the industrial sand producers shipping to glass plants, chemical plants and foundries are meeting current demands; A.Y. Gregory, president of the National Industrial Sand Association, asserted yesterday in a special statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The second of the two companies that will give opera during the summer at Carnegie Hall opened there last night. It was Alfredo Salmaggi's Popular Price Grand Opera Company, which crossed the river from Brooklyn to give opera in Manhattan for the first time in four years.

Frazer A. Bailey, president of the National Federation of American Shipping, has been elected to membership in the general council of the International Shipping Federation, it was disclosed last week. Maitland S. Pennington, former NFAS vice president, was elected to a similar post with the ISF.

Retail trade here continued active last week, with the percentage of gain over last year wider than in the preceding week. Department store volume was estimated as showing an increase of 12 per cent over 1946.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am inserting your editorial of June 14, entitled "The Territory of Guam," into the Congressional Record in the hope that it will thereby come to the attention of the members of Congress and the public who do not have access to THE TIMES or who, if they do have access to THE TIMES, may have overlooked it.

EVANSVILLE, IND. BECAUSE it was the last day of school the men folk of our Third Grade put on their Sunday pants. Little girls contrived ringlets arranged in the formal manner. Not to be outdone, I fastened a rose to the front of me with a paper clip, and declared all rules off.

IT was a Wednesday night at Hussey's Bar and Grill, over at Forty-seventh and Ninth. The well-worn rail was lined with many shoes, tapping expectantly, and the dark 40-foot bar seemed to sprout hands and glasses. Coco, the bartender, shuffled along the tile floor toward the back and clicked a few knobs on a large machine mounted on a wooden pedestal.

The invisible ray lamp which enables industry to transmit messages from point to point without the use of wires or visible signals are now available to plant engineers, Samuel G. Hibben, director of applied lighting, Westinghouse Lamp Division, Bloomfield, N.J., disclosed here yesterday.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 21 (AP) -- See-Tee-See and Artillery flashed under the wire in a dead heat, with the favored Honeymoon a close third, to break the track record and divide the purse in the $50,000 added Golden State Breeders' Handicap before 44,629 fans at Hollywood Park today.

IN this well-flavored book, his eighteenth, Fairfax Downey sets before his readers a dish comparable to a pot-pie he describes, which concealed under an inch-thick crust "a layer of ground ham and onions, * * *, one turkey, two chickens, two partridges, two pigeons and two rabbits," the whole washed down with a sizable river of assorted liquors.

IT is curious that an Anglo-Irish author of Joyce Cary's capabilities should have been largely overlooked in America. Since 1930 he has published eleven novels in England, though, besides "The Moonlight," only one, "The African Witch," has been brought out here.

Sentiment in the financial community improved considerably last week following a veto of the tax and labor bills, which had been discounted marketwise. The firm undertone, evident in steel and kindred stocks, lifted prices for the fifth consecutive week.
ST. LOUIS, June 21 -- Warnings of a third major flood came today as the rampaging Mississippi and Missouri rivers rolled into the fourth week of floodtide.

Of the 1,000 graduating classes that will receive diplomas from New York high schools this week, the smallest probably will be that of the New York State Reconstruction Home at West Haverstraw. It will also be one of the most unusual, for, garbed in cap and gown, its two members will be pushed forward in their wheelchairs to receive diplomas.

GOING to Mexico a quarter century ago for a brief visit, Miss Toor fell in love with the land and its people and stayed on to become better acquainted with their colorful folkways. She never seemed to be "working" at it; but on foot and horse and mule and burro, on bus and auto and train and plane, she has been wandering up and down the countryside collecting her treasures of folklore.

FRANKFORT on the Main, Germany, June 21 -- The assistance of the United Nations through the International Refugee Organization, an international loan and emigration are urged as solutions of the problem of 12,000,000 Germans expelled from the East in a report prepared by a committee of the Council of States of United States occupation zone.
PITTSBURGH, June 21 (AP) -- Emil (Dutch) Leonard, the American League cast-off, today stopped the Pittsburgh Pirates with eight hits as he won his eighth game of the season for Philadelphia, 5 to 1.

CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 300 heads: total 3,000 (estimated). Compared with week ago: all weights and sows steady. CATTLE
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- A ninth-inning pinch single by Sherry Robertson with the bases loaded turned the trick for Washington today and gave them a 5-4 victory over the St. Louis Browns.

Starting tomorrow morning the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's forty-fourth annual golf championship will get under way over the beautifully groomed Century Country Club course at Purchase, N.Y. It will continue through Saturday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Arthur L. Williston's attempt in the June 15 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES to rebut Hanson Baldwin's argument against universal military training begs the question of whether regimentation is a good thing in itself, carefully avoids discussing the military merits of the matter, and finally contradicts itself as to the financial basis of military policy.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 -- Creation of a World Affairs Council of Northern California, with forty-five civic leaders as trustees, to provide facts and appraisals concerning the world's economic, political and social problems and promote public education on world affairs, was announced today.
The newly-formed Fourth Armored Division Association completed yesterday its three-day organizational convention here.

BACK in the days when Lytton Strachey was making impious changes in the Victorian formula for biography, Harold Nicolson wrote an exceedingly interesting little book called "The Development of English Biography," in which he traced the fluctuating course of that literary form from its beginnings, and hazarded a guess or two regarding its immediate future.

ROWING Navy won the intercollegiate championship in the three-mile varsity race as the Poughkeepsie regatta was renewed yesterday for the first time since 1941. Cornell was second, less than half a length behind, and Washington third.

NEW DELHI (By Wireless). LOIUIS FRANCIS ALBERT VICTOR NICHOLAS ISCOUNT MOUNTBATTEN of Burma, at present serving as India's last Viceroy, belongs to the relatively small class of people for whom the good fairies appear to throwall niggardliness to the winds.

PARIS, June 21 -- The Tass statement yesterday on the British and French notes, indicating Moscow would not be hurried into either acceptance or refusal of the two Western powers' proposal for a three-nation discussion of the Marshall plan, caused more disappointment than surprise in official circles here today.
A new cargo handling system that moves goods on pallets along pier tracks to similar tracks aboard ship attracted attention among shipping men in demonstrations here last week.

For the first time in six years the General Conference of Christian Workers will be held on the campus of the Northfield School for Girls, East Northfield, Mass. The conference will open Aug. 2 and continue through Aug. 11. Clergymen of international reputation will deliver series of sermons.

The college graduates of 1947 are the best equipped in American history because of the presence of veterans on the nation's campuses, it was said yesterday by Dr. Harry J. Carman, Dean of Columbia College.
PHILADELPHIA, June 21 (AP) -- A four-run explosion in the eleventh inning broke up a defensive battle and gave the White Sox a 6 -- 2 decision over the Athletics today.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Lee Pressman, general counsel of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, denounced tonight the TaftHartley labor bill as a conglomeration of "legal barriers" against the unions that "reflects the bias and animosity of the few employers who have never yielded in their determination to destroy labor unions."
WASHINGTON. "CAPITAL FEVER" -- a strange malady that impels many former political figures to haunt Washington after they have retired or been retired from public life -- seems to be spreading.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The President likes, in his crisp, chipper way, to tell visitors who inquire about his health that he is feeling fine. "I haven't had a crisis in twenty-four hours," he is likely to remark.

WHAT is there in this Rocky Mountain land that it should grip men's hearts and make them so steadfastly cherish it? In partial answer, the editors offer three hundred praiseworthy pages of tales, yarns, legends and accounts of ways of living.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- President Truman went on temporary leave today from the repercussions of his veto of the TaftHartley Labor Bill by taking his family and White House staff to the American League baseball game at Griffith Stadium.

FRANKLIN SQUARE, L.I., June 21 -- Called the world's first "financial department store," the newly enlarged Franklin Square National Bank, here, will be opened to the public Monday morning. Formal dedication of the new fourstory structure built onto the original bank will take place after banking hours Friday night.

THE ranch-type home shown above, purchased for immediate occupancy by James M. McHugh of Flushing, Queens, is typical of the houses in New Hyde Park Manor at New Hyde Park, L.I. Designed by Rudolph A. Matern, architect, the houses are built by Joseph Mascioli.
SALT LAKE CITY, June 21 -- Herb McKenley, sprint star of Illinois' defending champions, bettered the accepted world record tonight for the 440-yard dash in the twenty-sixth National Collegi-
CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- Boston's Johnny Sain hurled a seven-hit, 5to-1 victory over the Cubs today, enabling the Braved to cling to their slender lead in the snarled National League pennant race.

IS there a place for religion in the public schools of this country? Many Americans, particularly church leaders, believe that there is. Others are just as certain that there should not be any teaching of religion in the public schools, and that such teaching constitutes a dangerous encroachment on individual rights and on the democratic tradition of this country.

IT'S probably just as well for Frank Shea that Paul Krichell, the demon Yankee scout, is a persistent sort of person. Otherwise the citizens of Naugatuck would not be trooping en masse to the Stadium this afternoon to pay special tribute to their illustrious townsman. It's a bit out of the ordinary anyway for a rookie to have a "day" set aside for him.

EXPERIENCED parents may skip this. It is about the routine instructions, the telephone numbers, et al., left for the "sitter" who stays with the children. Judging by recently published hints on the subject, every parent does not know the score.

BATAVIA, Java, June 21 (AP) -- The Dutch took steps today to force a decisive political showdown with the Indonesians after a twoyear stalemate, demanding specific assurances from the Indonesian Republic that it accepts, completely, all the Netherlands proposals for an Interim National Government.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., June 21 -- Benjamin Siegel, 42 years old, former New York gangster, was slain last midnight by a fusillade of bullets fired through the living room window of a Beverly Hills house where he was staying.

TO THE EDITOR: Adelheid Wawerka's article, "Hunger -- Scourge of Millions," however good her intentions may be, deserves refutation on at least one issue. The author initiates a comparison of Vienna's "semistarvation" to the sufferings of the forced laborers and concentration camp inmates of Hitler's Germany.

PRINCE RUPERT, B.C., June 21 -- Northwestern Canada, with its vast expanses of uninhabited land, is actively urging that Europe's displaced people be allowed to migrate to this country. Fears expressed in some parts of Canada over the admission of European refugees have had few echoes in British Columbia.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 21. -- In a finish identical with 1931, Navy, the only Eastern varsity winner since that same year, fought off the terrific challenge of Cornell and slammed through in front of a record field in the Poughkeepsie Regatta today.

ST. LOUIS, June 21 -- The Cardinal steamroller, it seems, has just begun to roll. It was going in high gear today as the Redbirds flattened Mel Ott's Giants for their second straight victory of the series, 11 to 5. The triumph over the outfit that earlier in the year had tripped them six straight times, was rather easy.

CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- Wheat advanced today under persistent buying attributed mainly to cash houses on the Board of Trade. Feed grains were firm with the exception of July corn, which retreated under profit-taking.

RECITALS in the straw-hat theatres are the latest development in the ever-increasing field of summer music. Just how many of the rural playhouses will feature concerts is not certain, but there will be one for sure, the Hunterdon Hills Playhouse at Jutland, N.J.

TO THE EDITOR: Inspired by the analyses of character by "doodles experts" in Charlotte Kamp's recent article, "Doodles Are 'SelfPortraits,' " I set about to analyze the doodles of a few notables myself.

The National Inventors Council has released a list of twenty-five inventions wanted by the Army, Navy and Coast Guard. Here is the list: (1) Soil-Solidifying Method -- An emergency stabilization of soils, good for only a short time, must provide surfaces of great load-bearing capacity to greater depths (two to four feet) than has previously been practical.

The question whether Russia will cooperate in a unified program to rehabilitate Europe's wrecked and stagnant economy cannot be decisively answered by news that Moscow is considering the matter or even that she has agreed to a conference with the Foreign Ministers of Britain and France.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The President having exercised his veto prerogative on the more important half of the major legislation passed at this session of Congress -- and expanded it historically in disapproving the tax reduction bill -- the interparty, intra-party and executive-legislative split has come that otherwise would have been deferred until early in the Presidential election year of 1948. Even then it would not have come with such depth and violence.

CARNEGIE TECH -- Veterans' Survey More than 90 per cent of the students of the Carnegie Institute of Technology whose education was interrupted by service in the armed forces will have returned to complete their college courses by next September. The classes entering in the fall will include less than thirty such students, indicating that practically all former students have returned to the campus who will do so.

BUDAPEST, June 21 (U.P.) -- The White Paper said that Milos Jarmay, police officer and bodyguard of Mr. Kovacs, former secretary of the Small Landholders and now in a Russian Army prison, had declared : "I worked for British officers, Captain Clark and Colonel Hanley, and supplied them with documents and details concerning the police organization in Budapest and in the provinces, and told them the political allegiance of various police officers."

SHOULD Dashiell Hammett's "Fat Man" ever be tagged for an appearance before the television cameras, J. Scott Smart, who portrays that rotund sleuth for the microphone, still figures to be sure of his job. Unlike many radio actors who do not look their parts, Mr. Smart lends fidelity to his characterization with 265 pounds, twenty-eight more than the recorded heft of the private detective he inspirits.

LONDON, June 21 -- British India was one thing and its fate, in theory at least, has been settled. But this week, India and the world have been made to realize that there is such a thing as "Indian India" or the Princely States. There are 562 of them; they cover over two-fifths of that subcontinent with a population of nearly 100 millions out of India's 400 million inhabitants.

LONDON, June 21 (U.P.) -- Harry Pollitt, secretary general and founder of the British Communist party, disclosed today that United States authorities had refused to let him enter the United States to attend the Communist party's convention there July 4.

PANAMA CITY, Panama -- Some people claim to have driven from Costa Rica to Panama. This reporter, obedient to the best available advice, drove his jeep to Puntarenas, on Costa Rica's Pacific Coast, hoisted it aboard a Grace Line steamer and shipped it to Panama.

DETROIT, June 21 -- Lew Worsham, the new national open champion, moved one notch nearer to "double" today when he trounced Reggie Myles, middle-aged profrom East Lansing, Mich., to gain one of the eight places in tomorrow's quarter-final round of the P.G.A. championship.

FLOWERING shrubs and vines whose bloom is now past can be pruned at this time. Many popular plants are included -- the forsythias, honeysuckles and flowering quince that blossomed early in spring, climbing and rambling roses as soon as they fade, wistarias that have failed to produce any display this year, and many others.
HELSINKI, June 21 -- All Finish radio stations interrupted their broadcasts today to announce the International Olympic Committees' award of the 1952 games to Helsinki.

Four Flatbush high schools -- Erasmus Hall, James Madison, Samuel J. Tilden and Midwood -- have started a drive for erection of a modern stadium on the Paerdegat Woods tract provided the city includes this thirty-one acres in the Vandeveer Park section if and when it takes over the Flatbush system of the New York Water Service Corporation, on July 1.

SHOULD a chronicler comb the archives, sifting every threeact rumpus loosed hereabouts since "Chris and the Wonderful Lamp," it is doubtful that he could find a more fertile incubator of talent than "Dulcy," a comedy that flourished at the Frazee Theatre for thirty weeks in the 1921-1922 season.

TOKYO. MORE Japanese worry about the four-letter word l-o-v-e than about the housing shortage or the sharing price of rice. Love, a constant topic of conversation, is the Japanese motion picture industry's biggest competitor.

HERE is a "Thesaurus of Scales," by Nicolas Slonimsky (Coleman-Ross Company, Inc., New York City), a modern spirited musician, with an extremely sensitive ear, a damnably active mind, and a soul with a passion for exploration and classification.

WHEN, several years ago, Graham Greene's "The Labyrinthine Ways" was published in this country, the bulk of the Catholic press lambasted Greene as a traducer of the Church, largely because the at first pitiful and then increasingly heroic protagonist of the novel was a corrupt priest.

Senor Peron's Country It must be regretfully admitted that we in the United States are not as well acquainted with the main facts of South American history as we might be. When it comes to the specific item of South American liberators there is just one name that will be generally recognized.
STANTON, Del., June 21 (AP) -- Walter P. Chrysler Jr's Brabancon and Jockey Charlie Givens of Wilmington shared the spotlight at Delaware Park today.

THE flat suburban vastness of Brooklyn and/or Queens, as viewed from a commuter's trestle, would seem the last spot on this planet capable of inspiring optimism. We have Thomas Wolfe's word for it that only the dead know Bensonhurst thoroughly; Thomas Bell visited Flatbush a few years ago, and yearned for demolition bombs.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- Members of the House Armed Services Committee said today that an all-out drive for a bill to cash veterans' terminal leave bonds probably will sidetrack universal military training legislation until next year.

ACCORDING to persons who make a business of keeping track of such things, some 184,000 school-age children will leave New York City to spend at least part of the current vacation season in summer camps.
