This total, if concentrated in one spot at one time, would constitute a city of children more than double the size of Little Rock, Ark. -- a prospect likely to dismay even the most resourceful camp counselor.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 21 -- The heads of state of the United States, Britain, France and China will broadcast Thursday in the highlight of the celebration of the second anniversary of the signing of the United Nations Charter, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Heavy pressure was concentrated today on a handful of Senators who hold the fate of the Taft-Hartley bill.

Ordinarily when an organization runs a baby contest and decides to give away a prize for "the cryingest baby," the judges have difficulty in choosing the baby that did the most crying. Yesterday, things were a bit different in the Chinese Baby Contest run by the Chinese Community Club in Columbus Park, at Mulberry and Park Streets.

HOLLYWOOD. AS an ace photographer, A.L. "Whitey" Schafer's outstanding claim to public notice is his use of "canned sex" grease on the bare shoulders of Hollywood's beauties to make their publicity pictures more alluring.

HOW can anyone figure out but what to give the bride and groom? Close friends and relatives may venture direct inquiries. But most couples would hesitate to give a more specific answer than "something for the mantel," or "we can always use glasses."

LISTED as a "water-color festival," the current exhibition at the Mortimer Levitt Gallery is nevertheless dominated by Charles Umlauf's powerful and profoundly moving bronze "Pieta," a detail of which we reproduce.

SONORA, CALIF. THIS little northern California community, nestled deep in the towering, snowcapped High Sierras, is presently playing host to its 200th motion-picture location company in thirty-five years.

Spurred by the threat of loss of a lucrative market to the electric light and power industry, the gas industry last week intensified its drive to corner the lion's share of the rapidly developing field of year-round air-conditioning of virtually every type of dwelling.

THE latest symphonies of Igor Stravinsky and Dimitri Shostakovich are at hand. Both are played by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, with Mr. Stravinsky conducting his own Symphony in Three Movements (three twelveinch records) and Efrem Kurtz conducting Shostakovich's Ninth Symphony (four twelve-inch disks).

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The filibuster of a little band of irreconcilables collapsed in hoarse weariness today and the Senate agreed at last to vote at 3 P.M. Monday, Eastern daylight time, on President Truman's veto of the Taft-Hartley Labor Bill.

Charging that proponents of the Taft-Hartley labor bill have deceived the American people, Louis Hollander, president of the New York State Congress of Industrial Organizations, yesterday challenged sponsors of the measure to leave the issue to the decision of the American people in the 1948 election.

THERE were signs last week that the Habimah Players would be coming here from Palestine next winter. The man in the crow's nest could not be positive, he said, but he did know that conversations were under way.

CRESTLINE, Calif. -- Visitors to southern California who plan escape from warm weather should not forget the chain of man-made lakes in the San Bernardino Mountains, particularly Lake Gregory, the newest and nearest in the group to Los Angeles.
Back at Aqueduct, the track where he won his first race in 1945, Assault yesterday scored the victory that ended Whirlaway's five-year reign as the world's No. 1 money-winning thoroughbred.

FOR THIS WEEK: Rain makes weeds grow, often so thick it is hard to find rows of seedlings. Loosen or remove the weeds by cultivating with the most convenient tool.... Order seeds of foxgloves, sweet william, English daisies and other biennials for prompt sowing and consequently flowers next year.... Cut off the faded blossoms from pyrethrum, peonies, lilacs and rhododendron.
DETROIT, June 21 (AP) -- Most 1948 model automobiles still are six months away, but guessing regarding their features already is well under way.

Confidence that Regulation W for the control of consumer credit is on the way out and may disappear by the end of this month or at the end of July at the latest was expressed here yesterday in credit circles.

In three world capitals -- Paris, Moscow and Washington -- one topic of immense international significance held the spotlight last week. That topic was the "Marshall plan" for the economic rehabilitation of war-racked and divided Europe. Outlined by the Secretary of State in his historic Harward speech of June 5, it is based on the premise that American aid is essential to avert a European disaster and that piecemeal methods will be of no avail.

OTTAWA, June 21 -- For the third time since the Canadian confederation was formed eighty years ago, discussion will begin here next week as to whether and on what terms Newfoundland should be included in Canada.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., June 21 -- After 250 years in desks and safe deposit boxes as the possession of one family, the historic royal charter creating the 87,000acre Manor of Cortlandt will be displayed publicly for the first time on July 4 at the anniversary celebration here of the Philipse Castle Restoration, it was learned today.

The world is neurotic and will survive only if it applies the methods of experimental science to its problems and also sets its capacity for love against its destructiveness. James Marshall, member of the Board of Education, declared last night at the ninety-sixth commencement of Hunter College.

CLEVELAND, June 21 -- Hershel V. Johnson, deputy United States Representative in the United Nations Security Council, declared today that there was little in the present world situation to justify optimism about the possibility of averting another war.

TOKYO, June 21 -- Fifteen billion yen in shares of Japan's leading corporations will start moving into the hands of the public within four weeks. They will be not only shares in the great family holding companies, seized by the Government, but also shares delivered to tax officials who collected the capital levy early this year.
A mysterious movement of thousands of food parcels from the Mediterranean area to the United States has been in progress for months, it became known yesterday.

Joseph Winiewicz, Polish Ambassador to the United States, expressed the fear last night that Jews now settled peaceably in Silesia and the western provinces of Poland may be compelled to leave if the three great powers question the country's right to the territories along the Oder and Neisse Rivers promised under the Potsdam agreement.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 21 -- The Orienta Yacht Club was host for the tenth championship regatta of the season today, and bright weather brought out 133 craft, the largest fleet of the spring. The breeze was light, fading to a whisper in the middle of the racing, then perking up.

CLIFTON Fadiman once said that book reviewing serves the public as "a mildly useful sieve." If the figure of the sieve implies letting the good books through to the deserving reader and trapping the bad ones, it is hardly any great insult to the reviewer's craft. But the acerb Mr. Fadiman, as Francis Hackett points out in his "On Judging Books," goes on to twit the professional reviewer with failure to be "a whole man."

THE British have always been indefatigable travelers, for pleasure and profit. Sometimes the result has been exasperating to their hosts, for the Englishman is usually a discerning critic of what he sees and is at no pains to be reticent when he takes a dim view of things seen.
NANKING, June 21 (AP) -- Chinese Communists had Szepingkai almost in their grasp today, thereby raising a new peril for Manchuria's capital of Changchun and its United States trained New First Army.

MONTEREY, Mass. -- The 305 inhabitants of this South Berkshire upland town are getting ready for a bangup Fourth of July. Monterey is 100 years old this year and Independence Day will mark the beginning of the three-day centennial observance.

Old-time pricing traditions are being thrown out on a nation-wide basis by most of the largest manufacturers and distributors of castiron pipe fittings, brass and iron valves and brass plumbing fittings, distributors disclosed here yesterday.

FIFTEEN years ago in this Review: It was the last lingering months of the Hoover regime and James M. Beck, whose book on Washington "Our Wonderland of Bureaucracy" was reviewed on the front page, sang no exultets at the sprawling growth of the Federal Government.

The legend is that if the Yankees ever let Dizzy Trout get out in front, they never can overhaul him. But, with a club leading the league in team hitting, total hits, two-base hits, home runs, runs batted in and complete games pitched, the record sometimes goes out the window.
DARIEN, Conn., June 21 -- Golden Hill, owned by Mr. and Mrs. J. A. Hale of Greenwich, scored today at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club fixture.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 21 -- Today's revived Poughkeepsie races could almost be called the regatta that nobody saw. Precious few aboard following launches and in the air saw it in its entirety and even they weren't always in the best positions.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 -- West Coast ship operators and seafaring unions reached agreement today on four one-year contracts based on the same 5 per cent wage increase and nine paid holidays granted to Atlantic Coast unions to end the nation's shipping tie-up.
Nearly 500 realty men, delegates and guests are due to attend the forty-third annual convention of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards, opening on Wednesday at Saranac Inn, N.Y.

STOKE-ON-TRENT, England, June 21 -- The British pottery industry, one of the great traditional and specialized trades of this country, is flourishing and it has a very promising future. To say this of a British industry in the present period of crisis and economic strain is news.

USING a practical demonstration of how modern science has conquered time and space to illustrate the topic under discussion, the July 3 program of Town Meeting of the Air (ABC-WJZ, Thursday, 8:30 P.M.) will present two sets of speakers 3,000 miles apart in a perusal of the proposition "Has Twentieth Century Civilization Improved Mankind?"

One hundred and eighteen German scientists and technicians and their 240 dependents, gathered up in the Reich after the war in "Operation Paperclip," have formed a miniature "Peenemuende," a visit to the outskirts of El Paso, Tex., reveals.

BAR HARBOR, Me., June 21 -- Mary Roberts Rinehart, whose mystery novels have entertained two generations of readers, was the principal character in a reallife thriller today when her Filipino cook was alleged to have tried to shoot and stab her.

BAR HARBOR, Me., June 22 (AP) -- Blas Reyes, 65, Filipino chef who allegedly menaced the mystery novelist, Mary Roberts Rinehart, yesterday with pistol and knife, hanged himself today in a lockup cell with a noose fashioned from clothing, Police Chief George E. Abbott said.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., June 22 -- The Jewish Child Care Association's 125th anniversary celebration literally opened with a splash today at its Pleasantville Cottage School as the new outdoor pool was dedicated. Nearly 100 of the 250 youngsters at the school plunged into the clear water.

STONINGTON ISLAND, Palmer Land, Antarctica, June 19 (Delayed) -- The British and American expeditions now in this area of Antarctica have decided to cooperate to the full in the geographical field. This was agreed today betweeen myself and Maj. K.S. Pierce-Butler, leader of Base E of the British Falkland Island Dependencies Survey, after weeks of detailed discussion and planning.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Browns battered five Washington pitchers for eleven hits to win the second game of a doubleheader, 9 -- 6, today, snapping an eight-game losing streak. The Senators won the first contest, 3 -- 2, before a crowd of 21,863.

The War Department has begun its task of establishing a final resting place for each of our 275,000 overseas war dead. At the present time they are buried in more than three hundred temporary military cemeteries in almost every part of the world. The task of the Graves Registration Service in establishing this first interment has been a difficult one.

Though some of the Hungarian pastries featured at Liehtman's Bakery, 561 Amsterdam Avenue, may be quite unfamiliar, there is no mystery about how they are made, for customers may watch the bakers working at the cleanscrubbed mixing tables and huge ovens in the rear of the shop.

THERE are some athletes so richly endowed with natural talent that they prefer to let nature take its course. They won't work hard to improve themselves and therefore they never achieve the success destiny offered them. True stardom comes only to the few who labor diligently to fan the spark of greatness to a roaring flame.

A bill now in the South African Parliament, which will create the South African Tourist Corporation, which in turn will determine the amount of money to be spent on tourist advertising abroad is expected to be enacted shortly, it was revealed over the week-end by V. Pistorius of the South African Government Information Bureau in New York.

Higher production costs and prospects of a shift from a seller's to a buyer's market are causing management to consider industrial standardization as a means of turning out a quality product at the lowest price compatible with satisfactory performance, according to a survey released over the week-end by the National Industrial Conference Board.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Greek General Security authorities early in April arrested and exiled 571 Greek citizens, among them three lawyers of the Supreme Court and the Council of State, it is alleged in a letter given to THE NEW YORK TIMES today.
Girls, school teachers and ambition are causes of juvenile delinquency according to eight boys at Youth House, the New York detention home. They took part in a discussion yesterday over WQXK.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Former Premier Nagy of Hungary today termed charges made against him by Communists "absurd" and said they had thrown him out of office apparently for "conspiring to establish friendly relations with the United States.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 22 -- Gustavus Town Kirby, one of Westchester County's oldest officials in birthdays but one of the youngest in ideas, took a look into the future today and saw a vastly increased commuter population served by swift and comfortable buses connecting with improved subways at a "dream plan" terminal in the Bronx.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : In connection with the argument over the ownership of Belize, in British Honduras, I wish to submit the following views sent to me by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Guatemala for publication in THE NEW YORK TIMES : "Guatemala has faith in its rights and in the justice of its endeavors to reincorporate the territory of Belize into the national domain.
CAMBRIDGE, Neb., June 22 -- A flash flood at dawn left eleven persons dead and four missing here today as torrential rains and tornadoes swept central and southwest Nebraska.

CLEVELAND, June 22 -- Manufacturers in the country's $1,000,000,000 -a-year dress industry were urged today to cooperate in the development of a union-management program to expand the market for American dresses abroad.

CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- The Braves retained their leadership in the National League race today by defeating the Cubs, 8 to 7, in a wild eleven-inning contest before 38,438. Dick Culler singled to drive Phil Masi across with the winning run off Johnny Schmitz.

Quite a chore confronts Canada Lee and Philip Huston. Both are to produce and act the leads in "Painted Wagon," a collaboration by Mr. Huston and Elizabeth Goodyear. Mr. Huston says $28,000 is in hand toward the production cost of $65,000, an indication, he thinks, that rehearsals aren't too far off.

The first contribution of the present writer to this space appeared on Nov. 11, 1946, which was six days after the Congressional elections. That event had been, in at least one major respect, totally unprecedented in American politics.

To the sad melodies of Finnish folk songs and with stamping of young boys and girls in old dances, the Finnish population of New York yesterday afternoon celebrated the pagan Festival of Light on the mall in Central Park.
Opposition to a proposed ban by the Board of Higher Education on student organizations deemed subversive was expressed from two sources yesterday, with the National Lawyers Guild taking the lead.

Structural steel interests in New York have offered to form a committee to confer with city authorities to accelerate New York building. Their program envisages methods that would reduce costs as much as 25 per cent and might release large-scale new projects for immediate action.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 -- A vigorous campaign to help the independent retail grocer "meet any competition which may be offered him," including that of prices, will be pursued during' the rest of 1947 and the first half of next year, it was announced today by Patsy D'Agostino of New York, president of the National Association of Retail Grocers.

Today at 3 P.M. the fate of the Taft-Hartley Labor Bill will be decided. At that hour the Senate, by agreement, will vote either to override the President's veto or sustain it. If the veto is overridden the bill will be automatically entered on the statute books and become the law of the land.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 22 -- The gay red Doberman Pinscher, champion Duvetyn of Stone Croft, owned by F.F.H. Fleitmann of Far Hills, N.J., got best in show at the eighth exhibition of the Kennel Club of Northern New Jersey today.

DARIEN, Conn., June 22 -- Golden Hill, chestnut gelding owned by Mr. and Mrs. J.A. Hale of Greenwich, Conn., garnered 19 1/2 points in the two day Ox Ridge Horse Show here to win the conformation hunter championship. He repeated his performance last week-end in the Greenwich Horse Show when he took ribbons tallying 33 points.

Displaced persons in Europe who may be admitted to the United States must be trained so that they will fit into the economic structure on their arrival, Ilja Dijour, former director of the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society in the occupied zones in Germany and Austria, said yesterday.

LONDON, June 22 -- The heavy fall in the price of rubber since complete removal of control of prices continues to attract attention and discussion here. Fuel has been added to the fire of resentment Continued on Page 28, Column 4

A resolution urging Congress to pass the Stratton bill to admit 400,000 displaced persons to the United States is expected to create controversy in the fifty-sixth annual convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs which opens today.

A 102-foot sight-seeing vessel ran aground at 4:45 P.M. yesterday in Spuyten Duyvil Creek, near the entrance to the Hudson River, and was refloated three hours later after 100 of her 271 passengers had been taken off by the fireboat Cornelius W. Lawrence.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- President Truman created today a special nonpartisan committee of nineteen domestic leaders, to be headed by the Secretary of Commerce, to determine the capabilities of this country to assist foreign lands.
Conflicting opinions on whether Federal aid to schools throughout the country would mean Federal control of education were presented yesterday in a radio debate over the Columbia network.

Despite the lateness of the season, new art exhibitions continue to be launched. The Wildenstein Galleries are opening a summer show of work by some of the most widely known French and American painters of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The text of President Truman's statement today announcing the creation of three committees to study the relationship of this country's foreign aid program to the domestic economy: The impact upon our domestic economy of the assistance we are now furnishing or may furnish to foreign countries is a matter of grave concern to every American.

About two-thirds of the number of collections paid by Latin-American countries through twelve reporting New York City banks in May were "prompt," according to a monthly survey just inaugurated by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Forty-nine persons were injured at 8:05 o'clock last night when a double-deck bus of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company with seventy-nine passengers on board skidded as the result of a tire blowing out and struck a girder on the Manhattan-bound roadway of the Queensboro Bridge.
LONDON, June 22 -- Europe's foreign trade, both export and import, is marking time, awaiting definite developments on the Marshall proposal for rehabilitation of Continental Europe.

New York Catholics were requested yesterday to join in prayers for world peace to mark the closing of the International Marian Congress in Ottawa. The plea was made by Msgr. John S. Middleton, secretary for education of the New York archdiocese, in a sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Fondly fingering his "lucky" red scarf, Capt. Michael Graham, young British airman who survived ten air mishaps in the war, stepped jauntily from a Pan American World Airways clipper plane yesterday and told of his latest narrow escape.

Donald Budge came back from the rout of last year's final to prove that he still ranks among the great tennis players of the world, even though the national professional championship again went to Robert L. Riggs.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- With the Labor Bill out of the way tomorrow -- it will either be killed or become law when the Senate votes at 3 P.M. -- Congress will turn immediately to a number of important measures on which leaders hope to complete action before the proposed adjournment date, now just five weeks away.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 22 (AP) Jersey City climbed into second place above their victims by sweeping a double-header from the slumping Syracuse Chiefs today, 6 to 1 and 9 to 6. A crowd of 10,811 watched the home club drop the pair.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 22 -- Ewell Blackwell, brilliant young right-hander, came within an eyelash of joining Johnny Vander Meer in that lonely double-no-hit Hall of Fame niche as the Dodgers and Reds split a double-header here today before 31,204 cash customers, and the Brooks dropped into third place.
DETROIT, June 22 -- Two more high and mighties of the golf world trod down the well-worn path leading to the exit gates of the Plum Hollow Golf Club today.

NEW DELHI, India, June 22 -- What the peoples of the world -- and even of India -- don't realize is that India is about to become two nations, Mohammed Ali Jinnah, president of the Moslem League, said today in an interview.

Week Ended June 20, 1947 A number of significant fluctuations in the foreign exchanges made last week's market interesting because of the cross-currents which developed. The acute weakness of sterling "forwards" was one case in point, shared by a setback in the Canadian free dollar, while the Swiss free franc reversed the trend of the last fortnight and staged a brisk advance.

A million convention visitors, spending approximately $150 each, will bring $150,000,000 to New York City this year, according to a report prepared for today's meeting of the board of directors of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, Inc., at the Biltmore Hotel.
The 36,287-ton Holland-America liner Nieuw Amsterdam is scheduled to leave Rotterdam on Oct. 29 for her first post-war crossing to New York, it was announced here yesterday.

STOKE-ON-TRENT, England, June 22 -- The British potteries centered here are working far more for the United States than for Britain. Yet American housewives in New York, Boston, Chicago and elsewhere would be lucky to find any British tableware.

BERLIN, June 22 -- Scores of former Nazis in the bi-zonal government will be subject to mandatory removal when headquarters moves to Frankfort on the Main, and a head-on collision between United States and British denazification policies is believed inevitable.

The Association of Radio News Analysts, of which H.V. Kaltenborn is president, expressed opposition yesterday to the proposal that radio stations should be allowed to editorialize in their own name. The commentators, in effect, disagreed with the National Association of Broadcasters, which has been conducting a widespread campaign for the right of the station itself to editorialize in the same manner as a newspaper.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 -- Millions of dollars a year will be channeled into the West Coast economy through operation of the new luxury liners, President Cleveland and President Wilson, which are to be placed in service the latter part of the year, according to E. Russell Lutz, executive vice president of American President Lines.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 22 -- Following a delay of exactly one hour because of the lack of wind, the eleventh Yacht Racing Association regatta of the season, sponsored by Knickerbocker Yacht Club, started at 3:05 P.M. today with a new record entry of 143 craft.

BOSTON, June 22 (AP) -- Before the season's largest crowd at Fenway Park, 34,863 paid, the secondplace Red Sox and Cleveland today divided a double-header, the Indians taking the opener, 8 -- 2, behind the veteran Mel Harder and Boston winning the second contest, 6 -- 3, in back of rookie Harry (Fritz) Dorish.

JERUSALEM, June 22 -- After laboring through five long private meetings, the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine finally produced a resolution today expressing concern "as to the possible unfavorable repercussions" that might result from the hanging of three condemned Jewish terrorists awaiting execution in Acre Prison.

IONA ISLAND, N.Y., June 22. -- All efforts to petition Congress and the Navy Department to retain the 47-year-old Navy ammunition depot here failed with the announcement today by the commanding officer, Capt. William A. Gorry, that the depot was to be deactivated at once.

WARSAW, Poland, June 22 -- Angry outspoken attacks on British Foreign Secretary Bevin were made today by two Polish newspapers. Each voiced strong suspicion of Mr. Bevin's endeavors to induce the European countries to avail themselves of the opportunity offered by the Marshall plan.

DENVER, June 22 (AP) -- John Fiscalini's last-ditch single in the ninth inning, scoring Doug Clayton, gave California's Golden Bears an 8-7 decision over the Texas Longhorns in the final of the Western N.C.A.A. baseball play-offs today.

PARIS, June 22 -- A showdown on the French Government's emergency finance bill is in prospect when the Assembly meets in special session tomorrow to consider the measure, which was defeated in the Finance Committee yesterday.
TEXAS CITY, Tex., June 22 (AP) -- Two months after its disaster of chain-like explosions and fires, Texas City today buried its sixtythree unknown dead.

GENEVA, June 22 -- The imminent Anglo-Soviet trade deals may be expected to bolster the lagging Geneva trade talks by showing that the Russians are willing to enter into extensive trade relations with the West, according to opinion expressed here today.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 22 -- Laboratory success with a modified form of the new drug, gramicidin, in research work at the University of California Medical School led to the observation today in an announcement from the university that it "may be as important to surface medication as penicillin is to internal treatment."

And Men Change With Them Our city scout, prone to nostalgic retrospect, and particularly attentive to changes in the setting of the stage on which the drama of New York is played, tells us that he was sharply reminded this past week that it is not only the setting that changes but the cast of players.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 22 -- Albert Lewin, independent producer -director, has joined MetroGoldwyn-Mayer as a producer and story executive under a three-year contract. The agreement provides, however, that he may take a leave of absence next year to produce and direct his own screen story, "Pandora," in association with Charles K. Feldman's group productions.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (AP) -- Carl Scheib, the Athletics' 20-yearold pitcher, won his third successive start and gained his second shut-out today by defeating the White Sox. 3 to 0, in the second game of a double-header after the Mackmen had dropped the opener on an unearned run in the tenth inning, 1 to 0.

The oldest Protestant Episcopal Church in New York has sent a gift of $50,000 to what is considered the oldest ecclesiastical structure in London, to restore the edifice that was blitzed in World War II.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Senate tomorrow will seal the fate of the Taft-Hartley Labor Bill. There is every prospect that this most debated measure of the Eightieth Congress will become law over President Truman's veto.

MADISON, Wis., June 22 (AP) -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York, Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota and Gen. Douglas MacArthur rank, in that order, as the leading choices of Wisconsin Republican party workers for President, it was announced today.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., June 22 --The 11,000-ton tanker Markay, loaded with nearly 3,000,000 gallons of gasoline, exploded and burned at her dock in Los Angeles harbor at 2:05 A.M. (Pacific standard time) today. Several men were believed killed and adjacent shore installations worth upwards of $10,000,000 were destroyed.

Many buyers of ready-to-wear garments were in the market last week but a large number placed orders only according to what was actually needed for the fall. This was due, it was pointed out, to uncertainty as to what the situation would be in regard to a proper coordination between dress manufacturers and those making coats.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Prices of grains were on the upgrade last week on the Board of Trade, paced by the July delivery of corn, which developed congestion and advanced 11 1/2 cents a bushel from the finish of the previous week to a top of $2.00 3/4 the highest price on record for any future delivery of that grain.

There never has been a time when it was more important to raise the Cross of Christ than in Europe today, the Rt.Rev. John I. Blair Larned, Bishop in charge of the Convocation of the American Episcopal Churches in Europe, declared yesterday in a sermon at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue at Thirty-fifth Street.

AMSTERDAM, June 22 -- Prof. Gerard Verryn Stuart, manager of the Amsterdamsche Bank, said last week that although he was not afraid of sudden and wild inflation in the Netherlands, all efforts should be concentrated on preventing any further rise in the inflationary spiral.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read the article by Dr. Rusk on leprosy in THE NEW YORK TIMES for Sunday, May 18. I am especially interested in the following statement: "Apparently no action has been taken by the Surgeon General on these proposals, which recently were endorsed by the Committee on Public Health Relations of the New York Academy of Medicine."

CARLSTADT, N.J., June 22 -- Resuming where he left off six years ago, Freddie Jacoby Jr., veteran speed-boat pilot who at one time or other has won most every high point and professional championship in sight, today stole the show in his first outboard regatta since the war.

A survey designed to supply data to guide American Jewish community leaders and volunteer agencies in determining long-range financial and functional responsibilities for relief and rehabilitation of Jews overseas was announced yesterday by the Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds.

Brith Sholom, one of the oldest Jewish fraternal orders in the country, ended its forty-first annual convention yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker with the presenation of the Brith Sholom 1947 National Award to Sari G. Harrison, dean of the University of Pennsylvania Law School, in recognition of "his selfless devotion to the cause of humanity and his pursuit of justice for mankind."

MILWAUKEE, June 22 --The American Veterans Committee tonight started its second year of constitutional existence with a decisive disposal of the issue of Communist influence in its leadership and policy.

ATHENS, June 22 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Constantin Tsaldaris said today he had asked the Green consul in New York to cable him full details of reports published there that thousands of food packages had been shipped from Greece to the United States for "supposedly starving Americans."

YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo., June 22 -- Snow plows today inched along the earth's roof toward Beartooth Pass on the Montana-Wyoming border in the wake of blizzards which killed at least three persons, injured others and marooned many automobiles.

After moving steadily upward last week, prices of cotton in the domestic market turned moderately easier in the final trading session. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange at Friday's close showed for the week net gains of 64 to 130 points, compared with a net improvement the week previous of 15 to 67 points.

ZURICH, Switzerland, June 22 -- Restrictions on the export of Swiss watches to all countries in the dollar bloc, including presumably Argentina, are abolished as from July 1. This decision is the outcome of long negotiations among the National Bank of Switzerland, the Swiss Federal Council and key organizations in the Swiss watch industry.

The people and the Government of Poland desire a Europe free of economic and political divisions and cooperating closely with the United States and the Soviet Union, Dr. Oscar Lange, chief of the Polish Delegation to the United Nations, declared yesterday.

More than $1,280,000 worth of war surplus farm, construction and mining machinery is listed for a spot sale in the Capitol Hotel here on July 8, Carl P. Malmstrom regional director. War Assets Administration, revealed in a statement over the week-end.

When Mayor O'Dwyer's Administration came into office on Jan. 1, 1946, there were ninety-nine city departments with books that had not been audited beyond Dec. 1, 1939, Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday. Mr. Joseph said that he found thirty departments that had not been audited at all, but that fourteen of these had had complete audits of accounts as of May 28 this year.

ST. LOUIS, June 22 -- The Giants and Cardinals chose this, the longest day of the year, to battle eleven innings in bringing their series to a close, but so far as the Polo Grounders were concerned the effort paid off handsomely.

Aboard USS Power at Sea, June 22 -- Baruna, Henry C. Taylor's big black yawl which has given so good an account of herself in blue water racing since 1938, led the fleet of thirty-six yachts tonight as they passed a point some thirty-five miles east of Barnegrat Light.

LANGHORNE, Pa., June 22 (AP) -- Wild Bill Holland gunned his Peters Offenhauser around the one-mile Langhorne Speedway today in 1:08:23.59 to win the 100mile national championship big car auto race by two and a quarter laps before the largest crowd -- 52,000 -- ever to witness a race here.

The Police Department announced yesterday that it would begin a new Radio Emergency Patrol at 8 A.M. tomorrow with the prospect that the city's street patrol will be increased by 240 men daily if the experiment succeeds.

The factory division of Detecto Scales, Inc., Brooklyn, will shut down June 27 to give its 400 employes a two weeks vacation. The shipping departments will be fully manned, according to David S. Hammerman, executive vice president.

"Help!" Twice yesterday at the Stadium the cry for succor was heard by "Bucky's Brigadiers," the emergency mound corps of the Yankees. And twice the right man emerged from the distant bullpen to cut short a Detroit rally.

LONDON, June 22 -- The Financial Times' index of thirty industrial ordinary shares, based on July 1, 1935, as 100, was 136.6 at the close of last week, compared with 135.5 the week before, 134.2 a month ago and 127.0 a year ago. The high record is 140.6, made on Jan. 18 last.

Disturbed over the drastic reductions in the budget of the Maritime Commission by the House Appropriations Committee, local shipping men are hoping for more favorable action by the Senate, which is to hold a hearing on the commission's budget tomorrow.

LONDON, Monday, June 23 -- The Moscow radio said today the Soviet Union had agreed to attend a three-power Foreign Ministers' conference proposed by Great Britain and France to discuss United States Secretary of State Marshall's aid-to-Europe proposal.

BERLIN, June 22 --Taking note of the recent fears and accusations regarding Soviet policy in Europe, a Soviet writer warmly denied today any designs on any regimes in any other countries. This statement of policy was carried in a two-column, front-page editorial in The Taegliche Rundschau, official Soviet Army newspaper.
NANKING, June 22 (U.P.) -- Government dispatches from Mukden said today that counter-attacking Government forces had driven most of the Communists out of the hotly contested Szepingkai area.

ROME, June 22 -- Speaking in Naples today, Communist leader Palmiro Togliatti indirectly acknowleged the defeat the communists suffered yesterday when the Constituent Assembly voted its confidence in Premier Alcide de Gasperi's fourth government by a majority of forty-three.

Leading men's clothing manufacturers have cither sold up their output completely through November or December or can be counted upon to complete the process of selling up within the next few weeks, according to the "open letter" issued over the week-end by Jerome I. Udell of Max Udell Sons Co., Inc.

One hundred and one young men and women, the first graduating class of the School of Religious Education of Hebrew Union College, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street, received certificates yesterday at commencement exercises held in Beth-El Chapel of Temple EmanuEl, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

NANKING, June 22 -- Renewed clashes on the Sinkiang-Outer Mongolia border at Peitashan are reported in dispatches to the Government's Central News Agency received here last night and tonight from Urumchi.
OTTAWA, June 22 (AP) -- Approximately 250,000 Roman Catholics joined in special masses and other rites today at the closing of the Marian congress.

Pleas for passage of the WagnerEllender-Taft housing bill will feature programs throughout the country marking national "Fight for Housing Day" on Wednesday, according to an announcement yesterday by the Citizens Housing Council of New York, which will lead the local movement for enactment of the legislation.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $53,710,528,452. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

JERUSALEM, June 22 -- Within two blocks of the Y.M.C.A. where the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine was meeting today, the Jewish underground tried to kidnap a veteran British police officer from a bookshop. The would-be abductors lost their nerve and fled when the tough 50year-old Assistant Superintendent of Police, C.J.C. Pound, put up a fight and shouted for help.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Political analysts of the Republican and Democratic parties agreed today that President Truman had held the 15,000,000 votes of organized labor in line, but had lost a good deal of independent support in vetoing the tax reduction and labor bills.

The dispute between the Backers of the proposed Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass., widened yesterday as George Alpert, president of the board of directors, charged that two members of the board who announced their resignations on Saturday had tried to give the school a "radical, political orientation."

About $93,000 of city money, already spent or contracted for in connection with 1940 plans for a $3,600,000 central office building for the Board of Transportation in downtown Brooklyn, must be charged off to profit and loss, it was learned yesterday.

LORDSHIP, Conn., June 22 -- Richard Shaughnessy of Egypt, Mass., today became the first man to capture the all-bore championship twice as he took the event in a seven-man shoot-off that featured the fifteenth annual Great Eastern skeet shoot at the Remington Gun Club range here.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Senator Taft, addressing the nation by radio for the second time in three days, said tonight he had "no doubt whatever" that the Senate would pass the Taft-Hartley labor bill over President Truman's veto.

Only one upset was recorded and top seeded Don McNeill swept past three opponents as play continued in the Mew York State clay court tennis championships at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills, yesterday.

TENNENT, N.J., June 22 -- Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson drew a lesson today from the Battle of Monmouth, fought in 1778, to guide us in today's problems. The Will to peace, he warned, is not sufficient to avert war, and unless it is supported by ready military resources, it may provoke rather than avert war.

Henry A. Wallace, a bitter opponent of President Truman's foreign policies, indicated yesterday that he supported the plan of Secretary of State George C. Marshall for American aid to Europe on a continent-wide basis.

Some of the ironies of life in this post-war world are revealed in attempts now being made to decide the future of Newfoundland -- an Atlantic island a little smaller than the State of New York on which a population about equal to that of Rochester is trying to make a living.

ST. LOUIS, June 22 -- The Mississippi and Missouri Rivers continued to rise today toward new crests of the second major flood of the month while torrential rains in the watersheds built up the threat of a third flood.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 22 (AP) -- Illinois' decisive team victory for the second straight year and thrilling races by two great Negro speedsters which surpassed world's records highlighted today the first N.C.A.A. track and field meet ever held in the mountain section.

A Princeton senior who was studying for the Presbyterian ministry left the university's seminary in 1941 to join the Royal Canadian Air Force, mainly because he "resented ministers' being exempted from service."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 22 -- Officials in charge of the establishment of the International Refugee Organization, which is to take over the refugee work of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration oh July 1, have prepared plans to place the new agency in operation on an "I.O.U." basis, it was learned today.

PARIS, June 22 -- The Soviet Union is trying to raise its annual production of petroleum to 60,000,000 tons. This figure would probably make Russia the world's second largest oil producer, according to data received here.

PITTSBURGH, June 22 (AP) -- The battle of the last-placers -- the Phillies and Pirates -- wound up after seventeen long innings today with the Pirates more firmly entrenched in the National League cellar.

BOSTON, June 22 -- So great is world confusion that "liberty may pass from the face of the earth before any of you are as old as I am." Admiral Richard E. Byrd told 450 graduates of Northeastern University at the commencement exercises today.

LAKE BALATON, Hungary, June 22 (U.P.) -- President Zoltan Tildy dangled a fishing rod from the pier of his modest estate today and scoffed at reports that he had tried to resign when Premier Ferenc Nagy quit.

Ration banking, the system in which billions of ration coupons and stamps were handled for business men through special accounts in commercial banks, came to an end last week when the banks were ordered to terminate the acceptance of deposits of such items.

Sixty-five city school children, between 12 and 15 years old, spent yesterday getting readjusted to paved streets, apartment houses and life with mother and father. They were members of the group from Public School 147, Queens, and Junior High School 118, Manhattan, that spent three weeks in tepees, covered wagons and roundto's in the city's first public school experiment in camp education.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Efforts in this Congress to arrive at agreement on a Cabinet post of health, education and security, are accompanied by a move to round out Federal programs in those fields.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 22 -- Travel between the planets may well be possible "during our lifetime" through use of a rocket which has atomic power as its source of energy, Dr. Lyman Spitzer, Jr., associate professor at Yale, predicted tonight.

BLUFFTON, Ohio, June 22 -- Today was ingathering day in the "talent program started in the First Presbyterian Church here twenty weeks ago with the distribution of a $10 bill to each member of the congregation.

Despite recent weakness in the unofficial Canadian dollar rate, the development does not foreshadow a change in the official exchange rate, although there is the eventual possibility of restrictions on imports as a means of protecting Canada's dwindlin dollar reserves, according to a study just completed by the Bankers Trust Company.
ROME, June 22 -- Twenty-four persons were arrested in Rome and several more in Milan in the last twenty-four hours in the largest haul of neo-Fascists this year.

PITTSBURGH, June 22 -- The steel ingot rate edged off only slightly last week, order volume remained heavy and there was no evidence of a weakening in steel demand according to steel sources. Furthermore most steel officials were of the opinion that it would be months before there was any representative drop in steel activity.

GENEVA, June 22 (Reuters) -- British Commonwealth delegates attending the trade conference here have decided, it was learned tonight, to defer a statement on the United States bill increasing import duties on wool until President Truman decides whether to veto it.

Two bills of importance to the morale and efficiency of the services are now before Congress. These bills would establish a post-war system for the selection and promotion of Army and Navy officers. Both measures, incidentally, reflect the heartening progress of service cooperation, for the bills -- similar in their broad provisions -- obviously are the product of close inter service consultation.

NO matter how distinguished the family, be it Adamses or Hapsburgs, its history is rarely equivalent to the history of its country. Yet there is at least one family whose story is practically that, the story of a nation. The family, of course, is not just a family, but a clan, a large one divided into four sub clans. And whether a clan is really a family might be questioned by some people.
New Yorkers responded to the first day of summer yesterday by increasing their usual week-end migration to the mountains, the country and the seashore.

LAHORE, Punjab, India, June 22 (Reuters) -- Tonight, on the eve of the Punjab Assembly's verdict on partition, Lahore, capital city of nearly 1,000,000 people, was completely at a standstill after a week-end of rioting in which 250 houses were gutted and nine persons killed.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 23 -- In a drive to complete its threeweek session, a United Nations drafting committee today whipped through sixteen articles of a draft international bill of rights. Final vote on the draft and the drafting of a preamble tomorrow will wind up the committee's work.

TOKYO, June 23--Probably for the first time, a Japanese Premier, the Socialist Tetsu Katayama, today held a street-corner meeting to explain the policies of his newly formed Government. All passers-by who cared to could listen. Later the Premier faced questions and heckling from the crowd.

In a drive to lower consumer prices and move dormant merchandise, President Truman has been asked to set the week of July 14 as "National Surplus Week." The request was made in a telegram sent yesterday by Henry Modell, retail executive and president of the Smaller Business Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, Inc.

BOSTON, June 23 -- The "Dream City" which will house the United Nations in New York City was described today to about 750 delegates at the fortieth annual convention of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers by Glenn E. Bennett, executive officer of the United Nations planning office.

LONDON, June 23 -- Welcoming the Soviet Union's acceptance of an invitation to join Britain and France in talks on the Marshall proposals for aiding European recovery, Foreign Secretary Bevin told the House of Commons today that he would go to Paris this week and "try to get on with the job."

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 23 -- President Zoltan Tildy found it expedient a fortnight ago to deny a statement by former Premier Ferenc Nagy that the President was being forced by a threat of deportation to retain his office. He found it expedient today to give an interview to the Social Democratic newspaper Vilagossag criticizing Mr. Nagy as "powermad."

PARIS, June 23 -- France accepted today with "lively satisfaction" the Soviet Union's agreement to join Friday with Britain and France in a Foreign Ministers' conference on Secretary of State Marshall's proposal of United States aid for Europe.

The answer to the city's childcare program may be establishment of an additional "and substantial" agency to operate an institution for Protestant children on an interracial basis, coupled with a new foster-home program, Welfare Commissioner Edward E. Rhatigan suggested yesterday.

Immediate changes in policy which will speed up the machine tool surplus disposal program of the War Assets Administration were requested yesterday in a broad four-point recommendation for improvement of present methods sent to WAA Washington officials by Robert L. Giebel, New York machine tools distributor and member of the WAA industry advisory committee in this field.

WIMBLEDON, June 23 -- (AP) Law student Tom Brown, who was taking a final exam at the University of California only four days ago, squeaked through his opening-round singles match today to keep intact the seeded ranks of the Wimbledon tennis championships.

LONDON, June 23 -- It was some hours before the United States Justice Department filed suit today against the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, accusing it of taking part in an international cartel monopolizing musical performing rights, when ASCAP resigned from the International Confederation of Authors and Composers Societies.

Julius Lobel, alias Jimmy Collins, Broadway and Hollywood habitug, whose alleged share in the Mergenthaler Linotype Company swindle came to approximately a half million dollars, was sentenced yesterday in Kings County Court to twenty to forty years in Sing Sing.
PHILADELPHIA, June 23 (AP) -- Dorothy Shaver, the Arkansas girl who became a leader in department store merchandising and advertising, received $110,000 last year as president of Lord Taylor.
BERLIN, June 23 -- The bi-zonal civil service panel has disapproved of the rule adopted by the German bi-zonal communications committee banning the employment of former Nazis.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 23 -- Last year residents of this town were embroiled in controversy over the prospect of Greenwich becoming the headquarters for the United Nations. Today they were again choosing up sides, this time in "The Battle of the Comma."

MOSCOW, June 23 (AP) -- Authoritative foreign, informants expressed pleasure today over Russia's decision to join France and Britain in exploratory talks on the Marshall aid-to-Europe plan, but added that it did not signify eventual Soviet participation:

ATHENS, June 23 -- Minister of Coordination Stephanos Stephanopoulos said today the Greek Government was "seriously concerned" about reports from New York that vast amounts of foodstuffs of Greek origin had been sent to the United States.

The stock market broke through yesterday to further new high marks since April, having anticipated correctly the Senate temper on the labor bill in over-riding President Truman's veto of the legislation. The actual vote did not come until shortly after the close of trading, but there had been every indication that the TaftHartley bill would be accorded double confirmation.
MUNICH, Germany, June 23 -- Officials here requested the extradition of a War Department civilian employe from Switzerland today in connection with a gigantic swindle involving Government property.

Leonard Bernstein and William Kapell are two of the brightest young men in American music. Their collaboration last night attracted at audience of 10,000 to the Lewisohn Stadium for the first concert of the second week of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's summer season.

"MY real birth took place in Mexico, long before I was born," says Gilbert Neiman, author of "There Is a Tyrant in Every Country."* "It's been my home for 3,000 years. North Americans I don't understand. I act awkward around them. The most complex statement of the Mexican I can understand, the simplest statement of the North American confuses me completely."

American maritime wages are continuing to increase out of all proportion to those of foreign nations, the National Federation of American Shipping declared yesterday in its continuing survey of seagoing wages.

Store Sales Here Up 5% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 5 per cent over the like week of last year, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 23 -- The American Federation of Labor was urged today to call an emergency conference of the presidents of all affiliated unions and set in motion a campaign looking to the election in 1948 of "a Congress upon whom the people of this country can rely."

SPORTS books have been pouring off the presses in such a flood this spring that there is practically a literary log-jam. If fans remained at home to read them all in succession, there wouldn't be a turnstile moving for a solid week. It's much more enjoyable to take them one at a time. That eliminates the log-jam aspects.

Regular network television service between New York and Washington will be inaugurated on Friday when the National Broadcasting Company formally dedicates its new video outlet, WNBW, in the capital city. The Washington station will relay the programs originated by NEC's New York television affiliate, WNBT.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 23 -- Complete agreement on terms providing for elimination of the veto in day-to-day operations of the proposed international atomic control agency was reached here today by the Working Committee of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission.

Robert Moses, Construction Coordinator for New York City, will depart for Berlin tomorrow to spend one month at War Department invitation as a special economic adviser to Gen. Lucius D. Clay, American Military Governor in Germany, it was learned yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, June 23 -- Formality invades the fall collections of designers noted for their carefree clothes, and a citified appeal is practically universal. Shoulders still are padded, but without the exaggerations of the past. Padded hips are almost non-existent, but cuts and drapes often center interest here.

CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 8,500 head, total 10,000: market moderately active and uneven but generally steady to 25 cents lower on all weights and sows; top $25.25 sparingly but very little above

Pangs of conscience among those who have defrauded the city in one way or another have brought almost $2,000 into the city's "Conscience Fund" in the last two fiscal years, it was announced yesterday by Arthur A. Lynch, Deputy City Treasurer.

The black-bass season for the big majority of New York State fishermen is in the offing. It's exactly a week off, on July 1, to be specific, and a lot of anglers are looking forward to it as wholeheartedly as they did in April for the trout opening.
John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, presented scholarship awards yesterday to eighteen New York public school pupils at the Board of Education, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

Keeping pace with the victorious Red Sox, the Yankees counted four runs in the eighth inning and defeated the Indians, 8 -- 5, before 17,543 fans at the Stadium yesterday, thereby maintaining their twolength lead over the Red Sox. It was the fifth straight triumph for the New Yorkers, who were favored by sound relief pitching by Lefty Joe Page and solid, timely hitting by Yogi Berra and Tommy Henrich.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (U.P.) -- The Department of Commerce said tonight the United States will reimpose wartime controls on exports of petroleum products.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, June 23 (AP) -- Leaders of the American Newspaper Guild accused each other of attempting to gain control of the CIO union today as the dissension among Guild officers reached the floor in the first general session of the annual convention.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June (AP) -- The men who make equipment for railroads were told today at further research and development is called for by the demands of shippers and the traveling public.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 23 -- Clarence Streit, founder of the "Union Now" movement and editor of the magazine Federal Union, predicted tonight that the Soviet Union would engineer a Communist coup in Czechoslovakia within the next six months.

CLEVELAND, June 23 -- The world welterweight title he acquired last Dec. 20 by beating Tommy Bell in Madison Square Garden will be defended at the Arena here tomorrow night by Ray Robinson for the first time.

LONDON, June 23 -- Members of the National Union of Mine Workers were strike breakers today to maintain production in 270 Welsh mines hit by a jurisdictional dispute. Miners and coal weighers took over the duties of 4,000 members of the Clerical and Administrative Workers Union, who struck because of their failure to gain sufficient recognition for their union from the National Coal Board.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- President Truman now has a new labor law to administer which repeatedly he characterized as "unworkable" legislation that would "do serious harm to our country."

DETROIT, June 23 -- The golf ball is due for terrific punishment in the final round of the P.G.A. championship tomorrow when two of the siege gunners of modern times meet for the throne evacuated last Friday by Beltin Ben Hogan.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Representatives of the St. Louis Southwestern Railway Company (Cotton Belt) presented their case to Examiner H.C. Howard of the Interstate Commerce Commission today for the approval of extension of certain outstanding notes, representing the one step left for the discharge of the railroad from bankruptcy proceedings in the Federal District Court at St. Louis.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- A new radio communication system that can send 1,000,000 words a minute means many broadcasters will become "electronic" newspaper publishers, Niles Trammell, president of the National Broadcasting Company, said today.

A two-and-a-half-year agreement freezing wages and working conditions has been reached between the Heavy Construction Council, representing thousands of American Federation of Labor workers in New York State and New Jersey and the General Contractors Association, it was announced yesterday.

Last week the Metropolitan Museum opened a sculpture show made up of American work from its own collection and that of the now affiliated Whitney Museum. Yesterday the Brooklyn Museum performed a similar service, putting on a summer exhibition containing sculpture belonging to the permanent collection there.

The contest among city employes sponsored by the Citizens Budget Commission to produce suggestions for economy and greater efficiency takes on increased significance this year because of New York's financial condition. As Mayor O'Dwyer says, civil service employes in constant touch with the operation of municipal affairs are in a position to know the opportunities for savings without sacrifice of essential functions.

A model playroom that enables small fry to play with toys at convenient levels off the floor, climb or slide on a two-way staircase, and even hide in a "cave" was opened yesterday by the American Toy Institute at 200 Fifth Avenue. Special cabinets, tables and staircases have been designed by Joseph Aronson, who planned the indoor playground in an average room area of twelve by eighteen feet.

An issue of $15,000,000 of industrial debentures, and blocks of public utility and industrial stock having aggregate value of $10,448,407 will be placed on the market by underwriting managers here today as follows: National Supply Company -- $15,000,000 of twenty-year 2 3/4, per cent debentures, at 100 3/4% to yield about 2.70 per cent, by Goldman, Sachs Co. and Lehman Brothers.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Charges of violation of the Sherman Anti-trust Act in control of titanium compounds were upheld by the Supreme Court today against the E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., the National Lead Co., Inc., and the Titan Co., Inc.

Grim news from the outskirts of Yellowstone National Park, from the valley of the Republican River in Nebraska and from the banks of the Missouri and Mississippi as a new flood crest moves downstream reminds us tragically that this continent is not yet tamed.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The votes of Southern Democrats, which enabled the Republican majority in the Senate to override President Truman's veto of the Taft-Hartley Labor Bill served fresh notice today upon the Democratic National Committee that the Solid South insists upon a larger voice in party affairs.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- Productive efficiency in the field of agriculture must be increased if America is to continue using food as a weapon to sustain freedom and democracy in the world, Dr. Mark L. Nichols, president of the Society of Agricultural Engineers, said today.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 23 -- Possibilities of utilizing the United Nations in developing the Marshall aid-to-Europe plan were considered here tonight to have improved appreciably.
TRENTON, N.J., June 23 -- The New Jersey Senate probably will be recalled next Monday afternoon by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll to consider his nominations to several state positions.
CHICO, Calif., June 23 (U.P.) -- The Rev. Bernard Hubbard, the former "glacier priest" of Alaska mission fame, said today that Russia had an atomic energy plant a year ago but that it blew up.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 23 -- A champion is always tough to beat -- and two champions are better than one.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- President Truman sought today Congressional approval of nine conventions and four recommendations affecting maritime employment standards adopted by the twenty-eighth International Labor Conference.

LAHORE, Punjab, India, June 22 -- In surroundings that suggested war rather than peace, the Punjab Provincial Legislative Assembly this morning upheld the British proposal for the partition of the province. The Moslem majority areas will go to Pakistan and the non-Moslem eastern districts will go to Hindustan.

ST. LOUIS, June 23 -- The world that science gives us is one in which education plays an unprecedented part, Dr. Arthur H. Compton, Chancellor of Washington University, told the first general meeting of the thirty-eighth annual convention of the American Home Economics Association tonight.

Almost 20,000 members of six union locals from shipyards in the Port of New York halted work yesterday afternoon as a port-wide mass meeting was held here in connection with union demands for higher pay and improved working conditions.
NANKING, June 23 -- In a formal reply, which reached here today, Russia rejected the Chinese protest over the clash between Chinese and Outer Mongolian forces near the border of Sinkiang Province.

A limited number of scholarships for training and research for highly qualified graduate students in Columbia University's Russian Institute have been made possible for the next academic year through a gift of $20,000 from the Carnegie Corporation of New York, Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of the university, announced yesterday.
MELBOURNE, Australia, June 23 -- Foreign Minister Herbert D. Evatt protested tonight against the American authorization of a second Japanese whaling expedition to the Antarctic.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The "Labor Management Relations Act, 1947," is the first amendment to the National Labor Relations (Wagner) Act of 1935. It adds a new story and a new facade to the earlier law in an effort to "equalize the relations between employers and employes."
More than 18,000 of the nation's 400,000 soft coal miners stopped work yesterday within a few hours after the Taft-Hartley labor measure became law over the President's veto.

Action in the New York State clay courts tennis championships was speeded up yesterday at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills as Sidney B. Wood Jr. and Earl Cockell of Los Angeles arrived. Both seeded stars, who follow Donald McNeill in the favored list, advanced three rounds, with the assist of a default.

ROME, June 23 -- Salvatore Giuliano, Italy's best-known bandit, who bids fair to eclipse in Sicily the exploits for which about thirty years ago the late Pancho Villa became famous in Mexico, declared war to the death today on communism.
With a moderate volume of business, cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced yesterday 1 to 37 points, with the distant months relatively stronger than near months.

Fleet Admiral William F. Halsey expressed the view last night that the two principal ideologies of the world, the totalitarian and the democratic, would find a common meeting ground and understanding among their peoples. Meanwhile, he told a meeting of the Reserve Officers of the Naval Services in the Hotel Astor, "we've got to be plenty tough."
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The vote by which the Senate today overrode President Truman's veto of the Taft-Hartley labor bill (twothirds majority being required to override):

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The enormously valuable oil-bearing lands under the ocean off the California coast belong to the Federal Government, the Supreme Court decided, 6 to 2, in an important opinion today.

At the Association of Art Museum Directors' meeting recently held in Montreal the following resolution was passed in connection with the cancellation of the art exhibitions sponsored and circulated by the State Department: "The United States members of the Association of Art Museum Directors express their thorough endorsement of the recent programs of the Department of State in furthering the cause of international understanding by disseminating American art in foreign countries.
Anthony H. Miller has been appointed eastern sales representative of the George H. Morrill division, Sun Chemical Corporation.

ST. LOUIS, June 23 (AP) -- With Enos Slaughter batting in four runs, the St. Louis Cardinals recovered their winning form tonight as they downed the league-leading Boston Braves, 6 to 2. Slaughter's three-run homer in the third inning gave Red Munger all the margin he needed to rack up his sixth victory.

OTTAWA, June 23 -- Discussions will begin on Wednesday between the Canadian Government and a delegation from the Newfoundland Convention, Prime Minister William L. Mackenzie King announced today in Parliament, with the aim of discovering "whether there is a fair and equitable basis for a federal union of Newfoundland and Canada."

MINDEN, Germany, June 23 -- The United States War Department has signed a $3,250,000 contract with the Soviet zone Military Government for the purchase of potash, it was learned today. Under the terms of the contract, the Soviet is to deliver in the next five months 95,000 tons of fertilizer for shipment to Japan and Korea.

The Gulf Oil Corporation took over ownership and operation of the North American Airports Corporation in October, 1946, only after it had received an ultimatum from Westchester County officials endangering its investment in North American, Milton N. Weir, assistant to the vice president of Gulf, testified yesterday.

Blum's candy shop is a small place, still located in the same spot, near San Francisco's Nob Hill, where it was opened in the Gay Nineties. Yet throughout the West, and even among some Easterners, too, it is known for its fine American-style confections.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox broke a 3-3 tie with a seven-run outburst in the ninth inning tonight to defeat Washington, 10 -- 6. It was Chicago's ninth victory in ten games with the Senators, who added three runs in the ninth.

ST. LOUIS, June 23 -- Heavy rains in the Missouri and Mississippi River watersheds swelled the flooded streams and their tributaries today as estimates of damage caused by the June floods soared to $159,000,000.

MEXICO CITY, June 23 -- The Government of Mexico published today a decree of President Aleman, creating an intersecretarial committee "to maintain just and convenient equilibrium between national and foreign investments in Mexico."

Hailed as a major advance in television, a large-screen projection receiver providing a television picture 15 by 20 inches in size, and claimed to be brighter than any previous projection receiver, was announced last night by the Philco Corporation at a dinner meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel attended by more than 1,000 dealers from the New York metropolitan area.

Delayed Divestment Today's scheduled marketing of 408,000 shares of California Oregon Power Company's common stock by a Blyth Co., Inc., First Boston Corporation syndicate marks the last of the year-long effort of Standard Gas Electric Company to divest itself of its holdings of its affiliate.

The American premiere of Hector Berlioz' "Funeral and Triumphal Symphony for Band" made last night's Goldman Band concert a musical event of major importance. Credit for rediscovery of the score, modernizing of the instrumentation and conducting the performance goes to Richard Franko Goldman.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 8, John MacCormac offers some comments on recent developments in Hungary and comes to the conclusion that the weakness of the leaders of the Smallholders party, representing 57 per cent of the electoral vote, is in the first place responsible for the defeat of the cause of democracy in Hungary.

Rita Hassan and the American Repertory Theatre announced yesterday their decision to close "Alice in Wonderland" at the Majestic Theatre after Saturday night's performance, the 100th. Plans call for sending the show out on a coast-to-coast tour, starting late in August.

The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers (ASCAP) was accused of illegally engaging in a world-wide cartel and conspiracy to monopolize music -performing rights in a suit filed in Federal court here yesterday by the Anti-trust Division of the Department of Justice.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 23 (AP) -- The Maryland Board of Public Works, headed by Gov. William Preston Lane Jr., accepted unanimously today a bid from the Harris Trust and Savings Bank of Chicago on $9,625,000 worth of general construction bonds.

TRENTON, N.J., June 23 -- Proposals for extending the term of New Jersey Governors, with the privilege of seeking re-election, and for the creation of the new position of Lieutenant Governor may be offered tomorrow by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll to a committee of the State Constitutional Convention.

Women trained in business and club and community work were called upon by Governor Dewey yesterday to take part in government. The Governor's message was read to 2,500 delegates attending the opening of the fiftysixth annual convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs.

Behind the Times Perhaps it is Prime Minister Attlee's old-fashioned education at Oxford in the early years of the century that will explain his old-fashioned definition of democracy in his speech to the Yorkshire miners:

The Italian liner Saturnia arrived at Pier 84, North River, yesterday with the bizarre story of a former Philadelphia woman who jumped from the vessel as it neared Gibraltar on its eastbound run and when rescued fifteen minutes later was found to be carrying $150,000 in currency and travelers' checks and a fortune in jewelry.
A new church edifice that will serve thousands of workers in "the world's best-known market place" -- the New York financial district -- was dedicated yesterday by Cardinal Spellman.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 23 (AP) -- An annoying cross-course wind sent scores skyrocketing but not for a couple of freshmen who stroked out par 72's today to pace the field for the opening round in the 36-hole qualifying test for the 1947 National Collegiate Athletic Association championship.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today upheld an order of the Securities and Exchange Commission preventing the management of a company being reorganized from profiting from purchases of securities made during the course of the reorganization.
Brown Mogul, Joe W. Brown's steady going 4-year-old gelding, won the Fleetwing Handicap, $20,000 added feature on the opening card of the Empire City Racing Association meeting at Jamaica yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Supreme Court ended its term today with a multitude of words. Recessing for the summer, the nine Justices announced decisions in sixteen cases, involving a total of thirty-two documents, or an aggregate of 160,000 words.
Marked gains made by special children in a special camping program are shown by a three-year study announced yesterday by Mrs. Lawrence Ottinger, president of the board of directors of Camp Rainbow.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- Dr. Harley Farnsworth MacNair, authority on China and Professor of Far Eastern History and Institutions at the University of Chicago, died of a heart attack last night in his home here. He was 55 years old.

The National Rainwear Manufacturers Association will begin an advertising campaign to educate consumers on rainwear, it was revealed yesterday by Simon Cohen, chairman of the board. A secondary phase of the campaign, he said, will seek to make store owners conscious of rainwear and to foster better merchandising of the product.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 23 -- A proposed merger of the County Trust Company of White Plains, the Washington Irving Trust Company of Tarrytown and the Bank of Westchester of Yonkers was approved by directors of each bank at meetings today and the plan now awaits action of the stockholders and the State Banking Department.

ROME, June 23 -- The Government said today that it wholeheartedly approved Secretary of State Marshall's plan for coordinating Europe's economy, and it promised full support provided Italy would be included as a partner on an equal footing.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Supreme Court sustained today the law preventing James Caesar Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, from forcing broadcasters to hire more workers than were actually needed to perform radio station services.

Artists and architects must work in close cooperation to create houses of worship in keeping with contemporary religious spirit, speakers agreed yesterday at the closing sessions of a conference on the modern synagogue.

JERUSALEM, June 23 -- Although not in so many words, the Palestine Government told the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine today that it had acted hastily and improperly yesterday in expressing the concern of most of its members over the possible hanging of three convicted terrorists.

PARIS, Tuesday, June 24 -- Protected by large forces of police from hostile demonstrations by long sino dispersed crowds of Communist-directed workers, the National Assembly was still debating Premier Paul Ramadier's fiscal emergency program early today.

MEXICO CITY, June 23 (AP) -- The Bank of Mexico is known to have entered the silver market here on a large scale, avowedly to get ready for coining pesos this fall but at a time when the buying will support the sagging market.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Senate by 68 to 25, or six votes more than the necessary two-thirds, overrode President Truman's veto of the Taft-Hartley Labor Bill today, and at 3:17 P.M., Eastern daylight time, made it the law of this country.

Secretary Marshall made his customary able explanation to Congress of one facet of the United States foreign policy in urging passage at this session of the Inter-American Military Cooperation Bill that has been long discussed and was presented formally to the Congress on May 23 by President Truman.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- The misadventures of the Giants in the West continued to pile up today as the Polo Grounders went plunging down to defeat in the opener of their three-game series with Charlie Grimm's Cubs before a jubilant gathering of 13,779.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a plain ordinary citizen of the South, I think the picture of our race relations has been badly distorted in the news. The horrible Greenville, S.C., episode is no more typical of the South than the Valentine Day massacre of gangster days is typical of the Midwest or Murder, Inc., of New York.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 23 -- Prospects of American business' coming to Turkey depend entirely on Turkey's interpretation of state control, according to Max W. Thornberg, who is making an economic survey here for the Twentieth Century Fund of New York.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The House of Representatives passed today and sent to the Senate legislation giving to reorganized railroads coining out of receivership or bankruptcy with new chapters, certain tax credits of their predecessor corporations.

A four-story tenement house at 636 Second Avenue collapsed at 3:55 P.M. yesterday only a few minutes after the police had evacuated safely the occupants of that building and three others of the same height that adjoin it.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Discussions of further United States aid to China have not reached a point at which figures have been discussed, Dr. V.K. Wellington Koo, Chinese Ambassador, said today. His statement came at the close of the first session of negotiations of our war accounts with China, totaling about $2,000,000,000.

Plans for a seven-story school and parish house at 66 East Ninety -second Street for the Brick Presbyterian Church, 62 East Ninety-second Street, were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The cost is estimated at $375,000.

The Fifth Avenue Association added its influence yesterday to the growing demand for city action on the proposed $25,000,000 plan to relieve parking congestion by construction of garages and parking lots.

In a rousing finish, the Fire Department scored one of the most thrilling triumphs in its twentysix-year baseball rivalry with the Police Department last night at the Polo Grounds before a crowd of 28,000. The 4-3 victory enabled the smokeaters to retire the Mayor O'Dwyer Trophy with three triumphs in four years.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Catholic University Theatre inaugurated its Playwrigting Festival last night with a deft farcecomedy about GI's and the French black market entitled, "All Gaul Is Divided."
