WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today agreed to review an anti-trust decree issued by a special United States District Court in New York City against a group of leading motionpicture companies.

A graduating class of 2,074, the largest since the beginning of World War II, will receive degrees tonight at 8:30 o'clock when City College holds its 101st commencement in Lewisohn Stadium at 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Supreme Court divided 5 to 4 today in upholding the conviction by a New York "blue ribbon" jury of Joseph S. Fay and James Bove, labor union officials, on charges of extorting money from construction contractors.

LONDON, June 23 -- Soviet acceptance of the invitation to attend the Paris conference for discussion of the proposals of Secretary of State Marshall had no effect on the stock markets here today. Conditions generally were dull.

Fall style trends emphasizing femininity and expanding interest in formal wear make the outlook for costume jewelry bright for the coming season, it was reported in the trade here yesterday. Lower prices and the steps taken by retailers to put their stocks in good shape during recent months were also cited as favorable factors.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Prompt Congressional authorization for military aid to LatinAmerican countries by the United States, to prevent them from seeking weapons and training "elsewhere," was urged jointly today by Secretary of State Marshall and Robert P. Patterson, Secretary of War.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 23 -- Two planes sent out from the Naval Academy today to locate the thirty-six yachts in the race from Newport here reported most of them having a long drag in a faint air and smooth sea. One plane which returned here at 5 P.M. sighted three of them an hour previously off Rehoboth, Del.

With commendable speed and a fine disregard of its own propagandists, the Russian Government has accepted the invitation of the British and French Governments to discuss with them a joint program of European reconstruction with American aid, as suggested by Secretary Marshall.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 23 -- If the Brooklyn Dodgers play in the World Series, Laraine Day will be able to be on hand even though she today signed with Sam Coslow to star in "Champagne for Everybody" after it had been announced that the deal was off.

A partial solution of the Palestine problem would be immediate unrestricted immigration of European Jews into that country, Dr. Emanuel Neuman. vice president of the Zionist Organization of America, and Hayim Greenberg, member of the executive committee of the Jewish Agency, declared last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 -- High food prices were attributed today by Tyre Taylor of Washington, general counsel of the National Association of Retail Grocers, to the Truman Administration and to "politicians who are trying to work both sides of the street."

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 23 -- When the qualifying round in the forty-fourth annual women's metropolitan golf championship was completed today two New Jersey golfers were deadlocked for medalist honors. Mrs. Philip Cudone of Knollwood and Miss Maureen Orcutt of Ridgewood, scoring 79 apiece, led the field over the tricky Century Country Club course.

One thousand persons fled from the eleven-story Brill Building, Broadway between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets, at 11:45 A.M. yesterday when fire broke out in the basement kitchen of the Turf Restaurant and Bar.

MUNICH, Germany, June 23 -- The American Military Government in Bavaria announced today its recognition of a five-man committee elected by an insurgent group of the Economic Reconstruction party as against Dr. Alfred Loritz, Denazification Minister and former party chairman.
BOSTON, June 23 (AP) -- Denny Galehouse celebrated his return to a Boston uniform by giving up only six hits today as the Red Sox defeated the faltering Tigers, 8 -- 2.

LONDON, June 23 (Reuters) -- Brilliant batting by England's third wicket pair, Bill Edrich and Denis Compton, put England in a strong position today at the end of the second day of the second cricket test match with South Africa.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of June 19 about Tonga would be a commendable gesture of good-will toward a people with excellent qualities if it did not say more than the actual situation justifies. Some correction is indicated. Having just returned from eleven months of gathering material in the Pacific Islands, I may be able to supply it.

SEOUL, Korea, June 23 -- Extreme rightists, led by Kim Koo today staged a minor anti-trusteeship demonstration. They paraded to a sitdown by several hundred before Duk Soo Palace, where the Joint United States-Soviet commission was meeting.
A new captain will lead the United States Davis Cup team this summer in the defense of the trophy wrested from Australia last December.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- Grains turned strong in the late trading after an early sinking spell on the Board of Trade today. Closing trades were about the top on coarse grains, corn gaining 2 1/4 to 2 3/4 cents a bushel and oats 1 to 1 7/8 cents.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 23 -- Secretary General Lie has decided to turn over to the British Government the requests for clemency for three condemned Palestinian terrorists.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 23 -- Pat Cici of the Nassau County Park Club, winner of the last seventy-two-hole tournament in 1941, set the pace during the opening round of the Long Island Open, sponsored by the Long Island Golf Association, at the Brookville Country Club today with a 37, 3471, one under course figures.

PEIPING, June 23 -- Report from Manchuria indicate that the Nationalist leaders there may be forced to abandon defensive tactics and begin a limited offensive against the Communists in an effort to save Szepingkai.

A Department of Justice investigation into the newsprint industry, which has been under way for several months, has hit a snag because of the refusal of officials of the International Paper Company to produce the records of its Canadian subsidiaries, it was disclosed yesterday in Federal court.

Many dealers attending the opening yesterday of the fiftysixth summer furniture market in the New York Furniture Exchange exercised great caution in placing orders, with a substantial portion devoting their time to "outright shopping."

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The International Monetary Fund acted today to wipe out an international black market in gold, warning that its existence threatened world exchange stability and calling on member nations to prevent transactions in the metal at premium prices with other countries or their nationals.

Harry M. Durning, Collector of Customs, took action yesterday to halt the mysterious flow of Greek food parcels into this country. In the last six months thousands of such parcels, containing an estimated 100,000 to 160,000 pounds of meat, have been received here from that hungry country.

Henry Root Stern, chairman of the State Board of Social Welfare, said yesterday that the question of public hearings in a state investigation of home relief cases by the city Department of Welfare would await a careful review of a high percentage of cases.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Bank for international Reconstruction and Development considers coal production revival in the Ruhr the key to the reconstruction of Western Europe and will support the project financially and technically as soon as an administrative formula has been agreed upon, Robert L. Garner, vice president of the institution, said today.

LONDON, June 24 -- The long road -- and Europe hopes the great road -- toward economic cooperation with the United States began this morning when William L. Clayton, United States Under-Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, went to 10 Downing Street.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Prominent Republicans in Congress, many of them key political figures in their home states, agreed today that Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio had picked up strength as a possible candidate for the Presidency by his forceful fight to make the Taft-Hartley labor bill law.
With the doubeled-bareled Stieglitz memorial exhibition now well under way, the energetic Museum of Modern Art is opening to the public today three new shows.

We hope that President Truman will veto the wool tariff bill, and if he does so we shall find no difficulty in reconciling our approval of such action with our disapproval of the vetoes of the tax and labor bills.
Members of the Eric Guerin Rooting and Marching Society had a delightful time at Empire Cityat-Jamaica yesterday despite the rain and the way the favorites continued to roll over and play dead.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The groundwork for an inquiry into oil shipments to Russia was laid today with a report by the House Merchant Marine Committee that the oil was being hauled in American tankers flying the Soviet flag.

THE men who report the doings of the turf world are a breed apart from other sportswriters. Superlatives gather dust on their typewriter keys. The baseball or football writers or any other sports chroniclers go overboard in their enthusiasm. But not the boss experts. Their restraint is almost annoying and it's only with extreme reluctance that they'll even admit that a horse is "great" -- which isn't even a superlative.
For the first time in the memory of officials at the Board of Education, triplets were graduated yesterday from a New York public elementary school.

As the result of the collapse of the four-story tenement house at 636 Second Avenue Monday afternoon. Robert F. Wagner Jr., Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, ordered yesterday that re pairs be made on the four-story building at 638 Second Avenue.

All activities of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research are to be consolidated in the East River buildings of the institute by transferring the Department of Animal and Plant Pathology from its 780acre site near Princeton, N.J., to this city, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The House voted, 272 to 97, today to give formal Congressional authorization and permanent status to the State Department's long-contested international information and educational exchange program. It was predicted at key points in the Senate, however, that the House measure's chances for enactment were "practically nil."

The conference between the Big Three of Europe, beginning in Paris on Friday, will necessarily be a preliminary and exploratory meeting to determine whether the Western Powers and Russia can cooperate in putting together the shattered pieces of Europe's economy.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 24 -- Two important aspects of the Hungarian election campaign which begins Sunday with a speed in Debrecen by Premier Lajos Dinnes, became clear today. One is that there will be no free speech The other is that, despite the Communists efforts to achieve a common ticket, the Socialists and the Small Landholders insist on separate lists.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 24 -- Leading all others of the thirty-six contending craft in the New York Yacht Club's race from Newport, R.I., here still was Henry C. Taylor's fleet, black-hulled yawl Baruna. That was definite tonight when the zig-zag pieces of information of the Navy and Coast Guard, like a crossword puzzle, were pieced together.

The Transport Workers Union, CIO, asked the Board of Transportation yesterday for an immediate negotiation meeting on its demands, including $25,000,000 in wage increases, for the 29,000 operating employes of the city's transit system.

ST. LOUIS, June 24 -- The June floodtide continued to roll through the vast Mississippi and Missouri watersheds today as the crop loss in the country's "breadbasket" mounted to tremendous proportions.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Dr. Louis T. Wright, physician, of New York City, chairman of the national board of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, tonight placed the security of person as "a basic right" of a free man.

It was not to be expected that the partition of India would be accomplished without violence and sudden death. Such grim forebodings have been fully realized now that the process of separation has actually begun. Lahore, capital of the Punjab, is a shambles and troops in Calcutta, metropolis of Bengal, have been compelled to fire on communal rioters there.

DACHAU, Germany, June 24 (U.P.) -- Otto Skorzeny, former lieutenant colonel of the SS (Elite Guard) officially described as the "most dangerous man in Europe," was arraigned before, a United States military court today on charges of torturing and murdering surrendered United States troops and wearing their uniforms.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The strength of the Army has dropped to approximately 1,000,000 men and women and the recruiting of volunteers continues in the fourth month of a definite slump, it was disclosed today by Maj. Gen. Willard S. Paul, director of personnel of the War Department General Staff.

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 24 -- The two New Jersey leaders who tied yesterday for medalist honors in the forty-fourth annual women's metropolitan golf championship, Mrs. Philip Cudone of the Knoll and Miss Maureen Orcutt of Ridgewood, both had tussles in their first round of match play in a steady downpour over the Century Country Club course here today.
SHANGHAI, June 24 (AP) -- Delegates to the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East, tempers slightly frayed by nine days of bickering, in effect concluded their first series of sessions today.

The Queens Street Realty Corp. Morris Rosenwasser, president, obtained through Hosinger Bode Inc. brokers, a first mortgage loan of $450,000 at 4 per cent for ten years on the entire block bounded by Jackson Ave. Queens and Orchard Sts. and the Long Island Railroad, Long Island City, Queens. The property is improved with office and factory structures.
Queens residents will pay the heaviest real estate tax in the city under schedules adopted yesterday by the City Council, which set the Queens rate at $3.06 for each $100 of assessed valuation.

"Mr. and Mrs. North," the serviceable mystery series from the pens of Frances and Richard Lockridge, is returning to the air next week after being off the air since December. It will be heard at 8:30 P.M. Tuesdays over CBS, with Joseph Curtin and Alice Frost in the title roles.

JAFFA, Palestine, June 24 -- The Arab boycott of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine became noticeably more frigid today when the committee visited Jaffa, the chief Arab city of Palestine and center of the Arab anti-Zionist youth movement.
CHICAGO, June 24 -- If Clarence Iott, strapping left-hander bought by the Giants a few days ago from the Browns, lives to be a hundred, he never will forget his first day in the National League.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., June 24 -- The problems of industrial relations cannot be solved solely by legislation, but must be stabilized by both employes and management putting their respective houses in order and cooperating to the fullest, foremen and top management executives have agreed following three days of conference here.

DETROIT, June 24 -- With the most amazing exhibition of approaching and putting ever seen in any golf match, big Jim Ferrier, 32-year-old Australian-born pro, finally wore down Melvin (Chick) Harbert of Michigan to win the twenty-ninth annual P.G.A. championship before a crowd of close to 7,000 at the Plum Hollow Golf Club today.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- John L. Lewis may take advantage of a unique situation and ignore the soft coal operators in an effort to force their hand or the Government's to get the contract he wants or test the new labor law.

ALBANY, June 24 -- A committee of twenty-one educators was appointed today by Dr. Francis T. Spaulding, commissioner of education, to assist him in formulating plans, organization and procedure for administering the minimum state salary schedules for teachers.

A demonstration of a new type, twin-section, double-engined passenger bus, forty-seven feet long, was held yesterday on a trial run from mid-Manhattan to Forest Hills, Queens, under the direction of officials of the Twin Coach Company of Kent, Ohio, and the B.F. Goodrich Company, joint manufacturers.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were 13 points higher to 7 points lower than Monday's levels at the close yesterday after a fairly active day of trading.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Representative Harold Knutson, Republican, of Minnesota, re-introduced his vetoed tax-reduction bill today with the effective date changed to next Jan. 1. The surprise move, backed by Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. and the other House leaders, evidenced a determination to give the country the type of tax reduction favored by the Republican Congress regardless of President Truman's belief that it is "the wrong kind."

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- Partly to get even with Southern Democrats who helped kill the income tax reduction bill, the Republican leadership today crammed an anti-poll tax bill onto the House schedule for passage this session.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Polish Government informed the State Department today of Poland's intention to adhere to the plan of Secretary of State Marshall for the economic recovery of Europe.

MERE, England., June 24 (U.P.) -- Tuning up for the British open at Hoylake Monday, Johnny Bulla, the United States Airlines pilot, shot a 71 today in the first round of the $5,600 Manchester Evening Chronicle's professional golf tournament.

ATHENS, June 24 -- Minister of Coordination Stephanopoulos said at a press conference tonight that shipping agencies, a number of which advertise in the Greek language American press, had exploited the sentiment and good-will of several thousands, of persons in America and Greece by charging exorbitant sums for transportation of food both ways.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- President Truman presented the International Harmon Trophy today to Maj. Alexander P. de Seversky in recognition of "outstanding contributions to American victory" through his efforts as champion of a strong military air fleet.

CHICAGO, June 24 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 10,500 head, total 15,000; market moderately active and 25 to 50 cents lower on weights under 240 pounds; weights over 240 pounds and sows 25 cents lower; top

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court voted unanimously yesterday to reverse the conviction of Mrs. Genevieve Rivera, the first parent to be sent to prison in Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander's campaign to hold parents responsible for the delinquencies of their children.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A majority of the National Labor Relations Board ruled today that one department of a plant was an appropriate unit for bargaining purposes. A dissenting member of the board, James J. Reynolds Jr., likened the decision to gerrymandering.

The murder and robbery last June 3 of James C. Small, a Detroit tavern owner, was prompted by the desire of two boys to obtain funds with which to run away from home, one of the boys disclosed here yesterday in a confession to the Federal Bureau of Investigation of his part in the crimes.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 24 -- Pat Cici, professional from Nassau County Park, and Jack Lyons, amateur from the Garden City Golf Club, shared the lead with 145 totals at the halfway point in the Long Island open at the Brookvilla Country Club today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 -- The International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, is withdrawing its support of the CIO Maritime Committee, headed by Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, it was disclosed today.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 24 -- Evarts Boutell Greene, who was De Witt Clinton Professor of American History at Columbia University from 1926 until his retirement in 1939, died here tonight of a heart attack at his home on Mount Airy Road.

The State of Connecticut yesterday awarded at competitive sale issues of bonds totaling $52,200,000 to a banking syndicate headed by the National City Bank of New York. The issues consisted of $50,000,000 of veterans bonus bonds due from 1948 to 1957 and $2,200,000 of university bonds due from 1948 to 1967.

Americans doing business in the Philippines should at all times work for the benefit of the Filipinos as well as themselves, Merle Robie, resident representative in the Philippine Islands of the Columbian Rope Company of Auburn, N.Y., told a gathering of foreign trade bankers and editors at a luncheon yesterday in the India House.

Secretary of State George C. Marshall's speech at Harvard on the rebuilding of Europe brought encouragement and hope that has aroused the whole continent, Henri Bonnet, French Ambassador to the United States, told the graduating classes of City College last night at commencement exercises.

Highlighted by unusual dyeing, bleaching and plucking processes, a collection of furs designed for the budgets of young career and college women was presented for the first time yesterday by Esther Dorothy at 78 East Fifty-sixth Street.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 24 -- A five-point program designed to broaden the powers of the executive was presented to the State constitutional convention here today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, who differed sharply with several delegates and former Governors on the desirability of creating the office of Lieutenant Governor.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Aggressive buying of July corn by brokers who frequently act for a large cash interest absorbed the surplus in the pit today and prices ran up 3 1/4 cents above Monday's finish to $2.01 1/2. This was a new high record on the Board of Trade.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 24 -- Yugoslavia delivered today a note to the United States Embassy protesting against a request by American authorities in Vienna to Yugoslav repatriation officials there to leave by June 14 and to a Yugoslav war crimes investigation team to leave by June 20.

A two-day cycle of happy events for Shirley Alexon, 12 years old, of 430 East Seventy-third Street, reached its grand climax yesterday when she won the "most amiable girl in Yorkville" title at the Childrens Aid Society's Jones Girls Club.

Prices of five cuts of beef and veal dropped another cent or two in retail shops throughout the city yesterday as consumer resistance to high prices caused a further glut in wholesale markets. Other retail meat prices remained unchanged, and pork went up two cents more at wholesale.

RYE, N.Y., June 24 -- J. Ellis Knowles, who never has failed to win the United States Seniors' Golf Association championship -- always played at his home course at the Apawamis Club -- since he reached the minimum age limit six years ago, found himself in a tie at the halfway mark today.

Glancing Through the Paper Choice of General Eisenhower for president of Columbia University has naturally brought up a famous earlier case of the kind, involving a military name as eminent as that of the Allied commander in the late war, though a much smaller college than Columbia today.

PARIS, June 24 -- The advance guard of the Russian delegation to the three-power Foreigrn Ministers' conference that opens Friday arrived in Paris today. They came in two DC-3 planes with the Soviet Red Star insignia, which recalled a time when material aid from the United States was eagerly welcomed by Russia, fighting to drive out an invader.

Public utility bond issues aggregating $16,500,000 and a block of industrial common stock priced at $2,625,000 will be placed on the market here today by underwriting managers as follows: Southern California Gas Company -- $12,000,000 of first mortgage 2% per cent bonds, due in 1977, at 104.213, to yield 2.67 per cent, by White, Weld Co.

After fifty years of service in the New York public school system, forty-nine of which were spent in the same school, Miss Anna F. Magee, first grade teacher at Public School 166, Manhattan, will retire on Friday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 (AP) -- In a sixty-page discussion of the proposed stock allocation in liquidation of Public Service Corporation of New Jersey, Edward Hopkinson Jr., senior partner in Drexel Co., bankers, today put his camp of approval on the plan.

Goodman Manufacturing The Goodman Manufacturing Company voted a dividend of 75 cents on the common stock, payable on June 30 to holders of record of June 27. The company paid 50 cents in March and in the first three quarters of 1946, as well as a year-end dividend of $1.25 in December.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A special train left Washington today for Warm Springs, Ga., for the dedication tomorrow as a public shrine of the Little White House where Franklin D. Roosevelt died on April 12, 1945.

WIMBLEDON, June 24 (AP) -- Australia's Geoff Brown and Jack Bromwich had their anxious moments today in the second-round men's singles matches of the Wimbledon tennis championships, but all eight seeded favorites advanced to the third round while the topranked women rushed through easy opening victories.

CLEVELAND, June 24 -- With only three of the 900 delegates dissenting, the convention of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, adopted a resolution today denouncing Soviet foreign policy as "the most serious threat to world peace."

Elmer Haslett, city airports director, intervened again yesterday in his hearing on charges of improper and inconsistent conduct to bring out that in December, 1945, when he was being supported by the Gulf Oil Corporation in an airport operation, he caused the filing of a $125,000 claim by the city against Gulf.
ST. LOUIS, June 24 (AP) -- A ninth-inning rally failed to overcome the six-run lead of the Braves and the Cardinals ended up on the little end of a 9-6 score tonight with Billy Southworth's team.

With virtually no hope of averting a shipyard strike remaining, approximately 40,000 workers in nine East Coast yards of the Bethlehem Steel Company, 12,000 of whom are employed locally, are poised to drop their tools at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- L.A. Wheeler, chairman of the International Wheat Council, said today, a long-term international agreement to stabilize prices and supplies of wheat in world markets would not be put into effect for at least a year.

CLEVELAND, June 24 -- Jimmy Doyle, Los Angeles welterweight, was carried out of the ring of the Arena tonight on a stretcher, his dream of a ring championship shattered, his life jeopardized. He was removed to St. Vincent's Charity Hospital under orders of Dr. Arthur F. Hagedorn of the Cleveland Boxing Commission.

PITTSBURGH, June 24 -- Nearly one-half of the country's 400,000 soft coal miners had quit work by tonight in a wildcat strike that continued to mushroom through the bituminous fields. Their action was ascribed to protest over the Taft-Hartley labor law.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 24 -- As a result of a corridor conference today between Secretary General Trygve Lie and the Soviet delegate, Andrei A. Gromyko, all the Big Five powers will be represented in a world-wide broadcast Thursday commemorating the second anniversary of the United Nations Charter.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE TIMES of June 18 there is an article concerning the distribution by the Army of a pamphlet on communism, which asserts that communism is the opposite of democracy.

For the fourth time in his career, Edward V. Broderick, a trial lawyer in the New York Criminal Courts for almost three decades, was found guilty of contempt of court yesterday when General Sessions Judge James G. Wallace fined him $200 and sentenced him to five days in City Prison.

GENEVA, Switzerland, June 24 -- The United States has enjoyed particular success in obtaining desired changes in the draft charter being formulated at the world trade conference Here, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Complying with President Truman's request that they remain at their posts, the members of the National Labor Relations Board pledged today that they would "give the new (labor relations) act the fairest and most efficient administration that lies within its power."

Fourteen Tammany district leaders, and three Republican leaders were faced yesterday with contests in the primary election on July 29 as the time for filing designating petitions with the Board of Elections expired at 5 P.M.

ANN ARBOR Mich., June 24 (AP) -- Louisiana State's evenly balanced squad, posting three firstround 75s and a 76, pulled into a one-point lead today as contender for team honors in the National Collegiate Athletic Association golf championship.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 -- Retail grocers were cautioned today to watch their prices closely, guarding against "even a one-cent overprice" on the present competitive market, but were told that production of new crops and stabilization of wages must precede any appreciable price decline.
Chairmanship of the new national Christian committee for the United Jewish Appeal was accepted yesterday by Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation.
College graduates owe an obligation to their communities which "entirely too few" of them ever pay, Dean Earl G. Harrison of the University of Pennsylvania Law School declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 18: Increases of $425,000,000 in holdings of United States Government obligations, $221,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, and $269,000,000 in demand deposits credited to domestic banks.

ROME, June 24 -- L'Osservatore Romano today publishes a fullpage report on what it terms "developments in religious persecution in Yugoslavia". The report, originally printed by the magazine Civilta Cattolica, which is edited by Jesuit fathers, contained little that had not already been said in Catholic publications.

The vast powers enjoyed by James C. Petrillo of the musicians' union have been in large part the result of onesided Federal law. Mr. Petrillo has thrived on a policy of forcing broadcasters and others to employ more musicians than they needed. It has been an outrageous instance of feather-bedding.

Today we deal with the subject of cooking with wine. It's an interesting topic any time, but it becomes actually absorbing when it's treated the way Mrs. Jeanne Owen has written about it in "The Lejon Cook Book."

ALBANY, June 24 -- Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi said today that he had accepted proposed minimum wage rates of 65 cents an hour and $25 weekly in Zone 1, and 58 1/2 cents an hour and $23.40 weekly in Zone 2 for beauty service workers.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 24 -- There can be no peace unless human rights are respected, the United Nations committee drafting the International Bill of Rights emphasized today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 24 -- The stormy and colorful life of Fyodor Dostoievski, famed Russian author of "Crime and Punishment," "The Brothers Karamazov" and other novels, is to be brought to the screen by Metro-GoldwynMayer, probably with Spencer Tracy in the principal role.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The creation of an Inter-American Defense Council on a permanent basis carries no implication of a threat to peace, or challenge to any power or group of powers, Dr. Alberto Lleras Camargo of Colombia, newly elected director general of the Pan American Union, said today.

VIENNA, June 24 -- The United States Government intends, according to a report heard here today, to repay all previous occupation payments made by the Austrian Government to Americans. It is said that as a liberated victim of Adolf Hitler's aggression, Austria never was morally obligated to pay occupation costs.

TOKYO, June 24 -- Proposals to exempt Japanese assets held in neutral countries from reparations claims are understood to have been approved by Gen. Douglas MacArthur and to be now awaiting sanction by the Far Eastern Commission.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa. June 24 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Guild tonight defeated a proposal for a paid presidency of the union. The vote, 242 13/14 to 91 1/14, came after about two hours of debate.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- A gasoline allocation program, entailing informal rationing by some filling station operators in Chicago and other parts of the Middle West, was announced today by the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, largest operator in the Midwest.

ST. LOUIS, June 24 -- A broad program of national legislation, including reconstruction of war-torn countries to preserve peace, was proposed today by the annual convention of the American Home Economics Association.

A shortage of unlicensed personnel for the American Merchant Marine has reached such a critical stage that representatives of shipowners and maritime labor groups are joining in a recruiting campaign to obtain trained seafarers, it became known here yesterday.

A fisheries company, a milk reconstituting concern and a food warehousing and distribution unit will be the first projects to strengthen and broaden the economy of Venezuela under an agreement just closed between the Government of President Romulo Betancourt and the Venezuela Basic Economy Corporation, controlled by Nelson A. Rockefeller and his four brothers.

The new fall millinery styles are beginning to emerge from the workrooms. The first to show is Sally Victor, who presented her collection to the press in her establishment at 18 East Fifty-third Street yesterday morning. There's lots to talk about in the new hats.
LONDON, June 24 -- The best section in generally dull stock markets here today was the oils group where the increased dividend announced by Anglo Iranian caused some heavy trading.
LONDON, June 24 -- The British government took legislative steps today to enable it to increase the import duty on American movies by changing the basis on which duty is now evaluated.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 24 -- The Soviet Union indicated today that it would turn down the new approach to international control of atomic energy suggested by representatives from the other members of the Big Five and Canada.

Crude Oil Prices The surprise announcement made yesterday by the Union Oil Company of California that it will increase by 7 to 30 cents the prices it will pay for crude oil does not mean that there will be a similar rise east of the Rocky Mountains.
A 15-year-old Persian prince, who is believed to be playing American hookey in royal style, was the object last night of a confidential police alarm here.

The thirty-nine-story office building proposed for the East Side on the site now occupied by the Hotel Marguery will cost an estimated $21,164,000, according to plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings by Harrison Abramovitz, architects, of 45 Rockefeller Plaza.

SEOUL, Korea, June 24 -- Col. Gen. Terentyi F. Shtikov, chief of the Soviet delegation in the Joint United States-Soviet Commission, complained today to American authorities that Koreans had thrown dirt and stones at a Soviet car yesterday.

The General Federation of Women's Clubs, the largest organization of women in the world, was called upon yesterday to urge the passage of the Stratton bill and thus become "the big sister" to the displaced women of Europe desperately in need of aid.

The stock market underwent the severest attack in a month yesterday when late selling cut prices 1 to 4 points in a long list of major issues. The interruption to the advance coincided with the news of a threatened tie-up of industry through a coal strike designed to test the new labor law.

BOSTON, June 24 -- In the face of an acute shortage, the United States is losing enough lumber and labor time through building and home fires annually to construct 200,000 five-room dwellings, the fortieth convention of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers was told today.

The "abnormal and unstable" character of the large volume of United States export trade since the end of the war is emphasized by recent statements concerning the world-wide shortage of dollar exchange, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York declares in its monthly review of business and financial conditions published today.
Diplomas were presented to 247 seniors at graduation exercises yesterday afternoon at the Central High School of Needle Trades, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- In the geographical sources of the votes cast by the House and the Senate to override or sustain the President's two recent vetoes there is a message from the Southern wing of the Democratic party to the national organization and to the Administration.

A resolution paying tribute to Boleslav Beirut, President of Poland, for the democratic efforts of his regime and its desire to guarantee full citizenship rights to its Jewish population, was voted here last night at the final session of the Inter-American Conference of the World Federation for Polish Jews.

ROME, June 24 -- Large forces of police are combing Sicilian mountains in the greatest post-war manhunt to arrest Salvatore Giugliano. The fugitive is the bandit who began an anti-Communist campaign with terrorist attacks.

Covering 55,000 employes of railroads and express companies in the metropolitan area, new provisions of the Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act will become effective next Monday, P.B. Hogan, district manager of the Railroad Retirement Board at 641 Washington Street, said yesterday.

General of the Army Dwight David Eisenhower will become the thirteenth president of Columbia University, it was officially announced yesterday. He will be installed as the successor to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler some time next year, probably in its first six months.

Buyers' Arrivals Lower Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,957, against 2,379 last week and 1,802 in the similar week of last year, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- American trade interests will be better served if the rehabilitation of Japan is postponed to permit other Oriental countries which were United States Allies in the war to get back on their feet, Paul V. McNutt, former Ambassador to the Philippines, said today.

LONDON, June 24 -- Britons were warned today that next winter might be even bleaker than the last from the standpoint of supplies of gas and electricity to which the average householder looks to supplement his meager coal ration for heating.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There is a move on foot to abolish PR, or proportional representation, for electing the New York City Council. Various criticisms are brought up by the attackers in their eagerness to return to the plurality method of electing representatives from small districts where the party machines hope to control the election as they did so effectively in the long unfettered rule of Tammany Hall.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 (AP) -- The Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals today upheld Federal District Judge Paul D. Leahy of Wilmingtort, Del., in his dismissal of suit brought by a group of the United Corporation's stockholders to hold former officers and directors of the company, J.P. Morgan Co. and other New York bankers liable for reputed losses of upward of $100,000,000.

ORLANDO, Fla., June 24 -- Brig. Gen. Charles McCormick Reeve, who was Yale's oldest living graduate, died today in his summer home at Minnetonka Beach, Minn., according to word received here. He was in his hundredth year.

American Jews were warned last night by Bartley C. Crum that failure to provide hope for the displaced Jews in Europe might lead to violence there that could be reflected in a violent wave of antiSemitism in the United States.

At exactly 2 o'clock Sunday morning a trolley car will run into its station at Amsterdam Avenue and 129th Street. After that Manhattan will hear no more clanging, no more motor chugging, and no more old windows rattling. For after that car is off the streets the trolley becomes a thing of the past in the borough.
BERLIN, June 24 -- The city assembly defied the Soviet Army's threats today and elected Ernst Reuter Lord Mayor.

JERUSALEM, June 24 -- A hand grenade exploded tonight in the front yard of a house about fifty yards from the site of the military courts, and a wave of nervousness swept the city. All zones were immediately closed. Orders went out over the military radio to "watch out for booby traps especially."

Lower selling costs can be achieved by retailers by greater emphasis on branded lines and stepping up use of related selling, it was pointed out yesterday by Harold W. Brightman, president of Lit Brothers, Philadelphia department store.

OTTAWA, June 24 -- Behind Newfoundland's search for a change of government, which has brought a commission here to discuss the possibility of joining the Canadian Confederation, lies resentment against the action of the British Government in leasing bases to the United States on what was Newfoundland territory.

There's a movement afoot in New York State to bring about closer relations between the sportsmen and the Conservation Department and possibly solve some problems through a committee working with Commissioner Perry B. Duryea.

Urging business men here not to sell Great Britain short, Sir Frederick Bain, M.C., president of the Federation of British Industries and deputy chairman of Imperial Chemical Industries Ltd., said yesterday that anyone who thinks England will not win through her present difficulties is "making a very grave mistake."

A recession, so far as "progressive action in behalf of the common man" is concerned, already is a reality, Rabbi Israel M. Goldman of Providence, R.I., declared here yesterday. As president of the Rabbinical Assembly of America he spoke at the forty-seventh annual convention of the assembly.

In a final message sent to the teaching and administrative personnel of the New York public school system, John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, bade farewell yesterday to the more than 35,000 men and women he has supervised for the last five years.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 24 -- Lucretiu Patrascanu, Communist Minister of Justice, confirmed today that additional arrests could be expected in Rumania as the Government ferreted out more information concerning the leadership and organization of the campaign of agitation for an armed uprising against the regime.

The three-power meeting to be held this week in Paris is unlike any other post-war conference. In some respects it will be the most interesting of them all. It is important because of its timing, because of the acceptance of Russia despite all the prior outcry against the Marshall proposal in the Moscow press, and not least because of the absence of the United States.

Seven excited youngsters from Salvation Army Sunday schools rang the doorbell yesterday morning at Mrs. Wendell Willkie's apartment at 1010 Fifth Avenue to pick up two valises belonging to the late Wendell Willkie that she had promised to donate to the current "Make it a case for a kid" campaign to provide luggage for camp-bound youngsters.

George Alpert, president of the board of trustees of the proposed Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass., said yesterday that the institution would be opened in the fall of 1948 as planned, despite the withdrawal of support by Dr. Albert Einstein and two associates.

Little likelihood of any change in Atlantic air fares this summer was foreseen by observers as the North Atlantic Traffic Conference of the International Air Transport Association met yesterday at its New York offices, 11 Broadway.

CINCINNATI, June 24 (AP) -- Harry Gumbert cut off a ninthinning Philadelphia rally here tonigt to save a 4-2 victory for Cincinnati after Kent Peterson, rookie southpaw, checked the Phillies with five hits in eight and onethird innings.

Comparatively small changes in the pace of lending activities by leading New York banks during the first half of June, over the first half of March, is disclosed in the quarterly survey of bank loans and rates compiled by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Kermit Bloomgarden consider the Fulton an ideal operating base. Two of his attractions, "Deep Are the Roots" and "Another Part of the Forest," resided there. That may be construed as a tribute to Louis Lotito, who operates the house as well as others for the City Investing Company.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, June 24 -- Business is contributing $100,000,000 worth of time and space a year to advertisements which support important national educational programs, Charles G. Mortimer Jr., chairman of The Advertising Council, told the convention of The Advertising Association of the West here today.

NANKING, June 24 (AP) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Chief of Staff conceded today that his armies to Manchuria were in a perilous position and accused Russia of giving the Communists "substantial" help in the civil war.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- The shortage of gasoline in the face of growing demand that forced the Standard Oil Company of Indiana today to allocate its output was attributed to inadequate pipeline and refinery capacities rather than any shortage of crude oil.

Maxwell H. Tretter announced yesterday his resignation as executive director of the New York City Housing Authority. The resignation was accepted by Edmond Borgia Butler, chairman, to become effective July 1. On the same date Mr. Butler will be succeeded by Maj. Gen. Thomas F. Farrell, recently appointed by Mayor O'Dwyer to become the authority's first paid, full-time chairman.
PHILADELPHIA, June 24 (AP) -- After spotting the Athletics three runs in the first inning, the Browns rolled to a 12-3 victory here tonight before 8,707.

PARIS, June 24 -- Having won the National Assembly's approval of its fiscal measures, the Cabinet faced a rising tide of strikes and protests today and must meet an even harder fight on economic policy in the Assembly tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Two of the capital's most influential figures, a banker and an industrialist, pictured today a good prospect of maintaining the currently high level of economic activity for several years but with labor casting much uncertainty upon the outlook.

In the omnibus Independent Offices Appropriation Bill, which has passed the House and is now before the Senate Appropriations Committee, is a sixline proviso aimed at bringing the discharge from responsible positions of five executives in the National Archives, including the Assistant Archivist.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the June 17 issue of THE TIMES, Dr. Roger I. Lee of Boston, past president of the American Medical Association, at the New England Health Institute meeting held at the University of New Hampshire, is reported as challenging the wisdom of retirement of personnel at ages such as 60 and 65.

NEW DELHI, India, June 24 -- The Moslem newspaper Dawn called today upon the Governor of the Punjab Province, Sir Evan Jenkins, to relinquish his post before the forthcoming partition of this territory which was voted at Lahore yesterday.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 24 -- The complete list of the fifty-odd delegates from the various states of the British and American zones making up the new Economic Council was released here today on the eve of its initial session tomorrow.

Concern over the "evident intention of Congress to defer action on the Taft-Ellender-Wagner Housing Bill" was registered yesterday in a statement by the Inter-Diocesan Committee on Legislation. The committee represents the Departments of Christian Social Relations of the six Episcopal dioceses in the state.

The right of the State Labor Relations Board to avail itself of "competent assistants in the sifting and analyzing" of matters brought before it was upheld yesterday by the Appellate Division, Second Department.

TEANECK, N.J., June 24 -- Accused of killing a 75-year-old widow in an automobile accident which, according to the police, he said he did not remember, George Schmitter, 45, was arrested today at his home, 1549 Teaneck Road. After examination by a physician at Police Headquarters, he was charged with driving while intoxicated, leaving the scene of an accident, and death by automobile.

A Government drive against alleged violators of construction regulations of the Civilian Production Administration was indicated yesterday with the filing of complaints in Federal court, Brooklyn, against six individuals and three companies.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- By a vote of 334 to 4, the House approved today another two-year extension of the life of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, but with its operations and lending capacity curbed sharply.

PITTSBURGH, June 24 -- They're never too old to learn something. The 40-year-old Fritz Ostermueller learned tonight at Forbes Field, before 35,331 distressed witnesses, that it is unwise to wind up with Jackie Robinson on third base.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- Chicago's White Sox shattered Walter Masterson's streak of shutout innings at thirty-four here tonight en route to a 3-0 victory over Washington. It was their tenth triumph over the Senators in eleven games this season.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The War Department, which handles Austrian occupation costs and United States payments, tonight declined to comment on the Vienna report.

Sharp improvement in delivery dates of electric motors, coupled with five other important heavy equipment developments, indicate that a normal buyer's market is extending itself in durable goods lines, purchasing executives revealed here yesterday.

Thirty-one passengers and ten crew members escaped injury yesterday when an Air France plane from Paris, landing at La Guardia Field, ground-looped severely and came to a sudden stop in the center of the airport with its weight resting on its right wing.

The enlistment figures for the Army since the expiration of Selective Service on March 31 indicate that we are losing the gamble that President Truman said we would be taking in relying on volunteers to keep our Army and Air Force strength up to 1,070,000 and the Navy at 571,000.

With Frank (Spec) Shea scintillating as master of ceremonies, the league-leading Yankees celebrated "million night" in gala fashion at the Stadium last night before a crowd of 60,090 that swelled their paid home attendance to the impressive total of 1,018,082 for twenty-eight showings in the Bronx.

A daring hold-up in an eighth floor apartment at 360 Central Park West, a building which fronts the avenue from Ninety-fifth to Ninety-sixth Streets, netted two young gunmen $15,000 worth of jewelry and $250 in cash last night.

Benjamin Fielding, Commisioner of Licenses, declared yesterday after a three-week survey that second-hand automobile dealers in this city had worked up a scheme in the sale of cars that was comparable to "the worst evils of the former OPA black market racket."
PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (AP) -- With Eddie Joost returning to his place at shortstop the Athletics turned back the Browns tonight, 4 -- 2.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., June 25 -- Leaders of industry were among 400 persons who attended a funeral service here this afternoon in the Dutch Reformed Church for Walter B. Weisenburger, executive vice president of the National Association of Manufacturers, who died on Monday at his home.

VIENNA, June 25 -- The United States Government has already, in effect, surrendered back to the Austrians all Austrian occupation cost payments made to American forces to date, according to reports available here.

The summer season's first BroadWay opening takes place tonight at the Cort Theatre where "Laura," a dramatization by Vera Oaspary and George Sklar of the former's novel, will be presented. H. Clay Blaney is producing the work in association with S.P. and Roy P. Steckler by special arrangement with Hunt Stromberg Jr.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 25 -- A showdown over Bulgaria's refusal to admit a subsidiary group of the United Nations Balkan investigation commission was ordered by the full commission today on the demand of Mark F. Ethridge, the United States member.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 25 -- The United Nations today completed the first stage in the drafting of an International Bill of Rights intended for the citizens of all member nations.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am one of those who received three unsolicited packages from Greece containing olive oil, raisins, honey, figs, garlic, fascolimo, camomile and the like, which came from people to whom we had sent scores of food and clothing packages since the day Greece was liberated.

PITTSBURGH, June 25 -- The steel industry, with its source of fresh coal cut off, began today banking blast furnaces and curtailing operations as a strike of soft coal miners in protest over the Taft-Hartley labor law continued to spread over the country.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., June 25 -- A simple, six-room $8,700 house with fieldstone fireplaces, historic only because Franklin D. Roosevelt died there was turned over to the American people as a shrine today while 2,000 persons looked on.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Swedish import restrictions will be eased appreciably under an agreement between that country and the United States, the terms of which were announced today by the State Department.

Philip N. Cohan has been elected president of Oppenheim, Collins Co., Inc., and Lester Hano and Jack A. Segal were elected vice presidents and general managers of the Philadelphia and Buffalo stores, respectively, it was announced yesterday by Albert M. Greenfield, chairman of the boards of the corporation and of its parent company, City Stores Company.

Technical considerations, assisted by strength in previously weakened positions enabled the stock market yesterday to recover part of the ground lost on Tuesday. American Telephone was the individual strong spot of the session. The composite rate advanced 0.38 point.

MINDEN Germany, June 25 -- In an attempt to spur manufacturers' interest in producing for the bi-zonal export program, the American and British Military Governments plan the establishment of an "exporters' fund."

SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 -- Without specifically mentioning chain store systems as its target, the National Association of Retail Grocers called today for a Federal investigation of quantity discounts to large buyers.

GENEVA, Switzerland, June 25 -- An attempt by New Zealand to amend the draft of the world-trade charter to permit her to arrange her imports as she pleased, was blocked today by the United States in the trade conference here.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 25 -- Despite Russian objections, the United Nations Security Council acted unexpectedly today to order its Military Staff Committee to report by Monday on the number of men and weapons needed for an effective international police force.

The Title Guarantee and Trust Company, 176 Broadway, and three of its officials were indicted yesterday on charges of conspiracy and issuing false information to other banking establishments concerning the financial stability of William B. Benjamin.

Two veterans who set up their own retail business in this city a year ago with the guidance of the State Department of Commerce received the commendation of Governor Dewey yesterday in a letter that was read at a brief ceremony by Thomas J. Curran, Secretary of State.

Labor relations in the Board of Transportation are "chaotic," representatives of four labor unions and employe associations told members of the Committee of 100 on Transit last night at a meeting in the Commodore Hotel. Three of the organizations, with a fourth joining them, also declared they would favor a secret election to determine union representation by units of service.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Senator Robert A Taft, Republican, of Ohio, expressed hope today that a public housing bill could be passed in the Senate before adjournment next month, but he indicated that the measure would run into stiff opposition in the House.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 25 (AP) -- Navy Veteran Bo Wininger of Oklahoma A. and M. and the Northern California junior champion, Bob Harris of San Jose State, tied today for medalist honors in the thirty-six-hole qualifier for the 1947 National Collegiate Athletic Association golf championship.

Surprised in the act of ransacking an apartment at 328 West Eighty-third Street -- just east of Riverside Drive -- a 24-year-old robber was shot to death by Patrolman John Schroeder late yesterday afternoon. The thief was killed with a single bullet after he, had attempted to attack the policeman with a jimmy.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his recent letter to THE TIMES the British delegate to the B'nai B'rith convention in this country expresses his gratitude "to find a very strong condemnation of the incitements to violence emanating from one small section of the American Jewish community."

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 25 -- At a meeting Friday the Hungarian Cabinet Council will deprive the Rev. Bela Varga, Count Gyula Dessewffy and a number of other Small Landholder Deputies and other persons who have fled from the country of their citizenship.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We deeply appreciate your editorial entitled, "Open Session in Korea."

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The taunts, surprisingly good-natured in the circumstances, which were cast at Senator Morse of Oregon for filibustering to delay the vote on the President's veto of the Taft-Hartley bill, after having established himself as the leading crusader against filibustering, had one interesting effect.

New issues of public utility bonds totaling $29,000,000 and industrial debentures and preferred stock of $23,946,700 principal value -- a total of about $53,000,000 -- will be offered to investors today by underwriting managers as follows:

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The first major development bearing upon the working of the new labor relations act will be efforts by unions representing several million workers to seek from corporate employers in the mass production industries a clearcut decision on how they plan to carry on present labor-management contracts.

Because of "terrific production costs," Liberty Magazine will become a monthly publication beginning with the Aug. 2 issue, Paul Hunter, its publisher, announced yesterday. His statement followed rumors that the magazine would cease publication.

Tex McCrary and his wife, Jinx Falkenberg, have been signed to provide the summer replacement program for "Duffy's Tavern." They will start work at 9 P.M. next Wednesday on the NBC network. Their new program's format for the most part will be an elaboration on their daily local show, with guests, interviews and feature stories, etc.

BOSTON, June 25 -- Asserting that some realtors are overplaying their hands" and asking "all that the traffic will bear," Frank H. Whiston, president of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers, told the fortieth convention today that unpleasant effects are likely to follow this course.

Elmer Haalett, city airports director accused of improper or Inconsistent conduct, took the witness stand in his own behalf yesterday at his hearing before Herbert Wechsler, temporary Deputy Commissioner. For nearly three hours he told "my side of the story" of his dealings with airlines and oil companies at La Guardia Field and Idlewild Airport.

PITTSBURGH, June 25 -- Hospitably, not to say royally, entertained by their old friend, Kirby Higbe, and his generous teammates, the Dodgers today completed their most successful western trip in two years.

"BRITISH THOUGHT 1947" is not, in spite of its sedate title, an anthology wholly devoted to serious, philosophical themes. Except in the sense that all writing involves thought -- or is expected to -- the title fails to indicate the variety and richness of the contents. There is, among these thirty-seven, pieces by forty-six contributors (plus an introduction), a good deal of seriously informing material on historical and current topics.

A last-minute meeting yesterday afternoon of high officials of the Bethlehem Steel Company and the Industrial Union of Marine and Ship Building Workers of America, CIO, failed to produce an agreement, and 35,000 workers in ten East Coast shipyards, nine of which are Bethlehem owned, went out on strike at 12:01 A.M. today.

A shiny black Victoria drew up to 191 Livingston Street, Brooklyn, late yesterday afternoon. Its arrival was the signal for the start of ceremonies formally opening the new building of Abraham Straus, Inc., 84-year-old department store.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., June 25 -- After a six month recession, the real estate market in all parts of the state has revived, and nearly all types of property are participating in the upturn, leaders in the industry reported today as they opened the meeting of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- Demand for july corn developed in the late trading on the Board of Trade today and that delivery went to a few high for the second consecutive day. closing at the top at a ain of 3 1/2 cents a bushel. The deerred deliveries went to a new seasonal high and closed with gains of 1/4 to 4 1/2 cents, September leading.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Loren Miller, a Los Angeles lawyer, told the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People tonight that housing was the most explosive social question in America today.

Ten graduates of New York public high schools have been selected as winners of Pulitzer scholarships, it was announced yesterday at the Board of Education. Each award consists of $1,000 in cash, and free tuition if the recipient attends Columbia University.

New Jersey Approves IBRD The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development cleared another marketing hurdle yesterday -- this time in New Jersey. The state's Governor, Alfred E. Driscoll, signed a bill making it legal for banks, insurance companies and certain others in the state to invest in obligations issued or guaranteed by the bank.

LONDON, June 25 -- Interest in the stock markets here today centered almost entirely on the oil section, where the Anglo-Iranian increased dividend brought in a wave of buying. Anglo-Iranian soared to a new high mark, last year's results surpassing the City's most optimistic forecasts.

Eugene Cardinal Tisserant, Bishop of Porto and Santo Rufino, Italy, and spiritual leader of the Eastern Catholics, left La Guardia Field yesterday aboard a Trans-World airliner bound for Rome. He will report to Pope Pius XII on his sixty-seven-day tour of the United States and Canada.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The United States protested in a sharp note to Rumania today the arrest of hundreds of opposition party and non-party persons and the "drastic deprivation" of civil liberties in that country.

BOSTON, June 25 -- A new method of merchandising cod and haddock, developed here by the Atlantic Coast Fisheries Company, should put an end to the old complaint that all housewives utter at least once in their culinary careers: "It's hard to cook fish so it's really delicious."

The American Export liner Marine Shark arrived at pier 97, North River yesterday from Italy with 900 passengers and the body of a fifteen year old boy, Dominico Ferraro, who died of a heart ailment about thirty hours after the vessel left Naples.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- George C. Marshall, Secretary of State, returned to the Capitol today to put up a further fight for more money with which to broadcast The Voice of America to the world.

CLEVELAND, June 25 (U.P.) -- Jimmy Doyle, Los Angeles fighter, died today of injuries caused "largely by blows to the jaw and face" suffered in his welterweight championship fight last night at the Arena with Ray (Sugar) Robinson.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 25 -- At a record "meeting" that began at 9 A. M. and continued for six hours, the Westchester Board of Supervisors posed in action here today for the State Department's motion picture of "Democracy at Work at County Level."

WIMBLEDON, June 25 (AP) -- British Empire stars collaborated to repel some tennis invaders from the United States today as Australia's Billy Sidwell and England's Tony Mottram eliminated Tom Brown of San Francisco and Budge Patty of Los Angeles, seeded fourth, from the men's doubles, 6 -- 2, 2 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4, in the first upset of the Wimbledon championships.

Anaconda Wire and Cable The Anaconda Wire and Cable Company authorized yesterday the payment on July 22 of a dividend of $3 a share on the common stock. In April one of 50 cents was distributed. Last year shareholders received 25 cents each in the first three quarters and a year-end of $2.25 in December.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., June 25 -- Finishing with a pair of 70s, Al Brosch, professional at the Cherry Valley Club in Garden City, retained his Long Island Open championship with a 287, one stroke under par, at the Brookville Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Edward A. O'Neal, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, suggested today that a meat shortage threatened by prospective failure of the corn crop might make restoration of price control necessary.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Austrian Government has agreed that it will permit none of the supplies to be furnished by the United States under the $350,000,000 foreign relief program to be diverted to Austrian armed forces or to Russian or any other occupation troops.

Rabbi Bernard Segal, executive vice president of the Rabbinical Assembly of America, announced yesterday afternoon the opening of six regional branches as the first step to implement the work of the national body in local areas.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 25 -- While battle lines were drawn today in the state constitutional convention over the future of Chancery Court. A. Harry Moore of Jersey City, who served three terms as Governor, advocated that no limitation be imposed upon the eligibility of a chief executive to succeed himself.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 25 -- The United States protest to Rumania over the arrest of opposition party members and others is one of the bluntest notes Washington has sent to any country in the post-war period. It goes far beyond a formal diplomatic protest.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: When THE TIMES sets out to chide Representative Hoffman for his "attempt to find some political or subversive influence at work" in the Freedom Train project it appears to be as little "conversant with the facts" as it claims Mr. Hoffman to have been.

TOKYO, June 25 -- Although the Japanese Government has taken over more than 600,000 acres of land from former owners, not a single acre has been sold to tenant farmers under the rural land reform program, Robert S. Hardie, chief of the Headquarters agricultural economics branch, told the Allied Control Council today.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- With their big guns roaring a farewell broadside into the enemy, the Giants, today ended their second successive Western tour on a triumphant note as they flattened Charlie Grimm's Cubs, 9 to 3, and drew within one game of the idle league-leading Braves.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had granted only conditional approval to the North American Light and Power Company's liquidation plan, on the ground that it did not provide adequate participation for holders of common stock of the company.

An issue of $2,000,000 of school bonds of Prince George's County, Md., will be offered to bidders on July 8, it was announced yesterday. Dated Aug. 1, 1947, the bonds will come due Aug. 1 from 1948 to 1967.

The mid-mark yesterday of the fifty-sixth annual summer furniture market recorded an appreciable upsurge in retailer purchasing but the increased activity came primarily from some small local dealers and many out-of-town buyers.

Lack of an established exchange rate for the yen should not prove a major handicap in opening private trade with Japan, according to Thomas R. Wilson, acting director of the areas branch of the Office of International Trade (OIT).

RYE, N.Y., June 25 -- Vincent L. Banker, 47 years old, a vice president of the Chase National Bank of New York, died in United Hospital, Port Chester, today under circumstances leading to investigations by the police and the medical examiner.
Although fourteen Tammany Assembly district leaders face contests at the primary election on July 29, the leadership of Frank J. Sampson, head of Tammany, is not involved.

JERUSALEM, June 25 -- Sumnarizing twenty-seven years of British mandatory rule in the Holy Land, the Palestine Government told the United Nations Special Committee in a memorandum today that it could not report "any measure of progress in the political reconciliation" of the Arab and Jewish communities.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- A planned transfer of up to 100 United States naval vessels, including a few cruisers, to other American countries for hemispheric security was indicated today.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

BOSTON, June 25 (AP) -- Lefty Hal Newhouser won his seventh game of the season and the Tigers ended a winless streak at ten games today by beating the Red Sox, 4 -- 2, in the opener of a double-header, but the defending American League champions bounced back to take the second contest, 4 -- 3, behind Dave Ferriss, who won his seventh.

CURRAGH, Eire, June 25 (AP) -- Sayajirao won the Irish Derby today and strengthened his chances of carrying the Gaekwar of Baroda's colors into the $100,000 International Gold Cup race at Belmont Park in New York next month.

ST. LOUIS, June 25 -- A home can be made a more satisfying place for all members of a family if they Join in testing ten basic values and them start a five-year improvement program, Mrs. Virginia Cutler, head of the Department of Home Economics of the University of Utah, told the American Home Economics Association today.

NANKING, June 25 -- The Chinese Government today lodged a strong protest through the Russian Charged Affaires here against the continued Soviet refusal to permit the establishment of the Chinese Government's authority in the Dairen and Port Arthur areas of Manchuria.

THIS is the approximate date when the headlines would be proclaiming, "Joe Louis will defend his heavyweight championship for the twenty-fourth time tonight." But there won't be any such headlines today, tomorrow or the next day. The Brown Bomber is currently on a sabbatical leave. Ordinarily, though, he'd be squaring off against Joe Baksi or some such other whipping boy tonight.
There was some let-down in the volume of business on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, but the undertone was very steady and closing prices for futures were 14 to 30 points net higher.
SAVANNAH, Ga., June 25 -- Nine Negro policemen, the first er appointed in Georgia, have been patrolling their beats here for the past six weeks.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Congressional action at this session on Army-Navy unification, as long sought by the Administration, was substantially assured today by the application of tactical pressure by the Republican leadership in the House.
As each of the manikins came into Madame Pauline's showroom, yesterday morning, wearing one of this designer's new large-crowned hats, one could not refrain from thinking how pretty they looked.

PARIS, June 25 -- As the French prepared for the meeting on Friday of the Foreign Ministers of France, Britain and Russia to discuss United States aid for Europe, great curiosity was aroused today by news from the principal capital involved -- Washington.
ROME, June 25 -- L'Osservatore Romano said today that it favored the Marshall plan for European reconstruction.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Secretary of State Marshall said today that it was with the idea of helping the rehabilitation of Italy that Congress had been asked to authorize the turning over of thirty-one American merchant ships to that country.

CINCINNATI, June 25 (AP) -- Hugh Poland's pinch-hit single climaxed a four-run uprising by the Reds in the ninth inning to beat Philadelphia today, 9 to 8, before 4,475 paying fans and 3,378 members of the knothole gang.

The resignation of the first provisional President of the Italian Republic, Enrico de Nicola, is a blow to Premier de Gasperi, who has just succeeded in winning a vote of confidence for his first non-Communist Government. Unless Signer de Nicola is induced to reconsider, the Cabinet assembled with so much effort may be forced to resign and the painful business of recruiting another will begin all over again.

William P. (Bill) Odom, the "sleepless" pilot who flew the Reynolds Bombshell around the world, is going to do it again -- the hard way. His sponsor, Milton Reynolds, Chicago pen maker, announced at a luncheon of the Aviation Writers Association in the Hotel Sheraton yesterday that about Aug. 1 Mr. Odom would fly around the world from north to south, passing over both poles.

PARIS, June 25 (U.P.) -- Iranian Prince Hamid Riza Pahlevi, 15-year-old transatlantic truant, arrived at Orly airport today aboard an Air France Constellation liner from New York and said he wasn't really playing hookey from a Rhode Island school.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -- The promulgation of a set of rules under the Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934, as well as an interpretation of the Trust Indenture Act of 1939, with regard to securities of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development were announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
RYE, N. Y., June 25 -- J. Ellis Knowles of Apawamis, champion five straight years and playing his home course, did just what every one expected of him today.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Proposals to send the voted Republican tax reduction bill back to President Truman before Congress adjourns next month, with the measure's effective date changed to next Jan. 1, won the support of influential Senate Democrats today.

While a partial victory was won in gaining a deferment of final decision on the "broken-time" issue until after the Olympic Games next year, amateur sports leaders who oppose the move to legalize compensation of athletes for time lost from work while competing still face a stern battle to make their views prevail.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- Representatives of the country's railroads today formally rejected demands of seventeen non-operating groups for a pay increase of 20 cents an hour. The railroads' answer on the wage issue came as the roads and unions were negotiating the pay question.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today granted permission to Michigan and Virginia interests to intervene in proceedings before it looking to a change in the relations of the New York Central and the Chesapeake Ohio.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 25 -- The summer scourge of the East -- Japanese beetles -- is due to appear in less than a week. Before the pests return to the ground for winter breeding they are expected to eat $3,000,000 worth of farm produce, gardens and foliage, officials of the chief United States control station for the beetles here said today.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Counsel for James M. Curley, sentenced to serve six to eighteen months for mail fraud, urged the Federal District Court today to suspend the penalty because the Boston Mayor was in "a most serious and precarious physical condition."
Sidney Wood of New York came from behind to gain his place in the quarter-finals of the New York State tennis championship yesterday at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills.

Two years ago today the representatives of fifty nations, assembled in San Francisco, put their signatures to a leather-bound parchment entitled "Charter of the United Nations." Therewith they launched in a world still at war a new international organization dedicated to the maintenance of peace, if necessary by armed force.

MONTREAL, June 25 -- The Central Conference of American Rabbis, meeting here in its fifty-eighth annual convention, went on record today as opposing the Taft-Hartley Labor Law and commended President Truman's veto.

JERUSALEM, June 25 -- A brazen but futile midday attempt was made today to kidnap a Palestine Government liaison officer to the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine. He was knocked unconscious and partly chloroformed before his wife's screams caused the would-be captors to flee.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Soft coal wage negotiations probably will be resumed early next week, if not earlier, according to reliable signs today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 25 -- Twentieth Century-Fox announced today that the screen version of John Klempner's novel, "A Letter to Five Wives," would be done with eight leading stars in the top role. When the story gets on film, however, it will bear the title "A Letter to Four Wives," since one sequence in the book is being deleted, the studio says, to shorten the script.

PURCHASE, N. Y., June 25 -- One exciting match that went twenty holes and the defeat of a former champion featured the second round of match play in the forty-fourth annual women's Metropolitan golf championship over the Century Country Club course here today.
CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

There is strong nonpartisan support in Congress for H. R. 2910. This is the Stratton bill, which would "authorize the United States during an emergency period to undertake its fair share in the resettlement" of the 834,000 DP's in Germany, Austria and Italy -- a share put at 400,000 admissions over the next four years.
DETROIT, June 25 -- More than 32,000 workers in the automotive industry will be laid off, many of them for two weeks, because of a shortage of steel.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 25 -- Ceremonies befitting its possible future significance as the nucleus of a central German government marked the permanent organization of the bizonal economic directorate here today.

A three-alarm fire aboard the American President Lanes' freigher Marine Flier at Pier 9, Jersey City, was brought under control in less than an hour yesterday. The blaze damaged about 400 tons of a 6,000-ton general cargo loaded on the vessel for her scheduled departure tomorrow on a round-the-world voyage.
Deaf-blind Helen Keller arrived here from Chicago yesterday to officiate at the presentation of the Migel Medal at the American Foundation for the Blind, 15 West Sixteenth Street.

A resolution to endorse the Stratton bill was defeated yesterday as delegates to the fifty-seventh annual convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs defied their leaders who recommended the resolution. The count was almost two to one, with 556 voting against the admission into this country of 400,000 displaced persons and 341 voting for their entry.

Evelyn Stiasny, 18-year-old Czechoslovak refugee, received yesterday afternoon a first scholarship prize of $500 from the School Art League at its annual meeting at the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West.
