WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The Treasury said today that a construction laborer won $200,000 gambling but lost trying to beat Uncle Sam out of income tax on it. Aided by an informer, Treasury agents driving against tax evasion got their man, gave him a $160,000 bill for taxes, interest and penalties, and marked him down for criminal prosecution, Secretary John W. Snyder explained.

Armed with pledges of support from the craftsmen of the building trades, a group of leaders in the city's construction industry started a campaign yesterday to stimulate building and dispel the "wait and see" attitude of investors who are delaying construction in hope of big savings.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Fredric March and his wife, Florence Eldridge, led a parade of witnesses for the defense today in the mass trial of sixteen members of an alleged Communist-front organization for contempt of Congress.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- Witnesses from the radio industry testified today that a pending bill would so regulate radio as to violate the "American democratic tradition" of unrestricted discussion.

LONDON, June 25 -- Another day of discussion of the Marshall plan by William L. Clayton, United States Under-Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, and leader of the Labor Government has considerably encouraged the British it was learned tonight.

The nation's production pf crude oil last week averaged 5,114,500 barrels dally, a new peak, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This represented an increase of 1,300 barrels-over the preceding week and made the seventh consecutive week that output had exceeded 5,000,000 barrels.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Nineteen companies, which were said to account for 95 per cent of all the corn derivatives manufactured and sold in this country, were charged today by the Federal Trade Commission with "engaging in a combination and conspiracy to fix and maintain prices, terms and conditions of sale of their products."
Price reductions in three more cuts of meat from their record highs of about ten days ago were reported yesterday by Markets Commissioner Eugene G. Schulz.

We believe that General Eisenhower will make an excellent president of Columbia University. The responsibilities that go with the post are so varied that no one man could be found who would combine all desirable qualities in exactly the right proportions. General Eisenhower has been a student all his life, but he would probably not lay claim to being a scholar except in military matters.

Unable to come to an agreement with the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council on how to resume service on about $90,000,000 of Peruvian Government debt defaulted fifteen years ago, Dr. Jose Barreda Moller, a special financial emissary of the Republic of Peru, announced yesterday that his Government will now deal directly with bondholders on the basis of the offer proposed originally by the law adopted on March 14 by the Peruvian Congress.
The critical shortage of skilled and unskilled seamen continued yesterday to hamper movements of ships in the Port of New York.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 25 An agreement between the United Nations and the United States defining the status of the world organization's East River headquarters district will be signed tomorrow by Secretary General Trygve Lie and Secretary of State George C. Marshall on the second birthday of the United Nations.

MOSCOW, June 25 (AP) -- Pravda said today that the Marshall plan for European recovery would be "doomed to failure" if it were patterned after the Truman Doctrine, and made it plain that the Russians "wanted no part of any United States aid that might be interpreted as infringing on the sovereignty of other countries.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 25 -- With twenty-three yachts of the thirty-six in the New York Yacht Club's ocean race checked in tonight, it was established that David Z. Bailey's sloop Alar cleaned up in the 466-mile contest from Newport, R. I.

BOSTON, June 25 (AP) -- Three Massachusetts psychiatrists told a Federal jury today they believed Douglas Chandler was mentally capable of forming an intent to betray his country, and that he was not suffering from paranoiac delusions when he made "Paul Revere" recordings for the Nazi radio.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Three generations of the Theodore Roosevelt family called President Truman, today and presented him with a set of 32 commemorative poster stamps showing scenes from the life of the late Brig. Gen. Theodore Roosevelt Jr. and his family.

PARIS, June 25 -- A near-crisis in the Cabinet was averted today when the National Assembly decided to postpone the conclusion of the debate begun today on the Government's economic policy and to hold its showdown on internal affairs next week.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board said today that no indication of mechanical malfunctions had been found in the engines or controls of the United Airlines plane that crashed in attempting to take off at New York's La Guardia Field on May 29.

LONDON, June 25 -- The British Government is prepared to pay $600,000 to help underwrite deficits of the British Export Trade Research Organization, it was reported in foreign trade circles here today. The reports followed an address by Sir Stafford Cripps, president if the Government's Board of Trade, at the annual BETRO luncheon.

Assets of the savings and loan associations in New York State reached a new high record of $906,627,342 on May 31, it was announced yesterday by Zebulon V. Woodard, executive vice president of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations.

There was no catching Saggy in the Wakefield Stakes at Empire City at Jamaica yesterday. Mrs. Stanley Sagner's colt flashed to the front soon after the start and stepped six furlongs over a sloppy track in an estimable 1:11 3/5 to win with not a bit of trouble.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- South Korea will be opened to foreign trade in a limited degree on July 15, the State, War and Navy Departments announced today.

Mrs. Genevieve Rivera, whose conviction for contributing to the delinquency of her 14-year-old son was upset by the Appellate Division Tuesday, had already been committed to the New York State Hospital for the Criminally Insane before the decision was announced, it was learned yesterday at the offices of the City Department of Correction.

TEL AVIV, Palestine, June 25 -- With the terrorist underground providing a spectacular propaganda sideshow, the world's only all-Jewish city today presented the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine with striking contrast to its sluggish twin city, the Arab municipality of Jaffa, which the committee visited yesterday.
Four children met their father yesterday after a separation of eleven years and they could barely understand the words of his fervent welcome.

Warning that the 1947 ratio of $16,000,000,000 in exports against imports of $8,000,000,000 will prove "dangerously unsound" for this country in the long run, Earl I. McClintock, vice president of Sterling Drug, Inc., yesterday urged both governmental and private action to increase imports to furnish dollars to pay for exports.

CLEVELAND, June 25 -- The convention of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, voted unanimously today to carry on an unremitting fight against Communists "until American public life and the American labor movement are completely rid of their influence."

Alice Fischer, founder and honorary president of the Twelfth Night Club, who acted in many Broadway shows during the half centtiry ending in 1935, died yesterday at her residence, 162 West Fifty-fourth Street, at the age of 78.

Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, speaking last night at the Park Central Hotel at a conference of the Jewish Labor Committee and the Workmen's Circle, asserted that Palestine must be kept open "to free and untrammeled immigration."

Mayor O'Dwyer reported last night that contracts have been let for the demolition of buildings now within the boundaries of the United Nations site on Manhattan's East Side. The work will begin on July 1, he said.

The United States is leading in some phases of jet aircraft development, lagging in others and our guided missile development is probably about abreast of the German optimum at the end of the war two years ago.

Fall Clothing Deliveries Slow Affected by both the linings shortage and slow deliveries by the mills, initial deliveries on men's fall clothing will probably be slow. Vacations of clothing workers in this market next month will also be a factor.

Two fines exceeding $11,000, levied against Local 807 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, for "wildcat" strikes were upheld unanimously by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in a decision announced yesterday.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 25 -- The American Optometric Association urged today that motor vehicle drivers be required by state law to pass adequate visual examinations periodically.
ROME, June 25 -- A Presidential crisis was opened today when Provisional President Enrico de Nicola tendered his resignation to the President of the Constituent Assembly, Umberto Terracini.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- The Cudahy Packing Company has announced that effective immediately one general advertising department will handle all matters pertaining to advertising for the entire company. L. G. Tremblay heads the new department, with the title of general advertising manager.

Go to a meadow on a beautiful day in early summer and listen to the music. Beneath the urgency of a sun circling close to the horizon's pole the grasses reach upward toward maturity. Flocks of white clouds wander casually along the broad sky trails overhead.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -- Individuals' savings in liquid form dropped to $1,400,000,000 during the first quarter of 1947, the lowest since 1940 and less than half that of the last quarter in 1946, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
SEOUL, Korea, June 25 -- Conferences between the joint American-Russian commission and representatives of Korean democratic parties and organizations opened formally today.

Cornelius A. Hall, Borough President of Richmond, cut through red tape yesterday to permit a Staten Island couple with six small children ranging in age from 6 months to 9 years, who had been evicted from their home, to move into three rooms on the top floor of the old Village Hall on Lafayette Avenue, New Brighton.

LONDON, June 25 -- A development corporation with capital of u100,000,000 is to be set up by Britain to help in the economic development of the colonies, Arthur Creech Jones, Colonial Secretary, revealed in the House of Commons today.
A demonstration of the supermodern communications system that is being devised for the future world capital in mid-Manhattan, was presented yesterday by United Nations technical experts.

NEW DELHI, India, June 25 (AP) -- Indian interests have purchased British business undertakings in deals involving some u20,000,000 ($80,000,000) during the past twelve months, according to the British-owned newspaper, The Statesman.
Savings of $25,000,000 in interest payment and $4,640,000 in subsidies were listed yesterday by the New York City Housing Authority in its thirteenth annual report.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Secretary of the Treasury Snyder said today that Secretary of State Marshall's European recovery proposals were not to be construed as an offer of unlimited aid from the United States or as an invitation to European countries to tell this country "what they need or want."
Write Don't Wire After that overridden veto it is still true that if a citizen feels strongly on an issue up in Washington he should write to his Congressman, as the familiar reminder says.

MADRID, June 23 (Delayed) -- Local authorities have already been told privately that returns in the July 6 referendum should be made to show 70 to 75 per cent favorable to the succession law, an opposition source charged.

L. Goldstein, Attorney General, announced today that he has asked the Federal Power Commission to deny an application by the Electric Power Company of New Jersey, Inc., for a license to build a private power project along the Delaware River between New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 -- A proposal that the United Nations Economic Committee for Europe prepare this summer a "comprehensive and practical plan for the gradual solution of the Continent's economic difficulties through self-help and with the assistance of the United States" was made tonight by Adrian Pelt of the Netherlands, assistant Secretary General of the United Nations.

PARIS, June 25 -- The legal punishment of collaborators has dragged on so slowly that political prisoners still detained, many after three years or more, have quadrupled the prison population of France, according to Gerard Boutelleau in an article in the responsible Popular Republican weekly Carrefour today.

The organizing of an East Harlem Council of Churches by Protestants to coordinate their religious activities and increase emphasis on social services has been recommended in a survey of East Harlem by the Pathfinding Service for the Churches of the New York City Mission Society, made public yesterday.

PEIPING, June 24 (Delayed) -- The news that President Chiang Kai-shek will return shortly to Mukden for his second personal inspection of the critical Manchurian war front within three weeks was reported here today in both official and newspaper circles.

Isaa Cohen. builder, has purchase the vacant industrial plot, 100 by 150 feet, at the northwest corner of Oak Point and Bryant Avenue, in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx, from Adeline Bell. The new owner plans to develop the site in the near future.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The House approved today a bill putting the United States into the International Refugee Organization. The bill authorizes a contribution of 573,500,000. The vote was 124 to 43.
Hugh E. Potts has sold his colonial dwelling, containing eight rooms and three baths, on Halls Lane in the Milton Point section of Rye, N.Y., to Philip E. Beach. Edward V. Siedle was the broker.

BOSTON, Mass., June 26 -- The Massachusetts Legislature voted tonight to make City Clerk John B. Hynes acting Mayor of Boston, while Mayor James M. Curley is serving a term for mail fraud. Curley may resume the position when he is released.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., June 26 -- The modified rent-control bill recently passed by Congress and now before President Truman for signature, "undoubtedly will act as a tremendous stimulant" to the construction of new rental housing throughout the country, in the opinion of Alexander Summer of Teaneck, N.J., head of the realtors' Washington committee.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Dr. W.E.B. Du Bois, editor and educator and one of the founders of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, told 1,000 delegates this morning that socialism and the United Nations were the only hope for the backward races of the world.

Senator Gabriel Ramos Millan of Mexico, chairman of the newly appointed Mexican Corn Commission, and members of the Government body established by President Miguel Aleman to end the country's deficit in corn, its most important staple, arrived here yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- A tentative date of July 8 has been set for the National Railway Mediation Board to begin proceedings in Chicago on the current wage dispute between the railroads and seventeen nonoperating unions. Direct negotiations have ended without agreement.

The Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday sold $75,000,000 of forty-year debentures to underwriters at an interest cost of about 2.78 per cent. In about an hour the whole new issue was resold to institutional and other investors at a price of $102.80 for 2 7/8 s, a yield of about 2.76 per cent to maturity.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Friends of Philip B. Perlman of Maryland, both on the Republican and Democratic sides of the fence, sought today to spur the Senate Judiciary Committee to rush a favorable report on his nomination as Solicitor General.

WASHINGTON. June 26 -- George Sylvester Viereck. the Nazi propagandist, was paroled from his prison sentence, three weeks or a month ago, his counsel. Col. O. R. McGuire said tonight. Eighteen months of his term remained to be served, it was estimated.
TULSA, Okla., June 26 -- Two wholly owned subsidiaries of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana announced today completion of banking arrangements to borrow $105,000,000.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Federal District Judge Michael L. Igoe today ratified the senior bondholders' appointments of four reorganization managers for the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad, and announced that William E. Fay, Illinois racing commissioner, was the court's appointee to the five-man reorganization board.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: According to the report published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 16. Henry A. Wallace, at his press conference in Washington on June 15, speaking of the possibilities of war, stated: "There are certain very extremist groups in eastern Europe -- take the nationalist Serbs, for example -- which might very well want to cause a war between the United States and Russia."
When the war damage insurance program closes its books on Monday it will have assets of $250,000,000 derived from accumulated premiums, according to an accounting made public yesterday.

A set of standards for determining satisfactory teaching service, and a recommendation that the present in-service program of the Board of Education be largely retained to determine "promotional increments" as required by the amended State Education Law, wag made public yesterday by Superintendent of Schools John E. Wade.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent during the week ended June 21, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, as agricultural prices rose slightly. Non-agricultural prices remained unchanged on the average.

CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) -- Ernie Bonham, the former Yankee, today hurled his second straight shut-out since being elevated to a starting role by Manager Billy Herman last Friday and led the Pittsburgh Pirates to an 8-0 triumph over the Chicago Cubs.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission dismissed today stop-order proceedings against the Tucker Corporation, recently organized Chicago automobile concern, clearing the way for its proposed sale of 4,000,000 shares of class A common stock at $5 a share.

BERLIN, June 26 -- United States Military Government officials here have been officially advised by Washington authorities that they may consider Germany as eligible for aid under the Marshall plan, it was learned today. The immediate reaction to this information was the drafting of a confidential brief in which the sore problem of the economic unification of Germany and a "softening" of the Russian reparations stand were discussed.

Naval personnel from seaman third class to admiral will stand at attention today in Bayonne, N.J., for one of the most somber ceremonies of naval procedure -- the decommissioning of a veteran warship.
B.C. Price has been named vice president in charge of manufacturing of the Swan-Finch Oil Corporation. Walter W. Brey, controller, has been named treasurer.

"Lest We Forget -- the American Dream," a transcribed series of dramas designed to combat the problems of prejudice and discrimination, will make its bow at 9:15 P.M. next Tuesday over WNEW. The series is sponsored by the Institute for Democratic Education, which is offering the programs free of charge to stations throughout the country.

In the battle for first place waged before 33,102 alternately pained and pleased Flatbush fans under the Ebbets Field lights last night, the Dodgers defeated the Braves, 8 -- 6, and moved to the top of the National League, a half game ahead of Boston.

Scoring five runs in the ninth and one in the tenth, Lafayette captured the Public High Schools Athletic League city baseball title yesterday with a 10-9 triumph over Grover Cleveland, Queens titleholders, at Brooklyn College Field.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 26 -- County Executive J. Russel Sprague warned residents of Nassau today that they "must be made aware of an approaching critical condition" -- the threat of contamination of the county's underground drinking water by overflowing cesspools, with consequent menace to health.

ST. LOUIS, June 26 (AP) -- Ewell Blackwell, sensational young righthander of the Cincinnati Reds, chalked up his tenth straight victory tonight when he checked the St. Louis Cardinals with 8 hits and bested the veteran southpaw Harry Brecheen, who was pounded for thirteen blows.

NANKING, June 26 -- Chen Chitien, Minister of Economic Affairs, added a non-Kuomintang voice to the appeals for American assistance today. In an interview, Mr. Chen, a leader of the Young China party, painted a black picture of the economic and military future of the Government and pleaded for prompt, large-scale aid from the United States.
The exodus to camps for underprivileged oldsters and youngsters who would have no summer vacations away from town without the help of various organizations began in earnest yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's veto today of the wool bill: To the Senate of the United States: I return herewith, without my approval, S. 814 entitled "The Wool Act of 1947."
Joseph and George The critics say about Joseph Stalin in the new Soviet film that he takes on the same guise and proportions as George Washington in the eyes of the American schoolboy.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The legend is that Aristides was exiled from Athens because people got tired of hearing him called "The Just," though cautious historians attribute his ostracism to the fact that his policy of keeping Athens a land power was rejected in favor of the naval policy of Themistooles.

Today is definitely not one of those times when the housewife will return from the week-end marketing with the triumphant feeling that thanks to a few bargains she has spent less money than she planned to.
WIMBLEDON, June 26 (U.P.) -- four Americans and four Australians blazed into the round of 6 in the All-England tennis singles championships today.

Council Backs Public Causes Business is donating annually a hundred millions dollars worth of advertising space and time to focus public attention on public problems, the Advertising Council's fifth annual report, entitled "Business Steps Up Its Candle Power," stated yesterday.

CLEVELAND, June 26 -- Senator Robert F. Wagner, New York Democrat, advised organized labor today that the best way to offset the impact of the Taft-Hartley Labor Relations Act was to elect President Truman and a Democratic Congress next year.

NEWARK, N.J., June 26 -- Three thousand dollars is the price set by Bamberger's decorating department for furnishing a five-room house in the Ivy Hill housing development here. The store has decorated two model units in one of the houses at Norman Road and Irvington Avenue that will be opened officially to the public on Sunday.

PARIS, June 26 -- The Foreign Ministers of Britain, the Soviet Union and France will meet at 4 o'clock tomorrow afternoon to discuss what lead, if any, they will take together toward organizing a collective European response to the Marshall suggestion of further United States economic aid for this Continent.

NANKING, June 26 (U.P.) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek called an urgent meeting of top Government advisers today. A source close to the Generalissimo said China was framing a new policy, calling for a stronger stand against the Soviet Union and Chinese Communists.

PITTSBURGH, June 26 -- A fullscale test by John L. Lewis of the Taft-Hartley labor law appeared to be shaping up as the number of miners idle in a four-day-old strike protesting the law mounted to 250,000 tonight.

Another substantial portion of Tuesday's losses was recovered yesterday by the stock market, with volume and price appreciation approximately the same as in Wednesday's session. Most of the key issues closed below the best levels of the day, a few scattered stocks made major gains and the composite rate scored a rally of 0.55 point.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Weekly sales of department stores were up 3 per cent for the week ended on June 21, as compared with the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Percentage changes from like periods of a year ago are indicated in the following table:

The huge gathering present to hear Marian Anderson, who appeared as soloist with the Philharmonic -Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Leonard Bernstein, last night at the Lewisohn Stadium, attested to her unwaning popularity with the public.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 26 -- The Marshall plan for aid to Europe found a champion in the Hungarian Parliament today in Bela Zsedenyi, an independent Deputy. Provided that the Soviet Union collaborates, he said, the plan will enable Hungary to stagger up from the crushing burdens of her past.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 -- Members of the National Association of Retail Grocers were told today by Cecil B. DeMille, movie producer, that labor union "dictators" would take over their businesses "unless you act in unity and strength to strip them of their control of the right to work."

More than two years ago Jean Dalrymple announced her intention of reviving Marc Connelly's famous play, "The Green Pastures," with Mr. Connelly attending to the direction. She hasn't forgotten about it. Yesterday Max Jelin, the new lessee of the International, admitted he had a verbal understanding with her to open the attraction there in September, perhaps on Sept. 17.

Diplomacy rather than rollingpin tactics for handling recalcitrant husbands was advocated yesterday by brides and fiancees who were guests at a "Guide for Brides Day" held jointly by Macy's and Kenyon and Eckhart, Inc., advertising agency.

CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 7,000 head, total 10,000; market generally steady to 25 cents lower; most decline on hogs over 280 pounds and on sows over 400 pounds; trade fairly active on barrows

JERUSALEM, June 26 -- A petition filed today in the Supreme Court challenged the right of the Jewish Agency for Palestine to import "gift" dollars from the United States and thus create a monopoly for Jewish merchants.
LONDON, June 26 -- The best sections in a generally dull stock market here today were the oils and Orange Free State gold groups.

ATHENS, June 26 -- Vice Premier Constantin Tsaldaris denied in an interview today that Greece had "sanctioned discrimination against the Slav minority" as charged in the United Nations Balkan inquiry commission's findings.

RYE, N.Y., June 26 -- Col. Martin S. Lindgrove of Baltusrol, one of five who met Ellis Knowles of Apawamis for the United States Seniors Golf Association championship in an unprecedented sixway play-off last year and finished second, hammered at the door again today with a 37, 36 -- 73 for his first round as the second section of 211 players began the 36-hole trek at Apawamis.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Emil Rieve, speaking for the Congress of Industrial Organizations, told the Joint Congressional Commitee on the Economic Report today that the committee's leaders should resign if it "continues willfully to violate both the spirit and Letter of the law."

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The House Appropriations Committee swung its economy axe at the legislative establishment today, recommending a 27.7 per cent cut in funds for the fiscal year starting July 1.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 (AP) -- The sale for $74,954,909 of the Pullman Company to a group of fifty-seven United States railroads which will operate their own sleepingcar service was approved today by the United States District Court.

The Regional Plan Associations, which had the cooperation of New Jersey authorities in drafting over two years a long-term program for the integration and development of metropolitan airports, announced yesterday that Newark's present stand was a threat to the area's position as the world center of air commerce.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Washington defeated the Boston Red Sox, 7 -- 3, tonight before a crowd of 18,001, clustering four runs off Earl Johnson in the seventh inning to give Bobo Newsom his fourth victory of the season against six defeats.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- A Collective bargaining election found to have been conducted in an atmosphere of community intimidation was set aside today by the National Labor Relations Board and a new one ordered.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (U.P.) -- Warning of a "dangerous" lag in American development of guided missiles that might mean defeat in another war, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Chief of Naval Operations, asked Congress today to authorize $34,000,000 for a naval test range at Point Mugu, Calif.

The countries of the Western Hemisphere should contribute to the promotion of Western civilization by welcoming more refugees from Europe Dr. Julio Ortega Frier. Ambassador of the Dominican Republic to the United States, declared yesterday.
Dr. Herbert Temple Wikle of 200 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, surgeon and gastroenterologist, died yesterday in the Brooklyn Hospital at the age of 53. He had an office at 195 Hicks Street.

GREENSBORO, N.C., June 26 (AP) -- Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis, the defending champion, and two brilliant amateurs -- Miss Louise Suggs of Lithia Springs, Ga., two-time Western open queen, and Miss Polly Riley of Fort Worth, Tex., Trans-Mississippi champion -- set the pace with two-under par 74 cards as play opened here today in the $7,500 women's open golf championship.

A Yale undergraduate, back on the tennis courts after three years' service in the Army, eliminated one of the top favorites in the New York State championship yesterday at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills.

A program to provide for three juvenile juror to act as court advisers in cases involving juvenile delinquents was announced yesterday by Magistrate Anna M. Kross of New York City's Home Term Court. Speaking at the annual convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, she said she had submitted the plan to the New York State Board of Magistrates.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Federal District Judge Elwyn R. Shaw today dismissed an amended and supplemental complaint by Cargill, Inc., of Minneapolis, cash grain dealers, seeking treble damages of more than $10,000,000 against the Chicago Board of Trade and its officers.

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 26 -- Three Jerseyites and one Long Islander reached the semi-final round of the forty-fourth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Championship at the Century Country Club course today.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- A new move to cut income taxes by $4,000,000,000, effective Jan. 1, picked up more support of Capitol Hill today. President Truman declined to say whether he would veto it. Asked at a news conference for his reaction to the move he said he would take care of that development if such a bill reached him.

Complaint that instructors at Brooklyn College have been carrying a heavier teaching load than those at New York's three other municipal colleges was made yesterday by Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of the college, in a report sent to Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education.

Roger N. Baldwin, director of the American Civil Liberties Union, back home from a threemonth inspection trip of Japan and Korea, brought encouraging word yesterday of the development of democracy in the former but expressed pessimism over the future of the latter.

Plans to raise an endowment of $850,000 for the American Press Institute of the School of Journalism of Columbia University were announced yesterday by Grove Patterson, editor-in-chief of the Toledo Blade and chairman of the advisory board of the institute.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The complete integration of the effort of the aviation services of North and South America is essential to the hemisphere's peace and security, Lieut. Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, deputy commander of the Army Air Forces, told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today.

Possibly marking the end of the seasonal decline in such borrowings, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System last week rose $18,000,000, it was disclosed yesterday.

The Conservation Department press department sounded a bit breathless yesterday when it announced that Seneca Lake was witnessing the best trout fishing in the memory of man. More and bigger fish were coming out of the Central New York waterway than ever before, was the report.

MOSCOW, June 26 (AP) -- The Soviet Union announced in a decree today that large groups of 18- and 19-year-old youths previously subject to military service might be called to dig coal and for training and other service in the industrial machine.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- President Truman said today he personally contemplated no action at this time in the soft coal strikes and deadlocked wage negotiations but that the Attorney General was studying the case.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 26 (AP) -- Pre-tournament favorites led a steady, true-to-form parade into the second round of match play in the National Collegiate Athletic Association golf championship today. The co-medalists, Francis (Bo) Wininger of Oklahoma A. and M. and Bob Harris of San Jose (Calif.) State scored impressive victories and Charley Coe of Oklahoma, No. 1 choice among the insiders, beat Junius Hebert of Louisiana State, 7 and 6.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- President Truman today vetoed the Wool Price-Support Bill on the ground that its tariff provisions would have "adverse effects" on the country's international relations and undermine "our leadership in world affairs."

CLEVERLAND, June 26 (U.P.) -- Coroner Samuel Gerber today absolved Ray (Sugar) Robinson, world welterweight champion, of all blame in the death of Jimmy Doyle, his opponent in a title fight here Tuesday night.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- During the week ended June 25 member bank reserve balances decreased $160,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
The city asked yesterday that teeth be put into the proposed law to license garages and parking lots by including a price-fixing clause.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Not as a matter of Marxian piety but for the sake of historical accuracy, I hope I may be permitted to enter a protest against the statement, in your issue of June 10, that the International Working Men's Association was "wrecked by Marx' ambition for personal power."

Billy Fox, who has resumed the string of knock-out triumphs that was interrupted by his unsuccessful bid for Light Heavyweight Champion Gus Lesnevich's title last February, will test his punching prowess against Artie Levine in a ten-round contest at Madison Square Garden tonight.

CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) -- Voting in 193 centers to determine the starting line-up for the fourteen annual All-Star game ended midnight tonight with Joe DiMaggio, New York Yankees, and En Slaughter, St. Louis Cardinal running ahead of all opposition the latest count.

PARIS, June 26 -- In the breathing spell permitted by the postponement of the Cabinet's difficulties, Premier Paul Ramadier and his Cabinet concentrated today on an effort to settle the labor troubles that continued to dominate the political situation.

JOGJAKARTA, Java, Friday June 27 (AP) -- President Soeka assumed full powers over the in donesian Republican Government just before dawn today after accepting the resignation of Premier Sutan Sjahrir.
The house flag of the SoconyVacuum Oil Company fleet was raised yesterday on the mainmast of the tanker Tascalusa, which served the Navy as an oiler in the Pacific during the war.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- President Truman appealed today to labor and management "to exercise patience and moderation in accommodating themselves to the changes made necessary by the (Labor Relations) Act," which was passed over his veto on Monday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -- Time was when the Yankees relished a visit to Shibe Park and a chance to fatten up at the expense of the once-lowly Athletics. It's different now. The Mackmen, now a confident outfit possessing the wherewithal to make trouble for anyone, did precisely that today, inflicting a 4-2 setback on the league-leading New Yorkers.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 26 -- Secretary of State Marshall chose the second birthday of the United Nations to say flatly today that all United States foreign policy was aimed at strengthening the world organization -- the "first hope" of all peoples.

CLEVELAND, June 26 (AP) -- Al Gettel hurled the Cleveland Indians into undisputed possession of fourth place tonight, Setting the Chicago White Sox down with four hits as the Tribe won, 5 to 1. Jim Hegan's sixth-inning home run following Ken Keltner's single was the big blow of the Indians' offensive.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Representatives of key organizations in the newspaper, magazine, motion picture, radio and book publishing fields received assurance from President Truman today that he believed a free press and free speech must be preserved.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 26 (U.P.) -- Eric Johnston today attacked Henry A. Wallace for planting bad misconceptions and bad advice concerning the United States and world affairs during "his grand tours." He said they damaged the moral standing of the United States and hurt the cause of peace and recovery.

The transcript of testimony heard by a New York County grand jury that has been investigating since last February alleged underworld control of professional prizefighting was sent yesterday to the State Athletic Commission with a recommendation for "prompt and vigorous action."

ST. LOUIS, June 26 -- The rampaging Mississippi and Missouri Rivers and their swollen tributaries continued to sweep a wide path of death and destruction today as the toll of flood refugees soared to the highest number since 1937.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Bernard M. Baruch urged today enactment of a sixteen-point, work-or-fight mobilization program which he said would enable this country to cope with an emergency without repeating the preparedness errors of the two World Wars.
HOBOKEN, N.J., June 27 -- Ground was broken today for the construction of two buildings to complete a U-shaped Science Center at Stevena Institute of Technology.

Eighteen new school buildings will be in the "above ground" stage of construction by Jan. 1 and twenty-five old buildings will be rehabilitated when the new school term opens in the fall, the Board of Estimate was told yesterday by Nathaniel Kaplan, secretary of the Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- President Truman gave the Marshall plan for European recovery his unqualified endorsement today and said he was completely in agreement with Secretary of State George C. Marshall and Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder on the program.

For the first time since Reconstruction days a white man in Georgia imperiling the public peace and safety may now be arrested by a Negro policeman. This is not the intent of the new arrangement by which nine Negroes have been added to the police force of Savannah.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced last night that he had ordered John M. Murtagh, Investigation Commissioner, to look into the circumstances surrounding the purchase by private corporations of eleven parcels of property later condemned for the state-sponsored Lillian Wald Houses project on the lower East Side of Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- James M. Curley, Mayor of Boston, failed today to obtain suspension of his sentence of six to eighteen months for mail fraud and went this afternoon to the Federal Correctional Institution at Danbury, Conn.

The Board or Education approved unanimously yesterday the appointment of four new assistant superintendents for three-year probationary periods beginning next Sept. 3. Their salaries will be $11,500 a year each.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Corn futures on the Board of Trade were on the upgrade early today, advancing 1 to 2 cents a bushel, with July selling at $2.03 1/2, a peak for the third consecutive day, and the distant months went into new seasonal ground.
The incredible dual career of Gus Fusaro as an assistant elevator starter and big-time stock market operator came to an end yesterday.

Players of odds-on favorites had no fun in the Empire City-at-Jamaica proceedings yesterday, two in succession biting the dust. The second was Mrs. W. Plunket Stewart's Rytina in the $6,000 added Cherryola Handicap.

NIR AM, Palestine, June 26 -- Palestine's Zionists showed the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine today what they would do with the Negev, the parched and nearly desolate southern quarter of the country, if they were allowed to colonize it and make it part of a Jewish state.
A buyers' market in textile merchandise does not exist today and is not likely to prevail for months to come, Seymour Phillips, president of the Phillips-Jones Corporation, said yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 26 -- Despite a renewed pledge of support from the United States, the United Nations celebrated its second anniversary today and fears that the struggle for power among the Big Five and particularly between Washington and Moscow might make it impossible to carry out the aspirations for lasting peace that were written into the Charter at San Francisco.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 26 -- The creation of a United Nations oil authority to administer the world's oil resources will be considered by the Economic and Social Council at its fifth session next month it was learned today.

ROME, June 26 -- Senora Maria Eva Duarte de Person, wife of the Argentine President, arrived in Rome by air from Barcelona, Spain, this evening. She was warmly welcomed at the airport by a crowd of about 1,500 persons, mostly Italian officials and members of the Argentine colony in Rome.

President Franklin D. Roosevelt in the Slimmer of 1939 told James A. Farley, then Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, that he would not run for a third term, Mr. Farley asserts in the third of his series on "Why I Broke With Roosevelt" in this week's issue of Collier's.

The Seafarers International Union, AFL, reopened negotiations yesterday with Atlantic and Gulf steamship operators, submitting contract demands including a 5 per cent wage increase and two weeks a year vacation with pay.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Congress was urged today to extend its present session to deal with legislation for universal military training by the Citizens Emergency Committee for Universal Military Training. Formation of the group was announced today.

RYE, N.Y., June 26 -- The fist fight that occurred at the Shenorock Shore Club here between two vice presidents of the Chase National Bank of New York was described by club employes today when Dr. Amos O. Squire, Westchester County Medical Examiner, opened an inquest at police headquarters into the death of Vincent L. Banker, one of the participants.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 26 -- The United States repeated its insistence today that international atomic control must be set up through just one treaty.

President Truman has wisely and properly vetoed the House-amended wool bill, which would have empowered, and morally obligated, the President to raise wool tariffs or fix wool import quotas if foreign wool imports threatened to interfere with the privileged position of a small minority of American wool producers.

In policy meetings held here this week by individual manufacturers of metal products, revisions in price and distribution plans to include "downward escalator clauses," were stressed, spokesmen revealed here yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- The foreign loans and investments made by the United States must be serviced and repaid if the country is to have a strong export program, William S. Swingle, president of the National Foreign Trade Council of New York said today.

LONDON, June 26 -- A sharp warning that propaganda aimed at fostering the belief in the certainty of war must cease if any plan for Europe's economic reconstruction is to be successful, was sounded here today by Lewis W. Douglas.
Dr. John Leonard Kantor of 295 Central Park West and Westport, Conn., a leading gastroenterologist of this city, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. His age was 57.

The Park Association of New York City has asked Park Commissioner Robert Moses to hold a public hearing on his recent proposal as City Construction Coordinator, for a general-purpose roadway through Van Cortlandt Park as a one-mile link in the $30,000,000 Major Deegan Expressway project in the Bronx.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 26 -- Eddie Cantor, who has starred in many pictures himself, is now about to become the subject of a screen play in which he will not appear. Jack L. Warner of Warner Brothers today said he had just closed a deal with Cantor whereby the studio will produce "The Life Story of Eddie Cantor."

THE East-West competitions have ended until after the All Star game and therefore it seems time for one of those periodic audits of the baseball account books. The American League race has developed into a two-team affair between the Yankees and the Red Sox because the Tigers have been walking on banana skins for the past fortnight.

CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) -- Sammy Snead, the Hot Springs, Va., hotand-cold campaigner, sizzled today with an eight-under-par 63 to pace a seventy-six-player field which riddled the course in the opening 18-hole round of the $15,900 Chicago Victory National golf tourney.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong yesterday and closed 25 to 63 points net higher.

The Liberal party will help to contest the constitutionality of certain provisions of the TaftHartley Labor Act and will campaign for its "rectification" by democratic methods but is opposed to the use of the strike as a political weapon, Adolf A. Berle Jr., state chairman, announced yesterday after adoption of a party policy by the state executive committee.

In the second successive day of defiance of their leaders, delegates to the fifty-sixth annual convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs defeated yesterday a resolution urging the continuance of "an equitable rent-control program."

Ferdinand Eberstadt a prominent Republican with a long record of wartime service in the Government, said yesterday that members of his party in Congress may be open for criticism for failure to debate certain aspects of this nation's foreign policy.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 26 -- The man who once said, "If I am elected President of Chile, I'll be the ambassador for Brazil in my country," arrived here today in the person of Chilean President Gabriel Gonzalez Videla.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Senator Robert A. Taft today lessened prospects for the enactment of universal military training legislation at this session of Congress.

Since murder mysteries nave been more superfluous than usual this season, "Laura," which was put on at the Cort last evening, deserves a nod or two on a comparative basis. For Otto Kruger is giving a most accomplished performance in a part that a mediocre actor would make unbearable.

The output of chemicals by members of the United States chemical industry is still insufficient to supply industrial requirements in spite of continued highlevel operations, L.L. Horch, regional director, the United States Department of Commerce, reported in a statement released for today, on the basis of the June chemical industry report of the department.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 26 -- In the face of reportedly growing sentiment within the executive committee to lift all restrictions on the succession to office of New Jersey Governors, Dr. Charles R. Erdman Jr. of Princeton called today upon the constitutional convention to prohibit reelection.

The uneasy truce between the Board of Transportation and the Transport Workers Union, CIO, in their war over labor relations on the municipal transit lines faced disruption yesterday when the board directed the dismissal of two union members who took part in the recent "book of rules" slowdown on the subway lines and ordered two others suspended for thirty days and placed on probation for six months.

MADRID, June 26 -- Spain is up against a dollar crisis. It has been widely rumored in business circles that drastic measures are about to be taken because supplies of dollars and sterling are almost exhausted.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 (AP) -- The United Light and Railways Company today withdrew the plans it had submitted to the Securities and Exchange Commission providing for dissolution of American Light and Traction Company and proposed the continuation of American Light as parent of an integrated gas system.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 26 -- Although consultation through the International Emergency Food Council has resulted in a more equitable distribution of food during the last year, there is a greater disparity in nutrition among countries of the world than before the war, Dr. Hazel K. Stiebeling told pie closing session of the American Home Economics Association's annual convention today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 26 -- The Greek Government today filed formal charges of aggression against Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Albania and appealed to the United Nations Security Council to use its full powers to stop the "breach of peace" in the Balkans.

BOSTON, June 26 -- Owners of urban real estate stand to gain more than any section of the business community from the industrial exploitation of atomic energy, Arthur C. Babson, vice president of Babson's Reports, told the fortieth convention of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers at their closing luncheon today.

United States Industrial Chemicals, Inc., and its subsidiaries had record net sales of $69,706,149 in the fiscal year ended with last March, an increase of 45 per cent over the $48,182,081 volume, the year before, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, June 26 -- The strike of St. Louis street car and bus operators, in effect two weeks and one of the costliest labor disputes in the city's history, ended today when the union agreed to accept a compromise proposal advanced by Mayor Aloys P. Kaufmann.

The Office of Rent Control has granted 6,664 rent increases in the last four months in this five-state region without giving tenants an opportunity to oppose the landlords' petitions, it was learned yesterday.

PARIS. June 26 -- Col. Dieudonne Costes who with Maurice Bellonte made the first transatlantic flight from Paris to New York in 1930, was arrested here today by Surete agents in connection with charges of relations with the enemy.

Fourteen colors for women's shoes have been adopted for the 1948 spring and summer seasons by the joint committee of the Tanners' Council of America, National Shoe Manufacturers Association and the National Shoe Retailers Association, it was announced yesterday by the Textile Color Card Association.

The trial of I. James Brody, former Deputy Commissioner of Marine and Aviation; James V. Auditore, "millionaire stevedore," and Albert Gross, former business associate of Auditore, on charges of conspiracy and accepting unlawful fees was set yesterday for July 14.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended June 21, 1947, totaled 901,296 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 6,004 cars, or 0.7 per cent more than in the preceding week, 42,873 cars, or 5.0 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 24,593 cars, or 2.8 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Married and single veterans attending City College have living expenses far in excess of allotments received under the GI Bill of Rights and many are drawing on savings and cashing in war bonds to meet the deficit, it was reported yesterday by the college's Social Research Laboratory.

The Rabbinical Assembly of America in executive session closing forty-seventh annual convention yesterday morning at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America Broadway and 122d Street "strongly" approved the passing of the Stratton Bill to permit entry of 100,000 displaced persons in the United States annually for four years.

ALBANY, June 26 (AP) -- Governor Dewey was asked by a delegation or sixty New York City apartment house owners today to call a special legislative session to re-enact the present mortgage moratorium, which will be superseded July 1 by a modified act.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 25 -- Energy from rays of the sun in an area of 100 to 150 square miles during the course of a year, if they could be harnessed, conceivably could provide a year's supply of power for the entire world.

BOUND BROOK. N.J., June 26 -- Residents of this quiet New Jersey community today went all out in their celebration of the second anniversary of the signing of the United Nations Charter at San Francisco.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 26 -- The East River front headquarters site of the United Nations was established as an area "under the control and authority of the United Nations," but without extraterritorial rights under an agreement signed today by Secretary of State Marshall and Trygve Lie, United Nations Secretary General.
Two former Navy men moved in yesterday to the first apartments to be occupied in Peter Cooper Village. Both were finding permanent homes of their own for the first time.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- With the last five years of "holiday" in an all-pervasive seller's market abruptly replaced by an increasingly wide and competitive buyer's market, 500 department store, newspaper and radio advertising men from all over the country gathered here today for two days of school work in the techniques of sales promotion, a function which it was said might well have become atrophied.
GENEVA, June 26 -- Care must be taken to prevent the Marshall plan from splitting Europe, Gunnar Myrdal, General Secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, said today.

One firm answer to the problem of greater safety in the air was given at yesterday's forum of the aviation section of the New York Board of Trade at 291 Broadway. Advocates of radar, radio, better fighting and other devices disagreed so thoroughly that the board abandoned its intention of making recommendations as the result of the discussion.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 26 -- Restrictions on foreign exchange declared by Brazil do not mean that Brazil is against importation of luxury items, as has been reported, according to Correa Castro, Minister of Finance. The Minister reiterated today that the exchange measure is temporary.

ANNVILLE, Pa., June 26 (AP) -- Andy Kerr, who rose to football coaching heights at Colgate and Washington and Jefferson, today signed a one-year contract as head coach at Lebanon Valley, a college with an enrollment of 400.

Unexpected Treasury Call Despite recent heavy tax collections the United States Treasury issued yesterday a further call on its War Loan accounts. Somewhat unexpectedly, apparently in anticipation of some heavy disbursements at the beginning of the new fiscal year, the Treasury now has asked the B banks for 35 per cent of the accounts as of the close of business on June 25, and payable on July 1.

The Foreign Ministers of Britain, France and Russia meet in Paris today to explore the possibilities of agreement on a joint program for European reconstruction with American aid. This is an entirely European and entirely economic conference. As such it may be able to sidestep or surmount some of the political problems which have deadlocked the Big Powers in Europe and throughout the world.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- A Federal court jury tonight convicted Eugene Dennis, general secretary of the Communist party, on charges of contempt of Congress.

The Port of New York Authority approved yesterday the sale of a $16,200,000 serial bond issue to finance the Authority's proposed union motor bus terminal on the block bounded by Eighth and Ninth Avenues and Fortieth and Forty-first Streets.

Shipbuilding and repair work came to a standstill yesterday morning in ten East Coast shipyards as 35,000 workers, members of the Industrial Union of Marine and Ship Building Workers of America, CIO, failed to report for work. Their action followed by six hours the walkout of emergency crews and tied up the yards.

Before 1945 we heard a good deal about utilizing the enormous amount of solar energy that falls on the earth on a bright day. What if all the coal and oil should be exhausted in some centuries? Out there was the sun pouring on the state of New Mexico alone ten trillion horsepower-hours a year-more power than the United States was getting annually from fuel and falling water.

New Capital Market A respite from June's impact of competitive marketings is in store for underwriters next week. The only competitive corporate deals scheduled are railroad equipment trust issues -- $6,000,000 by the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad on Monday and $4,650,000 for the Chicago North Western Railway on Wednesday.

The East Coast television network serviced with programs by the National Broadcasting Company was expanded to four outlets last night with the opening of WNBW in Washington, the second owned and operated video station of NBC, which also controls the pineer transmitter, WNBT, New York.

JERUSALEM, June 27 -- An obscure man who advocates the union of Palestine and Trans-Jordan under King Abdullah will receive an oral hearing by the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine. His name, J.W. Abileah, was among those of nine organizations and individuals whom the committee decided today that it could hear.

Heavy plastic dinnerware, a large-size mixer for blending waffle batter or washing nylons, and knitting needles with inch marks printed into the surface for easy measuring were among small plastic accessories exhibited yesterday in a one-day showing by the Plastics Club of the United States, Inc.

Not all the news that comes from Palestine is discouraging. One good piece of news is the building of better health for Jew and Arab alike. Twentytwo years ago the Hebrew University was established on Mount Scopus, above Jerusalem. Eight years ago the Hadassah-University Medical Center was built to house the university's growing research and hospital facilities, the latter open to Jews, Moslems and Christians without distinction.

Making the greatest financial gains in their history, teachers in virtually every state in the union will receive substantially higher salaries during the 1947-48 school year than they did in the academic year just ended.

PARIS, June 27 -- The first proposal placed before the Foreign Ministers of Britain, the Soviet Union and France at their fourhour meeting today was that they agree on a series of committees to study European assets and needs, notably in terms of coal, food, transport and steel.

ALBANY, June 27 -- The Personal Finance Company of New York, 30 South Broadway, Yonkers, N.Y., filed today with the State Banking Department an application for permission to change its place of business from 447 to 430 Eighty-sixth Street, Brooklyn.

GENEVA, June 27 -- A resolution associating the International Labor Conference with the aims of the Marshall plan was offered to the conferenee today by Leon Jouhaux, one of the general secretaries of France's Communist-dominated General Confederation of Labor [CGT]. There is little doubt that the resolution will be adopted.

In a move unprecedented in the history of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, delegates to the fifty-sixth annual convention reconsidered yesterday a resolution and reversed their vote on it. They endorsed the Stratton bill, providing for the entry of 400,000 displaced persons into this nation, which they had voted down on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Senator Wallace H. White, Republican, of Maine, author of a controversial bill applying to radio, suggested today that the Senate Commerce Committee not try to report it to the Senate this session.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Two appropriation measures were acted upon by Congress today and a third, the civil functions budget of the War Department, was reported out by the House Appropriations Committee with a recommendation for an 11.4 per cent, or $43,540,231, slash in the $382,727,100 requested.

Alphonse Milo and nine other members of his family, evicted Thursday from a rented house at 60-11 136th Street, Flushing, Queens, following a change in ownership of the house, were running down a lead on a four-room bungalow at Rockaway Beach, Queens, last night.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 27 -- Juliu Maniu urged the United States and Britain today to sever economic and diplomatic relations with Rumania in an effort to force the downfall of her present Government. The regime here, M. Maniu contended, was installed illegally with the aid of the Soviet Union in violation of a series of Big Three agreements.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 27 -- Whether or not atomic energy can be developed sufficiently for use in large-scale production of power, England must have coal for technological purposes and for its expanding industries, according to Dr. Robert Spence, an official of the British atomic energy project at Harwell, England.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had approved the New England Public Service Company's simplification plan, filed last March 8, on the condition that prior lien preferred stockholders receive at this time $100 a share plus accrued dividends.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized transcontinental railroads to increase their rates 5 per cent on about sixty commodities, at the same time authorizing intercoastal water carriers to increase their rates by the same amounts in cents per 100 pounds, giving them what amounted to a 7 per cent increase.

SHANGHAI, June 27 (AP) -- The Chinese Government's failure to get a $500,000,000 loan from the United States pushed the currency down today. The official rate remained at $12,000 [Chinese] to $1 [United States] but Shanghai black market quotations hit a record 58,000 to 1.

SEATTLE, June 27 (AP) -- The men who know their crew racing tonight were high on Harvard and Cornell in tomorrow's second holding of the Lake Washington regatta, a 2,000-meter dash. Twelve of the nation's top crews will be shooting for the unofficial American sprint championship.

Importers and wholesalers of champagne will soon ask hotels and restaurants to reduce their $18 per bottle prices to levels around $10 to $12 in order to break the present sales slump, in which wholesale sales are off from 50 to 75 per cent below 1946 levels, industry spokesmen revealed here yesterday.

"The Balkans: Frontier of Two Worlds," by William B. King and Frank O'Brien, an analysis of the present situation, has been scheduled for publication July 10 by Knopf. The book covers the rise of Tito Mikhailovitch and his trial, the growth of Russian control in Rumania, Albania and Bulgaria, the Greek factions, the position of Turkey and the nature and strength of British influence and United States policy.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 27 -- Hungary ratified the Hungarian peace treaty today. The only remaining obstacle in the path leading to the restoration of Hungarian Sovereignty is the fact that the Soviet Union has not yet ratified the pact.

BERLIN, June 27 -- Robert Moses, New York's Construction Coordinator, arrived unannounced in Berlin today aboard Gen. Lucius D. Clay's plane on an undisclosed mission. After all other officials --and Mr. Moses himself -- had refused to comment, General Clay issued a short statement that said:
Margaret Kent, formerly with Henri Bendel, Inc., and BergdorfGoodman, has been named manager of the New York office of Venus Foundation Garments, Inc. She also will be in charge of publicity.
SEOUL, Korea, June 27 -- United States correspondents here will not be allowed to accompany the joint commission into the Soviet occupation zone of Korea, it was disclosed today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 27 -- Gabriel Gonzalez Videla, President of Chile, made it clear today here that his country favors an interAmerican army, to be ready at all times to defend the continent against menace from the outside.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Acquisition of individual pledges from two-thirds of the Senate's members that the members would vote to override another possible veto was laid down by Republican leaders today as the rigid condition for renewing the tax reduction fight before adjournment of Congress.

Here and There At first it was hard to see how Niles Trammell could possibly be serious when he said technology can now transmit a million words a minute electronically. It was not the sending that seemed incomprehensible but how anybody could speak or write a million words a minute for transmission.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, June 27 (AP) -- A bitter election fight for the presidency of the American Newspaper Guild ended dramatically and unexpectedly on the convention floor today when President Milton Murray withdrew from the race.

MANILA, June 27 -- Jorge B. Vargas, who for two years headed Japan's first Commission Government in the occupied Philippines, appeared for the fifth time in the People's Court today to ask postponement of his trial for treason on 116 counts stemming from his activities during the Japanese occupation.
Assault not being on the premises, durable old Stymie has the chance at Jamaica today to get a little attention in the chase after the money-winning crown.

Robert Reud, producer and coproducer, respectively, of "Ramshackle Inn" and the successful thriller, "The Two Mrs. Carrolls," has added another play to his agenda. It is Russell MacCallum's drama, "O Coward Heart," which is set in the Canadian Laurentians and concerns the reshaping of the lives of an assembly of people on a night when tragedy strikes.

A critical shortage of gas for cooking as well as heating in Long Island on severely cold days next winter was forecast yesterday by the Public Service Commission in a decision affecting three gas companies in Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The House Republican leadership has given the signal that legislation to increase the minimum wage under the Fair Labor Standards (WageHour) Act is to be brought forward and passed at this session.
Citations for meritorious service were granted yesterday to 200 members of the Police Department in general orders issued by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The State Department announced today that it recently had discharged ten employes for reasons of security as a result of a continuing investigation by a special...

BOSTON, June 27 -- Continuing the assault staged last night in Brooklyn, and doing a bit better job of it, the Dodgers tonight maltreated four Boston pitchers for fifteen hits to beat the Braves, 8-5, and increase their first place lead over Billy Southworth's men to a game and a half.

BATAVIA, Java, June 27 (AP) -- A swift reversal in Indonesian politics tonight apparently paved the way for the reappointment of Sutan Sjahrir to the premiership, from which he was ousted nineteen hours earlier. But neutral informants said the shift would not halt the Dutch from resorting to military action.

Elmer Haslett, city airports director, disclosed to his superior in the city service, Frederick G. Reinicke, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, that he was getting a $50,000 payment from the Gulf Oil Corporation, Mr. Reinicke testified yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Selling pressure increased today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade and there was not the snap to the buying of corn in evidence recently except for a brief period early when a cash house bought the July and September deliveries aggressively.

TOKYO, June 27 -- Totalitarian ideas are proving to have a remarkable vitality here, especially among recent college graduates, despite the occupation efforts to achieve a democratic Japan. There has been no apparent strain in shifting from Gen. Hideki Tojo's statism to Moscow's statism.

PRAGUE, June 27 -- Prague today experienced a new invasion this time -- that of Czechoslovak youth. For four hours the main streets in the heart of the city were closed to traffic as 80,000 boys and girls took possession.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 27 -- Dr. Harold Stonier, director of the Graduate School of Banking conducted by the American Banking Association, told 227 members of the class of 1947 tonight that American loans abroad should be made to help production lines and not merely to create bread lines.

LONDON, June 27 -- An easier tendency was seen today in the stock markets here, brokers reporting that their clients were showing some nervousness on the industrial outlook largely as a result of recent warnings of danger of another fuel crisis next winter.

It was quite warm in the city yesterday, but in one part of town it was snowing. And the reason it snowed was because a 17-year-old high school girl with blue eyes and reddish hair breathed into a wash tub.

ROME, June 27 -- Late last night a group of about 100 Communists staked a demonstration against the Argentine President's wife, Senora Eva Duarte de Peron, outside the Windows of her rooms in the Argentine Embassy.

Nudging a rack of salamis and bolognas that had been moved to make room for him, an exotic clown grinned down from one of the walls of the Fifty-eighth Street Delicatessen that yesterday became an equally exotic art gallery.

James V. Bove, 48 years old, former vice president of the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union, AFL, was sentenced yesterday to five years in prison and fined $30,000. He had pleaded guilty before Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard to two indictments charging the evasion of $85,000 in income taxes between 1938 and 1942.

City Councilman Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, threatened another slowdown on the subways yesterday when he joined other union leaders in addressing an 800-member demonstration outside the offices of the Board of Transportation, 250 Hudson Street.

Action taken by states this year on teachers' salaries included the following: Eastern States NEW YORK During the past year New York adopted new State minimum teachers' salary schedules. For up-state the average salary as of June 30th, was $2,303. The State average, including New York City, was $2,931. For September, 1947, it is estimated that the median salary for upstate New York will be $2,800; for New York City, $4,400.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday plan for selling on July 16 an issue of $16,350,000 of fifteen-year serial bonds to finance the cost of constructing the Union Motor Bus Terminal to be located between Fortieth and Forty-first Streets and Eighth and Ninth Avenues.

PURCHASE, N. Y., June 27 -- Mrs. William R. Kirkland of Piping Rock and Miss Laddie Irwin of Glen Ridge reached the final round of the forty-fourth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Championship over the Century Country Club course today.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People announced today a "systematic" drive against the dual educational system of seventeen Southern and border States. The line of attack as described by Thurgood Marshall, chief of the legal staff, "will start from the top, with professional and graduate schools being given first consideration."

ST. LOUIS, June 27 (AP) -- Whitey Kurowski's eleventh-inning single with the bases loaded sent two runs across the plate and enabled the St. Louis Cardinals to win an exciting game from the Cincinnati Reds tonight, 6 to 5.

Queen Elizabeth owned some Chinese porcelain cups and counted them among her greatest treasures. England itself, however, did not learn how to make fine china until the middle of the eighteenth century, when the famous Chelsea works turned out some of the loveliest ceramics ever produced.
Claudia Cranston, author, traveler and a former associate editor of Good Housekeeping Magazine, died Thursday at 55 in Winnsboro, Tex., after a brief illness.

June usually is the time for peak lettuce shipments in New York City, and this year is no exception. Though total receipts for the month are unavailable as yet, a glance at records of other seasons shows how plentiful the salad green is at this period.

RYE, N.Y., June 27 -- Col. Martin S. Lindgrove of Baltusrol, Army Air Forces veteran of two World Wars, ended the five-year tenure of J. Ellis Knowles as United States senior golf champion today when he carded his second 73 to win the forty-third national tourney at the Apawamis Club.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Aprocess whereby high concentrations of penicillin are said to be produced in increased quantity in much less time than by any previous method was one of the 425 inventions for which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.

Mayor O'Dwyer has failed in a second attempt to win control of a majority of the five-member New York City Housing Authority, it was learned yesterday. Frank R. Crosswaith, only Negro member of the agency, which builds and operates hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of public housing, has chosen to remain in his unpaid post, rather than accept an assignment to the Mayor's Division of Labor Relations at a substantial salary.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 27 (AP) -- The two hottest choices of the greenside experts, Charley Coe of Oklahoma and Charles (Babe) Lind of Denver University, fought their way into the quarter-final round of the National Collegiate A.A. golf championship today with lopsided third-round triumphs as the sloping, 6,600-yard University of Michigan course started taking its toll in upsets.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: David Martin's letter to THE TIMES, published on June 20, contained many distortions, but I would like to point out just one example.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Navy Department today asked Congress to give a permanent place in the United States Navy to the Waves and sent a draft of a proposed bill which would authorize a maximum of 10,000 enlisted women and 1,000 women officers.

CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates managed to turn back a hard finishing drive by the Chicago Cubs today for a 12-8 decision. The victory gave them their second straight triumph in the series and extended the losing streak of the fading Chicagoans to four in a row.

DETROIT, June 27 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers, returning home after a disastrous Eastern road trip on which they dropped 10 of 11 games, smashed out 18 hits today to wallop the St. Louis Browns, 11 -- 2, in a twilight game called in the last of the eighth because of darkness.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 27 -- Following is the text of a United States proposal on the Balkan question, submitted today to the United Nations Security Council: The Security Council, Having received and considered the report of the commission of investigation established by resolution of the Council dated Dec. 19, 1946;

The strike of 35,000 workers in ten East Coast shipbuilding and repair yards continued through its second day yesterday with no move by the Industrial Union of Marine and Ship Building Workers of America, CIO, or the shipyard owners to renew negotiations broken off Wednesday.

John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, started yesterday what he described as a "full and thorough inquiry" into the acquisition by the city of property for the site of the Lillian Wald Houses, a low-rent housing project on the lower East Side.

Gus Fusaro, 53-year-old, $50-aweek elevator starter charged with having lost $247,000 of his friends' money in stock market operations, stoutly protested his innocence yesterday as he was released in $15,000 bail after spending the night in City Prison.

BAYONNE, N.J., June 27 -- Two rugged veterans of the South Pacific, the battleships North Carolina and Washington, joined the "moth-ball" fleet here at the Naval Annex today in the first double decommissioning ceremony for battleships.
DANBURY, Conn., June 27 -- Mayor James M. Curley of Boston was reported in "good spirits and good condition" tonight by officials of the Federal Correctional Institution here.

Not since the dispute over Iran has the United Nations faced a graver issue than is likely to develop as the debate over the Greek situation opens in the Security Council. It began with a bang yesterday when American delegate Warren Austin, in one of the most forceful speeches yet addressed to that body, charged Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Albania with planned aggression against Greece.

In New York's biggest track and field show of the year, a starstudded field of 425 athletes will compete for twenty-one titles today in the fifty-seventh senior championships of the Metropolitan A.A.U. The program, which will be staged in Triborough Stadium on Randals Island, will get under way at 1:30 P.M.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- An urgent Navy program for the construction of a $34,520,000 guided missile test center at Point Mugu, Calif., some thirty-five miles above Los Angeles, was approved today by a House Armed Services subcommittee.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., June 27 -- On the assumption that President Truman, will sign the Wolcott Bill modifying residential rent controls and lifting restrictions on nearly all types of construction, Morgan L. Fitch of Chicago tonight predicted that a "normal balance between supply and demand in housing" would be achieved within a reasonably short time.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Taft Health Bill was opposed today as unworkable and bad from the point of administration by officials of both the American Public Health Association and the American Public Welfare Association. Spokesmen gave their views at a hearing before a Senate health subcommittee.

LAKE MINNEWASKA, N.Y., June 27 -- Military training was attacked here today at the opening of the three-day joint session of two New York yearly meetings of the Religious Society of Friends in that it tends to force the minds of secondary school students toward military training.

MOSCOW, June 27 (AP) -- A Tass dispatch from Paris, commenting on remarks of Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder, gave the Russians the impression today the United States might be trying to back out of the Marshall suggestion of economic aid for Europe, now that the Soviet Union had agreed to the talks.

When Dan Falcone, manager of the barber shop in the La Guardia Field Administration Building, left New York yesterday aboard the Saturnia, bound for his native Italy for a three-month visit, the airport temporarily lost one of its most steadfast and popular Thirty-Niners.

VIENNA, June 27 -- The Austrian Government and Headquarters of the United States forces in Austria made public today an agreement by which the United States turned over to the Austrian Government 308,382,590 schillings.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 27 -- Close competition in three jumper classes marked the opening session of the three-day Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show today. Three jump-offs were required in the knock down-and-out event, won by My Play Girl, bay mare owned and ridden by Russell Stewart of Albany, N.Y.
