Newspaper Gain 20% Newspaper advertising in fiftytwo cities during May totaled 172,375,817 lines, a gain of 20 per cent over the corresponding month in 1946, according to Media Records. All classifications showed gains for the month except financial which dropped 9.7 per cent.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 27 (AP) -- Henry James Foan, organist at the Church of St. Mary Magdalene, Newark, and formerly organist at several churches in London, died today at East Orange Hospital after a month's illness. He was 65 years old.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 27 -- How the Economic Commission for Europe might help give effect to the Marshall plan will probably be debated at the fifth session of the United Nations Economic and Social Council, commencing here on July 19.
DETROIT, June 27 -- The Ford Motor Company set a precedent in the automobile industry today when it agreed to set up a pension plan for its 107,000 production workers.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- Reports of a new boy wonder, a 20year-old pitching sensation who had won all his three starts for the Athletics and had yielded only two earned runs in twenty-seven innings, were thoroughly investigated by the Yankees tonight.

JAMES ONEAL, long active in the Socialist party and editor of The New Reader from 1924 to 1940, originally wrote "American Communism"* in 1927. The account has now been brought up to date by G.A. Werner, a native of Sweden, doctor of philosophy of the University of California and professor of Russian history at the College of the Pacific.

Continuing an exodus to camps for underprivileged adults and children which started Thursday, more than 1,000 more campers left yesterday for summer vacations under auspices of various welfare groups.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 27 -- The United States demanded today that the United Nations Security Council use force, if necessary, to prevent Yugoslavia, Albania and Bulgaria from sheltering and supporting any armed bands that might violate Greek territory.
After a year of hesitation because of widespread opposition by dog lovers, the city health officials moved yesterday to begin a public anti-rabies vaccination program for dogs.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Disavowing any intention of forming a new political party, Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, declared today that the CIO executive board would renew its work in the political field to offset the effects of the new Taft-Hartley Labor Relations Act.

It is an interesting experiment that Nelson Rockefeller and his brothers are attempting in Latin America -- an extension by private capital of the Good Neighbor policy that Mr. Rockefeller had an important part in promoting as an official of the State Department. If Venezuela is a good example, the experiment is to have an enthusiastic welcome and full cooperation from the Latin Americans.

A close-flying formation of 125 naval aircraft of varied types will fly over Manhattan tomorrow at 1:15 P.M., marking the opening of a two-day celebration of the first anniversary of the Naval and Marine Air Reserve.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Myths are hard to destroy. This is proved once more by the case of Hjalmar Schacht, still considered, in this country, the mastermind of international finance. But who can be blamed for this error, when even outstanding leaders of the financial world were time and again double-crossed by the fast-thinking and even faster-talking Dr. Schacht?

PARIS, June 27 -- While the Cabinet was split on the settlement on the coal and other Communist -encouraged strikes, Jacques Duclos launched a Communist bid at the party convention in Strasbourg today for regaining a place in the Government.

On the question of Universal Military Training it would seem that everyone is out of step but Congress. In announcing formation of the Citizens Emergency Committee for Universal Military Training, former Justice Owen J. Roberts said that of 400 prominent persons polled on their views only 6 per cent opposed the idea.

LONDON, June 27 (AP) -- Tom Brown, the lanky San Francisco law student, battled his way to the quarter-finals of the Wimbledon tennis championships with an uphill, five-set triumph today. He was joined in the round of eight by the men who met for the title in this tournament a year ago.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Senate, by a vote of 50 to 35, passed today a succession bill, requested three times by President Truman since 1945, which would put Joseph W. Martin Jr., Republican Speaker of the House, next in line for the Presidency in the present absence of a Vice President.

TOKYO, June 27 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur, in an interview today with a group of visiting United States newspaper publishers, reaffirmed his belief that the military occupation of the defeated nation could be terminated soon. He added, however, that Japan should continue under Allied supervision "for a generation" to assure the effective growth of democratic ideals implanted since the surrender.

GENEVA, June 27 -- A proposal by the United Kingdom to permit such countries as Ceylon and Burma, which have independent customs control, to attend the coming world trade conference was debated today at the Geneva trade discussions.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 27 -- The Rev. Dr. Joseph W.A. Stewart, former president and Professor of Christian Ethics of the Rochester Theological Seminary, died yesterday in his home here at the age of 95.

PITTSBURGH, June 27 -- The steel industry, dependent on coal, made its first major production curtailments today, only a few hours before the country's 400,000 bituminous miners were scheduled to begin their official ten-day paid vacation at midnight tonight.

Net profit of the Canadian Industrial Alcohol Company, Ltd., for the nine months ended with last May amounted to $1,094,823 after all charges, equal to 98 cents a share, the report disclosed yesterday. For the corresponding period of the prior year, the net profit was $819,305, or 74 cents a share.
Clint Hartung's woeful inadequacy as their starting pitcher nullified the otherwise distinguishing features of the Giants' homecoming last night.

One of the finest displays of offensive tennis seen at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills carried Donald McNeill to a decisive victory over Jack Geller of New Rochelle yesterday in the New York State championship.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Representative Robert F. Jones, Republican, of Ohio, nominated by President Truman to the Federal Communications Commission, denied today charges by Drew Pearson that he had "bigoted, antiCatholic, anti-Jewish" affiliations.

PASSAIC, N.J., June 27 -- Back home today after being committed by mistake to the State Hospital for Mental Diseases at Greystone Park in Morris Plains, Mrs. Anna Parfinska, 177 Fourth Street, Passaic, declared today "she almost went crazy" in the three days she spent in the hospital.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- As sixteen board members of the Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee, including Howard Fast, novelist; Herman Shumlin, theatrical producer, and Dr. Edward R. Barsky, were convicted today of contempt of Congress, Gerhart Eisler, described as the "No. 1 Soviet commissar" in this country, was sentenced to one year in jail and $1,000 fine on the same charge.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Department store public relations programs must not be permitted to "die of malnutrition" with the return of competitive merchandising, Lawrence B. Sizer, divisional vice president and sales promotion manager of Marshall Field Co., warned today in opening a public relations clinic sponsored by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
After fairly active trading, cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 5 to 43 points net higher.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- An international commission of conciliation today refused to accede to Siam's demands for territory taken from her by French Indo-China.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., June 27 (AP) -- After a stormy start, California's batters teed off on virtually the entire Yale pitching staff today to whip the Elis, 17 to 4, in the opening game of the collegiate world series -- the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship.

ST. LOUIS, June 27 -- The floodmad Mississippi and Missouri Rivers and their tributaries sent several hundred more persons fleeing from their homes throughout the watersheds today as the swirling waters breached additional levees and inundated more homes, farm lands and highways.

Despite the pleas of a young woman who for several minutes kept up a running conversation with him through a barricaded door, a 23-year-old Navy veteran shot himself in the left side of the chest yesterday morning in his furnished room at 112 West Sixty-fourth Street.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., June 27 -- Indications are that the nation's retailers expect "good business" next fall, it was said today by Gordon K. Creighton, assistant general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, at a meeting of the New England Association of Commercial Executives in the Thorwald Hotel.

Pre-Independence Day services will be held in churches of the city tomorrow, next Friday being July 4. Patriotic sermons will be delivered. "On Being Worthy of Our Forebears" will be the topic of the Rev. Dr. Theodore C. Speers, the pastor, in the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

BAYREUTH, Germany, June 27 (U.P.) -- A parade of witnesses who were persecuted by the Nazis testified today that Frau Winifred Wagner, daughter-in-law of the great composer, helped them escape from concentration camps or elude the Gestapo.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Two of the country's top coal and iron industrialists have secretly offered to grant John L. Lewis' basic wage and hour demand in full, it was learned authoritatively today.

Strength was maintained yesterday in some of the oil shares, but the main list of the stock market drifted irregularly and closed with mixed changes in prices. On balance, the market ended about at the levels of the previous session, although a slight trend to the higher side persisted, with the composite rate rising 0.15 point on the day.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Mickey Haefner registered his first shutout of the season today as Washington defeated the Boston Red Sox, 3 to 0.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- Registration statements covering $62,500,000 of bonds, $2,500,000 of debentures, 840,448 shares of common and 20,099 shares of preferred stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by seven companies.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 27 -- Developments here today indicate that rivalry is in the making between two independent producing companies to see which can reach the screen first with a film biography of Ludwig von Beethoven, the composer.

An unscheduled passenger only two days old was among the 553 travelers who arrived at pier 88, North River yesterday aboard the Polish liner Sobieski. The baby girl, born to Mrs. Fryma Rozen, wife of Rabbi Rozen, who also was aboard the vessel, was named "Brucha," meaning "Blessed" in Hebrew.

VIENNA, June 27 -- Hungarian Communist leader Rakosi is probably visiting Czechoslovakia to lay the ground for some kind of Communist-dominated eastern or central European federation, Count Gynla Dessewffy said today.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Two of the country's top coal and iron industrialists have secretly offered to grant John L. Lewis' basic wage and hour demand in full, it was learned authoritatively today.

VIENNA, June 27 -- Hungarian Communist leader Rakosi is probably visiting Czechoslovakia to lay the ground for some kind of Communist-dominated eastern or central European federation, Count Gynla Dessewffy said today.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- The Government charged today that Andrew J. May, wartime chairman of the House Military Committee, was the real Washington "expediter" for munitions makers Henry and Murray Garsson.
MUNICH, Germany, June 27 -- Authorities are concentrating on the background of the murder of Hugo Maenner whose nude body wrapped in gunnysack, was fished from the Isar Canal last Friday.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Fear of another world war in 1948 or 1949 was expressed here today by former Supreme Court Justice Owen J. Roberts, testifying before the House Armed Services Committee on the Administration-supported universal military training plan.

GREENSBORO, N.C., June 27 (AP) -- Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page of Chapel Hill, the women's national amateur champion a decade ago, fired a sparkling three-under-par 73 today to go into a tie with Miss Polly Riley of Fort Worth, Tex., for the lead at the halfway mark in the $7,500 national women's open golf tournament.

Billy Fox, hard-punching light heavyweight from Philadelphia, knocked out Artie Levine, game Brooklyn battler in the main bout listed for ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The fight, a bitterly contested one from the opening bell, ended in 1:32 of the third round, when Referee Ruby Goldstein stepped in to prevent an obviously groggy Levine from absorbing further punishment.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- A fifteen-pound radar gadget installed in a Constellation flashed sight and sound warnings every time the big plane came within 2,000 feet of mountainsides today in a cruise over the Blue Ridge Mountains.

Retail Trade Somewhat 'Soft' Retail trade here turned "soft" this week, with volume gains over last year limited. Estimates put the rise for department stores at around 2 per cent. Although volume has been running under expectations for the last two weeks, store executives said it was too early yet to determine an economic trend, as weather conditions have been abnormally cool for brisk turnover of summer merchandise.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The sale to China of 130,000,000 rounds of small ammunition at a tenth of its procurement cost of $6,566,589 was announced today by the State Department.

NEW DELHI, India, June 27 -- With the exception of Hyderabad, Travancore and possibly Kashmir and Bhopal, all the 562 Indian Princely States will come within one of the two dominions, it appeared today.

MILWAUKEE, June 27 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. John Lewis, a Presbyterian clergyman, who the prosecution said wanted a "bigger and better church than the seventy -seven-year-old red brick edifice in which he preached for twelve years, was convicted today of setting it afire last January.
GUAM, June 27 (AP) -- A prosecution witness testified today that he saw Japanese naval surgeons boil the severed heads of four United States war prisoners to preserve the skulls as specimens.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Navy asserted today that it was so short of oil that it could not cope with an emergency at the present time and must buy 3,000,000 barrels from the Middle East to fulfill its requirements.

CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) -- Sammy Snead of Hot Springs, Va., who passed up defense of his British open title to concentrate on domestic cash-collecting, zoomed along at 12-under-par with a card of 130 for a three-stroke halfway mark lead in the $15,900 Chicago Victory national golf tourney today.

Justice Phillip M. Kleinfeld presiding over a naturalization term of the Richmond County Supreme Court at St. George, S.I. yesterday dismissed the application of Eberhard Dietrich von Ascheberg, a former Staten Island resident, to become an American citizen when the petitioner from the witness chair gave his residence as Ellis Island.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Chief of Staff, declared today that when he becomes president of Columbia University next year national security still would be his major interest, but it would be translated into a different form.

Prospects for an increase in the basic wage rates of the 29,000 operating employes of the municipal transit lines, so long as the fare remains at 5 cents, neared the vanishing point yesterday after Mayor O'Dwyer held a thirty-minute conference at City Hall with the three members of the Board of Transportation.

Justice Phillip M. Kleinfeld presiding over a naturalization term of the Richmond County Supreme Court at St. George, S.I. yesterday dismissed the application of Eberhard Dietrich von Ascheberg, a former Staten Island resident, to become an American citizen when the petitioner from the witness chair gave his residence as Ellis Island.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Chief of Staff, declared today that when he becomes president of Columbia University next year national security still would be his major interest, but it would be translated into a different form.

Prospects for an increase in the basic wage rates of the 29,000 operating employes of the municipal transit lines, so long as the fare remains at 5 cents, neared the vanishing point yesterday after Mayor O'Dwyer held a thirty-minute conference at City Hall with the three members of the Board of Transportation.

PARIS, June 27 -- Although the Foreign Ministers conference that began here today was blanketed in secrecy, enough is known of its background to make it certain that British Foreign Secretary Bevin's ideas dominated the discussion.

Federal Judge Gunnar Nordbye sentenced John T. Jatoft, 26 years old, and David M.N. MacIntyre, 27, both of the Bronx, to twenty years each in prison yesterday for the kidnapping last Dec. 12 of Julius Siegel, paymaster of the Diecaster Company of Ridgefield, N.J.

Not more than once in a legislative blue moon would anything happen like the Senate's passage of the Presidential succession bill on Friday by a vote of 50 to 35. The bill had been three times proposed by President Truman. On Feb. 5 of the present year Mr. Truman wrote Senator Vandenberg that he saw no reason to "change or amend the suggestion."

HOLLYWOOD. AFTER an active career of thirty-nine years in the motion -picture industry. Robert Z. Leonard, veteran MetroGoldwyn-Mayer director, concludes that directing films these days is easy work -- if you can get it.

Small plants in the eastern states will be hit harder than any other branch of industry if steel and iron output is further reduced because of coal shortages, spokesmen for New York steel distributors revealed here yesterday. Many small plants are still operating hand-to-mouth on day-to-day shipments of sheets and plates, they explained, and these users will have no other option except to close down until pipelines start to fill up again.

LAKE MINNEWASKA, N.Y., June 28 -- The United States must find a common ground and act more conciliatory toward Russia if the peace is to be secured, it was agreed here today at the joint session of two New York yearly meetings of the Religious Society of Friends.
PITTSBURGH, June 28 -- Most of the drop in business reported at the middle of June was recovered last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh.

MANY a man in writing of his conversion to Christianity wants to tell about his spiritual pilgrimage, his despair, his emotional experiences of forgiveness. This is not the method of Chad Walsh. Instead, he believes that the simple restatement of Christian beliefs will have an appeal to the saddened secularist in revolt against the emptiness of sell-worship.

THE week, so far as my own findings in the galleries are concerned, was characterized by visual reports on largescale urban building projects, on bridges by a distinguished Swiss engineer-architect, and on new stage designs by Boris Aronson -- all of these embodied in exhibitions just opened at the Museum of Modern Art.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a member of the President's Civilian Commission on Universal Training, I have had occasion to answer many questions on the report of the commission. I include here some of the replies which I have made to them. I am sure that also they represent my associates' views.

BUDAPEST, June 28 -- The Socialist party's plans for nationalization of all Hungarian banks of any substantial size has been adopted by an interparty conference of the Government coalition, as against the Communist proposal for nationalization of only the three big banks that control some 80 per cent of Hungarian industry.

ANN ARBOR, June 28 (AP) -- University of Michigan's sloping 6,600-yard golf course and a couple of determined underdog competitors wrecked the hopes of favorites in the national collegiate golf championship today. Bespectacled Jack Coyle, 21-year-old Louisiana State University ace, and Dave Barclay, captain of the University of Michigan team, reached the final round, to be held over thirtysix holes tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Labor-Management Relations Act of 1947 became law last Monday, but the storm brewing over it threatens to exceed the bounds of any similar controversy.

MADISON, Wis. HERE on the shores of Lake Mendota last week-end the first off-year State political convention of 1947 fired the first gun of the 1948 Presidential campaign. The convention was Republican; 1,500 of the party faithfuls came together to talk and be talked to. As the first of its kind, and literally a grass-roots gathering, it was the subject of much interest among the politically minded.

PLYMOUTH, Mass. -- The only fully operated two-foot gauge railroad in America gives an extra fillip to Cape Cod vacations. It is the Edaville Line, operated by Ellis D. Atwood, the Cape's largest individual cranberry farmer and an enthusiastic railroad hobbyist, who welcomes tourists for free rides.

ST. JOSEPH, Mich., June 28 (AP) -- As a group of CIO pickets stood across the street from the church, Lloyd Bowers Taft, third son of Senator and Mrs. Robert A. Taft of Ohio, married today Miss Virginia Stone.

BATAVIA, Java, June 28 -- A pledge from the United States today to discuss economic aid to Indonesia was believed to have prevented the possible renewal of military operations by the Dutch against the Indonesian Republic. The Republican radio said the attack was to take place on Monday.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Denny Galehouse, newly acquired by the Boston Red Sox, held the Washington Senators to four hits today for an 8-to-0 victory.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 28 -- California legislators boosted Governor Earl Warren's pay from $10,000 to $25,000 a year, but as the longest session in the state's history adjourned this week it was apparent that the Governor had engendered more bitter opposition within the state than during the sessions marking his first term.

MANILA, June 28 -- The Philippine Government is neck-deep in business enterprises ranging from cement production to hotel operation. These have been so successful that President Manuel A. Roxas finds his treasury in a considerably better condition than was expected at the end of the fiscal year, June 30.

ALBANY, June 28 -- Governor Dewey announced today the appointment of Dr. Herman B. Hilleboe, assistant Surgeon General and associate chief of the Bureau of State Services, United States Public Health Service, as State Commissioner of Health.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 -- They jeered when George McQuinn stepped to the plate in the first inning of the get-away game between the Yankees and Athletics at Shibe Park today. But the derisive remarks of 12,908 partisans, who remembered the veteran firstsacker only as a local flop in 1946, failed to disturb him.

Because of carefully planned cooperative buying for its own affiliates and other health and welfare agencies, substantial saving's in time and money as well as "the stretching of the philanthropic dollar" were reported yesterday by Norman S. Goetz, president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York.

VIENNA, June 28 -- Armed Yugoslavs who crossed the frontier into Austria near Schlossberg, Styria, and attacked an Austrian police patrol at 10 o'clock last night killed two police officers and renewed the fighting at various times all through the night, the Austrian Government announced today.

MAN O' WAR, the first allGeorgia streamliner, was placed in service last week by the Central of Georgia Railway between Columbus and Atlanta on a schedule of two round trips daily. Two chair cars, a baggage-passenger car and a tavern-observation car, with a total seating capacity of 208, make up the new train.

TULKARM, Palestine, June 28 -- As a result of the Arab boycott of the United Nations Committee of Inquiry on Palestine, United States newspapermen were barred today from the grounds of an American Institution visited by the committee, the Friends Mission School in the Arab Christian town of Ramallah.
The season just ended at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, was the fourth consecutive one to realize more than $6,000,000 in auction sales.

OUT of many seasons' experience in working with the junior members of a Maine yacht club, the author has spliced together into a shipshape volume a course of instruction for small boat beginners and a manual for the more seasoned sailor.

PARIS, June 28 -- Amid the complex post-war stirrings and new games of power politics being developed in the uneasy world is a huge realm of primary importance which, as an entity, is rarely considered: that of resurgent Islam. Since the days of the Prophet Mohammed and his energetic followers, whose aggressive activities persisted through the Middle Ages, the Islamic world, as such, has been a negative factor in world affairs.

VERY few novels for young people have dealt with divorce; none of them have centered quite so directly on the problem as does Miss Lewiton's. Yet there are many girls who, like the 15-year-old Julie, must have felt the hidden tension between two beloved people, have tried to shut it out and, in the end, faced an inevitable separation.

A SUMMER exhibition of painting's by French and American artists has opened at the Wildenstein Galleries. "Melting Snow at I'Estaque," seen in the recent Cezanne show, renews its appeal and suggests that that French master certainly influenced Vlaminck.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 28 -- Despite the continued silence of the United States, it is still hoped that the United Nations will be permitted to play a major part in working out the Marshall plan for European reconstruction.
KALAMAZOO, Mich., June 28 -- California's batting power again proved too much for Yale today and the Golden Bears won college baseball's first world series in two straight games by defeating the

THIS is the third novel by Prince zu Loewenstein dealing with the life of Christ and the beginnings of Christianity. It carries the story through cue period immediately following the Crucifixion. Simply told, with just enough plot complication to keep the narrative moving along, the novel emphasizes the conception of a universal and united Christianity paralleling a single world state, the Roman Empire.

CHICAGO, June 28 (AP) -- Directors of the Progressive Citizens of America declared today the voters in the United States should "be guaranteed the opportunity, by a new party if necessary, to have a clear choice between progressive and reactionary candidates for President."

EUROPE has switched roles with America. She is now the isolated continent. She is now the continent that has not made up its mind. In the same way that America was uncertain twenty-five years ago, Europe is uncertain today what her right role is in a world where her accustomed position has been shattered and all the standards of the past are being called in question.

MUNICH, June 28 (AP) -- Speakers from seven countries exhorted a German youth rally here today to break away from warlike traditions and build a new and democratic Germany that will help preserve international peace.
JERUSALEM, June 28 -- Two British soldiers were killed and five wounded tonight in Tel Aviv and Haifa when terrorist warfare broke out on a large scale.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., June 28 -- New Zealand's determination to retain her foreign trade quota system and Finance Minister Walter Nash's recent defense of it were attacked today by The Evening Post, which supported the United States demand to Geneva that these restrictive practices end.

The United States has "missed the boat," to a large extent, by not asking that its overseas war surplus be paid for in strategic materials that could be stockpiled for the future, Senator William F. Knowland said last night.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. REMARK to a Missourian that his State is just now the first State of the Union and he gives you a funny look, as much as to say, "Are you telling me? Listen, stranger, Missouri has been this country's No. 1 State as far back as I can remember."

IN the thirty-six years he has been a top Hollywood camera man, Joseph August has run the photographic gamut from bang-up, two-reel Westerns to the murky mood cinematography of "The Informer" and from hazardous underwater submarine scenes to the romantic doings of Jennifer Jones and Joseph Cotten in "Portrait of Jennie," which he is now shooting around town.

OF all the volumes issued so far in the admirable series of Viking Portables, this one, in my opinion, is the best. Much of the credit for this distinction must go to Dante himself; for in his case it is as easy to select the essential works as, in Shakespeare's, it is impossible.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Although Gov. Thomas E. Dewey continues well in the lead, choice of the Republican Presidential nominee for 1948 may be decided by United States relations with Russia and the third-party plans of Henry A. Wallace, according to former Gov. Alfred M. Landon of Kansas.

While endorsing in part the measure designed to amend the city's administrative code in relation to exits and fire protective requirements for certain multiple dwellings, the New York State Society of Professional Engineers, Inc., protested yesterday, in a letter to Mayor O'Dwyer, that in its present form the bill offers "a threat to public safety."

To avoid the alternative of housing built almost entirely by Government agencies, inducements and advantages must be made available to private builders and investors, according to a report of the housing policy committee of the Northeastern Retail Lumbermen's Association.

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 28 -- Putting an end to her rival's hopes by winning eight straight holes on the first nine of the afternoon round. Miss Laddie Irwin of Glen Ridge won her first Metropolitan golf championship today. She defeated Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of Piping Rock, 8 and 7, in a thirty-six-hole final over the Century Country Club course.

BERLIN, June 28 -- The Soviet sone's new Economic Commission, which has been compared to the western zones' Economic Council, met yesterday. The high point, according to authoritiative reports, came in an assurance to German leaders that the new program is not designed to increase reparations to Russia.

The present widespread debate over universal military training centers on arguments that have arisen since the President's Advisory Commission recommended six months' basic training for youths of 18 and six months' supplementary training, or education. In view of the debate several questions about UMT were put to Robert P. Patterson, Secretary of War.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 28 -- The New Rochelle Yacht Club staged its first regatta of the season and the twelfth Y.R.A. championship event of the year today in a good, steady south-southwest breeze which came up after a 15minute postponement of starts.

The worst crisis in its history looms for the aircraft manufacturing industry unless the Government quickly outlines a long-term plane-procurement program and a national policy for sponsoring the engineering and development of new craft, industry officials told Congressional committees recently.

MISS SCOTT outdoes all the recent case histories of dipsomania in this raw revelation of pathological drunkenness. Her hero -- or rather victim -- not only loses week-ends but whole years from his tortured existence, and, in the inevitable catastrophe, life itself.

THE Postoffice Department announced last week that a 25-cent blue airmail stamp "intended for use on mail destined to Pacific and Asiatic areas and to portions of Africa" would be issued on July 30, with first-day sale in San Franciso.

THIS season the national parks and Western mountains are getting at least a fourth of the vacationists who have more than two weeks to spend on a holiday trip, according to local travel bureaus. It is as though Americans had suddenly discovered how much their parks have to offer, one bureau head says.

NEW DELHI, India, June 28 -- The Moslem League's president Mohammed Ali Jinnah, plunged tonight into the North-West Frontier Province-Pathan controversy, which shares attention with the independence of Hyderbad and Travancore States as a question of major importance in India at this moment.

ALTHOUGH there are such matters as a brace of productions in the making at his Shepperton and Worton Hall Studios near London, Sir Alexander Korda is not rusticating. The titled film maker has formed an alliance with none other than Cary Grant and the pair will make an independent film, which probably will go before the cameras in October.

A prediction that the current realty market "boom" in New Jersey will continue for ten to twelve years was made by Ray A. Mulhern, vice president of the Underwood Mortgage and Title Company of Irvington, N.J., at a recent meeting of the Women's Council of the Board of Realtors of the Oranges and Maplewood, N.J.

JERUSALEM, June 28 -- In a 12,000-word document outlining its case, Irgun Zyai Leumi, terrorist underground organization, gave the United Nations Committee of Inquiry on Palestine today a five-point plan "solving" the Palestine problem once and for all.

CLEVELAND, June 28 (U.P.) -- Coroner Samuel Gerber completed his investigation of the ring death of Jimmy Doyle today with the questioning of Promoter Larry Atkins, Referee Jackie Davis and Cleveland Boxing Commission physician A.E. Hagedorn.

PACKED in these covers is a wide variety of literary smorgasbord for those who read and run. For the psychiatricminded, the clinical studies (both male and female) are of the more elegant type: for readers who follow the antics of those addicted to the little brown jug, the material is plentiful.

AFTER staging what was an almost overnight change to the favorable side, business sentiment last week seemed to fall back to uncertainty again. Labor repercussions to the legislation which was passed over the Truman veto represented the chief cause and for obvious reasons.

Application of the community spirit to a solution of the housing problem is recommended by Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, who advises meetings of realty and financing interests, builders and leaders in the building trades unions to spur new construction.

One of two experts representing the United States, Dr. Edward Lasker of New York started off with a well-earned victory in the first round of the international chess masters tournament at the newly organized Club de Ajedrez Capablanca of Havana, according to a report received yesterday from Cuba.

For the first time in twelve years labor-management relations last week were governed by a new "book of rules." On Monday the Senate, by six votes more than the necessary two-thirds majority, passed the Labor -Management Relations Act, 1947, over the President's veto.

SAINT LOUIS -- Philosophy Summary Graduate philosophy studies at Saint Louis University have been summarized and defined in a bulletin now being distributed. The sixteen-page publication declared that "every graduate student will be expected to acquire a thorough and integrated understanding of Thomistic philosophy and to learn to use it as a basis of progress and as a criterion of philosophical evaluation."
Mort Cooper made his first appearance at the Polo Grounds in a Giant uniform yesterday. Apparently everybody on the premises, including the Phillies, was determined to make a success of it.

The thunder from the Labor front which filled the air before the TaftHartley Act became the law of the land seems to be abating. It is no longer described in flaring newspaper advertisements as the "Slave-Labor Bill." It is denounced in no uproarious meetings.

For the better part of two sets, Sidney Wood was again the master of Wimbledon yesterday. Then fatigue blighted the touch of one of the most gifted hands to hold a tennis racquet and an attack of baffling variety and rare skill fizzled out in defeat.

PARIS, June 28 -- World communism indicated for the first time last night its intention of seeking to establish a "Free Greek Government" in that part of northern Greece where the Leftist partisans are fighting.

TWO major conducting vacancies have been filled. The position as conductor of the Duluth Symphony Orchestra has gone to Joseph Wagner, assistant professor of music at Brooklyn College, and the leadership of the Utah Symphony has gone to Maurice Abravanel.

A 12-year-old girl picked up 366 jacks yesterday in the city-wide finals of the jacks contest sponsored by the Department of Parks to win first prize, a small goldfilled medal, and the city championship.
The Bronx Zoo solved a major problem yesterday when a couple of sea lions were evicted from the Bronx Zoo in preparation for a trip to Paris.

ON Friday, the start of the Independence Day week-end, Americans will set out to cover some 4,000,000,000 road miles in 30,000,000 motor cars. They will happily ignore warnings from police chiefs, automobile club statisticians and others that seme of their number must surely die -- so many on the road, so many by drowning, so many by fireworks.

-- WAGING PEACE-FARE An Iowa railroad fireman has shown one way for the voice of America to be heard where needed. Having some spare time and $22.50 on his hands, he called up Foreign Minister Molotov in Moscow.

IN the belief that opportunities lost by producers to develop fully unique story ideas are of greater consequence to the progress of pictorial expression than is the successful production of a variation on an old theme, we would like to call attention to a little film entitled "My Brother Talks to Horses."

Strike committees of the CIO shipyard workers prepared yesterday to go ahead with a nationwide walkout at 12:01 A.M. Tuesday, with no evidence that its wage and working dispute with employers might be settled by deadline time.

The main reason why John Kiszkiel, 29 years old, was in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday was that Melvin Kelman, 18, wants to be a detective and was out practicing on the night of June 17. As a consequence of Kelman's efforts Kiszkiel was arraigned on a charge of burglary before Magistrate Charles E. Hirsimaki and held in $2,500 bail for a hearing Wednesday.

ELSEWHERE in this issue is a note on Maxwell Evarts Perkins, whose recent death removed one of the outstanding figures in American book publishing. The reading public has, I think, little conception of the part played by men of his caliber in influencing the course of contemporary writing.

TO THE EDITOR: In William D. Ogdon's "All for a Cent," I notice that, in telling of the history of the postcard, he jumps from 1890, when Heinrich Lange, a German stationer, was using picture postcards, to 1905 -- and here is where my husband comes into the picture.

MAMMOTH HOT SPRINGS, Yellowstone National Park, Wyo. -- A special ten-day horseback trip, to be known as the Diamond Jubilee Trail Ride, is scheduled for Aug. 19-27 as part of the observance of the seventy-fifth anniversary of Yellowstone as a national park.

ARCHITECTS hardly ever talk about porches or terraces any more. The new phrase is "outdoor living area" and modern site planners place it where it will have at least as much privacy as the indoor living room or the kitchen. Our daily chores and pleasures have become so tied up with the watt and ampere, however, that no living area can function on a sixteen-hour-a-day schedule unless it is wired for electricity.

MONTREAL, June 28 -- The Central Conference of American Rabbis, at its fifty-eighth annual convention, declared today that "mixed marriages are contrary to the tradition of the Jewish religion and should therefore be discouraged by the American rabbinate."
SAVANNAH, Ga., June 28 -- King Cotton is dead in Savannah, the most famous of the Old South's cotton ports, and the stately pine tree is the new ruler.

PARIS. CAMUS' new novel: The publication of Albert Camus' new book, "The Plague" ("La Peste"), his first full-length novel, confirms his position as one of the most important figures of the generation of French writers which has emerged since 1940.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Officials of the Maritime Commission testified yesterday that they fear "collusion" might result on sales of the Government's wartime ships under a provision voted by the House when it trimmed the agency's operating fund $73,000,000 for the coming fiscal year.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y. June 28 -- Dr. Jesse Hoyt Haley of 949 Palmer Road, principal of Public School 83, the Bronx, assigned to the division of child welfare of the New York Board of Education, died today in Bronxville Hospital after a long illness. His age was 65.

Part-time student-veterans in the University of Cincinnati's Evening College who are employed during the day have equaled and in some respects surpassed the generally high records made by their fellow-ex-service men who are regular full-time day students. The evening veterans have also outperformed their non-veteran classmates.

DETROIT, June 28 -- An estimated 5,000 employes of the Ford Motor Company will be eligible for pension benefits immediately when the retirement plan, agreed to yesterday by the company and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, becomes effective.

DEER that wander through the neighborhood from nearby open spaces or reservations harass gardeners in many sections. State game laws vary, and control of damage by shooting the deer should not be undertaken without consultation with the proper authorities.

New York City has about 475,000 real estate taxpayers who own 830,675 parcels of property assessed at $16,938,467,453. This week the city tax collector's office will begin preparing the 1947-48 cream colored forms (one for each parcel) which list the assessed valuation, total amount of taxes for the year and the semi-annual payments due in October and April.

A careful check on customers to make sure that new cars will not be sold after delivery for speculative profits was urged yesterday by Fred L. Yarrington, president of the Automobile Merchants Association of New York, as a measure to curb over-price sales of "new-used" cars.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The six "most significant" chapters of the inside story of the war and post-war conferences being written by James F. Byrnes, former Secretary of State, will be published by The New York Herald Tribune and other newspapers throughout the world in a series of installments, an announcement said tonight.

The season for black bass opens in most of New York State on Tuesday. Mention of that fact in this space the other day prompted Ralph C. Benedict of Brooklyn College, currently at Pilot Knob, N.Y., to forward some observations that may interest you.

WITH the exception of "Power for the Small Boat," these three books will appeal primarily to the experienced sailing man. That applies particularly to "Blue Water Navigation," for the celestial triangle is one thing the average yachtsman can ignore until he has mastered piloting and built a sturdy pair of sea legs.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower told Congress today that the Army he leads is "a poor second" to Russia's.

FOLLOWING the disclosure that Theatre Incorporated may be involved in the importation of Palestine's renowned Habimah Theatre in the fall, the departmental operative now arrives with equally cheering news that Theatre Incorporated also may bring over Old Vic in the spring.

As city life grows ever more complicated and civilized, the idea of a vacation down on the farm close to nature sounds more inviting to more people. This year, it is estimated, more than a couple of hundred thousand of city dwellers will spend their vacations on "dude farms" in the Catskills, the Poconos and the Berkshire Mountains.
AS I was about to fly to Spain recently some one suggested: "Find out what the Spanish people are reading and writing. By the written word perhaps we shall know them."

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today adopted a resolution aimed at barring from the organization "any organized clique, political party or religious group" seeking to seize control of any part of the NAACP "for the purpose of undermining the program to which the association is dedicated."
Dr. Vannevar Bush pointed out again last week to a Congressional committee that the era of "pushbutton war" was far away.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The text of an interim report to President Truman by the President's Special Board of Inquiry on Air Safety was as follows: PRESIDENT'S SPECIAL BOARD' OF INQUIRY ON AIR SAFETY WASHINGTON, D.C.

A SITE with poor soil does not make a flower garden impossible. Even though time and labor may be limited, an attractive planting that increases pleasure in outdoor living and provides flowers for cutting can be worked out successfully.

BASEBALL The Giants, behind Mort Cooper, unleashed a 16-hit barrage on Al Jurisich to rout the Phils. 14 to 6. Walker Cooper, the other half of the brotherbattery, poled his seventh home run in six consecutive games to tie a 23-year record held by George Kelly, a former Giant.

LONDON, June 28 -- Budge Patty, 23-year-old ex-GI from Los Angeles, assumed the role of giant killer at the Wimbledon tennis championships today when he blasted Australia's second-seeded veteran, John Bromwich, out of the singles division, 6-4, 0-6 6-4, 1-6, 6-4.

On Friday of this week 171 years will have passed since we, as a nation, gained our independence. In the Revolutionary War following that July 4, 1776, 4,044 Americans lost their lives and 6,004 became permanently disabled. However, these were not the only casualties of the War for Independence.
TOKYO, Sunday, June 29 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur disclosed today that Korean Rightists had failed in an attempt to take over the Government of southern Korea in March.

HOUSTON, Tex., June 28 -- Army and Navy officials and representatives of some Government bureaus were accused today of attempting to stampede public opinion into believing the country is dangerously short of crude oil.

Reports that needs for foreign economic rehabilitation to be disclosed by the Marshall Plan investigators will total from five billion to six billion dollars annually for several years are "grossly exaggerated," according to financial observers here.
Eighteen weeks of opera have been scheduled for the Metropolitan Opera House for the 1947-48 season, which is to equal in length the highly successful 1946-47 season.

KETCHIKAN, Alaska, June 28 -- A herd of shaggy-coated musk oxen, each animal possessing a surly temper and twice the bulk of a reindeer, has become a topic of lively controversy among the people of Alaska, the musk oxen inhabit lonely Nunivak Island in Bering Sea; they were brought from Greenland a few years ago as an experiment to determine whether they could be raised domestically for food as well as for their wool.

THE burden of this little sea chantey, in its symbolic aspects, concerns the problem of man in relation to the machine world he has created. Mr. Loughlin writes of his central character: Lately he had felt, keenly and personally, the utter dependence of the modern American on his implements.

With the new trade-mark law going into effect in seven more days, manufacturers and merchants indicated last week that the year-long waiting period after enactment has contributed very little to clarify the many doubts that exist concerning advantages of registering under the new law.
FOR the fourth consecutive year, WQXR will observe the July 4 holiday by scheduling nothing but American music by American composers from 7 A.M. until sign-off at midnight.

Coming from far back in each race with his distinctive galloping charge down the home stretch, Reggie Pearman of the Pioneer Club scored a spectacular double triumph in the 440 and 880-yard runs in the Metropolitan A.A.U. senior track and field championships at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday.

ROME, June 28 -- Italy is located on the very edge of a vast Communist empire which stretches from Vladivostok to the very heart of Europe. It, therefore, seems the next logical place for communism to strike if its westward expansion is to continue.
A heat wave sent the mercury up to 87.2 degrees at 1:05 P.M. yesterday to make June 28 the hottest day of the year. The humidity stood at 55 per cent at the time.

Volume buyers of industrial commodities may find attractive offers for future delivery with price decline protection, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents revealed in their monthly report. Producers cutting down their abnormal backlogs for replacement demand are offering inducements for future firm coverage, the survey disclosed.

THIS is the story of "God's Messenger to Japan," Gen. Douglas MacArthur and his willing "Charlie," the very much dedeified Emperor Hirohito; of the amazing American GI, "the best ambassador the United States ever had," and his somewhat bawdy Madame Butterfly; of equally amazing American correspondents in their extracurricular hunts for top-level war criminals; and of Suzuki-san, the bedraggled Japanese-in-the-street who gropes his arduous way to political adolescence.

THE new catalogue of the Drinker Library of Choral Music, which will appear next fall, is a perfectly amazing document; amazing not only for what it tells of a library of noble contents, but for what It represents of the labors of a single man, not a musician by profession, but passionately addicted to music; and for the fundamentally democratic concept of musical culture which it embodies, and which it aims to spread.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Some dissension among soft coal operators was reported today over the private wage offer of two major producers to John L. Lewis, President of the United Mine Workers.

BOSTON, June 28 -- That $50,000 tag on Hank Behrman was marked down slightly today when Earl (Specs) Torgeson belted a chalk line double to right in the ninth inning with two out to give the Braves a 5 -- 4 triumph. This cut the Dodger's first-place lead to only half a game.

STANTON, Del., June 28 (AP) -- Royal Blood, royally bred 2-yearold son of Coldstream and Spotted Beauty who cost Mrs. Elizabeth N. Graham (Maine Chance Farm) $50,000 at the 1946 yearling sales, scored his first stakes victory and became a contender for honors in his division when he won the Dover Stakes at Delaware Park today.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 28 (AP) -- Polynesian, rated one of the nation's outstanding sprinters, outraced the field in the early stages, then fought off a stretch bid by Flash Burn, to win the $10,000 added Long Branch Handicap by a nose at Monmouth Park today, despite being assigned top weight of 129 pounds.
BOSTON, June 28 (U.P.) -- Douglas Chandler, former Baltimore newsman, was convicted of treason today for broadcasting propaganda for the Nazis during World War II.
CHICAGO, June 28 (AP) -- The Cubs won two games from the Pirates today, 6 to 2 and 6 to 5, ending a four-game losing streak before 37,111 fans.

Stymie rang the cash register yesterday in the $25,000 added Questionnaire Handicap, highlight of the Empire City-at-Jamaica proceeding's, and with the smashing victory skipped past Whirlaway into second place on racing's world money-winning roster.

Another of the "heroines" of World War II, the Standard Fruit Steamship Company's Contessa, is due to return to private operation this week after a wartime career that included service in the Atlantic, Pacific and Indian Oceans, it was disclosed yesterday.

PARIS, June 28 -- Although a compromise in the coal strike that will permit the resumption of work in the mines on Monday was announced tonight, the French political crisis has resolved itself into a question whether the Communists will be called back to the Government.

The United States Treasury Department last week was one of the busiest places in all of sultry Washington. Congress, after five months of trying to trim President Truman's budget estimates to the level desired by the economy-minded Republican majority, was in one of the worst appropriation tie-ups in a number of years.

NO sport, or maybe I should say industry, ever had a more tireless historian and apologist than baseball has in J.G. Taylor Spink, publisher of The Sporting News, which is often spoken of, with no demurrer from Mr. Spink, as "baseball's bible."

A FEW years ago Mr. Rogers Bordley, well-known art critic, advanced a startling theory which may become the art world's equivalent of the ShakespeareBacon controversy. It was Mr. Bordley's contention, briefly, that most of the great paintings attributed to the Flemish master Peter-Paul Rubens were actually the work of a forgotten Antwerp artist named Frans Snyders.

IT was eminently fitting for Bill Mauldin to write the preface to Allen Matthews' diary of the first twelve days on Two Jima. It was Mauldin's cartoons which kept the doughfeet laughing at their own misery, and Matthews tells of that misery as well as it has ever been told.
Narcotics smuggling on the Atlantic Coast is on the increase and New York Customs authorities are tightening port surveillance to lessen the traffic, it was reported yesterday.

VIENNA, June 28 -- Matyas Rakosi, architect of the Communist coup in Hungary, by choosing to visit Prague this week, brought into sudden prominence the question of just what the Czechoslovak Communists plan.

CHICAGO, June 28 (AP) -- Selling in expanded volume entered the corn pit on the Board of Trade today and prices broke several cents a bushel. Wheat and oats were lower most of the session, although deferred wheat contracts displayed a firm undertone.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 28 -- Paced by Herb McKenley's worldrecord bettering quarter-mile run and other outstanding performances. Big Nine athletes scored a smashing 94 1/2-37 1/2 victory over Pacific Coast Conference rivals today in their all-star track and field meet.

BERLIN, June 28 -- In a hall lavishly decorated with the colors of the Weimar Republic, the new Bizonal Economic Council held its first meeting last Wednesday in Frankfort on Main, new capital of the Anglo-American zones.
FOR the second time within the past eighteen months the President by a Health Message has refocused the nation's attention on our greatest national asset the health of our citizens.

THE writings of humorist James Thurber constitute one of the most remarkable menageries of the human animal in existence. Chief among the specimens is the Thurber Male -- a strange class of men who are uniformly henpecked, harassed and, sometimes, haunted by their women and even their dogs. Now Hollywood, through the offices of Samuel Goldwyn, producer, and Danny Kaye, star, has undertaken to translate the Thurber Male to the screen.

As a consequence of his epochal triumph in the British Amateur championship, Willie Turnesa of Knollwood has received the honor rating of plus one on the first of the 1947 handicap lists issued by the Metropolitan Golf Association.
KEARNY, N.J., June 28 -- Trygve Hammer, painter, sculptor and well-known art teacher, died this morning in his home at 87 Belgrove Drive after a long illness. He was 69 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- President Truman is expected to sign early next week the Republicansponsored bill extending rent controls to March 1 and authorizing 15 per cent "voluntary" rent increases. He has until midnight Wednesday to act on the measure.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Senator Joseph H. Ball, Republican, of Minnesota, declared tonight in a radio discussion of the Marshall plan for the rehabilitation of Europe that Congress "is not anxious to appropriate funds to keep people over there on a dole while Communists use their power to block any realistic program for recovery."

THE Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival (near Lee, Mass.) under the new direction of Arthur Mahoney and Thalia Mara, gets under way with its first set of performances on Friday and Saturday afternoons and Saturday evening.

The National Retail Furniture Association will conduct a special sales training school for owners of 675 furniture stores throughout the country at the Chicago furniture market which begins July 7, James P. Oliver, merchandising director, said at the local offices last week.
ONE line of the children's hymn was "How strong and sweet my Father's care." But one little girl never got it right. As seriously as the rest she always sang. "How strong and swift my father's cane."

POLIO VACCINE -- Monkeys have been successfully vaccinated against polio with live virus by Drs. Isabel M. Morgan, Howard A. Howe and David Bodian of Johns Hopkins University, but the vaccination of human beings in the same way is still considered too dangerous.

A CLEMATIS vine in full bloom never fails to be admired. An amazing quantity of starry blossoms covers each seemingly fragile plant. Rare, however, is the garden containing this beautiful perennial vine in any of its varieties.

In the cream and gilt Salon des Perroquets in Paris' Palais de Quai d'Orsay last Friday the Foreign Ministers of Great Britain, the Soviet Union and the French Republic gathered around the table for a unique conference.

It is impossible to strain every political element out of the meeting in Paris of three foreign ministers, each flanked by advisers and experts, each in close communication with his own government, each instinctively putting his own country's interests ahead o those of other countries.

RICHMOND, June 28 -- In the light of "the dollar situation," the tobacco industry of Virginia is disturbed over export trade. It was one of the chief subjects discussed by members of the Tobacco Association of the United States and Leaf Exporters Association in session at Virginia Beach earlier this month.

STADIUM CONCERTS Lewisohn Stadium, 8:30 P.M. Monday. Conductor, Smallens; Mischa Elman, violinist. Brahms' Symphony No. 1: Schumann's Manfred Overture: Mendelssohn's Violin Concerto in E minor. Tuesday. Conductor, Smallens.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The State Department said today that instructions were despatched Wednesday night to Waller A. Foote, American Consul General at Batavia, to urge both sides in the Indonesian controversy to cooperate in working out promptly an interim Federal Government.

The Army wanted to know how much work soldiers can perform in hot climates without danger and the effect of clothing on the amount of work that can be done. So the Department of Physiology of Indiana University's Medical School conducted some investigations for the Quartermaster Corps.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, June 28 (AP) -- As Government forces drove toward flaming Szepingkai today, their leaders reported that 50,000 Communist troops -- three-fifths of the entire Red striking force in Manchuria -- had been killed or captured in this costliest battle of the past year.

THE time has come to catch up with the recording's of folk music, which has its own and expanding following. The new albums contain a wide range of material, including song's of America, Spain and even an album of Songs From the Ghetto, made secretly in Berlin at the height of the Hitler terror.

"THE GREAT BEYOND" is a work made up of aphorisms and dialogues, illuminating some of the author's ponderous concerns -- the relation of man's soul to the infinite, the mysterious nature of death, imagination, memory.

THIS novel by Jose Revueltas was Mexico's entry in the recent Latin-American prize novel contest. It is to be hoped that the camera (the story is now being filmed in Mexico) will serve to focus the contours and context that Mr. Revueltas' involved construction and involved symbolism fatally obscure.

WITH the aid of a deftly contrived projection lantern and a small shadow-box model stage, Boris Aronson is demonstrating at the Museum of Modern Art some of the possibilities inherent in the technique that he calls "painting with light."
FLOWERS play a major part in the decoration of the house for the Fourth of July. Red, white and blue bouquets from the garden carry out the spirit of the holiday.

NOVELTY is no longer an attribute of Russian literature. On the verdict of reprints, Tolstoy and Dostoevsky would seem to be already more popular with our public than Balzac and Flaubert, to have long since passed Goethe and Schiller, to gain daily on Dickens and Thackeray.

MY most violent enthusiasm ? Well, my dears, for all you've heard to the contrary, and I guess you've heard plenty, it's the New York Giants. When they win I want to do cartwheels on top of their dugout -- and don't think I can't. When they lose, my vichyssoise is curdled, to say nothing of my gizzard.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- The Democratic National Committee billed the Taft-Harley Labor Act as a political campaign issue today with an assertion by Gael Sullivan, its director, that it had arrayed his party members "dramatically in opposition to GOP reaction."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 28 -- At midnight Monday the fouryear career of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration will come to an end. The job of caring for Europe's 1,000,000 refugees will be handed to an agency that still has not been officially set up, the International Refugee Organization.

Laugh, Serf, Laugh That was a very good political anecdote which The Herald Tribune's Madrid correspondent reported the other day, but for a long time now it has been difficult to read anecdotes from Europe with a glad heart.

Two flying policemen, who flagged down their quarry high over the Rockaways and later served a summons at Floyd Bennett Field, demonstrated yesterday that the future of private flying may not be as carefree as it seems.

HOLLYWOOD. ON the movie lot where Mack Sennett last glorified the custard pie and where today the six-guns crack in Republic's sagebrush dramas, Shakespeare has returned to Hollywood. This past week Orson Welles stepped before the camera and launched a unique effort to put "Macbeth" on film in twenty-one days.

The award of two $1,750 scholarships for study leading to the degrees of Master of Science in Naval Architecture and Master of Science in Maritime Engineering was announced yesterday by the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers.

The decision last week of the Supreme Court of the United States in the California tidelands case may raise more questions than it settled. In deciding that the Federal Government owned the bed of the ocean off California from the low-water mark to the three-mile limit, the court held that this stemmed from the principle that "peace and world commerce are the paramount responsibilities of the nation rather than of an individual state."

Tenant occupancy is set for Tuesday in the four-story fortyfive-family garden apartment of the Bank for Savings at the northeast corner of Seventy-second Street and Third Avenue. Space in the building for the bank's branch office, now at Third Avenue and Seventieth Street, is scheduled to be available in September.

New York Retail trade here last week turned "soft," with demand for seasonal merchandise reduced somewhat by abnormally cool weather during much of the period. Department store sales were estimated at about 2 per cent over last year as compared with recent gains ranging up to 10 per cent.

Daisies gleam along the untrimmed roadsides and stand in drifts of white at the fence corners. Some call them Farmer's Curse, but they are flowers of the chrysanthemum family. The common field daisy, often called oxeye daisy, is botanically Chrysanthemum leucanthemum, and it is cousin of the herb Feverfew, which was brought from Europe long ago and naturalized into our gardens.

IN the foreword to this curious book, which is not exactly history but which is nothing else, either, Mr. Hale reveals how he happened to write it. He was talking to his publisher and wagered that he had forgotten most of the American history he had learned.

THE South Carolina Unionist whose career is the concern of this enlightening volume was born in 1805, the year after John C. Calhoun was graduated from Yale College. He was, like Calhoun, a Carolina up-countryman; but, while Calhoun's ancestors were Ulstermen -- which means Scots who came by way of Ireland -- Perry's came from England by way of several generations of New Englanders.

OMAHA, June 28 -- Americans are meat-hungry. The hard-pressed shopper in sea-board butcher shops may have his own view of current meat prices, but the men of the range country and the booted commission people in cattle runs at Midwest stockyards point to the statistics.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The greatest congestion of appropriations bills in the memory of veteran aides at the Capitol faced Congress today as the Federal Government approached the new fiscal year, which begins Tuesday, without any funds whatever having yet been provided for its continued operation.
TO THE EDITOR: Your picture feature, "Custard -Pie Classics," concerning the old Mack Sennett comedies, is a quick and happy trip back to a more innocent time. My only criticism: not enough of it.
President Truman signed legislation in Washington yesterday extending the authority of the Maritime Commission to continue the operation of ships and the ship disposal program.

AMATEURS with cameras having top shutter speeds of only 1/100th or 1/200th of a second need not be deterred from shooting fast action which normally calls for higher speeds to stop movement. The generous lighting of the summer season permits the use of very high shutter speeds to insure overall sharpness, and the tendency is to use the fastest shutter speed possible to stop the action completely.
LONDON, June 28 (U.P.) -- British newspapers today defended Foreign Secretary Bavin's blackout on news about the three power conference in Paris on the Marshall plan.

WESTPORT, Conn. June 28 -- My Bill, chestnut gelding owned and ridden by Mrs. Hank Greenberg of New York City, leads the field of 136 horses entered in the Fairfield County Hunt Club show in the number of ribbons earned, having garnered four blues in addition to two seconds and three thirds yesterday and today.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 28 -- With Chris Dunphy, Meadow Brook club guest, equaling the course record of 67, he and John R. Fell defeated Bradley Collins and W.E. Stockhausen, Garden City Golf, in the quarter-finals of the Piping Rock invitation golf tournament today.

THIS is one of the moat ambitious general commentaries on psychic matters that has ever been attempted. And though it is based on such authorities as J.B. Rhine (for extra-sensory perception), Whately Carrington (for telepathy) and Gelet and Schrenck-Notzing (for materialization), it is by no means confined to the study of what we generally call abnormal or supernormal experiences.
ROME, June 28 (AP) -- Pope Pius XII today awarded the Great Cross of the Order of Pius IX to President Juan Peron of Argentina.

Details of plans for apartment house developments in Manhattan and New Jersey to accommodate about 600 families were announced yesterday by Milton L. Ehrlich, veteran apartment builder and president of Milton L. Ehrlich, Inc. The builders are undertaking three projects -- one in Manhattan and two in New Jersey -- and estimate the total cost at $4,665,000.

TO see a few clumps of the peach-leaved bellflower in bloom in the border is certain to make a gardener wish for more plants of the same kind for next year's enjoyment. It isn't hard to decide that this perennial bellflower, Campanula persicifolia, is especially worth increasing.

PARIS, June 28 -- The conference of British, Soviet and French Foreign Ministers on the Marshall plan seemed doomed tonight after Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov had flatly refused to accept the principle of a common European economic plan, upon which the present discussions were based.

IN the light of the vituperative controversy over programs for young listeners, the Saturday morning lineup of children's fare on WNBC comes close to being a true bonanza for the harried parent. Put together by James M. Gatnes, manager of the station, it cumulatively provides entertainment, guidance and, perhaps most important, a sense of participation for the child devotee of the loudspeaker.
ROME, June 28 (U.P.) -- Senora Peron told an audience of 600 women today that her name had become a "battle cry" for women the world over.

SCULPTURE by Robert Cronbach and Harold Ambellan is being shown at the Fortyfourth Street Gallery and Bookfair. Some of these pieces are recent; others date back a decade. Both men are modern in spirit. Cronbach has essayed quite effectively modern genre in pieces such as "Industry" and "Committee Meeting," and, also, in the "Engine Room" which was shown at the Whitney last season.

ROSES seem to be everywhere when, at the end of June, climbing binds add their multitude of blossoms to bush roses. The climbers flaunt their colors from fences, walls and banks as well as draping such restricted positions as gateways and ordinary posts.

MUNICH, June 28 -- More than 1,000 German boys and girls from various parts of the country met here today for an international conference. They vigorously applauded every mention of the need for world unity to ensure the welfare of humanity.

Now that the Taft-Hartley LaborManagement Relations Act has become the law of the land, its tremendous significance for peace and prosperity has become more apparent. If this law works, the United States can have labor-management cooperation instead of class war.

MEXICO CITY, June 28 -- On almost any street corner in Mexico this summer the gringo tourist is likely to be confronted by an agent of Mexico's National Lottery. Stop at a traffic light and he is at the car window with a sheaf of tickets importuning you to win a fortune at a spin of the wheel.

Although the influx has passed its peak, large numbers of buyers continued to visit the market last week, according to a market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company. Noted was a good demand for piece goods, wash goods and domestics.

THE radio industry had a double measure of confusion in labor matters last week. Union leaders and industry executives not only had to study how the Taft-Hartley Labor Law would revise their existing relations but also had to take into account the Supreme Court's decision upholding in part the Lea act directed against James C. Petrillo.

Headed by Miss Florence Schmitt, United States long distance champion from Port Washington, L.I., national and metropolitan titleholders will make their initial 1947 bid for metropolitan outdoor swimming crowns in an A.A.U. meet to be held at the Raven Hall pool in Coney Island this afternoon.

CHICAGO, June 28 (AP) -- Ben Hogan of Hershey, Pa., slashing a five-under-par 66, zoomed into the three-quarter mark lead of the $15,900 Chicago Victory National golf tourney today with a fiftyfour-hole aggregate of 200, thirteen under par.

VALLEY CITY, N.D., June 28 -- This North Dakota city is temporarily quiet, as local business men wait for Don C. Matchan to sell The Times-Record. Matchan, whose editorial policy disturbed the conservative element in this tight little community, intends to sell as soon as he can find a buyer.
ST. LOUIS, June 28 -- The Mississippi River rose toward its greatest flood crest in 103 years here today.

GENEVA, June 28 -- In an address at the International Labor Conference today, Daniel Mayer, French Minister of Labor, said that the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe already was doing work similar to that proposed in the Marshall plan.

The effort of the Treasury in recent weeks to keep prices of long-term Government bonds from rising unduly by openmarket sales of Government trust-fund holdings is directing the attention of financial observers to the growing financial power accruing to these banking and insurance agencies by reason of their constant accumulation of reserves.
CLEVELAND, June 28 (AP) -- A two-run homer by Hank Edwards in the third inning today carried the Cleveland Indians to their third straight victory over the Chicago White Sox, 3 to 2.

MR. HILTON'S amiable book emphasizes above all that Mexico City is not Mexico. Honest residents of the capital must regard his tales of the northwestern border State of Sonora as dealing with a foreign land. It is a land lacking the growth and glitter, the fancy clothes and contemporary plumbing of the capital -- but a land to be preferred in many ways.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- When Gen. George C. Marshall held his first news conference after becoming Secretary of State in January he repeated over and over that he had "joined a team."

ST. LOUIS, June 28 (AP) -- Whitey Kurowski again turned apparent defeat into victory for the Cardinals when he came through with a two-run homer in the ninth inning tonight to give the Cards an 8-7 triumph over the Reds.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- A terse press release by the Navy Department ten days ago, disclosing an acute shortage of aviation gasoline, had developed by this week-end into a "situation of robust proportions."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: By overriding President Truman's veto last Monday, the Senate put into action laws and machinery which will change a pattern of managementlabor relationships that have been a controversial reality in our nation for twelve years.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., June 28 -- New York City's law, hitting discrimination against tenants has closed the door on scores of big, moderate-rent housing projects involving "many millions of dollars," realty leaders and mortgage executives revealed today.

The proposed fur labeling legislation now before Congress would cost the fur trade heavily without giving the consumer measurably greater protection than that which would be afforded if the present trade practice rules of the Federal Trade Commission were strictly enforced, it was stated in trade circles last week.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- A House Investigating subcommittee reported today that the record of war surplus property disposal was one of "confusion, carelessness and chaos." The replacement with civilians of Maj. Gen. Robert M. Littlejohn, the administrator, and other military men holding key posts, was recommended.

SIXTEEN years this week in this Review: Another proof -- if one were needed -- of Germany's surrender and abjectness before the military mind is seen in the review of the writings of Rudolf von Valetini, head of the Kaiser's Civil Cabinet.

IN Hollywood, where the peaches look for the plums, nothing is more coveted than a prize role. Scarlett O'Hara, Father Chisholm, Wilson, Bernadette, the man who came to dinner and good old Abe Lincoln have all had the actors casting sheep's eyes at the casting corners.

PITTSBURGH, June 28 -- The dingy mining communities were offering a study in bitterness and mental confusion as thousands of miners laid down their tools this week in protest over the TaftHartley labor law.

ELEVEN American and foreign airlines flying the Atlantic have been pondering fares all week, but as this is written there seems little likelihood of any immediate substantial change in the basic rate of $325 one way between New York and London.

THE job of the legendary Dutch boy who thrust his finger into the leaking dike and so, bless his heart, saved his lovely country from being engulfed by the angry sea, was child's play compared to a stint I had to do recently.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Federal Treasury is closing its books on the 1946 tax year with a record $1,500,000,000 in overpaid taxes refunded to income-tax payers.

Commodore Darius W. Sylvester's Gold Cup committee of the South Shore Y.C. is holding weekly sessions and sometimes oftener on a million and one details for the blue ribbon classic on Aug. 20 on Jamaica Bay, just inside Rockaway Inlet.

LIKE John Cheever in his "Town House" pieces in The New Yorker and Eric Hodgins in "Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House," Mr. McDonald apparently also feels that a man doesn't just shape his house -- very often the house takes over and shapes the man.

EVENING primroses are quite remarkable flowers. At about 3 o'clock every afternoon during their June-toAugust blooming season, they open with jerking motions that are startlingly sudden compared to the almost imperceptible unfolding of most blooms.

THE legitimate theatre, frequently the purveyor of gaiety, has dropped all pretense of frivolity in its discussions of a script prepared in Washington by Messrs. Taft and Hartley. Not even the threat of censorship or the promise of new theatres ever started so much conjecture.

ANYONE who wants to estimate trends and values in American writing current during 1947, runs at once into the inherent contradiction which governs literary events. The world of books is simultaneously managed on two contradictory time systems. One of these is publishing time, the other is literary time.

CONNIE MACK is such an ageless individual that time doesn't mean very much to him. One day before the turn of the century the fans in Meriden, Conn., presented a gold watch to him for being the most valuable player on the Meriden team. In his speech of acceptance the gentle Mr. Mack expressed his deep gratitude and promised to return some day for a visit with his friends.
LONDON. WITH the solid success of "Great Expectations" to encourage them, those enterprising young men, David Lean and Ronnie Neame of Cineguild, have gone on the floor with another Dickens subject.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 28 -- The Rev. Dr. William L. Scheding retired pastor of Mount Taboi Lutheran Church here and widely known Lutheran leader, died of a heart attack in his home here this morning, at the age of 65.

WHATEVER this novel intended to say about the creative spirit in travail, it has ended by telling a love story of melancholy enchantment, which is best listened to through its undertones. Andrew, a struggling artist, and Catherine, a passive dreamer, are presented in smooth stream-of-consciousness fashion.

IN the June issue of The Bridge world Magazine Oswald Jacoby advocates the elimination of the rubber from contract bridge scoring and the adoption, instead, of a method whereby the score is totaled and the players change partners after every four hands.
LONDON, June 28 -- Eros-Pixie of Picadilly Circus -- the winged God of Love who holds a special place in the hearts of all true Londoners, was back upon his plinth in London's center tonight.

The second all-Russian program of the week drew an audience of 10,700 to the Lewisohn Stadium last night. This time the program was choral as well as orchestral, for after the intermission the General Platoff Don Cossack Chorus took over the show.

SEATTLE, June 28 -- A great Harvard crew with the delayed but devastating punch of a world champion boxer rowed to victory today in the second annual Lake Washington regatta in 5 minutes 49 seconds, said by regatta officials to be the fastest time ever recorded for 2,000 meters.
