WHEN your husband earns $41 a week in this day and age when pot roast costs as much as 65 cents a pound and you have three hungry sons to feed, aged 4, 12 and 16 it's possible that you stand in need of help on how to plan nourishing meals without wrecking the budget.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 28 (AP) -- Miss Stella Walsh, who has been competing in track and field since 1930, won a close victory in the 200-meter dash feature of the senior women's national A.A.U. meet tonight.

MOSCOW, June 28 (AP) -- A Tass dispatch from Paris declared today the first task of the aid-to-Europe conference should be to ask the United States how much credit it would advance for helping rebuild Europe's war-torn economy.

ST. LOUIS, June 28 (AP) -- The board of directors of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., or Trans World Airline, has approved a reorganization plan that will center its administrative offices in Kansas City.

DETROIT, June 28 (AP) -- The Tigers posted their second straight victory over the Browns today as they pummeled Jack Kramer for four first inning runs and went on towin, 6 -- 3, in the second of a four-game series.

THE mourning for Max Parkins, the Scribners editor whose death shocked the publishing world, was very great, and will continue so. In each editor and publisher we talked to it was marked by a sense of personal and professional loss.

IN 1938 Dorothy Norman published the first number of "Twice a Year" and, though it mostly has failed to come out twice a year (rather coming out in double numbers once a year), it has been, year after year, an unusually consistent "book" of literature, the arts and civil liberties.

THE nice, old-fashioned love story has languished during these years of war novels, political novels, psychoanalytical novels, historical novels. As a result, Helen Rich's simple tale of a young widow's love life strikes one as a bold departure.

DESPITE the title, the three lawyers who figure in this novel are all male. One, the hero's patron, known reverently as the Old Man, is dead. He was Judge Haynes, a famous New York Court of Appeals judge whose "instinct for fairness had flourished in spite of the snobbish New England background."

The scheduled revision by the Federal Reserve System of its method of compiling weekly statistics for member banks in leading cities, to begin with the statement as of Wednesday, will provide a more balanced representation of the member banks participating, financial observers asserted yesterday.

DETROIT, June 28 (AP) -- The Tigers posted their second straight victory over the Browns today as they pummeled Jack Kramer for four first inning runs and went on towin, 6 -- 3, in the second of a four-game series.

THE mourning for Max Parkins, the Scribners editor whose death shocked the publishing world, was very great, and will continue so. In each editor and publisher we talked to it was marked by a sense of personal and professional loss.

IN 1938 Dorothy Norman published the first number of "Twice a Year" and, though it mostly has failed to come out twice a year (rather coming out in double numbers once a year), it has been, year after year, an unusually consistent "book" of literature, the arts and civil liberties.

THE nice, old-fashioned love story has languished during these years of war novels, political novels, psychoanalytical novels, historical novels. As a result, Helen Rich's simple tale of a young widow's love life strikes one as a bold departure.

DESPITE the title, the three lawyers who figure in this novel are all male. One, the hero's patron, known reverently as the Old Man, is dead. He was Judge Haynes, a famous New York Court of Appeals judge whose "instinct for fairness had flourished in spite of the snobbish New England background."

The scheduled revision by the Federal Reserve System of its method of compiling weekly statistics for member banks in leading cities, to begin with the statement as of Wednesday, will provide a more balanced representation of the member banks participating, financial observers asserted yesterday.

JERUSALEM, June 28 -- If the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine is able to agree on a report to the General Assembly by Sept. 1, a Jerusalem diplomat professes that he will be the most surprised man in the Near East. At least one judicious member of the committee agrees with his viewpoint.

NANKING, June 28 (U.P.) -- Government quarters today hailed the sale, by the United States Foreign Liquidation Commission, of 130,000,000 rounds of small ammunition to China as a most significant step in American foreign policy.

AIDED by grants from the Commonwealth Fund, the Milbank Memorial Fund and the Josiah Macy Jr. Foundation totaling $54,000, a committee of the New York Academy of Medicine in 1943 began a study of medical care in this country "to determine how the beat of elements in the science of medicine and in its services to the public may be preserved and embodied in whatever new social order may ultimately develop."

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The President's Special Board of Inquiry on Air Safety, which has been investigating the crashes of three Douglas DC-4 transports since May 29, recommended today major changes in take-off regulations for the big four-englned planes.

Paralleling the tremendous growth in the undergraduate colleges is that which the graduate and professional schools throughout the country are now experiencing -- the greatest enrollment boom in their history. Many of the graduate fields receive from five to ten times as many applications from qualified persons as can be accepted.

BOSTON, June 28 -- It was not without some passion, recrimination and bewilderment that Boston this week accepted its unique role of being a major city whose Mayor was not only in Federal prison as a felon, but at the same time was still drawing his salary and free to resume his office when he finishes a sentence of six to eighteen months for mail fraud.

PARIS, June 28 -- British Foreign Secretary Bevin came out of the Foreign Ministers' conference today looking grim and harassed. While Quai d'Orsay observers said part of his appearance might be attributed to the excessive heat, all agreed that it accurately reflected his growing discouragement and exasperation.

MOST communities welcome motorists to their highways with large signs proudly announcing the name of the town and the speed limit enforced within its boundaries. But few of them take the trouble to post signs telling the motorist when he has passed the town line and is once again out on a State highway.

GENEVA, June 28 -- Duties on wool still constitute the most urgent of several important problems that will confront William L. Clayton, United States Undersecretary of State for Economic Affairs, who is due here tomorrow. On his arrival Mr. Clayton will resume direction of the United States delegation to the International Trade Conference.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The New Deal, both its theory and its practice, has been officially interred on a number of separate occasions in the last few years. Its obituary has been read with gleeful finality by most of the Republican orators in Congress at one time or another.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The United States Information Libraries, maintained by the State Department in important cities of the world, contribute vastly, not only to an understanding of the United States by foreign peoples, but to international good-will. Their loss would be a disaster.

Financial markets were busy backing and filling last week, following the overriding of the Presidential veto of the Taft-Hartley Labor Bill and the changing character of the news. Although stocks slumped on Tuesday under the weight of profit-taking after five weeks of rising prices, there was more interest in labor's reaction to the new law than to its immediate effect on industry.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- American Federation of Labor lawyers put their fingers today on at least two provisions of the Taft-Hartley Law which they regard as so clearly unconstitutional that they will advise their unions to violate them.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel Null denied yesterday a petition by Raymond G. Ingersoll of 350 Cabrini Boulevard, American Labor party candidate, for an order holding the new Wilson-Pakula law unconstitutional. The action was directed against members of the Board of Elections as respondents.

Henry Morganthau Jr., general chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, announced yesterday that 5000 Jewish communities throughout the country would continue their campaigns during the summer to help raise the $170,000,000 national quota for refugees, overseas needs and Palestine.

THIS volume bears an ambitious title, but it is no more ambitious than the editorial plan of which the book is a first evidence. The present publication begins a series to be made up of volumes of short stories collected from the writings of world authors and appearing annually.

Savings and loan associations by tomorrow will complete dividend distributions for the first six months of this year amounting to $103,040,000, the first time the semi-annual interest payments have gone over the $100,000,000 mark since 1938, Morton Bodfish, chairman of the United States Savings and Loan League reported yesterday.

HER first book, "Lament for the Chieftains," gave unmistakable evidence that Martha Bacon is a poet born. Her present collection, a small book containing twenty-two lyrics, each bearing the impress of the author's individuality, is further evidence.

If we have any teachers in New York who conceive of their job as routine time-serving we hope they will make it their business to read the address made at the University of Pittsburgh by Ordway Tead, chairman of this city's Board of Higher Education. It may convey to them some of the excitement that always inspires great teachers.

EAST COAST vacationists can look forward to a heavy schedule of regattas to add the spice of sports competitions to this summer's holidays. New Yorkers are especially fortunate, for most of the yacht and power-boat races are scheduled for waterways within easy reach of the city.

Massed planes of the Naval and Marine Air Reserve swept above the city yesterday afternoon in an aerial parade marking the opening of a two-day observance of the first anniversary of the reserve organization. The celebration will close today with a four-hour air show at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn.

THE new Defender Veltura paper, announced last week, features "exceptionally warm tones." It is described by its makers as a chlorobromide enlarging paper yielding brown images. Veltura may also be used for contact printing by relatively weak light.

CHICAGO, June 28 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: hogs Salable hogs. 300 head; total, 3,300 (estimated). Compared with week ago: Barrows and gilts generally steady, a few over 350 pounds
To the Drama Editor: THE controversy raging over the proposal of the Herd Theatrical Corporation to subsidize embryonic playwrights has been of considerable interest to several New York play agents.

A sympathetic telephone operator, who did not bother to leave her name, enlisted the help, early yesterday morning, of customers of a bar and grill to provide temporary shelter for a homeless family of father and mother and eight of ten children who were sleeping in a vacant lot.
PITTSBURGH, June 28 -- Reeling under the "one-two" of the coal miners' strike and ten-day paid vacation, steel mills today scheduled lay-offs Monday of 15,000 workers.

LONDON, June 28 -- In the preparation of any balance sheet of Europe's assets and needs, such as Foreign Ministers Bevin, Bidault and Molotov have met in Paris to prepare in response to Secretary Marshall's invitation, Germany is a factor of decisive importance.

Four hundred thousand residents of the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, city officials and civic leaders win join tomorrow in welcoming to that area the change-over from hard to soft water. The ceremonies will be held on the steps of Borough Hall.

A PICTURE of two boys watching a toy sailboat won the grand prize of $500 plus a class prize of $100 for J. Michael Conner, 19, of 1200 Windemere, Baltimore, in the 1947 National High School Photographic Awards, Kodak announced last week.

CHICAGO, June 28 (AP) -- The starting line-ups for the fourteenth annual All-Star game at Wrigley Field on July 8 were announced today when final tabulations were completed on balloting by the nation's baseball fans.

With cotton dresses particularly selling well, store-wide activity was good last week, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Also busy were departments handling sportswear, neckwear, jewelry, major appliances and infants' and girls' items.

NOW that "Open City," the Italian-made topical drama about the resistance in Rome, is in its seventieth week at the World Theatre, a statistically inclined researcher for the distributors last week presented figures to prove that the picture not only holds the longrun record for films shown on a continuous basis but also is runner -up for the all-time longevity mark.

GREENSBORO, N.C., June 28 (AP) -- Miss Betty Jameson, professional of San Antonio, Tex., one of the few women to win the national amateur title twice, set the pace today in the third round of the $7,500 national women's open golf tournament with a two-under-par 74 for a 54-hole total of 225.

Fear that their reformatory record would be a handicap in future employment was the principal anxiety expressed by girls at Westfield State Farm whose talks with Dorothy Gordon, moderator of THE NEW YORK TIMES Youth Forums, were broadcast last night over WQXR.

Fourteen-year old Fred Rein of 30 Elwood Street, a student at Junior High School 52, Manhattan, will be "Borough President" tomorrow as top winner in an essay contest sponsored by Borough President of Manhattan Post 84, American Legion, it was announced yesterday.

Representatives of forty-four Atlantic and Gulf ship operators have offered to grant a pay rise of 5 per cent sought by the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, but the union will reject the offer because it calls for a contract extension, it was announced here yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., June 29 (AP) -- The Newark Bears moved into sixth place in the International League today by walloping the Baltimore Orioles in two extrainning decisions, 11-8 and 4-3. The Orioles now have lost seven straight to drop to seventh.

The Bigelow - Sanford Carpet Company will continue active alterations of its franchised dealer set-up for at least another six months, C.G. Denebrink, vice president in charge of sales, disclosed over the week-end.

PARIS, Monday, June 30 (U.P.) -- The official French Press Agency said today that the negotiations on the Marshall plan for European recovery were deadlocked completely and that the Soviet Union was following a procedure that might wreck the conference.

GENEVA, Switzerland, June 29 -- The Soviet Union's attempt to bar officially recognized American Federation of Labor observers from the sessions of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe is reported here to be among reasons why the United States is cool toward using this commission to handle European reconstruction under the Marshall plan.

Justice Isaac Siegel of the Domestic Relations Court, a former Representative in Congress and well known in Republican political circles, was killed shortly after 8 o'clock yesterday morning by a fall from a window of his ninthfloor apartment at 221 West Eighty-second Street.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- All deliveries of corn on the Chicago Board of Trade sold at new seasonal high prices last week, with July at $2.03 1/8 a bushel, highest on record, as the result of buying induced by high premiums for the cash grain, and unfavorable weather conditions.

SHANGHAI, June 29 (U.P.) -- Government reports from Mukden said that the eighteen-day siege of Szepingkai, strategic rail point seventy miles south of Changchun, was lifted today When a Government column from the Mukden area fought its way into the city.
ST. LOUIS, June 29 -- While the St. Louis area struggled to check a record-breaking flood, it was rocked at 11:25:14 P.M. Central daylight time tonight by one of the worst earthquakes in its history.

NANKING, June 29 -- Nanking may find itself free to buy military equipment from a number of countries as a result of the latest Washington move to support the Chinese Government against the Chinese Communists.

Dr. David Petegorsky, executive director of the American Jewish Congress, assailed the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards yesterday for taking a stand against anti-discrimination laws affecting tenants. The city has such a law.

DEBRECEN, Hungary, June 29 (U.P.) -- Premier Lajos Dinnyes told an audience of 25,000 or more in a campaign speech today that abandonment of the principle of private property, which the Communists advocate, would mean the end of his Small Landholders party and of Hungary itself.

Increase in business, in employment, and in availability of materials, with little change or lower prices for materials, is the outlook for the second half of 1947 as reported by a large proportion of manufacturers in New York City in a spot survey made public over the week-end by Thomas Jefferson Miley, secretary of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc.

It would have been a tragedy beyond repair if armed conflict had been resumed in Indonesia on the hollow issue of whether the Netherlands shall relinquish sovereignty over the islands now or a year and a half hence. Hotheads on both sides were readying their weapons for another footless war.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 29 -- Skippers of the Class S sloops at the Larchmont Yacht Club today took the third and final race of the team match with the sailors from Narragansett Bay, making it three straight for a total point score of 101 3/4 to 64.

Cigar withdrawals for consumption during May aggregated 473,968,346, a 14 per cent increase over April, according to an analysis by the Cigar Institute of America, released over the weekend. The withdrawals were the highest since January of this year and show much larger increase over the previous month than has been reported in any of the last three previous years.

GREENSBORO, N.C., June 29 (AP) -- Miss Betty Jameson of San Antonio today won the second Women's National Open Golf championship at Starmount Country Club by firing a brilliant sixunder-par 70 for a four-round total of 295.

JERUSALEM, June 29 -- After three more attacks by gunmen of the Zionist dissident underground against British soldiers and police, the United Nations Special Committee of Inquiry on Palestine declared tonight that such acts "constitute flagrant disregard" of the United Nations appeal for an interim truce in the country.

CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) -- Kirby Higbe won the 100th game of his major league career today when the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the Chicago Cubs, 10 to 4, spoiling Claude Passeau's debut of the season before 27,385 fans.

MANILA, June 28 -- The expiration of UNRRA aid will have as little effect on the Philippines as on any country now receiving relief, according to Frank S. Gaines, local director. The Philippine agency will remain in operation until the end of September, Mr. Gaines said.

Week Ended June 27, 1947 The foreign exchange market during the past week was quiet and lacked any special movement. Amount of business transacted was routine and price fluctuation was confined to a fairly narrow range. Canadian free dollar rallied fractionally over the previous week while sterling futures eased in midweek and then held steady. Swiss franc was lower.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 28 -- With the shutdown of UNRRA, Marshal Tito will be on his own for the first time since the war's end.

The retail buyer's psychology last week changed from the ultraconservative attitude, adopted earlier in the season, to one of concern over the comparatively small amount of merchandise on order, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

School is out, and this week New York enters its phase as the country's largest summer resort. Families of means have fled to the hills and to the beaches, leaving visitors and low-budget dwellers to figure ways to cool off. Some of the escape spots will be indicated in a series of eight articles in THE NEW YORK TIMES . This is the first.

It is up to stockholders of private business enterprises to try to make public opinion and governmental opinion aware of the economic need for providing a reasonable return on investment, and for the shareholders to do so on their own initiative, not through the campaigns organized by management.
The first advertising agency exhibit of a new "art form" using metal type rules and decorations for creating illustrations was held at the New York office of Geyer, Newell Ganger, Inc.
MADRID, June 29 -- The Bishop of Orense today added to the growing list of pastoral letters on the forthcoming referendum with an exhortation to his diocese to vote and to vote "the right way."
GOERLITZ, Germany, June 25 (Delayed) -- For the people of Goerlitz, east of Dresden in the Russian zone, the dispute over the Oder-Neisse line is more than academic.

The "moral and spiritual vandalism which is invading the sacred temple of our Christian civilization and culture" was denounced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Albert J. McCartney, director of the Chicago Sunday Evening Club, in a sermon at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.
Ten thousand persons watched as a Navy plane crashed on a Floyd Bennett Field runway yesterday afternoon in a four-hour showing of the strength of the Navy and Marine Air Reserve.

CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) -- Ben Hogan of Hershey, Pa., vaulted into professional golf's top moneywinning spot today by taking the $15,900 Chicago Victory National tournament at the Westward Ho course with a 14-under-par 270.

SEATTLE, June 29 (AP) -- Harvard, a pioneer in American crew racing, rowed to the unofficial American sprint championship in record-shattering time yesterday. The Crimson led eleven other college crews across the finish line in the second annual Lake Washington regatta.
One of the largest groups of Metropolitan New York athletes in history will compete in the National A.A.U. track and field championships at Lincoln, Neb., next Friday and Saturday.
SEOUL, Korea, June 29 -- The termination of UNRRA supplies to Korea will be felt most severely by the national and private institutions that care for homeless and destitute children.

The New York Black Yankees and Newark Eagles split a Negro National League twin bill before 7,000 fans in Yankee Stadium yesterday. The Eagles, current pacesetters, won the opener, 9 -- 8, and lost the nightcap, 6 -- 5.

One of the major obstacles to unification of the Christian Churches is the interpretation placed upon the text "Thou art Peter, and upon this rock I will build my Church" by the Bishops of Rome, Canon Thomas A. Sparks, pastor of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, told his congregation yesterday.

LONDON, June 29 -- Last week's slump in silver which has brought the price to the lowest recorded for many years, while not surprising the market, has been severe enough to occasion comment, more particularly outside market circles. It is not realized as widely as it should be that this weakness of the world market in white metal is the outcome of the Indian Government's action last spring in suspending imports of silver into India.

An increase in guidance and counseling services in New York academic high schools was recommended by the committee on education of the Women's City Club in a report made public yesterday. The committee made a survey of eleven high schools in the five boroughs.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (U.P.) -- Eugene D. Millikin, Republican, of Colorado, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, predicted tonight that if Congress decided to pass and send to the White House another income tax cut bill before going home, it would reject President Truman's demand for greater relief for "the little fellow."
SHEMYA ISLAND, Aleutians, June 29 -- The United States Army has begun its withdrawal from its westernmost bases in the Aleutians.
Eight tips to parents to prevent traffic fatalities and injuries to children during the summer vacation were issued yesterday by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallender.

CLEVELAND, June 20 (AP) -- Four Chicago hurlers muffled the Cleveland Indians with four hits to register a 4-to-3 victory today as Taft Wright's single in the ninth, scoring George Dickey from second, broke a 3-3 tie. The second half of the scheduled double bill was rained out after half an inning.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 29 -- The Conference of Studio Unions, the American Federation of Labor craft group which has been on strike at the major motion-picture studios for nine months, made a new proposal tonight for arbitration of its long jurisdictional feud with the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, also AFL.

The analysis of publicly offered foreign bonds published annually by the Institute of International Finance of New York University shows that debt service for 1946 has been paid in full on $2,255,399,950 or on 50.04 per cent of the $4,507,084,749 of publicly offered foreign dollar bonds outstanding on Dec. 31, 1946.

Humidity for breakfast, heat for lunch and dinner, and a plentiful serving of smoke-laden fog during the supper hours gave New York a disagreeable weather diet yesterday and sent 3,000,000 persons out of the city in the largest Sunday migration this season.

WARSAW, June 29 (AP) -- The Polish Government announced today that 406 Ukrainian Nationalists had been killed in a drive by the Polish Internal Security Corps to rid southeastern Poland or antiGovernment underground bands.

WHEN the National A.A.U. track and field championships are staged at Lincoln, Neb., this week-end, there is likely to be a stampede along the comeback trail. Scores of pre-war stars, most of them completely out of top-flight competition for many years, will be making that laborious climb back toward the peak. It's an arduous journey, too, and few of them will meet with success.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 29 -- Those participating in the thirteenth championship regatta of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, sponsored by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, saw the larger ocean-going racers get off to a stirring start today.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 29 -- Horses from the stable of Mr. and Mrs. J.A. Hale of Greenwich, Conn., won two of the Fairfield County Horse Show circuit championships. They did this by maintaining, in the Fairfield County Hunt Club show this week-end, the leads gained at the Greenwich and Ox Ridge shows the past two weeks.

ST. LOUIS, June 29 (AP) --The Reds and the Cardinals each gained a decision in a pair of wild slugging matches today, the Redlegs winning the opener 9 to 7 and Cards rallying to overwhelm their opponents, 17 to 2, in the curfew contest.

New art exhibitions announced for this week include the showing at the Metropolitan Museum of forty-six Dutch paintings looted from the Netherlands by the Nazis and safely returned, through the instrumentality of the Monuments, Fine Arts and Archives Commission.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 29 (AP) -- Dave Barclay, University of Michigan golf captain from Rockford, Ill., who was never considered among pre-tournament favorites, today captured the fiftieth national collegiate golf championship by defeating Jack Coyle of Louisiana State, 1 up, on the thirty-sixth hole.
The Corn Is Green Our old friend, the confirmed countryman and unterrified foxhunter, Hezekiah Cobb, has honored us, not with a visit, but a written communication.

NUREMBERG, June 29 (Reuters) -- Dr. Schumacher said the time was short until a German collapse would be avoidable only by general help all along the line. He welcomed the formation of the bizonal economic council but contended that the Anglo-American attitude toward dismantling would be the key to whether western Germany was to become a center of recovery.

At midnight tonight the curtain will fall on history's greatest relief operation to date -- the forty-four months' career of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration in Europe and the Near East. In the Far East mopping-up activities will continue until fall.
CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) -- The Progressive Citizens of America today advocated "public ownership of coal mines, railroads and electric power."

A proposal that Protestant churches clarify their stand on mixed marriages as the Roman Catholic Church has done "for many centuries" was made by the Rev. Harold C. DeWindt, pastor of the West Park Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, in his sermon yesterday on the subject, "Should Protestants Marry Catholics?"

Domestic market cotton prices continued upward last week, strengthening the trend of the two previous weeks. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains for the week of 88 to 138 points at the close of trading on Friday, after an advance during the previous week of 64 to 130 points. The independent strength of new crop positions featured price movements last week.

"HERE we're doing just what we want to do," said one of the world's happiest men, "what we'd prefer doing to anything else, and, to cap it all, being paid for doing it." Was there ever a better definition of happiness? The happy man was a zoologist and Arthur Loveridge, another zoologist, quotes him with complete approbation in his "Tomorrow's a Holiday."*

SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 29 (AP) -- Five shipwrecked fishermen, their clothing in rags and their bodies blackened by tropical sun, were reported in "fair condition" today after nearly six weeks on a tiny Pacific island off the coast of Mexico.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 29 -- The first holiday in the twelve-day encampment period that ends Wednesday for troops of the New York Guard at Camp Smith was observed today. Last Sunday was a regular training day after church services.

PARIS, June 29 -- The Saudi Arabian Government has requested a loan from the United States of more than $100,000,000 primarily for the construction of a railway from the Arabian American Oil Company installations at Dhahran, on the Persian Gulf coast, to one of King Ibn Saud's capitals at Riyadh, in the heart of the plateau region of Nejd.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The end of the fiscal year at midnight tomorrow and the beginning of the last scheduled month of its present session combined to bring Congress a rush of "must" business.

A workshop in nutrition education will open tomorrow at the Joan of Arc School, 154 West Ninety-third Street, Ernest O. Melby, dean of the New York University School of Education, announced yesterday.

President Truman's address yesterday to the conference of the National Association for the Advancement of the Colored People, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES, was as follows: Mr. Chairman, Mrs. Roosevelt, Senator Morse, distinguished guests, ladies and gentlemen:

PRINCETON, N.J., June 29 -- Time is running out and unless the "imperative problem of international control of atomic energy" is solved, "the alternative is the death of our society," the Emergency Committee of Atomic Scientists warned here today.

Women of forty countries will be among 1,000 delegates attending the first post-war convention of the International Council of Women to be held in Philadelphia from Sept. 5 to 12. Sessions will be held on the University of Pennsylvania campus, and discussions will center around the power and responsibilities of freedom, Mrs. Ambrose N. Diehl, president of the National Council of the United States, announced from its headquarters, 501 Madison Avenue.

Executives in two of every five companies report that production per employe is greater now than a year ago, according to the latest monthly survey on personnel problems by the National Industrial Conference Board, released over the week-end.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 29 (AP) -- Officials of the Amateur Athletic Union were gloomy today over prospects of the United States winning the women's track and field championship of the 1948 Olympic games.

Of 60,000,000 persons in this country who drink alcoholic beverages, 3,000,000 drink to excess and about 750,000 are "problem drinkers," the Research Council on Problems of Alcohol, an affiliate of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, announced yesterday.

The entire men's clothing industry in the United States will stop production from Thursday until July 14, inclusive, to permit 150,000 members of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, CIO, to have paid vacations at the same time, it was announced yesterday They will receive an extra day's pay for the July 4 holiday, the union said.

Carnegie Hall tonight will be the scene of the national finals competition in Sammy Kaye's "So You Want to Lead a Band" contest, with WJZ and the ABC network carrying the festivities from 9:30 to 10 P.M.

"An enduring era of labor peace and the full production that such an era would mean" was foreseen in a report issued over the weekend by the National Association of Manufacturers, in which its 16,500 member companies were urged to do their part to make the new Taft-Hartley labor law work.

The strike of 42,000 shipyard workers on the East Coast will become nation-wide and involve a total of 120,000 union members just after midnight tonight, if negotiations to be conducted today bring no results.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- A better undertone developed in the lard market last week as the result of emergency allocations against third quarter exports, the bulk of the product being assigned to Latin American countries. It is expected that third quarter allocations to Europe will be announced within a few days, and will be in line with those earlier in the year.

With the approach of Independence Day the time has come to take stock of the opportunities and possibilities of the days in which we live instead of longing for the past, the Rev. Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers, pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, said in a sermon yesterday morning.
LAKE MINNEWASKA, N.Y., June 29 -- Young Quakers led the way here today toward the reunion of the two branches of the Society of Friends of New York State which have been split since 1828.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- President Truman declared today that the nation has reached the turning point in the long history of its efforts to guarantee freedom and equality to all Americans.

PITTSBURGH, June 29 -- While some steel companies here found their operations unaffected by the wildcat coal strike last week in advance of the ten-day vacation of the miners, other producers were forced to curtail some blast furnace operations.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Joseph A. Padway, general counsel of the American Federation of Labor, said today it was his personal opinion that the Taft-Hartley law "does not apply and cannot be made to apply" if the soft coal miners did not return to work when their ten-day official vacation ended on July 8.

The Standard Register Company has named E.R. McKeag, manager of its Chicago region since 1940, to be manager of the New York region, succeeding J.W. Lawrie, who has been made sales manager of the company's Central division with headquarters in Dayton, Ohio. R.M. Henry, former Eastern division manager, has been named manager of the Northeastern sales division.

MANHASSET, L.I., June 29 -- Queen's Flight, 7-year-old chestnut mare owned by Miss Dolly Von Stade of Westbury, won the working hunter championship in the Oaks Hunt horse show, the first one since 1941, today. Albert H. Markel's Victory Lad, a bay gelding, from Forest Hills was the reserve.

JERUSALEM, June 29 -- Public hearings of the United Nations Special Committee of Inquiry on Palestine will begin Friday morning in the Jerusalem Y.M.C.A., the committee announced today. Limited numbers of the general public will be admitted.

MUNICH, Germany, June 29 -- German youth representatives in the current international conference demonstrated anger and resentment this morning against critical remarks of Dr. Dorothy Salomonides, Greek observer, who expressed keen disillusionment at the attitudes she had observed among the German population.

ATHENS, June 27 -- With the closing down of UNRRA aid, the distribution of basic rations to hospitals, orphana arylums and like institutions will cease in Greece. The child-feeding project in which many schools assumed responsibility for providing their younger pupils daily with one meal of 700 or 800 calories also will end.

SHANGHAI, June 29 (AP) -- Drastic efforts to halt the steep rise of prices were predicted today following the return of Mayor K.C. Wu from Nanking, where he conferred with President Chiang Kai-shek on the economic problem.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The National Coal Association in a bulletin issued today, asserted that "there is no authority anywhere for so-called vacation" of soft coal miners after tomorrow. The Federal Coal Mines Administration challenged this contention at once.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (U.P.) -- The National Association of Commodity Exchanges and Allied Trades, Inc., tonight placed the blame for current high prices of corn and other grains on the Government's practice of buying huge quantities for export.
LONDON, June 29 -- There is spasmodic activity here in the stock markets. Usually this signifies that boom conditions are slowly coming to an end.

BATAVIA, Java, June 29 (AP) -- Dutch and Indonesian officials conferred today over the United States note, which both sides welcomed as halting the immediate threat of a renewal of fighting in the Netherlands East Indies.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: My knowledge of aerodynamics and airplane construction is limited to the hectic few occasions when I have volunteered to help my young daughter build models which, largely because of my gratuitous interference and advice never flew.

In the two years in which the Ives-Quinn anti-discrimination law has been in operation it has been shown to work successfully, Mrs. Leopold K. Simon, a member of the State Commission Against Discrimination, said yesterday.

India presents the greatest opportunity in the world today for the creation of a new land, the Rev. Dr. E. Stanley Jones, Methodist missionary who has just returned from India, declared yesterday at the morning service of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fiftyfifth Street.

Large scale mail-order bid schedules and a spot bid clearance sale comprise the new surplus listings of the War Assets Administration, Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director, announced over the weekend. Current sales of all types in this region, he reported, number more than 122 programs covering approximately $83,000,000 worth of supplies and equipment.
CAMP BARREE, Pa., June 29 -- Girl Scouts representing twenty nationalities were welcomed officially today, to the first World Girl Scout Encampment since 1937, by Gov. James H. Duff of Pennsylvania.

Increased sales of three-way portable radios within the last two weeks, although appreciable, have not taken up the dollar volume slack resulting from the traditional summer slump in larger models, retailers agreed over the week-end. It is understood that while virtually all dealers are enjoying satisfactory portable sales, there is a definite conservative group that feels the market for them was overestimated.

PESHAWAR, North-West Frontier Province, India, June 29 (Reuters) -- Sir Firoz Khan Noon, Moslem League leader and former member of the Viceroy's Executive Council, today conveyed an appeal from the League president, Mohammed Ali Jinnah, to the Pathans of the North-West Frontier Province, calling on them to make full preparations for the polling and not to rest until the referendum (due to begin on July 6) had been won for Pakistan.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Steps to facilitate the recovery of property owned by nationals of the United Nations seized by the Japanese during the war were announced today by the Department of State.

LENOX, Mass., June 29 -- Speaking to an audience of 800 this afternoon at the opening of the fifth season of the Tanglewood Music Center, Dr. Serge Koussevitzky, the director, said that a part of the duty of the democratic state should be "the ultimate support of the arts."

Five hundred American exchange students will sail today aboard the Marine Jumper for Europe, where for the summer they will study at universities, visit youth hostels and attend international meetings.

VIENNA, June 28 -- The final UNRRA deliveries to Austria will dovetail into Congressional relief provisions. Accordingly, it is expected here that the end of the aid organization will bring no special hardship.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- A publication of the Labor Department calculated today that most Russian workers, despite wage increases, were enduring lowered purchasing power as a result of the higher costs of rationed foods.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- It isn't often that Bucky Harris is happy over splitting a doubleheader, but today at Griffith Stadium the pilot of the Yankees was indeed jubilant over the standstill his club gained with the Senators. The Yankees, after losing the opener, 5 -- 1, rebounded with a 3-1 triumph that grew in stature because of the double loss by the Red Sox at Philadelphia.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, June 29 -- Starring roles in forthcoming pictures for three movie actresses were announced here over the week-end. Included is the newcomer, Hazel Brooks, 22-year-old former model in New York and now under contract to Enterprise, who so far has done but two films.

Passenger shipping activity on a scale comparable to pre-war days will take place today along Manhattan's waterfront with the arrival and departure of ten liners, carrying more than 7,400 passengers. All movements, with the exception of one arrival at an East River pier, will be concentrated along the North River.

Last March this column indicated that the screen rights to "Harvey," Mary Chase's Pulitzer Prize comedy, produced by Brock Pemberton and staged by the late Antoinette Perry, which has been a fixture at the Forty-eighth Street since Nov. 1, 1944, would be purchased by Universal-International.

DRESDEN, Germany, June 24 (Delayed) -- Prof. Hugo Hickmann, leader of the Christian Democratic party in Saxony, in the Russian zone, complained today as discreetly as he knew how that parties opposing the Russian-sponsored Socialist Unity party were being squeezed out of the way by disproportionate newsprint allotments.

Following is the text of the statement issued yesterday at Princeton, N.J., by the Emergency Committee of Atomic Scientists: A year has passed since the founding of this committee and the publication of our first appeal to reason in the face of the overwhelming threat presented to civilization by the atomic bomb.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 28 -- Although UNRRA's contribution to Hungary was valued at only $4,000,000, the time at which it was made and the nature of the supplies provided made it peculiarly effective, and the cessation of that aid will be felt.

The return of the Moore-McCormack Lines' "Good Neighbor Fleet" to regular peacetime passenger service between New York and East Coast ports of South America is being eagerly awaited by the travel-hungry of both continents, a spokesman for the steamship company said yesterday.

BOSTON, June 29 (AP) -- Boston's battling Braves regained the National League lead with a halfgame to spare on the Dodgers by overtaking the Phillies for a 10inning 8-7 triumph and, thanks to a five-hit pitching performance by Bill Voiselle, a 4-2 victory for a doubleheader sweep today before a 20,786 crowd.

PARIS, June 29 -- The meeting of the British, Soviet and French Foreign Ministers tomorrow is expected to bring a showdown that will quickly determine whether any common European action on the Marshall plan is possible.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Harvesting of a record-breaking crop of winter wheat, the first 1,000,000,000bushel yield in the history of this country, will get well under way this week. Combines have started to operate in Kansas, a state which as a prospective yield of 277,000,000 bushels, which, would be an average crop in Argentina and about double the average output in Australia.

A woman's touch is very evident at Zoe Chase's restaurant, 115 East Sixtieth Street, not only in the special culinary features that lend individuality to the lunches and dinners but also in the attractive, flowered-wallpaper atmosphere of the place.

Dr. Albert Einstein has issued a statement declaring that he is "in complete harmony" with Prof. Otto Nathan of New York University and S. Ralph Lazrus, secretary of the Benrus Watch Company, in the controversy that resulted in their resignations from the board of directors of the proposed Brandeis University at Waltham, Mass.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 29 -- With home sites fast being absorbed in a post-war building boom, private residential construction here is hitting a faster pace than at any other period in the last eighteen years, a resume of permits issued by Walter F. Fromm, municipal building superintendent, shows.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- At least 559 cities of more than 10,000 population have adopted plans for giving war veterans preference in obtaining city jobs, the International City Managers Association said today. In most cases the larger cities have more definite and comprehensive plans than the smaller ones.

Delays in the reconversion of three Victory-type vessels purchased from the Maritime Commission by the South African Marine Corporation for service between the United States and East and South Africa have forced a second postponement of the new route, which will not get under way for at least another month, it was learned yesterday.

SEOUL, Korea, June 29 -- The United States delegation to the joint United States-Soviet Commission left tonight by train for Heijo, in North Korea. The delegation, with its clerical staff and a large contingent of military personnel, is expected to arrive in the capital of the Soviet zone early tomorrow morning.

LONDON, June 29 (AP) -- The text of a Moscow-broadcast Toss dispatch, recorded by the Soviet Monitor, on the Marshall plan: On June 28 the (Paris) newspapers l'Aube and le Monde published a detailed exposition of the French Government's stand at the conference of the three Ministers in Paris.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 28 -- Finland will feel the cessation of UNRRA aid less than many other nations because a special relief agency fund of approximately $2,750,000 is being left behind to continue in some respects the organization's work in the country.
The United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration officially ends at midnight tonight its four-year program of supplying emergency aid to countries in Europe and Asia.

The conference between the Big Three of Europe is still in that initial stage in which the conferees reveal their preliminary positions from which they expect to bargain for a result most favorable to themselves. It is, therefore, perhaps premature to join in the gloom emanating from Paris and to forecast the failure of the conference at this time, especially in view of the grave consequences bound to follow such a contingency.

The Giants and Dodgers each took a stride forward and another backward yesterday as they regaled a gathering of 52,147 for all of six hours at the Polo Grounds by splitting 3 twin bill right down the middle.
PHILADELPHIA, June 29 (AP) -- The Athletics smashed out three home runs to defeat the Red Sox twice today, 3-2 and 6-5.

ROME, June 29 -- Fierce riots broke out in Venice today when Communists armed with clubs tried to disperse a crowd of some thousands gathered in St. Mark's Square to hear a speech by Premier Alcide de Gasperi.

PARIS, June 29 -- More definitely than ever before former President de Gaulle defined his position today as anti-Communist and pro-Western in the event of an extension of the "dangerous rivalry" between the Soviet Union and the United States.
PARIS, June 28 -- British proposals for implementing the Marshall plan of European economic self-help differ completely from the Russian propositions, it can be stated authoritatively tonight.
Donald McNeill of Orange, N.J., won his fourth New York State tennis crown yesterday.

The Ponta Delgada soccer team of Fall River, Mass., won the Eastern championship of the National Challenge Cup competition at Hawthorne Field, Brooklyn, yesterday, by defeating the Brooklyn Hispanos, 2 -- 1, in the second game of the home-and-home series.

MANILA, June 29 -- The Philippine Foreign Office has been considering seriously the idea of recognizing the Indonesian Republican regime as a de facto Government, says the American-owned Manila Daily Bulletin today. The current Indonesian-Dutch crisis, it declares, has caused the deferment of any such consideration.

For once the American Government has put the Soviet Government in a dilemma. Reports from Paris indicate that it is difficult for Mr. Molotov to cooperate in a plan designed to break down the economic barriers of Europe and restore the circulation of its vital products.

The increasing number of people, exclusive of commercial hunters and fishermen, who are turning to the streams and woods for recreation is posing a serious problem for the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service. In recent testimony before the House Appropriations Committee Albert M. Day, Chief of the Service, emphasized that wildlife in the United States is facing one of the most critical periods in history.

EIGHTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Yokohama, Japan, June 29 -- A vigorous economy drive ordered by Lieut. Gen. Robert L. Eichelberger, commanding the United States Eighth Army, has lopped about 20,000,000,000 yen ($4,000,000,000 at the official exchange rate) off the occupation costs that the Japanese Government otherwise would have been forced to pay for the fiscal year 1947, according to authoritative estimates today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 29 (AP) -- The Pan-American Airway's clipper plane, the America, landed here at 12:44 P.M. (Pacific Standard Time) today on the next to last leg of the line's inaugural round-the-world passenger service.

SPARTANBURG, S.C., June 29 -- Upon his retirement from active duty, Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, U.S.N., will become a director of Reeves Brothers, Inc., manufacturer of cotton textiles, it was announced here today by John M. Reeves, president.

RUMSON, N.J., June 29 -- Best- in-show at the seventeenth allbreed fixture of the Monmouth County Kennel Club went to a black miniature poodle, Ensarr Salute, on the grounds of the Rumson Country Club today. Polo and sailing near by added an extra sporting touch to a fine day whose heat was tempered by an off-river breeze.

Eros, the winged God of Love, whose statue is so dear to all Londoners, came back to Piccadilly Circus and adorns again the graceful memorial fountain to the seventh Earl of Shaftesbury, who was a great philanthropist. ErosPixie had been absent for eight years, having spent the war years as a refugee in the country, where he survived German bombs and rockets.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- With the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration virtually closing down tomorrow, Maj. Gen. Lowell W. Rooks called today for a global approach to the "global problem of world recovery."

James H. Durkin of Buffalo has been elected to succeed Lewis Merrill as international president of the United Office and Professional Workers of America, CIO, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Merrill, who had headed the union since May, 1937, the year it was founded, resigned June 8 "for reasons of health."

Edward J. Flynn, Bronx County Democratic leader, has written an analysis of professional politics and public personalities, entitled You're The Boss," which Viking will bring out in September. His book explains political machines and the spoils system, who wins the elections and what political bosses do.

Mayor O'Dwyer intervened yesterday in the dispute between the Triboro Coach Corporation and the Green Bus Lines, Inc., and their 900 drivers and mechanics, who have voted to strike at 10:01 A.M. tomorrow, leaving large areas of Queens without surface transportation.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Bight airlines paid $19,100 for infractions of the civil air regulations during the last twelve months, the Civil Aeronautics Administration said today in response to an inquiry.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On June 26, Letters to THE TIMER contained a communication expressing concern about the nature of the documents to be carried on the "Freedom Train." This letter also imputed a partisan interest to those responsible for the program and based this contention upon a list of documents which the writer claimed were to be included in the exhibit.

When it became clear a few weeks ago that Congress was not to be dissuaded from its purpose with respect to the Taft-Hartley Labor Bill, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, looked about for a battlecry with which to rally his forces.

DETROIT, June 29 (AP) -- Beaten ten straight times on their last Eastern road trip, the Detroit Tigers made it four victories in a row at home today by sweeping a double-header from the St. Louis Browns, 7 to 5 and 6 to 1, and climbed into a third-place tie with the Athletics in American League standings.

LONDON, June 29 -- Optimism as to the prospects of Soviet cooperation in the present effort to rehabilitate European economy with the assistance of the United States was expressed by Sir Hartley Shawcross, Attorney General in the British Cabinet, in a speech in Brighton today.
NANKING, June 29 -- Despite the inefficiency with which UNRRA supplies have been distributed in China, termination of the relief shipments will be a heavy blow to the country.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 29 -- Although the Democrats have a registration advantage of almost 1,000,000 more than the Republicans in California, there is "no semblance of an active organization" in the Democratic party, James Roosevelt, Democratic State Chairman, was informed in a letter that was made public today.

ZURICH, Switzerland, June 29 -- The annual report of the Bank for International Settlements (BIS) for the period ended on March 31 has just been made available in 180 pages with a full text in English.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President Truman, choosing the "lesser of two evils," approved today the bill extending modified rent controls for another eight months but permitting "voluntary" 15 per cent increases in new leases and terminating many restrictions on nonresidential housing construction.

GENEVA, Switzerland, June 30 -- The first major international agreement indicating a means for controlling restrictive business practices such as cartels has been reached at the International Trade Conference here, it was learned today.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 30 (AP) -- Defending champion Irvin Dorfman of Yale, top-seeded in the men's singles of the twenty-fifth annual Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships, joined fourthseeded William Vogt of Princeton and unseeded Bruce Johnson of Miami in the fourth round at the Montclair Athletic Club today.
WILMINGTON, Del., June 30 (AP) -- The nation's sleeping car facilities today pased into the hands of fifty-seven railroads.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (U.P.) -- The Government's wartime sedition case against twenty-eight persons accused of conspiracy to undermine the morale of the armed forces was dismissed by the United States Court of Appeals today with a stern rebuke to the Justice Department for its "lack of diligence" in prosecuting the group.

Effective cooperation by parents of school children with the Police Department's drive to prevent fatalities will be needed if there is to be any substantial reduction in the number of youngsters killed or injured by automobiles in the streets this summer. Commissioner Wallander wisely has appealed to parents to see that their children play in areas set aside for the purpose and that they keep away from places where accidents are likely.

A set of housekeeping toys that really stand up, a plastic train that runs on flashlight batteries, and waterproof sponge rubber toys for the young child are among new designs in playthings shown in the Toy Guidance Exhibit opening today at 1124 Broadway.

Homemakers can now find a large variety of patterns and pieces available in sterling silver flatware and at no increase over pre-war prices, A.L. Zeitung, director of flatware sales for the International Silver Company, declared yesterday.

The city put the first small dent yesterday in the alleged $100,000,000 practice of selling "new-used" cars. In Municipal Term Court, Francis Goby, a "curbstone operator," pleaded guilty to doing business without a license, and Magistrate Peter M. Horn sentenced him to five days in the workhouse and fined him $100 for violating the Administrative Code.

Harry Fairfield of Pittsburgh was re-elected president of the United States Soccer Football Association as that organization concluded its annual meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday. Fairfield defeated Harry Kraus of Brooklyn, secretary of the New York State Football Association, in a close race.

JERUSALEM, June 30 -- All British troops not on duty were ordered back to barracks today, because of sporadic sniping on the troops by terrorist bands, who since Saturday killed four Britons and wounded eight in unprovoked attacks.
ROME, June 30 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi protested by radio tonight against aggression suffered from Communists by a crowd of Christian Democrats waiting to hear him speak in Venice yesterday.

Lee Shubert returned yesterday from his first post-war European shopping trip with half a dozen prospects for theatrical importation in the coining season. The latest item in the Shubert portfolio is "Piccadilly Hayride," a successful revue that will be brought over from the West End intact, alongwith its star, the English comic, Sid Field.

TOKYO, June 30 -- Less than a month after the formation of the new Socialist-led Japanese coalition Government dissension has appeared. It threatens the legislative program that the Socialists hoped to introduce at the current Diet session.

More than 7,000 orphans from forty-eight institutions in the New York area spent yesterday at Steeplechase Park, Coney Island, as the guests of the Police Anchor Club. They were loaded into buses for the trip and rode behind a motorcycle escort with sirens, just like any visiting celebrity.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The revised "Underwriter's Manual" of the Federal Housing Administration, which has eliminated from its discussions of residential restrictions all mention of race or color, remains essentially the same manual, with just a touch of liberal thought for the benefit of minorities, both, friends and critics agreed today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were quiet yesterday and prices closed steady, unchanged to 18 points higher than Saturday's final levels.

ROSLYN, L.I., June 30 -- Tom Dena, Garden City Country Club, and Al Brosch, Cherry Valley, the new Long Island open champion, turned in a 33, 31 -- 64, six strokes under par, to win the one-day amateur-pro of the Long Island P.G.A. at the Engineers golf course today.

Mayor O'Dwyer's decision to deny the demands of city transit workers for higher wages and better working conditions was based an the recommendation of Budget Director Thomas C. Patterson, after the Board of Transportation had recommended $5,500,000 in increases.

The long-awaited agreement between the United States Commercial Company and the International Silk Guild for a promotion fund to popularize silk has finally been signed, it was learned yesterday. Details of the contract will be made known by the USCC, according to trade sources here, but it is anticipated that up to $300,000 will be raised for advertising and publicity campaigns to step up consumer demand for silk products.
Residents of West Fifty-third Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas held a protest meeting last night over the "terrifying" crime conditions in their block.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Permit me to make a few observations anent Mortimer Hays' letter, which appeared in THE TIMES of June 25.

Gus Fusaro, the elevator starter who was indicted for larceny after he lost $247,000 of his friends' money in the stock market, was permanently enjoined from dealing in securities by the Supreme Court in 1938, it was learned yesterday.

In a special survey of "Prices, Rations and Wages in the Soviet Union," the Monthly Labor Review, issued by the Bureau of Labor Statistics in Washington, points out that since September last year prices of rationed foods in Russia have risen upward of 166 per cent, while the announced wage increases average only 25 per cent.

LONDON, June 30 -- An austerity import program designed to conserve dollars during the coming twelve months was laid before a sombre House of Commons today by Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer. Mr. Dalton told the House that the gravity of Britain's dollar position made it necessary to do everything possible to close the gap between the high import volume and the comparatively low export trade.

With ceremonial good wishes of the State Department marking its departure, the Marine Jumper sailed yesterday afternoon from Pier 32 for England and Norway with 800 students, teachers and other academic personnel, the largest such group in nearly a decade.
CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- Sigma Delta Chi, professional journalism fraternity, listed today its medallion awards for outstanding achievements in journalism in 1946.

The proposal to construct a onemile general-purpose highway through Van Cortlandt Park, as a link in the Major Deegan Expressway project, is to be discussed at a public hearing before the City Planning Commission at 2:30 P.M. tomorrow in City Hall, it was announced yesterday.

Store Sales Even With 1946 Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed no change last week compared with the same period of 1946, according to the "flash'' report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Robert H. Sohmer, second grandson of the founder of the piano house of Sohmer Co., Inc., has been appointed personnel director of the company's factories in Astoria.

Elmer Haslett, city ariport director, testified yesterday that he had disclosed to Florello H. La Guardia, then Mayor, his interests in authorship and in private airport management and undertook these business dealings with his superior's approval.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The House voted by 196 to 133 today to admit Hawaii to the Union as the forty-ninth state.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 30 -- Economic fatalism has come close, "to a degree that is positively dangerous," to capturing the clergy, intellectuals, politicians and business men of this country, Charles P. Taft, president of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, declared today at the eighty-second commencement of Vassar College.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- Buying of grain futures by professional traders started the markets on the upgrade on the Board of Trade today. This was followed by broad commission house buying which lifted July corn 4 1/4 cents from Saturday's finish to above $2 a bushel, coming within less than 3 cents of the record high established last week.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The text of the Housing and Rent Act of 1947, which President Truman signed today, is as follows: An Act relative to maximum rents on housing accommodations; to repeal certain provisions of Public Law 388, Seventy-ninth Congress, and for other purposes.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As an American citizen of Hungarian origin, and a working member of the foreign language press, I should like to preface this letter by stressing my complete adherence at all times to the principles of democratic government as known and practiced in this country.
BERLIN, June 30 -- The United States as firmly but politely as possible is pressing Great Britain to give up control of the Ruhr mines and hand them over to a responsible Germany agency.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Former Gov. Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota, the only avowed Republican candidate for the Presidency, disclosed today that he had authorized entry of his name in the Wisconsin preferential primary next April 6.

ROME, June 30 -- The Pope today urged the British, French and Russian representatives discussing the Marshall plan for European reconstruction in Paris to make concrete decisions that would lift the European peoples out of their misery.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 30 (AP) -- With unheralded Budge Patty turning in another astounding upset, a California trio reached the semi-final round in the men's singles of the All-England tennis championships today while four favored United States women advanced to the round of eight in their division.

Richard J. Butler of 316 West Forty-fourth Street, a famous character of rough-and-tumble politics of three decades ago, known to many as "The Dock Walloper" through the published story of his life, died in the Beekman Hospital on Sunday afternoon. His age was 72.

Brig. Gen. E.F. Jeffe, vice president in charge of sales, Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., proposed last night that "for a trial period" the appliance industry pass on to the consumer only such added costs as are actually imposed upon the manufacturer, distributor and retailer.

We do not see how it is possible to challenge successfully the basic points in the analysis made by the Emergency Committee of Atomic Scientists of the situation which we (and all the other peoples of the world) are up against as a result of the development of this dread new power.

Establishment of a technical program embracing sixty-seven projects by the council of the International Organization for Standardization at its first meeting at Zurich, Switzerland, was announced yesterday by Howard Coonley, president of the ISO, at the offices of the American Standards Association.

If parents have not taught their children about birth and growth before the age of 6, "this is the time to begin," according to a new pamphlet issued yesterday by the social hygiene committee of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association.

As Mayor O'Dwyer points out in a letter of farewell, Edmond Borgia Butler as chairman of the City Housing Authority has been dealing with "a difficult, aggravating problem." Mr. Butler served as chairman for five years, and now turns over his task to Maj. Gen. Thomas F. Farrell.

ALBANY, June 30 -- Twenty-one teachers and other representatives of the education system, appointed by Commissioner of Education Francis T. Spaulding to make recommendations to assist in carrying out the provisions for promotional increments established by the 1947 teachers' salary law opened a two-day session here today.

Clouds of oily smoke billowing up a burning elevator shaft in a forty-two-story office building at 515 Madison Avenue gave several thousand occupants an uneasy half-hour yesterday afternoon before they found they could walk in safety to the street.

LONDON, June 30 -- Growing doubts about the course of the Foreign Ministers' Conference in Paris, domestic fuel outlook and the bad showing made by savings last week overshadowed the stock markets today. With some selling all sections were easier.

Herbert H. Lehman issued yesterday a statement strongly endorsing the proposal of Secretary of State George C. Marshall for the economic rehabilitation of Europe. At the same time the former Governor urged the United States not to "by-pass the United Nations."
ALBANY, June 30 -- Governor Dewey has appointed two men to the State Parole Board, the membership of which was increased from three to five by the 1947 Legislature.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 30 -- Provisional estimates on the over-all strength of the proposed United Natians police force were submitted to the Security Council today by the Military Staff Committee. As the committee could not reach agreement, it reported three separate proposals, with none from the Soviet Union, which said it felt that it was necessary to wait until the Security Council had completed action on the first report of the Military Staff Committee.

A flood of warnings to tenants against signing leases that would raise their rent came yesterday from tenant, labor and consumer organizations after President Truman signed the amended rent law, which permits "voluntary" increases up to 15 per cent under certain conditions.

Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank, who arrived here yesterday from England, declared that Secretary of State George C. Marshall's plan for reconstruction had provided new hope for the people of Europe.

After some twenty-seven years of intermittent debate, Congress seems at last to be on the road to voting statehood for the Hawaiian Islands. The House yesterday passed by a vote of 196 to 133 the bill introduced by Delegate Farrington, of Honolulu, which has been unanimously approved by the House Public Lands Committee and which is supported by President Truman and Secretary of Interior Krug.
CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- The White Sox spotted Detroit a 5 to 0 lead tonight and then came on to defeat the Tigers, 6 to 5, on Luke Appling's home run in the eighth inning.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 30 -- The United States delegation to the United Nations Military Staff Committee wants an international police force with the striking power of 1,250 bombers and 2,250 fighters and fighter-bombers, plus 300 reconnaissance planes, it was disclosed today.
This city's Negro community grew by 67 per cent between 1930 and 1945, according to the annual report for 1946 made public yesterday by the Urban League of Greater New York.

Mischa Elman, violinist, made his annual appearance last night at the Lewisohn Stadium before an audience of 9,700. The concert opened the third week of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's summer season. Alexander Smallens conducted.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President Truman today nominated Representative Leo F. Rayfiel, Democrat, of New York, to serve as United States District Judge for the Eastern District of New York, embracing Kings, Queens, Nassau, Suffolk and Richmond counties.

STANTON, Del., June 30 (AP) -- Crispin Oglebay's oft-beaten favorite, Upper Level, stuck it out today to win the six-furlong Union Park Gardens Purse, fifth and feature race at the Delaware Park track.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Hearings on the application of Press Wireless for amendment of its license to permit inclusion of administrative as well as strictly press messages for its clients, and, in the absence of full-time occupation with press traffic, deferred commercial messages for its clients and others, as a secondary but presently needed source of additional revenue, were opened today before the Federal Communications Commission.

The domestic steel industry, which had operated between 90 and 97 per cent of capacity for the last twenty-five weeks, has been forced to cut production schedules to an average rate of 72 per cent for this week because of the coal miners' idleness.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The character and quantity of United States export possibilities not only to Europe but to the entire world will be studied by the nineteenman National Inventory Committee recently named by President Truman, Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman, chairman of the committee, said today.

Five parcels of city owned real estate, offered by the Board of Transportation in an auction sale, yesterday at the Commodore Hotel, brought high bids of $402,800 when they were put up for sale through John J. Reynolds, Inc.
PEIPING, June 30 -- Intense fighting between Nationalists and Communists was reported in two major battle zones in North China and Manchuria today.

Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, verified yesterday a report that many large investors had told him they would not build moderate-rent, taxexempt housing while the city anti-discrimination law was in effect. Mr. Stichman defended the law, out suggests a way of amending its penalty provisions to make it less discouraging to some investors.

The stock market embarked yesterday on a short work week due to the forthcoming Friday and Saturday shut-downs with a further lift on the recovery side. While the gains proved selective, with the composite rate up only 0.25 points, gains in the two leading motors issues ran beyond a point.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that it will offer to growers price supporting loans on 1947 crop wheat at rates averaging $1.83 a bushel nationally.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Lord Inverchapel, the British Ambassador, found that he and Secretary of State Marshall held substantially the same views on the Paris talks on European rehabilitation, he said after a forty-minute discussion today in the State Department.

JOGJAKARTA, Java, June 30 (AP) -- President Soekarno of the Indonesian Republic asked leaders of the four largest political parties today to form a coalition Cabinet before 6 P.M. tomorrow to cope with the critical situation now confronting the Netherlands East Indies.

LONDON, June 30 (Reuters) -- W.J. Edrich, English test player, today again came to the rescue of Middlesex against the champion county, Yorkshire, with a brilliant innings of 102 -- his sixth century of the season.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30 -- Fattening both their batting averages and pennant ambitions on the Phillies, the Dodgers won tonight's arclight affair, 7 -- 4, before a Shibe Park crowd of 28,515 cash customers.
PARIS, June 30 -- Secret diplomacy was knocked on the head today with such a resounding thwack that it may not again arise in conferences that involve the great powers.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The end of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration in Europe today was marked by an expression of "thanks and profoundest appreciation to the people of the United States" in a letter to President Truman from Director General Loweil W. Rooks.
The North Atlantic Traffic Conference of the International Air Transport Association made yesterday an unexpected move toward peace with the steamship companies.
BOSTON, June 30 -- No matter what happens between now and July 4, the Yankees will be in first place on that date.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 30 -- The award of a $300,000 contract for the razing of buildings on the United Nations permanent Manhattan site was announced here today.

Employes in shipyards throughout the East and South went on strike at 12:01 A.M. today, joining the walkout that began last Thursday in ten Eastern yards. Meanwhile, however, Federal conciliators planned to continue this morning their efforts to settle the dispute.

TIBERIUS, Palestine, June 30 -- Members of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine ate and drank their way through some of the oldest and most prosperous Jewish settlements in Palestine today, and this afternoon came here to the shores of the Sea of Galilee, the scene of Christ's life and teachings.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 30 -- An announcement in a Hungarian language broadcast from Moscow that the Supreme Soviet had adjourned until September dashed the last hopes entertained here that Hungary might be allowed comparatively free expression of her electoral will this summer.

BREMEN, Germany, June 30 -- The extent to which this port is recovering its pre-war importance to the German economy was disclosed today when American Military Government officials disclosed its earnings.

The Babe came back home yesterday. Unless you're a sports fan you may not know who "the Babe" is, but if you are we won't have to tell you that she's Mrs. George Zaharias of Denver, the former Mildred (Babe) Didrikson of Dallas, Tex.
VANCOUVER, B.C., June 30 (Canadian Press) -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Russia's Deputy Foreign Minister, believes women "talk too much" and for that reason opposes their leaving the Soviet Union.

In summer New York can be a glaring oven by day, a blast furnace by night. Its towers and tenements hoard heat. When the sun goes down the heat oozes slowly from the pavements and from the walls of man-made canyons. Then the populace fries.
TRENTON, N.J., June 30 -- Nine major appointments by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll were confirmed promptly today by the New Jersey Senate in special session.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Operation of the country's 2,600 coal mines faced an uncertain future today as they were turned back to their private owners by the Government. Relinquishing the properties which were seized under the War Labor Disputes Act on May 21, 1946, the Coal Mines Administration ordered the American flag to be hauled down from tipples in twenty-six states.

GOSHEN, N.Y., June 30 (AP) -- Nymph Hanover, owned by Mrs. Henrietta Meyers Miller and driven by Thomas S. Berry, won the $10,000 Coaching Club Oaks for 3-year-old trotting fillies today a Historic Track as Grand Circuit came to the east.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 30 (AP) -- Leaders of the oil industry expressed confidence here today that over-all needs for gasoline, fuel oil and other petroleum products could be met although temporary shortages might develop in some areas because of transportation difficulties.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 30 In an effort to reach agreement on a new contract between actors and film producers before Aug. 22, which under the new Taft-Hartley law has become a significant date, the negotiating committee of the Screen Actors Guild and the Employers' organization, Association of Motion Picture Producers, Society of Independent Motion Picture Producers and the Independent Motion Picture Producers Association, agreed today on another extension of the existing contract until July 31.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 30 -- The quality of library service is being "seriously diluted" by a shortage of professional personnel and insufficient recruitment when the responsibilities of libraries in the "atomic age" are greater than ever, Miss Mary U. Rothrock of Knoxville, Tenn., asserted tonight in her presidential address to the American Library Association.

Hardy residents of the Flatbush section of Brooklyn no longer will be able to say they were driven to drink by water. For yesterday that brackish, odoriferous spigot mystery that has plagued the area since 1881 was supplanted by Catskill water used by the rest of the city.

EVER since the first All-Star game was staged it essentially was the matching of American League power against National League pitching. At least that was the theoretical matching anyway. Occasionally the senior loop would erupt at bat and more frequently the junior loop would come through with gilt-edge hurling.

REHOVOTH, Palestine, June 30 -- Dr. Chains Weizmann, scientist and Zionist statesman, described today as "a peculiar type of pioneering, scientific pioneering," the efforts now being made to set up in Palestine "institutions with high scientific standards which can equal any of importance in America and England."
