New bond financing in June was the largest for any month since October, 1945, and the largest amount for any June in more than twenty years. The total of $729,132,000 for fifty-one issues, compared with $357,023,000 for thirtynine issues in the preceding month and $403,464,000 for forty-one issues in June, 1946.
CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- Qualifying play at 18 holes was held for the amateurs today in the Tam O'Shanter golf tournament.
ST. LOUIS, June 30 -- Under the impact of heavy rains, the Mississippi River surged upward again tonight and forced evacuation of over 4,000 more persons behind two levees.

LONDON, June 30 -- The British Government has instructed its Embassy in Washington to reopen the question of Japanese whaling expeditions in the Antarctic with the United States Government, it was announced today in the House of Commons.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: You are to be complimented for bringing out into the open, by your article, "6,664 Rents Raised; Tenants Ignored," the un-American practice of the Office of Rent Control of granting landlords specific rent increases and specific authorizations to reduce standards and services without hearing the affected tenants.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Washington clustered three runs with two out in the ninth inning to defeat the Athletics, 8 -- 7, tonight before a crowd of 18,155.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- President Truman today signed a proclamation terminating on Aug. 15 regulations permitting dutyfree importation of lumber or lumber products certified by the Housing Expediter as suitable for housing construction.

TWO months ago one of the most original and entertaining books of the year was published and generally ignored. Such disasters happen frequently, for the strident voices of advertising and promotion hoop-la easily drown out the more quiet and true note of an unassuming but genuinely good book. Dorothy Carrington's "The Traveler's Eye" is such a good book, a wonderful storehouse of astonishing information and a grand collection of expert and amusing writing.

Station WHN will devote its broadcasting day tomorrow to campaigning for the Damon Runyon Memorial Fund for cancer research. For twenty consecutive hours, from 6 A.M. until the customary sign-off time at 2 A.M. Thursday telephone pledges from listeners will be solicited.

Mayor O'Dwyer rejected yesterday the demand of the city's transit workers for pay increases because the city cannot afford to pay them. Later in the day, his lastminute efforts averted a bus strike in Queens within ten minutes of the time it was to have become effective.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Air Weather Service of the Army Air Forces announced today that it expected to begin a daily weather flight to the North Pole by the end of July.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- With the medal for merit, bestowed by President Truman, and the best wishes of his colleagues, Dean Acheson left the State Department today after six and a half years as Assistant Secretary and Under Seecretary.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- At least sixty persons were injured, some seriously, when the Baltimore Ohio's Columbian, bound from Chicago to Washington, D.C., ran through an open switch at seventyeight miles an hour in Alida, La Porte County, Ind., at 6:15 P.M. today.

Bond issues with a par value o $3,191,517,000 have been added to the list of securities eligible for purchase by savings banks in New York State, and issues having a par value of $1,282,211,400 have been delisted, Elliott V. Bell, Superintendent of Banks, reported yesterday.

The first commercial around-theworld airplane flight ended at La Guardia Field at 5:14 P.M. yesterday when the Clipper America discharged seventeen passengers, fourteen of whom had traveled 25,003 statute miles from New York to New York in 13 days, 3 hours and 10 minutes.

PARIS, June 30 -- The formation of a new "national-salvation" Cabinet, with former Premier Leon Blum recalled to active participation, was projected today by Premier Paul Ramadier as the last chance to save France from inflation.

Many hotels in New York are planning to increase the rental rates of their permanent guests by 15 per cent with the removal of Federal ceilings from hotel accommodations under the rent control extension law, signed yesterday by President Truman.

New issues of Industrial and railroad securities totaling $31,000,000 in par value will be placed on the market here today by underwriting managers as follows: General Foods Corporation -- 250,000 shares of $3.50 cumulative dividend preferred stock at $100.50 a share, by Goldman, Sachs Co. and Lehman Brothers.

Bonds called before maturity for payment in June totaled $159,686,000, the smallest amount for that month since 1943, when $149,875,000 was redeemed, and compared with $483,692,000 in 1946. However, last month's retirements exceeded the $143,934,000 for May of this year.

Norman Greenberg, 28 years old, of 3145 Brighton Fourth Street, Brooklyn, who interrupted his trial last June 11 to plead guilty to attacking the French bride of an Army lieutenant colonel, was sentenced yesterday in Kings County Court by Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz to an indeterminate term in the penitentiary.

Rail Freight Rate Increase The proposed increase in freight rates which the railroads are expected to ask the Interstate Commerce Commission in a petition to be filed next Monday, are calculated to yield the carriers additional revenues of about $800,000,000 to $900,000,000 annually.

Marquetry decorations used in modern furniture of simple design are the specialty of Schuster Geiger, a new firm with studios at 368 East 148th Street. Its first collection was presented yesterday at a private showing in Miss Geiger's home.

HOYLAKE, England, June 30 (AP) -- The five-man Yankee bid to retain the British open golf championship got off to a ragged start today with one American, Vic Ghezzi, facing a stiff battle to join the select group of qualifiers for a chance at the crown.

PARIS, June 30 -- Foreign Ministers Bevin and Bidault pointed the way to future implementation of Secretary of State Marshall's offer of aid to Europe at today's fateful conference of the three Ministers.

No End of Main Streets Manhattan Islan is, of course, the heart of New York City. For quite "a while it was all of New York City. But our biggest boroughs are on Long Island and they have taken generous bites out of what used to be green countryside over there.

BUFFALO, June 30 -- Surgical practices new in the treatment of kidney infection and hypertension relative to pregnancy were described here today before the American Urological Association by Dr. Charles J.E. Kickham of Brookline, Mass., as helpful in protecting the lives and welfare of both mother and child and avoiding medical abortion.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- If M. Molotov in his speech at Paris, and Tass in its dispatch from there, had proclaimed Soviet agreement to explore the American government plan to rehabilitate Europe according to the French-British formula, that would have seemed to Washington too good to be true.

NANKING, Tuesday, July 1 -- One of the first Chinese moves since the end of the war to sponsor mutual understanding and beneficial commercial and political relationships with Japan was announced yesterday in Shanghai.

NEW DELHI, India, June 30 -- From all over India members of a dissident Moslem organization called the Khaksars are assembling in the ancient quarter of Delhi for a three-day rally protesting against the partition of the Pakistan Provinces of Bengal and the Punjab.
The Soviet Government has acquired an imposing mansion on the upper East Side of Manhattan as the new home of its consular staff here.

Seven hundred and eleven mothers and children sailed down the bay to Sandy Hook yesterday in the first trip of the eighty-first season of the St. John's Guild Floating Hospital. The Lloyd I. Seaman, fourth boat of its name run by the guild, was scheduled to pick up passengers at 9:00 A.M. at the foot of East Twenty-second Street, 10:00 A.M. at the foot of Jefferson.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 30 (AP) -- New York State building contractors said today they were in better position to undertake projects than at any time since V-J Day.

On this first day of July the series of floods which have been afflicting the Upper Mississippi and Missouri Valleys since April are not yet abating. Some lives have been lost. Thousands have had to leave their homes. Final property damage has been estimated at a figure close to the total cost of our relief programs in Greece and Turkey.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Senate and the House were headed toward a clash tonight as the fiscal year 1947 ended. Only one of twelve major appropriation bills, involving the many billions of dollars it takes to run the Government, had been completed.

Seeking to fill fabric needs for fall production, dress manufacturers are paying premiums of 25 per cent and more for desirable plied yam rayon fabrics, it was learned yesterday. Manufacturers who delayed entering commitments for September and October delivery are faced with the prospect of paying prices higher than those which immediately followed Office of Price Administration decontrol, according to trade sources.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month dropped to the smallest total of any month in three years, or since September, 1944, and to the dullest for a corresponding month since 1942. The turnover of 125,369,656 shares for the first six months of this year also was the smallest in five years.
The season for black bass is open in New York State today. Actually, by the time most readers see this column, a considerable amount of trying for these fighters will have taken place.
NANKING, June 30 -- Meeting in a five-hour secret session, Kuomintang leaders prepared today to draw more sharply the lines of conflict with the Communists.

The genuine tea devotee rarely orders his favorite beverage in restaurants because so few of them brew it as it should be brewed. Realizing how bad the drink can be, the Tea Association has developed a mechanism for speedily making good iced tea, with which 120 eating establishments are experimenting this summer.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 30 -- After four ballots an all-Belgian jury at the World Festival of Films and Fine Arts today awarded first prize to a French picture, "Le Silence est d'or" (Silence is Golden), a Pathe-RKO production, directed by Rene Clair.

WESTWOOD, Calif., June 30 (AP) -- Former Congressman John H. Tolan, whose granddaughter has been missing near Mount Lassen National Park since yesterday, died in a hospital here tonight of a heart condition brought on by the child's disappearance.

VIENNA, June 30 -- Karl Altmann, only Communist in the Austrian Cabinet, declared in a speech in Innsbruck today that if war should break out, ten days later only one uniform would be seen throughout Europe -- the Soviet uniform.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., June 30 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development Washington, D.C., filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission today covering an aggregate of $250,000,000 of ten-year, 2 1/4 bonds, and twenty-five-year, 3 per cent bonds, dated July 15, 1947.

ALBANY, June 30 -- The gross bonded debt of New York State's nearly 10,000 units of local Government was cut last year by $118,567,650, or 3.23 per cent below 1945 levels, Frank C. Moore, State Controller, said today.

HOYLAKE, England, June 30 (AP) -- Officials of the British Professional Golfers Association took brisk exception tonight to an American P.G.A. inference that the next Ryder Cup match in the United States might have a commercial sponsor.

PARIS, June 30 -- A Rightist plot to overthrow the republic and establish a military dictatorship with the aid of French armored units has been thwarted and several of its leaders have been arrested, Edouard Depreux, Minister of the Interior, announced today.

CAMP BARRE, Pa., June 30 -- Almost 100 foreign and American delegates to the Thirty-fifth Anniversary International Encampment of the Girl Scouts have settled down to camp routine. It was their first full day of joint camping here today, and songs were issuing from the camp's mess hall at 8 A.M.

The Sparks Withington Company, producers of Sparton radios, has organized a coordinated advertising plan to insure that insertions placed by the company in national magazines and those placed by its local dealers will appear simultaneously.

Paintings looted from the Netherlands during the war by the Nazis and afterward returned to their owners by the monuments, fine arts and archives section of the United States Army, have been hung in Gallery D6 at the Metropolitan Museum.

Although the Giants, with the optional release of Mike Budnick to San Francisco, have now pared their pitching staff to nine hurlers, Manager Mel Ott yesterday gave no intimation that he planned to make any further mound acquisitions in the immediate future.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Hearings on the bill of Representative Gerald W. Landis, Republican, of Indiana, to increase the national minimum wage from 40 to 60 cents an hour under the Fair Labor Standards Act were pushed forward today in a House labor subcommittee session lasting into the afternoon.
LONDON, June 30 -- The British Government today resisted Parliamentary pressure calling for a protest to the Hungarian Government against maltreatment of Opposition deputies.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Senate, following a House lead, rejected today President Truman's Reorganization Plan No. 2.
PARIS, June 30 -- The complete deadlock over United States aid to Europe brought the conference of British, Russian and French Foreign Ministers to a virtual end tonight.

Maj. Gen. Thomas F. Farrell was sworn in as chairman of the New York City Housing Authority yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer, who had appointed him to the newly created $17,500-a-year post. General Farrell resigned as chief engineer of the State Department of Public Works to accept the position.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30 -- The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to reclassify its Common stock from 46,484 no-par value shares to 880,000 $25 par value shares.

BOSTON, June 30 -- The Danish motorship Bolivia, struggling toward New York with twenty feet of water in her hold after a collision with the Army transport St. Albans Victory, radioed to the Coast Guard for help tonight and lad twelve passengers transferred to the Coast Guard cutter Hornbeam.

Retail organizations, particularly department stores, are adopting long-range personnel training plans to decrease operating ratios now running at "dangerous levels," John B. Pope, specialist in distributive education, National Retail Dry Goods Association, reported yesterday.

CINCINNATI, June 30 (AP) -- Ewell (No-Hit) Blackwell recovered from a poor start to mark up his eleventh straight and thirteenth pitching victory of the season as the Reds came from behind to defeat the Chicago Cubs, 6 -- 4, before 31,637 fans tonight.

While the two leaders, Dr. Edward Lasker of New York and Gilberto Garcia of Santiago, adjourned their third-round match, Juan Quesada of Santiago gained by defeating Carlos Calero of Havana in the masters tournament at the Club de Ajedrez Capablanca in Havana yesterday, according to a report from Cuba.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 30 -- At the end of an all-day procession of contestants for the 28th Metropolitan Father and Son championship today new champions were crowned. Ellis Knowles of Apawamis played alternate shots with his son, James, to card the winning score of 38 -- 36 -- 74 over the Garden City Golf Club course.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 30 (AP) -- The author of the state's stand-by residential rent-control law predicted today that the 1948 Legislature would allow no "run-away" in rents after new, sharply modified Federal controls expired next March 1.

The Government's fiscal year 1946-47 ended at midnight last night. And as the Treasury closed its books it closed them on the first budget surplus recorded in seventeen years. In the sixteen deficit years that have intervened we have seen the public debt rise from slightly more than $16 billions at the close of 1930 to approximately $258 billions today, or by nearly $242 billions.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- The basic building code, now being prepared by the Building Officials Conference of America, and which is designed to be continuous because of its "open door" character, will save $5,000 to $20,000 to communities, sums which they would otherwise spend in periodic revisions of their codes, it was held here today.

DRESDEN, Germany, June 24 (Delayed) -- At the age of 6 a youngster in Saxony, in the Russian zone, has the opportunity to join the Kinderland, which is a part of the zone-wide organization of Free German Youth. At 14 he is eligible for full membership in the main group.

Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., New Jersey Republican and co-author of the Taft-Hartley bill, last night called upon President Truman to set up "immediately" a board of inquiry as a step to halt a nation-wide coal strike. Mr. Hartley spoke at a meeting of the National Association of Personnel Directors in the Hotel New Yorker.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Readers of your paper have frequently discussed the problem of airplanes flying over the Lewisohn Stadium while a performance is in progress. However, while it seems that a great many people talk about this nuisance, nobody does anything about it.

LONDON, July 1 -- Saturday will see the end of the first season of opera given by the New Covent Garden Opera Company at the Royal Opera House, London, under the present regime of the trustees and under the administration of David L. Webster.

LOS ANGELES, July 1 -- The rebellion among California Democrats against James Roosevelt, state party chairman, because of his opposition to the Truman Doctrine, grew today, with Will Rogers Jr. vociferously joining the opposition.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, July 1 (U.P.) -- The Foreign Ministers of the American republics were called today to meet here, beginning Aug. 15, to adopt a formal treaty for the defense of the Western Hemisphere.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The House of Representatives, the United States Senate and the New York Legislature joined forces to remove all rent controls from hotel accommodations.

TOKYO, July 1 (AP) -- A Supreme Headquarters spokesman denied today that Gen. Douglas MacArthur had authorized a Japanese whaling expedition and phosphate mining project on Angaur Island without "due discussions with the Australian and British Governments."

In an effort to save the "Save-Europe" conference in Paris, French Foreign Minister Bidault has submitted a last-minute compromise proposal which Mr. Molotov has referred to Moscow for further examination and which the conferees have agreed to consider at another session today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 1 -- Press coverage of atomic affairs was criticized today by Col. William R. Hodgson of Australia, who said that the majority of newspapermen were incapable of giving a fair and faithful report of a meeting.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 1 -- Yugoslavia today entered a sweeping denial of charges by a United Nations commission that it had supported guerrilla warfare against the Greek Government. She asserted that border violations had been provoked by the Greek Government as a consequence of "the internal policy of the Greek Government and of its aggressive foreign policy."

Irving Trust Company The Irving Trust Company reported as of June 30, total deposits, including official checks outstanding of $1,035,687,213 and total assets of $1,159,522,229, compared, respectively, with $974,839,269 and $1,105,777,671 on March 31.

LONDON, July 1 -- Although tobaccos, oils, films, motors, transport and newspaper shares were marked down following the announcement by Chancellor of the Exchequer Hugh Dalton of import cuts, jobbers found selling light in stock markets here today.

PITTSBURGH, July 1 (AP) -- Erv Dusak, Cardinal outfielder, hit a home run in the top half of the ninth inning tonight to break a 1-1 tie and give St. Louis a 2 -- 1 decision over the Pirates. It was the third straight night game won by the Cards on long hits in the final inning.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- To avoid the Taft-Hartley labor relations law some unions may serve notice on employers of terms and conditions of employment they wish to arrange without formal contracts, it was reported today in union circles.
Removal of controls over industrial and commercial buildings was marked by a wave of new inquiries and actual orders, it was disclosed here yesterday.

ATHENS, July 1 -- A Communist plot to seize control of northern Greece and set up a "free government" has been forestalled for the time being by the arrest in Salonika of the chief and forty-seven members of a guerrilla organization called Opla, Minister of Public Order Napoleon Zervas announced tonight.

Questions about the effect of the amended rent law on escalator clauses in leases, evictions, hotel rents and rights of tenants and landlords were answered yesterday by Ira A. Schiller, chief attorney of the New York area rent office. The questions and answers follow:

With the Senate scheduled to begin debate today on the bill to unify the armed services and a House committee ending its hearings today on a similar measure, there is every indication that a decision will be reached at this ssession of Congress. Opposition in both chambers is expected to be lively but not large.

In an outdoor ceremony yesterday at Governors Island, Gen. Courtney H. Hodges, commander of the First Army, presented medals to two generals, three former officer, now civilians, and nine enlisted men.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The most practical form of social work for the South is financial aid for the poor farmer, Dillard B. Lasseter, Administrator of the Farmers Home Administration, said today.

HOYLAKE, England, July 1 (AP) -- Johnny Bulla, an Arizona golfer who pilots an airplane for a living, shot a scorching 67 today and led an unbroken contingent of five Americans through the qualifying play of the British open to a chance at the crown which is being given up by Sam Snead.

LONDON, July 1 (AP) -- Uncle Sam's nieces did today what his tennis-playing nephews did yesterday -- sent three players into the semi-final round of their single division at the world-famed Wimbledon tourney.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 1 -- President Gabriel Gonzales Videla of Chile made it clear today that the first thing the Americas should do is put in order their economic house before attempting anything else. He said American economic unity was vital to ward off a certain type of propaganda trying to undermine democracy.

Total resources of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York as of June 30, were $2,808,162,975 compared with $2,841,800,875 at the end of the first quarter this year, and $3,489,673,320, on June 30, 1946, according to the statement of condition released yesterday.

The French, too, face a dilemma in Paris -- perhaps more difficult than that of the Russians because for France the dividing line of Europe does not run only from Stettin to Trieste. It also runs through Paris, Marseille and Lille, even through the neat, well-tended countryside.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Secretary of State Marshall assured a group of Democratic members of Congress at a conference this afternoon that there had been no change or departure from the traditional United States policy toward Palestine.

Fred Corcoran, promotion director of the United States Professional Golfers Association, is bound for Hoylake, England, by air for a conference with British P.G.A. officials today regarding the Ryder Cup matches for 1948.

VIENNA, July 1 -- The Government was jubilant today when it learned that the long-drawn-out paralysis of industry caused by inadequate fuel supplies might be ending through a financing offer made by the United States.
CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- Alton Benton allowed only three hits today in earning his fifth triumph of the year as the Tigers defeated the White Sox, 2 -- 1, for a split of their two-game series.

Most Europeans -- and especially displaced persons -- reacted to Secretary of State George C. Marshall's proposal for American air to Europe as though they had received a "shot in the arm," David Bernstein, a representative of the American Jewish Committee just back from seven months in Europe, said yesterday.
New York is loveliest at dawn, by moonlight and at sundown, phases overlooked by professional tourist guides, whose patter tends to shy from the esthetic.

JERUSALEM, July 1 -- Persistent rumors that the impending trial of Maj. Roy A. Farran might be held in camera to prevent the possibility of public demonstrations brought protests today from the Executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine and the Hebrew press.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores in June showed an increase of 5 per cent over the same month a year ago, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The increase is the smallest this year, with the exception of a small decline in April, but nevertheless was on top of a 38 per cent gain in June, 1946.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Edgar L. Warren, director of the United States Conciliation Service, resigned today. The resignation will take effect when his successor assumes office as the director of the new Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service under the TaftHartley Labor Relations Act of 1947, but in any event not later than Aug. 21.

NEW DELHI, India, July 1 -- The existing armed forces of India will be divided immediately between the Union of India (Hindustan) and Pakistan on a communal basis. All Moslem majority units will move into Pakistan areas and non-Moslem units will be transferred to the Indian Union.
With real summer weather setting the right mood, city-sponsored vacation programs for children were formally started yesterday in every borough.

The nine outstanding presentations of the School of the Air dramatic series during the last five years will be repeated by the Columbia Broadcasting System in a succession of Tuesday night offerings at 10:30, beginning Aug. 5 and running through Sept. 30.
In moderately heavy trading, cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange broke yesterday and closed 24 to 45 points net lower on the day.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The application of Press Wireless for permission to transmit deferred commercial messages among the services it is presently licensed to render its clients, was opposed at today's concluding hearing before the Federal Communications Commission by six other carriers as an unjustified invasion of their respective fields of activity.

The New York premiere of Darius Milhaud's "Opus Americanum No. 2," conducted by Alexander Smallens, was the inducement which led a fair crowd to the French program at Lewisohn Stadium last night in spite of lowering skies.

Reports that have been coming to this office indicate that the larger species of game fish are working into the off-shore grounds. School tuna between fifty and sixty pounds were taken east of Manasquan Inlet over the weekend, the first of them being a 54-pounder on Saturday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial of June 24, "Tragedy on Historic Ground," advises caution when touring the great hills of our West. The incident of the raging blizzard of June 20, in which tourists were snowed in on Beartooth Pass near Yellowstone, was, in part, inspiration for the editorial subject.

ST. LOUIS, July 1 (AP) -- A fiverun seventh inning with home runs by Hank Edwards and Ken Keltner sent the Cleveland Indians on to a 9-to-3 victory over the St. Louis Browns tonight. Jeff Heath and Vern Stephens hit circuit blows for the Brownies in the contest which saw eight two-base hits for both clubs.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The text of Secretary of State Marshall's address today to the Women's National Press Club: Some people think they see in the evolution of our political life evidences of radical changes in our policy on international affairs.

Surrogate William T. Collins set Sept. 18 yesterday as the date for a hearing on a claim by James Stewart Cushman, realty operator of 815 Fifth Avenue, to $1,618,171 of the $2,073,413 estate of his wife, Mrs. Vera Scott Cushman, who received a Distinguished Service Medal for her Y.W.C.A. work in World War I.
ALBANY, July 1 (AP) -- Francis T. Spaulding, State Education Commissioner, was chosen chairman today of the twenty-onemember Advisory Committee on Teachers' Salaries.
CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- Two Californians -- 13-year-old Marlene Bauer of Huntington Beach, and her 19-year-old sister Alice -- were co-queens at Tam o'Shanter's unique golf extravaganza today.
The Rev. James Edward McManus stood before the altar of his boyhood parish church in Brooklyn yesterday morning and was consecrated Bishop of Ponce, a province on the south coast of Puerto Rico.

The scolding habit is easy to fall into, and there has been a good deal of evidence recently that the President has permitted himself to drift markedly in this direction. That tendency is particularly apparent in the message which he sent to Congress on signing the bill extending rent control.

Thomas F. Farrell assumed the chairmanship of the New York City Housing Authority yesterday. He promptly obtained the full approval of his fellow authority members for the appointment of five men to important positions on the agency's staff.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 1 (U.P.) -- Four Catholic psychiatrists today denounced the charge of Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen of Catholic University that "the practice of psychiatry is irreligious."

Stanley Balaban, 11 years old, of 1141 Elder Avenue, the Bronx, was chewed to death and badly mangled yesterday by a pack of white bullterriers in a patch of shrubbery behind the Castle Hill Bathing Park in the Bronx. A patrolman who went to investigate the case was also attacked by two of the dogs and severely injured.
Kenneth H. McLellan, formerly banquet sales manager, has been named general manager of the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn. He replaces Patrick J. Douirs, who has resigned because of ill health.

GENEVA, July 1 -- The United States Congress will not ratify any world trade charter containing provisions for arbitrary import restrictions as now proposed, a United States delegation spokesman warned the Geneva Trade Conference today.

A tip from the wife of a 69-yearold photographer that her husband was bound for New York, threatening to shoot a prominent lawyer, resulted in the arrest of the photographer yesterday morning in the lawyer's offices at 14 Wall Street.

Midyear reinvestment demand gave the stock market yesterday one of the most substantial lifts of the year. Buying reached its height in the final hour and permitted prices to go to the best levels since March. Closing gains ranged from 1 to 4 points in some of the key industrials, while the composite rate was up 2.08 points on the day.

NUREMBERG, Germany, July 1 (U.P.) -- Thirteen high elite guard officers and one former Government official were indicted today on charges of murdering children and stifling birth rates in occupied countries to help carry out Germany's program of insuring "master-race" superiority.

Box luncheons neatly packed with sandwiches and cake, or more elaborately, with half a broiled chicken and vegetable salad, may be helpful to many Fourth of July excursionists whether their trip is by car, train, plane, boat or via subway to a cool picnic spot near by.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. said today that the House was "likely" to pass the vetoed tax-reduction bill again before adjournment, with the effective date changed to next Jan. 1.

Mayor O'Dwyer advised 100 Columbia University law school students yesterday to scrub their minds clean of bigotry if they want to have good judgment. He addressed a luncheon-meeting of the Burdick Moot Court Society of the law school in Columbia's Faculty House, 400 West 117th Street.

With an expert river pilot on the bridge, the 12,000-ton Holland America liner Westerdam will sail the narrow channels of the Hudson River to Albany today for the first time in her career as a transatlantic passenger carrier.
It was off to Lincoln, Neb., last night for one of the strongest delegations of metropolitan athletes ever to compete in the National A.A.U. track and field championships.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The campaign of the House Republican leaders for a rise in the minimum wage at this session moved with increasing force today but the outlook for Senate action was still uncertain.

An increase of $937,162,000 in the volume of loans outstanding at the end of June, as compared with a year ago, was reported yesterday by the Bank of America National Trust Savings Association, which holds the title of the world's largest commercial bank.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 1 -- A film musical to be built around the Olympic games was announced today by MGM. With the title "Olympic Queen," it will star Esther Williams, former swimming champion, and lift Ricardo Montalban to a co-starring role.

Business and civic groups offered mixed opinions yesterday on the proposal for an eight-cent fare. Some suggested that Mayor O'Dwyer's executive committee had not gone far enough and others agreed that if the higher fare were accepted it might be the solution of the city's transit problem.
Eleven-month-old Ann Devine died of a fractured skull yesterday afternoon in a three-story fall from the nursery of her parents' apartment at 424 East Fifty-first Street.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 1 -- United States participation in the International Refugee Organization, which was authorized formally with approval of a Congressional resolution by President Truman today, means that the relief agency will begin operations with about 66 per cent of its $151,060,000 budget pledged by member governments.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The text of President Truman's statement upon signing the TreasuryPost Office Supply Bill: I have today approved H.R. 2436, providing appropriations for the Treasury and Post Office Departments for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1948, because it provides for continuing in part the essential activities of these departments.

BOSTON, July 1 -- Eleven newspaper workers, including two women, three foreign correspondents and three labor reporters, have received Nieman Fellowships for the next college year starting in September, Harvard University made known today.

Escalator clauses, under which many thousands of tenants agreed to pay higher rents upon the lifting of Federal ceilings, cannot be invoked by landlords to raise their rates now, the Office of Rent Control said yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 -- A sudden splurge in the sixth inning, in which they scored all their runs, gave the Phillies a 5-3 triumph over the Dodgers today. It prevented the Brooks from taking over the league lead from the Braves.

TOKYO, July 1 -- The grimmest picture of Japan's post-war situation yet presented either to the Japanese people or to the world was painted today by the new Socialist Premier, Tetsu Katayama, in his first administrative speech before the Constitutional Diet.

BAY SHORE, L.I., July 1 -- Jack Layton and Russ Ebbets of the Brookville Club turned in a 79 -- 13 -- 66 to win low net honors today in the first foursomes tournament, alternate shots, of the Long Island Golf Association at the South Bay Club.

LASSEN NATIONAL FOREST, Calif., July 1 (AP) -- Twelve hours after the shock of her disappearance caused the death of her grandfather, former Representative John H. Tolan of California, Greta Mary Gale was found alive and unharmed early today.

LONDON, July 1 -- There will be no food crisis in Britain between now and the next narvest, and, despite the dollar problem, food supplies for the coming year will be ample, John Strachey. Minister of Food, said in the House of Commons tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Restoration of educational opportunities, hospitalization for service-connected disability, and burial and funeral allowances to Filipino veterans of World War II was urged on Congress today by President Truman.

Deadlocked with management over wages, hours and a union security provision, Local 1199, Drug Store Employes Union, CIO, called its members out on strike yesterday against forty-three Whelan drug stores in Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens, Staten Island and Lond Island.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Secretary of State Marshall today branded as "malicious distortion the suggestions that the United States sought, through financial assistance abroad, to achieve imperialist domination of the recipient nations.

ST. LOUIS, July 1 -- The Mississippi River racing in the most destructive flood ever to strike the St. Louis area topped or breached four more levees today, drove nearly 5,000 persons from their homes and rose to a new high level here.

Six years of abnormal demand have not diminished the importance of a sound pricing policy and companies of all types still regard it as a matter for top executive consideration, according to a survey of business practices, released yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

The United States Conciliation Service moved into the shipyard tie-up yesterday in an effort to bring about a settlement of the strike that is keeping fifteen major yards and an estimated 53,000 workers idle.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Lieut. Gen. Raymond A. Wheeler, Chief of Engineers, flew to the floodstricken areas today to inspect the Army steps taken on the Missouri and upper Mississippi River systems and to attend an emergency meeting of the Missouri River TenState Commission at Omaha tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau reported today that prospects for the corn crop had brightened in the last four or five days, with better weather in flooded Midwest areas.
LONDON, July 1 -- The British Government sent today another stiff note to Bulgaria, protesting against the suppression of opposition newspapers in Sofia, the Foreign Office announced.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Only with a mild winter free of strikes in the heavy industries can the United States hope to avoid "widespread" fuel shortages when cold weather arrives, Max W. Ball, director of the Department of the Interior's oil and gas division, declared today.

Most hotels in New York and other cities throughout the country began raising the rents of their permanent tenants yesterday despite an attempt by the Federal Housing Expediter to require them to show first that they come under the exemption written into the rent control extension law.
Frederick G. Reinicke, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, issued yesterday a new schedule of pier time an space for sightseeing boats operating from the Battery and West Forty-second Street.

PARIS, July 1 -- A last-minute effort to save the Foreign Ministers Conference on United States aid to Europe and to persuade the Soviet Union to accept the Marshall proposal was made today by French Foreign Minister Bidault against the will of British Foreign Secretary Bevin, who wanted a showdown immediately.

Sidney Reiter, twice-decorated war veteran, lost his first legal battle yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber denied him an injunction to restrain the General Duffy Post, No. 1141, American Legion, from taking steps to expel him on charges that he is an "active Communist."

Thirty-six out of 152 fellowships and scholarships, awarded by Columbia University for advance study and research during the 1947-48 academic year, have gone to residents of this city, Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of the university, announced yesterday.

Italy's urgent need for economic aid from the United States to avert a totalitarian threat was underlined here last night by Giuseppe Saragat and Matteo Matteotti at a dinner in their honor given by the Italian-American Labor Council.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 1 (AP) -- While the men's singles seeded list of the twenty-fifth annual Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships was melting under torrid competition today, fourthranked William Vogt of Princeton and unseeded Fred Otto of the University of Michigan broke out of the field to land in the quarterfinals.

PARIS, July 1 -- Premier Paul Ramadier's economic program, which he will submit with a demand for a vote of confidence to the National Assembly tomorrow, calls for "keeping on with the Blum experiment on a higher level."

Formation of a world government to avert wars was suggested yesterday by Dr. Joshua Loth Liebman, author of "Peace of Mind" and rabbi of Temple Israel, Boston. He spoke to religious leaders of the School of Religious Education of Hebrew Union College and the Union of American Hebrew Congregations at a seminar in the Central Synagogue, 35 East Sixtysecond Street.

Details of India's import policy following expiration of import licenses on Monday were clarified here yesterday by L.L. Horch, New York regional director of the Department of Commerce. He announced receipt of information that valid licenses for the importation of the following items into India will be automatically revalidated for shipments to Sept. 30.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 1 -- The British Government has declined to intercede in the case of three convicted terrorists, it was learned today, despite a warning from the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine that execution of the youths would stir up more trouble in the Holy Land.

CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- Three New York Yankee hurlers, Bobby Feller of Cleveland and Hal Newhouser of Detroit dominated an eight-man American League pitching staff chosen today for the fourteenth all-star baseball game at Wrigley Field next Tuesday.
MADRID, July 1 -- With the national referendum on the Franco succession five days off, the monarchists have finally adopted a definite attitude and advised their supporters not to vote.
The free society versus the police state is the supreme political issue of today, declares a statement prepared by the Commission on a Just and Durable Peace, and adopted yesterday...

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, which closed its work in Europe yesterday, today received a commendatory message from Prime Minister Attlee of the United Kingdom.

The departmental hearing of Elmer Haslett, protege and aviation adviser of former Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, adjourned at 2:45 P.M. yesterday afternoon in the City Court Building, 52 Chambers Street, to reconvene at Mr. La Guardia's bedside in Mount Sinai Hospital.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- A conference to discuss the position of the California undersea oil producers in view of the recent Supreme Court opinion was held today by representatives of the Federal Government, California, and private interests.

CAMP BARREE, Pa., July 1 -- The first in a series of discussion groups on global Girl Scout activities was conducted here today at the girls' International Encampment, with the delegates from twenty-one countries giving eyewitness accounts.

NANKING, July 1 -- Moscow's decision to take into Russia almost the entire Soviet Russian non-official community in China proper has stirred intense interest among foreign diplomats and Chinese officials.

A serious shortage of trained workers is hampering the development of child welfare programs and public health services in China, Dr. and Mrs. Ernest G. Osborne, just returned from a nine-month stay in China, reported yesterday in an interview at the offices of the China Aid Council, 1790 Broadway.

The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. Bar Percentage Markup End Appliance dealers and distributors yesterday expressed opposition to a recent proposal that percentage markups be abandoned in passing manufacturers' price increases on to the consumer.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 -- Put on record by the American Library Association's council as believing that librarians should "facilitate an adequate interpretation abroad of the United States," the association's convention heard tonight from Carl A. Sauer of the State Department that the librarian abroad must be "a sort of universal genius, an exemplar of the best type of human being America has to offer."
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- John L. Lewis is asking the soft-coal industry for an agreement which would be effective only as long as the miners are "willing and able to work."
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Hearing on a plan of reorganization for the Central Railroad Company of New Jersey opened today before J.V. Walsh, examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission.

During the dog days business has a tendency to slip in the Broadway show shops. When producers start to inquire how their competitors are faring, that's the tip-off that all isn't hunky dory. How things are going along at the moment can be deduced from the report that only three of the twenty-two current productions haven't been affected by the slump.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 1 (AP) -- The marketing division of the American Petroleum Association today authorized appointment of a committee to consider advisability of a study of marketing functions and costs, with special reference to problems of independent companies.

An attempt to shake down a mop and brush manufacturer for $5,000 to settle a three and a half month old strike in the latter's plant was alleged yesterday in Felony Court when Carmello I. Monarchio, 36 years old, president of Local 292, United Paper Workers of America, CIO, was arraigned on a charge of attempted extortion.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 -- Permanent guests at most of the city's hotels were placed on a daily rate basis today and in some cases rooms that rented for $120 a month were increased to $20 a day, or about $600 a month.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 1 -- The Hungarian three-year plan received its first reading in Parliament here today after a disorderly debate that was interrupted by the departure of the Liberty party in a body from the floor.

Although no formal step has been taken to effectuate Monday's resolution of the Atlantic Traffic Conference of the International Air Transport Association, the suggestion that joint sea-air ticketing and baggage arrangements be made was received favorably yesterday in both airline and steamship circles.

Directors of Spear Co. yesterday elected as vice presidents A. Manheimer and Arthur S. Gold. Godfrey Daum was elected a director. Mr. Manheimer joined the company's Pittsburgh organization in 1913, was elected a director in 1931 and is general manager of the Pittsburgh operation.

A 19-year-old youth who said he was a student at the University of Illinois was accused yesterday of taking advantage of the housing shortage to obtain almost $5,000 by an apartment subleasing racket. He was held at the Elizabeth Street police station on a charge of grand larceny.

A releasing agreement between the American and British film industries, under which all films produced by Sir Alexander Korda in England in the next four years will be distributed by Twentieth CenturyFox, was announced here yesterday by Spyros P. Skouras, president of the American concern.

LONDON, July 1 (Reuters) -- Tom Goddard, Gloucestershire bowler, who is nearly 47 years of age, today became the first cricketer to complete his 100 wickets of the season when he dismissed Parker of Surrey at Kennington Oval.

Announcement by Edouard Depreux, Minister of the Interior, that France has uncovered a plot by the "black maquis," a group of Fascists, to overthrow the Fourth Republic adds a note of tension to a political situation already strained. The Security Police continue to round up suspects, sensational details are supplied by unnamed spokesmen, but so far the outline of the conspiracy remains somewhat vague.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- President Truman,, in signing the $3,240,000,000 Treasury-Postoffice departmental appropriation bill today, accused Congress of having approved a $20,000,000 economy cut that would cost the Government at least $400,000,000 in tax losses in the fiscal year, which started at 12:01 A.M.

ALBANY, July 1 -- Four newly appointed state officials took office today as a fifth, Commerce Commissioner Martin P. Catherwood, agreed to continue in his $15,000 a year job until Governor Dewey can decide upon a successor.

Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, CIO, last night invited leaders of all maritime unions, whether affiliates of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, the American Federation of Labor or independent organizations, to meet here on July 14 to map out a program to bring about the repeal of the Taft-Hartley Bill.

Two items of news in a single day point up dramatically man's ever-growing mastery of the air. One recounts the arrival of the Clipper America at La Guardia Field after a voyage around the world of 25,003 statute miles in 13 days 3 hours 10 minutes. The scheduled course of Pan American World Airways' flight is only the curtainraiser for a regular round-the-world service.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., July 1 -- In the last one day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association until September, Mrs. Philip Cudone of The Knoll walked off with low gross honors as she toured the Glen Ridge course in 39, 43 -- 32 today.

BERLIN, July 1 -- Robert Moses, New York's construction coordinator, finally disclosed today his mission to Germany. He must, in three weeks' time, study the destroyed cities of western Germany, then offer his proposals for rebuilding them.
Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, marked his twenty-fifth year as a member of the body yesterday.

BUFFALO, July 1 -- Advances in the treatment of cancer of the bladder and in surgery involving the ureter, the tube connecting kidneys to the bladder, were described in papers read today to the American Urological Association.

THIRTY minutes from Times Square, somewhere in Brooklyn or Queens, was a twostory building with shops underneath and eight small, shabby apartments on the second floor. Across the street were a bar, a gasoline station and a parking space. Watching them through borrowed opera glasses was the chief pleasure in life of Mrs. Lily Marsan, who enjoyed her insomnia and didn't understand why other people didn't enjoy theirs.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 1 -- The United States has reported to the United Nations that it is considering steps to authorize the election of a resident commissioner for the Virgin Islands as a nonvoting member of the House of Representatives, it was learned today.

Most basic commodities have declined in price from their post-war peaks, but only in rubber is the current quotation below that prevailing when the Office of Price Administration lapsed a year ago, according to a study of price trends by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

"JIMMY loves oranges," said Mrs. Silas Creed Thompson. Jimmy's eyes glistened as he watched her peel an orange, break it into segments and offer him a piece. Considering the fact that Jimmy is just 5 years of age he ate with surprisingly good manners. There even was a touch of delicacy to the way he munched on the fruit.
New York Summer Resort We presume that the sales effectiveness of the travel prospectus now being written in a series of articles by Meyer Berger depends somewhat on the mood of the reader.

A substantial portion of blame for unsatisfactory employer-employe relations rests squarely with management for its failure to make workers, particularly in repetitive and monotonous jobs, fully aware of company operations and their essential share in them, Harry H. Willett, industrial relations director, Cleveland Cap Screw Company, declared yesterday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 1 -- A simplified court system designed to carry out swift justice, curtail appeals and reduce costs to litigants was advocated today by Roscoe Pound, former dean of the Harvard Law School, appearing as a witness before the Judiciary Committee of the State Constitutional Convention here today.

Plans for reopening the Peiping Union Medical College this fall were announced yesterday by the new board of trustees of the China Medical Board, Inc., which has been organized since the termination of all relationship between the board and the Rockefeller Foundation.

Defrosting Monday's meeting of the executive committee of the Open Market Committee intensified reports in Wall Street yesterday that the rate on Treasury bills is scheduled for "defrosting" at the end of this week.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 25: An increase of $171,000,000 in loans, and decreases of $284,000,000 in holdings of United States Government obligations, $422,000,000 in demand deposits credited to domestic banks, and $168,000,000 in balances with domestic banks.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 1 (AP) -- Forbes Chief, 3-year-old pacer of the Newport Stock Farm Stables, today established a course record over Goshen's historic track in winning the $4,000 pace which topped the card.
MERIDEN, Conn., July 1 (AP) -- Cornelius McGillicuddy came back to the grass roots of his venerable career in baseball today, fulfilling a promise to return he made sixtythree years ago.

A cooler air mass, charted on Weather Bureau maps to move into this region before last midnight, ended on schedule a week-long heat wave here. The weather relief followed a temperature record for the year of 87.8 degrees at 3:30 P.M.

Babe Ruth, a fair-to-middlin' hand at fashioning home runs in his day, was among the 36,923 fans at the Polo Grounds last night and witnessed a one-sided slugfest in which the Giants crashed five four-baggers and smothered the league-leading Braves, 15 -- 3, in a game halted by rain after seven innings.

CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 12,000 head, total 18,000, weights under 250 pounds fairly active but 25 cents lower; heavier weights slow, 25 to mostly 50 cents lower; sows 25 to 50 cents lower; most

STUTTGART, Germany, July 1 -- Whatever plans are worked out for Europe' rehabilitation under Secretary of State Marshall's proposal must inevitably, in Gen. Lucius D. Clay's opinion, take into consideration Germany's productivity as one of the integral factors.

Running in his typical "come from behind" style, the Argentinebred Vertigo II won the Hilltop handicap, the Class C race that served as the major attraction on the card of the Empire City Racing Association at Jamaica yesterday.

Since the first of the year twenty-one new retirement plans for the personnel of colleges, universities and other educational institutions have been set up through Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association of America, it was announced yesterday by R. McAllister Lloyd, president.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 1 -- Dean Earl G. Harrison of the University of Pennsylvania's Law School in Philadelphia said here tonight that the legal profession should welcome and encourage other skilled professions in the administration of criminal law, in divorce cases and in other fields.

A major advertising and public relations effort will be undertaken by tie manufacturers beginning in the fall to make St. Valentine's Day the tie-giving occasion of the year, it was disclosed yesterday by the Men's Tie Foundation, Inc. The campaign will begin with the September and October issues of trade publications, followed by an intensive use of consumer periodicals of January and February issues.

Recommendations for increased subway and elevated fares at the rate of 8 cents for a single ride and two rides for 15 cents were transmitted to the Board of Estimate yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer, after he had received them from the three-man committee he appointed to study the subject.

High on the list of things police do not like in hot weather is a monkey chase. And the monkey that two emergency squads pursued for nearly two hours in Brooklyn yesterday was, if anything, even more perverse than most of his breed.

The first day's trading in sugar futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday after a lapse of five and one-half years bore out, at least for the first day, the predictions of sugar dealers and brokers who had pressed for the resumption of activity since the end of the war.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., July 1 -- The Ashland Stadium Association, which was formed by a group of citizens who 26 years ago sponsored construction of the stadium here because Mayor Charles H. Martens feared a collapse of the stands in use at the time, last night sold the stadium for $1 to the Board of Education.

Union standards for salesmen which follow those set for production workers would work contrary to labor's best interests, it was pointed out yesterday by Gene Flack, president of the National Federation of Sales Executives.

Immediate increases in deliveries of steel wire and rod to bolt mills are needed to prevent a dangerous wave of speculation in standard nuts and bolts by black market operators, hardware distributors disclosed here yesterday in discussing critical shortages of these items.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, July 2 -- Premier Dr. Louis Beel and Minister for Overseas Territories Dr. Jan Jonkman informed leaders of all the Parliamentary groups today about the Dutch attitude regarding the present deadlock in Indonesia.

HOYLAKE, England, July 2 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan, Toledo amateur, shot a 71 today to keep America in the running for the British open golf championship a heart-breaking first round that virtually eliminated two of the five United States contenders -- Pro Johnny Bulla of Phoenix Ariz., and Staff Sgt. Charles innings of Medford, N.J., ateur.

The stock market made new gains yesterday on the basis of domestic developments but became slightly chilled in the afternoon over the foreign situation. The composite rate reached its best level since early March, when strength in the rails spread to other divisions, but the inability of the industrials to retain their best gains left the average only 0.21 point higher on the day.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- John L. Lewis reached an agreement in principle today with more than 40 per cent of the soft-coal industry bringing his miners their greatest grains in the history of the United Mine Workers.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Representative John W. McCormack of Massachusetts, Democratic whip of the House, admitted today that he was circulating a petition among members calling upon President Truman to extend "early executive clemency" to Mayor James M. Curley of Boston, who began serving a sentence of six to eighteen months last week for mail fraud.

LONDON, July 2 (Reuters) -- Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer, tonight tabled his anticipated resolution asking power from Parliament to levy an excise duty on the earning capacity of films imported for exhibition in Britain.

PARIS, July 2 -- The complete failure of the conference of Foreign Ministers of the three big European powers on United States aid to Europe was formally recorded today. With it the splitting of Europe into two separate blocs headed in different directions became conclusive and virtually official.
SEOUL, Korea, July 2 -- American prestige fell sharply here today as reports of the conditions under which the Joint Commission consultations in Heijo are being held became known.

NANKING, July 2 -- Efforts by the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration to obtain a cessation of the civil war fighting along the new channel of the Yellow River so that dikes can be repaired against the threatened flood waters have got off to an uncertain start.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read David Martin's strictures on my report in THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 8 on the mass removal by the British Army of some 12,000 Chetnik prisoners of war to Germany and their reclassification as displaced persons. I have also read an account in THE TIMES of June 24 of a condemnation by "Borba," a Belgrade Communist paper, of Mr. Martin's views.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Federal Reserve System terminated today its policy of maintaining the fixed rate of seven-eighths of 1 per cent on ninety-day Treasury bills and announced that after July 10 the bill rate will be permitted to find its own market level in relation to the higheryielding Treasury certificates.

With a general exodus from the city expected for the holiday weekend, butchers and grocers have been buying only limited supplies in the wholesale markets, and today they are featuring easy-toprepare items that will cut down on cooking.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today a $22,382,250 operation for refunding obligations of the St. Louis-Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railway Company. The plan is designed to take the road out of bankruptcy proceedings.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- President Truman will spend the Independence Day week-end in and around Charlottesville, Va., the White House said today. He will stay at the home of Stanley Woodward, Chief of Protocol of the State Department.

In 1684 La Salle saw the Mississippi overflowing its banks. Bienville chose the site for New Orleans because it happened to be above water at the time. The first levee was constructed at New Orleans in 1717, and ten years later the Governor proudly proclaimed that it was a mile long and eighteen feet wide.

"Exiles, the only play by the late controversial literary titan, James Joyce, has been acquired for a Broadway production in mid-November by a new husband-and-wife managerial team. The producers, Kerry Stuart and John Wray, are trying to persuade Melvyn Douglas to star in and direct the drama, a story of love and jealousy in pre World War I Dublin.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- A Senate-House joint committee today approved $6,857,000 for the State Department's "Voice of America" broadcasts after Secretary of State Marshall had...

PEIPING, July 2 -- North China's leading newspapers devoted considerable editorial space yesterday to the fact that the June 30 deadline had passed without the granting of the much-mooted $500,000,000 loan by the United States to China.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- The House Agriculture Committee today approved a bill allocating sugar quotas to domestic and foreign areas as proposed by Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson.

Despite widespread employe misconceptions concerning "exhorbitant" management profits, the only certain way to an improved standard of living for workers lies in increased individual productivity, Dr. Frank M. Surface, executive assistant to the president, Standard Oil Company (N.J.), declared yesterday.

The passage of the Housing and Rent Act of 1947 is an important factor toward the full restoration of a free competitive construction market, in the opinion of Thomas S. Holden, president of the F.W. Dodge Corporation.

An increase in total resources to $5,044,245,923, as of June 30, over the level of $4,873,737,691, at the end of the first quarter this year, was reported yesterday by the National City Bank of New York. The figure compares with total resources on June 30 last year, of $5,184,476,441.

PARIS, July 2 -- Submitting a program that amounted to a new edition of the Blum anti-inflation plan, Premier Paul Ramadier tonight asked the National Assembly for a straight vote of confidence in his government to restore the shaken French economy.

GENEVA, July 2 -- An agreement giving the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization administration of displaced persons assembly centers in the United States zone in Germany is expected to be signed Monday by Gen. Lucius D. Clay.

In an article in the current issue of the New Republic, Henry A. Wallace calls upon members of the American Federation of Labor, the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the railroad brotherhoods to join with the small farmers to wipe out the reactionary, feudal leadership of the Democratic party in the South as "the one course to save the Democratic party."

The nation's gasoline stocks last week declined 71,000 barrels, according to the weekly report of the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 91,806,000 barrels, compared with 81,877,000 a week earlier and 92,072,000 on June 29, 1946.

The New York Society for the Suppression of Vice will change its name to Society to Maintain Public Decency, it was announced yesterday in the society's annual report. The society's charter has been amended to incorporate the ideas inherent in the changed name.

JERUSALEM, July 2 -- The Fighters for Freedom of Israel (the Stern group) replied tonight to the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine on the latter's condemnation of recent terrorist attacks on British soldiers.

The big news along the local racing front yesterday was the announcement from James Butler of the Empire City Racing Association that sixteen North Americanowned horses, just about double the number expected a week ago, have been named for the $100,000 Empire Gold Cup race at Belmont Park July 19.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 2 -- Negotiations involving the future ownership of United Artists are reported today to be nearing conclusion. Arnold Grant, Beverly Hills lawyer and member of the United Artists board of directors, said that an official statement would be issued either tomorrow or Monday regarding them.

The Pacific Coast Company and its officers were sued yesterday in Federal Court here by two holders of preferred stock who allege that between 1936 and 1946 the company failed to pay dividends of $2,493,345, although its earnings available for dividends during that period amounted to $5,177,475.

CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- With some $36,000 waiting at the end of the four-day 72-hole trek, 188 male professional, amateur and women golfers start over Tam O'Shanter's rolling hills tomorrow in the seventh annual three-ply all-American tournament.

VENTNOR CITY, N.J., July 2 -- With a brilliant victory over E. Strang of Camden in the sixth round, Anthony E. Santasiere, New York State champion, continued to set the pace in the preliminaries of the open championship tournament of the New Jersey State Chess Federation on the Municipal Pier today.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 2 (AP) -- Two American contenders for top honors in the Henley Royal Regatta advanced easily to second-round races today in the 102d running bf Britain's oldest rowing classic.

Prompt action on the Palestine issue by the United Nations was asked yesterday by a group of United States Senators in statements released here by the Zionist Organization of America, which opens a four-day national convention today.

City control of hotel rents for permanent guests, who were excluded from the benefits of the new Federal rent control law, became a distinct possibility yesterday as the volume of protest from hotel tenants who have been notified of increases ranging up to 100 per cent mounted sharply.
Mayor O'Dwyer sent a call yesterday to the heads of seven city departments and bureaus to meet with him at City Hall today to discuss ways of preventing mass evictions under the new rent law.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- National and state banks in Chicago reported increased savings, deposits, loans and discounts, total deposits, and government bond holdings today in responding to national and state calls for the condition of banks as of June 30. In cash resources the national banks had a decline, but state banks made a substantial gain.

Bayside National The Bayside National Bank, Bayside, Queens, reported as of June 30 total deposits of $10,491,845 and total assets of $11,634,264, compared, respectively, with $9,642,967 and $10,615,362 on Dec. 31, 1946. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $2,844,913, against $1,589,214; holdings of United States Government securities to $3,210,269, against $3,725,200, and loans and discounts to $5,373,173, against $4,955,353.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The text of the second interim report of the President's Special Board of Inquiry on Air Safety follows: An emergency situation leads to this second interim report of your Special Board of Inquiry on Air Safety.

A possible hitch in the use of the former Pyne mansion at Park Avenue and East Sixty-eighth Street as the consulate of the Soviet Union developed yesterday, even as the consular staff was busy moving into the imposing edifice.

Carl Stern, the first 'cellist of the New York PhilharmonicSymphony during its summer seasons, appeared as the soloist with the orchestra last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. With Alexander Smallens conducting, he played Tchaikovsky's Variations on a Rococo Theme.

MINDEN, Germany, July 2 -- A proposal by British Military Government officials calling for the production of vanadium in the economically merged zones gave an indication today that a new levelof-industry plan for the two zones might restore to the German economy some industries prohibited by the Potsdam Agreement.

The Yankees were swinging for the fences last night at the Stadium, for the edification of 53,520 enthusiastic fans. Joe DiMaggio larruped his tenth home run of the campaign. Snuffy Stirnweiss exploded a double and a triple, in that order, successively.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 -- Trained civilian librarians who operate libraries for the Army are resigning in great numbers, especially in the occupation zones overseas, and a "serious deterioration" in the quality of the Army Library Service is in prospect, the American Library Association was warned at its conference here today.

ST. LOUIS, July 2 (AP) -- Home runs by Jeff Heath and Walt Judnich helped the St. Louis Browns to a 7-to-1 victory tonight over the Chicago White Sox. Jack Kramer scattered eight hits and five walks for his sixth victory against the same number of losses.

OMAHA, Neb., July 2 -- While the Mississippi and Missouri rivers continued their destructive sweep througrh the country's vast "breadbasket," the Governors of the ten Missouri Basin states called upon Congress today to appropriate ample funds to meet the needs for flood control and basin development next year.
Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were 5 points higher to 11 points lower than the day before.
Pan American Airways received word yesterday from the Boeing Aircraft Corporation in Seattle that the first Boeing Stratocruiser was ready for flight test.

MANILA, July 2 -- Conscious of success and progress in its first year as a republic, the Philippines has completed arrangements for a Fourth of July celebration, complete with, parades, speeches and merrymaking that will rival anything that America has ever put on.
LONDON, July 2 -- The Labor party has definitely decided to alter radically the powers and composition of the House of Lords if it should be re-elected in 1950, it was learned today.

People in the city began to beat the gun on the Fourth of July holiday as early as yesterday afternoon. The scheduled three-day week-end seemed as if it was going to run five days, and possibly into the sixth, before sun-burned and weary folk return to their homes Monday or Tuesday.

PITTSBURGH, July 2 (AP) -- Scoring eight runs in a wild fifthinning, the Cincinnati Reds defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 8 to 6, tonignt. A crowd of 23,384 watched five Pirate hurlers make a futile attempt to stop the Reds.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (U.P.) -- Chairman Arthur H. Vandenberg and members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee tonight issued a strong criticism of United Nations budgetary practices, warning that unless corrective steps were taken the United Nations would have financial difficulties of a "serious nature."

PITTSBURGH, July 2 -- The executive board of the 875,000-member United Steelworkers of America, CIO, voted here today to ignore the new labor board set up under the Taft-Hartley law and seek to work out problems between the union and management through "bona fide collective bargaining."

ROME, July 2 -- The Italian Communist party should aim at bringing about a "peaceful" transformation of the Italian social structure, Communist leader Palmiro Togliatti said in a speech to the Central Committee of the party last night.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Administration's program for interAmerican military cooperation went under organized fire today as one that would give support to dictatorships, depress economies and living standards of neighbor nations, and foment wars.
John W. Hanes, former Undersecretary of the Treasury, said yesterday that the Truman Administration had "juggled the figures" to keep the surplus for the fiscal year down to $754,000,000.

Decision was reserved yesterday by the City Planning Commission after a two-and-one-half-hour public hearing of arguments for and against the proposed one-mile, allpurpose highway through Van Cortlandt Park. The highway would be a link in the proposed Major Deegan Expressway in the Bronx, which will connect with throughway facilities in Westchester County.

An amendment to the by-laws of the National Association of Broadcasters, permitting radio chains to hold associate rather than active membership, has been approved by a referendum vote of 629 to 28, the industry group announced yesterday from Washington.
TOKYO, July 2 -- The prospects are that the foreign buyer will have both Japanese and occupation officials sitting in his lap when limited trade is resumed on a limited scale after Aug. 15.

The traditional American success story -- in the manner of the Horatio Alger heroes -- is symbolized best by five business leaders, according to a nation-wide poll of college students and faculty members.

AMSTERDAM, July 2 (Aneta) -- Prices were irregular in light trading on the Stock Exchange. Industrials and State bonds were higher, while Indies plantations and funds and shipping issues were weak. Bank stocks were firm.
PARIS, July 2 -- The dismissal of Maj. Gen. Edgard de Larminat as Inspector General of French colonial forces was announced today by the Cabinet Council.

GENEVA, July 2 -- The Marshall plan of rehabilitation would have no permanent results if the present international trade conferences fail, William L. Clayton, United States Under-Secretary of State or Economic Affairs, said today.

CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the united States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 8,500 head; total, 13,500; very slow; hogs under 240 pounds, 35 to 50 cents lower; heavier weights and sows 30 cents to $1 lower; market closed dull and spots $1
Don M. Parker Jr. has been appointed director of personal plane sales for the Republic Aviation Corporation, replacing Gordon C. Sleeper who has resigned.

ALBANY, July 2 -- Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Chairman of the Joint Committee to Study the Problems of the Aging, estimated today that by 1960 New York State will have 2,000,000 residents of 65 years of age or over, compared with a present population of about 1,200,000 in that age bracket.

Herbert Wechsler, trial commissioner in the inquiry by the Department of Marine and Aviation into the private business dealing's of Elmer Haslett, city airport director, gave Max M. Bernstein, assistant corporation counsel, two weeks yesterday to arrange for personal testimony by former Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia.
The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it would offer this month two issues of temporary loan notes totaling $14,301,000.

LONDON, July 2 -- Egypt will leave the sterling bloc under the terms of an Anglo-Egyptian financial agreement, which were published here today. The agreement further provides for the freezing of the bulk of Egypt's sterling balances estimated at about $400,000,000 (the equivalent of $1,612,000,000), but it does not include any scaling down of the debt.

ATHENS, July 2 -- Themistocles Sophoulis, head of the Liberal party, declared last night that if Communists attempted to impose a revolutionary "free government" on Greece by force, his party, which hitherto had headed efforts to appease the Communists, would join the rest of the country in using force to resist.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 2 -- The Spanish Republic Government in exile today attacked as a "fraud" Generalissimo Francisco Franco's call for a plebiscite in Spain to give himself the sole right to elect his successor.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Taft health bill for Federal aid to states was attacked by Leon Henderson today as "an expression of the present political and economic desires of the American Medical Association."

Three more shipyards, two on the West Coast and one on the East Coast, joined the ranks of struck yards yesterday as an estimated 10,000 workers left their jobs. This raised the total of affected yards to eighteen, and the number of men idle to 63,000 men.

Of the 580 state-chartered banking organizations, 470, or four fifths have eliminated Saturday service at least part of the year, according to the results of a survey by the State Banking Department, released yesterday by Elliott V. Bell, Superintendent of Banks.
ALBANY, July 2 -- The HollandAmerica passenger liner Westerdam steamed up the Hudson River to Albany today to be loaded with gifts from the people of Albany to the people of Nijmegen, Holland.

A check yesterday on how the new bass season was progressing in Westchester and Putnam Counties indicated that while bass were being taken, the fishing was not consistently good. One source, the local office of the State Conservation Department, held that the fishing "was nothing to brag about."

After only five brief sessions, the Paris conference has ended in complete failure and amid an exchange of scarcely veiled challenges and counter challenges. The end came when, despite a French compromise proposal, Russia flatly rejected the very principle of European unity and cooperation in a joint program of self-help as a condition for further American aid.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 (AP) -- The Phillies struck from behind with four runs in the eighth inning and then scored on a passed ball in the ninth to defeat the Boston Braves, 6 to 5, before a crowd of 14,754 at Shibe Park tonight.

MUNICH, Germany, July 2 -- The largest political post-war mass meeting in Munich to date drew a crowd estimated as high as 15,000 tonight to the Koenigsplatz. There Dr. Alfred Loritz, until recently Minister of Denazification in Bavaria, presented to his constituents his version of his dismissal from office.
DARIEN, Conn., July 2 -- As usual in these all-day medal play handicap tournaments of the Metropolitan Golf Association, it was the last foursome that brought in two winners.

MANILA, July 2 -- Military police today routed thirty-two escaped convicts who seized and held Calapan, capital of Mindoro Island, in the Philippines, for several hours after capturing military police arms and uniforms and disarming police, the Governor, a Congressman and other officials.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Fluegge of 168 East Seventy-fourth Street and Mrs. Fluegge's sister, Mrs. Winthrop G. Slade, left yesterday for Prout's Neck, Me., for a fortnight's stay.
