Having failed to escape a summer session of study by placing 3,000 miles of blue Atlantic between him and the Newport, R.I., school at which he had been enrolled, Prince Hamid Reza Pahlevi of Iran arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday aboard an Air France plane from Paris.

A new national advertising representation system for the sale of distribution advertising has been adopted by the board of directors, Advertising Distributors of America, Inc., George P. Johansen, secretarytreasurer, revealed yesterday. He spoke at the organization's annual convention in the Commodore Hotel.

Americans should realize that the Truman doctrine is dead, James P. Warburg, banker, asserted last night in an address over the Columbia Broadcasting System. Mr. Warburg said the doctrine had been succeeded by the Marshall program, which he contended was "basically different in objective as well as approach."

Bobby Feller's doubtful status in Tuesday's All-Star game at Wrigley Field, Chicago, has swung added support to the National Leaguers, who have bowed to their American League rivals in nine of thirteen previous meetings, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- House and Senate Republican leaders decided in joint conference today to start a session-end drive for enactment of a tax reduction bill at the possible expense of nearly all other pending legislation.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The evidence in the case of the ten State Department employes who were dismissed recently after an investigation indicated that some of them had been indirectly keeping company with foreign powers, Secretary George C. Marshall said today.

JOGJAKARTA, Java, July 2 (AP) -- Reliable non-Indonesian informants arriving here today said that the Southeast Java area around Banjuwangi was in a state of alert and that a large proportion of native villagers had fled to the interior in the belief that the Dutch planned to attack that sector if the current Indonesian crisis resulted in armed conflict.

The Board of Estimate will hold another executive meeting at Gracie Mansion at 2:30 P.M. on Monday to discuss informally the question of an eight-cent fare on the city's subway and elevated lines. Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday.

The Office of Rent Control said yesterday that the granting of rent increases to landlords in "hardship" cases did not preclude the right of affected tenants to petition for rent reductions on the ground of decreased service or inadequate maintenance.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 (AP) -- A $44,000,000 registration statement was filed today by the Dow Chemical Company, Midland, Mich., with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering 40,000 shares of no par value convertible second preferred stock.

In the very short time available to it, Mayor O'Dwyer's Executive Committee on Administration has done an extraordinarily good job of factgathering on the 5-cent fare, its effect on the city's economy and the fiscal outlook. It was only three weeks ago that the Mayor made known his changed attitude toward the fare.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Every indication today was that the United States would place no obstacle in the way of Great Britain and France in their working out of a plan for European economic revival, with Russia excluded by her own decision.

Howard Chase, director of public relations for the General Foods Company, declared yesterday at the New School of Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, that no human institution could long withstand mass disapproval, "whether that institution is a state, a church, a lodge, a labor union or a corporation."

H.C. Turner Jr., president of the Turner Construction Company, announced yesterday that the Atomic Energy Commission had signed a contract for management of Oak Ridge, Tenn., the atom city, for three and one-half more years by Roane-Anderson Company, a Turner subsidiary. The contract runs to Dec. 31, 1950.

Quotas of shipments of common nails to Eastern distributors have been cut 26 per cent for the third quarter of this year, creating an emergency in supplies required by both industrial and construction purchasing agents, spokesmen revealed here yesterday. These shortages threaten further cutbacks in housing construction, they said.
Lord Inverchapel, British Ambassador to the United States, took home the bacon literally yesterday, when he sailed on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth on his first vacation since 1937.

Dr. Walter W. Pettit, dean of the New York School of Social Work, Columbia University, and a member of the faculty for thirty-two years, will retire from his post on Sept. 30, it was announced yesterday. He will be 65 years old on Aug. 9.
There are those who hold -- the late H.G. Wells was one -- that you may cross the world and find no resort to compare with Jones Beach on Long Island's south shore, thirtythree miles from the city.

LONDON, July 2 -- British consumption of newsprint -- already down to about a third of the prewar level -- is expected to be reduced another one-fifth by import cuts designed to conserve Britain's dwindling supply of American and Canadian, dollars.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The War and Navy Departments started an all-out legislative offensive today to establish the Women's Army Corps in the regular Army and the Waves in the regular Navy.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 2 (AP) -- Algiers, leading money winner of the harness turf for 1947, added to his laurels today at the historic track by winning the $10,000 Titan free-for-all trot before a capacity crowd.

Several thousand retailers throughout the country will participate in National Surplus Week, July 14-19, and offer millions of dollars worth of goods in the aggregate at sacrifice prices, it was predicted yesterday by Henry Modell, president of the Smaller Business Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

BOSTON, July 2 (AP) -- The Athletics blasted three Red Sox pitchers for sixteen hits for a 7-6 victory tonight before a crowd of 32,809. Four of the Boston tallies resulted from homers by Ted Williams (No. 14), Bobby Doerr and Birdie Tebbetts.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- A House Foreign Affairs subcommittee has drafted a report asserting that maritime unions are getting what amounts to a $500,000,000 a year subsidy under the Administration's foreign aid program.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- July corn sold at a new record high on the Board of Trade today and July oats went to a new seasonal top. However, the strength in the nearby deliveries of the two grains failed to have a lasting effect on the distant months and all futures reacted from the peak.

The City Council adopted yesterday a proposal to license garages and parking lots to avoid the chiseling about which metropolitan motorists have complained. If, after a public hearing, the measure gets the approval of the Board of Estimate and Mayor O'Dwyer the provisions will be supervised by Benjamin Fielding, Commissioner of Licenses, who sought the legislation.

LONDON, Thursday, July 3 -- With very few expressions of bitterness against the Soviet Union, editorials in most of this morning's papers here held that Britain and France must go ahead on the economic recovery of Europe without Russia.

Committees representing the City Council, City Commissioners and City Hall reporters appealed yesterday to Mayor O'Dwyer to name the umpire who will officiate at the annual baseball game between teams composed of reporters and Councilmen and Commissioners.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 2 -- The United Nations will send economic field missions to the former Italian colonies of Cyrenaica, Tripolitania, and Eritrea, the first to visit conquered enemy territory, it was announced today.

CLEVELAND, July 2 (AP) -- Stopping a late rally, the Detroit Tigers' ace southpaw Hal Newhouser edged the Cleveland Indians, 6 to 5, tonight for his ninth victory of the season before a "Mel Harder Night" crowd of 56,359 fans.

Bankers here serving the readyto-wear trades have been impressed and gratified by the improvement in the financial position of garment manufacturers as of July 1, compared with six months ago. Frozen inventories and loans have been liquidated or are currently in work, "lickings" have been taken without serious upsets in the industry, and considerably more early buying for fall than was anticipated has developed, it was pointed out yesterday.
Their big guns spiked until it was too late to do much about it, the Giants ran into a fearful ambush at Ebbets Field last night that all but blew them into shreds.

The statement prepared by a commission headed by John Foster Dulles and adopted yesterday by the Federal Council of Churches helps to clarify a lot of muddy thinking when it declares that the supreme and critical issue of our time is that of the free society versus the police state.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- Warning that hospital blood banks now in common use are dangerous and may transmit deadly disease was given today by three doctors of the Harvard Medical School faculty in the July 5 isssue of The Journal of the American Medical Association.

Buyers' Total Lower Out-of-town buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended Tuesday totaled 1,144 compared with 1,957 last week and 794 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in The New York Times.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- President Truman's special board of inquiry on air safety called on Congress today to reduce the number of air crashes through the provision of funds for adequate safety aids against approach and landing accidents, which the group described "as by far the largest category" of air tragedies.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On July 1 the New York City Housing Authority begins a new existence. Edmond B. Butler, the chairman, goes out of office and with him Maxwell H. Tretter, the executive director, Frank M. Didisheim, secretary, and Simon Rosenzweig, counsel.

Peak sales achieved last year by the Sterling Drug Company are expected to be maintained during 1947 but competition for the drug sales dollar is definitely increasing while the break-even point of business has risen substantially, James Hill Jr., president, said yesterday in making public a summary of the first annual combined meeting of the company's standing committees held at Montauk Point, L.I.

THOSE rugged individualists of the left who have been muttering of the need for a third party because, they say, there is little to choose between Republicans and Democrats, might ponder the situation in 1860. James G. Randall's authoritative and fascinating "Lincoln: The Liberal Statesman"* shows that the complaint is not new.

CHICAGO, July 2 (U.P.) -- The Zenith Radio Corporation announced today development of a 'pay-as-you-see" television set and predicted that it would remove the last obstacles to making topflight television entertainment a household commonplace.

JERUSALEM, July 2 -- Irgun Zvai Leumi swelled its coffers by the equivalent of about $3,200 today when seven of its men robbed a bank in Haifa. This terrorist organization depends largely on bank robberies and extortion to finance its activities.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 2 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, expressed regret today over the collapse of the Paris conference on the Marshall proposals, and declared that the United Nations Secretariat would hold itself in readiness to take any action that might be considered helpful by members of the organization.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 2 -- Three players from Yale and one each from Princeton, Virginia, Michigan, Rollins and Fresno State were holding brackets this evening in the quarter-final round of the Eastern Intercollegiate tennis championship at the Montclair A.C.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 2 -- "A heavy flow of information will be channeled from Lake Success to Moscow beginning Sept. 1," Tor Gjesdal, director of the United Nations Public Information Department, said today.

NEW DELHI, India, July 2 -- Pat Wellington, 21-year-old ship's radio operator from Jackson, Miss., traveled here from Bombay in the hope of meeting Mohandas K. Gandhi. To his own amazement the tall, bespectacled American youth, who had tried unsuccessfully to meet in his home state Senator Theodore G. Bilbo, not only had a private two-minute audience with Mr. Gandhi today but got an answer to his one question:

Mrs. Wagner Nugent of 44 West Tenth Street said she was the most surprised woman in the country yesterday when she accepted a first-place award for her son Frederic in the senior division of the regional contest of the 1947 Fisher Body Craftsman's Guild competition.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 2 (AP) -- Gardner Larned, collegiate champion, withdrew from the national clay courts tennis tournament today because of injuries, but other seeded favorites continued their march through the third round.

BUFFALO, July 2 -- One-third of the estimated 1,500,000 involuntary childless marriages in the country are probably attributable to faults in the husbands, Dr. Robert S. Hotchkiss, director of urology at Bellevue Hospital, New York City, told the American Urological Society today.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Six Federal agencies are unlawfully using government funds to propagandize Congress into passing the Wagner-Murray-Dingell Bill for compulsory health insurance, a House subcommittee charged today.
Rising prices here and abroad pose a "most serious problem" for the Joint Distribution Committee, Moses A. Leavitt, executive vice chairman of the JDC, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- A Federal budget surplus of $753,787,660 for the 1947 fiscal year ended Monday was announced today by Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder, ending seventeen years of deficit financing under Presidents Hoover, Roosevelt and Truman.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 2 -- As a result of an inter-party agreement, 6,435,000,000 forints ($585,000,000) are to be invested in the three-year plan assented to by the Hungarian Parliament yesterday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 2 -- Doubt that the State Constitutional Convention would vote to eliminate New Jersey's three race tracks with their pari-mutuel betting was expressed here today by Judge Wesley C. Lance, Hunterdon County delegate, as Methodist and Catholic groups clashed before the legislative committee on a proposal to abolish all gambling.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Declaring that "fair-minded Americans have long deplored the existence of wage differentials based on sex in American industry," Senators Claude Pepper, Democrat, of Florida, and Wayne Morse, Republican, of Oregon, introduced today "the equal pay bill of 1947."

NANKING, July 2 (U.P.) -- An official Chinese Government spokesman charged today that the civil conflict in China had become an "international war" because Chinese Communists were receiving outside aid.

LEESBURG, Va., July 2 (U.P.) -- James M. Landis, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board raised a question today whether pilot violation of a company rule, with approval of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, caused the crash taking fifty lives near here on June 13.

NEWARK, N.J., July 2 -- Acceptance or rejection of the offer of the Port of New York Authority to take over and develop the airport and marine terminal here was postponed today until at least the middle of September by action of the City Commission.

PARIS, July 2 (AP) -- Following is the text of Soviet Foreign Minister Molotav's statement at the final meeting of the three-power conference on the Marshall Plan and excerpts from subsequent statements by British Foreign Secretory Bevin and French Foreign Minister Bidault:

LONDON, July 2 (AP) -- Jack Kramer, top-seeded favorite from Los Angeles, removed the last Australian hope from the Wimbledon tennis championships today and lined up against Tom Brown San Francisco in an all-American battle for the men's singles title in Friday's final.

LONDON, July 2 (AP) -- Jack Kramer, top-seeded favorite from Los Angeles, removed the last Australian hope from the Wimbledon tennis championships today and lined up against Tom Brown San Francisco in an all-American battle for the men's singles title in Friday's final.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations attacked today as inadequate the plan of the House Republican leadership for a rise to a 60-centsan-hour minimum wage.

Off to Camp We are pleased to see evidence, in several recent cartoons, that the annual exodus to summer camps of thousands of city children has not failed to reflect in some observers at least that mixture of pathos and humor the season deserves.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The National Labor Relations Board issued today its first policy instructions under the Taft-Hartley Law in an effort to "clear the decks" of some of the backlog of 4,300 cases in its twenty-one regional offices.
Because the records of their first marriage were destroyed during the war, Jacob Klueger of Detroit, and his wife, Florentina, will be remarried on Sunday in a ceremony attended by their three sons.

ALBANY, July 2 -- The Court of Appeals handed down a unanimous decision tonight upholding the constitutionality of the WilsonPakula Law, enacted by the 1947 Legislature, which prohibits a candidate from entering the primary of a party in which he is not enrolled except with the permission of the appropriate party committee.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Five months after the President sent to the Senate the name of Philip B. Perlman of Baltimore to be Solicitor General of the United States the nomination is still being investigated by a Senate Judiciary subcommittee headed by Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan.

HOYLAKE, England, July 3 (AP) -- Tempers and golf scores blew sky high at the halfway mark in the British open golf tourney today and United States hopes to keep the trophy sank as Toledo's Frank Stranahan, who had been setting the pace for the American contingent, found himself seven strokes off the pace.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 3 -- Father Istvan Balog, who resigned his position as Secretary of State in the Prime Ministry as part of the overturn that followed the resignation of Premier Ferenc Nagy, was reported to have petitioned the Allied Control Council today for permission to found a new Hungarian party.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 3 -- Defending the equity law of New Jersey as "the finest in the United States," Supreme Court Justice Frederic R. Colie called today upon the constitutional convention to guard it jealously and to do nothing to impair it.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The Yugoslav Embassy announced here today that ten leading representatives of the Protestant Church in the United States have been invited by the Government of Yugoslavia, to visit that country for several weeks later this month.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 3 -- "Danger" that a new drive is in the making to restore control of atomic energy to the military, resulting in "the most serious consequences," was reported to the American Library Association's annual conference today by Dr. Joel H. Hildebrand, Professor of Chemistry at the University of California.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Something like a conspiracy of silence has prevailed ever since the passage of the Foreign Service Act of 1946 in regard to certain provisions of the act which threaten a return to the old, bad political days unless Congress or public opinion or both bring about their repeal.

BERLIN, July 3 -- Russian interpretation of the Berlin Constitution is preventing the city government from operating under that Constitution, in the opinion of Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor.

PITTSBURGH, July 3 (AP) -- The Pirates found their shortened leftfield fence an inviting target today and belted four home runs into the bullpen area known as "Greenberg Gardens" to defeat the Cincinnati Reds, 7-3.

Complete dinnerware and serving sets by craftsmen who have been concentrating in the past on individual ceramic bowls, vases, and similar accessories are now available for homes. Unlike the thick peasant type of handmade dishes, these are carefully finished, with fired clay bodies completely covered by glaze.

Through the progress of the days and of the seasons the people of the United States have come again to the anniversary of the adoption by the Continental Congress in 1776 of the Declaration of Independence. Elsewhere in this newspaper, as is our annual custom, appears a photostatic copy of the Declaration as it was signed by the members of that Congress.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- During the week ended July 2, member bank reserve balances decreased $93,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Joe Louis will defend his world heavyweight championship at the Yankee Stadium on the night of Sept. 19 against Joe Baksi, the former Kulpmont (Pa.) coal-miner, if the latter beats Olle Tandberg in his bout at Stockholm, Sweden, on Sunday.

MOSCOW, July 3 (AP) -- Moscow newspapers devoted considerable space today to the closing of the three-power Foreign Ministers conference in Paris on the Marshall proposal for European economic recovery, but there was no editorial comment.

Enjoying well-earned rewards, the Theatre Guild faces the new season with complete serenity. Why shouldn't it? At this early date, mind you, no fewer than four offerings -- virtually a whole season's program -- are waiting to be unveiled.

Estimates for the first six months of this year and final reports from last year show a marked increase in venereal diseases for the Harlem area, Dr. Vernon A. Ayer, district health officer for the Central Harlem Health Center of the New York City Department of Health, 2238 Fifth Avenue, reported yesterday.
Two transatlantic liners familiar to thousands of America travelers before the war, will soon be scrapped, it was reported here yesterday by the Steamship Historical Society of America.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Weekly sales of department stores were up 2 per cent for the week ended June 28 compared with the corresponding period last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Percentage changes from like periods of a year ago are indicated in the following table:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 3 -- The famous harness-racing track at Goshen, N.Y., will soon become the location grounds for a Hollywood film company. Eddie Bracken said today he would take a company to Goshen this fall to make a picture based on an original screen story, "Hambletonian," by Martin Jurow.

ALBANY, July 3 -- Governor Dewey warned landlords tonight that unless they exercise "complete reasonableness" in operating under the new Federal law they will be asking for "extremely repressive legislation." He also gave virtual assurance that the emergency state residential rent-control law would be continued until June 30, 1949, instead of ending next June.

OXFORD, Ohio, July 3 -- A nationwide campaign to improve the standards of the educational profession to include a minimum of four years of college preparation for every teacher in the United States was recommended at the opening session of the National Conference for the Improvement of Teaching today.

PITTSBURGH, July 3 -- The steel industry reacted favorably today to a settlement of the soft coal miners' wage contract, but rumblings of dissatisfaction among smaller coal producers presaged the possibility of some strikes next Tuesday.

Dr. Abba Hillel Silver of Cleveland, retiring president of the Zionist Organization of America, said last night that the United States Government must take the lead if there is to be a proper and just solution of the Palestine problem.

BERLIN, July 3 -- The arrival of Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman and Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson here today emphasized the determination of the United States not to wait for the Russians to agree to economic unification of Germany but to do all in its power to accelerate the process of restoring at least Western Germany to this country's former key role in European trade and industry.

AQUAINT and curious little book, which was unjustly neglected in these columns on its appearance several months ago, deserves to be called to the attention of all those who enjoy odd bits of literary lore and delight in the company of writers. It is called "Bookman's Pleasure: A Recreation for Booklovers,"* and is the fruit of the editorial labors of Holbrook Jackson.

Modine Manufacturing The Modine Manufacturing Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of 75 cents a share, payable to common stockholders on July 25. A quarterly dividend of 25 cents and an extra of 25 cents were paid on June 20.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Cooperation between the baking industry and other food and allied industries in advertising and sales promotion programs was indicated today as a new development in the $1,500,000 plan financed by the members of the American Bakers Association.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The breakdown of the three-power Paris conference for European reconstruction left a wake of reactions and developments in Washington today.

The first potential break in the current shipyard tie-up occurred yesterday when Todd Shipyards Corporation, one of the largest ship repair companies, offered its shipyard workers here an increase of eight cents an hour and a threeweek vacation after twenty years' service.

NEWARK, N.J., July 3 (AP) -- Mayor Vincent J. Murphy said tonight he had called a special conference of the City Commission for Tuesday in an attempt to decide whether the city should lease its air and sea ports to the Port of New York Authority.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 11 to 36 points net lower yesterday after light trading.

LONDON, July 3 -- Great Britain will cut her imports of tobacco by 20 per cent and reduce her dollar expenditure on United States films by 17 per cent, Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer, revealed today.

Critical shortages of steel pipe here have been further tightened by cancellation of September quotas for some New York distributors, spokesmen revealed here yesterday. Pipe scarcities have now become so acute that large users of 20 and 24-inch sizes, essential for gas, water and steam mains, are having local plate fabricators make up pipe, welded from steel plates, to meet emergency needs in this city, industrial buyers disclosed.
BOSTON, July 3 (AP) -- Phil Marchildon pitched the Athletics into third place over the Red Sox today with a seven-hit, 8-4 victory against the American League champions before a crowd of 16,969 fans.

Somebody switched the script at Ebbets Field yesterday. The result was that the Giants not only reversed their one-sided defeat of the night before, but added some terrific new business that left a ladies' day crowd of 27,938 practically in a state of coma.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Senate and House passage sent to the White House today a bill providing $551,275,932 for the State, Commerce and Justice Departments and the Federal judiciary for this fiscal year.

LONDON, July 3 (AP) -- Miss Doris Hart of Miami, Fla., who turned to tennis at the age of 10 to erase the effects of infantile paralysis, upset Miss Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., 2 -- 6, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 4, today to reach the Wimbledon final against Miss Margaret Osborne of San Francisco.

News from London that the British Revolution begins to cast its shadow over the House of Lords is not unexpected. Ever since the Labor party came to power the noble Lords have been a little uneasy in their seats. Few debates have not been punctuated by warning's, tinged with melancholy humor, that this ancient body should watch its step lest its dwindling prerogatives be abolished altogether by the impatient majority in the Commons.

GRAND TOWER, Ill., July 3 (AP) -- A day-and-night fight against Mississippi flood waters continued at several critical points, but Army engineers reported today that most of the remaining dikes in Illinois and Missouri were expected to hold under pressure of the river's peak crest, barring further heavy rains.

CLEVELAND, July 3 (AP) -- After blowing a five-run lead in the eighth inning today, the Detroit Tigers scored an unearned marker in the ninth to defeat the Cleveland Indians, 6 to 5, in a wild contest in which eight pitchers saw action.

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- Hank Borowy outpitched Harry (The Cat) Brecheen with a six-hitter today and the Chicago Cubs slowed down the upsurge of the St. Louis Cardinals, 4 to 2. The defeat put the Cardinals into a tie with the Cubs for fourth place.

VIENNA, July 3 -- Austria's political leadership expects something in the order of an economic war to break out on the country's eastern and northern frontier. Nevertheless a decision was informally reached by the chiefs of the two major parties today to go all the way with the Anglo-French plan for the economc revival of Europe.
ALBANY, July 3 (AP) -- Veterans with "zero per cent" disability ratings must stand with non-disabled veterans in competition for civil service jobs, the Court of Appeals has decided.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- The New England Public Service Company filed an amendment to its corporate simplification plan with the Securities and Exchange Commission today providing for payment to prior lien preferred stockholders of $100 a share as recommended by the SEC.

NEW DELHI, India, July 3 -- The final draft of amendments to the Government of India Act to divide the country into an Indian Union and Pakistan was reported to have been approved this morning by Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru and Sardar Vallabbhai Patel, representing the Indian Union, and Mohamed Ali Jinnah and Liaquat All Khan of the Moslem League in a two-hour meeting with the Viceroy, Viscount Mountbatten.

STOCKHOLM, July 3 (AP) -- The role of American business as a "social institution" striving to better the life of the entire nation was outlined today to the International Management Congress by Alvin E. Dodd of New York, president of the American Management Association.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 3 -- Yale qualified two semi-finalists in the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championship at the Montclair A.C. today as Princeton and Rollins College gained the other two brackets.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 3 -- Direct Express, 4-year-old black horse owned by Fred B. Greenly of Harrington, Del., and driven by Paul Vineyard, defeated Jimmy Creed, the favorite, to win the $25,000 National Pacing Derby in 2:02 2/5 before 20,586 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

LONDON, July 3 (AP) -- The Gaekwar of Baroda has decided not to send his 3-year-olds, Sayajirao and Mighty Maharatta, to America to run in the $100,000 Empire City Gold Cup at Belmont July 19, Trainer Fred Armstrong announced tonight.

Fall coats, suits and dresses are beginning to move in sufficient volume from New York manufacturers to enable retailers to start their early promotions, according to resident buyers yesterday. Insistence on early deliveries, they said, will enable stores to exceed their July figures by wide margins.

The National Maritime Union, CIO, challenged a report published yesterday that quoted unnamed members of Congress as declaring maritime unions were receiving a $500,000,000 annual subsidy under the Administration's foreign aid program.

Market Closings Security and commodity markets throughout the United States will be closed today in observance of Independence Day, with the usual summer shut-down tomorrow also for these exchanges with the exception of the grain markets, which will operate tomorrow as usual.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Representatives of the Peasant parties of Eastern Europe, through leaders now in exile, issued a declaration today on the eve of the United States Independence Day in behalf of a democratic peasant movement aimed at the eventual liberation of their countries and the establishment of a United States of Europe.

PARIS, July 3 -- Premier Paul Ramadier was expected to receive a vote of confidence from the Assembly tomorrow, but in the opinion of all parliamentary circles he must entrench his Government against renewed and concentrated assaults from the Communists.

LEESBURG, Va., July 3 (U.P.) -- The Airline Pilots Association, American Federation of Labor, today made six recommendations to the Civil Aeronautics Board for averting mountain crashes and otherwise improving air transport safety.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Politicians generally and labor, too, it was learned today, are watching closely a series of polls being conducted in Texas which indicate that Senator W. Lee O'Daniel, who must stand for re-election next year, is slipping badly in public favor.

Eight members of the Westo gang, a highly organized hijacking ring, were sentenced yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to terms ranging from a year and a day to six years and ten months. The sentencing of five others was postponed until next Thursday.

ALBANY, July 3 (AP) -- D. Mallory Stephens, Republican Assemblyman, author of the state rent law and chairman of the Joint Committee on Rents, said Monday that the Legislature would block any "runaway" of rents and that it probably would extend the New York law.

Market Closings Security and commodity markets throughout the United States will be closed today in observance of Independence Day, with the usual summer shut-down tomorrow also for these exchanges with the exception of the grain markets, which will operate tomorrow as usual.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Representatives of the Peasant parties of Eastern Europe, through leaders now in exile, issued a declaration today on the eve of the United States Independence Day in behalf of a democratic peasant movement aimed at the eventual liberation of their countries and the establishment of a United States of Europe.

CLEVELAND, July 3 (U.P.) -- Following Brooklyn's precedent-shattering example with Jackie Robinson, the Cleveland Indians announced today the signing of Negro infielder Larry Doby and predicted that "within ten years Nego players will be in regular service with big league teams."

ALBANY, July 3 (AP) -- D. Mallory Stephens, Republican Assemblyman, author of the state rent law and chairman of the Joint Committee on Rents, said Monday that the Legislature would block any "runaway" of rents and that it probably would extend the New York law.

PRACTICALLY every sport one can mention suffers seriously from a literary standpoint. Historical books are few and far between so that wide gaps occur in the documentary details which should be passed down from one generation to another. If there be an exception to this rule, it's in boxing where the Manly Art of Self-Defense has a tireless chronicler in Nat Fleischer, the editor of Ring Magazine.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The House Ways and Means Committee reported out the new personal income tax reduction bill today in accordance with a Republican time-table aimed at...
LONDON, July 3 (AP) -- Britons doubt that Mrs. Margaret Sanger will get very far with her proposal that Britain's cradles stay empty for the next ten years.
LONDON, July 3 -- Failure of the Paris conference depressed the stock markets here today. Business was slow and losses exceeded gains.
The number of test and development centers in the nation for planes and missiles is some index of the importance attached to these weapons.

New Yorkers generally closed their offices early yesterday, and bosses and employes alike headed out of town for the start of the July 4 week-end. The week-end was the longest, and the weather forecast the best, in a long time, and all-prepared to take advantage of it.

Lewis Parker, 14 years old, is going to celebrate the Fourth of July today at the Madison Square Boys Club's Clear Pool Camp at Carmel, N.Y., by "throwing a fish fry" for his intimates, among 350 boys at the camp.
DUBLIN, July 3 -- In the Dail Eireann here this evening Premier Eamon de Valera put forward a plan for ending the thorny problem of Ireland's partition which, he hopes, may yet lead to a solution.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The program of increasing United States influence on the Saudi Arabian peninsula is gaining more than considerable momentum, it is believed in official circles here.

Gus Fusaro, the elevator man and stock speculator who is charged with grand larceny in connection with his loss of $247,000 of acquaintances' money, was questioned yesterday by State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein.

MOBILE, Ala., July 3 -- Some of the East Coast ports have been having difficulty in signing up crews for their ships, but the reverse is true of Alabama's floating exhibit ship which will tour LatinAmerican waters, according to Henry W. Sweet, Alabama's Director of Docks.

Affiliates of the Palestine Economic Corporation will purchase this year between $3,000,000 and $5,000,000 worth of American goods, primarily machinery and agricultural equipment, if the merchandise is available and the British grant the necessary import licenses, Julius Simon, president, said yesterday.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 3 -- Long Island's first potato and vegetable harvest festival will be held at the old Suffolk County Fair grounds here on Saturday afternoon. A feature will be the selection and coronation of the queen of the festival. The queen will be chosen by a committee of judges from a group of ten attractive young women, daughters of farmers, of Nassau and Suffolk counties.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., July 3 -- The Jane Brooks Robbins Memorial tournament was played over the Mount Kisco Country Club course today and forty-five of the late Mrs. Robbins' friends took part in the competition, which was divided into two contests.

DETROIT, July 3 (AP) -- Motor vehicle production in the United States and Canada this week was estimated by Ward's Automotive Reports today at 66,537 units, compared with a revised total of 103,203 last week.

Except for adjustment in yields on Treasury certificates due to mature within the next few months, the market for Government securities was virtually unaffected yesterday by the announcement that beginning next week, the interest cost of new issues of Treasury ninety-day bills will no longer be pegged at three-eights of 1 per cent.

Wherever social work is practiced a former student will respond with admiration and affection to the name of Walter W. Pettit, who is retiring as dean of the New York School of Social Work, Columbia University. Appointed to his post in 1939, Dean Pettit served on the school faculty for thirty-two years.

The stock market received another substantial lift yesterday as threats faded of another stoppage of soft-coal production. While firmness developed soon after the opening, the list scored its sharpest rise in the final hour under increased bidding. A long list of industrials showed gains of well beyond a point, the composite rate rising 1.12 points.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The Senate approved today a bill extending for one year President Truman's full wartime control over exports and likewise his control over the importation of a small number of short supply items, notably fats and oils.

We regret that Governor Dewey has failed to appoint a woman to the State Parole Board. To express such disappointment is not a criticism of the two men just chosen to fill the places added by increasing the board from three to five. Edward J. Donovan has been Deputy State Commissioner of Correction since 1944 and previously served twelve years in the Westchester County Department of Probation.

SEOUL, Korea, July 3 -- The American delegation to the joint American-Soviet Commission on Korea will return here from Heijo, capital of the Soviet occupation zone, tomorrow morning, it was learned today.
A local law to freeze hotel rents in this city as of June 30 will be offered at a special meeting of the City Council on Tuesday, Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Passage of the Taft-Hartley Labor Bill provided a mutual opportunity for management and labor to practice the good-will and fair dealing which is the only conceivable basis for industrial peace, Earl Bunting, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said today.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on June 28 totaled 846,141 cars the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 55,155 cars, or 6.1 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 33,403 cars, or 3.8 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 47,806 cars, or 5.3 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

JOGJAKARTA, Java, July 3 (AP) -- Former Defense Minister Amir Sjahriffoedin became Premier of the Indonesian Republic today and immediately pledged himself to a "policy of peace" in future relations with the Netherlands.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Action of the July deliveries dominated the corn and oats markets on the Board of Trade here today. July corn advanced 2 3/4 cents a bushel to $2.05 1/2 and closed at the top, while July oats, after selling at $1.00 7/8, a new seasonal top, reacted slightly in the later trading and ended 1 1/4 to 1 3/8 cents higher than Wednesday's closing levels.

Private enterprise has made five positive contributions to living standards in the United States, Larry C. Hart, vice president of the Johns-Manville Corporation, told more than 500 members of the Rotary Club of New York at their luncheon meeting yesterday at the Commodore Hotel.

Holiday Affects Trade Figures Retail trade here was fairly active this week, but reflected influences arising from the approaching holiday week-end. Estimates put department store sales at about 10 per cent above a year ago, but it was pointed out that it may be laid to the opening of several stores for four days this week against three days the same period of 1946.

ATHENS, July 3 -- When Deputy Premier and Foreign Minister Constantin Tsaldaris makes his scheduled call on Dwight F. Griswold, Greek director, in the United States he will have to tell him that the Truman program for aid to Greece is in some respects already out of date, according to diplomatic and Greek Government sources today.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The one hundred and seventy-first anniversary of the signing of the American Declaration of Independence will dawn over a nation vast and powerful beyond the dreams of the Signers and troubled with trends and events in Europe which also they never envisaged. It is not surprising that in the eighth decade of the eighteenth century their mental prospect should have been their limited.

The Bowne House in Flushing, built in 1661 on land purchased from Indians for eight strings of white wampum, reopens today at 10 A.M. with flag-raising ceremonies at 37-01 Bowne Street. Open today until 5 P.M. After today open only Tuesdays and Saturdays from 3 to 5 P.M. Children under 12 should be accompanied by parents. Free.

PARIS, July 3 -- A conference of twenty-two European states to meet in Paris July 12 to make a collective response to the Marshall proposal was summoned by Britiish Foreign Secretary Bevin and French Foreign Minister Bidault today.

Because there was no corroborative evidence to support their admissions of holding up and robbing the late Edward Herbert, 60year-old auditor, last May 13, two men were freed yesterday by Magistrate Morris J. Rothenberg in Felony Court on a motion of the District Attorney's office.

RYE, N.Y., July 3 -- Two teenage couples, who set out at 5 P.M. yesterday for a three-mile joy ride to this harbor in a 22-foot sloop, Timtee III, arrived here safely at noon today after a "very slow trip." Owing to a squall that struck their light craft shortly after departure, they were driven eight miles across Long Island Sound to the vicinity of Bayside, L.I.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- President Truman's statement follows: I have today requested the Congress to enact legislation authorizing me to approve on behalf of the United States, the trusteeship agreement between the Security Council of the United Nations and the United States of America.

TRENTON, N.J., July 3 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll said today he would ask the Legislature to extend the New Jersey rent law beyond its expiration date, June 30, 1948, if housing conditions still were critical next March when Federal controls end.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Capitulation of practically the entire soft coal industry by Monday to one of the most munificent wage settlements ever negotiated by a labor union was forecast in governmental and labor quarters today.

Those who adhere to the Jewish dietary laws will applaud Horowitz Bros. Margareten of Long Island City for introducing a wide assortment of chicken products prepared and canned under strict orthodox rabbinical supervision. This is the first time that such a complete line, including seven versions of chicken, has been put out in conformance with Kashruth.

LONDON, July 3 (Reuters) -- The Western powers should now take the "iron curtain" at its face value and refuse to deal with the Soviet Union until Moscow in turn is prepared to raise the "curtain," Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said in an interview today.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 3 (AP) -- John B. Kelly Jr. of Philadelphia advanced to the semi-finals in his quest for the Diamond Sculls Challenge Cup today as two American schoolboy crews moved nearer the renewal of an old grudge for the Thames Challenge Cup at the Henley Royal Regatta.

STOCKHOLM, July 3 -- Twelve hundred delegates representing twenty-three nations attended the solemn opening of the eighth International Management Congress in Symphony Hall here today in the presence of Prince Bertil and leaders of Swedish scientific and industrial circles.

The possibility of further difficulties for the Russians in establishing their consulate here seemed to fade yesterday. Robert F. Wagner Jr., Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, reported that he had received a letter from the Soviet representatives, outlining uses for their handsome building at Park Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street that would not conflict with the zoning laws.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Lower prices for meats and some industrial commodities were responsible for a decline of 0.1 per cent in average primary market prices during the week ended June 28, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

HAMBURG, Germany, July 3 -- A proposed British Military Government ordinance for land reform in the British zone has aroused the opposition of every party in the zone. Although it is believed that the ordinance will be issued substantially as it was conceived in London, land reform experts in all German parties are in complete agreement that the plan cannot be implemented.

It remains to be seen how far the Republican Government in Indonesia is willing to go to meet Dutch objections to past attitudes and actions, but the acceptance by Amir Sjahriffoedin of the Premiership vacated by Sutan Sjahrir is at least an augury of their intention to continue to seek a peaceful solution of differences.

BUFFALO, July 3 -- Albumin, a derivative of blood plasma widely used in the war for shock, is highly valuable in the therapy of edema caused by kidney disease, Dr. George W. Thorn, of the Harvard Medical School, today told members of the American Urological Association.
PHILADELPHIA, July 3 (AP) -- Tommy Hughes, pitching his first complete game of the season, held the Boston Braves to five scattered hits to give the Philadelphia Phillies a 3-0 triumph today.

PARIS, July 3 (AP) -- The English -language text of the BritishFrench communique on the European reconstruction program: The British and French Governments reached the following decision in order to give prompt effect to the suggestions made by Mr. Marshall in his speech at Harvard University on June 5 that Europe should take the initiative in the work of reconstruction.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The country's 699 railroads petitioned the Government today for an increase averaging 16 per cent in their freight rates to add more than a billion dollars to their revenues in 1947.

The United Furniture Workers of America became yesterday the third affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations to announce it would by-pass the new labor board set up by the TaftHartley law.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y. July 3 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie now has his architectural staff working to reduce the cost of the United Nations future headquarters by $2,000,000 to $10,000,000, it was announced here today.

Increased supplies of bristles available to brush manufacturers have come largely from southern China ports, and although high quality bristle-stocks from northern China in temporary supply are adequate, the paint brush industry would be faced with serious shortages if there should be any extensive effort to export large quantities of American-made brushes to Europe during late summer and fall, industry members revealed here yesterday.

DETROIT, July 3 -- The Ford Motor Company today served notice on the Foremen's Association of America, 3,800 of whose members have been on strike against the company, that company recognition of the union was being withdrawn.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 3 -- With trips abroad this summer awaiting twenty-one of the outstanding performers and the burden of favoritism in next year's Olympic Games due to fall upon many of the winners, the National A.A.U. track and field championships will open tomorrow at the University of Nebraska's Memorial Stadium.

Adventures as encountered by a New York newspaper columnist, who also has a network radio audience, will be created by Robert Shaw for "Christopher Wells" and retailed weekly over WCBS and the entire CBS chain, beginning Sept. 28 at 10 P.M.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 3 -- While motor traffic into the lower Catskill region today set a preFourth of July record with an estimated 75,000 vehicles, there was less congestion and confusion than during a corresponding period last year, according to a survey sponsored by the Automobile Club of New York.

JERUSALEM, July 3 -- Two weeks of public hearings by the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine will begin tomorrow in the Y.M.C.A. auditorium here with the presentation of the Zionist political aims for Palestine by David Ben-Gurion, chairman of the Jewish Agency for Palestine.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 3 (AP) -- Shipowners announced plans today to tie up most of their vessels in intercoastal service and warned the withdrawal of Federal operation without further remedy would virtually dry up the trade.
MANILA, Friday, July 4 -- President Manuel Roxas, speaking today on the first anniversary of the Philippine Republic, stressed his country's progress.
MADRID, July 3 -- The Monarchist attitude on Generalissimo Francisco Franco's referendum on Sunday to ratify his position as lifetime Chief of State was clarified today by a Monarchist leader.
Weekdays and week-ends, pavement -blistered New Yorkers pour by thousands down to the seawalls and to the railroad terminals for quick flight to open water, and fishing.

One hundred and fifty old persons, 65 to 78 years of age, agreed they had the "time of our young lives" yesterday at an Independence Day party at the William Hodson Memorial Center conducted in part by the City Welfare Department at Bronx Borough Hall, 177th Street and Third Avenue.

The classroom as a place "where emotional maturity is enhanced" is threatened by frustrated women who, as teachers, get a "sense of power out of the classroom situation," Dr. Abraham N. Franzblau, dean of the School of Religious Education of Hebrew Union College, declared yesterday.

JERUSALEM, July 3 -- Two weeks of public hearings by the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine will begin tomorrow in the Y.M.C.A. auditorium here with the presentation of the Zionist political aims for Palestine by David Ben-Gurion, chairman of the Jewish Agency for Palestine.

LONDON, July 3 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin flew in from Paris at 5:20 o'clock this afternoon in a fighting mood. He is angry with the Russians who he feels wrecked the chances of a joint European economic program to meet the offer of United States Secretary of State, Marshall.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- A preliminary inquiry into reports that strange "flying disks" have been whizzing at 1,200 miles an hour over the Western United States "has not produced enough fact to warrant further investigation," an Army Air Forces spokesman said today.

A program for improvements in making plutonium in the great atomic plant near Richland, Wash., was announced yesterday by the Atomic Energy Commission in a release issued by the General Electric Company, which is to do the main work, The Associated Press reported.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 3 -- After a three-hour drive through Virginia's battlefields, including Bull Run and Manassas, President Truman arrived here late this afternoon for the Independence Day week-end.

VENTNOR CITY, N.J., July 3 -- After having won six games in a row, Anthony E. Santasiere, New York State champion, suffered his first defeat in the seventh round of the open tournament sponsored by the New Jersey State Chess Federation on the Municipal Pier today.
Edward A. Varni has been appointed buyer of upstairs women's and children's hosiery for Gimbel Brothers, New York, effective July 14. He was with Hearns.
Gallorette took some mild exercise at Jamaica yesterday and demonstrated to all hands that she has recovered completely from the injury that kept her out of the Brooklyn Handicap.

LONDON, July 3 (U.P.) -- Radio Moscow said tonight that Foreign Minister Molotov had arrived home from the Paris Big Three Conference. This was the first mention by Moscow that Mr. Molotov had left Paris without saying formal good-by to French or British Big Three leaders.

NEWARK, N.J., July 3 -- The Traffic Telephone Workers Federation was stayed by a decision today by a three-judge statutory Federal court from proceeding with a Federal court test of the constitutionality of the amended Public Utility Anti-Strike Act of New Jersey pending the disposition of such a test in the state courts.
Worcester, Mass., announced yesterday that it would receive bids up to July 11 for $2,682,000 of sewer and street bonds dated July 1, 1947, and due on each July 1 from 1948 to 1957.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- A Senate appropriations subcommittee today voted to give the Army almost $600,000,000 more than the House allowed, mostly for new planes and Air Force equipment.

Demands for public hearings on the proposal to increase the fare on subway and elevated lines to 8 cents, or two rides for 15 cents, were made yesterday by the New York Consumers Council and State Senator Kenneth Sherbell, ALPRepublican, of Brooklyn, in telegrams to Mayor O'Dwyer.

Normally one of the largest exporters of hides, Argentina has virtually been forced out of the hide market and current estimates indicate an existing stockpile in that country of 2,000,000 or more hides. Why Argentina has not been releasing hides is one of the prime questions interesting the domestic shoe and leather industry here, it was pointed out yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Senator James E. Murray, Democrat, of Montana, author of a health insurance bill, accused Senator Forrest C. Donnell, Republican, of Missouri, of "smear tactics" at today's hearing of a Senate Labor and Public Welfare subcommittee on the Taft and Murray health bills.
The disposition of more than 300 food parcels from Greece was in the balance yesterday as a result of Government action to stop illegal importations of meat products.

Lauritz Melchior, heroic tenor of the Metropolitan Opera and Hollywood, was featured in his first Stadium appearance last night before an audience of 13,000. Alexander Smallens conducted the Philharmonic-Symphony in a program which ran the gamut from Wagner to Youmans, and which would have smothered a less imposing soloist under its very diversity.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The Senate half of the joint Committee on Labor-Management Relations which will, among other things, watch the operation and administration of the Taft-Hartley Labor Relations Act, was named today.

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- Bobby Locke, South African champion, Herman Keiser and Ed (Porky) Oliver today rolled into the first round lead of the $36,000 Tam O'Shanter golf tournament with six-under-par 66's.

Total earning assets, consisting of all loans and investments of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System during the week ended on Wednesday declined $36,000,000 to $20,082,000,000, according to the statistics issued in revised form yesterday for the first time by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

World Upside Down In the autumn of 1781 there was a popular song called "The World Turned Upside Down." It has a place in American history. When Cornwallis' army marched put of the trenches between lines of American and French troops at Yorktown to stack arms, some English officer, name unknown but clearly a person with a pretty wit, ordered the bands to play "The World Turned Upside Down."
TOKYO, July 4 -- Under Hiroo Wada, its new chief, the Economic Stabilization Board has finally tackled the long-deferred problem of wage and price stabilization.
LONDON, July 4 -- The best features in otherwise quietish stock markets here today were British Government stocks and industrial shares.

Monticello is a peculiarly evocative spot. Few men have left so lasting an impress on the place where they lived as Thomas Jefferson. His genius and his personality, his taste and curiosity, still animate the serene and graceful house he built in the Virginia hills. The intellectual father of the American Revolution gave the world a new definition of human rights.
ALBANY, July 4 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, accompanied by Mrs. Dewey and their two children, left here tonight for a four-week trip that will carry him into most of the Mountain States.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 4 -- Installed tonight as president of the American Library Association, Paul North Rice, head of the reference department of the New York Public Library, told colleagues from twenty-four nations attending the annual conference of the association that it might be "necessary" for librarians to "desert our boasted neutrality" in this atmoic age.

JERSEY CITY, July 4 (AP) -- Felix Mackiewicz put on a one-man display of Fourth of July fireworks today as he blasted three home runs, two in the first game and one in the nightcap, a jackpot job, to lead Jersey City to a twin victory over Newark, 5 -- 3 and 7 -- 5, before a crowd of 9,309.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 4 -- The two top favorites in both the men's and women's singles advanced to the final round of the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships today at the Montclair A. C.

ROME, July 4 -- Ambassador James C. Dunn for the United States and Foreign Minister Carlo Sforza for Italy this morning signed the Italy-American agreement regulating assistance to Italy under the United States' foreign relief program.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 4 The collapse of the Paris conference, coupled with reports that the Soviet Union will not ratify the satellite peace treaties at least until September is regarded in informed quarters today as a certain sign that Russia intends in the next few months to strengthen her economic, political and potential military hold in the Eastern European bloc.

BOSTON, July 4 (AP) -- A threehit pitching performance by Tex Hughson enabled the Boston Red Sox to end a six-game losing streak by shutting out the Philadelphia Athletics, 4 -- 0, in the second game of today's holiday double-header.
PITTSBURGH, July 4 -- The engagement of Miss Ruth Plato McClelland to the Rev. Stewart Payne Robinson, has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. William David McClelland of this city.

MOBILE, Ala., July 4 (AP) -- Capt. E.W. Higginbotham, national president of the AFL Masters, Mates and Pilots, announced today the union had obtained a 5 per cent wage increase in negotiations with Atlantic and Gulf steamship operators.

Oak Beach, which is just east of Jones Beach, is a favorite place for those surf fishermen who aren't anxious to make the long haul from the city to Shinnecock and Montauk of a week-end. Sometimes it looks as though a picket fence had been built along the water's edge, but it's no fence, just a long row of surfers.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 4 -- Rooting through splash and whitecaps of a real northerly breeze with a session of prolonged and steady life in it were 172 starting craft today out on Long Island Sound in the annual regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Canon Bernard Iddings Bell will be guest preacher tomorrow at 11 A.M. and on succeeding Sundays through August in Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street, it was announced yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, the rector, will be on vacation.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, July 4 (U.P.) -- Gen Hsiung Shih-hui, commander of the Nationalist, Army in Manchuria, said today that Soviet Army units had violated the Chinese-Soviet border and occupied the city of Tahcheng in Sinkiang Province.

ROME, July 3 -- The Italian Government received and accepted today an invitation to the Paris aid conference. Extraordinary importance is attributed to the parley in Italian political circles because though its ostensible purpose is to discuss plans for application of the Marshall plan the general belief is that it may lay the foundation for a federation of western European states.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 4 -- When William Marcey (Boss) Tweed comes to the screen in the Romberg-Fields musical, "Up In Central Park," for Universal-International, he will have romantic interests not even suggested in Mike Todd's Broadway production of two years ago.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Southern coal operators, officially undecided whether to accept the terms agreed to by Northern and "captive" mine owners and the United Mine Workers, waited in a vacuum today while lawyers drafted the contract.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 4 -- Close competition marked the special holiday horse show staged by the Westchester and Fairfield chapters of the Professional Horsemen's Association on the Frank Altschul estate today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: An unfortunate feature in connection with legislation regarding labor unions lies in the disinclination or reluctance on the part of these unions to indicate in what forms and to what extent government supervision or regulation would be acceptable to them.

Many will be appalled at some of the facts developed or restated at the meeting in Ohio of the National Conference for the Improvement of Teaching. More than half of the 850,000 teachers in this country have no college degree, and 60,000 have not even gone beyond high school.

CINCINNATI, July 4 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds swept a doubleheader with the Pittsburgh Pirates before 19,293 here today, winning the first, 8 -- 0, as Ewell Blackwell notched his twelfth straight and fourteenth victory of the season and the second, 6 -- 4, on Grady Hatton's two-run homer in the ninth inning.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 4 -- The 220-pound Carl DeRose, who became the first sore-armed pitcher in baseball history to pitch a perfect no-hit, no-run game in which he faced only 27 batters, was the recipient of enough awards here today to soothe the pain of his pitching flipper.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 4 (AP) -- Before the largest crowd to witness Grand Circuit racing at Historic Track in a decade, Judge Moore, owned by W.N. Reynolds of Winston-Salem, N.C., today won the $5,000 Harriman Challenge Trophy for 2-year-old trotters.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 4-President Truman strode across the shady quadrangle of the University of Virginia today with a grinning three-year-old youngster perched happily upon his shoulders.

LONDON, July 4 -- Correcting reports of his speech in the House of Commons on Tuesday, John Strachey, Minister of Food, made it clear today that Britain was not sure of obtaining an ample food supply in the coming year.

By correlating basic Jewish teachings with newer scientific facts in programs of counseling for marriage and family living, rabbis can help to avert the "threat to traditional Jewish family life," Dr. Lena Levine, director of the Marriage Counseling Service of the Margaret Sanger Bureau and medical director of the New York City Planned Parenthood Centers, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- A second group of B-29 Superfortresses is being deployed on the West Coast.

PRAGUE, July 4 -- Czechoslovak leaders hurriedly scheduled a trip to Moscow tonight, undoubtedly in the hope of conferring with the Russians about the serious economic situation created here by Soviet rejection of the French plan for implementing the Marshall proposals for aiding Europe.

Advertising linage in New York newspapers during June totaled 11,988,051 lines, a gain of 9.4 per cent over the corresponding month of last year, according to a compilation of Media Records. Losses, however, were recorded for financial, 33.4 per cent; and classified, 4.16 per cent.

BERLIN, July 5 -- The United States guaranteed today to establish food exports for Germany on a high-enough level in the next twelve months to keep the ration for the normal consumer at 1,550 calories daily.

LONDON, July 5 (Reuters) -- President Truman's Independence Day speech was praised by some sections of the British Press today, one paper describing him as a bigger man "than many of us first estimated."

As part of a plan for reorganizing the property on a cooperative basis, a new ten-year mortgage loan of $800,000 at 3 1/2 per cent has been made by the Aetna Insurance Company of Hartford on the apartment building at 40 Fifth Avenue. E.F. Rodgers, vice president of Douglas L. Elliman Co., arranged the refinancing, which replaces an original mortgage of $1,250,000 at 6 per cent.

MOSCOW, July 4 (AP) -- Informed persons said today that Russia, with one of her best harvests in years in prospect and industry building toward an impressive production rate, was in a position to offer economic aid of her own to European countries as a counterattraction to the Marshall proposal.

LINCOLN, NEB., July 4 -- One meet record fell in a series of brilliant performances today as the sixtieth National A.A.U. track and field championships got under way before a crowd of 10,000 in the University of Nebraska's Memorial Stadium.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- Armed, the nation's 1946 handicap champion, sizzled to a two-length victory in the $55,700 Stars and Stripes Handicap at Arlington Park today to achieve his first Chicago triumph in five starts.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Overseas Consultants, Inc., of 51 East Forty-second Street, New York, will survey Japan's potentialities for industry, economic recovery and reparations removals, the War Department announced today.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- Record attendance at the Summer Furniture Market, opening here Monday for a two-week period, was predicted today by officials of the American Furniture Mart and the Merchandise Mart, but the volume of buying was declared to be "an unknown quantity."

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- Under pressure of a 500 to 1 side bet on the 18th green with promoter George S. May, Ed (Porky) Oliver today missed an 18-foot, $3,000 birdie putt. However, he carded a record-breaking 36-hole score of 131 to nail down the halfway lead in the Tam o'Shanter golf jamboree.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., July 4 (AP) -- Mrs. Katharine St. George, Republican Representative of the Twenty-eighth District of New York, said tonight the American people were demanding a "thorough cleansing" of their civil government to obtain relief from the "twin burden" of big taxes and high costs.

The Robin Gray, a reconverted C-3 type vessel, will be turned over to the Seas Shipping Company, operator of the Robin Line, within a fortnight, it was announced yesterday. The ship is the third of six similar vessels bought by the concern for its service between the United States and South and East Africa.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 4 -- The date for moving approximately $16,000,000 worth of machine tool exhibits into the Dodge-Chicago Plant for the 1947 Machine Tool Show has been advanced from Aug. 25 to Aug. 4, the National Machine Tool Builders Association announced here today.

PARIS, July 4 -- Seven European countries indicated tonight their acceptance of the Anglo-French invitation to the July 12 Paris conference on the Marshall plan for European reconstruction [A dispatch from Istanbul said Turkey would accept, and United Press reports indicated that Belgium and Switzerland also would send delegations to Paris.]

Historic Bowne House at 37-01 Bowne Street, Flushing, Queens, built in 1661 and dedicated on October 10, 1945, as a shrine of religious tolerance and freedom, was visited by more than 500 persons yesterday after it was opened formally to the public with flag-raising ceremonies at 10 A.M.

PRAGUE, July 4 (UP) -- Premier Cyrankiewicz said today that Poland's reply to the French-British invitation to the Paris Conference could not be drafted until he and his Cabinet members now here returned to Warsaw.

NANKING, July 4 -- The Chinese Government went a technical step further today in its war with the Communists through a resolution calling for "national general mobilization to quell the Communist armed rebellion."

LOS ANGELES, July 4 (AP) -- A holiday outburst of brush and forest fires, in the midst of record July Fourth travel, spread smoke over much of Southern California tonight, brought property damage in excess of a half-million dollars and left 150 or more homeless.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- The Cubs lost, 7 -- 0, to the Cardinals but won the second game, 5 -- 4, today before a capacity crowd of 44,954 and the two teams remained tied for fourth place in the National League.

LONDON, July 4 (AP) -- Jack Kramer of Los Angeles added the Wimbledon singles championship to his imposing list of tennis titles today by routing Tom Brown of San Francisco, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, in one of the most one-sided finals ever played in the All-England tournament.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 4 -- Led by Cecil Smith, who scored six goals, the Texas poloists romped to an 11-3 victory over Bostwick Field in the final of the third Westbury Challenge Cup tournament on Cochran Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.

PARIS, July 4 -- The Food Supply and Agricultural Ministers of fifty-two countries, who will attend the cereal conference meet here early next week, will prepare the data to assist the European conference on the Marshall plan July 12, for which formal invitations were sent out today.

Set in a bowl of crushed ice, cold soups are as refreshing an appetizer on a hot day as the tomato or fruit juice cocktail that Americans accept much more readily. Perhaps we regard the dish with suspicion because it's never been the custom here to serve soup chilled, although in the last decade jellied consomme has become quite popular and the French have succeeded in introducing their famed vichyssoise.
A dispute among writers regarding the proposed American Authors Authority appeared yesterday to be on the way to a solution.

DECORAH, Iowa, July 4 -- Miss Marge Hurlburt of Painesville, Ohio, holder of the women's international air speed record, crashed to her death before an estimated 2,500 spectators today while performing in a Fourth of July show at the Decorah Airport.

Fear that real estate interests would wage a protracted and eventually successful legal battle against the local hotel rent law promised by Mayor O'Dwyer and a majority of the City Council to halt runaway rent increases prompted some tenant groups yesterday to seek legislative protection through the State and Federal Governments.

VICKSBURG, Miss., July 4 -- This nation dares not neglect now the security of military, moral and economic strength, nor ignore "the possibility of insane attack on those who work for peace," Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower declared here today.

ST. LOUIS, July 4 -- Six hundred persons, two-thirds of the population of Grand Tower, Ill., ninety miles south of here, were forced from their homes today as the Mississippi River reached a record level there and breached a sandbag barrier thrown up by the townspeople.
LEE, Mass., July 4 -- The Jacobs Pillow Dance Festival opened its annual season in its charming rustic theatre near here this afternoon.

The following is the text of President Truman's address at Monticello, home of Thomas Jefferson, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES: Governor Tuck, Mr. Houston, distinguished guests and fellowcountrymen:

It was close all the way from the middle of the turn, but C. V. Whitney's Ghost Run, handled by the talented Ruperto Donoso, managed to get to the wire a neck to the good in the $25,000 added Demoiselle Stakes at Jamaica yesterday.

Determined to prove their superiority over their ancient foes regardless of what hour of the day the combat is staged, the Dodge battled the Giants through a lot daylight at Ebbets Field yesterday. They emerged with a clean sweep of the "one day tournament" while retaining at the same time their hold on the National League leadership.

PARIS, July 4 -- Premier Paul Ramadier obtained a vote of confidence, for his program against inflation today and he declared solemnly before the National Assembly that France had accepted without qualification the Marshall suggestion for European aid.

JOGJAKARTA, Java, July 4 (AP) -- Indonesian Premier Amir Sjahriffoedin asked the United States in a Fourth of July message today to remember her "revolutionary tradition" and help the Indonesian Republic attain an "independence day free from fear."

The establishment of a Jewish national home in Palestine as quickly as possible is in the best interests of Great Britain and the United States, James G. McDonald a member of the American-Anglo Committee of Inquiry in Palestine said yesterday at the fiftieth annual convention of the Zionist Organization of America in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Insect repellants more powerful than DDT lie in the immediate future.

WILDWOOD, N.J., July 4 -- At least forty men, women and children were hurt, some seriously, a little after 9 o'clock tonight when a large section of the walkway around Convention Hall collapsed while they were looking at a Fourth of July fireworks display on the beach front.

GENEVA, July 4 -- The United States and Australia have begun talks on the American wool tariff, it was learned today. As far as could be learned, the United States has made no offer of tariff reductions.

LONDON, July 4 -- In a ringing affirmation of belief in human liberty, Foreign Secretary Bevin warned the Soviet Union tonight against carrying provocation too far and vowed that nothing would ever separate the United States and Britain.

HENLEY-ON-THE-THAMES, England, July 4 (AP) -- John B. Kelly Jr. of Philadelphia, wearing the green cap that is his family's flag of revenge, paddled into the final of the Diamond Sculls today with a four-length victory over Bert Bushnell, last hope of the British.

MOUNTAIN VIEW, N.J., July 4 -- Wayne Township, which embraces this community and eight others in its twenty-seven square miles, began today a three-day celebration of the 100th anniversary of its organization on April 12, 1847.
LONDON, July 4 (AP) -- Americans in Europe observed in scattered celebrations today the 171st anniversary of their independence.

John Green, national president of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, declared yesterday that any argument that traces an American shipyard slump to competition with "allegedly lowercost" labor in foreign shipyards is "specious."

The feud between the Coney Island Chamber of Commerce and the Chamber of Commerce of the Rockaways flared up anew yesterday, when for the first time, and without any advance notice, the Park Department declined to make any estimate of the holiday makers at the Rockaway beaches.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 (AP) -- The Boston Braves swept a doubleheader from the Phillies today, Frank McCormick's big bat leading a fifteen-hit onslaught to take the opener, 10 -- 3, and two Philadelphia wild throws paving the way for a 7-1 decision in the aftermath.

An abrupt change of pace is in store for Henry Morgan fans the night of July 16 at 10:30, when that durable chiller, "Lights Out," is revived with Boris Karloff as principal bogeyman. Presumably, Mr. Karloff will have the WJZABC audience in that half-hour time segment begging for a laugh by the time the whimsical Mr. Morgan returns Sept. 10 from the vacation he will begin after his performance Wednesday.

"Finian's Rainbow," the musical comedy hit, will get a new Finian McLonergan -- its fourth -- in about two weeks, it was learned yesterday. Unlike his predecessors, he will be neither Irish nor within twenty years of the 60-year-old character's age.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 4 -- (London Times Dispatch) -- Turkey will be glad to accept the invitation to attend the July 12 conference. She will take part in a spirit of readiness to do whatever she can to contribute to the alleviation of the distress in Europe.

Supplies of food and textiles in Norway have increased to the point where there is now "little need for outside help," the Norwegian Government has informed the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe, 50 Broad Street. As a result CARE will accept no further orders for that country, Paul Comly French, executive director of the organization, announced yesterday.

LONDON, July 4 -- The bill granting independence to India was presented to the House of Commons by Prime Minister Attlee this afternoon. History will have to record the curious coincidence that this fateful act took place on the United States' Independence Day, and Britons have not failed to note that fact.

Sometimes perspective is more important than close association. A view from a distance is often more revealing than one from close by. Take, for instance, our Independence Day. Too often we treat the famous Declaration as a mere historical document with little application in today's world.
Elmer J. Rose and Milton R. Bailey have been named vice presidents of the Bulkley, Bunton Pulp Company, it was announced by Fred Enders, president.

New England Landmark Along the coastline of the Northeast you will find them -- in villages of Cape Cod, on the salty island of Nantucket, by the granite-fringed coast of Maine, and on the hillsides of river towns that form a link between the mainland and the sea.

GSTAD, Switzerland, July 4 (U.P.) -- Count Richard Coudenhove-Kalergi, founder of the Pan-European movement, said today at a meeting to plan the preliminary European parliamentary conference that a union of Europe was no longer a distant dream.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- A 1947 employment peak of 59,300,000, or 1,300,000 higher than ever before, is a near certainty, the United States Employment Service indicated today.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 4 -- The fourth anniversary of the Philipse Manor restoration here was marked today with the opening to public view of two new features of the project, a historic royal charter that created the 87,000acre manor of Cortlandt and a huge Dutch barn, believed to be the oldest of its kind intact in America.

ROSELLE, N.J., July 4 -- Mr. and Mrs. Richard V. Reamer of this place have announced the engagement of Mr. Reamer's sister, Miss Mary F. Reamer, to Don J. Stuehler, son of Mrs. Otto Stuehler of Union, N.J., and the late Mr. Stuehler.
