The Ways and Means Committee has reported out a new version of the tax reduction bill recently vetoed by the President, and the Republicans are reported to be counting upon the House and Senate to act on the legislation in time to send it to the White House by the end of next week.

JERUSALEM, July 4 -- David Ben-Gurion, chairman of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, called on the United Nations today to undertake the immediate end of British restrictions on Jewish immigration and settlement in the Holy Land.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 4 -- A stern remonstrance to the Soviet Union and its satellites for blocking world reconstruction was the theme of President Truman's Independence Day address today. He delivered it from the east portico of Thomas Jefferson's home, Monticello, atop a mountain five miles from here.

HOYLAKE, Eng., July 4 (U.P.) -- Frank Stranahan, 24-year-old amateur from Toledo, Ohio, lost the British open championship by three inches today, but he gained the most important victory of his career when he captured the heart of embittered Britons with a courageous finish that left him only one stroke behind the new champion, Fred Daly of Belfast, Ireland.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A recent dispatch from Paris dealing with surplus property which has, apparently, disappeared, states "It is said that (the French statisticians) are unable to trace any sign of a magnificent pipe line, built by the United States Army to keep war machines rolling, all the way up the Valley of the Rhone."

OXFORD, Ohio, July 4 -- Warning that the United States faced the worst school building crisis in its history, educators attending the National Conference for the Improvement of Teaching, declared today that obsolete building's, fire traps and hovels hardly fit for cattle were being used for classrooms.

MONTEREY, Mass., July 4 -- Speaking today at the start of the three-day centennial celebration of this South Berkshire town, Brig. Gen. William H. Middleswart, Assistant Quartermaster General and chief of the Military Planning Division, asserted that training, promotion of research and development and industrial mobilization were necessary to assure the nation's military security.

Constantin Tsaldaris, Minister for Foreign Affairs of Greece, declared here yesterday that the plain people of Europe understand the Marshall proposal for continental aid is intended for the benefit of the whole of Europe.
The noise which reverberated over the east bank of the Harlem yesterday was kicked up by a Yankee artillery display in an appropriate celebration of Independence Day.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 4 -- Mr. and Mrs. William O. Melvin of this place have announced the engagement of Mrs. Melvin's sister, Miss Virginia Monks, to Benjamin M. Burr, son of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Burr of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., and North Haven, Me.

The German people are "making hay" out of the conflict between East and West European factions, according to Theodore Geiger, who returned on the United States liner America yesterday after a survey of conditions in Germany as executive officer of three welfare committees.

OXFORD, Ohio, July 4 -- The school of the future was described here today -- and it was pretty to look at. Instead of the clanging bells to dismiss students or summon them to luncheon, the school will have musical chimes. Out will go the traditional blackboard, and in its place will come an attractive green or white board.

Two youthful fishermen were drowned at 12:15 P.M. yesterday when a new motor cruiser on Long Island Sound crashed into their rowboat and cut it in, two. The accident happened 400 yards off Belden Point, at the southern tip of City Island, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- Morgan L. Fitch, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, said today President Truman's criticism of the new rental act shows he is either "woefully uninformed or has been maliciously misinformed about housing conditions in the United States."

ANSONIA, Conn., July 4 -- Three days ago Mayor Thomas J. Nelligan of this town of 20,000 in the heart of the industrial Naugatuck Valley borrowed the Police Commissioner's golf clubs and hied himself to Vermont.

The casual visitor thinks of New York City as all pavement and stone, but more than 22,500 acres or thirty-five of its 321 square miles are public parks laid out in greensward, lakes, beaches, picnic grounds, fishing spots, pools and playfields.

SOUTH KINGSTOWN, R.I., July 4 -- Gael Sullivan, 42-year-old executive director of the Democratic National Committee, pleaded innocent in State District Court tonight to a charge of driving a motor vehicle while under the influence of liquor.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- An improved optical system for periscopes, designed to eliminate the loss of light in transmission from air to glass, which in the case of submarine periscopes involving the inclusion of more than one complete telescope system arranged in series may range from 4 to 6 per cent, was one of the 354 inventions for which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.
Six crack trains and a dozen others of the New York Central System were delayed yesterday after derailment of a tank car at the Kingsbridge freight yard blocked the tracks near by.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 4 (AP) -- A marine mystery surrounded reports today of a ship burning and sinking off the Northern California Coast. The Coast Guard, after almost twenty-four hours of air and surface search between Point Reyes and Point Arena, admitted bafflement.

Ambassador Carlos P. Romulo, Philippine representative to the United Nations, spoke here last night at a celebration of the first anniversary of Philippine independence. He said his country had made "remarkable progress" in the year and declared that he would support the "legitimate aspirations of all peoples to freedom and independence."

STANTON, Del., July 4 (AP) -- Charging down the middle of the track while his rivals fought it out on the rail, Camargo from Harry M. Lunger's Christiana Stable scored a surprise victory in the Delaware Oaks at Delaware Park today.

CLEVELAND, July 4 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians came up with one run in the last of the ninth to tie the Detroit Tigers, 4 to 4, in the nightcap of today's doublehader. The contest was called at the end of the regulation distance to permit Cleveland Stadium to be used for a Fourth of July celebration.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 4 (U.P) -- A rescue party crawled through the black corridors of Nickajack Cave today with grappling equipment to probe the depths of a subterranean pool for a man's body.

VIENNA, July 4 (U.P.) -- Interior Minister Oskar Helmer told Parliament today that Russian authorities had forbidden Austrian police to report to Government agencies the frequent kidnappings by Russian soldiers within the Russian zone.

AALBORG, Denmark, July 4 -- The Independence Day festival in the Danish-American National Park at Rebild, Jutland, where the day was observed on a scale at least matching that in any country outside the United States, took on added significance this year.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., July 4 -- Though this woodland resort had more visitors today than ever before, it was not the people that disturbed park officials. It was the bears.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 4 (AP) -- Justice Robert H. Jackson of the Supreme Court asserted today that he did "not expect the resumption of warfare in my time" and called forecasts of another war "regrettable" and "vicious."
Americans the world over took stock of their heritage of freedom yesterday on the 171st anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (U.P.) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration today distributed a report on non-scheduled air carriers. A pessimistic future was predicted for the industry that mushroomed immediately after the war.

ST. LOUIS, July 4 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns roared back to crush the Chicago White Sox, 10 to 2, today after Chicago had won the opener of the Independence Day double-header, 6 to 3, before 9,500 fans. Jeff Heath, Browns' left fielder, hit a homer in each game, the second coming with the bases loaded.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 (AP) -- Joe McIntyre, 20-year-old Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia oarsman, won the Plaisted Mug, symbolic of the senior singles scull title, in the annual Peoples Regatta on the Schuykill River today.
Strikebound stores of the Whelan Drug Company were opened yesterday afternoon soon after members of Local 1199, Retail Drug Store Employes, CIO, had approved a new company settlement proposal.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that meat animal prices averaged about 50 per cent higher during the first half of 1947 than under price ceilings of a year earlier. They were reported 16 per cent higher than in the last half of 1946.
Five youths were arrested on homicide charges yesterday as the result of work by detectives who had built up a file of information on Harlem gangs.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is a most disturbing sign when responsible leaders in the real estate field in New York State publicly denounce efforts to do away with racial and religious discrimination in the housing field primarily because such efforts handicap "vast potential institutional investments under the limited-dividend and urban redevelopment laws."

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 4 -- The Zoning Board of Appeals of Oyster Bay Township announced today that the public hearing on the application for a change in the zoning law to permit Long Island University to take over the Hillwood estate of Mrs. Joseph E. Davies had been moved to a larger meeting room.

Gilberto Garcia of Santiago, with a well-earned victory over Jose Florido of Havana, yesterday moved into the lead in the sixth round of the international chess masters tournament at the Club de Ajedrez Capablanca of Havana, according to a report from Cuba.

MADRID, July 4 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco tonight made a direct personal appeal to this nation to vote on Sunday for his law of succession that will establish him as lifetime dictator of Spain.

BOSTON, July 5 -- The Soviet Union is seeking to sell back to the Gillette Safety Razor Company thirteen trade-marks of the American company's almost wholly owned German subsidiary which were taken over by Russia in the peace treaty with Finland.

DETROIT, July 5 (U.P.) -- The Automobile Manufacturers Association reported tonight that one out of every seven workers in the United States earns his living in the automotive and related industries. The AMA, in its 1946-47 "Automobile Facts and Figures" yearbook, said that 537,000 automotive business places -- one-sixth of all concerns in this country -- employ 8,200,000 persons.

STUTTGART, Germany, July 5 -- United States Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson expressed encouragement today that the Germans themselves were awakening to the imperative necessity of increasing their food production to balance the cost of supplies imported into this country.

THE amateur photographer with a desire to do something different can achieve fantastic scenic effects simply by loading his camera with infra-red film. This film is available now for cameras using miniature and roll film, sheet film and plate sizes.

Boys in short pants from Hell's Kitchen and Tenth Avenue who have spent previous summers playing stickball and kick the can on steaming streets left New York yesterday morning for Fox Lair, the Police Athletic League's camp in the Adirondack Mountains.

The police at the Far Rockaway station get all sorts of fish stories in summer, particularly over the Fourth of July weeK-end. So yesterday morning when a woman telephoned and said she was a nurse and reported "an enormous fish" the police told her that fish belonged to the Coast Guard.

THOSE fabulous bon voyage parties that mellowed departing voyageurs in the lush pre-war days have undergone a change in keeping with the times. The ships are again leaving, the planes are flying and the spirit is there.

GADGETS galore, oceans a lotions and all sorts of aids are being displayed in the shops to increase the joys of summer and remove some of its sting. Among the newest things under the sun are non-oily suntan lotions, collapsible cabanas, folding charcoal grills and electric picnic stoves with four heat levels.

IN its July travel survey and forecast, the American Express Company sees the vacation peak for July and August accentuated by reason of the belated summer season. "Resort reservations will be at a premium and mileage to places of considerable distance by all forms of transportation will equal the highest pre-war period," continues the report, "with indications that the dollar spending for July and August alone will exceed last year's by 10 per cent."

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 5 (AP) -- Lighthouse, highly regarded 3-year-old colt from the Woodland Stable, led a field of nine 3-year-olds over the entire mile and a sixteenth, romping to the wire five lengths in front of the odds-on public choice, Trapeze, who finished second, in the Lamplighter Handicap at Monmouth Park today.

Effects of corporate income taxes upon prices under present conditions have been greatly exaggerated, Dr. Joseph J. Klein, senior partner in Klein, Hinds Finke, member of the New York bar and former president of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants, said yesterday.

The annual sea serpent has been taking a much-needed rest along our coasts this summer. But while Old Reliable has been lying low, those sky-skimming saucers have been flying high. Their natural habitat appears to be the Pacific Northwest, but they have now been "observed" from California to Nova Scotia.

WRITING about writing is often dreary to review, and drearier still to read: the performance of wheels within wheels (even when it is accurately observed and noted) is seldom as exhilarating as the end-product cavorting at stage level.
PINE MOUNTAIN, Ga., July 5 (Religious News Service) -- Among pine trees in the center of this mountain valley is one of America's most unusual churches despite its familiar name.

GENEVA, July 5 -- William L. Clayton, Under-Secretary of State, intends to leave Geneva late next week to be in Paris for the opening next Saturday of the conference on aid to Europe. Twenty-two nations have been invited to participate, it was learned tonight.
Favored with balmy weather, although the humidity was somewhat higher than on the Fourth, New Yorkers continued yesterday to enjoy their three-day holiday week-end, in most cases away from the city.

"LE DIABLE AU CORPS," one of the prize winners at the recent World Film Festival in Brussels, which was produced by Paul Graetz and financed by Universal, is being held by Treasury Department officials in Washington pending a final decision on its admissibility to this country, it was learned last week.

MADAME MARIA DSIERZANOWSKA, in her shabby black dress with the neat white bow at her throat, stood in the doorway of her home at Francuska 8-M-9, Warsaw, and looked inquiringly at the Polish jeep driver and the American relief worker. Her wise old eyes, apparently oblivious of the rubble-heaped street, turned in fascination to what her visitors carried -- two packages.

BEFORE a book of stories as delightful and wise as these a reviewer might conceivably falter -- seeing that well-worn enthusiasms will not do. One hesitates to say that Mrs. Weston has captured the spirit of India; the same has been said of journalistic works that have, at most, illumined a single aspect of that most complex (for the Western mind) of Eastern lands.

JERUSALEM, July 5 -- Four members of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine made the committee's longest and most cordial contact with Palestine Arabs when they informally visited the Arab College, Government teacher-training institution in Jerusalem, today.

LONDON, July 5 -- Half a dozen tennis stars from the United States, headed by Jack Kramer of Los Angeles, divided the honors among themselves today by sweeping four titles and sharing in the fifth as the curtain fell on the 1947 Wimbledon championships.

CRITICISMS of one sort or another leveled at the Experimental Theatre last season may be bearing salutary results. At least so it seemed when the departmental operative had a look at the plans for the coming campaign.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- Twenty disgrunted mule dealers held an indignation meeting at the Capitol this week to complain to their Senators about the bursting of the great Mexican mule bubble.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- John W. Bulkley, assistant deputy customs commissioner, said this week that gangs in Mexico were using airplanes to fly opium to the United States border area so that it could be smuggled into this country.

HONOLULU -- Hawaii is getting more visitors now with two major airlines offering service from the West Coast to supplement the ship schedules, which have not yet returned to peacetime normal. But even among the new crop of tourists the old fallacy continues -- that Hawaii is encompassed by its capital island of Oahu, with its cosmopolitan Honolulu and famous Waikiki Beach.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 5 -- Delinquency in Cincinnati is on the decline, Miss Lois E. Elliott, instructor in sociology at the University of Cincinnati, reported here today.
NEW ORLEANS, July 5 -- Diversification is becoming the rule rather than the exception in the agriculture of the Deep South.

NOW it is San Francisco that is sponsoring a new ballet company. At an "Evening of Ballet" on June 9, consisting of several numbers by members of William Christensen's San Francisco Ballet and speeches by Anton Dolin, guest speaker; George Washington Baker Jr., president of the San Francisco Civic Ballet Association, Inc.; and Irving Deakin, general manager of the latter organization, a three-year plan was officially outlined.

A 12-year-old boy skillfully maneuvering a stolen automobile through several miles of Bronx traffic was captured yesterday when a tire on the car burst and the vehicle mounted the curb and smashed into the heavy wire fence of Public School 119 at Pugsley and Watson Streets.

A lean, red-haired fellow came bustling in from Jamaica and, instead of launching a conversation piece about the horses as was his wont, surprisingly began sputtering about striped bass. He was pretty indignant over the subject, letting on that it was harder to take a striper than it was to boot home a long shot and twice as aggravating.

GILBERT and Sullivan have been praised ad nauseam. For a time their admirers constituted one of the most active religious sects of the age. When, therefore, our fathers rebelled against our grandfathers, Gilbert and Sullivan were among the many eminent Victorians to be torn limb from limb.

HAMILTON, N.Y., July 5 -- If compelled to choose between American and Russian ideology, Asia will probably choose communism as more compatible with its own ideals and goals, Ruth I. Seabury, educational secretary of the American Board of Foreign Missions, told the New York Institute of International Relations at Colgate University tonight.

NEW MILFORD, Conn., July 5 -- Dr. Otis William Caldwell, general secretary since 1933 of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, died tonight in his home here after a brief illness. His age was 77.

BILBAO, Spain, July 5 -- Voters in this Opposition stronghold got a blunt warning tonight that they would be permanently penalized if they did not vote in tomorrow's referendum on the Franco law of succession.

HAVANA -- Vacationists coming to Havana this summer will find added enjoyment in trips to many interior places of interest now easily accessible owing to continued expansion of air transportation. Flying down to Santiago de Cuba at the eastern end of the island is a pleasant four-hour trip which gives a panoramic view of the country.

JESSE BUEL, whose writings form the subject of the twelfth volume of the Columbia University Studies in the History of American Agriculture, was born in Connecticut in 1778. Like many others who contributed to the greatness of America, he was self-taught.

ON Tuesday the Professional Training Program of the American Theatre Wing will be able to put one candle on a its birthday cake. That candle will get there because the entertainment industry as a whole -- radio, theatre, dance, music, vaudeville and the screen -- organized through its wartime service organization, the American Theatre Wing, a plan to assist veterans who were returning to their particular crafts.

TCHAIKOVSKY fans are apparently numberless and insatiable. Recordings and re-recordings of his music have been absorbed by an apparently bottomless market. This week two companies have produced three of his major works and included him in a collection of shorter pieces, thus staging a small Tchaikovsky festival all of their own.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 5 -- Mrs. Marion Steedman Mason Wilson, widow of Richard T. Wilson, New York banker, who was long president of the Saratoga Racing Association, died at the Newport Hospital this afternoon.

ON or about July 18 two small private planes of the type seen most often putt-putting around some suburban airport will take off from New York and head northeast on a flight around the world. About forty-five days later, if everything goes well, the same two planes will put down in New York to end a 21,350-mile trip that will have taken them over both the Atlantic and the Pacific Oceans.
CHICAGO, July 5 -- As in 1944, the name of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur is again cropping into Central West political news as a potential Republican candidate for President.
Phalanx followed the script in the thirty-ninth running of the 550,000-added Empire City Stake at Jamaica yesterday.

Anticipating continued receptivity of their securities by the investment community, the growing number of operating utility companies that have been divorced from holding systems may have reached its crest. This was the opinion of several utility analysts in Wall Street last week as they reported that institutional investors are less inclined to increase their holdings of such securities.

The United States Government will pay $40,000,000 as compensation for ships taken over during the war from Scandinavian countries, Jesse E. Saugstad, chief of the shipping division of the Department of State, announced yesterday.

WELLESLEY -- Foreign Students Wellesley College will sponsor its Institute for Foreign Students for the second time this summer "to help newcomers make the adjustment to life in this country." The students, all of whom have been accepted by American colleges or universities, will have the opportunity to improve and strengthen their knowledge of the English language both through class work and through informal contact with faculty, student-assistants and persons from the surrounding communities.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 5 -- Three radio sound studios, a recording workshop, a master control room, a one-kilowatt amateur station and a fireproof vault for storing recordings are being built in the interim headquarters of the United Nations here, it was learned today.

BABYLON, L.I., July 5 -- For the second straight day Ed Ketcham of Bay Shore won the Star class sailboat race held at the Babylon Yacht Club today. Calm water and a brisk southwest wind made it a perfect sailing afternoon, as Ketcham piloted his Draco to victory over the twelve-mile course.

OMAHA, Neb., July 5 -- The most destructive floods in more than 100 years which have been rolling down the vast Mississippi and Missouri River valleys, have been caused almost wholly by extremely heavy rains.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 5 -- Former King Carol of Rumania has moved to legalize his twenty-three years' companionship with the gravely ill Mme. Magda Lupescu in a "death bed" ceremony. The ceremony was performed Thursday in Carol's suite at the Hotel Copacabana.

Fifty-two judges, headed by Dr. Samuel Milbank of New York, will pick the winners at the seventy-second Westminster Kennel Club show, according to the list made public yesterday by John W. Cross Jr., chairman of the show committee.

That tenuous thread by which the Dodgers were suspended in first place on July 4 was unceremoniously snapped by the Boston Braves at Ebbets Field yesterday. As a result Billy Southworth's athletes moved into the National League lead by the slight margin of two percentage points.

VENTNOR CITY, N.J., July 5 -- Drawing his last two games, in the eighth and ninth rounds, Anthony E. Santasiere, New York State champion, today finished first in the open tournament of the New Jersey State Chess Federation on the Municipal Pier.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 5 (Religious News Service) -- Two Disciples of Christ conventions attended by delegates representing two million members of the denomination will be held in Buffalo, N.Y., July 29 to August 7.

For the first time in many years the scene of the New Jersey State women's tennis championship changes. Starting tomorrow and continuing through Saturday the top women tennis stars will be playing on the courts of the Maplewood Country Club.

THOMAS STEARNS ELIOT is a friendly man, but he doesn't do much talking. If and when he does, it is usually a discourse, distinguished and amiable, about such a figure as Massinger or Milton. The other week, though, he talked, and uniquely for Mr. Eliot, about contemporary matters.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- House Democrats mapped organized resistance to the Republicans' new tax reduction bill today with the main emphasis on a contention that it would favor the rich.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- (AP) -- July corn futures soared more than 7 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade today to another all-time peak of $2.13. All other grains also advanced in heavy trading. Short covering lifted corn prices and other grains followed the upturn.

To meet the higher costs of operation, including wages, the nation's railroads on Thursday filed a petition with the Interstate Commerce Commission for an increase in freight rates averaging about 16 per cent for the country as a whole. On the basis of present traffic it is anticipated that such an increase would add more than $1,000,000,000 annually to the gross revenues of the carriers.

Scientists yesterday were at a loss for an explanation of the so-called "flying saucers" reported seen speeding through the sky by observers throughout the country, unless it was that those who first observed the strange phenomena beheld a prank of nature, now being perpetuated by the "popular imagination."
PITTSBURGH, July 5 -- As far as he was concerned, big Pres Stickle, the 225-pound president of the Stambaugh mine local, was ready to go back to work before his ten-day vacation was half over.

DENNIS, MASS. THE Cape Playhouse at Dennis has busied itself this week with celebration and song. The occasion has something to do with the theatre's coming of age, although the exactness of reasoning depends on the point of view.

AFTER its great tidal flow of men like Titian, Tintoretto and Veronese, Venetian art subsided into almost a century of mediocrity. Apparently the city beside the lagoons was spent and never could recover its former glories.
PARIS, July 5 -- France will publish in the form of a Yellow Book all documents relating to the disastrous three-power conversations on the Marshall project.

FOR a while it looked as though industry was in for a bad skid as it rounded the year's halfway mark. But the threat of a general coal strike, with steel, automobile and other curtailment, now seems to be removed.

A mysterious will, whimsically popping up at two places at once, has started a new wave of claims to a multi-million-dollar share of New York City real estate which has been disputed in the courts for 200 years, The Associated Press reported.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- A countrywide survey conducted by the rural editorial service of the University of Chicago, while revealing a general pattern for a school system with high teacher morale, declares that factors other than adequate salaries are important requirements for general contentment among instructors, the university announced today.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 5 -- New York Guard officers at Camp Smith have completed plans for greeting a large number of visitors from New York and Brooklyn tomorrow. The first units from the metropolitan area entered camp Wednesday for a twelve-day tour of duty, the 12th Infantry coming from Manhattan and the 13th from Brooklyn.

LONDON, July 5 -- An immediate intensification and speeding up of the struggle between rival ideologies cannot fail to be the result of the breakdown of the Paris talks of the Foreign Ministers of Britain, France and the U.S.S.R. The nations of Europe must choose now between the traditional democracy of western Europe and the hammer-and-sickle brand of Moscow.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 5 (U.P.) -- Joe Baksi, husky Kulpmont, Pa., heavyweight contender, was expected to enter the ring a 1-to-5 favorite over Olle Tandberg of Sweden tomorrow in an international bout. The winner will get a shot at Champion Joe Louis in September.

Dr. A.A. Brill, prominent American psychoanalyst, replied yesterday to the recent denunciation of psychoanalysis by Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen, declaring the statements attributed to him were "false views" and "foolishly untrue."

THE antiquity of man is an intriguing subject which makes armchair archaeologists of many of us. The discovery of remains of prehistoric man is always news. Particularly has the forgotten past of the American Indians possessed an interest for later Americans.

CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows. Figures of receipts were unavailable because of extended holiday in the yards.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: At long last it appears likely that Congress will act in the matter of raising the Federal minimum wage from the pitifully inadequate level of 40 cents per hour. Although welcome no matter what its motivation, the last-minute decision to add this to the category of "must" legislation is obviously intended to sweeten somewhat the bad taste resulting from the Taft-Hartley battle.

IT was a version of the old radio game, "Beat the Band." The visiting actress from New York explained the rules and gradually the contest got under way. A young war veteran called out, "Slow dice," and the band, after a slight pause, began to play the popular song, "Lazy Bones."

BUCHAREST, July 5 -- Rumania's top food authority predicted confidently today that next month would see the end of the country's grave food situation, which has amounted to famine conditions in Moldavia. Unofficial estimates place the number of dead from starvation at 20,000 to 40,000 despite the foreign aid.

The unpegging of the fixed three-eighths of 1 per cent interest cost to the Treasury on its ninety-day bill borrowings is not likely to lead right away to the marking up of the seven-eighths of 1 per cent rate for the Treasury's one-year certificates of indebtedness, in the opinion of market observers.

FOR THIS WEEK: Weeds have grown so well that every method of attack is needed now. Spray those in stone driveways or flag paths, hand-pull in crowded flower borders, use hoe or wheelhoe between rows of plants, and clip off those that have shot up through a thick groundcover.... Cut back daisies, even field ones that have strayed into the garden, to prevent their seeding....

SALT LAKE CITY, July 5 (U.P.) -- After dropping the first set, champion Frank Parker of Los Angeles regained his form to down Seymour Greenberg, also of Los Angeles, 4 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1, in the national clay courts tennis championships today.

A renewal of interest in small building plots and a growing demand for realty with investment possibilities was noticeable in the first six months of the 1947 market, in the opinion of Bernard P. Day, president of Joseph P. Day, Inc., who also notes a falling off in the purchase of business buildings by concerns for their occupancy.

TOKYO, July 5 -- Less than twenty-four hours after its issuance, the Socialist Government's White Paper, proposing recovery measures, has become probably the most controversial document issued since Japan's surrender.

Rogers, president of the Producers Council, national organization of manufacturers of building materials.

One fact in the European situation is clearly evident this morning. This is that if Russia chooses to hold aloof from any workable plan for continental recovery the choice is hers alone. She has been offered every inducement as come in, except such inducements as would have broken the plan down and made it unworkable.

The Gotham Hosiery Company has leased for a period exceeding ten years three Homestead mills located in the South which were purchased by the Hess-Taylor-Kreiss interests from the Government in 1945, it was announced yesterday by Roy E. Tilles, president of Gotham.

THE Metropolitan Opera Association had to delay its final planning and the public announcement of its opening date last year until well in the fall because of difficulties in negotiations with the three major unions.
The nation's tangled housing problem entered a new and turbulent phase last week when modified Federal rent regulations went into effect.

LONDON, July 5 -- Anthony Eden, deputy leader of the Opposition in Britain, threw the support of the Conservatives today solidly behind Foreign Secretary Bevin's efforts to organize effective European response to the Marshall proposals.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The Republican - controlled Eightieth Congress is now tired, moody and very busy in a grim, determined sort of way. The distress etched into many of the faces on Capitol Hill is attributed by some, particularly the members themselves, to the setting in of Washington's celebrated summer heat.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- A final tally on the sea war waged against Japan, issued tonight by a joint Army-Navy assessment committee, showed that United States forces accounted for 9,736,068 of the 10,583,755 tons of naval and merchant shipping sent down by attacks of the Allies.

PONTIAC, Mich., July 5 (AP) -- The body of 19-year-old Richard Schweitzer, Detroit factory worker whose disappearance two months ago was followed by a "ransom plot" against his widowed mother, was found in a swamp today.

GLORIOSA lilies are much easier to grow than other types of lilies and yet they are rarely seen in our gardens. Both G. rothschildiana and G. superba have gorgeous crimson and gold blossoms produced on a vine arising from a large sweet potato-like tuber.

EXCEPT in Plato and, perhaps, again in Chesterton, God seems to have sundered forever the philosopher and the creator. Mr. Kenner, writing as a philosopher, well understands the philosophic side of a creator, but, in the process of vindicating Chesterton's claim to be considered an original and profound thinker, he angrily, even contemptuously, dismisses the creative side of a philosopher, as "spurious Toby-jug heartiness."

BOSTON, July 5 -- Attorney General Clarence Barnes of Massachusetts is prepared to rule that the Hartley-Taft Labor Law does not prevent labor unions from making political contributions for State and local purposes. Published reports on this point were confirmed by the Attorney General's office.

IT is a time-honored custom among real estate men to expatiate on the future possibilities of the attic in any house that has an attic. "Just look," they love to tell prospects, "you can have two more bedrooms up here whenever you need them."

WE have been hearing a good deal about the admirable work accomplished by the Monuments, Fine Arts and Archives Branch of the United States Army. Last week, at the Metropolitan Museum, a practical demonstration was furnished by a group of nearly fifty Dutch paintings, chiefly seventeenth century, sent on a touring visit by the grateful Netherlands Government.

THE problem of light glare and unwanted reflections bothers the photographer more during summer than at any other season because he makes most of his summer pictures outdoors, where he has no control of the light source and the light is strong and full of hazards.

Unwilling to dig into surplus to finance expanding post-war business, conservative, old-line fire and casualty insurance companies are turning to Wall Street in what may become their biggest bid for new-money financing from the public since the Twenties.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 5 -- The Hungarian Government will decide whether to accept the Anglo-French invitation to the Paris conference after Premier Lajos Dinnye's return to Budapest Tuesday, according to Foreign Minister Erno Mihalyfi.

THE Long Island Horticultural Society will hold a meeting at the Long Island Agricultural and Technical Institute, Farmingdale, on Friday at 3 o'clock. E.L.D. Seymour will speak on "When the East Views the West," surveying garden conditions and practices in California and the Northwest.

To the Art Editor: IN your very interesting reviews of the exhibition of American sculpture now being held at the Metropolitan it is not surprising to find the criticism of lighting and installation. You state that you have never seen a show "flung together with less taste and imagination."

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- While Southern operators reported getting "a complete brush-off" from John L. Lewis, head of the United Mine Workers, a union spokesman ascribed the one-day delay in the signing of the softcoal contract to the fact that the lawyers "simply haven't got the language of the agreement worked out yet."

PITTSBURGH, July 5 (AP) -- Bill Nicholson's long double in the sixth that scored two runs enabled the Chicago Cub, to trip the last-place Pittsburgh Pirates, 4 to 3, today in the opener of a three-game series.

WHEN fruit trees bloom in spring, the apricot is hardly missed around New York, so abundant are peach and pear, cherry and apple blossoms. The dearth of apricot trees is more likely to be noticed later in summer when fruit begins to ripen.

OXFORD, Ohio, July 5 -- In a historical document unprecedented in American education, the teachers of this country laid down their own "Bill of Rights" today and listed the grievances that have brought about a mass exodus from the teaching profession since Pearl Harbor.

COLLECTORS await an announcement by the Postoffice Department regarding a stamp which President Truman has directed be issued, commemorating the sesquicentennial of the launching of "Old Ironsides," otherwise the U.S.S. Constitution, which maritime authorities have called "one of the most famous ships in the annals of the American Navy."

John Green, national president of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, called yesterday upon President Truman to bring an end to the present shipyard strike by invoking his powers under the Taft-Hartley Act.
HEIDELBERG, Germany, July 5 -- One of the few bright spots in the German political scene is the Heidelberg. Action Group, a political discussion forum organized by a group of liberal professors.

LONDON, July 5 -- In spite of the continued austerity and the prospect of a bleak winter ahead, there is a gallant and gala quality about this London summer. Not much new building is going on but old houses are being painted and refurnished.

CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- Larry Doby, first Negro player in the forty-seven-year history of the American League, made his debut in a Cleveland Indian uniform today by striking out as a pinch-hitter against the White Sox. The Chicagoans won, 6 -- 5, Ed Smith gaining the victory, though being relieved after six innings.

THE U.S. Navy is enlisting television in its recruiting drive. Beginning at 7:30 P.M. on Wednesday, the fifteen-minute comedy sketch, "Bill's Best Bet," now being broadcast by standard radio stations, will make its debut as a television feature on WABD, the Dumont station.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 5 -- North-western University's Dyche Stadium will be the scene of the final track and field tryouts for the Olympic team July 9-10, 1948, it was announced today by Kenneth L. (Tug) Wilson, chairman of the United States Olympic Track and Field Committee.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., July 5 (AP) -- After running last in the backstretch in a field of seven, Mrs. R.L. Gerry's Young Peter, a 3-year-old bay son of Peanuts, closed with a terrific rush to defeat the Market Stable's Royal Lover by two and a half lengths in the $25,000 Providence Stakes today before a 22,000 crowd at Narragansett Park.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The United States Atomic Energy Commission, it was learned today, has decided to established a Division of Medical Research to intensify its operations in the beneficial use of atomic energy.

The Holland-America Line announced yesterday that its passenger and cargo fleet, which was reduced 60 per cent through war losses, has been built up by purchases and new construction to twenty-four vessels, two less than the pre-war fleet total.

GARDENERS who are ever on the lookout for a good blue flower will welcome a member of the mint family, Nepeta mussini. This catmint, which is now in full bloom, has small lavender flowers filling the upper third of the twelve-inch stems, in fine contrast to the tiny gray-green leaves.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- Representative William M. Colmer, Democrat, of Mississippi, a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said today that the shipping industry and the maritime unions were being aided financially by appropriations for foreign relief.

In "As You Sow" Walter Goldschmidt makes a really valuable contribution to an understanding of the agricultural revolution of our times.

Three Swedish youths arrived at La Guardia Field on Tuesday as stowaways aboard a Scandinavian Airlines plane from Stockholm, it became known yesterday. They are believed to be the first stowaways to cross the Atlantic by air.

TOP drawer among movie doubles, those hard-working anonymities who rarely if ever see their own faces on the screen, are Dorothy Whalen and Cliff Rathjen. As stand-ins for Jennifer Jones and Joseph Cotten, they have shared fragments of every role the stars have portrayed in the last four years.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 6 -- The first Long Island potato and vegetable harvest festival, which was held at the old Suffolk County fair grounds here this afternoon, was attended by about 5,000 persons. It was sponsored by the Long Island Farmers' Institute, composed of 1,000 farmers of Nassau and Suffolk counties.

PARIS -- To the average French driver an automobile consists of a horn supported by four wheels. Gasoline is available again, but not enough to squander. The result is that taxi drivers and other motorists seldom bother to slow down at intersections or the many traffic circles -- gear-shifting wastes essence -- all of which makes crossing the street an adventurous sport.

A DEAR little Boston lady once told me that she just loved Maine. "We have pawsed forty-two years at Baw Hawbor," she said. There are witnesses to confirm my reply, namely, "That ought to be enough." The little Boston lady felt the conversation was adequate for the moment, and we parted.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 5 (AP) -- A civil liberties specialist condemned two means he said were used in the South to disfranchise the Negro in an address before the Institute of Race Relations at Fisk University today.
CARACAS, Venezuela, July 5 -- The new Venezuelan Constitution was signed and promulgated today -- Venezuela's Independence Day -- in a solemn session of the National Constituent Assembly.

Henry A. Wallace, former Secretary of Commerce and recent critic of the Truman administration, has refused an invitation to debate the country's foreign policy with Norman Thomas, Socialist leader. Mr. Wallace's letter declining the debate and Mr. Thomas' reply that Mr. Wallace had evaded the questions in the letter of invitation were made public by The Call, a newspaper, and the Post War Council, 112 East Nineteenth Street.

Over Aid For Europe In the dawn half-light of Paris Russian Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov last Thursday left the Russian Embassy and went to Le Bourget Airport. There he boarded a transport plane for Moscow. His departure wrote a portentous "Finis" to the effort of the three principal countries of Europe -- Russia, Great Britain and France -- to arrive at a common plan for the rehabilitation of the warscarred continent.

LONDON, July 5 (Reuters) -- County cricket enthusiasts saw bright cricket today all over the country. At Lords, where Oxford University and Cambridge University met in their annual match. Oxford's New Zealand test player Martin Donnelly scored 81 runs.

USE of Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) as a photographic developer similar in characteristics to hydroquinone is described by Dr. Leo A. Flexser of Hoffman-La Roche, Inc., Nutley, N.J. A rapid developer, producing a black image with a tendency to fog, Vitamin C is highly sensitive to the restraining action of potassium bromide, which reduces fog, slows development to two to ten times normal time and changes the color of the image from black to brown.

Tenant groups widened yesterday their campaign for improved legislative controls over runaway rents, with some supporting a call by Assemblyman Louis Peck, a Democrat of the Bronx, for a special session of the State Legislature to deal with the situation created by the new Federal rent control law.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 -- By way of demonstrating that they have not lost any of their extraordinary resilience, the Giants came bouncing back Into the thick of the National League's dizzy flag race tonight by snuffing out Ben Chapman's Phillies, 4 to 0, to the keen disappointment of 26,379 sweltering onlookers.

Southeast Asia's hope for a peaceful settlement of the Dutch East Indies problem still teetered in the balance last week. The Netherlands Indies Colonial Government and the Republic of Indonesia -- which has been recognized by the Dutch as the de facto authority over the three most populous islands -- continued a war of nerves over differing interpretations of the agreement they initialed at Linggadjati, Java, last November and formally signed on March 25.

The race for tomorrow's air supremacy is now being waged in the laboratories and on the proving grounds of the world's great powers, for piloted jet-powered aircraft and crewless guided missiles will be some of the principal weapons of the future.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 5 -- John B Kelly Jr. of Philadelphia ended his father's 26-year wait for a family victory in the Diamond Sculls of the Royal Henley Regatta today with an eight-length triumph that brought boos from British spectators.

ALBANY, July 5 (AP) -- The net bonded debt of New York's sixty-one up-state cities totaled $203,782,898 on Jan. 1, a decrease of $14,252,396 from Jan. 1, 1946, the State Conference of Mayors reported today.
LONDON, July 5 -- The shortage of newsprint is "the real danger to freedom of the press" in Britain, Leslie Hore-Belisha, former British Cabinet Minister, declared today in a speech in Gloucester.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., July 5 (NANA) -- Baby white rats, brought into a germ-free world by Caesarian, section, are given twenty- four - hour attention in the Notre Dame Laboratories here in an unending fight against diseases of man ranging from cancer to tooth decay.

PARIS, July 5 -- The French Government has assured the "United States that, with certain exceptions, displaced persons recruited in the American zone of Germany for work in France would never be forced to go to a country against their will.
BUENOS AIRES, July 5 (U.P.) -- President Juan Peron tonight disclaimed any intention of increasing Argentina's armed forces or of engaging in any armament race with neighboring countries.

"I wake up nights dreaming about you," he remarked. McQuinn grinned at him because he understood perfectly the significance of the statement.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 5 -- A javelin thrower stole the show in the sixtieth annual National A.A.U. track and field championships today before a banner crowd of 18,000 at the University of Nebraska Memorial Stadium.

CONSIDERABLE travail attends the activities of the production organization now feverishly working to get Ingrid Bergman before the Technical cameras in "Joan of Lorraine" by July 14, according to Victor Fleming, who will direct for Sierra Pictures, the independent unit formed by Miss Bergman, Walter Wanger and himself.

MIDWAY in his mocking first novel, T.E. Doremus changes his mind, and readers will probably like him all the better for it. His slow-ebbing disdain for his principal character (whom he cannot quite bring himself to impale) may lend a certain unevenness, but once compassion creeps in, vitality follows after, and "Flaw Dexter" becomes something better than a rather bloodless and precious satire on the literary world.

BY early July, a regular spray program should be under way in both the flower and vegetable garden. This is to control the pests and diseases that can be most destructive. Spraying at two-week intervals is advisable so that serious infestations can be prevented rather than merely cured.

RYE, N.Y., July 5 -- Two former national women sailing champions returned to competition today. They were Mrs. Lorna Whittelsey Hibberd and Mrs. Sylvia Shethar Everdell. Both are from the American Yacht Club here and they crowed in its regatta, the second over-the-holiday event of the Yacht Racing Association.

After being robbed of $60 by two gunmen about 5 P.M. yesterday, Thomas Lewis, 43 years old, proprietor of a stove repair shop at 1,202 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, chased them out of his store and pursued them a half block, catching up with one thug.

Well to Left of Center When Cicero wrote to his friend Atticus, "Utor via," he was saying literally, "I use the highway," but what he meant was: "As for me, I am playing safe by keeping in the middle of the road."

THE Right Hon. Anthony Eden is a shade too well-bred to assert in so many words that this equally well-bred society novel, written many years ago by one of the numerous clan of Victorian Edens to whom he is collaterally related, can actually displace the works of Jane Austen in the public eye.

BOSTON, July 5 (AP) -- The Red Sox hammered Sid Hudson for six runs during the first two innings but it took Ted Williams' sixth-inning three-bagger into right and Jake Jones' single to give the American League champions a 7-6 victory over the Washington Senators today.
Two of the most widely-known national Protestant Episcopal periodicals will merge with their next issues, it became known yesterday.

Trading in the security markets was on a restricted basis last week because of the July 4 holiday. Prices, however, reached their highs since early March as the outlook for industrial peace became brighter following termination of the soft-coal dispute.

MONTEREY, Calif., July 5 (Science Service) -- The first "Sofar" receiving station in the new Navy long-range, underwater sound system for locating air and ship survivors at sea, is ready for operation here. This station recently heard and recorded the sound of a bomb exploding under water 2,300 miles away, it was revealed today.

Regatta officials and lesser badge-wearers of the South Shore Y.C. at Freeport, who are getting more gray hairs planning the Gold Cup fixture for Jamaica Bay on Aug. 10, are beginning seriously to talk of perhaps as many as twenty contestants for the famous trophy to be defended by Guy Lombardo in his Tempo V. IN "Off Broadway" Maxwell Anderson presents ten brief essays -- articles, after-dinner speeches, lectures, and introductions to published plays -- dealing with the ethical and practical problems of the modern playwright. These, as even the ordinary playgoer now realizes, are many.

New York University's School of Education in cooperation with the Chautauqua Institute will open tomorrow its annual summer school program at Chautauqua, N.Y., it was announced yesterday by Ernest O. Melby, Dean of the School of Education.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 5 -- Congress of Industrial Organizations maritime workers at small yards in Westchester and Fairfield counties have adopted a policy of continuing negotiations for contracts based on the national pattern of a 13-cents-an-hour increase and six paid holidays.

BALTIMORE, July 5 (AP) -- Edison Hedges, Atlantic City, N.J., bettered a world record for Class B racing runabouts today, averaging 51.429 miles per hour in two one-mile trial heats at the Wilson Point Men's Club powerboat regatta.

The name hawkweed has little meaning unless one knows the old legend, which says that hawks drank the plant's juice to make their eyesight keener. Botanically it is Hieracium, one of the composites, and it is a European native brought over here as a garden flower.

Financial institutions have been flooded with inquiries during the past week asking whether or not investors in Great Britain are to be allowed to regain their "frozen assets" after July 15, under the latest sterling plan. According to observers who have studied the program, Great Britain is striving to pay her neighbors some of the $12,000,000,000 in sterling balances acquired by them during the war years.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am indeed gratified at the attention the people of Guam are now receiving, even though a considerable part of that attention seems based upon the idea of forcing upon them the government various proponents deem best, rather than what is historically appropriate and is suited to their needs.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The fact that the United States has drawn to itself the greater part of the gold in the world is a matter of common knowledge. It has banished gold from its internal economy. Its banks and its currency are now based on reserves that take the form of bonds -- generally government bonds -- instead of gold.

IF Noel Coward had not taken a jaunt through India nearly two decades ago Charles Dickens' "Great Expectations," which recently concluded a good run at Radio City Music Hall, might not have been the artistic success it was.

JOGJAKARTA, Java, July 5 (AP) -- An Indonesian Republican delegation left by special train tonight for Batavia with a note from the new Republican Cabinet which Premier Amir Sjariffoeddin said he was "confident would prove acceptable to the Netherlands and dissipate fears of war."

CHICAGO, July 5 -- The opening this week of the thirteenth season of Chicago's famous Grant Park concerts, which have brought the finest of classical and semi-classical music to Chicago in free open-air concerts, has served to emphasize in the public mind two contrasting facts.

Franklin Simon, Fifth Avenue specialty shop has completed negotiations with the Life Insurance Company of Georgia for the leasing of a new Franklin Simon branch store to be erected at the southwest corner of Peachtree Street and Ponce de Leon Avenue, in Atlanta, Ga., it was announced yesterday by J. Howard Denny, president of the store.

A COMPLETE revision of the section on Dufaycolor film, based on recent improvements, is included in the quarterly supplement, No. 32 of the Photo-Lab-Index, published by Morgan Lester. Dufaycolor, once available in the United States and now produced in England, where it has wide popularity, is still being used by a number of American photographers who import the film for personal use owing to certain advantages it offers in special color work.

Strewn out on many a living room floor this week will be great sheets of stiff paper. They will be nautical charts. Books and pamphlets being thumbed through will be tide and current tables, Coast Pilots and other references. Pencils, dividers, pelorus, even slide rules, will be tools of the sport.

A FEW months ago Mr. C. Vann Woodward brought out a remarkable book on the battle for Leyte Gulf, in which careful research, straight thinking and a highly literate style were happily blended to produce something like a definitive work.

FROZEN VEGETABLES -- Vegetables must be heated in hot water or flowing steam before they are frozen to retain color and prevent deterioration of flavor. The process leaches out vitamin C and some of the vitamins in the B complex, and it may damage the texture.

Psychiatric services in Brooklyn are undermanned to the point where it is impossible to obtain prompt treatment for a child in any one of the borough's thirteen clinics, according to a survey made public yesterday by the Mental Hygiene Committee of the Brooklyn Council for Social Planning.

CONFRONTED by the shortage of parking space, which has become one of the nation's outstanding traffic problems, automotive engineers are turning their attention to shorter wheelbases and increased operating economy in designs for the cars of the future.

ATHENS, July 5 -- The essential difference between the British economic mission that has bean here since January, 1946, and the new United States mission headed by Dwight P. Griswold, which is about to replace it, is that the British mission could advise but not enforce; the United States mission will be able to advise and enforce.

Formation of a Keep PR Committee, with Samuel Seabury as honorary chairman and Richard S. Childs as acting chairman, was announced yesterday. An audience of 13,500 assembled at Lewisohn Stadium last night for a program which considerably lowered the standard of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony's summer season. It was the third annual "Viennese Night."

PARIS, July 5 -- The French Government won a move in its latest effort to conciliate Morocco when it announced today the signature by the Sultan of Morocco of a series of decrees creating a new form for Morocco's Government.

The international masters chess tournament, arranged to mark the official opening of the Club de Ajedrez Capablanca in Havana, has been concluded, according to a report from Cuba yesterday. A Cuban competitor, Gilberto Garcia of Santiago, was the victor with a score of 5 1/2 -- 1 1/2.

Retail trade during the second half of this year appears likely to level off on a plateau about even with a year ago, with the possibility that gains may extend to 5 per cent above the corresponding period of 1946, according to estimates in retail circles here.

Commercial bankers, eager to offset increased operating costs with new means of revenue, are showing marked interest in the promising insurance pro-payment plan recently undertaken here. Under the plan, which the Chase National Bank started six months ago, customers are enabled, to prepay their life insurance on an annual basis through monthly payments figured at the quarterly premium rate.

8-Cent Ride? A successful New York Mayor, a political adage holds, "should be shrewd, honest, able to say 'hello' in eight languages, and should stand pat on the 5-cent fare." For thirty years, the nickel subway fare has been a political "hot potato."

UNDER the "Labor-Management Relations Act, 1947" the Government has assumed greater responsibilities for regulating and directing industrial relations than ever before. One fact, however, about the new act stands out above all others. It does not insure industrial peace.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 5 -- President Truman spent a day of complete relaxation today following his busy, though pleasant, program of yesterday. He now plans to drive back to Washington in time for luncheon on Sunday.

CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- Times have changed in baseball when the bunt-minded National League, now populated by home run-happy citizens, banks on power from the booming bats of New York's Johnny Mize and Walker Cooper to put the slug on the American League pitchers in the fourteenth all-star game Tuesday at Wrigley Field.

Store-wide activity last week was good, with buying for the week-end holiday at a peak in sportswear and beachwear departments, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

A record volume of motor traffic will pour into New York today through all main approaches to the city, the Automobile Club of New York predicted yesterday upon the basis of outbound travel for the week-end holiday. The influx is expected to exceed 400,000 cars, as an estimated 600,000 departed in the few days prior to and on the Fourth of July.

The reported settlement last week of labor issues in the soft-coal industry without a strike is regarded in responsible quarters as showing what can be done in the way of industrial peace through labor-management cooperation under democratic free enterprise.

The reported settlement last week of labor issues in the soft-coal industry without a strike is regarded in responsible quarters as showing what can be done in the way of industrial peace through labor-management cooperation under democratic free enterprise.

ST. LOUIS, July 5 -- Army engineers continued today their battle to hold critical levees seventy-five to 100 miles south of St. Louis on both the Illinois and Missouri sides of the Mississippi River as the general flood situation appeared to be improving.

LA PORTE, Ind., July 5 -- What remains of Kingsford Heights, a $13,000,000 town built by the Federal Government during the war ten miles south of La Porte, is about to be sold by the Federal Public Housing Authority for $359,000 if a group of residents of the project can complete plans for financing the purchase.

STANTON, Del., July 5 -- Stymie turned on his vaunted speed in the home stretch today and stepped to the front as the world's leading money-winning thoroughbred by capturing the mile and one-quarter Sussex Handicap in track record time.

WORCESTER. THERE has been a lot of talk -- and little action -- in the industry about what radio can do about the juvenile delinquency problem. In Worcester, Mass., station WTAG has spent the better part of a year doing something about it, and the results seem to have paid off.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 5 -- The women's Eastern intercollegiate tennis championship remains with the University of Miami, but a new player wears the crown.
PARIS, July 5 -- Underlying the turbulent political, economic and social conflicts in France are two fundamental and as yet unsettled controversies.

THESE figures were modeled by boys and girls aged 5 to 15 in Erna Weill's studio classes in Kew Gardens, L.I. The children are now working in Mrs. Weill's garden. She assures us that home backyards could be the scene, simple equipment the means and parent encouragement the impetus of much creative play with clay out of doors this summer.

Elsewhere on this page we publish a letter from Sir Richard Tute on the nation's gold "hoard" at Fort Knox. Sir Richard's thesis is that this gold, at present "sterile," could and should be put to use to re-energize the world economy. In one form or another the basic idea behind Sir Richard's thesis has a way of being put forward every so often.

Retail business last week was still holding its own while the price structure remained relatively firm, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc. Buyers are expected to return to the wholesale markets after the holidays.

SEOUL, Korea, July 5 -- The United States and Soviet delegations to the Joint Commission are deadlocked on the question of consultation with Korean political organizations, it was revealed today by Maj. Gen. Albert E. Brown, chief of the American delegation.

THE CBS Documentary Unit's presentation last Monday night (9 P.M.) of "The Sunny Side of the Atom" scored an eloquent appeal for broader popular understanding of an obviously vital issue. It projected the urgency for reinvigorated interest by the individual in the significance of nuclear fission; it underscored the necessity for governments to solve their disagreements over international safeguards for atomic power by peaceful and early compact.

BERLIN, July 5 -- Seven wartime German leaders who were convicted in Nuremberg but spared execution will be transported from Nuremberg and delivered to the grim Spandau prison here within ten days, a reliable report said today.

DICTATORSHIP and Depression were probably the most frequently mentioned evils in the Review of fourteen years ago this week. Ireland's De Valera -- described by P.W. Wilson, in a review, as "a political porcupine, bristling all over with points of controversy" -- occupied the front page as the subject of a critical biography which viewed his program with "ironical skepticism."

Sixteen State-supported colleges and universities in Texas have joined forces in a $60,000,000 building program to be financed largely from taxes at present authorized for support of Confederate pensions.

SEVEN new group exhibitions opened last week providing decidedly varied fare for the summer gallery-goer. Paintings and sculpture by artists associated with the organization and who won prizes during the season opened at the Grand Central (Vanderbilt Avenue) Galleries, with members of the recently formed "modern" group characteristically and for the most part well represented.

CINCINNATI, July 5 (AP) -- Archbishop John T. McNicholas today proposed a joint committee of the National Education Association and the National Catholic Educational Association to "decrease the deplorable tension between Catholic and public schools."

DO you ever doubt that science is wonderful? If so, here is a book to renew one's belief. T. Swann Harding, a veteran of more than thirty years in the United States Department of Agriculture, has written a fascinating account for the layman of scientific developments in the department in his book, "Two Blades of Grass."

LONDON (By Wireless). IT is now more than two years since the end of the war and the great problem of the world remains now as then -- Germany. The menace of Germany is not as loud or as obvious as it was during the war; but it is just as urgent. Germany diseased is just as dangerous as Germany mad.

The Maritime Commission has awarded contracts for the reconversion of four "Exporter" type cargo carriers to the Bethlehem Steel Company, but is withholding formal announcement pending the settlement of the shipyard strike, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- President Truman proudly called attention today to the record-breaking shipments of food by the United States during the last twelve months, but added that millions of "still desperately hungry" person still needed substantial aid from this country.

PORTLAND, Ore. AT our house we eat the good old-fashioned way. We put everything on the table and sit down and pitch in. It's all there from soup to nuts, except that we don't ever eat nuts at dinner. But we bring on the soup in a big tureen we bought at a rummage sale, and we've also got the main course and the dessert squatting right there, too.

Dr. Lyman Spitzer Jr., Associate Professor of Astrophysics at Yale University, predicts that since we have in uranium a rich source of energy, it may well become possible to voyage in interplanetary space within our lifetime. He even thinks a little moon carrying a telescope for astronomical observations could be made to circle around the earth after suitable interplanetary rockets have been actually developed.

VACATIONISTS who go near the water this summer, and particularly those who go down to the sea in boats, will rind themselves benefited by a modernized peacetime Coast Guard. Services rendered may be prosaically commonplace (such as advice on where the fish are running) or daringly spectacular (an offshore air-sea rescue), but they will be performed with efficiency and dispatch -- and all on a very small budget.

IF "Americans One and All" does nothing else, it at least demonstrates that inside U.S.A. is a United States of Europe and of both Americas. This better than-average anthology of recent American short stories by well-known writers concerns people whose backgrounds are "foreign."

LAKE CHAUTAUQUA -- On the shores of the westernmost of New York's lakes, the Chautauqua Institution, one of the seedbeds of American culture and education, opened its seventy-fourth consecutive season last week.

NANKING, July 5 -- New military strategy against the Communists will be adopted as part of the Government's new all-out anti-Communist suppression program, a high Government leader said today, The offcial said that the former concept of driving through Communist areas and occupying points and lines would be dropped in favor of a slower program of combing Communists out of selected territories as Government armies advance on a broad front.

ISTANBUL, July 5 -- It is beginning to be recognized here that Turkey cannot continue both to maintain a large army and try to become economically self-sufficient unless she is prepared to face higher production costs, a further lowering of living standards and more unrest among the working class.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- Although shooting his poorest golf of the meet, a one-under-par 71, Ed (Porky) Oliver, Wilmington, Del., held a three-stroke lead over South African Bobby Locke today in their international golf showdown for the Tam O'Shanter tournament's $7,000 first prize.

BASEBALL The Dodgers yielded first place to the Braves by two percentage points when they lost, 4 -- 1, to Boston. Bill Voiselle limited the Brooks to six safeties. Johnny Mize walloped two homers as the Giants blanked the Phils, 4 -- 0.

The eugenists have been shouting for decades that what used to be called the "lower classes," which meant the poor, uneducated and feeble-minded, are reproducing more rapidly than the intellectual "upper classes," out of which come our leaders in all walks of life, and that if we do not correct what is already an imbalance, society will go to the dogs.

ST. LOUIS, July 5 -- Barak T. Mattingly, Republican National Committeeman for Missouri, predicted tonight that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York would be nominated for President on the first ballot at next year's Republican national convention.

Josef Cardinal Mindszenty, Priamte of Hungary and Archbishop of Esztergom, and the Archbishop James Duhig of Brisbane, Australia, attended 10 o'clock high mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. Cardinal Spellman presided.

Reporting progress yesterday in its eight-month survey of possible economies in five major city departments, the Citizens Budget Commission made known that its recommendations would be completed in December.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The appointment of military men to civilian positions of authority after the war has aroused a considerable amount of comment, favorable and otherwise. It was felt, apparently, that "the military mind" might be disadvantageous or even dangerous to the satisfactory pursuit of our civilian life.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The War Department's attempt to complete the Inter-American Highway as a war project added $36,000,000 to the cost of the war "without contributing to the defense of the United States," the Senate Special War Investigating Committee reported today.

CHESTER, Ill., July 6 (UP) -- The flooded Mississippi fell slowly between St. Louis and Cape Girardeau, Mo., today and Army engineers said the outlook all along the stream was much brighter, although stages generally were still far above flood level.

Production of FM radios will be increased appreciably from now on, Arthur Freed, treasurer of the FM Association, predicted last week Mr. Freed stated that the recent announcement by the association, that by the end of 1947 there will be well over 700 FM stations servicing 80 per cent of the population, has decided radio makers to switch more output to FM and has caused many newcomers to try the field.

Forty-six per cent of our population is carrying the load for itself and the remaining 54 per cent, the Rev. Dr. Nathan H. Gist said yesterday in a sermon preached in the First Presbyterian Church of Staten Island, Stapleton.

BILBAO, Spain, July 6 -- The Spanish national radio network said tonight, without giving the actual figures, that today's vote in Spain's referendum on the succession law was averaging 90 per cent of the registered voters. It certainly did not approach that in Bilbao.

Millions of dollars in death benefits may be paid by insurance companies to the heirs of deceased members of the armed forces, even though the policies contained war clauses that absolved the companies from such payments in death that occurred as the result of war.

The Radio Officers Union, AFL, announced yesterday that agreements had been signed with a majority of its forty-five contract steamship lines calling for "broad increases" for all of its radio men. The new scale ranges from $292 to $375 a month, depending on the classification of the vessels, according to Fred M. Howe, general secretary-treasurer of the union.

A bill to complete the transfer of the Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation from the Department of Commerce to the Coast Guard is scheduled to come before the House of Representatives today on its consent calendar.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The National Labor Relations Board's report for May revealed today that, as Congress worked out details of the Taft-Hartley labor bill, cases brought before the board were actually 25 per cent fewer than a year ago.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Once each year hundreds of eager young ears listen excitedly and breathlessly for that thrilling call --"All Aboard for Camp." Living in" stifling tenements in overcrowded East Harlem, American boys and girls of different races, creed and color muddle through the sultry summer days, playing on tenement streets.

LOS ANGELES, July 6 -- Despite a slow start in its project of shifting procurement of $50,000,000 worth of parts annually from the East to the West Coast to save freight charges and effect other economies, Ford Motor Company officials tonight reported encouraging acceleration in the program.

City officials will meet today in City Hall to devise a way to hold hotel rents for permanent residents at their June 30 level. To get the emergency measure passed by the City Council and signed by Mayor O'Dwyer with the least delay, it is expected that an amendment will be made to a proposed rent control law pending before the Council.
NEW DELHI, India, July 6 -- Leading Indian newspapers in their first comments praised the Parliamentary Indian independence bill in editorials today but made some qualifications.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 6 -- Asserting that lack of tenure and retirement benefits were keeping thousands of competent men and women from the teaching profession, educators attending the con vention of the National Education Association mapped out a country wide campaign to obtain tenure for teachers.

WHEN Christine Weston writes, about India she does so exceedingly well, as she demonstrated in her distinguished novel, "Indigo," and as she has again done in a collection of stories published today, "There and Then."* But when she writes a romantic novel about wartime love in New York and Maine, as she did in "The Dark Wood," the lamentable result is best left in the decent oblivion which mercifully awaits all such mistakes.

New or increased state taxes on popular commodities have been approved by the legislatures of almost twenty states since Jan. 1, according to a survey recently completed by the Public Administration Clearing House of Chicago. Most of the new or increased levies are on sales, cigarettes, gasoline and liquor.

PITTSBURGH, July 6 -- Settlement of the coal-labor issues for steel company "captive" mines has prevented a serious drop in steel operations. Last week's output was estimated at 76 per cent of capacity for the country, compared with a revised rate of 95 per cent the week before.

LONDON, July 6 -- Britons of all religions joined today at King George's summons in prayers for the welfare of the country and the British Commonwealth. The call was for personal loyalty In these difficult and anxious times.

The Citizens Housing Council took the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards to task yesterday for its advocacy of repeal of the city law prohibiting discrimination in the selection of tenants for publicly aided housing projects built by private enterprise.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $50,589,724,452. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Something like half the population of this city must have gotten up aria gone somewhere during the three-day vacation that this morning is but a memory. More than a million each day managed to find space on the Coney Island beach. Six hundred thousand motor cars, each with its happy passengers, took to the highways.

A group of Bronx citizens interrupted their Sunday lethargy yesterday to chase three armed men who had robbed a neighbor of $845. Aroused by their cries, a policeman off duty shot one of the suspects after he had run through his yard.

Senator Owen Brewster, Maine Republican, and Senator James | E. Murray, Montana Democrat, charged last night that the State | Department had failed to act definitely and constructively in regard Palestine.

A new workhorse of very high potential has been added to the Air Transport Command, which recently celebrated its sixth anniversary as a member of the Army Air Forces. This is the giant cargo plane, the Boeing C-97 Stratofreighter, largest flying freight car thus far in operation.
A 45-year-old policeman, in the Jewish Memorial Hospital because of a heart condition, helped a nurse yesterday morning to rescue a 250 pound patient who was hanging from a third-floor window ledge.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 6 -- More than half the members of Princeton University's 212th graduating class, who received bachelor's degrees last month, won honors for outstanding academic achievement in their upper-class years, it was announced today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 5 -- In the prolonged negotiations between the film studios and the Screen Actors Guild concerning a new contract, the question of so called portal-to-portal pay for the players is said to be no longer a major issue, while that of the actors' interest in revivals of old pictures is understood to be moving toward a compromise.

Two explosive innings, one early, the other late, brought the Yankees a double victory over the Athletics yesterday at the Stadium. A fiverun outburst in the first frame of the opener led to an 8-2 conquest and a seven-run barrage in the eighth of the afterpiece turned a tightly knotted struggle into a topheavy, 9-2 rout.

TOKYO, July 6 -- All the implications on the new wage and price policies that the Government announced over the week-end will not be clear for some time. They constitute almost a complete reversal of the policies that Japan has been following under the occupation's urging since the surrender.

Advertising in newspapers, magazines, trade journals, editorials and other promotional media, including films and point-of-sale pieces, will toe used in an intensive merchandising public relations campaign by the Radio Manufacturers Association to stimulate demand for and sales of radios, it was announced over the week-end.
