PITTSBURGH, July 6 (AP) -- Aging Fritz Ostermueller pitched a six-hit shut-out today as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the Chicago Cubs, 10 to 0, in the nightcap after taking the opener of their double-header, 6 to 2. It was the first twin bill the last-place Pirates have captured this season.

The Navy held yesterday a traditional full-dress ceremony for one of its greatest heroes, Commodore John Paul Jones. It was the 200th anniversary of the birth of the American Revolutionary War officer.

The Railway Business Association, in a report prepared by P. Harvey Middleton, its executive vice president, announced yesterday that higher railroad earnings are the only way to insure solvency of that industry and to avoid the nationalization not only of the railways but also of all other forms of transportation.

JERUSALEM, July 6 -- Tiny Palestine contains enough land and water to feed two or three times more than her present population, the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine was emphatically told today by Eliezer Kaplan, Treasurer of the Executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine.

Comparatively few buyers visited the New York wholesale markets last week because of the holiday, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. As a result, activity in general was quiet. Business is expected to increase with the anticipated influx of buyers this week and during the rest of the month.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 6 -- The men's eastern intercollegiate tennis championship, like the women's, went to the South today.

HAMBURG, Germany, July 6 -- The British Military Government is seeking the complete elimination of the once-powerful Germanischer Lloyd Classification Society and the transfer of its functions to a small, bi-zonal government shipping board, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (U.P.) -- Hundreds of industrial and public organizations are lining up behind the War Department mobilization program to provide a reserve pool of trained manpower for immediate use as service units in the event of another war, the Army revealed today.

ATHENS, July 6 -- Greek Government observers of the fighting in the high mountains along Greece's long frontier with Albania, Yugoslavia and Bulgaria have been driven to the conclusion in recent weeks that the Greek Army will never be able to impose a strictly military solution.

LONDON, July 6 -- Last week was one of gloom and dejection for the stock markets here, with depressing news coming thick and fast. Chief among the depression factors were the announcement by Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer, of the coming cuts in imports to help meet the dollar shortage, and the breakdown of the Big Three's talks in Paris on the American aid plan.
CHICAGO, July 6 -- The grain markets on the Chicago Board of Trade were featured last week by the development of congestion in July corn and oats due to a lack of cash grain available for delivery.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 6 --The visit of Gen. George Washington here on June 28, 1775, was reenacted today at the Christ and Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, which is on the site of the old Wakeman Inn. There General Washington and his aide, Maj. Gen. Charles Lee, stopped while en route from Philadelphia to join the Continental Army at Boston.

ROME, July 6 -- An indication that not all Communist leaders see eye-to-eye in matters of party policy was given today by the different ways in which the Communist leader Palmiro Togliatti and the Communist party organ Unita reacted to the Marshall plan and to Italian participation in the conference to meet in Paris Saturday.

JERUSALEM, July 6 -- In a series of speeches in Haifa that were more inflammatory than any others heard in Palestine since the Arab revolt a decade ago, Arabs sounded today a virtual "call to arms." There were threats of another revolt unless the United Nations met their demands of sovereignty.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6 -- American business, exclusive of agriculture, expects to spend about $3,800,000,000 during the next three months for the construction of new plants and the purchase of new equipment.

Formation of an agency to seek the cause of rheumatic fever, leading fatal disease of chilhood, was announced yesterday. The unit will be known as the Helen Hay Whitney Foundation for Rheumatic Fever Research.

DETROIT, July 6 -- The Foremen's Association of America voted today to end its strike against the Ford Motor Company. The 3,800 members who went out forty-seven days ago, will return to work tomorrow without gaining a single concession from the company.

New Yorkers by the millions returned to the city yesterday from beach and mountain resorts in the wind-up of the three-day Fourth of July week-end. They returned as they had gone -- in perfect summer weather.

Immediate action by the Federal Government to create an adequate copper stockpile for national defense purposes was urged here over the week-end by spokesmen for the industries on which production requirements would be placed in any future emergency.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat, of Wyoming, said in a radio debate today that "the real drive for income-tax reduction" came from two sources.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (U.P.) -- Government figures for the first six months of this year, released today, indicated that 1947 might be a record construction year measured in money spent but a failure in terms of actual housing built.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- John Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, today disclosed that his Department had begun a detailed study of a huge "tax avoidance" loophole under which more than $5,000,000,000 in income is annually escaping taxation.

CHICAGO, July 6 (AP) -- South Africa's Bobby (Cash-and-Carry) Locke conquered a heavy wind and stampeding galleryites today to card a sub-par 71 and move into a 72-hole tie with Ed (Porky) Oliver, who skidded to a 74, thus throwing the rich Tarn o' Shanter golf tournament into a play-off.

The missing two of the three Swedish youths who came to this country on Tuesday as stowaways on a plane from Stockholm were taken into custody late Saturday night at Mount Kisco, N.Y. They had gone there to visit a relative.
As part of its sweeping schedule realignment, WNYC, will introduce on Friday a new musical series entitled "An Evening With Great Masters."
AT SEA, June 25 (By Wireless, Delayed) -- Occasionally, on moonlight nights, we get in our rubber dinghy and two or three of us will drift off to look at the raft from a distance.

WITH ARMY TASK FORCE FURNACE in the Arizona Desert July 6 -- Out here in one of the hottest and dustiest sections North America, the Army Ground Forces, as a phase of global preparedness, are continuing their experiments in climatic extremes started in Alaska last winter.

ST. LOUIS, July 6 (AP) -- A fiverun ninth inning at the expense of Reliefer Jack Kramer put the Detroit Tigers well ahead of the St. Louis Browns for an 8-4 victory in the second game. They had trounced the Brownies, 10-2, with four home runs in the opener of the doubleheader today.

Following a survey which revealed a disposition on the part of a large number of manufacturers' agents, particularly newer ones in the field, to operate without definite written sales agreements, the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., has published a guide for contract forms, it was announced over the weekend.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Aggressive speculative buying of lard futures, especially for eastern account, lifted prices rapidly early last week on the Chicago Board of Trade. Active months were up more than 2 cents a pound from the recent low, but the delivery of some 5,000,000 pounds of cash lard on July contracts started a liquidating movement that more than wiped out the advance.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 6 (AP) -- Frank Parker of Los Angeles retained his national clay courts tennis championship today by beating Ted Schroeder second ranking American player, also from Los Angeles, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 2 6 -- 4.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., July 6 -- Tom Mather's Pala Dura quartet rode into the semi-final round of Pete Bostwick's $5,000 handicap polo tournament today. The victors whipped an all-South American side, Los Andinos, 12 to 6, before 2,500 persons at Bostwick Field.

RYE, N.Y., July 6 -- Sam Hayes of the County Club captured the final round match of the Paul Martin Memorial Tennis tournament at the Westchester Country Club today. Seeded No. 4, Hayes beat the second seeded star, Alexander Carver of the Pelham Country Club, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3. 6 -- 2.

Memory is the basic word of the Christian religion, the Rev. Dr. John A. Mackay, president of the Princeton Theological Seminary, declared yesterday at the morning service in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

QUINCY, Mass., July 6 -- A few moments after taking off from the Squantum Naval Air Station late today, a Navy "Helldiver" plane, crashed into three houses in the Wollaston section here, killing the pilot, seriously injuring an enlisted passenger and leaving a smoking trail of wreckage.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 6 -- Seven newly crowned national champions were among the twenty track and field athletes named today by the Amateur Athletic Union to represent the United States abroad on pre-Olympic good-will tours this summer.
A fifteen-car special train advertising the-industrial advantages of Oklahoma arrived at Pennsylvania Station at 10:15 A.M. yesterday for a three-day visit in New York.

CHICAGO, July 6 (AP) -- Lwry Doby, 22-year-old Negro newcomer to the Indians, Singled to drive in a run as the Tribe defeated the White Sox, 5 to 1, in the second game today after losing the first, 3 to 2, before 31,566 persons.

Two facts assumed major importance yesterday, as members of the Board of Estimate prepared to consider, at an executive meeting this afternoon at Gracie Mansion, the proposal to increase the fare on subway and elevated lines to 8 cents, or two rides for 15 cents.

MEXICO CITY, July 6 --The flyIng visit of seven United States Congressmen during the past week to the livestock-producing areas of this country that is suffering severely from hoof and mouth disease spotlights the current efforts toward economic cooperation being undertaken by the United States and Mexican Governments.

Palace of the Soviets Establishment of an outpost of the U.S.S.R. in Park Avenue invites a number of reflections. The very existence of that broad thoroughfare north of the Grand Central Station where a great tower with a glittering gold crown stands as a double gateway to Multimillionaires Row is a monument to capitalistic enterprise.
NANKING. July 6 (AP) -- President Chiang Kai-shek, in a bitterly worded radio address, tonight told his people that the nation would die unless they conquered the Communists.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 6 -- With a real south-southwest breeze and enough of a sea to make lively going, 135 craft started today in the regatta of the Riverside Yacht Club. A number did not finish as both wind and sea became too much for those with tender and skeletonized rigging.

A neat new carton for those half-pound loaves of processed cheese that many housewives buy regularly has been designed by a New York packaging expert for Zausner Foods, Inc. It's a simple thing, but one that contributes to ease in storing and serving a nourishing product.

MARLBORO, N.Y., July 6 -- Don Whitfield, the veteran outboard driver from Montclair, N.J. and Warren Kenny, another amateur of Hempstead, L.I., stole the show on a rough regatta course in the Hudson River today. Each captured a New York State championship title in two straight heats.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market for future delivery eased last week after early firmness and closed in lower ground. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed for the week net losses of 33 to 73 points. The smallest net recession was registered in the spot July position.

The Dodgers had no difficulty in serving an eviction notice on the Boston Braves at Ebbets Field yesterday, taking over the National League penthouse and dropping the temporary tenants a floor below them in second place.

More than 750,000 briar pipes and other smoking accessories, over $2,000,000 worth of gasoline and diesel engines, paints, oils and greases, industrial sewing machines and more than 650,000 insecticide bombs are among current surplus property offerings listed by the War Assets Administration, Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director, disclosed over the week-end.

BERLIN, July 6 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Commander in Europe, disclosed today in his semi-monthly report that the coal and transportation shortages had forced a 30 per cent curtailment in the industries in the United States zone.

The bright dream known, as the Inter-American Highway, from Laredo to Panama, long had a sentimental appeal. In the spring of 1942, when Nazi submarines infested the Western Atlantic and Caribbean, it had a military appeal. Hence our Government took up the proposal of Brig. Gen. W.D. Styer to fill in the gaps in existing roads, so that our Canal garrison could be supplied by truck.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Twenty prominent Americans, predominantly educators and churchmen, denounced today proposals for universal military training as outmoded military preparation in the atomic age and as an integral part of an armaments race that would make inevitable "a titanic showdown conflict between the United States and Russia."

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 6 -- Tommy Pierce of the Rutland Country Club, the Vermont State champion, won the invitation amateur golf tournament for the Robert Todd Lincoln Memorial Cup today. He defeated Charles Mulcahy of the Brae Burn Country Club, 2 up, in the final round at the Ekwanok Country Club.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 6 -- Larry Friedman of this city, winner of last year's initial tournament for the junior championship of the United States Chess Federation in Chicago, is defending his title with success in the current tournament at the Higbee Auditorium.

Three young thugs walked into the lobby of the Hotel Brevoort early yesterday morning, held up the night clerk, assaulted the elevator operator, and walked out with about $500 of the hotel's money. They sped away in a dark two-door sedan, driven by a fourth man.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (U.P.) -- A deadlock developed today in wage contract talks between Northern coal operators and John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, raising the prospect of a strike on Tuesday when the miners' ten-day vacation ends.
Miss Josephine Clarke of the contract decorating department at Macy's is departing by plane this morning for Monrovia, Liberia, to set up a housekeeping establishment for persons unknown to her.

The only use of atomic power the world has so far seen is the destruction wrought by the atom bomb. Scientists in many countries know how to explode the atom, and the United States knows how to make the bomb. There the thing rests in the mind of the general public.

From all outward appearances, cotton textiles will enjoy a stabilized market for the balance of the year, according to a consensus of opinion in Worth Street over the week-end. The industry, however, is concerned with two factors which could change the present bullish outlook, textile merchants pointed out.

BOSTON, July 6 (AP) -- Regaining their slugging eyes in the nightcap, the Red Sox swept a doubleheader from the Senators with a 10-1 victory today before a crowd of 29,309. They took advantage of six Washington errors for a 7-4 opening game triumph.

PARIS, July 6 -- Norway and Belgium, as well as Italy and Portugal have told the French Foreign Office they would attend the European meeting in Paris July 12 to implement the Marshall project on United States aid to Europe.

LONDON, Monday, July 7 -- Britain's harvest prospects are poor, The Times of London announced today in publishing a summary of crop reports from all over the country. An editorial pointed out that "this will come as an unpleasant surprise to many who thought that so far this summer had not been bad."
HAVANA, July 6 -- Some 1,000 delegates of anti-communistic unions opened the fifth national workers' congress today as the labor split widened.

A little more than one hour out of mid-Manhattan by bus, motor car or New York Central Railroad you can stand on a hilltop in Ward Poundridge Reservation in upper Westchester County and look out upon five states -- New Jersey, New York, Massachusetts, Connecticut and Pennsylvania.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Republican leadership in the House and Senate plans to make every effort to pass and send to the White House a new income tax reduction bill before the end of this week.

PEIPING, July 6 -- Political conditions in Northwest China are generally stable at present, according to a group of American and European travelers who have just returned from a two-month survey trip through this vast frontier zone.

HAMILTON, N.Y., July 6 -- Discussing immigration control and foreign policy, Dr. Ira De A. Reid, visiting Professor of Education at New York University, said here tonight that "the United States must take leadership in resettling of world populations by revising its immigration laws to meet world needs."

SAPULPA, Okla., July 6 -- Lew Wentz, Republican National Committeeman for Oklahoma, today declared himself in favor of nominating Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York for President at next year's Republican national convention but added that no one could presume to deliver the Oklahoma delegation to any prospective candidate.

PARIS, Monday, July 7 -- After an all-night sitting, delegates to the Socialist National Council approved today maintenance of the present Ramadier Cabinet and adopted a motion supporting the Marshall proposals for American aid to Europe.

When Foreign Minister Molotov broke up the Paris conference for European reconstruction on the basis of the Marshall plan, he did so on the ground that continent-wide cooperation among European nations would mean Big Power domination of the small nations to the detriment of their sovereignty and independence.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in the period June 28 to July 4 are given in the appended tabulation: The Senate On the House Concurrent Resolution disapproving the President's Reorganisation Plan No. 2 (placing the United States Employment
PHILADELPHIA, July 6 -- The Giants won a ball game today without hitting any homers and that is almost like saying they did it without mirrors.

When the United States Treasury concluded the fiscal year 1946-1947 at midnight last Monday with a surplus of $753 millions, that fact may not have marked the end of an era, but it at least interrupted one. The last time the Federal fiscal authorities were able to report an annual excess of receipts over expenditures was in 1930.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (U.P) -- More than 160,000 disabled civilians have been placed in paying jobs since the civilian vocational rehabilitation program was expanded four years ago, Michael J. Shortley, director of the Federal Security Agency's Office of Vocational Rehabilitation, announced tonight.

TETERBORO, N.J., July 6 -- Twelve hundred veterans of World War II -- Air Corps almost to a man -- have developed Teterboro Airport from a field that handled fifty plane movements a day at the end of the war into an operation involving 1,000 a day.

All was confusion in local boxing circles yesterday following the Baksi upset in Sweden. The Associated Press said that of the 20th Century officials who were available none could throw any light on the future -- or present.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 6 -- Military aircraft hunted the skies over Pacific Coast states today for sight of the mysterious "flying saucers" that for twelve days have puzzled the entire country. Early reports of results were negative.
LONDON, July 6 -- Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer, made another urgent plea, in a speech in Manchester today, for higher production in British industry and agriculture.

BUENOS AIRES, July 6 -- President Juan Peron pledged Argentina today to work with the American republics and other peace-loving countries to aid the world, spiritually and materially, toward a secure peace.

Hurry! Hurry! If anyone has not got around to seeing "Life With Father" since it first eyed Broadway with a certain amount of misgiving on Nov. 8, 1939, let this be a warning: Not much time remains because the end is in sight for the world's longest run play.

STOCKHOLM, July 6 (U.P.) -- Olle Tandberg of Sweden scored the biggest upset in the heavyweight division in eleven years today when he defeated Joe Baksi, America's top title contender, but there was so much controversy over the decision that the Swede may not get his promised championship bout with Joe Louis.

A note approaching desperation seems to underlie Chiang Kai-shek's latest effort to rally his people to battle against the Communists. "Help us," he says, "or stand by and watch your nation die." The rebels are "only tools of a vast imperialism whose goal is eventual destruction of the Chinese race."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 6 -- A world-wide network of "repository libraries" to receive all official United Nations documents and act as local research centers on problems of world organization is being built up by the United Nations Library Service, it was learned today.

BERLIN, July 6 -- The Russian Military Government in eastern Germany has proposed that all major legislation be decided by a small coalition of political leaders dominated by pro-Communist elements. The non-Communist parties in the zone must decide in a few days whether to accept the plan and lose what political autonomy they have or reject it with approximately the same result.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 6 (AP) -- The condition of Magda Lupescu, who went through a "deathbed marriage ceremony" with former King Carol of Rumania,on Thursday, was reported today to be still grave. Mme. Ernesto Udreanu, wife of the former monarch's secretary, said Mme. Lupescu had passed a bad night.
John C. Leppart has been appointed a vice president of Prior Chemical Corporation.

NEWARK, N.J., July 6 -- When a 10-year-old boy attempted to pay for a 6-cent ice cream cone with a $50 bill at a concessionaire's stand in the Branch Brook Park boathouse here this afternoon, Sgt. Edward O'Mara of the Essex County Park Police, standing near-by, became suspicious.

HOLLISTER, Calif., July 6 (AP) -- Peace, but not quiet, was restored to Hollister today after thirty-six hours of turmoil created by hundreds of visiting motorcyclists and their friends who turned a city street into a speed-and-stunt area.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 6 (AP) -- Operation of Russian commercial aircraft in northern Iran was apparently prohibited today by a decree of the Iranian Government.

NANKING, July 6 -- The departure of W. Walton Butterworth, American Minister to China, for Washington for consultations this morning may foreshadow major new decisions on American policy in respect to China.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES. Your editorial "Patents and Research," of June 9, focuses attention on the need for study of the involved subject of allocation of patent rights in work done for the Government. A fuller appreciation of the fundamental principles underlying the problem is necessary if we are to find an appropriate solution.

The summer recreation program of the Flay Schools Association will get under way this morning with the opening of seventeen all day centers operated by or affiliated with the organization. Seven weeks of games, hobbies, short excursiqns and educational play will be offered to 5,000 city children, five to thirteen years of age.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (U.P.) -- A dispute over final disposition of the Government's Big Inch and Little Big Inch pipelines will be aired tomorrow at hearings on the question of extending use of the lines to serve the Appalachian area and the Eastern Seaboard permanently with natural gas.

CINCINNATI, July 6 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals scored a twin shut-out triumph over the Cincinnati Reds today, 3 -- 0 and 2 -- 0, to move into fourth place in the National League. Jim Hearn pitched a three-hitter in the opener and Murray Dickson allowed one more to win the nightcap as a rain-dampened crowd of 24,635 looked on.

BABYLON, N.Y., July 6 -- A brisk southwest wind and moderately calm water provided the third straight ideal sailing day at the Babylon Yacht Club today. The Great South Bay skippers entered the final day of the Fourth of July series.

GLASGOW, July 6 (AP) -- The title fight between Flyweight Champion Jackie Paterson of Glasgow and Dado Marino of Honolulu was postponed for the second time today. The challenger's manager declared angrily that he didn't believe the Scot could make the 112pound weight.

MUKDEN, China, July 6 (U.P.) -- Gen. Tu Yu-ming, commander of Government armies in Manchuria, said today that fighting in China could not be described correctly as a civil war, since it was a struggle between the legitimate Government of China and a foreign power making use of Chinese "traitors."

HALIFAX, N.S., July 6 (Canadian Press) -- With part of her crew safe on Sable Island and the others on a salvage tug bound for Halifax, the Greek freighter Mannasset was abandoned today, to join scores of other ships in the shifting sands of the Atlantic graveyard.

The Port of New York Authority is preparing to open Floyd Bennett Field to commercial aviation about Aug. 1, Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the authority, announced yesterday in giving a progress-report on the bi-state agency's first month of operating the major airports of New York.

SPOKANE, Wash., July 6 (AP) -- Eight flying saucers, described as "more like washtubs" and each "about the size of a five-room house," were reported today by Mrs. Walter Johnson of suburban Dishman as having fallen in view of ten persons Thursday evening near St. Maries, Idaho.

An issue of $6,000,000 of bonds of Kern County, Calif., Union High School District was awarded yesterday at a bid of 100.195 for 1.20s to a banking syndicate composed of the National City Bank here, the Bank of America National Trust Savings Association, the Harris Trust Savings Bank, the Anglo California National Bank, R. H. Moulton Co., California Bank, and Security Trust Savings Bank.

Fordham University's new frequency modulation radio station, WFUV, started its first day of regularly scheduled programs yesterday at 9 A.M. The station is operating under a temporary license from the Federal Communications Commission.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- What goes on here, anyway? When the script originally was written for the All-Star game which will be resumed at symetrically beautiful Wrigley Field on the morrow, the American League was allotted all the power and the National League was supposed to regard a bunt as an awesome display of hitting strength.

LONDON, July 7 -- The National Union of Mine Workers opened a crucial annual conference today at Rothesay, Scotland. Coal is the key to British recovery, but the highlight of today's proceedings was a strong attack against the United States by Will Lawther in his presidential address.

CINCINNATI, July 7 -- Despite increased salaries and somewhat improved conditions, an acute teacher shortage will confront the United States when schools reopen this fall, educators attending the eighty-fifth conference of the National Education Association warned today.

Abraham Bricken of 14 East Seventy-fifth Street, who arrived here a penniless immigrant from Kiev, Russia, in 1905 and became one of the largest builders of Manhattan's modern garment center, died yesterday in the Riverdale Nursing Home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, after an illness of two years. His age was 63.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Two members of the Black Legion swore today that Representative Robert F. Jones, Republican, of Ohio, joined the hooded organization at a flashlight ceremony in 1938, but Mr. Jones denied that he had and six character witnesses lauded him as a fair and tolerant man.
Insurgent candidates for Tammany leaderships generally fared badly yesterday before the Board of Elections, which began a series of hearings on protested primary designating petitions.

MUNICH, Germany, July 7 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay told the second rabbinical conference of the American and British zones today that he could not answer the problem of their future and their congregations, but he assured them that they could await the decisions of the various Governments involved in security and freedom.

George Gershwin remains a very popular composer, but last night's audience at the Lewisohn Stadium indicates that perhaps the frenzy for his works has begun to wane. For the first time in eight years the annual Gershwin Night throng fell below 19,000.

New York City sits on many waters. It fronts on open sea, on wide bays and on broad rivers. Excursion, sightseeing and fishing craft sail these waters. They take the heat-weary and the seeker after scenic beauty out of the city into cool and dreamy places.

Mayor O'Dwyer is not yet ready to state his position on the proposal to raise rapid transit fares, he said last evening after a second executive session of the Board of Estimate had considered the plan for three hours at Gracie Mansion.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Democrats in key Congressional posts were represented authoritatively tonight as being ready to offer $4,000,000,000 in tax cuts affecting personal incomes in order to beat the Republicans' 10.5 to .30 per cent reduction bill.

JERUSALEM, July 7 -- A virtually new proposal was advanced by the Zionist movement today. Calling for further colonization and the transformation of the Holy Land into a Jewish state, it suggested temporary supervision of Palestine by the United Nations while such steps were being carried out.

BATAVIA, Java, July 7 (AP) -- Premier Amir Sjahriffoedin announced today that his Indonesian Republic Cabinet would reject Dutch demands for a joint Netherland -Indonesian gendarmerie to police Republican areas, and urged his followers to remain "calm, united and alert."

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Employing such terms as "flagrant fraud" and "mockery of universal democracy," the Spanish Republican Government in exile today thoroughly denounced the Franco referendum Sunday on his law of Succession.

Store Sales Here Up 12% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 12 per cent last week over the comparative week of last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 7 (AP) -- One of the two personal physicians attending Magda Lupescu in the suite of former King Carol of Rumania declared this afternoon she was slightly improved and added: "Where there's life there's hope."
Establishing a new record, the New York Hospital provided care for 72,271 patients last year, the Society of the New York Hospital announced yesterday in its 1946 annual report.

NANKING, July 7 -- President Chiang Kai-shek's broadcast to the nation last night was the climax of a series of Government resolutions statements dealing with the new policy of "war to the death" with the Communists.
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 7 -- Austria has applied for membership in the United Nations, and the tiny Republic of San Marino has received advice on how to apply, it was announced here today.

Representatives of John L. Lewis' soft coal miners and the Northern operators were in session in Washington all day yesterday in a frantic effort to iron out remaining points of difference over the new wage contract agreed on last night. The reason for this frenzied activity was that negotiations had "drifted" into one more crisis of the kind that have long since become familiar in this area of labor-management relations.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 7 -- Two foreign-born Princeton University graduate students started off this afternoon on an 18,000mile jeep trip to Tierra del Fuego, Patagonia, on the southernmost tip of the South American continent.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As I have listened to the objections of some of our citizens to the proposed Stratton bill, which permits a certain number of displaced persons to come into the United States, it has seemed to me that most of these objections come from a lack of information and understanding of the immigration laws already in force and of the care with which these laws are administered.

The Cunard White Star liner Mauretania arrived here at 8:55 A.M. yesterday with 1,146 passengers from Southampton and Cherbourg, including Princess Brinda of Kapurthala, a princely state in Punjab Province, India.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- First milk purchases by the International Children's Emergency Fund were announced today by Dr. Martha Eliot, associated chief of the Children's Bureau and special technical consultant of the fund.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 7 -- A boom market for automatic washers will prevail for the next five years at least, Cylde G. Remmo, sales manager of F.L. Jacobs Company, producers of Launderall home laundries, predicted here today. Mr. Remmo made the forecast, which he emphasized is a minimum prediction, at a sales convention of the company's distributors from all over the country.

Following is the text of the proposed local law on hotel rents which will go before the City Council today: A LOCAL LAW TO AMEND THE ADMINISTRATIVE CODE OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, IN RELATION TO THE REGULATIONS, CONTROL AND STABILIZATION OF RENTS IN HOTELS, ROOMING HOUSES AND LODGING HOUSES WITHIN THE CITY OF NEW YORK DURING AN EMERGENCY, CREATING A TEMPORARY CITY HOUSING RENT COMMISSION AND DESCRIBING ITS POWERS, GENERALLY.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: One hesitates to can attention to any error in such an Interesting column as the Topics of the Times. But, in the recent description of the view from the Latting Observatory, there is a slip which concerns the family of Mary Murray of Revolutionary fame, so that perhaps THE TIMES will pardon a slight correction.

The "flying saucer." though still adept at eluding the most powerful telescopes in America, continued yesterday to flash in increasing numbers and variety before the goggling eyes of rooftop and roadside amateurs.

A local law freezing hotel rents for transient as well as permanent tenants at their June 30 level and providing for a three-man Temporary City Housing Commission to adjust "inequities'' is to come before the City Council in a special session today.

CLEVELAND, July 7 -- Junior national chess champion Larry Friedman of this city maintained his fine form today in the fifth and and sixth rounds of the finals in the second annual tournament sponsored by the United States Chess Federation.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 7 -- The Music Academy of the West, a non-profit institution supported by endowments, opened its initial session today when fifty-three enrolled students gathered for classes with ten nationally known faculty members on the campus of the Santa Barbara School in suburban Carpinteria.

A program of rehabilitation and re-education for the disabled under the "operating affiliation" of Columbia University and the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled, 400 First Avenue, was announced yesterday by Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of Columbia, and Walter Ewing Hope, president of the institute.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Opponents of universal military training urged Congress today to put more faith in the United Nations and in diplomacy, and to deemphasize military might.

PEIPING, China, July 7 -- President Chiang's proclamation of total national mobilization against the Chinese Communists has been received with mixed reactions in usually well-informed circles in North China. These circles regard this proclamation, first, as firmly closing the door on any possibility of a negotiated settlement to the civil war, and, second, as failing to add any new element to the present deteriorating situation.

The Pilsner beer that arrived from Czechoslovakia last month, the first since November, 1939, has "rested" from its trip sufficiently to be ready for distribution. Last week saw its return to several good restaurants in the metropolitan area, including such famous German-type establishments as Luchow's, Hans Jaeger's and the Blue Ribbon.

Fighting off the challenge of the first and second choices in a blistering stretch run, the Brenda Hope Stable's Station won the Class C race that featured the program of the Empire City Racing Association at Jamaica yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Senate began debate today on the bill to unify the armed forces, with the prospect of voting on the issue by Thursday afternoon.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 7 -- A clash on policy between King Michael and Premier Petru Groza's Government, which might have had a decisive effect on the future of the monarchy, appears to have been temporarily averted.

BUENOS AIRES, July 7 (AP) -- Argentina followed up President Juan Peron's Sunday plea for world peace with a proposal today that the nations of the Western Hemisphere and the Holy See offer "necessary cooperation so the desires of the peoples of the world can be satisfied."

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Still smarting under the sting of last year's fearful 12-0 drubbing, not to mention the equally unenviable record of having won only four of these thirteen classics in the past, the National League tonight appeared determined to go all out in a bid to regain some of its lost All-Star game prestige tomorrow.
After opening unchanged to 11 points higher than Thursday's final prices, cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 17 to 35 points net lower.
No flying saucers were visible at La Guardia Field yesterday, but three flying horses put in an appearance at 8:12 A.M.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The United Mine Workers Policy Committee tonight ratified an agreement reached earlier in the evening to forestall a strike tomorrow in the mines of "captive" steel interests and commercial operators in the northern Appalachian fields.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The National Petroleum Council said today that the United States needs full capacity refinery output, but that the refineries are operating instead at 91 per cent of capacity, it estimated full capacity at 5,648,000 barrels of crude oil daily.

The Meadow Brook Club, Westbury I., will stage its second tournament of the season today, when the twelve-goal polo competition for the Hempstead Cups gets under way. Four openinround matches are scheduled, with action to begin at 3:30 o'clock.

GENEVA, Switzerland, July 7 -- Yugoslavia served notice upon the International Labor Organization today of her intention to withdraw from that body. The action is based on the argument that the tripartite nature of the organization, in which workers, employers and Government each are members of equal standing, is antipathetic to her form of government.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today directed the Market Street Railway Company of San Francisco to furnish to a protective committee of the company's prior preference capital stock a list of all holders of such stock, their addresses and the number of shares owned by each.

SONGULDAK, Turkey, July 7 -- There lies in the substream of northwestern Anatolia Province a thick vein of coal 100 miles long and 30 miles wide, bordering the Black Sea littoral. In this vein there are 500,000,000 tons of easily exportable, blocked out coal rated at 1,890 B.T.U's.

WITH ARMY TASK FORCE FURNACE, in the Arizona Desert, July 7 -- In a spirit of unprejudiced research, the "acid test" of rigorous desert heat, wind and sand is being given to Ground Forces Equipment ranging from tanks to T-shirts in this continuation of the Army's experiments in climatic extremes started in Alaska last winter.

Four dozen babies, each bitten by four dozen mosquitos, according to an adult spokesman, joined their four dozen irate mothers yesterday at Thirtieth Avenue and Seventy-third Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, in a perambulator protest before the offices of the surrounding veterans' housing development.
Good luck, American steaks and vitamin pills were credited yesterday by Jack Kramer for his victories in the British singles and doubles championships at Wimbledon.

PITTSBURGH, July 7-- Miners in Western Pennsylvania indicated tonight that they probably would not return to work until the late afternoon shift tomorrow pending official word from John L. Lewis that a new wage agreement had been signed.
With the pre-Fourth of July camp exodus over, the day camp season for stay-at-home youngsters opened officially yesterday throughout the city.

Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle, who has been seeking to put the Fire Department back on its pre-war three-platoon system, announced yesterday that the complete eight-hour set-up should become operative by July 16.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The House passed today by 386 to 0, over the protests of the Treasury that its action would be inflationary, a bill to permit $1,792,000,000 in terminal leave bonds to be cashed in by former members of the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Federal Reserve System told Congress today in its annual report that it was powerless under existing law to control excessive bank credit expansion, except by permitting interest rates to rise to a point that night demoralize the Government securities market.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- An intensified drive to enlist the sympathies of this country in Moroccan and French North African independence is to get under way shortly, it was learned today.
PARIS, July 7 -- The Government is seeking the strictest control of the press to protect it from "economic influence," Pierre Bourdon, Minister of Information, said today.

CHICAGO, July 7 (AP) -- Bobby Locke, playing his shots like a machine, clicked a four-under-par 68 today to fashion a three-stroke lead over Ed (Porky) Oliver in the first round of their 36-hole playoff for the Tarn O'Shanter, $7,000 professional top prize.
LONDON, July 7 (Reuters) -- New amateur regulations were issued today by the Royal and Ancient Golf Club at St. Andrews, using the same wording recently adopted by the United States Golf Association.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Unanimous approval of legislation to enable the United States to administer the trusteeship of the former Japanese mandated Marianas, Caroline and Marshall Islands as "the Territory of the Pacific Islands" was voted by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Prices of corn soared again today on the Board of Trade, both the July delivery and white cash corn setting new high records. The July delivery reached $2.17 1/4 a bushel and No. 2 white corn went to $2.47, which was 31 cents over the July at the time of sale.

Mayor O'Dwyer formally opened two new rehabilitation wards in Bellevue Hospital yesterday afternoon -- the first in this country established for disabled veterans. Patterned after the rehabilitation services of the Army and Navy, the new facility was described as "medical history in the making" by Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals.

A strike that would have tied up most of bread and cake production in this area was averted yesterday when seven large bakeries reached a wage agreement with Local 50, Bakery and Confectionery Workers, AFL. The settlement was announced by Jacob R. Mandelbaum of the United States Conciliation Service.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 7 -- Westchester County's 2,200 employes hit a mid-year bonanza today in the form of higher income and shorter working hours. Officials estimated the extra budget cost at $750,000 a year.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 7 -- Europe has taken big strides toward economic recovery since hostilities ended, an analysis of the latest issue of the United Nations Monthly Statistical Bulletin showed today.

The total of striking shipyard workers rose to an estimated 67,000 yesterday as 4,000 members of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, walked out of the Alabama Dry Dock and Shipbuilding Company yard at Mobile, Ala.
LONDON, July 7 -- Capital, labor and Government are represented on Great Britain's new Economic Planning Board, whose composition was announced today in the House of Commons.

When we measure the immensity of the task, the formal opening of the two new rehabilitation wards for disabled civilians at Bellevue Hospital yesterday is only a modest beginning. There are only eighty beds. But hardly more than six months ago there were none. This is the first medical rehabilitation program in any civilian general hospital in the nation.

With forty stunned passengers as unwilling witnesses, a patrolman and a cornered thug shot it out shortly after noon yesterday in the aisle of a crowded crosstown bus at Forty-second Street and the Avenue of the Americas. The brief duel ended in death for the robber and serious injury for the patrolman.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 7 (AP) -- Headed by a tall New England girl who finished the qualifying play six strokes ahead of her nearest rival, sixteen qualifiers in the national intercollegiate women's golf tournament will tee off in the first round of match play over a shortened Ohio State University Scarlet course tomorrow.

BERLIN, July 7 -- The United States is expected to take a stiffened stand against the Russians in what is freely described here as the "political battle for Berlin." It has been compared to the maneuvers in Hungary and is said to be part of the pattern of Russian aims in eastern Europe.

Buyer activity at the first postwar Curtain and Drapery Show, which opened yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker, was confined primarily to "shopping" and "number taking." Although the show management gave the registration of buyers for the day as 250, the three floors occupied by 125 exhibitors were all but empty in the middle of the afternoon.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Senator Eugene D. Millikin, Republican, of Colorado, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee and cochairman of the Joint Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation, declared today that "great difficulty" was being encountered in probing billions of dollars of income that are escaping taxation.

Gian-Carlo Menotti, the composerplaywright-director, who was introduced to Broadway last season through "The Medium" and "The Telephone," will be represented again next year, probably in the early spring, with "The Consul," a three-act tragedy about displaced persons.

VIENNA, July 7 -- Austria is running into a flash coal crisis just at the moment when it had been thought that the basic coal problem had been solved after the successful negotiations of a coal deputation that had just returned from the United States.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 7 -- Premier Lajos Dinnyes, it was learned tonight from a reliable source, has decided to ask the Allied Control Commission for permission for his Government to accept the Anglo-French invitation to the Paris conference on United States' aid to Europe.
Earnings of the 2,386 pupils enrolled in the cooperative education program of the New York public school system reached the record high of $907,761 last year, it became known yesterday.

Child care agencies have raised substantially the board rates paid to families that take in foster children, a study distributed by the Child Welfare League of America announced yesterday. The twentypage report was based on replies to a questionnaire from 101 members of the league in rural and urban areas throughout the country.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- A near-record rush of buyers greeted exhibitors at the Summer Furniture an Homefurnishings Market today, but there was evidence that the market has returned to "normal" as buyers, in general, were reported to be shopping around before making commitments.

PARIS, July 7 -- Acceptances had been received here tonight from eight European countries to attend Saturday the conference on United States aid to Europe that was called by France and Britain and that today received the name of "Conference for European Economic Cooperation."

VIENNA, July 7 -- United States military authorities in Salzburg were reported tonight to have decided to move hundreds of Jews from the Franz Josef Camp to the near-by Riedenburg Camp this month whether the inmates agreed or not.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Recommendations requiring commercial passenger planes to install radar or its equivalent and clear mountainous areas by 2,000 feet when flying at night or by instruments, were submitted to President Truman today by his special board of inquiry on air safety.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, served notice today that his organization intended next year to stop making recordings, transcriptions and broadcasts for national networks.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Unspecified changes in United States strategic planning have made essential a re-evaluation of the size and type of aircraft industry the nation must support in peacetime to be prepared to meet any emergency, it was announced today by the Air Coordinating Committee.

SEOUL, Korea, July 7 -- The meeting of the joint United StatesSoviet commission scheduled for today was called off at the request of Col. Gen. Ternentyi F. Shtikov, chief of the Russian delegation. He notified Maj. Gen. Albert E. Brown, chief of the American delegation, that he was ill.

TOKYO, July 7 -- The Japanese Cabinet today approved the draft of a long-projected legislative program designed to take "bureaucracy" out of Japan's top-heavy civil service. A new civil service law, efectauting the Government's plan, it was announced, will be introduced at the current session of the Diet.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was interested in the editorial in THE TIMES on the sun as a source of energy.

BILBAO, Spain, July 7 -- The Franco authorities today expressed complete satisfaction with yesterday's voting on the law of succession endorsing Generalissimo Franco as dictator. They said that in all Spain about 90 per cent of all eligible voters had cast their ballots.
PHILADELPHIA, July 7 (AP) -- Lawson Robertson, head coach of the University of Pennsylvania track squad and former U.S. Olympic track coaeh, retired today.

PARIS, July 7 -- The resolutions adopted by the Socialist national council early today supporting Premier Paul Ramadier's Cabinet and Secretary of State Marshall's proposals seemed, after the National Assembly's vote of confidence, to give the Government a new lease on life at least until the October elections.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 7 -- Charles Chaplin told THE NEW YORK TIMES through an authorized spokesman at his studio here today that negotiations for the sale of United Artists Corporation being carried on by Mary Pickford and various other persons in New York have been wholly without his participation and that he has no present intention of letting go of his half interest in the company.

MANCHESTER, England, July 7 (Reuters) -- England's sterling batsmen, Bill Edrich and Denis Compton, today retrieved England's position after a poor start in their first innings of the third test cricket match against South Africa.

DID you ever read the shortest ghost Story in the world? Maurice Richardson tells it in his introduction to "The Beast With Five Fingers,"* by William Fryer Harvey. It is here reprinted in its entirety: "A man went to bed one night and hung his wig on the bedpost. In the morning it had turned white.

TOKYO, July 7 -- Japan's two largest trading companies -- at one time perhaps the world's largest -- have been ordered dissolved. The occupation authorities have also taken precautions against the revival of either Mitsui Bussan Kaisha or Mitsubishi Shoji Kaisha by forbidding their executives from combining to form any new company or more than two executives from becoming advisers of any company.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 7 In its internal form, rather than through, any symbolism as such, the skyscraper headquarters in Manhattan will remind the representatives of all fifty-five member nations of "something that represents the spirit of his country." Nikolai D. Bassov, Soviet member of the Headquarters Advisory Committee, said today.
THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, July 7 -- The reply of the Indonesian Republic cannot be accepted by the Dutch Government as it agrees only partly with the points contained in the Dutch note of May 27.

The 21-year-old Mel Torme, who already has earned his letter in the entertainment world as musical arranger and singing favorite in the night-club circuit, has been tapped, for his vocalizing, to head an NBC quarter-hour to be advertised as "Torme Time," which is booked for a 5:30 P.M. debut during an August afternoon as yet undetermined by date.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Truman asked Congress again today to authorize the admission of a "substantial number" of displaced persons from eastern European countries who had refused repatriation in Communist-controlled areas.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced this afternoon that it had permitted the Tucker Corporation's registration statement, covering 4,000,000 shares of class A common stock that are to be offered publicly at $5 a share, to become effective at 5:30 P.M. today.

Generalissimo Franco of Spain has just gone through the motions of having himself elected dictator for life, a step he forgot to take in the hurry of events ten years ago. His opponents have charged that orders went out two weeks ago to the election officials to turn in a yes vote of 70 to 75 per cent.

Anglo-California, San Francisco The Anglo-California National Bank, San Francisco, reported as of June 30 total deposits of $415,513,514 and total assets of $453,131,094, compared, respectively, with $418,857,810 and $458,646,482 March 31.

After considerable early irregularity, prices of shares in the final hour yesterday resumed their forward swing on the Stock Exchange with the railroad, liquor and a few specialty issues setting the pace. Prospects of an early settlement of the wage controversy in the coal industry and the improved showing of the railroads were factors in the advance.
Reorganization plans for to Equitable Office Building Corporation at 120 Broadway were offered yesterday by Wertheim Co. and the Manufacturers Trust Company.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 7 -- Despite a request by the United States for further discussion, the Working Committee of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission gave its tentative approval today to a Soviet proposal that the proposed international atomic control provide for the destruction of all atomic weapons in existence when the plan becomes effective.

Charges that old residents of Greenwich Village are harboring anti-social elements who make life miserable for newcomers were made last night by persons summoned to discuss racial tension in that neighborhood by the Greenwich Village Post of the Jewish War Veterans at 6 Fifth Avenue.
The last of the Fourth of July week-end travelers returned to New York yesterday in crowded buses and trains and in cars on clogged highways.

JERUSALEM, July 7 -- Two 17year-old Jewish girl messengers of the underground who were arrested by the police Saturday while delivering documents to the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine will be released tomorrow, official quarters said tonight.

Price increases of about $2 a ton probably will be announced after final settlement of the coal labor contracts, steel warehouses revealed here yesterday, following a review of their inventory and delivery situation covering the first six months of 1947.

LOS ANGELES, July 7 -- Alarmed by what it called the succession of current attacks on "liberals," the Hollywood Arts, Sciences and Professions Council of the Progressive Citizens of America will open Wednesday a five-day conference on "thought control in the United States."

In an analysis of the program for national security presented by the President's Advisory Commission on Universal Training, a committee including Josephus Daniels, former Secretary of the Navy; Robert Hutchins, Chancellor of the University of Chicago, and several other educators and church leaders, makes several general points against adoption of universal training for the young men of the United States.

Florence Reichman has chosen a middle course for her millinery trends in this season of extremes. The hats she showed yesterday afternoon to buyers in her West Fifty-seventh Street establishment made that clear. Yet, in letting conservatism guide her, she maintained the feeling of the day: importance of crown, side-to-side width and in many cases height.

HANOVER, Germany, July 7 -- A German track walker prevented what is believed to have been the biggest single attempt at sabotage since the end of the war, it was learned today. The aim was to blow up a train carrying hundreds of Allied personnel and their families from here to Hamburg.

After the Seignorage By offering a $100 premium to handle the stand-by underwriting of $7,000,000 of Public Service Company of Colorado 3 per cent fifteen-year convertible debentures, a Halsey, Stuart Co. banking syndicate came into possession at par of $518,900 of debentures not taken up by stockholders and thereafter was enabled to sell them at 113.07.

LOS ANGELES, July 7 -- The Conference of Studio Unions, American Federation of Labor craft group which has staged the ninemonth Hollywood strike, today brought suit against the major motion picture firms, charging violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law and demanding $43,000,000 damages.
SAPULPA, Okla., July 7 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York today received assurances of substantial support from the Texas delegation at next year's Republican National Convention.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- The National League, meeting today on the eve of the All-Star baseball game, reelected Ford C. Frick president for a four-year term. His regime dates back to 1934 when he succeeded John A. Heydler. President Will Harridge of the American League has two years to go under a tenyear contract.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- In a unanimous decision, the United States Court of Claims held today that former Judge William Clark, of Princeton, is not entitled to resume his seat on the Third Circuit Court of Appeals which he left, in March, 1942, to enter the Army.

BOSTON, July 7 (AP) -- On July 27, if the wind and weather are favorable that day, the auxiliary schooner Morning Star VI will sail out of Boston Harbor to follow the 90-year-old sea route of five previous "missionary packets" to Hawaii and islands in the Micronesian Archipelago.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 7 -- An upswing in new construction in May, represented by the issuance of 495 building permits with an aggregate value of $2,037,379 as against 471 in the preceding month for $1,928,883, has been revealed in the monthly business index of the Chamber of Commerce covering eastern Union County.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Truman's message to Congress asking legislation to admit European displaced persons as immigrants: To the Congress of the United States: On several occasions I have advocated legislation to enable a substantial number of displaced persons to enter the United States as immigrants.

GENEVA, Switzerland, July 7 -- A Soviet charge that Britain and France had connived in a plot to undermine the sovereignty of European nations through the Marshall plan touched off a sharp diplomatic clash today at the second day's session of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 7 -- With "full-industry" effort and cooperation now effective, national advertising in newspapers will be more than $300,000,000 this year, compared with $270,000,000 in 1946, it was predicted here today by George J. Auer, sales manager of Moloney, Regan Schmitt, Inc., newspaper representatives.

Modernization of most stores at least ten years overdue, but this promises to be corrected soon. Charles M. Edwards, dean of the Graduate School of Retailing of New York University, said at the clinic held in conjunction with the opening yesterday of the first anual Store Modernization Show at the, Grand Central Palace Questioned later, Dean Edwards said the accepted estimate is that merchants will do $3,000,000,000 worth of modernization in the next three years.

Royalty Is With Us A stranger among us might think it odd that just when we are celebrating American indpendence every year and our challenge to European monarchs and monarchies this nation breaks out into a perfect rash of royalty.
BLOOMFIELD, N.J., July 7 -- An auctioneer's hammer tomorrow will end a Bloomfield era started more than a century ago when David Oakes founded the woolen mills of Thomas Oakes Co., Inc., in 1830.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The American Council of Commercial Laboratories filed a complaint with Congress today charging that fiftytwo land-grant colleges and universities are engaged in business operations netting millions of dollars annually on which they pay no taxes.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 8 (AP) -- Chief of Police Daniel Gray announced tonight that Philip Schreil, 57 years old, of Plainfield had been arrested at his home in connection with the slaying of a woman whose body was found on April 19 strangled by a dog leash in a trunk dumped on a road near Keyport.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Adolf A. Berle, Jr., veteran New Dealer and chairman of the Liberal party in New York, on leaving a halfhour conference on state politics with President Truman, asserted today that agitation for a third party in 1948 "all started on Thirteenth Street in Communist headquarters."

PARIS, July 8 -- Having failed to agree with Premier Paul Ramadies today on pay increases, the civil service unions announced tonight that they were making final preparations for a strike that, if successful, would paralyze almost every publicly administered activity with principal exceptions of the railroads and gas and electricity.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- In picturesque Wrigley Field today the American League demonstrated once again that, when it comes to grappling with its rival loop in baseball's annual midsummer classic, it still knows how to play the winning hand.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- William C. Foster, Under-Secretary of Commerce, opposed today the prohibiting or "drastically curtailing" the export of American petroleum products.
CHICAGO, July 8 -- The ball players' pension fund was a substantial winner in the All-Star game which the American League took from the National League today on Wrigley Field.

The Philharmonic-Symphony, under the direction of Alexander Smallens, played to a small audience in the moisture-laden air at Lewisohn Stadium last night. The featured work was the first New York performance of Frederick Jacobi's "Concertino for Piano and String Orchestra," with his wife, Irene Jacobi, playing the solo part.

CLEVELAND, July 8 -- A suit to halt the consolidation of ClevelandCliffs Iron Company with the Cliffs Corporation, steel holding company, on the grounds that the merger plan is illegal was filed today in Common Pleas Court on behalf of sixty-one holders of ClevelandCliffs preferred stock.

The stock market drew further strength from the soft-coal situation yesterday with the actual signing of the wage agreement and scored major increases from the inflationary aspects read into the higher pay scale. New high marks for the current upswing produced gains up to 2 points, although late realizing whittled final quotations by about half.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Harvesting of the bumper 1947 wheat crop is being hampered by some of the bad weather conditions which materially reduced the corn crop, the Department of Agriculture revealed today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8 -- The American States Utilities Company and the Cities Service Power Light Company received today from the Securities and Exchange Commission permission to reargue certain phases of their dissolution plans.

With his love of the dramatic Walter Florell gave quite a flare to the hats he presented yesterday morning. The collection represented his feeling for the fall and winter styles. It included many types from tiny theatre hats sparkling with jewel-like bead embroidery to large-brimmed beavers richly covered with flowers or feathers.

A local law freezing rents in hotels, apartment hotels, and rooming and lodging houses at their June 30 level was passed yesterday by the City Council. The control, however, will apply only for tenants who have occupied their rooms for "not less than ninety days immediately prior to July 1, 1947," or since April 2.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 8 -- Norway and Sweden have received memorandums from the Soviet Union outlining Foreign Minister Molotov's reasons for refusing to cooperate on the Marshall plan.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 8 (AP) -- Miss Grace Lenczyk, who easily disposed of her first opponent today, was paired against the only Far Western entrant in the women's national intercollegiate golf tournament for quarter-final play tomorrow.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 8 (AP) -- The Glen Riddle Farms' Merry Lass was an easy winner today over four rivals in the mile-and-asixteenth Nellie Bly Purse at Monmouth Park.

Jimmy Evans, 175 1/2, Bay Ridge, scored a technical knockout over Tommy Campanella, 181 1/2, Bay Ridge, in 45 seconds of the fifth round of the scheduled eight-round feature last night at MacArthur Stadium, Brooklyn, before a crowd of 3,500.

As monkeys go, tarsiers are not too smart, not nearly so clever as chimpanzees, for example. However, these tiny monkeys, which went on display yesterday at the Bronx Zoo, can do tricks with their ears.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 8 -- The tennis season in the Bast picked up momentum today as the annual Spring Lake invitation tournament opened at the Bathing and Tennis Club with four of the country's top ten players in the field of thirty-two.

NEW DELHI, India, July 8 -- This city's Sikh and Hindu communities today observed a one-day hartal -- a peaceful protest taking the form of a stoppage of all acivity -- as a demonstration against the splitting of the Sikh homeland between the dominions of Pakistan and India [Hindustan], as outlined on the British plan of June 3.

The practice of the Presidential veto is fraught with very real political perils for the Executive and his party. This is a lesson that the late President Roosevelt had to learn the hard way; but he did learn it, and in the later years of his Administration he rarely employed the veto with respect to measures which came to him with decisive majorities in the two Houses of Congress.

CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) -- Strictly choice steers went to $30.10 today, the highest since Jan. 16, while most cattle were steady to 40 cents higher, hogs generally were steady to 25 cents up, and sheep and lambs steady to 50 cents more.

If the Board of Estimate has completely accepted the facts in the committee report for a higher subway fare, as Mayor O'Dwyer has announced, we should be able to assume that acceptance of the conclusions will follow. The hurdle that must be taken from fact to conclusion is that of politics.

PARIS, July 8 -- Noting "with great concern" the downward trend in the market price of natural rubber, the International Rubber Study Group, concluding its session here today, decided to ask the Governments concerned to take urgent action in the matter.
When the Board of Education meets this afternoon it is expected to approve an experimental course in automobile driver training, first of its kind in the New York public school system.

A recommendation that the test for a negative Rh factor in the blood be made mandatory for married couples as a means of preventing abnormalities, such as cerebral palsy, was made yesterday at a demonstration of such cases at the Department of Rehabilitation and Physical Medicine, Bellevue Hospital.

Four issues of public utility and industrial securities, including new issues of bonds aggregating $145,000,000, and blocks of preferred and common stock priced at $15,968,814, will be placed on the market by underwriting manager here today as follows:

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- John L. Lewis signed up nearly 75 per cent of the bituminous coal industry today to unprecedented contract terms which apparently write the United Mine Workers of America out of major sections of the Taft-Hartley labor act.

With Mayor O'Dwyer remaining non-committal yesterday on the higher transit fare proposal, the Board of Estimate marked time pending a special meeting at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon, when the members may discuss the proposal further.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 8 -- With Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll and his immediate predecessor, Walter E. Edge, advancing sharply divergent views on the state constitutional convention here, the executive committee today lined up behind the former by voting to permit executives to succeed themselves in office.

The Association of Ex-Members of Squadron A, Inc., announced yesterday that it had written to all members of Congress urging prompt passage of the bill for universal military training. In urging adoption of the bill a special committee of the association approached the problem from a different viewpoint than most proponents, arguing that if war comes it will be a "people's war."

GENEVA, Switzerland, July 8 (AP) -- Belgium accused the United States and Britain of violating the Bretton Woods Agreement in a written memorandum on commercial relations with Germany circulated today to the delegates at the Economic Commission for Europe meeting here.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel Null denied yesterday a petition for reinstatement of Adrian Cabral of 923 Kelly Street, the Bronx, and Mark Kavanagh of 617 West 152d Street, transit maintenance men who were suspended on June 7 by the Board of Transportation in connection with the slowdown on the subways.

British cooperatives are in extremely strong financial condition and, if free market conditions prevailed, could spend many millions for badly needed goods, according to officials of the London Cooperative Society interviewed yesterday at the Hotel Commodore.

HAMBURG, Germany, July 8 -- Maj. Gen. W.H.A. Bishop, Deputy Chief of Staff of the British Military Government, gave an indication today that the new level of industry plan for the combined zones would ease considerably reparations demands against the Germans.

The prosecution's case against I. James Brody, former city official, and James V. Auditore, "millionaire stevedore," on charges of irregularities in the sub-leasing of city-owned piers took shape yesterday as the third defendant, Albert Gross, pleaded guilty to two counts of a seventeen-count indictment.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- In a surprise move, James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, agreed today to iron out a long-standing controversy between his union and academic institutions and music schools over the musical activities of students.
The Argentine Naval Commission, for many years centered in Washington, opened new quarters yesterday at 12 West Fifty-sixth Street.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- A curious thing about this fourteenth All Star game which gave the American League a 10-to-4 edge over its National League rivals was that three of the heroes of the lowest scoring game since the fixture was inaugurated in 1933 were in at the finish by remote control.

CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) -- Bobby Locke, the South African golf perfectionist, won the $7,000 Tam o'Shanter first prize today by shooting 140 -- four strokes under par -- and six under Ed (Porky) Oliver's 146 in their thirty-six-hole play-off.

BERLIN, July 8 -- The Berlin City Government planned a virtual sitdown strike tonight against the Allied Kommandatura as a result of a stalemate in its affairs caused by a Russian blockade of all important decisions.

TRENTON, N. J., July 8 -- A special committee of the New Jersey Welfare Council began today a drive against disintegration of the family and related juvenile delinquency. Improvement in case work and uniformity of methods by case workers will be sought as a first objective.

LONDON, July 8 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin gave a pledge to the people of the United States today that for Great Britain there would be no turning back from the task of furthering the economic unity of Europe on the basis of the Marshall proposal.

SINCE Moses laid down the law that witches must not be allowed to live, and undoubtedly for a millennium or two before that, witches have dealt in magic and ordinary folk have feared them. It is only 231 years since the penal laws against witchcraft were repealed in England. The repeal reflected a growing skepticism and humanitarianism; but belief in witchcraft has never completely died out anywhere in the western world.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 8 -- An important shift in the Communist party's tactics, promising an end to the evil of the disguised dole for hidden unemployment, was disclosed today.

The Working Committee of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission has given tentative approval to a Russian proposal that the proposed international control of atomic energy should provide for the destruction of all atomic weapons in existence, if and when a control plan becomes effective.
Fifty-one little girls competed yesterday in a pigtail contest on a West Side playground. At least as many little boys were also on hand when the beauty parade began -- watching a game of box ball.

It may not be long before the nation's duck hunters know what is in store for them next fall. The Associated Press reported yesterday from Washington that the Fish and Wildlife Service had completed the recommendations for the various zone seasons and was sending them out this week to the game commissions of the states.

The Board of Elections threw out yesterday the primary designating petitions filed by Anthony Guida, candidate for the Tammany leadership of the Sixteenth Assembly District, north, against Frank Rossetti, the incumbent. Mr. Guida has been openly backed for the leadership by Clarence H. Neal, one of the powers behind the throne in Tammany Hall until the recent election of Frank J. Sampson as leader.

DALLAS, Tex., July 8 -- A new play by Tennessee Williams, "Summer and Smoke," was given here tonight for the first time anywhere by the civic repertory company known as Theatre '47. The capacity audience, made up largely of socialite backers, gave the piece a stunning ovation.

CLEVELAND, July 8 -- With a victory over Julian J. Leavitt of Brookline, Mass., chess champion of Harvard University, in the seventh round of the finals, Larry Friedman of this city, defending titleholder, made it seven straight today in the second annual tournament for the national junior championship.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- Small allover patterns with a "calico look" are coming to the fore everywhere in the new designs for home furnishings fabrics, according to Dorothy Liebes, textile designer. She spoke today at the Home Furnishings Division of the Chicago Fashion Group here.

BERLIN, July 8 -- Taking cognizance of charges that Americans seek the economic control of western Germany, the American Military Government formally denied them today to reassure the Germans on the recent property-decontrol directive.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 8 -- Action toward founding a "new and united Protestant youth movement" was recommended tonight by the Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling in his address to the first postwar convention of the International Society of Christian Endeavor.
LONDON, July 8 -- A sharp advance in British Government securities cheered the stock markets here today.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The "willing and able" phrase which John L. Lewis put into today's new agreement between the United Mine Workers and at least 75 per cent of the operators of softcoal mines will crop up often during the life of the contract, and the inevitable dispute over its practical and legal effects has already begun.

The first major change since about 1941, from a sellers' to a buyers' market in paper products has occurred in corrugated paper cartons and prices have dropped from 10 to 15 per cent, trade spokesmen revealed here yesterday.

"We are dealing with a human problem, a world tragedy. * * * Let us join in giving [the DP's] a chance at decent and self-supporting lives." With these words to Congress, President Truman has thrown the prestige of his office behind the demand of every responsible Government, labor, civic and welfare agency that America take a fair proportion of the refugees.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 8 -- Following is the text of the Russian resolution on the report of the Balkan Investigating Commission, presented to the Security Council this afternoon: I. Having considered the report of the Security Council's Commission of Investigation concerning Greek frontier incidents, the Security Council considers as established:

BERLIN, July 8 -- Taking cognizance of charges that Americans seek the economic control of western Germany, the American Military Government formally denied them today to reassure the Germans on the recent property-decontrol directive.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 8 -- Action toward founding a "new and united Protestant youth movement" was recommended tonight by the Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling in his address to the first postwar convention of the International Society of Christian Endeavor.
LONDON, July 8 -- A sharp advance in British Government securities cheered the stock markets here today.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The "willing and able" phrase which John L. Lewis put into today's new agreement between the United Mine Workers and at least 75 per cent of the operators of softcoal mines will crop up often during the life of the contract, and the inevitable dispute over its practical and legal effects has already begun.

The first major change since about 1941, from a sellers' to a buyers' market in paper products has occurred in corrugated paper cartons and prices have dropped from 10 to 15 per cent, trade spokesmen revealed here yesterday.

"We are dealing with a human problem, a world tragedy. * * * Let us join in giving [the DP's] a chance at decent and self-supporting lives." With these words to Congress, President Truman has thrown the prestige of his office behind the demand of every responsible Government, labor, civic and welfare agency that America take a fair proportion of the refugees.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 8 -- An American plan of work for the United Nations' Commission on Conventional Armaments, previously adopted by the Commission in preference to a Russian plan, was approved by the Security Council today, 9 to 0, the Soviet Union and Poland abstaining.

Newspapers will be used for the first time, together with radio and class magazines, in the major campaign against hatlessness which the Hat Research Foundation will start in the fall, it was disclosed yesterday at the semi-annual meeting of the foundation at the Hotel Commodore.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- A quietly organized bipartisan movement aiming at curbing or killing the veto power, through which Russia has blocked United Nations actions, is under way in the Senate.

More Buyers in Market Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,156, against 1,144 in the preceding week and 863 in the similar week last year, according to listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
