Demolition work on the East River site of the United Nations future headquarters began yesterday morning after Mayor O'Dwyer had expressed the hope that the organization would construct an institution bringing freedom and liberty to all men.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 8 -- As a result of the slash in the State Department cultural and information program, the American staff of the Information Service here is being cut to one person. The Hungarian personnel is being substantially reduced.

NANKING, July 8 -- Americans in China on private or official business are dismayed by the Congressional slashes in appropriations for the United States information program, which is leading to a reduction of the staff and its activities in this country.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is to be regretted that your editorial, "Figures From Utopia," in THE TIMES of July 1 distorts what has happened to the Soviet standard of living and makes rather unfair comparison with the United States.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 8 -- Interracial movements and group and institutional practices are the "spearhead of social change" in the improvement of race relations, the American Missionary Association's fourth annual Institute of Race Relations was told today.

BATAVIA, Java, July 8 (AP) -- Fears of war in Indonesia faded tonight when the Netherlands published the text of a new note in which the Indonesian Republic accepted with one exception the Netherlands proposal for an interim national government.

Perfect Bahram just couldn't make it at Jamaica yesterday. Installed the odds-on choice at 7 to 10 in the Garrison, the Class C event that featured the program of the Empire City Racing Association, the Maine Chance Farm's 4-year-old had to be content with second place behind A.F. Plock's Ellis in the six-furlong dash.

Reporting "tremendous" demand for modernization by automobile dealers. R.L. Paulson, director of dealer building design and layout for the General Motors Corporation, yesterday estimated this market at over $750,000,000.

Plans for erection of a $500,000 plant on a five-acre plot in South Hackensack, N.J., to produce complete pre-cooked dinners were announced yesterday by the Alexander Summer Company, brokers, who assembled the plot in conjunction with Nicholas Volk of New York.

CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) -- The play-by-play of the All-Star baseball game at Wrigley Field today follows: FIRST INNING AMERICAN -- Kell became a strikeout victim, swinging at Blackwell's sweeping curve after fouling two into the stands.

At least thirty-six feature films will be released by RKO Radio Pictures during the 1947-48 season, it was announced yesterday by Ned E. Depinet, executive vice president, at the company's sixteenth annual sales meeting at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

Cleveland, Ohio, awarded an issue of $8,000,000 of water works revenue bonds due from 1953 to 1972 and callable in 1958 to a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at an interest cost of 1.808 per cent. The bid was 100.004 for 2s, 2 1/2 s and 1 3/4 s.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 8 -- Formation of the 102d Medium Maintenance Ordnance Company as a unit of the new National Guard organization to be quartered in the armory here was announced today by Guard headquarters at Camp Smith.
In an active and buoyant market cotton futures made net gains of 75 to 109 points yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

The Lehman Corporation during its fiscal year ended with last June reduced its common stock holdings in the automotive, rubber, merchandising and miscellaneous manufacturing fields and increased its holdings in the oil and building and construction industries, the annual report issued by Robert Lehman, president, disclosed yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, July 8 (U.P.) -- Argentina's attitude toward foreign capital did an about-face today when the powerful Central Bank decided to remove all restrictions on the entry of foreign capital to this country.

In search of a leading man for their offering of "Eastward in Eden," Beatrice Straight and Nancy Stern went to London. According to word received here, their mission has been accomplished. They are said to have engaged Denis O'Dea, a stalwart of Dublin's Abbey Theatre company, who appeared here several times with the famous acting group in the 1930's and also in independent presentations.

Another Persian prince made travel news yesterday. This time it was not the 15-year-old Prince Hamid-Riza Pahlevi, who flew to Paris on June 24 to escape attending school in this country, but an older brother, Prince Abdor-Riza Pahlevi, Harvard graduate, class of '47.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8 -- A $2,000,000 push-button system of telegraphy, the largest in a new country-wide network being set up by the Western Union Telegraph Company, was demonstrated today. Company officials said the system would triple the capacity of the office here.

With Newark's City Commission standing 3 to 2 for a qualified acceptance of the Port of New York Authority's offer to lease and develop Newark's airport and marine terminal, the two bodies will meet here this afternoon in an effort to settle the long-standing controversy.

A further hearing on July 22 on the alternate plans for obtaining $6,163,693 to pay off the debentures of the Equitable Office Building Corporation, 120 Broadway, was ordered yesterday by Federal Judge John C. Knox.

A procession of hotel chambermaids and waitresses appealed to State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi at a public hearing in the State Office Building yesterday for a forty-hour work week to protect their health, and to give them time and a half for overtime.

Thirty-three property owners in the Rockaways pleaded guilty to fire hazard violations in Kew Gardens Magistrate's Court yesterday and were granted two weeks by Magistrate Edward Thompson in which to show good faith in correcting the infractions.

Investors Mutual Four directors were elected to the board of Investors Mutual, Inc. at the annual meeting of stock holders held yesterday in Minneapolis. E.E. Crabb, president and board chairman, announced. They include Carl R. Gray Jr., vice president of the Chicago and North Western Railway system; B.C. Gamble, chairman of the board of Gamble-Skogmo, Inc. and of the Western Auto Supply Company:

JERUSALEM, July 8 -- The death sentences against three terrorists who participated in the Acre prison break on May 4 were confirmed today by Lieut. Gen. G.H.A. MacMillan, the British commander. A few hours later five separate appeals for clemency had been made to Lieut. Gen. Sir Alan Cunningham, the High Commissioner.

PITTSBURGH, July 8 -- With hundreds of miners already at their jobs in the big bituminous fields of Pennsylvania, industry spokesmen estimated tonight that 60,000 to 70,000 of the state's miners would be back by tomorrow morning.
After nearly two years' delay, the city Board of Health tightened its control yesterday on the sale of common sleeping potions over the protests of organized druggists.

Erwin Feldman, director and counsel of the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers, yesterday proposed that the house dress industry make every effort to inform retailers that intensive purchasing activity by piece goods buyers with a view toward increasing over-the-counter sales constitutes a real threat to volume of ready-made house dress departments.

LONDON, July 8 -- The Burmese good-will mission started back for Rangoon today in what was authoritatively described as the friendliest of moods. Britons are more than ever convinced that, given time and careful handling, Burma will yet decide to join the British Commonwealth in company with the two new Indian dominions.
NANKING, July 8 (AP) -- Eighty thousand refugees stranded in Tsingtao by China's civil war were added to the Government's worries today.

LLANGOLLEN, Wales, July 8 (Reuters) -- For the first time in the history of the Welsh Eisteddfod (music festival) no Welsh choir took part in the male voice contest at the Llangollen International Eisteddfod, which has just been held here.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- Buying activity during the first two days of the summer furniture and home furnishings market has been spotty, industry sources revealed today. Merchandise which has been in limited supply was in active demand, but other lines of goods in general have been on the shopping list.

Negotiating committees of the Bethlehem Steel Company and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, agreed yesterday to a threeday adjournment to study a "fresh approach" toward possible solution of the shipyard strike.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 7 (Delayed) -- The Turkish DemocratRepublican struggle of the last month took an acute turn tonight when the Democratic party leader, Jelal Bayar, accused the Government of Premier Recep Peker of terrorism and hampering democratic progress.
LONDON, July 8 -- The Government moved today to free a German war prisoner from jail and speed his marriage to his son's British mother.

ROME, July 8 -- Ratification of the Italian peace treaty ran into unexpected difficulties today when a strong current of opinion contrary to such a step developed in the Constituent Assembly's international Treaties Committee.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- A profound revision of the system of military justice which would sharply reduce the traditional powers of combat commanders over men breaking the Articles of War was recommended today to the House Armed Services Committee by a subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The House passed the Republicans' new tax reduction bill today, 302 to 112, in what was by far the most emphatic demonstration it has given in support of such a measure at this session.

Day by day it becomes clearer that the Marshall challenge has done more than anything else since the liberation to change the mind and stir the spirit of Europe. Just the suggestion that they could do something for themselves, plan for their own future, was like the opening of a dead-end street for the nations of that continent.

A musical "field day" featuring the Boston Symphony Orchestra, under the baton of Serge Koussevitzky, and various instruments for musical reproduction, will be held at Tanglewood, Lenox, Mass., on Tuesday, July 29.

BERLIN, July 8 -- United States civilians legally in Germany are becoming increasingly restive under the arbitrary regulations imposed by the military commanders and to which they must conform or get out.

Manufacturers' unit labor costs continued rising at the beginning of 1947, while the large gains in output per man-hour, predicted for shortly after the war, did not materialize, according to an analysis of productivity and labor cost trends, issued yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- President Truman submitted to Congress today an exhaustive plan for the financial stability and economic require additional foreign credits recovery of the Philippine Republic through tax reforms and increased production and trade.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The United States faced today the prospect of the smallest supply of cotton for the coming marketing year in nearly a quarter of a century.

Joseph F. Taggard, a city housing inspector, who was suspended on June 12, went on trial yesterday before his superior, Robert F. Wagner Jr., Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, on charges of having failed to explain how he deposited $5,100 in a bank while receiving a salary of $4,130 annually.

PARIS, July 8 -- Twelve countries in addition to the inviting powers, France and Great Britain, now have agreed to attend the conference here Saturday on United States aid to Europe. Reports from the north today indicated the probability of favorable replies from the three Scandinavian countries, which would mean fifteen acceptances out of twenty-two invited.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- July corn broke 4 cents from yesterday's high and closed at the low point to a fraction above on the Board of Trade today, or 3 1/4 to 3 3/8 cents a bushel lower at $2.13 1/2 to $2.13 1/4, after having advanced 34 3/8 cents from the low set on June 16.

Despite a continued Russian propaganda barrage against it, the second conference on European reconstruction is already assured of sufficient attendance to make it the potential turning point in post-war history. Of a total of twenty-two nations invited, twelve, in addition to Great Britain and France -- the inviting nations -- have already announced their acceptance.

JERUSALEM, July 8 -- Speaking as a private citizen, Dr. Chaim Weizmann, former president of the world Zionist organization, implored the United Nations today to deliver a quick and effective decision for the establishment of a Zionist state in an area of Palestine large enough to accommodate 1,500,000 more Jewish colonists.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Under running fire for lack of action on the nomination of Philip B. Pearlman of Maryland, as Solicitor General, Senator Homer Ferguson of Michigan today ordered a series of judiciary subcommittee meetings to speed a decision.

Despite a continued Russian propaganda barrage against it, the second conference on European reconstruction is already assured of sufficient attendance to make it the potential turning point in post-war history. Of a total of twenty-two nations invited, twelve, in addition to Great Britain and France -- the inviting nations -- have already announced their acceptance.

JERUSALEM, July 8 -- Speaking as a private citizen, Dr. Chaim Weizmann, former president of the world Zionist organization, implored the United Nations today to deliver a quick and effective decision for the establishment of a Zionist state in an area of Palestine large enough to accommodate 1,500,000 more Jewish colonists.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Under running fire for lack of action on the nomination of Philip B. Pearlman of Maryland, as Solicitor General, Senator Homer Ferguson of Michigan today ordered a series of judiciary subcommittee meetings to speed a decision.

Our First People One way to try to understand the United States is to consult some of the new books on the subject which continue to flow from the press, popular or scholarly, along with some of the older books, of course.

MOSCOW, July 8 (AP) -- Indicating wide successes on the economic front, the Soviet Union's State Planning Commission reported today that for the second quarter of 1947 crop acreage was 20,000,000 acres higher and industrial production 15 per cent higher than for the same quarter last year.

Unpegged Bills Traders in Government securities hazarded yesterday that the range of bidding on the first series of newly unpegged weekly Treasury bill offerings was exploratory and inconclusive. The range of yields represented by the Treasury's acceptance of bids was from a basis of 0.748 per cent, to 0.372 per cent, with the average 0.594 per cent.

Celestial crockery had the Army up in the air for several hours yesterday before an Army officer explained that what a colleague thought was "a flying disk" was nothing more than a battered Army weather balloon.

GENEVA, Switzerland, July 8 -- International amity received a second jolt today when British and American delegates to the International Labor Organization's conference squared off against Argentine representatives in the worker delegates' section.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 8 -- The Soviet Union today disapproved a United States proposal for the establishment of a semipermanent Balkan frontier commission, and urged that the United Nations Security Council recommend the withdrawal of foreign troops and foreign military personnel from Greece.

Cases of acute communicable diseases -- the most common of which are diphtheria, scarlet fever, measles and whooping cough -- should be admitted into the city's general hospitals, according to reommendations that the Hospital Council of Greater New York made public yesterday.

PARIS, July 8 -- The Conference for European Economic Cooperation to prepare the ground for the United States aid will receive a report from the special International Emergency Food Council conference that opens here tomorrow to study means of minimizing this year's world grain deficit.

It has become a saying in trade circles that present-day transportation has done away with "seasons" so far as fresh fruits and vegetables are concerned. The tomatoes that used to be enjoyed only in warm weather are with us the year 'round, and this goes, too, for lettuce and green peas and snap beans.

MADISON, N.J., July 8 -- Georges S. Burgess, who feels strongly that the peace and quiet of this residential town in the New Jersey hills has been shattered forever by air-beating planes, today made public his invitation to James M. Landis, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board in Washington, to spend a week-end at the Burgess home here.

Cases of acute communicable diseases -- the most common of which are diphtheria, scarlet fever, measles and whooping cough -- should be admitted into the city's general hospitals, according to reommendations that the Hospital Council of Greater New York made public yesterday.

PARIS, July 8 -- The Conference for European Economic Cooperation to prepare the ground for the United States aid will receive a report from the special International Emergency Food Council conference that opens here tomorrow to study means of minimizing this year's world grain deficit.

It has become a saying in trade circles that present-day transportation has done away with "seasons" so far as fresh fruits and vegetables are concerned. The tomatoes that used to be enjoyed only in warm weather are with us the year 'round, and this goes, too, for lettuce and green peas and snap beans.

Outbound passengers at La Guardia Field were bewildered yesterday when they found that as they boarded planes for points within the United States and Canada they had to undergo the close scrutiny of two pretty girls in uniform who stood at each side of the planes' doors.

The stock market experienced yesterday its first reversal after nine consecutive sessions of rising prices, but only after the list had shown firmness for the greater part of the day. Gains which earlier in the session ranged beyond a point in a few issues and major fractions in the main section of the market were eliminated and in the majority of instances, gave way to losses with the composite rate lowered 0.51 point.

S. Kip Farrington Jr. of Easthampton, L. I., has been named chairman of the executive committee that will run the resumed international tuna tournament at Wedgeport, N. S., in September. The appointment was made at a meeting of the board of directors at which details for the competition involving teams from the United States, the British Empire and Cuba were divulged.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 9 -- Norway, Sweden and Denmark, whose foreign and trade ministers met here today, agreed to accept the Anglo-French invitation to attend the Paris conference on European self aid.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Clarence Francis, chairman of the board of General Foods Corporation, said today that average food prices might be down "as much as 15 per cent" by harvest time in 1948.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Southern Coal Producers Association capitulated today to John L. Lewis' terms for the operation of their mines.

William M. Hickey, president of the United Corporation, made public yesterday details of a proposed amendment to the plan for retirement of the remaining 1,136,199 $3 preference shares of the company.

BERLIN, July 9 -- The United States became today the first of the occupying powers to name any war plants in its territory as having been completely expurgated of their war potentials. Certificates of liquidation of six plants will be submitted Friday to the Allied Control Council war plants bureau.

The latest threat of a Communist coup in Athens seems to have been timed to coincide with the reopening of discussion of the Greek question by the Security Council of the United Nations. The Council is considering the report of its Balkan investigating commission, charging Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Albania with aiding the Greek guerrillas, and proposing to establish a semi-permanent United Nations frontier commission to halt such activities.

American companies now engaged in export may well consider the possibility of surveying foreign markets to see what goods they can import and merchandise here, Harold Sweatt, president of the Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company, said in an interview yesterday at the Hotel RitzCarlton.

Canadian Gold The offer of the American Smelting and Refining Company to provide a free market abroad for certain gold-mining companies in Canada is expected to have some repercussion from officials of the International Monetary Fund.

Denunciation of the Taft-Hartley Labor Law was the keynote of the majority of speeches yesterday as the Atlantic Coast District Convention of the International Longshoremen's Association got under way at the Hotel Commodore.

Here's a true fish story. Last winter a community drive in Flatbush induced the New York State Department of Conservation to stock the Prospect Park Lake with calico bass for youngsters up to 16 years old. The department said "No Fishing" signs were to apply to adults.

Expressing hope that "we have stopped talking ourselves into a recession," Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, predicted yesterday that business will be good for the remainder of this year and probably for several years to come.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Powerful organizational and religious support was thrown behind the Stratton displaced persons bill today as representatives of the Labor Department, the National Conference of Catholic Charities and the Catholic and Jewish War Veterans advocated a favorable report before a House Judiciary subcommittee.

JERUSALEM, July 9 -- The recent British measures against unauthorized Jewish immigration to Palestine have been so effective, a spokesman for Haganah declared today, that the immigration scheme must be completely reorganized. Haganah, the Zionist movement's militia, is the principal organizer of unauthorized immigration.

Antony Wright, formerly manager of the television receiver engineering section of the Radio Corporation of America, has been appointed chief engineer of the United States Television Manufacturing Corporation.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Mrs. J. L. Blair Buck, new president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, today said in her first press conference that she expects to work hard for passage of legislation to admit displaced persons. The federation changed its stand on this bill at the recent New York convention.

The American Repertory Theatre, which was sharply criticized last season for its choice of revivals from the standpoint of boxoffice appeal, has just tabulated the results of a survey through which it tried to learn what plays the theatre-going public wants most to see revived.

Mrs. Sheila Mannering, 49 years old, a former motion picture and radio actress, was found dead yesterday morning in her apartment at 333 West Fifty-seventh Street. She had been strangled with a bed sheet. The police said that the circumstances indicated she had been slain by someone she knew.

Deep in the stretch it looked like a lost cause, but Larney Hansman kept booting away with William Helis Elpis in the $25,000added Comely Handicap at Jamaica yesterday, and the result was a last-gasp decision for the 12-to-1 shot.

CLEVELAND, July 9 -- Larry Friedman, 17-year-old Cleveland player, was settled safely in first place beyond the reach of his nearest rivals today and retained the national junior chess championship. Regardless of what may happen in the last round tomorrow, the position of the champion is unassailable because of the onepoint lead he established in the preliminaries.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 9 -- Frederick H. Osborn, deputy United States representative, urged the Controls Committee of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission today to limit atomic research by individual countries in all cases where the amount of nuclear fuel produced could become of "military significance."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 9 -- A public referendum every twenty years on the question of the revision of the New Jersey Constitution was urged upon the Constitutional Convention today by James Kerney Jr., editor of The Trenton Times and president of the New Jersey Committee for Constitutional Revision, to make the charter "more accessible" to the people.
The "Dither of the Disks" yesterday was spinning erratically somewhere between Mars and what a learned social psychologist termed "the projection of e delusion."

Opposition to establishment of a branch of Long Island University on the estate of Mrs. Joseph E. Davies at Oyster Bay, L.I., is largely the work of "a vocal minority, Tristram Walker Metcalfe, president of the university charged yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Transportation took steps today to obtain the prompt return of United States freight cars, particularly coal cars, from Canadian rail lines.

On April 21, 1947, in Capetown South Africa, a serious-faced young woman spoke quaveringly into a microphone in a small broadcasting studio. Her voice, carried to millions in all parts of the world, pronounced these solemn words of self-dedication:

LONDON, July 9 -- Despite a blunt warning from Lord Hyndley, chairman of the National Coal Board, that miners are "failing to justify the five-day week," the Government feels that the present pessimism on the fuel outlook is "overdone."

Caught in the log-jam that always piles up in Congress toward the end of a session, the Langer-Chavez-Stevenson Postal Retirement bill is still held up on the calendars of both Houses. As a matter of simple justice it should be voted into law.

ATHENS, July 9 -- In a sweeping operation that the Greek Government announced forestalled a Communist revolution scheduled for 1 A. M. tomorrow, some 2,300 persons in Athens, Piraeus and their environs and some 500 in the provinces were arrested between 3 and 5 o'clock this morning.
PARIS, July 9 -- A strike of I 1,200,000 Government and municipal employes was put off today at least until tomorrow night. When the Government is expected to present its final proposals.
The biggest narcotics seizure in the Port of New York in the last four months was made yesterday by two veteran members of the Customs searching squad.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (U.P.) -- Representative George A. Dondero, Republican, of Michigan, asserted today that Communist sympathizers in the past had infiltrated into key War Department posts and that Secretary Robert P. Patterson's failure to ferret them out "endangers our national security."

Although a former member of the Greek royal house, Lieut. Philip Mountbatten has not a drop Greek blood in his veins. A great-great grandson of Britain's Queen Victoria, a Prince of Denmark, a descendant of the German line of Battenburg, now Mountbatten, second cousin to his future father-in-law and third cousin to his bride-elect -- that is the pedigree of Lieut. Philip Mountbatten.

The name of John L. Lewis has become a symbol in the past two or three years for power -- political power, with which he dazzles rival union leaders, and economic power, which he has wielded, and continues to wield, with ruthless disregard of its consequences to American life.
To judge by the records for the first half of this year, more babies will be born to Father Knickerbocker during 1947 than for any previous year.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 9 -- The American Federation of Labor has asked the United Nations Economic and Social Council to establish international measures to protect the working conditions of migratory labor, it was announced today.
LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., July 9 -- A family turnout of 31 teams playing alternate shots toured the hilly Cedar Creek Club course today in a one-day Women's Long Island Golf Association tournament.

The shipyards strike that is holding nineteen major yards and 67,000 workers idle rounded out its second week yesterday in an air of peaceful inactivity. The only meeting held was one here between officials of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, and representatives of the Todd Shipyards Corporation, whose yards are not on strike.

LONDON, Thursday, July 10 -- John van Druten won the praise of London's drama critics today for the skillful writing of his play, "The Voice of the Turtle," which was presented at the Piccadilly Theatre last night. Their qualifications were reserved for what most of them thought was slenderness of subject matter and for Margaret Sullavan's acting in the part of Sally.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Walter S. Tower, of New York, president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, said today he foresees no continuing shortage of steel in this country.

Americans have a cousinly and affectionate interest in the life of the English Royal Family. They will hasten to share with the King and Queen the pleasure expressed in the court circular announcement that Princess Elizabeth and Lieut. Philip Mountbatten, R.N., are engaged to marry.

CHICAGO, July 9 (AP) -- Hal Price Headley's Pellicle smashed an American grass course record for the second consecutive time when he galloped home an easy winner of the $25,000 Grassland Handicap before 19,000 spectators at Arlington Park today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 9 -- Film producers and the Screen Actors Guild today are understood to be near an agreement whereby negotiations regarding a new contract may be carried on for another year if necessary. Should this plan prevail it will be accomplished by extending until Aug. 1, 1948, the present contract under which the actors are working.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 9 -- Twenty students representing eleven Eastern colleges will report for work at the United Nations' headquarters tomorrow morning as "internes" in international organization, under a new program arranged by the United Nations training division.
Prices continued to rise on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, and at the close were 35 to 46 points net higher than Tuesday's final levels.

Two reports from Europe suggest that the Marshall plan is running into competition. One, from Vienna, quotes the official organ of the Communist party to the effect that a Molotov plan for the economic reorganization of Central and Eastern Europe is being prepared in Moscow.
LONDON, July 9 -- The British are making one last and rather despairing effort to conclude their trade pact with the Soviet Union, it was learned today.

To the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES: Quite apart from any political consideration, I trust the editorial in your issue of June 20 under the caption of "A Bill to Hinder Trade" will be widely read and digested.
LONDON, July 9 -- Generally London critics were full of praise today for "Deep Are the Roots," which opened at Wyndham's Theatre last evening.

To the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES: Recently the Disabled American Veterans of the State of New York, at their annual convention, reaffirmed their intense belief in the vital need for Universal Military Training. The convention as a body voted to wire Senators Wagner and Ives and all Representatives from the State of New York that they feel the security of the nation is at stake in this issue.

GENEVA, July 9 -- A proposal for establishing a clearing house for Europe in which net trade balances of European countries would be settled in dollars furnished by the United States will be proposed at Paris talks, it was reliably reported here today.

The newly opened Leslie House at 30 West Fifty-sixth Street, boasts an unusual decor, a managing director once associated with the Stork and an excellent head chef. The latter is Achille Placchi, for many years with the Moulin Rouge in Paris and later saucecook at the popular Italian Pavilion at the World's Fair.

JERUSALEM, July 9 -- The Jewish Agency for Palestine concluded the presentation of its case before the United Nations inquiry committee today without indications that it had converted any substantial part of the committee to the idea of a Zionist state in either all or part of the country.

DALLAS, Tex., July 9 (U.P.) -- Night baseball definitely will shorten the playing span of major league players, Babe Ruth, who spent twenty-two profitable years in the big time, told a group of American Legion junior baseball, players today.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 9 -- Rumania's rejection today of the Anglo-French invitation to the Paris recovery talks was based on the opinion that the Marshall project was not sufficiently clear to make the prospect of the United States seem a reality.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (U.P.) -- The War Department announced today a command shakeup in which Lieut. Gen. J. Lawton (Lightning Joe) Collins, mentioned as a possible successor to the Chief of Staff, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, will become deputy Chief of Staff on Sept. 1.

American, retail merchandising and management methods are sorely needed in Ireland, Mary Ellen Clancy, treasurer of the Mail Advertising Service Association and proprietor of her own business at 250 Park Avenue, disclosed yesterday following her return from an extended visit in Dublin.

The sharp difference of opinion in the matter of margin requirements that exists between officials of the Federal Reserve System and leaders in the nation's securities markets was brought into the open yesterday by the release of correspondence exchanged between them.

GENEVA, July 9 -- The Soviet Union is planning to press its demand that the two-thirds majority voting system rather than the simple majority method shall be included in the permanent rules of procedure for the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, it was learned today.

PARIS, July 9 (Reuters) -- The moderate newspaper Ce Matin said today that although there was need to give the five settlements of French India a special status, it was in France's interest to remain in India, "which is half-way between Africa and Indo-China."

HAMBURG, Germany, July 9 -- The German advisory council completely rejected today the British Military Government's plan for land reform. Presenting the plan to the council, Lieut. Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, Deputy Military Governor, asked last month that the group seek no drastic changes in the proposals.

OTTAWA, July 9 (AP) -- Financial and mining circles showed keen interest today in a report from Toronto that the American Smelting and Refining Company has offered to sell gold to foreign buyers at more than the official price of $35 an ounce.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Witnesses today continued their testimony on the Taft bill for Federal aid to the indigent poor and the Murray bill for compulsory national health insurance as the Senate Public Welfare subcommittee members continued charges and counter-charges of "propaganda."

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- A quietly mobilized, bipartisan movement in Congress to strengthen the United Nations through a curbing of veto powers and other charter revisions spread and broke into the open today.

BERLIN, July 9 -- Americans working for, or at the mercy of, the United States Army in Germany run into an endless maze of bureaucratic red tape if they are so foolhardy as to try to hire a servant or other employe.

MUNICH, Germany, July 9 -- The sixty-day ration plan, initiated by former Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia of New York as head of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, to assure a new start in life in their homelands for repatriates, is being circumvented, especially by the Poles, according to reports in various communities of the American zone of occupation.

MANCHESTER, July 9 (Reuters) -- England today defeated South Africa by seven wickets in the third test cricket match and took a lead of two victories to no defeats, with one match drawn. Two matches remain to be played.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm income, including Government payments, was about 25 per cent higher during the first half of this year than in the first six months of 1946.

The new Consolidated B-36 bomber, largest of the world's combat planes, cannot be mass produced as it is now designed, a recent trip to the Consolidated Fort Worth plant and talks with industrial mobilization experts disclosed.

Advertising linage in New York Newspapers during the first six months of the year totaled 70,564,266 lines a gain of 15.19 per cent over the corresponding period last year, according to a compilation by Media Records. A loss, however, was recorded for financial, 21.82 per cent Gains were shown for automotive, 105.98 per cent; retail, 18.12 per cent; general, 14.05 per cent, and classified, 7.05 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Two hundred top officials of American Federation of Labor unions today adopted a six-point policy statement on the Taft-Hartley Labor Act based on the belief that it would "weaken, render impotent and destroy labor unions."

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Senate passed by a voice vote tonight the bill which would unify the armed forces, create an independent air force and integrate all the war-making potentials of the country in the defense system.

There will be no decision by the Board of Estimate on the proposed eight-cent fare on the subway and elevated lines until after Controller Lazarus Joseph returns next week from his vacation upstate, it was reported yesterday at City Hall.

HAMILTON, N.Y., July 9 -- Maynard Krueger, former national ! chairman of the Socialist party and Vice Presidential candidate in 1940, told the New York Institute of International Relations at Colgate University today that "Americans have assumed the dangerous tendency of thinking of a superstate as the solution to our problems."

Prof. Maximilian Philip, for forty-five years a teacher of mathematics at City College, has retired as chairman of the department of mathematics, effective Sept. 1, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college.

TOKYO, July 9 -- The Japanese Government today promised to eliminate after the next harvest the long delays in distribution of rationed food at fixed prices -- one principal cause of the black market. Such ration delays also have been a factor necessitating large releases to the Japanese people of foodstuffs imported from the United States on credit, which this year amounted to more than 500,- 000 tons.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Constantin Tsaldaris, the Greek Foreign Minister who is in this country for meetings of the United Nations, held extended conferences this afternoon with Secretary of State Marshall and with other ranking officers of the State Department regarding conditions in Greece, including the large-scale Communist arrests there.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 -- Dock workers affiliated with the CIO International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union agreed today to postpone from 8 A.M. until 5 P.M. tomorrow a strike against West Coast steam schooners.

The Carroll Club, 120 Madison Avenue, is seeking fifty volunteers to aid the summer program of its joint emergency committee, Miss Helen M. Feeney, the director, reported yesterday. She explained that the workers were needed to sew religious articles and to pack food and clothing for relief abroad.

NEW DELHI, July 9 (Reuters) -- Police used tear gas today to disperse a crowd in Chandni Chowk, business center of the old city of Delhi, after the arrest of eight Khaksars ("servants of dust" -- extreme Moslem volunteers) in the area. Nine other Khaksars were arrested in another area of old Delhi.

A letter of congratulations and welcome to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower on his appointment as president of Columbia University has been sent by the Columbia chapter of the American Veterans Committee, Walter C. Taylor, chapter chairman, announced yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 9 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York arrived here tonight for conferences with Republican leaders of Kansas and Missouri that may assure him of the united support of these two key mid-western states for his party's presidential nomination next year.
PITTSBURGH, Pa., July 9 -- Soft coal production was at about 50 per cent of capacity today as thousands of miners failed to return to the pits under their new wage contract.

AMSTERDAM, July 9 (ANETA) -- The market rose sharply in active trading on the Stock Exchange, reflecting optimism concerning developments in the Indonesian situation. Indies plantations issues, shipping shares and oil stocks registered gains, while industrials and banking stocks were irregular. State bonds were firm.
LONDON, July 9 -- Plain speaking by Lord President of the Council Herbert Morrison in the imports debate in the House of Commons yesterday had no adverse effect on stock markets here today.

The Beekman-Downtown Hospital yesterday filed plans for its new building to be erected at 170-80 William Street and estimated the cost at $4,000,000. The plans were prepared by Eggers Higgins, architects, and call for a nine-story and penthouse structure with basement, cellar and subcellar.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Political trade winds, blowing hot and in the same westerly direction that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York is pursuing, are beckoning to other likely candidates for 1948, not the least of them President Truman.

Charles L. Wagner, concert and opera manager, was elected president of the League of Grand Opera Producers Association at a meeting of the newly formed organization held in Steinway Hall Monday, it was announced yesterday. Fortune Gallo was chosen vice president, Felix W. Salmaggi executive secretary and Michael De Pace treasurer.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Senate Finance Committee approved the Republicans' new personal income tax reduction bill today by a bipartisan vote of ten to three.

LONDON, July 9 -- True love had its way today when King George VI gave his consent to the betrothal of his daughter, Princess Elizabeth, to Lieut. Philip Mountbatten, the former Prince Philip of Greece. They will be married before next spring and probably as early as October.

The quarter-billion dollar program of the Port of New York Authority for the lease and integrated development of the major airports in this area was made complete yesterday. Except for certain formalities, a majority of the Newark City Commission agreed to include that airport and marine terminal in the plan.

PARIS, July 9 -- Self-help among the European nations as the prerequisite to aid from the United States and other exporting nations was the keynote of the address today by John Strachey, British Food Minister, to the special International Cereals Conference of thirtythree nations assembled here today.
NANKING, July 9 -- A disagreement between China and the United States may delay indefinitely implementation of the Fulbright Bill cultural program for China.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 9 -- Led by W. H. (Rube) Williams, the Rumson, N. J., polo quartet topped Jericho, 9-5, in one of the two opening round matches of the Hempstead Cup handicap tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today.
PHILADELPHIA, July 9 -- Registration statements covering 1,027,000 shares of common stock were filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today by two companies.

A statement opposing universal military training was sent yesterday to members of Congress by officers and members of the national committee of the Church League for Industrial Democracy, an Episcopalian social research and action organization.

Sportswear to Be Shown Oct. 6 The complete resort and spring collections of the Sportswear Guild member companies will be presented in the week beginning Oct. 6, it was announced yesterday. The collections introduced at that time will be the only ones that the companies will present for the whole of the resort and spring season.

An 11-year-old -boy, after clinging to the outside of a subway car on a terrifying six-block ride, was injured fatally yesterday when the train sped into a station and he was crushed or flung against the station structure. The boy fell unconscious onto the platform and died in an ambulance on the way to Unity Hospital.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 9 -- Minority groups should unite in a strategy for a common goal rather than a strategy against a common enemy, the American Missionary Association's Institute of Race Relations was told today.

The Board of Estimate at a special meeting approved yesterday the establishment of a New York City Youth Board of thirteen unsalaried members, functioning as an agency of the Mayor's office to coordinate and supplement the activities of public, private and religious agencies devoted in whole or in part to the welfare and protection of the city's children.

Democratic supporters of Representative Vito Marcantonio, New York County chairman of the American Labor party, suffered a double set-back yesterday when the Board of Elections invalidated the petitions of Frank A. Holecek and Martin X. Cawley.
To the editor of the new york times : Daniel A. Poling has written, in the times of June 29, a thorough rationalization for military training, but it is almost completely erroneous.

As the result of a switch in sponsorship, the adventures of Sherlock Holmes will return to the air in the fall, probably early October, the cast, time and network all changed, it become known yesterday. The series closed for the vacation season Monday night on the WJZ-ABC hook-up, with Tom Conway and Nigel Bruce playing the detective and Dr. Watson, respectively.

George A. Garrett, recently appointed United States Minister to Eire, was among the 992 passengers who left here yesterday for Europe on the United States liner America. The ship sailed from Pier 61, North River, at 4:13 P.M. for Cobh, Cherbourg and Southampton.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Senate Finance Committee approved today a bill to freeze the Social Security payroll tax at the present rate until Jan. 1, 1950.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- It was strictly accidental, of course, but Ted Williams called the turn on the All-Star game long before it was played. He was talking about Johnny Sain of the Braves. The grinning Red Sox star became rather violent as he began to describe Sain's pitching technique since Ted did all with gestures.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Two war veterans' organizations, the American Legion and Amvets, urged Congress today to move swiftly to enact a universal military training law. On the other side, officials of the Young Progressive Citizens of America, the American Veterans Committee and the Socialist party opposed such legislation.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 9 -- Deszo Sulyok, leader of the Liberty party, today denounced the new Hungarian election law's "recommendation system." According to that system, the political parties not represented in the governing coalition must obtain notarized signatures in each electoral district before such parties can run candidates.

While garage owners threatened to discontinue delivery of cars to motorists' homes unless the police and courts "stopped persecuting" them, Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger in Washington Heights Traffic Court yesterday adjourned hearings on overtime parking summonses issued to thirteen garage employes and forty-five car owners despite their willingness to plead guilty and pay a fine.
NANKING, China, July 9 (U.P.) -- A Central News Agency dispatch from Tihua charged today that Outer Mongolian troops and planes had made four new attacks on Chinese positions in Sinkiang Province.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 -- Told in a message from President Truman that the Christian Endeavor movement was "one of the most significant and dynamic forces for world peace," 2,000 delegates to the convention of the International Society of Christian Endeavor today began discussion of post-war policies and program.

Braagaard has succeeded in carrying his customary sense of delicacy in millinery design over into this season when hats are assuming greater proportions and importance. In the hats shown yesterday in his West Fifty-seventh Street establishment, he found a way of utilizing color and manipulating materials so that they tell the story of the new hat look without over-dramatization of crown or brim.

Yara Bernette, Brazilian pianist, whose recital debut took place at Town Hall five years ago, made her first New York appearance with orchestra last night when she played with the New York PhilharmonicSymphony at the Lewisohn Stadium.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- Scattered liquidation developed in July corn and oats on the Board of Trade today, causing a lower range of prices, but all deliveries of wheat and the distant months in corn and oats showed strength, with corn in the lead.

NEW DELHI, India, July 9 -- The rulers and Premiers of some of the leading Princely States of India opened consultations here today on the future relationships of Royal India with the new Dominion Governments.

RYE, N. Y., July 9 -- One of these fine days Mal Galletta, 36-year-old Long Island building contractor belonging to the North Hills Club in Douglaston, is going to win the New York State amateur qualifying medal outright.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Norman Armour, Assistant Secretary of State in charge of political relations abroad, encouraged Russia today to reconsider her attitude toward the Marshall plan for the economic rehabilitation of Europe and to attend the Paris Conference of interested states on Saturday.

CINCINNATI, July 9 -- Pledging an all-out campaign to obtain immediate passage of a Federal aid to education bill, 2,500 delegates attending the National Education Association convention adopted, without a dissenting voice, a report calling for Federal support of the nation's public schools.

Following a relatively lean first quarter, seven, international airnes flying the Atlantic between Europe and the United States hit new peaks in the second quarter for numbers of flights and passeners and poundage of mail and express carried, according to a round-up of figures that are unofficial but are believed to be acurate.

Instructors at the Arthur Murray Dance Studio at 342 Madison Avenue changed from their dancing pumps to their walking shoes yesterday when a strike was called by Local 16 of the United Office and Professional Workers of America, CIO.

Thirty Westchester County and New York policemen fished hard at the foot of 135th Street and the Harlem River for six hours yesterday and came up with a crowbar and a pinchbar. The 525-pound safe they were seeking was still resting in the murky waters -- believed to contain $60,000 worth of Soviet mining bonds and $6,000 worth of heirloom jewelry.

An effort by Italian artists to reach an American market was denounced yesterday by the National Better Business Bureau. Thousands of individuals and business concerns are being "stuck" with customs duty charges on unordered etchings sent from Genoa, the bureau charged.

The Board of Estimate speeded yesterday city control of rents for permanent tenants in hotels, apartment hotels and rooming and lodging houses. The board in a special meeting approved unanimously the City Council emergency measure fixing such rents at their June 30 level and creating a rent commission to administer the law and "correct inequities."

SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 9 -- Shortly after his arrival here from Salt Lake City, Frank Parker was on the courts of the Bathing and Tennis Club and proceeding to the business of establishing the first leg on the new Clifford Hemphill Bowl.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 9 (AP) -- Joseph M. Roebling's Cacique remained undefeated in three starts at Monmouth Park today when he proved an easy winner of the second running of the $10,000-added New Jersey Futurity. Eight New Jersey bred 2-year-olds competed in the five and a half furlong dash and Cacique's share of the purse was 58,980.

COLLEGE STATION, Tex., July 9 (AP) -- Leonard Dickey, Texas A. and M. varsity tackle the past two seasons, announced today he had signed to play pro football with the New York Yankees. Dickey, who also was a track letterman in the weights, was a standout Aggie tackle in 1941 before entering the service.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- Furniture retailers were warned today by a banker and a store executive that higher costs of merchandise will require increased operating capital, while larger accounts receivable will also place a heavy financial burden on the retail store.

The (Lanham) Trade-Mark Act of 1946, although an improvement on previous trade mark legislation, may result in serious limitations on product competition because of restrictions governing retention of certificate marks, Casper W. Ooms, Commissioner of Patents, warned yesterday.

Henry A. Wallace said yesterday that he believed the Soviet Government should have accepted the opportunity offered by the Paris conference for the economic reconstruction of Europe. He added that without participation of Russia there was grave danger that the program offered by Secretary of State George C. Marshall might further divide the world, -- ''unless the philosophy behind the Truman Doctrine is disavowed."

The refusal of the crew of the Marine Carp to sign on yesterday morning delayed the vessel's departure nearly ten hours. The Carp, operated by American Export Lines as general agents if the Maritime Commission, was scheduled to leave at noon but the crew would not sign articles until repairs to the davits of the No. 5 lifeboat were completed.
JONES BEACH, L.I., July 9 -- A thousand youngsters from Nassau and Suffolk counties and the metropolitan area attended today the first of a series of children's day programs at the state park here.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 2, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:

Glancing Through the Paper Perhaps one reason why more and more people have been seeing those flying saucers in the air is our new ethical standards. What is saucer for the goose is today saucer for the gander, too.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Plans of the Italian Government to offer new bonds in payment of suspended dollar issues totaling $93,000,000 and interest of $42,000,000 to last Jan. 1 were announced today by Ivan M. Lombardo, head of the Italian Economic Mission to this country.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 9 (AP) -- The Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Company and the Cliffs Corporation of Cleveland were merged today under articles filed with the Secretary of State to form a new corporation, the Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Company.
The city will make every effort to bring a substantial part of the nation's motion picture industry to New York, Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- It has been established to the satisfaction of most persons that when a busman goes on a holiday he preferably rides in another busman's bus". The proclivity of sailors on shore leave to rowboats around lagoons has been steadily observed by strollers in city parks.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- A Senate Education subcommittee today favorably imported a. bill which would give about $2,600,000 annually in Federal grants to the states for extension of library services to remote rural areas. It would allow $25,000 to each state per year for five years for library "demonstrations" such as book-mobile service to a community without a library.

New York's public school lunch program is inadequate, unnecessarily expensive and erratically administered, James Marshall, a Manhattan member of the Board of Education, charged yesterday. At a meeting of the board in 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn, the program was defended by two other board members and the Superintendent of Schools.

ALTHOUGH E. M. Forster had begun a first novel at 20 -- which means he has been writing now for nearly half a century -- only some dozen volumes now bear his name. The volumes he has written are marked by a simple, polished style; a point of view that is ironic yet compassionate; and a mastery of the nuances of character and feeling.

PARIS, July 9 -- Describing Russian totalitarianism as a new menace to the same rights and liberties that Germany had sought to destroy, former President de Gaulle said today that, unless this danger could be overcome, Europe would succumb and the world would face an "immense and unpardonable war."
The highly regarded law firm of Mudge, Stern, Williams TucKer, 20 Pine Street, was thrown into something resembling a dither yesterday afternoon.

The 1947 All-Star baseball game has had its brief moment in sports spotlight. It wasn't, perhaps, the most exciting ever staged in the series of fourteen battles that started in 1933, but it certainly was one of the best ever played by both sides.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Senate passed without dissent today legislation to restrict the Department of Agriculture's crop insurance program beginning with the 1948 growing year.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 9 -- Rumania's oil industry, which was the world's sixth largest producer before the war, graphically illustrates the road to ruin down which all Rumanian industry seems to be rushing as a result of wild inflation, high operating costs and low production.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Robert W. Johnson, chairman of Johnson Johnson of New Brunswick, N.J., said tonight that one of the principal roots of labor-management troubles was destruction of human dignity, and declared "the task of restoring dignity to workers rests squarely upon management."

The Federal Public Housing Authority awarded yesterday issues of temporary loan notes totaling $36,409,000 in behalf of fourteen local housing agencies. All the issues were dated July 29, 1947, and will come due on Aug. 10, 1948. The Chemical Bank and Trust Company bought thirteen issues totaling $36,083,000 at bids ranging from 0.85 per cent to 0.91 per cent.

To the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES: I hasten to inform you that I, too, have seen the "flying disks." and contrary to the vague and, I believe, unreliable description given oy others, I am in a position to give you a full report.

Brig. Gen. Marlborough Churchill, USA, retired, who won distinction in a military career he adopted immediately after his graduation from Harvard in 1900, died yesterday at his home, 40 East Eighty-third Street, at the age of 68.

Under the Taft-Hartley Act labor unions continue to be especially favored and protected institutions under the law, David R. Clarke, general counsel, National Metal Trades Association, said in an interview following an association meeting of more than 300 members at the Commodore Hotel yesterday.
Millinery was shown yesterday at 1 West Fifty-seventh Street by Laddie Northridge. The models gave the feeling of bulk that the designer felt should accompany the new fashions.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 9 -- Yugoslavia's rejection of her invitation to attend the Paris conference was handed to the British and French Ambassadors in Belgrade tonight by Stanoye Simitch, Yugoslav Foreign Minister.

The refreshing view afforded by a picture window in a country house has been reproduced in a photographic wall treatment introduced yesterday for city dwellers whose apartments face an undistinguished court view. The Scenichrome shown at Sylvania Electric Products, 500 Fifth Avenue, features a colored enlargement of a scenic photograph that is framed between two layers of clear Plexiglas and then lighted in back by fluorescent tubes.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange again turned strong yesterday and closed with gains of 47 to 120 points net on the day.

Defense counsel in the city dock fraud trial yesterday assailed the credibility of Albert Gross, ex-convict and one-time bootlegger, whose guilty plea last Tuesday made him available as a prosecution witness against his former codefendants, I. James Brody, ousted city official, and James V. Auditore, powerful waterfront figure.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 10 -- A screen drama based on the life of Davy Crockett, early American frontiersman and soldier, is to be filmed for release on its 1947-48 Schedule by Paramount.

In establishing its course on "Great Issues," Dartmouth College has set an interesting and useful pattern. Convinced that the liberal arts college must assume responsibility in training its men and women for community leadership, the college this fall will require all its seniors to attend three sessions weekly on the significant issues facing the world.

ST. LOUIS, July 10 -- The forkland flipping and unexpected hitting of Joe Page enabled the Yancees tonight to stretch their lead in the American League pennant race to eight and one-half games and their winning streak to nine in a row, a new league high which equals the Cardinals' major league record for the season.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The Maritime Commission announced today that it would not resume Government operation of cargo ships in any domestic trade without first holding a public hearing to determine if resumption is required "in the public interest."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 10 -- For the second time, the Soviet Union declined today to make any estimate on the size of the proposed United Nations police force until agreement had been reached on the proportion of contributions by the Big Five.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 10 -- The Hungarian Government declined today the invitation to discuss the Marshall plan in Paris. It did this, according to a communique after a joint conference of the parties in the government coalition had "unanimously decided that Hungary should not take part in the Paris conference."

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 10 -- Sidney Wood had the old magic in his racquet today and the biggest gallery of the week at the Bathing and Tennis Club was held in suspense for an hour and a half as he came dangerously close to defeating Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla.

Three young lesser pandas from Calcutta are new attractions at the Bronx Zoo. They are three feet tall, have chestnut colored fur, white striped faces, and lots of pep. They spend their time eating bamboo tips, wrestling with each other, and scampering up and down trees.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 10 -- Kansas Republicans are leaning strongly toward Gov. Thomas E. Dewey for the Republican Presidential nomination next year, leaders from all parts of the state agreed here today at a reception and luncheon for the New York chief executive.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- Representative Clair Engle of California said today a bill now before Congress would permit the United States Steel Corporation to "put a gun at the head of the Kaiser Steel Company" in endeavors to acquire coking coal lands in Utah.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., July 10 (AP) -- Miss Betty Rosenquest of South Orange and Mrs. Betty Hulbert James of Miami, seeded No. 2, gained the semi-final round today in the New Jersey state tennis championships at the Maplewood Country Club.

Strenuous objections have been raised by Francis W. Sullivan, lawyer and prominent Catholic layman of Portland. Me., against Michael Myerberg's tryout of "Dear Judas" the week of Aug. 4 at the Ogunquit (Me.) Playhouse, it was learned yesterday.

PARIS, July 10 -- A Soviet offensive against the European conference on the Marshall proposal seemed to begin today when the Czechoslovak Government suddenly withdrew its previous acceptance of the invitation to take part in the conference that will open in Paris Saturday.

Why They Ballot Some day in the not too distant future a dictator who has gone temporarily or permanently mad, as dictators, emperors, czars and caliphs have been known to do in the past, may order a new kind of plebiscite.

Despite a moderate decline in operations during June, the domestic steel Industry in the first six months of 1947 produced a larger total tonnage of ingots and steel for castings than in any similar peacetime period, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Unless Congress appropriates adequate funds to administer unemployment insurance "there is danger of a breakdown in the system" in New York State "altogether this year," State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi warned yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, July 10 -- In a drastic effort to halt the recently accelerated drainage of its foreign exchange, the Mexican Government late tonight announced its intention to place a temporary embargo on imports of luxury articles and to impose considerably increased import duties on other semi-luxury items.

Less Hope for Lower Prices Buyers in a number of soft goods lines now feel that chances of significant price reductions for the last half of this year have dimmed appreciably in recent weeks. At the same time, however, caution on adding to forward orders is still marked, it was reported here yesterday.

CHICAGO. July 10 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 6.500 head, total 9.500: market very slow and extremely uneven but generally steady to 25 cents lower on all weights of barrows and gilts: sows steady early but closed

Members of the American Union of Telephone Workers voted by a five-to-three ratio in a national referendum to affiliate with the new CIO Telephone Workers Organizing Committee, it was announced last night by John J. Moran, president of the union.
CLEVELAND, July 10 (AP) -- Don Black of the Indians, supported by fielding that matched his brilliant pitching, tonight hurled the first no-hit no-run game of the 1947 American League season.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- State and national leaders of the Young Democratic Clubs of America selected Cleveland today as the scene of the organization's first national convention since 1941. The dates were tentatively set for Oct. 3 and 4.

PRAGUE, July 10 -- Czechoslovakia backed down tonight from a decision to attend the Paris conference on the Marshall plan. The Cabinet acted upon telephoned instructions from Communist Premier Klement Gottwald in Moscow.

Despite the campaign of the Brooklyn Heights Association to bar additional liquor stores in the Heights section, another store has been permitted by the State Liquor Authority at 72 Clark Street, site of the old First Methodist Episcopal Church.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10 -- Gabriel Caplan of New York, a stockholder of the International HydroElectric System, filed a plan with the Securities and Exchange Commission today for liquidation of the company. The SEC ordered liquidation of the system in 1942.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In thinking of the tax bill now before Congress the average taxpayer sees no good reason why, if only the swollen Government payroll can be sufficiently cut, we should not only make some reduction of the national debt but give him tax relief as well.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Nelson H. Cruikshank of the American Federation of Labor, James B. Carey of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and Horace R. Hansen of the Cooperative League of the United States today advocated the Murray compulsory health insurance bill.

The hats of the Middle Ages and the hats of 1912 provided inspiration for millinery shown yesterday by Edward Paine at 53 East Sixty-seventh Street. From the medieval styles he took a flair for velvets and rich colors, bloused crowns and elegant feather trims.

In accepting the invitation to the Paris conference a few days ago the Czechoslovak Government openly proclaimed its desire to cooperate in the general plan for European rehabilitation. In withdrawing now this acceptance at a word from Moscow it has no less openly admitted that it is not free to follow its own choice.

The Triborough Bridge, one of New York's most Important traffic links, is eleven years old today. The Triborough Bridge Authority, which operates it and numerous other spans and arteries, announced yesterday that it expects 1947 to be the banner year in the span's operations, with a probable revenue traffic of more than 15,000,000 vehicles.

CINCINNATI, July 10 -- Erupting violently after smoldering all week, the question of whether public funds should go for the support of parochial schools broke into the open today in one of the most spirited and heated sessions of the eighty-fifth conference of the National Education Association.

PARIS, July 10 -- Vaclav Major, Czechoslovak Minister of Supplies, proposed to the special international cereals conference today that it set up "machinery to mobilize all stocks of grain available and then assure a democratic and fair distribution."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 10 -- The state is paying 20 per cent of the public school costs in Westchester County, compared with 25 per cent in New York and an average of 32 per cent throughout the state, the Westchester Board of Supervisors was told today by State Senator Pliny W. Williamson of Scarsdale.

The Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad, its operations fully restored this week for the first time since a twenty-month strike, is about to "ring doorbells" in an attempt to regain its former business, President Russel Coulter said yesterday.
LONDON, July 10 -- The bells of Westminster Abbey pealed poignantly today as, "with proud thanksgiving," King George VI unveiled the Battle of Britain Memorial Chapel.

A total of $6,500,000 has been allocated for the 1947-48 advdrtising campaign of Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation and its dealers and distributors throughout the country, Benjamin Abrams, president, announced yesterday.

Retailers for the most part are continuing to bold back placing of orders on furs for fall, but in so doing run a marked risk of not being able to obtain timely deliveries in August or September, it was reported yesterday at the first Fur Forum held by the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, Inc., at the Hotel Biltmore.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- Kermit Eby, a Congress of Industrial Organizations official, denounced universal military training as "virtually a call to arms" today but a Catholic priest, the Rev. Dan A. Laning, praised it as "the best protection from a fighting war."
The City of Cleveland, Ohio announced yesterday that it would receive bids until July 29 for an issue of $22,000,000 of transportation system revenue bonds.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Department store sales in the week ended July 5 were 8 per cent above those in the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes front like periods of 1946:

SEOUL, Korea, July 10 -- The Joint United States - Soviet Commission for the establishment of a provisional government for Korea "made zero progress in the last three days" in its efforts to break a deadlock, according to Maj. Gen. Albert E. Brown, chief of the American delegation.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 10 -- Despite Soviet objections, the United Nations Security Council decided today to consider Austria's application for membership in the world organization.

The Port of New York Authority officially increased its offer yesterday for the lease and development of Newark Airport and Marine Terminal. Six members of the authority voted unanimously at a special meeting to continue the 75-25 per cent split of net revenue in Newark's favor through the fifty-year term of the lease, as demanded by the three-man majority of the Newark City Commission.

The prospect of good bargains lured 350 persona to the United States Appraisers Stores at 201 Varick Street yesterday, where 500 lots of abandoned and unclaimed merchandise were offered to the highest bidders by order of the Collector of Customs.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The United Mine Workers and the Pennsylvania Anthracite operators agreed tonight to contract revisions raising the pay of 75,000 hard coal miners by $1.20 a day.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 10 -- With five members reversing their position, the executive committee of the State Constitutional Convention voted today to limit gubernatorial tenure in New Jersey to two successive terms.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The Senate Commerce Committee recommended today the confirmation of Representative Robert F. Jones, Republican, of Ohio, as a member of the Federal Communications Commission.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended July 5 totaled 629,204 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Maximilian Elser Jr. and Ben J. Cothran have resigned from the J. Walter Thompson Company, advertising, to establish a general public relations firm known as Eiser Cothran, 521 Fifth Avenue, it was announced yesterday. The former was editorial head and chairman of the plan board of the public relations-publicity department; the latter, an account executive in the same department.

City Hall reporters and members of the City government, headed by Mayor O'Dwyer, renewed their annual outing feud -- their first since 1940 -- yesterday at the New York Athletic Club on Travers Island in Westchester County. When the long day was over, it was agreed that the reporters had more athletic prowess than the City Commissioners.

GENEVA, July 10 -- Twice since 1939 Australia has received tentative offers of duty cuts on United States imports of raw wool, it was learned authoritatively today. On both occasions, which arose during two previous efforts to negotiate a reciprocal trade agreement, the matter never got beyond preliminary talks because demands on both sides were viewed as excessive.

NANKING, July 10 -- Dr. Fei Hsiao-tung, eminent Chinese political analyst, holds that China has been relegated to a secondary role and that Japan has been elevated to the position of major importance in terms of American strategy in the Far East. As a result, he holds, the Chinese Government will receive only the minimum of assistance and support from the United States while Washington will concentrate on rebuilding and stabilizing Japan economically and politically.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 10 -- The United States survey planning group, which has been here since May 22, is nearing the end of its mission after a series of conferences with Turkish officers and tours of the country's important areas.

VIENNA, July 10 -- Some of the thousands of refugees arriving recently from Yugoslavia brought stories of wholesale terror against the German-speaking population An investigation of the refugees reports showed agreement among many of them that as many as 200,000 persons have starved to death or died from ill treatment in Concentration camps.
MADRID, July 10 -- As the summer harvest begins to come in Spain appears safe from a serious wheat shortage this year if Argentina provides the 400,000 tons due from her, it was learned here today.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (U.P.) -- A delegation of food canners and distributors braved a chilly reception from Congress today to ask that the Government help them get rid of a "dangerous surplus" of canned foods by including such products in its overseas relief shipments.

TRENTON. N.J., July 10 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll today virtually completed his work of signing new laws for New Jersey and rejecting measures, passed by the 1947 Legislature, which he found undesirable.

New bearing rollers, known as "rockers," are being installed in two towers of the 44-year-old Williamsburg Bridge to eliminate the "jolt" caused to the span by temperature changes and heavy traffic. From 11 o'clock last night to 5 A.M. today the East River suspension bridge was closed to all private vehicles and subway traffic.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 10 -- Westchester successfully defended its intra-association team golf honors against Fairfield today at the Woodway Country Club, 23 1/2 to 21 1/2 points. With all except the last of fifteen twosomes finished, the score was tied at 21-all.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- With higher prices both for agricultural and industrial commodities, average primary markets rose 0.3 percent during the week ended on July 5, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, United States Department of Labor. The bureau's index of commodity prices in primary markets reached 148.0 percent of the 1926 average, the highest level since early April and 26.3 per cent above the corresponding week of 1946.
V.R. Van Natta has been elected vice president of Reid Murdoch, a division of Consolidated Grocers Corporation.

THERE was a youthful spring to his walk but his hair was completely gray. A visitor to Chicago had to look twice to make certain that it was Freddie Lindstrom. The erstwhile Boy Wonder of the Giants is just as trimlooking as he was two decades ago but that blond thatch has a silver sheen to it these days. Naturally enough, the first question had to be how he acquired the gray hair.

We believe that the Senate's vote on unification of the armed forces reflects accurately the general sentiment on this important matter, both civilian and military. Senate debate was short and to the point. There must have been little doubt in any Senator's mind as to the issue -- a unified department of national defense or the division, jealousy, separation and confusion of function that the country had before Pearl Harbor.

VIENNA, July 10 -- Lieut. Gen. L.V. Kurasov, Soviet High Commissioner in the Allied Council for Austria, demanded today withdrawal of the inspection and control features of the United States $100,000,000 Austrian aid program. He charged that United States control was a direct attack on Austrian independence and a breach of United States agreements with the other occupying powers.

A new loophole was discovered yesterday in the Federal rent law and as a result some speculating landlords were again trying to coerce tenants into buying their apartments under so-called cooperative tenant ownership plans.

A strong advance in the wholesale price of meat took place this week, the United States Department of Agriculture reported yesterday. Steer beef, which increased from $1.50 to $3, a hundredweight, is now higher than it was the second week in June, when meat tariffs first rose sharply, and only a little under the record for the year reached last January.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 10 -- A picture of two hands planting a small tree, the leaves of which are the fifty-five flags of the United Nations, today won for its painter, Henry Eveleigh of Canada, $1,500 and first prize in the United Nations' first international "poster of the year" contest.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- President Truman strongly endorsed today not only the proposed Missouri Valley Authority but also an integrated flood control program for the Missouri, Mississippi and Ohio River basins.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- A shortage of wanted merchandise in curtain, drapery and slip-cover fabrics departments this fall was predicted as a result of present short-term buying policies being followed by many buyers attending the Summer Furniture and Home Furnishings Market being held here this week and next.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 10 (AP) -- The combination of Owner Cornelius V. Whitney, Trainer Sylvester Veitch and Jockey Willie Saunders stole the show at Monmouth Park today.

After a short ownership, Town and City Equities, Inc., sold the taxpayer containing fifteen stores at 605-29 East Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, to an investing client of Paul P. Zinner, Inc., broker in the transaction. The property is assessed at $108,000 and was sold for cash over mortgages totaling $87,250. William Duncan was the co-broker.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- President Truman announced today he would veto the new personal income tax reduction bill, and the Senate began debate on the measure with Administration supporters concentrating all efforts on sustaining him.
