Georgie Abrams of Brooklyn and Steve Belloise of the Bronx, middlewelghts, meet in a return tenround engagement at Madison Square Garden tonight. Abrams won a split decision in their previous bout last August and rules a slight favorite at about 5-to-7 to repeat. A crowd of 10,000 is expected.
With 35,876 witnesses, by far the largest Ebbets Field crowd of the season, looking on in high glee, the league-leading Dodgers defeated the Chicago Cubs in both ends of a double-header yesterday.

ATHENS, July 10 -- The biggest and fiercest battle to date has developed between the Greek Army and 4,000 guerrillas who are desperately clinging to a thirty-fivemile-long strip of Greek soil along the Albanian frontier, Minister of War George Stratos disclosed to this correspondent late today.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The current publications in Collier's by James A. Farley, which deal with the gradual breach that arose between President Roosevelt and himself over the third term and other matters, have many facets of intense interest.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- A bill introduced by Senator Owen Brewster. Republican, of Maine, to establish a temporary air policy board, was reported favorably to the Senate by the Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee today.
CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) -- The Senators broke their cousin complex against the White Sox by sweeping a doubleheader, 4 -- 0 and 7 -- 2, today. They had lost ten of their first eleven games to the Sox.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- During the week ended ended July 9, member bank reserve balances increased $202,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The House, by vote of 365 to 11, passed and sent to the White House today a succession bill which would make the Republican Speaker, Joseph W. Martin Jr., Chief Executive of the United States if President Truman should become unable to complete his present term.

Evidence that corporations are giving more consideration to the good-will of their stockholders continues to be received. The latest is McKesson Robbins, Inc., wholesale drug concern, which has offered stockholders a free sample of its newest product, a suntan lotion.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- President Truman said today that he saw at present no reason for calling a special session of Congress this fall.
LONDON, July 10 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin will leave London by air tomorrow evening at the head of a strong British delegation to the Paris Conference, the Foreign Office announced today.

RYE, N.Y., July 10 -- With the first-round matches in the New York State Golf Association's silver anniversary championship at the Westchester Country Club completed, the Metropolitan district has a decided bulge on the rest of the Empire State with nine representatives left among the surviving sixteen.

A wild three-day party, staged over the Independence Day weekend in the apartment of an absent neighbor, brought sixteen Bronx boys and girls into court yesterday on charges ranging from illegal entry to malicious mischief. They were accused of destroying clothing and furniture in the flat, which they had entered without the owner's permission.

The government-ship ownersunion program of specialized training of stewards for service aboard American flag passenger vessels received added impetus yesterday when a suite of seven full-scale, completely furnished shipboard staterooms were formally presented by American Export Lines to the Maritime Service Training Station at Sheepshead Bay.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Controller General of the United States, Lindsay C. Warren, reported to Congress today that "at least" seventy-nine settlements of war contracts, involving nineteen contractors, "were induced by fraud."

Within a few days British India will be two Dominions, legally on the same standing within the Commonwealth of Nations as Britain herself, one called the Indian Union, with Viscount Mountbatten as Governor General; one called Pakistan, with Mohammed Ali Jinnah as Governor General; one mainly Hindu, one mainly Moslem.

MILWAUKEE, July 10 -- The executive board of the CIO Gas, Coke and Chemical Workers Union upheld tonight the payroll suspension of two vice presidents, William Ross of Newark, N.J., and Charles Doyle of Niagara Falls, N.Y., for opposing the board's anti-Communist policy statement.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- Continued high meat prices and some reduction in livestock production next year was indicated today by a report of the Department of Agriculture, forecasting a sharp drop from wartime level in this year's corn crop.

The stock market yesterday almost completely reversed Wednesday's performance, as modest bidding and a lack of offering's produced gains of 1 to 2 points in some of the leading industrials. However, such gains were not general in all sections of the list and the price average only rose 0.66 point on the day.

The author of this article is the leader of the Kon-Tiki Expedition -- a group of youthful Norwegian scientists who are trying to prove, by duplicating the feat, that ancient pre-Incan Indians travelled from South America to the Polynesian islands on rafts carried by the Peruvian or Humboldt and the South Equatorial Current.

American Stove A dividend of 40 cents on common stock payable August 11 to holders of record on July 22, has been voted by the American Stove Company. Previous payment was 35 cents in May. Previously quarterly dividends of 30 cents were paid.

Short casts: A State Conservation Department crew headed by Cecil Heacox, senior aquatic biologist, is devoting this week to making a survey of Cross River Reservoir up around Katonah with an eye to seeing how it can be developed fishwise.

A woman's prerogative late yesterday afternoon saved three pedigreed Afghan hounds -- recently arrived from Germany -- from the dog pound. It also calmed harassed officials of the American Overseas Airline and terminated feverish pondering by the legal brains of the airline.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- Brokers were inclined to place a moderately bullish construction on a Department of Agriculture estimate of the corn and oats crop issued after the close today, corn being somewhat below the average expectation while oats failed to reflect any improvement in the situation.
LONDON, July 10 -- The Moscow radio said tonight that the Albanian Government had declined the Anglo-French invitation to attend

LONDON, July 10 -- There is no big news to be written about Princess Elizabeth and her fiance, Lieut. Philip Mountbatten, today except the obvious fact that they are very happy on this first day of their engagement.

Although Harry Moskowitz' betting luck was running high, his presence at Jamaica Racetrack Wednesday afternoon proved to be his downfall. Arrested there by two detectives who had been carrying his picture for three years, Moskowitz was arraigned yesterday in Felony Court on a fugitive charge and turned over to Police Chief James Bomano of North Pelham, N.Y., where he has been wanted since 1937 for the alleged passing of a bogus check.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Export-Import Bank is expected to begin the disbursement of the $100,000,000 earmarked for Italy soon after Congress appropriates the already authorized $350,000,000 for post-United Nations Rehabilitation Relief Administration aid to Europe.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, July 10 (Reuters) -- Dr. Louis J.M. Beel. Dutch Prime Minister called on the Indonesian Republican authorities, in a speech in the Dutch Parliament here today, for an immediate cessation of hostilities, breaking off of unauthorized foreign relations and lifting of a food blockade.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 10 -- Seventeen volunteer "internes" in international administration began work today in the United Nations secretariat.

But for the efforts of some Johnny-come-latelies and a few fancy free observations from Amsterdam, the Netherlands, to Amsterdam, N.Y., the skimming saucers appeared headed yesterday for that special limbo reserved for illused dishware.

Joseph Szigeti, the eminent violinist, was the soloist at the concert given by the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, under Alexander Smallens, last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. Mr. Szigeti, who had not appeared previously at the outdoor amphitheatre, was heard in the Concerto in D major of Brahms, on a program also containing that composer's "Tragic" Overture and Fourth Symphony.

Financing of an East Side cooperative housing venture was announced yesterday with the placing by the New York Life Insurance Company of a fifteen-year mortgage of $1,100,000 on two tenstory and penthouse apartment buildings running through the block at 115 East Sixty-seventh Street and 116 East Sixty-eighth Street.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 10 -- Representatives of Victor Emmanuel, III, former King of Italy, are negotiating for the purchase of property in Southport as a residence for the one time Italian monarch, it has been learned here.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 10 -- The Westchester County Golf Association played host to a pro-amateur best-ball tournament today over the Hudson River Country Club course which brought forth a large field of fifty-nine teams.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Senate Foreign Relations committee arranged today for a liaison with Secretary of State Marshall of a strength and continuity without precedent since the end of the war. It will be on a more nearly fixed basis than any ever maintained.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Broadway, the attraction will be "Copacabana," a musical, starring Groucho Marx and Carmen Miranda. Produced by Sam Coslow for United Artists release, the film features Steve Cochran, Gloria Jean and Andy Russell.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10 (AP) -- In a battle for seventh place in the National League, the Phillies shoved the Pirates further into the cellar today by taking both ends of a doubleheader, 7 -- 2 and 2 -- 1.
NANKING, July 10 (AP) -- New Communist advances in Shantung Province and reports of Russian movements in southern Manchuria marked China's civil war today.
LONDON, July 10 -- British Government stocks were the exception in a generally cheerful stock market here today.
CHICAGO, July 10 -- A year's paid vacation after six years of service is how M. Glen Miller, head of an advertising agency, plans to keep his twelve employes "contented and happy."

Most of the 5,500 employes of Republic Aircraft Corporation will lot forget soon the luncheon hour yesterday, nor the loudspeaker announcement that followed at the Farmingdale plant after nearly four tense hours, when they were told of the safe landing of the Army experimental XF 12.

Reflecting the heavy consumption over the July 4 holiday, the nation's gasoline stocks last week dropped 2,132,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 89,674,000 barrels, compared with 91,806,000 a week earlier and 91,627,000 on July 6, 1946.

A sharp drop in loans, due mainly to the sale by brokers and dealers of Government securities, produced a further contraction in the total earnings assets of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System during the week ended last Wednesday.

PITTSBURGH, July 10 -- The CIO Political Action Committee opened here today an intensified drive aimed at the 1948 elections in what may become the first major test by a labor organization of the non-political contribution section of the Taft-Hartley labor law.

BERLIN, July 10 -- Maj. Gen. Alexander G. Kotikov, Russian member of the Allied Kommandatura, took an unusual tack today in assailing the Social Democratic party in general and Lord Mayorelect Dr. Ernst Reuter in particular.

AMSTERDAM, July 10 (Aneta) -- Prices were firm in slow trading on the Stock Exchange as the public awaited publication of the expected Government statement on its Indonesian policy. Indies plantations issues, oil stocks and banking shares were strong, while industrials and shipping stocks were lower. State bonds were steady.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Photographic negatives of equipment used in making atomic bombs were among the secret documents filched from the Los Alamos, N.M., atomic bomb plant, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Although President Truman is finding it difficult to obtain nominations for two places open on the new National Labor Relations Board, it is hoped by White House attaches that a list of the nominees may be sent to the Senate early next week.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.T., July 10 (AP> -- Millbrook, perennial challenger for the pacing championship, captured the Star Pointer Stakes today in the fastest twoheat time of the Saratoga Raceway summer meeting.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 10 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, delegate of the Philippines, and Ratan K. Nehru of India today urged that the dependent territories of Asia, although not members of the United Nations, should have full membership rights in the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East.

BERLIN, July 10 -- The high prices and the monthly ceiling on purchases at the Military Government food commissaries and post exchanges have caused so much uproar among American civilians in Germany that headquarters recently put out through Stars and Stripes an official denial that anything was wrong.

MUNICH, Germany, July 10 -- Red-headed, quick-witted Frau Ilsa Koch, personification to United States prosecutors of the infamy that was the Buchenwald concentration camp, draped a cloak of innocence and purity about herself as she took the stand in her own defense today in the war crimes tribunal in Dachau.
The police of the Richmond Hill, Queens, station were looking last night for the victim of a holdup instead of the perpetrators. The latter have been jailed.
OAKLAND, Calif., July 10 (AP) -- One of the best kept secrets of the war -- almost within sight of the skyscrapers of Oakland and San Francisco -- came to light today.

WHITE PLAINS., N.Y., July 10 -- Disturbed by the problems of trying to balance the 1948 local budget In view of new salary increases and reduced working hours for employes, municipalities in Westchester County renewed today a search for additional revenues.

With Board of Estimate action on the proposed eight-cent transit fare here deferred temporarily, the Chicago Transit Authority adopted yesterday an ordinance setting the basic fare on the surface lines there at 10 cents, instead of the present 9 cents.

UNION CITY, N.J., July 10 -- A 22-year-old former Army Air Force warrant officer today calmly confessed, the police say, the fatal shooting of Patrolman Arthur McKenna, headquarters radio dispatcher, as the policeman was eating his breakfast at 4 o'clock this morning.
Butter prices are continuing on the erratic course that they have followed since the end of Federal controls a little more than twelve months ago, it was reported yesterday.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 10 (AP) -- Ed Furgol of Pontiac, Mich., and George Schoux of San Francisco teamed up as the perfect pair today to blaze a birdie trail into a long lead in the first round of the tenth Inverness four-ball matches.

Stressing individuality rather than trends in the size and shape of hats, Mary Goodfellow presented her fall millinery collection yesterday at the Sherry-Netherland Hotel. The hats are designed to be flattering to and wearable by most types of women.

Production of television receivers this year will exceed 250,000 and for 1948 will reach 1,500,000, Dorman Israel, vice president of engineering and production, Emerson Radio Phonograph Corporation, predicted yesterday. Mr. Isreal ruled out immediate price reductions for television receivers but said that production techniques are being developed so that the instrument will "inevitably" follow a course similar to that of radio.

TULSA, Okla., July 10 (AP) -- Former Representative Roger C. Slaughter, Democrat, of Missouri, whom President Truman helped to defeat for renomination last year, charged today that "a scandal threatens the great office of the President of the United States and will inevitably become an issue in the campaigns next year."

WHEN Joan of Arc was burned in the market place of Rouen she left behind her some major unfinished business, the completion of the One Hundred Tears War and the expulsion of the English from France. Charles VII, that weak, vacillating, treacherous and generally contemptible individual on whose unworthy head she had set a crown, Was not capable of the leadership or energy necessary for so great a task.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- Delegate E.L. Bartlett of Alaska says the Maritime Commission has authorized Seattle shipping companies operating the Alaskan service an "unjust increase (in rates) made legal by an edict of a United States governmental agency."

BOSTON, July 10 (AP) -- Babe Young's second homer of the day, with one aboard, enabled Buddy Lively to give the Cincinnati Reds an even split with a three-hit, 2-1 decision over the Boston Braves tonight before a 27,455 crowd. Young belted his sixth homer of the season during the afternoon contest which the Tribesmen won, 6 -- 4, with Tommy Holmes bashing two consecutive four-baggers.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- United States diplomatic officials said tonight Czechoslovakia's decision not to attend the Paris conference was the "crudest demonstration yet" of Soviet control over the Governments of Eastern Europe.

Both of Venezuela's former Presidents joined yesterday in condemning that country's Constitution which was adopted last week by the administration of President Romulo Betancourt. In separate interviews here, they characterized the new code as a repudiation of individual liberties.

GLASGOW, Scotland, July 10 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Pacific liner Empress of Canada, transformed from the wartime gray she wore as the Duchess of Richmond in troop transport service, rode the Clyde in compass trials today in fresh white paint with a sash of green and buffcolored funnels.

LONDON, July 10 -- The Indian bill, by which the British Empire voluntarily gives political independence to one-fifth of the world's population, passed its second reading in the House of Commons today without a vote.

With the action yesterday of the House of Representatives both branches of Congress have now approved Mr. Truman's proposal for a change in the line of Presidential succession. Henceforward (as soon as Mr. Truman has signed the completed bill) it will be the Speaker of the House rather than the Secretary of State who will stand next in line after the Vice President.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 10 -- A bitter denunciation of Communist tactics and influences in the trade union movement was delivered here today by two Congress of Industrial Organizations officials before the American, Missionary Association's Fourth Annual Institute of Race Relations.

The Sunday afternoon concerts of the New York PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall will continue to be broadcast by CBS this fall and winter, whether or not a sponsor lends support to the undertaking. The disclosure was made yesterday by a spokesman of the network following the announcement by the United States Rubber Company that, after four consecutive years of sponsorship, it had decided to drop the program.

JERUSALEM, July 10 -- Members of the Palestine Arab Higher Committee in Jerusalem drafted a reply today to the latest appeal of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine for cooperation with its inquiry. It was apparent that the reply would be a reaffirmation of the Arab boycott of the inquiry, but it is not being published until it has been communicated to the committee.

Detectives investigating the strangling of Mrs. Sheila Mannering located yesterday a safe deposit box belonging to the former actress. It contained several thousand dollars in cash, several thousand dollars in war bonds, a Tiffany wrist watch valued at $700 and a quantity of costume jewelry.
Most of next year's high school graduates should have little or no difficulty entering college in September, 1948, a study just completed at New York University indicates.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Since I arrived in the United States this year I have been a regular reader of your newspaper, which has impressed me deeply with its objective truth.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 10 -- The Sixth International Congress for Experimental Cytology was opened here tonight, with 410 delegates from twenty-five countries in attendance. The congress brings together for the first time since 1938 leading investigators in the field of research into the nature of the living cells of bacteria, plants and higher animals.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Lifting of the nine-month-old embargo on non-food railway shipments to the Port of New York for transhipment abroad was announced today by the Association of American Railroads. The embargo-lifting does not, however, affect relief shipments to Europe and North Africa, it was announced.

WARSAW, July 11 (AP) -- Poland wants foreign assistance for reconstruction and would consider it "lamentable" if her refusal to attend the Paris conference on the Marshall Plan created an unfavorable impression in the United States, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said tonight.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 11 -- Following is the text of an appeal against Britain presented by Egypt to the United Nations through Secretary General Trygve Lie today.

BOSTON, July 11 (AP) -- Aided by six Boston errors, Ewell Blackwell gained his fifteenth victory and his thirteenth in a row for the Cincinnati Reds with a 10-6 triumph over the jittery Braves tonight before 27,701 fans.

Flying to Europe where he will spend three weeks studying the physical and financial management of the ports of England and the continent, Carl G. Holmquist of the engineering firm of Sanderson Porter, 52 William Street, left La Guardia Field for London yesterday aboard an American Overseas Airlines plane.

DENVER, July 11 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York conferred for several hours this afternoon with a group of Colorado Republican leaders, who were anxious to obtain his views on reclamation and irrigation. These subjects are of major political importance in the mountain states.

An independent stockholders committee, headed by Robert A.W. Carleton, who resigned as president and chairman of the board of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company in January, is soliciting proxies for a meeting of stockholders scheduled for July 28.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- A bill calling for a special five-man committee to investigate "all the facts" in the draft-evasion case of Serge Rubinstein, New York financier now serving a two-and-a-half-year prison sentence, was introduced in the House today by Representative Ellsworth B. Buck, Republican, of New York.
War in the Bazaar Words do take on meanings, don't they? And, on the other hand, words do have a habit of concealing their meanings. There is the case of collective bargaining.

VIENNA, July 11 -- The Soviet Union intends to enforce, at least in its zone, Moscow's ban on economic cooperation with the West, political quarters implied today. This was the interpretation put an the Soviet demand at the Allied Council meeting yesterday that the United States-Austrian aid agreement be amended to exclude United States inspection and control rights.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- A $213,439,000 operating fund for the Maritime Commission was recommended to the Senate today by its Appropriation Committee.
LONDON, July 11 -- The stock markets here today finished the week on a bright note, the sustained strength of gold shares and equities providing the main features.

Hotpoint, Inc., will start a nation-wide drive through dealers' stores on its Disposall, using newspaper advertising in key cities to tap the garbage disposer market offered by the nation's thirty-five million wall-type sinks. Store displays as well as specialized product newspaper advertising will back the campaign to widen the market for this appliance, which has previously been sold mainly as an item for new sinks.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- President Truman will send to Congress within a week or ten days a report on the economic condition of the country at mid-year, it was made known today. He will reiterate many of the sobering observations he made in his formal economic message on Jan. 8.

JERUSALEM, July 11 -- A new element was strongly introduced into the deliberations of the United Nations Special Committee on the future of Palestine today. The Anglican Bishop of Jerusalem demanded that if Palestine remained a unitary state the Christian voice in the government should be strong enough to assure justice to the country's Christian minority.

NEW DELHI, India, July 11 -- The allotment of armed forces between the Dominions of India and Pakistan was announced tonight by the Partition Council. It gives a heavier share to India on the basis of need. The Royal Indian Air Force and a few Army units remain to be divided.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 11 -- The American Graves Registration unit was subject to a strong editorial attack today by Tanyug, official news agency, which charged its members with having used the unit as a cover for spying.

Joseph G. Papa, head of the union whose members truck food and produce throughout the city, admitted yesterday before a House of Representatives subcommittee in the Federal Building the union entrusted to him the power to close a business for violation of its contract with the union. The committee is investigating the causes of rising food prices and labor racketeering.

The Newark City Commission moved yesterday to arrange for official consideration of the latest offer of the Port of New York Authority for the lease of Newark Airport and marine terminal, and hope was expressed that the offer might be approved within a month.

CHICAGO, July 11 (AP) -- Livestock closed one of its most active weeks in several months today showing continued strength and with prices $1.00 to $2.00 higher on hogs than a week ago and as much as $1.50 up on cattle and spring lambs.

Vic Lombardi, the vest pocket southpaw, gave an Ebbets Field crowd of 31,508 fans their biggest thrill of the series last night as he whitewashed the Cubs on four hits while the Dodgers made it three straight over the Bruins by a 5-0 count.

The most disappointed trippers of this vacation season had returned to New York yesterday -- thirty-seven boys whose all-summer "adventurous" canoe trip through the Canadian north woods had foundered on financial rocks after a $25,000 expenditure by their parents.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- In a long, grave conference today Secretary of State Marshall put before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee this Government's anxious view of a continent breaking in two by the total withdrawal of the Soviet bloc from joint efforts at Europe's rehabilitation.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- A Republican and a Democratic Senator joined today in a proposal to lift the Taft-Hartley law ban on union political expenditures. This is the provision which some unions have decided to violate on grounds that it interferes with freedom of press and speech and is therefore unconstitutional.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill providing for the re-establishment, with modifications, of quotas on sugar production and imports that had been suspended during the war years.

LONDON, July 11 (AP) -- The Evening Standard said today the directors of the Argentine Railways may expect some trouble from shareholders irked because the directors failed to show the basis on which the Argentine purchase money has been allocated to different share categories.

CAMP BARRE, Pa., July 11 -- Post-war Girl Scouts "have ceased to be children, they are older for their ages than six years ago, with a more mature point of view," Mrs. Paul Rittenhouse, director of the National Girl Scouts declared today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The dispatch from Jerusalem by your correspondent Clifton Daniel, dated June 23, which appeared in your issue of June 24, regarding the testimony -- behind closed doors -- of the Palestine Government, before the United Nations Special Committee, contains a rather interesting insight into the official British approach to the Palestine problem.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee voted today to report out a measure authorizing continuation, until the end of the year, of controls on consumer credit.

HONOLULU, July 11 (AP) -- Congress of Industrial Organizations workers went on strike against Hawaii's multi-million-dollar pineapple industry today, and the paralysis quickly spread to the waterfront as stevedores joined the cannery picket lines.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 11 -- After a seven-hour hearing lasting until nearly 2 o'clock this morning, the Zoning Board of Appeals in the Town of Oyster Bay reserved decision on the application of Long Island University of Brooklyn to occupy the estate of Mrs. Joseph E. Davies in Brookville.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 11 -- The next President of the United Nations General Assembly and the chairmen of the main committees will be provided with a manual, now being compiled, telling them how they can most efficiently run their meetings.

PRAGUE, July 11 -- The vast majority of Czechs and Slovaks are extremely distressed that second thoughts have caused the Czechoslovak Government to withdraw from the Paris conference on the Marshall offer. They see in the Prague action a distinct blow to the efforts to unify Europe economically.

TOKYO, July 11 -- Preliminary steps have been taken toward creation of a revolving fund for financing Japanese foreign trade and industrial recovery. The State, War and Navy Departments' coordinating committee, which advises General MacArthur on policy, has approved the revolving fund plan virtually as proposed here but stipulated that it shall become effective after the Supreme Command of the Allied Powers receives an official directive from the Far Eastern commission.
An active and buoyant cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday carried prices upward to net grains of 18 to 50 points.
The prospect of six nights at sea in an upper berth only an inch longer than his 6-foot 2-inch overall frame proved to much for screen actor Dennis Morgan yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, July 11 -- "For New York, Newsom pitching." The cry will ring out in Chicago Sunday, unless Manager Bucky Harris' plans undergo a sudden change.

BERLIN, July 11 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay made it known today that United States and British Military Government officials would go to Washington to discuss the Ruhr production problem. Coal is just not being produced while the rest of Europe, to say nothing of Germany, is depending upon it.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 11 -- The Soviet Union objected today to a British move to allow membership on the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East to any dependent country proposed by the supervisory state.

A decision was handed down yesterday in the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court, First Department, upholding the principle that the purchaser of a cooperative apartment is a landlord and entitled to sue to evict the present tenant.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- Peanut processors testified today the industry will use "very little" of the 1947 crop unless there is relief from what they termed "extravagantly high" prices.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday dismissed an appeal brought by Arnold Bernstein of Larchmont who sought $900,000 from a Belgian shipping company for the loss of a unit of a fleet of ships he operated in Germany prior to 1937.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 11 -- Bulgaria appeared before the United Nations Security Council today to challenge that it had the right to set up a permanent Balkan investigation commission without the consent of all the states involved in the Greek border warfare.

A Navy diver found yesterday twenty-five feet down in the Harlem River at 135th Street a safe identified by one of two prisoners as the one they had stolen a year ago and in which they had left $60,000 worth of bonds and antique jewelry valued at $6,000. Authorities found nothing of value in it.

TOLEDO, July 11 (AP) -- The tenth Inverness four-ball matches settled down to a two-team race at the end of three of the seven best-ball rounds today, with defending champions Ben Hogan and Jimmy Demaret firing a pair of sixty-two totals to take a 1-point lead.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- By voice vote the House of Representatives passed today a measure sharply curtailing the Federal Power Commission's control over production and distribution of natural gas and setting up a new formula for fixing wholesale and -- indirectly -- consumer rates.

The need for instruction of Chinese parents in matters of sanitation and nutrition to reduce the high death rate among children in China was emphasized by four Chinese women pediatricians at a meeting here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- A basic policy for Japan until a peace treaty is signed was issued by the Far Eastern Commission today. It constitutes final approval of a set of fundamental principles that had been under continual examination since the organization of the commission.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11 (AP) -- Billy Cox clouted four safeties tonight as Ernie Bonham held the Phillies to six hits to give the Pirates a 7-2 triumph in the third game of their series before 12,670 fans. It was Bonham's seventh victory against two setbacks.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 11 -- The question as to what Mary Pickford and Charles Chaplin will do regarding a new president for United Artists was undecided at a late hour here this afternoon. Although due to arrive from New York by plane last night, Miss Pickford did not get in until this morning, thirteen hours behind schedule.

The New York Athletic Club's yachting department last night started its thirty-eighth annual sailing race out to Block Island. This morning its thirty-fourth event for motor boats will get under way. The course from the Execution lighthouse buoy to the entrance to West Harbor is 106 miles.

The Atlantic Coast district of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, unanimously adopted yesterday a resolution to cooperate with other AFL organizations "to bring about the repeal" of the Taft-Hartley law "and the defeat of those who voted for it."
HAWORTH, N.J., July 11 -- Under threatening skies a field of forty-four golfers took part in a one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the White Beeches Club here today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11. The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today an application filed by the American Power and Light Company whereby it would issue $29,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, due 1977, of which $26,900,000 would be sold at competitive bidding.

CINCINNATI, July 11 -- The National Education Association, in the closing hours of its five-day convention today, declared against strikes by teachers. The resolution adopted asserted that members should seek salary adjustments "in a professional way through group action," and added:

In view of the action impending by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service of setting the length of next fall's duck season and the bag limits, two reports that came in yesterday may be of interest. One was from Bert W. Cartwright, chief naturalist of Ducks Unlimited.

BOSTON, July 11 (AP) -- J.H. Carr's Gray Star, 4-year-old roan filly, won her third consecutive sprint victory today, defeating Tom Haskos' Windmill by a neck with T.C. Melrose's Foxy Nettle third, two lengths farther back, before a crowd of 13,609 at Suffolk Downs.

PARIS, Juply 11 -- Distinguished members of international society, the French couture and the press were guests last evening at a supper party given by Charles James, the first American dressmaker since the, war to show a collection in Paris.

PARIS, July 11 -- At 11 o'clock tomorrow morning in a large, ornate dining room at the French Foreign Office, delegates of sixteen European nations will meet in a conference that was called into being by a suggestion made by the Secretary of State of the United States five weeks ago.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 11 (AP) -- Lanlast, a New Jersey-bred son of Catalan and Last Light and owned by Mrs. W.W. Vaughan, sprung a mild surprise by beating seven rivals in the six-furlong Select Purse at Monmouth Park today.

We have had a costly lesson this year in the necessity for further control of the Upper Mississippi and Missouri Rivers and their tributaries. This investment of at least a quarter of a billion dollars is not recoverable, except as it may stimulate action to prevent such losses in the future.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies increased 19.8 per cent in June compared with the same month last year, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. This compared with a rise of 25.8 per cent in May.
TRENTON, N.J., July 11 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's office announced today he had vetoed twelve measures adopted by the Legislature in its closing hours on April 22.

Steve Belloise knocked out Georgie Abrams in a savage battle at Madison Square Garden last night. The fight, scheduled for 10 rounds, ended in the fifth when Referee Johnny Burns called a halt with Abrams on the floor just as the bell signaled the end of the session.

NANKING, July 11 (Reuters) -- The Chinese Foreign Ministry announced today that they had lodged new protests with both Soviet Russia and Outer Mongolia against the alleged attack on Chinese positions in Sinkiang, northwest Chinese Province.

NANKING, July 11 -- Goverment and Communist troops have made gains in new hostilities in Shantung. The fighting will test the ability of Government forces to progress with the task of defeating the Communists on the most crucial front in China proper and opening communications to Tientsin.
CHICAGO, July 11 (AP) -- Lured by an, $80,000 purse, seventeen 2-year-olds today were nominated for the eighteenth running of the Arlington Futurity tomorrow at Arlington Park.

The stock market yesterday came close to the year's previous high, with prices up 1 to 3 points and the average raised by 1.25 points. Some easing occurred during the last few minutes of trading, but most issues managed to retain the early gains.

A private passenger car owner who "tried to mislead the court, taking advantage of the hue and cry against garage owners," was fined $15 yesterday for overtime parking. Originally he had received a suspended sentence on the charge.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 11 -- Termination of British control of the Sudan and "total and immediate" evacuation of Egypt, "including the Sudan," by British troops were demanded by Egypt in an appeal today to the United Nations Security Council.

Although allocations of virtually all carpet lines will be continued for the remainder of the year, most mills win substantially increase them, it was learned yesterday. Moreover, return of a few lines and qualities to the "free" list before the first of the year was termed "entirely possible" by several mill executives.

CLEVELAND, July 11 (AP) -- Bouncing back from their no-hit, no-run loss to Cleveland's Don Black, the Philadelphia Athletics today snapped the Tribe's three-game winning streak by rapping two Indian hurlers for nine hits and a 4-2 victory.

Despite increased costs of materials, including coke, scrap and pig iron, Barnett Foundry Machine Company, Irvington, N.J., has decided to absorb these expenses and continue to guarantee second quarter prices to its customers for the third quarter, H.K. Edinger, president, revealed here yesterday.

Substantial orders for modernization equipment were placed at the first Store Modernization Show at the Grand Central Palace, it was reported here yesterday. The show, confined to the trade, closes tonight at 6 P.M.

At eleven o'clock this morning the representatives of sixteen European nations will meet in Paris in a conference that has a brighter prospect of success than any other of the long series of conferences that have been held since the war's end. The reason for this, to put it bluntly, is that Russia will not be there.

PARIS, July 11 -- Asserting that the International Cereals Conference findings permitted "no other conclusion than a very serious deficit in grain" for the coming year, a special committee today voted a series of motions that would recommend that:

Three of the ushers completed this week a decade as guides in showing thousands of worshipers through the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, of which the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick is pastor emeritus and the Rev. Dr. Robert James McCracken is pastor.

The summer weeks bring with them hot and sultry days, and there is nothing so comforting and refreshing as a dip into the spraying surf of the ocean or the placid waters of the creek or lake or, for that matter, the outdoor swimming pool. Record throngs here in the city already have visited the more than fourteen miles of shorefront and seventeen outdoor pools maintained by the Department of Parks.

"Flying saucers" were just so many brass rings on the publicity agents' merry-go-'round yesterday Otherwise, apart from a few scattered reports from Japan and Holland, the sky seemed to have returned to normalcy.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 10 (Delayed) -- Soviet authorities today suspended indefinitely the publication of an independent Bucharest newspaper, thereby demonstrating again their acute sensitivity concerning any references to territorial acquisitions made by Russia during the period of the German-Soviet pact.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In an editorial on the recent election in Spain you give new life to an oversimplification that has already appeared in your news columns when you state that "the National Confederation of Labor, which is said to be dominated by anarchists, is politically monarchist."

Jules J. Lieventhal's edition of "Joan of Lorraine" starring Sylvia Sidney, which opened this week on the subway circuit, has been booked for a tour of three major cities. The tour will keep the company busy until Sept. 6, when -- the Playwright's Company willing -- it could become an entry in next season's Broadway sweepstakes.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- The House Armed Services Committee concluded public consideration of universal military training today with a barrage of opposition testimony and complaints of "unbalanced" hearings.

STOCKHOLM, July 11 -- A new cultural technique for growing tubercle bacilli was reported today at the International Congress for Experimental Cytology by Dr. Rene J. Dubos of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research in New York.

BRUNSWICK, Ga., July 11 (AP) -- Five Negro convicts were shot to death and eight others were wounded, two critically, in an escape attempt at a state highway work camp today, Warden W.G. Worthy said. The camp is an all-Negro prison and has about seventy-five inmates.

Clearances Mark Trade Retail trade here continued fairly active this week on seasonal merchandise. Clearances of summer merchandise were begun, some ranging up to 50 per cent of former levels. Estimates put department store volume at about 8 per cent ahead of the like week last year.
Buddy Behrens of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Sidney Schwartz of Brooklyn stroked their way into the singles final yesterday in the Eastern junior tennis tournament at the Poly Prep courts in Brooklyn.

ST. LOUIS, July 11 -- Base hits for the Yankees were on the rationed list today. Bucky Harris' troupe got only three, but these were enough to beat the Browns in a twilight game at Sportsman's Park. The New Yorkers thus stretched their league lead to nine games and soared to a season's major league high with their tenth straight victory.The score was 3-1.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: When one thinks of peace, one thinks of the organization of the United Nations, created by the world's great powers for the express purpose of preserving peace. Undoubtedly the most fruitful thing that we in this country can do to stave off war is to make sure that our Government gives its full support to the United Nations.

CHICAGO, July 11 (AP) -- Champion Tony Zale and Challenger Rocky Graziano did some carefully observed breathing, muscle-flexing and squinting for the Illinois Athletic Commission today. Then they were pronounced fit as fiddles for their world middleweight title bout at the Chicago Stadium next Wednesday night.

The investigation into the three-day-old strangling murder of Mrs. Sheila Mannering went into its routine phase yesterday. Deputy Chief Inspector Edward J. Mullins reported in the afternoon that "there is nothing new."

CHICAGO, July 11 (AP) -- Livestock and meat authorities in the nation's largest marketing center disagreed today as to the effect on supplies indicated in the Government's forecast of a sharp drop in the corn crop.

CALCUTTA, India, July 11 -- For the first day in five. Calcutta enjoyed some respite today from all-out communal strife. A day that began furtively, with shops shut and no public vehicles on the roads, saw the city grow busier as the hours advanced, and by evening only ten "incidents" -- a word that in official parlance covers anything from the use of a Sten gun to a brick -- had been reported.

N.Y. City Housing Authority The New York City Housing Authority yesterday awarded issues of temporary loan notes dated July 29, 1947, and due on Feb. 10, 1948, at bids ranging from 0.85 per cent to 0.82 per cent for $1,651,000 of notes and at bids ranging from 0.76 per cent to 0.74 per cent for $500,000.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Two color television systems developed by Alfred N. Goldsmith of New York and assigned by him to the Radio Corporation of America, were among the 388 inventions on which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 11 -- Such havoc has been caused within the core of the atom by the University of California's giant new cyclotron that twenty-two, and possibly as many as thirty, nuclear particles have been freed from it in a single bombardment, compared with the normal two or three blasted out of atomic nuclei by former atom smashers, it was reported today at a meeting of the American Physical Society at Stanford University.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 11 -- Frank Parker, national clay court champion from Hollywood, Calif., and Edward Moylan of San Francisco, ninth in the ranking, gained the two remaining semi-final brackets in the Spring Lake invitation tennis tournament today at the Bathing and Tennis Club.

At 7:17 P.M. yesterday Umpire Al Barlick declared it too dark for the Giants and Cardinals to complete the second game of their twin bill at the Polo Grounds. Ordinarily, there would have been room for argument, but the Giants the Cardinals and those of the original crowd of 35,664 still on the premises gladly awarded the benefit of the doubt to the arbiter.

NOORDWIJK - ON - THE - SEA, The Netherlands, July 11 (AP) -- Miss Doris Hart of Miami, Fla., and Mrs. Pat Todd of Hidden Valley, Calif., Wimbledon doubles champions, defeateAd their Dutch doubles opponents in the Noordwijk international tennis tournament today, but both were upset in singles.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- A bill recommending a $1,048,266,136 outlay during the current fiscal year for Federal farm programs was sent to the Senate today by its Appropriations Committee.

If Europe is indeed to be split between East and West, Russia will certainly intensify her effort to influence the policy of France. A strong and well-disciplined Fifth Column marches there. Without France the West cannot coalesce. A Russian veto exercised through France would doom all hope of Western cooperation.

Iron, Scrap Higher Two forerunners of higher steel prices -- increases in the prices of iron and scrap material -- were announced yesterday. The E. G. Brooke Iron Company of Birdsboro, Pa., advanced the price of pig iron $6 a ton across the board, while the Alan Wood Steel Company of Swedeland, Pa., raised the price of basic iron by $1 a ton.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Secretary of War Patterson today filed with the Speaker of the House a War Department bill that would adopt the Hoover plan for the charter of idle Liberty ships to German, and, later, to Japanese citizens for the shipments of food abroad.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- A $75,000,000 Increase in 1948 operating funds for the Atomic Energy Commission was voted by the Senate Appropriations Committee today after a heated argument.

Somewhere in New York there may be someone who has a grand piano for which he has no use. To such a person, the Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases, which has a real need for that piano, issued an appeal yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- A $6,000,000,000 cut in individual income taxes and a 50 per cent limit on taxation of big earnings was proposed to Congress today by the National Association of Manufacturers.

SEOUL, Korea, July 11 -- United States Military Government authorities yesterday scrapped former orders prohibiting mass meetings of Koreans during the discussions of the Joint United States-Soviet Commission.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 -- Scientists working under military secrecy have made their first attempts to hurl objects off the earth and turn them into satellites destined to circle around the globe forever.

Talks between officials of the striking Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, and the Bethlehem Steel Company were resumed yesterday afternoon after a three-day adjournment. No progress was reported after a two and one-half hour meeting in the offices of the United States Conciliation Service, 341 Ninth Avenue.
NEW LONDON, Conn., July 11 -- Seventy men were "rescued" today from a "disabled" submarine, out of the New London submarine base. It was a search and rescue drill, not often executed recently.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The possibility of an all-night Senate meeting, the second within a month, arose today as Republican leaders drove for passage of the second tax reduction bill before recessing tomorrow.

DETROIT, July 11 (AP) -- Little Stubby Overmire saved the Detroit Tigers' precarious hold on second place in the American League today by blanking the Boston Red Sox, 3 -- 0, after the Sox had won the opener of a double-header, 4 -- 3.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 11 (U.P.) -- Cuba's controversial winter league was formally accepted into organized baseball as an unclassified minor circuit today in a move which National Association Commissioner George M. Trautman labeled "mutually beneficial" to Cuban and American baesball.

LONDON, July 11 -- Britons heard some blunt talking today from United States Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman at a press conference in the United States Embassy. He dashed some hopes regarding British rights under the Marshall plan, stressed the importance the United States placed on the Ruhr, explained United States export problems and pointed up Britain's low coal production.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 -- Longshore walking bosses affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations began picketing the piers of the Luckenbach Steamship Company today in a move which, the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union predicted, was expected to spread "to the entire waterfront and other ports."

PARIS, July 11 -- Using United States Army surplus material, including tents, cots, blankets and equipment, visiting American students are camping in the midst of Paris in a tent center on a vacant lot near the National Assembly.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Albert D. Lasker, donor of several million dollars to cancer-research projects since his retirement five years ago as chief executive of the Lord and Thomas Advertising Agency, today spent four hours before the Senate Sub-committee on Health testifying for the Murray-Wagner-Dingell Health Insurance Bill.

LONDON, July 11 -- Unpublished writings of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, including an important new Sherlock Holmes manuscript, have been found in an old cardboard hatbox in the vaults of an English country bank.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 -- The International Society of Christian Endeavor, at its annual convention here today, approved "in principle" a proposal for a worldwide union of Christian Endeavor, the United Christian Youth Movement and other Protestant Evangelical youth agencies into "an ecumenical Christian youth movement for Christ and the Church."
Only five are in it, but there's no lack of quality in the line-up for the thirteenth running of the $50,000 added Butler Handicap at Jamaica today.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The British Government will send a mission here to discuss "urgent problems" concerning the improvement of coal production in the United States and British zones of Germany, the State Department said today.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (Science Service) -- An effort to cut down one of the worst of this country's metal wastes, the discarding of empty food cans, is represented in a patent, No. 423,708, taken out by two New York inventors, T.P. Keogh and H.A. Fink, and assigned to the Continental Can Company.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Dwight P. Griswold, administrator of the United States program for aiding Greece under the Truman Doctrine, announced today that $35,000,000 of military supplies already were on their way to United States ports for shipment to Greece to equip her army on "an anti-bandit basis."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is indeed sad to read that the way to get truly democratic legislation in Washington nowadays is by inciting our distinguished legislators to vengeance and retribution.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Dwight P. Griswold, administrator of the United States program for aiding Greece under the Truman Doctrine, announced today that $35,000,000 of military supplies already were on their way to United States ports for shipment to Greece to equip her army on "an anti-bandit basis."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is indeed sad to read that the way to get truly democratic legislation in Washington nowadays is by inciting our distinguished legislators to vengeance and retribution.

In presenting the Republican tax reduction bill to the Senate for the second time in the present session of Congress Senator Millikin of Colorado supported his plea for the measure with some budgetary figures for the fiscal year 1947-48.
ANKARA, Turkey, July 10 (Delayed) -- Premier Recep Peker, in a declaration tonight, made clear that he would not resign but remain in power until overthrown by a parliamentary vote.

TOKYO, July 11 -- Widespread public protests have begun to appear in Hokkaido, Japan's northernmost and poorest island, over the long delays in the distribution of food rations. The delays average fifty days throughout the Prefecture. In some communities no food has been available, except on the black market, for three months.

GENEVA, July 11 -- A resolution laying down the basic principles of freedom of association and the right to organize and bargain collectively was unanimously adopted by the International Labor Conference which ended here tonight. The conference also asked the governing body to examine the question of establishing international machinery to safeguard that freedom.

SWRYE, N.Y., July 11 -- Three extrahole matches and the ousting of the pair that tied for medal honors high-lighted today's second round in the New York State Golf Association's silver anniversary championship at the Westchester Country Club.

AMSTERDAM, July 11 (ANETA) -- The Government's policy statement on Indonesia had little apparent influence on the market, as trading was quiet and prices for the most part showed little change. Indies plantations issues and shipping shares closed higher, while industrials and oil stocks were lower.

That large group, including many men, who pride themselves on the special dressings they make for green salads imply that it's done by some mysterious method that they alone can understand. Actually, we think, it's because they avail themselves of the various ingredients for unusual dressings, which may be found by anyone who does a bit of looking around in the stores here.

The summer replacement for "The Theatre Guild on the Air" will make its debut tomorrow night at 10 o'clock on the WJZ-ABC network as the "Hour of Music" and reveal a grab-bag format. In addition to music, fantasy and dramatic episodes from the lives of great composers will be offered as drawing cards.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Legislation to enable the United States to assume trusteeship over strategic Pacific islands wrested from Japan was unanimously passed by the House today.

ATHENS, July 11 -- In an effort to allay any doubts about the existence of a revolutionary plot that has caused the Greek police to arrest more than 3,000 Communists since early Wednesday, Napoleon Zervas, Minister of Public Order, today told a press conference about Communist "Plan F" and "Order G."

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 11 -- The second annual Riverside Yacht Club race to Nantucket was started tonight off here, with a fleet of fourteen. This year it is to be a one-way event, and not another race back after a layover.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Army failed to hit its monthly recruiting target of 30,000 men even in the high-school graduation month of June, it was learned today.

The conference that opens in Paris this morning is the fruit of a grand conception. It represents a sweeping detour around the broken bridge which has stalled the conventional approaches to European recovery and peace. The Moscow meeting of the Big Four proved that we were getting nowhere on the political road.
LOS ANGELES, July 12 -- California Democrats, whose destiny for the past year has been directed by James Roosevelt, are going through a process somewhat resembling atomic fission.

BOSTON, July 12 -- A male youth should have an average of 90 per cent marks, or better, in his pre-university studies to be sure of being admitted, without influence, in the principal institutions of higher learning in New England.

AS E.M. Forster nears the age of 70, his literary productiveness, which has always been distinguished for its quality rather than extinguished by its abundance, is not likely henceforth to be very great. In fact, though the fact seems incredible, it is nearly twenty years now since Forster has published any new fiction.

NANKING, July 12 -- As a result of a State Council resolution last week and subsequent pronouncements from President Chiang Kaishek and Premier Chang Chun, the Chinese Government today stands committed to uncompromising all-out "war to the death" with the Chinese Communists.
TOKYO, July 12 -- Never in modern times has Japan faced a food situation more critical than at present, according to officials of Supreme Headquarters.

THE endless debate about the educational value of radio is being reconsidered locally since the opening last week of the first college nou-commercial station in the metropolitan area. The new outlet is WFUV, operated by Fordham University under a temporary license from the Federal Communications Commission on 90.1 megacycles in the Frequency Modulation band.

JERUSALEM, July 12 -- The willingness of the world Zionist movement to consider proposals for a partition of Palestine was repudiated today by the United Zionist Revisionists, who rejoined the movement last year.

DR. SHELLABARGER is a scholar of the Renaissance, but he is also a disciple of Dumas: the synthesis, as readers of his "Captain From Castile" will remember, makes for enchantment. Now comes "Prince of Foxes," another swashbuckling romance in the unabashed cloak-and-dagger tradition.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation late today arrested two former Army sergeants accused of taking atomic bomb documents, some of them said to be "top secret," from the Los Alamos (N.M.) testing station.

FEW authors of informal musical memoirs have dealt as charmingly with such a variety of topics, places and people as has Mr. Helnsheimer. Equally familiar with Europe and America, he moves from dusky music offices in Vienna to swimming pools in Hollywood, from clamorous cocktail parties in New York City to Berlin in the early days of the Nazis, from a town in Texas to the sophisticated salons of Paris.
PARIS, July 12 (AP) -- Following are the texts of the statements of French Foreign Minister Bidault and British Foreign Secretary Bevin at the opening session of the Paris aid conference:

Work was started by private builders last month on only 630 dwelling units in New York City, as compared with 1,150 in May and 2,590 in June last year, according to a report issued yesterday by the Bureau of Labor Statistics on the basis of figures compiled by the Department of Housing and Buildings.

A soldier AWOL from Camp Kilmer, N.J., was accused yesterday of holding up three taxicab drivers in rapid succession. He was caught just after he allegedly had taken $12 from the third victim. The arrest was made by Patrolman Walter Rowley, who felled the suspect, John Burns, 24 years old, with a blow from his service revolver.

COOPERSTOWN -- This gracious old village with its wide streets, its great trees, its fine early houses, and its abundance of historical and literary associations, has been a mecca for travelers for 150 years. Now, with three museums in operation, including the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum, Cooperstown continues to gain popularity as a tourist attraction.

OTTAWA, July 12 -- Twenty parties are in the field throughout the Northwest Territories of Canada prospecting for radioactive materials, Reconstruction Minister C.D. Howe told the House of Commons this morning during a debate in the committee on the expenses of the Atomic Energy Control Board.

PRAGUE, July 12--Communist Premier Klement Gottwald and Foreign Minister Jan Masaryk returned from Moscow today with a five-year Czechoslovak-Soviet trade agreement in return for Czechoslovakia's boycott of the Paris Marshall plan conference.

GENEVA, Switzerland, July 12 (U.P.) -- The United Nations Economic Commission for Europe voted today to set up a "Committee on Industry and Materials" with power to recommend increased production of scarce goods as well as suggest improved use or economy in their consumption.

ST. LOUIS, July 12 -- The Mississippi River was dropping rapidly tonight after thirty - four days above flood stage during which it reached the highest crest in 103 years. It was expected to be back within its banks by midnight. The Missouri River at St. Charles, north of St. Louis, was expected to return to its banks tomorrow.

James T. Watters of 2626 Kings Highway, Brooklyn, was elected yesterday commander of the Kings County American Legion in the closest election since 1936. Mr. Watters, the administration candidate, defeated Howard Anderson, county vice commander, by a vote of 910 to 744.

NORTHPORT, L.I., July 12 -- A civil engineer for the State of New York, Arthur Johnson of Huntington, today demonstrated that he was the best yacht navigator among the Long Island North Shore group of power squadrons gathering in the local harbor for a week-end of high jinks.

Basil Goulandris, chairman or the board of the General Steam Navigation Company (Greek Line), declared here yesterday that Liberty ships bought from this country by Greece have been providing satisfactory service for their present operators.

IN 1946 a scientific forum was held in Pittsburgh, a three-day affair celebrating the hundredth birthday anniversary of George Westinghouse, inventor of the air brake, pioneer in the manufacture of electrical devices and chief parent of the organization known today as the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

ANY chance that there would be a price collapse similar to that of 1920-21 in the month of May this year was removed from calculations some Weeks ago, of course. Retailers stood out against high prices after Easter to little avail.

OF all European cities, perhaps only Rome, Venice, and Paris have maintained throughout many centuries such a constant appeal to the foreign visitor as has Oxford. It is not easy to account for this attraction.

THIS book is a collection of good stories, told with the simplicity of Aesop and the humanity of Saroyan. The stories are about Greeks, Greeks in Macedonia and Greeks in America, potters and waiters, blacksmiths and professors, doctors and models, sculptors and adventurers.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 12 (AP) -- Yankee Valor easily won the $50,000 Hollywood Derby today, defeating the favored On Trust and eight other 3-year-olds in the seventh running of the race before 38,657 fans at Hollywood Park.

Out of America's 140,000,000 souls, hardly more than a baker's dozen have driven a speed boat a mile a minute. It takes dare-deviltry to try it. The slightest irregular ripple can catapult a hydroplane out of the water, and on a really rough regatta course the pilot is puddle-jumping and soaring through the air about half the time, always hoping he lands right side up.

The Rev. John E. Odou, founder and director of the National Convert Makers of America, who is stationed in Los Angeles, will come to New York soon to intensify on the Atlantic Coast the activities of the comparatively new organization.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- John L. Lewis' tour de force in coal this week jolted economists who were enjoying a respite from charts and slide rules.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The standard of living of the average American today -- in terms of weekly wages and what they will buy -- still is almost ten times higher than that of the average Russian worker.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 12 -- State Guardsmen from New York and Brooklyn will start occupying Camp Smith exclusively tomorrow (Sunday) as the Seventh and Eighth Infantry Regiments of New York and the Fourteenth Infantry of Brooklyn replace the Twelfth of New York, Thirteenth of Brooklyn, Sixty-fifth of Buffalo and the Sixth of Utica.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 12 -- Chester W. Bowles, former economic stabilizer of the United States, has been asked to head the United Nations' world-wide appeal for funds to feed and clothe needy children of all countries, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, July 12--An attempt to assassinate Senator John W. Bricker of Ohio, candidate for the Vice Presidency in 1944 and a possible candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1948, failed today.

THE Russians' bold post-war expansion across the face of Europe did not stop at the Atlantic Ocean. The propaganda salient that is such an integral part of their campaign was projected well ahead into New York City, Buffalo, Detroit, Chicago and other centers of the foreign-born and of those of foreign extraction.

The ten-goal Cecil Smith will head a Texas side against the Brookfield quartet led by Henry Lewis in the second match of Pete Bostwick's $5,000 handicap polo tournament today at Bostwick Field, Old Westbury, L.I. The match is scheduled to begin at 3:30 o'clock.

A crowd of 16,500, the third largest of the season, turned out last night for the New York Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra's second annual "Italian Night" at the Lewisohn Stadium. From the applause and the way the audience disbanded, whistling and humming the familiar melodies, it was plain everyone had a good time.

Any restoration of import restrictions on sugar by Congress to pre-war levels would have a serious effect on the economic life of Peru and virtually would close the United States sugar market to that country, Dr. Enrique Garcia-Sayan, Peruvian Minister of Foreign Affairs and Culture declared here yesterday.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 12 -- What remains of democracy in Hungary seemed today to be making its last effort to struggle out of the grasp of the Russian-backed Marxist bloc that is seeking to install a puppet government by means of a new election law.

HOLLYWOOD. FOUR gentlemen of imposing reputation in the world of the stage and screen are putting their heads together at Universal-International Studio these days in an amiable conspiracy which may produce something of a stir during the coming Presidential year.

ALTHOUGH much has been written about the Nuremberg trials, this book is original in form and content. Dr. Gilbert (Ph. D. Columbia), the official prison psychologist, gave the defendants psychological tests. But as an experienced psychologist he does not rely too much on formal tests and spares the reader their details.

MR. CORWIN'S latest collection consists of seventeen radio scripts, all written during the war years. The first ones in point of time (1942) are from the "American in England" series; the last (1945) are "On a Note of Triumph," done on the fall of Germany, "14 August," ditto Japan, and "Set Your Clock at U235," on the atomic bomb.

President and Congress At the start of 1947 relations between the Democratic President and the new Republican Congress were relatively cordial. Once a week Congressional leaders of both parties conferred with Mr. Truman at the White House.

ATHENS, July 12 -- Nicolas Zachariades, secretary general of the Greek Communist party, broached openly in Athens today the prospect of a separate Leftist partisan "free state" in the north. He held out a "final" olive branch to the Athens Government.

THIS department has been poring over some recently published research concerning children who can't carry a tune. The purpose of this study was to discover whether children who are "monotones" are also maladjusted in personality.

FOLLOWING receipt of "many complaints concerning the recent Roosevelt issues of various countries," the American Stamp Dealers Association announced last week through its president, Peter G. Keller, that it had directed inquiries to several of the Governments which have postally honored the late Franklin D. Roosevelt.

JIMMY STEWART, whose years in the limelight have been divided almost equally between playing in the movies and flying for Uncle Sam, never has had the misfortune to crack up. But he nevertheless finds himself at the moment somewhat in the position of a man who has spun in, and is quickly taking another flight to forestall loss of nerve.

Statements of the fifteen largest banks here of their condition on June 30 showed many gains in the second quarter and a less severe adverse comparison with a year ago. Deposits and resources of the banks in the quarter increased for the first time since 1945.

The part played by pre-fabricated units in solving the housing problem is the subject of a symposium in the current issue of Tomorrow's Town, publication of the National Committee on Housing, in which the contributors express widely different opinions as to what may be expected from factory-built homes.

BUCHAREST, July 12 -- Five top leaders of the Rumanian Government left Bucharest for Sofia today for important conferences with the Bulgarian Government. It is planned to forge another link in the Soviet scheme for organizing Eastern Europe.

CHARLESTON, S.C., July 12--South Carolina Negroes won a court victory today in their fight for the right to participate in the state's Democratic primary, limited by party rules since 1944 exclusively to "white Democrats."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is gratifying to see how quickly some of the European nations took Mr. Marshall's hint and gathered to seek a common solution of their economic problems. After two years lost in the vain pursuit of a political agreement, it is at long last recognized that economic problems cannot wait.

IT is one of those curious paradoxes that unfathomable Hollywood, in all its eager pursuit of story material, should so seldom turn unto itself. For it goes without too much demonstration that the movies and their makers themselves are one of the most fascinating subjects in our crazy contemporary life.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., July 12 (AP) -- Irvingr Mondschein, New York University track ace, led the field today at the end of the first day's events in the twenty-ninth annual National A.A.U. decathlon championship at Foley Field.

ELLEN MARSH, if we may believe the critical hosannas that greeted her first novel ("Drink to the Hunted"), is a young novelist to be reckoned with. Her second book, though it is an egregious failure, confirms that impression.

BATAVIA, Java, July 12 -- The Shofuka Maru, former Japanese freighter now flying the British flag, arrived today at Tandjung Priok, Batavia's port, under Netherlands naval orders after being halted by a Netherlands Navy patrol off Lampung Bay, at the southern tip of Sumatra.

THE third program in the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, under the direction of Arthur Mahoney and Thalia Mara, near Lee, Mass., will be of a largely ethnological character this next week-end. Guest artists will be Reginald and Gladys Laubin, and La Meri, and the resident company headed by Miss Mara and Mr. Mahoney will also appear.

JUST before his death in 1945 President Roosevelt asked the advisory board of the Office of War Mobilization and Reconversion to study the whole problem of "guaranteed wages." Recently President Truman released a several-hundred-page economic report on this important issue.
BERLIN, July 12 -- The East-West split on the European rehabilitation program changes Germany's economic outlook only as to degree but carries many political implications.

BENJAMIN BRITTEN'S opera, "The Rape of Lucretia," will be presented at a Broadway theatre during the 1947-48 season. Giovanni Cardelli's Opera Theatre, which gave the American premiere of the work last month in Chicago, has secured the rights to present it in New York and subsequently on tour.

ROME, July 12 -- An article in Osservatore Romano today urges the delegates at the Paris conference so to orient their plans and activities as to overcome the diffidence and hostility of the Soviet Union and pave the way for its eventual participation in Europe's reconstruction.

ON May 5, 1847, some 250 medicos met in the Academy of Natural Sciences in Philadelphia and founded the American Medical Association. Today the association has over 132,000 members; and, as its lobbying and other activities in Washington indicate, it is one of the more powerful pressure groups with which Congress has to cope.
This comes under the head of ancient history, but since the areas covered, Montauk and Peconic Bay, are favorite New York fishing centers, it's passed along as something you may like to know.

PHOTOGRAPHIC paper, reported scarce only a month ago, is now in plentiful supply, according to word received from paper manufacturers in Rochester. New York dealers no longer have difficulty filling customers' orders and papers suspended during the war are gradually being returned to dealers' shelves.

PEORIA, Ill., July 12 (AP) -- Clipping eight strokes off par with 33, 31 -- 64 for a course record, Freddie Haas Jr. of New Orleans sailed into the lead today in the fifty-four-hole $5,000 Peoria open golf tourney.

NANKING, July 12 -- The Resident Committee of the People's Political Council here has issued an appeal to the Government and the Communists to halt fighting along the new course of the Yellow River so dike repairs can be made against threatening flood waters.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- A group of House members considered today cutting Poland and Hungary out of the $350,000,000 European relief program because the two countries and boycotted the Paris conference on the Marshall plan.
HOW a Weston photoelectric exposure meter can be made to give direct readings for color work was revealed recently by Owen K. Taylor of the New York Color Slide Club.

BRUNSWICK, Ga., July 12 (AP) -- A Negro convict told a coroner's jury today that Warden W.G. Worthy was "half drunk" when prison guards opened fire with shotguns on twenty-seven escaping Negro prisoners near here yesterday.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 12 Thomas M. Lane, senior member of the law firm of Lane, Young Fox, 2 Broadway, New York, died here today at his home, 76 Whitehall Boulevard, after an illness of two and a half months. He was 75 years old.

The one most important, and most controversial, change suggested in the system of military justice by a House subcommittee is that which would make the Judge Advocate General's Office a branch of the Army divorced from the line, with a separate promotion list.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass. -- After six years of Army service as a quartermaster depot, the Eastern States Exposition will return to civilian life again with its first post-war show Sept. 14-20. Readying the great 175-acre plant in West Springfield with its many permanent buildings presents a herculean task, which is being vigorously attacked by an army of workmen.

While there are no all-breed dog shows this month or next in the metropolitan area, the game is far from dormant as a glance through the announcements of forthcoming events on the vacation circuit indicates.

BERLIN, July 12 -- The long-awaited new and higher-level industry plan for the economically combined American and British zones of Germany may be disclosed Wednesday, it was indicated today by Gen. Lucius D. Clay after a lengthy session with Lieut. Gen. Sir Brian Robertson.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 12 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, permanent Philippines delegate to the United Nations, declared here today that America needed not only military might but "friendship with other nations" in its quest for peace.

TOKYO, July 12 -- The Far Eastern Commission's announcement of a post-surrender policy for the Japanese provided "the entire framework for a treaty of peace" between the Allies and Japan, Gen. Douglas MacArthur said today.

TO direct the new Policy Planning Staff of the Department of State, General Marshall has chosen George F. Kennan, one of the ablest and most talented American foreign service representatives. At the moment Mr. Kennan is completing one year as Deputy for Foreign Affairs at the War College.
WARTIME experience brought thousands of soldiers into close contact with the field of photography for the first time in their lives, and many of them, apparently, were bitten by the camera "bug."

THREE recently published books on photography have the common aim of offering practical information and instruction. The most comprehensive and important fit the three -- "Graphic Graflex Photography," edited by Willard D. Morgan and Henry M. Lester (New York: Morgan Lester. $4.50) -- is the completely revised eighth edition of a book that has become the standard work on the use of larger cameras.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Attendance during the first week of the Summer Furniture and Home Furnishings Market has been slightly below that of the July, 1946, showing at the Merchandise Mart, Wallace O. Oilman, general manager, disclosed today, while observers stated that a similar situation existed at the American Furniture Mart.

SIC TRANSIT DEPT.: From Partisan Review's Paris correspondent, seen in Les Lettres francaises, a notice, "wherein a lonely lady requests the company of a cultivated gentleman, about 50 years old," and adds, "existentialists please abstain."
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Senate ended an extraordinary Saturday evening session at 8:50 P.M., after an informal agreement had been reached to vote Monday on the tax reduction bill.
