Why is the earth magnetic so that compass needles point north and south? Some physicists found the answer in the nature of the material of which the earth is composed. At a time when it was thought that the earth's core was a huge lump of magnetic iron this hypothesis seemed reasonable enough.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 12 -- Russell Stewart of Albany, N.Y., with his consistent aged bay gelding. My Play Boy, took a big lead toward the open jumping championship of the twenty-second Harrison Horse Show today. The opening sessions of a two-day stand were held at the Kentucky Riding Stable, off the Hutchinson River Parkway.

CINCINNATI, July 12 -- Gathered for their second post-war conference, three thousand of the nation's school leaders examined the state of American education this week, and found that much remained to be done before free public schools were restored to a sound basis.
Harbor police recovered yesterday morning the body of the second youth drowned July 4 off City Island, the Bronx, when a forty-foot cabin cruiser sliced through the rowboat the young men had rented.

With a number of buyers still in town last week, there was considerable activity in domestics, home furnishings, millinery and accessories, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Co., resident buyers.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -- Combining the science of criminal investigation and perseverance, a corporation lawyer has proved the innocence of a man who had served almost twenty-one years of a life prison sentence for a murder he did not commit.
ST. LOUIS, July 12 -- By air, land or water the great flood in the Missouri and upper Mississippi Valleys is an awesome sight.

ROME, July 12 -- Italian Communists consider the Truman Doctrine and the Marshall proposal for European self-help the severest blows yet struck against their chances of world-wide expansion. That much is clear to anyone who has watched the reactions of the Communist leaders and press.

PARIS, July 12 -- The open split between East and West as a consequence of the Russian refusal to participate in the European economic conference suggested by Secretary Marshall, among its many results, has forced the French Communist party into opposition to the Government headed by Socialist Paul Ramadier.

As Senate and House committees near the end of debate on several bills affecting public and private power, observers last week were inclined to look for a victory for Government power advocates. Their main reason, it was said, was the lack of an aggressive, concerted industry drive to offset the growing success of public power.

To the Drama Editor: I WAS greatly disturbed by the recent Helen Hayes article, "How Much Talent?" I have Deen connected for sixteen years with one of the agencies to which she allocates the responsibility of weeding out the undesirables among the youthful aspirants to the theatre.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 12 -- A program to cooperate in distributing the tax dollar in Kentucky, rather than fighting over it, is being supported by the Committee for Kentucky.

IF Lafayette could feel that "every man has two countries, his own and America," there was ampler reason for Mbonu Ojike to feel so, too. In his native Nigeria a handful of whites exploited millions of blacks; what he sought was a place where white and black could live together in relative equality.
This city has a big heart, the directors of the Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases, 444 East Sixty-seventh Street, agreed yesterday.

Three building industry groups which are sponsoring a program to increase the volume of construction work in the New York area have pledged their support to the work being done by the Housing Labor Committee in investigating the building situation, according to Max H. Foley, president of the New York Building Congress.

MOSCOW, July 12 (AP) -- An announcement by the Council of Ministers that medals would be awarded henceforth to Soviet athletes who set national and international records appeared today to have eliminated the last technical obstacle to Russian participation in next year's Olympic Games.

CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- Champion Tony Zale and Challenger Rocky Graziano, the latter confident that "no punch in the belly's gonna stop me this time," today ended heavy preparations for their second middleweight title scrap at the Chicago Stadium Wednesday night.

A fourteen-coach special train carrying 170 Southern Californians on an 11,800-mile tour of the United States and parts of Canada and Mexico arrived here yesterday morning on the first privately organized West-East tour since the end of the war.

SCION of an old and prominent Parsi family of Bombay, Mr. Karaka received his education at the University of Bombay and at Oxford, where he also became the first Indian President of the Union. On his return to India he became a staff writer on The Bombay Chronicle, an influential nationalist daily with liberal leanings, for which he later covered World War II on a number of fronts, from Arakan to Europe.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, July 12 -- A scramble for delegates to next year's Republican national convention got under way here today as Governors began arriving for the thirty-ninth annual Conference of Governors which starts officially tomorrow.

CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- Wheat futures, which advanced sharply yesterday, slumped 2 cents a bushel and more today on profit-taking and other selling, apparently influenced by reports that flour business has fallen off.

Questioning of friends and acquaintances of the woman who called herself Mrs. Sheila Mannering was continued for the fourth day yesterday, but as on the previous days no tangible lead to her slayer was uncovered.

DETROIT, July 12 (AP) -- Lefty Earl Johnson, made his 1947 debut as a starting pitcher a crackling success today by hurling the Boston Red Sox into second place in the American League with a 2-0, six-hit victory over the Detroit Tigers.

PARIS, July 12 -- The demands for wage increases being made on behalf of 1,200,000 civil service workers constitute a menace to the financial structure of the country and a menace to the Fourth Republic, Premier Paul Ramadier said today in a broadcast.

AS a seasoned scenarist and padishah of producers at RKO, Dore Schary, here last week for the company's annual sales convention, told this department that it was unlikely that the studio would be profligate in its story buying.

RYE, N.Y., July 12 -- It will be Up-State vs. the Metropolitan District in tomorrow's final round of the New York State Golf Association's twenty-fifth annual championship at the Westchester Country Club. Stan Kowal of Utica, former lieutenant commander in the Navy, will oppose young Dick Mayer of Winged Foot in the thirty-six hole battle.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 12 -- Acute distress, and in some cases bankruptcy, aces the grape industry in this state unless a Federal raisin program, providing a minimum support price, is instituted for 1947, according to Arpaxat Setrakian of Fresno, grower and president of the Raisin Producers Association of California.

Here it is almost mid-July, Tomatoes are setting on the vines, pie cherries are ripe, early sweet corn is tasseling, squash is in bloom, green beans are ready to be picked. And it seems only a couple of weeks ago that we were wondering if it was ever going to get warm enough to permit planting.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations and its president, Philip Murray, offered themselves today as point blank targets for prosecution under the political-expenditures section of the Taft-Hartley Law.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The world broadcast last Sunday in which President Juan D. Peron emphasized Argentina's "vehement desire for peace and concord" has been received here as a fresh indication of a desire to cement relations in the Western Hemisphere.

IN spite of generous rainfall throughout the spring, a few dry days brought out yellowing patches along the traffic lanes of fresh green lawns. Even a short rainless spell reminds the proud possessor of rich greensward that auxiliary watering is needed to keep the pile of his outdoor carpet thick and resilient.

From a communication published by E.B. Kraus and P. Squires in Nature we learn the details of the experiment in rain-making that "made" the front page of this newspaper recently. Kraus and Squires say that they visited Schenectady, N.Y., in July, 1946, and there learned of Schaeffer's experiments in which ice crystals were produced artificially in the laboratory by the sudden cooling of moist air in a refrigerator.

Assault won a ring-tailed sizzler at Jamaica yesterday. He beat Handicapper John Blanks Campbell, Stymie, Gallorette, Risolater and Rico Monte in that order. The handicapper was the only one who enjoyed taking the beating.
WITH the official arrival of summer, a number of art colonies are opening, many of them in Connecticut.

NEW DELHI, India, July 12 -- The selection of the Moslem League president, Mohammed Ali Jinnah, as the first Governor General of Pakistan has been received with surprise and mixed feelings. The more extreme section of the Hindu press hints that Mr. Jinnah somehow outmaneuvered the Hindu leaders.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Sir John Boyd Orr, Director General of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, said today that international cooperation on food would start the world toward solutions of other crises.

SINCE the liberation of Europe, only one European literature of vigor has manifested itself to us and that has come from Paris. Despite material difficulties, original creative works have been appearing there in great numbers and literary reviews have burgeoned even more profusely than before the war.

MADRID, Spain, July 12 -- American doubts that Spaniards enjoyed full freedom, in last Sunday's referendum have aroused violent indignation in Falange circles here. Norman Armour, Assistant Secretary of State, appears to be the focal point of their wrath.

ATLANTA, July 12 (AP) -- Athletic Director W.A. Alexander of Georgia Tech has sent a strongly-worded protest to the New York Yankees of the All-America Football Conference and to Conference Commissioner Jonas H. Ingram on what he terms "a slick approach to tie up football players, still eligible for college competition, to the Yanks."

SAN FRANCISCO, July 12 -- The West Coast weighed the chances today for a complete tie-up of seaborne Shipping, as longshore walking bosses of the Congress of Industrial Organisations continued to maintain a picket line at the Luckenbach freighter Douglas Victory at Pler 29 here.
HONOLULU, July 12 (AP) -- A Federal conciliator proposed today application of the new Taft-Hartley Labor Law as one means of settling the strike in Hawaii's pineapple industry.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Hawaiian Islands, the well-known land of dreams, are closer than ever to realizing a dream of their own -- statehood in the Union.

FOLLOWER -- In American Fork, Utah, a lonesome cow followed her mistress on a shopping tour. When the woman turned into a store, the cow, unable to negotiate the door, plowed through a window and ambled up the aisle, mooing moodily.

Every few years since 1912 local speed boat folks have looked at a chart of New York waters. This reminded them that Manhattan is an island, bordered by the Hudson, East and Harlem Rivers. On paper it looks like one of the world's most natural courses for a long distance speed boat regatta.

The first debentures of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development will take their place this week in the public markets and among the private investment assets of the capitalist world. The long-coming offering has been set tentatively for Tuesday, July 15.

The historic biplane in which the Wrights first took to the air in 1903 made no more than thirty-one miles an hour. Since then aircraft speeds have increased each year on an aver age of fourteen miles an hour. Now we have experimental planes that can be flown at more than 600 miles an hour.

TYLER, Tex., July 12 (AP) -- Champions and runners-up of last year's meet at San Diego, Calif., plus teams from the nation's leading universities and athletic clubs and the Army Air Forces will be among the 250 entries in the National A.A.U. swimming and diving championships here July 31 through Aug. 3.

A SENTENCE from the story "Nightmare" by Marjorie Bowen in this anthology is appropriate for Mr. Derleth's latest group of strange tales: "The acorn is not yet formed that shall grow the oak that shall make the cradle to rock the wise man who shall solve my bewilderments-for me."

BERLIN, July 12 -- Dr. Josef Baumgartner, Bavarian Minister of Agriculture, who on March 4 belligerently criticized virtually every aspect of the United States Military Government, is the leading candidate for the top bizonal agriculture post.

BOGOTA, Colombia -- This is "Tinto Town," where life floats along on a flood of sweet, black Colombian coffee called tinto. A cup costs 5 centavos (3 cents) in any of the hundreds of cafes where cachacos -- Bogota's dandies -- pass their time.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., July 12 -- A new metropolitan junior champion was crowned today in the person of Bill Edwards of Hempstead, L.I. Edwards defeated Walter Robbins of Rock Spring, New Jersey State junior champion, 5 and 4, in the Metropolitan Golf Association's junior championship final held at Easex Fells Country Club.

BOSTON, July 12 (AP) -- What's New, Greentree Stables' chestnut filly, today captured the $10,000 added Betsy Ross Stakes, defeating Mrs. M. Jolley's Picnic Lunch, the 8-to-5 favorite, by a length and a half with John A. Kelley's Crimson Flash another half-length back before a crowd of 22,372 at Suffolk Downs.
NANKING, July 12 -- The announcement of the Wedemeyer inquiry mission to China and Korea apparently surprised Chinese and American officials here.

MOSCOW, July 2 (Reuters) -- In a new tirade against the implications of United States' "assistance" to Europe, Tass, official Soviet News agency, reporting today from Paris on the Marshall Plan talks, elaborated Moscow's view of the position of participating countries.

PARIS, July 12 -- Abolition of the French protectorate and a general election to establish a provisional government that would draw up a constitution have been demanded by the Moroccan Independence party.

A COORDINATED commercial airport program that will cost about $250,000,000 and will continue the New York metropolitan area's world leadership in air transport was assured last week when the city fathers of Newark, N.J., agreed to lease their big airfield to the Port of New York Authority for fifty years.

The Holland-America motoriner Westerdam last week rounded out her first year of service with a record of twenty-one Atlantic crossings between Rotterlam and New York, all of which were booked to the ship's capacity. She is still the only new post-war passenger vessel operating out of New York in the transatlantic trade, company officials asserted yesterday.

THROUGH a somewhat unlikely series of accidents, Nina Latham finds herself signed up and installed as a member of the faculty of Willard College in New Orleans before she becomes aware that it is a college for Negroes.

MR. A.M. SULLIVAN, in his long and rather diffuse foreword to "Stars and Atoms Have No Size," undertakes to justify the modern poet for seeking the material of poetry in the instruments of scientists and in the constructions of engineers.

PARIS, July 12 -- The special International Cereals Conference closed its meeting today after having reported an unparalleled European scarcity in grain and computed the world's requirements at 50,000,000 tons.

STATISTICS compiled in various sections of the country by automobile clubs and other organizations indicate that Eastern drivers are more careful than Western. This superiority is attributed to the density of traffic in the East, which compels caution, and to the safety campaigns which have been intensified hereabouts during the past year.

CHICAGO, July 12--Piet, a little chestnut colt, whose father, Grand Slam, won the 1935 Arlington Futurity at odds of 32 to 1, galloped to an upset victory in the 1947 Futurity today, richest 2-year-old event in eighteen years, before a stunned crowd of 30,000 at Arlington Park.

BEING an animal fantasy, one of those subtle tales all childlike and pretty on the surface, in which dumb beasts speak with human folly and reason with divine wisdom, "Rumor in the Forest" is part of a very special tradition in literature.

ICEBERGS -- During 1845 and 1946 the International Ice Patro carried out experiments to find out if radar would detect low-lying masses of ice. From a lecture delivered at Harvard by Lieut. (j.g.) Garth H. Read of the Coast Guard it appears that radar is not effective.
"In great cities men are like a lot of stones thrown together in a bag; their jagged corners are rubbed off till in the end they are as smooth as marbles." -- William Somerset Maugham.

A growing demand for specialized business and industrial training will take up a predicted slack in enrollment in liberal arts colleges, Dr. Robert A. Love, director of the Evening and Extension Division of the City College School of Business, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON. THE vigilant approach of Representative John Taber to his job as chairman of the House Appropriations Committee has inevitably won him the title of "Watchdog of the Treasury."

Good news, in the form of cash awards, was announced by the Navy yesterday for fifty-one officers and 829 enlisted men who were serving aboard the USS Omaha or the USS Somers in the fall of 1941 when the two vessels apprehended and salvaged the camouflaged freighter Odenwald.

WITH the introduction last week of "CBS Is There," which embodies the novel idea of recreating histortorical events by applying the technique of contemporary radio news coverage, the network went another step ahead with its manifest intention to build divertingly informative programs outside the song and dance format.

Negroes donated $600,000 during the fiscal year 1946-1947 for the support of colleges of their choice, plus an additional $130,000 to the joint campaign conducted for thirty-three member colleges by the United Negro College Fund, Inc., of 38 East Fifty-seventh Street, fund leaders announced yesterday.

The Federal Housing Administration, in cooperation with state and local health officials, has developed standards for the installation of individual water supply and sewage disposal systems in residential areas.

COLDFRAMES filled with plants in summer are the all-too-infrequent sign of an expert at work. They shelter the stock from which next year's garden will grow, and carry it through the hot months in much better condition than it could have in the open ground.
Many American business men believe that a more realistic approach could be taken to the Paris conference that opened yesterday to draw up a plan for the reconstruction of western Europe.

George Humes Reaney of 25 Hillside Road, Bronxville, N.Y., who had been president of the United States Guarantee Company, 90 John Street, since February, 1929, died yesterday in the Lenox Hill Hospital, Seventy-sixth Street and Park Avenue, after a brief illness at the age of 60.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- President Truman will urge in a special message to Congress next week that the Federal Government undertake a vast flood control plan for all the great river valleys of the Middle West, the White House announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Japanese over-estimated American losses in the decisive Battle of Midway, but recognized their repulse and the serious nature of their own losses, an official Japanese naval document, made public today by the Navy Department, reveals.

STOCKHOLM, July 12 -- Studies revealing a complex hereditary mechanism in a virus entity existing in the twilight zone between the living and non-living were described today at the International Congress for Experimental Cytology by Professor Salvador E. Lurla of Indiana University.

THE issue of racial discrimination should logically have been atomized by now, what with the sheer weight of literary tracts against it. On this theme, Millen Brand (who once wrote an exciting novel about a mental patient, "The Outward Room") seems in this book to be less concerned with psychological motivations than with real estate values.
OMAHA, Neb., July 12 -- Midwesterners watched with the eagerness of a first-night audience as the Government's gloves came off this week in the Kansas City vote-fraud case.

Higher coal wages which may set in motion a new upward cycle, the impending steel price advance, and the firmness of market conditions in soft goods lines are causing retailers reluctantly to revise their views on forward orders, it was reported in merchandising circles here last week.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 12 -- Britain has asked the United Nations Security Council to postpone hearing Egypt's appeal until the first week of August, it was learned today. Cairo asked yesterday for control of the Sudan and evacuation of British troops from Egypt and the Sudan.

DETROIT, July 12 (U.P.) -- President Walter P. Reuther of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, declared tonight he had deliberately violated the Taft-Hartley Labor Act and defied its sponsors to prosecute him or his union.

ALTHOUGH most players, strong and weak alike, use the forcing two-bid to show their biggest hands, it is likely that a majority of the leading players consider the "two-club system" preferable. The only reason they do not often use it is the nuisance of changing systems as they change partners.

NINETEEN years ago in this Review: Fact and Fantasy seemed to vie for prominence. For the "lost generation," there was a glimmer of hope in an astronomer's report of "Life in the Stars," reviewed on front-page by R.L. Duffus -- not recommended for those to whom "a primrose * * * is a primrose."

Bronco Kosanovich and Bill Moore, former star linemen with Penn State, have accepted invitations to play with the Eastern All-Star team against the New York Giants in the ninth Tribune Fresh Air Fund game at the Polo Grounds, Sept. 3, it was announced yesterday.

EMPLOYING a format similar to that of the volume on Nijinsky published some months ago [reviewed Jan. 19] the Ballet Society has now brought forward documentary records in text and photographs of two other celebrated dancers of the first quarter of the present century.

A story of extortion, violence and intimidation in connection with the union trucking of fruit and farm produce in New York was unfolded in testimony yesterday in the Federal Building before the House Labor subcommittee investigating racketeering in food costs.
HONOLULU, July 12 -- The world's first airfield built expressly for atomic warfare is being rushed to completion on the outskirts of Fairbanks, Alaska, the Honolulu Advertiser has reported.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read with interest the editorial in THE TIMES of July 8 entitled "A Synthetic Crisis."

EVERY schoolboy understands (or fancies that he understands) the brief, white meteor in the night of feudalism which history has labeled Jeanne d'Arc; few of those same schoolboys have delved in the cruel half-century that followed the Maid's death in Rouen. Offhand, the expectant novel-reader would turn away from this black era as readily as any schoolboy -- until he had the good fortune to sample the present gleanings.

Permanent international management and ownership of Germany's steel, coal and chemical industries in the Ruhr and Rhineland by a consortium of Allied governments was advocated yesterday by the Society for the Prevention of World War III.

The inflationary spiral, which has been moving up steadily since the outbreak of World War II, is making another turn. However, coming this time from a higher level and driven with the increased demand for virtually every product of factory and farm, the present upturn may be more pronounced than any in the past.

MOSCOW, July 12 (AP) -- There is reason to believe that the Russians do not want anyone to get the impression that the Eastern European nations -- including the Soviet Union -- desire economic isolation from the United States or other countries.

LIERATURE, the arts, everything not connected with the sciences of war, did not flourish in Japan during 1935-45. The written word was keyed up to heroic concepts of Japanese expansionism, so that while publishing went on and even grew, it was blueprinted for a design of the political future -- not for literature.

IT was only a matter of time after Bing Crosby's pioneering experiment with the transcription of his radio shows before someone would make a similar one on commercial records. Appropriately enough, it was a group of radio artists themselves, under the trade name "Top Ten," which first hit the market with full-blown comedy radio shows, including audience laughter, on records.

CLIMBING and rambler roses are pruned immediately after flowering. Neither type is difficult to trim if the basic principles and objectives are kept in mind. Purposes of pruning are to train the plant the way the gardener wants it to grow for best effect, to increase vigor, for neatness, and to help prevent disease through broken or dead canes.

"THE Confucian conception of the individual as inseparable from society," writes Dr. Francis C.M. Wei in his lucid summary of Chinese culture, "is essentially in terms of duties rather than in terms of rights.
Builders at the peak of their summer construction programs are rushing work on new units to meet the increasing demand for homes in Long Island areas.

OCEANPORT, N.J. July 12 -- Elpis made it two stakes in a week by winning the Molly Pitcher Handicap at Monmouth Park today. The 5-year-old daughter of Blue Larkspur -- Faucille d'Or flashed a fast finish under the expert guidance of Jockey Frank Moon to take first place in the $15,000 added mile-and-a-sixteenth event.

And New Labor Issues Large questions were raised last week for the future of the national economy and of labor-management relations. They were raised by a contract between John L. Lewis and the operators of the soft-coal mines, giving 400,000 United Mine Workers one of the largest wage increases in labor history.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 12 -- Employment of Negro policemen in Savannah, a city long noted for its Old South traditions, made Georgia the tenth of thirteen Southern States in which cities have taken such action to curb crime in all-Negro districts.
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox regained sixth place in the American League standings today by ending a four-game losing streak with a 6-to-5 victory over the Washington Senators.

SALT LAKE CITY. WHEN Desperate Destry dashes out of the gulch, six-shooters blazing at the bevy of badmen in hot pursuit -- is he as vigorously applauded by filmgoers in the heart of the rangeland as by audiences in New York City?

ST. LOUIS, July 12 -- Reaching the halfway mark in the American League pennant race the Yankees today marshaled a twenty-eight-hit assault that sank the Browns in both ends of a double-header, 12 to 2 and 8 to 5. The double triumph moved them nine and one-half games ahead of the champion Red Sox and stretched their winning streak to a major league high of twelve in a row.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., July 12 (AP)--The wife and 2-year-old daughter of a New Jersey manufacturer died today in a seaplane accident on Lake George and shortly afterward another plane, circling the scene, also crashed.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 12 -- Prospects for international atomic control, which appeared virtually hopeless a month ago, have improved a trifle in the past two weeks. Long debates lie ahead, and the most optimistic concede that there is no prospect of a complete agreement for another eighteen months or two years, but progress has been made on some of the less controversial points.

LONDON (By Wireless). THERE is a popular belief -- a modern version of the old legend of the Sibylline Books -- that the opportunities of history occur twice; in other words, an individual, a nation, or a group of nations may be given a second chance of recovery from a mistake.
The agrony and fortitude of British explorers near the South Pole have been made to live again with the discovery by American sailors of a yellowed document deposited there thirty years ago.

Aside from the visiting club's share of the gate -- no insignificant cut, by the way -- the Cubs got nothing at all out of their stand at Flatbush. Their five-game series with the Dodgers at Ebbets Field came to an end yesterday with the league-leading Brooks sweeping a double-header, 7 -- 2 and 6 -- 5, and the set, 5 -- 0.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., July 12 -- Mechanization of the Trafford foundry of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation has increased productivity and incentive earnings of employes, improved the quality of castings and reduced absenteeism, C.B. Dick, manager of this feeder division, announced here today in revealing details of a unique foundry "face-lifting" program.

PARIS, July 12 -- Two days before the opening of the European conference, to give effect to the Marshall proposal for United States aid to this continent, Soviet Russia sharply cracked her whip er the heads of those of her satellites that might be tempted by the lure of dollars to waver ven slightly in their solidarity with Moscow.

YELLOW columbine begins to flower about a week later than some of the hybrid kinds, thus extending the season of this charming flower. It will continue intermittently into September, although a bit of care is needed to make this possible.

Sixty-one minutes in the grand dining room of the French Foreign Ministry in Paris yesterday made history. It was the kind of history of which those present, and the nations they represented, could be proud. In a meeting to which all European governments (except Franco's Spain) I had been invited to send delegates, in speeches immediately made public throughout the world, the Foreign Ministers of Britain.

One of the high spots of the racing season will be hit this week with Saturday's first running of the $100,000 added Empire Gold Cup race. In order to provide the best possible local setting for this international contest, the Empire City Racing Association will shift the last two sessions of its twenty-four-day meeting from Jamaica to Belmont Park.

PARIS, July 12 -- The conference of sixteen European nations to give effect to the Marshall proposal of United States aid to Europe made a rapid business-like start today, with no East-West split to hamper it.

A WORK of art is wonderfully ambiguous. Every man can find in it the object of his own concern: it can be an illuminating historical fact for Taine or Rostovtzev, a layered symbol of the id for Freud, a detouring reflex for Watson, a sensuous concretion of the Absolute for Hegel, or a shrewd buy for an auctioneer.

LONDON, July 12 -- On Tuesday of this week Herbert Morrison, Lord President of the Council, put Britain's cards on the table. Everybody had been looking over his shoulder and should have known that they were pathetically small cards, but somehow it was a tremendous shock.

AT the end of one of the busiest seasons in New York's art history, with an average of about thirty shows a week from September into June, American artists who pause to look back to the depths of the depression when the WPA came to their aid may well be gratified at the progress in the intervening fifteen years.

BENJAMIN Harris' "Publick Occurrences" was published by Richard Pierce in Boston in 1690. It was promptly suppressed for being too outspoken, but it ushered in the history of the American press. The first newspaper illustration was a woodcut printed in Campbell's Boston News-Letter in 1704, and in the same year the first advertisement appeared.

SOUTHERN Negroes are not quick to take their troubles with white men to court. But "The Hourglass" is the story of a Negro who did. His wife had been the victim of a brutal incident involving three white men; and when the affair is brought into the open it becomes a cause celebre, climaxed by a well-publicized jury trial, armed deputies in the courtroom and a swarm of Northern newspaper reporters buzzing about the town.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Now that the proposed Presidential two-term amendment has been transmitted by the Congress to the State Legislatures for ratification, in disregard of the well-considered recommendation of the Senate's Judiciary Committee that ratification be by conventions in the several states, as provided in the Constitution, it is to be hoped they will resist all political pressure for haste and ill-considered action.

The long-awaited upsweep of the Cardinals caught the Giants right under the short ribs at the Polo Grounds yesterday and there was absolutely nothing that Mel Ott's men or 41,625 anguished fans in the stands could do about it. Whatever the Polo Grounders did the Redbirds did infinitely better as they made off with both ends of the afternoon's double-header.
WASHINGTON, July 12--President Truman today withdrew "with great reluctance" the nomination of Francis Biddle as United States representative in the United Nations Economic and Social Council.

ZURICH, Switzerland, July 12 -- Expressing complete approval of the reply of the Swiss Government accepting the Franco-British invitation to join in implementing the Marshall Plan, competent Swiss finance quarters said today that if the stipulations made in the Confederation's reply were respected, substantial capital would become available in Switzerland for the acceleration of European recovery.

Financial markets strengthened last week as the threatened coal strike was averted and various business prophecies became more cheerful. The changed attitude was reflected in all lines, despite the fact that it is still a sellers' market for scarce durable goods.

The complete story on the nation's ninety-one leading investment trusts, with assets of over $2,000,000,000 and more than a million stockholders, is reported in the recently published 312-page 1947 edition of "Investment Companies," prepared by Arthur Wiesenberger.

EARLY July is the time for blue and white flowers. Indeed, the garden may be almost monotonous unless the planting scheme has been carefully worked out, or an attempt made to accent perennials and bulbs that add orange, yellow or shades of pink.

TEN years ago the United States, Great Britain and Germany were engaged in making "survey flights" over the Atlantic in preparation for regular commercial passenger, mail and express service. During the late spring and early summer of 1937 the newspapers gave the flights a lot of space and predictions of early passenger service were made by everyone connected with aviation and taken with a grain of salt by everyone else.

IN 1772, Dr. John Fothergill of London agreed to pay young William Bartram, an earnest, imaginative Pennsylvania naturalist, fifty pounds a year "to search the Floridas and the western parts of Carolina and Georgia for the discovery of rare and useful productions of nature, chiefly in the vegetable kingdom."

IT is unfortunate that the series of lectures on which this book was based was not delivered to members of Congress, rather than to students at Cornell University. If House and Senate leaders had heard and taken note of Professor Slichter's analysis of the country's labor problems, they might have brought forth a saner legislative program for balancing the rights and obligations of unions, industry and the public.

Symbols AT some time, perhaps many times in his life, every man is likely to meet with a thing in art or nature or human life or books which astonishes and gives him a profound satisfaction not so much because it is rich or beautiful or strange, as because it is a symbol of a thing which, without the symbol, he could never grasp and enjoy.

An increase of 13.63 per cent, or from 2.2 to 2.5 cents a mile, in basic passenger fares within the state was granted yesterday by the New York State Public Service Commission to fourteen railroads. An increase of 6.06 per cent, or from 3.3 to 3.5 cents a mile, was granted for first-class fares required with Pullman travel.

Thirty-five students from fourteen countries are attending a unique summer seminar conducted by the Institute of World Affairs at Twin Lakes, Conn., designed to promote better international understanding by fostering cooperative living and study. Established in 1924 at Geneva, Switzerland, the institute initially had a student body of eighteen and represented six nations.

ATHENS, July 12 -- In the last ten days, before the arrival of Dwight P. Griswold, director of the $300,000,000 Truman aid plan, smoldering guerrilla fighting has suddenly flared into furious military and political battle.

The Finnish Government awarded Marshal Mannerheim medals last night to three Americans for "helping the suffering humans" in Finland. At a dinner at the Roosevelt Hotel, Dr. Arvo Ylppo, who arrived here last week from Helsinki with six other Finnish doctors to attend the Fifth International Congress of Pediatrics, presented the medals in behalf of his country.

MUSIC in this country has been the victim of a pernicious practice in many circles for many years -- the "musical appreciation racket," as it has been called. "Musical appreciation" has undertaken, in most cases, to explain the mystery of music by using fancy, high-flown terminology that adds to the mystification.

Batting honors during the 1947 Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League campaign were annexed by Norm Felske, Yale catcher, while Bob Wolcott, Princeton sophomore, had the best earned-run average among the pitchers, according to statistics announced yesterday.

Another auction year of high prices was reported yesterday by the Plaza Art Galleries, Inc., 9 East Fifty-ninth Street, with the announcement that $1,411,426 had been grossed in 131 sessions during the 1946-47 season.

THAT Madison Square Garden program planned to aid the American National Theatre and Academy this fall on longer is to be counted upon. Guiding lights of ANTA learned the other day that the "benefit" business at the Garden had been hit along with the Broadway box offices and the chances of netting the hoped-for $150,000 were rather slim.

CAMP BARRE, Pa., July 12 -- Girl scouting is being started in the American, British and French zones of Germany, Mrs. Paul Rittenhouse, national Girl Scout director, announced here today at the group's world encampment. She explained the operation of scouting in Germany following a report on the International picture given by Miss Helen Young, delegate from Readsville, Pa.
PITTSBURGH, July 12 -- Bernhard Ragner, publicity director for the Pittsburgh Chamber of Commerce and former overseas correspondent, died today in his home at Mount Lebanon. His age was 56.

LONDON, July 12 -- The British Overseas Airways Corporation has ended its first year of normal peacetime operation as a state-owned and operated company with a record deficit running into millions of pounds.

NORTH TEXAS TEACHERS -- Comics A study in the use of comic strips in the classroom is being made this summer by students at the North Texas State College. According to an announcement there, comic books are now taking their place on the shelves of elementary schools throughout the nation "as important instruments in progressive education."

Eighteen hundred doctors from all parts of the world who specialize in the treatment of children will meet for four days at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel beginning tomorrow for the Fifth International Congress of Pediatrics, the congress committee announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Organized labors, major strategy in seeking to cope with the new Taft-Hartley labor relations act took shape this week when the terms of the new bituminous coal contract were divulged and the circumstances of its framing became known.

PIOCHE, Nev., July 12 (AP) -- Former President Hoover today called for Americans to institute voluntary food conservation, "restrictions on abnormal fec of wheat to animals and lation of the processing trades" to insure adequate food supplies to the world next year.

FOREIGN tourists visiting the United States seldom spend much time in our national parks, at seaside resorts, or other vacation spots which attract most Americans, according to Malcolm LaPrade, vice president of Thos. Cook Son.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- Many American visitors remain faithful to the horse in Bermuda. One meets them on the road in victoria and surrey, leisurely scanning the countryside, and they are inclined to take pity on the sophisticates who ride in little English cars at Bermuda's maximum speed -- twenty miles an hour.
CLEVELAND, July 12 (AP) -- The Indians clung to fourth place today by salvaging the second game of a twin bill with the Athletics, 5 to 4, after dropping tha opener, 4 to 2.
SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 12 -- Frank Parker finally met his master at Spring Lake today.
The Split Is Official There opened in Paris yesterday the first conference of a new European period -- a period marked by a declared division of Europe into Eastern and Western blocs.

NEW YORK musical life has been abetted by the arrival of the Lemonade Opera Company in Greenwich Village. It is a lively group whose average age is 25, and who believe they see an answer to the problem of getting heard without the devastating expense of debuts.

Mission to Greece Today, in President Truman's new DC-6, an important emissary of the Truman doctrine will leave for Athens. He is Dwight Griswold, 54, former Republican Governor of Nebraska, who heads a staff of forty American civilians and eighty military men.

Squeeze for Britain In London's Chelsea section a few days ago a housewife, standing in a long queue to buy horsemeat, told an American tourist about Britain's economic plight. She said: "Take this ruddy food situation now, and there's practically no clothing or petrol or home furnishings.

THE death of Joan Murray at 24 was one to depress all young poets -- especially those who have not yet mastered their difficult art. It occurred in 1942, the final stage of a childhood heart illness. She had been born in England, and educated there and in France, Canada and the United States.

Of all the disabled in America, the largest occupational group is the housewife. Hers have been the forgotten casualties. The Government has assumed the responsibility for the rehabilitation of disabled veterans, and industry is recognizing increasingly that the salvaging of manpower through rehabilitation of disabled workers is a sound investment.

"Life With Father," theatrical champion of Broadway, retired last night without a serious title contender in sight. For the 3,213th and last time father bitterly acquiesced to baptism and, as was proper for a play that had shattered the record of "Tobacco Road," a large audience was on hand at the Alvin Theatre to pay homage to the comedy of domestic tribulations of the Day manage.

CHIVES, mint and others of the best known herbs are cut and used constantly during summer. Evergreen herbs are not so noticeable in this season, but if they also have been included, will be enjoyed outdoors and in the house next winter.

Sportswear and beachwear clearance sales were being actively conducted last week, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Cotton dresses and infants' and girls' departments were active with dress departments, in which there was a demand for satins.

Something new is on tap for the women golfers of the Metropolitan district Tuesday and Wednesday. Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont, chairman of the Women's Metropolitan tournament committee, has scheduled for the Sunningdale Golf Club, Scarsdale, N.Y., a four-ball best-ball match play tournament.

It must be a relief to the Army that the "flying saucers" have been seen not only in forty-three States but in Canada, Iran, Australia, the Netherlands and England. Ordnance experts do not have to roam over the North American continent and then cross the Atlantic and Pacific to test new missiles.

EVER since Twentieth Century-Fox plucked Peggy Cummins from the London cast of "Junior Miss," in which she played Fuffy, a pigtailed, sassy teen-aged gremlin, and cast her as Amber, the sexiest, wickedest, meanest siren of all time, it was obvious that her Hollywood career was going to be an odd one.

KNOWING a good thing when their camera sees it, the editors of Look have been turning a contemplative eye on New England. For this, the second of their regional guide books, they have tracked down the cod and the Brahmin, the sea captain and the Connecticut Valley farmer, and have packaged them under a familiar corporate label.

WRITERS continue to occupy the lowest position in the salary scale of employes in the radio industry, according to figures released last week by the Federal Communications Commission. Salesmen are the highest paid, musicians are in second place, followed closely by news personnel.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 12 -- Despite a weather report predicting line squalls with winds of fifty miles an hour, 128 craft set sail today in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's regatta, seven-teenth in the Long Island Sound championship series.

Realism Moves Back Ever so many of the new books and plays, to judge from the reviews or the preliminary announcements, have their action "around the turn of the century." Sometimes the period is the Gay Nineties, which is practically the same thing.
BUCHAREST, July 12 -- The Governments of eastern European countries behind the Iron Curtain found themselves committed this week, either voluntarily or under duress to a "Molotov plan."

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Pledges of support for the Republican Presidential nomination that are being received daily by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York on his "vacation trip" in the West are bona fide, but neither surprising nor spontaneous. They are a carefully planned part of the build-up necessary to a front-runner in politics. And Mr. Dewey has shown he is that.

A GENERATION of theatre-goers will bless Patrick Hamilton for his gelid magic in "Angel Street"; addicts of the psycho-thriller will turn back to his "Hangover Square," no less fondly, for a restrospective chill. The dour little novel now offered to us by his American publishers is strictly a minor-league item.

THOSE who bear such surnames as Smith, Farmer or Hunter give silent testimony to the long-standing associations of men with trades. The trade, symbolic of many aspects of status, remains a vital consideration. Moreover, in a rapidly changing industrial society, the value of a trade can wax or wane within the life span of the tradesman.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 12 (AP) -- Defending champions Ben Hogan and Jimmy Demaret suffered their first defeat in five matches today, losing, 1 up, to national open champion Lew Worsham and Johnny Palmer, but they clung to the lead for the top prize of $3,000 in the Inverness best-ball matches with a "plus 13" score.

General Wedemeyer's sudden mission to China and Korea suggests that the United States is about to make profound decisions on what our policy shall be in the continental Far East. The situation there, both in China and Korea, is admittedly desperate. The fate of Manchuria and perhaps of all North China is at stake.

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 12 -- American cosmic ray researchers are investigating the reported discovery by Soviet scientists of a new fundamental particle of matter, called the varyton, Dr. Robert Brode of the University of California told a two-day meeting of the American Physical Society here, but experimental evidence constituting proof of the Russian claim was declared to be lacking.

ROCKY GRAZIANO'S face was virtually unmarked. Tony Zale's looked as though it had just been through a meat-chopper. A stranger, who was unaware of what had happened, would have glanced at the pair and instantly pointed to the Rockabye Baby as the winner of the fight. But he would have been wrong.

CHATTANOOGA is not, as the authors of this volume make clear, a typical Southern city. Although, because of its strategic location, it was bitterly fought over in the War Between the States, its population at that time was only about 5,000 persons.

THE quotation at the head of today's Treasure Chest is from a writer little known to American readers; a few know his poetry, fewer still his prose. Edward Thomas died in the first World War at the age of 37. He had been a friend of Robert Frost during Frost's early residence in England, and was one of the first to draw public attention to his work.

Sixteen nations met in Paris yesterday to take stock of Europe's resources and needs. The Marshall plan would figure as a means of meeting the needs. While the conference is basically economic, it has assumed considerable political importance. This is true because of the Russian fight against the project of Europe's getting aid from the United States.

SHANGHAI, July 12 (AP) -- The independent newspaper Ta Kung Pao said today that Jecheng, former pro-Chinese Regent of Tibet, had been blinded and then killed by poison on charges of plotting to overthrow the present Regent at Lhasa, Tibetan capital.

BOSTON, July 12 (AP) -- Warren Spahn shut out the Cincinnati Reds for the third time this season, allowing but four hits as the Boston Braves beat the Reds, 4 -- 0, today to even up the four-game series.
VIENNA, July 12 -- Both major Austrian parties, through their central political newspapers, showed today strong optimism as to the eventual result of splitting Europe into two great economic blocs.

PARIS, July 12 -- Demands for the early stabilization of the German Reichsmark as a key step in any plan for improving the European economy will be placed before the current Conference for European Economic Cooperation by the Low Countries, according to word here today.

ARTHUR HONEGGER arrived in America last week, enroute between Paris and Tanglewood. He is now 55. We remember him twenty-odd years ago, in Paris, his exuberant youth, his laughter, echoed in the pages of "Pacific 231," the steam-engine piece which remains, for this writer, one of the wittiest musical creations of the century.

Four major pressures were responsible for the settlement of the coal labor controversy with the mine owners, and among the four steel producers were of considerable importance, interviews with steel officials revealed here yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The reason given by Mr. Vyshinsky for opposing Russian women leaving the Soviet Union -- that they are needed "to produce Soviet children" (NEW YORK TIMES, July 1 ) -- should be considered in the light of the tremendous disproportion of sexes there.

Favored third among the 128 entries, Charles T. Mattmann of Roslyn had little trouble moving into the second round as play in the annual men's Eastern clay courts singles tournament began yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

LOS ANGELES, July 12 -- Legally compulsory open-forum pages in newspapers and similar programs on the radio were urged today at the legal section of the "conference on thought control," sponsored by the Progressive Citizens of America.
The Air Forces are lending lip service -- but insufficient practical effort -- to industrial or economic planning.

Additional demands that are deemed necessary to union security are being made by the 67,000 striking members of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, John Green, national president, announced yesterday.
In discussions of the Labor Act and the labor situation we are running into the subject of semantics -- that is, the meaning of words.

THE 9-year-old, who had vanished into the high foliage of a neighbor's cherry tree when the neighbor wasn't home, emitted a cherry pit, then called out to his friend a few boughs below, "Gee, the more I eat, the more I want."

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The American child of the future may be able to brag that mother was a veteran of the Regular Army. For that matter, mother or sis could also be a line officer of the Navy, or a regular Marine, if Congress passes pending bills.

JERUSALEM, July 12 -- Two British Army intelligence sergeants were kidnapped at Nathanya early today and were being held as hostages against the impending execution of three terrorists whose death sentences were recently confirmed. Nathanya lies between Tel Aviv and Haifa.

Among the art exhibitions opening today will be a group show of work by artists associated with the gallery at Contemporary Arts; paintings of Alice in Wonderland, by Jessie Drew-Bear of New Hope, Pa., at the Weyhe Gallery; work by artists who won honorable mentions in the recent (ninth) annual competition for a one-man show at the A.C.A. Gallery, together with paintings by ten Puerto Rican artists, and a group show at the RoKo Gallery.

UNION, N.J., July 13 -- Stuyvesant Town, Inc., has been granted a permit for the construction of a $1,770,000 garden apartment development in Columbia Avenue here, near a $1,325,000 apartment project already under construction in Walker Avenue by the same builders.

Modernization of railroad roadbeds, estimated to require improvements which will total more than $20,000,000,000 in expenditures before 1960, will provide one of several major new markets for future construction equipment sales, Frank Knight, executive secretary of the Associated Equipment Distributors, revealed here last week, following a meeting of more than 50 eastern regional members at the Ridgewood, N.J., Country Club.

Although retailers last week, because of prevailing high prices, maintained their conservative attitude and refused to be stampeded by reports of the possibility of merchandise shortages, they increased some orders and made some new commitments, according to the reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

The man strong enough to be his own judge, brain, guide, strength and ultimate source of all power can do without religion, the Right Rev. Austin Pardue, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Pittsburgh, declared yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

ATHENS, July 13 -- "Greek and Albanian bandits" numbering more than 1,000 invaded Greece from Albania early today and besieged the town of Konitsa, ten miles from the frontier, the Greek government said tonight on the basis of a General Staff report.
ATLANTA, July 13 -- Georgia's 350,000 Methodist church members were called upon today to oppose vigorously "by every possible means the injection of race or class prejudice into political campaigns."

The citizens of Goldsboro, N.C., and the folks at the University of North Carolina may do a little pointing with pride today. For Clyde King, 22-year-old native of the Carolina town and product of the University, pitched and batted the league-leading Dodgers to their seventh straight victory as they downed the Cincinnati Reds, 9 -- 1, at Ebbets Field yesterday.
Despite intermittent overcasts and showers, the New York-New Jersey beach belt bustled yesterday as 3,000,000 persons disported themselves in sun, sand and surf.

The trained observer of the current American scene cannot fail to see "how increasingly ready our people are to take refuge from the ignobility of greed and boredom of pleasure in a pursuit of nationalistic power," Canon Bernard Iddings Bell, consultant on education to the Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Chicago, said yesterday in a sermon at Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway at Wall Street.

A blue-uniformed Air France pilot, who wore the red rosette of the Legion of Honor on the lapel of his tunic, was arraigned yesterday on a charge of forgery before Magistrate Abraham M. Bloch in Felony Court. Magistrate Bloch held him in $15,000 bail for a hearing tomorrow.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 13 -- A meeting of the National Executive Board of the International Longshoremen's and Warhousemen's Union, CIO, has been called in this city for July 24 and 25 to consider, among other things, a proposal of the officers that the union bypass the National Labor Relations Board as reconstituted under the Taft-Hartley Act.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 13 -- A statement charging that "the traditional practice of separation between church and state in the United States of America is endangered by attempts to secure public funds for the support of parochial schools" was read today from the pulpits of nine Protestant churches here and in Northport, L.I.
PARIS, July 13 -- Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg will speak with a single voice on matters arising during the European economic cooperation conference, it was learned here today.

The principal factor in the Board of Estimate's delay in acting on the pending proposal for a higher transit fare is the fear of some of its members that such an increase would be rejected in a popular referendum, with political damage to its sponsors.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- A 25 per cent reduction in air freight rates is proposed by nineteen airlines in an official rate tariff to be filed tomorrow with the Civil Aeronautics Board.

It's Brock Pemberton's good fortune to sponsor the Broadway return of James Stewart, a name to conjure with in films. Who else but a magician endowed with B.P.'s dexterity could snatch a top-ranking Hollywood star out of thin air to play the role Frank Fay has made so peculiarly his own in "Harvey" while the latter is on vacation for seven weeks?

CHICAGO, July 13 -- The Yankee juggernaut rolled on to its fourteenth straight victory today. It took a double-header from the White Sox to equal the club's best winning streak since 1941 and move 10 1/2 games in front of the Tigers, 11 1/2 ahead of the faltering Red Sox.

CLEVELAND, July 13 (AP) -- Steve Gromek and Ed Klieman throttled the Boston Red Sox with five hits as Cleveland downed the Sox, 6 to 2, in the second game of today's double-header before 51,998 fans. The Indians also won the opener, 8 to 0, behind Mel Hardens nine-hit pitching. The double loss sent the Red Sox to third place, 11 1/2 games behind the Yankees.

Unseeded Paul Napolitano of Trenton, N.J., registered the first upset of the Eastern clay court men's singles tennis championship tournament at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday. Facing J. Gilbert Hall of New York City, the tourney's sixth seeded player and holder of the national veterans' championship, the Trenton player came through with a sparkling 6-2, 4-6, 6-1 triumph.

Fourth place yawned before the Giants yesterday when out of nowhere came to the long suffering Melvin Ott and an equally patient gathering of 30,166 onlookers that long-awaited well-pitched ball game.

PARIS, July 13 -- Premier Paul Ramadier appealed today to the nations of eastern Europe, including the Soviet Union, to join in building a united Europe, and said the Paris economic-cooperation conference would be open to them to its end.

SOFIA, July 13 -- The Rumanian Government delegation, led by Premier Petru Groza, arrived in Sofia today on a four-day visit to Bulgaria. The Rumanians were warmly welcomed at the station by Bulgarian Premier George Dimitrov, other Cabinet ministers, foreign diplomats and thousands of citizens.

Disillusion, frustration and cynicism have engulfed the clergy and laity of the Protestant Episcopal Church, the Rev. Dr. Louis W. Pitt, rector of Grace Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, charged in a sermon from that pulpit yesterday morning.
Pete, the Methuselah of the hippopotamus world and elder statesman of the Bronx Zoo, gravely accepted the homage of photographers and reporters yesterday as he observed his forty-fourth birthday.

The remains of the first dinosaurs that lived in the United States 200,000,000 years ago have been discovered in New Mexico by an expedition from the American Museum of Natural History here, it was announced yesterday.

JERUSALEM, July 13 -- Clearly mirroring the Soviet Union's views, the Jewish Communist party of Palestine recommended today the eviction of Britain from the Holy Land as the panacea for all the country's problems. The recommendation was made in testimony before the United Nation's Special Committee on Palestine.

TOKYO, July 13 -- A plan long discussed by many Japanese to eliminate the multitudinous "splinter" groups from national politics as a step toward the establishment of the two-party system along American lines is likely to receive a legislative test before the present Diet session.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 13 (AP) -- The largest generator ever assembled, at least in this country, to produce the nearest thing to natural lightning, has been enlisted in the first comprehensive basic research project to study the effects of lightning on aircraft in flight, it was announced here today.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., July 13 (AP) -- Irving Mondschein, New York University athlete, won the 29th annual A: A.U. decathlon championship today with a total of 6,715 points for the two-day event, taking the title for the third time in four years.
NEW DELHI, India, July 13 (Reuters) -- The Sylhet District of Assam Province today voted to join Pakistan by a majority of 55,578, an announcement from the Viceroy's residence said tonight.
The thirty-three Puerto Ricans from New York who met death or injury as a chartered plane crashed in a Florida swamp yesterday comprised a "bargain" passenger list.

Continuing to rise in the first full year of peacetime production, the working capital of manufacturers during 1946 increased about $150,000,000 for 214 manufacturing corporations sampled, according to an analysis released over the week-end by the National Industrial Conference Board.

PARIS, July 13 -- The conference planning the economic reconstruction of Europe adopted today a simple but comprehensive organization to draw up by Sept. 1 a survey and forecast of Europe's assets and needs for the next four years.

A political party does not cease to be such when it calls itself a club. Nor can a repeal of the primary election laws reduce it to that status. Hence, in the State of South Carolina, where three years ago the primary laws were repealed, the Democratic party cannot set itself up as an organization of kindred souls which can exclude unwelcome members.

LONDON, July 13 -- Bernard Cardinal Griffin. Roman Catholic Archbishop of Westminster, appealed to the United Nations today to hold an inquiry into "crimes against humanity" in Yugoslavia. He was addressing a Catholic rally in London on what he termed persecution of the church in Yugoslavia, which he said "equals in severity the worst crimes committed by the Nazis."

GREENWICH, Conn., July 13 -- A breeze that was dormant in Spells and took on life occasionally greeted 156 sailing craft in the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's championship series regatta out on Long Island Sound today.

Denouncing French and Spanish administration in North Africa, a powerful group of Moroccan nationalists has informed Tryvge Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, that Morocco will appeal to the United Nations General Assembly for independence.

LONDON, July 13 -- Clinton P. Andersen, United States Secretary of Agriculture, and W. Averell Harriman, Secretary of Commerce, left London today by plane, the first for Washington and the latter for Rome. British officialdom is sadder and wiser for their brief visits.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Senator John W. Bricker, who escaped injury yesterday when two shots were fired at him by a former Capitol policeman, expressed grave concern today over the general safety of members of the Senate.

PITTSBURGH, July 13 -- The steel operating rate staged a quick comeback here last week when this district reached 90 per cent of rated capacity, compared with 63 per cent the week before. This area was one of the hardest hit by the vacation shutdown in the mines.

For those women who turn their backs on the kitchen range in the warm weather and "cook" in the refrigerator, this department has prepared "Twelve Frozen Desserts," a leaflet of the choicest Times-tested recipes on this subject that have appeared here and in the Sunday Magazine food column.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13 -- Owen J. Roberts, former Supreme Court justice, asked Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, in an open letter today to cease being "the major stumbling block" in the path of universal military training.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, July 13 -- Unless Gov. Earl Warren of California soon indicates a positive interest in winning next year's Republican Presidential nomination he may forfeit the support of several Western delegations which could be his.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 13 -- Yonkers city officials have struck legal snags in trying to extend for three months, from Oct. 1 to Jan. 1, operation of the child-care centers that handle 250 children of working mothers on week-days.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The general index of basic commodity prices based on the level of August, 1939, rose from 303.2 on July 7, to 305.3 on July 11, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The following lists daily index numbers and spot primary market prices:
Two visitors from North Dakota stopped before a barrier at Rockefeller Plaza yesterday afternoon. They stared at the roped-off area between forty-eighth and fiftyfirst Streets.

MADRID, July 13 -- A sister of the puppet ruler of Spanish Morocco was married today in Tetuan, Morocco, in a colorful Moslem ceremony. The bride, Princess Lala Amina Ben Muley el Mehedi, is an important figure in the North African situation today, as she represents most nearly the emancipated type of modern Arab woman.

PARIS, July 13 -- French policy in Indo-China is expected to pass from, the military into the political stage, with a drive for peace, upon the return of Emile Bollaert, High Commissioner, who after consultations here will leave by air for Saigon on Tuesday.
The Association of the Bar of the City of New York and two other legal groups here endorsed yesterday the recommendations of a House subcommittee to revise the system of military justice.

HAVANA, July 13 -- Minister of Labor Carlos Prio Socarras and Senator Eduardo Chibas waged a saber duel today in the arms salon of the National Capitol. Senor Chibas' face, left side and right arm were cut and Senor Prio Socarras' right side was bruised.

DETROIT, July 13 (AP) -- The Tigers went back into undisputed possession of second place today by sweeping a double-header from the Athletics, 4 to 2 and 7 to 6. Roy Cullenbine's eleventh homer of the season provided the winning marker in the nightcap after Virgil (Fire) Trucks limited the Athletics to five hits in the opener.

JEAN-PAUL SARTRE, high priest of the philosophical sect called Existentialism, is the most versatile French man of letters to achieve prominence since the liberation of his country. Novelist, poet, short-story writer, playwright, former philosophy professor, editor of a philosophical journal, lecturer, leader in the resistance -- few people have ever done so much in so little time.

Egypt's appeal to the Security Council of the United Nations to settle her dispute with Great Britain over the evacuation of British troops and control of the Sudan hands that harassed body one of the knottiest problems it has yet been called upon to solve. Both nations see their national safety at stake and are in head-on deadlock.

ATHENS, July 13 (AP) -- Air Minister Panayotis Kanellopoulos said tonight that the Konitsa assault and the concentration of fighters in Albania was viewed by the Government as "a serious attack against Greece."

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 13 (AP) -- Jimmy Demaret and Ben Hogan split up the first prize of $3,000 and a special purse for scoring the most birdies as they won the Inverness four-ball golf tournament today for the second straight year.

A total of $670,000 worth of unused spare parts of many types of construction machines, Diesel engines and farm tractors are among the items being offered by Region 2 of the War Assets Administration, it was announced over the week-end by Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Economic Outlook, monthly publication of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, advanced an eleven-point program today to curb monopolies. It held that by imposing a hidden tax on the consumer they stand in the way of an "economy of abundance with full employment at a fair wage and full production."

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 13 -- The silence of the press over Czechoslovakia's not attending the Farts conference on the Marshall plan is broken. Front-page editorials today took notice of the nation's abstention.

The "set of the individual's soul" and what happens inside him are more important than external events that teach him, the Rev. Dr. George E. Sweazey, secretary of the Department of Evangelism of the Presbyterian Church, declared yesterday at the morning service of the West Park Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue at Eighty-sixth Street.

BOSTON, July 13 -- Police were forced to intervene today to restore order in historic Old South Meeting House when a crowd drowned out Gerald L.K. Smith, former head of the America First Party, who is now seeking to organize the Christian Nationalist Crusaders.

RYE, N.Y., July 13 -- Playing steady and oftentimes brilliant golf, Dick Mayer, 23-year-old Westchester star today won the New York State amateur championship by defeating his 28-yearold rival, Stan Kowal of Utica, former Navy flier, 4 and 3, in the 36-hole final on the 'Westchester Country Club course.

A new series of dramatic programs, featuring hour-long adaptations of great plays, classic motion pictures, best-selling novels, prize-winning short stories and an occasional musical, will make its debut over the National Broadcasting Company network on Sunday, Oct. 5, from 5 to 6 P.M.
The National Labor Relations Board has dismissed cases involving a dispute between ship officers and two steamship lines on the ground that it cannot process cases involving supervisory employes.

UTICA, N.Y., July 13 -- Governor Dewey's position on repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act emerged as an important factor today in the attitude of the State Federation of Labor toward New York's Chief Executive.

A "fourteen-point peace plan" based upon the fourteen traditional works of mercy as a solution for current national and international tensions was advocated yesterday in a sermon in St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Michael J. Deacy of the cathedral staff.

Business depressions, whatever else may be said of them, are rarely without their salutary byproducts. For one thing, they have a habit of showing defects in the economic mechanism that previously had been invisible or had gone unnoticed.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial on "Our Useless Gold" is excellent. Now that Sir Richard Tute has expounded his views on our "sterile" gold, it would be interesting to hear his views on Britain's "stagnant" sterling and what is to be done about it on July 15.

"We can stand personal loss and the wreck of civilization if we believe in the most important event on this planet -- that God was made man," the Rev. Herman F. Reissig, field secretary for the American Committee of the World Council of Churches, said yesterday.

The Rent Comes Round New Yorkers, nervous about what the landlords may do to them in the way of raising rents, may be mildly interested in what happened in their city when the armies of King George III took it over from General Washington's Continentals in September, 1776, and held it for the duration, or until November, 1783.

VIENNA, July 13 -- The Russian Army's command here, which publishes the Oesterreichische Zeitung, told Austrians today that they would be better off without the estimated $100,000,000 relief expected under Congressional action. The article's tone suggested that Moscow intended to prohibit the distribution of relief goods in the Russian zone unless the relief agreement based on the legislation were changed to suit Russian desires.

NEW DELHI, July 13 -- Mohammed Ali Jinnah, president of the Moslem League and Governor Generaldesignate of Pakistan, pledged today full protection to minorities in the Moslem state when he becomes the constitutional head of the Government.

After easiness in the trading in the first part of last week, cotton prices in the domestic market turned strong on the small acreage report by the Department of Agriculture. At the close of trading on Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains for the week of 185 to 271 points, the sharpest advance for a week this season.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (U.P.) -- The Navy disclosed today that two new experimental submarines -- the world's fastest undersea combat craft -- would be completed in 1951 and would be radically different from those that sank two-thirds of Japan's merchant fleet in World War II.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- An official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that the bureau believes the atom bomb secrets which two ex-Army sergeants are accused of taking did not get away from them before they were arrested.

LONDON, July 13 -- How unpredictable the course of the stock markets can be has been strikingly illustrated in the last week. Instead of being depressed by the extremely gloomy picture drawn in Parliament during last Tuesday's debate on Britain's economic situation, the markets have displayed something very like buoyancy.

Ocean liners of nine nations carried an estimated 205,110 passengers between European ports and New York during the first six months of this year, according to a survey completed here yesterday. Of the total, which does not include travelers aboard Army and Navy transports, 114,385 were westbound and 90,725 were carried to European destinations.

HARTFORD, July 13 -- Connecticut employers covered under the unemployment compensation law will save an estimated $15,000,000 in tax payments between now and the end of the year under the new contribution rates prescribed by the 1947 session of the General Assembly, it was announced over the week-end by John J. Egan, Commissioner of Labor, through the office of Howard E. Hausman, executive director of the Employment Security Division.

NEWARK, N.J., July 13 (AP) -- After Jersey City pitching had muffled their bats through 13 innings, Newark finally exploded for five runs on home runs by Al Clark and Jack Phillips in the fifth inning of the nightcap here today to win, 6 -- 4, after losing the opener, 5 -- 2.

JAFFA, Palestine, July 13 -- The organized Arab youth of Palestine pledged themselves today to go the limit in preventing further land sales to Jews and to strengthen the boycott of Zionist goods. These youths, who formerly comprised two opposing "scout" organizations, are now united and claim a membership of more than 50,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 13 -- With Margaret O'Brien definitely set to star in it and with the title of the picture changed for the third time, "The Big City" today was scheduled to go before the cameras at M-G-M on Aug. 15.

The United States should act now to solve the problem of European displaced persons and refugees without waiting for the recommendations on immigration of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine, Ira A. Hirschmann declared yesterday.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 13 -- About twenty miles from Ankara there is the little known village Institute of Hasanoglan, where Anatolian boys and girls are being equipped to go out as pioneers to tackle at the source Turkey's most vital problem, the peasant question.
ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, July 13 (AP) -- While a crowd of 8,000, mostly Yugoslavs, yelled for the losers, Czechoslovakia took the first two matches today in the European Zone Davis Cup final.

JERUSALEM, July 13 -- A British ultimatum for the safe return of two Army sergeants kidnapped by terrorists as hostages was issued today to the residents of Nathanya, seaside Jewish town, and its environs.

In population and in the nature of its transportation system Chicago is perhaps, more nearly like New York than any other American city. Its transit fares are therefore of considerable interest to New York. Chicago surface lines raised their fare to 8 cents on April 20, 1942, and discontinued a 3-for-20-cents token ate.
MUNICH, Germany, July 13 (AP) -- Germans are fleeing from the Soviet zone into Bavaria in such numbers that the United States Military Government described the situation today as serious.

Suggestions for resolving the dilemma confronting employers in inserting "no strike" clauses while negotiating union contracts under the Taft-Hartley law are contained in a special bulletin which will be issued to members today by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc.

BOSTON, July 13 (AP) -- Coming from behind on both occasions, the Boston Braves today twice defeated the Cubs, 8 -- 7 and 6 -- 5, before 22,719 fans who saw the Chicagoans lose their eighth and ninth games in succession.

LONDON, July 13 (Reuters) -- Princess Elizabeth, in the uniform of Chief Ranger of the British Empire, took the salute today at a march-past of 2,000 girl guides from all over Europe and the United States in Pall Mall.

American manufacturers, now awakening to the need for more imports if they are to continue to export in volume, can do much to accomplish this by seeking elimination of "unreasonable and archaic" customs administrative rules, which are the chief barrier to increased imports, according to James B. Herzog, president of Stern, Morgenthau Co., Inc., exporters and importers.

AMSTERDAM, July 13 -- The expected full Dutch-Indonesian agreement is bringing considerable activity to Dutch Indies enterprises here. These concerns are sending hastily by plane scores of employes to Batavia in preparation for the early return of property, though it is understood that there will be no return unless full safety is guaranteed.
PARIS, July 13 (Reuters) -- The text of the draft plan of organisation submitted by the working committee and adopted at today's plenary session of the aid-Europe conference follows:

PEIPING, China, July 13 (AP) -- Heavy fighting in the area of Wanteh and Chiehshou, twenty miles south of Tsinan, Shantung Provincial capital, was reported today in Chinese Government dispatches, which said several "key points" had been wrested from the Communists.

Week Ended July 11, 1947 Strength in sterling "forwards," the Canadian free dollar and a firm undertone in the Swiss free franc represented the highlights of the trading in the foreign exchange market last week. In other sections business was small and no important rate changes were reported.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13 (AP) -- After losing the first game, 4 to 2, the St. Louis Cardinals rallied to tie the score at 2 -- 2 in the ninth inning of the second contest and then won out in the tenth, 3 to 2, to split a double-header today with the Philadelphia Phillies before a crowd of 27,036.

Proposals to construct garages under Bryant and Madison Square Parks, as recommended by the Mayor's Special Traffic Committee, were defended yesterday by Hugo E. Rogers, Borough President of Manhattan.
