ST. LOUIS, July 13 (AP) -- Jerry Witte singled in the last of the ninth today to bring Vern Stephens across the plate with the winning run to give the St. Louis Browns their first victory in the last eight starts, 3 to 2, over the Senators.
Pressure for the prosecution of landlords who seek to gain rent increases by threats of eviction was renewed in various quarters yesterday.

JERUSALEM, July 13 -- Zionist military strength is "adequate to defend Jewish Palestine against any attacks from the Arabs of this country," regardless of any help the Palestine Arabs may get from the Arab League states, the official Zionist resistance movement declared today.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 13 -- If there were a rating that exceeded ten goals in this country, Cecil Smith would be the man to get it. The ten-goal Texan, doing everything that possibly could be asked of a polo player, rattled fourteen goals off his mallet as his Texas side whipped Brookfield, 27 to 14, in a first-round match in Pete Bostwick's 55,000 Handicap Tournament at Bostwick Field today.

From last Jan. 29 until last Saturday the Senate Foreign Relations Committee had on its docket the nomination of former Attorney General Francis Biddle to succeed John G. Winant as our representative on the United Nations Economic and Social Council. Mr. Biddle, whose character, ability and previous public services certainly merited consideration, was called before the committee but once, in May, in an executive session.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Representative Walter C. Ploeser, Republican, of Missouri, declared today that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation could not argue on good grounds that its ability to take prompt action in an emergency would be impaired if it were brought under Congressional control.

Fears that manufacturers of industrial supply lines would "overprice" their products by further increases at this time were expressed here over the week-end by industrial distributors. They cited a 44 per cent increase in resale prices of standard dry-cell batteries, effective on July 1, as an example of one recent advance which has not been followed by distributors.

The Hanscom Baking Corporation, strike-bound since June 13, resumed work at its Astoria, Queens, plant yesterday with new employes obtained through newspaper advertisements and prepared to reopen its retail stores today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 13 -- Peace Bridge, a thoroughbred bay mare owned by Miss Elizabeth Ham of Scarsdale, N.Y., and handled throughout by Miss Verenne Mitchell, also of Scarsdale, which was appearing in her first show of the season, walked off with the conformation hunter championship of the twenty-second Harrison horse show as the two-day event was concluded here today.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- With passage assured, the Senate will vote tomorrow the bill pushed by the leadership of the Republican majority to reduce the income tax rates.
SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 13 -- The youth who ended Frank Parker's long reign at Spring Lake on Saturday won the first leg on the new challenge bowl today.

Vicente Lombardo Toledano, founder of the Mexican Federation of Workers, president of the LatinAmerican Federation of Workers and a vice president of the World Federation of Trade Unions, arrived last night at La Guardia Field with the opinion that the workers in Europe are in a much stronger position than those of the Western Hemisphere.

PRAGUE, July 13 -- In a lastday session before its vacation Parliament passed a bill on a revision of the land reform program carried out after World War I. In 1919 Czechoslovakia passed a progressive land reform bill of great social significance.

Stay-at-home vacationers will find greater enjoyment in the parks this summer, thanks to the interesting programs arranged by the Department of Parks for children and adults. To a permanent staff of 400 playground directors have been added 300 seasonal directors.

PEIPING, China, July 12 (Delayed) -- A blunt warning that the United States must not ignore the present power and prestige of the Communists in China was voiced here today by Prof. Chang Tungsun, noted Chinese philosopher and leader of the "liberal" North China Democratic League.

From behind a slightly opened door, a man who identified himself as a deputy commander of the Stern underground group in Palestine, yesterday gave in the Hotel St. Moritz an interview that was cloaked with mysterious trappings.

Roman S. Weller has been appointed assistant controller of Macy's New York, with councilor status. Ezra Moscrip becomes manager of the systems department, Jack L. Selkowitz manager of the budget office and John F. Cribbon sales auditor.

CAMP BARREE, Pa., July 13 -- American and foreign delegates to the World Encampment of Girl Scouts prayed today for the 2,000,000 members of the organization in services which marked the end of the gathering. The Protestant group assembled in the Mail Lodge while the Catholic contingent worshipped in the Orchid Valley Unit.

Frank J. Sampson, Tammany leader, sent out yesterday to 5,000 Democratic voters on the West Side letters urging them to support Eugene E. McManus for reelection as the Tammany district leader in the Third Assembly District (Middle).
LONDON, July 14 -- The British press has agreed "under strong protest" to accept a 20 per cent cut in consumption of newsprint beginning next Monday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 (AP) -- Tommy Hughes and the Philadelphia Phillies halted George Munger's string of consecutive victories at seven tonight before 10,158 fans in defeating the St. Louis Cardinals, 5 -- 2. The Phils took two out of their three-game series.

CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock market here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs. 9,000 head: total 12,000: weights under 300 pounds fairly active and uneven; generally 25-75 cents higher: heavier weights and sows steady to 50 cents lower:

ALBANY, July 14 -- The Public Service Commission denied today a request for a 5 per cent increase in intrastate freight rates on certain manufactured articles, ruling that railroads in New York State had not justified the necessity for the rise.

GENEVA, Switzerland, July 14 (U.P.) -- Sir Stafford Cripps, President of the British Board of Trade, said today that the time had come when decisions on outstanding tariff difficulties in the world trade discussions, including those with the United States, could and would be reached.
CHICAGO, July 14 -- The weather tonight accomplished what other American clubs have been unable to do -- check the Yankees' winning streak.
Rear Admiral Stanley F. Patten, USN (Ret.), has been appointed administrative assistant to the president of Du Mont Laboratories.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The text of President Truman's statement today on coal and steel prices follows: Deep concern is being expressed in many quarters over possible results of the recent settlement between the miners and the coal operators.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I wish that our Municipal Art Society would take a tip from your editorial "Eros Returns" and start erecting some statuary that people would miss, as was the case in London when the status of Eros had been exiled and was finally replaced, with much effection expressed by Londoners.

WHEN Samuel Shellabarger sat down to write his historical romance about love and politics and war in Renaissance Italy he had no way of knowing that at the same time Maurice Samuel was working on an identical literary project. Dr. Shellabarger is the extraordinarily popular author of "Captain from Castile."

THERE'S no race quite like the Irish for bristling indignantly at injustice. In fact, they've been bristling for centuries. But, whisht, man, have you heard that the Irish are being deprived of the right to compete under the Irish banner in the 1948 Olympic Games? Frank O'Connor, former 440-yard champion of Ireland, has just called the attention of this corner to the dastardly situation.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 14 -- H.H. Giles, executive director of the Bureau for Intercultural Education of New York, said today that there was a "potentially great leadership" in the South which "will and must" solve the problem of racial discrimination.

Seattle, Wash., awarded yesterday an issue of $7,000,000 light and power revenue refunding bonds due Aug. 1 from 1954 to 1970 to a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at an interest cost of 1.99 per cent. The bid was 100.135 for 2s. Other bids for 2s ranged from 98.72 to 98.31.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 14 (AP) -- Hugh McL. Fenwick's Harem scored a nose victory over the heavily-backed War Trophy in the one-mile-and-a-sixteenth Atlantic Purse today at the Monmouth Park track.

The increases in intrastate rail passenger fares and higher commutation rates on the Long Island Railroad seem to have been accepted by the public with resignation rather than with protest. In both cases this latest blow to the private pocketbook is somewhat softened by special considerations.

Miss Arminda Rea Dunning, niece of Mr. and Mrs. Howard B. Dunning of Paterson, N.J., and daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Dunning of Ridgewood, N.J., has completed plans for her marriage to Eleuthere Irenee du Pont of Greenville, Del., which will take place here on the afternoon of Aug. 9 in the chapel of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 14 -- Six hundred apartments in Peter Cooper Village will be set aside for United Nations personnel under the terms of a contract signed between the world organization and the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, builders of the housing project, it was learned today.

Consolidated net profit of Willys -Overland Motors, Inc., for the quarter ended June 30 amounted to $1,165,103, after taxes, James D. Mooney, chairman and president, reported yesterday. He said that the profit was the largest quarterly return for the company for any peacetime year since 1928.

LOS ANGELES, July 14 -- Public ownership of railroads, coal mines and atomic power installations was urged by Robert W. Kenny, national co-chairman of the Progressive Citizens of America, tonight at the final session of the "conference on thought control" sponsored by the organization's Hollywood Council.

Frazer A. Bailey, president of the National Federation of American Shipping, reported yesterday that assurances have been given by the State Department that the proposed transfer of eighteen Liberty ships to Italy is not to be considered as a precedent for similiar moves with respect to Germany and Japan.

CINCINNATI, July 14 (AP) -- Ezzard Charles, 174, Cincinnati, knocked out Fitzie Fitzpatrick, 182 1/2, Los Angeles, in two minutes and forty-three seconds of the fifth round of a scheduled ten-round bout tonight. A solid left hook, followed by a terrific right put Fitzpatrick down for the full count.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared here yesterday that he would urge its membership to vote against Senator Irving M. Ives because of the latter's activities in behalf of the Taft-Hartley law.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The vote by which the Senate passed today the bill to reduce income taxes by $4,000,000,000, starting Jan. 1, was as follows:

While the honest tradesmen and artisans who each day labor in the six-story loft building at 48 and 50 Walker Street were enjoying a respite from their work over the week-end, burglars were putting in a full day. Systematically they looted the five upper floors, stopping when their work was done to partake of a light lunch and a cold bottle obligingly left at hand by one of the tenants.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 14 -- The Soviet Union's fight for the destruction of atomic bombs on a certain date, rather than as the climax to the stage-by-stage process of setting up international control, was brought into the open today by Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister.

Merchants in the areas recently afflicted by floods need not worry about obtaining merchandise to take care of their requirements, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, said yesterday. Credit representatives, and the houses they represent, will respond to the needs of stricken areas, the credit chief said.

YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif., July 14 (AP) -- A mountain climber with both legs broken in a fall that left him dangling at the end of his rope was rescued yesterday by thirteen park rangers who brought him down the steep sides of Upper Cathedral Spire after a tense thirteen-hour ordeal.

CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- It is an old fight-game gag that there's no proper answer to a right-hand shot on the whiskers, but you still have to lean to Tony Zale in Wednesday's middleweight title battle, even though Rocky Graziano is the one sporting the righthand convincer.

BOSTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Cubs broke a nine-game losing streak today by defeating the Braves, 5 to 3, in a Ladies' Day game before 15,278 (9,055 paid) that saw Johnny Sain, ten-game winner for the home forces, knocked out in the sixth with an injured pitching hand.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 14 -- An announcement today by Warner Brothers concerning a short subject documentary film the studio recently made, "The Power Behind the Nation," signalizes the beginning of a plan by the motionpicture industry to help sell America more thoroughly to its people.

Plans for the early presentation in dramatic form of the Twentieth Century Fund's survey, "America's Needs and Resources," which contains estimates of the country's condition for 1950 and 1960, have been all but completed by ABC, it became known yesterday.

Senator Vandenberg came out of yesterday's bipartisan conference with President Truman with the announcement that it seemed "all but impossible" to adjust the immigration laws at this session to admit displaced persons. If this is true, the Stratton Bill and one of similar intent in the Senate will die.
Directors of the Phillips Petroleum Company yesterday increased the annual dividend rate to $3 from $2, with the declaration of a 75-cent quarterly dividend payable on Aug. 30.

Announced today as the winner of the semi-annual Metro-Goldwyn -Mayer Novel Award, is "Raintree County," a first novel by Ross Lockridge Jr., to be published by Houghton-Mifflin. The author receives a minimum of $150,000 with a possibility of $250,000 contingent upon sales, plus $25,000 should the book receive the Pulitzer Prize.
It never fails: as soon as we leave for our vacation the mail and wires begin pouring in a flood of wonderful fishing reports from Maine to Ocean City, and this year was no exception.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Current thought on Greek problems would be clarified if a distinction were made between the internal and the international difficulties of that country. Having just returned from Greece, where I stayed for some ten months, I feel keenly interested in a proper solution of the dilemma presented there, and would like to offer an opinion based to a considerable extent on personal experience.

The first bonds of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development were cleared for public offering yesterday at 3:30 P.M. by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Sale will begin today. The total is $250,000,000.

LONDON, July 14 (Reuters) -- Bill Edrich and Denis Compton, whose third wicket partnerships featured England's test matches with South Africa, today unleashed an onslaught against Leicestershire's bowlers and added 277 runs in two hours and ten minutes for a second wicket partnership for Middlesex.

"Rip Van Winkle," July's lone addition to Broadway's dwindling list of attractions, will be presented at 8:30 o'clock this evening at the City Center. It is the first offering -- and the crucial bid for survival -- of a dozen actors and theatre technicians in a cooperative venture incorporated as the Company of Twelve and billed as the New York City Theatre Company.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- With President Truman and many of the highest Government officials in attendance Mrs Franklin D. Roosevelt today received from French Ambassador Henri Bonnet a posthumous presentation of France's Medaille Militaire for the late President Roosevelt.
TOKYO, July 14 -- Great gains have been made in the prevention of disease in Japan, "chiefly because of Allied assistance and guidance," the Welfare Ministry reported today.

ESSEN, Germany, July 14 -- This city has launched a full-scale barrage for the retention of at least part of the capacity of the Krupp steel works. The municipal government has asked the British Military Government that the works in the city be permitted to produce at least 100,000 tons of steel annually of whatever output is allowed to Germany by the Allies under the new level-of-industry plan.

To substitute for Frank Fay, who is taking a busman's holiday west of the Hudson, James Stewart turned up in "Harvey" last evening at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre. As a tribute to his eminence, the populace and the officers of the law lined the street to try each other's mettle, and some Broadway characters came back to Times Square to look things over and complain of the humidity.

M. Abbott Van Nostrand's 10foot putt on the home hole for a birdie three gave him and Joe Sylvester of Pomonok a card of 31, 33 -- 64 and victory in the Metropolitan amateur-pro event sponsored by the Long Island G.A. at the Pomonok Country Club in Flushing yesterday.

A bottleneck has developed in the shipment overseas of urgently needed clothes by the Church World Service. Ships stand ready and the clothing is at hand, but there is a shortage of volunteers to sort the material now stored at the Long Island warehouse.
LONDON, July 14 -- The u32,000,000 Southern Rhodesia 2 1/2 per cent loan, the first gilt-edge issue underwritten by the market since the war, proved a failure in the stock markets here today.

Sales and billings of the Douglas Aircraft Company for the six months ending on May 31 amounted to $54,534,370, compared with $57,146,830 during the first six months of 1946, Donald W. Douglas, president, reported to stockholders yesterday.

Finding the conditions exactly to his liking, Mrs. B.F. Whitaker's Hitem galloped home to victory in the Dobbs Ferry, the Class C event that served as the main attraction on the card of the Empire City Racing Association yesterday.

BERLIN, July 14 -- The new level of-industry plan for the economically merged American and British zones, which is expected to be announced on Wednesday, will provide for substantial increases in reparations deliveries to the western nations and possibly to the Soviet Union, it was learned today.

STOCKHOLM, July 14 -- The isolation from the nuclei of living cells of a chemical believed to be the substance transmitting heredity was reported today before the International Congress for Experimental Cytology.

UTICA, N.Y., July 14 -- Senator Irving M. Ives was denounced here today by George Meany, secretarytreasurer of the American Federation of Labor, as the legislator primarily responsible for the enactment of the Taft-Hartley Labor Law.

GENEVA, Switzerland, July 14 (AP) -- Valerian A. Zorin of Russia lashed at the Western powers today in the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe while seeking to block direct contact between the commission and the individual occupation zones of Germany.

Fears that national defense stockpiles are being permitted to drop to dangerously low levels were expressed here yesterday by industrial executives. They urged a vigorous policy of stockpiling by the Federal Government during the remainder of the year.

Herbert Livingston Satterlee, eminent lawyer and son-in-law of the elder J. Pierpont Morgan, ended his life yesterday in his apartment at 1 Beekman Place by shooting himself through the right temple. He was 83 years old and in failing health.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 14 -- Gradual withdrawal by the Federal Government from the taxing of alcoholic beverages, inheritances, gasoline, luxuries and amusements so that the states can tap these sources for their own revenue needs was urged today at the annual conference of Governors. In return it was suggested that the states abandon the personal and corporate income tax field to the Federal Government.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 14 -- A warning that the United States must help the nations of Western Europe rehabilitate themselves economically or see them drift into the Russian orbit was given tonight by Secretary of State George C. Marshall at the annual conference of Governors.

WASHIWGTON, July 14 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy tonight canceled an investigation scheduled for tomorrow morning, of sources of certain recent newspaper stories bearing on the security of atomic bomb secrets.

Two eight-story seventy-ninefamily apartment houses in Forest Hills, Queens, were among plans for new buildings filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The buildings are to be erected at the northeast and southeast corners of Sixty-fourth Road and Ninety-eighth Street by the Nepartk Realty Corporation at an estimated cost of $1,200,000, L. Stillman of Manhattan is the architect.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., July 14 -- Mr. and Mrs. Anthony L. Adrian have announced the engagement of their daughter, Josephine T., to Alexander L. Keyes son of Dr. Edward L. Keyes of 79 East Seventy-ninth Street, New YorK, and Fair Oaks, Southampton, L.I. The wedding will take place in September.

The three Swedish stowaways, who arrived in New York from Stockholm on July 1 in the tailsection of a transatlantic airplane, left La Guardia Field yesterday aboard a Scandinavian Airlines System transport.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (U.P.) -- Fifteen Senators, including two Republicans, introduced legislation today to repeal the Taft-Hartley labor law "lock, stock and barrel."
CORK, Ireland, July 14 (AP) -- A German sea captain who preferred Ireland's plenty to voyages between Germany and England put his British-chartered vessel to work today in Cork Harbor.

A dispute among local leaders of the American Labor party over the proposal to raise the basic transit fare to eight cents came out yesterday as Mayor O'Dwyer indicated that the Board of Estimate would take no definite action on the plan until after July 23.

The Securities and Exchange Commission submitted yesterday to the United States District Court its conditional approval of the trustee's revised plan of reorganization for the Childs restaurant chain.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (U.P.) -- Representative Clarence J. Brown, Republican, of Ohio, introduced a resolution today which would exempt fifteen-inch rolls of newsprint from tariff duties.

The controversy between the Borough of the Bronx and the World Trade Corporation, which is conducting a survey of pier and trade facility improvements, continued yesterday with Borough President James J. Lyons charging the corporation's efforts do not extend far enough into the port's potentialities.

PARIS, July 14 -- A contingent of about 1,000 British students and about 250 United States and Canadian students marched in the Communist ranks in the Bastille Day parade today. Many of the British marchers clenched their fists in the Communist salute.
LONDON, July 14 -- Britain is going to export beer, biscuits and chocolate to get hard currencies, John Strachey, Minister of Food, announced in the House of Commons today.

Peter Doelger, Inc., in a purchase for Investment, has acquired the Gladstone Apartments at 10802 Seventy-second Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens, from Mirod, Inc. The building contains four stores and twenty-seven suites. This is the second sale of the property since the building was erected nineteen years ago.
SEOUL, Korea, July 14 -- Regulations governing Korea's foreign trade, which will be opened tomorrow, were announced yesterday by the Commerce Department of the South Korean interim government.

LONDON, July 14 -- By the end of this week the bill authorizing Indian independence will be law. Another step in the process of rushing it through Parliament was taken today when the House of Commons discussed details of the measure in committee.

One of the largest purchasing organizations in this area was instructed yesterday, in an official semi-annual statement of policy, to cease deferring purchases in the hope of lower prices, it was revealed in a conference with the chief executive purchasing officer of the group.

ATHENS, July 14 (UP) -- Government troops routed an invading force of 1,000 Albanian and Greek guerrillas from Konitsa and forced them to retreat to St. Nicholas, five miles to the northwest, where savage fighting is under way, official sources said today.

As the new commutation rates on the Long Island Rail Road went into effect yesterday, officials of the road disclosed that it had purchased $2,500,000 worth of electrical equipment, as the first step in its promised $16,000,000 program to improve service.

How to choose accessories to personalize a dress or suit and new ways to wear them were demonstrated yesterday at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel by Ann R. Silver Associates, representing Coro jewelry, Criterion belts, Glentex scarfs and Aris gloves.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 14 -- The Greek government charged today that "strong and well-armed hostile forces" had invaded Greece from Albania yesterday and that leading Greek Communists were now in Albania and Yugoslavia with the aim of forming a rebel Government.
After rising to new highs for the season, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday lost all the gains and closed 39 to 55 points net lower.

ATHENS, Greece, July 14 -- Dwight P. Griswold, director of the United States aid program in Greece, and thus the principal figure in the new American commitments in the Eastern Mediterranean, landed here in a United States Army C-47 plane at 8 o'clock this evening. He had boarded the plane in Rome.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 -- West Coast ship-owners were challenged today by the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, to "allow the stevedoring firms" to cast a secret ballot under Government or impartial auspices on the question of bargaining collectively with longshore walking bosses.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- It appeared tonight that when the first session of the Eightieth (Republican-controlled) Congress adjourns late this month, it will stay away until January. Despite implications of the Marshall aid-for-Europe plan, now undergoing survey at the Paris conference, it seemed that Congress would not be called upon to take action on it before next January.

Early Iron Curtain A friend of this department whose summer reading carries him into unexpected places is moved to ask why it should surprise anyone that Soviet Russia has refused to go along with Western Europe on Secretary Marshall's rescue plan.

NANKING, July 14 -- Chinese Communist leaders are still thinking of a settlement of China's civil war in terms of a "coalition government" but appear to reject any possibility of relations with Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and many of his colleagues.

PARIS, July 14 -- The United States and British occupation commands in Germany are sending delegations to Paris to remain for the duration of the present sixteen -nation conference on the Marshall plan for economic aid to Europe.

ILION, N.Y., July 14 -- A 27-dayold dispute at plant No. 1 of the Remington-Rand reached a new stage of bitterness here today when a mass picket line of more than 2,000 successfully blocked a back-to-work movement.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The office of the Housing Expediter, charged with the administration of rent control, indicated today that it intended to take action to halt illegal attempts by landlords to force rent increases.

Store Sales Here Up 11% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 11 per cent last week over the comparable week last year, according to the "flash" report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday. In the previous week a rise of 14 per cent was reported, while for the four weeks the gain was 6 per cent.

Problems of malnutrition and the increase of disease, especially tuberculosis, among children are of principal concern to delegates to the Fifth International Congress of Pediatrics, which opened yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Former Gov. Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota, Republican aspirant for the Presidency, laid down a threepoint program of American action tonight, designed to convince Russia that she must share "constructive leadership in a peaceful, progressing world."

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Truman opposed today an "immediate" increase in steel and coal prices because of the new coal wage contract completed last week between the United Mine Workers of America (AFL) and the coal industry.

VIENNA, July 14 -- Strongly protesting against Austria's signing of the American-Austrian $100,000,000 relief agreement, the Soviet commander, Col. Gen. L.V. Kourasov, informed the Austrian Government today that his occupation force did not regard it as binding on them.

PARIS, July 14 (Reuters) -- In his broadcast tonight Foreign Secretary Bevin said that Britain and France were resolved that nothing should separate them. He said: "The fall of the Bastille and the French Revolution inaugurated a great period of freedom.

Governors of American states, regardless of party, have much in common. All of them are familiar with the technique of getting elected to public office, though naturally a Democrat doesn't talk to a Republican about that. All of them have to deal with legislatures. All of them just now want to make a reputation for economy, at the same time spending enough money to get what their constituencies think are necessary thing's done.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- General short covering developed today in the deferred deliveries of corn on he Board of Trade here, with an advance of as much as 6 cents to a new seasonal high. The July was inclined to lag owing to evidence of weakness in the cash market.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Senate passed today a $1,048,466,184 Agriculture Department appropriation for fiscal 1948, after restoring more than half of the amount cut from the department's budget by the House.

LONDON, July 14 -- A motion was introduced in the House of Commons today calling on the Government to request the United States to release Britain from the non-discrimination clause of the American loan agreement.

Bendix Home Appliances, Inc., may reimpose allocations on its automatic washer for distributors in various parts of the country who are now able to fill all dealer orders as taken, Judson S. Sayre, president, disclosed yesterday. Mr. Sayre stated that the company has definitely abandoned all plans to terminate allocations for 50 per cent of its distributors now operating under such limitation.

PEIPING, July 14 -- A sure sign that the Chinese Government has decided to make sweeping changes in Manchuria is seen in today's announcement that Lieut. Gen. Tu Yu-ming has been relieved of the supreme command there for reasons of "health."

The latest addition to the Cunard White Star Line's fast-expanding post-war fleet, the new 14,000-ton Media, now is scheduled to enter service on Aug. 20, on her maiden voyage from Liverpool to New York, H.P. Borer, general manager of the line, announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 (AP) Miss Dorothy Head of Alameda, Calif., stroked her way into the third round of the annual Pennsylvania and Eastern States women's grass court tennis tournament today by defeating 14-yearold Laura Lou Jahn of Florida, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3.

A special detail of guards at the Empire State Building that has thwarted five suicide attempts in the last two months failed yesterday to prevent an unidentified young man from plunging to his death from the eighty-sixth floor observation deck.

PARIS, July 14 -- The conference of sixteen European states, called to frame a collective response to the Marshall proposal of United States aid in the reconstruction of this Continent is expected to hold its final session at this stage tomorrow, when it will set up a series of committees to assess European resources and needs.

LONDON, July 14 -- Poland's reply to the Anglo-French invitation, published here today, denounces the conference on the Marshall proposal, now under way in Paris, on the ground that it would "contribute to the rebirth of German imperialism" and that it "implies an important threat to peace."

LONDON, July 14 (AP) -- Sportsminded Britons met a rebuff today in their efforts to drive a wedge into the strict food rationing system for the benefit of their own and foreign athletes coming here for the 1948 Olympic Games.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- One of the thirty-two Senators who voted today against the revived and redated tax reduction bill just possibly might change his mind and vote to override the Presidential veto that is awaited, though no one expects any Senator to do that.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am greatly distressed at the progress being made in Congress toward the admission of Hawaii to statehood and the like action contemplated first for Alaska and then for Puerto Rico.

Campers are reminded in a bulletin from the Chicago office of the Wheat Flour Institute that hot breads may be "baked" over an open grate. Bereft of ovens as the great outdoors may be, it's still possible to have a warm biscuit or supper.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, indicated on his return today from the Paris cereals conference that next year's United States food relief shipments would not go to countries in the Russian orbit.

ATHENS, Greece, July 14 -- The Government announced tonight that "a new invasion of Greece took place this morning," and a Cabinet Minister said that a 2,500man guerrilla force was advancing on the important city of Yanina, twenty-five miles from the curving Albanian frontier.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The House Republican leadership decided today to establish a special committee, with authority to investigate abroad as well as at home, to keep abreast of economic and other aid requirements of foreign nations and of the ability of United States resources to meet them.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 14 -- Countries not members of the United Nations may become "associate'' members of the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East, the commission's committee of the whole decided today by a 9-0 vote, with Russia abstaining.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 -- The National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards, Congress of Industrial Organizations, announced today that it would demand a Congressional investigation of the Matson Navigation Company for halting reconversion work on the liners Monterey and Mariposa.

CLEVELAND, July 14 (AP) -- A home run by Bobby Doerr in the ninth inning gave the Boston Red Sox a 1 to 0 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight as Dave (Boo) Ferriss shaded Don Black in a torrid pitching duel before 20,789 fans.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 14 -- Following is the teak of Secretary Marshall's speech to the Conference of Governors here tonight: I have welcomed the opportunity to meet with you gentlemen again but not the obligation to make a formal public statement.

ST. LOUIS, July 14 (AP) -- The last-place Browns shelled three pitchers for twenty hits, half of them good for extra bases, for a 13-3 triumph over the Senators today, but only 478 fans witnessed the Brownies' best offensive of the season.

Everett (Bud) Lively, a 22year-old red-haired right-hander from Gardendale, Ala., last night showed the Dodgers the best pitching they have seen since his teammate, Ewell Blackwell, shut then out with two hits on June 22.

The Better Business Bureau of New York City advised fur retailers yesterday of its special recommendations for advertising July and August fur sales. Past seasons have shown, the Bureau pointed out, that future fall and winter prices are unpredictable and it therefore recommends discontinuance of comparative price statements based on prediction of stated future prices, and claims of savings which use percentages based on future prices.

SAG HARBOR, L.I., July 14 -- A few thousand dollars can prevent destruction of one of the oldest buildings in America and perhaps lead to its establishment as a national shrine. If this village cannot raise $4,000 in a few weeks the hand-hewn timbers of a building here that antedates the Revolution will be leveled to make way for a parochial school, it became known today.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Truman today made known the resignation of Howard C. Petersen, Assistant Secretary of War, effective July 31.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 14 -- The Soviet Union's concern to impress fourteen European nations with its views on the nature of the Marshall offer of aid to Europe and its version of the reason for the breakdown of the Foreign Ministers' conference in Paris were expressed in a Russian note to Sweden published tonight.

Aerial service between New York and the Far East was started yesterday afternoon at La Guardia Field by a Northwest Airlines DC-4 transport carrying twenty-six passengers." Flying via Minneapolis, Anchorage, Alaska; Tokyo and Shanghai, the plane was expected to reach Manila in the Philippines at 7:55 P.M. Thursday.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Chairman Wint Smith of a House labor committee sharply criticized today some provisions of the contract of Local 202, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, American Federation of Labor, in New York City.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- A leader in the field of retail business expressed the view today that "it is probable that we are near or past the peak of prices," but he cautioned that consumers "are deluding themselves to expect pre-war prices."

Twelve large concentration camps are being used by the Russians in their zone of occupation in Germany, and a purge of former officials of the German Social Democratic party by the Russian secret police is under way, a report released here yesterday charged.

When the Giants, loaded as they are in the power department, hit three homers in a game, as they did against the Pirates at the Polo Grounds yesterday, it's hardly a surprise. But when they complement such slugging with a wellpitched game, this one by Clint Hartung, one pities the opposition.

The Monroe Calculating Machine Company announced yesterday that it had decided to sell "Seven Oaks," the twenty-sixroom former Colgate mansion on South Center Street, in Orange, N.J. The company's sales training program, for which the property had been used since its purchase in December, 1944, has been shifted to its 150 branch offices throughout the country.

BOSTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Sandy Strand Stable's 3-year-old Gelding Manna H. withstood a late challenge by T.C. Melrose's Mel Eppley to win the feature by half a length at Suffolk Downs today before a 14,164 crowd. The Orefield Farm's Oresusan showed a length back.

NATHANYA, Palestine, July 14 -- Nathanya and four settlements on its fringe were cut off from the rest of the world at 7 o'clock tonight to permit wide "searches" for two British Army sergeants who had been kidnapped early Saturday by terrorists.

JERUSALEM, July 14 -- If the United Nations were obliged to impose any solution of the Palestine problem, Dr. Judah L. Magnes, president of the Hebrew University, testified today that one solution that could be imposed would be that of a bi-national state.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Senate failed by two votes to roll up a veto-proof majority today in passing the second personal income tax reduction bill, 60 to 32.

Rail Earnings An indication of how the increased costs of operation are cutting into the earnings of the nation's railroads is shown in the petition of the carriers to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to increase their freight rates by about 16 per cent.

The military position in Indo-China is apparently a stalemate. The Viet Namese are not strong enough to drive out the French. The French themselves are not strong enough to seize control of more than a few port cities or areas that can be supplied by air; nor can they keep open the lines of communication to the interior rice fields and plantations.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 14 (AP) -- O.A. Johnson's little 45-foot cutter, the Spookie, on the basis of corrected time, won the annual 243-mile Port Huron-toMackinac yacht race today over fifty-one rivals. Her corrected time, which was her total time minus her handicap of four hours, eight minutes and forty-two seconds, was 38:24:43.

DES MOINES, July 14 (AP) -- Marvin (Bud) Ward of Spokane, Wash., fashioned a 4-under par 68 today as only seven players were able to beat or match par 72 figures for the hilly fairways am lightning fast greens of the Wakonda Club in the opening qualifying round of the Western Amateur golf tournament.

Inability of Lancashire mills to obtain a fair quota of labor will keep cotton textile production in Great Britain at a low level for a long time to come, N.S.W. Vanderhoef, president of the Textile Export Association of the United States, asserted yesterday.

Albert Gross, a former bootlegger with the assured manner and appearance of a successful business man, testified yesterday in General Sessions Court that he personally had paid $3,000 "under the table" over a period of months to I. James Brody when the latter was Deputy Commissioner of Marine and Aviation.

President Truman resumed yesterday his campaign, comparatively neglected of late, of combating inflation with exhortation. During the weeks when John L. Lewis was maneuvering the coal industry into a corner where he could bludgeon it into last week's agreement, the Administration, figuratively speaking, had its back turned.

NEW DELHI, India, July 14 -- A potentially ticklish political situation involving some of the Moslem League members elected to sit in the Indian Constituent Assembly from the Pakistan territories appeared to have been solved amicably today.

The National Collegiate Amateur Athletic committee on swimming records has approved twenty-eight standard performances achieved this year and two of earlier date, it was revealed yesterday by Philip S. Harburger, chairman of the committee.

Finding jobs for graduates of Children's Village is becoming increasingly difficult, Frank M. White, placement director at the school, said yesterday. Located at Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., the school gives vocational and citizenship training to boys with special problems.

Inflationary psychology became more persistent yesterday on the stock market as prices climbed to new highs since early February, although late realizing reduced extreme gains of 1 to 4 points by approximately one-half. Activity in the steels and motors was most pronounced, and while some of the high-price issues showed sizable gains at the close, the composite rate advanced only by 0.43 point on the day.

The United States Conciliation Service has arranged a meeting for today at 10:30 A.M. at 341 Ninth Avenue between Maurice K. Gottfried, president of the Hanscom Baking Corporation, and Local 50, Bakery and Confectionery Workers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: No tax-reduction bill should be vetoed, provided, of course, it is not flagrantly partisan and unjust. And the present bill is neither. Far more important than the mere percentage reduction that the bill would extend to the "common man" is the economic optimism that its passage would assure.
Charles Mattmann of Rosyln, third in the list of favorites, was eliminated from the eastern clay court championship yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Glut in Queens.

Garage operators, charging that the police and traffic courts were "harassing and persecuting" them, have curtailed sharply all pick-up and delivery service and intend to eliminate it entirely unless city policy is altered, it developed yesterday.

MADRID, July 14 -- Reprisals have been taken against the Monarchist newspaper ABC for refusing to support Generalissimo Francisco Franco's law of succession in its editorials, it was learned tonight. Its paper ration has been cut by half, causing a serious loss in revenue.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Efforts of Senate Republicans to bring about an investigation of alleged Federal inaction on Kansas City vote fraud charges were blocked again today as one of their own number stood with the Democrats in opposition.

The case of a confidence man who made a "legitimate sale of a stolen automobile and then followed it up by duping the buyer and making off with the vehicle, was reported yesterday by the police as they announced the arrest of the swindler.
An experiment was tried last night with Puccini's "Madama Butterfly" at the Lewisohn Stadium. For the first time in thirty seasons the sponsors presented a complete opera in concert form.

CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- Earnest D. Wallis, 34 years old, former Army sergeant and formerly an official photographer at the Los Alamos. N.M., atom bomb plant, pleaded innocent today to a Federal charge of removing top secret atomic photographs and negatives.

LONDON, July 15 -- The pound sterling, within certain limitations, became convertible into all other currencies for current transactions today. As a result there are a lot of frightened Treasury officials, bankers and economists keeping their fingers crossed.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, Virgin Islands, July 15 -- Gov. William Henry Hastie of the Virgin Islands said today he is prepared to go to Washington to tell Congress that a ceiling of $500,000 on internal revenue funds due the islands from the export of rum would keep them in the red indefinitely.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 9,000 head, total 11,000: market fairly active and 25 to 50 cents higher on all weights and sows; bulk of good and choice 170 to 240 pounds. $26.50 to $27.25; 250 to 270

UTICA, July 15 -- William Green proposed today organic unity between the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the American Federation of Labor as a prerequisite to combined political action by the two labor groups in the 1948 elections.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The several Republicans, now in Washington, who hope to be nominated for President by their party did not fail to note that Governor Thomas E. Dewey of New York, who is attending the Governors' Conference at Salt Lake City, once again declined to comment on a great public issue.
Frederic Ernst, associate superintendent in charge of the New York public high schools, said yesterday he was convinced that a new specialized high school of science is needed in Queens.

Although a number of business and industrial papers showed a loss in advertising volume for the first half of 1947 compared with the same period in 1946, the likelihood of such papers reintroducing copy service and other competitive advertising services is remote, according to trade paper executives here.

Blyth Co., Inc., and other underwriters will place on the market today an issue of 300,000 shares of common stock of Kimberly -Clark Corporation, manufacturer of cellulose wadding and other paper products. The stock is priced at 24 7/8 % a share.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 15 -- Although they have worked out sailing problems along with mere men to the point of superiority in a number of open championships, the sailors of the fair sex still have rivalry among themselves, and today they started competition for their top place on Long Island Sound.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 15 -- The United Nations Security Council today rejected a demand by the United States that it hold emergency meetings all day tomorrow as a result of the reported invasion of Greece by forces from Albania.

Showing no compassion whatever for a foe who already seemed to be reeling in circles, the Giants rolled right over Charlie Grimm's stricken Cubs at the Polo Grounds last night, 4 to 0, to nudge their way into the seething National League flag race.

In keeping with his plan for a permanent three-platoon system in the New York Fire Department, Commissioner Frank J. Quayle announced yesterday a new system of working hours for five battalions to give additional time off for the uniformed men.

A group of New York restaurant interests closed yesterday an agreement, with the approval of the United States Treasury Department, to buy the Longchamps chain of nine restaurants, it was announced by Theodore T. Mets, president of the Exchange Buffet Corporation.

VIENNA, July 15 -- The Soviet High Command's note to the Austrian Government against the terms of the American relief program -- made known yesterday -- contained a direct threat, it was learned today. The note said in a passage not released by the Russians yesterday:

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Republican leaders were divided today over the question of a third attempt to enact a personal income tax reduction bill before the 1948 elections. As Congress awaited President Truman's veto of the second bill, Representative Harold Knutson of Minnesota said that failure to override would "probably mean the end of prospects of individual income tax reduction" before 1949.
The former Lady Iris Mountbatten, a member of the British royal family, was arrested yesterday at 926 Park Avenue on a charge involving a worthless check issued last June 9 in Washington.

Albert Gross, designated by the District Attorney as the "money man," stoutly contended under cross-examination yesterday by defense attorneys that he was a "sucker" who had been "badly trimmed" in the alleged scheme to make millions by obtaining pier leases with James V. Auditore and I James Brody, ousted Deputy Commissioner of Marine and Aviation.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 15 (AP) -- Jockey Jimmy Stout, leadingrider of the Monmouth Park meeting, stole the show today when he won three of the first five contests, including the featured mileand-sixteenth Don Alonzo Purse.

MOSCOW, July 15 (Reuters) -- The Communist party newspaper Pravda carried a dispatch from its Paris correspondent today alleging that Paris "press circles" believed United States political representatives in Athens were working out with the Greek Government and General Staff a plan for United States military intervention in Greece.

When Mr. and Mrs. Burton E. Moore Jr. decided to go into the food business in a small way by preparing unusual delicacies in the kitchen of their farm at South Coventry, Conn., they drew for ideas on a recipe book that had belonged to Mr. Moore's greatgreat-grandmother.

BERLIN, July 15 -- The United States Government's new directive to Gen. Lucius D. Clay, American Military Governor, is intended to integrate American policy toward Germany with the Marshall Plan, it is understood here. The most significant part of the directive is the section dealing with economic unity and recovery, according to the highest officials.

If Commander E.F. McDonald Jr., president of a Chicago radio corporation, has his way with the Federal Communications Commission and with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company we may in the near future pick up the telephone receiver and say "Give me phone vision" whenever we want to see a television play or a baseball game.

Elated at the prospect of a home of their own, Mr. and Mrs. Irving Spieler settled down yesterday in their two-room apartment in the frame building at 1741 Eighty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, which formerly housed Public School 101.

GARDEN GROVE, Iowa, July 15 (AP) -- Transportation troubles reminiscent of those which slowed their forebears a century ago plagued 148 Mormons as they arrived here tonight at the end of the first leg of a trek commemorating the journey of Latter Day Saints to Utah in 1846-47.
ROME, July 15 -- Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza is expected back from Paris tomorrow to lead the Government's fight for ratification of the Italian peace treaty.

Food and clothing packages provided by CARE (Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe), at 50 Broad Street, may be sent to Ireland, it was announced yesterday. In a conference at the Hotel Biltmore, the terms of the agreement signed by Sean F. Lemas, Deputy Prime Minister of Ireland, on distribution of CARE packages on July 3 was made public by Paul Comly French, executive director of CARE, who recently returned from Europe.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Some weeks ago a distinguished committee appointed by the President to make a study of problems arising from the atomic age published its report.

ATHENS, July 15-- In the first official allegation that members of an "international brigade" were participating in the guerrilla invasion, Minister of War Stratos' stated tonight that the Greek Government would ask the United Nations subcommission to interrogate twenty prisoners at Konitsa.

Net assets of Tri-Continental Corporation, before deducting funded debt, amounted to $46,040,596 on June 30, according to the quarterly report issued yesterday by Francis F. Randolph, chairman of the board. This compares with $56,614,322 on the same date a year ago, and $46,858,980 at the end of last March.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 15 (AP) -- Remington-Rand, Inc., today declared that "violence, assaults" have occurred at the strikebound Elmira plant, but Police Chief Elvin D. Weaver asserted there was "no justification" for the company's statement.

BOSTON, July 15 (AP) -- After getting only one man on base through the first five innings, on a walk, the Cardinals erupted for four runs in the sixth inning tonignt and went on to defeat the Braves, 8-2, before 29,605 paying fans.

TOKYO, July 15 -- Attempts by occupation officials to steer the Japanese labor movement into "appropriate and proper trade union activity," and incidentally away from the Communist party, appear to be successful.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- President Truman expressed the opinion today that Government controls of United States exports would be required for the indefinite future. His views were given in a statement accompanying his signature of the Second Decontrol Act of 1947.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau reported today that the corn crop, hampered by excessive early season rains and floods, made "much" improvement during the last week.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The House Armed Services Committee approved today a bill of vast scope revising the Army's system of military justice and taking the judge advocate general's office out of the old chain of command.

Any curtailment or service by a garage should be followed by a reduction in rental charges, J.R. Crossley vice president of the Automobile Club of New York asserted yesterday. He pointed out that since the first of the year charges have increased 30 to 100 per cent in many cases.
PARIS, July 15 -- The conference of sixteen European states adjourned today until late August after having created machinery to prepare western Europe's collective response to the Marshall plan.

Louis Waldman, general counsel of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, yesterday called the Taft-Hartley Bill "class legislation of the worst sort" and added that in addition to being unconstitutional, it was contrary to the whole American tradition of equal treatment before the law.

Here and There New Mexico would not be an American commonwealth if it did not advertise its natural merits and pleasures to its fortyseven sister states. To be sure, we do not recall anything from New Mexico like the special fourteen-car train with, which Oklahoma has been touring the country, but some publicity campaign or other there must surely be under way emanating from Santa Fe or Albuquerque.

Some price increases on major, appliances will occur this fall as a result of higher costs of sheet and other steel occasioned by the recent coal settlement, an executive of a large national appliance distributing organization predicted yesterday.

We hope that a law creating an air policy board gets through the lastminute rush of the Congressional hopper before recess and becomes operative this summer, Senator Brewster's bill to this end has been reported to the Senate floor with recommendation for passage from the Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce.

Bonds of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development changed hands yesterday for the first time. The first dealing took place on the New York Stock Exchange's public market immediately after the Exchange opened for trading, and while the bank was still being pressed for allotments from dealers all over the nation.

In an active session, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange rose yesterday to net gains of 83 to 102 points on the day. There was heavy covering by the trade, since the spot basis in the South was strong for new crop ginnings and futures were selling at least 4 cents a pound under spot cotton in the South.

Twenty-four persons were injured, sixteen of them so severely that they required hospital treatment, at 11:20 o'clock last night in the collision of a Seventy-ninth Street cross-town bus and a Board of Transportation emergency truck at Fifth Avenue and Seventy -ninth Street.
LONDON, July 15 -- For the first time since the war a prominent British labor leader advocated today "a limited measure" of direction of labor as a means of meeting Britain's production crisis.

LONDON, July 15 -- The Indian independence bill completed its swift passage through the House of Commons today without division, and will go to the House of Lords tomorrow. Never in the long history of Parliament has so momentous a measure been drafted and rushed toward enactment with such speed.

The Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company's net earnings for the six months ended on June 30 reached a new high of $6,419,027, equal to $2.51 a share, John D. Biggers, president, reported yesterday. In the first six months of last year, earnings of $805,729 or 32 cents a share reflected difficulties resulting from strikes and the confused governmental price control situation, Mr. Biggers said.

GUAYQUIL, Ecuador, July 15 -- Dr. Robert Triffin, American financial expert, has made a, preliminary report on his survey of economic conditions in Ecuador, which he says is suffering more from inflation than any other country on this continent.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- On the eve of the second anniversary of the experimental explosion of the first atomic bomb, Prof. Albert Einstein pleaded today for continued faith in the United Nations as the hope of the world for solving the problems of atomic control and peace.

JERUSALEM, July 15 -- Two top-grade Irgun Zvai Leumi terrorists and one second-stringer were among fifteen wanted men sifted out of a large-scale screening process today in the sealed-off city of Nathanya, where the British are trying to find two of their sergeants kidnapped early Saturday.

Still bending its efforts toward a "key settlement" in the present shipyard tie-up, the United States Conciliation Service three-man panel here met yesterday morning with Bethlehem Steel Company officials for more than two hours. The meeting was held in the Service's headquarters, 341 Ninth Avenue.

TRENTON, N.J., July 15 -- New Jersey was prepared today under special Congressional action to pay unemployment compensation to idle seamen who in the last two years worked on vessels of the War Shipping Administration.

South African buyers of goods exported from the United States were severely critical of the poor quality and the careless packaging of many products forwarded by American manufacturers, Robert H. Johnston, president of American Exporter Magazine, declared yesterday.

PARIS, July 15 (U.P.) -- The four top-seeded Americans -- Miss Margaret Osborne, Miss Doris Hart, Miss Louise Brough and Mrs. Patricia Canning Todd -- advanced into the third round of the French lawn tennis tournament today, but Miss Hart was within two games of suffering an upset before she rallied to beat her opponent.

Recent wage increases granted to mineworkers will cost New York householders 90 cents to $1 a ton more for anthracite coal after Aug. 1, it was indicated yesterday when the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Coal Company announced increases to its dealers ranging from 45 to 90 cents a ton.

World Bank Although hailed ungrudgingly on all sides as a "market success," yesterday's first offering of bonds of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development was something of an ironic innovation in "outsider" accommodation.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday that net income for the twelve months to June 30 rose $1,155,089 to $180,760,000.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Behind schedule, the fourth and fifth of a dozen big departmental appropriation bills needed to run the Government for this fiscal year went from Congress to the White House today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have just returned from a seventhousand-mile business and pleasure trip by car through twenty states. Through Virginia, southwest from Washington, some three hundred miles, the erosion everywhere is appalling, the poverty of the countryside sad indeed.

STOCKHOLM, July 15 -- Exploration of the interior constitution of an individual living cell with a new type of ultraviolet microscope has revealed important chemical differences between the nerve cells of normal human beings and those suffering from various mental diseases.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The House, over bitter protests even from some conservatives that ancient legal rights were being jeopardized, passed today a bill ordering a loyalty investigation of the more than 2,000,000 Federal employes.

NEW DELHI, India, July 15 -- Representatives of India's Princely States are to meet with the Viceroy, Viscount Mountbatten, here on July 25 to arrange their relationships with the Dominions of India and Pakistan after Aug. 15.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Three prominent capitalists emphasized today before the Joint Congressional Committee on the Economic Report that only increased production could halt a wage and price spiral.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 15 -- Sir Alexander Cadogan, British representative, proposed today that the United Nations Security Council make another effort to determine the Soviet Union's views on how large the proposed international police force should be.

FORT DIX, N.J., July 15 -- Six months to the day from its deactivation in Europe the Ninth Infantry Division was revived here this afternoon at ceremonies that also marked the transformation of Fort Dix to its traditional status as a divisional headquarters.

DETROIT, July 15 (AP) -- Collecting their runs in clusters, the Detroit Tigers pounded three Washington pitchers for fourteen hits for an 11-to-6 triumph over the Senators here today before 11,378 fans, one of the Tigers' smallest twilight crowds in history.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 15 -- The establishment of an Economic Commission for Latin America was proposed today by Dr. Hernan Santa Cruz, Chilean representative to the United Nations. He requested that his resolution for such an organization be placed on the agenda of the next meeting of the Economic and Social Council.

Gant Gaither is a young producer who just loathes twiddling his thumbs. Rather than bide his time until Cecil Beaton arrives here from London toward the end of October to design the decor and costumes of "Camille," in which Judith Evelyn is to be starred, Mr. Gaither is concentrating on a play right now bearing the lilting title of "Waltz Me Around Again."

Many of the women of Britain feeling that they did a good job during the war, now resent the fact that they are being discriminated against in the rate of pay, Mrs. Arthur E. Turner, of the Central Office of Information of England, declared yesterday.
The Pennsylvania Game Commission has anounced the dates for the upland game and big-game hunting season this fall, which will include a season on wild turkeys in ten counties.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 15 -- Several leading members of the Government's principal opposition, the National Peasant party, were arrested yesterday at an airport just outside Bucharest while trying to flee to another country, it was announced tonight.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 15 -- Mayor Vincent J. Murphy of Newark opened today a drive by state municipalities to eliminate the preferential tax rate for railroad properties in New Jersey.
Changes in hats for fall were shown last night in the Hotel Astor under the auspices of the Millinery Stabilization Commission.

Joe Louis will not engage in an outdoor bout this summer. The heavyweight champion, in conference with Acting Director Sol Strauss of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club yesterday, made the fact known after he and Strauss went down the list of all likely opponents and decided that not one of them would have enough boxoffice appeal to warrant a bigscale promotion this year.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 15 -- Mrs. Lillian Grecz of Brookville was shot and seriously wounded here today while embracing her brother, Patrolman Henry Kohanski of the Manhasset precinct, at a party given at his home in honor of her twenty-eighth birthday.
Arthur R. Lewis Jr., president of the Robin Line, declared here yesterday that South Africa was on the verge of the greatest development in her history.

Final plans have been completed by the Association of Steel Distributors, Inc., to complete the first independent national survey of industrial demand and available supplies of a wide range of individual steel mill products, Morris Rosoff, general counsel, revealed here yesterday.
Fourteen girls and one boy from an almost entirely white community in Massachusetts arrived in Harlem yesterday to visit a Negro parish of their church.

DETROIT, July 15 (AP) -- A decision to halt passenger car production for one week, with a layoff of 180,000 workers, was announced by General Motors tonight because of the steel industry's "disturbed conditions."

CHICAGO, July 15 -- General public buying and short covering swept September and December wheat, the deferred deliveries of corn and May oats to a new seasonal high on the Board of Trade today, and July corn equaled the record high of $2.21.

With no apparent obstacles to production, the millinery business this fall is expected to be equal or better than last year, Gordon K. Creighton, assistant general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, declared yesterday.

DES MOINES, July 15 (AP) -- Marvin (Bud) Ward of Spokane, Wash., played a one-over-par 73 on the rolling fairways and tricky greens of the Wakonda Club course today for a 36-hole low medal score of 141 in the qualifying round of the Western amateur golf tournament.

After her sudden appearance before the Grand Jury yesterday afternoon, Mrs. Doris Coppola, 25-year-old wife of Michael (Trigger Mike) Coppola, was released in $15,000 bail as a material witness in the investigation of the fatal Election Day beating of Joseph R. Scottoriggio.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- Tony Zale of Gary, Ind., the titleholder, and Rocky Graziano, New York challenger, were resting quietly tonight on the eve of their second ring battle for the world middleweight championship.

ATHENS, July 15 -- Airborne Greek Army reinforcements today abruptly halted a drive by 2,500 savagely fighting guerrilla troops nineteen miles from their objective, the Epirian capital of Yanina in northwestern Greece, and enveloped them in a trap from which they "cannot escape," a Cabinet Minister said tonight.

Buyers' Arrivals Increase Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,488 compared with 1,156 last week and 1,084 in the corresponding week of 1946, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The gravest economic problem confronting the British people at this time is a scarcity of foreign exchange, and particularly of dollars. It is necessary, therefore, that some further curtailment be made in British imports, and this the British Government is prepared to do.

Two hundred leaders of the Amusement Industry Division, including motion picture executives, producers and composers, contributed $200,000 yesterday to the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York at an emergency luncheon at the Hotel Astor.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- The White Sox used a four-run seventh inning to rout Tex Hughson and hang a 5-1 defeat on Boston before 30,849 tonight. Lefty Frank Papish checked the Red Sox on six hits for his season's sixth victory against five losses as the White Sox gained their eighth decision in sixteen night games thus far.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 -- A strike of longshore walking bosses, which began here Friday, had spread this afternoon to Los Angeles and tied up five ships.

To open a season of summer stock, the New York City Theatre Company put on "Rip Van Winkle" at the City Center last evening. Since the City Center needs a theatre troupe and the current company includes some interesting actors, it would be pleasant to report that the opening bill supplies a ripping good show.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Spokesmen for the American and New York State Bar Associations opposed confirmation today of Representative Leo F. Rayfiel of Brooklyn as United States district judge on the grounds they could "find no evidence whatever that he is qualified for the position."

The New York City Housing Authority awarded yesterday $12,150,000 of temporary housing notes due on Jon. 29, 1948, to the Chemical Bank and Trust Company and associates at 0.93 per cent. Proceeds of the sale will be used to continue the temporary financing of the Jacob Riis Houses and Jacob Riis City Houses.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 15 -- J. Ellis Knowles of Apawamis, who lost one championship last month, gained a new one today, winning the Metropolitan seniors' title with 37, 38 -- 75 over Winged Foot's West course. It was a 5stroke triumph.

ALBANY, July 15 -- The Adjutant General released the following orders today: NYNG Officers Assigned Lt. Col. J.W. Utter to 71st Inf. to Hq. as Ex. O. Capt. J.J. Ennis to 71st Inf. to Hq. 3d Bn. as S-2 1st Lt. H.L. Beck to 71st Med. Det as Med.

JERUSALEM, July 15 -- An agreement between the late Fawzi Darwish el Husseini, a relative of the exiled Grand Mufti of Jerusalem, and the League for Jewish Arab Rapprochement and Cooperation, a Zionist organization, was disclosed to the United Nations' inquiry committee today.

LONDON, July 15 -- Signing of the Anglo-Uruguayan agreement on sterling balances was the signal for a flurry in Uruguay rail stocks in stock markets here today. A British mission, it is understood, will leave for Uruguay shortly to discuss purchase of the railway by the State.

The police found themselves in the business of art appraisal yesterday after they had arrested a man who was carrying a package of twenty-six etchings they said had been stolen from art galleries and warehouses.

LONDON, July 15 (Reuters) -- Alec. Bedser and Alf Gover of Surrey took leading parts in defeating Kent today. Kent was left to make 256 runs to win in about three hours, but Bedser finished the game by taking the last two wickets with consecutive balls with only five minutes of play left.

LONDON, July 15 (Reuters) -- The latest wave of arrests of Rumanian Opposition politicians was considered by London observers tonight to be the most drastic and most significant that had taken place since the pro-Communist National Democratic Front Government of Petru Groza was placed in power by the Russians in 1945.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 -- A new rule, to be known as N-17G-1, covering the bonding of officers and employes of management investment companies registered under the Investment Company Act of 1940 is being considered, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

The United States Government is the biggest and most important business in the world. It operates on a budget of $38 billion. Its actions directly affect millions of people and businesses doing many more billions of dollars. In its administrative posts it should have the best men this country can produce.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, July 15 -- In a terse letter that reproaches Gen. Lucius D Clay, United States Military Governor, for having taken them to task, nineteen of the highest German bizonal officials have presented for enforcement by the occupying powers a four-point program to save the United States and British zones from what was termed "imminent anarchy."

The Paris Conference has completed the first phase of its task with record speed and refreshing unanimity. In only four days and three plenary sessions, which, as Foreign Minister Bidault puts it, set a fine example to the world of what people can do if they want to, it has accepted the Marshall Plan without reservations and created the machinery to put it into effect.
The Brooklyn pennant balloon may not have burst at Ebbets Field yesterday, but it certainly developed a fast leak.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 (AP) -- Ewell Blackwell pitched his fourteenth straight victory tonight as the Reds rallied to defeat the Phillies, 5 to 4, with Eddie Miller driving in the deciding run in the eighth inning before a crowd of 19,298.

Because of the alarming abortion rate in Germany among married women, doctors there are appealing to this country for aid in furnishing material on planned parenthood, Dr. Abraham Stone, vice chairman of the newly formed International Union of Family Organizations, reported yesterday.

City College has elected six new department chairmen and has reelected twenty-four other departmental heads for three years, effective July 1, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Department of Agricultur has eased penalties imposed against Daniel F. Rice Co., Philip R. O'Brien and Lawrence L. Ryan in connection with its findings that they, together with General Foods Corporation, attempted to corner the rye market in 1944.

A new nominee for the meanest thief in the world arose yesterday. An amputee veteran, Albert Super of 2839 West Thirty-first Street, Coney Island, reported that his specially fitted car, which enabled him to drive to work for the Veterans Administration in Brooklyn, had been stolen from in front of his house.

PARIS, July 15 -- Russia has made a great mistake in banking upon a major economic upset in the United States in the near future, Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Producers of America and former head of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said here today.

The stock market shuttled yesterday over an irregular course and, after a series of alternating movements, came under mild profit taking in the final hour. Contrary price changes ruled in the heavy industrials as a result, and the composite rate showed a decrease of 0.37 point on the day.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read -- but with no surprise -- the letter of Congressman Willis W. Bradley, former naval governor of Guam, addressed to THE NEW YORK TIMES. I say "with no surprise" because Mr. Bradley is essentially a Navy officer, and his letter obviously attempts to support the Navy in its current fight to retain its supervision over Guam.

Adding to his holdings on Thirtyfifth and Thirty-sixth Streets between Broadway and Eighth Avenue, Samuel Kaufman, through his Kaufman-Wales Corporation, has purchased the fourteen-story mercantile building at 242-52 West Thirty-sixth Street from Joseph W. Ferris, Henry Leifert and George L. Long, trustees.

NUREMBERG, Germany, July 15 (AP) -- Two German field marshals and nine lesser generals went on trial before a United States military court today on charges of executing 13,000 civilians who resisted the German occupation of the Balkans and Norway.

EVERY observant, thoughtful spectator of the tragic drama which is India reacts with the shock of personal discovery -- at least those who write books seem to. No advance preparation, no previously accumulated information and no extensive experience of men and cities can cushion it. Some see only squalor, ignorance, suffering and superstition; others find spirituality, holiness and ancient wisdom.
One hundred and fifty civic, welfare and social representatives attended the dedication ceremonies yesterday of the Interracial 110th Street Community Center at 31 West 110th Street.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project won approval of a Senate subcommittee today as a House committee began consideration of the controversial international development.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Occasionally THE TIMES prints an editorial on an earthly subject, the recollection of which has awakened nostalgic yearnings in some editorial breast. The countryman reads these sallies with pleasure and sometimes awe in speculating how some drudgery or, monotony of farming can inspire poetic rhapsody.
ST. LOUIS, July 15 (AP) -- A proposal to do away with racial segregation in the Evangelical and Reformed Church was approved today by the church's General Synod.

With one of the fourteen competitors absent, but due to arrive for the second round, play began yesterday in the European zonal world championship chess tournament, according to a report from Hilversum in the Netherlands. Palestine was included among the fourteen nations at the last minute because of the withdrawal of Dr. Trojanovici of Rumania, for whom H.I. Foerder of Tel Aviv was substituted.

As representatives of ten nations stressed yesterday the effects of war upon nutrition and economics, President Truman, in a message to the Fifth International Congress of Pediatrics, asserted that promotion of children's health was part of the task of building permanent world peace.

Capt. Edward Steichen, who early in 1945 was in command of all Navy photography and who organized and directed the Navy Photographic Institute, was installed officially yesterday as the director of the Photographic Department of the Museum of Modern Art.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 15 -- Governors of the states and territories of the United States were urged today to support a program of adequate national preparedness that includes universal military training, unification of the armed forces and strengthening of American intelligence services.

In two cases yesterday the law cracked down on landlords. In one a Brooklyn woman was committed to the workhouse for thirty days and fined $100 as a gouger. In the other a Manhattan real estate man was fined $1,000 and placed on probation for one year for demanding a $1,200 bonus from a veteran for renting an apartment.

UTICA, N.Y., July 15 -- Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner, told the State Federation of Labor convention today that the "widely anticipated recession had not yet made its appearance" in this state and reported state-wide employment of 5,400,000.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 15 -- Readers who use the Montclair Library rely on newspapers even more heavily than members of the Montclair community in general in forming their opinions, according to two polls recently taken in Montclair.

LONDON, July 15 -- Linking Secretary of State Marshall's speech in Salt Lake City with the auspicious start made at the sixteennation economic conference in Paris, official British opinion is distinctly cheerful about the prospects for eventual success of the Marshall plan for United States aid to Europe.
