Work is being started immediately on the construction of a new aboratory for the Sterling-Winthrop Research Institute, a division of Sterling Drug, Inc., at East Greenbush, N.Y., near Rensselaer, as the result of an agreement just made between Sterling and the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York.

GLASGOW, Scotland, July 15 (U.P.) -- Local sports writers who have watched both Champion Jackie Paterson and Challenger Dado Marino in training for tomorrow night's world flyweight title bout picked Marino to win.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The unification of the armed forces took a decisive step toward early realization today. Under speed-up orders from the Republican leadership, the House Committee on Expenditures in the Executive Department approved its own measure to put the Army, Navy and Air Forces, as independent departments, under a single Secretary of Defense.

LONDON, July 15 -- Linking Secretary of State Marshall's speech in Salt Lake City with the auspicious start made at the sixteennation economic conference in Paris, official British opinion is distinctly cheerful about the prospects for eventual success of the Marshall plan for United States aid to Europe.
Ready Jack, Phalanx's kid brother, stole the show at Jamaica yesterday with a rip-roaring run through the stretch that gave him a nose decision in a three-horse photo finish.

DETROIT, July 15 -- Members of the United Auto Workers, CIO, apparently have rejected the proposed merger with the Farm Equipment Workers, also a CIO affiliate. With an estimated 60 per cent of the votes tabulated today, the count was 2,932 against the proposal and 1,043 for It.

CLEVELAND, July 15 -- Maybe the Yankees of 1947 are not quite as great as the Yankees of 1926. Maybe the current edition does not quite measure up to the Yankees of Ruth and Gehrig and Pennock and Shawkey. This is hardly the time to weigh their respective merits.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 15 -- The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association staged a brand new type of tournament today, a bestball of partners with a combined handicap of no less than 6. The morning round was a qualifying round at 18 holes, and the afternoon a first round of match play.

PARIS, July 15 -- As the National Assembly's finance committee will meet tomorrow to take up the Government employes' payrise question, what might have been France's most disastrous modern labor upheaval seemed averted.
LOS ANGELES, July 15 -- A Hollywood branch of the International Rescue and Relief Committee, an anti-totalitarian agency for aiding democratic refugees in Europe, has been started.
Samuel A. Alter, formerly client service executive at the A.C. Nielson Company, has been appointed manager of product development at the White Rock Corporation.

A new method for printing newspapers without the use of linotype machines, matrices or stereotype plates was announced yesterday ay two officials of the William J. Higgins Company, 318 East Fortyfifth Street.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 15 -- The chances for friends of democracy in Hungary are running out. It was announced today that the general assembly of the majority Small Landholders party, summoned for July 18-22, at which an eleventh-hour attempt to free the party from Communist domination was to have been made, had been canceled by order of the party leaders.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 15 -- The extent of forthcoming price increases in commodity sheet steel as a result of higher costs occasioned by coal wage advances is "uncertain." R.C. Todd, vice president of the American Rolling Mill Company, said here today.

The westward crossing of the Atlantic continues heavy with the traffic of athletes returning from England loaded down with trophies. Yesterday the Queen Elizabeth brought a consignment of tennis players and oarsmen.

Ginny Simms signed a contract yesterday in Hollywood calling for her talents as featured vocalist with Percy Faith's orchestra on the Coca-Cola program, scheduled for an Aug. 17 debut on the facilities of CBS. The thirty-minute series, originating in New York, will mark her first appearance on a network show coming from this city since her association with the Kay Kyser program.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson was reported today to have submitted his resignation to President Truman, to become effective as soon as possible after unification of the Armed Forces becomes a fact.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, announced today that the pound sterling convertibility provision of the United States loan to Great Britain had been fulfilled by the British Government.

In the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission Mr. Gromyko is now pressing a demand that a definite date be fixed for the destruction of existing supplies of atomic bombs. This is a demand to which the United States cannot afford to yield, and this is equally true, we believe, of other nations which support the Baruch plan.

SEOUL, Korea, July 15 -- The chief of the American delegation to the Joint United States-Soviet Commission for the Establishment of a Korean Provisional Government today accused the Russians of attempting to "exercise a veto power" on the question of consultations with Korean political and social groups.

ROSLYN, L.I., July 15 -- After eating a lunch today that included potato salad, remnants of which are to be examined chemically, more than 100 children between the ages of 4 and 10 years were taken violently ill at a private summer day camp on the estate of Miss Jean Sibley in the nearby incorporated village of Roslyn Estates.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The United States Military Government of Germany has been instructed to take measures to bring about stable political and economic conditions in Germany and to enable Germany to make a maximum contribution to European recovery.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 15 -- Samuel Bischoff, president of Star Films, independent producing unit formed last September by Bischoff and George Raft, said today that negotiations had been completed with the French Government and the French Foreign Legion for the filming in North Africa this fall of Raft's next starring picture, "Outpost in Morocco."

Another of the favorites was eliminated from the Eastern clay court championship yesterday when Charles Masterson, seeded fourth, was defeated by Jack Geller of New Rochelle at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club, Queens.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 15 -- The world food situation has become "immediately crtical" owing to the disappointing response to the United Nations' appeal for contributions to meet shortages in war-devastated countries, Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, reported today.

Dan Murphy, the young policeman who shot it out with a hold-up man on a crowded Forty-second Street bus ten days ago, became a second grade detective yesterday after a visit from ex-patrolman William O'Dwyer.

Today has been set as a deadline by the International Association of Machinists, AFL, in its wage negotiations with the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company of Stamford, Conn. Unless agreement is reached, the union will decide on future action at a meeting to be held in Stamford tonight.

DES MOINES, July 16 (AP) -- The defending champion, Frank Stranahan, and the medalist, Marvin (Bud) Ward, survived the opening round of match play in the Western amateur golf tournament today, but not until they had received warning that the championship road is going to be rocky all the way.

LONDON, July 16 -- The National Union of Journalists submitted a 20,000-word memorandum to the Royal Commission of Inquiry into the Press today calling for action to curtail chains and monopolies among British newspapers.

TORONTO, July 16 (Canadian Press) -- A par-walloping contingent of Americans and Canadians took apart Scarboro's tough course today and an even two dozen bettered regulation figures in the first eighteen holes of play for the $10,000 Canadian Open golf championship and the Seagram Gold Cup.

JERUSALEM, July 16 -- After nearly two weeks or concentrated Jewish denunciation of the British regime in Palestine, the United Nations inquiry committee is beginning to get the viewpoint of the British. The contention of the British is that the Palestine problem is an Arab-Zionist quarrel and that any decision favorable to Zionism would provoke Arab violence.

ROCKLAND, Me., July 16 -- Capt. William H. Wincapaw, known as "the Flying Santa Claus" because of his custom every Christmas of dropping gift to isolated lighthouse keepers along the New England coast, was killed with a passenger when his plane crashed in Rockland Harbor this afternoon.
ILION, N.Y., July 16 (AP) -- The three Ilion plants of RemingtonRand were closed today and the keys turned over to municipal authorities for protective custody of the strike-bound establishments.

MANILA, July 16 -- Sugar and gold, the Philippines' pre-war economic mainstays, representing the two leading exports in money valua, are slowly returning to life. Government trade officials estimated today that 250,000 short tons of Philippine sugar would be available for export from this year's crop, after six years in which Philippine sugar has been out of the world market.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 16 (AP) -- Elmendorf Farm's Polynesian proved something to those who doubted his ability as a route runner when he not only won the mileand-a-furlong Omnibus Handicap, but set a new track record of 1:50 3/5 at Monmouth Park today.

LONDON, July 16 -- Herbert Morrison, the British Government's chief economic planner, issued today a "solemn warning" that unless some agreement were reached along the lines of the Marshall proposal for solving Europe's dollar problem Britain "would have to reconsider her whole position."

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Gerhard P. Van Arkel, who resigned as general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board in criticism of the Taft-Hartley act, stressed tonight four results which he expected from the operation of the law.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 16 -- The controversial gambling issue may be submitted to the voters of the state in a separate referendum this fall, it was announced this evening after completion of deliberations by the legislative committee of the Constitutional Convention in session at Rutgers University.

DETROIT, July 16 (AP) -- The Senators jumped on Hal Newhouser today for five runs in the first two innings, but the Tigers came back to save the game 9 to 8 with a four-run eighth inning rally that enabled them to split a double-header.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Trading in grain futures was unusually heavy on the Board of Trade today. A broad buying movement lifted the deferred deliveries of wheat and September and May corn to new seasonal highs. Profit-taking developed later.

WASHINGTON, July 16--The United States has formally proposed to the ten other Governments represented on the Far Eastern Commission the holding of a conference "as soon as practicable," in order to discuss a peace treaty for Japan, the State Department announced today.

ATHENS, July 16 -- Most of the 2,000 guerrillas whom the Greek Army yesterday sought to surround in the heights of Kalpaki escaped to the northeast into the Gamila Mountains last night and now are believed heading for the Grammos Mountains, authoritative military sources admitted tonight.

The adventures of a pretty 14-year-old runaway girl, who had spent almost two months touring the country "by thumb," neared an end yesterday when she landed at La Guardia Field at 10 A.M. and departed for Boston an hour and a half later on another plane. She was met at the Boston airport by her father.

Establishment of the American National Film Committee for the United Nations was announced yesterday by Benjamin Cohen, assistant Secretary-General and chairman of the U.N. Film Board, at a luncheon attended by motion-picture and educational leaders at the Hotel Astor.

Gasoline stocks last week declined an additional 883,000 barrels, according to the American, Petroleum Institute. At the weekend they amounted to 88,791,000 barrels, compared with 89,674,000 a week earlier and 90,807,000 on July 13, 1946.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- House Republicans in controlling positions are about ready to give up their long-held determination to put through at this session a bill raising the 40-cent-an-hour minimum wage to 60 cents.

LONDON, July 16 (U.P.) -- A high Government source said today that Great Britain is planning increased trade with western Europe and her African colonies to offset the grave and growing dollar shortage at home.

COLORADO SPRINGS, July 16 (AP) -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias, United States and British women's amateur golf champion, smashed the competitive course record at Broadmoor by three strokes today with a 68, seven strokes under par.

The Giants continued the pleasant business of drubbing the Cubs at the Polo Grounds yesterday, although they didn't do quite so neat a job as they had the previous evening. In fact, there was some heavy breathing before the Chicagoans were put down for keeps, 6 to 3.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Senator James P. Kem, Republican, of Missouri, charged today that all Attorney General Tom C. Clark did in investigating alleged vote frauds in Kansas City was to "tie the hands of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and to whitewash the whole incident."

A new laboratory technique for viewing posters, which closely approximates actual driving conditions, called the "Rotary Set for Viewing Posters," was introduced yesterday at a meeting of the Copy Research Council by Richard G. Holbrook of Batten, Barton, Durstine and Osborn.
PARIS, July 16 -- The committee on European economic cooperation probably will distribute questionnaire tomorrow to the sixteen nations that conferred her on the Marshall proposal.

Strike activity in New York state in the first half of this year was considerably below that in the similar period of 1946, which was the peak year for strikes in American industrial history, statistics obtained yesterday from the State Labor Department showed.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Annual incomes of so-called whitecollar families rose more last year than those of the combined skilled, semi-skilled and unskilled wage earners, the Federal Reserve Board stated today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 16 -- Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, today proposed the establishment of an international quota system, under which the participation of each country in the peaceful uses of atomic energy would be defined exactly in a convention separate others setting up international atomic control.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Los Alamos, N.M., the forbidden city which grew up around the atomic bomb, will be modernized in a three-year construction program, the United States Atomic Energy Commission announced today.

PARIS, Thursday, July 17 -- Premier Paul Ramadier won what amounted to a vote of confidence in the National Assembly early today when the Government's program of limited pay rises for Government employes was unanimously adopted.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- President Truman recommended Congress today the expenditure $4,000,000,000 during the next ten years to increase control of flood in the Mississippi Basin. The outlays have been authorized by Congress, but appropriations have been backward.

There wasn't much quality to the Empire City-at-Jamaica racing show yesterday, but there was the customary number of winners in the seven races, the supply of mutuel tickets didn't run out and the 18,700 in attendance seemed well content.

The House of Representatives has passed a thoroughly bad bill in the name of a thoroughly good cause. The cause, stated generally, is a wish to make certain that those who hold public office in a democratic government actually believe in the democratic method and do their best to make it work successfully.

The Greater New York CIO Council, which has gone on record against any increase in subway fares, announced yesterday that it would conduct a public straw poll on the question, beginning tomorrow and ending next Tuesday.

TRENTON, N.J., July 16 -- A decision of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals at Philadelphia today returning to State Court jurisdiction a tax appeal case of the Central Railroad of New Jersey was seen by Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper as increasing New Jersey's opportunity to collect $15,000,000 in delinquent tax interest and penalties.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Herbert Hoover was chosen today for one more in his long series of official missions, membership on a new bipartisan commission to survey the operations of the Federal Government and reeommend ways to simplify its vast structure.

While a delegate from the Soviet Union described optimistically the advancement of health protection of children in Russia, a British authority told the Fifth International Congress of Pediatrics here yesterday of the "utmost seriousness" of Great Britain's diminishing birth rate.

Frank J. Shanaberg has been named Eastern district sales manager of the American Welding and Manufacturing Company, Warren, Ohio. The Eastern district offices will be moved Monday from 500 Fifth Avenue, New York City, to 1060 Broad Street, Newark 2, N.J.
More than one hundred persons were dispossessed yesterday from their rooms in the Imperial Hotel, Broadway and Thirty-second Street. Those remaining will be ousted this morning.

Delegated to the thirty-fourth convention of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, adopted a resolution here yesterday offering the union's support to future Government action against totalitarian and aggressor nations. The resolution was one of three adopted on the third day of the convention at the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- John D. Battle, executive secretary of the National Coal Association, told President Truman in a letter today that the Government's own figures made it "obvious" that the commercial soft coal mines were "in no position to absorb the costs that will accrue from the recently adopted contract."

Six car owners were absolved yesterday in Uptown Traffic Court of overtime parking in the early morning hours. In each instance Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger directed the issuance of a court summons against their garage, all returnable Oct. 13.

As a condition for marriage, women are insisting that they be allowed to continue in careers, Dr. Marynia F. Farnham, practicing psychiatrist, author and staff member of the New York State Psychiatric Institute and Hospital, declared yesterday at the Fashion Group monthly luncheon meeting at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Albert Gross, the stocky exwrestler and bootlegger, testified yesterday that he was told to see Clarence Neal, then a power in Tammany, if he wanted to get a pier lease, but that he failed to get a lease because he and his associates would not stand for a $100,000 "shakedown."

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- The Senate today passed an emergency bill intended to provide delayed pay checks for thousands of Government workers. The measure must go back to the House for agreement on a minor Senate amendment before it can be sent to the White House.

BATAVIA, Java, Thursday, July 17 (AP) -- Netherland sources predicted without reservation today that armed hostilities would break out in Java as a result of the rejection of Dutch proposals for a compromise settlement in Indonesia by Amir Sjahriffoedin, Premier of the Indonesian Republic.

The strong voice of Secretary Marshall has now been raised in a final plea to Congress to admit "a substantial number" of Europe's 850,000 "displaced persons" to this country. Congressional leaders offer only a plea in avoidance -- that there is not time before adjournment to pass the Stratton Bill providing for the admission of 400,000 of these homeless and stateless refugees in the next four years.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., July 16 -- Criminal charges filed here on June 10 against two men for the killing of a championship Doberman pinscher and the maiming of mother Doberman were dismissed this afternoon by Justice of the Peace Ray W. Aylesworth after he had examined the sheep corral that the dogs were alleged to have invaded.

A new issue of $1,750,000 water works bonds of Napa, Calif., maturing on each June 15 from 1957 to 1981 and callable in 1971 was awarded yesterday to a banking group at a bid of 100.16 for 2 1/2 s and 2 1/4 s, an interest cost of 2.29 per cent.

One major coal producing company announced price increases yesterday to its agents and wholesalers ranging from 55 to 95 cents a ton for anthracite coal while other companies prepared to make similar announcements.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of Selective Service, today was one of a dozen witnesses who urged before a House subcommittee the need for better health services for the school children of America.
HONOLULU, July 16 (AP) -- Labor peace returned to the fruitheavy pineapple plantations and empty canneries of Hawaii today under a contract negotiations truce.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., July 16 -- Representatives of four Rockland County commuter groups threatened today to begin a boycott on Aug. 1 against the Rockland Coaches, Inc., and the Spring Valley Motor Coach Company as a reprisal against the bus companies for "discriminatory and exorbitant" fare increases put into effect last May 1.

Winter fur styles made their debut at Arnold Constable's yesterday afternoon. A first glance revealed the new lengths. Hems have been let down several inches to meet the dropping hems of dresses and suits. Even the threequarters coat has added to its former length.

LONDON, July 16 -- Ten members of the British trade delegation to Moscow returned home today with the news that contracts had been negotiated for Russian timber, grains and other foodstuffs. The trade pact will be signed by the end of this week or Monday at the latest, barring an unexpected last minute hitch, they said.

UTICA, N.Y., July 16 -- Parting with past custom, the annual convention of the State Federation of Labor approved today the intent of a constitutional amendment which would create a Negro vicepresidency in the federation.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 9: Decreases of $235,000,000 in loans and $101,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 16 -- Despite a downpour and risk of wet powder puffs, the women sailors seeking their championship of Long Island Sound today went out and continued their racin in Atlantic Class sloops.

ATHENS, July 16 -- In a formal statement today to the Greek people, Dwight P. Griswold, chief of the United States mission to Greece, said he hoped the United Nations would eventually assume the mission's responsibilities here.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Stratton displaced persons bill, which is daily facing less possibility of coming up for a vote at this session of Congress received today the support of three Cabinet secretaries.
CHICAGO, July 16 -- Rocky Graziano is the new middleweight champion of the world.

Furniture Purchases Limited Furniture store purchases at the Chicago homefurnishings market have been very limited and extremely selective, an executive of a large local homefurnishings chain reported yesterday. He described the event as "pretty much of a frost" and added that most large retailers have bought for thirty to sixty days ahead at the outset, thus abandoning long-term purchasing characteristic of markets for the last five years.

Arthur Miller has rejected a Hollywood writing offer and is hard at work on two new dramas, hopping from one to the other because "both seem equally urgent." At the moment the author of the prize-winning "All My Sons" is devoting himself to one of the scripts, still nameless, that tells a love story of working people in an industrial city.

Brandishing a razor, a burglar entered the ground-floor apartment of Mrs. Fay Maydeck, 35year-old widow, and her three daughters at 529 Saratoga Avenue, Brooklyn, at 4:30 A.M. yesterday. He slashed the woman on her face after attempting to rape her and escaped with $7 and a key to the front entrance of the apartment.

ST. LOUIS, July 16 (AP) -- After losing the first game of a twi-night doubleheader, 5 -- 4, on two successive eleventh-inning home runs, the Athletics took the second game from the Browns tonight, 4 -- 1, with a three-run second inning. Bill McCahan held the Browns to four hits.

LONDON, July 16 - The Indian independence bill passed through all its stages in the House of Lords today and now awaits only royal assent to become law. This is a foregone conclusion before the week ends, which means that on Aug. 15 Britain's great empire of India divides into the Dominions of India and Pakistan as two fully independent states.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 16 -- While five ships remained tied up here and in Los Angeles by a strike of walking bosses, the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, was accused today by the Waterfront Employers Association of the Pacific Coast of "negligently or willfully" misinforming the bosses of their legal rights in collective bargaining.

Random notes. New Brunswick salmon fishing reports are excellent, with the Restigouche and the St. John Rivers apparenty giving up more and larger salmon than the others at this time. The famous Hartland Pool on the St. John provided a lot of excitement last week when a big run of salmon arrived there.

TOKYO, July 16 -- The hardest times since the war have caught up with Suzuki San, the average working-class Japanese. In part, the reasons are the continuing exhaustion of Japanese stocks of materials, the failure of successive Governments to collect rice from the farms and deliver it to the cities, the long economic blockade, which still persists, and doubt over the reparations program, which has hampered industrial recovery.
The severe rainstorm, with thunder and lightning, that broke over the city just before commuter time yesterday morning delayed many work-bound persons and caused-property damage in several places.
CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Fervent, continuing his late drive for the 3-year-old crown, easily outran seven rivals in the $32,950 Dick Welles Stakes at Arlington Park today.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- President Truman's message to Congress today on flood control follows: To the Congress of the United States: The major opportunity of our generation to increase the wealth of the nation lies in the development of our great river systems.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Leon Henderson, former Office of Price Administration chief, said today the nation is headed for a price collapse rivaling the 1920-21 slump unless consumer buying is jacked up but Senator Taft flatly disagreed.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, said in a press conference here tonight that the company planned no price increases for its passenger cars or other products despite recent increases in costs resulting from the raising of wages of Ford's own employes, and the higher steel prices expected from the coal miners' new wage scale.

Applications for liquor licenses for the nine restaurants in the Longchamps chain bought by the group of New York restaurant men headed by Theodore T. Mets, president of the Exchange Buffet Corporation, were filed at 5 P.M. yesterday with the New York City Alcohol Beverage Control Board, 2 Lafayette Street.

The Roth-Schenker Corporation announces the appointment of Richard Murray as supervisor of tenant selection for its Marine Terrace Apartments, the $13,000,000 rental housing project in Astoria, Queens. Mr. Murray will make his headquarters at the development.

Waning Honeymoon As World Bank bonds backed away from the plump premiums that marked their first appearance on the New York Stock Exchange, dealers perceived a first cooling off of speculative wishfulness. New bonds reaching the market yesterday evidently derived in great part from the final subscriptions allotted by the bank on Tuesday night.

RENO, Nev., July 16 -- Mrs. James Paul Warburg received a divorce today following an action in which she charged her husband, New York City financier, with mental cruelty. A sealed agreement settled property matters.

The patients of the Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases, 444 East Sixty-seventh Street, were assured yesterday of programs of popular and classical music. They had their concert piano. Offers continued to pour in to the hospital by mail and telephone from musicians offering their services.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- A ten-point plan of action to provide homelands for the world's displaced persons has been sent to Secretary Marshall by Representative Chelf. The program was submitted at Secretary Marshall's suggestion.

AHOSKIE, N.C., July 16 (AP) -- The Ahoskie Kiwanis Club, spurred on by a mounting wave of protests decided today to provide a $3,200 Cadillac automobile for Harvey Jones, the 25-year-old Negro war veteran, who held the lucky number in the club's raffle of such a car last week but who was told after the drawing that Negroes were not eligible for the prize.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Worsened conditions in the southern European area appeared, on word from authoritative Congressional quarters tonight, to have assured at least $400,000,000 of American aid to Greece and Turkey in their struggle against totalitarianism.

Tremendous catches of whitefish in some of the Great Lakes -- catches larger than at any time in the last seven years -- have brought the price of this fresh water variety down to a city-wide average of 55 cents a pound. This is 15 to 20 cents less than was charged last July.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Senate Republican leaders, still faintly hopeful of overriding President Truman's promised veto of the second tax reduction bill, have been working overtime in an attempt to convert Senator William Langer of North Dakota.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Government took steps today to assure continued production of badly needed binder and baller twine during a lapse of allocation controls over sisal and henequin fibers.

BOSTON, July 16 (AP) -- Warren Spahn tonight pitched his thirteenth victory and his fourth shutout of the season as the Braves defeated the Cardinals, 3 -- 0, before a paid attendance of 28,651, which made the Boston home attendance 700,410 for forty-five games on thirty-eight dates.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 16 -- Announcements made today by M-G-M regarding the forthcoming filming of the unpublished prize novel, "Raintree County," by Ross Lockridge, indicate that it will be a production project of unusual size, costing at least $5,000,000 and that several of the studio's stars will be in the cast.
The United States Conciliation Service continued yesterday its efforts to bring about a settlement of the shipyard strike, which entered its fourth week this morning.

JERUSALEM, July 16 -- The Irgun Zvai Leumi opened its retaliation against the Nathanya cordon and martial law today with five attacks on military vehicles. The casualty list stands at one dead and thirteen injured.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 16 -- The United Nations committee of the whole of the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East today decided that non-selfgoverning territories in that region might be admitted as associate members of the commission only on the approval of the metropolitan power responsible for their international relations.
LONDON, July. 16 -- With many buyers absent in the stock markets here today, the three-week account opened with an all-round decline in prices.

New issues of senior securities of public utility and industrial enterprises, consisting of $24,500,000 of bonds and debentures, and $3,000,000 of preferred stock, will be placed on the market by underwriting managers here today as follows: Iowa-Illinois Gas Electric Company -- $22,000,000 of first mortgage thirty-year 2 3/4 per cent bonds, at 101.40 to yield about 2.68 per cent, by The First Boston Corporation.

James William Gibson, 22 years old, porter-elevator operator in a five-story Harlem tenement at 207 West 147th Street, was booked on a homicide charge last night in the West 135th Street police station, in Harlem.

SEOUL, Korea, July 16 -- In an effort to stimulate small business in southern Korea, the disposal of former Japanese small-business holdings will soon take place, it was announced yesterday by Government authorities.

ROME, July 16 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Pope's address today: You have come, gentlemen, from an important meeting of the international organization that is charged with improving the condition of the working man.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Central Committee of the Eastern European peasant leaders here issued a declaration today condemning the attitude of the Soviet Union toward the Marshall plan for European recovery while praising the attitude of the United States.

MOSCOW, July 16 (AP)--A Pravda commentator, Boris Leontiev, said today that the Soviet Union was "steadfastly developing economic collaboration with all countries which have inclinations toward such."
NANKING, July 16 -- A new Yellow River flood that will threaten the homes and lives of three to four million persons was predicted today.

The Port of New York Authority yesterday sold to underwriters at an interest cost of 1.4404 per cent an issue of $16,350,000 of serial bonds to finance the cost of building the Union Bus Terminal now under construction between Fortieth and Forty-first Streets and Eighth and Ninth Avenues and connected with the Lincoln Tunnel by overhead ramp.

PARIS, July 16 -- At considerable sacrifice to its own economy, the United States is making heavy shipments of grain, coal and other requisites to Europe and other parts of the world, Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman told a press conference here today.

HALIFAX, N.S., July 16 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Tribal Class destroyer Micmac put in here tonight under her own power and landed five dead and sixteen injured after a collision with a freighter at the harbor mouth while her sister ship Haida continued to search the outer waters in a dense fog for six missing men, including a dockyard civilian worker.

CLEVELAND, July 16 -- Chalk up another victory for the Yankees and label it No. 17 in the amazing string of successive triumphs by the flag-bound New Yorkers. With an 8-2 rout of the Indians tonight at Municipal Stadium, the Yankees set an all-time high in the club's history, surpassing the sixteen straight annexed by the Miller Huggins-managed Yankees of 1926.

BERLIN, July 16 -- The British were understood today to have balked at some provisions in the proposed new level-of-industry plan for Western Germany. The specific provisions they opposed were not disclosed.
A six-run sixth inning enabled the Dodgers to overcome various shortcomings, afield and on the bases, to beat the Pirates, 10 -- 6, in a three-hour battle under the Ebbets Field lights last night.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Coal is the fundamental raw material essential to the rehabilitation of Europe, Secretary of State Marshall said today at his news conference. Since the Ruhr is the center of that raw material, he declared, an increase in its output is considered urgent. Means to that end will be explored in the United States and British conference that will open here late next week.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 16 -- A mass meeting of United Nations employes will be held here tomorrow to discuss formal staff charges that new rental agreements between the international organization and the Metropolitan and New York Life Insurance Companies imposed "racial discrimination."

SALT LAKE CITY, July 16--The Governors conference approved tonight by unanimous vote a resolution declaring that the foreign policy of this country should be nonpartisan ana should represent the United States to the rest of the world as a nation "that seeks peace and is united in its determination to protect the inalienable rights and privileges that our citizens now enjoy."
Their first day in Harlem complete, most of Grace Church's young white visitors from Massachusetts sat down last night to write home about the hospitality of their Negro hosts.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 16 -- The first best-ball golf tournament of partners with a combined handicap of no less than 6 was won by Mrs. Philip Cudone of the Knoll and Mrs. Theron V. Lyman of Maplewood over the Sunningdale course today.

Edward R. Murrow will vacate his post as vice president and director of public affairs for CBS at the end of this month to return to the microphone as a working news commentator and analyst. On Sept. 29 he will replace Bob Trout on the CBS quarter-hour beginning at 7:45 P.M., Mondays through Fridays, the time spot for which Campbell soups foots the bill.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has taken by assignment the twenty-two-year-old mortgage of $1,050,000 held by the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York on the sixteen-story office and showroom building at 244 Madison Avenue and the southwest, corner of Thirty-eighth Street, owned by J.Chr.G. Hupfel Company.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 (AP) -- The veteran Emil (Dutch) Leonard of the Phillies pitched a three-hit 4-to-1 victory over the Reds tonight before a paid crowd of 10,832. It was his tenth triumph of the season against four defeats.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- President Truman is expected to send to the Senate by Saturday the names of his nominees for three posts in the new National Labor Relations Board, it was reported today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Even those believers in democracy who disapprove of the pending tax bill must view with regret the prospect that the President will veto it. The veto is an attempt to make the will of an individual or a minority prevail over that of the majority and is, therefore, essentially anti-democratic.

The guns that were supposed to fall silent in Europe on May 8, 1945, but never did completely, are barking again in rising crescendo in that continent's most dangerous trouble-spot -- the Balkans. Once more we read of invasions and attacks, of open warfare and pitched battles, of slaughter, death and annihilation.

The Navy Reserve Pennant was awarded yesterday to the United States Lines freighter Golden West by Capt. John J. Mockrish, USNR, in charge of the merchant marine component of the Reserve in the Third Naval District.

Nearly 600,000 employes of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company will be permitted to purchase a total of 2,800,000 shares of capital stock under the Employes' Stock Plan recently approved by stockholders. The board of directors of the company voted yesterday to proceed with the offering.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The unconscious errors engaged in by Rowland Stebbins in his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 4 point up a method of scoffing at what is and what is not "our business," thereby placing the onus for coming situations upon our shoulders.

Traditional Short Commons We are not so sure about this forecast of dark days ahead for the authors of really worth-while books. It is being said that because of soaring production costs without a corresponding rise in prices the publishers' profits are being cut to a minimum.

Royalty can promote democracy, Miss Sara McCauley, director of Colony House, settlement house at 297 Dean Street, Brooklyn, declared yesterday. She reached this decision after shepherding 125 youngsters from eight nonsectarian settlement houses to a picnic in Prospect Park.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Exports of United States goods climbed to a post-war high of $1,408,500,000 in May as a result of larger shipments of raw materials and semi-finished and finished manufactured items, the Department of Commerce reported today.

SECURITY COUNCIL Meets today at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. to resume debate on Balkan report (open). Committee 2, Atomic Energy Commission -- Soviet Union approved proposal to establish international quota system for mining of ores.

VIENNA, July 16 -- The Austrian Government has answered the note of the Soviet command protesting the United States-Austrian relief agreement with relatively sharp references to Soviet interference in Austrian sovereignty through the Russians' economic activities here.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder indicated today that the Government was unconcerned over an American concern's offer to sell gold internationally above the United States price of $35 an ounce and would not try to prevent it.
LONDON, July 16 -- New Yorkers will have to wait quite a. while before they see one of their favorite pre-war vessels, the 22,575-ton Queen of Bermuda, and before they can travel in her to Bermuda.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Recent continued emphasis on the "weakness" of United States military strength is doing no service to our cause abroad.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The House approved today a bill to set up, as an independent government agency, a National Science Foundation to encourage research toward civilian health and safety and above all to perfect and sharpen technical American weapons and arms.
Mayor O'Dwyer signed yesterday the Sharkey bill freezing rents for permanent tenants in hotels, apartment hotels and rooming and lodging houses at their June 30 level.

ALTHOUGH this may come as something of a shock to certain elderly folk who still insist progress ceased with the good old days, the incontrovertible fact remains that in most any sport, practiced and performed by men who devote the better part of their lives to it, the caliber of performance is bound to improve.

Local 96 of the Financial Employes Guild, CIO, announced early this morning that as of last midnight the 700 members of the guild employed by the Brooklyn Trust Company and its twenty-four branch offices went on strike, in what was described as the first walkout against a major bank in the United States.
LONDON, July 16 -- Britain's biggest labor union turned down today a resolution advocating the compulsory direction of industry by the Government.

WASHINGTON, July 16--Secretary of State Marshall asserted today that the United States military mission in Greece in connection with the $300,000,000 aid program had the right to advise the Greek Army on how to carry out warfare against the guerrillas in the northwest.

A collection of hats designed to appeal to those with a subtle sense of fashion was presented yesterday by Madame Andree at her salon, 61 East Fifty-seventh Street. Particularly favored by this designer were the three-cornered and fourcornered models.

HONOLULU, July 16 (AP) -- The United States Steel Corporation will not increase the price of steel until "a fair test" is made of cost factors created by the new coal wage agreement, its president, Benjamin F. Fairless, said today on his arrival for a Hawaiian vacation.

The City Planning Commission unanimously approved yesterday the proposed all-purpose highway through Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx to serve as a one-mile link in the proposed $30,000,000 Major Deegan Expressway. The expressway will connect with the Westchester County throughway system at Central Avenue in Yonkers.

The first attempt ever made to fly non-stop around the world will start from La Guardia Field on Aug. 15 when two veteran pilots and small airport operators take off in a somewhat modified Piper Super Cruiser, it was announced here yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department at Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 10,000 head, total 13,000: moderately active and steady to 25 cents lower on butchers under 300 pounds and on sows under 400 pounds: heavier weights on both

Alberic O'Kelly de Galway and Ludek Pachman; representing Belgium and Czechoslovakia, respectively, were leading the field of fourteen experts after two rounds of the European zonal preliminaries in competition for the world chess championship, according to reports received from Hilversum in The Netherlands yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- A $100,000 joint Congressional investigation, here and overseas, into the policies, functions, personnel and value of the State Department's International Informatior and Educational Exchange Service was recommended almost unanimously today by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 16 (AP) -- Details concerning the size and operation of a $30,000,000 mill to manufacture newsprint to be constructed at Childersburg, near here, were announced today by the Coosa River Newsprint Company.

GLASGOW, Scotland, July 16 (U.P.) -- World Flyweight Champion Jackie Paterson collapsed today before his scheduled title defense against Dado Marino of Honolulu and was replaced by Rinty Monaghan of Ireland, who was disqualified for holding in the ninth round of a non-title match.
CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- Ted Williams teamed up with Dennie Galehouse to earn the Red Sox a 7-2 victory over the White Sox before 6,213 here today.
Alexander (Zan) Carver of Pelham provided the daily surprise it the Eastern clay court championship yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club, Queens.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Dr. Edward K. Barsky, chairman of the Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee of New York, received a six months jail term and a $500 fine today for contempt of Congress. He was sentenced by Federal Judge Richmond B. Keech who also handed out three-month terms and $500 fines to each of ten other leaders of the organization, including Howard Fast, novelist.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated over a fairly wide range yesterday and showed gains of 51 to 101 points net at the close.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 16 -- American circles expressed confidence today that the United Nations Security Council, which meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. tomorrow on the Balkan question, will accept unchanged a United States resolution for the establishment of a new semi-permanent commission in the Balkans.

Efforts to obtain confirmation from official Indian Government sources that the United States burlap quota for the next twelve months has been set at 300,000 long tons have proved fruitless, according to burlap traders yesterday. Steamships at Calcutta, it was reavealed, have ben held up awaiting burlap freight, while the low supply in this country falls short of filling demand.

DALLAS, Tex., July 16 -- In the development of cotton export programs the Government's "major emphasis now is to get this business into the hands of private traders," the eighth annual Cotton Research Congress was told today at its opening session.

The stock market went through another indecisive session yesterday, although the late trading produced a firmer tone and permitted a few major gains in some key units. The market was highly selective, however, with special situations receiving the bulk of attention.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- The United Steelworkers Union, Congress of Industrial Organizations, some of whose members permanently injured Miss Helen Barr Scharf, 42, of Gary, Ind., when they ejected her from a bus Feb. 26, 1941, today paid her $46,162.08.

BRADLEY BEACH, N.J., July 16 -- Mayor Albert Kirms led volunteers that early today rescued the Rev. Oliver C. Apgar, pastor of the Bradley Beach Methodist Church, and his companion Robert Van Note, a trustee of the church, after they had become lost in a swamp in near-by Wall Township while on a blueberry picking expedition.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 16 -- Hungary's Communist Minister of the Interior, Laszlo Rajk, presented to Parliament today a new election law that insures the return of the present Communist-dominated coalition Government.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Webster Atlas National Bank of Boston today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to authorize "abandonment" of Boston's South Station, owned by the Boston Terminal Company, as a preliminary step to foreclosing the mortgage under which it is trustee.
MINDEN, Germany, July 17 -- German economists and businessmen have set the cost of immediate German participation in the economic reconstruction of Europe at $750,000,000, it was learned today.

The General Electric Company had a net income of $37,979,536 in the first half of this year after all deductions, including $23,000,000 for taxes, Charles E. Wilson, president, reported in a statement mailed to stockholders yesterday. The net income, which is equivalent to $1.32 each on the 28,845,927 shares, includes a non-recurring dividend of $5,306,835 received during the first quarter in connection with the liquidation of Electrical Securities Corporation, a former investment affiliate.

In his message of last Jan. 6 President Truman urged that "the development of the great river systems of America * * * be pushed with full vigor." The House of Representatives commented on this proposal by drastic cuts in appropriations for the already authorized long-term program for the control of the Missouri River.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 17 -- Wage increases and gains in working conditions for more than 8,500 film actors were agreed upon today by principal producers and the Screen Actors Guild after long negotiations concerning a new contract.

PARIS, July 17 -- The danger of a strike of Government employes and of others in public services appeared to have subsided today following the unanimous vote of provisional pay increases by the National Assembly early this morning.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- A Senate subcommittee reported today that the pilot probably could have avoided the May 29 crash of a DC-4 airliner at La Guardia Field by exercising good judgment in any one of three decisions preceding the accident.

The 1948 Packard super eight convertible will be shown today for the first time by the Packard Motor Car Company of New York, Broadway and Sixty-first Street, and other dealers in the metropolitan area.

Platinum Fox Brings $64 Top Platinum fox furs brought a top of $64 at the auction held yesterday by the New York Auction Company. White face mutations sold up to $40. The offering attracted fair interest and only 35 per cent was sold.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 17 -- Gross commercial revenues of the Pan American World Airways System in the first five months of 1947 increased approximately 40 per cent over the corresponding period of last year, Juan Trippe, president, informed stockholders here today at the company's annual meeting.

An "all-star" team of thirty expert industrial engineers from nine New York and two New England companies has been formed for the purpose of rehabilitating the industrial economy of Japan, reopening Japanese markets for machinery, tools and metals and preparing a complete technical study on reparations, it was disclosed here yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer named yesterday afternoon the three-man temporary commission that will administer the new local law freezing rents for permanent guests of hotels, apartment hotels and rooming and lodging houses.
LONDON, July 17 -- Business in stock markets here today generally was small, with few price changes of any importance.

VIENNA, July 17 -- A Russian officer and four Austrian detectives forced an American citizen, Frank Mehler of 161 West Seventyeighth Street, New York, into a car in the center of Vienna's international first district at noon today and carried him off to an isolated police station in the Russian sector.

VIENNA, July 17 -- The Austrian Government published tonight the text of its note declaring the Soviet refusal to cooperate in the implementation of Austrian law made rigid United States inspection and control of United States relief necessary.

ATHENS, Greece, July 17 (U.P.) -- The Greek Government is still investigating the shipment of thousands of food parcels from "starving" Greece to the United States, and further movement of such packages has been halted -- for the time being, at least.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 17 -- Ethiopia advised the United Nations today that she would renounce United Nations reconstruction aid "in favor of other member nations more immediately in need of urgent assistance."

An economic upheaval, labor conflict and chaos in Cuba's economy, as well as a sharp drop in imports of American goods, will result if the sugar bill passed by the House last Friday becomes law, it was predicted yesterday by Senor Jesus Menendez, a member of the Cuban House of Representatives and secretary of the Cuban Sugar Workers Federation.

BOSTON, July 17 -- There is an "unprecedented" demand for electric power in the United States and private electrical companies are moving in to fill the gap. This was asserted here today by Richard B. McEntire, Commissioner of the Securities and Exchange Commission, before the convention here of the National Association of Railroad and Utility Commissioners.
DETROIT, July 17 (AP) -- Coming from behind in both games, the Tigers swept a double-header from the Senators today, 7 to 5 and 4 to 3, to take the series, four games to one.

Gold Market A free market for gold appears to be developing gradually abroad. While the development of these markets is not being encouraged by the United States Government, indications are that no determined effort will be made by Government authorities to stop them.

The stock market suffered yesterday its most serious reversal of the month when supporting bids failed to appear in the late trading to counterbalance moderate liquidation. Losses ranged from fractions in the lower price issues to slightly more than a point in the industrials and up to 4 points in the thin market stocks.

WASHTNGTON, July 17 -- Quiet departmental investigations have resulted within a nine-month period in the ouster of an estimated 811 Federal employes found disloyal to the United States, the Civil Service Commission disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- President Truman said today that the administration was looking into the need for reviving coast-wise shipping operations from which the Government withdrew June 30.

LONDON, July 17 -- A high court jury upheld today the contention of Miss E. Arnot Robertson, author and film critic, that Metro-GoldwynMayer Pictures, Ltd., of London had been stung by her radio criticisms of their pictures into maliciously libeling her.

James A. Moffett, oil company executive and former Federal Housing Administrator, failed yesterday in his attempt to force the Arabian-American Oil Company to produce in Federal court the text of the oil concession it obtained from King Ibn Saud of Arabia.

PARIS, July 17 (AP) -- Four feminine stars, from the United States pushed aside all opposition today and entered the semi-finals of the French international tennis championships, assuring an All-American fight for the women's singles title.

A charge made by a Queens bookmaker that "every bookie in the city has to pay the police from $1,500 to $3,000 every month to operate" will be considered on Tuesday by a special session of the Queens Grand Jury, District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan announced yesterday.

VIENNA, July 17 -- Austrian authorities claimed today that every hotel accommodation fit for foreign guests in Salzburg still was being occupied in one way or another by the United States Army, despite figures issued by the military that showed it occupied only 34 per cent of the total hotel beds.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- During the week ended July 16 member bank reserve balances increased $146,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 17 -- PrePresidential campaign activities were in progress today in widely separated parts of the far west. Washington Republicans prepared to open a drive on behalf of Eric W. Johnston for the Republican Vice Presidential nomination and a faction of California Democrats completed plans for a Henry A. Wallace-for-President meeting at Fresno.

The general desirability of good health is about as noncontroversial a subject as one could mention. The techniques which promote health are as effective in Russia or Latin America as they are here. Consequently it looked as though the World Health Organization, for which a constitution was drawn up in this city last July at a meeting attended by representatives of sixty-one nations, would go through without a hitch.

Supreme Court Justice James B. M. McNally upheld yesterday the right of Assemblyman William T. Andrews, a Democrat, to seek the American Labor party nomination for State Senator in the Twentythird District, and issued an order directing the Board of Elections to place his name on the primary election ballot.

Another golf title went on the auction block yesterday when the Long Island Golf Association's twenty - fourth annual amateur championship got under way at the Pomonok Country Club, between Flushing and Jamaica.

DETROIT, July 17 (AP) -- Thirtytwo Ford Motor Company foremen, accused of "violence and terrorism" during a recent fortyseven-day strike, were fired today and their union countered with the threat of another walkout.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 17 -- Demolition work on the $70,000,000 world capital of the United Nations in midtown Manhattan is progressing nicely but only because an eleventh-hour loan of $5,000 was arranged for two Pacific war veterans to buy a gasoline station, it was disclosed today.

Joseph P. Ryan's lifetime tenure as president of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, was reaffirmed unanimously yesterday by delegates to the union's thirty-fourth convention, at the Hotel Commodore.

Disturbed by the results of surveys made by affiliated clubs and its field reporters, who cover more than 500,000 miles of highway annually, the American Automobile Association is resuming and intensifying its "Take It Easy" safety program. On the basis of these practical reports, the AAA finds that there is a resurgence of excessive speed and recklessness on the road which must be curbed.

The Empire City Racing Association yesterday completed its summer activities at the Jamaica track, where a 3-year-old named Ben Lewis gained an eight-length triumph in the top event and another stalwart steed accounted for a $157.60 listing on the tote board.

DES MOINES, July 17 (AP) -- William Campbell of Huntington, W.Va., and Robert (Bob) Willits of Kansas City stole the thunder on the favorites today with spectacular rounds of golf in the Western amateur tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- President Truman today named the expanded five-member National Labor Relations Board provided under the Taft-Hartley Labor Management Relations Act. He made Robert N. Denham of Maryland, ex-cowpuncher, lawyer and financier, the new general counsel.

An increase in millinery sales is easily attainable if retailers begin thinking of the product as one that is not necessarily seasonable, and one which deserves salesmanship of a high order, it was pointed out yesterday in a millinery round-table discussion sponsored by the Millinery Fashion Bureau at the Hotel Commodore.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 17 -- By the margin of two points or two boat places in the series of five races the American Yacht Club of Rye won the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound today. As a result the crew skippered by Mrs. Sylvia Shethar Everdell will represent the Sound in the national championship at Edgartown, Mass., in September.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office has been quietly investigating for several months the charges that former Tammany Hall officials sought $100,000 for permanent leases on city-owned piers, it came out yesterday.

Just Everyday Problems Baby-sitting has apparently fallen victim to one of the hazards which confront Small Business. One shrewd commentator remarked some time ago, when Washington had the interests of small-business men close to heart, that we must try to prevent Small Business from prospering too much and becoming Big Business.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The House wing of the Joint Congressional Committee established to keep under constant survey the workings of the Taft-Hartley Labor Act, was appointed today by Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. It was a panel well sprinkled with advocates of "strong" labor legislation.
ROCKY GRAZIANO and Tony Zale gave the customers a lively evening in Chicago, but if it's excitement you're looking for, tennis and not prize fighting is the ticket, and it comes a little cheaper.

A city fireman whose idea, of vacation is to abandon fire apparatus for a small private seaplane and who, between flights on the Fourth of July, rescued a drowning man from the Hudson River has been recommended for a departmental decoration, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Final passage of the so-called merger legislation by Congress -- expected within the next week or so -- will pave the way for establishment of a system of unified military commands within the United States, it was learned today.

High prices offered for German cameras by Swedish and Swiss photographic dealers have caused American occupation authorities to increase export prices, resulting in a rise of 12 to 25 per cent in prices here, camera dealers reported yesterday.

The Transport Workers Union, CIO, began yesterday in the Supreme Court four separate suits to nullify action by the Board of Transportation on June 26, dismissing two union members from city service and suspending two others.

LONDON, July 17 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin called today upon his old trade union -- the "Transport and General Workers' Union -- to work harder and produce more so that Great Britain could become economically independent of the United States.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Liquidation by recent buyers of grain futures developed on the Board of Trade today and disclosed what brokers regarded as an over-bought condition. Support was lacking from the start and at no time were prices above the close of the previous day.

MONMOUTH PARK, N.J., July 17 (AP) -- J.M. Roebling's Marble Arch came out ahead by a neck in a stretch duel with O.L. Nyberg's Irisen in the mile-and-a-sixteenth Merchantville Purse at Monmouth Park today.

BATAVIA, Friday, July 18 (AP) -- A belated effort to alter the determined stand of the Indonesian Government against Netherland demands had come to nothing today, and Dutch sources said the Indonesian crisis was more dangerous than ever.

HONOLULU, July 17 (AP) -- The trim yawl Chubasco, trailing a "lucky" chicken wishbone from her stern, sped through a searchlight beam under a green flare off Diamond Head at 1:58 A.M. today while hundreds of sleepless spectators shouted and honked horns.

WASHINGTON, July I7 -- Tom C. Clark, Attorney General, filed a new complaint against 159 railroads today in an effort to obtain refunds for the Government on alleged freight rate overcharges for shipment of crated automobiles to the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, July 17 --The four men whom President Truman today appointed to the commission of twelve which is to survey the processes of the Federal Government, with a view to improving them and at the same time making them less costly are of the same high caliber as the eight previously named by Senator Vandenberg and Speaker Martin.

Charley Fusari, Irvington, N.J., welterweight, is favored at 1 -- 2 to beat Eddie Giosa of Philadelphia in their ten-round main bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. Giosa has been waging his bouts in the lightweight division up to now and makes his first start as a welter.

Disks, or as John, of John Frederics chose to call them, "flying saucers," made the chief topic of interest at the showing held by this famed millinery duo, yesterday morning. The disk, a flat sailor, provides a new silhouette. It is raised above the forehead by a bandeau that must be carefully adjusted to the head and worn with ever-so-slight a tilt to give it the correct angle, according to John.

DULUTH, July 17 (AP) -- The president of the Associated General Contractors of America told the American Society of Civil Engineers' convention today that buyer resistance to high prices was delaying $10,000,000,000 worth of ready-to-go construction in the United States.

After advancing earlier this week to new twenty - seven - year highs, the cotton futures market yesterday turned reactionary, and closing prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 24 to 70 points net lower on the day.

John W. Hart, vice president of Winthrop Products, Inc., has been appointed vice president in charge of professional relations of the Winthrop Chemical Company, Inc., pharmaceutical manufacturing subsidiary of Sterling Drug, Inc.
Alexander (Zan) Carver of Pelham and Tony Vincent of the University of Miami did the unexpected again in the Eastern Clay Court championship yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club, Queens.

Growing public indifference to the problems of World War II veterans and a lack of improvement in their circumstances, economic and otherwise, have made the first six months of this year a period of increasing uncertainty for former service men, John W. Hooper, chairman of the Brooklyn Red Cross Chapter, said yesterday.

The school tuna season now seems to be in full swing, and if the weather man will put off the rest of the rain until next week, tomorrow and Sunday should find a peak crowd of off-shore anglers putting out from a score of nearby ports.

PARIS, July 17 -- France renewed today her opposition to proposals for a general increase in the industrial production of the Ruhr according to suggestions that have just been supported by United States Secretary of State Marshall.

The strong advances in the wholesale price of meat that took place a week ago evidently had a delayed influence. Retail costs, largely unchanged last Friday, at a time when those increases were occurring, shot ahead this week in several cases.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Average primary market prices rose 0.2 per cent during the week ended July 12, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, as higher prices for foods and a few non-agricultural goods outweighed lower prices for a number of commodities.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The suggestion made by Secretary Marshall to the European countries might properly be described as "The Cooperative Way, a Method of World Reconstruction."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 17 -- The first picture to be made by Independent Artists, Inc., the Rosalind Russell-Dudley Nichols Company, will be "The Velvet Touch" instead of "Lucky Penny," the option on which was recently dropped.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- The House Commerce Committee today considered legislation to return to Italy $60,000,000 in wartime seized property and provide thirty-one ships for the Italian Merchant Marine.

BERLIN, July 17 -- Obviously concerned over the effect on reparations of the projected upward revision of the level of industry in the economically combined United States and British zones, the Russians have put forth a vigorous new demand for the dismantling and distribution of "surplus" plants, it was learned today.

Production of the new engine-inrear Tucker car will begin in early September, Preston T. Tucker, president of the Tucker Corporation, said yesterday at a preview of the unit at the Commodore Hotel. The car will sell at retail for $1,845 in Chicago, where it is manufactured, and for less than $2,000 on the Atlantic and Pacific seaboards, he added.

"Look, Ma, I'm Dancing," a musical, has superseded the Sam and Bella Spewack comedy. "The Way of A Hen," on George Abbott's list of great expectations. "Hen," for which Shirley Booth had been standing by, was supposed to arrive at the Biltmore in October.

Representatives of the American and British motion picture industries and delegates to a Baptist World Convention were among the 2,245 passengers who left here yesterday for Southampton on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth.

CLEVELAND, July 17 -- They made it! "They" are the Yankees and "it" is the all-time American League winning streak of nineteen games, a record in the books since the White Sox placed it there back in 1906. Whether Chicago will continue sharing the honor depends on developments at Detroit tomorrow, but today long will be remembered, regardless.

Eighteen leading American track and field athletes, divided into two groups of nine each, left La Guardia Field yesterday to compete in a series of athletic contests in eleven European countries during the next five weeks. They were selected by the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The American Federation of Labor today urged the Congress of Industrial Organizations to meet with it as soon as possible in order to further the organic unity of the rival labor federations.

The theory that a cable to a trim tab [an auxiliary control surface] on one of the elevators of the Eastern Air Lines Douglas DC-4 might have given way and put the plane into a diving attitude that caused it to crash near Bainbridge, Md., last May 30, killing fifty-three persons, was advanced yesterday as the Civil Aeronautics Board opened the second phase of its inquiry into the accident.

LONDON, July 17 (Reuters) -- Widespread rain hampered county cricket matches today and games could not be held at Nottingham where the home county is playing Hampshire and at Westcliff where Essex has Glamorgan as visitors.
DALLAS, July 17 -- To maintain a favorable position among the world's cotton producing countries this nation must accept foreign goods and services to enable its customers to acquire dollars.

Downtown Fulton Street, Brooklyn, took a big step forward yesterday toward taking on the aspects of Manhattan's Fifth Avenue. A new zoning restriction went into effect prohibiting opening of other than high-class retail stores. From Flatbush Avenue to Borough Hall and that part of Court Street facing Borough Hall has been changed from a business use district to a restricted retail use district.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Senate and House conferees were reported in a tight deadlock today as economy-minded House members balked at some $341,000,000 in Senate-approved farm funds for fiscal 1948.

MILWAUKEE, July 17 -- The results of a National Labor Relations Board collective bargaining election among about 7,500 production and maintenance workers of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company here tonight hinged on the determination of how the 247 challenged ballots would be counted.

BERLIN, July 17 -- In an unusual move the Russians have agreed to a four-power interzonal inspection tour, of the food production areas of Germany. Members of the food and agriculture branches of the four Allied milltary administrations are scheduled to depart tomorrow evening aboard a special train for the British zone.

TORONTO, July 17 (AP) -- Ed (Porky) Oliver, Wilmington, Del., pro, set a blistering pace today in the second round of the Canadian Open golf championship, establishing a double-round record of 131 for the open and equaling the Scarboro Club's competitive course record of 63.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 17 -- J. Kendrick Noble, chairman of the Yonkers Municipal Housing Authority, and John K. Kelley, its secretary-director, resigned today amid reports that recent bickering among authority members reached a climax in a stormy meeting last night.

LONDON, July 17 (AP) -- Britain has withheld acceptance of a United States invitation to an AngloAmerican conference in Washington on increasing Ruhr coal production and asked that the scope of the talks be broadened to include German food, finance and new levels for industry, the Foreign Office disclosed tonight.

Enrollment in the regular day sessions of New York's four municipal colleges will reach a new peak of more than 30,000 for the coming fall term, it was learned yesterday. Returning veterans and an unusually large freshman class will swell the total registration to well over the previous high mark of 28,040 set last February.

The Pirates, who live in the National League cellar, made it three out of four and the Dodgers, who have a temporary lease on the loop penthouse, barely made it to the clubhouse after taking a 7-1 shellacking at Ebbets Field yesterday.

A study, of public debt policy, financed by the Falk Foundation, yesterday advocated continued retirement of the public debt, a reduction in Government expenditures, and the establishment of a taxing system which would promote a "flourishing economy under which the debt burden may be carried more easily."

JERUSALEM, July 17 -- Hebrew newspapers in Tel Aviv received telephone calls from alleged representatives of Irgun Zvai Leumi today announcing that the two British sergeants kidnapped from Nathanya are being held in Tel Aviv. The British have been searching for them in the Nathanya area and have placed the district under martial law.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 17 -- In a race among Westchester County communities to provide new public housing on a vast scale, New Rochelle appeared likely today to win in a photo-finish with its approaching construction of the $2,667,000 Winyah Gardens and the $3,000,000 Huguenot Gardens.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 17 -- The Rumanian Government today suppressed the principal Bucharest opposition newspaper and kept the Peasant leader, Dr. Juliu Maniu, under armed surveillance, forbidding any interviews.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission said today that a survey showed that eleven states were working on plans for statewide FM radio networks for educational purposes.

LONDON, July 17 -- The outcry in Great Britain against the cut in newsprint imports spread from the press to Parliament today and forced an unexpected debate in the House of Commons. But the Government refused to give way and was upheld by a vote of 234 to 113.

Police and pickets clashed briefly yesterday morning in front of the Brooklyn Trust Company, 177 Montague Street, Brooklyn, a few hours after Local 96 of the Financial Employes Guild, CIO, went on strike against the bank and its twenty-four branches in the nation's first major bank walkout.

LONDON, July 17 -- Great Britain's coal situation, which is priority No. 1 for industrial recovery, is gradually improving, Emanuel Shinwell, Minister of Fuel and Power, said in the House of Commons today. Many other speakers, and not only from the Opposition benches, could not agree with him.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial of July 12, commenting on a report by Comptroller General Warren alleging fraud in certain settlements of terminated was contracts under the Contract Settlement Act, you say that you "support Mr. Warren's insistence that Congress order independent audits" of such settlements.

CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 7,000 head, total 10,000: generally steady on all weights and sows: slow on butchers over 300 pounds and on sows over 400 pounds: top $27.25: bulk of good and choice

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Following his recommendation to Congress yesterday urging the expenditure of $4,000,000,000 in ten years on flood control in the Mississippi valley basin, President Truman sent to the Capitol today details of the projects he wants to get under way in this fiscal year.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 17 -- Egypt's demand that all British troops be evacuated from her territory and that Britain surrender control of the Sudan will be taken up by the United Nations Security Council by Aug. 5, it was decided here today.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- President Truman today announced the names of the ten-member board of foreign scholarships which will, select American Students to study abroad under the terms of the Fulbright Act passed a year ago. It will also finance the transportation of some foreign students to this country.

Betty Lou Pray, 10 years old, of the Children's Aid Society's Harlem Center, skipped her way to fame yesterday in the first intercity rope-jumping contest conducted by the society at its Lower West Side Center, 209 Sullivan Street.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 17 (AP) -- The New York State Public Service Commission endorsed today the Pennsylvania Gas Company's application to the Federal Power Commission for permission to construct fifteen miles of gas transmission main in Warren County, Pa.

Representatives of many wellknown societies and clubs and members of the Morgan family were among the 550 persons who attended yesterday a funeral service for Herbert Livingston Satterlee, son-in-law of the late J.P. Morgan, the elder, and one-time Assistant Secretary of the Navy, at St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and Sixteenth Street.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: My attention has been called to an editorial in the July 14 issue of THE TIMES under the title "Egypt and the Sudan." While in no way wishing to discuss the merits of the article or to question the policy of your newspaper, may I be permitted to elucidate a few points concerning a matter most vital to Egypt?

Now that the Senate and the House have passed almost identical bills which provide for the creation of a National Science Foundation, the prospect is bright that the wartime work of the Office of Scientific Research and Development will be continued, though at a slower pace and on a more modest scale.

D.W. Frease of Dover, Ohio, has been elected president and James Hill chairman of the board of the Empire Steel Corporation. Mr. Frease has been operating vice president of the Reeves Steel and Manufacturing Company and replaces Joseph E. Montgomery Jr., who resigned as president and chairman of the board.

Radio will cover the tour in this country of the Roman Singers of Sacred Music, a fifty-four-voice a capella group drawn from the four Vatican choirs, in an as yet indeterminate number of broadcasts, it was learned yesterday. However, both the Polo Grounds concert Aug. 2 and that at Ebbets Field Aug. 7 were said to be scheduled for broadcast, although the network which will have the assignment was not disclosed.
For five summers children, equally divided between Negro and white, have enjoyed without racial tension their two-week vacations at the two Catholic Youth Organization Camps near Peekskill, N.Y.

Action of the Consumers Cooperative Association, Kansas City, in discontinuing payment of patronage refunds to non-coop patrons, effective Sept. 1 was interpreted here yesterday as indicative of a trend among cooperatives to pay taxes on profits rather than operate under restrictions required to earn exemptions.
SUMMIT, N.J., July 17 -- Two holes in one featured the initial round of the twenty-seventh New Jersey State 72-hole medal play open golf championship at the Canoe Brook today.

Archbishop Gregory, Metropolitan of Leningrad and Novgorod, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday afternoon as the special representative of the Patriarch Alexei of Moscow on a mission to unite spiritually the Russian churches in the United States with the mother church in Moscow.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, July 17 (AP) -- President Rafael Leonardis Trujillo Molina, speaking before a joint session of Congress today, introduced legislation to pay off the republic's entire external debt of more than $10,000,000.

NANKING, July 17 -- It is reliably learned that Lieut. Gen. Sun Li-jen, who was graduated from the Virginia Military Institute in 1927, has been named deputy Commander of Chinese Army ground forces and will direct a modernized training program aimed at improving the efficiency of Government troops.
