In a new effort to solve serious truancy and delinquency problems among New York public school pupils, the Board of Education is establishing a special adjustment program that will go into effect in the fall, it became known yesterday.

These prices result from a spot check of independent and chain stores in leading shopping centers of this city, and are reported by the Department of Markets. Asterisks indicate particularly good purchases in fresh produce.

MUNICH, Germany, July 17 -- Fritz Wiedemann, German Consul General in San Francisco just prior to the United States' entry into World War II, is a prisoner in a jail in Pfarrkirchen, awaiting a summons before a German denazification tribunal.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 17 -- The Pine Bluff Victory of the Luckenbach Steamship Company, carrying cargo from New York, Boston and Philadelphia for West Coast ports, docked here today and immediately was picketed by walking bosses holding membership in the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO.

Directors of the textile concern of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., announced yesterday that in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 37 1/2 cents a share on each of the 1,000,000 common shares outstanding an extra dividend of 50 cents a share also had been declared.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., July 17 -- Paul Green's stirring drama of American independence, "The Common Glory," opened tonight before a capacity audience in the newly completed open-air theatre, with its beautiful lake-side setting, between this restored Colonial capital and Jamestown, where so many of the play's real-life characters enacted their historic roles.

The Cities Service Company and the Continental Oil Company announced yesterday formation of the Citcon Corporation, for the manufacture of solvent refined lubricating oils. The announcement said the new company, which will be 65 per cent owned by Cities Service and 35 per cent by Continental, will have the largest, plant of its kind in the United States.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 17 -- Rental agreements between the United Nations and the Metropolitan and New York life insurance companies were strongly attacked tonight at an emergency meeting of United Nations employes. Three resolutions calling for corrective measures from member Governments and for a boycott of the two companies were referred after a two-hour debate to a committee to consolidate into a single protest.

ST. LOUIS, July 17 (AP) -- The Browns' defense collapsed completely in the ninth inning tonight as the Athletics -- already fairly certain of a triumph -- clubbed home nine runs to crush the lastplace team, 16 to 2.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- President Truman declared today that the executive branch of the United States Government must undergo a comprehensive and fundamental review in order "to be adequately equipped to meet the challenges it must face in a modern world."

ATHENS, July 17 -- The elusive Communist-led guerrillas boldly challenged the Greek Government and Army again today by beginning broadcasts, allegedly from Gen. Markos Vafthiadis' headquarters, and by popping up in the Zagori Mountains to the south at the heights of Kalpaki.

There was a feeling of extramusical excitement in the air last night, when Paul Robeson held an audience of 18,720 entranced at Lewisohn Stadium. With the accompaniment of the PhilharmonicSymphony, conducted by Alexander Smallens, Mr. Robeson sang a group of classical arias in the first half of the program, but it was clear that most listeners were really interested in his second group and their implications.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Recent floods on the Missouri and Mississippi Rivers were cited today at a Valley Authority conference as reasons for putting the country's water basins under "Authority" control.
BOSTON, July 17 -- A Massachusetts mother and her five children are held prisoners in Siberia by the Soviet Union, Acting Governor Arthur W. Coolidge, informed the American Legion here today.
BOSTON, July 17 -- A Massachusetts mother and her five children are held prisoners in Siberia by the Soviet Union, Acting Governor Arthur W. Coolidge, informed the American Legion here today.

JERUSALEM, July 17 -- One final appeal from the world Zionist movement for Jewish immigration and Jewish statehood in Palestine concluded the public hearings of the United Nations Committee of Inquiry in Jerusalem today.
CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- The Red Sox took a double-header from the White Sox today, 4 to 1 and 6 to 3, scoring three runs in the eleventh inning to win the second game.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 17 -- The Catholic Daughters of America pledged today their support to the United Nations and the United Nations Educational, Social and Cultural Organization. They also commended President Truman for his stand in behalf of displaced displaced persons and concurred with Secretary of State Marshall's statement that the forcing of these DP's to return to their pre-war homes would violate both American tradition and principles adopted by the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- R.J. Eggert of the American Meat Institute said today the normal fall and winter movement of livestock to market would increase meat supplies about 15 per cent above present levels, but that the 1948 outlook was not bright.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- The spotlight in boxing swung to New York today in the wake of Rocky Graziano's six-round knockout of Tony Zale of Gary, Ind., and the ascension of the East Sider with the uncontrollable temper to the world middleweight championship.
LONDON, July 17 -- The epic evacuation of Dunkerque, in which 330,000 soldiers were rescued from bombed, shell-torn beaches, was planned in the "forlorn hope" of saving a maximum of 45,000 men.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- The largest campaign in its history will be launched this fall by Motorola, Inc., for the new 1948 Motorola home radios, it was announced here today by Victor A. Irvine, advertising manager. Featured will be the new "Furniture Styling" theme, illustrating the various models of the line in harmonious room settings.
BOSTON, July 17 (AP) -- Harry (The Cat) Brecheen, St. Louis Cardinal southpaw, suffered what might prove to be a serious injury tonight when the world champions beat the Braves, 5 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended July 12, 1947, totaled 806,961 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 177,757 cars, or 28.3 per cent more than for the preceding week, 88,221 cars, or 9.8 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 76,582 cars, or 8.7 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- President Truman's bill for military co-operation with Latin America to establish a standardized hemispheric defense was approved by the House Foreign Affairs Committee today.

Negotiations are apparently at a stalemate in Indonesia over the question of what part the Netherlands Colonial Government will play in policing Java and Sumatra, and military action is momentarily threatened. In these circumstances Vice Premier Gani asserts that if the Dutch now decline further negotiations the Republic of Indonesia will appeal for outside mediation.

Harlem, one of the worst reservoirs of tuberculosis in the nation, is likely to become a vast experimental laboratory for the vaccine BCG in a controlled fight against the disease, it became known yesterday at the close of the Fifth International Congress of Pediatrics at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 17 -- Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, served notice on the United Nations Security; Council today that the Soviet Union "cannot agree" to the United States proposal for the establishment of a semi-permanent frontier commission in the Balkans.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Catholic Association for International Peace today urged a liberalization of United States immigration laws to permit the entry into this country of a substantial number of displaced persons whose "misery" in Europe was "a blot on the conscience of the world."
LONDON, July 18 -- The legislative process terminating British rule over the Indian Empire ended today when a Royal Commission signified the Royal Assent to the Indian Independence Bill.

For the first time since the report of July 30, 1945, Walter Winchell's Sunday night commentary leads the popularity poll conducted by C.E. Hooper, Inc., moving up from fourth position. Second place went to the "Crime Doctor," which advanced from the thirtieth sport, while "Take It or Leave It" secured the third berth, coming up from fourteenth place.

The New York Stock Exchange Initiated yesterday the practice of publishing quarterly reports of income and expenses of the Exchange and its affiliated companies. It reported total income for the quarter ended on June 30 of $1,830,798 and a net profit of $20,693.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 18 -- New financial aid from the Federal and state governments to help rising school costs were asked today by William Hart Hussey, Mayor of Mount Vernon and new president of the State Conference of Mayors.

SEOUL, Korea, July 18 -- The joint United States-Soviet Commission held one of the shortest meetings of its current sessions today. Maj. Gen. Albert E. Brown, chief of the United States delegation, handed Col. Gen. T. F. Shtikov, head of the Soviet delegation, a detailed statement covering "freedom of expression."
BOSTON, July 18 (AP) -- Scoring the winning run in the eighth inning without making a hit, the Pirates tonight defeated the Braves, 2 -- 1...

Johnny Neun and his Reds put the first of their superb staff of pitchers on the line at the Polo Grounds last night. Long before the evening's show was over the young man was lying on a rubbing table wondering what had cracked down on him.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- A smoke-producing device, primarily for use as a distress signal by those lost at sea or elsewhere in places difficult of access or location, even by aircraft, but also effective as a smudge pot in orchards and the like, has been patented by Joseph W. Van Karner of New York City.

John F. Keller, construction superintendent for the New York City Housing Authority since last November, was dismissed by that agency yesterday, soon after Mayor O'Dwyer had made public a report by Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh, recommending such action.

The stock market scored yesterday a modest recovery as the House overrode President Truman's veto of the revised tax bill but the demand was tempered by speculation on the fate of the legislation in the Senate. While the composite rate showed an advance of 0.12 on the "day, it marked the first time in nine weeks that the list had closed lower on the week.

JERUSALEM, July 18 -- Palestinian Jewish journalists were unexpectedly informed today that they would receive visas to attend the hearings in Lebanon of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine. These hearings will receive the views of representatives of Arab states.

Random notes. The first tarpon taken on rod and reel in North Carolina for ten years was brought in Thursday by Tom Eaton of Hatteras, fishing in Pamlico Sound. The fish scaled thirty pounds and was taken on a strip mullet bait.

Supreme Court Justice Charles S Colden in Queens yesterday gave the go-ahead signal for the completion of a multi-milliondollar realty development in East Hills, L.I., after receiving evidence that the Village Board was ready to amend the building laws in a manner that would stymie the larger part of the project.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 18 -- Miss Catherine Schaeter of Washington, official observer for the national Catholic Welfare Conference at the United Nations, said today that it is regrettable so many women in these crucial times are so complacent about their duties as citizens and the "tremendous opportunity that is theirs to mold public opinion for world peace."

PARIS, July 18 -- The Rumania that refused to participate in the Paris conference on the Marshall Plan is not the real Rumania, according to a statement issued here today by representatives of three Rumanian pre-war parties who came to Paris to demonstrate their country's approval of the Marshall proposals.
NANKING, July 18 -- Sweeping changes in Chinese Army training methods along modern lines developed during the World War were forecast here today in American Army circles.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- President Truman accepted today the resignation of Robert P. Patterson as Secretary of War with "poignant regret," then nominated Under-Secretary Kenneth C. Royall to succeed him.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Here is the vote by which the Senate today failed to muster a twothirds majority required to override President Truman's veto of the income-tax-cut bill: FOB OVERRIDING -- 57 Republicans -- 47

In bowing last March to the opposition in Congress to extension of Selective Service for another year, President Truman warned that if enlistments did not meet expectations a re-enactment of this statute might become necessary. This is an issue which Congress has studiously avoided to date.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Joseph William Martin Jr., of North Attleboro, Mass., Speaker of the House of Representatives, a Republican, became today the man legally designated to succeed President Truman as Chief Executive, should he be unable to finish his term expiring on Jan. 20, 1949.

A man identified as Jack Rybakoff, 39 years old, of 166 West Eighty-seventh Street, described by the police as a petty racketeer with a criminal record, was shot four times and fatally wounded about 9 o'clock last night on East Sixth Street, by one of two thugs who escaped in a waiting car.

"An Inspector Calls," the J.B. Priestley play that John Golden wanted to produce last season, will be brought to Broadway in the autumn by Courtney Burr, it was learned yesterday. Rehearsals are scheduled to begin Sept. 1, and though contracts still await signing, Melville Cooper is a likely prospect for one of the major roles.

At first glance the Trinacria Importing Company at Twenty-ninth Street and Third Avenue appears to be just an unusually wellstocked market -- probably Italian since loaves of provolone cheese and bottles of Chianti wine vinegar hang from the ceiling beams.

LONDON, July 18 -- Two new natural anti-bacterial substances showing promise as agents for combating the germs of tuberculosis were reported today at the Eleventh International Congress of Pure and Applied Chemistry by two groups of British investigators.
Week-end covering of cotton f uturesh on-the New York Cotton Exchange, yesterday, brought about a late rally which left prices 11 to 28 points net higher than Thursday's final levels.

LONDON, July 18 -- Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer, got his 1947-48 budget bill through the House of Commons without a division today and congratulated all concerned in having accumulated a revenue surplus in hard cash of L234,000,000 since the start of the fiscal year last April 1.

MUNICH, Germany, July 18 -- The torrid sessions held recently by the Bavarian Landtag (state legislature) reached a climax tonight when yelling representatives surrounded Dr. Alfred Loritz on the rostrum and threatened to throw him out because of what they considered an insult.

DETROIT, July 18 (AP) -- The Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia captured three of the eight races to take a long lead today for the Julius H. Barnes trophy at the midway point of the two-day national amateur rowing regatta on the wind-swept Detroit River.

PARIS, July 18 -- France's formal protest on increased German industrial production to Washington today followed a verbal protest to the United States and British Ambassadors yesterday by French Foreign Minister Bidault.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Wilson W. Wyatt, national chairman of Americans for Democratic Action, declared tonight that a third party in 1948 would be a "catastrophe" for liberal democracy, and would advance the ends of communism and fascism.

PARIS, July 18 (AP) -- The same four feminine stars from the United States who dominated the women's side of the recent Wimbledon tennis tournament were all alone tonight in both the singles and doubles divisions of the French international championships.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 18 -- An attempt to obtain the release of a 19-year-old boy who has spent two and a half years in reformatories for a Hallowe'en prank he played has been started here by a local lawyer.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Legislation to authorize construction of the controversial half-billiondollar St. Lawrence seaway and power project went to the Senate today for action next January.

Recent unfavorable export advertising prospeqts in Latin-American countries have been offset to some extent, by increasingly, favorable prospects in Far Eastern markets, Irwin A. Vladimir, president of Irwin Vladimir Co., Inc., stated yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Any false idea may become a danger. However, the potency of the danger will depend a great deal on the reputation of its proponent. One such economic idea which I consider particularly dangerous is that we might have avoided the 1929 depression, or at least have alleviated it if wages had been higher in the Nineteen-Twenties and particularly after 1926.

MADRID, July 18 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco today marked the eleventh anniversary of the outbreak of the civil war with his first exposition at views on Spain's position in the world since the referendum on the law of succession. Published as an interview in the official Falange newspaper Arriba, the statement was notable for its bitter charges of dishonesty and bad faith against the United Nations.

Cash, purchases here by purchasing agencies for foreign governments are continuing to provide competition for domestic industrial and commercial buyers in obtaining available supplies of steel, electrical apparatus, building materials, stock metals and other items, spokesmen revealed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Increased commutation fares for fourteen railroads serving the New York, Chicago, Youngstown, Ohio, and other metropolitan areas were recommended today to the Interstate Commerce Commission by one of its examiners.
The plea of organized labor for a statutory forty-hour work week in the restaurant and hotel industries in New York State appeared lost yesterday.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 18 -- Representatives of the Stamford Division of the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company and the International Association of Machinists, independent union, signed here today an agreement granting pay increases averaging 6 cents an hour and six holidays a year with pay.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The House shouted approval tonight of appropriations totaling $1,353,024,900 to assure economic and military aid and relief from starvation to countries of Europe and the Far East that have resisted communism. With the same vote it denied funds, previously allotted tentatively, to two -- Poland and Hungary -- which, it was held, had yielded to the Soviet Union.

MONMOUTH PARK, N.J., July 18 (AP) -- Cornelius V. Whitney's Snowfall qualified for the $10,000 Monmouth Oaks by winning the six-furlong Starlight Purse today at Monmouth Park. Snowfall very likely will be a running mate with First Flight, voted "the best 2year-old of 1946," in next Wednesday's Oaks.

TORONTO, July 18 (AP) -- Bobby Locke of South Africa took over the lead in the Canadian Open golf championship tonight with a four-under-par 67 on today's third round for a 54-hole total of 201. This was one stroke better than Ed Oliver of Wilmington, Del., and Nick Wisnock, Detroit amateur.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18 -- President Truman's appointment of an emergency board to investigate the dispute between the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and the Southern Pacific Railroad will have no effect on plans of the engineers to go on strike at 6 P.M. on Monday, it was announced today by P.O. Peterson, general chairman of the Brotherhood for the Southern Pacific lines.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- French opposition to increasing the German industrial potential now, as set forth in the Cooperation Committee of the sixteennation economic conference in Paris yesterday, was communicated to the United States Government today by Henri Bonnet, French Ambassador, at a conference with Robert A. Lovett, Under-Secretary of State.

SUMMIT, N.J., July 18 -- One stroke separated leader and runnerup today at the end of thirtysix holes in the New Jersey State open golf championship over the Canoe Brook south course. The tourney will be completed with a thirty-six-hole final tomorrow.

Ten thousand lay workers in churches of every denomination from all Protestant evangelical churches in the United States and Canada have been called to the twenty-first International Sunday School convention of the International Council of Religious Education at Des Moines, Iowa, from July 23 to 27.

The United States Television Manufacturing Corporation has completed production plans for its new 'large-image projection-type television receiver designed for public places, and first deliveries will be made to dealers within thirty days, William H. Higgins, sales manager, disclpsed yesterday.

Longer skirts for women have changed dance styles, producing smoother and more dignified dancing, Miss Lucille Stoddart, director of the seventeenth annual Dance Congress, said yesterday at the Hotel Commodore.

Commutation passenger service on the Old Colony Line will be continued for at least two years under the plan of reorganization for the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, which already has been approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission and confirmed by the courts, trustees for both roads announced yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 18 -- In a surprise move, Argentina proposed today that the United Nations General Assembly convene a conference of all member countries to abolish, the "privilege of the veto" in the security council by amending the Charter.

CHICAGO, July 18 (AP) -- Joe Haynes allowed only four hits in pitching the White Sox to a 4-to-1 triumph over the Athletics before 17,988 persons tonight. The Athletics scored an unearned run in the ninth inning to rob Haynes of a shutout as the veteran righthander posted his fifth victory in the rapid time of 1 hour 34 minutes.

Rocky Graziano returned to New York yesterday to be met with all the fanfare and ceremony due a conquering hero. The newly crowned middleweight champion of the world, officially discredited in his own state by the boxing commission, learned that he is boxing's top man in the hearts of his boyhood friends and neighbors in the vicinity of Second Avenue and Seventh Street, where he grew up as Tommy Barbello.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 18 -- The Civic League of Westchester, with a membership embracing leaders of county taxpayers organizations, charged today that the Westchester Board of Supervisors was "hasty and ill-advised" when it recently altered the county pay schedule in the middle of the fiscal year without first conducting a public hearing.
LONDON, July 18 -- Excited bidding for oil shares by brokers was the feature in a generally firm stock market here today.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The recent Paris conference on the world cereals shortage has demonstrated to the needy countries of Europe the necessity for continued tight restrictions and better management of their own food supplies, D.A. FitzGerald, SecretaryGeneral of the International Emergency Food Council, said today.

Eleven modern hotels will be erected in the next four years in Latin America to house visiting business men and tourists from the United States, it was announced here yesterday. The cost will be $75,000,000.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The son of a blacksmith, a short, round man who has been thirty-five years in the hard-handed politics of industrial New England, was separated tonight from the Presidency by the hairline of providence on which the life of any man depends.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The text of President Truman's message vetoing the income tax reduction bill today follows: To the House of Representatives: I return herewith, without my approval, H.R. 3950, entitled "An Act to Reduce Individual Income Tax Payments."
Sale of $45,000,000 of New York City 0.75 per cent tax anticipation notes dated July 18 and due on Oct. 3 to twenty-six local banks was announced yesterday by Controller Lazarus Joseph.

SHAWNEE-ON-THE-DELAWARE, Pa., July 18 -- M.P. Catherwood, dean of the School of Labor and Industrial Relations of Cornell University, declared today a number of Federal agencies "mean to gain control over the destinies of large sections of the country in which they operate through, a stranglehold on the development of natural resources."

New Capital Market The successful marketing of the first bond issue of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development -- $100,000,000 of tenyear 2 1/4s and $150,000,000 of twenty-five-year 3s -- dominated the market for new capital this week.

A day after he had put the finishing touches on his larger-than-life sculpture of Man o' War, which has been seven years in the making and is intended to perpetuate the form and the fame of the great thoroughbred, the American sculptor Herbert Haseltine sailed yesterday for France aboard the Colombie of the French Line.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- President Truman created today an emergency board to intervene in the Southern Pacific Railroad labor dispute in which a strike has been called for Monday night.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On July 6, you published Congressman Willis W. Bradley's letter of June 23, in which he takes me to task for certain statements contained in a letter of mine published in THE TIMES on June 22. As will be recalled, my letter was critical of a proposed organic act for Guam being sponsored by the Navy and Interior Departments.

The strike of Local 96 of the Financial Employes Guild, CIO, against the Brooklyn Trust Company, which began with picket-line violence early Thursday, gave indications yesterday of developing into a stalemate.

Six officials of Camp John Paul Jones at Shelter Island, Suffolk County, were being sought yesterday by the office of the District Attorney of Kings County for questioning about the failure of the resort to open on schedule for 200 young campers.

The National Navigation Company, James V. Auditore's shipless shipping company, produced a cityowned pier like a magician pulling a rabbit from a hat for a ship agency that had been told by I. James Brody, then Deputy Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, that no berths were available.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Armour Co., moving to make effective its recapitalization program approved by stockholders last year, sold today privately to about 20 insurance companies $35,000,000 of 25 year 3% per cent cumulative income debentures (subordinated).

A shorter hospital stay for mothers after childbirth and methods for bringing mother and baby together in the same hospital room were suggested yesterday at Bellevue Hospital by Dr. Harry Bakwin, associate professor at the New York University College of Medicine.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Grain markets, were unsettled on the Board of Trade today, breaking early, only to rally strong later and ease again toward the last. Wheat had a range of 3 1/2 to 4 1/2 cents a bushel, closing at about the bottom, down 1% to 3 cents, and corn, after a range of 4 to 5% cents, finished % cent higher to % cent lower.

DETROIT, July 18 -- Randy Gumpert didn't have it. Freddie Hutchinson did. That is the shortest explanation for the season's saddest report concerning the Yankees, who, on the brink of immortality, fell before the Tigers, 8 to 0, in the twilight at Briggs Stadium this evening.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 18 -- This country's Communist-dominated Parliament 'today, formally accused Dr. Juliu Maniu and five other Ifational Peasant party Deputies with efforts to overthrow the present Government and approved a measure removing their Parliamentary immunity from arrest.

Gerald L.K. Smith, national director of the Christian National Crusade, is in New York to aid in what he described yesterday as a "revival" of the Christian Front. He discussed his organization's plans in an interview at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

JERUSALEM, July 18 -- One British soldier was killed and seven soldiers and one Jewish civilian was wounded today in a series of Jewish underground attacks. Palestine authorities expect the attacks to continue and probably intensify between now and September when the United Nations General Assembly will take up the Palestine problem.
As organized consumer groups began yesterday to observe "Buy No Meat Week" In protest against high prices, a marked weakening was noted in local wholesale markets.

ATHENS, July 18 (U.P.) -- The Greek Army's war with a guerrilla invading force dwindled to small, isolated clashes today and a General Staff spokesman said guerrilla casualties in ground fighting totaled 110 killed and seventy captured.

NEW DELHI, India, July 18 -- India is expected to have a new Government Monday, with the present interim regime giving way to two provisional Cabinets for the respective Dominions of Pakistan and India.
BERLIN, July 18 -- Seven former Nazi greats walked single file, handcuffed and under the guard of Russian tommy gunners, into grim Spandau prison today.

HAIFA, Palestine, July 18 -- After a prolonged battle at sea with a naval boarding party the largest contingent of unauthorized immigrants ever to reach Palestine shores arrived here today with three of their number dead and scores injured. The boarding party was badly beaten up but only three required hospital treatment.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have been a constant reader of THE TIMES for many years and therefore appreciate fully its great influence and world-wide appeal. On June 26 I read Charles Egan's report from London, in which he quoted at some length the speech of Lewis W. Douglas.

Big Ralph Branca almost pitched himself into baseball's Hall of Fame under the Ebbet's Field lights last night. He blanked the world champion Cardinals on one hit while the Dodgers hammered out a 7-0 triumph.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Attorney General Tom Clark extemporaneously voiced before the Immigration Subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee today the last spoken plea at this session for the admission of 400,000 displaced persons to this country in four years.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 18 -- Recommendations by the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission for the "disposal" of atomic weapons as the climax to the stepby-step introduction of international control are "unacceptable" until the Commission agrees that such weapons are to be destroyed, Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, announced today.

The following books of a religious or inspirational nature have recently been published: WHY I AM FOR THE CHURCH, by Charles P. Taft. 100 pages. Farrar, Straus. $2.25 -- Son of the Chief Justice and brother of the Senator, Mr. Taft is the first layman to be president of the Federal Council of Churches.

LONDON, July 18 -- Details of the acquisition of the American ship President Warfield by agents in New York for carrying unauthorized immigrants to Palestine were issued here tonight on the basis of official British reports.

Immediate action of the Maritime Commission's projected $47,000,000 program for the rebuilding of the nation's coastwise passenger ship fleet was proposed yesterday by the American Merchant Marine Institute.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The State Department announced today that it would review through a Personnel Security Board the investigative records on employes who were being considered for possible discharge as security risks.

YELLOWSTONE PARK, Wyo., July 18 -- For the first time since he left Albany July 4 for a fourweek "non-political" vacation tour of the West with his family, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey spent an entire day today without conferring with Republican political leaders.
ST. LOUIS, July 18 (AP) -- Ted Williams hit two home runs tonight, but Ray Coleman, Jeff Heath and Paul Lehner slammed out one circuit blow apiece to send the Browns ahead of the Red Sox, 9 to 8.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Bondholders who have opposed sale of $103,000,000 of revenue bonds by the Chicago Transit Authority today announced they would not attempt to carry their objections CHICAGO, July 18 to the United States Supreme Court, thereby removing the last legal barrier to the proposed bond offerings.

The restored transatlantic liner De Grasse, of the French Line, the first of the company's ships to return to regular passenger service, will arrive in New York late Monday afternoon, the company announced yesterday.

In one of the final shows of the week for the out-of-town press, the Junior Dress Creators of New York demonstrated yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel that junior fashions are designed both for age and size. Both groups stressed such new fashion points as the longer hemline, the fuller skirt, the rounded look at the hipline, the rounded shoulderline and the ballet length evening frock.

The proxy right between the management of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company and a group of stockholders represented by the Carleton-Compton-Day proxy committee over candidates for the directorate was intensified yesterday by the latter group, which made several charges against the management in a letter to stockholders. The election is scheduled for July 28.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 18 -- Relatives who reported three former Worcester women held prisoner in Siberia by the Soviet Union expressed fear today that the publicizing of their plight might result in the deaths of the prisoners and their children.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- For the second time in four weeks the Republicans failed in efforts to reduce taxes today when the Senate sustained President Truman's veto of the GOP bill to cut personal income levies by from 10.5 to 30 per cent.

MEXICO CITY, July 18 -- The anniversary of the death of Benito Juarez, one of Mexico's three foremost national heroes, was made the occasion today for a major demonstration by powerful LeftWing political groups against what they termed the "provocative violations of the Constitution by the entire Catholic clergy in Durango State.
Eddie Giosa, Philadelphia battler, registered an upset victory over Charley Fusari of Irvington, N.J., in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

It will be North America vs. South America in the $100,000 added Empire Gold Cup race today at Belmont Park, to which point the New York racing show was transferred from Jamaica yesterday for the international program arranged by the Empire City Racing Association.

DES MOINES, July 18 (AP) -- Scoring three eagles along the way, Frank Stranahan, the defending champion, defeated William (Bill) Campbell of Huntington, W. Va., 2 and 1, and Marvin (Bud) Ward toppled John Jacobs of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, 1 up, today as the favorites advanced to the semi-finals of the Western amateur golf tournament.

Hans Schweiger, conductor; Helen Traubel, Wagnerian soprano, and Ruggiero Ricci, violinist, will all make their first appearances at Lewisohn Stadium next week. Other featured artists during the week will be Stell Anderson, pianist; Alec Templeton, pianist, and Paul Lavalle, radio conductor.

ANTWERP, Belgium, July 18 (Aneta) -- The Port of Antwerp definitely established its position as first of the European mainland ports when figures for shipping that passed through the port in June were made public here today.

Playing too well to let the usual medalist jinx bother him, Jack Lyons, Garden City Golf Club star, advanced to the quarter-final round of the Long Island amateur championship at the Pomonok Country Club course yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The State Department confirmed today that the case of the American woman who has long been held by the Russians in Siberia and prevented from coming to the United States was that of Mrs. Voldemaras-Vytautas Carneckis of Worcester, Mass. Her husband was formerly Foreign Minister of Lithuania.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (AP) -- The Cubs unlimbered their heavy artillery for four extra base hits and as many runs in the third inning tonight, then went on to whip the Phillies, 7 to 5, before a crowd of 16,573.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The House spent seven hours and went through seven roll-call votes today without breaking its deadlock with the Senate over the near-billion dollar Agriculture Department appropriation bill for the fiscal year which started July 1.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- A measure extending the Government's price support program for domestic wool through 1948 was cleared today by the House Rules Committee for action next week It has been passed by the Senate.

Trade Active in Week Retail trade was active here this week, with gains running ahead of expectations. Department store volume was put at about 15 to 16 per cent ahead of the comparative week last year.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 18 -- A special United Nations investigation team said today it had received "little first-hand evidence" to support Greek Government charges that detachments from an "international brigade" were among guerrilla fighters said to have invaded Greece from Albania.
FRESNO, Calif., July 18 -- The three-way split of California Democrats was widened tonight as leftwingers gathered here to open a Wallace-for-President drive tomorrow.

BUDAPEST, July 18 -- A clash between the insurgent group in the majority Smallholders party, which wishes to free it from Communist domination, and President Zoltan Tildy, party leader, who believes it should bow to the inevitable, may present next Tuesday the spectacle of police power being used to bar the national meeting of the party.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Following is the vote by which the House today overrode President Truman's veto of the tax bill: FOR OVERRIDING -- 299 Republicans -- 236 Allen (Calif.) Foote Mack Alien (Ill.) Fulton Mackinnon Anderson Gallagher Macy (Calif.) Gamble Maloney

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The formulation of a national program for military and civil aviation was entrusted today by President Truman to an air policy commission, made up of five private citizens and directed to submit its recommendations by Jan. 1.
Cardinal Spellman put out a small fire in his bedroom shortly before last midnight and received the congratulations of firemen on the dispatch with which he handled the blaze.
CHICAGO. July 18 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

DALLAS, July 18 -- A cotton research program large enough to meet effectively the challenge of competing synthetic fibers is the only measure that will prevent "staggering losses for the cotton farmer in the years ahead."

Charles H. Tuttle, counsel for the Gulf Oil Company, denied any impropriety in the company's dealing's with Elmer Haslett, suspended City Airports Director, as both sides summed up yesterday on charges of misconduct in office against Haslett.

Faced with the renewed possibility of a strike by the 900 drivers and mechanics of the Green Bus Lines, Inc., and the Triboro Coach Corporation, which serve about one-third of Queens, Mayor O'Dwyer asked spokesmen for the two companies and the unions representing their employes yesterday to confer with him at City Hall at 10:30 A.M. on Monday.

Charging that increases of 300 and 400 per cent over 1942 in summer rentals are not the exception but the rule at metropolitan seaside resorts, Assemblyman Louis Peck of the Bronx asked the City Council yesterday to include a rollback of such rentals in the proposed omnibus city rent control law.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The Treasury and Federal Reserve Board today appealed jointly to American individuals, banks and business enterprises to help stop speculation in gold in foreign markets.

Three in One This is the season when Americans are continually being reminded of the threefold governmental system under which they live. They live under a federal government which conducts foreign affairs, organizes and reorganizes military forces, and collects a great many taxes, including a 20 per cent charge on theatre tickets.

TOKYO, July 18 -- With the Katayama Cabinet apparently determined to stand or fall on the coal nationalization issue, the operators are digging more coal to prove that state management is not necessary. It is predicted that July production will exceed June's by 20 or 25 per cent.

Tony Vincent came to the end of his winning streak in the Eastern clay court championship yesterday, but not until the strongest attack sent in the tournament had almost collapsed against his rockribbed defense.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The Valley Authority Conference protested to the Senate Appropriations Committee today on "secret hearings" by the committee with Army engineers on an appropriation of $250,000,000 for MissouriMississippi Valley flood control.

Three in One This is the season when Americans are continually being reminded of the threefold governmental system under which they live. They live under a federal government which conducts foreign affairs, organizes and reorganizes military forces, and collects a great many taxes, including a 20 per cent charge on theatre tickets.

TOKYO, July 18 -- With the Katayama Cabinet apparently determined to stand or fall on the coal nationalization issue, the operators are digging more coal to prove that state management is not necessary. It is predicted that July production will exceed June's by 20 or 25 per cent.

Tony Vincent came to the end of his winning streak in the Eastern clay court championship yesterday, but not until the strongest attack sent in the tournament had almost collapsed against his rockribbed defense.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The Valley Authority Conference protested to the Senate Appropriations Committee today on "secret hearings" by the committee with Army engineers on an appropriation of $250,000,000 for MissouriMississippi Valley flood control.

Failure of some small, war-born lumber yards in the metropolitan area to meet financial obligations promptly recently may be the initial indication of forthcoming heavy mortality among such operators, Sol Kaplan, president, New York Lumber Trades Association, said yesterday.

Some United States newspaper publishers are paying sky-high prices for newsprint in an international free market that stretches from New York to the Orient, it was reported yesterday by The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Democrats quietly but grimly raised today an all but impenetrable barrier against the efforts of Senate Republicans to force an investigation of Attorney General Tom C. Clark. The inquiry was being demanded, with the support of the Republican party leadership, by Senator James P. Kem of Missouri on the claim that the Attorney General "whitewashed" a Federal inquiry into alleged voting frauds in Kansas City in the 1946 congressional primary.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Col. Florence Blanchfield, superintendent of Army nurses, today received from Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower the first Regular Army commission ever given a woman.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., July 18 -- In honor of Virginia's contribution to the establishment of democratic government in the New World, several Virginia people have established a patriotic music drama, "The Common Glory," which had its first production in a new outdoor theatre here last evening.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Creation of a master catalogue of the skills and experjence of all veterans of World War II under 45 years of age has been proposed in identical bills introduced into both houses of Congress, it was disclosed today.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander declared yesterday, in connection with the Queens grand jury investigation of alleged bribery of policemen by bookmakers, that "if there is any evidence of corruption against any member of this department I will personally see that the guilty one is properly dealt with."

PARIS, July 18 -- Alphonse Juin, Resident General of Morocco, arrived here today to take part in the conferences in which the Government will discuss the attitude 'it will take this fall when, in all probability, France's North African policy will be challenged before the United Nations.

The Stratton Bill, H.R. 2910, powerfully backed by the Administration and leading Republicans, by organized labor and all religious groups, has a fighting chance if the public and legislators can get it before the full House for a vote. This is the bill which would admit 400,000 DP's over a four-year period.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- A sharp spurt in housing construction and other favorable developments in June were reported today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Twenty-one reports by Eastern Air Lines pilots of "bad" to "excessive" vibration in the landing gear of the Douglas DC-4 that crashed near Bainbridge, Md., last May 30, killing all fifty-three passengers and crew members, had been made between Oct. 22, 1946, and the time of the fatal crash, according to testimony given yesterday at the Civil Aeronautics Board hearing on the accident.

IN "Our Lusty Forefathers"* Fairfax Downey has hammered together a cheerful collection of tales that emphasize the more exuberant aspects of the American past. They are all based on reality, though sometimes Mr. Downey touches them up with splashes of imaginative writing. And they range from New England bundling and New Orleans dueling to prodigious eating and drinking scenes and unorthodox battlepieces out of the American Revolution.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 18 (AP) -- Acting Gov. Joe R. Hanley said today that Senator Irving M. Ives had done "as much, if not more, than anyone in bringing together discordant elements" in labor-management relations in New York.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Day and night sessions of the Senate next week were agreed upon by Republican leaders today as they clung to plans for adjournment of Congress on July 26 -- a week from Saturday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 18 -- As the studies in the Independent Motion Picture Producers Association continue their efforts to obtain from Hollywood guilds and labor unions special concessions affecting film costs, one of the most important organizations in the association, Monogram Pictures Corporation, today said it expected to be able to resume making its B features soon.

First Grade Detective John J. Broderick put in for retirement yesterday after almost twenty-five years with the Police Department. His application will be acted upon by the board of trustees of the Police Pension Fund at its next regular meeting a month hence.

CLEVELAND, July 18 (AP) -- Don Black pitched and batted the Indians to a 6-to-0 shutout over the Senators tonight to snap the Tribe's six-game losing streak. Black held Washington to five singles and contributed a base-cleaning double in the second inning.

Failure of the European glove industry to make a comeback in the last twelve months spells a temporary end to the glove importing business here, according to Arthur Stanton, president of Aris Gloves, Inc.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (AP) -- Allied Chemical Dye Corporation, today told the Securities and Exchange Commission that American Light Traction Co. is controlled "illegally" by United Light Railways Co.

FLOWERS for cutting are beginning to be plentiful in the home garden. Inspiration for arrangements comes from the material now available and suitable placement indoors or on the porch is suggested by colors and design, which will change character as new bouquets are made each day.

Man's age-old quest for hidden and forgotten treasures will be aroused in the next few weeks as the lists of missing depositors, which banks are now starting to publish in newspapers, increase in number. Always fascinating because of the possibilities of financial gain, the lists kindle in the minds of readers the hope that they, or their kin, may be the owners of some of the unclaimed property in the banks.

THE authors of this volume present the first panoramic view of economic warfare in World War II. They are indeed highly qualified to do so, for during the war they were successively chiefs of the Blockade Division of the Foreign Economic Administration.
LONDON. THE British radio, with maddening insistence is plugging the haunting tunes from "Oklahoma" and "Annie Get Your Gun," the two American musicals which have conquered London's theatreland.

Awakened by shouts that their home was about to collapse, residents of the sixteen-family building at the northwest corner of West Eleventh and Hudson Streets hurried out of their apartments early yesterday morning.

Television receiver producers last week assailed retailer complaints that the latter are not being permitted adequate mark-ups to make for satisfactory net profits. They also contended that installation fees received by retailers, whether set by the manufacturer or levied on the consumer at retailer discretion, do not result in losses.

The tangled fiscal affairs of the Equitable Office Building Corporation, which controls the big Equitable Building at 120 Broadway, entered a new phase last week when the courts and trustee received a new plan for refinancing the skyscraper.

THE Dial Press' reprint of "A Raw Youth" now makes readily available to the English reader that work of Dostoevsky which, chronologically, stands midway between "The Possessed" and "The Brothers Karamazov." An able introduction to this edition has been provided by Alfred Kazan, whose occasional rhapsodic tone serves to remind us that the appreciative school of criticism has always been relevant to Dostoevsky.

THERE will be few books published this year that will hold greater interest to serious readers of poetry than the present selection of poems from the manuscripts of Samuel Greenberg -- and the dates of Greenberg's life are: Born in Vienna, Nov. 3. 1893: died of tuberculosis at Sea View Hospital on Staten Island.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Soviet Embassy charged the State Department today with an "inaccuracy" when it announced Wednesday that a Soviet Embassy representative had been president when it had been decided to call a Japanese peace-treaty conference.

JERUSALEM, July 19 -- Terrorists struck four blows in Palestine tonight, killing one British police constable and injuring twelve men, including five soldiers, with mines and ambush attacks. It was apparently in retaliation for the British naval interception of the unauthorized immigrant ship President Warfield, renamed Exodus 1947, yesterday when a sea fight developed and three Jews were killed.

CONFIDENCE in retail trade propects for fall has now increased substantially, following the "softness" in volume which was evident a few weeks ago. While the economy of the country apparently is drawn to a very fine balance, with events producing a quicker reaction than heretofore, merchants are strongly impressed by the combination of factors shaping up to influence trade between now and the end of the year.

THE general consideration of the problems of young people, mainly their willful morals and aberrant energies, is most often the property of two distinct groups -- the mourners, who waggle their heads individually or in pairs, and wall, "What is our youth coining to?";

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 19 (AP) -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay publicly criticized one of his highest-ranking generals in Germany tonight for the officer's connection with the Hesse (Kronberg) jewel theft trials.

WE were filming -- I stopped using the word "shooting" while in Palestine -- we were filming the most delicate dialogue sequence in "Survivors" on the grounds of the Hebrew University, with Jerusalem and the burnt wilderness of Judea as our background.

CLEVELAND, July 19 -- The entire fleet of 274 bulk freighters is operating in the ore trade, C.C. Lindeman, statistician for the M.A. Hanna Company, disclosed today. The D.J. Morrell of the Bethlehem Transportation Corporation, which has been undergoing repairs, gave the Great Lakes fleet 100 per cent representation in the ore trade late this week when she sailed for the head of the Lakes.

CINCINNATI, July 19 -- Rupert Andrew Anderegg, Professor of Civil Engineering at the University of Cincinnati and authority on flood control, died of a heart ailment late yesterday at his home here. His age was 53.

THIS is the story of a great patron of the Renaissance, but of one who lived in Portugal, not Italy, and devoted his wealth and his influence, not to the support of art and humanism, but to the accumulation and promulgation of that sort of knowledge which would benefit those who go down to the sea in ships.

CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- Delegates representing more than 5,000 Lutheran congregations will assemble here tomorrow for the centennial convention of the Evangelical Lutheran Synod of Missouri, Ohio and Other States.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The final approval of the International Refugee Organization by both branches of the American Government marks a step forward in the attempt to deal with the problem of displaced persons, which has been one of the tragic failures of the peace.

HOLLYWOOD. AFTER providing its producer, Arthur Hornblow Jr., with what he describes as the most extraordinary filmmaking experience in his Hollywood career, Greer Garson's latest picture, which has given Hornblow's department at MGM a vast amount of trouble and concern is now about ready for general release.

NEW DELHI, India, July 19 -- Today, less than a month before formally relinquishing the Government of India, Britain deposed one more potentate in the Princely States and invoked the name of the King Emperor for perhaps the last time.

FROM a friend of a friend, whose daughter contemplates a debut recital next season in New York, comes an inquiry of a kind often received by this department. If the debut recital is given next season, can the recitalist be sure of a detailed criticism the morning after in THE TIMES?
DETROIT, July 19 -- Fear of a possible letdown by the Yankees, following yesterday's streak-popping setback, was dispelled this frigid afternoon at Briggs Stadium.

BERLIN, July 19 -- The United States and British bi-zonal level-of-industry plan is being held up for integration with the economic program to be worked out in Paris, authoritative sources said today. This decision has been made by the highest authorities in Washington and London and will defer until Sept. 1 at least the projected increase in industrial capacity to be permitted in Western Germany.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Isolationism has reappeared on the national political scene. To many close observers here today it stands threateningly across the path of such large-scale programs for the economic rehabilitation of Europe as presumably would be embraced in the Marshall Plan.

RAHWAY, N.J., July 19 -- Alfred C. Brooks of 831 Pierpont Street, a member of the Union County Board of Freeholders, twice Mayor of Rahway and former all-American football star at Brown University, died yesterday at the Pine Acres Nursing Home, Madison, N.J., after a long illness.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The greatest peacetime reorganization in the history of the armed services commenced this week with the announcement of Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson's resignation.

MORE tourists visited Grand Canyon during June than in any previous month, according to figures released by the Chief Ranger of Grand Canyon National Park. The total number of guests arriving by automobile, rail, stage and air was 98,545, an increase of 37 per cent over June, 1946.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- The Department of Interior will get $194,500,000 for the current fiscal year if the House and Senate ratify an agreement reached today by a conference committee.

The realty mortgage is not a modern instrument. The business as it is carried on today had its inception back in ancient times, points out Nathan Goldman, of the Sonnenblick-Goldman Company, mortgage brokers, who cites some interesting records of early deals of this type.

BAD SALZUFLEN, Germany July 19 -- A new high in German sabotage was achieved recently when wireless equipment still on the British War Office list of secret material was stolen from a Royal Air Force airfield, it was learned today.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 19 -- Swift punishment by special people's courts for Dr. Juliu Maniu and other Peasant party leaders accused of having plotted the overthrow of the Rumanian Government was demanded today by the Communist directors of the ruthless purge.

As a representative of what is probably the first American film contingent to use postwar Berlin as a location setting for a picture, Robert Ryan, who will be featured in RKO's "Berlin Express," paused here briefly before sailing for the German capital.

CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- Papers of Abraham Lincoln which are to be opened July 26 in Washington after having been sealed for twenty-one years probably will not reveal any sensational new events in Lincoln's life, but they will be of great value to historians.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The United States shipped a recordbreaking volume of nearly 30,000,000 long tons of coal abroad in the last fiscal year, the White House said today.

LONDON, July 19 -- A solution of the mystery of the chemical architecture of streptomycin, which ranks with penicillin as one of the greatest medical discoveries of all time, was reported today at the International Congress of Pure and Applied Chemistry.

The two top players in the European zonal preliminaries for the world chess championship at Hilversum were again successful yesterday, according to reports from the Netherlands. Ludek Pachman, Czechoslovakia, remained in first place with five straight victories, closely, followed by Alberic O'Kelly de Galway of Belgium with 4 1/2-1/2.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- In the past week there has been a last minute effort to get Congressional action for the DP's before adjournment. Unless Congress takes action within the next seven days, the question, which has gone unsolved for two years after the war, will probably be put aside for another year.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 19 -- Presidential politics was the main topic of discussion here this week as the Governors of forty-four States and the territories of Alaska, Hawaii and Puerto Rico met for the annual midsummer conference, ostensibly to discuss and exchange views on common problems.

Last week we heard by way of Palo Alto, Calif., where the Pacific section of the American Physical Society held a meeting, what the 4,000-ton cyclotron or atom-smasher of the University of California can do. Atoms were broker up as never before. Out of the nucleus flew twenty-two and possibly thirty particles.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- The American Veterans' Committee at its Milwaukee convention last month overwhelmingly opposed universal military training, it was announced here today. The results of recently-completed ballot counting on this platform plank were 46,000 to 12,000 against the plan.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Unification of the armed forces, long blocked by deadlocked controversy within the services and Congress, was approved by a voice vote of the House this evening.

To the Drama Editor: WHEN Walter Kerr, in his article, "Failure Noted," claims that university and community theatres have not of late produced many untried playscripts, he points to a state of affairs which, unfortunately, is true. However, when he attributes this condition to a lack of courage on the part of the directors of these theatres, he is arguing rather wide of the mark.

THIS volume, containing the personal opinions of Harvard's Emeritus Professor of Philosophy, is likely to cause journalists in all media more uneasiness than did the commission's report on "A Free and Responsible Press," published some months ago.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Some years ago when Thurman Arnold suggested that labor unions were within the scope of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law, you accorded me the facilities of your columns in answer thereto. Events subsequently proved Judge Arnold's thesis wrong.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 -- The Pacific Coast Longshore Safety Commission, agreed to last year in the contract between the Waterfront Employers Association and the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, held its first meeting here this week before surveying safety procedures in West Coast cargo handling and preparing written recommendations.

Unaccustomed to the idea of beating the world champions, the Dodgers yesterday bowed to a fourteen-hit attack and permitted the Cardinals to even the series by winning, 7 -- 5. A small but eternally hopeful crowd of 15,685 Flatbush fans saw the game at Ebbets Field.

BEFORE long the North Pole may be only a whistle stop for airplane tourists, but thirty-eight years ago when Peary raised the American flag on an icy hummock there, it was the unattained goal of Arctic exploration.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Senate unanimously passed and sent to the White House today a bill to authorize the redemption in cash of terminal leave bonds issued to enlisted service men upon their discharge.

Piet H. Hofstra, Regional Administrator of the Office of Rent Control, warned yesterday that leases which fall-short of meeting the requirements of the new Federal rent control law or which contain evasive clauses must be rejected by his office.

Editor New York Times Book Review: IN my copy of THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review for July 6 there is a regrettable error in Theodore Draper criticism of Robert Merriam's "Dark December." Mr. Draper attributes a foolishly optimistic American evaluation of German strength before the Ardennes offensive of December 1944 to the G-2 of the First Army.

MOTORISTS will rejoice in the findings of Associate Dean Roscoe Ellard of Columbia University's Journalism School in a survey he made on means of enforcing highway statutes and winning simultaneously the widespread support of the motoring public.

LONDON, July 19 -- When Lord Inverchapel, British Ambassador to Washington, returned to Britain for a visit a few weeks ago, he said that Anglo-American relations had never been better. There was a lot of diplomacy in that remark -- and also a lot of truth.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 19 (AP) -- John Voight of the Baltimore Olympic Track and Field Club piled up 2,972 points today to take the title in the twenty-seventh national A.A.U. pentathlon at Warinanco Park.

SUMMIT, N.J., July 19 -- Leading by only one stroke at the end of yesterday's competition, Gene Kunes, Englewood Golf Club professional, turned in two scintillating rounds today to capture easily the New Jersey open championship on the south course of the Canoe Brook Country Club.

The steady upward push of rayon fabric prices is the strongest factor in a new inflationary spiral for apparel, it was pointed out in the trade last week. If it continues unabated a price debacle of much more serious proportions than the one experienced last spring will eventually result, it was predicted.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- A House armed services subcommittee approved a universal military training bill today, but there was no prospect of action this session by the House or Senate.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Industrial democracy as practiced in the twenty-three domestic plants of the International Harvester Company is based on a policy which includes but goes somewhat beyond the essentially negative principle of anti-discrimination.
There is to be a debate on the subject: "Would an Increase in Rents Be Inflationary?"; but how about a debate on "The Inflation ary Effect of Increased Wages" -- or is that too obvious?

In the depression years of the early Thirties, Great Britain, previously a free-trade nation, adopted the practice of Imperial preferences, largely as a reaction to America's high tariffs. This practice involved preferential treatment for trade within the Empire and with a number of other countries having close commercial ties to the United Kingdom.

Harold D. Nixon, president of Harold Nixon, Inc., industrial realty company of Hackensack, N.J., announced yesterday that he had completed a series of conferences with Susquehanna Railroad officials, an investing syndicate and City Manager Carl Wright concerning plans for a $6,000,000 terminal building in the area of Mercer, Main and Moore Streets, in Hackensack.

THE weather is news -- important news. Fishermen, power companies, farmers, department store managers, oil dealers, highway engineers, amusement park managers, restaurant keepers, bakers, photographers, railway companies, in fact all business and professional men, must adapt themselves more or less to the weather.

ALBANY, July 19 -- New minimum wage levels of 57% cents an hour affecting 29,500 workers in the confectionery and cleaning and dyeing industries have been recommended to Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi. The recommendations were in reports from minimum wage boards that have been surveying both industries for several months.

THE Berkshire Festival gets under way in real earnest this week. There has been activity at Tanglewood ever since the Berkshire Music Centre opened there three weeks ago and there have already been two Bach programs in the Theatre-Concert Hall.

Except for the interspersion of a few warnings, the remarks made before the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners in Boston last Thursday by Securities and Exchange Commissioner Richard B. McEntire were hailed by the utility industry as the first sign of an era of amity between the private electric light and power companies and that Federal agency.

IN the foreword to her new book, Anna Kavan, English author of "Asylum Piece." reasonably contends that "If human life be accepted as the result of tension between the two polarities of night and day, the negative pole, night, must have at least equal importance with the positive day."

TO THE EDITOR: I read with considerable alarm Nathaniel Peffer's article, "Close-Up of China in Travail," and feel an urge to express myself on his sweeping statement that the Chinese Government is "one of the worst in the world today."

Back at Belmont Park, the track where he had been claimed for $1,500 in June of 1943, Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' gallant old Stymie yesterday wrote the brightest chapter in his rags-to-riches saga of the raceways when he won the $100,000 added Empire Gold Cup race.

Activity in all departments last week was good, with sales in sportswear and beachwear commanding very good response and dress departments active, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Lingerie and infants' departments were busy and housewares were moving.

THEY are moanin' -- and hardly low -- these days around the Main Stem. Summer is dealing some of its harder punches where it hurts -- at the box office -- and it's being said The Street hasn't seen the likes of the slump since before the war.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- President Truman has signed the agreement for United States rule of the former Japanese-mandated islands in the Pacific, the White House announced today.
ATLANTA, Ga., July 19 -- Atlanta's first summer operetta season has closed after five of ten scheduled performances with losses admittedly totaling more than $90,000.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: With the paramount thought in mind that the near future will express the urgent need and will provide for many memorials dedicated to the Second World War, there will no doubt be erected "living memorials" as well as the traditional, not strictly utilitarian, types.

Tomorrow Congress enters on what are scheduled to be the last six days of the present session. It has wasted much time since January. If it does what it ought to do it will have six busy days. We believe that it can and should do the following things:

Frank Strafaci of the home club and Billy Dear, New Jersey star, became finalists in the Long Island amateur golf championship tournament yesterday by capturing their semi-final round matches over the Pomonok Country Club course in Flushing.

HECTOR CHEVIGNY, having written a few thousand radio dramas, has concluded that ether theatricals are not much better today than they were twenty years ago and that there is little indication they will improve in the near future.

TRENTON, N.J., July 19 (AP) -- The New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce, in the first official pronouncement of its views on the proposed new constitution, opposed today a change in New Jersey's property tax system.

SUMMER mulching is just as important as winter mulching. Each has its place although the winter practice of covering plants with rough material like straw or evergreen boughs to protect them from the vagaries of winter is better known.

PARIS, July 19 -- As the experts of the Paris Conference press forward with their hasty task of tabulating national resources and needs, economists both from the West and East will be watching breathlessly to know if the West can organize without the East.

FLOWER shows are here again. So are the exhibitors, without whom there could be no shows, no exciting competition, no blue ribbons -- not even an honorable mention. These shows, which are brought into full bloom in nearly every section of our garden-conscious country from June through October, are the friendly, intimate and predominantly amateur type.

Physicists of the late nineteenth century were convinced that the smallest indivisible unit of matter was the atom. When the late Sir J.J. Thomson announced in 1897 that there was something still smaller, something one-eighteen-hundredth as big as the hydrogen atom, there was general incredulity.

Giving knows no season, and in midsummer's heat a unique gift has been added to THE NEW YORK TIMES Hundred Neediest Cases Fund, an annual Christmas appeal. It came by way of the New Hampshire Legislature from the estate of Marine Lieut. Benjamin Rush Toland, who fell on Iwo Island.

The second phase of the Civil Aeronautics Board's hearing on the crash of an Eastern Air Lines Douglas DC-4 near Bainbridge, Md., last May 30, killing all fifty-three passengers and crew members, ended here yesterday with several theories as to the possible cause of the crash but no single clear-cut solution.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 19 -- Forty-seven Governors attending their national conference here have been staring at forty-seven varieties of beards as fixedly as they have gazed at the Mormon Tabernacle. Black, brown, blond, red, gray and white whiskers are seen on every hand -- or face.

MUNICH, Germany, July 19 -- Former Denazification Minister Dr. Alfred Loritz, stormiest Bavarian in postwar politics, was behind bars today in Neudeck prison in Munich. He was arrested this morning and charged with subornation of perjury.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 19 -- Absence of democratic practices in the school systems of the nation is one of the major problems facing American education today, educators attending the second annual Human Relations Workshop here this week reported. Conducted by the New York University summer session in cooperation with the Chautauqua Institution, the workshop has brought together school leaders from every section of the country.

WITH the original cast in the featured roles, GianCarlo Menotti's new American opera, "The Medium," now playing at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre, will be given its first radio performance on CBS this afternoon from 3 to 4:30 o'clock.

The greatest thorn in the postwar operations of the domestic steel companies -- their lingering inability to produce sufficient sheet and strip steel -- plagued the industry anew last week when the General Motors Corporation announced that it will be compelled to halt passenger automobile production for one week, starting tomorrow, for lack of supplies.
LONDON, July 19 -- If the House of Lords goes on giving the British Labor Government "trouble," the Government will strip it of all power, Aneurin Bevan, Minister of Health, said today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 -- Anthony Henry Geuting, founder of the Geuting Shoe Company, one of the largest retail shoe outlets in the country, died today in his home here after a long illness. His age was 79.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 19 -- Demands for textbook revision to eliminate bias and an attack on compulsory military training were voiced by New York educators at the second annual Human Relations Conference held here today.

YANINA, Greece, July 19 -- Lieut. Col. Allen Miller, United States member of the United Nations Balkan subcommission investigating Greek border warfare, charged today that some of his colleagues were "merely trying to stall."

The largest meeting in the history of the chemical profession will begin here Monday, Sept. 15, when the American Chemical Society opens its 112th national conference, Dr. W. Albert Noyes, president of the group, announced yesterday.

LONDON, July 19 -- Not since last winter's fuel crisis has Britain's Labor Government run into such a storm of criticism as that aroused by the cut in newsprint imports. Even the reduction in the all-important English tea ration announced about the same time has stirred up less excitement.

LONDON (By Wireless). IT is all right, though somewhat ungracious, for a visitor to Britain to criticize the warm beer or bad cooking, or even to comment adversely upon the weather. This is regarded as fair comment and socially acceptable behavior, and a fair proportion of Britons will agree politely that these matters are managed better in France, South America or even the United States.

In spite of the record crude oil production, the petroleum industry is having considerable difficulty in supplying the unprecedented demand for its products. While indications are that the demand will be met with few exceptions so far as gasoline supplies are concerned, there may be some difficulty in meeting the huge demand for fuel and Diesel oils this fall and winter.
ALBANY, N.Y., July 19 (AP) -- State revenue is running $20,000,000 higher than a year ago, but no large-scale surplus should be anticipated, reliable fiscal sources said today.

BERLIN, July 19 -- Two young women, one British and one American, were held for twenty hours by the Russians last Sunday without food after they had inadvertently crossed the line into the Russian occupation zone.

GUESTS will receive photographic assignments, have their exposures developed and printed and the results judged for prizes at the Photo Hunt and Roof Garden Party to be held Aug. 2 by the Photo League, 30 East Twenty-ninth Street.

Heavyweights will return to the main bout scene at Madison Square Garden on Friday when Ezzard Charles, hard-hitting Cincinnati battler, opposes Elmer Ray of Hastings, Fla., in a ten-round battle. The fight will mark the local debut of Charles, who has compiled a formidable record in Western rings.

In London and Paris last week official statements were made indicating that European statesmen are beginning to realize that selfhelp through increased production and exchange of goods, even more than additional financial aid from America, is the key to world reconstruction and resistance to Communist expansion.

NORTH CALLAHAN, former executive officer of the Recruiting Publicity Bureau of the Army, editor of "Army Life," and supervisor of the radio program "Voice of the Army," has prepared a comprehensive handbook for those considering the Armed Forces as a permanent career.

PARIS, July 19 (AP) -- Miss Doris Hart of Miami, Fla., established herself as the second best amateur among America's feminine tennis stars today when she defeated Miss Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., for the second time this month to enter the final of the French international championship.

THIS is perhaps the least controversial book of the year. John Kieran contends that it is great fun to take a walk in the country, especially when you know what you are seeing. "Footnotes on Nature" amiably proves the point by describing the famously informed author's modest adventures afield, arranged roughly according to seasons and kinds of wild life.

The average American city has improved its tax-collection record for the thirteenth consecutive year, according to the annual survey of municipal property tax delinquencies made by Dr. Frederick L. Bird of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

THE photographer of flowers outdoors has other problems to add to those of lighting and arrangement and they are subject movement, distracting backgrounds and isolation of the subject. Indoors these matters are completely under the photographer's control; outdoors, he must rely on his ingenuity.

A survey of Navy scrap accumulations in the Pacific Ocean area show that 166,500 tons are available for return to the United States, according to a report made public yesterday to Secretary of the Navy James V. Forrestal.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The War Department is to have in Kenneth C. Royall, whose nomination was confirmed today by the Senate, a husky new Secretary of War who long has been in love with the Army.
TORONTO, July 19 -- Bobby Locke of South Africa today won the Canadian Open golf championship with a record-breaking 268 for the 72-hole tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The split in the ranks of "progressives" after the 1946 elections, chiefly over the Communist issue, continued to deepen today with a harassing effect on the Democratic high command's preparations for the 1948 candidacy of President Truman.

AN exhibition entitled "Eight Artists of the People" fills to capacity the small "Subway Gallery" of the Tribune Book and Art Center, at the southwest corner of Forty-second Street and the Avenue of the Americas. Only Director Alexan can tell how he crowded so many things into the space.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 -- Gov. Earl Warren's name was erased today from any list of friends of labor by the California State Federation of Labor, which supported him for re-election last year.
The next few weeks will be busy ones for both golfers and tennis champions. Two important championships will be contested starting tomorrow, followed by other title events the next week.

LONDON, Sunday, July 20 (AP) -- More than 4,980 Germans were shot, hanged or tortured to death in the reign of terror that followed the unsuccessful attempt to assassinate Adolf Hitler July 20, 1944, the British Admiralty announced today.

JERUSALEM, July 19 -- In a parting shot to the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine, the Palestine Government today made one of its bluntest accusations of broad Jewish support in the Holy Land for political terrorism.

Mayor O'Dwyer received late yesterday afternoon from William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, assurances that that organization would exert every effort to persuade 750 striking drivers and mechanics of two Queens bus companies to call off a sudden strike that deprived nearly two-thirds of Queens of surface transportation facilities.

SEOUL, Korea, July 19 -- Lyuh Woon-heung, chairman of the largest Leftist political group in South Korea, was assassinated here today. Exactly one year to the day from a previous attempt on his life, the popular leader of the Laboring Peoples Party was shot to death by a daring assassin who climbed upon the back of Mr. Lyuh's car and pumped two bullets into him.
