WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- Population experts have discovered a possibility that the intelligence of the American people is declining.

THE annual national print competition conducted by the Associated American Artists came to a close with the showing at the organization's galleries of about 150 of the many nundreds of entries. Three prizes of $1,000 each were awarded respectively to Stephen Csoka, Ivan Le Lorraine Albright and Luigi Lucioni, and ten purchase prizes of $200 each were also announced.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 19 -- Early rain and following thin fog did not stop 132 skippers from slipping their harbor moorings today and going out for the Huguenot Yacht Club's Long Island Sound championship regatta.

A definitive series of pamphlets interpreting sound mental hygiene for parents is being prepared for the New York City Committee on Mental Hygiene of the State Charities Aid Association. Written by Nina Ridenour, Ph. D., with the assistance of Isabel Johnson, the first eight pamphlets will appear on Sept. 1.

Rain and a water-logged field gave the Giants their second postponement of the week yesterday. It washed out the second engagement of their cuurrent series with the Reds at the Polo Grounds, thereby leaving only two games to be played this afternoon with the Cincinnatians before Mel Ott's men head for the West tonight.

COLUMBIA, S.C., July 19 -- Southerners generally and South Carolinians particularly are profoundly concerned over a Federal Court decision opening South Carolina's hitherto exclusively white Democratic primaries to Negro voters.

WHEN it comes to silver shopping, this year's brides have the advantage of their older sisters on more than one count. For the first time since before the war there are new patterns to choose from -- not merely different patterns but new designs with a truly contemporary feeling.
ST. THOMAS, V.I., July 19 -- A year-long observance of the hundredth anniversary of the abolition of slavery in the Virgin Islands will open on July 28.

IS the United States a nation composed chiefly of people who have not grown up, who think and act with the impulsiveness of adolescents? Many shrewd observers of the American scene, both abroad and here at home, are saying that this is indeed the case. They intentionally disturb our patriotic complacency.

Radio interference on the shortwave lengths, believed to have been caused indirectly by a huge sunspot now visible through smoked glasses, abated considerably yesterday so that most circuits again were operating in normal fashion, radio men said.

ATHENS, July 19 -- Faced by the probability that a Communist "free government," with a so- called "democratic army" of guerrillas will soon be organized in the mountains, many a Greek is searching his heart and mind as to how and why this movement beeame so powerful and so dangerous.

BOZEMAN, Mont., July 19 -- Republican leaders from Montana, Idaho and the State of Washington conferred here today with Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York on the national political situation. They reported that Mr. Dewey, who is in the West ostensibly on a vacation trip, was the leading candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination in the Pacific Northwest.
WHAT is the difference in standards of critical approach between road reviewers and New York critics?

LONDON, July 19 -- Appealing to the miners for more coal to hell build a better peace and to keep Britain "out of the money-lenders' grip," Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin said today that as far as he could see "there is no danger of another war in this generation."

BOSTON, July 19 (AP) -- Johnny Sain pitched his eleventh victory and third shutout of the season tonight as the Braves blanked the Pirates, 2 -- 0, to move into a virtual tie for second place with the Giants, two and a half games back of the National League leading Brooklyn Dodgers.

IN the Review of thirteen years ago this week: A front-page review of Harold Nicolson's "Curzon: The Last Phase," in which the English statesman's part in the last peace receives sympathetic treatment -- the spotlight being turned, as seems commonly done in those days, on the subject's psychological problems.

BAMBOOS are a fascinating part of the grass family. Many kinds thrive as far north as Washington and even around New York several of the hardier sorts can survive with protection. Bamboo plantings of long standing have been reported on Shelter Island and Long Island, and at Kingston, R.I., a Phyllostachys species is growing.

ALMOST all of I.A. Richards' many and fruitful works have been centered in the problem of communication. Near the beginning of his career, he wrote, with the psychologist, C.K. Ogden, "The Meaning of Meaning," which, though it has been superseded by more exact studies, was an early stimulus to interest in what has come to be popularly known as "semantics."

BALBOA, Panama -- Recommendations by the Senate War Investigating Committee to halt appropriations for the half-finished Inter-American Highway have focused attention on the 3,250-mile Texas-to-Panama route.

This is the season when songbirds are supposed to be too busy with family matters to give much time to music. But the catbird doesn't seem to know that. There may be those to say that the catbird isn't a songster, and dismiss the matter out of hand; but that's considerably less than the truth.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- The Senate unanimously confirmed tonight the appointment of Kenneth C. Royall to be Secretary of War. The confirmation was by voice vote.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 (AP) -- Backfield Coach Bill Howard has resigned from Ed McKeever's staff at the University of San Francisco and there is talk of end coach Perry Schwartz doing likewise.

Retailers last week were pressed to increase their orders or purchase their complete season's needs lest they find themselves with insufficient stocks to sell, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buyers.

CELL GROWTH -- The Sixth International Congress of Cytology held last week at Stockholm heard Prof. Paul Weiss (University of Chicago) expound his discovery that cells do all their growing in the immediate neighborhood of their nuclei, whereupon the new-grown living substance migrates to the outside of the cell.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, July 19 -- It was learned today in official circles that The Netherlands Government has decided to start military action in Java unless the Indonesian Republic accepts the Dutch proposals of July 15 and orders its troops to cease fire immediately.

Seventy years ago the medicos were telling the world that phosphates were good for the brain and that dull minds could be quickened if more fish, which contain phosphate, were consumed. Old people still talk about the benefits that spring from eating fish, but their grandchildren will pay more attention to the virtues of glutamic acid, which is one of twenty-odd amino acids.
DETROIT, July 19 -- Theo Dubois of the Winnipeg Rowing Club, who at 36 years of age was

NEW DELHI, India, July 19 -- The reconstitution of India's Interim Government into two groups, representing the Dominions of India and of Pakistan until these territories become independent on Aug. 15, was announced tonight by the Viceroy, Viscount Mountbatten.

Belated, but welcomed as always, Lloyd's Register of American Yachts last week made its first full-sized appearance since the war. Gin rummy and contract can expect to suffer until the skipper and all his shipmates have devoted countless hours in cabin or on afterdeck thumbing through its 786 regular pages, and its eight pages of addenda giving alterations and additions up to June 16.

NEWBURYPORT, Mass., July 19 -- A large business is being done by Newburyport retail stores with tourists anxious to take a look at the little Yankee town which, in April, made an attempt to really the nation to a stand against the upward spiral of prices.

Plans have been completed for a $260,000 garden-type apartment development at Randall, Pearsall and Long Beach Avenues in Freeport, L.I. Louis Marberg, president of the construction company, said work would be started at once, and the first units are scheduled for occupancy by the end of the year.

Under the management of the Kende Galleries of Gimbels, antique furniture and decorations, the property of Mrs. John B. Dennis of East Main Street, Oyster Bay, L.I., will be auctioned on the premises on Tuesday. The sale begins at 10:30 A.M.

An affiliation between Columbia University and St. Luke's Hospital, 421 West 113th Street, for the teaching of medical students, was announced yesterday by Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of Columbia, and Lincoln Cromwell, president of the hospital.

The Los Angeles Rams will furnish the opposition to the New York Giants, their National Football League rivals, in a pre-season benefit exhibition game at the Polo Grounds, Wednesday night, Sept. 17, it was announced yesterday. Proceeds of the struggle, which will mark the first home appearance of the Giants with a league rival, will be shared by the Hearst Fund for disabled veterans and other service charities.

THESE three books make a neat package: the first tells the reader exactly how he can go by car to see the natural wonders of the West; and the other two offer information and pictures to make him want to go. They will brighten the eyes of travel agents and stir the wanderlust in the most sedentary reader.

PROBABLY there is no legislative statute compelling a writer born in New Bedford to produce a story of the great old whaling days. But any close observer of historical fiction will tell you that the urge amounts to a natural law.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 19 -- Civic workers of Yonkers, who in four successive elections have backed Mrs. Edith P. Welty for member of the Common Council, expressed indignation today over the failure of the executive committee of the Republican City Committee to include her in its list of five Council candidates.

Manufacturers of ordnance equipment are "standing by" ready to meet Government demands for increased or altered production spokesmen revealed here yesterday, because recent events in Washington have convinced them that larger demands upon them facilities may be made within the next quarter.

HOLLYWOOD. THIS is an introduction to an old friend of yours. If you bumped into him on the street, actual experience indicates, you'd probably fumble vainly for his name, but would wind up definitely placing him as a man who was up at the lake two summers ago, or who ran a store back in your home town.

IT is fitting that the story of the 501st Parachute Regiment of the famed 101st Airborne Division should be told by a paratroop captain. The average GI never quite understood those strange infantrymen "whose wings and jump boots allowed them to raise hell with universal approval" in the back areas, and who seemed unsatisfied with the normal risks of soldiering on the ground.

DES MOINES, July 19 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan, defending champion from Toledo, Ohio, scrambled from almost certain defeat to advance to the final round of the Western amateur golf tournament today with a 4-and-3 victory over Thomas Sheehan of Birmingham, Mich.

THE dream of world empire based upon one civilization and one law has haunted the imagination of mankind from the days of Alexander the Great to the end of the Middle Ages. The poets of the Augustan age hailed the empire as the greatest promise of mankind and Dante looked back nostalgically to it.

A YEAR ago resorts and hotels were still seriously warning potential guests to be sure of advance reservations before starting out on a vacation or a motor trip. The situation in a number of areas is considerably easier this summer, although reservations are advisable, especially for the luxury hotels and resorts.

AS the Yankees go thundering along the trail, tearing the American League apart in a manner reminiscent of the days of Miller Huggins and Joe McCarthy -- days which some thought would never return -- there doubtless is more than one baseball observer remarking with gratification: "Well, it couldn't have happened to a nicer guy."

OF our major services the Army Air Forces are the most American. They are not, like the Army, founded upon German tradition; nor do they spring, like our Navy, from English custom. They are an American creation. Even their patron saint is a classical American, Billy Mitchell.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- From Mantoloking on Barnegat Bay north some forty miles to Long Branch stretch uninterrupted beaches which annually provide relaxation for many thousands of New Yorkers along with other thousands from more distant cities.

New York's marriage rate for 1946 was 13.4 for each 1,000 of population, compared with 9.4 in 1945 and 8.8 in 1944, according to the City Health Department's annual summary of vital statistics made public yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- Armed, the Calumet Farm's gallant gelding, catapulted to third place in the list of world's leading money winners today with an easy victory in the $55,500 Arlington Park Handicap before 30,000 fans. Armed earned $37,400 first money.

Metropolitan skippers are this summer making up for five long war years. They are cruising their heads off. They seem to be fairly wearing grooves in Long Island Sound, the Hudson, the Shrewsbury and down Barnegat way.

A LITTLE prize this department awards annually for the season's most literal-minded criticism (it was won last year by an advertising magazine's review of "The Hucksters") goes this time to Luigi Criscuolo, chief pundit of a locally published newsletter called The Rubicon.
FRESNO, Calif., July 19 -- The first formal step to make Henry A. Wallace a candidate for President in 1948 was taken today by a left-wing fragment of California's squabbling Democratic Party.

Competitive bidding as a mechanism of the new capital market is experiencing another breakdown -- its second major failure within a year. Its insufficiency this time, however, does not stem from the compulsion of bankers to renounce new commitments because of sudden impairment of capital, as in the market collapse of last September.

As a further step toward acquainting the public with efforts of the American Spaniel Club to bring the American cocker spaniel back as a field dog, a meeting was held at the New York Athletic Club last week. John J. Jacobsen of the Pentown Kennels was the host and Ralph C. Craig of Albany chief speaker.

IF you lived at Sereth in Bukovina, as the people of Leo Kate's novel did, the year of Our Lord 1907 -- and of the reign of His Royal and Imperial Majesty Franz Josef I the fifty-ninth -- was a hard year to understand. In America, the rich and far away, it was the year of hard times, when the uncle in New York or the brother in Pittsburgh stopped sending money home.

A FRENCH chef we talked with last spring advised using fresh tarragon in a particular salad dressing he had devised. Thinking of the many city people who never come within sniffing distance of green-growing herbs, we asked if the dried tarragon, the variety to be found in a jar on a grocer's shelf, might not do as well.
NANKING, July 19 -- Chinese and foreigners accept the Government's new mobilization measures with considerable skepticism, particularly the economic and austerity provisions.

THE great "sister act," delayed seven years by the vicissitudes of war, will make its bow on the North Atlantic the last day of this month. On that day the superliner Queen Mary, overhauled and rebuilt after arduous war duty, will sail from Southampton to join the Queen Elizabeth in an express passenger service the like of which has never been known in seafaring trade.

Adolf A. Berle Jr., state chairman of the Liberal party, declared yesterday that there was a strong feeling in New York and other states for the formation of a national liberal party. He added, however, that nomination of a national third ticket next year would defeat the Democratic nominee for President, presumably Harry S. Truman, and hand over control of the National Government to the reactionary wing of the Republican party.

"THE STEEPER CLIFF" is a remarkably interesting first novel. Its theme is man's struggle against fear. Lieut, Andrew Cooper, who is the central figure of the story, begins by asking himself: How well would I stand up under fire?

With two standout players from St. Bonaventure's fine team of 1946 added to the roster yesterday, Coach Tuss McLaughry of the Eastern College All-Stars, who play the New York Football Giants at the Polo Grounds, has filled out two important spots at tackle and halfback on the squad he will take to camp at Bear Mountain Aug. 17.

"REPORT on the Germans" is the latest addition to a growing list of apologias for what, since Mr. Byrnes' Stuttgart speech, has been the official American attitude toward Germany. Fear of Russia has engendered in many American hearts a desperate hope in the German people.

Last week the National Science Foundation bill slipped through the House without much discussion. The Senate passed its own bill by a vote of 79 to 8 a few weeks ago. Since the two bills are almost identical it would not take long for the Senate and House to iron out what differences there may be.
NEW ORLEANS, July 19 -- Huey P. Long was killed a dozen years ago, but his influence still is potent in Louisiana politics.
KINDERHOOK, N.Y., July 19 -- Columbia County's 137-year-old House of History, restored to its original beauty, was formally reopened today as a year-round museum.

Economic and Political The pattern of the now formally defined struggle between the West and Russia became clearer last week. In both the economic and political fields there were important developments affecting the "Marshall Plan" for Western Europe and the "Molotov Plan" for Eastern Europe.

PATERSON, N.J., July 19 -- The board of trustees of the Shapiro Foundation announced today the award of seventy-two scholarships in various colleges to residents of New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts, West Virginia, Maryland and Texas.
LONDON, July 19 -- It is becoming increasingly evident that the revival of the Ruhr industry must be the core of the Marshall Plan for the reconstruction of Europe.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Central Westerners observed this week that the zeal and optimism of the sponsors of the Wisconsin boom of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur for President on the Republican ticket in 1948 had reached new heights.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- The University of Illinois has been designated by the United States Public Health Service as the sole facility in this country for the manufacture of BCG (bacillus of Calmette and Guerin) vaccine by which it is hoped to extinguish the threat of tuberculosis in the United States in from twenty to forty years.

How various agencies in Evansville, Ind., helped to meet the housing shortage through the completion of a group of 278 permanent homes for veterans within a period of six months is related by Walter H. Dreier, Indiana director of the United States Savings and Loan League, in an article in the July issue of the Savings and Loan News.

MANHASSET, L.I., July 19 -- Mrs. Elsie Weston Stern, long active in Nassau County civic, political and social activities, and the wife of Henry Root Stern, chairman of the New York State Board of Social Welfare, died Friday night at Penwood, their estate here, after an illness of several months.
TOKYO, July 19 -- The ordinary Japanese citizen has a bill coming up for 70,000,000,000 yen, almost $1,500,000,000 at the current rate of exchange.

From Sete, a French port on the Mediterranean, a 4,273-ton former American excursion ship nine days ago stood out to sea. Her name was the Exodus 1947; her cargo was 4,500 European Jewish refugees. Her destination was Palestine. The Exodus 1947 was the biggest ship ever to attempt to run the tight British naval blockade of the Holy Land.

Forty-four million pounds of relief supplies, valued at $9,730,000, were shipped from this country to Jews in Europe in the first half of this year, Edward M.M. Warburg, chairman of the Joint Distribution Committee, announced yesterday.
Levitt Sons, Long Island home builders, have started production at the rate of twenty houses a day on their largest small-dwelling project.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Department of Commerce issued today a comprehensive and wholly revised study of the national economy of the United States since 1929. The survey provides figures on which President Truman's forthcoming economic appraisal for mid-1947 will, in part, be based.

PITTSBURGH, June 19 (AP) -- National Football League club owners will meet here tomorrow to weigh President Bert Bell's pet plan for a five-year schedule and to consider injecting a new type of "T" into the professional game -- television.

PARIS, July 19 -- After two days of discussions and at the very last moment under the time limit set, the Cooperation Committee of the sixteen-power economic conference adopted today a guiding document, which opened the way for the technical committees to start work.
At the direction of Mayor O'Dwyer, Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh opened yesterday a full-scale inquiry into allegations of police graft in Queens.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- Experts among ship operators predict that by next spring no more than 100 privately operated dry cargo ships will be engaged in domestic trade, compared to 400 before the war. Railroads and trucks have been gradually squeezing coastal and intercoastal water carriers out of business.

IN his autobiography, "Pilgrim's Way." John Buchan (Lord Tweedsmuir), when speaking of his reading habits, admits frankly to what many of us are reluctant to acknowledge. He remarks of the changes through which his taste in reading passed that they made "a sad tale, for it records a steady narrowing of interests."
NANKING, July 19 -- The reaction of thinking Chinese to the visit of Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, who is due to arrive in Nanking Tuesday, is threefold.

FIGURES on file at the Post-office Department show that the Philatelic Agency in Washington sold more than $26,460,000 worth of mint stamps and stamped envelopes during the fiscal quarter century which ended on this past June 30.

MICHAEL McLAVERTY is an Ulster schoolmaster who has written three good novels of Irish life. Clear and honest and beautiful as these novels are, his short stories are better. His novels lack momentum: the snowball of the narrative doesn't gather size and weight as it rolls along.

This fall, retail prices for women's apparel will not change from where they have been, on the average, but actual values will be enormously improved, Walter Hoving, president of Hoving Corporation, owner of Bonwit Taller, Inc., stated yesterday in an interview at his office.

RIGHT up to the outbreak of the recent war the two thousand year old fascination of life under sail persisted in the imaginations of all who knew even a little of the sea, though steam and Diesel had long since vanquished the windjammers.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 19 -- After prolonged debate, admission to the International Telecommunications Conference in session here was denied today to Franco Spain. Delegates from seventy-one nations are present.

ST. LOUIS, July 19 (AP) -- For their second consecutive game with Boston the St. Louis Browns appeared to be playing a man named Williams today as they dropped a 1-to-0 loss to the Red Sox, but Pitcher Earl Johnson's three-hitter was a contributing factor.
"HERMAN has taken to writing poetry." wrote Mrs. Melville to her mother in 1859. "You need not tell anyone, for you know how such things get around."

ATHENS, July 19 (AP) -- The Ministry of Public Order, disclosing the extent of the Government's crack-down against Opposition elements, reported today that 11,500 persons from all over Greece were now under arrest on political charges.

With strong enforcement of the fair trade powers given the New York State Liquor Authority promised for Sept. 1, competition among retailers in the metropolitan area has quietly assumed intensity short of price war proportions, according to reports here yesterday.

Workmen in the east tube of the Battery-Brooklyn Tunnel completed drilling a four-inch hole yesterday that constitutes the first connection between the Brooklyn and Manhattan tunnels now approaching each other under the East River.

The Atom Tempo Coupled with the familiar note of urgency there is what one might almost call a suggestion of humility in the second Los Alamos anniversary statement issued by the administrative committee of the Federation of American Scientists, including the name of Albert Einstein.
CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- A good demand developed for wheat on the Board of Trade today following trade advices that the Commodity Credit Corporation was inquiring for grain in the Southwest. Prices advanced nearly 5 cents and feed grains joined the upswing.
Department store sales by Reserve districts, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board, are listed in the following table which gives percentage comparisons with a year ago:

A step in the right direction is taken in the recommendations submitted to the President in a third interim report by the special board of inquiry on air safety of which James M. Landis is chairman. These recommendations are directed at the type of accident which has been relatively frequent among the accidents in commercial flight, involving what is officially called "collision with the terrain."

IT is always an arguable question how far a movie invades the mind of a person who sees it -- how much that person believes and how much illusion of experience or participation he carries away. Lay and professional psychologists have chewed over that one for years and, to the best of our acquisitive knowledge, haven't turned up a blanket answer yet.

BEVERLEY'S "History" is one of the delightful records of early Virginia which have long remained almost unknown except to specialists. Exciting reading came out of Virginia's first hundred years. The first accounts of discovery and exploration were written in the full flush of Elizabethan prose, and Virginia's later chroniclers were men of wit with a sense of style.

Many persons connected with entertainment, politics and journalism in Harlem attended a funeral ervice yesterday for Jimmie Lunceford, the orchestra leader, who died last Sunday in Seaside, Ore. The service was held at the Levy and Delany Funeral Home, 2250 Seventh Avenue.

The tattered and depleted hulk of the once great Normandie may make one more move before the last steel plate becomes scrap. On Wednesday the City Commission of Newark declined to extend for thirty days the contract terms between the Port of Newark and Lipsett, Inc., salvagers and wreckers, who are burning and tearing the ship down.

USHERED in with the enthusiastic publicity which customarily precedes the advent of network comedy shows, Johnny Wayne and Frank Shuster, a Canadian team, and Monty and Natalie Masters, working as the "Mad Masters," made their NBC bows Saturday, July 12.

THE title and subtitle of this book are likely to confuse the reader a good bit at the start -- particularly after he reads in Stuart Chase's foreword that: "Some day, not so far away in the Atomic Age, food, like air and water, is likely to go into the class of free goods."

Rocky Graziano has become the first boxer in history to win a title and still be able to say "We wuz robbed." For no sooner had the hard-hitting middleweight stepped into his Brooklyn home Friday, jubilant over having won the championship, than he learned that his clothes' closets had been ransacked.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial of July 16 on "Government Business" you used Howard C. Petersen's resignation from the post of Assistant Secretary of War as another example of the Government's inability to retain able men at the present level of salaries.

Rocky Graziano has become the first boxer in history to win a title and still be able to say "We wuz robbed." For no sooner had the hard-hitting middleweight stepped into his Brooklyn home Friday, jubilant over having won the championship, than he learned that his clothes' closets had been ransacked.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial of July 16 on "Government Business" you used Howard C. Petersen's resignation from the post of Assistant Secretary of War as another example of the Government's inability to retain able men at the present level of salaries.

DETROIT, July 19 -- Henry H. Reichhold, wealthy Detroit chemical manufacturer, who is a leading sponsor of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra and the Detroit Music Hall, today announced the formation of his own concert booking agency to combat what he termed the monopolistic practices of eastern bureaus.

BATAVIA, July 19 (ANETA) -- Indonesian Republican First Vice Premier A.T.K. Gani, in a statement issued here by the Republican Information Ministry, today appealed to the "common sense of the Dutch people and of the world" to avert "catastrophe" in Indonesia.
VIENNA, July 19 -- The United States Army's newspaper here flatly accused the Soviet Union today of intending to set up its own colonial system in eastern Europe.

ANOTHER young dancer has turned to choreography. Ruthanna Boris has just completed her first work, which if it all goes well, should be in the repertoire of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo when it opens its season at the City Center on Sept. 7.
New York State's answer to the postwar challenge for technically trained men and women at the sub-professional level has been the establishment of five State Institutes of Applied Arts and Sciences.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- The State Department today urged the Senate speedily to approve aid funds for Greece and Turkey, reporting that a guerrilla army was trying to "set up a stooge Government by force" in Greece.
Sigmund Romberg has had bad luck with the weather at Lewisohn Stadium. His concert was rained out twice there last summer, and last night the rain again bedevilled his program.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 19 -- The Catholic Daughters of America today set as their major charitable project for 1948 a program calling for the "adoption" of 2,000 needy families in war-torn Europe.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 19 -- The fifth session of the United Nations Economic and Social Council was opened today by Dr. Jan Papanek of Czechoslovakia. The chairman warned his colleagues that they had a special job at this session to convince those who were beginning to doubt the value of the United Nations.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 -- There is great concern in the agricultural valleys of California these days over the migrant worker who loads his family into his jalopy, and sometimes a limousine, and proceeds to follow the schedule of harvests through the Far Western States.

Financial markets moved cautiously last week pending the effects of the recent coal-wage increase on industrial production. Meanwhile, the tax question remains undecided, but the ultimate end will be no relief until next year. The change in public sentiment and among industrialists, against the possibility of a depression this year, seems to augur well for the immediate future.
BATAVIA, Java, July 19 (AP) -- The Netherlands Government at The Hague was authoritatively reported today to have ordered the breaking off of the two-year negotiations with the Indonesian Republic.

Builders meeting the demand for new homes in New Jersey are buying tracts to open new sections in their developments. One of the latest additions is a large tract in Carteret, adjoining Bast Rahway, where the Rapid Construction Company of Newark has just purchased land for 250 homes to expand its present project.

THE airplane, which in war has proved itself to be a formidable weapon and in peace a speedy means of transport, can also be an unmistakable and maddening nuisance. It can shatter the calm, disturb the peace and frazzle the nerves of householders, and a lot of people claim that it is doing just that.

With the waterfowl situation still uncertain and the subject of considerable controversy, the proposal to double the cost of the duck stamp is bringing out a volume of comment, pro and con, that is far too heated for this weather.

A LOT of farm journalists are uncertain whether farming is a business or an escape from business. But Lee Fryer, author of "The American Farmer: His Problems and His Prospects," avoids this dilemma. He knows farming is a business and a mighty poor one for at least one-third of the nation's farmers -- a business in which some two million families gross less than $600 annually and live in withering poverty.

LONDON, July 19 -- Six of the top leaders of Burma's Interim Government were assassinated and two were wounded this morning as the Executive Council was holding session in Rangoon, it was announced by the Burma Office here.

PARIS, July 19 -- In their embittered criticism of what they assumed to be Washington's intention of rebuilding Germany first, the French went so far today as to adopt some of Moscow's arguments against the Marshall plan and to suggest it might be wrecked by the United States policy toward Germany.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 19 -- Young Peter, Mrs. R.L. Gerry's consistent campaigner, ran down the stretch the fastest to win the Choice Stakes, the main attraction on the program of the Monmouth Park Jockey Club today. Piloted by Tommy May and assigned the heavy burden of 122 pounds, the Gerry thoroughbred overtook Wal-

THE extremely laudatory reviews accorded to the first volume of Granville - Barker's prefaces [reviewed here Jan. 26], made the reader of the book all the more aware of its limitations. Granville - Barker unhappily did not live to write prefaces to more than a handful of the plays, and those he did complete are of uneven thoroughness and quality.

Dr. Frank J. Curran has resigned as chief psychiatrist of St. Vincent's Hospital, Seventh Avenue and Eleventh Street, because of the failure of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York to clarify or repudiate an attack made on psychiatry by Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen, Professor of Philosophy at the Catholic University, Washington.

VASSAR -- Teacher Training Family and community living as well as problems connected with the teaching of children are combined in a newly developed teacher-training program now being sponsored by the Vassar College Summer Institute. Twenty-one young women from eleven colleges are taking part in the project.

BERLIN, July 19 -- A Heidelberg professor, a relatively young antiNazi who was recently reinstated after a twelve-year ban by the Hitler regime, had talked privately at length about the necessity for East-West amity, about the disastrous effects upon world peace of splitting Germany down the middle in a struggle between communism and capitalism as represented by the two great world powers.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- Three Senators who helped kill the $4,000,000,000 income tax reduction said today there still is a good chance that 1948 levies on 49,000,000 Federal taxpayers will be reduced.

OTTAWA, July 19 -- Puzzlement over the Canadian dollar position brought an outbreak of questions on the eve of the adjournment of Parliament Friday and drew from Trade Minister James A. MacKinnon the admission that the Canadian-United States trade position was becoming a matter of grave concern.
VIENNA, July 20 -- Austria's total grain harvest for this year will be considerably below last year's bad harvest, preliminary estimates of the Ministry of Agriculture disclose.

The Theatre Guild is said to be certifying the Eddie Dowling-Louis J. Singer production of "Our Lan'," due Sept. 27 at the Royale, to its subscribers, a procedure which will entitle them to buy tickets at less than the box office scale. The arrangement starts Sept. 29 and extends for two weeks through Oct. 11.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Congress, eager for departure, moved today into the scheduled final week of its session with the hope that morning and night sessions and a minimum of controversy would enable it to leave the heat of the Capital by Saturday.

Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen declared yesterday, in a letter to the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES telegraphed from Washington, that in a sermon March 9 at St. Patrick's Cathedral he had attacked Freudian psychoanalysis, but not psychoanalysis in general, and had described psychiatry as "a perfectly valid science."

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- About 1,800 former members of the international brigades that fought against Generalissimo Francisco Franco in the Spanish Civil War are joining the guerrillas fighting along the Greek frontier, it is learned authoritatively here.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Florence M. Kelley, in her letter to the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES in which she defends P.R., takes exception to the argument that P.R. is too expensive. She holds that a sum of $250,000, spent once every four years, is insignificant.

LENOX, Mass., July 20 -- An allMozart four-number program was presented this afternoon at Tanglewood before an audience of 2,600 persons by Dr. Serge Koussevitzky and a portion of his Boston Symphony Orchestra. Every seat in the theatre-concert hall had been sold weeks in advance, and the box office announced an overflow crowd of 1,400 on outside benches and the lawn.

PITTSBURGH, July 20 -- Steel ingot production, here last week was within striking distance of the rate in effect previous to the vacation coal mine shutdown. Production in the Pittsburgh area rose 6 1/2 points to 100.5 per cent from the revised rate of 94 per cent in the week before.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 20 -- Henry A. Wallace, in an interview with a correspondent of Tanyug, official Yugoslav news agency in New York, said he believed that "the Marshall plan delayed an economic depression in the United States."

LONDON, July 20 -- Anton A. van Sandik, manager of the Netherlands Trading Society, Amsterdam, said last week that if peace and quiet were restored, Indonesia would show a greater and quicker recuperation than Holland, owing to her natural riches.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The House of Representatives has voted, 319 to 61, in favor of a bill to test the "loyalty" of all federal employes.
One out of every five or six new leases binding tenants to "voluntary" rent increases is being rejected by the Office of Rent Control in Manhattan, it was learned yesterday.

Though Far They May Roam Millions of New Yorkers, the headlines say, cool off at the seashore over the summer week-ends. Uncounted New Yorkers go other places. But millions of New Yorkers stay on in the city and some of them take the air in Central Park, in very mid-Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Senator Owen Brewster, Republican, of Maine, urged Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson today to ban interstate shipment and marketing of potatoes infected by the golden nematode, a tiny parasite that saps strength from the plants.
MADRID, July 2O -- Heavy emphasis was laid on the "socialjustice" side of the Franco regime in recent days.

LONDON, July 20 (Reuters) -- The story of an ex-soldier in the Canadian Army, down on his luck in London, who masqueraded as a German prisoner of war and was "treated" by all for two days was told in the Sunday paper The People today.
The cruise liner Lady Rodney of the Canadian National Steamship Line will make her first post-war voyage out of Boston today.

Monogram Pictures Corporation will produce forty-eight feature films during the 1947-48 season, and Allied Artists Productions, Inc., the recently formed producing affiliate of Monogram, will produce seven during the same period, the companies announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The Treasury acknowledged today in a research analysis that the federal taxes on telephone and telegraph services "probably reduce demand" for those services.

Small tool sales are expected to increase during the third quarter because industrial buying has taken a sharp upward turn and industry-wide inventories are still inadequate to meet the expanded post-war demand, distributors and manufacturers revealed here over the week-end.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 20 -- The Big Four Section of the International Policy Committee of the CIO United Rubber Workers of America voted today to reopen its wage agreement with the Big Four rubber companies.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within, twelve months amount to $52,895,353,912. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Scarce items in marine supplies capable of immediate use by any boating or yachting enthusiast are included in current listing of surplus products offered by the War Assets Administration, Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director, revealed over the week-end.
ZURICH, July 20 -- Unofficial deliberations in London have clarified the attitude of Switzerland toward the problem of unrestricted convertibility of sterling.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 20 -- Thirty-five hundred engineers of the Southern Pacific stuck to their threat today to strike against the railroad at 6 o'clock tomorrow evening.
William D. Davies, chairman of the Joint Committee of Foreign Freight Forwarders Associations, declared here yesterday that existence of the industry was imperiled.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., July 20 (AP) -- Government prosecutors in the slavery case in which Mrs. Alfred Wesley Ingalls, 62 years old, was convicted last night will not press for another trial for her husband, Assistant District Attorney Betty Marshal Graydon said today.

NEW DELHI, India, July 20 -- The North-West Frontier Province, which holds the strategic Khyber Pass and the famous caravan routes from the Middle East, voted to join the Dominion of Pakistan in a referendum that was concluded yesterday, the Viceroy announced tonight.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 20 (AP) -- High winds plagued the cream of the country's pay-as-you-play golfers today in final practice rounds for the National Public Links Tourney which opens tomorrow, with a few of the boys losing pet clubs because of failure to conform with United States Golf Association regulations.

YANINA, Greece, July 20 -- The United Nations subcommission devoted today to a cross-examination of captured guerrillas and planned, despite Russian and Polish opposition, to visit tomorrow three points opposite Konitsa, where the invading force of some 2,000 crossed the Albanian frontier a week ago.
Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, conceded yesterday that garages could be built under Bryant Park and Madison Square Park.

Six-ton blocks of rock containing the fossil remains of tiny dinosaurs that lived in the United States 200,000,000 years ago are being carved out of a cliff in New Mexico and prepared for shipment here, the American Museum of Natural History announced yesterday.

DETROIT, July 20 -- The road trip that brought the Yankees coownership of the American League record for consecutive victories ended on a sour note today at Briggs Stadium. In fact, it was doubly sour, the league-leaders bowing twice, 4 -- 1 and 12 -- 11, to the second-place Tigers.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 20 -- While the Trieste Demarcation Commission is still working on a solution of the Free City boundaries, Belgrade is going ahead with plans to bypass the port.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, July 20 -- The press today deplored the announcement that the United States legation would close its information library following Congressional action on the State Department's budget.
Thirty-five crew members of the American tanker Newhall Hills, which lost her bow after a collision and explosion near the English coast on May 24, arrived here yesterday on the transport Ernie Pyle.

ROME, July 20 -- Blessed LouisMarie Grignion de Montort was solemly canonized by the Pope in St. Peter's Basilica today in the presence of a large crowd of the faithful with all the pomp and ceremony that the Roman Catholic Church reserves for such occasions.

In a ninth inning that developed into the rhubarb of all rhubarbs in Ebbets Field -- the terrain where that plant originated and flourishes -- the Dodgers yesterday came dramatically from behind to score all their runs and beat the world champion Cardinals, 3 -- 2.
Prices of cotton in the domestic market continued their upward trend during most of last week, with the July, 1947, contract reaching a twenty-seven-year high before it expired on Thursday.

Mrs. Marian C. Lukeman, the mother of five children, and Nicholas D. Volgare, a finance officer of a Long Island camp for children, were arraigned in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday on a charge of grand larceny in connection with operation of the camp.

PARIS, July 20 -- The violent opposition encountered by the Government's proposed statute defining the relationship of Algeria. to France may result in the postponement of the final National Assembly action on the statute until the fall session.

This summer's abundance of fresh fruits and vegetables is so unusually tempting that one is almost induced to abandon entirely meat, eggs and other such expensive foods and become a vegetarian. One of the most plentiful produce items is plums, offered in relatively large numbers and in rainbow hues -- yellow, purple, red.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 20 (AP) -- The General Electric Company local of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, refused today to restore to membership twenty-four persons who had been expelled on charges of holding Communist sympathies, and also adopted resolutions urging that Communists be barred from membership.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 20 -- Long Island Sound's long-standing record for the number of yachts in a regatta was more than shattered today. At least 387 craft were out in competition on the first day of the Larchmont Yacht Club's fortyninth race week. The old mark was 368 boats.

BATAVIA, Java, Monday, July 21 -- Dutch military operations against the Republic of Indonesia were launched with startling abruptness at midnight last night, but not until daylight neared was any sound of gunfire heard in Batavia.

Deputy Fire Chief Harold J. Burke, who was relieved of his command in the Bronx on June 20 and assigned to the limited service squad by Commissioner Frank J. Quayle, heads the list of three names certified by the Civil Service Commission for the post of Fire Chief, it was learned yesterday.

In a study released over the week-end, the New York State Bankers Association declared that the flat monthly charge imposed by banks on checking accounts "violates the fundamental principles underlying the determination of fair charges," and that prevailing so-called "measured service charges" should be "torn down completely" and superseded by formulas consistent with sound accounting and equitable treatment of depositors.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 20 -- Asserting "I am not a Communist, I am a peace-monger," Charles Chaplin today said he was sending a telegram to Representative J. Parnell Thomas of New Jersey, head of the House Un-American Activities Committee, accepting in advance of its formal receipt by him an "invitation" to appear before the committee in Washington.
The award of fifteen Rome Prize Fellowships, the first to be given since 1940, was announced yesterday by the American Academy in Rome, the New York offices of which are at 101 Park Avenue.

This is in the nature of a sequel to a piece which appeared here two weeks ago. That piece dealt chiefly with the peacetime deficits of the Thirties and with the Government's attempts to rationalize them by invoking one new budgetary doctrine or technique after another.

In a signed editorial in the current issue of The Liberal, official publication of the Liberal party, Adolf A. Berle Jr., the party's state chairman, charged that the first session of the present Congress "has turned in one of the worst records since the Civil War."
COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 20 (AP) -- Baseball Hall of Fame Day tomorrow will see the New York Yankees pitted against the Boston Braves and fifteen new plaques placed in the baseball shrine here.

DES MOINES, July 20 (AP) -- Staging one of the greatest rallies in the history of the tourney, Marvin (Bud) Ward defeated Frank Stranahan, the 1946 champion, 1 up, in a 36-hole battle for the Western amateur golf championship today.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Earl G. Harrison, former Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, appealed today for the admission of some of the displaced persons of Europe into this country as a means of stepping up European peace and order.
MONTVALE, N.J., July 20 -- Bees, beekeepers and bottles became entangled here today and what started out as a picnic and contest emerged as a form of minor masochism.

Five hundred of the 750 striking drivers and mechanics of the Green Bus Lines and the Triboro Coach Coporation of Queens voted overwhelmingly at 3:17 A.M. today to continue their two-day strike that has halted service on routes covering about two-thirds of the borough.

LONDON, July 20 -- Bombs weighing 25,000 pounds -- the biggest yet constructed -- will be used tomorrow by combined British and American squadrons in an attack on a reinforced concrete U-boat factory in Germany. As far as is publicly known, the largest bomb previously used was the 22,000pound "Ten-ton Tess" with which the Royal Air Force brought down the massive Bielefeld Viaduct in 1945.
ROME, July 20 -- Albanian Emigres here announced today that they had appealed to President Truman "to make free elections in Albania possible under the supervision of the United Nations."

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 20 -- Giving up an eight-goal handicap and outplaying its opponent for the first three periods, Bostwick Field's 25-goal team was unable to keep its forces together in the second half and dropped a 13to-10 decision to the All-Texas Palo Duro four in a semi-final of the 55,000 Handicap Polo Tournament at Bostwick Field today.

FORT DIX, N.J., July 20 (AP) -- Convoys of jeeps, trucks, halftracks and armored cars carried the 1,800 officers and men of the Fiftieth Armored Division here today for the first encampment of the New Jersey National Guard since 1940.

Contracts for new industrial plants in Argentina, Turkey and certain other countries have not been placed here because their foreign business agents do not have the "know-how" of doing business with American companies, and insist upon pre-war contract terms similar to their previous arrangements with British or German companies.

LONDON, July 20 (Reuters) -- Sister Elizabeth Kenny, the Australian nurse who won fame in the United States by her revolutionary treatment of infantile paralysis, said today that she might not be readmitted to the United States because of her criticisms of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

HIROSHIMA, Japan, July 20 (AP) -- The reconstruction of this first atomic-bombed city will halt on Aug. 5 for a three-day "peace festival." Citizens of Hiroshima will pray that the world will renounce war. The observance embraces Aug. 6, the second aniversary of the bomb burst.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On June 28 you published a letter by H.E. Priester, showing that Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, from 1933 to 1938 principal financial and economic adviser to Hitler, was by no means the "mastermind of international finance" which he is widely held to be, and warning that he should not be allowed a voice in the economic reconstruction of Germany.

The Giants topped the million mark in attendance at the Polo Grounds yesterday. They also toppled Johnny Vander Meer. But there was absolutely nothing they could do about a fellow named Ewell Blackwell.

The Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe, Inc., known as CARE, has been selected for a campaign by public service advertising to inform Americans of the European food crisis, the Advertising Council announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- The Athletics earned a split against the White Sox today by winning the second game, 7-4, after losing the first, 6-5, before a crowd of 17,905.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Basil O'Connor, president of the American Red Cross, announced today the appointment of Vice Adm. Ross T. Mclntire as director of the organization's new national blood program.

As soon as procedural and contractual problems can be solved, the American Broadcasting Company (WJZ) plans a revision of two of its late-afternoon programs embodying a departure from the accepted formula which dictates fifteenminute time segments designed to capture the ears of juvenile listeners.

The major portion of claims made by importers abroad on soft good lines stem from the desire to abrogate contracts made in a rising market, and are not necessarily the result of poor quality or unorthodox packaging, Max J. Lovell, director-counsel of the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers, declared over the week-end.
The spread of gang warfare on the Lower East Side was believed nipped yesterday with the arrest of three men, two of them ex-convicts, according to Deputy Chief Inspector Conrad Rothengast.
ST. LOUIS, July 20 (AP) -- The Browns scored all but two of their eleven runs today on circuit clouts, as they routed the Red Sox in a double-header, 4 -- 3 and 7 -- 6.

PITTSBURGH, July 20 (AP) -- The National Football League today adopted a rule prohibiting the signing of players who retain inter-collegiate eligibility beyond the time their classes normally would have graduated.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- The centennial convention of the Evangelical Lutheran Synod of Missouri, Ohio and Other States opened tonight with a service in Orchestra Hall here. Rededication was the keynote with an invocation to God to be present at sessions during the next nine days.

CHEMNITZ, Germany, July 20--The Russians are flying pitchblende, a source of uranium and radium, into the Soviet Union from a "forbidden area" in Saxony. It is being mined by tens of thousands of German men and women.

HENRI BOSCO, a French writer with a deep understanding of life on the land and of the spiritual relationships which that life can stimulate, has written, in "Farm in Provence,"* a fine and moving novel -- a novel that is also strange and somber. Winner of one of the numerous French literary awards, this is Bosco's first book to appear in English.

FRANKFORT, Mich, July 20 (AP) -- The 72-foot yawl, Royono III, skippered by John B. Ford Jr. of Detroit, led the fleet of fifty-seven craft in the 330-mile Chicago to Mackinac race as it neared Point Betsie, Mich., with 203 miles of the course behind.

People are not defeated by poverty but the loss of the meaning of life, the Rev. Dr. Frederick K. Stamm, minister of the First Congregational Church, Chicago, declared yesterday at the morning service of the Broadway Tabernacle, at Fifty-sixth Street.

"It is surprising how many adults, up-to-date, well-informed, mature in most fields, have niave and impossible ideas of God," the Rev. Dr. Robert James McCracken said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Riverside Church.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 20 -- According to Zagreb sources, negotiations are now going on in Rome for a modus vivendi between the Vatican and Belgrade, it was learned today.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 20 -- A workshop to provide further training for teachers of aviation subjects was held last week in the Rhode Island College of Education summer school under the sponsorship of the State Department of Education and the Civil Aeronautics Administration.

Bishop Austin Pardue of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Pittsburgh spoke yesterday in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. He asserted that it was easy to lose sight of the real purpose of the church, since "Satan's constant scheme is to sidetrack Bishops, clergy and laymen so that they will not spend time on the main issue of fighting evil in the individual soul."

CLEVELAND, July 20 (AP) -- The Indians defeated the Senators, 6 to 1, in the second game of a double-header today, after Washington had won the opener, 1 to 0, behind Mickey Haefner's five-hit pitching.

The result of an Rh factor blood test has been accepted as valid evidence by a Domestic Relations Court justice in determining that a man was not the father of his wife's child, it was learned yesterday.

JERUSALEM, July 20 -- More than 4,500 unauthorized Jewish immigrants who were deported from Hafia, ostensibly to Cyprus, are being returned to France, informed quarters indicated tonight. Terrorism in Palestine has spread, with one British soldier killed.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The virtual endorsement of President Truman for re-election by A.F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, only a year ago an avowed and outspoken political enemy, was considered here today a major blow to thirdparty planners.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20 (AP) -- The Cubs won both ends of a twin bill from the Phillies today, 4 -- 2 and 2 -- 1, before a crowd of 28,409 to run their string of triumphs for the season over the Phillies to twelve victories in thirteen games.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The CIO tonight branded abandonment of Republican plans to increase the minimum wage in this session of Congress as "an invitation to sweatshoppers to exploit their workers."

Neglect or misuse of God-given talents is one reason for "so much disappointment and frustration in the lives of men and women today," the Rev. Daniel J. O'Keefe of the New York Apostolate Mission Band declared yesterday in a sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- The national planning committee of the American Veterans Committee today unanimously adopted a resolution opposing "the unconditional financial and military support that the United States is giving the present corrupt and oppressive Government of Greece."
Week Ended July 18, 1947 Business in the foreign exchange market last week passed over without significance so far as rate variations were concerned. Only a light business was reported.

On many occasions the public has manifested its interest in and admiration for the work being done with "problem" boys by the Children's Village at Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. Boys referred to the cottage settlement by children's courts, social agencies and parents receive vocational and citizenship training for an average of eighteen months before they are graduated as ready to resume their rightful places in society.

BOSTON, July 20 (AP) -- Rattling out 16 hits, including nine off Left Warren Spahn, the Pittsburgh Pirates today walloped the Boston Braves, 9-1, before 15,675 paid fans in the last game of the current home stand, which ended with the Tribe having won six and lost seven.

ESSEN, Germany, July 20 -- The problem of reviving the Ruhr valley as a workshop for Europe is a much larger task, far more intricate, urgent and serious, than it appeared to most people in the United States just a few weeks ago.
Rebirth of the German and Japanese merchant fleets, forbidden by the Potsdam Agreement, is likely under a bill before Congress, the American Merchant Marine Institute declared yesterday.

MOSCOW, July 20 (AP) -- Prime Minister Stalin appeared in public for the first time this summer at a massive sports exhibition today and received an ovation from the audience of approximately 70,000 in Moscow's Dynamo Stadium.
Dismissed last week from a provisional job with the New York City Housing Authority, John F Keller denied yesterday that his activities as a city employe had been improper.

FRESNO, Calif., July 20 -- Robert W. Kenny and his group that launched a Wallace-for-President boom here yesterday will carry their fight against President Truman into the Democratic State Central Committee meeting in Los Angeles next week-end if any move is made to endorse the President.

Working at top speed at the order of Mayor O'Dwyer, Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh and James H. Sheils, his deputy, drafted yesterday the report of their investigation into allegations of police graft in Queens.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 20 -- Special consultations have been held this week-end between delegations of the United States, Russia, France, Britain and Colombia in an eleventh-hour attempt to reach wider agreement on the American proposal for a semipermanent United Nations Balkan Investigation Commission, it was learned today.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, which is celebrating its eightyeighth anniversary, reported yesterday that insurance in force with the company has reached a high mark of $11,245,834,492.

Flashing the best tennis he has played in the past several seasons, Ladislav Hecht of Kew Gardens reached the final round of the Eastern clay court championships at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday. Seeded No. 1 in the tourney, Hecht defeated Alexander Carver of Pelham in the penultimate round by 6 -- 0, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- H.F. Arthur Schoenfeld, former United States Minister to Hungary, reporting today on the situation in that troubled Balkan country in a nation-wide broadcast over the Columbia Broadcasting System, urged all Americans to follow the situation there "with careful attention."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A major calamity now threatens property owners because of the expiration on July 1, 1947, of the mortgage moratorium laws affecting apartment houses. Thousands of such buildings have been going along under expired or open mortgages.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Both British and American bombs will be used in the project, entitled "Operation Harken" and actually a resumption of the "Operation Ruby" tests conducted in 1945 and 1946 when United States planes dropped live bombs on Helgoland and non-explosive bombs against Farge, the War Department said today.

LONDON, Monday, July 21 -- Britain's embittered newspapers reduced themselves to the wartime size of four pages or cut their circulations this morning under Government orders. The measure was taken to save a Government expenditure of about u2,000,000 in dollars for imports.

Normal factors making for increases in productivity are now operating and such increases are anticipated, according to Solomon Fabricant, of the National Bureau of Economic Research. His statement is contained in a summary of a discussion by thirteen economists of "The Miracle of Productivity," released over the weekend by the National Industrial Conference Board.
A young policeman on duty in Brooklyn Police Headquarters' telegraph bureau came out of Sunday afternoon somnolence yesterday at exactly 4:14 with a start.

Members of the Board of Estimate, it was learned last night, still are fearful of the political consequences if they vote for a higher fare on the municipal transit lines. This will be one of the main issues to be threshed out when the board meets in executive session on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Poland, which refused to take part in the Paris talks on the Marshall plan, is attempting to persuade the participating powers individually that no stable peace could be expected if German industry were revived.

PARIS, July 19 -- Premier Paul Ramadier suggested toady that the Marshall plan for aiding Europe would fail unless the Soviet Union and its satellites were persuaded to take part. He said France would do her utmost to bring Russia back into "the place reserved for her in Europe" and would strive to prevent the United States and the Soviet Union from becoming enemies.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (U.P.) -- Commercial freight is moving over the Alaskan Highway for the first time since the road was built and maritime service has been resumed between Juneau and Prince Rupert, B.C., the Department of Interior reavealed today.

CHICAGO, July ,20 -- Grain markets fluctuated in a nervous manher on the Board of Trade last week, with the deferred deliveries of wheat and corn selling at new seasonal high prices before reacting under heavy profit-taking and liquidation which carried the markets off to well below the finish of the preceding week, both grains breaking around 10 cents from the extreme top before rallying.

Cola, Pretzels in Ad Hook-Up Advertisements featuring a new combination of Royal Crown Cola and pretzels will be placed in national magazines by Nehi Corporation in September, it was announced over the week-end. In line with this campaign a cooperative merchandising program is planned by Royal Crown Cola and the National Pretzel Bakers Institute to promote further the combination of the two products and the fact of their easy servability.

Activity in the wholesale markets last week was good, particularly in cottons and domestics, according to the reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Numerous buyers, the reports stated, were in town seeking specialized goods for quick delivery.

Orderly self-rule can never come to the Far East through the machine gun, either in the hands of assassins or of warring factions. The mass murder of almost the entire personnel of the interim government of Burma is a shocking reversion to barbarism and anarchy in a nation which had hopefully set foot on the road to freedom.

TOKYO, July 20 -- The Cabinet of Tetsu Katayama, Japan's first Socialist Premier, has had the briefest honeymoon period in Japanese history. Installed only two months ago, already it is under severe critical fire and there are widespread predictions that it will shortly retreat from a position in which no Cabinet could earn popularity.

LONDON, July 20 -- The stock markets here have lost a good deal of the buoyancy and activity that they so surprisingly displayed a week ago. The reaction, like the preceding advance, can be explained on the technical grounds that some of the factors responsible for the rise have ceased to operate.

Little Frankie Strafaci of Brooklyn won his third Long Island, amateur golf championship yesterday when he defeated Billy Dear, New Jersey ace, 5 and 4, in the scheduled thirty-six-hole final at the uphill, down-dale Pomonok Country Club, Flushing.

RANGOON, Burma, July 20 -- Burmese police have killed three followers of former Premier U Saw and arrested him and nineteen lieutenants in a raid in connection with the machine gun massacre of seven Burmese Council Ministers, including U Aung San, the de facto Premier, the Government announced today.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Trading in lard futures on the Board of Trade last week was fairly active, with commission houses on both sides of the market. The action of corn and hogs had considerable influence at times, especially the former, while packers and warehouse men were sellers hedging against the current market of lard.

WASHINGTON, July 20--The Special Senate War Investigating Committee has subpoenaed memoranda and other documents in the files of the late President Roosevelt in connection with its inquiry into war contracts, it became known today.

PARIS, July 20 (AP) -- Mrs. Pat Todd of Hidden Valley, Calif., came from behind to upset the defending champion, Miss. Margaret Osborne of San Francisco, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, today to advance to the All-American singles final of the French international tennis championships.
LAKE SUCCESS, July 20 -- The Security Council and other United Nations agencies plan to take a holiday during the last two weeks in August, it was learned today.

The House of Representatives has on its calendar today a measure which is of the highest importance in our continued cordial relations with our LatinAmerican neighbors. This is Representative Jonkman's bill, favorably reported last Wednesday by the Committee on Foreign Affairs, to re-charter the Institute of Inter-American Affairs for five years, combining it at the same time with the Inter-American Educational Foundation.

PARIS, July 20 -- Delegates from ten countries gathered in Paris for tomorrow's opening of the fourth congress of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women today attended memorial services for association members who were victims of the war.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Truman asserted today that the American economy was experiencing "unprecedented prosperity" and was currently "the richest and most powerful productive machine ever devised by the minds and hands of man."

LONDON, July 21 -- The synthesis of a group of substances that inhibit biotin, which is the most powerful growth vitamin in nature and essential for the growth of bacteria and higher animals, was announced today at the International Congress of Pure and Applied Chemistry.
LONDON, July 21 -- Events in Burma and Indonesia checked business in the stock markets here today.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Representative Eaton took sharp exception to a statement by Senator Tom Connally of Texas, ranking Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, who recently expressed doubt that the sixteen-nation Marshall plan conference in Paris could formulate a joint recovery plan.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- The Evangelical Lutheran Synod of Missouri, Ohio and other States has a membership of 1,564,000, the Rev. Dr. John W. Behnken, president of the synod, reported today to the centennial convention here, attended by 950 voting delegates representing more than 5,000 congregations.

PARIS, July 21 -- The French hope that United States Secretary of State Marshall or British Foreign Secretary Bevin or both will give them some reassurance regarding a limitation of German production before French Foreign Minister Bidault faces a critical Assembly in the foreign affairs debate Friday.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- War Assets Administrator Robert M. Littlejohn announced tonight that war surplus disposal has been brought "within sight of a sellout" in his one year in office.
The price of steel scrap rose yesterday $5 a ton in the Chicago area and 50 cents a ton in the Philadelphia district as industrial bidding for the material intensified.

Strength in the railroad issues failed yesterday to find sympathetic action in the industrial division as the stock market tended to the easier side. Major gains were sprinkled through the carriers, but the key stocks in the industrials faltered approximately a point and the composite rate declined by 0.57 point.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., July 21 -- Safecrackers blew open the safe in the Half Moon Art Galleries, 934 Boardwalk, early today and escaped with jewelry and cash loot valued by the owner at $250,000 or more. They left no workable clue for the police.

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 21 -- Delegations representing American, British and other foreign industrial interests were received today by Senator Charles S.F. Clarkson, Minister of the Interior, to direct attention to clauses in the Asiatic Land Tenure Act that seem discriminatory.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- A House commerce subcommittee suggested today that the Federal Power Commission meet with state regulatory bodies and electric utility representatives and try to agree on possible amendments to the Federal Power Act.
STOCKHOLM, N.J., July 21 -- Aerial Peeping Toms have appeared on the North Jersey horizon, flying and stunting at low altitudes over Rock Lodge, 220-acre nudist camp near Route 23.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Four steamship lines in the North Atlantic -Gulf trade asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to alter existing orders to permit them to increase rates.
HONOLULU, July 21 (UP) -- Frank Morgan, white-haired film actor, today became the first person ever to win the classic Californiato-Honolulu yacht race while fast asleep.

The breakdown of a freight train engine at the Port Washington station of the Long Island Rail Road yesterday morning disrupted service on the line for thirty-five minutes and caused much confusion among early morning commuters.

HALIFAX, N.S., July 21 (AP) -- The Miami Yacht Club ketch Ticonderoga became the first yacht to finish the Marblehead-Halifax yacht race tonight when she passed the Royal Nova Scotia Yacht Squadron's breakwater at 6:32 P.M. (ADT) after leaving Marblehead at 4 P.M. Saturday.

WASHINGTON, July 21--The Republican majority in the Senate, a worried eye on clock and calendar, sought means today to vote an investigation of Attorney General Tom C. Clark, pass other "must" legislation and end the session as scheduled on Saturday.

LONDON, July 21 -- Cheers greeted an announcement by Food Minister John Strachey in the House of Commons today that he had accepted the resignation of a food controller who, in a statement to German journalists visiting Britain, had singled out Jews as food black-market offenders.

JERUSALEM, July 21 -- Palestine's tenseness reached a new high tonight when it was learned officially that 4,500 unauthorized Jewish immigrants turned away from these shores on Saturday were being shipped back to France. Terrorists continued to strike throughout the day and there was a general feeling that the lid was about to blow off.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 21--While members of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine went sight-seeing in Damascus, arrangements were completed today for the presentation to the committee of the Arab states' views on the Holy Land problem.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 21 -- Residents of this area hailed "the fifth freedom" -- freedom from mosquitoes -- today as the Union County Mosquito Extermination Commission reported tests showed the pests definitely less troublesome this year.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 21 -- All real organized opposition to the Hungarian Communist-dominated Coalition Government will disappear tomorrow when the Liberty party will announce its abstention from the forthcoming general election and the further proceedings of Parliament.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Senator Hugh Butler, chairman of the Senate Public Lands Committee took charge today of a campaign to "free the Indians," acting for the ten tribes already officially pronounced ready to throw off wardship.

BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, July 21 (AP) -- A Catholic priest with a Communist party membership card in his pocket is fighting today in Slovakia to distribute 1,000,000 acres of Church land to the peasants.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 21 -- France today expressed "grave doubts" about the fitness of Albania to become a member of the United Nations. France supported Albania's application last year, when it was vetoed by Britain and the United States.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, July 21 -- With Dutch public opinion accepting or largely acquiescing for the time being in the military action in Indonesia, the Netherlands Government stated today that it was not yet prepared to resume negotiations with the Indonesian Republicans.

The Board of Superintendents of the New York public school system is studying a proposal to install public address systems in all city schools, it became known yesterday. The plan would make it possible for a principal to deliver announcements to all classrooms simultaneously.

MERIDEN Conn., July 21 (AP) -- Dr. Thomas P. Murdock of Meriden, a former president of the Connecticut State Medical Society, said last night that a national committee of which he is chairman planned soon to begin a yearlong study, the primary purpose of which would be to overcome the shortage of nurses.

PARIS, July 21 -- Senora Eva Duarte de Peron, wife of the Argentine President, arrived today from Lisbon. She was greeted by Foreign Minister Bidault; the Argentine Ambassador, Julio Roca; other Latin-American diplomats and Jacques Dumaine, chief of protocol in the Foreign Ministry.

The arrest of Richard K. Lukeman, 30-year-old director of Camp John Paul Jones, on Shelter Island, Suffolk County, was ordered yesterday by Assistant District Attorney Louis G. Andreozzi of Kings County.

The conviction of Henry Lustig, president of the Longchamps chain of restaurants, and two associates on charge of conspiring to defraud the Government of $2,872,766 in Federal income taxes was confirmed unanimously yesterday by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

Net earnings of the General Foods Corporation for the six months ended with last June amounted to $8,136,000, after taxes and all charges, Clarence Francis, chairman, reported yesterday. The net is equivalent to $1.46 a share of common stock and compares with $8,936,000 or $1.60 a common share earned in the first six months of last year.

SOUTH BEND, July 21 -- The special Outdoor Advertising School at the University of Notre Dame has been attended this year by about 100 plant operators and employes of many outdoor advertising firms in the United States, it was announced today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 21 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council, by a 7-1 vote, today approved Hungary's application for membership in the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. Since Russia still has refused to take part in the international educational agency, to date Czechoslovakia and Poland are the only eastern European members.

With the acquisition of Arthur Godfrey's talent scouts, the soapmaking Lever Brothers have put together a solid two-hour block of Monday night entertainment on the CBS hook-up, excepting an intervening five-minute news period at 8:55 P.M., under she aegis of Johns Manville.

Money Market Easier There was some inflow of funds into the money market from other districts yesterday. According to informed observers, the New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System started the day with $60,000,000 of excess reserves; Federal funds were about the same, and the money market continued somewhat easier.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 21 (AP) -- The narrow fairways and tricky greens of the Meadowbrook course kept all but five players at par figures or above today as 179 players toured the first eighteen qualifying holes in the national public links golf tournament.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., July 21 -- A world-wide food shortage this winter, principally attributable to flood destruction of crops in the West and the bad weather that retarded growth in the East, was forecast today by Merritt Hill, general sales manager of the Dearborn Motors Corporation.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 21 -- Well informed quarters expressed the belief today that the next move in the Communists' efforts to increase their stranglehold on Rumania would be an effort to restrict greatly the constitutional authority of young King Michael.

The long-prophesied comeback of the bluefish is beginning to show some evidence of being a fact rather than a hope, for reports from the Delaware to Sandy Hook indicate that these fish seem larger and more plentiful off-shore than they have in several years.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Gen. Douglas A. MacArthur won high praise today from an unexpected quarter.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- The first market-wide showing of department and specialty store merchandise by Chicago wholesalers and manufacturers since before the war will be held next month, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry announced today.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 21 -- Three thousand, five hundred engineers of the Southern Pacific Railroad went on strike at 6 P.M., Pacific Standard Time, 10 o'clock, Eastern Daylight Time, tonight, tying up more than one-third of the Far West's rail network at the peak of the harvest and tourist seasons.
