WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today withdrew the tariff schedule which it filed with the Federal Communications Commission several weeks ago covering proposed charges for its coaxial cables in television relay service.

Fur manufacturers with small capitalization had no means to combat the pressure of large buying combines except to adhere to rules of fair competition, Samuel I. Rosenman, attorney for the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, Inc., declared yesterday.

A general court-martial of a Navy non-commissioned officer on Charges of maltreating fellow prisoners of war in Japanese camps got under way yesterday in the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn. It is the first trial of an enlisted man on such charges arising out of World War II. A Navy officer was acquitted on similar charges last month.

Scoring his sixth consecutive victory, Ludek Pachman of Czechoslovakia increased his lead in the European zone championship chess preliminaries at Hilversum, according to reports from the Netherlands yesterday. Pachman, in the course of a Ruy Lopez opening, captured a pawn, but needed 71 moves to win from Max Blau of Switzerland.

World travel is a tool that will prevent future isolationism, Mrs. Ogden Reid, president of the New York Herald Tribune, told members of the National Council of Women at a tea yesterday in the home of Mrs. Ambrose N. Diehl, 280 Park Avenue.
PARIS, July 21 -- Small-scale recruiting for Communist partisan bands in the Greek fighting is probably going on in southern France, French authorities admitted today.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 21 -- With fifteen of the twenty topranking players of the country in the men's list, including six of the first ten, the fifty-ninth annual invitation tournament of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club began here today.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Truman sent a special midyear economic report to Congress noting unprecedented prosperity but warning of a necessity for some price reductions. He named an emergency board to attempt a settlement of the labor dispute on the Southern Pacific Railroad, accepted the resignation of Benjamin V. Cohen as counselor of the State Department and nominated Charles E. Bohlen to succeed him.

HALIFAX, July 21 (Canadian Press) -- After a week-end consultation on the French liner De Grasse at sea, two Canadian naval surgeons returned to hospital duties today, confident that the patient they left on the passenger ship had a 50-50 chance of recovery.

Success for the airports under the Port of New York Authority was predicted yesterday by Hervey F. Law, the Authority's new superintendent of airports, on his first day in office. He spoke in the Authority's headquarters, Eighth Avenue and West Fifteenth Street, where he will be until a permanent office can be prepared for him at La Guardia Field.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Irving S. Olds, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, tonight made public a statement in which he said that "Big Steel" or "Big Coal" did not dictate the controversial soft-coal wage contract signed with John L. Lewis.

Prices quoted by dealers at the Hempstead, L.I., Antiques Show, which opened yesterday afternoon, support their assertion that notso-rare antiques can be bought from 25 to 35 per cent less than a year ago. However, the rarer types of old-time furnishings, especially early Americana, show little recession from recent prices.
ROME, July 21 -- The United States today gave proof of its desire to help Italy by selling $184,000,000 worth of surplus property to the Italian Government for $18,000,000.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The House Committee on UnAmerican Activities took to the warpath against Henry A. Wallace anew today after testimony that Communists were "pushing" for a third party which he might head.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 21 -- In a smother of sails and splashing hulls, some of the former rainbow -hued, 375 craft today competed in the second session of the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week.

Example of Force It is recognized -- with sentiments ranging from smug satisfaction to dismay --that the new United Nations headquarters plant on our East River will have its outward shape powerfully influenced by that of Rockefeller Center.

Bus service on the struck Green Bus Lines and Triboro Coach Corporation in Queens was carried on yesterday on a limited scale under police protection as Mayor O'Dwyer criticized the strikers in strong terms and the union spokesmen lashed back at the Mayor in language equally bitter.

The Rev. Charles W. Hinton, who resigned last fall as rector of Christ Church, Cambridge, Md., and who was a former rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, L.I., died on Sunday at the Post-Graduate Hospital.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Excerpts from President Truman's Midyear Economic Report, transmitted to Congress today, follow: Foreword and Summary Americans today live in a richer and more productive economy and are enjoying its benefits more equitably than ever before in peacetime history.

BERLIN, July 21 -- The Russians are boldly attempting to kill off any leadership in minority parties in their zone that in any way opposes Russian policies. The first potential victim is the leader of the Berlin Liberal Democrats and the second is expected to be Jakob Kaiser, chairman of the Christian Democratic Union.

Mrs. Joseph F. Taggard, wife of a suspended Housing and Buildings Department inspector, qualified as an unusual type of housewife yesterday when she testified that she kept as much as $7,000 around the house for incidental expenses.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- At the suggestion of the Secretary of War, Maj. Gen. Leslie R. Groves, wartime producer of the atomic bombs, today issued a strong disclaimer of reports that he sought to discredit the United States Atomic Energy Commission.
VIENNA, July 21 -- United States military and diplomatic representatives here are seeking a compromise with the Russians on their objections to the United StatesAustrian relief agreement.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 21 -- Surrogate Frederick S. Quinterro of Dutchess County today decided that the late President Roosevelt made a valid and effective gift to the United States Government of all his papers and files, including those in his possession at the time of his death.

PITTSBURGH, July 21 -- Glendinning Keeble, former director of the College of Fine Arts, Carnegie Institute of Technology, died in New York at the Hospital for Joint Diseases yesterday of a stroke at the age of 60.

LONDON, July 21 -- With every prospect of a "very ample" grain crop this year, the Soviet Union is in a good position to use the surplus to help satellite countries in eastern Europe, Paul F. White, chief of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration's mission to the Ukraine, said today in London on his way back to Washington after winding up the UNRRA's activities in the Soviet Union.

The best chance for a peaceful solution of the problem of colonialism in Southeast Asia was rapidly being dissipated in Indonesia last night as Dutch Army, Navy and Air Force units moved against Republican Army positions in Java and Sumatra. The Dutch, with complete command of the air, using modern American-made P-51 Mustang fighters and B-25 Mitchell bombers, and vastly superior tanks, artillery and small arms, also largely Americanmade, apparently were meeting little effective resistance.
PARIS, July 21 -- A breakdown by countries of French foreign trade statistics for the first six months of 1947 shows the predominant part played by the United States in French commercial exchanges.

Store Sales Here Up 17% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 17 per cent last week over the comparable week last year, according to the "flash" report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday. In the previous week a rise of 10 per cent was reported, while for the four weeks the grain was 9 per cent.

Before the season's record crowd, 35,092, the Dodgers pulled out another one in the ninth inning to sweep a double-header with the Reds, 7 -- 4 and 4 -- 3, at Ebbets Field yesterday and started their Western tour last night holding a four-game lead over the second place Giants.

J. Warren Kinsman, general manager of fabrics and finishes department, and a member of the board of directors of E.I. Du Pont de Nemours Co., has been elected a vice president and designated as a member of the executive committee, it was announced yesterday following a board meeting held in Wilmington.
LONDON, July 21 -- The British Foreign Office and the Americans in the United States Embassy here sat back today with a feeling of helpnesses as they read the bad news from Batavla.
The regional Office of Rent Control said yesterday that leases embodying "voluntary" rent increases would not be ruled invalid merely because they superseded unexpired leases at lower rentals.

Short purchasing commitments by virtually all 745 attending buyers featured the opening yesterday of the twenty-second summer Lamp Show in the Hotel New Yorker. Orders placed covered store needs, in most cases, for only sixty days at the outset, and retailers' representatives reported that they are held to close buying by strict inventory limitation and multiple turnover requirements.

Pickets were back on duty yesterday morning in front of the main office of the Brooklyn Trust Company, 177 Montague Street, Brooklyn, after a week-end recess. After a mass demonstration a token force of pickets remained on the line, supervised by twenty-five patrolmen.

A revised 1947 American Football League schedule of thirty-five games was announced yesterday by Joe Rosentover, president of the circuit. The revamped schedule was necessitated by the recent withdrawal of the Akron Bears. Long Island and Paterson will meet on Sept. 21 in the opening game of the league season.

BATH, Me., July 21 (AP) -- This small port on the Kennebec River, which launched the New World's first ship and helped to turn out the nation's might in destroyers for the Navy in both World Wars, began today a six-day celebration of the 100th anniversary of its City Charter.

Warehouse inventories of steel in the metropolitan area have taken a downward turn and present stocks are now from 15 to 25 per cent lower than at any time since the coal strike, Charles Kramer, executive secretary of the New York Chapter of the American Steel Warehouse Association, Inc., revealed here yesterday in an interview.

Copper accessories designed for use rather than for ornamentation alone are now being fashioned by modern craftsmen for contemporary interiors. The beauty of the metal, however, is not neglected in the functional pieces.

Notwithstanding President Truman's warning on inflationary tendencies, cotton futures yesterday surged ahead to new high ground for the life of the deliveries. The list on the New York Cotton Exchange closed moderately lower than the best levels, but with net advances of 42 to 63 points, the far deliveries showing the greatest strength.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The House broke a series of delaying actions by Southern Democrats today and passed, for the fourth time in five years, a bill to knock out the poll tax voting requirement in national elections. The vote was 290 to 112.

ESSEN, Germany, July 21 -- Fundamental differences among the major Western Powers -- first over who shall manage and second over who shall own Germany's mines -- are holding up the revival of the Ruhr Valley.

The racing crowd went to Saratoga yesterday -- Saratoga-on-theLong Island Railroad. With the first part of the Spa meeting listed for the Jamaica track through the courtesy of the Metropolitan Jockey Club, the fact that the quaint points of interest of the upstate town were missing made little difference to the 20,895 fans on hand.

NANKING, July 21 -- Continued Chinese patience in handling the Sinkiang problem, despite the seriousness of the situation there, counseled by Gen. Chang Chihchung, commander of military headquarters in northwest China.

TOKYO, July 21 -- Japan intends to make no representations to the eleven-nation conference proposed by the United States for this fall as a preliminary to a Pacific peace treaty, Premier Tetsu Katayama asserted in an interview today.

The National Federation of American Shipping, representing the American shipping industry, has protested to the Congressional committee considering the Independent Offices Appropriation Bill that an amendment would allow sale of war-built ships at "cut-rate prices," it was announced yesterday.

The selection of a new Fire Chief went through a see-saw performance yesterday when Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle referred the question to Mayor O'Dwyer, and the Mayor referred it right back to the Fire Commissioner for decision.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 23 (AP) -- Abner Doubleday's old home town of his school boy days honored baseball's greats of yesteryear by unveiling fifteen new plaques in the Hall of Fame today and then turned out some 12,000 strong to watch the hot shots of 1947, the Yankees, drop a 4-3 decision to the Braves in a 10-inning exhibition game.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The United States Government regrets that peaceful negotiation has given way to armed force in the effort to effect "voluntary association between The Netherlands and the Indonesian peoples," the State Department said in a prepared statement issued today.

CODY, Wyo., July 21 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York visited the Heart Mountain reclamation project near here today and was told that the entire reclamation program, by which thousands of arid acres are being converted into tillable farm land through irrigation, was vital to the future prosperity of large areas of the West.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee recommended today that Philip B. Perlman of Maryland be confirmed as Solicitor General, a post to which he had been nominated by President Truman almost six months ago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 21--"The Turquoise," Anya Seton's novel about Santa Fe, N.M., which Warner Brothers acquired for the screen in 1945 and subsequently shelved, has been revived, and Harry Brown, who has joined the studio as a contract scenarist, has been named to prepare a new screen adaptation of the story.

First announcement of a change in policy in Sweden which now permits exportation of ball bearings to the United States for the first time since 1946, was made here yesterday by Commander Gustav Christiansen, export and import manager of Owensen and Company, Inc., of New York and Stockholm.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 21 (AP) -- Cara Mia, 53-foot sloop skippered by Leland L. (Olie) Karas of Chicago, today was declared winner of the fortieth annual 330-mile Chicago-to-Mackinac race.

PITTSBURGH, July 21 (AP) -- The Phils batted around in the first inning to score six runs, then went on to take an 8-1 victory over the Pirates tonight behind the veteran knuckleball artist Dutch Leonard.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations today announced an International Committee of Nutritionists from twelve countries to meet here July 23 to 26 to advise the International Children's Emergency Fund on how to get the most nutrition for the least money.

Dishwashing is among the dreariest words in the English language. It denotes monotony from which there's no escape except dining out, eating from paper plates or hiring a maid. Because all three are impractical for many families, the question arises, "What about a dishwasher?"

As the Queens grand jury prepared to open today its full-scale inquiry into allegations of police graft in that borough, local church and civic leaders announced yesterday that they planned to ask Governor Dewey to intervene "if it looks like a quick whitewash."

O. John Rogge, defense counsel for the sixteen board members of the Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee recently sentenced for contempt of Congress, explained last night that the group's records were withheld from the House Committee on Un-American Affairs to protect not only the group's contributors but relatives in Franco Spain of those receiving relief.

Jose Ferrer, appearing in a lastminute engagement at the Suffern, N.Y., County Theatre to fill a sudden booking gap, was being called upon late last night to play the role of the good Samaritan twice within two weeks. An emissary of the Company of Twelve, Inc., journeyed to Suffern with an appeal to Mr. Ferrer to star next week in a vehicle at the City Center.

PARIS, July 21 (AP) -- Mrs. Pat Canning Todd of Hidden Valley, Calif., rated the fourth-best woman amateur tennis player in the United States since Miss Pauline Betz turned professional, took over the top place in the scramble for feminine court honors today by winning the French championship.

Security dealers participating in the recent flotation of bonds by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development are being asked to account for the distribution of the bonds by states, countries and types of customers, it was learned yesterday.

A proposal that legislation be introduced to prevent the return of fashion "piracy," which he said nearly "wrote finis" to the dress industry during the early Thirties, was made yesterday by Maurice Rentner, American designer.

Operating costs and a shortage of nurses have compelled Mount Sinai Hospital to cut operating room schedules and to reduce the number of available beds, the institution's 1946 report indicated yesterday.

Legislatively the House passage of an anti-poll-tax bill yesterday does not mean a thing. The bill will not reach the floor of the Senate, and if it did it would be killed by filibuster. The House has passed such bills before -- in 1942 by a vote of 254 to 84; in 1943 by a vote of 265 to 110; in 1945 by a vote of 251 to 105.

As was to be expected, the decision of the Western Powers to proceed with the Marshall Plan after Russia had rejected it has prompted a Russian counter-offensive which is assuming more concrete forms than a mere propaganda barrage against the United States.

Betting at New York race tracks, with the halfway mark of the 1947 season just a few days away, is running $27,041,806 -- more than 12 per cent -- behind last year. Attendance is taking a drop of 164,993, a survey yesterday by The Associated Press shows.

CHICAGO, July 21 (API) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 8,000; total 12,000; general market on butchers fairly active and uneven; 25 to 75 cents higher. Sows mostly 50 to 75 cents up.

LONDON, July 21 -- The British Government's desire to have the United States bear the bigger share of the burden of supporting the population of the Ruhr is understood to have been emphasized by Foreign Secretary Bevin in a long talk with Lewis W. Douglas, United States Ambassador in London, at the Foreign Office today.

VIENNA, July 21 -- The Minister of the Interior sent a representative tonight to the International Refugee Organization's meeting in Lausanne to report the increasingly alarming refugee and displacedperson situation here.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., July 21 -- Extremely trying conditions were met by the field of eighty-nine in the eighteenth annual women's New York State golf championship at the Leewood Country Club today. Surmounting the obstacles created by heavy fairways and tricky greens, the defending champion, Mrs. R.M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley, took the qualifying medal with a score of 41, 39 -- 80.

Dr. Lawrence S. Kubie, chairman of the public education committee of the New York Psychoanalytic Institute, declared last night that Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen had ignored repeated requests on the part of psychoanalysts to gain a clear understanding of his views on psychoanalysis following his sermon attacking Freudian psychoanalysis on March 9 in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Nearly two hours spent in closed conference with Secretary of State Marshall, today, appeared to have brought members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee to two principal conclusions.

Meeting bankers, foreign trade association and company representatives at the regional office here of the United States Department of Commerce yesterday, Prince Saif al-Islam Abdullah of Yemen announced intention to purchase equipment for building roads, electrical plants and harbor facilities, including, possibly, harbor rail equipment, during his 20-day visit in this country.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- In his special economic report to Congress today President Truman listed these as key factors in the situation at midyear: Jobs -- Despite full employment conditions there has been "some weakening of demand for labor," especially in textiles, clothing, leather and electrical machinery.

Controller Lazarus Joseph returned from a Lake George vacation yesterday and visited Mayor O'Dwyer at City Hall as the Board of Estimate prepared for a fourth executive session on the higher transit fare tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The resignation of Benjamin V. Cohen as counselor of the State Department was accepted today by President Truman, to be effective on July 31. Charles E. Bohlen, the department's leading expert on the Soviet Union, was nominated to succeed him.
LONDON, July 21 -- Herbert S. Morrison, Lord President of the Council, told Britain's new Economic Planning Board today at its first meeting that it should be "the eyes and ears of the Government."

Congress could do much to insure the success of the forthcoming InterAmerican Security Conference, which is scheduled to convene at Rio de Janeiro within a month, by quick consideration and passage of the InterAmerican Military Cooperation Act. The House Foreign Affairs Committee has reported it favorably.

NEW DELHI, India, July 21 -- The Indian Constituent Assembly received the report of the Union Constitution Committee today. It recommended that the Dominion of India be set up as a "sovereign, independent republic" with a President, Council of Ministers and a bi-cameral legislature.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The roll call vote by which the House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill to prohibit collection of a poll tax as a voting prerequisite in elections for Federal offices was as follows:

A THIN-faced youth with a mop of flaxen hair passed through our town the other day and there was hardly a ripple of interest over his coming and going. He arrived on the same boat with John B. Kelly Jr., and all the hurrahs were for the winner of the Diamond Sculls.

While thirty policemen blocked exits, detectives and witnesses of a jewelry store hold-up searched the Bushwick RKO Theatre at 1396 Broadway, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. They found and arrested two suspects and recovered the loot, twelve wedding rings valued at $600.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 21 -- Theodore Heba, Albanian liaison officer with the United Nations Balkan Commission, today agreed to transmit to Tirana, Albania, a request by the commission's subsidiary group for permission to investigate frontier incidents in Albanian territory.

GENEVA, July 21--The first big step to reconcile the world trade charter with moves toward the economic integration of Europe under the impetus of the Marshall challenge will be taken at the Geneva Trade Conference tomorrow.

BATAVIA, Java, Tuesday, July 22--Dutch ground forces struck against the Indonesian Army and guerrilla forces at several undisclosed points on Java and Sumatra today as the second day of Dutch "police" action opened under weather conditions ideal for aircraft and armored units.

The Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company of New Jersey has purchased the sixtyfamily twin garden apartment units in Englewood, N.J., known as the Tracey Gardens and the Chester Gardens, from a New York investor who acquired the property about a week ago.
Indications that Martin Bormann and his wife may be dead came to light here yesterday.

The Council of Economic Advisers was created by Congress last year for the purpose of assisting the President in the formulation of reports on prevailing economic conditions, together with such recommendations as it might deem advisable. The theory of these recommendations is that they should constitute a framework and guide for legislation.
NANKING, July 21 -- The new Chinese Army Division Training Center, where Chinese divisions will be trained along American lines, will be in Formosa. It is scheduled to start late in August.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 21 -- The seizure of authorized atomic plants by an outlaw nation, rather than clandestine operations, constitutes the greatest danger of evading international control, an informal working group reported today to the Control Committee of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission.

The Stadium debut of Hans Schwieger as conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony, in a program which featured Alec Templeton, pianist, was cut short by rain last night. The program, committee, apparently adept at dealing with weather problems, changed the order to permit Mr. Templeton to play his own composition, "Concertino Lirico," before bad weather dispersed the audience of 6,500.

SEOUL, Korea, July 21 -- Col. Gen. Terentyi F. Shtikov, chief of the Soviet delegation to the Joint United States-Soviet Commission for Korea, denied today that the Russians were attempting to exercise a veto on the board's efforts.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 22 (AP) -- Four American women prepared to return to the United States today after an eight-week visit to Germany during which, they believe, they convinced at least some Germans that corn is food for people as well as livestock.
Brisk activity In the development of low-rent public housing was reported yesterday by Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (U.P.) -- Helen Reid Bryan, executive secretary of the Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee, testified today that she had paid more than $6,100 to Gerhart Eisler since 1942 in checks made out to "Julius Eisler."

James L. Fly, who has been arbitrating issues between the American Communications Association, CIO, and operators, awarded wage increases yesterday to radio officers aboard East and Gulf Coast tankers, raising their monthly pay from $240.75 to $288.45.

A Jersey cow that was inseminated artificially on an Australian farm, recently calved and the sire is a prize-winning Jersey whose sperm was flown to Australia from the Pennsylvania farm of Thomas Erwin, Mr. Erwin said here yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 -- New corporate securities offered for cash in April, 19,47, aggregated $449,000,000, about the same amount as was offered in March, the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today in its monthly statistical bulletin.

The Dutch Colonial Government of the Netherlands Indies began last Sunday midnight large-scale military actions against the Republic of Indonesia on the ground that the Republican Government was unable to implement a truce signed last October or the Agreement of Linggadjati.

The Office of Rent Control, seeking to forestall "unnecessary friction between landlords and tenants" in hotels and certain other rented dwellings, detailed yesterday the steps by which owners of seven types of housing might become eligible for freedom from Federal rent controls.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Suggestions for alterations in basic criminal procedure to permit the effective prosecution of men breaching the atomic secret, without at the same time compromising the secret itself, were submitted today to the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The late President Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harold L. Ickes, former Secretary of the Interior, declined to have a South Polar Sea and mountain range named in their honor, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The United States, at the request of Great Britain, has relaxed a nondiscrimination clause of the $3,750,000,000 British loan agreement so as to permit her to conserve her dollar supply, it was learned today.
The world-famous Roman Singers of Sacred Music, more popularly known as the Vatican Singers, will be welcomed officially by New York next Wednesday, it was announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 -- A strike of 3,500 locomotive engineers against the Southern Pacific Railroad and two of its subsidiaries was "postponed indefinitely" at 1 o'clock this morning, Pacific Standard Time (6 A. M. Eastern Daylight Time), seven hours after it began.

Four speakers appeared to agree that nobody really will know what the Taft-Hartley Act means until interpretations of the law have been made by its official administrators, according to members of the Trade and Commerce Bar Association who attended a forum discussion of the law yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt.

BATAVIA, Java, Wednesday, July 23 -- Rocket-firing Dutch planes made fifteen attacks yesterday on the northern Java coast port of Cheribon, the Indonesian Army said today, as Dutch seaborne invasion forces captured large segments of eastern Java.

In the first suit filed in Federal Court here under the Taft-Hartley Act, the Independent Fur Manufacturers Association asked $500,000 damages yesterday against the Furriers Joint Council of New York, a federation of Congress of Industrial Organizations fur unions, and the Fur Wholesalers Association of America, Inc., an organization of fur jobbers.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- The wage dispute between the railroads and the heads of seventeen non-operating railroad labor unions, under discussion for more than a month, appeared today to be headed toward a review by an arbitration board.

ARCOLA, N.J., July 22 -- The stage was all set tonight for the playing of the annual triangular team golf matches at the famous Arcola Country Club tomorrow, with teams representing New Jersey, last year's winner, Long Island and Westchester mixing it in singles and foursomes.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The House today assigned two investigating bodies, staffed by fortyfour Representatives, to spend much if not all of the adjournment period in following United States foreign policy, and the dollars required to finance it, to the four corners of the earth.

Harold J. Burke, deputy fire chief who placed first in a civil service examination for chief of department last February, was appointed yesterday to the $11,500 post by Frank J. Quayle, Fire Commissioner.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today a new rule, N-17A-4, under the Investment Company Act. It exempts from Section 17 (A) transactions presumably based upon "arm's length" negotiations.

MOSCOW, July 22 (U.P.) -- Lord Burghley, president of the International Amateur Athletic Federation, said today he believed the Soviet Union soon will join the organization, paving the way for participation in the 1948 Olympics in London.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 (AP) -- The Athletics spotted the Cleveland Indians three runs in the first inning tonight, then bounced back to score a 5-to-3 victory before a crowd of 15,749 at Shibe Park. The triumph tightened Philadelphia's hold on fourth place.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 22 -- The Sister Kenny Foundation has contracted to buy Poplar Hill, the Frederic B. Pratt mansion and estate here, for a hospital for non-infectious poliomyelitis cases, it was learned today.

TOKYO, July 22 -- Labor's long truce with the Government appears near its end. Ever since Gen. Douglas MacArthur banned the February general strike the unions have been docile, but the decline in real wages and the plan for dropping useless workers are making the work of agitators far easier.

LONDON, July 22 -- In "Peace in Our Time," which opened tonight, Noel Coward has written a play which can hardly fail to be a smash hit in London. He answers that question which every Briton has been asking himself ever since the Battle of Britain: If the battle had been lost, what would life have been like in occupied Britain?

The Organization for Rehabilitation through Training is preparing Jewish refugees for life in Palestine at a farm school in England, Mrs. William J. Borkovitz of Winnetka, III., president of the American ORT Midwest region, said yesterday in the Hotel Barbizon-Plaza.

Now, as the season begins when fresh fruit and vegetables from near-by orchards and gardens reach the peak of their abundance, home freezing operations are getting under way. Answers to some of the questions that our readers have asked us in connection with this method of preserving food are discussed here today.
Robert C. Benchley, actor, author and editor, who died Nov. 21, 1945, left a net estate of $60,353. according to schedules filed yesterday with Surrogate Charles H. Griffiths in Westchester County.

PARIS, July 22 -- Coordination with the United Nations and other international organizations was approved today toy the economic conference's executive committee | and submitted to the cooperation committee for adoption.
NANKING, July 22 -- Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer began his fact-finding mission to China and Korea tonight at informal talks with American Embassy officials.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., July 22 -- Patrolman James Sacco, 42 years old, of the Palisades. Interstate Park Police, rescued a 14-year-old boy in the Hudson at the foo of the Palisades this afternoon, almost paying with his own life for his courage.
New York Harbor gave the French liner De Grasse a full-dress reception when she arrived here yesterday from Le Havre and Southampton.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Carroll Reece, Chairman of the Republican National Committee, asserted today that a full investigation of what he called "the Kansas City vote fraud scandal" would reveal conditions that would "very seriously impair President Truman's chances of election."

BOSTON, July 22 (AP) -- J.H, Carr's Gray Star won her fourth straight sprint race today, defeating Brown Hotel Stable's Buzzaround by three-quarters of a length with J.L. McKnight's Blenweed another half length behind before 12,020 at Suffolk Downs.

ST. LOUIS, July 22 -- The Giants engaged the Cardinals in heavy action tonight before a gathering of 29,954, but drew the misfortune of seeing one of their heaviest guns put out of commission quite early in the battle.

PARIS, July 22 -- The Government felt assured today that there would be no more discussions of the Ruhr or German industry without France, and it was expected that the current interchanges would lead to three-power discussions among Britain, the United States and France.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The liquidation of the Wartime Emergency Maternity and Infant Care Program which provided Federally paid medical care for the birth of more than a million babies to the wives of service men in the four lowest pay grades, was announced today by the Children's Bureau.

CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) -- Charles (Red) Barrett of the Braves and Claude Passeau of the Cubs pitched shut-outs today as the Braves won the first game of a doubleheader, 2 -- 0, and the Cubs took the second game, also 2 -- 0.

A fugitive charge against the former Lady Iris Mountbatten was dismissed yesterday by Magistrate Ambrose J. Haddock in Felony Court after he had been notified that Washington charges of issuing worthless checks totaling $185 had been withdrawn.

ATHENS, July 22 (U.P.) -- Headquarters for the EAM, the liberal and leftist party coalition, announced today that police had arrested 7,800 suspected as Communists in the Athens-Piraeus area since July 9.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 22 -- Mrs. Anthony Del Guidice, wife of the former New York policeman called as witness in the Scottoriggio case, said here tonight that Mrs. Boris Coppola, her child, Michael Coppola, and her father, David Lehmann, took refuge in the Guidice home the first week in January.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- The Chicago Transit Authority's plans to take over and operate the surface and elevated lines on Sept. 1 moved a step nearer completion today when Federal Judge William J. Campbell overruled objections, to the prospectus of the authority's new $105,000,000 bond issue, on which bids are to be asked tomorrow.

Hampered by a further drop In volume, the stock market moved yesterday over an irregular course and final prices were mixed. An extension of the demand for rail issues gave the list some semblance of strength during the forenoon and enabled the rail averages to reach the best levels since last March.

BERLIN, July 22 -- Still energetically striving to increase the Unsatisfactory Ruhr coal production despite differences in over-all policy, the United States and British Military Governments have devised a new "dramatic" incentive scheme for the miners, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Referring to the new contract of the United Mine Workers, the midyear economic report of the President to Congress remarks: There has been exaggeration of the size of this adjustment compared with the adjustments made in any other industries.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The House unanimously passed today a bill to exempt commercial photographic equipment from the 25 per cent wartime excise tax and to modify the excise taxes on other items.

Travel and shipping agents in New York and other cities of the country were disturbed yesterday by the prospect of losses amounting to thousands of dollars as a result of the seizing of the small passenger liner City of Athens in Baltimore.

Two underwriting syndicates here won, at competitive sale yesterday, the award of new issues of public utility and railroad obligations totaling $30,650,000. A third syndicate announced the projected marketing of $11,000,000 of new public utility bonds. A public utility stock transaction which would have involved public offering of $10,000,000 of divested common stock of an operating company was called off when the parent company rejected the bankers' bids.

ATHENS, July 22 (AP) -- The Information Ministry said tonight that twenty-four persons, most of them women and children, were Slain last night in an attack by 400 guerrillas on Nigrita, about forty miles northeast of Salonika in northern Greece.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., July 22 -- The first round of the eighteenth annual women's New York State golf championship today was marked by an extra-hole match, in which Mrs. Charles Leichner of Willow Brook won from Miss La Junta White of Dunwoodie on the nineteenth.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 22 -- Alfred Santell, producer-director, and Republic Studios have abrogated Santell's agreement to make two pictures a year for the company on a profit-sharing basis, it was learned today. The arrangement was an amicable one, according to Santell, who disclosed that he had been given a choice between limiting the cost of his next production, "Sea of Darkness," to $750,000 or leaving the studio.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Ferenc Nagy, former Premier of Hungary, warned the United States today to be vigilant in dealing with Moscow because, he said, "you cannot do business with Stalin."
LONDON, July 22 --The stock markets here today underwent a further contraction in business and closed generally lower.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 22 -- J.W.M. Snouck Hurgronje, Netherlands representative to the United Nations, advised the United ment had been compelled, "with Government had been compelled, the utmost reluctance," to resort to "police measures of a strictly limited character" to maintain law and order in the Netherland East Indies.
LONDON, July 22 -- There is "not much hope of successful treatment of old age with hormones," it was emphasized today at the International Physiological Congress opening at Oxford University.

Buyers' Arrivals Decline Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,190 against 1,488 last week and 1,181 in the similar week a year ago, according to listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 663 arrivals yesterday compared with 723 last Tuesday.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 22 -- Low-hanging clouds over the stadium, of the University of Utah in this mile-high city provided a dramatic background last night as a capacity audience of 9,400 persons from a dozen Western states viewed "Promised Valley," most elaborate music-drama ever presented in this intermountain region.

HALIFAX, July 22 (Canadian Press) -- The winner of the Marble-head-Halifax international yacht race remained to be named officially tonight, but unofficially the 72-foot ketch, Ticonderoga, from the Miami Yacht Club was conceded the championship of the ocean classic.

ST. LOUIS, July 22 -- These are extraordinary days in this sprawling metropolis on the west bank of the Mississippi where the West begins and the East starts running into trouble. Considering this is the time of season you usually can fry an egg on the sidewalk, if that is how you care to prepare your breakfast, the temperature of the weather for some time, now, has been incredibly low.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- The Missouri Synod Lutheran Church today voted to extend its higher educational system to include a senior college for theological students. The group's centennial convention, in session here, voted to spend up to $1,500,000 for the project.

The Holland-America liner Veendam arrived here yesterday with 589 passengers, among them Jacobus Hut, his wife, Tjitske, and their thirteen children, one of the largest family groups to arrive on a Dutch ship since the war's end.

LONDON, July 22 -- The fate of the 4,500 immigrants removed from a steamer that reached Palestine last week was the subject of questions in the House of Commons today. Arthur Creech Jones, Colonial Secretary, insisted that the refugees, who are being returned to France in three British transports, would be landed there.

LONDON, July 22 (Reuters) -- The touring South Africans today dominated the last day of play against Yorkshire, last year's English county cricket champions, but had to accept a draw because rain in earlier Stages of the three-day match prevented its completion.

The Ukrainian Congress Committee of America, in a memorandum forwarded yesterday to Warren R. Austin, American delegate to the United Nations Security Council, urged a full investigation of "reliable reports" that the Soviet Union, Poland and Czechoslovakia "have entered into a definite international understanding to liquidate the Ukrainian people."

BUDAPEST, July 22 -- The Liberty party announced its dissolution in the Hungarian Parliament today. With it disappeared all effective opposition to the Communistdominated coalition Government in the general elections, expected Aug. 31.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 22 -- Under weird racing conditions so far as breeze went, another record shattering fleet was on Long Island Sound today for Race Week at the Larchmont Yacht Club. It set back many of the foremost skippers and lifted along others, a break they relished.

Egypt, whose "just and strong" case against Great Britain is to be presented to the United Nations' Security Council, has confidence in the organization and hopes to rid herself of crippling restrictions, Premier Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha asserted here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Delegate Edward L. Bartlett, Democrat, of Alaska, suggested to a Congressional committee today that the Government construct ships for the Alaska trade and thus permit lower freight rates for the territory.

LONDON, July 22 -- A minimum expenditure of $3,000,000,000 annually for the next three years is the bill the United States will have to pay to bail western Europe out of its present economic difficulties, according to experts examining the requirements of the Continent in the light of the Marshall proposal.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Hopes for high production of meat in 1948 rose today when the Department of Agriculture reported that favorable weather during the first half of July improved the corn crop prospects.

Ludek Pachman of Czechoslovakia and A. O'Kelly de Galway of Belgium played to a draw in the seventh round of the European zonal chess championship preliminaries yesterday, according to a report from Hilversum, the Netherlands.

BATAVIA, Java, July 22 (AP) -- An Indonesian National Army communique: East Java: Yesterday at 1:30 P.M. Grissee was fired upon from the sea. During three minutes we answered the fire with heavy machine guns.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Congress sent to the White House today a bill to establish a nationl science foundation which for the first time in peace would mobilize the country's scientific talent for research and development. The measure was approved in its final form by both chambers after unsuccessful attempts in the Senate to delay action.
Great Britain's seizure of the ship Exodus 1947 off Palestine last Friday was denounced yesterday by two leading Jewish organizations.

Leonard D. Goodman, the "dummy" president of the National Navigation Company, testified yesterday that he was once hurriedly sent out of the office to cash a check and that he returned with the money to a back room where I. James Brody, former Deputy Commissioner of Marine and Aviation; James V. Auditors and his father-in-law, Albert Gross, were waiting.

A strike against two Queen bus companies that began four days ago was called off last night after strikers had been assured by their leaders that their grievances, would be satisfactorily adjusted once they were back on their jobs.

Ervan Lucas Bols, Inc., liqueur concern of Holland, wall have its first American plant in Englewood, N. J., Lawrence W. Pugh, technical director of the company, announced yesterday. Scheduled for completion on Nov. 1, the plant will be on South Dean Street, north of State Highway 44, and will consist of a one and two-story building containing 24,000 square feet on a plot of 77,000 square feet.
Because of a steadily increasing demand on facilities, St. Luke's Hospital at 421 West 113th Street iiust expand and improve its services, the eighty-eighth annual report declared yesterday.

SINGAPORE, July 22 -- Sutan Sjahrir, who resigned recently as Premier of the Indonesian Republic and who now is special adviser to President Soekarno, came out of Java to Singapore by air today. He was flown by an Indian business man, a friend of Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, who took off from a secret airfield early this morning in a private plane.

Attorney General Tom Clark joined with officials of the United Jewish Appeal yesterday in urging immediate aid for thousands of displaced persons in Europe as a means of strengthening the nation's democracy.

JACKSON. Wyo., July 22 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York has requested friends and well wishers in Michigan to drop their plans for a series of home-coming celebrations in his honor that were being arranged for next week, it was disclosed today as he ended a day of sight-seeing in the Jackson Hole country with its breath-taking mountain vistas.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Victor A. Kravchenko, who turned on the Communist regime he once served, testified today that Russia was infesting America with spies and pursuing an international course that would make war "inevitable."

The second in a proposed network of juvenile delinquency "clinics" sponsored by the National Association of Women Lawyers will be organized in Knoxville, Tenn., this fall, Mrs. Jeanette Johnson, corresponding secretary of the association, announced yesterday.

LONDON, July 22 -- An increase of 31,204 tons in shipping under construction is noted for the quarter ended June 30 as compared with the previous three months, by Lloyd's Register of Shipping. The figures published today cover ship construction in Great Britain and Northern Ireland.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The House passed today a bill to require immediate termination of all Federal controls over consumer credit.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Powerful bipartisan Senate support today virtually assured another year of life for the Government's long-range farm program with its benefit payments to farmers.

Brig. Gen. E. F. Jeffe, vice president in charge of sales, Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., warned last night that failure to achieve a workable price structure may result in a business recession and urged business men to make every effort to solve price problems themselves rather than leaving the task to "economists and bureaucrats."

MINNEAPOLIS, July 22 (AP) -- Wilfred Crossley, 27-year-old former New England amateur champion, today virtually stole the medal in the national public links tournament from five other entrants by coming in late in the day with a three-under-par 69 for a 36-hole total of 139.

Congress has no more important obligation during the few remaining days of the present session than to arrange for the early admission to this country of a fair share of those war victims who carry the pathetic title of Displaced Persons. There are no arguments against this proposal that will stand examination by daylight.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Senate and House conferees were in deadlock tonight over the program for unification of the armed forces. The differences, however, were not considered fundamental.

Controlling interest of the RadioKeith-Orpheum Corporation, of which the Atlas Corporation owns 24.22 per cent interest, is expected to be transferred to N.P. Rathvon, president, it was learned in financial circles yesterday.
JERUSALEM, July 22 -- The underground organizations apparently united today in a campaign in retaliation for the reshipment of 4,500 unauthorized Jewish immigrants to France.

Chief Signalman Harold E. Hirshberg was accused before a Navy general court-martial yesterday of having reported to the Japanese in 1944 that a fellow prisoner of war in the Philippines intended to escape, thereby causing the man to be beaten so severely that he died.

I. J. Fox, who recently went to Paris to visit the fashion houses, presented yesterday his interpretations of French models in the Imperial Salon of his Fifth Avenue shop. The Paris houses that inspired the collection were Maggy Rouff, Christian Dior and Paquin.

Mayor O'Dwyer discussed the higher transit fare proposal yesterday with Controller Lazarus Joseph on the eve of another Board of Estimate meeting on the fare but would not attempt to predict the board's action today.

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 22 -- Mrs. George H. Bostwick of the Meadow Brook Club turned in a fine 43, 41 -- 84 card to finish 2 up against par in the annual Joseph J. Windle Challenge Cup golf tourney today at the Glen Oaks Club. The event was sponsored by the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association and attracted 122 players.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 22 -- The question of whether or not the people of New Jersey will permit the spread of legalized gambling in their state will be decided at the polls this fall when voters will get one of two proposed articles for inclusion in the new State Constitution.

Modernization of Washington, Market to reduce handling costs on fresh vegetables and fruits was urged yesterday by 100 farm bureau leaders from eleven States. The Northeastern regional conference of the American Farm Bureau Federation, ending a two-day meeting at the Hotel Commodore, also called for continuance of the Congressional investigation into labor costs in the New York and Philadelphia wholesale markets.

MOSCOW, July 22 (AP) -- New Times, the Soviet foreign policy magazine, said today the Paris economic conference on the Marshall proposal was a failure and that Great Britain and France had prepared "puppet" roles for the fourteen other European nations participating.

VIENNA, July 22 -- Austria's new coal agreement with Poland was publicized today. It provides for 85,000 tons a month and it is now hoped will make up in part for the chronic shortage of Ruhr coal deliveries that have been one of the major factors accounting for the paralyzed condition of the Austrian industry.

Housewares manufacturers who sold directly to distributors throughout the war and immediate post-war periods have intensified efforts in the last two weeks to secure services of competent wholesale representatives, it was learned yesterday.

The diamond wedding ring that Frederick Dodd, former Air Forces sergeant, was going to place on the finger of his French war bride almost preventel his meeting the plane on which she arrived from Paris at La Guardia Field yesterday afternoon.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: July 26 may be an important date in American history -- at least so far as those interested in the Lincoln saga are concerned. On that date the private papers of Robert Todd Lincoln, the Emancipator's son, will be opened to the public view.

On July 3, the date of the latest available Index of the Congressional Record, Congress had been in session for twenty-six consecutive weeks. During all this time the Index shows just four references to the subject of universal military training among all of the speeches made on the floor by all of the members of both Houses on all of the matters of interest to them.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 22 -- Financial transacations of James A. Sullivan, Vice Mayor of Yonkers and target of governmental reformers, were under close scrutiny today by municipal investigators as they strove to determine the origin of $268,131 that Mr. Sullivan and his wife were alleged to have banked between January, 1944 and early this year.

Higher hourly minimum rates for service workers in the hotel and restaurant industries throughout the state, recommended by Minimum Wage Boards to meet increased living costs, have been accepted by Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi, it was announced yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: One of the most widely held ideas among union members is that their right to strike is their "most powerful weapon." That might have been the case ten or twenty years ago, when industry's profits were much higher percentagewise and labor's share of the total sales dollar was much lower.

GENEVA, Switzerland, July 22 -- The American delegation has been stunningly defeated in its fight to gain the Geneva trade conference's approval for American agricultural export subsidies, it was learned today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a letter with reference to the Greek situation, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July I5, Robert Scranton, although admitting that "the difficulties in Greece are aggravated and exploited by foreign powers for their national and international ends," declares that the strife is of an internal nature.

BATAVIA, Java, July 22 (AP) -- A Dutch Army communique: Following: yesterday's communique regarding preventive air actions by the Netherlands Air Forces against air force units of the Republic, it is reported that three Republican planes were set on fire at Tasikmalaya airfield during a later attack.

Dr. Eelco N. van Kleffens, the new Netherlands Ambassador to the United States, declared here yesterday that the Dutch people "do not regard the military operations in Indonesia as war but as a necessity to restore order in a recalcitrant state in the federation that is to come into being under the Cheribon agreement."

Twenty-four persons were injured -- five of them seriously enough to require hospitalization -- when two trolley cars were in collision late last night at the Prospect Park Circle in Brooklyn. The accident tied up traffic there for almost an hour.

Mrs. Doris Coppola, wife of Michael (Trigger Mike) Coppola, material witness in the Joseph Scottoriggio murder, hid for eight months, while police sought her, in the home of Anthony Del Guidice. former New York policeman, at 62 Glover Street, Providence, R.I.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 22 (AP) -- W.E. Ferrell's War Glance, a distant last in his previous race, surprised today when he won the featured Neptune Purse over a sloppy six furlongs at Monmouth Park.

Eastern manufacturers of machinery and metal products are investigating the possibility of manufacture at attractive competitive cost levels in the South where manufacturing conditions have heretofore been considered unattractive.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, reserved decision yesterday on departmental charges against Joseph F. Taggard, an Inspector who was suspended last January from his $4,130-a-year post.

NEW DELHI, India, July 22 -- India's Chamber of Princes will virtually pass out of existence tomorrow with the expected agreement for a federal alliance between the Dominion of India and at least 60 per cent of the Princely States.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The State Department announced today that Leland Harrison, American Minister to Switzerland for the past ten years, who is being succeeded by John Carter Vincent, another career diplomat, had been requested by President Truman to relinquish his post and return here.

Random Notes. Those who have been postponing a trip to Ocean City, Md., for white marlin would do well to set a date and get a reservation, for the season is reaching a peak right now, with plenty of fish coming in every day.

Opening its investigation into charges that bookmakers paid protection money to policemen, the Queens Grand Jury heard testimony yesterday from Emetia Polizio, known as Joe Pledge, the exconvict and bookmaker who made the charges, and from sis other witnesses, including Assistant Chief Inspector John J. Martin and Deputy Chief Inspector Edward C. Moran.

A strike that threatened to paralyze one-third of all incoming and outgoing international cable and wireless traffic was settled at 2:30 o'clock this morning after a one-and-one-half-hour conference between the workers and the management.

ATHENS, July 22 -- After devoting Monday to examining the points at which guerrillas from Albania invaded Greek territory near Konitza ten days ago, the United Nations Balkan subcommission will cable tomorrow from Yanina its conclusions to the main commission in New York.
Walter R. Mohr has been appointed general sales manager and assistant to the president of the George Ehret Brewery, Brooklyn. He formerly was with the Krueger Brewing Company, Newark.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- A House public lands subcommittee approved today a bill to double the amount of Government-owned coal lands that may be leased to any one person or corporation.

CINCINNATI, July 22 -- Turning on their scoring power in two big innings, the sixth and eighth, the league-leading Dodgers tonight buried the Reds, 12 -- 1, for their fourth straight triumph and third in a row over the sixth-placers.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 22 -- Hector McNell, British Minister of State, criticized today as excessively bureaucratic the plans prepared by the United Nations Secretariat for collecting a day's pay from people throughout the world to relieve the needs of underfed and underclothed children.

TOLEDO, July 22 -- James W. Egan Jr., president of the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association, denied today that the resolution adopted recently by the NAEA recommends that newspapers charge other than " 'the retailers contract rate' " when mention is made in retail advertising of magazine, radio station, motion picture or stage play.

Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard ordered yesterday that the International Paper Company produce the records of its two Canadian subsidiaries for the scrutiny of a Federal grand jury investigating the newsprint industry.

Kay Kyser's program will be switched to Saturday nights when it returns to NBC's hook-up Oct. 4, thus bringing to a close its long tenure as a Wednesday evening fixture. A new hour also has been selected for the show, which is to go on at 10 o'clock, thirty minutes earlier than had been customary.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 22 -- The power of the United Nations Security Council to compel the Balkan countries to cooperate with the border commission proposed by the United States was challenged anew today by Yugoslavia.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The reputation of Dr. Edward U. Condon, atomic bomb scientist, was upheld today by Representative Chet Holifield, Democrat of California, who called on "rumor-mongering character assassins" to "put up or shut up."

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Following is the text of the note handed by the Netherlands Government to the British and American Governments on the Indonesian situation on Sunday as given out today by the Netherlands Embassy:

CHICAGO, July 22 -- The special report on the corn crop issued by the Department of Agriculture late today, although showing 158,000,000 bushels more than on July 1, was regarded by local crop experts as a rather surprisingly poor showing in view of the favorable weather that prevailed in the first half of this month.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- The special report on the corn crop issued by the Department of Agriculture late today, although showing 158,000,000 bushels more than on July 1, was regarded by local crop experts as a rather surprisingly poor showing in view of the favorable weather that prevailed in the first half of this month.

They Are Off Again It seems that our city scout has not been able to get his mind off the horse races -- he explains that the obsession is hereditary and has no serious connection with what Frederick C. Mortimer, who for many years took care of this corner, liked to call "aleatory pursuits."

BOSTON, July 22 (AP) -- Dom DiMaggio came home on a double by Birdie Tebbetts today to give the Red Sox a tenth-inning 3-2 victory over the White Sox, who have lost all six games in Boston this season.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Early Wynn scored his eleventh victory of the season for the Senators here tonight by stopping the Tigers, 6 -- 1, on two hits.

Pedagogue, owned by A.G.C. Sage, splashed through the mud at top speed to take the Stillwater, mile and a sixteenth race that topped the bill at the Saratoga Association's meeting at Jamaica yesterday. Under a steady lashing by Teddy Atkinson through the stretch, the 4-year-old gained the major share of the purse by a head over Mrs. Esther duPont Weir's Darjeeling.

"SECOND GROWTH,"* Wallace Stegner's new novel, dramatizes the brisk and sometimes burning animosities that flourish between villagers and the summer people who infest and disrupt their landscapes. It is a venerable theme. Many novelists have used it. But Mr. Stegner manages to give it a fresh shine, an uncommon incisiveness.
Although the cotton futures market fluctuated over a fairly wide range yesterday, closing prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 15 points lower to 10 points higher.
PHOENIX, Ariz., July 22 (AP) -- The Arizona Republic said in a copyrighted story today that dry ice dropped from an airliner on a cloud over Roosevelt Dam had caused heavy rain.

MOSCOW, July 22 (AP) -- Soviet concern over the operations of foreign intelligence agents was emphasized in an article in the Leningrad Pravda, which criticized several citizens for carelessly or unconsciously giving out State secrets.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 22 (AP) -- The Economic and Social Council was warned that "the children of Europe and of the world are facing starvation this winter" as a result of disappointing contributions to the International Children's Emergency Fund.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 22 -- For the first time the Arab side of the Palestine problem was formally presented to the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine today. The Arab states informed the committee that they would be obliged to resist by violence a Jewish state founded on violence.

Officials of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers maintained that consignment selling of odd lot goods at the end of the season did not constitute a violation of its fair trade regulations, according to testimony given yesterday at the Federal Trade Commission hearing of restraint of trade charges in the fur industry.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Senate approved today and thus put into automatic effect a Presidential reorganization plan to put under a single administration the major housing agencies of the Federal Government.

New York University's action in relieving Prof. Lyman R. Bradley from his post as chairman of its Department of German, after his conviction with fifteen others of contempt of Congress, was labeled yesterday as "unfair and unjust' by student leaders at a meeting of the university's chapter of Progressive Citizens of America, at which Dr. Bradley was a speaker.
Old Bobo Newsom made a dazzling occasion out of his Stadium debut as a Yankee last night against the tail-end Browns from St. Louis.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 22 -- Missing his chance to win in the second set, Sidney Wood came from far behind in the third to defeat Jack Tuero of New Orleans today in the invitation tennis tournament at the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club.

Stoppage Removed The new capital market breathed a bit easier yesterday following the repricing of the unsold part of the $125,000,000 New York Telephone Company bond issue. With the termination of the syndicate, the bonds dropped in price from a price to yield about 2.62 per cent to a price to yield about 2.65 per cent.

GENEVA, July 23 -- After several months of futile dickering at the Geneva Trade Conference, the United States has informed the French that no basis exists for tariff negotiations between the two countries.
CHICAGO, July 23 (U.P.) -- A cold snap tumbled temperatures to record lows in the Midwest today for the second straight day and moved toward the Atlantic Coast, moderating as it traveled eastward.
LONDON, July 23 -- Business was on a very small scale in the stock markets here today -- one jobber was in the market two hours before recording his first trade.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Senate Republicans outlined a sectional campaign today designed to increase their control of the Senate.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 23 (AP) -- James Minker, 26, branded a deserter by the United States Army while he was fighting as a paratrooper in France under an assumed name, has received an honorable discharge from the Army, his mother, Mrs. Etta Minker, disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (U.P.) -- The House Un-American Activities Committee called today a group of leaders and former officials of the Winston-Salem, N.C., local of the United Food, Tobacco and Agricultural Workers Union (CIO) to testify on alleged communism in connection with the strike called against the Reynolds Tobacco Company last spring.

A further decline of 1,546,000 barrels was recorded last week in the nation's gasoline stocks, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the close of the period supplies on hand amounted to 87,145,000 barrels, compared with 88,791,000 a week earlier and 89,519,000 on July 20, 1946.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 (AP) -- The Athletics tonight evened the score with Don Black of the Indians, who had tossed a nohitter last time he faced them, handing their tormentor a 6-to-3 defeat before a crowd of 34,879 at Shibe Park.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (U.P.) -- James C. Petrillo, head of the musicians' union of the American Federation of Labor has agreed to drop his ban on amateur radio broadcasting and record-making by school and military bands, Representative Carroll D. Kearns, Republican, of Pennsylvania announced today.

Mayor O'Dwyer and Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, signed yesterday a memorandum of understanding permitting the city to close off four streets on the East Side in preparation for the proposed N.Y.U.-Bellevue Medical Center.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- One of the two major syndicates bidding on the Chicago Transit Authority's $105,000,000 bond issue withdrew from the bidding today, making it possible that the issue will not be sold at this time and that the bonds will have to be made more attractive to investors and reoffered at a later time.

LONDON, July 23--The Soviet Union has rejected summarily a United States call for an elevennation preliminary Japanese peaca treaty conference in Washington Aug. 19, the Moscow radio announced tonight.

A new service to provide accurate information for American advertisers on the expanding Philippine market has been set up here, it was revealed yesterday by Albert C Capotosto foreign advertising manager of The Manila Times Publishing Company, who recently arrived in this country.

LONDON, July 23 (U.P.) -- The text of an official Soviet statement rejecting the United States proposal for a Japanese treaty conference in Washington, Aug. 19, as broadcast by the Moscow radio, follows: On July 11 (U.S. Ambassador) Bedell Smith told Molotov that the United States proposes to call on Aug. 19 a conference for preparing a peace treaty with Japan, comprising representatives of eleven powers, members of the Far Eastern Commission.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (U.P.) -- The House newsprint investigating committee said today that newsprint and paper prices have reached their peak and that any change in the next few months should be a drop.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 23 -- Herschel V. Johnson, deputy United States delegate, told the United Nations Security Council today that Bulgaria, Albania and Yugoslavia were menaces to international peace, and grimly warned that if war broke out in the Balkans the whole world would suffer.

Restoration of bus service in Queens is due to the firmness of Mayor O'Dwyer. To be sure, the men voted to return on the advice of their AFL high command, but it was the refusal of the Mayor to budge from his stand for fair dealing that actually ended the walkout.

LONDON, July 23 (Reuters) -- A good omen for England in the fourth cricket test match against South Africa opening at Leeds on Saturday was today's performance of the Middlesex "twins," Bill Edrich and Denis Compton, who figured in a brilliant third wicket stand of 211 runs against Northamptonshire.

TOKYO, July 23 -- Soviet Russia today returned to the attack against the Japanese rural land reform program. Lieut. Gen. Kuzma N. Derevyanko, the Soviet member, told the Allied Council that the "implementation even of the original half-way law has been quite unsatisfactory."

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- The American Legion today proposed to make the United Nations "fully effective" by trimming the veto, granting the Security Council new powers to control atomic and other weapons, and creating a world police force.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Former Senator Abe Murdock, nominee for one of the two new seats on the National Labor Relations Board, encountered opposition today from Senator Arthur W. Watkins, the Republican who defeated him last year.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 23 -- With the strike deadline for 25,000 workers but six hours away, John Green, national president of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, CIO, announced tonight a tentative agreement on wages and working conditions had been reached with the Todd Shipyards Compay by the union negotiating committee.

Reorganization, recruitment and the healing of old scars will be the principal tasks of the armed services with the signing of the socalled merger measure, now in the final stages of approval by Congress.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 23 -- The "clear-cut" division of the world into Eastern and Western camps at the recent Paris conference on the Marshall Plan has started "us on the greatest basic competition of all history" with the Communist system of Russia, Harold E. Stassen asserted here tonight.

BATAVIA, July 23 (U.P.)--Heaviest fighting in the three-day campaign was reported from central Java, where two Columns moving south from Semarang were closing in on Jogjakarta while planes went ahead to batter a dozen crossroads and the Republican capital itself.

Strength in the hide market was attributed yesterday to reports of large sales of Argentine hides to British and Russian interests. Active buying in the domestic market here accounted for advances in quoted prices of 75 to 80 points, spokesmen said.

RANGOON, Burma, July 23 (AP) -- Burmese newspapers said today that one of the suspected killers of Maj. Gen. U Aung San and six other Burmese Executive Council Ministers was shot dead while at tempting to escape from custody. There was no official confirmation.

SECURITY COUNCIL Although holding no brief for Greece, United States declared Bulgaria, Albania and Yugoslavia were menaces to international peace. Resumes discussion today at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. (Open). Committee on Admission of New Members -- Continued consideration of Albania's application to join United Nations.
Unregulated trade discounts can spell the ruin of the fur industry, J. Henry Bleistein, fur merchant and recently appointed executive vice president of Motty Eitingon, Inc., asserted yesterday.

OSLO, July 23 (AP) -- Americans won six events today at the opening of a three-day track and field meet before a crowd of 20,000 at Bislet Stadium. Teams from Sweden, Finland and Norway also are entered.

An appropriation of $100,000 virtually was assured yesterday for the city's temporary rent control commission to begin full scale operations in the old Board of Education Building at Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

Jitterbug and rhumba are being combined in a new dance, Miss Lucille Stoddart, director of the seveneenth annual Dance Congress, announced yesterday at the close of its five-day session at the Hotel Commodore. Titled "Rhumboogie," and not to be confused with the swing tune of the same name but different spelling, Miss Stoddart described it as a "South American type of jitterbug."

Mayor O'Dwyer has sent a check for $500 to the recreation committee of the Community Councils of the City of New York to provide a day's outing for 500 under-privileged youngsters, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Secretary of State Marshall reserved opinion and comment today on the Soviet rejection of his proposal for an eleven nation conference to prepare a peace treaty for Japan pending receipt and close study of the text.

While James V. Auditore's United Nations Steamship Company was paying 30 cents a day for the use of a city-owned pier, he was collecting $50 a day from a steamship agent for the use of that pier over a period of several days, according to testimony in General Sessions Court yesterday.

Tootsie, a young white rabbit, was safe yesterday after being trapped eighteen hours in a threeinch wide crevice between the building walls of 349-51 East Eighty-third Street. A trail of cabbage and lettuce, the anxious calls of her owner, Marianne Zimmerman, 5 years old and the efforts of the police and agents of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals rescued her.
The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials.

BOSTON, July 23 (AP) -- Don Gutteridge's perfect safe bunt with the bases loaded and one out in the fourteenth inning tonight batted in the winning run as the Red Sox defeated the White Sox, 8 -- 7, for their third overtime victory over Chicago.

NEW HOPE, Pa., July 23 -- St. Martin's Roman Catholic Church was the setting here today for the marriage of Mrs. Kathleen Haggerty Green, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel Leo Haggerty of Trenton, N.J., and Edgehill Gardens, Morrisville, Pa., to John A. Pardridge, son of Mrs. Albert J. Pardridge of East Hampton, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Pardridge.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board said today the crash of an American Overseas Airlines plane near Stephenville, Newfoundland, last Oct. 3, killing thirty-nine persons, resulted from the pilot's failure to be "alert" to hills lying on his night time course.

OTTAWA, July 23 -- Exploration by the Newfoundland delegation and by the Canadian Government of the proposal of a federal union between the island and the Dominion have made substantial progress, External Affairs Minister Louis St. Laurent said today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 23 -- With the insistency of a trip-hammer the Arab states' representatives, testifying before the United Nations' committee on Palestine, today reiterated and stressed the idea that acquiescence to the Zionists' ambitions in Palestine would mean war in the Middle East.

The resignation of former Supreme Court Justice Isidor Wasservogel as arbitrator of a Queens bus dispute was announced yesterday afternoon by Mayor O'Dwyer, thirteen hours after 750 strikers had gone back to work, ending a four-day tie-up of two bus lines.

A plan to rekindle a "hometown" feeling in New Yorkers is being sent by the Citizens Union to 1,000 civic and community organizations. It calls for the development of communities throughout the vast city to promote more orderly planning and decentralization of municipal services without increasing their cost.

Net profit of the Phillips Petroleum Company and its subsidiaries in the six months ended with last June was $15,459,699, compared with $8,002,179 earned in the corresponding half of last year, according to the semi-annual statement mailed to stockholders yesterday.
Four thousand persons with speech or voice defects were treated last year by the National Hospital for Speech Disorders, Dr. James Sonnett Greene, the medical director, made known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Retail prices of living essentials used by moderate-income families in large cities, in a reversal of the declining trend of the preceding two months, advanced slightly less than 1 per cent from mid-May to mid-June.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- An offer to buy the entire capital stock of The Chicago Times, Inc., for $5,339,000, or $60 a share, was made today by Marshall Field, publisher of The Chicago Sun, the morning competitor of The Chicago Tribune.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury today indicted Harold R. Christoffel on charges that he committed perjury in telling a Congressional committee that he was not a member of the Communist party.

CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 8,000 head, total 10,500: market fairly active: weights under 240 pounds steady to mostly 25 cents higher: butchers over 240 pounds. 25 to mostly 50 cents higher: sows

Modified offers by two underwriting groups, which would provide cash for payment in full of principal and interest on outstanding debentures of the Equitable Office Building Corporation, were submitted yesterday to Federal Judge John C. Knox.
PHILADELPHIA, July 23 -- Hearings on dissolution proceedings instituted last Feb. 25 against the Philadelphia Company of Pittsburgh by the Securities and Exchange Commission ended today.

The New York District of the United Public Workers of America last night accused the New York State Employment Service of failure to protect minority groups from job discrimination. A meeting at 13 Astor Place was attended by union members and representatives of the American Jewish Congress, the Brooklyn Urban League and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

Joseph S. Fay, vice president of the International Union of Operating Engineers, AFL, convicted of extortion and conspiracy charges in connection with the Delaware Water Supply project, yesterday began serving an eight-and-a-half to sixteen-year term in prison.

On many occasions in the past, high Administration officials have recommended wage increases while insisting that no price changes should take place. It has often appeared that they believed that such wage increases could be completely insulated from the price structure.
