Tex Jasperson was the lad the customers were talking about at Jamaica yesterday. The kid from Wyoming -- he's only 16 and that Tex is no nickname -- marked up his fourth winner since his debut on racing's "Big Apple" last Thursday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 23 -- Simplification and revitalization of New Jersey's antiquated court system is outlined in a tentative draft and schedule drawn up today by the Constitutional Convention's Judiciary Committee.

Veterans of World War II enrolled in New York public evening high schools last term earned a higher percentage of passing grades in their State Regents examinations than did their non-veteran classmates.

UNIONVILLE, Pa., July 23 -- Mr. and Mrs. W. Plunket Stewart of Brooklawn, this place, have announced the engagement of Mrs. Stewart's daughter, Miss Averell Penn Smith, to Joseph Walker Jr., son of Mrs. Robert Strausz-Hupe of White Horse Farms, Newtown Square, Pa., and Joseph Walker of Mount Kisco, N.Y.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 23 -- The basic economic differences of Russia, Britain and the United States that split Europe over the Marshall Plan were raised again today here as representatives of those states attacked the report of the United Nations Economic and Employment Commission in the light of their national interests.

John H. Powers, 41 years old, a former assistant port captain for Cities Service, was under arrest yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on charges of having aided in the furnishing of false statements to a Government agency, the Coast Guard.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The United States Atomic Energy Commission informed Congress today that it was establishing proving grounds in the Pacific for developing and testing atomic weapons. The project received the bare mention of one sentence in the commission's long semi-annual report. It was, however, a sentence which observers regarded as loaded with significance for the security of this country.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 23 -- After three and a half months of debate, the working committee of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission today halted its efforts to obtain the Soviet Union's acceptance of the general principles for international atomic control, which were adopted by the majority of the commission last December 30.
Perhaps it would be an exaggeration to say the Yankees fell apart yesterday at the Stadium. At the same time, however, it could not be said they held together well.

This is our semi-annual "gold star" column, in which we give pats on the back to some of the products reported here since the first of the year. Our apologies to certain food "notables" that do not appear in today's review. Our space just isn't large enough to include everything deserving of a second mention.

A fairly broad buying movement developed yesterday on the stock market, producing a million share turnover for the first time in almost a week and raising prices an average of a point. Wider gains were made by several unrelated issues while strength in the steels inspired a broadening of demand in other sections.

By a vote of 3 to 2, the Appellate Division last night upheld the right of Assemblyman William T. Andrews, Democrat, to seek the American Labor party nomination for State Senator from the Twenty -third District.

BATAVTA, Java, Thursday, July 24 -- Indonesian Republicans began a systematic application of a scorched earth policy yesterday as Dutch armor and infantry threatened the Indonesian capital of Jogjakarta with a two-way drive.

Corporate Feuds Constructive The dissension between present incumbents and opponents of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company over management policies has served to enliven interest of stockholders in the affairs of that company.

DETROIT, Mich., July 23 -- Seven thousand members of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, walked off their jobs at the two local plants of the Murray Corporation of America today in a strike which appears to be designed as a major test of the union's new policy toward the Taft-Hartley Bill.

PARIS, July 23 -- Certainly the strange monopoly on world statesmanship that men have held does not justify that it be continued, Miss Margaret Hickey, United States chairman of the United Nations' committee, today told the International Federation of Business and Professional Women.

NEWARK, N.J., July 23 -- Sixty room ensembles in striking color schemes marked the opening today of the August furniture show at L. Bamberger Co. Styles of furniture ranged from blond wood modern and eighteenth century mahogany and lacquered pieces to simple maple Colonial.

Ninety-five employes of the National Lead Company plant at 135 Marshall Street, Brooklyn, went on strike yesterday morning in an effort to win recognition as collective bargaining agent for the factory's 115 workers.
CHICAGO, July 23 -- Closing-out of July contracts, especially late in the session, resulted in nervous markets on the Board of Trade today.

CINCINNATI, July 23 -- The Reds maintained their hospitable spirit today and bowed to the league-leading Dodgers, 5 -- 2, for the fourth straight time, thus matching their losing streak with the Brooklyn winning one of five games.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- A House subcommittee announced today that it had requested the Justice Department to stop the War Department from what it said was the illiegal expenditure of public money to propagandize the country for enactment of a univarsal military training bill.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 23 -- The Ku Klux Klan will support all political candidates advocating white supremacy because it is the opinion of the hooded order that "no matter what the law says in this country, it's still wrong to allow a Negro to vote in a white man's primary."

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- President Truman's foreign aid program made headway in three areas today as relief funds were enlarged by a Senate committee. Poland was dropped from the list of the needy, and a score of private citizens and Cabinet members met to determine the "safe load" limit of the nation's economy.

The New York Tuberculosis and Health Association reported yesterday that New Yorkers appeared to have overcome their rather common fear of a few years ago of X-ray treatments. The fortythird annual report of the organization revealed that it had provided 13,232 chest X-rays in 1946 as a result of increasing demands from the community for its services.

Cooperative groups, builders and other investors can build housing for rental to middle-income families at $18.22 a room a month under the State Public Housing Law, Herman, T. Stichman declared yesterday. The State Housing Commissioner presented figures to show that comparable housing, built without the tax concessions granted to limited-dividend companies, would have to rent for $26 a room a month.

WASHINGTON, July 23--Experience has "taught us that labormanagement relation problems cannot be properly handled by law, edict or regulation," Edgar A. Warren, retiring Director of the United States Conciliation Service, declared in an address tonight before the Labor Relations Forum of the Catholic University of America.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 23 -- The first court test of the New Connecticut sales and use tax, which imposes a three per cent levy on most purchases, was begun here today by five of the state's largest public utilities.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 23 -- Gen. Courtney Hodges, commanding the First Army, was the guest of honor at a review of the Fifth Division of the New York Guard at Camp Smith tonight.

BERLIN, July 23 -- A tremendous explosion demolished the north wing of Berlin's traffic police headquarters in the Russian sector this morning, killing nine persons, including two high ranking officials.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 23 (AP) -- Elimination came quickly and in some cases abruptly for fortyeight aspiring amateur golfers today in first and second round matches in the national public links tournament. The field was pared from sixty-four who started the thirty-six holes of play in a hard rain to sixteen survivors.

PARAMUS, N.J., July 23 -- New Jersey maintained its domination over the other two sections that go to make up the Metropolitan Golf Association District by coming out on top in the annual triangular team match today with 28 1/2 points. Westchester scored 27 and Long Island 16 1/2.

CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- Bewitch, undefeated filly owned by Warren Wright's Calumet Farm, easily swept to her sixth consecutive triumph today in the $58,400 Lassie Stakes before 22,000 at Arlington Park. The sensational 2-year-old outran two stablemates, Airy and Whirl Some, and six other Juveniles in scoring by two and three-quarter lengths.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Two major investigations, both intended to guide future legislative work rather than to raise suggestions of bureaucratic wrongdoing, were approved today by the Senate.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I wish to compliment you on your editorial of July 10, "Pensions for Postmen," in which you urge passage of the postal bill, the provisions of which provide for an increase in annuity from $23 to $29 per week.

PARIS, July 23 (AP) -- A Government spokesman said today that France would "take humane solutions" in dealing with the 4,500 Jewish refugees expected to be returned to a French Mediterranean port tomorrow or Friday. Francois Mitterand, Minister of Veterans' Affairs, said that "France will guarantee their feeding and, if they wish it, hospitality."
The look of trimness and femininity for campus fashions was endorsed by Russeks yesterday in its back-to-school fashion show.

With the conflict in Indonesia now in its fifth day the strategy of the Dutch is taking shape. It appears to be to cut off Java and Sumatra from contact with the outside world by seizure of all deep-water ports and to carve Java itself into three or more pieces.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- President Truman walked into the Senate chamber in the midst of routine business today, took his old seat and sat there beaming like a schoolboy at the surprise of former colleagues.
PARIS, July 23 -- The difficulties that have held up the economic questionnaire of the sixteen-power aid conference for more than a week were said to be near settlement today.

Sales of the Monsanto Chemical Company for the six months ended on June 30, last, amounted to $71,085,736, an increase of 41 per cent over the corresponding period of last year, Edgar M. Queeny, chairman of the board, reported yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, July 23 -- The Cardinals, it seems, are not quite ready to fade out of the National League pennant race.

The Liberal party took its first step last night as a legal political party, a status won in last year's State election, by organizing its State Committee at a meeting in the Hotel Capitol and re-electing Adolf A. Berle Jr. State Chairman. An outline of party policy, presented by Alex Rose, a vice chairman of the committee, indicated that the party would support President Truman for election next year.

Residents and visitors received yesterday hints on how to guard against the methods used by pickpockets and their accomplices in stealing wallets and other valuables from pockets and handbags. The adviser was Lieut. Daniel J. Campion, head of the Broadway Squad, which serves as a special detail of the Police Department.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your edition of July 10 there was a very interesting article from Tillman Durdin in Nanking, reporting a disagreement between China and the United States which may delay indefinitely the implementation of the Fulbright Act with regard to China.

SOMERSET MAUGHAM'S "Creatures of Circumstance"* is a new collection of tales told in his resolutely suave and sardonic manner. They are not particularly memorable, but they certainly do help to pass the time of day. A couple of them are stories or London's mean streets. One concerns the happy comeuppance of a garrulous bore on a winter cruise.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 23 -- Mr. and Mrs. Richard Van Nest Gambrill of Vernon Manor, Peapack, N.J., and this city have made known the engagement of their daughter, Ann Van Nest, to James J. Casey of New York, son of Mrs. N. H. Casey of San Francisco.

The four-story sixteen-family apartment house at 1193 Eastern Parkway has been purchased by Samuel D. Belzer from Mike and Agnes Novakovich for cash above a mortgage of $37,250. Max Felner was the broker and the Title Guarantee and Trust Company insured the title.

Inquiries are being made by several large companies for the outright purchase of entire machine shops in the New York metropolitan area, provided the plants have a good pre-war steel purchasing record, it was revealed here yesterday by industrial purchasing sources.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Senate and House conferees reached complete agreement late today on pending legislation for unification of the armed forces through independent departments of the Army, Navy and Air Force functioning under a Secretary of Defense.

Convertible preferred stock of a chemical enterprise, bonds of a western public utility company, and common stock of a new motor car manufacturing business make up an aggregate of $87,900,000 of new securities to be placed on the market here today.

PARIS, July 23 -- A note from Secretary of State Marshall to Foreign Minister Bidault, promising there would be no decisions about the new level of industry in Germany without prior consultation with the French, was a diplomatic achievement that greatly strengthened the Government's hand.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- Rae Scarborough, Washington right-hander, blanked the secondplace Tigers, 5 -- 0, on six hits tonight as the Senators dealt Freddie Hutchinson his fourth defeat before a crowd of 11,784.

An unprecedented demand for new chemical processing plants has developed because present manufacturing capacity for chlorine and caustic soda are heavily overtaxed, Wells N. Thompson, vice president of the H.K. Ferguson Company, industrial engineers of New York, Cleveland and Houston, revealed here yesterday. Demand for new facilities is just as sharp in the United States as foreign countries, despite wartime expansion in this field, he disclosed.

PRAGUE, July 23 (AP) -- An American track and field team headed by James Kelly of the University of Minnesota placed first in every event it entered except the shot-put in the six-nation track and field meet today.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 23--At least five persons were killed by gunfire and fifty-nine wounded in a series of political clashes and street fights in San Jose and other Costa Rican cities. The disturbances began last Saturday and were brought under control today by police.

LONDON, July 23 -- While a number of peers looked on from the gallery, the House of Commons tonight went slowly and stormily but steadily ahead with the job of rejecting forty-two amendments made by the House of Lords to the Labor Government's bill for the nationalization of all inland transport in Britain.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read with great interest in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 16 the directive issued to Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Commander in Germany, which was intended to create political, economic and moral conditions in that country which would contribute to the development of a sound German democracy, a prosperous Europe and lasting peace.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 23--President Truman told the Mississippi Valley Association's Emergency Flood Control Conference today that Americans must pay the price for occupancy of the Mississippi River drainage basin in the form of recurring devastation or in preventive measures.

"Rip Van Winkle." the revival with which the Company of Twelve, Inc., launched its bid for a low-priced summer play series at the City Center, will return to the library shelf Saturday night after fifteen performances. Late last night, while the troupe still labored to salvage its project, there was no indication of what show, if any, would succeed "Rip" at the city-owned house next week.

LONDON, July 23 -- The British Government is not sure that the quickest and best way to end the conflict in Indonesia would be to bring it before the Security Council of the United Nations, Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin said in the House of Commons today.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- The Interior Department said today it would lease through competitive bidding 2,520 acres of Central Utah coal lands sought by both Henry Kaiser and the Geneva Steel Corporation. Mr. Kaiser wants the coking coal for use at his Fontana, Calif., plant; Geneva for use in its steel mills.

LONDON, July 23 -- Declaring that Great Britain was involved in a "battle of the balance of payments" in which her economic survival as a great power was at stake, Sir Stafford Cripps, President of the Board of Trade, appealed today to all Britons to give their utmost to increased production.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial, "Exploring Great Issues," concerning the "Great Issues" course at Dartmouth College, now in experimental form, leaves me with the feeling that a sister institution and THE NEW YORK TIMES have been behind the times.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 23 -- Edward Moylan, the youth from San Francisco, who defeated Frank Parker and Gardnar Mulloy at Spring Lake, suffered a crushing setback today at the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club.
G.K. Fry has been named branch sales manager in the New York office of Talon, Inc. He formerly was branch sales manager of the Boston office.

Eugene K. Denton, president of the Tailored Woman, gave a luncheon in the Janssen suite of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday, at which fashion writers were the guests. The object of the luncheon was to introduce new high style fashions in furs and to conduct a clinic at which furs and their quality were discussed and the difference between last year's prices and those of the garments shown at the clinic were quoted.

ONE never comes away from a national golf championship without wondering why in the world any club that doesn't need publicity (which few of those that are selected do) ever gives its course over to one of these affairs.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 23 -- Ted Donaldson, 14-year-old actor, was signed today by Warner Brothers to play the title role in the screen version of "Christopher Blake," which Ranald MacDougall has written and will produce from the stage play by Moss Hart.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., July 23 -- Upsets marked the second round of the eighteenth annual women's New York State golf championship today at the Leewood Country Club course. Mrs. Mortimer May of Willow Brook, Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century and Mrs. Harry McNaughton of Seawane Harbor were the victims in closely contested matches.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, July 23 -- In its first open meeting in more than a week, the International Refugee Organization's preparatory commission announced today the receipt of $3,000,000 worth of non-monetary gold situated in the American zones of Germany and Austria.

Net sales of Standard Brands, Inc., and its subsidiaries operating in the United States rose 20 per cent to 5147,463,527 in the first six months of 1947, but net income declined 40 per cent to $3,834,536 for the period, James S. Adams, president, announced yesterday.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 23. -- This was junior day of the Larchmont Yacht Club race week, when girls and boys who have not had eighteen candles on their birthday cakes had their innings.

A former Army private testified before a Navy general court-martial yesterday that Chief Signalman Harold E. Hirshberg informed the Japanese of planned escapes by three of his fellow prisoners of war in the Philippines.

The educational staff of the Office of Military Government of the United States in Germany is "entirely inadequate for the needs of 23,000,000 Germans," Dr. L. Thomas Hopkins, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday at the college's all-college lecture series.
CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- Homers by Bob Elliott and Phil Masi topped a fifteen-hit Boston attack which smothered the Cubs, 12 to 4, today and kept the Braves in the National League pennant contention.

TOKYO, July 23 -- Hokkaido's newly elected Prefectural Assembly -- the rough equivalent of an American State Legislature -- has petitioned Gen. Douglas MacArthur to obtain the return to Japan of the southern Kurile Islands, now Russian-occupied, the Kyodo news agency reported today from Sapporo.

Ludek Pachman of Czechoslovakia continued in the lead among the fourteen competitors in the European zonal championship at Hilversum yesterday, according to a report from the Netherlands. His eight-round game with H.I. Foerder of Palestine remained unfinished after sixty-five moves.

Seven in the series of free concerts being conducted for veterans in Army and Navy hospitals in the metropolitan area by Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians will be broadcast by WNYC, it became known yesterday. Agreement for the broadcasts was reached between Richard McCann, president of the local, and Seymour N. Siegel, program director of the municipal station.

Word was received here last night that W. Kerr Rainsford, architect and member of a prominent New York family, was drowned yesterday afternoon while bathing off Fishers Island, L.I., where he was vacationing with his family.

Three Manhattan automobile owners were cleared of illegal parking yesterday when they were able to show that, at the times their cars were left overnight on the streets, the vehicles were supposed to be in garages for which the owners were paying $35 and $40 a month. Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger issued summonses for the two garages involved.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange lost ground yesterday and prices closed 45 to 55 points net lower.

Wednesday nights at the Lewisohn Stadium, being reserved for soloists of medium fame, are not the most showy, but they are often the most satisfactory musically speaking. Last night's concert, which attracted 7,000, provided further proof to bear this out.

JERUSALEM, July 23 -- The British evacuation ship Empire Lifeguard, used to transport unauthorized immigrants to Cyprus, is resting on her keel in shallow water in the Haifa harbor today, a six-foot hole blasted by saboteurs in her bottom.

Chain jewelry stores have regained their pre-war position as definite factors in retail distribution of table radios, a spokesman for a large appliance distributing organization reported yesterday. He emphasized that jewelry store radio operations, with rare exceptions, are confined to table models because of limited floor space and servicing facilities.

PITTSBURGH, July 23 (AP) -- Three home runs, two by Ralph Kiner -- his twenty-fourth and twentyfifth of the season -- and one by Hank Greenberg, tonight helped the Pirates sink the Phillies, 6 to 2, before a crowd of 27,563.

SEOUL, Korea, July 23 -- In an exclusive interview lasting more than an hour today Col. Gen. Terentyi F. Shtikov, chief Soviet delegate to the Joint United States Soviet Commission, vigorously denied reports that 400 Koreans were massacred and thousands wounded in demonstrations in North Korea on June 30.

Visiting New York to confer with representatives of European consumer cooperative organizations on establishing a basis for world trading among consumer organizations, T. A. Tenhune, general manager of National Cooperatives, Inc., Chicago, revealed yesterday that the estimated 1946 retail sales through affiliated organizations were $698,520,633, a new peak.

GDYNIA, Poland, July 23 (AP) -- To spur foreign trade, Poland plans to establish zones free from customs duties in the Baltic ports of Gdynia and Gdansk and the former German port city of Stettin, now called Szczecin.

Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday that he considered Aug. 4 as the deadline for action by the Board of Estimate on pending proposals to increase the fare on municipal transit lines by an amount sufficient to wipe out their operating deficits for 1947-48 and 1948-49.

Domestic hide and calf skin production was well maintained in May and June but dropped off slightly during the first week in July, L.L. Horch, New York regional director for the Department of Commerce, said yesterday in announcing details of the July "Leather Industry Report" of the department.

Dr. Emanuel Neumann, newly elected president of the Zionist Organization of America, deplored, yesterday the failure of the United States Government to make its position on the Palestine question clear through the councils of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, snows the following principal changes for the week ended July 16: Increases of $99,000,000 in loans and $438,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, and a decrease of $163,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company reported yesterday that operations for the first six months of 1947 resulted in a net income of $168,032, equal to 23 cents a share, compared with $1,442,215, or $1.93 a share, in the 1946 period. For June the company showed a net loss of $43,583, compared with a net income of $604,997 in June last year.
CAMDEN, N.J., July 23 (AP) -- A 50-year-old war veteran lost today his Federal Court fight for reinstatement under the GI Bill of Rights as a commission salesman in his father's advertising concern.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Rudolph E. Schoenfeld, veteran foreignservice officer now on duty in the State Department, was nominated by President Truman today as the first American Minister to Rumania since the war.

ATHENS, July 23 -- Pressure from a variety of Greek and foreign quarters for a "broadening" or alteration of the Greek Government is expected to come to a head when Constantin Tsaldaris, Vice Premier and Foreign Minister and the strongest character in the Cabinet, returns from the United States.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, July 23 -- Premier Dr. Louis J.M. Beel addressing the lower house of the Netherlands Parliament today stated that arbitration under Article 17 of the Cheribon Agreement of the conflict with the Indonesian Republicans was ruled out.

Twelve hundred shop stewards, business agents and officers of 300 Congress of Industrial Organizations unions in this city voted aproval last night of a proposal that the entire CIO membership in Greater New York, numbering 600,000 workers, make voluntary contributions ranging from a minimum of $2 to a day's pay toward a fund to be used for political action activities in 1947 and "in preparation for 1948."
The only interpretation which could be made of the latest reports on the waterfowl situation at the great nesting grounds in Canada, submitted by Ducks Unlimited, is that the prospects are uncertain.
POCATELLO, Idaho, July 23 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey was welcomed to Southeastern Idaho today in the manner usually reserved for candidates for President or other high public office.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- A House judiciary subcommittee approved today a bill that would open the way to American citizenship for Victor A. Kravchenko, a former Soviet official, who has publicly renounced communism.

VIENNA, July 23 -- The Soviet Union is showing evidence of a possible desire to win Austria over by providing certain supplies. Austrian authorities are negotiating now to close a deal for a surprise Soviet offer of 150,000 tons of briquet coal from the Soviet zone of Germany.
Assistant Chief Inspector John J. Martin was defended by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander yesterday in a statement on alleged police protection of gamblers in Queens.

LONDON, July 23 (AP) -- Pealing bells, flowing champagne and public rejoicing appeared likely tonight to herald the wedding of Princess Elizabeth and Lieut. Philip Mountbatten, despite an undercurrent of protest against lavish pageantry in a time of national shortages.

The United States delegation of 1,090 Boy Scouts and leaders to the sixth World Scout Jamboree to be held at Moisson, France, from Aug. 9 to 22, held a "shove off" rally at Camp Kilmer, N.J., last evening. The outfit will sail at 1 o'clock this afternoon from Pier 11, Staten Island, aboard the Army transport General C. H. Muir.

The East's top players have extended a challenge to polo authorities on the West Coast and in Texas for a renewal of the highly successful East-West matches, it was announced yesterday by Robert E. Strawbridge Jr., chairman of the United States Polo Association.
LONDON, July 23 -- The AngloSoviet trade talks in Moscow have reached a deadlock, the Board of Trade announced today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 23 -- The Soviet Union accused the United States and Britain today of attempting to make Albania "the tool of dollar-bags," and heard its charges characterized as "junk" by Britain.

Lower prices on grocery items increase retail volume so much that profits rise despite reduced mark-ups according to data presented yesterday at a meeting of trade representatives held by Bernice Quality Foods, Bronx wholesaler, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Spokesmen of the broadcasting chains here declared yesterday that network musical programs would not be released to FM outlets unless James M. Petrillo, head of the American Federation of Musicians, officially rescinds his order calling for the hiring of double crews of musicians in the event of AM-FM program duplication.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., July 24 -- Two Long Island golf stars, and two from up-State New York, will meet in the semi-final round tomorrow of the eighteenth New York State golf championship over the Leewood Country Club course.
MADRID, July 24 -- The Spanish Government has taken a sudden action in the past week that has caused wide comment in both Spanish and foreign circles here.

ALBANY, July 24 -- Measured by the number of business failures, business conditions are better in New York State than in the country as a whole, according to the New York State Commerce Review, issued today by the State Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Washington officials hope that as a result of the Ruhr negotiations coal production in those German mines will be at least doubled. This is considered of primary importance because coal is regarded as fundamental to European economic rehabilitation and Ruhr production essential to any program having that objective.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 24 -- Hundreds of women here are protesting the current trend in women's fashions in a petition being circulated in business offices.

The Seafarers International Union, APL, and employing operators of the Atlantic and Gulf Ship Operators Association ended weeks of negotiations yesterday with an agreement for a new wage and working contract.

Kirsten Flagstad, the Norwegian soprano, was among the 1,004 passengers who arrived here yesterday from Europe on the United States liner America. The ship docked at Pier 61, North River, at 1:10 P. M.
CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- Three three-base hits and Doyle Lade's careful nine-hit pitching combined to give the Cubs a 6-to-4 triumph over the Braves today.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., July 24 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York was cheered this afternoon by a crowd of 20,000 persons when he appeared at the rodeo of Cheyenne's annual Frontier Days Celebration with Mrs. Dewey and his two sons.

Representatives of employer and union painters organizations jointly announced last night that they had formulated an agreement, which, if ratified by their respective parent bodies, will avert a threatened work stoppage of 10,000 painters in the Bronx and Manhattan.

ATHENS, July 24 (AP) -- Government prosecution officials tonight issued warrants for the arrest of Nicolas Zachariades, leader of the Greek Communist party, and Miltiades Porphyrogenis of the EAM, former Labor Minister, accusing them of an alleged Communist plot to start an uprising in Greece and "anti-national activities."

PRAGUE, July 24 (AP) -- An American track team whose nine members won eleven first places and four seconds out of eighteen events in the two-day, six-nation track and field meet, today received Czechoslovakia's award for the best team on the field.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Congress sent to the White House today a bill to peg the Social Security payroll tax at the present level until Jan. 1, 1950. The measure was a compromise agreed upon by conferees and approved by both chambers after the breaking of a conference deadlock over a House-approved formula for future increases in the levy.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Walter Masterson's 4-hit pitching gave Washington a 3-0 victory over Detroit tonight and a sweep of the three-game series with the Tigers. It was the second time this season Masterson registered a shut-out when opposed by Hal Newhouser, who was charged with his ninth defeat.

NOTRE DAME, Ind., July 24 --A protest against the theme of a new motion picture, "Black Narcissus," on the ground that it portrays a group of nuns in an "extremely unfavorable light as worldly, neurotic and frustrated," has been sent to J. Arthur Rank of Great Britain, its producer, by a special committee of Catholic priests here.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Robert P. Patterson, the Secretary of War, swore in his successor today and held a farewell press conference in which he stated that this potentially strongest country of the world was deficient in "ready military strength."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 24 -- Seymour Nebenzal announced today that he would produce the longprojected film version of Thomas Wolfe's "Look Homeward Angel" this fall in conjunction with Arthur Ripley and Rudolph Monter, who have owned the screen rights to the 1929 novel since 1944.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 24 -- Shops and banks were closed and boarded up in San Jose today despite the Government's appeals to reopen.

LONDON, July 24 -- The United States had been disillusioned since V-J Day in the type of world that has resulted from the latest war. William F. Knox, president of Westinghouse Electric International Company, said today.

MINEOLA, L. I., July 24 -- The Nassau County police announced today the arrest of a woman in Le Havre, France, for the theft last June of jewelry and smal antiques valued at $8,000 from the home of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Baker at Center Island, Oyster Bay.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended July 19 totaled 919,734 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 112,773 cars, or 14 per cent more than for the preceding week, 1,762 cars, or 2.10 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 37,086 cars, or 4.2 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

The country is once more being warned that a new inflationary spiral has been set into motion. The signal for these fears has been the combination of the coal wage settlement and the realization that large exports will continue to be necessary under the Marshall Plan.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 24 (AP) -- Yankee Valor, winner of the $50,000 Hollywood Derby and a leading candidate for the $100,000 Gold Cup next Saturday, died suddenly today.

A new technique for counting freckles was put to the test yesterday at the twelfth annual freckle contest conducted by the Children's Aid Society at its Jones Center playground, 407 East Seventy-third Street.
Two Navy men testified before a general court-martial yesterday that Chief Signalman Harold E. Hirshberg told them that he had a Japanese wife.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- An off-hand remark by President Truman at his news conference today to the effect that he might not necessarily lift consumer credit controls in case Congress failed to authorize their extension brought an angry burst of speed at the Capitol by which Senate and House conferees agreed to abolish all such restrictions next November 1.
A new bus dispute was laid on Mayor O'Dwyer's doorstep yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- Memorial services for the 3,738 service men, members of the Evangelical Lutheran Synod of Missouri, Ohio and other states, who died in World War II, opened the afternoon session today on the fifth day of the centennial convention.

Prominent Zionist leaders, speaking to a crowd estimated by the police at 20,000 persons at an outdoor rally in Madison Square Park, denounced yesterday the British seizure of the ship Exodus 1947, which was carrying 4,500 Jewish refugees to Palestine.
LONDON, July 24 -- The first atomic pile in Britain will be working experimentally some time this year, John Wilmot, Minister of Supply, announced today in the House of Commons.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 24 -- Russia's proposal to bar discussion of United Nations private human rights petitions was defeated today in the Social Committee of the Economic and Social Council by a vote of thirteen to three.

The state completed its case yesterday afternoon against L. James Brody, ousted Deputy Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, and James V. Auditore, the one-time "millionaire stevedore," on trial in General Sessions before Judge Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. and a jury on charges of conspiracy and accepting unlawful fees in the rental of city-owned piers.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The State Department was determined today to proceed with the making of a peace treaty for Japan through the agency of the several Pacific powers rather than through the Council of Foreign Ministers as proposed by the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Turned down by the Soviet Government on a trip to Russia, a House Labor Subcommittee today urged "immediate removal of all excess Russian nationals" from the United States.

STRATFORD, Conn., July 24 -- Faced with eviction from their home at 1681 Barnum Avenue, John L. Stryker, 79 years old, and his wife, 68, went to work -- with the aid of Richard Eddinger, 23, apprentice trainee veteran, and constructed a six-room house in six weeks.

WEST FRANKFORT, Ill., July 24 -- Twenty-three men were killed, three are missing and five were critically injured today in an explosion that rocked Old Ben Mine No. 8 while 225 men were at work in the pit in the heart of the Southern Illinois coal fields.

The election of Chester Young, a former union port agent at Charleston, S. C., as vice president of the National Maritime Union, CIO, was announced yesterday by the Honest Ballot Association, which made a final tabulation after a month's balloting by NMU seamen on ships and in ports throughout the country.

GENEVA, July 24 -- For the second time during the Geneva Trade Conference, the negotiation of new international tariff agreements has reached an almost complete standstill because of the uncertainty about United States action on wool.

The stock market broke through yesterday to within a fractional range of the year's high in a furtherance of the advance which exceeded Wednesday's rebound. Prices were marked up 1 to 2 points in many key issues and more in some of the thin market stocks as trading broadened to include 1,067 individual issues, of which 719 showed gains at the close.

The ideals of Simon Bolivar, liberator of five South American countries, are reflected today in the program of the United Nations, representatives of some of those nations declared yesterday at ceremonies commemorating the 164th anniversary of the soldier-statesman's birth.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The State Department said today that it had caused the War Department to delay publication of the report of Robert Moses on economic conditions in the British and American zones of Germany. The report included a discussion of the Ruhr coal situation and it was feared it might complicate the forthcoming coal negotiations with the British.

The toad and Insect population of New York parks faces bad days ahead if the snakes, salamanders and frogs imported yesterday by most of the 160 boys returning from the Police Athletic League camp in the Adirondacks live the full lives their young owners plan for them.
VIENNA, July 24 -- Premier Stalin has informed the four Austrian Communist Deputies that the regular return of Austrian war prisoners will now begin and will be completed by the end of this year.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The State Department's long and urgent campaign for legislative authority to continue its information service abroad was gravely endangered, if not lost, today as Congress rushed toward Saturday's scheduled adjournment.

Issues of new industrial common and preferred stock priced at $6,332,224 will be placed on the market here today as follows: Victor Chemical Works-40,000 shares of 3% per cent cumulative second series preferred stock at $100 a share, by F. Eberstadt Co., Inc.
James P. Murtagh, twin brother of Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh, was sworn in by Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday afternoon as counsel to the city's Temporary Rent Control Commission.

"Speaking Frankly, by James F. Byrnes, former Secretary of State, has been scheduled by Harper for Oct. 15 publication. It is Mr. Byrnes' report of the diplomatic trials and errors, crises, accomplishments and failures of the two years after V-E Day during his tenure of office.
CINCINNATI, July 24 -- Scoring three unearned runs in the first inning, the Dodgers breezed to a 6-1 triumph over the Reds today to sweep the series and extend their winning streak to six games.

Newspaper Advertising Service, Inc., and the American Press Association have worked out a program to produce more national advertising for weekly newspapers, it was announced yesterday. The plan is intended to eliminate duplication of lists and the confusion arising from different rates and circulation statements found in of this confusion, it was pointed out, arises because a considerable number of publishers have made representative agreements' with both APA and NAS.

NEW DELHI. India, July 24 -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, head of the Indian Interim Government, promised tonight "every possible help" by India in an effort to halt hostilities in the Netherlands Indies.

WASHINGTON, Friday, July 25 -- Tempers frayed and flared easily early today as the Senate, which has been in continuous session since noon yesterday worked through, the night under prodding of the Republican leadership in an effort to get a vote on the proposed Kansas City vote fraud investigation.

BATAVTA, Java, Friday, July 25 (U.P.) -- Indonesian President Soekarno appealed to the United States in a radio broadcast tonight to '"exert every effort to halt this war in Indonesia and bring about a peaceful settlement."

Elsewhere on this page we print a letter from Elisworth Bunker, of the United States Cane Sugar Refiners Association, dealing with the proposed Sugar Act of 1948, to which we referred here recently as "one of the most dubious, legislative contributions" of the present Congress.

LONDON, July 24 -- The weakest spot in a generally dull stock market here today was Central Uruguay Railroad, which was marked down 1 1/2 -- speculators being disappointed with the amount of sterling to be released under the joint agreement.

Unless a long mine strike or a shipping tie-up occurs, there will be enough coal for all uses this winter, according to a survey of fuel supplies released yesterday by the Research Institute of America.

The proposed act, through establishing fixed quotas on domestic consuming areas for a period of five years, and by allocating to Cuba 95 per cent of the Philippine deficit, which is expected to be substantial, will enable Cuba to secure a larger tonnage in the American market, and to take advantage of any increase in consumption which may be anticipated, both because of our increased population and the high level of purchasing power.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 24 -- Every once in a great while something happens at Larchmont Race Week that makes New York's canvas carnival a leading candidate for the national screwball championship. Yesterday, Junior Day, it was the case of the misnumbered dories. That threw approximately 300 lads and lassies and half a dozen race committee graybeards into a state of acute chaos.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 24 -- For years there has been a though in yachting that some time there might be 400 craft in a regatta. Each suggestion of such a thing was brushed aside as fantastic, but it came true today when 403 starters appeared in Race Week of the Larchmont Yacht Club.
Abington, Pa. On Aug. 12, Abington Township, Pa., will take bids on $150,000 of sewer bonds dated Aug. 1, 1947 and due on each Aug. 1 from 1949 to 1802.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Department store sales in the week ended July 19 were 8 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1946:

PHILADELPHIA, July 24 -- The United Gas Corporation and its subsidiary, the United Gas Pipe Line Company, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to sell $135,195,000 of bonds.

LENOX, Mass., July 24 -- The first concert of the Boston Symphony series of the Berkshiri Music Festival was given tonight in the Music Shed, Dr. Koussevitzky conducting, with an audience which far outnumbered the seating capacity of the outdoor auditorium and heard the first festival performance of Honegger's "Symphony for Strings" as the beginning of the program.

City Transit Financing The $105,000,000 revenue bond issue of the Chicago Transit Authority is now occupying a first position on underwriting calendars, with prospective bidding managers here confident that the Authority can meet the challenge of the investment market, and thereafter operate on a paying basis.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- All three of President Truman's appointments to posts on the National Labor Relations Board appeared able today to command a majority vote for confirmation in the Senate Labor Committee, but one or two of them face difficulties on the Senate floor.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 24 -- Yemen has applied for membership in the United Nations, bringing to ten the total of applications on file here, Acting Secretary General Adrian Pelt announced today.

JOGJAKARTA, Java, July 24 (AP) -- Premier Amir Sjahriffoedin of the Indonesian Republic said today that the Dutch were in the Cheribon area with a large force, but that their drive on Jogjakarta has been stopped, at least temporarily.

BOSTON, July 24 (AP) -- Coming from behind, the Red Sox today scored an 8-2 victory over the White Sox to sweep a three-game series and maintain a record of never having been beaten at home this year by the Chicagoans.

DECATUR, Ill., July 24 -- A charge made in Salt Lake City, Utah, today by Dr. Bidhan Chandra Roy, personal physician of Mahatma Gandhi, that service was refused him in a Decatur restaudant elicited expressions of regret from Mayor James A. Hendrick and an explanation from the restaurant proprietor.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Senite and House Republican leaders decided today to subject Congress to possible recall to duty, during the adjournment period -- now slated to start Saturday night -- on demand of the GOP Congressional High Command. Normally, the power of recall rests with the President of the United States alone.

As proof of their desire to make the Marshall Plan a success, France, Great Britain and the United States have reached tentative agreements to hold two conferences in an effort to iron out differences over the manner and the extent of utilizing Germany's idle production capacities for European recovery.
The city-backed bill to license garages and parking lots, one of the most bitterly fought legislative proposals in the post-war period, was approved unanimously last night by the Board of Estimate.

As a result of the inadequacy of the tariff system in maintaining the domestic industry, and of conditions in Cuba, which were a threat to our whole good-neighbor policy, an entirely new approach to the complicated sugar problem was adopted. Quotas were established for all areas which historically had supplied the American market.

A Center for Human Relations Education, designed to help combat prejudice and create better understanding among groups, will open in September under the joint auspices of the Bureau for Intercultural Education and the New York University School of Education, representatives of both organizations announced yesterday.

The reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased their commercial, industrial, and agricultural loan portfolio $3,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, possibly indicating the termination of the seasonal decline in such borrowings.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 24 -- On the same court where Robert Falkenburg defeated, him a year ago, William Talbert retaliated with a 6-4, 6-4 victory over the long-legged youth from Hollywood Calif., today in the invitation tournament of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 24 -- Seven members of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine concluded that group's inquiry in the Middle East today with a flying visit to Amman, capital of Trans-Jordan, at the invitation of King Abdullah.

The Board of Estimate took under advisement yesterday a plan for the development of the six-block area bounded by First Avenue. Third Avenue, Forty-sixth Street and Forty-ninth Street as an approach to the permanent home of the United Nations on the east side of midtown Manhattan.

Obstacles are easily brushed aside by playwrights, especially those with the resources of Sam and Bella Spewack, when they have faith in their brain child. Originally their comedy, "The Way of a Hen," was to have been escorted to the Biltmore in October by George Abbott, but he changed his mind and decided to give the right of way to his musical, "Look Ma, I'm Dancing."

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Rep. Donald L. O'Toole, Democrat of New York, charged in a speech on the House floor today that communal laundry machines in apartment houses and launderettes are a health menace so great as to call for state and national action.
SECURITY COUNCIL Debated composition of proposed semi-permanent Balkan Commission and studied suggestions ranging from one-man to eleven-men groups. Meets today at 10:30 A.M. (Open).

PITTSBURGH, July 24 (AP) -- The upsurging Pirates climbed out of the National League, cellar ahead of Philadelphia for the first time in weeks today, defeating the Phils in both ends of a twin bill. Pittsburgh won the first game, 8 -- 6, on the strength of a 7-run first inning and took the nightcap, 3 -- 2, by rallying for two runs in the eighth.

NEW DELHI, India, July 24 -- The joint partition council under the chairmanship of Viceroy Mountbatten announced today the creation of a special joint military command in Punjab Province. The purpose is to insure against disturbances when the partition boundaries between Pakistan and India are announced for that troubled area.

Helen Traubel, Wagnerian soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Company, sang before an audience of almost 13,000 at Lewisohn Stadium last night in a program notable for superior performances by Hans Schwieger, the conductor, and the Philharmonic-Symphony and some impresive singing by herself.
NANKING, July 24 -- American military men and diplomatic officials here warn that giving more money and arms to the present Chinese Government would be unsound and likely to defeat Washington's aims.

If the Yankees get farther in front than they are at the moment the runners-up may need high-powered binoculars to see them. Even so, Bucky Harris is worried. Not even a top-heavy, 14-5 rout of the Browns by the Yankees yesterday at the Stadium sufficed to ease the alleged pain the New York pilot suffers, because too many already are conceding the pennant to his charges.

Two hundred passengers, balked in their plans to go to Europe on the attached passenger ship City of Athens, may get there by air, was reported yesterday. The City of Athens, an old freighter recently rebuilt as a small liner, has been attached in Baltimore as a result of libel actions brought by Todd Shipyards Corporation and several supply companies for nonpayment of indebtedness.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 24 -- More than 1,000 staff members of the United Nations Secretariat today demanded that rental agreements between the United Nations and the Metropolitan and New york life insurance companies be canceled on the grounds that racial discrimination could be imposed by the contracts. The demand was made in an overwhelming vote at a mass meeting here.

ST. LOUIS, July 24 -- The fortunes of the Giants in the West continued to move entirely in the wrong direction today as the Polo Grounders, despite a Bill Rigney homer and eight fine innings of pitching by Larry Jansen, crashed down to defeat before the Cardinals 3 to 2, in the last of the tenth.

On the whole, the National Science Bill reaches the President much the better for the revisions made in conference to remove discrepancies in the separate measures passed by the two Houses. No longer compelled to distribute 25 per cent of its funds among land-grant and other state-supported colleges, the Foundation may exercise its discretion in encouraging research in small and promising Institutions.
ALBANY, July 24 (AP) -- More and more New Yorkers are passing their sixty-fifth birthday unmarried.
OSLO, July 24 (AP) -- Americans continued to take the major share of honors today as the international athletic meet at Bislet Stadium ended its second day's program.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- During the week ended July 23, member bank reserve balances decreased $92,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Training of doctors for rural practice will be provided as the result of the affiliation of Columbia University with the Mary Imogene Bassett Hospital in Cooperstown, N.Y., it was announced jointly yesterday by the university and the hospital.
SANTA FE, N.M., July 24 (AP) -- Two former soldiers were indicted by a Federal Grand Jury today on charges involving atomic bomb secrets.

The Board of Estimate voted unanimously yesterday to complete the demolition of the old Aquarium building in Battery Park, paving the way for sweeping reconstruction and rehabilitation of the park in connection with the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel project.
Members in good standing of the Knock Down the Favorite Club Long Island chapter, had a pleasant and profitable afternoon in the sunshine at the Jamaica horse park yesterday.

PARIS, July 24 (AP) -- Josef Asboth of Hungary upset top-seeded Tom Brown of San Francisco, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1, today to reach the singles final of the French international tennis championships along with Eric Sturgess, Davis Cup star from South Africa.

Joseph S. Fay obtained a court order through his counsel yesterday requiring the Rikers Island prison warden to present him in Bronx Supreme Court at 11 A.M. today, two days after he began serving terms of eight and a half to sixteen years for conspiracy and extortion.

GENEVA, July 24 -- The Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization decided at Lausanne today that the organization should aid refugees of German ethnic origin in camps in Austria.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- Grain markets developed a much easier undertone on the Board of Trade today. The easy close on the July yesterday and a desire to take profits as the result of the sharp upturn in prices recently found support less aggressive than of late and wheat closed 1 1/4 to 2 1/2 cents lower.

GRANVILLE, Vt., July 24 (U.P.) -- A professor's attempt to end the lifelong suffering of his mentally in and crippled daughter failed today when they were found bound together in an improvised gas chamber, the father dead, his daughter unconscious.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- The January-June passenger fatality rate for scheduled domestic airlines more than doubled this year, preliminary Civil Aeronautics Board figures showed today.

CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs. 6.500 head; total 9,000: general market active. 25 to 50 cents higher on weights under 250 pounds; heavier weight butchers, 50 to 75 cents higher: sows uneven; 50 cents to SI higher: top. $27.75; most good and choice 170 to 250 pounds.

Their five-day staging and processing period completed, 960 Boy Scouts and 130 Scout leaders who comprise the United States delegation to the Sixth World Scout Jamboree sailed yesterday afternoon from Pier 11, Staten Island, bound for France aboard the Army transport Gen. C. H. Muir.

We feel certain that public opinion in this country is overwhelmingly behind Frederick H. Osborn, our representative on the working commission of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, when he insists that there will be no retreat from the American position on the veto.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 24 -- United States Attorney General Tom Clark asserted here tonight that atheistic communism, was "spreading with the speed of a prairie fire." He called for a world brotherhood of the future built "on the rock of religion" as an answer to the present challenge to democracy and Christianity by would-be destroyers of both.

ON THE BATTLESHIP IOWA, En route to Hawaii, July 24 -- After five days aboard this 45,000-ton seagoing university, eleven Governors and Lieutenant Governors in signed statements today gave unqualified approval to the Navy's new program for training American college students as naval officers to supplement Annapolis' output.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) -- J. A. Krug, Secretary of Interior, gave Congress today what he said was just "hearsay" reports that West Coast industrialist Henry J. Kaiser "had put the heat of hell on everybody in Washington" to get $40,000,000 worth of war-time aircraft contracts.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 24 (Canadian Press) -- The scramble for Canadian Henley honors was wide open as clubs from the United States and Canada reached the halfway mark today of the four-day regatta. Buffalo West Side oarsmen, with 44, held the lead by one point over the Ottawa Rowing Club.

Construction work has been started by Shampan Shampan, architects and owners, on a one-story taxpayer on a plot 200 by 100 feet on the south side of Thirty-seventh Avenue between Eighty-fifth and Eighty-sixth Streets in Jackson Heights, Queens.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24 (AP) -- Bob Feller today became the first American League pitcher to score twelve victories this season, letting the Athletics down with five safeties as his Cleveland Indian mates banged out a 6-1 triumph before 19,204 at Shibe Park.

Evidence of a split in the ranks of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, appeared yesterday when one union local in Hoboken voted to accept a tentative agreement with the Todd shipyards and mother in Brooklyn failed to ratify and bluntly declared itself on strike.

Representatives of the Green Bus Lines, the Triboro Bus Corporation and the Amalgamated Association of Street, Electric Railway and Motor Coach Employes of America, AFL, agreed yesterday to resubmit to arbitration their dispute over the wages and working conditions of 750 drivers and maintenance men.
As part of its $3,000,000 postwar repair program, the Board of Education approved contracts yesterday totaling $568,161 for the modernization of four public schools.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., July 24 -- The Westchester County Golf Association had the largest turn-out for a one-day event in its history today when 101 pro-amateur teams toured the Tamarack Country Club course in a best-ball handicap tournament run in conjunction with the staging of the Westchester pro-amateur championship.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 24 -- Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet representative, repeated at the end of long discussions today that his country could not accept the United States resolution to set up a semi-permanent Balkan inquiry commission.

IN "Where No Birds Sing"* I.A.R. Wylle tears a number of passions to tatters. This is smooth and well-controlled melodrama, a calculated thriller that uses the American Zone of occupied Germany as 'its setting. Anything can happen in the murky depths among the ruins where the black marketeers flourish and the Nazi thugs begin to plot again, and Miss Wylie sees that it does, with considerable relish.

TOKYO, July 24 -- The growing tension between the United States and the Soviet Union is bound to be further increased by the Soviet reply on the proposed peace talks, an editorial in the important Tokyo daily Yomiuri declared tonight. This was the first Japanese comment on the Moscow radio's announcement of the Russian stand.

Random notes. Ichthyologists, as well as individuals who were just curious, have been studying fish reactions for years, to determine whether or not they perceive color and to what extent, if any, they experience pain.

The Shell Union Oil Corporation yesterday reported for the six months ended on June 30 a consolidated net income of $23,325,959 after charges and taxes. This is equal to $1.73 a capital share, and compares with $15,090,389 or $1.12 a share, in the first half of 1946.

The Drexel Furniture Company's new "Precedent" collection by Edward Wormley, introduced at McCreery's yesterday, is striking proof that this designer's talents are by no means limited to luxury furniture. The Precedent group, which will eventually total over sixty pieces, is specifically scaled for apartments and small houses.

Break of Gauge Having decided to defend the independence of the small Balkan countries against further encroachments from the West, the Russians have come out with a scheme to "integrate" the Balkan railroads with the Russian railroads, begining with Rumania.

LONDON, July 24 -- Britain and Burma have reached an agreement on arrangements for the transfer of power in fulfillment of the British pledges of last year to give the Burmese complete independence, Prime Minister Attlee announced in the House of Commons today.

All you Western fans -- and there must be a lot of them, or else they wouldn't make so many of these things -- can safely flock this week to the Victoria, where "Gunfighters" had its opening yesterday, for your gun-totin', hard-ridin', rootin'tootin' action.

Six detectives, two on each eight-hour tour, were assigned yesterday to guard Emetia Polizio, the Queens gambler responsible for the current grand jury investigation into alleged police protection for Queens County bookmakers.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Congress, concentrating on the main obstacle to adjournment Saturday, completed action on two appropriations bills today and advanced four others a step in the legislative process.

ROME, July 24 -- Count Sforza opened the debate on ratification with a fifty-minute speech especially underlining the dangers to which Italy would be exposed if she were to "isolate" herself by withholding ratification.

MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, July 24 (AP) -- Charles R. Hook, president of the American Rolling Mill Company, said tonight that ARMCO had increased basic prices of its j two finished steel products by $61 and $7 a ton.

Though there are no particularly cheering bulletins today for women about to set out on week-end marketing trips, yet neither is there any news of discouraging advances in prices, as have been reported so often lately in this Friday column.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Department of Agriculture today announced that the National Advisory Committee set up under the Research and Marketing Act of 1946 had recommended that "a large share" of the first $9,000,000 appropriation under the act "be used to develop practical methods for marketing critical farm surpluses that may arise in the years ahead."

The 1934 act expired in 1937 and was superseded by the Sugar Act of 1937, which is still in effect and which made possible the first effective international action on sugar, the International Sugar Agreement of 1937. Under the operations of the two sugar acts, the economic condition of the domestic and Cuban sugar industries was greatly improved.

BATAVIA, Java, July 24 -- The powerfully equipped Dutch army in four days of mobile warfare apparently has won its campaign for control of Java's strategic areas -- but in mountain and village strongholds the Indonesians planned tonight for another kind of resistance -- guerrilla fighting.
SALT LAKE CITY, July 24 (AP) -- A century of Mormonism in Utah reached a climax today.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey announced yesterday that it would not increase prices for either crude oil or petroleum products unless such price rises "will tend to maintain or bring out additional supplies."

As a result, consumers in the United States have been able to buy sugar during the war period and subsequently at prices below those prevailing in the free world market. The present wholesale price of sugar at 8 1/4 cents per pound, the highest we in the United States have had to pay, compares with prices of 10 to 15 cents a pound paid in other parts of the world.

The fact that the first wife of Elliott Roosevelt was permitted to marry a clergyman of the Protestant Episcopal Church, her third living husband, has brought a vehement protest from Bishop William T. Manning, it was learned yesterday.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 24 -- The Communist Minister of the Interior, Laszlo Rajk, was reported today to have asked for and to have obtained from the Cabinet powers that would make him virtual dictator over the whole national and local administrative apparatus of Hungary.

Frank J. Sampson, leader of Tammany, announced yesterday his support of Angelo Simonetti, leader of the Thirteenth Assembly District, West, and denied that Mr. Simonetti was allied with Clarence H. Neal Jr. and Bert Stand, who were ousted recently from control of Tammany.

As for the criticism that it is opposed to a freer world trade, the answer would seem to be that it expands the Cuban market for sugar in the United States, compared with its pre-war share, and thus will help to maintain and strengthen our export market in Cuba.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The War and Navy departments disclosed today the formation of the Armed Forces Special Weapons Project for military participation in the development of atomic weapons.

PARIS, July 24 -- Europe's economic cooperation conference reached the second stage of its work tonight when it sent out a memorandum to guide sixteen powers in answering five questionnaires, which will be the basis of the reply to United States Secretary of State Marshall's aid proposals.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Unification of the armed forces moved up another notch toward realization today. The Senate approved unanimously the conference agreement through which House and Senate differences were adjusted late yesterday.

JERUSALEM, July 24 -- Haganah, the Zionist militia, broadcast over its illegal radio tonight that another ship, the Return to Zion, with 400 persons aboard, was nearing the shores of Palestine. The vessel apparently was on the verge of being intercepted, because the broadcast said she was being watched by a British warship.

The newly formed Hospitalized Veterans Foundation announced yesterday the formation of plans to send theatrical units touring among nearly 200 Government hospitals and veterans' homes. The announcement was made in Chicago through a public relations firm, Robey Parks Co.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 24 -- Hinting at court action against fellow members of the Yonkers Common Council, James A. Sullivan, Vice Mayor, resigned today from that body. He was the only member of the five-member council not named to a special committee that is investigating possible official corruption in connection with reputed gambling in the former Labor Temple here.

LONDON, July 24 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin is making plans for an early visit to Washington to discuss European reconstruction under the Marshall proposal, it was learned today. The date tentatively selected for Mr. Bevin's departure is Aug. 15.

The two-week campaign for cleaner sidewalks, now being conducted by the Thirty-fourth StreetMidtown Association, swept along briskly yesterday. P. R. Haulenbeek, executive vice president of the North River Savings Bank, 206 West Thirty-fourth Street, set an example for other business men of the district by getting out broom and dustpan and tidying up the pavement in front of the bank.

Report Rush Furniture Orders Large retailers who held up furniture shipments earlier in the year because of unworkable inventories have notified supply sources to rush merchandise, manufacturers' representatives reported yesterday. While declining to confirm the situation as far as their individual stores are concerned, several merchandise executives admitted that it is "widespread trade rumor."
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday declined 46 to 65 points net under a moderate volume of business.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Michael Berescik testified today that the Congress of Industrial Organizations United Electrical Workers Union has "done everything in its power" to wreck the Bridegport, Conn., Local 203, of which he is president, because it expelled twenty-six Communist members.
LONDON, July 24 -- Proposals for setting up a Federation of Malaya early next year are contained in a White Paper-issued today by the British Colonial Office.

PARIS, July 24 -- German business and professional women are now organizing clubs, because of the personal initiative of Miss Molly Silva-Jones, supervision officer on the German Welfare Commission in the British zone.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The President's visit yesterday to the Senate, where he spent "what I think were the best ten years of my life," and his brief reoccupancy of his old seat in the chamber, will not bring enduring political peace between him and the Republicans. But the deft and brilliant personal touch of the episode somewhat soothed the ill-feeling which vetoes and other Presidential actions have aroused.

With a potential increase in metropolitan New York sales of fresh fruits and vegetables seen as totaling $100,000,000 to $200,000,000 annually, a new promotion group is being formed to stimulate consumer interest and work with retailers in speeding the flow of perishable foods to the user, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- W. Averell Harriman, Secretary of Commerce, revealed today that his "Committee of Nineteen" for determining this country's capacity for aiding the needy in other parts of the world would conduct a study of the United States economy and productive abilities unmatched in America's peacetime history.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Substantially higher prices for agricultural commodities and a number of industrial goods were responsible for an increase of 1.3 per cent in average primary market prices during the week ended July 19, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today called a hearing for Sept 9 on the joint application of the nation's railroads for a new freight rate increase estimated by the carriers to yield about $1,000,000,000 a year in additional revenue.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Chairman Harold Knutson, Republican, of Minnesota, of the House Ways and Means Committee, said tonight "it is highly improbable" Republicans will make another effort to reduce taxes before next year's Presidential election.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 24 -- If civilization is to survive, it Will be necessary to bridge the dangerous gap that now exists between the social and physical sciences, Charles Edison, former Governor of New Jersey, warned here today.

BERLIN, July 24 -- The Minister-Presidents of the Russian zone appealed to the Allied Control Council for the economic and political unity of Germany, it was learned today. Unlike their Russian sponsors, however, they did not regard the reparations settlement as a conditional issue.

with the score 2 to 0 in favor of St. Louis Lirst half of the ninth inning, two out, nobody on base. Player Northey of St. Louis hit a long high drive to centerfield. The ball hit a railing marking the stands, bounced high into the air and came back on the playing field.

Twenty leading gas-range manufacturers, representing 50 per cent of that industry's volume throughout the nation, have concentrated production on models which may be purchased by the consumer complete with automatic clock control attachment, a spokesman for the Gas Appliance Manufacturers Association reported yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 25 (AP) -- A very Beck of Raleigh, N.C., and Wilfred Crossley of Atlanta, Ga., won their semi-finals matches in the national public links tourney today, and will meet for the championship tomorrow.
Dish With a History The time has come to make a few observation about Boston brown bread. There are heretical goings-on these days with too many of the staple foods of yesteryear.
BATAVIA, Java, July 25 (AP) -- A Netherland Army communique:

A motley procession of pets, ranging from an ant in a paper drinking cup to salamanders, snails, goldfish and mongrel dogs, was paraded by lower East Side youngsters yesterday on the rooftop of the Educational Alliance at 197 Bast Broadway.

LOS ANGELES, July 25 -- Beset by insurgent movements from both flanks of his party, James Roosevelt, state democratic chairman has called his 660-member state committee into extraordinary session here tomorrow and Sunday to iron out the "party line."
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- President Truman announced today the resignation of Keen Johnson as under-Secretary of Labor, effective Aug.1, just a year from the day he was appointed to the office.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The House Armed Services Committee today put President Truman's program for universal military training in position for early action next year.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The CIO Maritime Committee accused "certain well-established American steamship lines" today of hindering the expansion of the American merchant fleet.

The semi-final bracket of the Le.nth invitation men's tennis singles tournament at the Hamilton Cowts was filled yesterday with seeded players advancing. Joey Fishbach, defending champion, eliminated William Madamba of San-Francisco State College, 8-6, 6-0.
PARIS, July 25 -- The United States possesses a virtual monopoly on marketable uranium, Frederic Joliot-Curie, French High Commissioner of Atomic Energy, said at a press conference here today.
PARIS, July 25 -- The terms of a special questionnaire regarding balance of payments were adopted at a meeting of the Cooperation Committee of the European economic conference today.

Through their activities in Germany, "monopolists" American corporations have strained the critical relations between the United States and Russia and are in the process of causing the deterioration of French-American relations, it was asserted yesterday by James S. Martin. He resigned recently as chief of the decartelization branch of the American Military Government in Germany.

WEST FRANKFORT,Ill., July 25 -- The explosion which took the lives of twenty-seven coal miners yesterday in Old Ben Mine No. 8 was officially ascribed to gas as John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine WorKers, made a surprise visit to the scene of the second major Illinois mine disaster in four months.

OSLO, July 25 (AP) -- The world record for the discus throw, held by Adolfo Consolini, an Italian, since 1941 went to the United States today when Fortune Gordien of the University of Minnesota established a mark of 178.47 feet-almost three and one-half feet better than the former standard.
WASHINGTON, Saturday, July 26 -- With eager scholars looking on, the papers of Abraham Lincoln which his son collected and sealed for twenty-one years after his own death were opened early today.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- President Truman called off the usual Cabinet meeting to give his attention to the hundreds of bills reaching his desk from the waning session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Two former Communists testified today that the Red party had contaminated the CIO United Electrical Workers from the level of top international officers down through Local unions.

NORTH ARLINGTON, N.J., July 25 -- Sixty men, women and children temporarily withdrew a threat to set up housekeeping in the Borough Hall here early this morning, when they were assured of a chance to put before state officials their demands for emergency housing.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The vote by which the Senate adopted early today a motion by Senator Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan, to table a motion by Senator George, Democrat, of Georgia, to postpone until Jan. 3, 1948, consideration of a proposal to investigate the Justice Department's handling of an inquiry into alleged Kansas City vote frauds:
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 25 -- What was put down to become a windless rout in the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week today was turned into a finish when a belated southerly breeze saved the situation.
The Board of Estimate is seriously considering a fare of 5 cents on subway and elevated lines during rush hours with a 10-cent fare in the non-rush hour periods, it was learned yesterday.

BATAVIA, Java, July 25 -- The Dutch declared today that they had virtually completed the first phase of their military operations in Java, and Dutch officials indicated that they now were turning to the political consolidation of their position through the organization of a new Indonesian Government.

ST. LOUIS, July 25 (AP) -- The Cardinals collected 13 hits, including two triples and a single by Pitcher Howie Pollett, to knock the Braves out of second place in the National League race with a 5-to-1 victory tonight.
ALBANY, July 25 -- The Adjutant Central released the following orders today:

DBS MOINES, Iowa, July 25 -- A statement of objectives pledging extension of religious education of American youth and announcing resistance within our borders to atheistic communism and "all other Godless materialisms" was unanimously endorsed today by the 5,000 lay and clerical educators attending the International Sunday School Convention here.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 25 (AP) -- Six out of every seven potential lynchings have been prevented in the South in the last ten years by courageous peace officers, alert public officials, and by popular reaction against mob-murder.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Unification of this country's armed forces, under a single Secretary of Defense, received final approval by Congress today.

Among the crimes for which the Nazi leaders were convicted and hanged at Nuremberg were crimes against humanity. These consisted, in the words of the Nuremberg Tribunal, of systematic violence, brutality and terror against the civilian population and of mass murder, deportation, slave labor and concentration camps for racial, religious or political groups for the purpose of their extermination.

BERLIN, July 25 (AP) -- A difference between the policies of the United States State Department and views of the United States Military Government here concerning governing Germany became apparent today.

In a supplementary report filed yesterday in the Federal Court, here, the SEC stated that the plan submitted by the trustees of the Childs Company for reorganizing the company would be fair, equitable, and feasible, if a modification is made relative to preemptive rights of stockholders.
