To emphasize on a world-wide scale a policy of peace-making "adequate to the atomic age," the Emergency World People's Congress announced yesterday plans for an airplane flight on Aug. 5 from New York to the New Mexico desert where the first atom bomb was exploded.

DETROIT, July 25 -- The Ford Motor Company today ordered suspension of production of Mercury and Lincoln automobiles as the result of the strike of 7,000 UAWCIO employes of the Murray Corporation of America, one of key parts suppliers for Ford.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

We find ourselves talking about cucumber pickles rather earlier than usual this summer. But, as we pointed out in yesterday's market column, the vegetable is of tempting quality now and of such low price (two pounds for 9 cents in some markets) that pickling seems indicated.

ALEY, Lebanon, July 25 -- Hedji Agus Salim, Foreign Minister of the Indonesian Republic, announced today that he was going to Cairo to consult with Arab League officials on a solution of the Dutch-Indonesian conflict and to seek support for Indonesia from the Arab states.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, July 25 -- The Preparatory Commission for the International Refugee Organization ended a ten-day session today.

Based on recorded interviews with people along the European and Pacific invasion routes of the American forces, "We Went Back," CBS documentary, will be broadcast Aug. 14 from 10 to 11 P.M. It will cast a highly negative reflection on wartime hopes for a new and better world, according to a preview yesterday of the program.

Taylor Gives Seven Hits Taylor, allowing seven hits, was in command all the way as he hung up his eighth triumph against three setbacks. He seldom was behind a hitter, walking three and striking out two.

The stock market turned cautious yesterday but only after a further new high for the current recovery movement had been set. Final prices were mixed. Moderate profit-taking appeared in the afternoon to cut down the morning bulge, and the composite price index showed a net decline of 0.09 point.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- A parachute release to provide means for the automatic or controlled disconnection on contact with the ground of the load, whether pack or person, to be dropped has been patented by Frank C. Anderson of the United States Coast Guard, to whom was awarded one of the 324 patents issued this week by the United States Patent Office.

GUATEMALA, July 25 -- Authorities estimated that a million persons here and in other Latin-American countries joined today in a protest against the continued occupation by Britain of British Honduras, which territory is claimed by Guatemala.

LONDON, July 25 -- Heavy selling of British Government stocks brought prices down with a run in the stock markets here today. Much of the persistent selling of gilt-edge issues is believed to be by industrial companies to obtain money for business purposes.

Trade Here Seasonally Active Retail trade here continued seasonally active this week, but percentage gains over last year were smaller. The increase for department stoics was put at 5 to 6 per cent over the like week of 1946.

Following the action taken by the American Rolling Mill Company on Thursday, the Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's third largest producer of steel, announced yesterday higher prices, effective immediately, for hotrolled carbon and alloy bars, cold finished bars, hot and cold-rolled sheets and strip and related products.

Chief Judge John T. Loughran of the Court of Appeals declined yesterday to call a special session of that court on Monday to hear appeals in four primary election cases. He held that they were not of sufficient importance to try to convene the court on the day before the election next Tuesday.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 25 -- Flashing a terrific burst of speed through the stretch, Proximity, 5-year-old brown mare by Protector and owned by Ralph and Gordon Verhurst of Victor, N.Y., won the $25,000 American Trotting Championship at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that minimum producer prices of Class 1 fluid milk in four leading Northeastern marketing regions will be increased the equal of 1 cent a quart Aug. 1 instead of on Sept. 1 as previously reported.

Two accidents within two days have taken the lives of two of the six children of Mr. and Mrs. Gustave Schleiser of 80-84 Fifty-ninth Street, Ridgewood, Queens, who, have been on home relief for three months.
City Markets Department inspectors are no longer making a daily survey of meat price fluctuations in various shopping areas, it was learned yesterday.

Kaiser aluminum plants have entered the building material field with a new alloy designed for roofing and siding for farm, residential and industrial applications, officials of the Permanente Metals Corporation disclosed here yesterday.

KEARNY, N.J., July 25 -- A 24-year-old Newark truck driver calmly re-enacted today for prosecutor's aides and the police the drowning of his attractive 23-year-old wife last night in the Passaio River under the Lincoln Highway Bridge.

Decision was reserved yesterday by Supreme Court Justice J. Edward Lumbard after a long and heated argument in four suits brought by the Transport Workers Union, which is seeking to void the dismissal of two employes and the suspension of two other municipal subway employes by the Board of Transportation in the slow-down of the subway lines last June.

BATAVTA, July 25 (U.P.)--Front dispatches and official advices indicated today that the Netherland High Command has thrown two armored columns from the west against Jogjakarta to support an attack that apparently was stalled in the mountains north of the Republican capital for the third day.
Dense, pungent smoke from a fire in a sweater factory on the top floor of 326-28 West Fortyfirst Street, swept over Times Square for twenty minutes yesterday.

LONDON, July 25 -- A warning that the imposition of a tax on imported American films would rebound to the disadvantage of British film earnings in the United States was sounded today by j. Arthur Rank, British film leader.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Retail food prices in large cities rose 1.5 per cent in the month to June 15, to set a new record high level for the retail food price index for the third time in eighth months. This was reported today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which said the index rose to 190.5 per cent of the 1935-39 average.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Prospects developed today that Belgium might desire to be consulted along with France on any decision concerning a higher level of industry in Germany. These prospects were based on a long conference held by Baron Robert Silvercruys, Belgian Ambassador, with Robert A. Lovett, Under-Secretary of State.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

A woman's persistence proved rewarding after she had accompanied policemen for five nights in their radio car on the lookout for the taxi driver who took $96 from her last Saturday night, the police revealed yesterday.

PARIS, July 25 -- Miss Sally Butler of Indianapolis was elected president of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women today. She was elected at the closing session of the Paris congress of the organization.

CHEYENNE. Wyo., July 25 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York headed east tonight after a three-week "non-political vacation" west of the Mississippi during which he talked with Republican leaders of twelve Western states with a total of 204 delegates to next year's national convention.

The three members of the city's new Temporary Rent Control Commission held their first meeting yesterday at 500 Park Avenue, and drew up the orders and regulations with which they will administer the municipa. rent law.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 (AP) -- Although in trouble every inning except the second and fourth, Phil Marchildon pitched his eleventh victory of the season tonight as the Athletics supported him with an eleven-hit attack that felled the Tigers, 9-5.

If the man who first turned out the so-called "popping plug" had taken out a patent he could spend these hot days reclining on a cool porch at his country estate and idly clip coupons while he tried to think up new methods of spending his income.

Many leading Baptists from this country will attend the seventh Baptist World Congress in Copenlagen, Denmark, opening Monday and continuing through the next Sunday. More than 12,000,000 Baptists from sixty nations will be represented, it was announced at the headquarters of the Northern Baptist Convention, 152 Madison Avenue.

Annual savings of more than $250,000 at each dock can be made by New York companies in reduced costs of handling freight, Preben Jessen, engineer-owner of Preben Jessen Company, Chrysler Building, disclosed here yesterday. Mr. Jessen said the findings were based on a recent survey.

The current controversy over the remarriage of divorced persons in the Protestant Episcopal Church widened out yesterday as Dr. Guy Emery Shipler, editor of The Churchman, said he disagreed "violently" with the stand taken by the Right Rev. William T. Manning, retired Bishop of New York.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., July 25-Four teams wound up in a deadlock for the medal when today's qualifying ended in the Charles R. Casey Memorial golf tournament. This annual fixture at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club commemorates the memory of one of its most popular members.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 25 -- The Control Committee of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission received today an informal proposal that an international court receive power to issue a "warrant" for inspection of suspected violations of atomic control.

Elmer Ray, Hastings (Fla.) heavyweight, gained the decision over Ezzard Charles, Cincinnati battler, in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The decision, which was not unanimous, was not accepted kindly by the crowd of 8,290 fans, most of whom thought that Charles was entitled to the award.
After a rather poor start, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange recovered yesterday and closed 5 to 29 points net higher.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 25 -- Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer today signed George Brent to replace Walter Pidgeon in "Luxury Liner," a comedy, which Richard Whorf will direct starting next month. The cast will also include Frances Gifford, Lauritz Melchior, Jane Powell, Xavier Cugat and Marina Koshetz.

Two more plays have obtained Broadway bookings for the new season. Coming up first, probably during the week of Aug. 25, will be the Shuberts' "We Love a Lassie," the comedy by Marcel Wallenstein and Mary Kathleen Kennedy, which is earmarked for the Booth Theatre.

WASHINGTON, July 25--President Truman, by signing a Senate Joint Resolution ending about 175 of his war powers as of today or within one year, put a terminal limit on the vast system of benefits which were conferred on veterans of World War II.

LONDON, July 25 (Reuters) -- The view that women employed on cargo vessels constitute "a danger to the future well-being: and employment of men." In the British merchant navy received an endorsement by the conference of the National Union of Seamen here today.

Governor Dewey was asked yesterday to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate the charges of Emetia Polizio, avowed bookmaker, that the police exacted heavy tribute from him and his fellows as the price for permitting them to operate in Queens.

Upholding the protest of the Cardinals, President Ford C. Frick Of the National League yesterday nullified the Dodgers' 3-2 victory over St. Louis last Sunday and ruled the game a 3-3 tie. Simultaneously, he ordered the contest be replayed as the first game of a double-header at Ebbets Field on Aug. 18. Except for the disputed play, all batting, fielding and pitching records uf that engagement remain official.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Under the resolution signed by President Truman the following powers were repealed at once:
SECURITY COUCIL Continued discussion of Greek question and debated interpretation of Charter provisions on which United States draft resolution is based.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The new Joint Congressional Committe to watch over the Taft-Hartley Labor Act laid down today a heavy provisional agenda for its inquiry into the operations of that act and into labor-management difficulties in general.
BATAVIA, Java, July 25 (AP) -- An Indonesian Army communique:

ROCHESTER, Minn., July 25 (AP) -- Her normal weight of 120 pounds shrunken to a mere 46, Allie Tee Graham, thirty years old, of Lexington, Ky., was in St. Mary's Hospital here today undergoing tests by Mayo Clinic doctors who are trying to diagnose her mysterious ailment.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 -- Two corporations filed registration statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission today covering 100,000 shares of preferred and 200,000 shares of common stock and $800,000 of bonds.

A Dutch communique announces that the Java port of Cheribon has fallen to their troops. It is probable that by now armored Dutch patrols also are in the mountain town of Linggadjati, some thirty miles south. Here was negotiated and Initialed last November the agreement that, it was hoped, would provide for a peaceful transition from colonialism to self-government for the rich East Indies.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- Mel Ott's mounting pitching problems and the descent of the Giants continued to move apace today. Nor was there anything the vaunted power of the Polo Grounders could do to stem the one or the other.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- When President Truman signs the bill unifying the armed forces, Air Force leaders will begin a drive to forge the new independent but undersized United States Air Force jnto a ready-to-fight organization "by Christmas."

An all-the-way victory for Frank Frankel's colt Blunt Remark and a long-shot double for the up-and-coming master Tex Jasperson were among the highlights of the racing yesterday at Jamaica, where the favorites coninued to find the going rough.

ALBANY, July 25 -- Supreme Court Justice Isadore Bookstein is expected to rule shortly on an application for an injunction against Herman T. Stichman, Housing Commissioner, and other officials restraining them from allocating state funds to a denominational college.

Workers yesterday were sawing through the roofs, sidewalls and floors of barracks at Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn, cutting them into sections which next week will be trucked to the southeast section of the field where they will be reassembled.

The importance of community cooperation in the successful teaching of nutrition was emphasized yesterday by Dr. Clyde B. Shuman of the Department of Home Economics of New York University, who just completed an experimental nutrition project at the Joan of Arc Community Center summer play camp, 154 West Ninety-third Street.

City Council President Vincent R. Impellitteri welcomed to City Hall yesterday eleven officers and 110 cadets from the Capana, a training ship of the Venezuelan Kavy. At a ceremony held in the Council chamber, Mr. Impellitteri declared that the visit of the vessel served to strengthen the cordial relations now existing between the United States and Venezuela.

WASHINGTON, Saturday, July 26 -- The Democrats broke yesterday the long Republican campaign to force an investigation of Attorney General Tom C. Clark as the Eightieth Congress struggled, in hot and still rising partisan feeling, toward the end of this session.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 25 (AP) -- The racing silks of Joseph M. Roebling, New Jersey patron, played an important part in the sport at Monmouth Park today.

WARSAW, July 25 (London Times dispatch) -- The Polish Government, through an official spokeman, expressed amazement today at the American decision to bar Poland from receiving a share of the emergency relief funds. While not prepared to make an official protest, the Polish Government considers the American step "unjust" toward an Allied country that suffered so much in the war.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Andrew J. May, former chairman of the House Military Affairs Committee, and the munitions-making Garsson brothers were sentenced to from eight months to two years in Federal prison on war-bribe charges today despite their fervent pleas that they were guiltless.

BOSTON, July 25 (AP) -- Off to a four-run first inning in which Ted Williams and Bobby Doerr hitj home runs in succession, the Red Sox tonight defeated the Browns, 7-6, before a packed Fenway Park crowd of 34,059.

Herbert Livingston Satterlee, 83-year-old lawyer, who ended his life July 15, left his residuary estate in equal shares to his two daughters, it was disclosed yesterday when his will was offered in Surrogate's Court. The petition for probate, which was filed by the law firm of Satterlee, Warfield Stephens, of which he was senior member, formally valued the estate at "more than $10,000."

Parking lot fees, already at record high levels, were increased again yesterday. The move came twelve hours after the Board of Estimate had approved unanimously the Clemente-Schwartz bill to license garages, and lots. It is aimed at curbing a wide variety of abuses that have gouged motorists since Office of Price Administration controls were lifted last November.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Joseph S. Fay, labor leader, lost his plea yesterday to have his sentence for conspiracy and extortion stayed and was remanded to Rikers Island prison to continue serving his term of eight and a half to sixteen years.

The tentative formula for settlement at the Todd shipyards of the month-old strike of ship construction and repair workers though turned down by employes of that company's Brooklyn division Thursday, has resulted In renewed activity between union and management negotiators for other struck yards.
SEOUL, Korea, July 25 -- Authorities here expect the outbreak of widespread violence in the United States occupation zone in the next three weeks.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that reserves of corn on July 1 were about 37 per cent larger than a year ago. They totaled 727,359,000 bushels, compared with 532,157,000 a year ago. Farms held 687,800,000 bushels and off-farm storage 39,600,000.

WASHINGTON, July 25, (AP) -- Senator Reed, Republican, of Kansas, today introduced a resolution asking a Senate investigation of the administration of railroad reorganization plans by courts, the Interstate Commerce Commission and other agencies.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 25 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund have submitted draft agreements for entering into formal cooperation with the United Nations, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, Saturday, July 26 -- The Senate voted last night a bill providing practically all of the funds requested by President Truman for foreign relief and Greek-Turkish aid.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) Little Mick'ey Haefner checked Cleveland on three hits tonight to give Washington its fourth straight victory 5 to 1. before a crowd of 16,252. It was Haefner's fifth victory against eight defeats.

Reed Bill Blocked The controversial Reed bill, which would permit some railroads now in bankruptcy to reorganize voluntarily with the approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission, appears to have been blocked from more consideration before Congress adjourns.

NANKING, July 25 -- Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer will confer with Chinese liberals and with prominent non-Kuomintang figures during his mission to China for President Truman, it was said Mere today. However, he will make no effort to confer with Chinese Communists.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 25 -- Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, endorsing an argument advanced by Yugoslavia, asserted again today that the United Nations Security Council did not have the power to compel any country to admit an investigating commission.

Ill-advised sales of defective war surplus machinery and aircraft abroad have seriously damaged the foreign reputation and current marketing opportunities of reliable American manufacturers in these lines, spokesmen asserted here yesterday.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:
To meet higher operating costs the Public Service Commission has granted a temporary increase In gas rates to the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, it was announced yesterday.

Girl Scout officials greeted yesterday twenty-five foreign delegates from the thirty-fifth anniversary Girl Scout international encampment as they arrived at Pennsylvania Station for the "last lap" of their "camp log, U.S.A."

Cutbacks in production of automobiles and airplanes both at Detroit and in New York have caused major secondary set-backs or "chain reaction" in plants of parts producers, industry spokesmen revealed here yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 25 (AP) -- This was Tom Wright day at the $10,000 Columbus open golf tourney as the 31-year-old dark horse from Knoxville, Tenn., who has never won a king-sized event, fired a 33, 34-67, five under par, to pace a fine field through the first eighteen holes of the seventy-two-hole medal play test.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- Sharply lower prices prevailed on the Board of Trade today as the result of persistent hedging sales in wheat and a five-day weather forecast for above-normal temperatures in the Midwestern corn belt. Liquidation developed and with stop-loss orders uncovered closing trades were at the bottom, with wheat showing a loss of 2 1/4 to 3 1/4 cents.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- President Truman nominated today his military aide, Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, to be a permanent major general in the Officers Reserve Corps. He now holds that grade temporarily, by virtue of his assignment to the White House.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 25 -- The Hungarian Parliament, elected in November, 1945, was dissolved today by a decree of President Zoltan Tildy.

MOSCOW, July 25 (UP) -- The British-Russian trade talks ended today without agreement on outstanding financial questions of the vital wheat question, Harold Wilson, British Secretary for Overseas Trade, said at a press conference before he left by plane for London.

Both over-buying and underbuying are "bad" policies to follow at this time, and instead of these practices, industrial purchasing should be limited to placing orders for materials, parts and equipment actually needed for current output or construction, purchasing spokesmen asserted her yesterday.

Bernard Herrmann, radio conductor and movie composer, will make his debut at Lewisohn Stadium Monday night. He will conduct the Philharmonic-Symphony Monday through Wednesday. Thursday's and Saturday's concerts will be conducted by Richard Korn, also new to the Stadium.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Political and other "pressure" to head off an inquiry into wartime plane contracts of Howard Hughes and Henry J. Kaiser was reported today by Chairman Owen Brewster of the Senate War Investigating Committee.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

BAD SALZUFLEN, Germany, July 25 -- A wide split in trade unionism, as the result of the increasing influence of Communists in those groups, is expected to develop in the British zone within the next few months. It was learned today that a rival Christian union is expected to be formed, with the possible support of the Socialists.

LAKE SUCCESS. N.Y., July 25 -- Nations lacking free-press and information facilities should be barred from membership in the United Nations, Hector McNeil, the British representative, told the Economic and Social Council today.

Abstract and fine art in advertising, used during the war period for institutional ads designed to keep company and brand names before the public, are now being replaced by art which presents a strong selling message, Gilbert Tompkins, art representative, pointed out yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 25 -- Former Mayor Frank Hague, who led the fight against the proposed state constitution that was rejected in a referendum in 1944, intimated today that he would oppose the constitution being drafted in New Brunswick if the state's present system of tax assessment was retained by the convention.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 25 -- A sharp attack on the New York State school merit plan, adopted by the Legislature at its last session, was made today by educators attending the final meeting here of the Human Relations Workshop of New York University.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 25 (Canadian Press)--Crews from the Wyandotte (Mich.) Boat Club catapulted into the lead today at the sixty-fifth Royal Canadian Henley regatta and another American contingent, the West Sides of Buffalo, took over a close second position.

VIENNA, July 25 -- The Soviet Union, Britain and France were formally invited today to send a representative with each United States team investigating the distribution of $100,000,000 worth of United States relief goods in Austria.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Canada, India and the Philippines replied favorably today to the United States proposal for a conference to draft the Japanese treaty.

Preliminary figures for the first half of 1947 made public by the Civil Aeronautics Board show that 5.8 passengers were killed on the scheduled domestic airlines for every 100,000,000 passenger-miles flown. These figures compare with a rate of 2.3 deaths per 100,000,000 passenger-miles for the first six months of 1946 and a rate of 1.2 for the full term of last year.

ATHENS, July 25 -- A force of 1,200 to 1,500 guerrillas attacked the town of Grevena, thirty miles southeast of the Grammos Mountains, at 3 o'clock this morning, the Ministry of Public Order announced.

PARIS, July 25 -- The tension between the United States and the Soviet Union, which weighs heavily upon the spirits of the French, dominated the debate on foreign affairs in the Assembly today Speakers betrayed a sense of helplessness in face of this extra-European rivalry that dwarfs merely European issues.

LONDON, July 2o -- Secretary for Overseas Trade Wilson and five other members of the British delegation to the Anglo-Soviet trade talks were injured tonight when the plane bringing the party jack from Moscow crashed at the London airport.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 25 -- The Jewish Agency for Palestine submitted a, letter today to Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations accusing Britain of "shameful and inhuman action" in returning to France 4,500 Jews who tried to enter Palestine aboard the refugee ship Exodus 1947 a week ago.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 25 -- The special committee of the Yonkers Common Council investigating alleged gambling at the former Labor Temple here from 1944 to 1946 recessed tonight without setting a reconvening date, after hearing three witnesses and a statement by the attorney for James A. Sullivan, who resigned yesterday from the Common Council.

Having lost his first game in the ninth round of the European zonal chess championship preliminaries last night, Ludek Pachman, Czechoslovakia, leader since the start; still retained first place among the fourteen competitors, according to a report from Hilversum, the Netherlands.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., July 25 -- The defending champion and medalist, Mrs. R. M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley, reached the final of the New York State golf championship today at the Leewood Country Club course.

Five hundred pickets from several Congress of Industrial Organizations unions joined striking employes of the Brooklyn Trust Company yesterday on the picket line outside the main office of the bank at 177 Montague Street, Brooklyn.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 25 -- Two strokes removed from defeat at 4-5 and 0-30 in the third set, Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., overcame James Brink of Seattle, Wash., today in the semifinals of the "invitation tennis tour nament at the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club.
BUENOS AIRES, July 25 (UP) -- No more foreign exchange for newsprint imports will be allotted until further notice, the Government recently announced.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Senate jockeying today on President Truman's nominations to the National Labor Relations Board may mean that the men will serve only as recess appointees instead of for specific terms.
CHICAGO, July 25 (A.P.) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department at Agriculture follows:

CINCINNATI, July 25 (AP) -- Although battered for thirteen hits, Ewell Blackwell survived a ninthinning Philadelphia rally tonight to notch his sixteenth consecutive victory as the Reds trimmed the Phillies, 5-4, before a crowd of 24,430.

BILL MAtTLDIN says in his foreword to Allen R. Matthews' "The Assault"* that "the favorite method of settling international arguments looks downright" unattractive when viewed through these pages." It certainly does that For this is an excellently written account of a Marine rifleman's twelve days of twentieth-century hell after he hit the beach in the assault on Iwo Jima.

Satisfactory order volume was recorded at the twenty-second summer lamp show which closed yesterday in the Hotel New Yorker. This development was a surprise to most producers, who had braced themselves for a repetition of the almost no lamp buying activity which characterized the previous two weeks' Chicago homefurnishings market.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 25 -- A majority of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine, whose last contingent left Lebanon for Europe today, went away from the Middle East professing that its mind had not been made up on any solution for the Palestine problem.

The broadening horizons of European thinking are illustrated in the proposal at the Geneva Trade Conference to adjust the projected world trade charter in such a way as to promote Europe's economic integration through customs unions, which have often proved to be the precursors of political unification.

E.V. Murphree, executive vice president, was elected president yesterday of the Standard Oil Development Company, central research organization of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), to succeed Robert P. Russell, who is resigning to become technical consultant to the International Basic Economy Corporation.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- Oil companies producing from submerged lands off the California coast under state permit may continue their operations under an agreement announced today by the Justice Department.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The recent coal pact provides that it covers employes during such time as they are "able and willing" to work. This language has been the subject of much possible misinterpretation. A good deal of needless anxiety may thereby be created as to the attitude of unions generally to maintain uninterrupted production during the terms of their respective contracts.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 26 Frank Parker defaulted to Gardnar Mulloy in the final of the invitation tournament at the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club today. Parker will be out of competition with an injury for the next ten days and possibly for three weeks.

Retail trade here last week was seasonally active, with good response noted to clearance offerings. The sales increase over last year was smaller than in the preceding week, but comparison was with extremely high sales levels a year ago.

EAST BOOTHBAY, Me. -- This quiet little seaside town rising above the boatyards on the wide mouth of the Damariscotta River is to be host beginning Thursday to a three-day Maine State Fisherman's Fair. This is a brand-new event of Maine's summer season and its climax on Saturday will be the "Biggest Clambake on Earth."

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 26 (AP) -- Cover Up, a spanking chestnut 4-year-old, captured the eighth running of the $100,000 Hollywood Gold Cup today, soundly defeating eleven rivals by five lengths in near world record time before 48,846 fans at Hollywood Park.

Another in the major steps being taken by the few remaining utility holding company systems toward compliance with the dissolution provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act was taken last week by the 57-yearold North American Company. It began divestment of the Wisconsin Electric Power Company, the fourth subsidiary to be divorced from the parent company.

ON March 10, 1933, the fifteen hundred unorganized shoe workers who made up the labor force of the major industry in Yankee City (Newburyport Mass.) went out on strike. When they returned to work in the city's seven shoe factories almost a month later, they were members of the Shoe Workers Protective Union, which had been recognized by the manufacturers, and their wage demands were being arbitrated.

Radio has come a considerable way since the days of the crystal set. To keep pace with its technical advancement its minions have produced an increasingly specialized and -- to outsiders -- unintelligible jargon. Some of the more colorful phrases used by radio technicians and performers are:

THE seventeenth century in England produced a body of writing sometimes loosely referred to as "Characters," usually short, informal biographical or historical sketches, undoubtedly influenced in style by certain classical and popular French authors, but possessing a distinct vitality of its own.
A second defeat in consecutive rounds cost Ludek Pachman the lead in the European zone championship chess preliminaries, according to a report yesterday from Hilversum to the Netherlands.

WASHINGTON, July 26--As a result of unification of the armed forces, it was learned today, the War Department has conceived the eventual establishment of a single defense commander for the whole of this country.

"It is always a good thing to go away, if only to view one's friends for a while in perspective." -- Alphonse Karr. "One should never be awakened on a holiday. Nobody should ever dream of starting by any train before eleven o'clock in the morning.

Martha Ellen Truman mother of the President was frontier-born. Her father, Solomon Young of Shelby County, Ky., ran Conestoga trains and herded cattle from Independence. Mo., to Salt Lake City and San Francisco, along the old Overland Trail, more than 100 years ago.

Liquor taxes enriched Federal, state and local governments by nearly three and a half billion dollars in 1946, an increase of 15.28 per cent over the preceding year, according to a report released yesterday by the Distilled Spirits Institute.

MANILA, July 26 -- Although closely allied racially, and politically sympathetic to the Indonesians of Java, the Philippine Republic has adopted an official policy of aloofness and neutrality toward the trouble in the Netherlands Indies.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The first session of the Eightieth Congress, expiring wearily as this is written, has made history beyond the normal record of a national Legislature controlled by the party in opposition to the Administration, and has lived through a great deal more.

WHEN that bedraggled old eagle. Rip Van Winkle, descended to the plain from his eyrie among the Catskills, he virtually closed the terrain to further literary exploitation. Who could match Washington Irving on his home ground ?

IT is customary to think of Samuel Johnson only as an eccentric personality and forceful talker. Accepted without question by many people is the nineteenth-century verdict that Johnson's own writing may rightly be ignored.

JERUSALEM, July 26 -- Almost exactly a year after the King David Hotel explosion in Jerusalem, in which ninety-one Britons and Arabs were killed, the Irgun Zvai Leumi terrorist organization charged that the Haganah underground movement had been implicated in the attack.

Although Congress has indicated its desire to end control of consumer credit under Regulation W on Nov. 1, no broad change in credit granting practices appears likely immediately thereafter, according to views expressed in credit circles here last week.

Speed-boat veterans who have helped make Gold Cup history over the years since 1904 when the first race was held will rub their eyes in disbelief over the ambitions this year of Freeport's South Shore Yacht club, which will stage the classic on Jamaica Bay.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- A measure restoring Government support of domestic wool prices at their present levels went to President Truman today as the House, abandoning wait-and-see tactics, passed the bill without tariffboosting, quota-fixing qualifications.
Evidence of life of 3,000 years ago in the Back Bay section of Boston has been found in excavating for a new skyscraper building in that area, the Turner Construction Company said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON -- A group of Senators hag been finding out recently that it is not too easy to travel abroad, even if the tourist has plenty of money. What the legislators learned about passports and border red tape may be translated into legislation that may benefit vacation travelers of next season.

THE Postoffice Department made available last week a photograph of the promised 10-cent airmail stamp. To be black in color and of special-delivery size, it will receive first-day sale at Washington on Aug. 30.

A pioneer agricultural community will be established for 300 Jewish refugee orphans as soon as 300 to 600 acres of farm land are obtained in New York or neighboring states, Moses Rosenberg of the executive, committee of the Emergency Rescue Committee for European Jews, 316 South Fifth Street, Brooklyn, said yesterday.

HORSE BLOOD BANK -- There is a blood bank for valuable horses, cows and dogs at the State College of Washington. Blood is collected, preserved and transfused by the usual methods. Animal donors are lightly anesthetized before blood is drawn from their veins, and great care is exercised to avoid draining too much at a time.

AUBURN, Ala., July 26 (AP) -- Dr. Luther N. Duncan, president of Alabama Polytechnic Institute (Auburn), died in his home today of a heart attack. He was 72 years old. He had been in poor health for some time but had not been regarded as seriously ill.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 26 -- Conflicts within the Republican organizations of White Plains and New Rochelle hit crescendo today as Tuesday's primary election approached.

UPTON SINCLAIR once (1903) longed to publish books for thirty or forty cents a volume. He once planned to have everything he wrote published by his own press, so that everyone who bought one of his books would know that "he pays for it just what it has cost to create it for him -- the printing and handling of it, and what the author needed for food and shelter, and for books and music."

WHY has the straightforward teller of adult adventure stories become such a rarity in American literature? Our best exponents of this most stimulating but fading art, authors like Rex Stout or Earnest Haycox, appear to have been seduced into the ever-widening detective story field, or are to be found (their genius usually unsung) in the Western story -- both eminently laudable classifications but limited in scope and appeal by the unwritten laws of their genre.

NEW DELHI, India, July 26 -- The accession of the Princely States to the Dominion of India will imply the gradual introduction of democratic processes into those principalities that are now under autocratic rule, it was stated in authoritative quarters here today.

THE HAGUE, July 26 -- A charge made last night by Frans Goedhart, Socialist Member of the Dutch Parliament, that the decision of the Government to open police action in Indonesia had not been supported by its Commission General in Indonesia was described today in official circles as "absolutely false."

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Senators investigating Howard Hughes' war-time plane contracts enlisted State Department aid today to find a missing witness who previously had told of lavish entertainment for a high Government official.

IN a long, and often friendly, acquaintance with movie press agents I have never heard one say that the picture he was touting was a "screensation"; and although I am fairly familiar with followers of popular and classical music, no one in my presence has actually used the words "scorchestra" or "Beethoventhusiast."

IN his introductory remarks to this account of one of the auto workers' major strikes. Henry Kraus argues -- and justifiably -- that the amount of labor literature is limited. He contends that this situation has left the reading public ignorant of much important labor fact and history.

Apostle of Liberty An article in Foreign Affairs by the English historian G.P. Gooch, and two biographical studies published recently in England, point to a newly awakened interest in Lord Acton as historian and political philosopher.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Government aviation officials are turning their attention to fighting birds in order to have airline travel safer in the United States. The Civil Aeronautics administration has found that "bird strikes" are such a common cause of collisions they are threatening to become the No. 1 flying hazard of high-speed commercial planes.
Two important golf events and one tennis championship are scheduled for this week.

Ten contests for Tammany Assembly district leaderships will take place in Tuesday's primary election and three Republican leadership contests in New York County. There will be only three contests for party nominations for public office in the entire city.

THE name of George Macdonald means very little to contemporary world. The graduate student will have a vague impression of an early member of the kailyard school; the children's librarian has, perhaps, saved the author of the "Curdie" books from the Victorian limbo into which have drifted Horatia Ewing and Dinah Mulock Craik.

IT had been a lean week in Manila. Stateside supplies had been delayed and crews on the merchant ships which lay in the bay were weary of Spam and powdered eggs. One meat ship had arrived, but no one knew what had happened to the cargo.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, July 26 -- Premier Dimitrov, accompanied by five Cabinet Ministers and ten other high officials, left Sofia for Belgrade today on a special train.

PARIS, July 26 -- By virtually a unanimous vote the Assembly approved today the Government's foreign policy. At the same time it paid its tribute to United States Secretary of State Marshall for his proposal of United States aid to Europe.

News comes from Brussels that Profs. Auguste Piccard and Max Cosyns are completing their bathysphere or diving bell, which is much like that in which William Beebe went to the bottom of the sea to a depth of 3,028 feet off Bermuda in 1934. Beebe's bathysphere had a cable with which he could be lowered and hauled up and another with which he could communicate telephonically with the surface.
PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (AP) -- Virgil (Fire) Trucks shut out the Athletics with four singles today and the Tigers pounded three pitchers for fifteen safeties and a 13-0 victory.

SOUVENIR-COLLECTING is a big part of most vacations, so big that the business of making mementos is now a billion-dollar industry. The Department of Commerce estimates that spendings on handicraft products and gimcracks in all sections of the country this summer will exceed pre-war souvenir sales by $250,000,000.
